description: Report Offers Conflicting Signals on the Recession

title: Terror on Trial: An American Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIRCIELLO, GINO A.
description: CIRCIELLO-Gino A. Died at home on November 29, 2001. He was creator, founder and owner since 1945 of Gino's Restaurant with Guy Avventuriero and Emilio Torre, 780 Lexington Avenue, New York City until his retirement. Beloved husband of Nini Girdano Circiello. Beloved brother of Yolanda Gentile, Raffaella Musumeci and Augusto Circiello and beloved uncle. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, December 2, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10 AM at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76th Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to Sloan-Kettering Hospital or a charity of your choice.

title: Abroad at Home; It Can Happen Here
description: On the basis of secret evidence, the government accuses a non-citizen of connections to terrorism, and holds him in prison for three years. Then a judge conducts a full trial and rejects the terrorism charges. He releases the prisoner. A year later government agents rearrest the man, hold him in solitary confinement and state as facts the terrorism charges that the judge found untrue.

title: Stock Strategist at Merrill Said to Be on the Way Out
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has decided to dismiss Christine A. Callies as its chief domestic stock strategist just 18 months after hiring her away from Credit Suisse First Boston, people at the the firm said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Embezzlement At Foreign Ministry
description: The ministry will punish 328 employees for embezzlement after a six-month investigation into the misuse of nearly $2 million in official funds over the last five years, Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka said. The investigation showed that the workers had routinely pooled money left over after events such as conferences and used much of it for lunches and parties. Two workers will be dismissed and others face fines and suspensions. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Security Firm To Give Up Contracts At Airport
description: A security company that was cited for several security lapses at Logan International Airport after Sept. 11 will no longer screen passengers or baggage at the airport under an agreement reached today with the state.

title: How Casinos Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike Forces High Schools To Change Routines
description: More than 250 teachers at nine high schools run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York struck for a second day yesterday in disagreements over pensions and pay, forcing one school to close, six to release students as early as the lunch hour, and two to cut their daily attendance by half.

title: No Apology From Mayor On Refusal Of Donation
description: Although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is a man who speaks his mind, since Sept. 11 that quality has been somewhat muted. But yesterday, he was on a roll. Down at ground zero, where he took Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel for a tour of the site, the mayor was asked if he regretted returning a $10 million donation from a Saudi Arabian prince who criticized America's Middle Eastern policies.

title: Report Offers Conflicting Signals on Recovery of the Economy
description: The economy shrank significantly more this summer than the government initially estimated, the Commerce Department said yesterday. The revised report offered conflicting signals about how long the current recession would last.

title: Clamor Grows For Fiscal Aid To Hospitals
description: Amid a growing sense of desperation about the finances of hospitals in New York City, the state's political leaders, hospital chiefs and leaders of the powerful hospital workers' union met yesterday and agreed to step up the pressure on Congress and the White House for increased federal aid.

title: Alliance Says It Found School Run By a Titan of Terrorism
description: The Northern Alliance unit responsible for security in this former Taliban stronghold has found a small compound that it says was used as a headquarters for Central Asia's largest terrorist group and its near mythic leader, Juma Namangani.

title: NRG ENERGY TO BUY PLANTS FROM FIRSTENERGY
description: NRG Energy Inc., which owns and operates power generators in the United States and overseas, agreed to buy four electricity plants in Ohio from the FirstEnergy Corporation for about $1.36 billion in cash and the assumption of $145 million in debt. The coal-fueled plants are capable of generating as much as 2,535 megawatts, enough to light about 2.5 million homes. The sale, which requires approval from state and federal regulators, is expected to be completed in the second quarter and could add to NRG's annual earnings by as much as 23 cents a share, the company said in a statement. FirstEnergy will purchase 90 percent of the plants' output through 2005. FirstEnergy is based in Akron, Ohio. NRG is based in Minneapolis.

title: Man With Artificial Heart Dies 5 Months After Implant
description: Robert Tools, the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart, died yesterday at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky., where he had received the device nearly five months before.

title: Moments of Affirmation In Brahms's 'German Requiem'
description: Collegiate Chorale

title: Gamez Learns The Party Is Over
description: When Robert Gamez joined the PGA Tour in 1990, he made it look easy. He won his first tournament. He was the Tour's rookie of the year. At age 22, he was loving life and sitting on top of the golf world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, HAROLD A.
description: GOTTESMAN-Harold A. We mourn the passing of Harold A. Gottesman, a trustee from the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund for many years. He was instrumental in building the Jewish Chapel at West Point and in supporting the Jewish Cadet program. His wise counsel and support will be sorely missed. West Point Jewish Chapel Fund Louis Gross, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, EDWARD G.
description: WEINSTEIN - Edward G., 75, Thursday, November 29th. Beloved husband for 51 years of Barbara, devoted father of Kenneth (Elizabeth), Ellen Adnopoz (Stephen) and the late Peter. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Timothy, Taylor, Kara, Dana and Hayley. Loving brother of Paul J. Weinstein and brother-in-law of Ada V. Ciniglio. Graduate of The Horace Mann School, NYU, served in the Army Air Force in World War II, involved in the printing industry for more than 50 years, avid railroad enthusiast and expert in military hisotry. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Sunday, December 2nd, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Moments of Affirmation in Brahms's 'German Requiem'

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Cuts Price On Unit
description: Vivendi Universal, Europe's biggest media company, agreed to cut the price of the French trade magazine unit it is selling to Cinven Ltd. to make up for a slump in the advertising market, the company's chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, said. Vivendi had agreed in August to sell the unit for 2 billion euros ($1.8 billion). The company will also keep as much as 25 percent of the unit, Mr. Messier said at a news conference in Paris. He expects the sale to be completed within weeks. The company, based in Paris, is selling the business, which publishes trade magazines for doctors and builders, to finance its acquisition of the Houghton Mifflin Company. Mr. Messier said the reduced sale price would not affect the Houghton purchase.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ruling On School Lunches
description: The Supreme Court has ordered all states to provide cooked lunches in all government schools by January. When lawyers for some states said that the governments could not afford to do so, Judge B. N. Kripal retorted: ''We cannot compromise on school meals. Cut out the flab somewhere else.'' For five years the central government has provided grain to states for school lunches, but to cut costs many states just give children monthly dry rations instead of daily meals. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: That Cow! Those Beans! The Money!
description: A lot of old-money families got their original fortunes in less than admirable ways, but Jack Robinson's forebears take the cake. Jack (Matthew Modine) is a single, rich New Yorker with barely a care in the world (except that all the men in his family seem to die around age 40) until a Robinson International construction crew makes a strange discovery. Excavating for the Camelot Casino on the grounds of an old castle, they unearth a lot of giant bones. The key word here is ''giant.''

title: A Frustrated Izon Is Glad To Be Fighting Somebody
description: The ring was shaping up to be a showcase for the dour and the whimsical.

title: Devils Can't Keep Up With the Red Wings
description: The best team in the National Hockey League skated so fast tonight and the Devils struggled so hard to keep stride that it was almost exhausting to watch. Over and over, as the Devils corraled the puck in their own end, four Detroit skaters hovered behind the center line, waiting. And try as the Devils might to control the tempo, the Red Wings were smothering, relentless.

title: Working-Class Music Straight From the Organ
description: The idea of taking Hammond B-3 organ jazz -- soul jazz, if you like -- into Lincoln Center, for Thursday night's ''Jammin' on the Hammond'' concert at Alice Tully Hall, sounded disjunctive, as the idea of taking any jazz there once did. Organ jazz, as pioneered by Wild Bill Davis and Bill Doggett in the 1940's, popularized by Jimmy Smith in the 50's and extended into the present, is working-class music, even if much of the rest of jazz has done some social climbing.

title: Bush Administration Says It's Too Early to Deploy International Peacekeepers
description: The Bush administration said today that it was too soon to send international peacekeepers to Afghanistan, calling the conditions there too uncertain and too dangerous for that mission.

title: S. Korea's Second City Welcomes The World
description: This rough-and-tumble industrial port city is embracing its most venerated foreigners since thousands of American troops defended the region in the southeastern corner of the Korean peninsula against North Korean troops during the Korean War half a century ago.

title: Security, and Event, Will Be Extraordinary
description: Concerned that the country's most watched sporting event, the Super Bowl, would be an inviting target for terrorists, the federal government and the National Football League are planning extraordinary measures to protect the game and its site.

title: Amex Agrees To Reoccupy Damaged Site Downtown
description: The American Express Company has agreed to return next spring to its headquarters at the World Financial Center complex, which suffered extensive damage in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Accounting Firm Is Bracing for an Onslaught
description: The Enron debacle is building into a set of knotty problems for Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm that audited Enron's books for more than a decade.

title: Sticking to Homework
description: The Kinko's copy shop on Third Avenue in Midtown Manhattan bustles with businessmen building spreadsheets, tourists scanning the Internet, and job seekers printing rsums.

title: East Africans Rekindle Regional Grouping
description: The presidents of Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda re-established the East African Community today, nearly a quarter-century after the economic and political union was disbanded because of regional strife.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: LUXURY IN HARD TIMES

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Market Supervisor
description: As of midnight, Britain's Financial Services Authority was set to assume new powers as the country's market watchdog, combining 10 formerly separate bodies into one superagency that will try to provide a one-stop shop for the financial industry and its consumers. The new agency will have increased powers to investigate and discipline inside traders, money launderers and executives who fail to install proper financial controls at their companies. The enlarged powers combine oversight that in the United States is scattered among the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Reserve, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and others. If successful, the model could become a blueprint for other European countries, analysts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITOLO, RALPH FRANCIS
description: VITOLO-Ralph Francis, 59. Of Lido Beach, NY, died on November 17 in Pattaya, Thailand. Cause of death was heart failure. He is survived by Theresa Vitolo, mother Frances of Fort Lauderdale, FL, sister Ann Carol Caponi of Greenwich Village, NY and niece Meeso and nephew Jared. Mr. Vitolo had a 23 year career in New York City's Government, Computer and Data Communications Service Agency. He retired as Commissioner of User Services, which provided Telecommunications Services to over 40 City Agencies. Avid reader, traveler, and lover of life, he will be dearly missed by family, friends, and golf buddies. Memorial services to be held Monday, December 3, 2001 at The First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, Fifth Avenue, Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to The Tiger Woods Foundation at 4281 Katella Ave., Ste 111, Los Alamitos, CA 90720, would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Michael E. Hoffman, director of the Aperture Foundation, which publishes photography books and Aperture magazine, omitted a survivor. She is his sister, Jill Shore, of Bedford, N.Y. The article also misstated the location of his country home. It is in Dutchess County, not Columbia. In addition, the article misstated the year that Mr. Hoffman received an honorary doctorate from St. Lawrence University and the year of death of the photographer Minor White, whose workshop he attended in 1964. The degree was awarded this year, not last, and Mr. White died in 1976, not 1971.

title: Indians, Justice and Stolen Land
description: To the Editor:

title: China Wins the Wallets Of Tibetans, but Hearts Are Still Slow to Follow
description: Earlier this year, officials put up two large billboards here, portraying Tibet the way China wants it to be.

title: With a Beatle's Death, Mourning for Every Family
description: With news of George Harrison's death on Thursday, Strawberry Fields, the Central Park memorial to John Lennon, yesterday became a place for hundreds of people to mourn two Beatles and the aging of a generation. On the circular mosaic that spells ''Imagine,'' fans with eyes red from crying placed candles, photographs, flowers and a miniature guitar emblazoned, ''My Guitar Gently Weeps . . . Thanks guys!'' Nearby, a circle of musicians strummed Beatles songs, and fans young and old sang along.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC IS PLANNING TO CLOSE 10 FACTORIES
description: The Emerson Electric Company, the biggest maker of power systems for telecommunications and computer networks, plans to close 10 plants and lay off an unspecified number of workers in the next few years, the chief executive, David Farr, said yesterday. Emerson, whose profit fell for the first time in 43 years in fiscal 2001, wants to move production from the United States to countries with lower labor costs like China and Mexico, Mr. Farr said. Most of the plants being shut are in the United States. Emerson is based in St. Louis.

title: A Black Author Hurls That Word As a Challenge
description: At halftime of a 1993 basketball game against Miami University of Ohio, Keith Dambrot, varsity men's basketball coach at Central Michigan University, called his team together to talk about the word ''nigger.'' Mr. Dambrot, who is white, had overheard his African-American players call each other ''nigger'' to denote toughness and tenacity on the court. He asked the players permission to use the word in the same sense, and after they assented he adopted ''nigger,'' too. A few weeks later, after administrative censure, sensitivity training and two campus protests, Mr. Dambrot lost his job and promptly filed suit.

title: Ex-Pentagon Officials Cleared in Tripp Suit
description: Two former Pentagon officials who discussed the employment records of Linda R. Tripp with a reporter may not be held personally liable for invading her privacy, a federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 17 about problems encountered by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan in his efforts to reform the Japanese economy misstated the given name of the minster of administrative reform. He is Nobuteru Ishihara, not Nobutero.

title: German Utilities Scramble, but Regret Enron's Exit
description: The collapse of Enron had an immediate effect today on a small gas utility called Stadtwerke Peine: about one-third of its natural gas deliveries stopped flowing at 5 p.m.

title: Whitney Museum Cuts Its Staff and Budget
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced a package of layoff and budget cuts yesterday intended to pull the 70-year-old museum through a financial crisis that was largely precipated by a sudden and drastic drop in out-of-town visitors.

title: University of Michigan Won't Cooperate in Federal Canvass
description: The University of Michigan's police force has refused to help the federal government in its effort to interview thousands of foreign students and others in the United States on temporary visas, joining a handful of other law enforcement agencies raising questions about the propriety of the vast canvass.

title: Afghan Talks Stall in Bonn On Comments From Kabul
description: Negotiations on a future government for Afghanistan stalled today, after the leader of the Northern Alliance, in Kabul, refused to permit his delegation to submit names of candidates for an interim administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about human rights organizations' concern over reports of the execution of captured Taliban soldiers by other Afghan factions paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Sidney Jones, the Asia director of Human Rights Watch. She said the Geneva Conventions do apply to the internal conflicts in Afghanistan, as well as to international conflicts. She did not say it was unclear whether they applied. The conventions require the humane treatment of prisoners in both kinds of conflict. The obligations for treatment of prisoners of war -- that term is applied only to international conflicts -- are more rigorous.

title: Zimbabwe Proposes Keeping Reporters Out
description: Zimbabwe has proposed a new law that would effectively bar foreign journalists from working in the country, the latest effort to curtail international scrutiny as the nation braces for a presidential election next year.

title: U.S. Mad Cow Risk Is Low, A Study by Harvard Finds
description: The Agriculture Department released a study today that found that there is very little risk that American cattle will contract mad cow disease or that the disease would ever pose a public health problem for people.

title: U.S. Officials See Small Risk Of Anthrax in Mail Delivery
description: Federal health and postal officials said yesterday that there was no significant health risk from the mail despite the discovery of anthrax spores on a letter received near the home of the Connecticut woman who died of anthrax.

title: Jets' Special Teams May Be the Difference
description: He does not have degrees in horticulture, agriculture, meteorology or physics. But Chris Hayes understands this much about the problematic grass field and the unpredictable winds at Giants Stadium: the football takes funny bounces there, even funnier than they used to when the turf was artificial.

title: The Things Left Undone: Breakfast Runs and Second Honeymoons
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Governor Puts Philadelphia School Plan On Hold
description: Only hours before he was to take control of this city's troubled public school system, Gov. Mark S. Schweiker agreed tonight to put off such plans for at least three weeks while he and Mayor John F. Street try to negotiate a compromise.

title: For 2nd Time, NASA Delays Launching
description: NASA officials decided today to delay launching the space shuttle Endeavour until next week to allow astronauts aboard the International Space Station to tackle docking problems with a Russian cargo ship before the shuttle arrives.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Referendum On Abolishing Army
description: The Swiss vote tomorrow on whether to abolish the army, which critics say is useless for a small, neutral country. After one-third of the voters backed a similar proposal in 1989, the army's size has been reduced and another plan is under way to trim the force by half. Although the measure leaves open the possibility of armed participation in international actions promoting peace, the government opposes it along with a measure to start a voluntary civil service to promote peace. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Abbey Road Journal; Just Something in the Way He Moved Them
description: For a moment, the news that George Harrison had died sent Mark Allan, 39, right back to his childhood. Suddenly he was a boy again in Nottingham with little in the way of money or musical sense, hearing a classmate say, ''You've got to hear this album 'Abbey Road' -- it'll blow your mind.''

title: Fat Lady Sings, and Italians Don't Care for the Final Aria
description: It's not over, they say, until the fat lady sings. The fat lady at the finale of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals Tuesday night was the Appeals Committee. Long after all play had ended, it had to decide an issue that would determine the result of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, BRUCE
description: LAWRENCE-Bruce. We mourn the passing of our beloved friend. A man of warmth, understanding, intelligence and true love. Bruce, you will live in our hearts forever. Joyce and Richard

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retailer Plans Expansion
description: Carrefour S.A., the giant retailer, plans to invest 3 billion euros, or $2.7 billion, next year to open new stores, refurbish others and expand in Asia and Europe in expectation of a global economic rebound. ''I'm not pessimistic,'' Daniel Bernard, above, the chairman, said yesterday, reiterating the company's forecast for 15 percent profit growth this year. ''I don't see too many problems with consumption in Europe. People will continue to eat.'' Carrefour plans more than 400 store openings a year, including about 40 hypermarkets, 100 supermarkets and 300 discount stores.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I guess we all see a little of ourselves in him. He was in the background, and maybe we all do little great things in the background in our own lives.''

title: Ulster's Protestant Leader In Party Showdown Today
description: A showdown meeting of the Ulster Unionists on Saturday is calling attention to the persistence of dangerous divisions in the province's Protestant majority at a time when the end of a stalemate over the disarmament of militias seemed to have cleared the way for progress toward peace.

title: St. John's Puts Smith In Charge Of Offense
description: A check of his athletic record will show that success really should not be a surprise for Tristan Smith, a freshman point guard for St. John's who has been overlooked and overshadowed before. As a junior receiver at Amityville High School, he helped the football team to the Long Island Division III championship. A year later, he switched to quarterback for the first time after the starter was injured and guided the team back to the title game.

title: Civil Rights Panel at Odds Over Appointment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - A showdown is looming at the United States Civil Rights Commission that could threaten the control Mary Frances Berry has exercised as chairwoman for the last eight years. sv29,2if,,v29 At issue is whether the term of Victoria Wilson, an ally of Ms. Berry on the commission, has expired. If it has, that would create an opening for President Bush to appoint a new member to the board and would bring to a 4-4 tie the number of commissioners who lean Democratic and the number who lean Republican.

title: Shoplifting Charge Ends U.S. Manhunt For Real Estate Heir
description: A nationwide manhunt for the scion of a wealthy Manhattan real estate family ended yesterday when he was arrested in Bethlehem, Pa., accused of shoplifting at a supermarket. The fugitive, Robert A. Durst, is wanted in Texas on charges of beheading a 71-year-old man, and New York investigators are hoping to interview him about the disappearance of his first wife 19 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARWOOD, HARRY
description: HARWOOD-Harry. On November 28, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Alice. Loving father of Pamela and Leslie. Devoted brother of Maurice, Norma and Hilda. Dear uncle and good friend to many. He is enjoying eternity with his loving wife Alice. Service Sunday, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva will be observed at the home of Harry Harwood.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Battle Over Mining
description: Environmental groups and Indian tribes have joined forces to fight a utility company's plans to strip-mine coal in western New Mexico. The groups, which include the Sierra Club and the Zuni Pueblo tribe, formed the Zuni Salt Lake Coalition. Tribal members say the 18,000-acre area is sacred, especially the Zuni Salt Lake, where salt is extracted for religious ceremonies. A utility company based in Tempe, the Salt River Project, has had a permit for the mine pending before the Interior Department for years. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Casualness and Precision In an All-Tchaikovsky Program
description: St. Lawrence String Quartet

title: Currency Shift Frustrates European Consumers
description: One month before euros become the new common currency in 12 European countries, the great price shuffle is in full swing, and consumers are not amused.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK TO CLOSE 5 PLANTS AND CUT WORK FORCE
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the maker of Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers, will close five plants and eliminate 1,400 jobs, or about 2 percent of its work force, as competitors reduce prices. The moves will cost $120 million before taxes, including $90 million in the fourth quarter, the chief executive, Wayne Sanders, said yesterday on a conference call. Four of the plants make tissue and personal-care products in Latin America, and the fifth is an 80-employee paper mill in East Ryegate, Vt. He added that fourth-quarter earnings would be 75 cents to 85 cents a share, as forecast last month. Kimberly-Clark, the top diaper seller in the United States, said that it would not raise prices next year.

title: From the Frat House to the White House
description: George W. Bush is the most secretive president since Richard Nixon. He wants to hold closed military tribunals. He makes his vice president hide. He wants to conceal his White House documents -- and other presidents' papers too. He won't let his attorney general disclose the names of people arrested for -- well, whatever it is, the Justice Department doesn't explain. Sure, there's a war going on. But George W. has always been inclined to the hermetic. After all, he was molded in occult clubs of upper-middle-class white men who meet by night and engage in ceremonies they are sworn not to reveal to outsiders.

title: Lawyers Seek Insanity Defense In Deaths of Dartmouth Couple
description: A teenager accused of stabbing two Dartmouth professors to death will use an insanity defense at his trial, according to court papers filed today by the teenager's lawyers.

title: Margaret Byrd Rawson, 102, Educator and Dyslexia Authority
description: Margaret Byrd Rawson, an educator, researcher and author who spent some 70 years identifying and treating reading disorders, died on Nov. 25 at her home near Frederick, Md. She was 102.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, JAMES EDWARD
description: MOORE-James Edward, 70. A New York commodities trader who played a major role in emergency medical services in his community and the state, died Wednesday at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, New York City. Mr. Moore was a commodities futures trader with the New York Commodities Exchange, or COMEX and New York Mercantile Exchange, or NYMEX, for 50 years. Later in life he developed a second career, born of his love for boating, as owner of Brown's Point Marina in Keyport. But it was in a volunteer capacity that he may have affected the most lives during his years of service as an emergency medical technician and EMT trainer in Aberdeen. As an EMT trainer, Mr. Moore helped establish the EMT standard among first aid squads throughout the state, said Brian Gelburd, a former captain of the South Aberdeen EMS and longtime friend of Mr. Moore. ''He was instrumental in establishing the program in the state,'' Gelburd said. ''He was a natural leader, he would get on these crusades.'' Mr. Moore joined Matawan Township First Aid (later Aberdeen Township) in 1971. In 1972, he became an EMT and joined the South Matawan Township First Aid Squad (later South Aberdeen). He was a life member of South Aberdeen EMS, served several terms as captain, president and various other offices. He answered thousands of EMS calls, and also served as state testing coordinator for the National Registry of EMTs. After he moved away from Aberdeen, he remained active with the squad as a trainer and even went on calls when he was in the area, Gelburd said. In 1973, Mr. Moore started one of the earliest, if not the earliest EMT training programs for the state Department of Health. He remained coordinator of the Bayshore Area EMT course, one of the longest running programs in the state. He helped establish the pilot program for crash injury management/first responder for the State Police Academy, Sea Girt, which remains part of basic training in the academy. He was extrication training instructor and team captain for the state, and instrumental in bringing the first ''jaws of life'' rescue tool into service in Monmouth County. One of the earliest CPR instructor trainers, he coordinated one of the earliest testing sites at Bayshore Community Hospital, Holmdel. Mr. Moore began his trading career in 1960 as clerk for Anderson, Clayton & Fleming, and later became customers' manager for Bache & Co./Prudential Securities. He then joined Harmon Lichtenstein & Co., the oldest firm on the COMEX. He became a member of COMEX in 1965; NYMEX in 1966; and New York Cotton Exchange (New York Board of Trade) in 1977. He was a licensed broker for National Futures Association; and a member of Copper Club and various trade associations. He was one of the longest-serving members of COMEX. In addition to his commodities work, Mr. Moore was owner and operator of Brown's Point Marina, Keyport, for the past 20 years. He was drawn to the marina business because of his avid interest in boating. Largely through the efforts of his friend Paul Gasior, he acquired the marina in the late 1970s. Brown's Point Marina is one of the most active dealers for Suzuki Marine in the country. Mr. Moore enjoyed nothing more than his twicea-year boat trips to his home in Florida with Gasior, family and other friends. He enjoyed boating so much that he obtained his 200ton boating license through the Coast Guard, upgraded from 100ton. At the time of the World Trade Center disaster, Mr. Moore was staying at his New York apartment near the Trade Center, confined to bed because of his illness. His marina friends, especially Gasior, and Old Bridge Police Chief Jerry Polumbo and George Jensen, rescued him from the building after the Twin Towers' collapse. The building was not damaged, but was unlivable because of the debris from the collapse. In addition to his other pursuits, Mr. Moore served in the National Guard. He graduated from Xavier High School in New York City in 1950, but before that, in 1946, he lied about his age and enlisted in the New York National Guard. He first served in the 102nd Medical Battalion and later was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the Medical Corps, 107th Combat Team. He then was battery commander of Battery D955, 2nd Corps; artillery commander of Company D, 106th Infantry; and retired as a captain in the Army Reserve. He was a communicant of St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church, Matawan, and a member of the Knights of Columbus. He moved from Brooklyn to Aberdeen in December 1967. He became active in Little League, Pop Warner and other community organizations. He was a third-degree member of the Knights of Columbus, Cardinal Newman Council, Aberdeen. He received many community service awards including the Elks Club Man of the Year. ''Anyone who ever met Jim will never forget him,'' his family said. ''He left a lasting impression with his charm and sense of humor. Above all, he will be remembered as one of the most generous and giving men in the world. Even those closest to him will never know the extent of his giving and kindness, which is the way he wanted it.'' He was predeceased by two sons, James E. Moore, Jr., in 1975; and Daniel J. Moore, in 1990; a brother, John Moore, in 1997; and a sister, Florence Hunter, in 1961. Surviving are his wife, Anne Kristin Moore of Bainbridge Island, Wash; two daughters, Theresa Olsen of Bainbridge Island, Wash; and Martha MooreStoll of Charlottesville, Va.; a sister, Joan Riordan of Atlanta; a grandson, Joshua Andrew Olsen; and three grand-daughters, Madeline Anne Olsen, Veronica Jae Moore-Stoll, and Isabelle Marie Moore-Stoll. Visiting hours will be from 7 to 9 P.M., Saturday, and 2 to 4 P.M. and 7 to 9 P.M. Sunday at Day Funeral Home, 361 Maple Place, Keyport. A Funeral Mass will be offered 11 A.M. Monday at St. Clement's Church, Matawan. Cremation will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021.

title: Apple Offers More Than an Update to Its System
description: Sometimes engineers fix software mistakes; other times the task falls to lawyers.

title: Connecticut Detects Anthrax on a Letter Near Victim's Home
description: In their first investigative break, state officials said today that a trace amount of anthrax had been discovered on a letter delivered to a family living one mile from the home of the 94-year-old woman who died of inhalation anthrax last week.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Diseases At School
description: Three students at an Anchorage school have contracted rare neurological disorders this fall, but public health officials have not found any links among the cases, said Beth Funke, a state epidemiologist. One student at Mears Middle School died in September from what may have been viral encephalitis, and that disease was diagnosed in another student last week. In October, a student contracted meningococcal meningitis, a bacterial infection. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOXER, DAVID H.
description: BOXER-David H. Dec 1, 1994. Always remembered. Beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather & great grandfather.

title: Home Depot Ratchets Down Its Estimate of Profit Growth
description: Bowing to reality but still confident about growth, executives of Home Depot Inc. reduced the company's expected earnings growth yesterday to an increase of 18 to 20 percent a year for the next three years. Last year, they had predicted a growth rate of 23 percent to 25 percent for the company.

title: Iran and Pakistan Deport Afghans, U.N. Aides Say
description: United Nations officials accused Iran and Pakistan today of forcing Afghan refugees to return to Afghanistan despite continued fighting and instability in the country.

title: Sports of The Times; Time to Remember A Colorful Bond
description: BRIAN PICCOLO looked good, from the outside, that is. He was sitting in pajamas on the edge of his bed in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan and coughed. ''That's a legitimate cough,'' he told me, with a little grin. ''I've got a cold.'' He also had a cavity in his chest where a malignant tumor the size of a grapefruit had been dug out three months earlier.

title: Raid Exposes North Korean Support Network in Japan
description: Long murky, the flow of money from Japan to North Korea has suddenly burst into the daylight, becoming as visible as battered riot police vans, bloodied heads and protesters chanting in Japanese: ''Stop the unfair investigation!''

title: Benko Doesn't Let Knee Injury Slow Her
description: Swimmers train so hard maybe 10 miles a day, plus weight work, plus exercises on land -- that they treat superhuman efforts as ordinary. Take the case of Lindsay Benko, a 2000 Olympic gold medalist in Sydney, Australia.

title: Indians, Justice And Stolen Land
description: To the Editor:

title: WORKERS GET OPPORTUNITY TO EXCHANGE STOCK OPTIONS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the largest photography company, said yesterday that employees may exchange their stock options for fewer new ones as the decline in the company's share price has made the options essentially worthless. About 61,000 employees have rights to buy 33 million shares. Options were granted in 1998 and 2000 to all employees, giving them the right to buy shares at prices of $65.91 and $53.94, the company said in a statement. Kodak's shares closed yesterday at $30.27, up 77 cents; they have dropped 30 percent in the last year. Kodak is offering options as an incentive as it plans to cut as many as 7,500 jobs and employees face the possible elimination of an annual bonus for the first time since the Great Depression.

title: Terror on Trial: An American Test
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Dentsu Goes Public
description: Trading in shares of Japan's dominant advertising agency, Dentsu, got off to a rocky start on the Tokyo Stock Exchange yesterday when a technical error on one trade sent prices briefly tumbling. After the problem was corrected, Dentsu's shares finished the trading day up 12 percent at 470,000 yen ($3,797.06) a share, a weaker debut than many analysts had expected. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: ROTHMANS, CANADIAN TOBACCO COMPANY, SWEETENS OFFER
description: Rothmans Inc., Canada's No. 2 tobacco company, sweetened its takeover bid for the Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Company to $353.7 million, adding more cash to the offer and topping one by R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc. The original Sept. 27 proposal by Rothmans consisted of $275 million in stock, cash and debt for Santa Fe, a closely held maker of organic cigarettes. R. J. Reynolds, the No. 2 tobacco company in the United States, offered $320 million in cash on Nov. 22. The bidding war underscores the lack of growth opportunities as the number of smokers in North America declines. In Canada, tobacco-advertising rules are among the world's most restrictive and make it difficult for Rothmans to expand at home. Rothmans brands include Benson & Hedges and Craven 'A.'

title: INSIDE
description: Sheriff Held in Killing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWICK, AVRAHAM
description: ZWICK-Avraham, 81. Our Dolfi, beloved brother, brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle, died on November 28, 2001, at his home in Tivon, Israel. Dolfi was a good man, a loving and generous person, who served his country as a major in the IDF during the War of Independence, and as General Manager of the Israel Railroad. He will always be in our hearts. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Yudit, and their sons, Hanan, Rami and Uri. The Pickers

title: Correspondent; Join the Club
description: Next year, unless President Bush has a drastic change of heart, the United States will enlarge the American-led military alliance in Europe by as many as seven countries and extend its boundary to within an hour's tank drive of St. Petersburg. This may seem like an awfully ungrateful way to treat our new friend Russia, so quick to our side after Sept. 11, but the terror attacks have actually made this enlargement of the NATO family more right than ever.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with the Pop Life column, about bands that are bringing new energy to rock 'n' roll, referred incorrectly to a highly regarded recording by the White Stripes, which is in the forefront of the movement. It is ''White Blood Cells,'' not ''Is This It,'' and it is the group's third album, not its first. ''Is This It,'' as the column noted, is the first album by the band Strokes.

title: The Real Fritter
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Beliefs; After Sept. 11, a 62-year-old poem by Auden drew new attention. Not all of it was favorable.
description: It begins in a bar, ends with a prayer and, after Sept. 11, was endlessly quoted and reprinted to express grief over what had happened and foreboding about what was to come.

title: Arts Agency Delays Decision on Two Grants
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has delayed a decision on giving grants to two arts organizations sponsoring potentially sensitive works. One is a California production of Tony Kushner's new play about Afghanistan, ''Homebody/Kabul,'' said those involved with the application process.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BAXTER INTERNATIONAL INC., Deerfield, Ill., the biggest maker of treatments for blood diseases, said it would buy the closely held Autros Healthcare Solutions Inc., Toronto, which operates a system that links doctors, pharmacists and nurses electronically, to add products that can help reduce medication errors. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORO, GEORGE
description: TESORO-George. 97 years of kindness, loyalty and hard work. A beloved father, grandfather, uncle and friend. Esteemed lawyer, economist, professor, diplomat, Commendatore, a founder of American University of Rome. Service will be held Sunday, December 2, 11:00 A.M., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.

title: Envoy to Mideast Assails Palestinian Militants
description: Anthony C. Zinni, the American envoy sent here to broker a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians, accused Palestinian militants on Friday of trying to thwart his mission.

title: Research Cost For New Drugs Said to Soar
description: A new round in the national debate over prescription drugs opened today with a study from researchers at Tufts University estimating that the average cost of developing a new drug has more than doubled since 1987, to $802 million.

title: Terror on Trial: An American Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Mock Edition Falls Flat
description: On Thursday, The Daily Targum, the Rutgers University student newspaper, published a mock edition called The Mugrat. On the front page was an article headlined ''Anthrax found in U. mail.''

title: Plugging The Baddies Virtuously
description: ''Let them remember us not as men of vengeance but as men of law and justice.'' This noble sentiment, punctuated by a heart-rending tubercular cough, is intoned by Leander McNelly (Dylan McDermott), brave leader of the Texas Rangers, near the end of Steve Miner's movie of that name. The rangers themselves may be worthy of commemoration, but this violent meatball western deserves to be forgotten quickly, which seems to be just what its distributor, Dimension Films, had in mind when it snuck the movie into theaters yesterday with no advance screening.

title: Charged Up and Roaring, From Head to Footwork
description: It was high-octane night with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Thursday. A new program featured Ailey's delightfully funky ''Night Creature'' and two recent works: ''Following the Subtle Current Upstream,'' Alonzo King's inventive study in tension and release, and ''Grace,'' Ronald K. Brown's amazingly explosive image of a spiritual journey.

title: A Soprano Soars Over Her First Hurdle
description: In today's classical music world, the debut song recital has become a requisite hurdle, a kind of oral exam standing between a young singer and a major professional career. On Tuesday evening the exam, a New York debut, was administered by Young Concert Artists at the 92nd Street Y. And Courtenay Budd, a soprano, certainly passed.

title: Thanks to Injuries, Knight Gets Off End of the Bench
description: When the call comes from Jeff Van Gundy, Travis Knight rises, and as he heads to the scorer's table, the cheering begins. The ball lands in his hands and the fans grow louder, screeching for him to shoot. It is the usual home crowd support for an end-of-the-bench player, the sort of support Knight does not want.

title: 2 Sides Turn More Heated In Exchanges Over Economy
description: Democrats today intensified their efforts to portray Republicans as more concerned about corporate interests than laid-off workers and to pin blame for the recession on President Bush.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Why Western Soldiers Have Always Been Such Fierce Fighters
description: In 480 B.C., near Salamis off the coast of Greece, an armada of perhaps a thousand Persian ships attacked some 300 Greek vessels. This was, as the military historian and classicist Victor Davis Hanson writes in this provocative book, ''one of the most deadly battles in the entire history of naval warfare.'' Lured by a brilliant Greek strategy through the narrow straits, and rammed by Greek ships, hundreds of Persian vessels were sunk; more than 40,000 Persian soldiers were drowned or killed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Crackdown On Pro-Kurd Party
description: The police raided the headquarters of the pro-Kurdish political party in Istanbul and 28 of its branch offices across the country, seizing periodicals and arresting 40 of its members, party officials said. Dogan Erbas, the head of the Istanbul headquarters of the People's Democracy Party, said the raids had been carried out with a search warrant issued on suspicion that the party was helping to organize support of the outlawed separatist Kurdistan Workers Party, or PKK. The party denied the accusation. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: The Victims' New Referee
description: In a long career resolving complicated disputes, Kenneth Feinberg has never seen a case as tangled and emotionally volatile as the one he confronts now. Mr. Feinberg is the Bush administration's choice to run the multibillion-dollar, open-ended fund established by Congress to compensate families of people killed and physically injured in the September terrorist attacks. On the face of it, he seems the right man for the job. Mr. Feinberg, a Washington lawyer and arbitrator, has adjudicated claims in complex cases involving asbestos, Agent Orange and the Dalkon Shield, all the while earning a reputation for firmness and fairness. He will need both qualities in abundance as he goes about dividing the billions of dollars that will be the largest source of long-term financial support for thousands of families who lost a breadwinner in the attacks.

title: Torre's Deal Is Done
description: The haggling over the last details of Joe Torre's three-year, $16.2 million contract is apparently over, and all that is required now is Torre's signature, according to a baseball official.

title: Budd Boetticher, Director Whose No-Frills 50's Westerns Became Classics, Dies at 85
description: Budd Boetticher, who directed a series of stark, low-budget westerns regarded by film scholars as classics of the genre, died on Thursday at his home in Ramona, Calif. He was 85.

title: With All Clear, Marines Dig In And Scout Area
description: From a dry, isolated lake bed here in the high Afghan desert, American helicopter gunships and armored vehicles are probing the last military strongholds of Afghanistan's crumbling Taliban government.

title: Wilpon Might Increase Payroll
description: Fred Wilpon is trying to buy Nelson Doubleday's 50 percent share of the Mets, and the owners have spent months squabbling over the deal. But Wilpon insisted yesterday that the negotiations would have no impact on the way General Manager Steve Phillips constructs the team for next season, and he hinted that he might authorize Phillips to exceed the budget to sign a top player.

title: Bush Picks Virginia Prosecutor for U.S. Attorney
description: President Bush announced late yesterday that he would nominate James B. Comey as United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. If confirmed, he would succeed Mary Jo White, a Clinton appointee who served almost nine years, building a strong record in prosecuting international terrorism.

title: Argentines, Fearing a Freeze, Withdraw Savings From Banks
description: Argentines rushed to withdraw their savings from banks today on fears that the government could freeze deposits to shore up the weakened financial system and prevent a devaluation.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Reich Weighs Politics
description: Robert B. Reich, the economist who was labor secretary under President Bill Clinton, is considering a bid for governor of Massachusetts. Mr. Reich, a Democrat who teaches at Brandeis University in Waltham, said he would not decide until early next year, but he made no delay in criticizing his possible Republican opponent, Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, especially her handling of the Massachusetts Port Authority, which oversees Logan International Airport. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu To Shut Oregon Plant
description: Because of slack demand, Fujitsu Ltd., a leading chip maker, said that it would shut its plant in Gresham, Ore., in January and move its production lines back to Japan, laying off 670 workers. Fujitsu opened the Oregon plant in 1988 and last year made $300 million of finished goods there, mostly flash memory chips. The decision to close was made after Advanced Micro Devices pulled out of talks to buy a share of the plant, Fujitsu said.

title: U.S. TO PRESS IRAQ TO LET U.N. SEARCH FOR BANNED ARMS
description: A top State Department official said today that the United States was on ''a roll'' in its campaign against the Taliban in Afghanistan and that President Bush intended to use the momentum to force Iraq to open its borders to United Nations inspectors looking for weapons of mass destruction.

title: Getting at the Roots of Arab Poverty
description: Since the terrorist attacks, Americans have learned that in many Arab and Muslim nations there are large numbers of angry young men with time on their hands, unable to find jobs -- or jobs that make use of their education -- because of their countries' poverty. We've also learned that many Muslims blame us for their poverty. But in fact they are not poor because we are rich; they are poor because of the policies their countries pursue.

title: Striking Teachers Ignore Back-to-Work Order
description: Striking schoolteachers and secretaries here ignored a court order to return to work today and continued their walkout for a second day. School authorities immediately asked a state judge to fine, jail and dismiss them from their jobs if the strike persisted.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Security Concerns

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: A Newspaper Strike As Election Nears
description: A strike by workers has shut down 17 state-run newspapers just days before a national election Wednesday. Editors said the union is affiliated with the opposition United National Party. Many leaders of the opposition say the state-run newspapers have been used by the government in a smear campaign, and some members of the opposition have sued. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Suspect Held in Northwest Serial-Killings Case
description: The authorities here said tonight that they had detained a suspect believed to be responsible for the deaths of as many as four dozen women in the early 1980's that were attributed to the Green River killer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about murder charges against two Florida teenagers in the death of their father referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of sentences for two other Florida adolescents charged with murder. Lionel Tate, who killed a 6-year-old playmate, was sentenced in March, not January. Nathaniel Brazil, who killed his teacher, was sentenced in July, not May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONDOV, MADELEINE VITENSON
description: SONDOV - Madeleine Vitenson. Age 88 of Katonah, NY on November 30, 2001. Wife of the late David Sondov (1971) and Dr. Boris Vitenson (1964). Mother of Jack Vitenson, M.D. of Franklin Lake, NJ and Fernande Lipton of Katonah. Grandmother of Daniel, Randy, Todd, Monica and Brina. Greatgrandmother of Tom and Fina. Funeral services will be held at Joseph J. Smith Funeral Home, 692 Route 6, Mahopac, NY. Please call the funeral home for date and time of services at 845-621-1992.

title: John Knowles, 75, Novelist Who Wrote 'A Separate Peace'
description: John Knowles, whose coming-of-age novel ''A Separate Peace'' became required reading for generations of high school students, died on Thursday at a convalescent home in a suburb of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 75.

title: Devils Pursuing Lecavalier
description: With the Devils in the unfamiliar position of trailing the Islanders and the Rangers, Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' president and general manager, has increased his efforts to acquire Vincent Lecavalier, the 21-year-old former captain of the Tampa Bay Lightning, two N.H.L. executives said.

title: Football Team Heals Self-Inflicted Wounds
description: The high school football coach first heard about it as he was sitting at home in Ossining, N.Y., on the Sunday evening of Labor Day weekend.

title: City Island Is Alive With Sound of Radio; A Broadcaster Wants More Power, But Close By, Even Radiators Talk
description: On City Island, you don't need a radio to listen to the radio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, PETER
description: MURPHY-Peter, 61. An advertising copywriter who created numerous award winning campaigns for Dr Pepper, Bartles and James, Alamo Rent A Car and American Airlines, died Thursday at his home in Bridgehampton, NY. The cause was colon cancer. His quick wit and unique writing made him well known throughout the advertising community. Even those who didn't know Peter knew his work. From ''It's perfect, it's Perrier'' to Saturn's ''A different kind of car. A different kind of company''. Peter helped create some of the most memorable campaigns ever. His work became known for putting a human touch to some of America's largest companies. Most recently, Peter was an Executive Vice President, Executive Creative Director at Young & Rubicam. He also created award-winning work at Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco, Backer & Speilvogel, Marschalk, Wells, Rich & Green, NY and Doyle Dane Bernbach. He is survived by his wife Liz, his daughter Michele, granddaughter Alexis, brother John, sisters Mary and Ann, son-in-law Richard and his English bulldog Rocky, Labrador Retriever, Tyler, and hundreds of advertising people who were inspired by his spirit, generosity, smile, sense of humor and creativity. Wake to be held at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 91 Hampton St., (Route 114), Sag Harbor, NY, Saturday, December 1, 7-9PM, Sunday, December 2, 2-4PM. Funeral will be held on Monday, December 3, Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY at 1:30PM. Donations in Peter's name may be made to The American Cancer Society or the Animal Rescue Fund, Wainscott, NY. A memorial Mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church at 869 Lexington Ave. on Wednesday, December 5 at 10AM.

title: Greenspan Remarks on Euro's Weakness
description: The relative weakness of the euro against the dollar reflects Europe's inflexible labor policies and worker productivity gains that lag those in the United States, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer Warns About Documents
description: Interbrew, the Belgian maker of Stella Artois and Labatt beer, said documents circulated anonymously to the press about a bid it was preparing for South African Breweries contained falsified information. Corneel Maes, a spokesman, said Interbrew had instructed its bankers to draw up an analysis of S.A.B. as part of a routine assessment of the industry. But that analysis never contained a timetable for starting a bid, he said, adding, ''We never held any merger discussions with S.A.B.'' Interbrew is investigating the matter and has contacted stock market regulators in Belgium and Britain. Mr. Maes said it was too soon to say how the problem would affect Interbrew's relationship with its financial advisers.

title: Original AIDS Quilt to Hang in Manhattan
description: Nobody wanted it to get so big.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: New Jobs For Women In Navy
description: The navy has decided to include women in its officer ranks for the first time, but only as doctors and lawyers. Officials said that the change would be carried out gradually and that women would eventually be allowed to serve on warships. They are not allowed to attend the naval academy but that policy is expected to be reviewed. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: As 'Southern Alliance' Gels, Many Wonder if It Can Last
description: Even before the American-backed Northern Alliance swept across northern Afghanistan in the last three weeks, United States policy makers had urged the formation of a southern alliance of Pashtun tribes in the Taliban's political and ethnic stronghold in the south.

title: George Harrison, 'Quiet Beatle' And Lead Guitarist, Dies at 58
description: George Harrison, the Beatles' lead guitarist and the youngster of the group, who composed some of their most venerated songs, ranging from the intentionally prosaic to the hauntingly serene, died on Thursday at a friend's home in Los Angeles. He was 58.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,533 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Dips
description: Canada's gross domestic product shrank 0.2 percent in the third quarter, pulled down by a 2 percent decline in exports and a modest drop in consumer spending, Statistics Canada said yesterday. The economy expanded by a fractional 0.1 percent in the previous three months. The fall in exports was the fourth successive quarterly drop, making it the longest decline in more than two decades. The United States accounts for about 85 percent of Canada's exports. Statistics Canada said shipments of telecommunications equipment were half of their peak in late 2000, while exports of automotive products dipped 3.2 percent. The economy's overall growth over the last four quarters averaged 0.2 percent, down from 1.1 percent in the previous 12 months.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOUGHERTY, JAMES W.
description: DOUGHERTY-James W. 12/1/95 Everlasting.

title: Fly Free
description: The Puerto Rico Tourism Company has a limited number of airline tickets to throw in at no extra charge when travelers buy a hotel package of five nights or longer from participating tour operators. They include GoGo Worldwide Vacations, Travel Impressions, American Airlines Vacations, Brendan Tours, ATA Vacations and Apple Vacations. The offer is good for travel from Kennedy Airport, Newark, Chicago, Miami and Fort Lauderdale. It's good through Dec. 15 and is for two people sharing a room. Participating airlines are American, Delta, Continental, Spirit and American Trans Air. Information: (800) 866-7827 or on the Web at www.gotopuertorico.com .

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: After a sell-off earlier in the week, natural gas prices rose on technical buying, traders said. In New York, gas for February delivery rose 14 cents, or 5.47 percent, to $2.701 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: ASHCROFT WEIGHS EASING F.B.I. LIMITS FOR SURVEILLANCE
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft is considering a plan to relax restrictions on the F.B.I.'s spying on religious and political organizations in the United States, senior government officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Prices Offering
description: France's biggest consumer bank, Crdit Agricole, priced its initial public offering, which is scheduled to begin trading later this month at 14.30 to 16.60 euros ($12.68 to $14.72) a share. The final price will be set on Dec. 13, and the bank hopes to raise $3.6 billion from the sale. Crdit Agricole's offering will be the biggest in France since shares of Orange began trading in February, and the third largest in Europe so far this year. Crdit Agricole also said that it was interested in raising its stake in a smaller rival, Crdit Lyonnais, in which it owns a 10 percent stake. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Europe Toughens Up on Job Cuts
description: When it comes to laying off workers, European executives have long considered themselves the antithesis of American business.

title: Catholic Teachers' Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Spiral Staircase To Nowhere
description: DONNA E. SHALALA came to the phone upbeat and typically confident yesterday. Things have gone well during her first few months as the president of the University of Miami. Students are beginning exams, and the campus has been bursting with Rose Bowl fever.

title: Joblessness In Japan Rises To a Record
description: Japan's unemployment rate set another postwar record in October, rising to 5.4 percent, as homebuilding contracted and prices continued a two-year downward drift.

title: After Setback, Pirros Appear To Be on Track For Rebound
description: And so, after Al Pirro's federal tax fraud trial and Jeanine Pirro's closer-than-expected re-election as district attorney, we find Westchester's power couple heading back to the future. Or is the present looking a lot like the past?

title: After Sept. 11, the Best Office Is in the Den
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sharon Wants 1 Million Jews
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon announced that he wants to see a million more Jewish immigrants to Israel, bolstering a population of nearly 6.5 million. In a speech on Thursday to an annual gathering of newspaper editors and other journalists, Mr. Sharon said he wanted to focus his efforts on the economy, education and immigration. ''In the next year I want to see a million Jews come from Argentina, France and especially from South Africa,'' he said. Joel Greenberg (NYT)

title: A Soprano Soars Over Her First Hurdle
description: In today's classical music world, the debut song recital has become a requisite hurdle, a kind of oral exam standing between a young singer and a major professional career. On Tuesday evening the exam, a New York debut, was administered by Young Concert Artists at the 92nd Street Y. And Courtenay Budd, a soprano, certainly passed.

title: Czechs Urged Not to Return Opposition Leader to Uzbekistan
description: International human rights advocates urged Czech authorities today not to extradite the leader of Uzbekistan's democratic opposition, saying he could be killed if he was forced to return to his homeland.

title: Ambivalent Academe
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, EDITH
description: ALTMAN-Edith. A woman of warmth, generosity, and intelligence and cherished mother of our dearest friend Louise. Our deepest sympathies to the entire family. We will remember her with love. Madeline and Stephen Barkin

title: Nets Learning That MacCulloch Can Play
description: Todd MacCulloch was at the free-throw line as two dozen children and two child competitors watched him during his appearance at the N.B.A. Store in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday. He sat on a chair (to make it more fair) and sank two free throws.

title: A Worthy New York Prosecutor
description: After a stellar eight-year tenure during which she successfully prosecuted Al Qaeda terrorists, corrupt local cops, Wall Street scam artists and Bronx street gangs, Mary Jo White announced last month that she would step down as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York by the end of the year. President Bush has now announced that he will nominate James Comey to succeed her. Mr. Comey would be a solid choice. The job requires someone with strong federal prosecutorial experience and a reputation for independence, both of which he has.

title: As McGreevey Urges Frugality, New Jersey Senate Votes to Spend
description: Six weeks before taking office, Governor-elect James E. McGreevey of New Jersey is already clashing with the State Senate over spending measures that Mr. McGreevey says will contribute to a state budget shortfall of more than $3.5 billion in the next fiscal year.

title: Connecticut Panel Fails To Map New Congressional Boundaries
description: Legislative leaders failed to meet a midnight deadline Friday in a quest to redraw Connecticut's Congressional districts. The state Supreme Court will now decide how to reduce the number of House seats from six to five in response to the state's shifting population.

title: Special Education Increases Cut From Bill
description: Cutting to the heart of the debate over school financing, lawmakers today rejected an attempt to guarantee multibillion dollar increases for special education as part of a sweeping education bill.

title: Cuba Is Sued For Execution Of American 40 Years Ago
description: The widow and children of a United States businessman who was executed more than 40 years ago on charges of conspiring against Fidel Castro's revolutionary government today filed a wrongful death lawsuit against Cuba.

title: Germ Weapon Plans Found at a Scientist's House in Kabul
description: A group of armed men, reportedly Americans, dressed in gas masks, rubber gloves and boots, removed powdered chemicals this week from the home of a retired Pakistani nuclear scientist here, Afghan security guards at the house said today.

title: Beauty in the Details
description: Dagmar Spain was content to explore small worlds in a program presented by her Dance Imprints company on Nov. 16 at the Joyce SoHo. But there was nothing impoverished-feeling about the confident, expansive choreography and performing.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: DISCOUNTS FOR BUSINESS TRAVELERS TO BE EXTENDED
description: United Airlines will extend discounts for business travelers to March from December as it tries to win back customers after the Sept. 11 attacks. The company, the second-largest airline, is offering business travelers 50 percent off an unrestricted business fare, which requires a 21-day advance purchase, and 25 percent off a ticket bought 10 days in advance. The offer was extended to March 31 from Dec. 31, it said in a statement. The airline, owned by the UAL Corporation, is based in Chicago.

title: Bond With New York Is Felt In Firetruck-Building Town

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Foreigners To Build Power  Plants
description: The Brazilian government auctioned 11 licenses to build hydroelectric power plants to companies including Alcoa Inc., lectricit de France and Tractebel S.A. of Belgium, giving an important boost to investor confidence in the country's beleaguered electricity sector. The projects should draw $1.9 billion in investment over the next seven years, and earn the government $1.6 billion in fees over the life of the 30-year concessions. The government was forced to cancel two large privatizations in the power sector this year after investors backed out, citing uncertainties in the sector. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: While My Guitar Gently Weeps
description: George Harrison, who died of cancer on Thursday at the age of 58, always seemed to wear his electric guitar a little higher against his body than other guitarists did. It was an adjunct of his breastbone, not his pelvis. That was partly an illusion caused by his preference for the big-bodied Chet Atkins models made by Gretsch, guitars called the Country Gentleman and the Tennessean. Those instruments and the way he held them made George -- as every lifelong fan inevitably calls him -- look even more angular than he was by nature, more precise somehow. For him, the guitar seemed to possess a kind of acuity, a brightness intrinsic to the instruments he chose and to the guitarists, especially Carl Perkins and Chuck Berry, he emulated.

title: TELLABS, PHONE GEAR MAKER, TO BUY OCULAR NETWORKS
description: Tellabs Inc., the biggest maker of equipment that manages traffic on phone networks, agreed to buy the closely held Ocular Networks Inc. for $355 million in cash and options, to bolster its line of fiber optic products. Tellabs will pay about $300 million in cash and $55 million in stock options for the start-up company, a Tellabs spokeswoman, Jean Medina, said yesterday. Ocular's equipment organizes information and moves it through citywide optical networks more efficiently, reducing costs for phone companies. The purchase is part of a Tellabs push into so-called metropolitan optical equipment, which carries traffic through cities. Ocular is based in Reston, Va., and Tellabs in Napierville, Ill.

According to local press reports the three were part of a group of settlers who attacked a patrol from the Belize Defense Force inside a zone that had been set up as a haven while the two countries hold talks on the dispute. The region has long been claimed by Guatemala and in recent years Guatemalan peasants have moved from the protected zone into Belize. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Little Tree Meets Destiny
description: The poetry of E. E. Cummings, with its lively, inventive language and its frequent joy and optimism, has always held a special appeal for children, and his Christmas poem ''Little Tree'' is no exception. In it, a small child speaks wonderingly to a Christmas tree: ''look the spangles / that sleep all the year in a dark box / dreaming of being taken out and allowed to shine, / the balls the chains red and gold the fluffy threads, / put up your little arms / and i'll give them all to you to hold / every finger shall have its ring / and there won't be a single place dark or unhappy.'' In this season's LITTLE TREE (Hyperion, $16.99; all ages), the well-known writer and illustrator Chris Raschka uses Cummings's poem as a jumping-off point for his own story about a Christmas tree's journey from forest to city, where ''a little boy, a little girl, a little mother and father and their little dog walked up and down the little streets of the little big city, looking and looking for their own special, just right, one and only, perfect little tree.'' Predictably, Little Tree is taken back to the family's apartment, where he finds ''his own special place in the world, a special little place that was waiting for him all his life.'' Raschka's illustrations are bright, bold and busy, with a preprimary-school feel to them, as if a precocious child had been turned loose with a paint box. The pictures are constructed out of basic geometric shapes -- squares, circles, rectangles and, of course, triangles, to represent Little Tree and friends. Raschka's intention, presumably, was to create a visual equivalent for Cummings's faux-nave style. The book has brightly striped endpapers that look like holiday wrapping paper, and is encased -- like a present you can look into -- in a clear plastic jacket. It's a simple story that's been told before, but one that might appeal to very young children who want predictability, security and a happy ending. The best part is Cummings's poem. But please, Chris Raschka, did you have to say ''little'' 53 times? Elizabeth Spires

title: On a Luxury Liner to India
description: IN downtown Panaji, near Marmagoa, the port of Goa, one of the main streets was under construction. One couldn't help but think that it always was. A few men sat on the ground, breaking up pieces of pavement with small mallets, then placing them into piles. Women in saris, their movements mechanical, picked up the chunks, placed them in the containers atop their heads, walked listlessly down the street and then dumped them into another pile only a few feet away. All around, drivers and pedestrians and shop owners conducted business as usual, buying or selling film or clothes or cashews. The millenniums were clashing, as they so often do, on a single Indian street.

title: The Last Word
description: Carrie Donovan introduced The Times Magazine's readers to Donna Karan for the first time in May 1986, and this is how Donovan captured her: ''The designer strides forth, a freshly filled coffee mug in her hand, a big bag over her shoulder, dark glasses hiding some of her usually unmade-up face, which is framed by brunet hair casually tossed here and there. At 37, Donna Karan is a noticeable person, not beautiful, but handsome, with an infectious smile and a commanding voice accented unmistakably with the vowels of New York.'' That description is affectionate and blunt, insightful and superficial, typical for Donovan, who loved to play up the dichotomies of her own character. A few months before that cover article ran, a home videotape captured Karan accepting congratulations backstage after her first show. At the celebration, Donovan sat knee to knee with the triumphant, glowing designer and gazed gleefully into the camera: ''My daughter Donna,'' Donovan beamed. ''I'm so proud of her.'' Karan turned her attention away from Donovan only for a moment to look with ardor at her husband, Stephan Weiss, who gave her a short kiss, then a longer one.
