title: They Came Late to Nudity, but They Learned Fast
description: SO, the new commonplace goes, the Victorians were not prudes after all, just hypocrites. All that preaching against sin and depravity was only for public consumption. Behind the lace curtains of London's drawing rooms, a whole lot of fun was going on. Even Queen Victoria, so majestically austere in public, was a party girl at heart. Please don't imagine she was thinking of England when she gave Prince Albert paintings of naked ladies as birthday presents.

title: Brenda E. Conway: Half of a Lifelong Team
description: Brenda E. Conway was hard to miss. First, because of her unique style  an avid shopper, she preferred bright colors and patterns, and made funny socks her signature  and second, because you usually saw two of her. Mrs. Conway was rarely without her twin, Linda McGee. Though they were fraternal, the sisters still looked and sounded enough alike to draw attention.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CORAM BOY

title: Anger Erupts At Mosque, Site of Raid And Arrests
description: For years, the police have been keeping an eye on a nondescript building behind an auto parts store here. Inside is a makeshift prayer room, the Islamic Cultural Center and mosque.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a new recording of songs from the Stephen Sondheim works ''The Frogs'' and ''Evening Primrose'' misstated the surname of a singer. He is Neil Patrick Harris, not Barnes.

title: When the Ordinary Becomes Extraordinary
description: JOHN CRISCUOLO and his 25 guests were sitting down for the first course of their Thanksgiving Day dinner -- homemade chicken soup -- when the telephone rang in his Seymour home. The F.B.I. was on the line.

title: Taliban Arab, Like Many, Longs for Home but Faces a Doubtful Fate
description: The holy war of Fahad Nasir ends here, in a filthy corner of a lonely room with a bullet in his arm.

title: Man on U.S. List Is Found Guilty
description: A man named on the government's list of people charged with crimes arising from its terror investigation was convicted today in United States District Court on gun charges that could incarcerate him for 30 years.

title: Cruise Information
description: Silversea Cruises is at 110 East Broward Boulevard, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 33301; (800) 722-9955, fax (954) 522-4499; www.silversea.com . A 12-day cruise from Singapore to Bombay aboard the Silver Shadow, which is newer and slightly larger than the Silver Cloud, is scheduled for March 20. Prices range from $8,395 to $18,795 a person double occupancy, including round-trip air fare. A cabin on the fifth deck, with a private veranda, is $10,095 a person.

title: The Woman Who Would Be Claus
description: Whoopi Goldberg wears many hats: actress, comedian, producers, mother and grandmother. But her newest, a familiar red number with furry white trim, has generated a world of excitement - and not a few tricky situations.

title: Personal Business; Shaken Consumers Are Looking to Life Insurance
description: FOR years, life insurance was a hard sell. Even some companies that sold it began dropping ''life insurance'' from their names and calling themselves financial services companies. They recognized that Americans had become less interested in buying protection for their families than in making investments intended to make themselves comfortable in retirement.

title: What Design For a Synagogue Spells Jewish?
description: JEWISH writing on synagogue architecture is scant and contradictory. The Talmud decrees that synagogues must be built in high places. The Zohar suggests 12 windows; Maimonides defends darkness. Curiously for such a well-documented religion, there are few guidelines for the structure of its houses of worship. Interiors are shaped by the rituals of the service and by its equipment -- the bimah where the Torah is read and the Ark where it is housed -- but for the building itself there are no limits.

title: Odd and Odder
description: MARY GEORGE OF ALLNORTHOVER

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALLIS, MEYER
description: MALLIS-Meyer. 10/18/16-11/30/90. 11 years have passed. We remember, miss and love you daily and always will. You were the best Dad. Rest in peace.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 18, about Guangzhou, China, misstated the name of the railroad that runs from there to Hong Kong. It is the Kowloon Canton, not the Kowloon Central.

title: An Entrepreneurial Flair Worth Appreciating, Too
description: MOST CD boxed sets offer empty promises with full price tags. A few, like James Brown's ''Star Time,'' clarify a mercurial personality; a few others, like Harry Smith's ''Anthology of American Folk Music,'' use inspired selection to reveal historic threads. The new four-CD anthology ''Q: The Musical Biography of Quincy Jones,'' is singular in that while it both clarifies a personality and draws historic connections, it does not increase the stature of its subject as an artist. But extolling Quincy Jones the musician is not the point of ''Q.'' It is intended to present his case as a masterly entertainment mogul.

title: A Laos Huck Finn Would Love
description: IT is amazing but true. I am in the riverside town of Vang Vieng, Laos, standing on a bamboo bridge that spans the 150-yard breadth of the Nam Song, yet I am reminded, of all things, of the Garden State Parkway. This is because the man barring my way is demanding a toll: 1,000 kips for me, plus the same for my rented mountain bike.

title: Jrme R. Lohez: Vive l'Amrique!
description: Jerome R. Lohez was French, Dening Wu was a Francophile, and their first date was a film at the Paris Theater on West 58th Street.

title: St. John's Regains Its Form And Sends Fordham a Message
description: Mike Jarvis, the St. John's coach, preaches so often about the responsibility of being the New York metropolitan area's top basketball program that his players sometimes sound as if they are reading from a script. For one half yesterday, Fordham made that assumption seem silly, streaking to a double-digit lead.

title: In This Corner, Weighing In at 1,500 Pounds . . .
description: BEAR V. SHARK

title: Suffolk Cuts $400,000 From Marine Project
description: AMID the tax increases and spending cuts of a hard budget year for Suffolk County, a reduction of nearly $400,000 for a highly regarded marine program operated by the Cornell Cooperative Extension hardly stood out.

title: 'Travels With a Medieval Queen'
description: The tower of Trifels Castle beckoned, dark red against the pale spring sky and the new green of the tree-covered mountainside below. Princes, dukes, barons, and bishops came tiding from all parts of Germany, summoned by their suzerain, the thrice-crowned Henry VI, King of Germany, King of Italy, and Holy Roman Emperor, to attend high court on the feast of Pentecost, which in 1194 fell on the ninth of May.

title: Many Ways To Warm Cool Rooms
description: HOUSEHOLDERS looking for a way to warm a cool room will find many sizes and styles of room heaters. The options range from small cord-free heaters that, like night lights, sit directly on an electrical outlet to powerful gas-fired or hard-wired electrical appliances that can be hung on a wall to heat a large room, garage, patio or enclosed porch.

title: Gains for Social Screening
description: Assets in so-called socially responsible investment portfolios grew 36 percent, to $2.03 trillion, from 1999 to 2001, according to the Social Investment Forum, a nonprofit organization that includes mutual funds, community development organizations and portfolio managers.

title: At the Coliseum, in the Lap of, Yes, Luxury
description: IN a suite high above the rink at the Nassau Coliseum, Tom Cox sat in a plush leather swivel chair, a satisfied smile spreading across his face. The scenario couldn't have been better.

title: Business; Flood of Lawsuits Puts Underwriters in Cross Hairs
description: FOR Christopher Lovell, a New York lawyer, the class-action lawsuit boom of 2001 began with an after-hours phone call in January from Howard Sirota, another lawyer.

title: Footlights
description: Piano Playing for Peace

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LA CRUZ, PETER
description: DE LA CRUZ-Peter. Passed away on November 23, 2001. He has joined his Mother, Dona Polita, on that eternal journey. Although his later years were filled with suffering, God blessed him with a special person, who shared love and friendship, as well as, comfort and support. Jo Brewer is such an individual. His sister would like to acknowledge a personal thank you to her for bringing many moments of joy into his life. He is survived by his sister, Elma M. Lopez & his children Melissa, Corey, Adriana, Casondra and Mario. May the Divine welcome him into that peaceful abode where all suffering has ceased.

title: GARDENING
description: SOMEDAY, some mad compiler, a spiritual descendant of Borges, will write ''The Encyclopedia of Things That Have Never Been in Encyclopedias.'' That work will be the true corpus of knowledge, a completer and certainly stranger enterprise than any conventional encyclopedia has ever been.

title: For New Year's, The Party Is On
description: CAROL AND GEORGE HAHN have spent the winter holidays away for nearly 20 years and have no intention of changing that tradition now. This year, they are planning a three-week trip that will begin in Dubai and end in Hanoi, with New Year's Eve spent on a 747 from Johannesburg to Hong Kong.

title: Twin Chardonnays
description: Not only are Gristina/Galluccio Estate Vineyards and Pellegrini Vineyards nearly adjacent neighbors on Main Road in Cutchogue, their low-priced chardonnays are now neighbors stylistically.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Anthrax Vaccine Report Halts Stock Trading

title: Playing It Straight
description: Peter Schickele, the musical satirist and radio show host whose PDQ Bach Christmas concerts sell out Carnegie Hall each year, is not known for playing it straight. But he would like to be, and has by now composed more than a hundred pieces, meant to be played straight.

title: With Jets and Patriots, Game Replaces Feuding
description: It is as if someone tore down the big top to leave a minimalist tableau of stadium lights on the Jets and the Patriots this season. What had been a series mostly known for the circus-like clashes between coaches, owners, players and even front-office personnel is reduced today -- elevated, actually -- to a game with more riding on it than mere ego.

title: John B. Cahill: Good Humor in 3 Languages
description: When John B. Cahill was an undergraduate at Boston College, he was a real good-time guy, and his friends nicknamed him Mad Dog. But he calmed down and matured into a gregarious family man with a quirky sense of humor.

title: After Years Away From Campus, a Joyful Return
description: She strode up the steps tentatively at first, her body covered from face to foot by blue cotton. As she neared the door, she flipped the cloth back over her head, revealing round cheeks, dark ringlets of hair and the searching brown eyes of a student.

title: By Any Name, It's the Mercedes of Cargo Vans
description: ARE American tradesmen and delivery people ready for the Sprinter commercial van by Mercedes-Benz? My plumber would appear to be; he motored up in a vintage 560 SL roadster to give an estimate for a new bathroom. Given the size of that estimate, he may be able to afford several Sprinters.

title: A Husband Lost, and a Daughter Out of Reach
description: Every time she telephones her 8-year-old daughter in the Ivory Coast, Hadidjatou Karamoko Traor says, the girl cries that she wants to come to New York to see her mother.

title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; Bank Doors, Initials on Brick, 2 Buildings' Origins
description: Mystery of the Bronze Doors

title: Hoping a Family Farm Yields Harvests, Not Housing
description: David Weprin has shopped all his life at the fruit and vegetable stand in front of the two-acre Klein family farm on 73rd Avenue, stocking up on everything from pumpkins to kohlrabi. Like others in the neighborhood, he was troubled to learn over the summer that John Klein Sr., who owns the property, had signed a contract to sell to a developer with plans to build 22 two-family houses on the site.

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; U.S. and Vietnam in Trade Pact
description: Vietnam and the United States took the final step in putting the war behind them, normalizing trade relations six years after opening full diplomatic relations. After similar action in the United States Congress, the Vietnamese national assembly ratified a bilateral trade agreement that will give it access to American markets on the same basis as most other countries. Seth Mydans

title: Weibin Wang: Living the American Dream
description: Weibin Wang and Wen Shi met as students in Beijing, and married three years later. A few months after the wedding in 1986, Mr. Wang left for the United States to study geophysics, at Yale and then at Columbia. Ms. Shi followed a year later.

title: Let Us Count The Ways
description: Many thanks to Paul Auster for his hymn to the subway commuter. I share his appreciation for the daily rush-hour pageant, and I enjoyed his evocative description of it. He might have added that, since Sept. 11, the civilized silence when the train stops and the lights go out is not only patient but unmistakably tense.

title: Film Series Listings
description: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE  Master Class: The Art of Film Editing. Today, 1: Demme's "Beloved" (1998); discussion with Carol Littleton. Sat., 2: Demme's "Silence of the Lambs" (1991); discussion with Craig McKay. 35th Ave. at 36th St., Astoria, Queens. (718-784-0077)

title: Bush Urges Arafat to Bring Suspects to Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Bush today demanded that Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestinian Authority, break up Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, the groups that, he said, train and breed the kinds of suicide bombers who killed at least 25 people in terrorist bombings over the weekend.

title: Peter R. Kellerman: Dogs, Drums, Motorcycles
description: Robi and Peter R. Kellerman planned to have children, but first they had dogs.

title: William Anthony Karnes: Discovering New York
description: William Anthony Karnes made his living as a software trainer for Marsh & McLennan. But his life's passion was touting the virtues of his adopted hometown, New York, regaling his sisters with stories about the wonders of living in the city where anything is possible, a place grander than anything he imagined growing up back in tiny Corryton, Tenn.

title: Beginnings
description: There can be no doubt that the profile of New York in the egg on your cover represents the beat of an EKG (Nov. 11). And there is no doubt that the pulse of New York remains vibrant.

title: John Barth's Fun House
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Grazing at a 401(k) Buffet
description: A survey of more than 2,400 employer-sponsored 401(k) retirement plans has found that participants, on average, have 24 fund selections but choose fewer than four of them.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Amid Italian Fare, Wines Worth Toasting
description: OENOPHILES may want to rush to Valbella!! in Riverside for the wines alone. If restaurant reviews were based on wine, Valbella!! would merit an ''Extraordinary.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 11 about a traveling production of the play ''Ferdydurke'' misstated the location of a Feb. 13 performance in Indianapolis. It is Indiana University-Purdue University, not Indiana State University.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: LEST we forget: this season's photography offerings already reflect Sept. 11. Two compilations of pictures about the attack on the World Trade Center have appeared, with more surely to follow. They are welcome in part because they freeze-frame a calamity so great that the mind struggles, even months later, to comprehend the data being sent by the eyes. The books are also notable for having been produced with uncommon speed: publishers usually take at least a year getting a book from concept to print. And two more timeless books of photographs of New York, featuring lyrical black-and-white images by Helen Levitt and Roy DeCarava that are about a half-century old, were in production long before the terrorist attacks but have acquired a recuperative poignancy.

title: QUICK BITE/North Brunswick; A Cornucopia, Lebanese-Style
description: What's the weirdest food combination you can imagine being sold under one roof? How about Hershey's ice cream and Lebanese food? That's exactly what's in store for you at the Sweet Treat Cafe on Route 130 in North Brunswick. And it has been for the past couple of years, since Rajaa Balech, a former baby-furniture store manager, took over the place formerly known as Liberty Roastery. Actually, Miss Balech, clarified, ''Our specialty is ice cream and fresh roasted nuts'' -- which may sound appetizing to some, but not necessarily to those showing up for breakfast. For them, there are bagels, buttered rolls, herbal tea, flavored coffee, hot chocolate, muffins, waffles, egg-and-cheese sandwiches, bacon, sausage, ham and more -- none for more than $3. Inside the place, which seats about 15, are shelves crammed with a variety of Lebanese products: pita bread, fruits, canned goods, syrups. There are also home-baked cookies -- Lebanese-style, of course -- and fresh-baked Lebanese pastry. ''I used to work at night as a Lebanese cook,'' Miss Balech said. When she finds the time, she also makes gift baskets of food, fruit or candy and nuts -- which might include cashews, pumpkin seeds, chickpeas, macadamias, Brazil nuts and roasted corn -- for special occasions and holidays, or just for the fun of it. There are also hot pretzels for a dollar each. Finally, of course, there's that headlined Hershey's ice cream in a variety of flavors: in cone, packed, sundae or shake, a real Lebanese treat. Norm Oshrin

title: Private Sector; Planes, Heirs and Automobiles
description: THE gloomy day this past October was dampening the centennial celebration of Henry Ford's racing business. But Edsel B. Ford II, his great-grandson, was having a ball.

title: Los Angeles: Now There's a There There
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid the Tawdry, the Tacky (and Worse), One Man Hawks History From a Pushcart
description: Amid a sea of pirated compact discs, fake Fendi bags and widgets of dubious function, there is a lone man, pushing his shopping cart along Canal Street, selling a commodity that has no price: history.

title: Brazilian Slums Prove Location Reigns Supreme In Real Estate
description: Just off the main road, down a narrow alley closed in by brick walls, Marli Roseno's front door stands open invitingly. Inside is a tiny two-bedroom, one-bath dwelling, spotless but cluttered, in the midst of a giant shanty town.

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; H.I.V. Rise in Europe and Asia
description: H.I.V. infections have doubled in Eastern Europe and Central Asia over the last year and the AIDS virus is spreading faster there than anywhere else, the United Nations said in its yearly report on worldwide AIDS. Up to five million people are infected, far exceeding the official reports of about one million, the U.N. said. In Asia, new infections surpassed one million. In a continent with huge populations, rate increases of less than 1 percent can translate into millions of cases. If prevention efforts are not successful, Asia could eventually rival Africa, the world's worst affected area. Lawrence K. Altman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITOLO, RALPH FRANCIS
description: VITOLO-Ralph Francis, 59. Of Lido Beach, NY, died on November 17 in Pattaya, Thailand. Cause of death was heart failure. He is survived by Theresa Vitolo, mother Frances of Fort Lauderdale, FL, sister Ann Carol Caponi of Greenwich Village, NY and niece Meeso and nephew Jared. Mr. Vitolo had a 23 year career in New York City's Government, Computer and Data Communications Service Agency. He retired as Commissioner of User Services, which provided Telecommunications Services to over 40 City Agencies. Avid reader, traveler, and lover of life, he will be dearly missed by family, friends, and golf buddies. Memorial services to be held Monday, December 3, 2001 at The First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, Fifth Avenue, Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to The Tiger Woods Foundation at 4281 Katella Ave., Ste 111, Los Alamitos, CA 90720, would be appreciated.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 2, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Susan Orlean, John Gillespie Jr.
description: SUSAN ORLEAN is known for carving portraits out of startlingly concise prose that, slick as a whistle, cut to the heart of the matter. ''I like writing about the texture of ordinary life,'' said Ms. Orlean, a staff writer at The New Yorker. ''I'm curious about people's passions and subcultures.''

title: INSIDE
description: 850,000 Lose Internet Link

title: Giambi May Answer Yanks Tonight
description: The Yankees may learn tonight whether they will land first baseman Jason Giambi, their top target of the off-season, according to officials familiar with the negotiations.

title: Lost and Found
description: In much of the country, the dialogue of the past months has focused largely on national issues. On patriotism and on war, on the stock market and on the effect that this terror will have on the content of prime-time television. I, however, have been filled with thoughts of this city that raised me: ''I'm here because I was born here and thus ruined for anywhere else.'' I want to thank Colson Whitehead for saying it.

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; Not Down for the Big Count
description: Nearly 8 million Americans live in what the Census Bureau calls ''group quarters'' -- some willingly, like college students, some not, like prisoners. The precise location of such quarters is, as one local official put it, a ''huge issue,'' because state and federal payments flow to where the people are. The 2000 census, though, seems to have bounced some of those quarters around, in one case locating a prison 27 miles too far north, playing havoc with local budgets. The Census Bureau vows to fix the mistakes. By one school of thought, though, aid should be shifted even farther, to an inmate's home town. Hubert B. Herring

title: Berlin Museum's Revival Bolsters German Identity
description: When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, the Old National Gallery in the eastern part of the city, on the Spree River's Museum Island, was a faded institution, still pockmarked from World War II artillery and largely devoid of its once-great collection.

title: Wendy Hotchkiss, David Kurtz
description: Wendy Gail Hotchkiss, a daughter of Dr. Edward J. Hotchkiss of Rockville Centre, N.Y., and the late Judy M. Hotchkiss, is to be married this afternoon to David Michael Kurtz, the son of Arlene and Sander Kurtz of Lafayette Hill, Pa. Rabbi Julian I. Cook is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: In Seeking a Top House Post, Menendez Calls In His Debts
description: Robert Menendez has begun calling in his political chits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, EUGENE V.
description: REDMOND-Eugene V. On November 30, 2001. Loving husband of June. Devoted father of Randi and son-in-law Steven Oster. Proud grandfather of Gary and Matthew. He was a constant source of support and inspiration to all. Graveside service and interment at Congregation Beth-El Cemetery, Fairfield, CT.

title: James C. Cappers: Joys of the Outdoors
description: In her junior year at Quinnipiac College, Kathleen Vieira spotted a new man on campus. He was tall. He was handsome. He was wearing a pink rugby shirt.

title: Wall Street; Assessing the Role Of the Financiers
description: When a company Enron's size implodes, few financial firms escape unscathed. On Wall Street, there is plenty of blame, losses and shame to go around. Many reputations were dented; a few were buffed.

title: When Giving Leaves You Wanting
description: A COUPLE of Sundays ago, my husband, John, and I made our annual pledge to Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, N.J. Here's how we decided how much to give: Between yelling up the stairs to tell our children that it was time to go and throwing the breakfast plates into the sink, I said, ''I think we're supposed to pledge today.''

title: TRAVEL
description: YOUNG women are particularly avid travelers. And they seem to be edging out their male counterparts: the 16-year-old daughter of a friend just went to France for a month with a school group composed of 28 girls and 4 boys. One can hazard a few guesses why this might be so: traveling is a subspecies of self-improvement, and a voyage out is not infrequently also a voyage of self-discovery, one that requires a lot of navel-gazing and journal-writing, activities that most young men, unless they're aspiring rock stars, are disinclined to pursue.

title: Nov. 25-Dec. 1; On Russian TV, More of the Same
description: Politics, greed and revenge. Ask any observer of the Russian media what is behind the death of a the Moscow television station, TV 6, and one or all of the above will probably come up.

title: At a Scarsdale Tavern, Dishes Unfold
description: WE can't recall when Scarsdale's five corners were not dominated by the stone turret of a building that has long been the home to various restaurants. Many will remember the old dusty, gloomy dining rooms, and their transformation, almost four years ago, into the fresh, sparkling spaces that is Heathcote Tavern today. The dramatic vastness of the place, the semiprivate niches and a pretty, roomy tavern are something special.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 2, 2001
description: Weeks

title: The Nation: Ledger Allegiance; My Bottom Line, Right or Wrong . . .
description: THE attacks of Sept. 11 were aimed at the symbolic heart of capitalism, but that does not mean the titans of industry feel obligated to join the fight on terrorism.

title: Blasting? Don't Fret, But Geese Beware
description: LAST week, city enforcement officers in boats, armed with explosives, took to the Kensico Reservoir. Their target: Canada geese.

title: Community; A Crown Jewel Becomes a Liability
description: In a Houston economy where corporate stars like Continental Airlines and Compaq Computer were suffering, Enron had become the premier business. Its executives reveled in the role, naming the Houston Astros stadium for their company, building a new office tower and writing checks for every civic cause. Through Enron, above all, Houston, long the capital of the world's oil industry, was extending its claim to natural gas and electricity.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Battles, Past and Present

title: Robert Helps, 73, Concert Pianist And a Wide-Ranging Composer
description: Robert Helps, an American composer and concert pianist whose own works ranged freely through the lexicon of contemporary styles and techniques, died last Saturday at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 73.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HOW TA LOLA CAME TO STAY

title: Investing; A Siren Song Sounds Again From Wall St.
description: FIVE years after Alan Greenspan warned that investors might be displaying ''irrational exuberance,'' there are signs that the phenomenon may again be rearing its giddy head.

title: Community College Extends Its Reach in Yonkers
description: With the official opening of its latest off-campus site at the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers last week, Westchester Community College, based in Valhalla, continues its mission to take its offerings to its students. Earlier this year, the college opened a Health Sciences site in Ossining, and by next fall, will open at a location Mount Vernon. Other extension sites include Peekskill, Tuckahoe, New Rochelle, Mahopac, Shrub Oak and White Plains.

title: Christians Fleeing Strife in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 1 (AP)  Thousands of Christian villagers on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi are fleeing attacks by armed Muslim paramilitary forces, clerics and news reports said today.

title: When Desert Bounty Fills a Dinner Plate
description: I FINISHED Gary Paul Nabhan's new book, ''Coming Home to Eat: The Pleasures and Politics of Local Foods,'' at the kitchen table in between making Thanksgiving dinner: basting the pork roast (no turkey this year), chopping parsley (fresh from the garden), baking apples (local Winesaps doused with homemade maple syrup), stirring the risotto, getting out the cheese and wine from France, England and Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, JOSEPH
description: SACKS-Joseph, 75. Formerly of East Rockaway, New York, died November 28, 2001 in Florida. Survived by son Steven E. Sacks of Westbury, NY. Interment private.

title: The World: Afghanistan's Women; Hope for the Future, Blunted by a Hard Past
description: IT was a moment in Afghan history now often recalled for its daring. On Aug. 25, 1959, Prime Minister Mohammed Daud, along with other ministers and members of the royal family, escorted their wives and daughters to the reviewing stand for a parade celebrating 40 years of independence from British interference. The crowd gasped. All the women's faces were uncovered.

title: SHOPPING WITH -- Nikki S. Lee; Dressing the Part Is Her Art
description: THE discreet young woman walking into the DKNY store on Madison Avenue last Tuesday, dressed in black and wearing huge Chanel sunglasses like windows on a bulletproof limousine, has had previous lives.

title: The Stock Market Must Rise in 2002? Think Again
description: STATISTICIANS refer to it as the gamblers' fallacy: betting that the odds of an event's occurrence depend on previous events that in fact have no relationship to it.

title: U.S. and Britain at Odds Over Use and Timing of Peacekeeping Troops
description: After almost two months of walking in lock step, the United States and Britain are at odds over the use of peacekeeping forces in Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of the year's notable books on Page 63 of the Book Review today classifies "Trieste and the Meaning of Nowhere," by Jan Morris, incorrectly. It is nonfiction, not fiction. Arts & Leisure

title: America's Cup Maneuvers Precede the Racing
description: In the roiled waters off Auckland, New Zealand, masts are falling and keels are dropping. Elsewhere, in boardrooms and in courtrooms, television deals are being wrangled over, and allegations are flying.

title: Luxury In Hard Times
description: The second week of September was Fashion Week in New York, and Tom Ford, the designer of Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, was in town to meet with investors and to host a glitzy party for the newly redesigned YSL store on Madison Avenue. ''I'm a Virgo,'' Ford told me a week later. ''So I see all the problems.'' As usual, he was obsessive about the store's dcor. He moved a white stool, he worried that the handrail would give shoppers splinters and he set little marks on the stereo volume so the music would provide the proper ambience. The New York store, Ford reasoned, would set the YSL tone for the label nationwide.

title: Corrections
description: The Gazetteer chart last Sunday, about the Westerleigh section of Staten Island, misspelled the surname of the author of a book on the neighborhood's history. He is Lawrence J. Dober, not Dover.

title: COOKING
description: BURROWING in and devoting days to D & D dishes, as glamorous New York friends used to describe their ''difficult and demanding'' cook-offs, has rarely seemed so appealing, so necessary. Of course, this year's cookbooks were planned and written long before sticking close to home and hearth was mandated, but they provide plenty of pleasant ways to do just that -- and, as usual, plenty of ways to roam the globe by reading, marketing and then hunkering down at the stove. And not necessarily to produce a dauntingly D & D menu.

title: The Restaurateur
description: She usually -- wears a muted New York palette of gray, black and brown. But on Tuesday night Julie Menin will step into a strapless crimson dress by Alberta Ferretti with a ruffled hem and a soft flounce at the shoulder. ''There has been so little to celebrate downtown that I wanted to wear something festive and beautiful, yet still serious,'' Ms. Menin said.

title: As Guns Still Blaze, Bush Aides Debate Shifting Focus to Butter
description: Even as President Bush asks Americans to prepare for a sustained war on global terrorism, tensions are escalating between his domestic political team and his military policy advisers over whether the administration should turn more of its attention to pressing economic concerns.

title: DataBank; It Was Bears Over Bulls, by a Nose
description: The bulls and bears played tug of war last week. The bears are slightly ahead. For now.

title: Jack's Back: Same Beanstalk, Different Stakes
description: Jack (Matthew Modine) works furiously to outmaneuver the Robinson family curse, because of which no heir in 10 generations has lived past the age of 40, in ''Jim Henson's Jack and the Beanstalk: The Real Story,'' a two-part special on CBS tonight and Tuesday night at 9. Despite its use of Henson puppet wizardry, the updated fairy tale, in which Jack is held accountable for the crimes of his ancestor, is for adults and older children rather than the ''Sesame Street'' set.

title: Sydney
description: Sydney's mild maritime climate, balmy, sun-filled days and more than 70 harbor and ocean beaches are especially alluring to visitors from the Northern Hemisphere this time of year, with the coming of summer Down Under. The harbor is filled with sailboats, and residents often grab a swim before or after work or enjoy a long lunch outdoors.

title: Tours of Britain, In Search of Magic
description: Where can Harry Potter fans go for a glimpse of his magical world? They can see the film adaptation, of course. But some travel companies hope that they will also want to visit the British Isles, the setting for the children's book series and the movie.

title: The View From/Easton; Lights, Tinsel, Action: It's Tree-Picking Time
description: FOR all but a handful of weeks out of the year, Easton is a destination only for those 7,272 residents who call it home.

title: Hoping a New Season Will Dawn
description: DECEMBERS in this casino town have generally been slow. Buses come half-filled; slots stay unjingling; showrooms, where the headliners perform, are vast echo chambers.

title: Political Briefing; Montana's Baucus Faces Challengers
description: Speaking of vulnerable senators. . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZBART, EDNA
description: SCHWARZBART-Edna. 92, of Anaheim Hills, CA, formerly of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Elias, loving mother of Ellen McKoy, passed away December 1, 2001. She is survived by her adoring family, including her son-in-law Keith, grandsons Chris and Keith Jr., and great-grandson Conner. Private memorial service. Donations may be made to California Hospice Foundation, 1510 J Street, No. 135, Sacramento, CA 95814.

title: Boyish Wonder
description: On a white-sky November day, Wes Anderson is lounging in a darkened studio in the Brill Building, formerly the silvery hub of Tin Pan Alley. His slight six-foot frame, all 155 pounds of it, is decked out in undersize beige corduroys and an undersize beige shirt; his auburn hair, once unruly, has settled into a subtle and rather stylish alliance of tamed cowlicks. ''We're doing a weird little recording session,'' he quietly explains. ''Yesterday, our editor was whistling along with the soundtrack, and I thought, Wait -- that's good!''

title: Life Without Father
description: On Sept. 11 my younger brother, John McErlean, was murdered in the attack on the World Trade Center. I read Lisa Belkin's article with sadness and empathy. The Sheas were friends of my brother and his family. And like the Sheas, we have always considered ourselves lucky.

title: 'Broadway, The Golden Years'
description: When Agnes de Mille arrived with Oklahoma! in 1943, she changed the nature of the American musical. Up until then, dance had played a generally peripheral or subordinate role. But de Mille put it at the dramatic center of musical comedy, while integrating it smoothly with the development of the story. She gave the choreographer an importance previously reserved for stars, directors, and great-name producers; and in doing so she prepared for the arrival of the choreographer-director, or "superdirector," whose name appeared in lights on theater marquees above the other credits (it would be "Bob Fosse's Chicago " and "Michael Bennett's A Chorus Line "). The choreographer-directors did much of the best and most innovative work on Broadway in the decades that followed; and de Mille, who contributed to the excitement, was there at the beginning to set it all in motion.

title: Good Film Hunting, One Shot at a Time
description: THE idea, on paper, sounds like the kind of reality show only Hollywood insiders would love: choose a script from thousands of submissions, give the writer a guarantee that a studio will make his movie, and then turn him loose, wide-eyed and overwhelmed, to direct it.

title: Unbeaten Lehigh Rallies To End Hofstra's Season
description: The day began with Hofstra quarterback Rocky Butler returning to the area where he grew up to try to add to his legend and Lehigh quarterback Brant Hall seeking to finish his career without a loss at home. But it was the Lehigh backup quarterback Luke Ciannello who rallied Lehigh from a 14-point deficit to a 27-24 overtime victory over Hofstra this afternoon in the first round of the Division I-AA playoffs.

title: Bradley James Fetchet: Turning the Focus to Others
description: To his family and friends, Bradley James Fetchet always seemed an odd fit for the dog-eat- dog world of Wall Street that became his life as an equity trader for Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Quiet and reserved, Mr. Fetchet, 24, loathed being the center of attention, even on occasions when he deserved it. On his birthday, he preferred that the day go unnoticed, forbidding his mother from planning even the smallest celebration.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,533 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Q & A
description: Jamming in Paris

title: Mixers, Civics Lessons and Homework for Council's Freshmen
description: In a season when most students are finishing their terms and anticipating a well-earned winter break, a special group of rookies is in the midst of its own freshmen orientation. It could be called City Council 101: training for the incoming class of new members, nearly all of whom, despite having some governmental or legislative experience, have never held this particular office.

title: Troupers' Paradise
A New Count of the Dead, But Little Sense of Relief
description: The number tumbles. First 6,700, then 5,000. Down, down, down, 4,500, 4,000, now 3,300.

title: A History of Photography From the Eyes of Women
description: AT the Princeton University Art Museum, ''Camera Women'' is a concise survey of photographs taken by women from photography's inception through the present day. Everything about the show is brief and to the point, including the catalog, which has only three short essays. But viewers will linger over some of these images.

title: What to Build
description: It strikes me that if the U. S. Capitol or the White House had been hit by terrorists and burned to the ground, there would be no question about whether or what to rebuild. There would be no deliberation about turning Capitol Hill into a memorial to the fallen or designing ''something new'' for the site where the White House once stood.

title: Robin Michaelson, David Mack
description: Robin Lynn Michaelson, a daughter of Joyce Robbins Michaelson of Montclair, N.J., and the late William G. Michaelson, was married last evening to David John Rawson Mack, the son of Vanessa and John Mack of Sydney, Australia. The Rev. Dr. Allen R. Newman, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Carlyle Hotel in New York.

title: Shortage of Juvenile Vaccines Worries Doctors and Officials
description: Federal and state officials and doctors across the country are expressing alarm at shortages, delays and uncertainty in the production and supply of major childhood vaccines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLEDANO, JOSEPH L.
description: TOLEDANO-Joseph L. On November 30th, 2001. Passed away at home in Paris, France. Beloved husband of the late Estrella. Devoted father of Edward (Karla) and Sylviane Levy (Gerard). Cherished grandfather, great-grandfather, brother and uncle. He will be lovingly remembered.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the end of the cultural fascination for the dot-com revolution referred incorrectly to ''Startup.com,'' a documentary film on the rise and fall of a Silicon Alley company. It was directed by Jehane Noujaim and Chris Hegedus, not Sebastian Nokes. Mr. Nokes is the author of a similarly titled book, ''Startup.Com,'' whose subtitle is ''Everything You Need to Know About Starting Up an Internet Company.'' The book and film are unrelated.

title: Adventures in Baby-Sitting
description: In the dozen weeks since Sept. 11, the national mood has morphed so many different times -- shock, sadness, jittery determination, fear, redoubled determination, redoubled fear, fatigue, re-redoubled fear, glee -- that its movements have become impossible to predict. Go to bed during an outbreak of national giddiness and you might wake up in the midst of a dreadful new panic. But as the military victories began to pile up and the Taliban continued to defect, surrender, scatter and die, the mood on the home front seemed, for the first time in ages, placid. Even, dare I say it, normal. Almost, I worried, complacent: given that this nightmare began with an astoundingly cinematic image, I couldn't help thinking of the third-act war and horror movie clich: ''It's quiet out there -- too quiet.'' It wasn't just the lack of hijackings, or the slowdown in new outbreaks, or the virtual disappearance of the word ''weaponize'' in the public discourse, which for a while there in October looked to replace ''monetize'' as the 21st century's voguish verbed noun. It was that the government, for at least a moment, began to ease back on the ''credible threat'' alarms.

title: Energy Rivals; A Price to Pay For Opportunity
description: Enron's undoing may turn out to be both a blessing and a curse for rival energy traders. While more than a dozen energy traders have hundreds of millions of dollars of outstanding claims against Enron, Enron's ruin is likely to mean new profits for rivals that could make Enron's i.o.u.'s look like pocket change, analysts and some executives said.

title: What to Build
description: Great art is art that inspires the imagination. And the World Trade Center did inspire the imagination: the quixotic daring of Philippe Petit's tightrope walk, George Willig's climb and Owen Quinn's parachute jump. And the perverted evil of the terrorists. What other buildings have inspired such disparate ideas?

title: Paul Friedman: A Problem-Solver
description: Paul Friedman, a shy, kind man with a surging mind, was always a problem-solver. Of the five Friedman siblings, he was the listener, the untangler of life's knots. He would pose a zillion questions, leading his siblings toward their own solutions. Professionally, he played a similar role. With degrees in psychology, engineering and business, he became a management consultant for Emergence Consulting in Lincoln, Mass.

title: After a Mistake, a Funeral Under the Right Name
description: Firefighter Christopher Alexander Santora, 23, was laid to rest for the second time yesterday.

title: Cherchez 'La Femme'
description: To the Editor:

title: Union County's Past
description: Memories of people and places past of Union County take pride of place in an eclectic show at the Arts Guild of Rahway by the seven-member New Art Group. Artists in the show include Frances Heinrichs, who uses mixed-media to depict scenes of upheaval and despair in Elizabeth, and Thom Lynch, who has painted nostalgic acrylic renderings of defunct teenage hangouts.

title: Patriot Bond Sales To Begin This Month
description: The Treasury will begin selling Patriot Bonds this month, but unlike the war bonds of the 1940's, these savings bonds will not generate revenue designated for a particular national purpose.

title: U.S. PLANES POUND TALIBAN POSITIONS AROUND KANDAHAR
description: With relentless bombing and the checkmate positioning of their military forces around Kandahar, the United States military and allied Afghan forces continued today to send the Taliban's besieged defenders the message that surrender was the only way out of an otherwise hopeless plight.

title: A Carnivore's Best Friend
description: SEVERAL times during my 10 years as a waiter at Peter Luger Steak House in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Sol Forman, the restaurant's longtime owner, urged me to try his world-famous porterhouse.

title: In Paterson, an Unusual Alliance
description: THE Great Falls of the Passaic have always signified Paterson's history, the place where Alexander Hamilton envisioned the country's first planned industrial city.

title: Ashcroft and Leahy Battling Over Greater Police Powers
description: The issue of civil liberties has created a classic balance-of-power struggle between Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Attorney General John Ashcroft, a onetime colleague now leading the administration's domestic war on terrorism.

title: Political Briefing; Abortion Foes Cite Terror Attacks in Ad
description: The jury is still out on efforts to get political mileage out of the war on terror. Hardly any attempt goes unnoticed, so delicate is the subject. But beyond that, it is hard to get a good reading at this point on what the public views as acceptable and what it rejects as exploitation.

title: . . . and in Flushing, Turning Clamminess Into a Virtue
description: Hydrologically speaking, the Queens Botanical Garden is a drainage ditch. It is lower than its surroundings, so that much of the local rainwater pools there. Most of its 39 acres consist of landfill dumped on a creek, which pocks the ground with soggy sinkholes.

title: No Velvet Ropes Here
description: SADLY, one of the most exotic tourist attractions in Westchester is closed for the season. Kykuit, the Rockefeller estate that has thrown wide its doors to about 350,000 visitors during the past seven years, doesn't open again until April.

title: 'The Officers' Ward'
description: Iknew nothing of the Great War. I knew nothing of the muddy trenches, the dampness that seeps into the bones, the big black rats in their winter fur dodging among the mounds of refuse, the stench  a mixture of cheap tobacco and half-buried excrement  and over everything, the unvaried metal-grey sky that unleashes a torrent of rain at regular intervals, as if God can never refrain from hounding the ordinary soldier.

title: Michael A. Uliano: Pleasures of Shore and Stage
description: Michael A. Uliano, a broker for Cantor Fitzgerald, never changed much from the grinning 10- year-old boy who was profiled in 1969 by his Canton, Mass., paper for snagging a 20-pound bass off Cape Cod. That he had just recovered from a broken wrist only added to his reputation for athleticism.

title: Eric Thorpe: Ball Carrier on Wall Street
description: The booming voice, competitiveness and self-assurance that helped Eric Thorpe become the star quarterback of his undefeated high school football team in Wilbraham, Mass., served him well on Wall Street. Mr. Thorpe, 35, known as Rick, was one of the top salesmen at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.

title: Let Us Count The Ways
description: I have been impressed with many of your special issues, but there's something about this one that stands out. Paul Auster's essay on riding the subway will be the basis of a descriptive-language writing exercise for my seventh graders. Thanks for helping me remember why I love living in this the greatest of cities.

title: Dine Out (of Manhattan)
description: As has become increasingly clear in recent years, great dining in New York City isn't limited to Manhattan. The Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island all offer their share of interesting restaurants. Here are eight:

title: And the Winner Is: Patchogue!
description: SWANLIKE young women in glittering gowns floated onto the stage. A man in a tuxedo belted out ''Fly Me to the Moon.'' An audience of hundreds gazed at the spectacle, beaming.

title: Stephanie Despins, Christopher Daly
description: Stephanie Jane Despins, a daughter of Renee J. Despins of Manhattan and Karl A. Despins of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married yesterday to Christopher John Daly, a son of Joan Daly and Dr. John J. Daly of Manhattan. The Rev. Mary F. Grambsch, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Seamen's Church Institute in Manhattan.

title: In Napa, a Celebration Of Food, Wine and Art
description: Napa Valley visitors can now immerse themselves in gastronomy and related subjects at Copia: The American Center for Wine, Food and the Arts, a combination museum, education center and garden that opened two weeks ago in Napa, Calif. Copia, named for the Roman goddess of abundance, occupies 12 1/2 acres on the banks of the Napa River.

title: Sober Yet Sleek, To Match the Times
description: SUSPENDED from invisible wires or wrapped around floating dressmaker forms, Yeohlee Teng's capes and airy sarongs seem poised for flight. ''They are the kind of clothes that would look cool with flat shoes on, made for a quick getaway,'' she said. ''These days everybody knows that they can be evacuated at any moment in time,'' Ms. Teng added, only half in jest, as a wailing siren lent her words an unnerving gravity.

title: With Enron's Fall, Many Dominoes Tremble
description: The Enron Corporation ( news/quote ), despite its origins as a gas pipeline business, was no mere energy company. Its ambition, its passion for innovation and its boundless appetite for risk gave it a far greater reach than that of competitors, even those that control many more power plants or far larger reserves of natural gas.

Take the long view. What will New York be like on Sept. 11, 2011? It's not difficult to imagine a rather wretched future. You need only visit one of those cities -- Jerusalem or Belfast -- that have been fractured by terrorism and religious strife to get a glimpse. Imagine a segregated city, with a kind of Muslim ghetto in an outer borough that non-Muslims can enter only -- if they dare -- with a special endorsement on their ID cards. Imagine security checkpoints at every tunnel and bridge leading into Manhattan, where armed antiterrorist troops check every vehicle for traces of explosives and prohibited toxins.

title: U.S. Diplomat Meets Saudis Over Accounts
description: A senior American diplomat met here today with top Saudi officials, including Crown Prince Abdullah, for talks intended in part to seek further Saudi help in cutting off money to suspected terrorist groups.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 2000. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction and poetry, nonfiction, children's books, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings. The complete reviews of these books may be found at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: If Spector Has His Way, Will Court Be Out of Order?
description: Is New Jersey about to lose one of its four seats on the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit? If Senator Arlen Spector, the Pennsylvania Republican, has his way, yes.

title: Kabul Retraces Steps to Life Before Taliban
description: Dr. Nazifa Tabibzada cut into the abdomen of someone named Abdul last week. It was a routine procedure for a reliable surgeon, remarkable only because she had not operated on a man in five years. Under the austere restraints of the Taliban, men and women were not permitted to mingle, even if one was under anesthesia.

title: Peace Brigade On the March
description: If ''Peace on Earth'' -- is likely to be the top-selling holiday-card sentiment of the year, shoppers can easily find gifts to match. At Patricia Field NY, round dangling peace-sign earrings by White Trash are available in two sizes ($340 for the small, $475 for the large).

title: Ten Francs a Dance
description: MEMOIRS OF A COURTESAN IN NINETEENTH-CENTURY PARIS

title: Christine Kaming and Rodrigo Tomas
description: Christine Collins Kaming, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Kaming of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Rodrigo Martin Tomas, the son of Graciela D. Bonetto of Córdoba, Argentina, and the late Oscar Tomas. The Rev. Kevin A. McGrath performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan.

title: MOORESTOWN PROJECTS
description: The Township Council in Moorestown has approved zoning ordinances that would allow Toll Brothers to move forward on two projects, a 660,000-square-foot office park and 122 town houses for older residents. The ordinances will come up for their second reading on Dec. 17, when a public hearing will be held on them. Jill P. Capuzzo

title: Rodin's Universal Themes On Display at Hofstra
description: Many of Auguste Rodin's most famous sculptures, including ''The Thinker,'' ''The Kiss'' and ''The Three Shades,'' originated as parts of the Gates of Hell, a French government commission begun in 1880 but unfinished when Rodin died in 1917, by then the world's most famous sculptor.

title: 2 SUICIDE BOMBERS STRIKE JERUSALEM, KILLING AT LEAST 10
description: In a tightly coordinated assault in the heart of Jerusalem, two Palestinian bombers blew themselves up at each end of a crowded block of a pedestrian mall Saturday night, killing at least 10 other people and wounding about 150 more.

title: Flying to Santo Domingo, Rum in Hand, for Holidays
description: New York's Dominicans may soon have another carrier to ferry them on the immensely popular air route to their homeland. The move will challenge American Airlines, which is now the only commercial airline that flies from Kennedy International Airport to Santo Domingo.

title: Ideas & Trends: Guardians of the Faith; Speaking in the Name of Islam
description: IN Cairo last week, Arab intellectuals held a conference to discuss what they called the Muslim world's most pressing danger in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. The problem? Not how Islam itself has been hijacked by terrorists to justify the attacks, but what they called Islamophobia -- a Western fear of Islam.

title: Yaphet J. Aryee: Taxes and Taxis
description: Yaphet J. Aryee was the person everyone went to for advice. "He was born in Ghana so he was the expert on that," said Ely Yulman, who worked with Mr. Aryee as an auditor with the State Division of Taxation and Finance, on the 86th floor of 2 World Trade Center. "He made his furniture when he got married, so people asked him how to fix the stairs in their house, or how to fix the engine in their car. But first of all, he was the smartest corporate tax auditor in the department. Millions and millions he brought in."

title: Dr. King's Legacy, Exploited by Heirs
description: To the Editor:

title: Ariel Louis Jacobs: Working the Room
description: Watch the salesman work the room. His banter is interrupted because his cellphone rings incessantly, but every comer's gaze is met. The people in this room feel important; they feel at ease. They like this guy. This skill has made him a success.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing last Sunday for a chamber concert last Monday at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center misspelled two performers' given names. They were Matitiahu Braun, not Matitiahi, and Melanie Braun, not Belanie.

title: Before 'Novocaine'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIRCIELLO, GINO A.
description: CIRCIELLO-Gino A. Died at home on November 29, 2001. He was creator, founder and owner since 1945 of Gino's Restaurant with Guy Avventuriero and Emilio Torre, 780 Lexington Avenue, New York City until his retirement. Beloved husband of Nini Girdano Circiello. Beloved brother of Yolanda Gentile, Raffaella Musumeci and Augusto Circiello and beloved uncle. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, December 2, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10 AM at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76th Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to Sloan-Kettering Hospital or a charity of your choice.

title: The Next Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, SADIE
description: BAUM-Sadie. Loving wife of the late Joseph Baum. Beloved mother of Sy (Elaine), Albert (Barbara) and Robert (Phyllis). Dear sister of Abe Nagel and Min Jaroslow. Darling grandmother, greatgrandmother and aunt. Services today at 10:30 AM, at ''Parkside Chapels,'' Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills. Interment at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: YOU READ TO ME & I'LL READ TO YOU: 20th-Century Stories to Share. Edited by Janet Schulman. Knopf. $34.95. (Ages 5 and up) A senior editor of children's books has selected 26 stories and excerpts from novels for school-age children with the intention of having them read aloud, at home, by families. The mix is essentially pure gold; every story is someone's most favorite. Some purists may object to the loss of illustrations and form in condensations of picture books.

title: Diplomats Rush to Kabul To Secure an Early Edge
description: The Iranians were the first to arrive. Just a day after Northern Alliance forces swept into Kabul, a small group of Iranian diplomats turned up at their abandoned embassy compound in downtown Kabul.

title: Last Holdouts In Uprising Give Up Fort
description: Wounded, starving and near collapse after a week of relentless bombardment, more than 80 Taliban fighters, the last holdouts in a deadly prison uprising that began last Sunday, emerged from their bunker Friday night and today after Northern Alliance forces flooded their basement refuge.

title: Rivalry Redux As Argentina Blames Brazil For Slowdown
description: With Argentina tottering on the edge of bankruptcy and Brazil fearful of being ''contaminated'' by the economic crisis next door, relations between these former rivals, who have become allies and partners in recent years, have taken a sudden turn for the worse.

title: Michael Seaman: Smile at the Finish Line
description: Swimming was not among the many talents of Michael Seaman. He was a runner, a basketball player, a tennis player  and a gifted father, husband and friend. But a swimmer? Uh, no.

title: Deborah Buren, Marc Rothenberg
description: Deborah Ellen Buren, a daughter of Esther and Ronald Buren of Hazlet, N.J., was married yesterday to Marc Rothenberg, a son of Lee and Nat Rothenberg of Manhattan. Rabbi Amy Ehrlich officiated at the Shackamaxon Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: Twins Should Go
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mets Get Pitcher From Japan
description: When Al Leiter went on the disabled list last April, the Mets were unprepared to fill his spot in the pitching rotation and plunged toward the bottom of the standing. Manager Bobby Valentine identified the need for a reliable spot starter, and yesterday the Mets signed a pitcher very familiar to him.

title: Hope You Can Come!
description: The Justice Department wants to talk terrorism with 5,000 Middle Eastern men, but not in a confrontational way. ''We're being as kind and fair and gentle as we can,'' Attorney General John Aschcroft said on Tuesday.

title: In Chinatown, Demeanors Don't Betray Desperation
description: In her worst weeks, Wai Chun Ng at least had a $50 paycheck. After 40 years of sewing in Chinatown factories, job cuts had reduced Ms. Ng to working as a finisher, earning a penny for every two buttons she cut the thread on. Last month, when Ms. Ng finally lost her job, she turned to the Red Cross to help put food on the table for herself and her retired husband.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for LYNN TURNER; Lessons for Auditors In Enron's Collapse
description: AMONG the many questions raised by the stunning collapse of Enron last week was the role of Arthur Andersen, Enron's auditor. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating, influential lawmakers have called for hearings and a criminal inquiry may be started.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE leading lady (Sarah Jessica Parker) has changed her mind about the bare-breasted scene, unless she's paid an additional $800,000. The leading man (Alec Baldwin), who has an affinity for under-age girls, can't help noticing the local coffee shop owner's daughter (Julia stiles) when she delivers his tuna B.L.T. The screenwriter (Philip Seymour Hoffman), seemingly the only decent human being among them, has to do a complete rewrite, finds love with the local community theater director (Rebecca Pidgeon) and faces a moral crisis during a statutory rape trial. The director (William H. Macy) tries to keep it all straight. David Mamet's STATE AND MAIN (2000) is the story of a Hollywood film crew taking over a small Vermont town, only to find that the town has a mind of its own. Soon the old men in flannel shirts at the coffee shop are reading Variety and talking about per-screen averages. How could this not be satisfying satire? - Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 2:50 a.m. on Starz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, LAWRENCE
description: DIAMOND-Lawrence. Of Parkchester, died peacefully November 30th. Left his loving wife of 64 years, Beatrice, and many adoring nieces and nephews.

title: In Chappaqua, Pulling Together for Title Shot
description: From the embarrassment of a nationally publicized scandal to playing for the Class A state championship, perhaps no high school football team has taken a stranger road than the one that has brought Chappaqua's Horace Greeley squad to its meeting this afternoon with Aquinas-Rochester in Syracuse's Carrier Dome.

title: Blackburn Stops Canadiens
description: Dan Blackburn could have made it easy for the Rangers to send him back to his junior-league team this season. Blackburn, the 18-year-old goaltender, has made it a no-brainer for the Rangers to keep him around instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABBAGH, DONNA L.
description: SABBAGH-Donna L. of Westbury, LI on November 28, 2001, in her 45th year. (Ironworkers Local #

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column on Nov. 11 about a visit to the United States by Murray Smith, energy minister of Alberta, Canada, misstated a government estimate he gave for recoverable crude oil from the province's oil-sands reserves. It was 315 billion barrels, not 22.1 billion.

title: The Core of the Music: Family
description: LONG before record players, radios and other forms of electronic entertainment, families played musical instruments and sang together, making what Pete Seeger has called ''homemade music.''

title: Cardinal Rules
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, HARLIN C.
description: SCHWARTZ-Harlin C. November 2, 1929 to December 7, 1984. Forever in our hearts. The Famil

title: Soaking and Steaming in Japan
description: PUFFS of steam waft around the old woman as she squats naked on the tiles. She takes a cedar bucket and fills it with water, then carefully pours its contents down her knobby back. Slowly she scrubs her body with a long, soapy washcloth. When she's finished, she wrings the cloth, folds it into a square and places it on her head so it won't dirty the water. Only then does she ease herself into the deep, steaming bath.

title: For the National Title, It Will Be Miami Against Somebody
description: Now what? Somebody will have to play top-ranked Miami for the national championship in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 3. But who? It won't be second-ranked Florida. It can't be third-ranked Texas. Perhaps it should not be fourth-ranked Nebraska. Could it be fifth-ranked Oregon, sixth-ranked Tennessee or even seventh-ranked Colorado?

title: In and Out of the Pool, Swimmer Is Growing
description: IT was a year of growing stature for the Ursuline School swimmer Kimi Kelly.

title: Hunting, Gathering, Growing in the 21st Century
description: IFINISHED Gary Paul Nabhan's new book, "Coming Home to Eat: The Pleasures and Politics of Local Foods," at the kitchen table in between making Thanksgiving dinner: basting the pork roast (no turkey this year), chopping parsley (fresh from the garden), baking apples (local Winesaps doused with homemade maple syrup), stirring the risotto, getting out the cheese and wine from France, England and Australia.

title: Tiny Dancers

description: The Bush administration and Congressional negotiators struck a deal to allow long-haul Mexican trucks to enter the United States. Trucks will be inspected every 90 days and licenses of drivers of trucks carrying hazardous cargo will be checked electronically before entering the country. Lizette Alvarez

title: A Pantry Offers Soup and Solace, But There's Never Enough of Either
description: THE big trucks packed with cans of food and bags of grain arrive on Tuesdays at the West Side Campaign Against Hunger food pantry, a warren of basement rooms beneath the soaring white stones of the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, at West End Avenue and 86th Street. Inside, last Tuesday, a dozen volunteers and employees scurried about counting and stocking, knowing that when the shelves were full the next day the lines would wind around the block in the affluent Upper West Side neighborhood.

title: BELT 'EM IN
description: Children under the age of 8 or weighing less than 80 pounds must sit in a child safety or booster seat, under a new law that went into effect yesterday. The legislation, signed into law by Acting Governor Donald T. DiFrancesco in September, also says that children under the age of 18 must wear a seat belt, no matter where they are sitting in a car or truck. Drivers face fines of $10 to $25 for each passenger under 18 who is not properly restrained. Although New Jersey was at the bottom of a national report card earlier this year that ranked all 50 states on their law relating to child passenger safety, the new law will make amends, child safety advocates said. Sarah Rubenstein

Before we start talking about missile-defense-style solutions, let's limit trucks from daytime deliveries and enforce simple parking and moving violations. A car-free Manhattan is a pipe dream, but better traffic flow is well within reach of existing laws and enforcement techniques.

But last week, Mr. Troubh, a lawyer and financial consultant, added Enron to the list. He will be chairman of a new special litigation committee that examines claims in shareholder and related lawsuits against the company, which collapsed last week.

Its ambition, its passion for innovation and its boundless appetite for risk gave it a far greater reach than that of competitors, even those that control many more power plants or far larger reserves of natural gas.

title: ART

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Perth Amboy; A Waterfront City Planning a Comeback
description: THE new waterfront walkway along Sadowski Parkway in Perth Amboy reflects both the city's ambitious revitalization efforts and the challenges left by its industrial past. The esplanade, which has an immaculate red brick sidewalk, acorn-shaped Victorian lights and decorative iron and wood benches, overlooks a breathtaking view of Raritan Bay and Staten Island. In sharp contrast, however, it also overlooks Perth Amboy's battered and badly eroded shoreline to the east and its a sprawl of weathered brick and cinder-block industrial buildings -- some vacant with trash-strewn lots and broken windows -- to the north.

title: A Tough, Cold Night for Filling the Chowder Pot

This may seem like culinary heresy among ''fillet-and-release'' types who drool at the mere thought of bass fillets sizzling away in garlic and butter. But truth be known, on the plate, the striper falls far short of everything from the mighty yellowfin tuna, to the lowly scup.

title: Theater's Quicksilver Truth: All Is Change

Now that the movies and television (even radio) have exploded that ancient monopoly, is the theater the anachronism some think it is? Economically fragile and technologically backward, it hangs on, but how? Does anything but nostalgia and entrenched habit sustain its feeble pulse? Or does it, on the contrary, still serve some unique and vital purpose?

In just the last year, Enron signed billions of dollars' worth of long-term energy management contracts. Under those contracts, Enron generally pledged to provide its customers with electricity and natural gas, maintain generating, heating and cooling equipment, pursue conservation measures and protect against swings in energy prices.

title: Martha Stewart Brings Us All Together
description: MARTHA STEWART'S dazzling brand has been slightly dimmed over the years by critics aghast at her transmogrification of the most routine household chores into acts of domestic theater. Let it never be said, however, that in this she misconstrues the spirit of Christmas. Her Christmas publications, like the 1997 ''Christmas With Martha Stewart Living'' and the ''Martha by Mail'' 2001 holiday catalog, are as overstuffed as stockings with recipes and instructions for making geometric chocolates, professional-looking ornaments, fir-draped fireplaces and glistening banquets of prime rib and Yorkshire pudding served on the best silver. The very over-the-top-ness of Martha's productions testifies to her deep understanding of the holiday. Christmas has always been a time for extremes. That the extreme in her case should be a labor-intensive effort to summon up the ghost of Christmases past supposedly enjoyed by British gentlefolk in homes run by invisible servants amid cheery fires and well-heeled visitors proves mainly that she is a woman with an uncanny ability to capitalize on American dreams.

title: Building a Jazz Career by Working Outside Jazz
description: IT'S become a nasty truism that there's no good way to set up a decent jazz career today. It's not the early 1960's anymore, when a strong performance at the Newport Jazz Festival could engender a cult following or save a career. There are a few good apprenticeships to be had under veteran bandleaders, but the audience -- small, fragmented, fickle -- remains a problem. Except in the rarest cases, there's virtually no balance between a musician's growth and the development of his audience, both in numbers and sophistication. Increasingly, the serious musician goes it alone, burrowing inward as he puts out records on marginal labels or by himself, making a living through teaching and wedding gigs. The larger world rarely feels a ripple.

title: Rosemary Brown, a Friend of Dead Composers, Dies at 85
description: Rosemary Brown, who as a middle-aged widow living in a London suburb in the 1960's said she had been in contact with history's most illustrious composers, offering as evidence hundreds of piano miniatures that she said Beethoven, Bach and others had ''dictated'' to her, died on Nov. 16 in London. title: 'Lift Up Thy Voice'
description: There was nothing outwardly ostentatious about Charleston society. To primp and preen over their wealth, to lord their position over their "lessers," or to condescend to snobberythe province of the newly richwould have never occurred to John Faucheraud Grimke or the other gentlemen sons of South Carolina's great families. Such behavior would have been unseemly, undignified. White Charleston society was instead a world apart, a community of wealth, custom, and privilege built on the English model. Its oldest families, who were descended from the original settlers brought to the Carolinas from Britain in 1669 under the watchful eye of Lord Proprietor Sir Anthony Ashley-Cooper, had become the denizens of a new class of cotton, indigo, and rice wealth. Endowed with such a distinguished pedigree (their ancestors had been sent to the New World by their king, Charles II, himself), they affected what they believed to be the aristocratic manner of their British cousins. Their belief in their way of life, and in their right to live that life as they pleased, formed the central tenet of their faith.

description: Forty-two people were injured yesterday when part of a cooling and ventilation unit exploded in the basement of a downtown office building, officials said.

description: Taiwan's Nationalist Party was routed today in legislative elections on the island, completing a political fall from grace that began when it lost the presidency last year.

description: Lauren Beth Rutkin, a daughter of Gail Rutkin of Fairfield, Conn., and Arnold Rutkin of Milford, Conn., was married last evening to Rabbi Matthew Dennis Gewirtz, a son of Tabitha Gewirtz of Kingston, N.Y., and Dr. Arthur Gewirtz of New York. Rabbi Robert N. Levine performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, where Rabbi Gewirtz is the associate rabbi and Rabbi Levine is the senior rabbi.

title: Our Towns; Losing Dad, and Talking Through the Pain and Anger
description: THERE was a new boy at group Thursday night, so Lisa Protheroe, a counselor at North Shore Child and Family Guidance Center, asked all the children to introduce themselves and explain why they were there. ''I'm Andrew,'' began Andrew Lenoir, 11, the biggest. ''My sister is Courtney, and we lost our father in the World Trade Center attacks.''

title: A City Much Like Hell
description: LONDON

title: Lost and Found
description: As a frequent visitor to New York, I have been moved by your post-Sept. 11 coverage. Colson Whitehead's essay was especially touching.

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; Economic Woes Grow
description: It was a bad week on the economic front. The official arbiters of such things proclaimed that the longest business expansion on record ended in March, ushering in the first recession in a decade, and that the federal budget surplus has likely given way to persistent deficits.

title: Striking New Spaces for Russian Innovators
description: TO a visitor here earlier this year, the increasing commercialization of Moscow theater was noticeably offset by a spirit of theatrical investigation and renewal. And indeed, two groups with ties to Russia's illustrious theatrical past have moved into buildings newly designed for them in the middle of the city, with much of the construction financed by the city. The organizations are the School of Dramatic Arts, led by the director Anatoly Vasiliev, and the Meyerhold Arts Center, under the artistic directorship of Valery Fokin, which moved into the Meyerhold Center.

title: Bringing Out the Family Ties Of New and Old Music
description: PIERRE-LAURENT AIMARD, who offers his long-awaited Carnegie Hall debut recital tomorrow evening, is one of those rare pianists who can make us feel that, yes, there are musicians now whose work is as true, as vital, as individual as the performances we can hear on treasured old recordings. We do not have to live in a world of musical ghosts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, STANLEY
description: AARON-Stanley. Of Boca Raton, FL., and Cliffside Park, NJ died Sunday, November 25 of heart failure. A veteran of World War II, Mr. Aaron was a principal in the advertising firm Franklin Spier, Inc. from which he retired in 1982. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Doris, his children Jeffrey I. Aaron and Jessica Hildreth and his grandchildren Elizabeth, Jonathan, Alyson and Danielle.

title: 'Mary George of Allnorthover'
description: On 28th june 197-, Mary George of Allnorthover was seen to walk on water. It has to be said that the only witness was Tom Hepple, who was mad and had been away from the village for ten years until he turned up that very day, shouting. Mary had always been thought of as a peculiar child, but not one to seek attention. She had neither grace nor mystery and could not have wanted to become Tom Hepples angel, especially not the restoring angel he was looking for.

title: The Latest Casino Game: Luring Celebrities
description: WHEN the blues legend B. B. King finished a show at Foxwoods Resort Casino last year, the casino's vice president of entertainment, Thomas Cantone, began chatting with the musician in his dressing room.

description: David Trimble beat back a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionists today from party hard-liners, who are opposed to his cooperation with rival Roman Catholic politicians while the Irish Republican Army has not destroyed all its arms.

title: Hurricanes Headed To the Rose Bowl
description: Before they held the roses aloft, before they clenched them in their teeth, before they let a perfect 11-0 regular season and a trip to the Bowl Championship Series title game sink in, the Miami Hurricanes took a grateful moment in their locker room today. Larry Coker, a rookie head coach still wet from his water cooler shower, asked his players to acknowledge the Virginia Tech Hokies.

title: At Afghan Base, Marines Dig Foxholes and Spoil for a Fight
description: The days are dry and hot, the nights near freezing. The first few inches of sand are loose, then there is rock. It is here, more than a mile northeast of the main American base in Afghanistan, that Charlie Company has dug foxhole after foxhole into a rough, barren ridge facing in the direction of Kandahar, watching for an enemy who is not likely to come.
