title: Lost and Found
description: Colson Whitehead's essay was sad, gently uplifting and fortifying. I was moved and allowed myself to become emotional for the first time since Sept. 11. Until then, I'd had a hard time admitting personal grief, when so many others had lost so much. I've since shared his article with many friends and with some junior staffers at our firm, who are new to the city, to help explain why New York will continue to be great. It should be included in future collections of the finest writings about the city.

title: Patching Up A Boulevard Of Broken Dreams
description: AROUND 11 on a recent Friday night on the corner of Hollywood Boulevard and Vine Street, two worlds collided. Disney's ''Lion King'' let out from the newly restored Pantages Theater, and a crowd of ticket holders spilled onto the sidewalk, some still singing ''Hakuna Matata,'' the show's hit song.

title: Word for Word/Taboo Heaven; More No-Nos Than You Can Shake A Stick At. (Hey, No Stick-Shaking.)
description: THE Taliban will go down in history for many reasons, but their determination to encode in law their unique vision of an Islamic society will certainly be one.

title: There's Magic in Disney, But Where's the Substance?
description: ''Whistle While You Work and Other Disneyana'' [L.I.@Work, Nov. 4] correctly indicated that people came to the Sheraton on Oct. 26 to learn how the magic of Disney could be transferred to other businesses. The ultimate objective of this training, like any other, is to give people tools to improve their performance. It's up to each participant to take these tools and apply them. If all a participant gets is to be entertained, they have been to a good show.

title: Jennifer Dubinsky, Christopher Applebaum
description: Jennifer Paige Dubinsky, a daughter of Marlene E. Dubinsky and Steven L. Dubinsky of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday evening to Christopher Meir Applebaum, the son of Julia Garza of Los Angeles and Edward Applebaum of Houston. Cantor Kenneth Cohen officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Defenders of Riley Take Shots at His Detractors
description: The self-flagellation used to be enough. After each first-round playoff loss or numbing slump, Pat Riley would take a long drag on his cigarette, exhale, march from his office into a postgame news conference and beat himself up psychologically.

title: Here Come The Tears Again
description: TO sports-minded men now in their mid-40's and beyond, ''Brian's Song'' was a made-for-television revelation, a sentimental classic about the interracial friendship of a dying Chicago Bear, Brian Piccolo, and his star teammate, the transcendent Gale Sayers, that gave male viewers an Oprahesque green light to cry.

title: Sarah Whitsett, Carter Ruml
description: Sarah Louise Whitsett and Christopher Carter Ruml were married yesterday by the Rev. Laura Westby at Norfield Congregational Church in Weston, Conn. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, an Episcopal priest, also participated in the ceremony.

title: The Prey Of Demons, He Wrote Like An Angel
description: IN 1972 Miguel Piero was a 25-year-old Puerto Rican-born New Yorker serving a jail sentence for second-degree robbery. Two years later, he was catapulted to literary fame with the production of his first play, ''Short Eyes,'' a graphic portrayal of life, love and death among prison inmates. It won the New York Drama Critics Circle Award and was subsequently made into a film. A poet as well as a playwright, Piero helped create the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in an East Village storefront. His influence as a pioneering voice for Latino artistic expression ran parallel to his unrepentant relish for narcotics, impulsive crime, transgressive sex and other forms of bad behavior. By 1988 he was dead, of cirrhosis of the liver.

description: President Jacques Chirac of France swept into this port city for an eight-hour visit today, the first time a French president had been to Algeria in more than 12 years.

title: Food, Not 'Tude
description: Finally, one of the hippest parts of town has a restaurant worth flocking to for its menu rather than for its set design or the latest shade of black on its customers. And not just because of its novelty -- there are other Moroccan restaurants in New York -- but because of the imagination and finesse in its execution. In addition to serving the best food in the nabe and the best Moroccan in the city, Zitoune, which opened at an untimely moment following Sept. 11, is a delicious respite from the clatter and carefully coifed baldheadedness of most recent culinary arrivals in the area.

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: I read with great interest Joseph Lelyveld's article (Oct. 28). Clearly, the governments and cultures of these countries support the use of civilians as what are essentially covert military agents. Indeed, the mother profiled in the article served as a recruiting officer and was compensated for her job with a new apartment.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Douglas Stone: Perfect Business Partner
description: To know Douglas Stone was to know his distinctive brand of humor. "Cynical and dry" his son Zachary called it. "When he got going, everyone would be in tears." His business partner, Tad Parker, recalled the day that Mr. Stone, after dealing with some prickly personnel issue, sat down, looked up at the ceiling and stretched his arms out. "Can you feel the love?" he said, adding: "Human resources isn't my forte. Let's go have a toddy."

title: Laurence Michael Polatsch: No Date, but a Good Story
description: Laurence Michael Polatsch, an equities trader at Cantor Fitzgerald, hardly lacked for chutzpah, and may just have raised the meaning of the word to a new level. He was a free spirit who was able to talk his way into companies' holiday parties at Manhattan hotels year after year.

title: Like Canaries in a Mine, These Oysters Will Test the Waters
description: In recent decades, the marsh grass in Jamaica Bay has dwindled, a shift that threatens to erode the tiny islands that dot the bay and disrupt its delicate ecosystem.

title: What to Build
description: While political leaders go to ground zero every other day, the rest of us are wandering around in a daze. New Yorkers -- and all Americans -- are filled with a grief that needs a place to express itself. A temporary World Trade Center memorial should be erected in the Sheep Meadow in Central Park as soon as possible.

title: Carol Demitz: Made Happy by Motherhood
description: When Carol Demitz got home from Fiduciary Trust, where she was the chief corporate lawyer, she did not reach for a martini. She went directly to play with Annie, her 4-year-old. "I could tell what room the girls were in by the squealing and laughter," said Fred Brewer, her husband. "Carol would be playing hide-and-seek. Carol was thin and could squeeze herself into the most amazing little cubbyholes. You could hear Annie squealing when she found her."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAVEY, AMBROSE S. III
description: HAVEY-Ambrose S. III of Lakewood Ranch, FL. Died November 29, 2001. Former President of Havey Funeral Homes Inc., Yonkers, NY. Husband of Agnes S., father of Barbara of Sarasota, FL and Rev. A. Stewart IV of Lawrenceville, GA. Sister of Jean H. Seward; brother of Perry; 2 grandchildren, Elizabeth and Peter. A memorial will be held at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to The Kidney Foundation.

title: Gary Nicklaus in Position to Keep Card
description: Wearing sunglasses and trying to stay calm, Jack Nicklaus watched his son Gary compete today in the grueling PGA Tour qualifying tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, BLANCHE KASSIN
description: KATZ-Blanche Kassin. On Wednesday, November 21, suddenly at home in Brooklyn at age 93. Adored wife of the late Dr. Alexander A. Katz, mother of Vera Pavone of Brooklyn, Laura Strowe of Ann Arbor, MI and the late Paul Katz, grandmother of Chris and Joey Pavone and Anna Strowe. Hunter College, high school English teacher. She will be remembered for her wide-ranging interests, prodigious memory, political acumen, literary knowledge, and her ceaseless efforts to bring about world peace and social justice. A memorial gathering will be held on Saturday afternoon January 5th from 2:00 to 5:00 PM at Vera's home.

title: The Neediest Cases; Learning to Read to a 2-Year-Old Son, Dot by Dot
description: Maria Saverino moved her hands slowly across a cardboard page, her fingers gently gliding over the raised dots of Braille. Word by word, she read ''The Very Busy Spider'' to her 2 1/2-year-old son Luis. ''Early one morning the wind blew a spider across the field,'' she read. ''A thin silky thread trailed from her body.'' Then she paused and asked her son, ''Luis, where's the spider?''

title: United Nations

title: William & Mary? Not if She's His Student
description: When GQ published an essay by a former instructor last year portraying the College of William and Mary as a ''moral mosh pit'' of sexually overcharged coeds he was helpless to resist, a chorus of administrators, faculty members and students discredited the account as sheer fantasy.

title: Justice Deformed; War and the Constitution
description: The inconvenient thing about the American system of justice is that we are usually challenged to protect it at the most inopportune moments. Right now the country wants very much to be supportive of the war on terrorism, and is finding it hard to summon up much outrage over military tribunals, secret detentions or the possible mistreatment of immigrants from the Mideast. There is a strong temptation not to notice. That makes it even more important to speak up.

title: Robert Treuhaft, 89, Lawyer Who Inspired Funeral Expos

Retired CEO and President of GreerWoodycrest Children's Services, Millbrook, NY. World War II veteran, ex-POW. Survived by wife Naida, son Craig W. of Sarasota, FL, daughter Sheila N. Jackson of New Braunfels, TX, and three grandchildren. Career devoted to work on behalf of children; loved and admired by all who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARWOOD, HARRY
description: HARWOOD-Harry. On November 28, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Alice. Loving father of Pamela and Leslie. Devoted brother of Maurice, Norma and Hilda. How can you be sure the Arab passengers were the hijackers? Won't you be embarrassed if in a couple of years it turns out that the hijackers were really from Colombia?''

One would take him to Greece to study Byzantine art and fulfill a childhood dream of learning to make mosaics. The other was a prestigious Max Beckmann Memorial Scholarship at the Brooklyn Museum School of Art. Brooklyn won.

title: A Time That Is Still Hitting Home Today
description: READERS of The Waterbury Republican were assured 60 years ago this morning by a headline: ''Navy Ready in Pacific, Atlantic Oceans.'' Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, had informed President Roosevelt that his navy was ''ready for any emergency. We are able to handle all possible threats in both oceans.''

title: Women's Crusade
description: In the last few days we have seen something that three months ago we probably didn't expect to see for years, if ever, which is pictures of the faces of Afghan women. They have been beautiful and moving and, at least to me, an unequivocal good thing. At the same time, we have to recognize that without the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the United States would have been extremely unlikely to go to war for the sake of Afghan women, and for our leaders to say or imply otherwise is to ignore the history of the last five years. I used to regularly receive a certain petition by e-mail that described the horrific lives forced especially upon educated Afghan women. It had a hopeless air of institutionalized cruelty, and I always thought of those women as ones who could not be saved, at least by me. And there was no sign that anyone in our government was paying the least attention. And now our administration is taking the credit for saving them.

title: Ringing Everywhere But the Cash Register
description: STROLLING down a city street, you may find it hard to believe that demand for cellphones is slowing. But the eyes can deceive, because sales, which had been growing at an annual rate of 25 percent for years, have fallen in 2001.

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; U.S. Sends Envoy to Israel
description: A surge of violence greeted the Bush administration's new envoy to the Middle East, Anthony C. Zinni, who is trying to arrange a cease-fire after 14 months of Israeli-Palestinian fighting. On a helicopter tour with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, he flew over the town of Afula minutes after a shooting spree there by Palestinians killed two Israelis. After a suicide bomber in a bus killed three more, General Zinni, who retired from the Marines, accused Palestinian militants of trying to thwart his mission. Joel Greenberg

title: Harry Ramos: A Quest for Green Eyes
description: Migdalia Ramos remembers that she had just broken up with her boyfriend on her 18th birthday and was too despondent to dance. All evening, men asked her, and all evening she said no. Finally, the girlfriends trying to cheer her up told her, "If you don't dance with the next person who asks you, we're going to embarrass you."

title: It's All in the Seams
description: Zac Posen, -- whose first collection will be available at Henri Bendel on Dec. 14, is a devotee of Madeleine Vionnet, the 1920's French designer whose bias-draped clothes clung to a woman's body and fell fluidly, almost weightlessly, the fabric moving as she moved. From 1996 to 1998, when Mr. Posen was an intern at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he would put on white gloves and lie on the floor under Vionnet's garments as they hung on mannequins. With his gloved fingers, Mr. Posen said, he would ''follow the seams, from the bodice to the hem.''

description: LAWRENCE-Bruce. We mourn the passing of our beloved friend. A man of warmth, understanding, intelligence and true love. Bruce, you will live in our hearts forever. Joyce and Richard

title: Tourism in Asia Shifts Ground
description: THE largely Hindu island of Bali is advertising itself in capital letters, shrinking into fine print the name of the world's largest Muslim country, Indonesia. In Malaysia, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad ordered a police escort for a car rally in November by 200 Rolls-Royce enthusiasts from Britain in an effort to combat the perception that the country was unsafe. At Thai beach resorts like Phuket, where American, European and Japanese bookings are down by as much as 50 percent, hotels are slashing rates to get some cash for their perishable commodity: rooms.

title: Sprewell Slumping at Free-Throw Line
description: It started Nov. 6 in Minnesota. Latrell Sprewell, an 84 percent foul shooter at the time, missed his first four free throws and wound up 4 for 10 from the line. Sprewell said afterward that he was not worried about the performance, that he would shake it off and move on.

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; Caught
description: After 45-day nationwide manhunt, Robert A. Durst, 58, the scion of a Manhattan real estate family worth more than $2 billion, is a fugitive no more. Mr. Durst had fled Texas, where he faced charges of of beheading a 71-year-old man, after paying a $300,000 bond set by a judge who had no idea of his wealth. He was arrested in Pennsylvania after a supermarket clerk saw him take a Band-Aid and a $5.99 chicken salad sandwich. Investigators in New York are also anxious to question him about the disappearance of his first wife 19 years ago.

title: Art, a Healer, Draws Out the Artist in the Afflicted
description: CHARLES JENULEVICH has begun a new painting. Guiding his wheelchair up to a table, he bends over a bare white canvas and lays down a wedge of color with his left hand. His right arm hangs uselessly in a sling, a result of a stroke that paralyzed his right side and put a brake on his words.

title: A Leading Lower Manhattan Music Shop Is Back, and So Is the Volume
description: Contrary to the general impression, not all stores in Lower Manhattan are crippled, at least not when your customer base includes electronics geeks and the mayor of New York.

title: Introduction
description: The response to the special issue ''Beginnings'' was a virtual love letter to our city. Colson Whitehead's essay on his own private New York was singled out by readers for evoking particular memories. Others offered ideas -- some romantic, some realistic -- on what and how to rebuild.

title: A Noteworthy Collection
description: This collection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 2001 Summer Reading issue.

title: Letters: The Skyline
description: THE SKYLINE

title: The Ecstasy, and Agony, Linking Dance and Sport
description: ''Here . . . Now,'' a new ballet by Judith Jamison, the artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is a tribute to Florence Griffith Joyner, the triple gold medalist at the 1988 Summer Olympics who revolutionized women's sprinting. FloJo, as she was called, was known for her record-setting speed and her elaborately painted, six-inch fingernails and one-legged spandex bodysuits. She died of suffocation related to an epileptic seizure in 1998 at the age of 38. The new work was commissioned by the 2002 Olympic Arts Festival and will be presented at the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City in February. It will have its premiere on Friday as part of the Ailey company's current season at City Center in Manhattan.

title: Small, Stunned
description: VINCENT AU'S mother says that God messes with her son. Twice he has faced death. Twice he has lived. He has given both those lives to his work.

title: John J. Ryan Jr.: A Born Equity Trader
description: For John J. Ryan Jr., going to work on Wall Street was a natural: his father, John Sr., had been an equity trader. So, in due course, was his younger brother Patrick. "It was in the blood," said Patrick Ryan, who works for J. P. Morgan. `'We all have the personality where we get on with people, which you need. That and a sense of humor. And I guess we all like the energy you get on Wall Street."

title: A Culture of Lying
description: To the Editor:

title: Race Is in South Dakota But Interest Is National
description: On the surface, next year's race in South Dakota for the United States Senate appears clear-cut enough -- the incumbent, Tim Johnson, a mainline Democrat, faces a strong challenge from the state's sole House member, John Thune, a solidly conservative Republican.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ROBERT D.
description: NEWMAN-Robert D. Of San Diego, CA on November 29, 2001, age 91. Bob was the son of Dr. Serenus L. and Agusta Newman, and had a sister and three brothers. A 1930 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, he served in World War II as a U.S. Army Captain in the 66th Infantry Division. Bob's career as a manufacturer and sales executive spanned many years. He was the husband of Bernice for 60 years, father of Merry Newman of Manhattan and Robert Jr. of Culver City, CA, grandfather of Daniel and Gregory, and father-in-law of Dr. Sarah Carpenter and Jim Siegel. Bob's family and friends recall his integrity; his commitment; his unflinching courage in the face of pain and adversity; his high standards and fairness as a coach of sports for both girls and boys; his lifelong intellectual curiosity; his sense of humor; love of golf and opera; and his skill at Chinese cooking.

title: After a Quake, A Lost Horizon Is Rebuilt
description: ON Sept. 14, I bought an airplane ticket for a week in Shangri-La, a purchase that seemed like an excellent idea, given the state of things: I was stranded in Hong Kong. There were no flights leaving for the United States, and I didn't know when there would be.

title: After Pierce Finds Shot, Celtics Overtake Nets
description: While the Nets were skipping to a 14-point halftime lead today, the Celtics' Paul Pierce was mired in a frantic nightmare, missing 15 of 16 shots in every ugly way.

title: INVESTING WITH/John J. McCabe And Mark F. Trautman; M.S.B. Fund
description: FORECASTING what consumers, businesses and investors will do during normal times is as difficult as trying to put a pair of pants on an elephant, says John J. McCabe co-manager of the $58 million M.S.B. Fund.

description: Chill winds bring with them thoughts of Caribbean vacations. Here are a few other incentives:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELLMAN, ARTHUR C.
description: KELLMAN-Arthur C. It is a year since our local paper told about the tremendous contributions you made to our community as a civic and religious leader and Judge. Sadly, New Yorkers did not have an opportunity to know what a remarkable life had passed. You have left a lonely place, day and night, in the lives of your loving family. Beth, Donald, Hope, Nancy, Josephine, Spouses and Grandchildren

title: Iraq Accepts Oil-for-Food Deal but Rejects Trade Restrictions
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 1 (Reuters)  Iraq accepted an extension today of its "oil for food" deal with the United Nations but rejected a new list of items that would be reviewed by the Security Council members and would have to be approved separately before shipment to Iraq.

title: GIFTS TO RESCUERS DIVIDE SURVIVORS
description: One firehouse has collected $2 million in donations. Another received $225,000 out of the blue from a small company in Texas. In a single day, members of a family in Park Slope, Brooklyn, collected so much for their local rescue squad that they stowed garbage bags of cash in their shower stall for temporary safekeeping.

title: Genevieve Wilkinson, Andrew Priest
description: Genevieve Elaine Wilkinson, a daughter of Minette and Donald M. Wilkinson Jr. of Laurel Hollow, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Jonathan Priest, the son of Celia and Geoffrey Priest of Gatley, England. The Rev. Bill Robinson performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan.

title: For Russians, a Process of Constant Rediscovery
description: ON a bright Sunday morning earlier this year, four prominent representatives of Russian theater, all in their 50's, met in a large high-ceilinged room filled with natural light a few blocks from Red Square.

title: High School on a College Campus
description: HAZEL PARNELL is hoping that her 14-year-old daughter will be one of the lucky ones. A select group of ninth graders from Irvington, Harrison and Woodlands High Schools will be taking their classes on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase starting Jan. 28.

title: Habitats/Queens; From Manhattan's W. 50's To Forest Hills's 68th Ave.
description: SOME people find looking for new apartments so stressful they eagerly and perhaps a bit blindly fall in love with one of the first places they see.

title: The Public's Stake in a Cultural Crossroads
description: FOR a place whose stones are stained with the tomato traces of so many critics -- critics of architecture, urbanism, acoustics -- Lincoln Center has inspired a good deal of affection. Take this husband and wife (please): growing up in the suburbs, one of us made the pilgrimage with high school friends to receive the dual sacrament of high culture: Mozart on one side of Broadway, asparagus crepes on the other. One soft spring night years later, we had our first kiss by the Henry Moore reflecting pool. Our 5-year-old daughter has grown up at Lincoln Center, careering around the fountain by day (the white paving is dry land; the black, water -- don't fall in!), dancing to swing and merengue on the plaza by night and sleeping through third acts in many of its hallowed halls.

title: Hunting, Gathering, Growing in the 21st Century
description: I FINISHED Gary Paul Nabhan's new book, ''Coming Home to Eat: The Pleasures and Politics of Local Foods,'' at the kitchen table in between making Thanksgiving dinner: basting the pork roast (no turkey this year), chopping parsley (fresh from the garden), baking apples (local Winesaps doused with homemade maple syrup), stirring the risotto, getting out the cheese and wine from France, England and Australia.

title: WEST DEPTFORD SUBPOENA
description: The New Jersey Division of Criminal Justice has subpoenaed thousands of records and documents from West Deptford Township relating to work done for the township by JCA Associates, a Moorestown engineering company, since 1995. The subpoena included records relating to the River Winds redevelopment project on 1,100 acres along the Delaware River in Gloucester County. Gerald A. White, the township administrator, was ordered to supply the documents to a state grand jury that is scheduled to be convened on Dec. 11. Sarah Rubenstein

title: 'PROM MOM' RELEASED
description: Melissa Drexler, who was convicted of strangling her newborn baby boy at her high school prom in 1997, was released from state prison last week after serving three years and one month of a 15-year sentence. Ms. Drexler, an 18-year-old senior at Lacey Township High School in Forked River in 1997, had pleaded guilty to aggravated manslaughter. She was accused of killing her baby during the prom at an Aberdeen Township catering hall and leaving his body in a bathroom trash can. She then returned to the dance floor. Karen DeMasters

description: FACING a dire state economic forecast and increased security costs related to the threat of terrorism, Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano has proposed a budget for 2002 that would increase the property tax levy by 9.5 percent, the largest county tax increase in 12 years.

title: Scott Bart: Start of a Marriage
description: Scott Bart and Elizabeth Cappell conducted their courtship in a 96th-floor office at 1 World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEFLER, GEORGE W.
description: HOEFLER-George W. November 21, 2001. Beloved husband and best friend of Ethel Bonan. Respected lawyer in the Supreme Courts of the State of New York for over fifty years. Member of the Trial Lawyers Association of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Served overseas for the duration of the European invasion and awarded the Bronze Star for valor. Memorial contributions may be made to the Community Foundation of Sarasota County/Hoefler Fund, P.O. Box 49587, Sarasota, FL 34230-6587.

title: Psychiatric Miracle Puts Patient in Denial
description: I STARTED seeing a psychiatrist about a year ago to discuss the lingering mysteries of an affair gone wrong.

title: New Orleans Museum Recalls Pearl Harbor
description: Re-enactments of an amphibious assault and a battle between American and Japanese warplanes are among the events marking the opening of a permanent exhibit on the war in the Pacific at the National D-Day Museum in New Orleans. The events span three days starting Friday, the 60th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: Ask No Favors, Make No Excuses
description: I WAS 16 when my father, who worked for and later became chairman of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, got me a job at its plywood mill in Corvallis, an hour and a half from my home outside Portland.

title: Farmer Brown
description: ARTHUR R. BROWN JR. was known as ''Cow Brown'' in high school because of the whiff of manure that followed him to school from his family's 100-acre dairy farm in southern Massachusetts.

title: Oedipal Loop de Loop
description: So will the president focus more on Wall Street's lipstick index or Teddy Roosevelt's big-stick index?

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; Child Pornography Crackdown
description: A British-led police action uncovered an international network of Internet users distributing child pornography and led to scores of arrests across 19 countries of people whom Detective Superintendent Peter Spindler identified as an alarming new criminal class. ''This is a much younger, technically proficient group quite happy with using IT,'' he said, meaning information technology, ''and getting access in their own homes to material which would have been almost impossible in the past.'' Warren Hoge

title: Robert T. Jordan: Abstract and Focused
description: Robert T. Jordan had a laugh that friends said was a little louder and lasted a little longer than anyone else's. Behind that laugh was a 34-year- old man who by turns was kind and caring, imaginative and spontaneous, yet determined and focused.

title: That Old Fall Magic
description: It's the magical season of autumn in New York. The city parks are resplendent in fall colors, and shoppers are beginning to crowd Fifth Avenue. A man in a paprika-color Harris tweed suit captures the spirit. A few women in cloche hats echo the silhouette of the 1920's. Knitted coats and dresses are accessorized with camel-colored belts and scarves. Trousers as narrow as drainpipes are the newest width. The ultimate accessory is a sleek dog.

title: Cheering Port, Cheering Price
description: Late-bottled vintage port -- L.B.V. in Portuguese vintners' shorthand -- offers clues to the pleasures of vintage ports, which are pricier. Buyers will find Taylor Fladgate's hearty '94 L.B.V. and Fonseca's compote-like '95 L.B.V. addictive. Both are antidotes to icy days and are desserts in themselves. Acker Merrall & Condit, 172 West 72nd Street (Broadway), Manhattan, charges $17 for each. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Islanders' Mediocre Play Continues as Osgood Is Replaced Again
description: The Islanders have become ordinary in the past three weeks. They would have sold their souls to be ordinary in recent years, but everything changed in the magical first month of this season, which featured great saves and great escapes.

title: 'The Riddle and the Knight'
description: In the days when gods dwelt in temples, a soldier named Alban was converted to Christianity. For this crime he was hauled before Britain's Roman authorities and ordered to renounce his faith. He refused, was tortured and executed. His body was buried where it fell.

title: A Superhero for Nissan
description: CARLOS GHOSN'S nickname -- Le Cost Killer -- preceded his arrival in Japan in 1999, with the daunting assignment of reviving Nissan. Since then, he has returned the company to profitability, closed plants and slashed debt, and his decisive actions have made him a corporate hero to many Japanese.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINMANN, FLORENCE FUERTH
description: REINMANN - Florence Fuerth. Wife of the late William Reinmann, passed away on November 24, 2001 at the age of 92. Our family mourns the passing of our beloved mother Florence. Mom was a member of Temple Sinai in Forest Hills, Queens. Over a span of 50 years she was employed as a sales associate by a number of department stores including DePinna, Bonwit Teller, and at her last position by Bergdorf Goodman, selling fine men's clothing until her retirement at the age of 80. She is survived by her children, Harriet, Sylvia, and Richard, her grandchildren, Billy, Eileen, David, Daniel, Adam, Josh, and Andy, and her great grandson, Corey. Mom will be missed dearly by all who knew, admired, and loved her. May her memory be a Blessing.

title: Inquiry Includes Possibility of Killer From a U.S. Lab
description: The F.B.I. has expanded its investigation of the deadly anthrax attacks to include the laboratories of the government and its contractors as a possible source of the anthrax itself or the knowledge to make it, scientists and law enforcement officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, RUTH
description: BLOCH-Ruth. On November 27. Beloved wife of the late Max. Loving mother of Susan Loew. Adored ''Oma'' of Michael, Karen, Hans, Damian, Emily & Madeline. She will be sorely missed. Private burial service at Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, November 30.

title: A Multiuse Project Rises East of Seattle
description: ISSAQUAH, Wash.

title: As Golf Did, Tennis Needs to Find an Updated Vision
description: A few weeks ago, at the year-end Sanex WTA Tour Championships in Munich, a potential dream final between two fetchingly different personalities from the United States, Lindsay Davenport and Serena Williams, was ruined when Davenport came up lame and had to concede the match. Shortly thereafter, at the ATP Tour's championships in Sydney, Australia, 20-year-old Lleyton Hewitt, as combative as a badger, became the youngest man to earn the year-end No. 1 ranking while winning the Masters Cup.

title: With Roukema Bowing Out, Conservatives See Opening
description: Bret Schundler's defeat at the hands of James McGreevey does not seem to have discouraged conservatives. To the contrary.

title: Note to Readers
description: Beginning today, Thomas L. Friedman's column will appear Sundays and Wednesdays. Paul Krugman's column will appear Tuesdays and Fridays, as will Nicholas D. Kristof's column, which begins later this month. The schedule for other columnists will remain unchanged.

title: Heeding a 'Be Prepared' Call
description: Forget Hollywood muffin baskets -- and designer orchid boxes. This holiday season the hot gift for corporate clients and employees is the utilitarian emergency survival kit. Manufacturers are reporting a hefty increase in sales as companies from Neutrogena to Pacific Bell join ad agencies, hospitals and movie studios in stocking up.

title: Swiss Were Part of Nazi Economic Lifeline, Historians Find
description: Switzerland actively aided Nazi economic interests during World War II and afterward, according to new studies issued by a group of independent historians that the government commissioned to examine the country's role during that era.

title: A Sashay To the Right, Some Smiles From the Left
description: IT was a wish list for corporate lobbyists and conservative ideologues alike. As such, the tax bill pushed through the House this fall by Representative Bill Thomas of California, the Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, was clearly an opening gambit in what was sure to be an intense partisan battle over how to revive the economy. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill even dismissed it as ''show business.''

title: Quaker Oats Moves In Near Its Parent, PepsiCo
description: The food and beverages division of the Quaker Oats Co. has leased 25,000 square feet of space in Tarrytown at 660 White Plains Ave., and will transfer between 80 and 100 salespeople to the area early next year, said Mark Dollins, a spokesman for the company, which is based in Chicago. Because the company is sending its own employees, the move will not mean the creation of more jobs for Westchester residents. It will mean, however, the absorption of some vacant office space in the county, where the vacancy rate at the end of the third quarter was 14.9 percent. The new offices are located in a 256,000 square foot building owned by Reckson Associates Realty. The Tarrytown office will be one of five Quaker Oats customer business center sales offices in the United States. Md. Quaker Oats products include Gatorade, Quaker Oats, Quaker rice cakes, Chewy granola bars and Rice-A-Roni, among others. In August, PepsiCo, which is based in Purchase, completed its merger with Quaker Oats, creating a $25 billion food and beverage company. Elsa Brenner

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: THIS year's roster of best books contains five works of fiction and four of nonfiction, compared with last year's five of each. Choosing was easy. Nominating was not. Throughout the year there is some competition among editors to put books on the list for consideration. Yet from 1997 through last year, the numbers nominated declined by two each year. This year the process nasdaqed, ending in only 16 nominations, down from 20 last year.

title: Ties That Bind: 40 Years of Strikes and Fun
description: IT began in 1962 when a group of couples from St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church in East Meadow formed the Guys & Dolls Bowling League. The De Turrises, the Rays, the Barberas, the Ferrones, the Bonsignores, the Janisches, the Egans, the DiSantos, the Ciaramellas, the Vaccaros, the Falcanettis and the Benis all got together on Friday nights at AMF East Meadow Lanes.

title: So Ali Owned It. So What. How Many Bathrooms?
description: Float like a butterfly, sting like a flat market. The mansion that Muhammad Ali built in Cherry Hill in 1971 is up for sale by the man who bought it from The Greatest in the mid-70's. Tony Micale has put the 10,000-square-foot home -- which sits on two wooded acres -- on the market for $1.25 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JONES, PHILIP
description: JONES-Philip. You're not missing much these troubled days but I miss you. Beatrice

title: Private Sector; Sharing Wealth and the Family Name
description: Come the holiday season, Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, knows how to give. At the black-tie opening Wednesday of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season at City Center, the group's artistic director, Judith Jamison, told a star-studded audience that Mr. Weill and his wife, Joan, the chairwoman of Ailey, were contributing $15 million.

title: Kicks for the Whole Family
description: In the old days, Beth Albert went to soccer games only to watch her sons play. She was, alas, a Soccer Mom. But in 1998 she and other women in Montclair decided they deserved some fun too. Within two years the mothers had started an adult women's soccer league and last June held a tournament to raise money for breast cancer education. The joy of their transformation is recalled in ''Alive and Kicking: When Soccer Moms Take the Field and Change Their Lives Forever'' (Simon and Schuster, $20) by Ms. Albert's husband, Harvey Araton, a sportswriter for The New York Times. Ms. Albert continues to play soccer every Monday night at the Soccer Domain in Montclair with her team, The Shadow. ''I can't say enough about soccer and the benefits that come from playing sports, the physical and mental benefits, the self-esteem, the camaraderie,'' she said. ''An added benefit is the $31,000 we raised for breast cancer in the tournament last June.'' As for Mr. Araton, he said that seeing ''how much pleasure and passion the women were bringing to this'' led him to write the book. Margo Nash

title: Inquiry Into Anthrax Extends to U.S. Labs

title: SLIGHTLY LESS CONSTRUCTION
description: Construction for both public and private buildings during the next two years will decline only slightly despite the slowing economy, the New Jersey Alliance for Action's annual construction industry forecast says. Spending on construction during 2002 and 2003 should reach $20.1 billion, a decline of $332 million or 1.6 percent, from the estimates released last year, the alliance's report says. The largest declines are expected to be in industrial and office space and in construction by utility companies. Karen DeMasters

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; More Victims, More Funds
description: To help the families of those who died on Flight 587, which crashed on Nov. 12 after takeoff from Kennedy Airport, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that New York City was setting up a new charity, similar to one created for the families of lost rescue personnel after the World Trade Center attacks. The same spirit of inclusion moved in Washington, where a bill was introduced in the House that would open the federal Sept. 11 Victims Compensation Fund to the families of Americans killed or injured in the terrorist bombings of two embassies in Africa in 1998. Diana B. Henriques

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 1  An Australian doctor accused of murdering a dying patient was acquitted a few weeks before publication of a survey indicating that many Australian surgeons have hastened death for the terminally ill.

description: India's wonder girl, 14-year-old Humpy Koneru, tied for first place with the Yugoslav international master Mihajlo Stojanovic in the fourth edition of the Third Saturday International Tournament in Belgrade, Oct. 20 to 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAFFEO, JOSEPH. FDNY.
description: MAFFEO-Joseph. FDNY. On September 11, 2001. Killed in the line of duty at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Linda (nee Dornes), loving father of Christopher, fond son of Louis and Jean, cherished brother of Donna Maffeo, Susan Drury, Linda Manfredi and Debra Morri. Also survived and loved by many nieces and nephews. Memorial service at 11:00 A.M., Monday, December 3, Our Lady Queen of Peace Church, Staten Island, NY. title: No Creeps

Naturally, my roommates preferred someone with a regular job and a sociable demeanor. They considered advertising the place for $650 a month to 'cull the herd,' and then when they found a desirable tenant, informing him that the rent is in fact only $500. Is that ethical? J.A., Cambridge, Mass.

description: Before the suicide bombings here tonight, Israeli soldiers shot and killed two Palestinians in the West Bank, Palestinian doctors said.

title: Cooking Classes In Singapore, Thailand
description: A new culinary tour enables travelers to learn about the distinctive, complex cuisine of Southeast Asia at its source.

title: The Verdict He Heeds Is His Own
description: YOU could look long and hard at Campbell Scott's body of work without finding any projects that are embarrassingly stupid. Absent from the list of Mr. Scott's credits are the summer blockbusters and popcorn movies, sci-fi flicks and gooney comedies.

title: Book of Photos a Tribute To the Lost Firefighters
description: The pictures are undeniably powerful. A firefighter forlornly holding an American flag. A rack of firefighters' uniforms that will never be worn again. A crowd in front of Engine Company 54, on Eighth Avenue. A Vermeeresque image of the back room of a firehouse with a sign tacked to the wall that says, ''God Bless Red Hook,'' and a glimpse of a firefighter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, ROBERT L.
description: O'DONNELL-Robert L. On November 24, 2001 at age 74. Beloved husband of Barbara J. Ruby O'Donnell and loving father of Kevin O'Donnell and father-in-law of Ann. Grandfather of Elizabeth O'Donnell. Interment is private. Contributions in his memory may be made to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York City 10017.

title: 'Traveling on the Edge'
description: When you check in to the brutalist concrete monolith that is the Cape Sierra Hotel in Freetown, Sierra Leone, the first thing they do is ask you for a $2000 deposit. Cash only. The beautiful receptionist smiles winningly as you count out the notes. ‘I'm sorry, but we have to do it,’ she says. ‘It's in case you die before you check out.’

title: Racioppi's Passes Help Rowan Gain
description: Rowan quarterback Tony Racioppi threw for 330 yards and 4 touchdowns today as the Profs routed Ithaca College, 48-0, in the quarterfinals of the Division III playoffs.

title: November 25 - December 1
description: The Checks and Balances Thing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, EDITH (MILLER)
description: ALTMAN-Edith (Miller). Devoted wife of David, loving mother of Mel, Louise Stern, Alan and Judi, caring grandmother of Ilene, Marc, Matthew and Joshua. We'll always remember your kindness and love to us all. Graveside services private. Shiva will be observed at the Altman residence. Contributions in her memory may be made to Mount Sinai Breast Health Resource Program, 16 East 98 Street, New York, NY 10029.

title: Private Sector; Hedging His Hollywood Bet
description: Most people in the audiences who attended this weekend's opening of ''The Independent,'' a Hollywood spoof film starring Jerry Stiller as a director of B-rated movies, might be excused for focusing on its ample cleavage and off-color language. Many would also not necessarily know that the producer and co-writer, Mike Wilkins, has a regular day job as a senior manager at West Highland Capital, a hedge fund in Greenbrae, Calif., near San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELL, JOAN M.
description: ADELL-Joan M. Of East Norwich, formerly of East Hills, on November 30th, 2001, in her 70th year. Beloved wife of 48 years to Allan, mother of Steven, and the late Cathy Hertzberg. Devoted grandmother of Joshua, Michael, Rachel, Amy and Emily, and sister to her beloved Anita Grupp of Pittsburgh, PA. Joan was a well known person in the American Cancer Society on Long Island where she headed its Reach for Recovery unit for many years. She was presented with New York State's prestigious Courage Award by Libby Pataki in 1995 for her contributions towards helping others face the ravishes of cancer. Her life touched more people than she ever imagined possible. Graveside services will occur at 10:30 AM, on Monday, at New Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Don Monte Foundation, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY, would help her continue the battle.

title: Keeping Her Charges On Their (Tiny) Toes
description: THOSE who love the New York City Ballet production of ''The Nutcracker'' -- and there are legions of closeted adult fans -- tend to talk about the choreography and homey special effects in this standard-setting version. But there is another vital ingredient. And that is the children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBERG, G. PETER, M.D.
description: HALBERG-G. Peter, M.D. November 24, 2001. Memorial service on December 14, 2001, All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave (at 80 St), 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, donation to charity of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATZNER, YAACOV
description: MATZNER-Yaacov. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the tragic and sudden loss of Professor Yaacov Matzner, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at The Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical Center in Jerusalem. A distinguished physician and scientist, Professor Matzner received worldwide recognition for his research on leukemia and lymphoma, and he was presented with the Bayer-Pfizer Award and the Wolfson Research Award, as well as being honored by the European Society for Clinical Investigation. He also served as Head of the Hematology Unit at the HadassahUniversity Mt. Scopus Hospital. Professor Matzner was appointed Dean of the Faculty of Medicine in 2000, overseeing activities of the Faculty's five Schools. In his all too brief tenure, he made enormous strides as a visionary leader of a complex enterprise as well as securing needed resources for medical research and teaching. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Linesya, 2 children Hagai and Yonit, and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of The Board of Directors The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President Professor Haim D. Rabinowitch, Rector Yigal Arnon, Chairman of the Board of Governors

title: A Plunge into the Present
description: Ruben Dican adjusts the television, as everyone waits. A picture comes into focus. It's Bryant Gumbel. There's a shot of United Flight 175 ramming the south tower. Then it's run again. And again.

title: Nov. 25-Dec.1; Suspect in Anthrax Hoaxes
description: Since he escaped from prison in Illinois in February, Clayton Lee Waagner has been in all kinds of trouble, from bank robbery to car-jacking. Now he is the prime suspect in hundreds of anthrax threats mailed to abortion clinics this fall. Mr. Waagner, who is on the F.B.I.'s 10 Most Wanted list, claimed responsibility in a tape made at the Georgia home of a fellow anti-abortion activist: he also talked of his plans to kill 42 workers at abortion clinics. Tamar Lewin

title: Investing; Metal Stocks Gain Ground Amid Cuts In Production
description: WITH profits tumbling and mines closing, producers of base metals would appear to be enduring the worst of times.

title: Poof! Just Like Magic, Harry Potter Fills Restaurants
description: QUIET conversation, soft jazz, and the delicate clanking of fine dinnerware are the usual sounds in the dimly lit Kaleidoscope restaurant on Bank Street in New Milford.

title: Refurbishing a Courthouse, If Not Its Reputation
description: For nearly three years, the New York County Courthouse, better known as the Tweed Courthouse, had been shrouded in scaffolding as the city worked on an $85 million restoration.

title: Man in the News; Reputation for Tenacity; James Brien Comey
description: Last spring, Louis H. Freeh, the Director of the F.B.I., asked Attorney General John Ashcroft to transfer control of a major case, the investigation of the 1996 terrorist bombing at Khobar Towers apartments in Saudi Arabia, which killed 19 American servicemen, away from federal prosecutors in Washington.

title: Where More Is Less in Political Representation
description: AS Albany legislators armed with the latest census figures take up the once-a-decade task of reconfiguring legislative districts, some civic groups are pursuing campaigns to unify communities split among multiple representatives and divided by district lines.

title: Subletting Fees in a Condominium
description: Q: I own a condominium unit that I rent to a tenant. In the past, the board has imposed a $50 a month surcharge on rentals. Recently, however, it adopted new regulations increasing the surcharge to 20 percent of the rent for winter months and 30 percent for summer months. It is also imposing on tenants a fee of $100 a month for use of the facilities. This is all in addition to the security deposit. Is a condo board entitled to impose such charges? . . . Daniela Fahey, Warwick, N.Y.

title: Travelers From Antique Lands
description: TRAVELS WITH A MEDIEVAL QUEEN

title: Artifacts in Africa Suggest An Earlier Modern Human
description: More than 70,000 years ago, people occupied a cave in a high cliff facing the Indian Ocean at the tip of South Africa. They hunted grysbok, springbok and other game. They ate fish from the waters below them. In body and brain size, these cave dwellers were definitely anatomically modern humans.

title: Napa Valley; Airline Security; Cooking Classes in Asia
description: In Napa, a Celebration of Food, Wine and Art

title: Two Domes in Cornwall Defy Tourism Downturn
description: MENTION the idea of domes in Britain and most people think of the disastrous Millennium Dome on the banks of the Thames in Greenwich that turned into a sinkhole for bail-out money from the National Lottery.

title: An Important Person In Jazz Recording
description: I was pleased to see the opinion essay about Jack Crystal [''Introducing Billy Crystal's Father,'' Nov. 11]. I knew Jack and wrote about him. But there was one peculiar omission. By far, the most significant member of the clan, possibly even more important than Billy, was Jack's brother-in-law, Milton Gabler, who owned the all-significant, pioneer Commodore Record Shop in Manhattan and launched Commodore Records, the first independent jazz label. Milt died in July and received a major obituary in The Times. He was referred to four times in the essay, yet for some reason his last name was never mentioned; he was merely ''Jack's wife's brother''!

title: It's the Same, but Not
description: The surprise aerial assault on American territory, the unprecedented loss of life, the subsequent drums of war and patriotism - these have become the infamous chapter headings for Sept. 11, 2001. But many Americans immediately noted that they also told the story of another day - Dec. 7, 1941 - when Japanese aircraft attacked Pearl Harbor and propelled the United States into World War II. It's not a perfect analogy. The attacks at Pearl Harbor, which occurred 60 years ago this Friday, introduced reconizable enemies in the form of nation-states (Japan, then Germany and Italy); the Sept. 11 attacks introduced the nation to a Victory in World War II could be defined in straightforward terms: stop Hitler, go home. The current conflict has no clear finish line.

title: Susan Kerker, Garren Small
description: Susan Wynne Kerker and Garren Richard Small are to be married today by Rabbi Henry Sosland at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: How Islam and Politics Mixed
description: So what comes after the Taliban and Osama bin Laden are finished? Probably more Talibans and new Osama bin Ladens. This is the sad and shocking reality that we must confront. It will happen apart from all the fanfare surrounding America's military triumph in Afghanistan and all the other achievements of this so-called war on terror. Why? Because the Taliban and Mr. bin Laden are not isolated cases but manifestations of a complex, and potentially durable, sociopolitical phenomenon.

title: Millionaire Fugitive Has Been Caught, but Mysteries Remain
description: Robert A. Durst, an heir to a Manhattan real estate fortune, sat alone in a small cell in a county jail in Pennsylvania yesterday as investigators in three states tried to piece together the path of his six-week flight from murder charges in Texas.

title: Japan Royal Birth Stirs Talk of Return to Empress
description: With the delivery of a healthy baby girl today, Crown Princess Masako ended a long drought in births in the Japanese imperial family. But since only males are allowed to accede to the Chrysanthemum Throne, the debate over the future of the world's oldest imperial line is only just beginning.

title: Politics Served Straight Up, Often With a Twist
description: ''SHOULD she have a place at the table?'' asked John Lavelle, a state assemblyman and chairman of the Staten Island Democratic Party.

title: What to Build
description: As a frequent past visitor to the 101st floor of 2 World Trade Center, I was impressed with Ken Smith's ''Memorial in the Sky'' to honor the fallen of Sept. 11. The best memorials offer both a public place for visitors to reflect and a private sanctuary for the grieving. Arlington National Cemetery comes to mind as the best of these in offering the physical expanse to inspire reflection while maintaining a focus on individual losses. The Vietnam War memorial does the same, in the context of a sheltered space just off the expanse of the Mall.

title: The Devils Find A Little Intensity
description: In desperate need for points after winning just once in 10 games, the Devils played with intensity tonight and posted a 4-1 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings, avenging a loss in Detroit a night earlier.

title: Telecommunications; Bandwidth Traders' Uncertain Future
description: In the late 1990's, Enron almost single-handedly created the market for treating telecommunications bandwidth like a commodity similar to natural gas. Even after its broadband business reported large losses earlier this year, Enron boasted of its role as the world's largest bandwidth trader.

title: Weibin Wang: Living the American Dream
description: Weibin Wang and Wen Shi met as students in Beijing, and married three years later. A few months after the wedding in 1986, Mr. Wang left for the United States to study geophysics, at Yale and then at Columbia. Ms. Shi followed a year later.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASHBERG, ANDREW
description: MASHBERG-Andrew. On November 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Dr. Marcia Rosen. Loving father of Amy, Thomas and stepson Paul. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Ella and Anne. Devoted brother of Edward, Leda and Blossom. A forceful man who knew how to love. A dedicated reader who knew how to think. His passion and intellect inspired us. True love and best friend of Marcia. Wise and challenging mentor to his children. Bemused but generous grandfather. Funeral private. ''Il pleure dans mon coeur comme il pleut sur la ville.'' Verlaine

title: Devils Diverge in Views on Slump
description: DETROIT, Dec. 1 — Some of the Devils are trying to look at the bright side of their current slump, but their captain will have none of it.

title: ARCHITECTURE
description: LANDSCAPE DESIGN: A Cultural and Architectural History. By Elizabeth Barlow Rogers. (Abrams, $75.) In this magnum opus, Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, the founding president of the Central Park Conservancy and a longtime administrator of that celebrated oasis, stakes out and cultivates a breathtakingly vast terrain: the history of man-made landscape from Neolithic times to the present. Though Rogers focuses on a number of well-known gardens and parks -- from Hadrian's Villa of A.D. 118-38 outside Rome to Antonio Gaud's Park Gell of 1900-14 in Barcelona -- her subject is less horticulture than the social interaction of various cultures with their natural settings. Encompassing city planning as much as garden design, this panoramic study is impressive not only for its encyclopedic scope but also for the author's authoritative command of so much diverse material and for her lucid writing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCANENY, ERNEST J.
description: McANENY-Ernest J. Died peacefully at home on November 2, 2001, at 94 years of age. He was son of the late Marjorie and George McAneny, President of the Borough of Manhattan (1910-1913) and Executive Manager of the New York Times (1916-1921). His maternal grandparents were the promient physicians Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi and Dr. Abraham Jacobi, for whom Jacobi Hospital is named. Mr. McAneny is survived by his brother David G. McAneny and numerous nieces and nephews. He is predeceased by his sisters Ruth McAneny Loud and Elisabeth McAneny Harrison, and brothers Herbert McAneny and Arnold McAneny. Mr. McAneny graduated from Riverdale Country School in 1925, and Williams College in 1930. He taught at Riverdale Country School for thirty-one years and went on to serve as the school's archivist for twenty-five more years. The familiy held a private interment at Jacobi Point in Lake George, NY, and a celebration of his life will be held at Riverdale Country School on May 17, 2002. In honor of Mr. McAneny's 83 years at Riverdale, the family has established the Ernest J. McAneny Memorial Fund. Gifts may be sent to Riverdale Country School, 5230 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, New York 10471, Attn: Development Office.

title: Manifestoes for The Next New York
description: Frank Rich's nod to the ''crazy-quilt hodgepodge'' of the old Times Square should include street performers. I remember seeing break dancers in Times Square on my first trip to New York as a child in the 1980's. This entertainment is free and exciting and adds a festive atmosphere.

title: Tasty Bargains on the Pricey North Shore
description: BROWN'S TAVERN would be a bargain anywhere, but in a North Shore fox-and-hounds community like Locust Valley, it's a revelation. Its simple, satisfying food has generated enthusiasm in the ranks of the local, old-money country club set and young penny-wise families from afar. Both are making the trek to the Plaza, a smart, stylish shopping center filled with elegant little boutiques in the middle of town. There, at No. 4 (516-676-5793), where the Tavern on the Plaza had been, an eager-to-please Scottish family has opened a warm, cozy restaurant with prices that please, food that generates vivid tastes and people who charm.

title: Investing; A Diversification Path Leads Abroad
description: INVESTORS who who have limited themselves to American stocks may want to consider shares of foreign companies that, by some measures, are among the strongest in the world.

title: A Collection in Context
description: THE chemical business took Lawrence Gussman around the world, including a 1957 visit to the clinic of Dr. Albert Schweitzer in Lambarn, Gabon. He returned to the clinic as a volunteer every year for the next 30 years. Through this, he came to know Gabon, the country, the people and -- most importantly -- the art.

title: Backstage With Tom Ford
Donna Karan, Fashion Star
New Plans for Lincoln Center
Excite Said to Reach Pact To Keep Internet Service On
description: Excite@Home reached a tentative agreement yesterday with a group of cable companies, including Cox Communications and the Comcast Corporation, to keep their customers connected to Excite's high-speed Internet service, according to several people involved in the negotiations.

title: Clues, Overlooked, to a Coming Threat
description: The more investigators learn about the anthrax mailings, the more they realize their attitudes about this once-obscure bacterium and its potential as a weapon of terror were based on presumption as well as fact.

title: F.D.U. Ousts Seton Hall in Men's Tournament
description: By making the most of its rare opportunities yesterday, Fairleigh Dickinson defeated Seton Hall, 1-0, to reach the N.C.A.A. men's quarterfinals for the first time in school history.

title: A Zillion Channels to Tune Out the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Postal Center In Connecticut Shows Traces Of Anthrax
description: Trace amounts of anthrax spores have been found in the Connecticut postal distribution center that sorts the mail that goes to Oxford, where a 94-year-old woman who rarely left her house died last month of inhalation anthrax, state and postal officials said yesterday.

title: On the East River, A Big Fixer-Upper; Repair Work Is Monumental On an Oddly Designed Bridge
description: It is hard not to feel sorry for the Manhattan Bridge.

title: Fumigation Is Finished In Senate Leader's Suite
description: Technicians finished fumigating the anthrax-contaminated office suite of Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, today and immediately began purging the bleachlike gas that kills the infectious powdered spores.

title: Swiss Voters Reject Effort to Abolish Their Army
description: Swiss voters, turning aside arguments that their citizen army is outdated and unnecessary, today firmly rejected an effort to abolish the armed forces.

title: The Talk About Talk; With Hearst Restless, Financial Issues Threaten a Glamorous Magazine Marriage
description: It's beginning to look like a busted romance between Tina Brown and Hearst Magazines.

title: Arafat Not Present at Gaza Headquarters
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Dec. 4 -- Assaulting the symbols of Yasir Arafat's authority, Israeli warplanes, helicopter gunships, tanks and bulldozers struck in the West Bank and Gaza Strip on Monday night and before dawn today as the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, accused the Palestinian leader of provoking war by pursuing "the path of terrorism."

title: Steelers' Defense Wakes Up in Time to Hold Off the Vikings
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers were coasting, ahead by 21-3 against the Minnesota Vikings with less than 7 minutes left before 62,661 fans at the new and pristine Heinz Field. A Pittsburgh victory looked so certain that everyone in the stadium seemed to kick back, grab a drink and pay little attention to the lifeless Vikings.

title: Argentina Limits Withdrawals as Banks Near Collapse
description: The government has limited cash withdrawals from banks and taken a step toward adopting the dollar as Argentina's currency, as part of a desperate effort to avert a run on banks and a chaotic devaluation.

title: C.I.A. Chief Urges Pakistani to Crack Down on Militants
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 3 - George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, urged the president of Pakistan in a weekend meeting to go further in cracking down on militant clerics and other extremists, government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLEDANO, JOSEPH L.
description: TOLEDANO-Joseph L. On November 30th, 2001. Passed away at home in Paris, France. Beloved husband of the late Estrella. Devoted father of Edward (Karla) and Sylviane Levy (Gerard). Cherished grandfather, great-grandfather, brother and uncle. He will be lovingly remembered

title: Jets' Swagger Turns to a Stagger
description: Afterward, Curtis Martin was baffled, unable to summon words to describe how the Jets had dominated New England in one half and fallen flat on their faces in the next. The 17-16 loss to the Patriots today was that confounding and that damaging.

title: Sheepshead Defeats Lehman For Title
description: In a game full of momentum swings, Sheepshead Bay used a big play on offense and took advantage of two Lehman fumbles to win its first Public Schools Athletic League championship, 26-16, yesterday at Midwood Field in Brooklyn. The Sharks finished the season with a 12-0 record.

title: A Rock 'n' Roll Art Director Moves to GQ
description: Fred Woodward walked into the Cond Nast building last week, feeling a little daunted. After more than 14 years as art director of the rock 'n' roll bible Rolling Stone, the Mississippi native had arrived to do a makeover on the slick men's fashion publication GQ.

title: A Zillion Channels to Tune Out the World
description: To the Editor:

title: A Communal Search for Something Greater Than the Self. Call It God?
description: ''Serving Nia,'' the first premiere of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's season at City Center, is Ronald K. Brown's beautiful and lyrical sequel to ''Grace,'' the big hit he created for the company two years ago. Anyone who has followed Mr. Brown's own company, Evidence, knows that he is one of the few major choreographers to emerge in American modern dance in the last 10 years. He is an artist who never stands still: his work is full of change and exploration.

title: A new Listerine product is making a big splash after a short time on the market.
description: IT'S dainty, it's green and it's making the rounds, from movie theaters to Sunday services to the Emmy Awards. And it has a dual mission: to freshen breath, and to prove that an old consumer product can experience a renaissance.

title: Microsoft Deal Worries Apple
description: To Apple Computer, the proposal by Microsoft and plaintiffs to settle more than 100 class-action antitrust lawsuits against Microsoft is riddled with flaws -- and carries a big competitive threat.

title: An F.B.I. Career That Ran From Abscam to Al Qaeda
description: Thomas J. Pickard's first big assignment at the F.B.I. was to pose as the accountant of the fake Olympic Construction Company in the famed Abscam case in the late 1970's. The role was not much of a stretch for Mr. Pickard, a former certified public accountant with a master's degree in taxation who got bored at the age of 24 with number-crunching. He guessed -- correctly, as it turned out -- that a career in the Federal Bureau of Investigation would be more exciting.

title: Richter Makes It 2 Shutouts In a Row
description: Mike Richter must have wanted to prove it was no fluke. On Thursday, Richter recorded the Rangers' first shutout in 214 games and his first since February 1999. Last night at Madison Square Garden, he finished off his first back-to-back shutouts since October 1998.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Enron Seeks Bankruptcy And Takes Dynegy to Court

title: In a Recession
description: To the Editor:

title: Berlin Cameron in Talks About Being Acquired
description: Berlin Cameron & Partners, a leading midsize independent New York agency, is involved in ''very serious conversations'' about being acquired, said Andy Berlin, chairman.

title: Arson Suspected in Several New Jersey Fires
description: A string of fires, some of which were suspected as resulting from arson, broke out along the Hudson River in northern New Jersey on Saturday night and early yesterday morning, displacing more than 100 residents and destroying at least 12 buildings, fire officials said.

title: Forecasters Predict Drop in Ad Spending
description: Two forecasters are predicting declines in advertising spending, though they say signs of a recovery are becoming visible.

title: Hot Streak at Garden Adds Some Excitement
description: The Rangers entered last night's game against the Tampa Bay Lightning at Madison Square Garden with a 9-4-0-0 record on home ice. For a team that has not had a winning record at home the past four seasons, that is quite a turnaround.

title: MEDIA; Vanity Fair's Depiction Upsets Capitol Hill Women
description: Grave talk of war and terrorism has swept the topic of interns, sex and politicians from the Capitol.

title: Redskins' Streak Is Ended by the Cowboys
description: Forget the Redskins' winning streak, their improbable rise to a possible playoff berth, the much-hailed bonding of the disciplinarian coach, Marty Schottenheimer, and his sometimes unruly squad.

title: Terror Anthrax Resembles Type Made by U.S.
description: The dry powder used in the anthrax attacks is virtually indistinguishable in critical technical respects from that produced by the United States military before it shut down its biowarfare program, according to federal scientists and a report prepared for a military contractor.

title: Bush and Cheney Attend Kennedy Center Gala
description: This evening, in a picture of celebration and comfort, President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney stepped outside the White House together for the first time since Sept. 11, attending a gala black-tie performance to pay tribute to this year's five Kennedy Center honorees.

title: Fox Portrays a War of Good and Evil, and Many Applaud
description: Osama bin Laden, according to Fox News Channel anchors, analysts and correspondents, is ''a dirtbag,'' ''a monster'' overseeing a ''web of hate.'' His followers in Al Qaeda are ''terror goons.'' Taliban fighters are ''diabolical'' and ''henchmen.''

title: Distance Runner, Devoted Flight Attendants, Firehouse Party Planner
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Compressed Data; At M.I.T., Making Fun of the Alma Mater
description: Students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are known for their ambitious pranks. In 1998, for example, students hacked into the university's Web site, replacing its home page with an image of Mickey Mouse and the headline ''Disney to Acquire MIT for $6.9 Billion.''

title: Afghan Factions Work On a Draft Agreement
description: Delegates from the four Afghan factions negotiated here today over a draft of an agreement for a post-Taliban government drawn up by the United Nations. It calls for a 28-member executive administration, an international security force for the capital, and a symbolic role for the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah.

title: Yonghe Journal; Religion Museum in Taiwan Promotes Tolerance
description: Hsin Tao does not want to read too much into it. But the opening date of his museum -- Nov. 9, or 11/9 -- was the reverse of 9/11, the date of the attacks on the United States.

title: Fighters Uplifted Muslims, Bin Laden Aide Says in Book
description: Ayman al-Zawahiri, a top lieutenant to Osama bin Laden and a man with a price on his head, says in excerpts from his autobiography published today that the Arabs fighting in Afghanistan, no matter what their fate, succeeded in galvanizing Muslim youth around the world in taking on the West.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Nov. 20 about a speech on the Middle East by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell misstated the name of a pro-Israel lobbying group whose executive director, Howard Kohr, commented. It is the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, not the American-Israeli Political Action Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBITZ, NORMAN
description: LUBITZ-Norman. On November 27, 2001, after a long illness. Beloved father of Amy and Jeffrey. Grandfather of Joshua, Brandon, Zachary and Noah. His love and wisdom will be missed.

title: U.S. Planes Keep Up Bombing Of Kandahar as Allies Close In
description: American warplanes resumed their daily attack on Kandahar today, putting pressure on the Taliban from the air, as leaders of the Pashtun tribes in southern Afghanistan said their fighters had taken new ground and advanced to within 10 miles of that last large Taliban stronghold.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Manning's Mistakes Torpedo The Colts
description: When the Baltimore Ravens caught Peyton Manning in an all-out blitz, he ducked and swerved trying to evade his tacklers, backtracking desperately. Manning throwing a pass is a beautiful thing to watch. Manning trying to run is not.

title: Afghans Say Civilians Are Imperiled by U.S.
description: According to Afghan commanders here in the far eastern part of the country, civilians are being killed in the American hunt for Osama bin Laden.

title: Compressed Data; Most States List Campaign Donors Online
description: A mere five years ago, details about campaign contributors typically stayed stuffed in dusty file cabinets in the basements of government buildings. Generally, the only people who saw the files were reporters or opposition researchers paid to study them.

title: 17-Year-Old Makes PGA Tour
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3  Ty Tryon missed his 11th grade classes today, but his golf game passed a major test.

title: Michael Iovenko, 71, Lawyer; Led Aid Society During Strike
description: Michael Iovenko, a Wall Street lawyer and former New York State banking official who was president of the Legal Aid Society during a bitter 1994 labor confrontation between its staff lawyers and the Giuliani administration, died in Manhattan on Saturday. He was 71.

title: Viktor Astafyev, Who Wrote of Rural Russia, Dies at 77
description: Viktor Astafyev, a writer who became famous for his stark novels about the Soviet Union's costly victory in the Second World War and grim narratives about prison camps and the alcoholism and despair of provincial Russian life, died on Thursday at home in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia. He was 77.

title: Turnout for the Fall Nationals Proves the Game's Popularity
description: In spite of economic downturn and international crisis, the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, which ended Tuesday in Las Vegas, were the biggest in the event's 75-year year history. There were 16,818 tables in play in 10 days, indicating that bridge is flourishing in North America, as it is on other continents.

title: Ridge Issues Another Alert, Citing New Threats of Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The director of homeland security, Tom Ridge, said today that law enforcement and intelligence agencies had picked up numerous threats of more terrorist attacks, and that Americans should be vigilant even as they go about their lives.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about reaction to a recent change in the Turkish civil code, making men and women equal before the law, misstated the year in which the republic was founded. It was 1923, not 1926.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Bronxchester Developer Chosen
description: The Giuliani administration has selected the Starrett Corporation to build an office and retail complex at three city-owned urban renewal sites in Bronxchester. Construction on the $98.2 million project is to begin May 2003. The three sites, bounded by 149th Street, Brook Avenue and Bergen Avenue, and divided by Westchester Avenue, are now vacant. Starrett's proposed project is 500,000 square feet, including 314,000 square feet of office space, a 3,000-square-foot community center and two parking lots that would accommodate 335 cars. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARITA, LAURA MARIE
description: STARITA-Laura Marie. Daughter of the late Luigi and Antonina. Dear sister of Louis, Paul, Joseph, Regina and the late Rita Palermo and Victor. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Cusimano and Russo Funeral Home, 2005 West 6th St., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of the Resurrection Wednesday, 10 AM, St. Andrew's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting hours 2 to 5, 7 to 9.

title: German Panel Recommends Imports of Stem Cells
description: A commission handpicked by Chancellor Gerhard Schrder has recommended that Germany allow restricted imports of stem cells for medical research.

title: Sales of PC's Brighten a Bit This Season
description: The reeling personal computer market, whose fortunes turned sharply downward last holiday season, is showing some signs of life this season.

title: Vaudeville Antics of That Funny Girl
description: ''Incongruity was her thing,'' the singer and comedian Marilyn Sokol recalls in her ferociously zany cabaret tribute to Fanny Brice, ''Me and My Fanny.'' To demonstrate, Ms. Sokol dons a feathered headband to perform Blanche Merrill's nonsensical comic number ''I'm an Indian'' in a Yiddish accent. The song is the sort of ridiculous ethnic spoof that no one would dream of creating in today's more politically sensitive climate. As revived by Ms. Sokol, who more or less channels Brice's antic spirit, it reminds us that once a upon time the vaudeville stage was home to a kind of raw show business silliness that has all but disappeared in these more self-conscious times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, MAC
description: ROBBINS-Mac, was a man adored by all for his strength and kindness. He will always be remembered by each of us because of his very special way of always being there when we needed him. We will miss you, ''Mackie''. The Robbins Family

title: Stylized Community Rites, Some Formal, Some Sultry
description: Ballet Hispnico is looking better than ever these days. There is an extra softness to the stretch of the dancers' bodies. And the dancers' look of enjoyment was infectious in Pedro Ruiz's ''Guajira'' and David Roussve's ''Somethin' From Nothin','' presented on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Whose Number Is Up In Bowl Game Bingo?
description: When Tennessee plays Louisiana State on Saturday night in the Southeastern Conference championship game in Atlanta, the Volunteers may have the support of more than only their fans. A victory over the Tigers could send Tennessee to the Rose Bowl against unbeaten Miami in a matchup for the national championship that would validate the complicated Bowl Championship Series rankings.

Donations in his memory may be made to the NYS Talking Book Library Cultural Education Center, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12230. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809.

description: Robert W. Pittman, AOL Time Warner's co-chief operating officer, seemed unconvinced that business would turn around anytime soon.

description: Following are excerpts from a 1998 letter to President Bill Clinton from the Project for the New American Century urging the removal of President Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq. Among the signers were Donald H. Rumsfeld, Paul D. Wolfowitz and R. James Woolsey.

Devoted brother of Bunny, Doris, Alvin, Marty and the late Bernie. Dear uncle and friend. Respected attorney who loved boating, fishing, family and friends. Graduate of Catawba College and NYU Law School. Generous, witty and kind-hearted, a very special person who was one in a million. He will be truly missed by many. Services today, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Pitney Bowes Is Casting Off Copier and Fax Units Today
description: It has promised to do so for a year, and today it finally will: Pitney Bowes is formally turning over its copier and fax business to its shareholders.
