description: EVERY TONGUE

title: Looking for Judgment On a Shattered Deal
description: What is the penalty for walking away from the altar?

title: Vanity Fair's Depiction Upsets Capitol Hill Women
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  Grave talk of war and terrorism has swept the topic of interns, sex and politicians from the Capitol.

title: By Demanding a Diagnosis, He Lives to Tell of Anthrax
description: Leroy Richmond, gifted with a mellifluous voice and precise elocution, was often asked to read safety announcements at the Brentwood Road complex of the Postal Service in Washington. But the three October mornings that he stood to read the latest news about anthrax now seem strange, he said, a fractured memory that plays over and over in his head.

title: Rifts Imperil Quest for Federal Aid To Rebuild Downtown New York
description: New York City's fight to win $20 billion in emergency-reconstruction aid from Washington is being increasingly undercut by the change in administrations at City Hall and by the sudden escalation of the race for governor in New York, state and federal officials say.

title: Rather Reports Another War, This Time in a Windbreaker
description: In one of the seminal moments of his career, Dan Rather sneaked into Afghanistan in 1980 and dodged Soviet bullets wearing the uniform of the Mujahedeen fighters for a report on CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' The piece introduced the Afghan warriors to America and won Mr. Rather the nickname ''Gunga Dan.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: DNA Testing Bill Advances
description: The State Senate has approved legislation that would provide new procedures for DNA testing of prison inmates. The bill, sponsored by Edward T. O'Connor, a Democrat of Hudson County, was approved by the Senate last week and now goes before the General Assembly. It would create rules for inmates and lawyers to follow when requesting DNA testing that might clear inmates of crimes, and would set uniform standards for how judges should review testing requests. It also requires inmates themselves to pay for the testing.

title: Arthur F. Kelly, 88, Ex-Airline Executive
description: Arthur F. Kelly, chief executive of Western Airlines in the 1970's, died on Nov. 20 in Gig Harbor, Wash. He was 88 and lived in Gig Harbor.

title: Forecasters Predict Drop in Ad Spending
description: Two forecasters are predicting declines in advertising spending, though they say signs of a recovery are becoming visible.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 20 about a speech on the Middle East by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell misstated the name of a pro-Israel lobbying group whose executive director, Howard Kohr, commented. It is the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, not the American-Israeli Political Action Committee.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,533 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Schools To Get Sept. 11 Aid
description: Thirty-five New Jersey school districts affected by the terror attacks will receive $1.5 million in federal money for psychological counseling and other services, Commissioner Vito A. Gagliaro announced last week. The Fairview district in Bergen County, where students witnessed the attack on the World Trade Center and one staff member lost a son on United Airlines Flight 93, which crashed in Stony Township, Pa., received the largest grant. It will use most of the $212,000 for counseling.

title: E-Commerce Report; A new feature turns a cursor into an automatic price-comparison service.
description: PRICE comparison sites have always been popular with online shoppers, but for a small subset of that population, online shopping software ''agents'' do the bargain sniffing for them.

title: 'Israel or Arafat'
description: After his meeting with President Bush and just before flying back to his stunned and bloodied Israel, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon returned the call of a longtime supporter.

title: 15 ISRAELIS DIE IN BUS ATTACK; MILITANTS JAILED BY ARAFAT
description: The third Palestinian suicide bomber in just over 12 hours struck on a city bus here today, killing himself and 15 others and prompting Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to order arrests of suspects, as Israeli government ministers spoke openly of removing him from power.

title: Marines Build Firepower in the South, Bolstering Their Patrols and Readiness
description: The Marines nearly doubled the number of combat helicopters at an ever-sprawling desert airstrip here Sunday, sharply increasing their firepower as opposition forces, supported by American bombing raids, mounted a final drive on the Taliban's last stronghold, Kandahar.

title: Lure Tourists Back To a Wounded City
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Niagara Mohawk Merger Cleared
description: State regulators last week cleared the $3 billion merger of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and National Grid, a deal the companies say will save upstate customers up to $1 billion in electricity bills over the next decade. The deal, cleared by the Public Service Commission, will create the nation's ninth largest electric utility and reduce monthly bills an average of 5 percent, said Nicholas Lyman, a Niagara Mohawk spokesman. The merger, subject to clearance by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is expected to be completed early next year. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Mohammed I. Kamel, 74; Quit in Cairo Over Camp David
description: Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel, who resigned as Egypt's foreign minister in 1978 in protest against the Camp David peace accords with Israel, predicting accurately that they would isolate Egypt in the Arab world without resolving the Palestinian question, died on Nov. 22 in Cairo, the Foreign Ministry announced. He was 74.

title: The Studios Were Lost, But the Artists Get Their Day
description: Early in September, 15 artists were at work in studios on the 91st and 92nd floors of Tower 1 of the World Trade Center. A cosmopolitan bunch -- born in Korea, Singapore, Austria, Australia, Iran, Israel, Jamaica, Japan, England, Colombia and the United States -- they were part of an artist-in-residence program called World Views, sponsored by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

title: Quiz: Recognizing Hearing Loss
description: Realizing you have a hearing problem is the first step to getting help for it. Hearing loss commonly occurs so gradually that people tend not to notice it until it becomes quite pronounced. The American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery developed the following five-minute self-test for hearing loss.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Subway Deaths
description: In separate incidents, a man and a woman were found dead on subway tracks last weekend, the police said yesterday. It was unclear why they were on the tracks and whether they were alive when they were hit by trains, the police said. The body of the man, whose name was not released, was found at 8 p.m. Saturday beneath a southbound No. 6 train at the Longwood Avenue station in the Bronx. The train was pulling away from the station when its brakes locked, signaling an obstruction, the police said. The woman, who was not identified, was hit by a southbound F train at the Second Avenue stop in Manhattan about 1 a.m. yesterday and pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORT, EVELYN J.
description: PORT-Evelyn J. December 2, 2001, at the age of 56, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Garrett, and loving mother of Darren and Stephanie. Adored daughter of Margot and the late Henry Gutman. Cherished sister of Joan (Marc) Mintz and Karen (Steven) Yager, and sister-in-law of Penny and Lenny Goldberg. Also survived and loved by many nieces and nephews. A strong and independent woman filled with warmth and kindess, who touched everyone around her. She will be deeply missed and loved by her family and friends.

title: Out of Touch in St. Lucia
description: For those who have been watching cable-news channels for too long, the Ladera Resort, in the mountains above Soufriere in southern St. Lucia, has a No News package with some extras thrown in. It offers a two-night stay in a suite with a private plunge pool and no TV, phone or radio and no fourth wall (that's to provide a view of the Piton Mountains, without anyone's getting a view of you). With no links to the outside world, guests will have to wait to use the $25 gift certificate for Amazon.com that is also included, as are a guided half-day tropical rain-forest walk (valued at $30) and a breakfast each morning. Rates are $500 suite until Dec. 17 and $790 Dec. 18 to April 17. Not included are taxes, which are 18 percent. Information: (800) 738- 4752 or www.ladera-stlucia.com .

title: Bush, Mirroring Call on Taliban, Demands Arafat Stop Extremists
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 — President Bush demanded today that Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestinian Authority, break up Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, the groups that, he said, train and breed the kinds of suicide bombers who killed at least 25 people in terrorist bombings over the weekend.

title: Lady Vols Have the Numbers, If Not the Names, This Season
description: The team searches for a go-to player. There are only three seniors. Yet it is clear that the Tennessee women's team, trying for the program's seventh national championship, has one thing in distinguished abundance. Depth.

title: Come One, Come All
description: The two major political parties are thinking about holding their 2004 nominating conventions at Madison Square Garden in New York City. For reasons obvious and not so obvious, we think this is a wonderful idea. The obvious reason is that it represents a powerful gesture of solidarity with a city that has been physically, economically and emotionally bruised. Colorado's Republican governor, Bill Owens, framed the matter nicely when he said that the ''same compassion that caused me to root for the Yankees for the first time in 51 years makes me think it would be fun to go to New york and show the presidential flag there.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUBELO, DOMINGO, JR.
description: CUBELO-Domingo, Jr. Formerly of NYC. Died November 28, 2001 at Kingston, NY. Son of Bibiana Cubelo. Brother - Robert Cubelo. Funeral service 10 AM, Wednesday, December 5, 2001, Hynes Funeral Home, Margaretville, NY. Burial St. Francis DeSales Cemetery, Allaben, NY. Calling hours Tuesday, 2-4 PM, at the Hynes Funeral Home, Margaretville, NY.

description: LOEB-Louise Steinhart. Died Saturday, December 1, 2001, at age 86. Widow of Henry A. Loeb (who died in 1998). In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Child Development Center of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57 Street, NY, NY 10019, attn: Jane Berenbein; or to Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, attn: Alvin Teirstein, M.D., Director of Richenthal Institute.

description: It is not a hovercraft, a helicopter backpack or a teleportation pod.

description: A French venture capital group has become the latest bidder for Body Shop, the beleaguered retailer of health and beauty products, people close to the discussions said today.

title: New Economy; In an era of tighter security, how much cyberfreedom are we willing to surrender?
description: IN the debate about new surveillance powers for law enforcement officials, Americans, in various ways, are asking a basic question: Are we willing to curtail personal freedom in exchange for greater national security?

title: An Eye on Cuba While Blending In Country Music
description: Latin America has long provided secret ingredients for country music with bolero-tinged ballads and the bounce of norteo (Tex-Mex) in uptempo numbers. Meanwhile storytelling and plaints of lost love thrive on both sides of the border. Now Ral Malo, a Cuban-American singer and songwriter who spent the 1990's leading the Mavericks onto the country-music charts, has reversed the assimilation.

title: Executive Changes in Media Firms
description: Ed Brown, managing director for international sales and marketing at St. Maarten Spirits, Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., was named to the new post of executive vice president for worldwide sales and marketing.

description: HAIFA, Israel, Dec. 2  The third Palestinian suicide bomber in just over 12 hours struck on a city bus here today, killing himself and 15 others and prompting Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to order arrests of suspects, as Israeli government ministers spoke openly of removing him from power.

description: STEIN-KOHLER-Arthur. On December 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Maxine Stein-Kohler (nee Fertig). Dearest brother of Alex Steinkoler and brother-in-law of Ronnie. Uncle of Manya, Danny and Jeremy. He will be missed by his many friends. Donations will be gratefully accepted by the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, 1111 Stewart Ave., Bethpage, NY 11714. Service Monday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., 212-362-6600.

title: Radio Free Europe Hopes To Expand in Afghanistan
description: Radio Free Europe is a new front line in the American war in Afghanistan. By early February, if Congress approves, the network will resume broadcasting to Afghanistan for the first time in nearly a decade.

title: Mary Whitehouse, 91, a Foe Of Sexuality in British Culture
description: Mary Whitehouse, a British schoolteacher and mother of three who for more than 30 years campaigned vociferously against sex, violence and blasphemy on television, stage and screen, died on Nov. 23 in Colchester, England. She was 91.

title: Cambodia Labor Ruling
description: The International Labor Organization has said that working conditions in Cambodia's clothing industry meet its standards, paving the way for the United States to increase imports under a January 1999 trade pact. The United States may increase its clothing imports from Cambodia under the deal by up to 14 percent annually, on condition that Cambodia meet the labor group's standards, it said last week.

title: Digital Camera Sales Surged in October
description: Sales of digital cameras rose 83 percent in the four weeks ended Oct. 27 as camera makers vied for holiday shoppers with lower prices, while sales of film continued to decline, according to industry data.

title: Ford to Cut Retirement Benefits And Insurance for Some Workers
description: The Ford Motor Company will announce plans later this week to slash 401(k) and health benefits for its salaried workers as part of an effort to overhaul its cost structure and return to profitability.

title: Texas' Simms Cannot Back Up Talk
description: The Colorado Buffaloes were upset about Texas quarterback Chris Simms's boastful pregame comments. Then they heard he was wearing patent leather shoes during warm-ups for Saturday night's game at Texas Stadium.

title: Hotel Chain Considers Bid For Starwood
description: Six Continents, the hotel and restaurant company formerly known as Bass, is considering making an offer for Starwood Hotels and Resorts, people close to the companies said today.

description: SURRY-Mary. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted mother of Sharon and Jeffrey Wallberg and June and Lester Wohl. Dear sister of William Cohen. Adored grandmother of Michelle, David, Eric and Rachel. Cherished greatgrandmother of Robert, Julia and Jacob. For information, call ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 212769-4400.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Chiefs Asked To Resign
description: The Police Department's top supervisors have been asked to submit letters of resignation and their rsums, as the department prepares for the new commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, next month, police officials said yesterday. The request, first reported in The New York Post yesterday, is considered routine when a new mayor takes office. The department's 20 most senior chiefs and deputy commissioners must submit the resignation letters and rsums for potential reassignment by Wednesday.

title: A Backyard That Belongs to No One and Everyone
description: ''Central Park was built to make this city civilized,'' the historian Barry Lewis says early in ''A Walk Through Central Park,'' an effervescent valentine to this ''country estate for every New Yorker.'' The program, on WNET in New York tonight (and later on other public television stations), returns again and again to the notion that the park, along with the museums that surround it, contributes a vital element of grace to the hectic city.

title: No Lawyer to Call
description: The debate over President Bush's order establishing military tribunals has missed an important point: defense lawyers will be unable to practice in these courts. Every practicing American lawyer -- civilian or military -- must be a member of at least one state bar. And every state bar has ethics rules requiring competent representation for criminal defendants. So how does that affect individual lawyers? They may not lend their prestige and skills to a sham process that mocks their constitutional role in ensuring fair trials for their clients.

title: Australian Doctors Admit Helping Patients Die
description: An Australian doctor accused of murdering a dying patient was acquitted a few weeks before publication of a survey last month indicating that many Australian surgeons have hastened death for the terminally ill.

title: Congregation Thinks Twice About a Depiction of a Segregated Past
description: No one asked the parishioners of First Church of Christ Congregational if they wanted an art project that sometimes blocked their view of the pulpit and was attached to the pews and their cushions. So they didn't ask anyone when they had part of it removed. But the potent subject of this project, racism and church history, freighted its removal with meaning and touched off a controversy that may linger long after today, when the exhibit officially closes.

title: Asian English-Language Journals Are Reeling as Advertising Slumps
description: English-language journalism in Asia has taken a body blow in the last month, with the closing of one Hong Kong-based regional news magazine and a drastic retrenchment at another.

title: The No. 1 Ranking A Distant Memory, The Irish Fire Davie
description: The turbulent five-year reign of Coach Bob Davie at Notre Dame ended yesterday when university officials announced that Davie and his entire staff had been fired and a search initiated for a successor to fill one of the most prominent jobs in football.

description: Two forecasters are predicting declines in advertising spending, though they say signs of a recovery are becoming visible.

description: Kandahar Under Siege

title: The Wired Teenager
description: Teenagers, social creatures that they are, spend most of their online time exchanging e-mail and instant messages with friends. Those activities are followed closely by playing games or doing homework online -- at least, according to their parents, who were surveyed recently by the Yankee Group about their children's online activities.

title: Securing Base, U.S. Makes Its Brawn Blend In
description: Dressed in Afghan clothing and sporting scruffy beards, American soldiers here do their best to blend in when they move in and out of the Afghan capital, Kabul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, EDITH
description: ALTMAN-Edith. Ramot Shapira expresses their condolences to David Altman, Officer and Trustee of Ramot Shapira, on the loss of his beloved wife Edith and to Louise Stern, Mel and Alan Altman on the loss of their dear mother. May they all be granted an extra measure of inner-strength. Shelley S. Goren, President

description: To the Editor:

title: Spy, Citing Fears, Fights Return to China
description: Bin Wu, a former Chinese spy, has an immigration problem. He wants to stay in this country, where his brief tenure as a double or triple agent ended in 1992 with his arrest and conviction for shipping military goods to China.

title: Calls for New Push Into Iraq Gain Power in Washington
description: When President Bush told Saddam Hussein last week to submit to weapons inspections or else, he bolstered the spirits of a coalition of conservatives, cold warriors and Iraqi exiles determined to persuade the administration to overthrow the Iraqi leader once and for all.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Supply Carriers Are Vulnerable in Strait of Malacca, Admiral Says : U.S. Escorts Ships to the War Zone
description: SINGAPORE  In a move to guard against possible terrorist attacks, the U.S. military has started escorting key supply ships for its operations in Afghanistan through the Strait of Malacca, the main international shipping lane linking the Pacific and Indian oceans.

title: Week's Schedule of Credit Sales
description: The Treasury's schedule this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill tomorrow.

title: Martin Joins Elite Company
description: With an 11-yard sweep early in the second quarter, running back Curtis Martin surpassed the 1,000-yard mark for the seventh straight season. Martin, who finished with 87 yards today, is one of only three N.F.L. running backs to rush for 1,000 yards in each of his first seven seasons. The others are Barry Sanders (10) and Eric Dickerson (7).

title: Bare Bones in Albany
description: Gov. George Pataki and members of the Legislature, who should be working on a plan to respond to the economic downturn, are instead squabbling over who is to blame for state spending that went up this year at twice the inflation rate. Regular citizens may be curious about who the culprit is, too. The $84.3 billion budget for the current year was labeled ''bare bones'' by legislative leaders, who passed it as a stopgap measure last summer. Both the governor and the lawmakers seemed to feel that it was austere to the point of irresponsibility.

title: Italy Plans to Have Private Sector Run Museums
description: A law partially privatizing Italy's museums is expected to pass easily in Parliament here, where the pro-business, center-right coalition of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who is also the country's richest man, wins virtually every vote.

title: Rising Violence in the Mideast
description: The suicide bombings that rocked Israel over the weekend bring the Mideast conflict once again to the brink of conflagration. The current crisis is even more dangerous than previous flash points because these attacks suggest an internal rebellion among Palestinians that raises troubling questions about Yasir Arafat's capacity for continued leadership. The weekend's events threaten to undercut the Bush administration's most ambitious Mideast peace initiative just as it was getting off the ground. They also come at a sensitive moment in the war against terrorism, whose ultimate success depends on the cooperation of several Arab and Muslim nations. Nothing would play into Osama bin Laden's hands better than an unchecked escalation of violence in the Mideast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, MARY S.
description: McMAHON-Mary S. 87, of Rossmoor, on Friday, November 30, 2001. Sister of Eleanor G. McMahon. Funeral Tuesday, 9 AM, at A.S. Cole Funeral Home, 22 North Main Street, Cranbury, NJ. Mass 10 AM at Nativity of Our Lord R.C. Church, 185 Applegarth Road, Monroe Township. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. Calling Monday 3:30 until 6 PM, at the funeral home. Contributions to a charity of the donor's choice.

description: ''You're working on a story, aren't you, Father Greeley?'' one of my teenage water skiing companions complained.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Most states provide for the election of judges, and judicial candidates in many of those states face constraints on what they may say and do, designed to protect the appearance of judicial impartiality, that would clearly be unconstitutional for any other candidates.

title: Suitors Line Up to Compete For Cable TV Unit at AT&T
description: The story of AT&T's cable television unit begins a new chapter this evening, when bids are due from competing suitors for the unit, the nation's largest cable operation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drug-Trafficking Indictment
description: A trucking company and six of its officers and employees have been indicted on charges of conspiracy to distribute tons of marijuana by concealing it on tractor-trailers that were driven throughout the country. The company, Coleman Commercial Carriers, with offices in California and Maryland, transported the marijuana on behalf of drug-trafficking organizations from 1997 until last month, according to an indictment unsealed last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Drug Enforcement Administration agents have seized more than 8,000 pounds of marijuana from trucks operated by Coleman, according to the indictment. The company made $50 million on the operation, the indictment charged. Jane Fritsch (NYT)

title: Visa Starts Password Service to Fight Online Fraud
description: Something seems backward about the way that credit card companies have used the Internet. If you want to see your balance or pay your bill online, you will need to log on to the credit card company's site with a password. But to spend money on other sites, all you need is the card number itself, the same one available to anyone who finds a stray receipt or picks the wallet from your pocket.

description: Twenty years ago The New York Times ran a story out of Buenos Aires that mentioned a woman who was ''small and wiry and full of hate for the Argentine government.''

title: Deals, Debts And the Choice For Speaker In New Jersey
description: Surprises are a given in New Jersey politics, but few twists have been as unexpected as the selection of Mayor Albio Sires of West New York to be the next speaker of the General Assembly.

title: Path to Settling the Claims Will Be a Long One, Experts Say
description: Yesterday's bankruptcy filing by the Enron Corporation and 13 of its affiliates would rank as the largest in history, according to analysts who follow bankruptcy filings. The sheer size of the company, along with the complexity of its problems, could mean that it will take years before claims against the company are settled and creditors receive anything, these experts said.

title: Squeezing the Taliban, Seeking Compromise and a Fading Aid Lobby
description: Everything was moving into place for a final drive against Kandahar, the city in southern Afghanistan where the Taliban are taking what could be their last stand. ''Kind of like a snake,'' was the way an American intelligence officer described the squeeze being put on the city, as Afghan opposition forces approached from both the north and south, and United States troops gathered strength at a desert airstrip nearby. As if to echo the serpentine theme, more Cobra helicopter gunships kept arriving, carrying more troops, mostly marines. They were joined by liaison officers from allied nations, including Britain, Australia and Germany.

title: Low-Tar Duplicity
description: It is bad enough to learn that so-called low-tar and low-nicotine cigarettes are no better for your health than are regular cigarettes. It is even worse to find that tobacco companies have been marketing these brands as ''light,'' ''filtered'' or ''ultra-light'' -- implying that they might be less dangerous than ordinary cigarettes -- even while designing them so that addicted smokers can inhale just as much nicotine as they always have.

title: UConn and Maryland Reach Final
description: Connecticut and Maryland are two imperfect teams hoping to find themselves. Maryland is a collection of veterans coping with the expectations that followed its first Final Four appearance last season. Connecticut, in Coach Jim Calhoun's words, is merely trying to learn to compete in game situations.

title: Jokes Aside, It's the Hips That Do the Job
description: So just where is the engine that propels the perpetual motion machine named John Leguizamo? Early evidence indicated that it might be the rubbery, jittery organ he referred to as ''Mambo Mouth,'' the title of this comic actor's cultural self-portrait of 1991, or the hyperactive brain that peeked through his glittering, restless eyes in subsequent shows like ''Spic-O-Rama'' and ''Freak,'' his Broadway debut.

For every contending team, the road to the Super Bowl, if not to the playoffs, goes through the X-ray room more than it does through the 16-game schedule. Every contender's eventual success or failure often depends on which and how many of its best players are injured and unable to play.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition
description: The Mirant Corporation of Atlanta abandoned its effort to buy control of Bewag, Berlin's electric utility, and sold its 44.8 percent stake to Vattenfall of Sweden for $1.63 billion. The deal ends a takeover battle that began more than a year ago and will make Vattenfall the dominant electric company in eastern Germany. Vattenfall has already purchased VEAG, eastern Germany's main electric utility, and it will put that together with the Berlin company. Mirant, which bought a minority stake in Bewag several years ago, had tried without success to block Vattenfall from acquiring the shares from E.on, one of western Germany's biggest power companies. It then tried to negotiate a collaboration with Vattenfall, but talks broke down in September. Mirant executives said they had planned on buying out Vattenfall's stake in Bewag, but that Vattenfall surprised them with ''a price we could not refuse.''

His remark -- ''I don't understand it. I trust they know what they're doing'' -- was made in a brief interview at a dinner on Saturday for those being honored, not at the gala itself.

title: A Lyrical Power From Master Singers
description: Two veteran Wagnerians took over roles in the Metropolitan Opera's glorious and widely praised revival of Wagner's ''Meistersinger'' last Tuesday night. The radiant soprano Karita Mattila is the new Eva, a role she last sang at the Met in 1995. If anything, her performance this time is even richer. With her slender, blond beauty and her clear, rosy sound, she seems every bit a restless young woman, the daughter of the town goldsmith, nervously on the threshold of marriage. Yet when called for, she sings with cool, gleaming power, the quality in her voice that suggests there may be a Sieglinde or even an Isolde in her future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEGNER, GERHART, DR.
description: RIEGNER-Gerhart, Dr. The American Jewish Committee mourns the death of Dr. Gerhart M. Riegner, the former General Secretary of the World Jewish Congress. He is best remembered for his historic 1942 cablegram from Geneva that first alerted American religious and political leaders to the systematic mass murder of Jews in Europe. Stunned by the world's indifference to the Holocaust, Dr. Riegner became an extraordinary champion of universal human rights and a global leader in ChristianJewish relations. He was a trusted and beloved colleague of the AJC in so many significant efforts, especially within the International Jewish Committee for Interreligious Consultations, a group he helped establish in 1971. During his long and distinguished career that spanned nearly 70 years, Gerhart Riegner always remained an authentic original-erudite, vigorous and creative. We will miss his warmth, wisdom, and leadership. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Executive Director Rabbi David Rosen, Director, International Interreligious Affairs Rabbi A. James Rudin, Sr. Interreligious Affairs Adviser American Jewish Committee

What he has not done until this month is compete on the World Cup circuit, something generally expected of the world's top skiers.

title: Can Arafat Stop the Violence?
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, in response to three bloody attacks by Hamas over the weekend, has said Israel is engaged in a ''war against terror.'' Missiles fired early yesterday on the heliport of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestinian Authority, may have been just the first shots in this new war. Saeb Erakat, the authority's chief negotiator, said he believes Mr. Sharon has made simply ''a declaration of war.''

title: VALERO ENERGY AGREES TO SELL REFINERY
description: The Valero Energy Corporation agreed to sell a refinery in San Francisco to gain Federal Trade Commission approval for its $5.4 billion takeover of the Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation. Valero will sell the Golden Eagle Refinery in the San Francisco Bay area and 70 Beacon and Ultramar gasoline stations in Northern California, the company said. Ultramar bought the refinery from the Tosco Corporation for $950 million last year. Regulators are concerned that too few companies will control gasoline refining and sales in California.

title: Enron Causes 5 Major Japanese Money Market Funds to Plunge
description: Shares of five major money market funds in Japan have fallen below their face value because of extensive Enron holdings, and the stocks of the companies that manage the funds plunged today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Two New Ferry Routes
description: NY Waterway opened two new ferry routes between New Jersey and Manhattan yesterday, linking the Newport complex in Jersey City with West 38th Street and with the Battery. Travel during the service's first week is free, and more than 1,000 people used the two routes during yesterday's morning peak period, said Pat Smith, a company spokesman. Next week, service to 38th Street will cost $5 one way, and the trip to the Battery will cost $3. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

There has always been tension in the alliance, which was conceived more as an urban redevelopment project than as a joint artistic venture. If Lincoln Center had never been built and were being proposed today, the idea might well be rejected.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Militants Said To Plot Killings
description: An officer testifying in the military trial of 94 suspected Muslim militants said they had planned to assassinate a number of Egyptians and Americans, including President Hosni Mubarak. Human rights organizations have criticized the trial both because there is no appeal and because the charges of violent activity were added after Sept. 11, giving the appearance that the government was using the climate against terrorism to settle old scores. When cross-examined, the state security officer testifying about the alleged plot said he could not reveal secret sources. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Congress Pushes for School Reform
description: George W. Bush's promise to end ''the soft bigotry of low expectations'' that permits minority children to fall permanently behind at school seemed destined to go nowhere after Sept. 11. Even before then, the House and Senate appeared hopelessly tied up in bickering over the federal government's proper role in aiding local schools. But now the leaders of both parties have quietly reached tentative agreement on a ground-breaking bill that holds the states accountable as never before for rescuing failing schools and closing the achievement gap between rich and poor students. The only danger is that the federal government will deluge the schools with new mandates while providing too little money to get the job done.

title: A Private Bloomberg
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg did not have any public events last weekend, because he was not here. Unlike the mayors-elect before him, he did not release his travel schedule, and his staff yesterday would not say where he went, even though there was much speculation that he repaired to his estate on Bermuda, one of the many places where he has a home.

title: The Weaknesses Of Science For Profit
description: Last week Americans briefly diverted their eyes from Afghanistan to consider the announcement by a small New England biotechnology company that it had created human embryonic clones. President Bush expressed grave concern, and some members of Congress made renewed calls for legislation to ban the practice outright. One might think that a cloned human baby had been born.

title: Corrections

The comments were made by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and other officials, not by President Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIE, DAVID
description: BRODIE-David. A former steamship executive and a captain attached to The Office of Strategic Services during World War II, died after a long illness on November 24, 2001. He was 81 years old and a graduate of Colby College. Mr. Brodie was a friend to many, and a devoted member of ''The Greatest Generation.'' From his exploits in World War II, which included operating behind enemy lines as an intelligence officer, to the rescue of downed Army nurses and airmen in enemy-held territory, his patriotism and lust for life were indisputable. He was described by a commanding officer as someone who loved action and was completely qualified for difficult assignments, requiring skill, ingenuity, aggressiveness and personal courage. Mr. Brodie received five Bronze Battle Star commendations and is the holder of the Army's Legion of Merit Medal. He is survived by his sons, Edmond and Robert, his sister, Ruth Bendor, and his dear friend, Veronique Durnerin.

title: C.I.A. LEADER ASKS PAKISTAN FOR HELP IN BIN LADEN HUNT
description: George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, on a weekend visit here, sought tactical assistance for an assault on a mountain base in eastern Afghanistan where Osama bin Laden is suspected of hiding, government officials said today.

title: Israelis Attack Arafat's Compound and 7 Other Sites
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Dec. 4 -- In the most wide-ranging attack on Palestinian areas in 14 months of conflict, Israeli warplanes and helicopters bombarded security offices today in eight areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, killing at least two Palestinians and injuring scores.

title: John W. Collins, 89, Dies; Was Fischer's Chess Tutor
description: John William Collins, the top American chess teacher of the 20th century, whose students included Bobby Fischer, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 89 and lived in New York City.

title: Forests and Sprawl
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain's Vanishing Bears Have a Christopher Robin
description: They once roamed Europe as freely as buffalo roamed the American Plains. But today brown bears have almost vanished from most of Europe, depleted by hunting and the loss of habitat. Spain has fewer than 100, and in the Picos Mountains, in the north, the population has dwindled to about two dozen -- so few that wildlife conservationists have names for most of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SURRY, MARY
description: SURRY-Mary. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted mother of Sharon and Jeffrey Wallberg and June and Lester Wohl. Dear sister of William Cohen. Adored grandmother of Michelle and Jeff, David and Jen, Eric and Robyn, and Rachel. Cherished greatgrandmother of Robert, Julia and Jacob. For information, call ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' at 212-769-4400.

title: Attorney Says Tender Offer For Enron Is 'Off The Wall'
description: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones) - A private Illinois company that wants to take over Enron Corp. (ENE) is "off the wall" said a Chicago bankruptcy attorney Monday.

title: Neighbors Adding Bite to Criticism of Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 3  Officials in southern Africa, abandoning their muted rebukes of Zimbabwe, are increasingly raising their voices to criticize the government of President Robert Mugabe as his crackdown on opposition party members, journalists and white farmers widens.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau, New York, elected three executives to its board: Robert Bakish, chief operating officer for advertising sales at MTV Networks, New York, part of Viacom; Sonja Farrand, group vice president for advertising sales at OnMedia, Overland Park, Kan.; and Jon Spaet, president for advertising sales at USA Cable, New York, part of USA Networks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teachers Strike A Third Day
description: Lay teachers at 10 high schools run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York struck for a third school day yesterday as the teachers' union scheduled a rally with other unions in Midtown this morning. No talks with the archdiocese are scheduled. Only two high schools stayed open for the entire day yesterday, with the rest closing early for lack of teachers, some as early as 10 a.m., said Joseph Zwilling, the spokesman for the archdiocese. Henry Kielucki, business manager for the union, the Lay Faculty Association, said the number of striking teachers had grown to more than 300, up from 250 last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, KAREN
description: McLAUGHLIN-Karen. A valiant & loving woman. Vibrant, generous and kind. She loved her dogs and was beloved by her friends. Allan and Kendra

title: Hearing Opens On Contraction
description: A hearing on the players association's grievance against Major League Baseball's plan to eliminate two teams begins today in Dallas. The baseball owners are trying to drop 2 of 30 franchises, something the union has argued they cannot do. While the owners have not identified which teams they want to jettison, they are expected to be the Montreal Expos and the Minnesota Twins.

title: Economic Reports May Be Signs That Recovery Is on the Horizon
description: Consumer spending surged and construction unexpectedly rose in October, while manufacturing improved last month, according to data released today. The three reports signaled that the economy might be bouncing back from the recession, the first since 1991.

title: The Neediest Cases; Fewer Donors and Less Cash for Neediest Cases Fund
description: As the annual 90-day appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reached its 30th day yesterday, accountants reported that the fund had received $774,831 less than it had by the same point last year, a drop of 22 percent. They also reported that 2,069 people have given to the fund this year, 42 percent fewer donors than last year at the 30-day mark.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Judicial Candidates' Speech To Be Reviewed by Justices
description: Most states provide for the election of judges, and judicial candidates in many of those states face limits on what they may say and do that would clearly be unconstitutional for any other candidates.

title: Taliban Resists in Some Pockets North of Kabul
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  As the Americans marshaled their forces in the southern part of Afghanistan, the Pentagon today for the first time described several pockets of resistance in the north of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEERS, JOHN
description: STEERS-John. On December 2, 2001 in Greenwich, CT. Loving husband of Claudia Steers, father of Michael Steers, John C. Steers, Jr., Claudia M. Cutter, brother of Henry Steers, and Charles Robert Costa Steers, and six loving grandchildren. Calling hours Wednesday 4-8 P.M. Gallagher Funeral Home 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. Funeral will be held on Thursday at 10 A.M. at Sacred Heart Church, Byram, CT.

title: Fresh Look at a Fast Way to Kick a Heroin Habit
description: The patient strapped to the hospital gurney, breathing through a respirator, is James, a 40-year-old man addicted to heroin. The anesthesiologist loads a syringe with 20 milligrams of naloxone and slowly injects it into the IV in James's right arm. During the next 10 minutes, the drug will enter his system, pry off the billions of opiate molecules that have been clinging to his brain cells and wash them away.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Auto Sales Remain Strong As Incentives Are Reduced

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Pressure On The Legislature
description: Hoping to force lawmakers to release $23 million earmarked for ''clean elections,'' advocates took their case to the state's highest court. Dozens of candidates and organizations filed a lawsuit asking the Supreme Judicial Court to order the Legislature to make good on a law passed by referendum in 1998. The Legislature has not financed the law, which would make candidates who follow strict contribution guidelines eligible for public money. Court intervention, opponents say, would raise questions about the separation of powers. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: A Saudi Hospital Sues Over Tobacco
description: Saudi Arabia's main cancer hospital is seeking billions of dollars in compensation and damages from tobacco companies and their agents, the hospital announced today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Show Recovery
description: The trade association for the semiconductor industry said yesterday that sales of computer chips rose 2.5 percent, to $10.4 billion, in October, the fourth consecutive monthly increase. The Semiconductor Industry Association, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said that the chip industry was on track for 4.7 percent growth in the fourth quarter of this year. ''All geographic markets with the exception of Japan had sales increases in the period,'' said George Scalise, president of the group.

title: Osama bin Laden
description: The New York Times Gen. Muhammad Fahim, the new Afghan defense minister, said his government's sources indicated that Osama bin Laden had taken refuge in Tora Bora  a forbidding region of caves, tunnels, steep hills and hideouts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE
description: GOLDBERG-Rose. Beloved wife of George S. Devoted mother of Gary Goldberg and Deedee Friedman. Cherished grandmother of Michael and David Friedman. Loving sister of Harry Falik. Graveside services Tuesday, 10:30am, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: A Weekend of Terror in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Front Row
description: Found, a New Kate

title: Houston's Late Arrival Brings Victory to Knicks
description: Allan Houston was being embarrassed by the man who was his backup last season. Time after time, Glen Rice, playing as if he wanted to shame the Knicks for trading him, took Houston in the post, spun quickly and shot softly over his raised arms.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday with articles about the plight of the Enron Corporation, listing the biggest previous corporate bankruptcies, referred imprecisely to the asset sizes of the companies shown. The figures were adjusted for inflation. Unadjusted numbers appeared yesterday, in a chart with an article about Enron's bankruptcy filing.

title: When the Seeker of Revenge Becomes Its Victim
description: Murray Mednick packs a lot of ideas into the tiny Chashama Theater on West 42nd Street, where his play ''Mrs. Feuerstein'' is getting its East Coast premiere through Dec. 16.

title: Becoming A New Yorker In a Hurry; Vivendi's Chairman Seeks To Woo U.S. Investors
description: When the first jetliner crashed into the World Trade Center on the morning of Sept. 11, Jean-Marie Messier, chairman of Vivendi Universal, Europe's biggest media company, was the host at a typical New York power breakfast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARITA, LAURA MARIE
description: STARITA-Laura Marie. Daughter of the late Luigi and Antonina. Dear sister of Louis, Paul, Joseph, Regina and the late Rita Palermo and Victor. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Cusimano and Russo Funeral Home, 2005 West 6th St., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of the Resurrection Wednesday, 10 AM, St. Andrew's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting hours 2 to 5, 7 to 9.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Elec Sells Airline Business Unit
description: The Elec Communications Corporation, a provider of local and long-distance phone service, sold its Airline Ventures subsidiary to the unit's management for $500,000 in cash. Airline Ventures operates an Internet site that enables airline crew members to buy travel-related products.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Oliver Sacks; Character Forged By Periodic Table And Family Tree
description: Dr. Oliver Sacks is never still.

title: Doing Good Deeds, and Windows; Baptist Volunteers Clean Homes Near Ground Zero
description: John Gore swore that once he retired from his job as a traveling salesman, he would roam no longer. The pins on his hat say otherwise.

title: Asthma Risk Often Begins Before Birth
description: First-born children have been found to be more suspectible to asthma than younger brothers or sisters. A new study conducted on England's Isle of Wight suggests that this ''sibling effect'' may be put in place during pregnancy.

title: Karsay Could Be Bullpen's Missing Piece
description: George Steinbrenner would rather buy a new set of tires than patch a flat. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, is pursuing Jason Giambi because he is far and away the best American League hitter available, just as he pursued Mike Mussina last year because he was the best A.L. pitcher available.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: After Election, Eye On Beijing
description: Brimming with confidence after a victory in legislative elections over the weekend, President Chen Shui-bian renewed his plea for warmer relations with China. ''The mainland authorities looked down on me and the new government before the elections,'' Mr. Chen said, ''but I hope they can accept the choice of the Taiwan people.'' Mr. Chen did not signal any change in his refusal to recognize a single China governed by Beijing. China has not reacted to the vote, but the state-run China Daily said it would not ''drastically worsen'' relations. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALAY, IRVING ''PENNY''
description: PALAY-Irving ''Penny''. Died on December 3, 2001. Survived by his beloved wife Arlene Hochstat, his daughter Daryn Deodato-Almeida, and stepsons Michael and Jon Hochstat. ''Poppy'' of Samantha and Joshua Hochstat. Services Wednesday, December 5 at 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', West 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Merrill Lynch Picks New Strategy Chief
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has chosen Richard Bernstein, 43, to be its chief United States investment strategist, replacing Christine A. Callies, who was dismissed.

title: New Advice to Avoid More Back Pain
description: People with back pain try to protect their backs by changing the way they use their muscles -- but in doing so, they actually increase their risk of reinjury, a study conducted at Ohio State University says.

title: Yonkers Desegregation Plan Clears Hurdle in High Court
description: The United States Supreme Court refused to stop a court-ordered desegregation plan for Yonkers yesterday and in the process offered a reminder that after two decades the issues in the case still maintain a jagged emotional edge.

title: Vols Hold Key Spot In Pursuit Of Roses
description: The much-criticized Bowl Championship Series is on its face a deceit. There is no series to decide college football's top team, but rather one game played at rotating sites that preserves a bowl system that has been in place for decades.

title: Sports of The Times; Free-Agent Shoppers Dwindling
description: BARRY BONDS and Jason Giambi hit 111 home runs between them during the 2001 major league baseball season. They drove in 257 runs, pounding pitchers on opposite ends of the Bay Bridge, Bonds in San Francisco and Giambi in Oakland. At the plate, they were the best their respective leagues had to offer. They are charismatic stars, major box-office draws.

title: China Will Accept Soybeans From U.S.
description: China has agreed to import United States soybeans temporarily while it adopts new rules governing purchases of gene-altered crops, the United States trade representative's office said today.

title: Plenty of Pain to Go Around for Small Investors, Funds, Workers and Creditors
description: The list of investors who have lost money in Enron stock is a long one.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CUTS PRICE FOR TEXTRON DEAL
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation, a leading maker of automotive carpets, reduced the price of its acquisition of the car-trim business of Textron Inc. to $1.28 billion from $1.34 billion, citing ''changed economic circumstances.'' Collins & Aikman, which is 60 percent owned by Heartland Industrial Partners L.P., would about double its annual sales to about $3.9 billion with the Textron unit. The company is based in Troy, Mich.

title: HARTFORD FINANCIAL RENEWS CONTRACT WITH AARP
description: The Hartford Financial Services Group said yesterday that it had renewed its oldest and most lucrative contract in its sale of auto and home insurance through employers and membership groups: a deal with AARP, the organization of retired people. The deal has been yielding about $1.6 billion annually in insurance premiums. The arrangement, which began in 1984 and is to run for eight more years, provides discounts for AARP's 35 million members on auto and home insurance. The sales through AARP represent 62 percent of the Hartford's revenue for auto and home insurance. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Afghan Says Fighters Are Ready to Attack Cave Complex
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan, Dec. 3  An Afghan commander said tonight that 1,500 Pashtun fighters, accompanied by American Special Operations soldiers, were prepared to attack Tora Bora, the mountain cave complex where Osama bin Laden and 2,000 Al Qaeda fighters are believed to be hiding.

title: Hawaii Provides a Balm for Emotional Wounds
description: Like so many vacationers before them, 600 New Yorkers disembarked yesterday from their planes at Honolulu International Airport with the hope of easing their cares in the warm blue waters of the Pacific Ocean.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Trial For Communists
description: Five senior Communist-era officials went on trial, charged with masterminding a plan to force dissidents to flee the country in the late 1970's. A former interior minister, Jaromir Obzina, and four others are accused of ordering the secret police to use torture, beatings and psychological abuse against signers of the Charter 77 human rights appeal. The trial of two lower-ranking officers on charges of torture was postponed when a defendant did not appear. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bid To Curb Nuclear Plant Fails
description: The International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea rejected Ireland's request for an injunction to stop the expansion of the Sellafield nuclear processing site, on the west coast of Britain 60 miles from Dublin, but officials said they would continue their fight through other legal means. The ruling requires Britain to provide details of how it will monitor safety and environmental factors and to take additional precautions against polluting the Irish Sea. Environmentalists have long criticized the safety record at Sellafield, and Ireland fears that it could be a target for terrorist attacks. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan's Rating Raised
description: The ratings agency Moody's Investors Service raised the credit rating of the Nissan Motor Company to investment grade, rewarding the company, Japan's third-largest automaker, for cutting its debts. Nissan's credit is now rated Baa3, the lowest above junk status. Nissan's outstanding debt on Sept. 30 was 799 billion yen ($6.4 billion), down 16 percent from six months earlier. The company plans to slice another 6 percent off its debt in the half year that ends in March 2002. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Despite Ills, Automakers Report Solid Sales for November
description: Auto sales remained strong for much of November but began to slow after Thanksgiving, when the Big Three automakers started to restrict their interest-free financing offers. Still, the nation's auto industry remains on pace for what should be at least the third- or possibly the second-biggest sales year ever.

title: New Jersey Teachers Jailed for Continuing to Strike
description: A New Jersey judge sent four schoolteachers to jail today for disobeying a return-to-work order, the first time in more than two decades that striking teachers in the state have been incarcerated.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Notre Dame Loses Its Golden Halo
description: The Notre Dame mystique is dead. Its passing has little to do with the stormy tenure of the fired Bob Davie or the games his teams did not win in the past five years. No, the last rites on the special standing that the Fighting Irish's national fan base believes makes its football preternatural were performed by the university's athletic director, Kevin White, on Sunday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen weakened with Japanese stocks on concern that Enron's bankruptcy filing would hurt banks and other finance companies. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.03 yen, up from 123.20 on Friday.

title: Italy Seeks Al Qaeda Links
description: The Italian police searched a dozen companies in Northern Italy today, looking for evidence that they might be financing Osama bin Laden's terror network, Al Qaeda.

title: A Weekend of Terror in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Holiday Sales Rise 29%
description: Internet sales rose 29 percent in the first two weeks of the holiday season, helped by price cuts and free shipping, analysts said yesterday. Sales from Nov. 19 through Dec. 2 totaled $2.13 billion, up from $1.65 billion for the corresponding period last year, according to BizRate.com, which tracks transactions at 2,000 online merchants. Shoppers placed 16.3 million orders at Internet stores, buying mainly electronics, toys and computer hardware, the company said. Many stores are offering free shipping, including Amazon.com, the largest Internet retailer. The company, which is based in Seattle, is selling an Apex DVD player that had been priced at $119.95 for $99.99. JCPenney.com is advertising 25 percent off regular prices for clothing and shoes. BizRate.com is forecasting online sales will rise 31 percent in the six-week holiday sales period.

title: Mayor Submits $766 Million In Cuts to Balance City Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a $1.3 billion modification to the city's budget yesterday that included $766 million in cuts to various city agencies. The mayor had called for 15 percent cuts from almost all the agencies -- save uniformed forces and the Board of Education -- in October, citing a large budget gap caused largely by the terrorist attack in September.

title: For People With Hearing Loss, Some Holiday Gift Ideas That Offer Utility and Education
description: Make the holidays happy ones for those on your gift list who may be hard of hearing. Advocates for Better Communication, a volunteer consumer group allied with the League for the Hard of Hearing (71 West 23rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10010, 917-305-7770, TTY 917-305-7999, fax 917-305-7888), recommends the following:

title: Sent Home To Sit and Wait By the Phone
description: Carrying boxes packed hastily in the few minutes before police escorts started shepherding them into elevators, about 4,000 employees who had been summarily dismissed from the Enron Corporation streamed out of the company's two sparkling office buildings here today.

title: Draining a Hazardous Coolant Takes Caution, and a Long Hose
description: Work crews at the World Trade Center this week intend to undertake one of the most delicate and potentially hazardous assignments to date: removing an estimated 8,000 pounds of a chemical that once helped cool the air in the giant office towers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, BERNARD
description: ROSENBERG-Bernard. Temple Beth Sholom, of Roslyn Heights, New York mourns the passing of our beloved member, Bernard Rosenberg. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Rita, and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Rose Schecter, President

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''A war has been forced upon us, a war of terror.''

title: Bush Freezes Assets of Biggest U.S. Muslim Charity
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Bush significantly broadened his counterattack on terrorist groups today, freezing the assets of the largest Muslim charity in the United States. Mr. Bush accused the charity of supporting Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that took responsibility for three suicide bombings in Israel over the weekend.

title: Agreements on 2 Mergers In Biotechnology Industry
description: MedImmune agreed yesterday to acquire Aviron for about $1.5 billion in stock, taking a gamble that it can win approval of Aviron's groundbreaking flu vaccine, which is sprayed into the nose rather than injected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, SAM
description: LANDAU-Sam. Passed away December 1, 2001. He was the devoted husband of Caroline Landau. Beloved father of Dr. Karen Landau and loving grandfather of Lily Simone Landau. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Children's Museum of NYC.

title: Endeavour Is Set for Launching After Docking Problem Is Solved
description: The space shuttle Endeavour was approved today for a Tuesday launching to the International Space Station after two Russian astronauts cleared a jammed docking port during a spacewalk there.

title: Afghans Negotiating Makeup of New, Interim Government
description: BONN, Dec. 4  Afghan delegates negotiated late this evening over the composition of a new, interim government for Afghanistan, tentatively scheduled to take power in Kabul on Dec. 22, diplomats and delegates said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertising Concern Lowers Outlook
description: The Cordiant Communications Group, the British advertising company, lowered its forecast for 2001 sales for the second time in two months. The company, whose clients include Singapore Airlines and which owns the Bates Worldwide agency, said it would cut 1,100 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force. Full-year revenue is now expected to fall 9 percent, to about 467 million ($665 million). Cordiant, like other advertising agencies, is suffering as clients cut advertising spending, in part, because of an economic downturn made worse by the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: PGA Tour Has Courses For High School Junior
description: At 17 years old, facing the pressure of one of golf's most dreaded tournaments, Ty Tryon became the youngest player to earn a PGA Tour card, shooting a six-under-par 66 today during the final round of the Tour's qualifying tournament. It was an uncanny performance for someone too young to rent a car, too young to drink alcohol legally, but too confident and too determined to believe his dream would not come true.

title: Wounded Buildings Offer Survival Lessons
description: At some indefinable hour during an interminable night, the fires that had raged for nearly two days in the skyscraper at 90 West Street still puffed and flared when Derek Trelstad, a structural engineer, walked into the building and cautiously began climbing the stairs, the double snout of his respirator wheezing in the haze.

title: Liberty Media Increases Stake In European Cable TV Operator
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, the cable TV company run by the billionaire John C. Malone, has raised its stake in UnitedGlobalCom Inc., Europe's second-largest cable operator.

title: And the Winners in the Case Are . . .
description: The biggest corporate bankruptcy filing in American history may also be the biggest payday ever for American bankruptcy lawyers.

description: Senate Spurns Cloning Ban

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Raped At Store
description: A 36-year-old woman was raped at gunpoint in a children's clothing store on the Upper East Side early yesterday afternoon, the police said. The rapist also stole an undetermined amount of money before fleeing the store, the Baby Collection on Lexington Avenue near 91st Street. The woman was taken to New York Presbyterian Hospital for treatment and was released. ''I've never heard of this kind of thing happening around here,'' said Diann Williams, 48, who lives nearby and has bought clothing at the store. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Our Civil Liberties at a Time of Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost in New York, Rice Is Trying to Find His Game in Houston
description: Last week, when the Houston Rockets' two leading scorers were out with injuries and the opportunity was ripe for Glen Rice to turn back the clock and score 30, he missed 7 of 10 shots and clanked a 3-pointer off the side of the backboard.

title: Millions of Afghan Children, and No Ideas About Their Future
description: His face was dirty and his pants, cinched tight with rope, were several inches too wide in the waist. His rubber boots looked twice the size of his feet. He is 8 years old and has never been to school. He reached into his sweater, pulled out a few pages of Arabic script and began to read.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Search In Murder Case
description: Detectives searched past and present residences of Gary Leon Ridgway, left, who was arrested last week in connection with the Green River murders, the nation's largest unsolved serial killer case. Sheriff Dave Reichert of King County said Mr. Ridgway, 52, was suspected in the deaths of 4 of the 49 women who disappeared in the early 1980's. More than 50 investigators searched Mr. Ridgway's Auburn residence and two other previous homes. Mr. Ridgway is being held without bail in the King County Jail, and prosecutors have until Wednesday to file charges. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: 4 Factions Approve New Setup
description: The four Afghan factions agreed early this morning on a text setting out the responsibilities, shape and timetable of an interim post-Taliban administration for Afghanistan and the path toward a more permanent government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCH, RABBI NATHAN
description: BARUCH-Rabbi Nathan. We mourn the passing of our beloved husband, father and grandfather. He established the VAAD, Hatzala Organization in Germany. He worked tirelessly saving Holocaust survivors and helping them start a new life. His legendary efforts on behalf of Torah continued for decades. Shiva being observed in Long Beach, NY, until Wednesday. Baruch, Ehrlich, Pfeffer Families

title: The Big City; Better Leave The Marching To Marxists
description: A NEWS release last week announced that a group of New Yorkers would be marching up Fifth Avenue on Sunday to celebrate the first Capitalism Day, part of a global rally in more than 100 cities. In the wake of Sept. 11, the organizers explained, ''we need to defend the values and economic systems that have produced untold wealth for the Western world and are now under attack.''

title: New Plan Announced For Area of Rockaways
description: Almost four decades after the city razed the last crumbling summer bungalows in the Arverne section of the Rockaways, officials yesterday announced a new plan to develop a large portion of the 300 acres of vacant beachfront property in that Queens neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITLOW, IDA
description: GITLOW-Ida. On December 1, 2001 in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late Max, loving mother of Blanche Shapiro, and her husband, Sherwyn, and Stanley Gitlow, grandmother and great grandmother.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Fly's Breathing Engine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORT, EVELYN
description: PORT-Evelyn. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Joel Carlson, 75, Lawyer Who Fought Apartheid in 50's
description: Joel Carlson, a white South African lawyer who used spectacular political trials to battle apartheid and expose its practices of secret detention and torture, died on Nov. 25 at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Nortel To Supply Chinese Company
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, the world's third-largest maker of wireless-networking equipment, has agreed to supply about $78 million of equipment and software to the China Mobile Communications Corporation. Nortel said it planned to help China Mobile, the country's biggest cellular phone company, expand its network in several areas, including the Xinjiang region. Nortel's network software and system upgrades will allow China Mobile to manage more customers, company officials said. Nortel, which is based in Canada and provides services in more than 150 countries, said it had secured contracts this year worth more than $1.2 billion with companies in China. Its shares fell 33 cents to $7.47.

title: Miscellany
description: * Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago, part of the Bcom3 Group, is ending its affiliation with Reuveni Pridan, Tel Aviv, because, Burnett said in a statement, it was ''not prepared to further invest in the Israeli market at this stage.'' Reuveni Pridan is negotiating with the Interpublic Group of Companies to become affiliated with an Interpublic agency. Reuveni Pridan will continue working with Burnett clients like Philip Morris and Procter & Gamble until Burnett finds another Israeli affiliate.

description: BASEBALL

title: Arabs Say It Was Israel That Set Off Cycle of Violence
description: Even before Israel began its offensive against Palestinian targets tonight, Arab commentators were labeling Israel less as a victim than a provocateur in last weekend's terrorist attacks, and were calling on the United States to hold Israel accountable for the policies they said had ignited the violence.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about a delay in decisions about grants from the National Endowment for the Arts for a play and an art exhibition misspelled the name of the affected artist. He is William Pope.L, not Pope.

title: The 'Joe Torre' of River Vale, a Matriarch, a Man Who Lived a Lesson
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Microsoft Is Resisting Licensing Of Its Code
description: Microsoft is trying to head off demands that it give rivals licenses to use the basic code of its Windows operating systems as a way of settling antitrust action against it in Europe.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State Revenue
description: James E. McGreevey, below, the governor-elect and a Democrat, once again called for a formal certification of state revenue yesterday, and once again Donald T. DiFrancesco, the acting governor and a Republican, declined to provide it. A spokesman for Mr. DiFrancesco, Tom Wilson, said the revenue data available was too old and unreliable for a formal accounting. Mr. Wilson said a hiring freeze and newly found savings would help balance the budget. Mr. DiFrancesco has said he expects the $23 billion budget to be balanced when he leaves office. But Clifford Goldman, an adviser to Mr. McGreevey and a former state treasurer, said, ''There's money going out the door every day.'' Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Abroad at Home; Dust in Our Eyes
description: President Bush's order establishing military tribunals has a particular distinction apart from its impact on American traditions of justice. For a presidential directive of such profound importance, it is extraordinarily ill drafted.

title: Technocrats In Kabul Try To Rebuild
description: Burhanuddin Rabbani, the country's last recognized president, prepared for a news conference the other day as an aide nailed the green, white and black flag for his Islamic State of Afghanistan to the podium with a rock.

title: Venezuela's New Oil Law Is Seen as a Risk to Growth
description: A sweeping law signed last month by the left-leaning government of President Hugo Chvez could put a damper on foreign investment for increasing oil production just as the United States' market for Venezuelan oil seemed about to expand, oil analysts and economists say.

title: New Contenders For a Theory Of Everything
description: In science's great chain of being, the particle physicists place themselves with the angels, looking down from the heavenly spheres on the chemists, biologists, geologists, meteorologists -- those who are applying, not discovering, nature's most fundamental laws. Everything, after all, is made from subatomic particles. Once you have a concise theory explaining how they work, the rest should just be filigree.

title: Two Boxing Fans Sure They're Doing the Right Thing
description: At first sight they made an odd pair, the iconoclastic filmmaker Spike Lee and the white-haired scion of old Hollywood the screenwriter Budd Schulberg. The two were at Vassar College here to discuss their collaboration on a film about the boxer Joe Louis, and the more they spoke about their project, the more it seemed utterly fated.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Economic Stimulus Bill
description: Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders agreed on a procedure for negotiating an economic stimulus bill and said they would try to begin working on a compromise today. The parties have been deadlocked for weeks over the measure, with Republicans insisting on tax cuts for businesses and individuals and Democrats demanding increased aid to the unemployed and low-income workers. With the economy in recession, Congress is likely to have to consider raising the federal debt limit next year, an indication that plans to reduce the national debt could fall victim to the downturn. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, ESTHER M.
description: O'CONNELL-Esther M. December 2, 2001. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, St. Paul's Church, 10AM, Kings St., Greenwich, CT. Calling hours 5-7 PM, Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street Greenwich, CT.

title: Needless Silence for Hearing Impaired
description: Cindy Brody, my sister-in-law, was only 40 when she realized that something bad was happening to her ability to hear. Telephone conversations were a challenge and there were lots of misunderstandings even during one-on-one conversations, including those with her husband at the dinner table.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BONHAM, WILLIAM R.
description: BONHAM-William R. 1921-1987, Sorry I'm late. Thrown off course by WTC tragedy. Times my street closed. Still love you. Think of you every day. Mo

title: U.S. Is Said To Criticize Music Industry On Marketing
description: Recording companies have not done enough to promote warnings and curb advertising of inappropriate material in magazines and on television shows intended for young audiences, according to a Federal Trade Commission study to be released this week, industry executives and Congressional aides said today.

title: Riyadh Journal; An Ambassador's Journey From Rome to Mecca
description: For weeks now, Saudi Arabia has been on the defensive, tarred in the Western press as complicit in terrorism, portrayed as the proselytizer of Islam's least tolerant version, denounced for giving rise not just to Osama bin Laden but also to 15 of the 19 hijackers on Sept. 11.

description: NEW JERSEY
