description: To the Editor:

title: A Changed Police Department Awaits Kelly in Second Turn
description: When he returns for a second stint as commissioner on Jan. 1, Raymond W. Kelly will find a Police Department filled with old friends, a familiar office and a force so in vogue its fans wear N.Y.P.D. caps.

title: Tough Draws For Region's 3 Cup Teams
description: The coaches of Mexico and Costa Rica are lamenting their chances of advancing in the World Cup next year in Japan and South Korea, but they know the United States, the other qualifier from their region, has an even more difficult draw in a group with Portugal, Poland and South Korea.

title: U.S. to Block Assets It Says Help Finance Hamas Killers
description: Responding to the weekend's suicide bombings in Israel, President Bush is to announce on Tuesday the freezing of assets of a leading Islamic foundation in the United States and two other financial groups. The groups help finance the militant Palestinian organization Hamas, administration officials said.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Dealing with Threats

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUNG, CHING H.
description: LEUNG-Ching H., 66, of Mahwah, NJ died suddenly of heart complications on December 1, 2001. Beloved husband of almost 36 years to Clara (Wong). Loving father of Peter of Singpore, Joseph of NYC and Thomas of Boston. Devoted brother of Ching Por Leung, Ching Cham Leung, Ching Sang Leung, Ching Ho Leung and Ivy Yuen. For eleven years, Ching inspired hundreds of students to practice and love the art of Tai Chi Chuan at the Ramsey and Midland Park Community Schools. He was a member of the Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, NJ. He was also an alumnus of the Tai Chi Chuan Club of NY and a recent participant in the Garden Club of Manhattan. Mr. Leung was a member of the Royal Institute of Structural Engineers of London, UK and the Professional Engineers Society of NY and NJ. He was an honors graduate of the National University of Taiwan where he received his bachelor's degree in engineering. He also earned a master's degree in applied science from the University of Toronto and a master's in civil engineering from the University of Birmingham, UK. In 1967, he designed Hong Kong's first Cross Harbor Tunnel as well as Hong Kong's longest suspension bridge. He immigrated to the US in 1971 and joined DeLeuw Cather Engineering where he assisted with the design of the 2nd Avenue Subway Project in Manhattan. For the past twenty years, Ching was Senior Structural Engineer at STV Group in New York. At STV, he was in the design team of projects such as the Light Rail System at JFK International Airport, the Eastside Access project, and the new West Point Military Academy Library and Football Stadium. Friends and family will be received on Thursday, December 6th from 2-4 and 79 PM at Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey, NJ. A Funeral Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Friday, December 7th at 10 AM at the Church of the Presentation, 271 W. Saddle River Rd., Upper Saddle River, NJ 07458. Interment at Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY. The family can be reached at 201-818-9888. For information, contact the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey, NJ 07446. For directions, contact 201327-0032.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Company Continues Network Upgrade
description: Cingular Wireless reaffirmed yesterday that it would acquire gear from three European communications equipment companies as it proceeds with an upgrade of its nationwide wireless network, although its estimates for the contracts were less than those reported in Europe. Cingular, which is based in Atlanta and owned by SBC Communications and the BellSouth Corporation, said its contracts might total more than $1 billion each for Ericsson and Nokia, while the contract with Siemens is estimated in excess of $500 million. Clay Owen, a Cingular spokesman, said the upgrade might cost $2.6 billion to $2.8 billion but not as much as the $4 billion cited in some reports.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Hungry for Publicity

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about the arrest of Robert A. Durst, an heir to a Manhattan real estate fortune who is charged with murder in Texas, misspelled the surname of the investigating officer at the Colonial Regional Police Department in Pennsylvania, near the arrest scene. He is Officer Dean Benner, not Brenner.

title: Share a Taxi? Sure, and Bring the Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUXENBERG, HERBERT
description: LUXENBERG-Herbert. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) deeply mourn the loss of Herbert Luxenberg of Cleveland, a generous and dedicated leader of the ATS. Chair and immediate past president of the Cleveland Chapter, Herbert, along with his wife Mickey, demonstrated their deep commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel by attaining the rank of Technion Guardians. They established the Herbert and Marianna Luxenberg Academic Chair in the William Davidson Faculty of Industrial Engineering and Management, and helped fund numerous regional projects initiated under Herbert's leadership such as the Cleveland Creative Design Student Laboratory Fund; Northern Ohio Chapter Mathematics Incubator Fund; and the Elton B. Katz SelfStudy Multimedia Library, part of the Luxenberg Center for Self-Study in the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mickey and the Luxenbergs children, brothers Leonard and Norman, and the entire Luxenberg family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Evelyn Berger, President Lawrence S. Jackier Chair, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Morris Rochlin Chair, Detroit Chapter Nancy Gad-Harf, Director East Central Region

description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,533 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANG, DAVID P.C.
description: CHANG-David P.C., died, Friday, November 30, 2001 at Cornell Weill Medical Center of complications from heart surgery. He is the husband of Lorna Mickle Chang, father of Pamela, Christopher, David, and Jennifer, sister of Yi An Rosita Chou. David and Lorna live in East Barnard, VT.

title: Teenager to Plead Guilty as Accomplice in Dartmouth Killings
description: The younger of the two Vermont teenagers accused in the stabbing deaths of two Dartmouth College professors has struck a deal to plead guilty to a charge that he acted as an accomplice.

title: Judge Refuses to Permit Ex-Radical to Reverse Plea
description: In angry and at times sarcastic terms, a California judge today rejected Sara Jane Olson's efforts to withdraw her guilty plea to charges that she participated in a plot to bomb two police cars here 26 years ago as a member of a self-styled revolutionary group, the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: F.B.I. Creates New Management Structure for Better Oversight
description: Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the F.B.I., said today that he was reorganizing the bureau in an effort to fix embarrassing administrative problems and strengthen its ability to deter terrorist attacks.

title: High Court Considers What's 'Reasonable' in Disabilities Act
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  In the second of three cases it will decide this term under the Americans With Disabilities Act, the United States Supreme Court wrestled today with the meaning of the "reasonable accommodation" that the law obliges employers to offer to workers who could not otherwise remain on the job.

title: Zeroing In on a Lie's Home Base
description: Researchers have identified a specific spot in the brain that handles the task of telling a lie, raising the possibility of using brain scans to create a more accurate lie detector test.

title: In the Remains of Grozny, the Remains of Living
description: In a city where virtually every building has been bombed, burned, shelled beyond recognition or simply obliterated by war, a spanking new edifice has risen downtown. An immaculate stucco tower set between bookends of shattered brick, it is the headquarters of Grozenergo, Grozny's electric company.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: 'Ruthless' Pursuit Of Embezzlers
description: The government has banned 100 corporate and bank officials from leaving the country as it investigates embezzlement of more than $5 billion pumped into ailing companies. The National Tax Service also said it was investigating tax evasion by company executives. President Kim Dae Jung promised ''ruthless measures'' against those who stole taxpayers' money after having driven their companies into bankruptcy. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, LOUISE STEINHART
description: LOEB-Louise Steinhart. Died on Saturday, December 1, 2001, at age 86. Widow of Henry A. Loeb (who died in 1998). Survived by her children Jean and Raymond Troubh and Betty and John Levin, her seven grandchildren, her 14 great-grandchildren. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Child Development Center of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57 Street, New York, New York 10019, attn: Jane Berenbein; or to Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, attn: Alvin Teirstein, M.D., Director of Richenthal Institute.

title: H.M.O.'s Flee Medicare Despite Rise In Payments
description: The federal policy of increasing payments to health maintenance organizations in the hope of persuading them to stay in the Medicare program has largely been a failure, federal investigators said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSCHWEIGER, RICHARD
description: BRAUNSCHWEIGER-Richard of Katonah, NY, age 47 on December 2, 2001, after a courageous battle with Cancer. Vice President of Credit Agricole Indosuez Chevreux Securities. Beloved husband of Lorna (Lenley). Loving father of Matthew, Julie and Dana. Cherished son of Gretchen and Herbert Braunschweiger. Devoted brother of Carl Braunschweiger (Joan) and Gretchen King (James). Dear brother-in-law of Susan and Max Kooper. Caring uncle of Emma, Elyse, Eric and Erin Braunschweiger, August and Aiden King and Jay and Keith Kooper. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St Wednesday December 5th, 11:30am. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NYC 10021. Fund #

title: Jets' Second-Half Plan Was Not the Answer
description: From Aaron Glenn's knee injury, to the offensive lineman who blocked Vinny Testaverde's view of Curtis Martin on the critical fourth-down play, to dropping to a game behind the Dolphins in the division, the Jets' loss to the Patriots could hardly be laden with more regrets.

title: Taliban Resists in Some Pockets North of Kabul
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  As the Americans marshaled their forces in the southern part of Afghanistan, the Pentagon today for the first time described several pockets of resistance in the north of the country.

title: Views on Curbs on Freedoms Range From Qualified Support to Outrage
description: In this conservative waterside town, people go along with letting President Bush relax some constitutional freedoms in a period of terrorist threats. But just about everyone draws a line somewhere, and most often it involves investigators' eavesdropping on suspects talking to their lawyers.

title: A Niche Brewer Is Making Waves
description: When South African Breweries tore down a 100-year-old bottling plant on South Africa's eastern coast two years ago to make way for a new one, it was perfecting a blueprint for expanding into other risky but fast-growing emerging markets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, JOHN
description: ROBERTS-John. A memorial service will be held for John Roberts on Tuesday, December 11, 2:30 PM at Rodeph Sholom Congregation, 7 West 83rd Street, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page picture caption on Saturday about American marines who were fortifying their base in southern Afghanistan misattributed statements from Washington that it was too soon to send international peacekeepers to Afghanistan. The comments were made by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and other officials, not by President Bush.

title: FRIENDLY ICE CREAM SAYS DEBT PLAN IS STALLED
description: The Friendly Ice Cream Corporation, an ice cream maker and restaurant chain, said a plan to obtain new loans and buy back bonds had stalled. Friendly's shares fell 28 percent after the company said it was unsuccessful in obtaining $35 million in loans to lower interest expenses. The company also raised its offering price in an attempt to buy back debt due Dec. 1, 2007, and extended the offer for a second time after failing to attract enough sellers. Shares of Friendly, based in Wilbraham, Mass., fell 90 cents, to $2.30.

title: So Lucky To Give Birth In England
description: I gave birth to one child in England and three more in the United States. And when friends ask me about my overseas birthing experience, I tell them I was lucky to be in London the first time around.

title: DANA PUTS COST OF REALIGNMENT AT $445 MILLION
description: The Dana Corporation, a leading maker of axles for light trucks, said yesterday that it expected about $445 million in after-tax costs as a result of the elimination of 11,250 jobs and the closing or combination of more than 30 plants and offices worldwide. About 65 percent of the expenses will be recorded this quarter, a spokesman, Gary Corrigan, said. Dana reduced its dividend this year to 1 cent a share from 31 cents, the first cut since 1936, to save $178 million a year. Noncash expenses for the reorganization will amount to about 35 percent of the $445 million, Dana said.

title: U.S. Marines Probing Deeper Into Taliban-Controlled Areas
description: WITH MARINE TASK FORCE 58, in Southern Afghanistan, Dec. 4  Having established significant firepower on the ground here, American marines are now probing deeper toward the chaotic swaths of territory still under control of the Taliban, military spokesmen here said today.

title: Herald Tribune Executive
description: Donald E. Graham, chairman and chief executive of the Washington Post Company, has been named to the additional post of co-chairman at The International Herald Tribune, which is jointly owned by his company and The New York Times Company. He succeeds his mother, Katharine Graham, who died in July. The other chairman at The International Herald Tribune is Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman emeritus of the Times Company.

title: Paintings Too Perfect? The Great Optics Debate
description: It started personal and it stayed personal. Three years ago the artist David Hockney realized that he could not draw like Ingres. Worse yet, he thought that Andy Warhol could. Warhol's drawings were confident, quick and correct. They had the cool assurance of a photograph. The reason was clear: Warhol made his drawings by tracing photographs.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Less Money For Schools
description: The state's school construction program is expected to run out of money next year. The state has provided $2.1 billion in financing for school construction since legislators authorized the program in 1997. About 185 school districts are on a waiting list for grants that would total $900 million, but only $70 million remains in the program budget. Gov. George H. Ryan, who cut more than $450 million from the state budget last week, has not said whether he will seek more construction money in the next budget. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: A Siegfried Who Takes The Dragon In Stride
description: ''Siegfried,'' it is clear in retrospect, was the wrong place to make first acquaintance with Robert Wilson's emerging production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle at the Zurich Opera House.

title: Two leading forecasters say spending will remain low for another year but will not get any worse.
description: REMEMBER the old jingle for Alka-Seltzer promising that ''relief is just a swallow away?'' Well, two leading forecasters of advertising spending warned Madison Avenue yesterday that much gulping would be required before a turnaround slowly begins.

title: Brazilian Author Takes a Second Shot at Immortality
description: When Jorge Amado, Brazil's most acclaimed novelist, died in August at 88, the accolades and the reminiscences had not even ended before the literary establishment and the gossip columnists here began to speculate about a related and equally solemn matter. Who would succeed him as an ''immortal'' in the Brazilian Academy of Letters? Brazilians are not a people especially fond of reading, but polls indicate that the academy is the country's most esteemed cultural institution. The vote is on Friday.

title: George Harrison's Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Far West Village, a Bleecker Street Makeover
description: In the annals of New York real estate at the turn of this century, the name Oliver Dow could go down on a list of the very well-fated. Two years ago, Mr. Dow and his wife were looking for a new home when they came across a building on the corner of Bleecker and West 11th Streets, a few feet away from the Magnolia Bakery. Assuming he could bring a shopkeeper to the ground floor, Mr. Dow figured he would be able to afford to buy the building without having to subsist on cornmeal.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Fewer Patronage Jobs
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift vowed to stop patronage jobs at the Massachusetts Port Authority and follow an independent commission's other recommendations to overhaul the agency. The commission began looking into Massport, which runs Logan International Airport, after two airplanes that originated in Boston were crashed into the World Trade Center towers on Sept. 11. The steps, some of which must be approved by the Legislature, include scrutinizing political hires for the appropriate qualifications. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Social Security Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Need To Help Themselves
description: Even though the Devils beat Detroit, which has the N.H.L.'s best record, in their last game, Coach Larry Robinson and several players said today that the team's next two games, against Tampa Bay on Tuesday and in Montreal on Wednesday, would show whether Saturday's victory was a fluke.

title: Officials Suspect 4 Recent New Jersey Fires Were Arson
description: The worst of the fires began raging at 3:52 a.m., long after the bars had emptied and most residents had gone to bed. In 45 minutes, three of the fires, all within a few blocks of one another, had left more than 100 people homeless, many of them struggling immigrants, and destroyed half a dozen businesses, all of them small mainstays of Summit Avenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Car Sales Decline
description: New-car sales in Japan fell 9.3 percent in November from the month a year ago, the third consecutive decline. With wages and jobs disappearing, consumers are spending less on big-ticket items, including new homes, electronics and autos. That spells trouble for Japan's economy, half of which is driven by personal spending. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Putin Shakes Up Russian Navy After Receiving Report on Sub
description: Russia's navy was said to be reeling today after President Vladimir V. Putin moved over the weekend to fire or punish 14 of its high-ranking officers for ''serious shortcomings'' in training and daily duties.

title: Hobbled Enron Tries to Stay On Its Feet
description: The Enron Corporation dismissed 4,000 employees and lined up $1.5 billion in financing yesterday to keep its main businesses on life support while it reorganizes in bankruptcy court.

title: 2 Rival Chip Makers Consider Joining Forces
description: Two archrivals in the chip-making business, Hynix Semiconductor and Micron Technology, have begun negotiations on a strategic alliance that the chief executive of Hynix, Park Chong Sup, predicted today would ''change the landscape of the chip industry.''

title: A U.S. Convert's Path From Suburbia to a Gory Jail for Taliban
description: John Walker Lindh's parents knew he was a different sort of boy.

title: Sehorn Seeing Downside Of Stardom
description: Jason Sehorn is well aware the sheen is off his star.

title: 5,000 Jet-Engine Machinists End Talks and Begin a Strike
description: More than 5,000 machinists at Pratt & Whitney walked off the job today here and at three other plants in Connecticut, after rejecting a contract proposal that they say offered increased pay but not job security. It is the first strike of this magnitude in more than 40 years at Pratt, which makes half of the jet engines in the Western world.

title: A Weekend of Terror in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortgage Delinquency Rate Hits 10-Year High
description: The percentage of homeowners behind on mortgages in the third quarter rose to the highest level in 10 years as layoffs and a shrinking economy left more families short of cash.

title: Spy Wanted. Must Know Hollywood.
description: On the new television series about the Central Intelligence Agency -- ''The Agency,'' ''24,'' ''Alias'' -- the spies are so clever that it seems that America's espionage forces should be sent to Hollywood as part of their training.

title: A Weekend of Terror in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for a Japanese Empress
description: The women's rights movement has not devoted much time to the issue of whether little girls should have the chance to grow up to be emperor. But the question came up this week in Japan, when Emperor Akihito's eldest son and daughter-in-law gave birth to their first child, a girl. Current law bars her from rising to the Chrysanthemum Throne. Although her situation is, to say the least, unique, changing the law would send a positive message to all Japanese women. The rest of the world would welcome it as well.

title: Our Civil Liberties At a Time of Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Says U.S. Believes bin Laden Is Still in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that even though Afghanistan is a country with "long, porous borders," American military experts think Osama bin Laden is still in the country.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Cable Companies Sign On For Excite@Home Service
description: Excite@Home signed an agreement yesterday afternoon with a group of cable companies, including the Comcast Corporation and Cox Communications, to maintain high-speed Internet access for their customers.

title: Franco Has Surgery; May Miss Opening Day
description: The final pitch John Franco threw last season ended up in the left-field bleachers at Turner Field in Atlanta. Brian Jordan's home run on Sept. 29 effectively ended the Mets' playoff hopes, and it also marked the end of Franco's pitching for a while.

title: Senate Declines to Take Up Proposed Cloning Moratorium
description: Despite entreaties from President Bush to ban any type of cloning, either for reproduction or research, the Senate today refused to take up a Republican measure to impose a six-month moratorium on the technology.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARIE PATZ
description: COHEN-Marie Patz. Age 93, on December 1, 2001, in Baltimore, MD. Wife of the late Samuel J. Cohen. Mother of Elaine (Leonard) Wurzel. Grandmother of Mark (Ellen), Larry (Martha), and greatgrandmother of Jill, Max and Greg. Sister of Helen, Freda and Lillian. She will be lovingly remembered. Contributions may be sent to Samuel J. Cohen Fund (Jefferson House), C/O Eastern National, Attn: Jack Ryan, 470 Maryland Dr., Suite #

title: Collapse May Reshape the Battlefield of Deregulation
description: The bankruptcy of Enron has Washington debating the way it oversees the $200 billion power industry. But there is no consensus on erasing the legacy of deregulation that the company's political largess helped forge.

title: New Twist on a Timeless Preoccupation
description: It takes a certain gall to write about love these days, not merely as an element of a story but as a serious subject. For one thing, there's the challenge of being articulate and interesting, not to mention original, in an arena where everyone claims experience if not expertise and where so much familiar wisdom is so often repeated that it often feels as though nothing is left to say. For another thing, in the idiom of contemporary storytelling, love is rather a mundane issue, the lightweight stuff of resolvable conflict.

title: A Defining Issue
description: When a seemingly profitable enterprise suddenly goes bankrupt, there are surely lessons to be learned. When that enterprise is the most admired company in America, lauded by business theorists as the quintessential 21st-century corporation, one wonders if it is the tip of an iceberg. And how many of us have, without knowing it, booked passage on the Titanic?

title: New Leader Makes Plans to Revive a Faltering A.M.A.
description: Michael D. Maves is a former cancer surgeon who boasts of deft administrative skills that resuscitate ailing medical institutions. He cites turnaround successes with a crippled academic medical department and a stagnant national association of ear, nose and throat specialists. But now Dr. Maves, 53, faces a challenge that dwarfs anything in his past. He was hired last month to revive the struggling American Medical Association.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * Port Authority Police Department Patrolman's Benevolent Association, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., to Ziccardi Partners Frierson Mee, New York, to create a campaign to help raise money for the families of the 37 Port Authority officers who died in the World Trade Center attacks.

title: E.P.A. Once Again Orders G.E. to Clean Up Hudson River
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  The Environmental Protection Agency reiterated today its order that the General Electric Company remove hundreds of tons of poisonous chemicals from the Hudson River in New York.

title: Experts' Eyes Focus on 'the Bathtub' as Debris Is Cleared
description: Working their way through dirt and gloom and twisted steel like archaeologists sifting layers of lost civilizations, sidestepping random collapses, steam, smoke and dark crevasses, workers and engineers are slowly transforming the World Trade Center from a nightmarish mountain of debris to something resembling an ordinary construction excavation site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILICI, JONATHAN FRANCIS
description: MILICI-Jonathan Francis. October 27, 1968-December 1, 2001. Beloved son, brother and uncle. Service at Church of the Epiphany, 74th and York, NYC, 3 PM Wednesday, December 5. Memorials to Uniform Firefighter's Association Widow's and Children's Fund, 204 East 23 Street, New York City 10010. We love you and we will miss you.

title: Tunnel Vision; Taking the A Train, and Picking It Up With One Hand
description: The New York City subway has not been whole since Sept. 11.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Student Permitted To Wear Veil
description: A graduate student wearing a full facial veil has the right to use the library at the American University in Cairo, the administrative court in Cairo ruled. Though head scarves are common, the school banned veils, citing security concerns. The court called the veil a matter of ''personal and religious freedom.'' Full veils are banned at all state universities. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Canada and U.S. Sign Accord To Tighten Security on Border
description: Taking his antiterror campaign across the border, Attorney General John Ashcroft signed an agreement yesterday in Ottawa intended to keep terrorists and their supporters out of the United States and Canada while keeping $1.3 billion a day in trade flowing freely across the nations' shared 4,000-mile border.

title: Northern Alliance Presses for Surrender of Taliban Commander and Troops
description: The Northern Alliance massed several hundred soldiers on the western outskirts of this city on Monday in a move that alliance generals said was intended to put pressure on the neighboring town of Balkh to surrender a senior Taliban commander who is believed to be holding out there with his troops.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Plan To Expand O'Hare
description: Gov. George H. Ryan said he would send to Congress a plan to expand O'Hare International Airport even though he had not reached an agreement with Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago. Discussions fell apart last week over financing for Meigs Field, the city's small downtown airport. Under Mr. Ryan's plan, the airlines, rather than the state, would subsidize Meigs if it runs a deficit. Mr. Ryan said his plan reflected 99 percent of ''what I thought we had negotiated with the city.'' A spokesman for the mayor declined to comment. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Wines of the Week
description: Merry Edwards is a winemaker known for crafting pinot noir with personality.

title: Family Savings in the Caribbean
description: Through Jan. 5, children 12 and younger can stay and eat free when sharing a room with an adult at 15 Occidental-Allegro hotels in the Caribbean and Mexico. On Antigua, the Allegro Resort Pineapple Beach is charging $175 and up a person, based on double occupancy. In Costa Rica, it's $67 and up a person, double, at the Allegro Resort Papagayo. There are five choices in Mexico, including the Allegro in Cozumel (from $89 a person, double) and the Caribbean Village Cancun ($90 and up a person, double). These rates include all meals, drinks, nightly entertainment, nonmotorized water sports and taxes and tips. Information: (800) 858-2258 or www.allegroresorts.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Miner Expects a Higher Bid
description: The directors of Normandy Mining Ltd., Australia's largest gold producer and the target of a bidding war between AngloGold and the Newmont Mining Corporation, expect to get a better offer from Newmont soon. AngloGold added a cash component to its previously all-stock proposal for Normandy last week, topping Newmont's earlier bid. Normandy's board told the Australian Stock Exchange it ''considers there is potential for further developments.'' For now, the directors are waiting to advise shareholders, but they expect to respond within the next 10 days. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, HAL
description: ROSENTHAL-Hal. Dear Mucka, another year, eight in all, your presence is missed by so many friends who speak of you glowingly at all times. Sadly thinking of you missing your wonderful sons and their incredible achievements, most of all the Why question of my loss will always go unanswered. Love you forever. Your Hon, Jo

title: A Soprano Among Friends In an Adventurous Program
description: One had two nice things to say about Jennifer Aylmer's recital before she had sung a note. First was the musical curiosity: a program on Wednesday that avoided the usual touchstones of song repertory and lighted on Weill, Poulenc, Shostakovich, Bolcom and 20th-century Brazil. Hard to miss otherwise was Ms. Aylmer's ability to inspire friendship, as witnessed by a loudly affectionate audience at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRMANN, MARJORIE SARAH KIAM
description: HERRMANN - Marjorie Sarah Kiam on December 3, 2001 at age 91. Widow of John A. Herrmann, who died in 1959. ''Nan'' is survived by her children John Jr. and Mary Rossabi and their spouses Anne Herrmann and Morris Rossabi as well as her grandchildren Amy and Howard, Tony, Jed, Tim and Edward Levin. Marty spent her life assisting others through her work with: The Red Cross, Cancer Care, Blythdale Children's Hospital, Mount Sinai Auxillary Board, Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services and New Alternatives For Children. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to any of the above organizations.

title: First Challenge In Anthrax Case: Not Missing It
description: Is anthrax really as rare in this country as experts believe? Given the resemblance of its early stages to other ailments -- skin anthrax can look like a spider bite or acne, and the inhaled form like a viral respiratory infection -- many people have wondered whether other cases may have occurred in the past, unrelated to terrorism, and been misdiagnosed.

title: ISRAELIS STRIKE ARAFAT'S BASES; ACCUSE HIM OF 'A WAR OF TERROR'
description: Assaulting the symbols of Yasir Arafat's authority, Israeli warplanes, helicopter gunships, tanks and bulldozers struck in the West Bank and Gaza Strip on Monday night and before dawn today as the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, accused the Palestinian leader of provoking war by pursuing ''the path of terrorism.''

title: Argentine Economy: Postponing the Inevitable
description: The government's decision over the weekend to limit cash withdrawals may have succeeded in preventing a run on banks today, but it also signaled what may be the economy's last gasp before default, collapse and the adoption of the dollar as the currency.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KPN Lenders Get More Facts
description: Royal KPN provided more details of restrictions related to a 2.5 billion euro ($2.2 billion) credit facility it obtained last month, after a shareholder activist group filed a lawsuit demanding that the company make the same disclosures to all investors. The group, called SOBI, accused Royal KPN of providing more information to its largest shareholder, the Dutch government, as the company tried to raise 5 billion euros in fresh equity. SOBI withdrew the suit after KPN provided more details of the restrictions, which prevent it from spending more than 150 million euros ($134 million) on acquisitions and require it to get approval from the 10 lenders before agreeing to a merger. KPN is trying to reduce about 22.3 billion euros (about $20 billion) in debt issued to pay for new wireless services. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Drug Merger Canceled
description: The Taisho Pharmaceutical Company, Japan's biggest maker of over-the-counter drugs, has called off plans to acquire a rival, the Tanabe Seiyaku Company, for about 320 billion yen ($2.59 billion) in stock, saying the companies disagreed on a business strategy and the two had differences in corporate culture. The purchase agreement broke down when the companies discovered they had too many cultural differences and could not agree on a business strategy.

title: The Lady in Red, From City Hall to Town Painter
description: AS dragon ladies go, Cristyne L. Nicholas, the former City Hall official accused of playing the original ''other woman'' role in the disintegrating marriage of her then-boss and present patron, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, does not come on like much of a fire-breather.

title: Depression After Bypass
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Resistance, New Terror Worries, the Missing Who Weren't
description: The war in Afghanistan intensified on several fronts. There was fierce fighting in and around Kandahar, where the Taliban fought back as opposition forces approached the city, and some 1,200 United States Marines moved into a strike position from the southwest.

title: Deadline Is Extended in Questioning of Foreigners
description: Law enforcement officials here extended the deadline today for young Middle Eastern men to respond to letters sent last week requesting interviews about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, after only about 185 of the 550 people wanted for questioning called to schedule appointments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASHCOW, BERNARD
description: PASHCOW-Bernard. At age 91 after a lenghthy illness. He is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years Hannah (nee Taffet); two daughters, Dr. Kay Cowan (Richard) and Mrs. Ronnie Getz (Joseph); four grandsons, Dr. Gregory Cowan (Carol), Andrew Cowan (Suzanne), Lonny Cowan, Allan Barrie, and three great grandsons. Funeral services Tuesday December 4, 1:00pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza (opposite LIRR) Great Neck, NY.

title: A Weekend of Terror in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: From Governor To Chancellor?
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening would like to become chancellor of the state's university system when he leaves office after next year's election. A spokeswoman for the governor, Michelle Byrnie, confirmed his interest in replacing the retiring chancellor, Donald N. Langenberg, in the $345,000-a-year post heading the 13-campus system. The governor's term ends in January 2003. Mr. Glendening, a Democrat, taught political science for 27 years at the system's flagship campus, the University of Maryland, at College Park. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: U.S. Walks a Tightrope On Terrorism in Israel
description: The White House said today that ''Israel has a right to defend herself,'' but denied that President Bush had effectively encouraged Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to order today's military strikes in Palestinian-controlled territory.

title: All of Us Tourists
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Recommendation On Cars Towed On Sept. 11
description: The city's health commissioner said yesterday that he was recommending that the city condemn the 900 cars that were towed from the World Trade Center site after the towers came down. Although the cars' owners have in some cases been calling for their return, the commissioner, Dr. Neal Cohen, said that because asbestos and other contaminants were prevalent throughout the cars' engines and bodies, it would be too expensive to clean them, and such a cleaning could be inconclusive, in terms of safety. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETHILL, LILLIAN
description: BETHILL-Lillian. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mrs. Lillian Bethill, an esteemed member, and extend to her beloved husband, Lester, and family its deepest sympathy. Kenneth Apfel, President Sidney Gottlieb, Secretary

title: Yasir Arafat's Last Chance
description: Yasir Arafat has a long and frustrating history of fudging or postponing hard decisions. Now he can postpone no more. Last weekend's deadly terrorist attacks in Jerusalem and Haifa by Hamas suicide bombers have all but shattered his credibility as a negotiating partner. Important Israeli political leaders are ready to write him off and wait however long it takes for a more politically courageous and decisive Palestinian leader to emerge. Their impatience is readily understandable. Mr. Arafat's reluctance to shut down terrorist groups like Hamas has again led to the death of innocent teenagers and adults and thrown yet another set of Israeli families into mourning. Still, Israel should not take this decisive step just yet.

title: Temple Increases Bid for Gaylord
description: Temple-Inland Inc. increased its offer to buy a rival paper-and-box maker, the Gaylord ContainerCorporation, by 7 percent to entice bondholders who said the first offer was too low.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND CO., Decatur, Ill., the grain processor, said it had increased its stake in a German grain trader, Toepfer International, to 80 percent from 75 percent. Terms were not disclosed.

title: HOUSTON EXPLORATION AGREES TO BUY CONOCO PROPERTIES
description: The Houston Exploration Company, an oil and natural gas concern that is majority owned by the KeySpan Corporation, agreed to buy properties in South Texas from Conoco Inc. for $69 million to add onshore gas reserves. The properties, which include about 28,000 acres, will add 159 wells and increase Houston's gas reserves by 60 percent, the company said. Houston Exploration said the purchase would increase production and add to earnings immediately.

title: Experience Gives Maryland the Advantage
description: Connecticut looked at tonight's game as a yardstick for its season, and No. 3 Maryland provided a sobering response. Leading for all but the first minute of play, the Terrapins easily put away the Huskies, 77-65, in the championship game of the BB&T Classic at the MCI Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELIS, GEORGE J.
description: MICHAELIS-George J. Of North Bend, OR, formerly of Jackson Heights, NY. On Friday evening, November 30, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Ethel and Lillian. Loving father of Barbara. Devoted brother of Edwin and Henry. Services at 12 Noon, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Hospital Temporarily Suspends Heart Surgery
description: University Hospital of Brooklyn, the teaching hospital for one of the largest medical schools in the country, said yesterday that it had shut down its heart surgery department because of a recent surge in deaths during coronary bypass operations.

title: Afghan Says Fighters Are Ready to Attack Cave Complex
description: An Afghan commander said tonight that 1,500 Pashtun fighters, accompanied by American Special Operations soldiers, were prepared to attack Tora Bora, the mountain cave complex where Osama bin Laden and 2,000 Al Qaeda fighters are believed to be hiding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVEL, ROBERT B.
description: RIVEL-Robert B., 80. Of Pittsfield, MA, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, Westfield, NJ and Saddle River, NJ died November 30, 2001. Executive Vice President of Chase Manhattan Bank (1946-72), General Partner Lazard Freres & Co. (1972-74), CEO of Union Dime Savings Bank (1975-81), CEO of Private Export Funding Corp. (1982-86). He is survived by his wife Helen D. Stewart Rivel of Pittsfield, MA; a son, R. Wesley Rivel of Sao Paulo, Brazil; a daughter, Joan Rivel Pettrone of Averill Park, NY and six grandchildren. A memorial service is planned in January 2002 at a time to be announced. In lieu of flowers donations are suggested to the Vermont Veterans Home Alzheimer's Fund, C/O Wellington Funeral Home, 220 East Street, Pittsfield, MA. 01201.

title: NESTL TO BUY IONICS' BOTTLED WATER BUSINESS
description: Nestl agreed to buy the Aqua Cool Pure Bottled Water operations of Ionics Inc. for $220 million. Aqua Cool water is delivered to offices and homes in the United States, Britain and France, generating more than $70 million in sales annually. Nestl, which considers mineral water a high-growth business, has acquired other mineral-water companies, including Aberfoyle Springs of Canada, in the last year. Ionics said it planned to focus on its activities in water re-use, surface water purification, ultrapure water and water-quality instrumentation.

title: A Weekend of Terror in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Issues A New Terror Alert
description: The government warned that there could be new terror strikes against the United States in the next several weeks, perhaps tied to the final days of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan or other religious observances this month.

title: Brain Gets Rest When Hands Do Talking
description: Talking with your hands appears to take some of the load off your brain, a new study concludes.

title: Antimissile Weapon Hits Target in Latest Test, Pentagon Says
description: A prototype antimissile weapon demolished a mock warhead tonight high above the Pacific Ocean in the second consecutive success for the Pentagon's costly missile defense program, military officials said.

title: Yankees Talk Free Agents and Trades, in the Broadcast Booth
description: After the Mets unceremoniously replaced Tim McCarver as their lead television analyst in favor of Tom Seaver in 1999, Channel 5 snared him within a week to call Yankees games.

title: Accounts
description: * Castrol Worldwide, part of BP, London, consolidated the worldwide creative account for its lubricant brands like Castrol, GTX and Syntec by naming offices of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, to handle that assignment. Spending was estimated at $120 million. Ogilvy is also the worldwide creative agency for BP. The creative account of Castrol North America, with spending estimated at $40 million, will be moved to Ogilvy from Hampel/Stefanides, New York, part of the Envoy Communications Group, which had handled that assignment since 1993.

title: Favre Leads Strong Comeback As Packers Defeat Jaguars
description: Brett Favre threw three touchdown passes and ran 6 yards for the game-winner with 1 minute 30 seconds left to rally the Green Bay Packers from 14 points down for a 28-21 victory last night over the host Jacksonville Jaguars, the masters of the late-game collapse.

title: Hearing the Warning Bells
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA JAPAN: AN EQUAL-OPPORTUNITY THRONE The governing Liberal Democratic Party began deliberations on whether the law governing imperial succession should be changed to allow women to ascend the throne. The deliberations began three days after the birth of a baby princess, the first child of Crown Prince Naruhito and Princess Masako, with public support growing to change a 1948 law that allows only male succession. There have been no male births in the imperial family since 1965. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has said he will support a change in the law but has urged careful consultations beforehand.    Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFELD, MAX
description: WOLFELD-Max. Loving husband, father, grandfather, greatgrandfather. Services 10 A.M. Thursday at Edwards Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: U.S. Questions if Arafat Can Lead the Palestinians
description: In the wake of deadly suicide bombings and shootings by Palestinians last weekend, the Bush administration is questioning whether Yasir Arafat is capable of leading the Palestinian people and has dropped its public calls for Israel to use restraint in the Middle East crisis.

title: THE BOSS; Inspired by Chance Meetings
description: We're in a landmark building, the Aon Building. On Sept. 11, our chairman was in Miami. The vice chairman wasn't here either. The younger people were teary. After the second tower was hit, I said: ''Being in the firm is an option. You don't have to be a hero to stay.'' After the Pentagon attack I said, ''We're leaving.'' I was making the decision on instinct. It was one of those moments you are completely and totally learning by doing. Chicago was shutting down. Massive crowds were very quiet. I was traveling and had my wheelie. I pulled it behind me as I walked home.

title: Seeking a Business Degree, Across the Pond
description: A few years ago, David Pagliaro stumbled into an M.B.A. school fair at the Grand Hyatt New York, skirted past the students mobbing the Harvard and Stanford desks and headed for a stand with no visitors -- the one for the London Business School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMARTIN, TERESA V., A.K.A. ''TEDI''
description: GILMARTIN-Teresa V., a.k.a. ''Tedi''. Suddenly on November 2, 2001. Longtime partner of the late Mary Leone. Daughter of the late Katherine and Michael Gilmartin. Sister of the late Catherine Morrissey, Thomas and Patrick J. Gilmartin. Cherished aunt of Elizabeth O'Leary, James Morrissey, Patricia Killeen and Veronica Tompkins. Great-aunt to 11. Former longtime employee of Forbes Magazine. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, December 9, 2001, 10:30 AM at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street) NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Maoist Group Suspected In Bombing
description: Terrorists believed to belong to the Maoist Shining Path bombed an electricity tower 30 miles east of Lima. No one was hurt in the blast but it came only a day after the State Department warned that there was growing evidence the group was staging a comeback. It terrorized much of Peru with bombings and massacres in the 1980's and early 1990's before its main leaders were captured. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Scarsdale Says No to State Request
description: Last year, scores of eighth graders in Scarsdale, N.Y., boycotted state reading and math tests. Then several weeks ago, State Education Commissioner RICHARD P. MILLS asked MICHAEL V. McGILL, Scarsdale's superintendent of schools, how he planned to provide remedial help to those boycotting students who would have failed the tests. Now Dr. McGill has written back declining to offer that information.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PUSEY, NATHAN MARSH
description: PUSEY-Nathan Marsh. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 8 at 3PM at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue at 73rd Street.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I feel him kicking and I feel happy and then I feel sad.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHNER, GEORGE A.
description: RICHNER-George A. Executive recruiter, retailer, institutional food executive and a longtime resident of Summit, NJ, died December 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Beulah (Bee) May Young Richner. Father of Trina Richner Lawson of NYC. Brother of William Eugene Richner of Homosassa, FL. Uncle of seven nieces and one nephew. A memorial service to be held Saturday, January 5, 2002, at 11 AM in the Chapel of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Antiterror Effort Is Defended
description: After months of criticism by civil liberties groups, supporters of the Bush administration's antiterrorism crackdown have begun to outline a legal defense of the actions. Page B6.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREUND, LUCAS S.
description: FREUND-Lucas S. 12/5/81-6/27/97. HAPPY BIRTHDAY. Love Ya, Gran Arlene and Gramps Joel

title: Anthrax Pervades Florida Site, and Experts See Likeness to That Sent to Senators
description: Two months after the death of Robert Stevens, the first of the nation's anthrax victims, new tests at his Florida workplace reveal a pattern of pervasive contamination that mystifies investigators.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Greenwich: Employment-Agency Homicide
description: The woman charged with murdering the owner of a Greenwich employment agency on Monday believed that the victim had prevented her from obtaining work, the police said. The suspect, Flora Canales, 50, was arraigned on murder and other charges yesterday. She did not enter a plea and was ordered held, with bail set at $500,000. Mrs. Canales is charged with killing Alicia M. Kirkel, 41, of Rye, N.Y., who owned Royal Domestics, an agency that placed maids and other household help. The police said that they had found a gun and other evidence during a search of the suspect's home in Stamford. ''Mrs. Canales somehow felt blackballed'' by the agency, said Capt. David Ridberg, a spokesman for the Greenwich police. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Safety of Nuclear Plants Again Raises Concerns
description: Some people here never liked the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant, worrying about accidents and radioactive waste. Others always thought it was a reliable, cheap and clean source of electricity. Over 30 years of arguing, they had mostly run out of new things to say and bored the general public with their arguments. But that was before Sept. 11.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLER'S PROFIT TO BEAT FORECASTS
description: Profit next year at Coca-Cola Enterprises will rise more than forecast as the company, the largest bottler of the Coca-Cola Company's drinks, controls costs and increases prices and sales. Net income next year will be 80 cents to 85 cents a share, the company said. Analysts' average estimate is 75 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Coca-Cola Enterprises will raise prices 2 percent next year, the chief financial officer, Patrick Mannelly, said. The bottler, which is 38 percent owned by Coca-Cola, said it was negotiating a new multiyear contract with Coca-Cola that will end financing shortfalls.

title: Levin to Retire as Chief Executive of AOL Time Warner
description: AOL Time Warner Inc. ( news/quote ), the world's largest media business, announced today that its chief executive, Gerald M. Levin, would retire in May and would be succeeded by Richard D. Parsons, the company's co-chief operating officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, GRACE PIERSON
description: LEWIS-Grace Pierson on December 4, 2001 in Rye, NY (formerly of Short Hills, NJ and Westhampton Beach, NY), 103. Born April 7, 1898 in Brooklyn, NY, she was the daughter of the late Lewis E. and Blanche Thorne Pierson. Beloved by all. She is survived by her sons, Stanley P. Lewis of Westport, CT, John T. Lewis of Vero Beach, FL, Lewis P. Lewis of New York City, 14 grandchildren and 19 greatgrandchildren. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, December 18, at 10 AM, The Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach, New York.

title: Yasir Arafat, Center Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; The Big Five comment on accounting practices and the fall of Enron.
description: THE chief executives of the Big Five accounting firms issued an unusual joint statement yesterday on the collapse of Enron, saying they take their ''responsibility seriously'' and would work for better disclosure of some transactions that played a role in the collapse.

title: A Veggie Heaven That Admits Carnivores
description: Elemental Foods, a clean-cut sliver of a shop at 259 West 19th Street, could easily become a haven for people whose culinary philosophy is vegan, macrobiotic or vegetarian. They will feel right at home with velvety chickpea and basil spread in whole-wheat pita, vegetable-filled rice pancake rolls, miso soup, organic pasta with slow-roasted tomatoes or grilled tempeh with a sweet-and-sour glaze. But Katie Haje, the owner, at center in photo, does not ignore mainstream tastes, so her chef, Jennifer Hoy, right, also prepares dishes like moist shrimp-and-salmon cakes with a jalapeo dip. Prices range from $2 for a dish of steamed brown rice to $9.50 for grilled salmon. Ms. Haje has also opened her kitchen to Marius Hickman, left, the baker of Marius Morsels, first-rate chocolate chip, butterscotch, oatmeal and sugar cookies, $1 each. And he uses nary a grain or drop of whole-wheat flour, honey or carob. ''Treats should be treats,'' Ms. Haje said.

title: As Vote Nears, Bush Presses for New Trade Powers
description: As President Bush corners lawmakers on the White House dance floor and on Air Force One to urge them to back his bid for enhanced trade authority, his administration is warning that if Congress rejects the proposal this week ''no one will negotiate'' with the United States on trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, FLORENCE S.
description: GOLDBERG-Florence S. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Morris M. Goldberg, devoted mother of Perry and BeeJee Morrison, Sandra and Alan Wolfer, loving grandmother of Caren, Lori, Lesa and Abby, and great grandmother of Michael, Gabriella, Samuel, and Brandon.

title: Whitman Says PCB Dredging Will Proceed
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, Christie Whitman, said yesterday that the agency would move forward with a nearly $500 million dredging plan to remove PCB pollution from the upper Hudson River. In doing so, the agency rejected General Electric's efforts to scale back the cleanup.

title: During a Blue-Collar Upswing, Labor Seeks a Lift
description: The theme of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s convention is written in huge letters behind the ballroom's podium: America's Workers -- Heroes Every Day.

title: Expanding NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks in Bonn End With Deal On Leadership For Afghans
description: After negotiating all night, Afghan delegates reached agreement early this morning on a new, post-Taliban government for Afghanistan that will take power in Kabul on Dec. 22, according to Ahmad Fawzi, a United Nations spokesman.

title: Bush Defends Wartime Call For Tribunals
description: Before a cheering crowd in Florida, President Bush said today that he needed military tribunals and other legal weapons to protect Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEALLY, MARGARET P.
description: KENNEALLY-Margaret P. A lifelong resident of Manhattan, died December 1. Beloved sister of Catherine and Mary, adored aunt and great aunt of many and dear friend to many more. Mass to be celebrated Saturday, December 8 at 2PM at St. John the Martyr Church on 72nd Street west of 2nd Avenue. Contributions may be sent to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Street, New York, NY 10002.

title: Arms, Books And Noose Were Fixtures At Terror Lair
description: The crude metal noose said to have killed the mujahedeen commander Abdul Haq still hangs from a maple tree here, half a mile from one of Osama bin Laden's largest terrorist training camps.

title: Gino A. Circiello, Restaurateur, Is Dead at 89
description: Gino A. Circiello, a restaurateur who shunned credit cards, reservations and advertising but built a Manhattan institution on the strength of homey Italian cooking and 314 exuberantly leaping zebras on tomato-red wallpaper, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, SARAH
description: SCHIFF-Sarah. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member Evelyn Kranz and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: Congress Is Zeroing In on the Complex Deals at Enron
description: Congressional investigators looking into the collapse of Enron focused yesterday on records related to the company's labyrinthine dealings with investment vehicles tied to senior Enron executives.

title: The New York Times's Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: 3 U.S. Servicemen Killed by 'Friendly Fire' Near Kandahar
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Three American soldiers and five Afghan fighters were killed today when a one-ton bomb dropped from a B-52 went off course and landed near their positions, the Pentagon said.

title: Johnson Catches, but Doesn't Score
description: The former Jet Keyshawn Johnson finds himself having plenty of mood swings these days. He has a National Football League-leading 83 receptions. He also has zero touchdowns. Johnson, now with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, has never caught more than 89 passes in a regular season in his N.F.L. career, so this will probably represent a career year for the wide receiver. Yet the touchdown drought has left him exasperated, and on course to enter the record book.

title: Elite Troops Patrolling Desolate Swaths of No Man's Land
description: Having established significant firepower on the ground here, American marines are now probing deeper toward the chaotic swaths of territory still under control of the Taliban, spokesmen here said today.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Education Recommendations
description: A panel appointed by the state's school superintendent had recommended a statewide curriculum, testing of students at every grade and lengthening of the school day and year for struggling students. The recommendations by 40 educators, business leaders, elected officials and parents are to guide education policy for the next decade. Superintendent Nancy S. Grasmick is expected to sign off on the recommendations in January, and they must be approved by the state Board of Education. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Doubling of A's at Harvard: Grade Inflation or Brains?
description: A HARVARD UNIVERSITY report last spring complained of grade inflation that makes it easier to get high grades. Now the academic dean, Susan Pedersen, has released data showing that 49 percent of undergraduate grades were A's in 2001, up considerably from 23 percent in 1986.

title: Business Travel; Some female flight attendants are complaining of being 'fondled and groped' by security guards.
description: A UNION representing about 50,000 flight attendants said yesterday that it had been waiting almost a month for a federal response to its complaint that female flight attendants had recently been ''fondled and groped by male security guards'' at airports.

title: Minority Candidates Are on List for Fire Commissioner
description: Two black Fire Department officials as well as a female deputy commissioner have places on Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg's list of candidates to lead the department, which has come under criticism for having too few from both categories in its ranks.

title: Nasdaq Above 2,000; Dow Breaks 10,000
description: Stocks surged today as investors rallied around a new and unexpected sign of growth in business spending.

title: A Seaman's Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Economic Confidence Declines
description: Industrial and consumer confidence indicators in the 12-nation euro zone continued to decline in November, falling two points each from October, but the decline in confidence was less severe than a month ago, the European Commission said. Overall economic confidence in the euro zone fell to 98.6 from 99.1 the previous month. The indicators for the 15-member European Union copied the euro zone decline. Germany, Spain and France displayed the most important decreases, while economic sentiment picked up in seven member countries, including Britain, Denmark and Austria. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: DNA Clears 4 Men Convicted in '86 Murder
description: Charges against four men convicted in 1987 of the rape and murder of a medical student here will be dropped because of DNA evidence clearing them, the Cook County state's attorney's office said today.

title: A Long-Lasting Champion of Good Taste
description: HARRY WAUGH'S death in London a week ago brought to an end one of the longest and most distinguished careers in the British wine trade. He was 97.

title: Watching The Firms That Watch The Books
description: Too many publicly traded companies are manipulating their financial results, and auditors, Wall Street and the Securities and Exchange Commission are not doing enough to stop them.

title: Interviews Set For 86 Visitors In Terror Sweep
description: Law enforcement officials announced plans yesterday to begin interviewing up to 86 Middle Eastern men in New York City as part of the Justice Department's nationwide drive to talk to 5,000 visitors from countries with suspected terrorist links.

title: Paxson Communications Moves To Bar NBC Bid for Telemundo
description: Accusing NBC of breach of contract, the Paxson Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would ask the government to block NBC's planned $2.7 billion acquisition of the Spanish-language television network Telemundo.

title: A Family Makes Unbeautiful Music Together
description: Mom plays the piano! Junior plays the drums! And hey, they both love to sing! If they lived inside an old-style Broadway musical, or perhaps a television show like ''The Partridge Family,'' you can bet this little combo would have audiences whistling a happy tune by the evening's end.

title: Debate at Harvard Asks If Its A's Are Too Cheap
description: When Yann Kumin, a sophomore at Harvard, received a B on a recent 10-page term paper, he felt that he did not deserve that good a grade. Mr. Kumin, 19, said he had spent little time on the assignment, which he submitted in one of the core courses that is required of all Harvard undergraduates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, MEYER L.
description: GOTTLIEB-Meyer L. Outstanding biology teacher, he inspired many students to go into medicine and research. Died November 27 at age 90. For info, 212-362-6600.

title: President Tries to Give Florida, and Its Governor, a Boost
description: George W. Bush today confronted a growing vulnerability of his presidency, the languishing economy, by promoting a government program for laid-off workers and blaming the Democratic-controlled Senate for a deadlock in Washington over an economic stimulus bill.

title: Moody's Lowers Debt Rating On Government Credit in Yen
description: Leading its rivals in bearishness on Japan's prospects, Moody's Investors Service lowered its credit rating on Japan's yen debts for the second time in three months, and suggested that further cuts might be coming.

title: AOL Retreats From Big Push For E-Books
description: In the latest setback to the once-promising future of electronic books, the books division of AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it was cutting back its expensive line of digital books and laying off almost all 29 employees, citing a slump in sales of all books and especially digital ones.

title: Parsons to Become Next Chief of AOL Time Warner
description: Media conglomerate AOL Time Warner Wednesday said chief executive Gerald Levin will retire in May 2002, and will be replaced by co-Chief Operating Officer Richard Parsons.

title: Scarsdale Says No to State Request
description: Last year, scores of eighth graders in Scarsdale, N.Y., boycotted state reading and math tests. Then several weeks ago, State Education Commissioner RICHARD P. MILLS asked MICHAEL V. McGILL, Scarsdale's superintendent of schools, how he planned to provide remedial help to those boycotting students who would have failed the tests. Now Dr. McGill has written back declining to offer that information.

title: Mayor Commits $24 Million To Lincoln Center Rebuilding
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday authorized the city to allocate the first installment of a $240 million commitment for Lincoln Center's $1.2 billion redevelopment plan, several people associated with the project said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIFFONE, MARGARET E.

title: China Wary on Mideast, Criticizing Both Palestinians and Israelis
description: The Chinese government shied away today from characterizing the suicide bombings in Israel over the weekend as terrorism, instead criticizing the Palestinians and the Israelis equally for the use of violence and calling for renewed peace talks.

title: Israeli Missiles Hit Arafat Compound and Other Sites
description: In the most wide-ranging attack on Palestinian areas in 14 months of conflict, Israeli warplanes and helicopters bombarded security offices today in eight areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, killing at least two Palestinians and injuring scores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEGNER, GERHART
description: RIEGNER-Gerhart. We mourn and honor the valiant courier who helped inform the world of the systematic Nazi attempt to murder the Jews of Europe, and who became a postwar champion of human rights, an elder statesman of interfaith dialogue. His voice will be sorely missed. Seymour D. Reich, Chairman Dr. Leon Feldman, Secretary International Jewish Committee On Interreligious Consultations

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Bliveau Whispers Heard in Tampa
description: AS a Quebec teenager, he was compared to Jean Bliveau, the best center in the Montreal Canadiens' elegant history. When he was the No. 1 choice over all in the N.H.L.'s 1998 entry draft, he was touted by the Tampa Bay Lightning as ''the Michael Jordan of hockey'' -- the ultimate sports mixed metaphor.

title: Easy Pan Prep, For Bakers Whose Aim Is Steady
description: Using Baker's Joy, a spray coating for baking pans, requires a bit of practice. This clever timesaver, a combination of soybean oil and flour, does an excellent one-step job of greasing and flouring baking pans. But you have to work fast to get a light and fairly uniform coating. A good way to do it is to put your baking pan in the sink and let your spraying go a bit wild. A pastry brush can be used to smooth uneven spots. Baker's Joy also works well on cookie cutters and to coat bowls that will hold rising dough. When sprayed in the bottom of a heavy casserole, it helps in the browning of stew meat. It is $7.99 a can at the New York Cake and Baking Center, 56 West 22nd Street.

title: Authorities Capture Fugitive Suspected of Anthrax Threats
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  A fugitive from Illinois believed responsible for mailing hundred of anthrax threats to abortion clinics across the country was captured in Cincinnati today, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO PURCHASE CII TECHNOLOGIES
description: Tyco International Ltd., the largest maker of electronic connectors, agreed to buy CII Technologies Inc. for about $310 million in cash to expand its line of industrial-relay products. CII Technologies, a unit of the closely held CIIT Holding Inc., makes electric relays, transformers and filters under the CII, Hartman and Kilovac brand names, the companies said. Based in Asheville, N.C., CII Technologies has operations in France, Germany, India and China.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New in Midtown

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Gary Leon Ridgway, a suspect in serial murders known as the Green River killings, gave an incorrect name in some copies for the Seattle suburb where he lives. It is Auburn, not Austin.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Student Home Until Trial
description: A student accused of masterminding a massacre at his high school in New Bedford will be confined to his mother's home until his trial. The student Eric McKeehan, 17, pleaded not guilty to conspiracy and other charges. A judge said he must wear an electronic monitor and have no contact with students or teachers at the school. The crime was thwarted, the police say, when one conspirator, who is free until trial, warned her favorite teacher. Three youths, including Mr. McKeehan's 15-year-old brother, remain in custody. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: December Is No Time to Reminisce for Jets
description: Jets General Manager Terry Bradway has ordered the same bologna sandwich each Monday and Tuesday since the Jets started winning six weeks ago and wore the same sport coat to four consecutive games. No reason to mess with karma when the Jets were on such a roll, even if his cardiologist and the fashion police might say otherwise. But after Sunday's debacle, Bradway should consider a switch to tuna -- no, not that Tuna -- and take the jacket (a nice tannish houndstooth) to a consignment shop.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Law Firm Moves
description: Nearly three months after it was forced out from the World Trade Center by the attack, Sidley Austin Brown & Wood, the nation's fourth-largest law firm, has signed a long-term lease in the Equitable Center in Midtown. By next summer, it plans to take over 11 floors of the 54-story building, at Seventh Avenue and 51st Street. The firm has more than 1,000 employees. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Garry Davis Champions Life Without Borders : 'World Citizen No. 1' And His Quixotic Quest
description: PARIS  He once understudied for Danny Kaye, so it comes as no surprise that Garry Davis is a genuinely funny guy. But for the last half century, immigration and police officials around the world have failed to get the joke.

title: Isfahan Journal; Drought Dries Up a City's River, and Sears Its Soul
description: The people of this city are inconsolable. They talk as if a lover has left them, but it is worse. Lovers can be replaced.

title: Levin to Retire as Chief Executive of AOL Time Warner
description: The chief executive of the world's biggest media company, AOL Time Warner, surprised his company and his industry yesterday by announcing that he would retire in May. The executive, Gerald M. Levin, will be replaced by his hand-picked successor, Richard D. Parsons, who will face the daunting job of making a merger conceived in the soaring Internet economy come of age during an economic slump for old-line and online media companies alike.

title: A Roman Muse For America's Great Chefs
description: IN the cool, dim corner of a house in the hills overlooking Rome, Paola di Mauro was scuffing around her kitchen. The TV was turned to an Italian game show, saltimbocca was bubbling away on the stove and I was sipping on a juicy, red wine made from vines visible from the window.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEIL, BARBARA
description: BEIL-Barbara. Happy second birthday in heaven. Miss and love you very much. Love, Shelly

title: Pep Boys Pick Richards Group
description: Pep Boys -- Manny, Moe & Jack, the automotive products retailer and service chain from Philadelphia, named the Richards Group in Dallas yesterday to handle its account. It had been handled since 1998 by the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Tradition Trumped By Fear Of Terror
description: Saudi men applying for visas to the United States must submit photographs with their heads uncovered, the United States Embassy in Riyadh said. The new rule, requiring removal of the traditional Saudi headdress, is part of tighter procedures since the Sept. 11 attacks, diplomats said. The Bush administration has said that most of the 19 hijackers in the attacks were men who received their visas from American missions in Saudi Arabia. The embassy said women who cover their heads because of religious beliefs could continue to submit photographs with their heads covered ''on the condition that the applicant's face and features are clearly visible.'' Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, JOHN W. (JACK)
description: COLLINS-John W. (Jack). On December 2, 2001. In 1991 he was voted into the United States Chess Federation Hall of Fame and, a couple of years later, they awarded him the distinction of ''Chess Teacher of the Century.'' Among his students were Robert (Bobby) Fischer, Robert Byrne, William Lombardy and many other world chess dignitaries. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. on Thursday, 7-9 PM. Funeral service on Friday 11:00 AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, New Windsor, NY.

title: A Pianist Gathers The Radicals
description: There is a tendency in the classical music field to consign any artist strongly committed to playing music by living composers to the suspect category, some sort of off-putting contemporary music specialist. The French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard has been so tainted since 1976, when, at 19, he was asked by Pierre Boulez to become the resident pianist of his Ensemble Intercontemporain. Perhaps this explains why Mr. Aimard has not yet achieved widespread recognition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ARTHUR L.
description: LEWIS-Arthur L. Passed away on November 28, 2001 after a brief illness. He was 76 years old. Arthur is survived by his wife of 53 years, Joan Lewis, two daughters, Cathy Lewis of Larchmont, NY and Jane Horsfall of Freeport, Maine, and four grandchildren. He was a husband, father and grandfather extraordinaire, as well as an astute businessman and proud Marine. A memorial service will be held at the Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main Street, Eastchester, New York (914-337-4585) on Saturday, December 8 at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the East Yonkers Rotary Club Scholarship Fund, and to the First Church of Christ Scientist, White Plains-Scarsdale.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Medical School Sues Over Trade Secrets
description: A lawsuit by Baylor College of Medicine in Houston accuses a California biomedical services company of stealing trade secrets that had been developed in genomic research at the college. The suit says a Palo Alto, Calif., company, Clontech, agreed not to disclose trade secrets patented by Baylor in 1998 while negotiating a licensing agreement. The disputed procedure, named he Elledge technology after Baylor researcher Steve Elledge, provides a quick and simple system of identifying genes. Clontech officials said they could not comment on pending litigation. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRMANN, MARJORIE SARAH KIAM
description: HERRMANN - Marjorie Sarah Kiam on December 3, 2001 at age 91. Widow of John A. Herrmann, who died in 1959. ''Nan'' is survived by her children John Jr. and Mary Rossabi and their spouses Anne Herrmann and Morris Rossabi as well as her grandchildren Amy and Howard, Tony, Jed, Tim and Edward Levin. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to any of the above organizations.

description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing examining the scope and long-term consequences of hundreds of millions of dollars in emergency city contracts for the cleanup of ground zero. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7722.

title: Sharon's War Cannot Be Won
description: Once again the world has had to confront the horror of innocent men, women and children killed by suicide bombers in the heart of Jerusalem and in Haifa. No decent person can refrain from condemning such attacks in the strongest terms. Such deeds harm not only their innocent victims, which in this case probably included Palestinian citizens of Israel, but also the just cause of Palestine.

title: GOLDMAN SACHS SELLS 10% STAKE IN SOUNDVIEW
description: The Goldman Sachs Group, shedding an investment it made when Internet trading was exploding, sold its 10 percent stake in the SoundView Technology Group after two and a half years. The securities firm sold 11.7 million SoundView nonvoting Class B common shares for a total of $20 million to the private-equity firm General Atlantic Partners, an unidentified institutional investor and SoundView itself. The investment bank sold its stake because the company had changed since Goldman invested in what was then Wit Capital, one of the first to distribute initial public offerings online. Goldman invested about $25 million in Wit in April 1999. Joe Gleberman, managing director at Goldman, said in a statement, ''Since the combination with SoundView in 2000, the company has evolved into a more traditional technology-focused investment bank.''

description: In their first major push to support the nation's war effort, the major broadcast networks are producing short television messages conveying season's greetings to American troops stationed overseas.

title: U.S. Students Are Middling On Test Given In 32 Nations
description: An examination measuring practical knowledge in math, science and reading among students in 32 industrialized nations shows that those in Canada, Finland and New Zealand lead the world in all three categories, with American students performing at only average levels.
