description: EchoStar Communications' planned $32 billion purchase of DirecTV raised concern in Congress today that pay television would have fewer competitors, especially in rural communities.

title: The Latest Blow to Buffalo: A Layoff of Hundreds at Schools
description: Diana Seifert wants to stay in Buffalo even though, by her count, she has lost five jobs in the past eight years because of layoffs in the health care field. So this year, she began teaching in the city's public school system because she loved children and heard that there was a shortage of good teachers.

title: Senate Votes to Let Mexican Trucks in U.S.
description: The Senate gave final approval today to a measure supported by President Bush that will permit Mexican trucks to haul cargo in the United States but require them to follow strict safety and inspection rules before they cross the border.

title: Louise Steinhart Loeb; Philanthropist, 86
description: Louise Steinhart Loeb, a New York benefactor of child welfare agencies and other causes, died Saturday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 86.

title: Rich Are Different; They Get Elected
description: The list of also-rans from elections past is riddled with the names of rich candidates who poured millions of dollars of their personal fortunes into doomed bids for elected office. Some people seemed to take a kind of solace in the costly failures. However much may be wrong with the political system, this line of thinking went, at least you cannot buy an election.

title: MYRIAD GENETICS TO BE MARKETED BY LABORATORY CORP.
description: Myriad Genetics broadened the distribution of its tests for breast cancer and other diseases, signing up Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings to market them. Myriad is best known for a genetic test that can indicate a high probability of developing breast cancer, though it also has tests for colon cancer, melanoma and hypertension. Myriad, based in Salt Lake City, has a sales force of 85 that has been marketing its tests to oncologists. LabCorp, the nation's second-largest clinical diagnostic laboratory after Quest Diagnostics, will now add its 600-member sales force, which will market the tests to family doctors, gynecologists and other physicians. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLIN, ROBERT LAWRENCE, JR.
description: COUGHLIN-Robert Lawrence, Jr. The Honorable R. Lawrence Coughlin, Jr., 72, died Friday, November 30, 2001 at his Tidewater home in Mathews, Virginia. He is survived by his wife, Susan MacGregor Coughlin, four children, and five grandchildren. Congressman Coughlin was elected in 1968 to represent the 13th Congressional District of Pennsylvania in the United States Congress. He served as a member of Congress for 12 consecutive terms spanning 24 years. A funeral service will be held at the Old Chapel, Ft. Myers, Virginia at 9:00 AM on December 20, 2001, followed by interment at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Chief Says November Was Satisfactory
description: The technology bellwether Cisco Systems said orders for its networking equipment in November met the company's forecasts, but warned that it expected its corporate customers to spend cautiously until the economy recovers. Speaking at Cisco's annual meeting for financial analysts in Santa Clara, Calif., John T. Chambers, above, the president and chief executive, declined to update his earlier prediction that sales this quarter would be flat or slightly up from last quarter, when Cisco reported revenue of $4.4 billion. But Mr. Chambers said business in November, the first month of Cisco's fiscal second quarter, had pleased him. ''Our orders in November were linear and on expectations,'' he said. Mr. Chambers said Cisco had gained more market share last quarter than during any quarter in its history, and predicted that it would again win customers from its competitors this quarter. He also said he expected to acquire as many as a dozen companies during the next quarter, using some of Cisco's $19 billion in cash. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Panel Criticizes Restraints on Young Inmates
description: Juvenile justice officials in New Jersey have issued a report that strongly criticizes Joseph Clark, director of the Essex County Youth House, for using straitjackets and other restraints they condemned as ''egregious violations of professional standards.''

title: Minnesota Orchestra Takes a Lively Taste of the Future
description: Given the dwindling supply of conducting talent and the number of orchestras disparate in their search for what remains, the Minnesota Orchestra has landed itself something of a prize. Eije Oue's uneventful tenure as music director winds down this season and next, but then this city has Osmo Vanska to look forward to. Mr. Vanska was in town over the weekend with a preview of coming attractions: a 20th-century program including Einojuhani Rautavaara, Prokofiev and Vaughan Williams.

title: MARINES ADVANCE TOWARD KANDAHAR TO PREPARE SIEGE
description: United States marines advanced today from their Afghan desert base to prepare the siege of Kandahar, scouting enemy movements from helicopters and armored vehicles, and setting up checkpoints to seal the roads and prevent the Taliban from reinforcing -- or from escaping -- their largest stronghold, Pentagon officials said.

description: WARSAW-Theresa (nee Misiti). Of Riverdale, NY, formerly of Port Chester, NY, on December 4, 2001. Also surviving are 7 grandchildren and 6 great-grandchildren. Friends will be received Thursday, 4 to 8 PM, Hunt Stellato Funeral Home, 1601 Palisade Ave, Fort Lee, NJ.

description: Struggling with bankruptcies and hurt by foreign imports, the nation's biggest steel companies said yesterday that they were asking the Bush administration and Congress to back a plan allowing up to half a dozen steel makers to merge into a single company and to shift billions of dollars in retiree health care costs to the government.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bush Adviser Seeks Help On Cybersecurity
description: President Bush's computer security adviser, Richard Clarke, told a group of technology executives that the government would like to collaborate more with the private sector on security issues and asked them to help federal officials develop a national strategy for handling Internet threats and attacks. Mr. Clarke addressed the Business Software Alliance, which includes companies like Microsoft, Adobe and Symantec. He said that software companies and Internet service providers should protect customers from potential hackers -- making it easier to get software updates on personal computers, for example, and adding built-in firewalls to modems. But software companies have said their customers are more interested in advanced features than in better security. Mr. Clarke estimated that 90 percent of virus attacks could be prevented if software companies offered security improvements, beyond simply posting patch programs on their Web sites. ''America built cyberspace and America must secure its cyberspace,'' Mr. Clarke said.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 3 Cleared Of Coup Accusation
description: Three of the country's leading black businessmen, all central figures in the anti-apartheid struggle and senior members of the governing African National Congress, have been cleared of accusations that they were plotting to oust President Thabo Mbeki. The accusations against Cyril Ramaphosa, Tokyo Sexwale and Matthews Phosa were widely denounced as absurd and dangerous when they were made in April. In announcing the results of the investigation, Minister of Safety and Security Steve Tshwete, who first accused the men, expressed his ''profound apologies'' to them and their families. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer's Profit Slips
description: Scottish & Newcastle said first-half profit fell 8.7 percent, after it sold the Center Parcs holiday resorts and some pubs to focus on expanding its core brewing business. For the six months to Oct. 28, Scottish & Newcastle earned 148.9 million ($212 million), or 23 pence a share, compared with 163 million, or 25.6 pence a share, a year earlier. Sales declined 1.8 percent to 2.1 billion. Last year, the brewer of Newcastle Brown Ale acquired Kronenbourg beer of France, in an effort to expand its presence in Continental Europe. Analysts widely expect the beer industry to undergo consolidation as companies team up to cut costs. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESKIS, ALAN C.
description: SESKIS-Alan C. December 4, 2001, beloved husband of Barbara (nee Blickman), devoted father of Terry and Scott, loving brother of Barbara Harris, fond uncle of special nieces and nephews. A veteran of The U.S. Army serving in the Pacific during World War II, a graduate of The Fieldston School and Cornell University, and a longtime member of The New York Stock Exchange. A special friend to all who knew and loved him. Services Friday December 7, 2001, at 1:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: A Fish Stew of Many Flavors
description: BOUILLABAISSE, the Mediterranean fish stew that is more difficult to spell than to prepare, is traditionally neither an ide fixe nor the centerpiece of a grande bouffe, but a spur-of-the-moment combination of the day's catch. Trying to duplicate the real bouillabaisse is an exercise in frustration, as the traditional combination of fish is not found in American waters. But creating an admirable local version is no more difficult than making clam chowder.

title: Less Ambitious Security Force Is Favored by Afghan Leaders
description: The international security force now being envisaged for Afghanistan appears to be a far cry from the plans hatched by Britain and France last month for several thousand soldiers to help stabilize the country.

title: U.S. Is Trying to Lure Zimbabwe to Democracy
description: Adding to growing international pressure on Zimbabwe, Congress approved incentives today intended to persuade President Robert Mugabe to halt government abuses and undertake market reforms.

title: British Fashion's Changing of Guard

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Home Lender In Talks
description: The Housing Development Finance Corporation said it was discussing takeovers with several of its rivals as it tries to retain its position as the nation's leading home lender. Household Development is reportedly in talks with Tata Homefinance Limited, part owned by Abbey National P.L.C. of Britain, and several other companies to take over their business. The home loans sector has bucked the slowdown in other sectors, helped by falling interest rates and tax breaks. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZO, DR. PETER, CYRUS II, ''POP,''
description: RIZZO-Dr. Peter-Cyrus II, ''Pop,'' age 98 of Bronxville on December 3, 2001. Loving husband of the late Rose Dignan Rizzo, proud father of Thomas Dignan Rizzo, M.D. and the late Peter-Cyrus Rizzo III, M.D. Grandfather of Thomas, Jr., Peter, James, Peter-Cyrus IV, Marguerite Buttrick, Andrea Cuvelier, Kathryn, William and Francis. Great-grandfather of 18. An admired orthopedic surgeon, he served on the staffs of both The Hospital for Special Surgery and Lawrence Hospital for over 50 years and inspired both his sons and three grandsons to pursue medical careers. Visitation will be held at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, December 7 at 10AM, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Boys and Girls Harbor, 1 East 104th Street, New York, New York 10029 and St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, New York 10708.

title: Wide-Ranging Federal Sweep Changes Attitudes of Immigrants About U.S.
description: They settled in tattered apartment buildings in the working-class suburbs of northern Kentucky, thrilled to find fast-food jobs and to live among others who had managed to escape the parched fields back home in Mauritania. They smiled when they met their neighbors and worked on their English. A few managed to convince themselves that they had pierced the barrier into the American mainstream.

title: A Political Plan for Afghanistan
description: There has rarely been anything tidy about governance in Afghanistan, and that is likely to remain so long after the United Nations manages to get a new government up and running in Kabul. It is worth keeping that in mind as Afghanistan's rival ethnic and political groups near agreement on formation of a temporary coalition administration to take power in Kabul. Whatever the various factions come up with will not be easy to sustain and should not be mistaken by outsiders for anything approaching a national unity government capable of extending its rule throughout the land. But almost anything would be better than the Taliban or the anarchy that prevailed after the last Soviet-installed dictator was ousted in 1992.

title: Be on the Alert
description: To the Editor:

title: Team Winners in Science Contest
description: A precise new way of measuring the viscosity of thin lubricants of film earned SHIRA BILLET and DORA SOSNOWIK first place in the team category of the national Siemens Westinghouse Science and Technology Competition. Ms. Billet, 17, and Ms. Sosnowik, 16, seniors at the Stella K. Abraham High School for Girls in Hewlett Bay Park, N.Y., will divide a $100,000 scholarship.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SYKES, LOIS F.
description: SYKES-Lois F. Memorial service on Saturday, December 8, 12 noon, the Reformed Church, Pondfield Road, Bronxville, NY.

title: National Briefing | The Environment: Efforts To Clean Up Chesapeake Bay
description: Leaders from Maryland, Virginia, Pennsylvania and Washington, D.C., agreed to measures to reduce the flow of pollutants from urban sites into the Chesapeake Bay. The agreement calls for cutting storm water runoff, the fastest-growing source of bay pollution, on state and federal lands by 30 percent by 2008 in urban areas like Baltimore, Washington and Richmond, Va. The measures are part of an agreement signed last year to reduce nutrient pollution and sediment in the bay and its tributaries by 2010. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Some Cheeses Get Into the Wine Before Dinner
description: The combination of blue cheese and sweet wine is a flavor classic, and now a Belgian cheese maker, Jacquy Cange, has put them together in Fourme au Sauternes, a firm, smooth-textured cow's milk cheese, generously veined with blue, that has been washed with wine. The cheese offers a balance of rich creaminess and salt with a slightly honeyed aftertaste. Mr. Cange also makes Caprice de Blanche, a mellow, satin-textured cheese washed in Belgian white beer. A two-pound square is two inches thick and has a thin beige rind. The Fourme au Sauternes is $18.99 a pound and the Caprice is $17.99 a pound at Balducci's, Hay Day and Sutton Place Gourmet stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUPER, SIMON
description: SUPER-Simon. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our Board member Mollie Super, upon the loss of her husband. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Pataki Is Said to Weigh Increase In Cigarette Tax to $1.50 a Pack
description: Facing an enormous revenue shortfall in next year's budget, Gov. George E. Pataki is considering raising the state's tax on cigarettes to $1.50 a pack, which would be the highest tobacco tax in the nation, several lobbyists speaking on the condition of anonymity say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, LOUISE STEINHARDT
description: LOEB-Louise Steinhardt. The Faculty and Staff of Vivian Richenthal Institute of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine are saddened by the passing of Louise Steinhardt Loeb, a generous supporter of medical research and health care. Louise Loeb was a thoughtful and compassionate benefactress who shared our commitment to improving the lives of those suffering from pulmonary disease, and she will be missed. We extend our condolences to her children, Betty Levin, wife of Mount Sinai Trustee John A. Levin, and Jean Loeb, and to the entire family. Alvin S. Teirstein, MD Dr. George Baehr Professor of Clinical Medicine Director, Vivian Richenthal Institute of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Turning Up The Anti-U.S. Heat
description: North Korea stepped up its war of words, suggesting that it had to strengthen its military for self-defense against an increased threat from the United States. Rodong Sinmun, the newspaper of the ruling party, accused Washington of ''still pursuing the hard-line policy'' and scoffed at American calls for dialogue without preconditions. The North has stepped up its anti-American commentaries since the United States called for inspection of North Korean sites that might produce nuclear, chemical or biological weapons. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about artisanal cheese makers in California referred incorrectly to the product of Bellwether Farms in Valley Ford. It is made from the milk of sheep and cows, not goats.

title: Heisman Voters Thinking Passers
description: The odds are pretty good that the 67th Heisman Trophy winner will be a quarterback. But which one? The Downtown Athletic Club yesterday invited four of them to New York for Saturday's award dinner.

title: Suddenly, AIDS Makes the News in China
description: China's news media have been suddenly overflowing with stories about AIDS this week, from patients' testimonials to a fictional television drama about an H.I.V.-positive businessman.

title: The Intifada Is Over
description: The Palestinian Intifada II is finished.

title: Army Decides Not to Back Breaching Of Four Dams
description: Putting itself in line with the Bush administration's stance on a contentious environmental issue, the Army Corps of Engineers said today that it would recommend against breaching four large hydroelectric dams on the Snake River in eastern Washington State.

title: Venezuela Businesses Plan a Shutdown to Protest Leftist Policies
description: For half a century, discerning diners have known that the place to go for juicy steaks and seafood specialties is Tarzilandia. Tradition is everything at this Caracas institution, where customers sit among tropical plants and squawking macaws while choosing from a menu that has changed little since the 1950's.

title: Rahlves Is Portable Maier Happily Living on Edges
description: The unimaginable images were still as fresh as wet paint in the days after a summertime motorcycle accident left Hermann Maier crumpled on an embankment.

title: A Symphony for the Senses, at a Turkish Spot in Queens
description: CLUMSILY translated from Turkish, nazar means giving someone the eye, with the connotation that whatever is being looked at is worth seeing. Hence the eye embedded in the small ramp from the sidewalk to the door of Nazar Turkish Cuisine, a new restaurant in Sunnyside, Queens, and the occasional small eye found on the walls of its inviting little dining room. But at Nazar, the eye is not nearly as important as the nose.

title: In a Stressed City, No Room at the Bar
description: THEY were three deep at Guastavino's bar last Thursday night, downing flirtinis, cucumber martinis and patriots, a red, white and blue martini suitable for the times. Bartenders kept up a steady beat -- mix, mix, mix -- while waiters rushed to deliver trays of frothy daiquiris and coffee martinis.

title: They Looked, They Clicked, a New E-Mail Virus Conquered
description: A new malicious computer virus named Goner began making the rounds of the online world yesterday like an Internet IQ test. Anyone who has not learned the most important computer security message of the last two years -- do not open any unexpected files that come attached to e-mail messages -- ends up infecting the computer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BOB
description: ROSENBERG-Bob. So often we cite you. So often we think of you. So often we miss you. The Rosenberg Grou

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Deptford Township: Penalties For Fans
description: Unruly parents at their children's sporting events, as well as coaches, officials and other spectators, can be banned from the games and ordered to attend anger-management classes before they are allowed to return, under a new law passed Monday night by the township. It states that anyone who starts a scuffle or any type of threatened or actual physical or verbal abuse will be banned for 12 months. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A Bleaker Santa's-Eye View; Bell-Ringer Sees More Anxiety and Less Giving
description: There is a street-corner Santa who works Fifth Avenue at Rockefeller Center with a bell in his hand and a red chimney with a money slot at his side. He is the Santa who works on one knee.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Justice Department interviewing of men of Middle Eastern background in the Detroit area gave a misspelled surname in some copies for the Midwest director of the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, who sat in on some sessions. He is Imad Hamad, not Hammad.

title: Debt in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson to Lead Cyclones
description: The Mets yesterday named Howard Johnson as manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones, their short-season Class A affiliate, and retained Bob Ojeda as the team's pitching coach. Donovan Mitchell will serve as the Cyclones' hitting and first-base coach. ''I think it'll be a great mix of guys for hopefully another championship,'' Jim Duquette, the Mets' assistant general manager, said of the Cyclones, who won a share of the New York-Penn League championship in their inaugural season last summer. Brooklyn and Williamsport were declared co-champions when the league canceled the championship series after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Finding, and Savoring, A Muse in 'McHale's Navy'
description: The composer and saxophonist John Zorn emerged in the late 1970's from the Lower East Side avant-garde scene as the long-haired bad boy of contemporary music. A brash debunker of genres and categories, he claimed thorny composers like Pierre Boulez and hard-core bands like Napalm Death as equal influences upon his quick-cutting, stream-of-consciousness works.

title: The Great Optics Debate
description: The artist David Hockney believes that as far back as 1430, great artists like van Eyck, Caravaggio, and Vermeer secretly used optical devices to help them paint.

title: For Uptown Palates, A Would-Be Diner
description: EVERY culture has certain foods, and certain kinds of eating places, that can take on an almost mythic resonance. France has its cafes, bouchons and bistros where diners can count on pot-au-feu or steak au poivre. England without its horrible little ''caffs'' would not be England, and no program of culinary reconstruction will ever eradicate the English taste for mushy peas and Bird's custard. America has the diner, and immortal food like the cheeseburger, French fries, fried onion rings, baked beans, meatloaf and tall layer cakes.

title: 3 U.S. Servicemen Killed by 'Friendly Fire' Near Kandahar
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Opposition forces closed in on the last Taliban and Al Qaeda stronghold in the eastern mountains of Afghanistan today, while intensified combat in the south led to the deaths of three American soldiers in an accidental bombing.

description: NEW YORK

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Jails 43 More As Teachers Defy an Order
description: Forty-three more striking teacher-union members from Middletown, N.J., were sentenced to a week in jail today for defying a court back-to-work order, joining four colleagues already jailed.

title: As Shooting Spate Persists, 15 Police Leaders Face Transfers
description: Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik will transfer the leaders of at least 15 police commands after a monthlong increase in shootings in the city, officials said.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Embraces Pataki at Convention
description: At the giant A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention here, Republican politicians are, but for a few exceptions, persona non grata.

title: Day of Honor And of Pain For 40,000
description: One by one, they rose to stand in for the lost. Widows holding infants. Parents grieving for sons. Police officers with badges adorned with black bands of mourning. ''Receiving the medal for Officer Smith,'' Chief of Department Joseph J. Esposito said with a catch in his throat, ''are her husband, Officer Jim Smith, and their daughter.''

title: When Charity Gets Complicated
description: To the Editor:

title: Spencer Holst, 75, Writer and Teller of Fables
description: Spencer Holst, a writer of fables and a fixture of the downtown Manhattan avant-garde scene for 30 years, died on Nov. 23 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Purchased
description: Continuing its streak of state bank purchases, Brazil's second largest private bank, Banco Itau, bought Banco do Estado de Goias for $271 million. Itau narrowly beat out Brazil's largest private bank, Banco Bradesco, to win the privatization auction for the 153-branch bank in the agricultural state of Goias, offering more than double the base price. Itau has purchased three other state banks in recent years in its effort to surpass Bradesco as the country's largest retail bank. Brazil plans to auction five other small state banks by April. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Sidemen Become Frontmen, and What Follows Is Absurd
description: Polygraph Lounge is what happens to professional sidemen in their 40's when they've taken too many background roles. They tend to go a bit insane. Rob Schwimmer, a keyboardist, and Mark Stewart, a guitarist - each has a long list of rock, jazz, theater and avant-garde classical credits - have channeled their insanity into a hyperspeed matrix of dumb-and-smart references, lyric- and-music swapping between iconic songs, the playing of absurd instruments and Spike Jones-style extended parodies.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Court To Consider Redistricting
description: The State Supreme Court will consider on Friday whether to return the job of redrawing Congressional districts to a commission that failed last week to agree on a plan. By law, Connecticut must reduce its Congressional districts to five from six. But the bipartisan Reapportionment Commission failed to meet a deadline of Nov. 30. The high court must now decide whether to return the job to the commission, turn it over to a legal scholar or do the job itself. The deadline for a final plan is Feb. 15. Separately, the commission was able to agree on how to redraw districts for the State Legislature.

title: Holds Enough Blades To Startle the Swiss Army
description: This sleek, angled stainless steel knife holder, sold by the Museum of Modern Art, is not only stunning to look at, it solves a couple of problems. Unlike wooden knife blocks fitted with little slits of varying size, its flexible accordion-pleated plastic insert easily holds more than a dozen knives, no matter how large or small. And the insert can be removed for cleaning. The knife holder is $79 at the museum's shops, 44 West 53rd Street and 81 Spring Street (Broadway); from (800) 447-6662; or at www.momastore.org.

title: Some Skimp on Tinsel as Others Splurge
description: This year, many managers are cutting back or canceling office parties, but Alfred Portale is not one of them.

title: Levin to Retire From Post as Chief Executive of AOL Time Warner
description: AOL Time Warner Inc. ( news/quote ), the world's largest media business, announced today that its chief executive, Gerald M. Levin, would retire in May and would be succeeded by Richard D. Parsons, the company's co-chief operating officer.

title: When the Hero Wept
description: Gradually, with no one seeming to notice, Americans have changed their feelings about the right of men to cry. When after Sept. 11 big, strong, brave New York City firemen broke down, unashamed, during dozens of television interviews, the public's respect for them seemed only to increase. And when President Bush revealed a rim of tears after making one of his first televised statements on the terrorist attacks, Americans felt comforted, not scornful. What a change from 1972, when Senator Edmund Muskie's presidential campaign crumbled after he appeared to be crying as he defended his wife against disparaging remarks.

title: Honda Opens a U.S. Factory and a Front Against the Big 3
description: Top executives of Honda Motor criticized the Big Three today for what they view as a double standard on fuel economy. The executives said that domestic manufacturers were not willing to face the environmental implications of becoming increasingly reliant on sales of pickups and sport utility vehicles.

title: Companies Are Warned About Rosy Numbers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission cautioned investors yesterday against relying on ''pro forma'' earnings numbers and told companies that when they used them, they should make clear, in plain English, just how the results differed from profit figures calculated using generally accepted accounting principles.

title: Inspired by Chance Meetings
description: We're in a landmark building, the Aon ( news/quote ) Building. On Sept. 11, our chairman was in Miami. The vice chairman wasn't here either. The younger people were teary. After the second tower was hit, I said: "Being in the firm is an option. You don't have to be a hero to stay." After the Pentagon attack I said, "We're leaving." I was making the decision on instinct. It was one of those moments you are completely and totally learning by doing. Chicago was shutting down. Massive crowds were very quiet. I was traveling and had my wheelie. I pulled it behind me as I walked home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IOVENKO, MICHAEL
description: IOVENKO-Michael. The Board of Directors, Executive Director, staff, children and families of Berkshire Farm Center and Services for Youth express our deepest sorrow on the passing of Michael Iovenko. He was a vital and generous member of our Board of Directors for 32 years. He held the position of Vice President from 1973 until 1974 and 1980 until the time of his death. He served as President from 1975 until 1979. Mr. Iovenko chaired various committees during his tenure including residential care and treatment, community-based services and nominating. Mr. Iovenko was very involved in the initial development of Berkshire's Community-Based Services, which has grown into a network of programs serving children and families statewide. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Nancy, sons Christopher and William and the entire family. Charles H. Mott, President Board of Directors

title: Who's Joey Bishop?
description: It's endsville for that bum Osama. Time to send him to the big casino. That Clyde can't hide. When that crumb is gone, ring-a-ding.

title: Cloning Executive Presses Senate
description: The president of the biotechnology company whose cloning research has created a political uproar predicted today that his company would make quick progress toward developing therapies and urged Congress not to ban the work.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Shares In Water Utility Sold
description: Europe's biggest media company, Vivendi Universal, sold 9.3 percent of its stake in the water utility Vivendi Environnement, raising $1.1 billion. Vivendi will retain a 63 percent stake in Vivendi Environnement and intends to keep the stake, the company said. Socit Gnrale and Deutsche Bank are handling the sale of 32.4 million shares at about 38 euros each, a 6 percent discount to the stock's closing price Monday, but 11 percent higher than the initial offering price of 34 euros last year. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AT&T Ends Excite Bid
description: The AT&T Corporation dropped its $307 million offer to buy Excite@Home after the company, the bankrupt Internet service, disconnected AT&T customers over the weekend. No other buyers are likely to emerge, analysts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSCHWEIGER, RICHARD
description: BRAUNSCHWEIGER-Richard of Katonah, NY, age 47 on December 2, 2001, after a courageous battle with Cancer. Vice President of Credit Agricole Indosuez Chevreux Securities. Beloved husband of Lorna (Lenley). Loving father of Matthew, Julie and Dana. Cherished son of Gretchen and Herbert Braunschweiger. Devoted brother of Carl Braunschweiger (Joan) and Gretchen King (James). Dear brother-in-law of Susan and Max Kooper. Caring uncle of Emma, Elyse, Eric and Erin Braunschweiger, August and Aiden King and Jay and Keith Kooper. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St Wednesday December 5th, 11:30am. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NYC 10021. Fund #

description: Adapted from Paola di Mauro

title: Uneven Effort Leaves Islanders at a Loss
description: All the Islanders' effervescence has apparently fizzled. Michael Peca, the captain, said they have struggled, pressed and punished themselves too hard for their mistakes. If only they could make hockey a joy, as it was one long month ago.

title: Art for Arts School's Sake
description: ''We are not discouraged!'' the invitation began. ''Rather we are trying to figure out how to live to fight another day.'' No, these were not revolutionary warriors, exactly. Rather, they were a team of educators trying to raise money to open the Bronx Charter School for the Arts in Hunts Point.

title: Honors to a Studious Family
description: At its 75th anniversary celebration tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Marriott Hotel, Long Island University will honor 75 alumni, including HOWARD M. LORBER, chairman of Nathan's Famous Inc., and VELMA SCANTLEBURY WHITE, a transplant surgeon. The university will also honor a family: the Manziones.

description: INTERNET

title: Ground-Penetrating Radar to Aid in Cleanup
description: In its efforts to clear ground zero with as little disruption as possible to the surrounding area in Lower Manhattan, the city is exploring the use of ground-penetrating radar to map the tangle of underground utilities without digging them up first, a spokesman for the Department of Design and Construction said yesterday.

title: Battery Park Residents Oppose A Temporary Pedestrian Bridge
description: Dozens of angry residents of Battery Park City spoke out against the proposed construction of a temporary pedestrian bridge at a community board meeting last night, asking for alternative designs that would not cut across park space in the southern end of their neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWEN, AUGUSTA APTHEKER
description: LOWEN-Augusta Aptheker. Formerly of Great Neck, NY, died November 27, 2001 at the home of daughter, Abot Bensussen, in San Diego, CA. Born in 1911. Also survived by brother, Herbert Aptheker and children, Brenda Lowen and Dr. Beal Lowen.

title: Sprewell Feels Right at Home on the Road and Lifts the Knicks
description: Latrell Sprewell is the type to get excited about a pickup game in the park, so he does not need an incentive when he takes the floor for the Knicks. But Sprewell acknowledged that outside factors made tonight's game against the Milwaukee Bucks more special, more exhilarating.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Ads Down 4% In Quarter
description: Internet advertising in the United States decreased 4 percent in the third quarter to $1.79 billion from $1.86 billion in the previous quarter, according to a report prepared by PricewaterhouseCoopers for the Interactive Advertising Bureau, a trade group. Ad revenue for the comparable period last year totaled $1.98 billion. Over all, Internet ad revenue for the first nine months of 2001 fell to $5.55 billion from $6.06 billion a year earlier, an 8 percent decline. The report also noted that the top 10 online media companies received three-quarters of all Internet ad revenue in the third quarter of 2001. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORT, EVELYN J.
description: PORT-Evelyn J. December 2, 2001. Evie was a dear and treasured friend. She lived her life with dignity, determination & courage. We will miss her. Our thoughts are with Darren and Stephanie, her proudest achievements, and the entire family. Jayne and Burt Goldstein Nancy and Jerry Reisman Marcie Rosenberg

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Apple Founder Joins Start-Up's Board
description: Danger Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up working on an always-connected hand-held Internet device, will announce today that Stephen Wozniak, a co-founder of Apple Computer, will join its board. In an interview, Mr. Wozniak, left, who created Apple with Steven P. Jobs, said he would contribute engineering and entrepreneurial advice. Danger, based in Palo Alto, Calif., expects to begin selling its first device, called the Hiptop, for about $200 early next year through an undisclosed telecommunications carrier. Intended to compete with devices like the Blackberry pager, the Hiptop will enable users to check e-mail, surf the Internet and store appointments and contacts. In October, Danger raised $36 million in financing from venture capital concerns. ''I think they have an interesting ride ahead of them,'' Mr. Wozniak said. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: SPRINT CUTS EARNINGS FORECAST FOR THE QUARTER
description: The Sprint Corporation, the third-largest long-distance phone company, cut its per-share profit forecast for this quarter by as much as 21 percent, saying sales of services like data transmission had fallen short. Profit will be 31 cents to 33 cents, down from a previously projected 37 cents to 39 cents, the company said. The forecast excludes $2 billion in pretax costs Sprint has said it will incur to shut down its high-speed United States data business.

title: The Night They Bobbed for Foie Gras
description: IT was simply outrageous. But then, of course, it was meant to shock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMMERMAN, EVELYN B.
description: IMMERMAN-Evelyn B. On December 4, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Immy, loving mother of Michael and Richard, mother-inlaw of Dana and Marion, and grandmother of Tyler, Morgan, and David.

title: U.S. Hopes American Taliban Will Tell All
description: John Walker Lindh, the 20-year-old American who was captured with Taliban soldiers in northern Afghanistan, could provide a bounty of useful intelligence about the recruiting methods, hide-outs, supply routes and lower-level command structure of the Taliban military, senior Pentagon officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, STACY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Stacy. Homemaker and vice president of StaVal, Inc., E&S Sales of Union, NJ, resident of Peapack, NJ, passed away on December 3, 2001 at age 37 after battling breast cancer for 12 years, but she was like that/a fighter. Stacy was everything to her husband for 13 years, Robert, and to her son Jonah, her parents, Ed and Sue, and to her sister Valerie. She also meant so much to so many. Stacy was generous, in the truest sense of the word. She took care of others before she thought of herself. Stacy made her life full of music, laughter, and storytelling, and she gave all of this as a gift to everyone who met her. Even now, when the world is a sadder place without her, she is warming the hearts of her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Valerie Fund.

title: China Resists Efforts to Make Donation of Organs Feasible
description: Li Hao has been ready for a decade to help meet China's yawning demand for transplantable organs by donating his body after he dies, but there is currently little chance that anything other than his corneas will be used as more than a teaching tool.

description: To the Editor:

title: From King of Comedy to Ruler of the Roost
description: Bernie Mac still recalls the moment, when he was 5, that he decided to become a comedian. Mr. Mac, who grew up in a poor neighborhood on the South Side of Chicago, said he walked in from the backyard one evening and saw his mother sitting on a chair weeping.

title: LA-Z-BOY FORMS JOINT VENTURE WITH STEINHOFF GROUP
description: La-Z-Boy Inc., the furniture maker, said it formed a joint venture with the Steinhoff Group of Germany to sell recliners in Europe. La-Z-Boy Europe will design reclining chairs and sofas and manufacture and sell them throughout Europe using Steinhoff's German factories and distribution network. Steinhoff has factories in Europe, South Africa and Australia, and employs 21,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 21 about a campaign to preserve rare breeds of domesticated turkey referred incorrectly to the Broadbreasted White, today's main commercial variety, which suffers a number of side effects from selective breeding. While it must be inseminated artificially, it can in fact lay eggs.

title: Waiting for Babies Who Will Never Know Their Fathers
description: After three failed pregnancies, Jose and Paulina del Carmen Cardona were ecstatic at summer's end as each month ticked by and each trip to the doctor provided nothing but good news on the baby.

title: Panel Backs $15 Billion More in Emergency Funds
description: Though Senate Republicans accused Democrats of playing politics with homeland defense, the Appropriations Committee voted an additional $7.5 billion today for measures to combat bioterrorism and improve security at ports, borders and nuclear facilities.

title: Sweet, But a Bit Less Sinful
description: THIS year the season of indulgence, especially in New York, began long before Thanksgiving. From now until Jan. 2, more and more tantalizing goodies will be tempting us all.

title: Sondheim Sues to Proceed With His Show 'Gold!'
description: Bringing down the curtain on the first act of a bitter backstage battle, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction against Scott Rudin, the millionaire Hollywood and Broadway producer, that stops him, at least for now, from preventing the production of a long-suffering, long-gestating new Stephen Sondheim musical called ''Gold!''

title: A Wholesome Serving of Red, White and Blue
description: ''Tintypes,'' a musical revue of turn-of-century (20th, of course) Americana that had a short run on Broadway two decades ago, has been revived by the Melting Pot Theater in the snug confines of the McGinn-Cazale Theater on the Upper West Side.

title: Old School Meets New In Kidd Vs. Marbury
description: Jason Kidd remembers when he first returned to Dallas in 1997 after the Mavericks traded him to Phoenix. He was younger then, infused with pride and thoughts of vindication.

title: Accord on New Leader
description: After eight days, an agreement has been reached on the leadership and makeup of an interim Afghan government, tentatively scheduled to take power on Dec. 22, delegates meeting in Bonn, Germany, said.

title: A Germany-Israel heritage travel program. So why not?
description: IN September 1997, at the American Society of Travel Agents Congress in Los Angeles, a German delegate approached an Israeli delegate with an idea: Why not start a joint travel program focusing on significant sites of Jewish heritage in both Israel and Germany?

title: Sports of The Times; Escalator Warning For Dixie
description: AND now for the traveler's advisory for this weekend. Beware manic activity in the Atlanta area -- particularly zealots running down the up escalator.

title: Our Towns; Commerce Comes Calling In the Park
description: IT may have lawns, benches, winding pathways and frolicking children, but whatever you do, don't call the four-acre greensward in downtown Plainfield a park.

title: Capitals Find Way To Solve Richter
description: So much for Mike Richter's shutout streak and the Rangers' three-game winning streak. If the Rangers could find anything positive in tonight's 5-2 loss to the Washington Capitals, it was that they have to play the Capitals only one more time in the regular season.

title: The $69 Million Mayor
description: New York City's mayor-elect, Michael Bloomberg, told New York magazine last spring that he planned to spend no more than about $30 million of his own money for his campaign. ''At some point, you start to look obscene,'' he explained. That remark is likely to haunt Mr. Bloomberg for a long time. His filing with the city's Board of Elections this week showed that he spent almost $69 million of his own money to become mayor. It is a record for New York and for the nation -- the biggest price tag for a mayoral campaign, or any race below the level of president, in American history. It comes close to the amount that Ross Perot spent on his third-party presidential campaign in 1992.

title: The 50-Year History Of a Killing Machine
description: ''The B-52 is a very large aircraft,'' a crew member says in the straightforward new documentary ''B-52,'' which begins a two-week run today at Film Forum. Several clean-cut Air Force personnel give the aircraft's stats, which include a weight of 184,000 pounds when empty and a wingspan of 185 feet. The plane has been around for what feels like forever, and in this respect it seems like the ordnance version of a great white shark, an enormous and apparently efficient killing machine that hasn't evolved much since its creation ''over a weekend in a hotel in 1948.'' (It was first presented to the military in 1952.)

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani handed his plan for cutting $766 million from the current year's budget to the City Council last night, detailing millions of dollars in reductions to city agencies, schools, libraries and programs for the elderly and children.

description: Nassau County's executive-elect, Thomas R. Suozzi, is promising cash prizes to county workers for their best money-saving ideas. He has set a goal of $10 million for budget savings. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Set To Fly Pataki And Giuliani To Israel
description: The mayor-elect, the governor and probably the sitting mayor will all board a private plane on Saturday -- leaving behind a budget crisis, a mayoral transition and a nation on the highest state of alert -- to visit Israel and show their support.

title: Ex-Sotheby's Chairman Convicted of Price-Fixing
description: A. Alfred Taubman, the shopping mall mogul who became chairman and largest controlling stockholder of Sotheby's auction house, was found guilty today of conspiring with his supposed rival Christie's to set the same rates for sellers at auctions over the past six years.

description: Joe Mach talks Russian oil in an Oklahoma accent.

title: A Beat That Demands Dancing in the Aisles
description: Orquesta Aragn, a 12-man band from Cuba, packed 10 of its old hits into an introductory medley when it played at Town Hall on Saturday night, but that didn't prevent the audience from shouting more requests. There were still plenty of choices left, since Orquesta Aragn has been working steadily since 1939.

title: Sydney, the Next Wave
description: JUST as they are in New York, times are tough for restaurateurs in Sydney -- ''tougher than tough,'' as one of the local superchefs said.

title: Jordanian Student Held in U.S. Says Police Abused Him in Jail
description: A lawyer for a Jordanian student who was charged with lying before a federal grand jury investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks says his client was physically abused after being jailed in Lower Manhattan, court papers show.

title: O. J. Simpson's House Searched in a Drug Inquiry
description: Federal agents executed a search warrant this morning at O. J. Simpson's house in suburban Miami as part of a drug investigation. He was not arrested.

title: Arlington's Burial Regulations Anger Family of Hijacked Pilot
description: Family members of Charles F. Burlingame, who served 25 years in the Navy and was the captain of American Airlines Flight 77 when it crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11, said today that they were shocked and angered that their request that he be buried in a plot at Arlington National Cemetery had been denied.

title: A Few Lessons From the Kitchen
description: PAOLA DI MAURO'S talent lies more in her philosophy and approach to cooking than in formal training or technique. She cooks seasonally, uses what she has at hand, and prepares everything from start to finish, right at her stove. There is no advanced prep work, complex stocks or special equipment (other than a meat slicer). And yet, her cooking has a sophistication and purity that has kept chefs visiting her kitchen year after year.

title: Suffolk Real Estate Chief Resigns Amid Charges of Deal for Client
description: A top Suffolk County official resigned yesterday, a day after he appeared before a county legislative committee to defend himself against news reports that he had arranged a favorable deal for a business associate who sold land to the county.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: More National Guard At Border
description: An additional 55 National Guard soldiers have been sent to join the 120 who are guarding Texas border crossings with Mexico. Most of the additional troops were headed to El Paso and Laredo, the busiest commercial crossings. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: Alpine Ski Package
description: For those who prefer Alpine scenery, companion rates at Interlaken are being cut by half for three January departures from SkiEurope. The first person pays $870, the other $435. For that, each gets round-trip air fare on Continental from New York to Zurich, seven nights at the three-star Chalet-Hotel Oberland, a rental car at the airport and daily breakfast buffet. A one-week Jungfrau Region ski pass costs about $171 at 1.70 Swiss francs to the dollar. Trip dates are Jan. 4 to 12, Jan. 11 to 19 and Jan. 18 to 26. Information: (800) 333-5533 or www.ski-europe.com .

title: Anxious? Sleepless? In a Survey, Your Mom, Again, Tells You Why
description: JUST when you were re-evaluating your life-work equation in the context of a changed world, and now that you are worrying that the career you were so proud of might evaporate in this sagging economy, a researcher at the University of Michigan has proof of what you already suspected: your mother thinks you have your priorities out of whack.

title: In a Tinderbox, Sri Lanka President Turns Up the Heat
description: In the early years of her presidency, Chandrika Kumaratunga embodied the hope for peace in Sri Lanka, a democracy that had then struggled through more than a decade of insurrection, ethnic strife and terrorism.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Middletown: Fugitive In Murder Case Is Held
description: A man accused of a 1995 murder and listed as one of New Jersey's 12 most-wanted fugitives was arrested while working at a Home Depot store, the state police said. The man, William Douglas Bell, 42, is wanted in Newark in the killing of a woman who may have been his girlfriend. He apparently lived in upstate New York for several years using the alias Corey M. Coleman, said Michael DeWitt, a state police investigator. Acting on an anonymous tip, the police arrested Mr. Bell on Saturday in Middletown.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the excavation of the World Trade Center referred incorrectly to the makeup of the basement retaining wall. It now consists of concrete; slurry, a clay mixture, was used only as temporary filler while the trench for the wall was being dug.

title: Greens of a Different Color, in Miniature
description: These perky infant amaranth leaves are called microgreens even though they are a gorgeous burgundy. Grown organically in the Catskills, they add a bittersweet, almost wheaty flavor to a salad or can be used as a topping for soups, open-face sandwiches, eggs or even seafood dishes. One-ounce containers of De La Terre amaranth are $3.95 at Dean & DeLuca and Agata & Valentina through December.

title: Easy Pan Prep, for Bakers Whose Aim Is Steady
description: Using Baker's Joy, a spray coating for baking pans, requires a bit of practice. This clever timesaver, a combination of soybean oil and flour, does an excellent one-step job of greasing and flouring baking pans. But you have to work fast to get a light and fairly uniform coating. A good way to do it is to put your baking pan in the sink and let your spraying go a bit wild. A pastry brush can be used to smooth uneven spots. Baker's Joy also works well on cookie cutters and to coat bowls that will hold rising dough. When sprayed in the bottom of a heavy casserole, it helps in the browning of stew meat. It is $7.99 a can at the New York Cake and Baking Center, 56 West 22nd Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILICI, JONATHAN FRANCIS

title: Nasdaq Above 2,000; Dow Breaks 10,000
description: Stocks surged today as investors rallied around a new and unexpected sign of growth in business spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNEY, PAUL
description: CHERNEY-Paul, President and founder of Cinefot International, a photographic import-export management business until his retirement in 1987, died Decemer 3, 2001. He was 94. Born in Budapest, Hungary, he grew up in Vienna, and came to the United States in 1929. A major in the United States Air Force during World War II, he was stationed in London as a principal prisoner of war interrogator with the Combined Intelligence Objectives subcommittee of the Royal Air Force. President Emeritus of the National Association of Exporting Companies, in 1972 he received the ''E'' Award from the United States Department of Commerce for Excellence in promoting American exports. His first wife, Clare Rubin died in 1944. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis Brighten Cherney of Lenox, MA., and four daughters, Elizabeth Gordon of Sebastopol, CA; Sara Evans of New York City; Geraldine McElroy of Davidson, NC.; and Michelle Gillett of Stockbridge, MA; ten grandchildren, and three greatgrandchildren.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Rob Aronson was named a national sales account manager in the New York office of the Obie Media Corporation. He had been a national account executive in the Baltimore office of Clear Channel Outdoor, part of Clear Channel Communications.

title: An Echo of Big Dreams Of a World With Big Steel
description: The business executives gathered for a dinner on a brisk December evening in New York City's exclusive University Club. The speaker was the guest of honor, the young ambitious president of the nation's leading steel company. His chosen topic: his vision of the steel industry at the dawn of a new century.

title: Microsoft's Latest Settlement
description: Microsoft's plan to give away $1 billion worth of computer technology to the nation's poorest schools is hard to attack. Nobody is against improving technological resources for needy youngsters. But it may not be a proper settlement to end class-action antitrust suits. Federal District Judge J. Frederick Motz ought to push the software company and the plaintiffs' lawyers in these cases to substantially alter the terms of the settlement. Otherwise, he should consider rejecting it.

title: Bush Freezes Assets of Biggest U.S. Muslim Charity, Calling It a Deadly Terror Group
description: President Bush significantly broadened his counterattack on terrorist groups today, freezing the assets of the largest Muslim charity in the United States. Mr. Bush accused the charity of supporting Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that took responsibility for three suicide bombings in Israel over the weekend.

title: NBC AND DISCOVERY IN TALKS ON CHILDREN'S PROGRAMMING
description: NBC may announce as early as today that it has reached an agreement to sell its Saturday morning programming hours to Discovery Communications. Executives close to the deal said last night that Discovery had agreed to pay about $6 million a year for control of Saturday mornings on NBC. One executive said the deal would probably cover a three-year period to start next fall. Under the agreement, Discovery would fully control the NBC morning programming block and would reap all of the benefits from advertising sales. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: An Equal-Opportunity Throne
description: The governing Liberal Democratic Party began deliberations on whether the law governing imperial succession should be changed to allow women to ascend the throne. The deliberations began three days after the birth of a baby princess, the first child of Crown Prince Naruhito and Princess Masako, with public support growing to change a 1948 law that allows only male succession. There have been no male births in the imperial family since 1965. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has said he will support a change in the law but has urged careful consultations beforehand. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Stewart Has Found His Comfort Zone
description: Through seven seasons, Kordell Stewart has waded through taxing times with the Pittsburgh Steelers, periods in which he has been benched, forced to play wide receiver and scorned by fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNCHER, JACK

title: Justices Hear Case on the Disabilities Act and Seniority
description: In the second of three cases that it will decide this term under the Americans With Disabilities Act, the Supreme Court wrestled today with the meaning of the ''reasonable accommodation'' that the law obliges employers to offer to workers who could not otherwise remain on the job.

title: POLYMEDICA SAYS IT IS BEING INVESTIGATED BY GOVERNMENT
description: PolyMedica, a leading maker of diabetes test kits, said the Securities and Exchange Commission was conducting a formal investigation of the company's accounting, financial reports, sales of securities and other matters. Previously, the company had said the S.E.C. was conducting an inquiry. PolyMedica, based in Woburn, Mass., is already being investigated by federal authorities looking into possible fraud. The F.B.I. is investigating PolyMedica's Liberty Medical Supply and Liberty Home Pharmacy units.

title: A Stodgy Museum Spruces Up
description: The Victoria and Albert Museum can rightly boast one of the world's greatest collections of applied and decorative arts, one that mirrors the ingenuity of Britain's designers and artisans and the wide reach of its once global empire. Yet in the recent scramble to expand and refurbish the museums here, the V&A, as it is widely known, has come to be seen as a poor relation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Sotheby's Verdict
description: The jury in the federal price-fixing trial of the former Sotheby's chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, ended its first day of deliberations yesterday without a verdict. The eight men and four women sent out several notes requesting pieces of evidence. They also wanted to rehear Judge George B. Daniels's instructions on the antitrust law, under which Mr. Taubman is charged with conspiring with his counterpart at Christie's to set nonnegotiable fees for auction sellers. Ralph Blumenthal (NYT)

description: Pressed by employers, some of the nation's biggest insurers are introducing a new kind of health plan that would significantly change the way employees are reimbursed for ordinary medical expenses.

title: Giambi to Join Yanks Barring Bid by the A's
description: The Yankees are nearing the finish line in negotiations for Jason Giambi, and from all indications, they are going to sign him. But there is a something that worries some in the organization: a late bid by the Oakland Athletics, a final financial and emotional appeal from Giambi's first and only team.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Farm Prices Frozen
description: The government decided to freeze price levels for rice and barley next year after farmers protested World Trade Organization rules that call for opening markets to foreign rice, which is much cheaper than rice grown in the country. The government also reduced its purchases of rice for mounting stockpiles despite a plea by Paul Gruenwald, a representative of the International Monetary Fund, for increased government spending to speed economic recovery. Mr. Gruenwald, on the fourth anniversary of the signing of the agreement under which the fund pieced together a $58 billion package of loans to bail out the economy, also suggested another cut in interest rates. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Layering Sunshine in a Bowl
description: LIKE many French-trained chefs, I learned to make a good number of my desserts based on my experience as an apprentice in Paris. But when the holidays roll around, I find myself looking to England. The images of old-fashioned desserts like sugar plums, mincemeat and plum pudding seem so charming.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Newspaper Fined
description: A newspaper was ordered to pay more than $200,000 after a High Court judge found it guilty of contempt of court for publishing an article about the whereabouts of two young men convicted of killing a toddler in 1993. The Manchester Evening News published details about the incarceration of Jon Venables and Robert Thompson last June after the Parole Board ruled that they were ready to be released from detention, having been assigned new identities to protect them from vigilantes. The two, 10 at the time, tortured and beat 2-year-old James Bulger to death after luring him from a shopping center in Liverpool. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

description: Joachim Milberg, chief executive of BMW A.G., surprised his own company today by announcing plans to retire in May, almost one year ahead of schedule.

title: Lawmakers Weigh a Mental-Health Deal
description: House and Senate negotiators have begun serious discussions on a compromise that would broaden health insurance coverage for workers with mental illness while limiting the cost to employers. But senior House Republicans and business groups are staunchly opposed to the deal.

title: For Saudi Cleric, Battle Shapes Up as Infidel vs. Islam
description: The blind and withered cleric sat cross-legged on dirty carpets, in a canvas tent far from the grand palaces and mosques of official Saudi Arabia. But his listeners hung on each quavering word. To them, Sheik Hamoud al-Shuaibi was speaking a bold truth.

The hospitals posted nearly $115 million in profit on $11.7 billion of revenues in 2000, up from a $257 million loss in 1999, according to a report released Monday by the association. description: In the parking lot of a nondescript suburban office building here, about 300 supporters of the Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development gathered tonight for a religious vigil. Three times they knelt and rose as one, their lips mouthing nearly silent Arabic prayers.

title: Residents Flee Slum in Nairobi After 12 Are Killed in Clashes
description: Thousands of residents poured out of one of Africa's largest slums today, fleeing their ramshackle homes in the Kibera settlement after ethnic clashes prompted by poverty, overcrowding and a simmering rent dispute claimed 12 lives.

title: Enron Paid $55 Million For Bonuses
description: Just days before Enron filed for bankruptcy and laid off 4,000 people, it paid out $55 million in bonuses to about 500 employees, according to several people who had dealings with the company.

title: Clan Leader Turned Statesman: Hamid Karzai
description: Hamid Karzai, who has been named to lead an interim government in Afghanistan, is at once a traditional tribal chief from the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar and a longtime anti-Taliban leader who became known to policy makers in Washington.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Social Democrats Seek Coalition
description: The Berlin Social Democrats began talks to form a coalition with the former Communist Party of Democratic Socialism, after negotiations with the Greens and Free Democrats failed. Social Democratic Chancellor Gerhard Schrder had wanted to keep the ex-Communists out of power in the Berlin state government, but the local party, facing a financial crisis in the city, is under pressure to form a stable government. The Communists, under Gregor Gysi, the party's charismatic leader, won 22.6 percent of the vote in October. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: SYSCO, A FOOD SUPPLIER, AGREES TO BUY CANADIAN GROCER
description: The Sysco Corporation, a North American food supplier to restaurants, agreed to buy the Serca food-service unit of Sobeys Inc., a leading Canadian grocer, for 440 million Canadian dollars ($280 million). The purchase will triple Sysco's Canadian sales, which currently total about 900 million Canadian dollars, and will immediately bolster earnings, the chief operating officer, Richard Schnieders, said. Sysco, which will use debt to finance the purchase, wants to expand through acquisitions. Serca is Canada's No. 1 provider of food to restaurants, hotels, fast-food chains and institutions like hospitals.

title: Recession Saps Consumer Confidence in Japan
description: Japan and the United States, the world's two largest economies, have shown some similarities this fall: rock bottom interest rates, deflating prices and collapsing assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, MOE
description: KESSLER-Moe. Lifelong NYC resident as well as the founder, president and CEO of Outwater Plastics Industries and Architectural Products by Outwater, died on December 4th in Manhattan. Best remembered for his generosity and contributions that he has made to the lives of everyone who knew him. Kessler is survived by his second wife, Linda, his two sons Richard and Peter, daughterin-law Susan, and was the beloved grandfather of Stephen, Faye Lauren and William. Pre-deceased by his first wife, Sylvia in 1995. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday, December 9th at 2:30 PM.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms

title: YANKEES HIRE ASSISTANT GENERAL MANAGER
description: The Yankees have hired Jean Afterman, a lawyer with a background in negotiations and business law, as their assistant general manager. Afterman, 44, replaces Kim Ng, who left the Yankees last month and was hired by the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday to be an assistant G.M.

description: SOME things are almost always better when they're big: movie screens, diamonds and forests. Some things are almost always better when they're small: bills, spills and pills.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the reaction in Washington to a Vanity Fair article describing the lives of three flirtatious congressional staff members referred incorrectly to a published critique by the ombudsman of The Washington Post regarding his paper's gossip-column account of the magazine article. The ombudsman, Michael Getler, noted that the columnist, Lloyd Grove, had written that congressmen mentioned in the article did not return calls for comment, when in fact the paper had not approached their offices. While describing the mistake as unintentional, Mr. Getler called it ''a falsehood that went directly to the trust between a newspaper and its readers.'' He did not call it a violation of journalistic ethics. (The Post published a correction, and Mr. Grove apologized in his column.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Posts Strong Sales
description: Porsche reported surprisingly strong sales for the first four months of its fiscal year. In the August to November period sales rose 6.3 percent to 1.18 million euros ($1 million) and unit sales increased 1 percent to 14,615, the company said. Porsche said demand remained strong, especially for its 911 model, the most expensive car it sells.

title: Atypical Berlioz, Atypically Performed
description: ''L'Enfance du Christ,'' which was performed at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, sometimes seems to be everything that Berlioz's music normally is not: mild, reflective, recalling the past rather than rushing headlong into the future. But this beautiful performance tempered that judgment, made the work thoroughly alive.

title: Learn From Haiti
description: Of the 28 million people in Africa with AIDS, no more than 25,000 have access to medications. Officials of both Western nations and some affected countries -- like South Africa, which has millions in immediate need of treatment -- have said that poor countries have too few clinics and doctors and that their populations are too poorly educated to allow treatment of all infected people. This contention has become familiar in the debate over international financing to treat H.I.V.

title: The Market For Tragedy
description: They seem so remote from the jolliness of Christmas that one wonders what universe of meaning and emotion their buyers are entering. Usually this is the season for books of joy and playfulness, for children's tales, cookbooks, coffee-table books admired but seldom read. But this year among the biggest-selling books are three photo collections of the stark horrifying images of perhaps the scariest moment in American history, Sept. 11.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Hey, the law's the law.''

title: The Home-Front Emergency
description: The need to do more to guard against terrorism at home is obvious. Tom Ridge, the director of homeland defense, and members of Congress have certainly endorsed the idea -- in principle. Yet today, when the Senate takes up a measure that would add $7.5 billion to the budget for items like airport security and defense against germ warfare, Republican leaders will be trying to block it. The appropriation is tacked onto an emergency military spending bill that no one opposes. But an emergency also exists at home. Senators should put the safety of their constituents first and vote for the entire package.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LILLIAN Y.
description: KAPLAN-Lillian Y., 94. Devoted wife of Abraham, mother of Rhoda and Hazel, grandmother of Michael, Marcy, Dana, Alexandra and Jonathan, and great grandmother to Sara and Andrew, passed away on December 2, 2001. She graduated from Barnard College with honors, received her Master's degree in Education at Teachers College and her Ph.D. in Guidance from Queens College. Lillian devoted her life to the education of minorities. After retirement, she and her husband participated in The United States Executive Assistance Programs to help under-developed nations create manufacturing capabilities. They assisted with the construction of production facilities in Turkey, Korea and Colombia. Graveside service Monday, December 10th at 1pm at Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY.

Recipient of our 2001 Rohatyn Community Service Award, he embodied philanthropy at its finest: he wanted no glory, only quietly to help those who needed it most. Diana R. description: In choosing Richard Dean Parsons as its chief executive, AOL Time Warner entrusted its future to a diplomat, a leader who has traveled the halls of the White House and the sidewalks of 125th Street in Harlem -- not an imperious media chief or Internet visionary.

title: As Refugees Suffer, Supplies Sit Unused Near Afghan Border
description: Last week it rained and Ramazan's 2-year-old son and 50-year-old father fell ill and died, two more sorry statistics here in the Nasarji refugee camp on the southern part of town where at least 19 people have died in the last month. Ramazan began building mud walls and a roof to replace his makeshift tent, but it snowed on Tuesday and now he is fearful he will lose his other children.

title: With the Military Present, Red Cross Officials Talk to Captured U.S. Citizen
description: Red Cross officials said today that they had paid two visits in Afghanistan to John Walker Lindh, the American captured with the Taliban last week, and had taken a letter from him to carry to his family.

title: MIRANT, POWER CONCERN, TO BUY HYUNDAI ENERGY
description: The Mirant Corporation, an independent power producer based in Atlanta, said it plans to buy the Hyundai Energy Company and build a power plant in South Korea for about $300 million to expand in Asia's deregulating markets. Mirant, which controls 3,500 megawatts of generating capacity in Asia, said it planned to build a 520-megawatt power plant in southern Cholla province. The plant is part of Mirant's plan to increase its power-generating capacity in Asia to 10,000 megawatts, or enough to power New York, by 2005

title: Italy's Leader Tangles With the Judiciary, a Familiar Opponent
description: Italy's undersecretary of the interior, Carlo Taormina, resigned this week over his comment that judges who have investigated Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on corruption charges should themselves be arrested and tried. The controversy has underscored the Berlusconi government's problems on a variety of justice issues.

title: For Nervous Online Shoppers, A Virtual Credit Card
description: Disposable technology like throwaway cellphones and cameras may clog up the landfills, but a single-use credit card number can protect an online shopper from identity theft. Since last year, Orbiscom, a company specializing in safe online payment systems, has been working with the Discover and MBNA credit card companies to provide free one-time-use credit card numbers for customers making online purchases.

description: A border security bill with strong bipartisan support in the Senate would require American officials to develop new standards for granting visas to citizens of countries that are considered sponsors of terrorism and would also order thorough background checks.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Executive Change At Petrobrs
description: After two and a half years at the helm of Brazil's largest state-owned enterprise, the oil company Petrobrs, Henri Philippe Reichstul will step down for personal reasons. The president of the Brazilian National Development Bank, Francisco Gros, left, will assume leadership of the company at the beginning of the year. Under Mr. Reichstul's tenure, Petrobrs modernized and posted record profits but was also responsible for a series of major oil spills and an explosion that lead to the sinking of the world's largest offshore oil platform. Mr. Gros is a former president of Brazil's central bank and the former chairman of Morgan Stanley Latin America. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

They were mentioned only as examples of such lists, not necessarily as the sources of names in the article. While none of the news organizations maintain that their early lists were perfect, USA Today said that none of the people named in the article had ever appeared on its list.

title: Japan's dominant agency is looking overseas, but it will find that world to be much less congenial.
description: IT was an inauspicious start to the second century in business for Dentsu. After 100 years as Japan's dominant advertising agency, Dentsu made its trading debut last week as investors clamored for its shares. The celebration, however, fizzled quickly after an errant ''sell'' order sent the new shares skidding.

title: Is NATO 'Relevant' in Era of U.S. Power?
description: PARIS  A few mornings ago, George Robertson, NATO's secretary-general, was asked on television in Britain how the alliance was holding up through the Afghanistan campaign. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, he replied, was still relevant.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Fines For Price Fixing
description: Roche Holding, Archer Daniels Midland and three other companies were fined a total of 135 million euros ($120 million) by the European Union for fixing prices of citric acid, an additive used in products like soft drinks. Regulators fined Roche 63.5 million euros and Archer Daniels 39.7 million euros. They also sanctioned participants Jungbunzlauer, Bayer's Haarmann & Reimer and Cerestar Bioproducts. The regulators said the cartel for citric acid started in March 1991 at a hotel in Basel, Switzerland, according to documents they received from the companies. The companies conspired to fix target and ''floor'' prices for the acid and exchanged customer information, the regulators said.

title: Interface Design Is Trickier Than It Seems
description: As more and more gadgets and programs combine more and more functions, interface design is becoming a burning issue. The interface -- the layout of the controls -- determines how easily and effectively you can use the product: which buttons go where, how many layers down you have to burrow to find an important function, and so on.

description: Oakland has released wide receiver David Dunn days after he fumbled a punt that led to the Raiders' 34-31 overtime loss to the Arizona Cardinals.

description: For three-quarters of a century Franco Alfano has been remembered as the man who made a bad job of finishing Puccini's ''Turandot.'' That judgment is probably unfair, since ultimate responsibility for what became the standard edition rested with the original conductor, Toscanini. Friday night's performance by Teatro Grattacielo, a New York company, of Alfano's ''Risurrezione,'' however, suggested that this was a composer with a supreme aptitude for the uninteresting.

What the school lacked, however, was its own gymnasium. The $10 million Center for Well-Being, which includes a gymnasium and a cafe, was recently completed on the school's campus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, ISRAEL
description: RESNICK-Israel. Age 86. At home on December 5, 2001. Beloved husband for 50 years of the late Sadie (nee Pasiornick). Cherished father of Carole Crystal, Arthur Resnick and the late Robert Resnick. Father-in-law of Richard P. Crystal. Adored grandfather of Lara and Jessica Crystal. Devoted brother of the late Sylvia Bestimt. A chemist who spent more than 20 years in plastics research, he was the author of numerous technical publications and held several patents in the field of plastics. Later in his career, he worked toward safeguarding and improving the quality of water supplies throughout the world by coordinating the development of international water quality standards. He will always be remembered as a kind and gentle man with a sharp mind and a keen wit. Services Thursday, December 6, 2001, at 12:00 noon at Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises

The increase was unexpectedly modest compared with the preceding months, and the unemployment rate was unchanged at 9.5 percent. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Tennessee Uses the Element of Surprise

But with a new strategy introduced last week at Florida, the Volunteers sowed fresh confusion and reaped new success. The alignment is called Prowler, a fluid configuration in which Henderson and his mates sometimes avoided the classic three-point stance of pass rushers and run stuffers.
