title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM SALE PROCEDURE IS GIVEN APPROVAL
description: Fruit of the Loom won court approval for its proposed bankruptcy sale procedures, clearing the way for an $835 million bid for the underwear maker by Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. Judge Peter Walsh of United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware said two weeks ago that a $30 million fee that Mr. Buffett's investment company would get if it were outbid was too high. Mr. Buffett agreed to cut the fee to $25 million, lawyers told Judge Walsh yesterday. Judge Walsh's decision frees the company to be auctioned on Dec. 18. Mr. Buffett's bid may be among several for the Chicago-based company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in 1999 in the face of slumping sales tied to cheaper overseas imports and mounting debt

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Compaq Software Would Speed Upgrades
description: Soon, Compaq Computer said, it will begin equipping server computers with programs that allow faster software upgrades. The change will reduce the time needed to update software on as many as 100 Compaq Proliant servers to 1 hour from 16 hours. Compaq is trying to ease customer concerns about which products will survive its planned sale to Hewlett-Packard. Rivals like Dell Computer have said they are picking up customers as a result.

title: Impact of Camby's Return Is Undeniably Positive
description: Marcus Camby wants you to believe that he is just another Knick, that he ranks no higher than Othella Harrington or Charlie Ward on the significance chart. It is an admirable viewpoint but totally off base since he returned from a heel injury a week and a half ago.

description: Stocks shot sharply higher yesterday on growing optimism that the economy, which had been officially declared in a recession just over a week ago, would quickly rebound.

title: A Digital Camera Designed For Traditional Lenses
description: Digital cameras that use interchangeable lenses designed for 35-millimeter film cameras have been around for a while. But because the area of the light-sensing devices is smaller than the area of the photographic image, the newcomers aren't a perfect substitute. Among other things, the size difference alters the angle of view of the lenses so that a lens that offers a wide angle view when attached to a film camera gives a normal perspective on a digital.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 112 Charged In Fraud Scheme
description: The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced charges yesterday against 112 people said to be involved in a scheme to swindle auto insurance companies by submitting nearly $1 million in falsified bills. Among those charged are lawyers, medical doctors, chiropractors, a physical therapist, an acupuncturist, and a Police Department administrative aide. Allegations include the filing of 22 fictitious reports of automobile accidents involving 93 victims, $900,000 in fraudulent medical bills and payoffs to the police aide for the false reports. If convicted, the defendants could be sentenced to up to 25 years in prison.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Pharmacy Inquiry Broadens
description: The F.B.I. expanded its investigation of the pharmacist Robert R. Courtney after finding that fertility drugs dispensed from his second pharmacy may have been diluted. Two samples of the drug progesterone from Courtney's Pharmacy in Merriam, Kan., tested ''subpotent,'' and the F.B.I. is waiting for results on several other samples. In August, Mr. Courtney was indicted on 20 counts of adulterating, tampering with and misbranding chemotherapy drugs at his other pharmacy, in Kansas City, Mo. He has pleaded not guilty.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Ruling For Foster Children
description: Inadequate treatment for children in the state's foster care system causes psychological damage and violates their constitutional rights, a Bellingham jury decided on Tuesday in a class-action lawsuit on behalf of 3,500 children who have been placed in three or more foster homes. As part of the ruling, Judge David Nichols of Whatcom County Superior Court will oversee changes at the Department of Social and Health Services. Dennis Braddock, secretary of the department, said the state would appeal the verdict. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 27 about a company that said it had taken first steps in producing human embryos through cloning referred incorrectly to the timing of the announcement. Dr. Michael D. West, president of the company, Advanced Cell Technology, said he had chosen to publish the study in a peer-reviewed online journal, E-biomed, so he could control the timing; he did not say E-biomed had agreed to arrange for distribution to coincide with articles in Scientific American and U.S. News & World Report.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Layoffs At Phone Concern
description: Buffeted by a poor economy and fierce competition in its core long-distance phone business, Pacific Century CyberWorks laid off 506 people from its work force of 14,000. CyberWorks, Hong Kong's flagship phone company, said it would freeze hiring and salaries next year in an effort to avoid further layoffs, but could not rule them out. CyberWorks was formed last year by Richard Li, when his Internet start-up acquired Cable and Wireless HKT for $38 billion. The company has struggled under a heavy debt load and its declining share of Hong Kong's long-distance market. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Surveillance: From 'Big Brother' to Safety Tool
description: They are getting ready to wire up the palm trees in this desert resort, putting electronic eyes 24-7 on the main business street. On the other side of the country, Virginia Beach has decided to install outdoor cameras on its main boardwalk. The cameras will scan the faces of people at random, crosschecking them with faces of criminals stored in a computer database.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Government Sells Bank
description: The Irish government sold the last of its state-owned financial institutions, ACC Bank, to Rabobank of the Netherlands for 165 million euros ($146 million) as part of a continuing effort to privatize state companies to comply with European Union competition regulations. Once called the Agricultural Credit Corporation, ACC remains a strong lender to Irish farmers, but it has recently scaled back its expensive retail banking. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Manufacturing Turns Down
description: Sales and profit at the largest manufacturers in Japan collapsed in the July-September quarter along with the downturn in spending on technology globally. Pretax profit fell 32.5 percent in the third quarter, the largest slide in nearly three years, while sales fell 2.6 percent, a Finance Ministry report showed. Businesses surveyed also said they expected conditions to deteriorate further in the current quarter. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Looking for the Light in Cabaret Songs
description: Over an insinuating bossa nova beat Claus Ogerman's ominously beautiful orchestral arrangement for Diana Krall's recording of ''Dancing in the Dark'' rolls in like overlapping waves on a rising tide ahead of an approaching coastal storm. As the music thickens, and the heady romantic promise of a couple on the dance floor vowing to ''face the music together'' gathers force, Ms. Krall's darkly inviting voice steals into the arrangement. Her aura is sensual but also faintly surly and a little guarded. She wraps the song in mystery. As it comes to an end, the tide turns and slowly starts to roll away, fading out on waves that gradually recede into a murky void.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Opposition Holds Reins, Briefly
description: The new Senate president, Ramon Puerta, left, declared that he would not abuse his powers as acting president when President Fernando de la Ra is out of the country by signing presidential decrees and subverting the government's policies. Mr. Puerta's selection by the newly elected Senate created a stir last week because Mr. Puberta is an opposition Justicialist leader and he replaces a member of Mr. de la Ra's ruling coalition. Since the vice president resigned last year, the Senate president is second in line in succession under the Constitution and has presidential powers when the president is abroad.

title: Auto Fiber Optics Put Car At Driver's Beck and Call

description: A leading American human rights organization reported today that the Mexican government had failed to investigate and punish human rights abuses committed by the military, and has called on President Vicente Fox to do more, including ending the practice of allowing military courts to investigate soldiers' abuses against civilians.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New City: Rockland Budget Approved
description: Rockland County legislators have passed a 2002 spending plan with enough tax increases and program cuts to close a $44 million deficit. The lawmakers voted 16 to 1 on Tuesday night in favor of the plan, which increases the property tax by 2.5 percent and the sales tax by half a percentage point. The plan also includes a proposal by the county executive, C. Scott Vanderhoef, to eliminate 20 agencies, including a group promoting reading and a Haitian-American cultural organization, a spokeswoman for the County Legislature said. Mr. Vanderhoef has five days to sign or veto the budget plan or veto individual items. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Alert On Surgical Errors
description: Pointing out that there had been at least 150 operations on the wrong site or the wrong patient since 1996, the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations issued its second alert on the issue in three years. The group recommended that doctors place their initials on the surgical site, verify that they have the right patient before surgery starts and take a time-out to make sure the procedure they are about to perform is the correct one. The group said the most common mistake was operating on the wrong foot or leg.

title: Getting From Here to There, With the Car Parked at Home
description: For those who are considering travel by train rather than airplane this season, a perfect trip might mean taking the Lakeshore Limited to Chicago to see ''Modern Trains and Splendid Stations,'' an exhibition of 45 projects opening Saturday at the Art Institute of Chicago. Trains these days are faster, sleeker and more luxurious. And train stations themselves are ''symbols of cities, and motors for economic revival,'' said Martha Thorne, curator of the show. The 1995 train station in Solana Beach, Calif., below, combines the look of a Quonset hut with a traditional train station clock tower. The unbuilt HST 350 high-speed train (the model below center) influenced the JR 500, a Japanese high-speed train. An airport train station in Frankfurt, Germany, seen in a model at bottom, is under construction. Through July 28; the catalog is $29.95; (312) 443-3600.

But they are sure about one thing: the right engine of the Airbus A300 was about due for major maintenance. The engines, manufactured by the General Electric Company, were scheduled for an overhaul every 10,000 hours they were in service. The right engine on the plane had already logged 9,788 hours since its last overhaul, the left engine 684 hours.

title: LUFTHANSA IN MOVE TO PURCHASE 15 AIRBUS JUMBO JETS
description: Lufthansa's supervisory board voted unanimously yesterday to buy 15 Airbus A380 super jumbo jets, a person close to the company said. The airline is planning to announce the deal today. The total number of firm orders for the new 550-passenger A380 is now 97, just shy of the 100 that Airbus Industrie said it would have by the end of the year. The Lufthansa order is worth $3.6 billion at the A380's list price, but the airline will certainly receive a large discount. The first of the aircraft is scheduled to be delivered in 2007. Larry Zuckerman (NYT)

description: * At Zenith USA, New York, part of the Zenith Media unit of the Zenith Optimedia Group, Tim Jones, executive vice president, was named president. Peggy Green was appointed as president for national broadcast, and Neil Ascher was named executive vice president. Zenith Optimedia is owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and the Publicis Groupe.

title: Such Happy Feet, Noisily Slapping Feet
description: 'New York Delhi Mix'

title: Dispute Erupts Over Seat on Civil Rights Panel
description: The White House set up a confrontation with the United States Civil Rights Commission today, declaring a vacancy on the commission and appointing its own candidate even though the commission chairwoman said a vacancy did not exist.

title: No Stone or Story Left Unturned
description: IAN FALCONER was shopping for a decorative stone the other day when the store owner, an energetic woman named Mei Li Dong, began to tell her story. Mr. Falconer, 42, is an illustrator, set designer and as of last year the author of a witty and successful children's book called ''Olivia,'' the sequel to which, ''Olivia Saves the Circus,'' came out this fall.

title: U.N. Expected to Endorse Accord Reached in Bonn
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan and the Security Council welcomed the news today that their special representative, Lakhdar Brahimi, had succeeded in brokering an agreement among anti-Taliban Afghans to form a transitional ruling council. But the tricky issue of a multinational security force remained subject to further discussion.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Seattle Retains Police Chief
description: Greg Nickels, the mayor-elect of Seattle, has decided not to fire the city's police chief, Gil Kerlikowske. In his campaign Mr. Nickels had criticized the chief's handling of Mardi Gras violence that left one dead and 70 injured. But he said the chief had won his trust in a series of meetings after the election. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Indictments Name 73 Linked to the Genovese Crime Family
description: Federal prosecutors announced sweeping indictments yesterday of dozens of people they called leaders and associates of the Genovese crime family. The charges included racketeering and illegal activities that brought in $14 million this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Sweet Memories

title: $25 Billion to Aid the Jobless Is Backed by House G.O.P. Leaders
description: House Republican leaders offered to spend about $25 billion to aid the unemployed today as the two main economic issues before Congress -- trade powers for the president and stimulating the domestic economy -- merged in furious end-of-session horse trading.

title: Energy Traders Continue to Prowl The Floor That Enron Helped Build
description: Melissa Beckett checks prices on three computer monitors, fingers a microphone on her telephone and calls a broker in New York.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Government Updates Encryption Standard
description: The Commerce Department approved a new encryption standard for government and private sector use, replacing one adopted in 1977, officials said. They said the standard would improve privacy and security for financial and other sensitive communications, including e-mail, bank withdrawals and online purchases. The standard would help protect ''critical information infrastructures,'' Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans said, adding, ''It also will promote the president's efforts to provide secure electronic government services to our citizens.'' The standard is based on an algorithm developed by two Belgian scientists, Joan Daemen and Vincent Rijmen, who said the government could use it without paying royalties. The Commerce Department's National Institute of Standards and Technology selected the algorithm after a four-year competition that included researchers from 12 countries.

title: Argentine Economy Minister Tries to Maintain Optimism
description: In his eight months in office, Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo has increased tariffs, showered subsidies on exporters, slashed government salaries and pensions, lowered some taxes and raised others.

title: Transcript of Ethan Nadelmann's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Monday, Nov. 19, the NYTimes.com Drug Policy forum hosted Ethan Nadelmann, the Founder of the Lindesmith-Drug Policy Foundation . This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: When It's May in December
description: The phone calls and e-mail messages have been arriving daily, little poison darts to my Eastern-based skiing soul. Six feet of snow in Utah, no, make that seven feet. Fifty inches in Lake Tahoe. Vail has 2,700 skiable acres open.

title: Elemental, My Dear Watson: Serving Earth, Fire and Space
description: The Water Jug, above left, is part of the Arabia company's new Energy line based on the elements, including Earth (herb pots and planters), Fire (candleholders) and Space (Richard Meier's tableware). The Water Jug by Alberto Meda, comes with a filter (not shown) that fits into the funnel. Filtered water is served from the carafe. (Above right, the funnel and filter stored in a water glass.) The jug, filter and funnel, ideal for the bedside, are $100; (800) 448-8252 for store locations. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTONE, SIDNEY M., DR.
description: SILVERSTONE-Sidney M., Dr., on December 4 at age 93. Beloved father of Harris, Alan, and David and their wives Ruth, Janice, andBarbara. Beloved grandfather of Robert and Heidi, Aron Silverstone and Tai-ping Sun, Nancy, Murray, Jayme Silverstone and Fred Heiberger, Mark, Scott, Leonard Dunn, and Meredith Dunn. Beloved great-grandfather of Michael and Max. Beloved brother-in-law of Saranne and Bill Chayefsky. Beloved uncle of many nieces and nephews. A founding member and past President, along with his beloved wife Estelle of blessed memory, of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison. Pioneering radiation oncologist who introduced in 1953 the first cobalt-60 radiation therapy unit in the world in an outpatient setting. Clinical professor and former chief of radiotherapy at Mount Sinai Hospital and School of Medicine, with which he was associated from 1938 until his retirement this year. A Major in the US Army Medical Corps during World War II with active service in North Africa, Italy, France, and England. Funeral services will be held Friday at 11:30 A.M. at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Ave., Harrison, NY 10528. Followed by an Interment at Mount Pleasent Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Jewish Community Center of Harrison. For information, contact Zion Memorial Chapel, 914-381-1809.

title: Film
description: The light in the dark ... Enjoy some distinctive motion pictures

title: The Forest, the Trees And the Gas Below; Finger Lakes Residents Debate Plan For Drilling on National Woodlands
description: A quilt of forgotten apple orchards and tangled pastures, the Finger Lakes National Forest, the only national forest in New York, is an anonymous 25 square miles in the lush woodlands upstate, and a speck compared with the vast acres of wilderness in the West.

title: Looking Back; In the Beginning, a Note to Himself
description: Ray Tomlinson developed the first system for sending e-mail between computers in 1971 and 1972. In a recent e-mail exchange with Katie Hafner for Circuits, he discussed his own experience with the medium. Here are excerpts.

title: '98 Accident At Gasworks Still Shadows Esso Australia
description: Try as it might, Exxon Mobil cannot seem to keep a 1998 gasworks accident here -- and the way it responded -- from coming back to bite it again and again.

title: Kidd Gets First Laugh In Marbury's Return
description: No matter how often Jason Kidd said that tonight was going to be just another game, he did not mean it. Kidd was up all Tuesday night pacing instead of sleeping, planning a sweet revenge on the team that traded him to the Nets.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: American Casualties

title: Airing Some Century-Old Linens
description: Because many New York antiques shows were canceled this fall, some dealers, like Susan Simon, who sells antique linens, have started offering wares from their home or office. ''Old linen is silky and has a romance,'' said Ms. Simon, who finds century-old textiles at European estate sales.

title: Giuliani Seeks To Lead Fund For Uniformed After Jan. 1
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that after leaving office he would like to continue to run the city's charity for uniformed victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and to convert the fund into a private charity.

title: Anthrax Investigators Open Letter Sent to Senator Leahy
description: After weeks of careful preparation, forensic investigators at an Army research laboratory in Maryland today opened the anthrax-contaminated letter sent to Senator Patrick J. Leahy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GULFSTREAM AEROSPACE CORP., Savannah, Ga., a subsidiary of General Dynamics, the military contractor, said it had been awarded a contract worth up to $206 million for three Gulfstream V jets and support services from Israel's Ministry of Defense.

title: Slump in the Service Sector Was Reversed in November
description: Business at service companies expanded unexpectedly in November, reversing a slump that came after the September terrorist attacks.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN OVERVIEW: Dec. 5, 2001; A Deadly Error, Signing a Leadership Pact and Aid Out of Reach
description: It was the deadliest day of the war for the Americans. Three Army soldiers were killed in southern Afghanistan, the first American combat deaths. It was an accident that killed them, not the might of the enemy. An American bomb meant for Taliban fighters landed off course. In one stroke of good fortune, the Pashtun tribal chief selected at a meeting in Germany to lead a new government in Kabul survived the accident.

title: An Eye on History And the 'Ladies'
description: Celebrating his 99th birthday yesterday, Senator Strom Thurmond, the longest-serving member of the Senate, delivered a pithy reminder that he is not too old to admire the youngsters around him, especially those in heels.

title: Middle East Detainee Conducts Hunger Strike
description: Malek Mohamed Seif has been in custody here for six weeks. For most of that time, he has been on a hunger strike to protest his detention.

title: Making Arrangements, and Offering Bouquets of Advice
description: Banchet Jaigla, above, used to work out of her home in Bedford, N.Y., doing eccentric, exotic flower designs for Windows on the World and Le Bernardin, as well as for parties as far away as Paris. (For Dries van Noten's Paris fashion show last year, she arranged cones and spheres of tiny roses on a green wall, right.)

title: Big, Blue and Out of Breath: I.B.M. Kiosks Check for Fat
description: A few years ago, an I.B.M. computer defeated Garry Kasparov at chess. Now a new I.B.M. machine wants to size up some opponents for old-fashioned arm wrestling.

title: Suspect Charged in 4 Green River Slayings
description: Gary Leon Ridgway, a painter for a suburban Seattle trucking company, was charged today with four long-unsolved deaths linked to one of the nation's biggest serial killing cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIVSKY, ANNE
description: DUBIVSKY-Anne. At age 91, of Hartsdale NY, on December 5, after a long illness. Beloved sister of Barbara Dubivsky, devoted aunt to Carol Becker, and Jane Coene. Grand-aunt to Christopher, Susan, Michael, Stephen, Sally and Elizabeth. And great grand-aunt to ten. Services at St. Vladimir's Seminary, Crestwood, NY, Saturday, December 8. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Predeceased by parents John Sr. and Barbara and brothers: Stephen, John, Peter, George, and Theodore. During her career she was associated with the Department of Justice, RCA, and Morgan Stanley.

title: Sweet Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Deal Would Hurt Profit, Hewlett Says
description: Slumping PC sales and the worsening prospects for Compaq Computer mean Hewlett-Packard's proposed $23.6 billion acquisition of Compaq would reduce earnings more than expected, Walter Hewlett, a board member and son of one of Hewlett-Packard's co-founders, argued in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The proposed acquisition would reduce per-share profit by 34 percent in 2002, rather than 9.1 percent based on Aug. 31 estimates, Mr. Hewlett said in the filing. In addition, the deal would cut profit in 2003, instead of lifting it, as the companies have predicted, he added.

title: 'Voices Of Negativism'
description: Preparing to tell the Senate Judiciary Committee where to get off today, Attorney General John Ashcroft lashed out at all who dare to uphold our bedrock rule of law as ''voices of negativism.'' (A nattering nabob, moi?)

title: Museums
description: Exhibiting courage-hope-greatness - Many of the nation's premier museums will participate in Arts & Leisure Weekend. Most institutions below will offer free admission for two to Arts & Leisure Weekend passholders Jan. 11-13, unless otherwise specified.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: National Briefing | Washington: Music Advertising Faulted
description: A report by the Federal Trade Commission found that since September 2000, the music industry has continued to advertise violent material in venues intended for teenage audiences, while the motion picture and video-game industries have limited such advertising. The report examined advertising trends in print, television, radio and the Internet, as well as internal industry documents.

title: Annacone Steps Down As Sampras's Coach
description: Throughout a season that left Pete Sampras frustrated in his effort to revive his aura, he had discussions with his trusted coach of six years, Paul Annacone, on how to recapture his desire.

title: Man in the News; Party Chairman, Presidential Friend -- Marc Racicot
description: An important thing to know about Marc Racicot, whom President Bush named Republican national chairman today, is that he and his wife, Theresa, enjoyed a simple fish dinner with the Bushes at the White House a few weeks ago.

title: Central Bank in Australia Reduces Lending Rate
description: Australia's central bank cut the overnight lending rate it charges banks today for the sixth time this year, saying it is still worried about the global slowdown and the timing of a recovery.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Opposition Appears Headed for Victory in Sri Lanka Elections
description: Sri Lanka's leading opposition party appeared headed for a victory over the coalition that has ruled the island nation for the past seven years, according to state-run televison and election officials. The vote counting was still incomplete this morning, but computer projections showed the United National Party winning a bare mmajority in Parliament, officials said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Satellite Radio Coming To New York
description: A national digital radio service, XM Satellite Radio, will begin service in New York City today. The service, which has been available in various markets since September, completes its rollout in New York and Seattle. XM Satellite Radio beams digital radio signals from two satellites in orbit over North America. The service, which costs $9.99 a month, has 71 music channels and 29 news and entertainment channels. The company is betting that the nation's radio audience, bored by homogeneous fare in many markets, will gravitate to the more specialized offerings of digital radio. In July, the company opened a broadcast studio in New York, just blocks away from its rival, Sirius Satellite Radio. Shares of XM Satellite Radio rose $1.69, to $12.75. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Fuel Cell Field Tests Go Well
description: The H Power Corporation said its fuel-cell systems performed successfully in tests for the United States Air Force to determine their suitability for use during military operations. Testing by the Concurrent Technologies Corporation indicated the hydrogen-powered fuel cells have the capability for a range of tasks from powering an office in a tent city to aircraft tow vehicles, the company said.

title: Greg MacArthur, Philanthropist And Green Party Supporter, 53
description: Gregoire C. R. B. MacArthur, a member of one of America's wealthiest families and a supporter of human rights and liberal causes, died Nov. 18 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 53.

title: Sale of Building on 42nd Street Brings 30-Year Feud to an End
description: Two old real estate families that had been battling in the Times Square area for 30 years suddenly ended their feud yesterday.

title: UST, MAKER OF SNUFF, EXPECTS AN INCREASE IN PROFITS
description: UST Inc., the maker of Copenhagen and Skoal snuff, said next year's profit would rise 7.4 percent, less than analysts forecast, because it has one less shipping day next year. It also affirmed its fourth-quarter forecast that profit would rise 19 percent, to $137 million, or 82 cents a share, from $115.2 million, or 70 cents, in the period a year earlier. Earnings next year will increase to $528 million, or $3.10 a share, the chief financial officer, Robert D'Alessandro, said in a presentation to analysts and investors. UST, which also makes Chteau St. Michelle wine, has one more shipping day this year because it delivers products every Monday and there are 53 Mondays in 2001. That extra day represents about 10 million cans, the company said

title: Nassau Says Outdated Drugs Are Left on Shelves and Sold
description: Consumers are unwittingly buying many popular nonprescription drugs and nutrition products that have exceeded their expiration dates for safety and effectiveness, Nassau County officials said today.

title: 9 States to Ask For More Limits On Microsoft
description: The nine states that have refused to sign the Bush administration's proposed antitrust settlement with Microsoft will ask a Federal judge to impose tougher enforcement sanctions and eliminate a long list of loopholes from the agreement, state officials involved in the case said today.

title: 2 South Korean Chip Makers Turn Around Slide in Prices
description: A break appeared in the deep gloom enveloping the global semiconductor market today as two leading chip makers, both based in South Korea, reversed the steep slide in their products' prices and raised them 10 percent or more. Investors bid the stocks of both companies, Samsung Electronics and Hynix Semiconductor, up sharply.

title: AOL TIME WARNER GETS A NEW CHIEF AS LEVIN DEPARTS
description: The chief executive of the world's biggest media company, AOL Time Warner, surprised his company and his industry yesterday by announcing that he would retire in May. The executive, Gerald M. Levin, will be replaced by his hand-picked successor, Richard D. Parsons, who will face the daunting job of making a merger conceived in the soaring Internet economy come of age during an economic slump for old-line and online media companies alike.

title: A Taliban Defector Tells a Tale of Espionage: Tall, or Truly Daring?
description: Abdullah Gaurd, until recently a feared Taliban commander, sat barefoot on a blue cushion by a wood-burning pot stove. His one-eyed bodyguard huddled in the corner with a loaded automatic rifle, listening to every word.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Chip Maker Cuts More Jobs
description: A chip-making company that is being spun off by Lucent Technologies, Agere Systems, said yesterday that it was cutting its work force by another 950 jobs, bringing job reductions this year to nearly 7,000. The company, which is based in Allentown, Pa., is grappling with a slowdown in sales. Agere will have 11,300 employees after the cuts, which will largely take place at locations in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Dining Out
description: Hungry for more? Enjoy your meal and an 18.51% discount on your bill (gratuity not included), in honor of the year The Times was founded at the locations below. Just show your Arts & Leisure Weekend pass when you ask for your check. This offer cannot be combined with any other special offers.

title: M.T.A. Chief Favored for Post In Bloomberg Administration
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to name Marc V. Shaw, the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, to a high post in his government, most likely deputy mayor, said several people with knowledge of the mayoral transition.

title: Robertson Resigns From His Christian Coalition
description: Pat Robertson, the widely televised evangelist and one-time presidential candidate, resigned yesterday as president of the Christian Coalition, the grass-roots organization he made one of the most powerful political forces in the country in the mid-1990's, only to see it go into steep decline after that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONE, JULIA
description: MONE-Julia. Of Staten Island on December 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Frank Patrick Mone. Loving mother of Joan Lockwood and Jean Mone. Also survived by two grandchildren and one great grandaughter. Funeral from the Hanley Funeral Home, 60 New Dorp Lane, SI, NY Friday. Mass at St. Charles Church 9:45 AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery.

description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center begins its annual tribute to Iberian film tomorrow with the Spanish Cinema Now series, opening with ''Broken Silence'' (''Silencio Roto'') by Montxo Armendriz at 1 and 7:30 p.m.

description: On Tuesday, Nov. 13, Lynn Paltrow, Director of National Advocates for Pregnant Women visited the NYTimes.com Drug Policy forum. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: 2 Die and Several Are Wounded in Shooting at Indiana Factory
description: Agunman opened fire at a small factory in Goshen, Ind. today, killing one worker and injuring several other people before turning the gun on himself, the police and city officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Teacher Shortage Worsens
description: Connecticut is losing teachers at a worrisome rate and finds it difficult to hire qualified instructors, especially in low-income urban areas, a State Board of Education report said. The study, released on Tuesday, also shows that the state will need to replace approximately 19,000 retiring teachers in the next 10 years. Nineteen percent of urban teaching positions were vacant as of Oct. 1, compared with an average of less than 4.4 percent elsewhere in the state. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Vote on Spending Bill Is Risky for Republicans
description: President Bush today threatened to veto a military spending bill if it included money he had not sought, giving Republicans the uncomfortable choice of opposing their president or voting against more money for domestic security.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a telephone transcription error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Enron's bankruptcy paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Christopher Mayer, a partner in the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. Speaking about a decision by two of its clients -- J. P. Morgan Chase, an Enron creditor, and Arthur Andersen, Enron's auditor -- to retain his law firm in the bankruptcy case, Mr. Mayer said that in this case, both companies consented to it -- not ''can sense it.''

title: Bids In for German Tobacco Company
description: An auction for Reemstma Cigarettenfabriken G.m.b.H., a large German tobacco company, is reaching an advanced stage, people close to the discussions said today. Potential acquirers of the company have submitted a second round of bids, and final offers are due in January, these people said.

description: Such Happy Feet, Noisily Slapping Feet

title: Fusing Old and New
description: Two years ago, when America Online, the cheeky Internet powerhouse, announced that it was buying Time Warner, the paragon of offline publishing and entertainment, it was seen as confirmation that new media had officially overpowered the old.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Stake In Chip Maker Cut
description: Siemens, the German technology company, said it had cut its stake in Infineon Technologies to below 50 percent, removing the unprofitable chip unit from its own profit-and-loss account. Siemens said it sold enough shares on the open market to reduce the stake to less than 50 percent from 50.4 percent. It also transferred 200 million shares, equivalent to about 29 percent of Infineon's capital, to a nonvoting trust.

title: Economic Scene; Setting fuel-efficiency targets for vehicle fleets makes little sense.
description: GASOLINE prices have fallen sharply, to below $1 a gallon in some places, encouraging Americans to drive more. The war on terrorism, meanwhile, is raising questions about relations between the United States and Saudi Arabia and the future of Persian Gulf oil supplies. In response, some activists and commentators are calling for government action to require more fuel-efficient automobiles.

title: Sidetracked 36 Years, Designer Moves East
description: CALL it the realization of a dream deferred. Orlando Diaz-Azcuy, 62, a furniture and interior designer who has lived in San Francisco for 36 years, is setting himself up in Manhattan. He's wondering what took him so long.

description: Online Secret Santa

title: From Israel to Trenton to Queens
description: The dream, the driving force, the goal for the goalkeeper of the St. John's University soccer team's, which plays Southern Methodist University in the quarterfinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament in Dallas Saturday night, is no different from what he says his homeland, Israel, dreams for and seeks as a goal.

title: Grieving New Yorkers Are Guests of Hawaii
description: Anne McCann and her husband, Tommy, used to joke that after he died, he should have his ashes scattered on a golf course.

title: Yesterday
description: Like most Americans, the first time I heard of the Beatles was in January or February 1964. A buddy of mine named Leon Leach came by my house and started chattering about these four guys from England who had long hair and were driving women wild.

title: Man Is Arrested in Threats Mailed to Abortion Clinics
description: Clayton Lee Waagner, the fugitive sought in a nationwide wave of hundreds of anthrax threats against abortion clinics, was arrested today by federal agents after an employee at a photocopy store recognized him from a wanted poster.

title: Rooting Out Terrorists Just Became Harder
description: The debate about President Bush's order allowing suspected terrorists to be tried by military courts has focused on questions of constitutionality. There is an additional, practical concern: The order may actually make it harder to prevent and punish terrorism.

title: Under Tight Security, Shuttle Lifts Off After a Week's Delay
description: The space shuttle Endeavour blasted off for the International Space Station this evening under the tightest security measures in the history of the space program.

title: De Klerk's Ex-Wife Found Slain In Apartment Near Cape Town
description: The ex-wife of F. W. de Klerk, the last president in South Africa's era of apartheid, was stabbed and strangled in her luxury apartment near Cape Town in a slaying that has so far baffled investigators, the police said today.

title: Senate Opens Debate on $171 Billion Farm Bill Opposed by Bush
description: The Senate today began debating a 10-year $171 billion farm bill, a Democratic measure that the Bush administration said would undercut foreign trade, encourage overproduction and depress already low grain and cotton prices.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. BARS USE OF GUN CHECKS IN TERROR INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department has refused to let the F.B.I. check its records to determine whether any of the 1,200 people detained after the Sept. 11 attacks had bought guns, F.B.I. and Justice Department officials say.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Parents Want More Time Before P.S. 234 Reopens
description: Hundreds of parents at Public School 234, one of the schools near the ruins of the World Trade Center, said yesterday that their children needed many more weeks to prepare psychologically to move back to the school rather than meet a Board of Education deadline for returning in early January.

title: Performing Arts
description: Soothing, surging, uplifting ... Buy one full-priced ticket and receive a second ticket of the same value free. Please refer to code NYT02 on all ticket orders unless otherwise specified.

title: Three Cleared By DNA Tests Enjoy Liberty After 15 Years
description: Hours after they emerged from spending nearly 15 years in prison for a rape-murder that they apparently did not commit, three young men this afternoon were given gilt-edge plaques etched with today's date and a simple message, ''The first day of the rest of your life.''

title: An Afternoon of New Works, a Smorgasbord of Styles
description: The heart of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's program on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall was new music -- lots of it and in several varieties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTMAN, ADELAIDE K.
description: GERSTMAN-Adelaide K. On December 4, 2001. Cherished wife of the late Mortimer. Beloved mother of George, Richard and Nancy. Loving grandmother of Heidi, Kim, Gary and Bruce. Devoted sister of the late Bernard. A woman of extraordinary warmth who made us feel good when we were around her. She will always occupy a special place in the hearts of all who knew her. Services Sunday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Taklimakan Journal; Eons of Tension Crowd a Remote Chinese Tomb
description: At a visitor's approach, Aisham Han pulls her faded silk headdress across her face and gets up from her prayers in front of a small mud-brick mosque a mile from the nearest road. She walks across the sun-bleached courtyard to stand in the shade of an eave before saying a simple, friendly ''Hello.''

title: In a Desolate House, Vestiges of a Violent 1999 Hijacking
description: The tiny piece of paper is inscribed with the names, ages and nationalities of the hostages. Four Spaniards at first. Then an American. A 71-year-old Frenchman wrote his name and his wife's, the last name in capital letters, the first name in cursive. One captor, for some reason, kept this reminder of the lives he once held in his hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, DOLORITA WALLACE
description: MOORE-Dolorita Wallace. Age 68. A Christian lady entered into eternal rest suddenly and peacefully at home on December 4, 2001. Dolorita leaves her loving husband James, her two devoted sons James and Edmund, and daughter-in-law Margaret. Her son Stratford predeceased her. Dolorita was the eldest of the five children of Dr. Stratford C. Wallace and Dolorita F. Wallace and leaves her two sisters Marie W. Powers and Julia G. Wallace, and two brothers Stratford C. and William Wallace. After having attended Marymount School and Marymount College in New York and raising her family, Dolorita became a mainstay of Catholic organizations in New York. A life-long member of the Ladies of Charity Committee of 100, Board member of the Catholic Big Sisters, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary Auxilliary, Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Kennedy Child Study Center, Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club, New York Chapter of the U.S. Navy League, Hampton Bays Beautification Association, and a member of the Saint Vincent's Auxiliary. This past Spring, Chuck Scarborough (WNBC-TV news anchor) presented Dolorita with the Kennedy Child Study Center Annual Service Award for her generous support of programs for children with disabilities. Dolorita leaves hundreds of loving friends who celebrated with her the life of our city. A celebration of Dolorita's life and a Requiem Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, New York City on Saturday, December 8th at 10AM. Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 79PM. Contributions may be sent to the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67 Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10021 and the Hampton Bays Beautification Association, POB 771, Hampton Bays, N.Y. 11946.

title: Children Left to Wonder Where Their Friends and the Buildings Went
description: They have lots of questions, the inquisitive little ones at the Battery Park City Day Nursery, just a few blocks from ground zero.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Eighth Case Of West Nile
description: A 75-year-old woman has become New Jersey's eighth confirmed case of exposure to the West Nile virus this season, the State Health Department said yesterday. The patient, whose name has not been released, lives in Harrison and regularly spends time outdoors, health officials said. She has recovered and returned to work after being hospitalized in mid-August with fever, nausea and headache. Although preliminary tests were negative, blood tests later indicated exposure to the virus, and more sophisticated tests by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed the exposure.

title: Rivera Is Doing His Part For Children's Hospital
description: Mariano Rivera met Yordano Alvarez a year ago at a telethon in Panama, two heroes of their country. Rivera is the closer for the Yankees, the pitcher who finished three straight World Series championships before failing last month. The 11-year-old Yordano is the poster boy for the 20-30 Teletn, an annual fund-raiser for children in Panama.

description: BUNCHER-Jack. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our friend and mentor, Jack Buncher. His vision and energy continue to enrich the lives of young Jewish leaders and assure the future of Jewish life in communities around the world. Jack was the founder and visionary who made possible the creation of the Buncher Leadership Program, an all-important tool in the development of Jewish leaders on every continent. Sponsored by the Buncher family through the United Jewish Federation of Greater Pittsburgh, Jack's program has enabled more than 220 lay and professional leaders to acquire the skills they need to help their communities flourish. Through the continuous support of the Buncher Foundation, Jack witnessed the positive impact of the Buncher Program on the lives of Jews in developing communities the world over. The future of these Jewish communities is Jack's true legacy. Eugene J. Ribakoff, President Jonathan W. Kolker, Chairman Michael Schneider, Exec. VP

I could just point and click away while grabbing chocolate-chip cookies from Brenda the flight attendant.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''ICE CUBE: GREATEST HITS'' (Priority). There are two types of best-of compilations for artists. The first simply collects the highest-charting singles, an approach generally used for pop superstars. The second mixes the artist's best-known material with the most meaningful and important songs, an approach used for artists whose fans admire their musicianship or songwriting. Ice Cube (with a couple of narrow-minded exceptions early in his solo career) deserves this latter approach. This parting shot from Priority, however, doesn't give Ice Cube the respect he deserves, focusing instead mostly on hits and material that fit in with current pop trends. Though most of his classics are here, from ''Once Upon a Time in the Projects'' to ''It Was a Good Day'' to ''Pushin' Weight,'' some of Ice Cube's best songs are neglected, among them his brilliant gender battle with Yo Yo, ''It's a Man's World,'' and his from-conception gangsta autobiography, ''The Product.'' title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: JILL SCOTT: ''Experience 826+'' (Hidden Beach). Singing, reciting poetry, scatting, rapping, telling stories, imitating a scratching disc jockey or just riding the groove, Jill Scott takes her time on her live album. As her band eases between funk and jazz and her backup singers follow her every turn, Ms. Scott explores love that's simultaneously carnal, spiritual, Afrocentric, political, pragmatic and contentious. A live disc (''826,'' named for its August recording date) expands material from Ms. Scott's debut album, loosening up the songs for an elated audience. A second disc (''+'') includes strong new material from the stage and the studio that delves further into Ms. Scott's multiple agendas. With jazz improvisations, scratchy funk, seductive vulnerability and forthright poetry, Ms. Scott calls for respect that's as strong as lust, while she posits righteousness as essential to the deepest pleasure. JON PARELES

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: ''MTV TRL CHRISTMAS'' (Lava/Atlantic). For many teeny-boppers, this CD may be one of the most exciting presents to unwrap on Christmas. That's not just because of the music -- with a little 'N Sync pleading, Christina Aguilera showboating, TLC harmonizing, Blink-182 wisecracking and P.O.D. rap-rocking -- but because of the possible prize inside. That's right, kiddies, selected copies of ''MTV TRL Christmas'' come with a Willie Wonka-style golden ticket that grants the lucky winner a free trip to New York to join the studio audience at ''Total Request Live.'' Besides promoting the show and its acts, this album doubles as a way for Atlantic Records to sneak its up-and-coming acts (like Little-T and One Track Mike, and Willa Ford, who opens the compilation with a high-gloss ode to Christmas materialism) into the stockings of young pop consumers. title: The Peacemaker of the Pashtun Past
description: As the Afghan war enters into what may be its final days, and the international community begins discussing its next steps, Americans will be learning more about the warrior people known to the British as Pathans, and more correctly nowadays as Pashtuns. Most of the Taliban were Pashtun -- as is the new interim leader of Afghanistan, Hamid Karzai, to whom Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, has ceded power. The Pashtuns number upwards of 20 million, and their squat stony villages straddle the Durand Line that nominally demarcates Pakistan from Afghanistan, where Pashtuns form the largest ethnic group. These are the fighters who inspired reams of fearful and admiring verse from Rudyard Kipling, the sharpshooters blessed with perfect sight who picked off the soldiers of the British Raj. But the Pashtuns also produced one of the most remarkable pacifist movements of the 20th century.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: DESTINY'S CHILD: ''Eight Days of Christmas'' (Columbia). It's interesting that the first Christmas of the recession is accompanied by a particularly heavy blizzard of materialist Christmas songs, with They Might Be Giants asking for ''lots of money'' and Willa Ford begging for mansions around the globe to a chorus of ''Gimme gimme gimme.'' The singers in Destiny's Child are the greediest on ''Eight Days of Christmas,'' raking in a diamond belly ring, a CLK Mercedes-Benz and a lot of pampering, before concluding that they love their man ''for his generosity.'' This happens to be one of the best tracks on a 12-song collection that veers from beguilingly slick pop to completely uninspired droning that leads one to wonder if someday Destiny's Child will just be replaced by a computer program. title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: LILIPUT/KLEENEX: ''The Complete Recordings'' (Kill Rock Stars). The do-it-yourself ideology of punk spread across Europe in the late 1970's to spawn groups like Kleenex: a band from Zurich, led by Marlene Marder and Klaudia Schiff, that sang most of its rudimentary but skewed songs in English. It changed its name to Liliput to avoid trademark infringement. The band started out shouting girlish group chants and terse life lessons set to unison drums and electric guitars, sometimes adding a saxophone or a scratchy violin; later, more adept on its instruments but still wayward, it toyed with funk, clanking metal and leisurely melodies. Liliput lasted from 1978 to 1983, making music as feisty, sinewy and self-invented as the riot grrrls and indie-rockers who were bound to rediscover them. JON PARELES

title: SUIZA FOODS TO SELL 5 MORE DAIRIES TO HELP DEAL
description: The Suiza Foods Corporation, a leading dairy, will sell five additional plants in an effort to resolve antitrust enforcers' concerns about the company's planned $2.5 billion purchase of the Dean Foods Company. Suiza expects to sell a total of 11 plants to National Dairy Holdings. Selling the extra dairies should ease concerns that the combined company would have too strong a hold on dairy sales in certain parts of the country, the companies said. With the purchase, the company would have about $10 billion in annual sales and 35 percent of the nation's dairy market.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Can't Fly With Mayor-Elect
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is still hoping to travel to Israel this weekend, but an aide said yesterday that a scheduling conflict would prevent him from flying aboard Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg's private jet. Mr. Giuliani said earlier this week that he hoped to join Gov. George E. Pataki and Mr. Bloomberg tomorrow for the flight on Mr. Bloomberg's plane to Israel, where they planned to stay overnight to show their support in the wake of the recent suicide bombings. But last night the mayor's spokeswoman, Sunny Mindel, said that the mayor would not be able to make the flight because he planned to attend the funeral of a firefighter who died in the World Trade Center terrorist attack, tomorrow afternoon. Michael Cooper (NYT)

description: Bayer, the German chemical and pharmaceutical company, gave a small nod to frustrated shareholders by announcing plans to divide its businesses into four separate companies: pharmaceuticals, chemicals, polymers and agricultural sciences. But Bayer's chairman, Manfred Schneider, once again made it clear that he had no intention of splitting up the company or selling off a controlling stake in the struggling pharmaceutical business. ''It is not intended that we will split with the drug division,'' Mr. Schneider said to reporters. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: ''A SEASON OF SOUL AND SOUNDS'' (Epic). The current crop of rhythm-and-blues artists on Epic doesn't fall prey to the Christmas-album fallacy, which is that one must sing war horses woodenly, as if in a 70's television special. They just use Christmas for their own ends and do what they know best: seduction. Ginuwine's ''Christmas Day'' is a sex song, simple and straight to the point: the thing is, he wants to have sex -- on Christmas. Glenn Lewis's ''This Christmas'' proves that a Stevie Wonder song by any other name will smell as sweet. Amel Larrieux's moody ''Believe in Love'' gets at the spirit without Hallmark-card lyrics. And B2K, in the desperate plea ''Why'd You Leave Me On Christmas?,'' gets the lyrics award: ''I bought you a two-way/I even left Chante/I won't cheat again/I need you, my friend.'' It's only Macy Gray, ever the kitsch maven, who croaks through a sonically tricked-up but uninspired ''Winter Wonderland.'' BEN RATLIFF

title: Mets Trade Ventura to Yankees for Justice
description: The rare trades between the Yankees and Mets require a harmonic convergence of circumstance, and with both teams looking to shed a high-salaried veteran, the Mets sent third baseman Robin Ventura to the Yankees for outfielder David Justice. It is only the 11th player transaction between the teams in 40 years and by far the most significant deal.

description: DEANA CARTER: ''Father Christmas'' (Rounder). The family plays together on ''Father Christmas,'' for which the singer Deana Carter is backed only by her father, Fred Carter Jr., on an acoustic guitar or two (with overdubs). It's made in a home studio but is by no means primitive, as Mr. Carter's careful arrangements mix the jazzy and the folky behind Ms. Carter's playful voice. Christmas albums rarely get more understated than this one. JON PARELES

title: ING CUTTING 1,600 JOBS AT ITS U.S. INSURANCE DIVISION
description: ING Groep, the large Dutch financial-services firm, said it would cut 1,600 jobs, or 15 percent of the workers, at its United States insurance unit in an effort to bolster profit. The cuts follow a spending spree last year in which ING bought the ReliaStar Financial Corporation and two units of Aetna. But those deals have so far generated returns well below company guidelines. ReliaStar and Aetna combined added 5 cents a share to ING's earnings for the first nine months of the year, well below the 26 cents a share the company initially predicted. ING lowered the target in March to 17 cents. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, DOLORITA WALLACE
description: MOORE-Dolorita Wallace. Age 68. A Christian lady entered into eternal rest suddenly and peacefully at home on December 4, 2001. Dolorita leaves her loving husband James, her two devoted sons James and Edmund, and daughter-in-law Margaret. Her son Stratford predeceased her. Dolorita was the eldest of the five children of Dr. Stratford C. Wallace and Dolorita F. Wallace and leaves her two sisters Marie W. Powers and Julia G. Wallace, and two brothers Stratford C. and William Wallace. After having attended Marymount School and Marymount College in New York and raising her family, Dolorita became a mainstay of Catholic organizations in New York. A life-long member of the Ladies of Charity Committee of 100, Board member of the Catholic Big Sisters, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary Auxilliary, Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Kennedy Child Study Center, Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club, New York Chapter of the U.S. Navy League, Hampton Bays Beautification Association, and a member of the Saint Vincent's Auxiliary. This past Spring, Chuck Scarborough (WNBC-TV news anchor) presented Dolorita with the Kennedy Child Study Center Annual Service Award for her generous support of programs for children with disabilities. Dolorita leaves hundreds of loving friends who celebrated with her the life of our city. A celebration of Dolorita's life and a Requiem Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, New York City on Saturday, December 8th at 10AM. Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 79PM. Contributions may be sent to the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67 Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10021 and the Hampton Bays Beautification Association, POB 771, Hampton Bays, N.Y. 11946.

description: ''CLASSIC REGGAE: THE DEEJAYS'' (Music Club/Demon). If the stream of Jamaican dub-reggae reissues from the English label Blood and Fire scares you a bit -- is there time for the collected works of King Tubby and for things like eating, sleeping, and family? -- this one-disc survey may ease your problems. With toasters (Jamaican proto rappers, dating back to the late 1960's) like U-Roy, Dennis Alcapone and Big Youth, this album jostles the pleasant (King Stitt's infectious ''Dance Beat'') with the dire (Big Youth's ''Wolf in Sheep's Clothing'') and the dryly absurd (Sir Lord Comic's ''Great Wuga Wuga''); above it all is a ceaselessly inventive vernacular, chatting, whooping, singing. title: Technology Briefing | Software: VA Linux Becomes VA Software
description: VA Linux Systems Inc. said yesterday that it was changing its name to the VA Software Corporation, a moniker that reflects its exit from the Linux server business earlier this year. The struggling company, based in Fremont, Calif., has refocused on selling a proprietary version of SourceForge, the collaborative programming software that the company once offered as open-source software to programmers. ''The name VA Software Corporation better identifies us and our primary business: developing, marketing, selling and supporting the SourceForge collaborative software development platform,'' Larry M. Augustin, the company's chief executive, said in a statement. ''The name VA Linux Systems is primarily identified with our former Linux hardware systems and consulting businesses.'' The name change, announced at the company's annual shareholders meeting, took effect immediately. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

description: SUZY BOGGUSS: ''Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas'' (Loyal Duchess Records). Not to be lost in the glut of country albums (''Christmas Cookies,'' ''No Wrapping Required'' and other compilations) is this understated gem from Suzy Bogguss. At first this album threatens to leave no impression: the songs are predictable classics, and Ms. Bogguss delivers straight-ahead, no-frills versions. But her voice is so well calibrated to each song and her delivery is so seemingly effortless, and the arrangements are such a perfect balance of country and holiday that, in almost no time, this CD begins to seem as comfortable as a pair of warm socks on Christmas morning. title: The Man Who Was Martha Stewart Back Before She Was
description: If you were a middle-class American housewife from the 1930's to the 50's, it was hard to escape Russel Wright (1904-76). It was more than possible that he had designed at least some of the dishes you and your family ate from, the furniture and appliances you used and the sheets you slept between.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Service Disappoints Web Surfers
description: A research group at Ohio State University said its findings showed that nearly half of those whose access to the World Wide Web was through an Internet service provider were dissatisfied with the quality of service. ''Interrupted connections are a frequently cited concern -- 75 percent of the respondents told us that their connection is occasionally or frequently interrupted,'' said Vivian Witkind-Davis, associate director of the university's National Regulatory Research Institute. About 48 percent of those surveyed cited the desire for fewer service interruptions as the primary reason for changing providers. Connection quality was the reason most frequently cited by people who said they had switched or had considered switching, followed by faster data rates and lower prices. Fewer than 25 percent said the speed of their Internet connection met their expectations. The institute surveyed 14,000 users from Oct. 25 to Nov. 3.

title: A Cornered Enemy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The American war aims were clear: Take down the Taliban regime, which had converted Afghanistan into a temple for terrorists, and destroy Al Qaeda, the terror network that operated freely there. The war oratory was sharp: Bring to justice those responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks on America, or bring justice to them.

title: Donor Tissue Blamed in a Knee Surgery Death
description: An investigation into three deaths last month in Minnesota after routine knee surgery has left two cases unexplained but has made an ominous finding in the third: that donor tissue commonly used in certain knee operations can spread life-threatening infections.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 — Mark Parrish knows exactly how to make hockey fun for the Islanders again. "Win," he said.

title: Kvasha Helps Isles Regain Their Edge
description: The other Oleg Kvasha showed up tonight. This Oleg Kvasha played like a menace and handled the puck as if he knew exactly what to do with it. In other words, it was not the Oleg Kvasha who has been playing for the Islanders most of the season.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Rise In Salmon Population
description: Officials at the Seattle Aquarium are recording the largest return of chum salmon to the facility's fish ladder on Elliot Bay in its 24 years of operation. Roger Ogren, a staff biologist, said he had counted more than 600 chum, well beyond the 1993 record of 50. Mr. Ogren said favorable ocean conditions, including large populations of herring and krill, which salmon feed on, contributed to the large run. Chum migrate downstream to open ocean soon after birth and return to fresh water to spawn after four years. Puget Sound is also seeing large runs of coho and pink salmon this fall. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: CONSECO BUYS BACK MORE BONDS TO REDUCE DEBT LOAD
description: Conseco Inc. said yesterday that it had purchased an additional $108 million worth of bonds due in 2002 in November as it seeks to trim its debt load to bolster profit. The purchases bring to $232 million the amount of debt the company has bought back this year, or 27 percent of its obligations maturing in 2002. Conseco, which is based in Carmel, Ind., has been trying to cut costs and increase earnings at its insurance and finance units to meet $1.28 billion in debt obligations due next year. The company's total debt, rated below investment grade by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, stands at about $6 billion.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: CORPORAL BLOSSOM: ''A Mutated Christmas'' (Illegal Art). Made by the same sonic whippersnappers who made ''Deconstructing Beck'' a few years back, this does a similar cut-and-paste job with famous Christmas music, taken from hundreds of sources. Some are more obvious than others; Corporal Blossom, one of 10 artists or DJ teams represented here, goes for the biggies, including Armstrong, Sinatra, Crosby and Presley, using their voices and bits of their backing music, draping the goopy old string arrangements over new digital beat-box rhythms. It's exactly the irreverence needed for songs like ''I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus''; if it becomes obnoxious at times, that's the point.

title: Commander Of a Precinct Is Suspended
description: The commanding officer of the 42nd Precinct in the Bronx was suspended from duty yesterday after he barged into an East Harlem police station Wednesday night, slapped a female officer in the face and urinated into the office sink of the captain in charge, the authorities said. No charges have been filed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, GREG
description: MacARTHUR-Greg. The Center for Media Education and the Center for Digital Democracy mourn the passing of our friend and supporter. Greg was an accomplished journalist, filmmaker, activist, and philanthropist. Through his efforts, many critical public interest issues were effectively addressed. title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: DJ RED ALERT: ''Presents . . . Beats, Rhymes and Battles, Vol. I'' (Loud). Rappers often talk about the legacy of their music in educational metaphors, speaking of schools and history. This CD makes the metaphor literal, offering a lesson in hip-hop history like a book on tape. The CD intersperses conversations about the roots of the form with some of the legendary back-and-forth song battles in which rival rappers traded insults. An interesting twist to this CD is that in a music genre often accused of misogyny and patriarchy, this collection offers a gender-mixed take on battling: man to man (Kool Moe Dee versus LL Cool J), woman to man (Salt-n-Pepa versus Slick Rick), and woman to woman (MC Lyte versus Antoinette). NEIL STRAUSS

description: The economy of Japan, the world's second largest, officially entered a recession today as figures showed the gross domestic product contracting for a second consecutive quarter.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Pager Files For Bankruptcy
description: Arch Wireless, a provider of wireless messaging services, said yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection. The company, based in Worcester, Mass., also said it and its creditors had reached a debt restructuring agreement under which it will issue $300 million worth of notes in exchange for about $1.3 billion of outstanding bonds. Arch, the nation's largest paging company, has been hurt by pager customers swapping their units for cell phones. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: CAMPBELL BROTHERS: ''Sacred Steel for the Holidays'' (Arhoolie). Chuck Campbell on pedal steel guitar and Phillip Campbell on guitar and MIDI (synthesizer) guitar play for gospel services in House of God churches, with their instruments taking over for singers' swoops and wails. Now they take on Christmas standards and ''The Dreydl Song,'' refreshing the songs with the incongruity of the pedal steel in the foreground. The arrangements lean toward jazz and pop-jazz, sometimes with the country touch of western swing. For half the songs, a singer, Denise Brown, holds her own alongside the pedal steel's insouciant, wavering lines. JON PARELES

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: SLAID CLEAVES: ''Holiday Sampler'' (Philo). This five-song album is intended to take one all the way through February, with songs about Christmas, the New Year and Valentine's Day from one of the finest singer-songwriters from Texas, Slaid Cleaves. The EP highlights the goofy side of Mr. Cleaves rather than the ballads of troubled, down-and-out, kicked-around characters that litter his previous albums. There's the fun honky-tonk stomp ''Monster-in-Law'' and a well-done twanging, accordion-laced rendition of ''You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch.'' In an alternate version of ''One Good Year,'' one of Mr. Cleaves's lost characters, desperately clinging to his last spark of optimism, offers the New Year's Day wish in the title. The only problem with this album is that there aren't enough songs; it would have been interesting to see further intersections of Mr. Cleaves's broke-down aesthetic with that of holiday cheer. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: LARRY GRAHAM AND GRAHAM CENTRAL STATION: ''The Jam: The Larry Graham and Graham Central Station Anthology'' (Warner Archives/ Rhino). This is an essential compilation for funk fans, charting the work of the monster bassist Mr. Graham after his departure from Sly and the Family Stone. The first disc here is phenomenal and doesn't let up, with Mr. Graham's picking, popping, plucking and slapping bass-playing driving each soulful jam to transcendence, but always stopping short of indulgence. The second disc soon begins to wane as the late 70's and 80's wreak havoc on the band's style and direction. Fortunately, a closing cover of ''I Want to Take You Higher'' (recorded live in 1992) returns this masterly musician to his original mission. And as good as this collection can be, it's still no substitute for the powers of the band live. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Ashcroft Defends Antiterror Plan and Says Criticism May Aid Foes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  In forceful and unyielding testimony, Attorney General John Ashcroft today defended the administration's array of antiterrorism proposals and accused some of the program's critics of aiding terrorists by providing "ammunition to America's enemies."

title: When Business and Pleasure Don't Mix
description: Whether exuding Manhattan-style noblesse oblige in ''Six Degrees of Separation'' or Washington-style political clout in ''The West Wing,'' Stockard Channing embodies the sort of patrician grandeur that actors like Mary Astor and Barbara Stanwyck conjured in their more upscale movie roles. And in ''The Business of Strangers,'' Patrick Stettner's chilly corporate nightmare, her aristocratic command inflects her portrait of a hardened, lonely American businesswoman at the top of her game with a hint of tragedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEMEL, FRANCES
description: SEMEL-Frances. The Semel Society records with sorrow the loss of our esteemed member, Frances Semel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Abraham and children Peter and Bernice and their families. Martin Semel, President

title: Swept Up by Nature In His Own Backyard
description: Capturing the soul of a sunflower or the tilt of a worn rain pipe, Charles Burchfield (1893-1967) was as obsessed with small-town America as was, say, the folk painter Edward Hicks with his otherworldly ''Peaceable Kingdom.'' He was imbued with passion for the local and particular, but also for the powerful forces of nature and its seasons. And along with his contemporary and friend Edward Hopper, he is considered a founder of American Scene painting.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil plunged on concern that inventories would keep increasing as producers delay an accord to trim output. In New York, crude oil for January delivery fell 95 cents, or 4.9 percent, to $18.54 a barrel.

description: HARRY ALLEN: ''Christmas in Swingtime'' (Koch Jazz). Mr. Allen, a young, traditional, swing-oriented tenor saxophonist, plays the expected numbers (''O Christmas Tree,'' ''White Christmas,'' etc.), with a band that includes the organist Larry Goldings and the guitarist Peter Bernstein. title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''IT CAME FROM MEMPHIS, VOL. 2'' (Birdman). As Mark Twain might have put it, you don't know about this music without you have read a book by the name of ''It Came From Memphis'' (Pocket Books), but that ain't no matter. That book was by Robert Gordon, and he told the truth, mainly, though it is unapologetically a guide to the self-styled eccentric's Memphis, with its prominent heroes -- the producer and keyboardist Jim Dickinson, the clarinetist Robert Palmer (a former New York Times critic), and the guitarist Tav Falco -- rather than the ones you might expect (Elvis, Sam Phillips, et al.). The eccentrics' music lies herein; it's raw and funny and powerful. BEN RATLIFF

description: Mario Monti, the European Commission's antitrust chief who has blocked both European and American mergers, will circulate a broad range of proposals next week that could increase his power at the expense of Europe's national regulators.

description: For the last 24 years, the McDonald's All-America basketball game has showcased some of the nation's most talented schoolboys. Michael Jordan, Shaquille O'Neal, Allan Houston, Kobe Bryant and Patrick Ewing were McDonald's all-Americans as high school seniors.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Medicine And Ethics
description: Only 5 percent of doctors in Poland said they were regularly offered bribes, but patients told a different story to the nation's leading newspaper: 53 percent of Poles questioned by Gazeta Wyborcza said they had offered health-care workers money for better care in the state-run system in the last three years. Only 10 percent of doctors said it was completely unethical to take bribes. Forty-four percent said it was all right after treatment; 15 percent said it was permissible to take a bribe to speed up a patient's treatment. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Labor: New Term For Union Chief
description: John J. Sweeney, left, was re-elected to a four-year term as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. at its convention in Las Vegas. Mr. Sweeney, who ran unopposed, has headed the 13-million-member federation for six years. Richard L. Trumka was re-elected as secretary-treasurer, and Linda Chavez-Thompson as executive vice president. The labor federation, which includes 66 unions, also called on the federal government late Wednesday to end its supervision of the Teamsters union, which began in 1989 in an effort to end Mafia domination of the 1.4-million-member union.

title: U.S. Forces Engage Taliban Fleeing Kandahar
description: United States marines have been engaged in several fights in the last 24 hours with Taliban forces fleeing the southern Afghan city of Kandahar, the American general overseeing the military operation in Afghanistan said today.

Usually at this time of year, there is only one question surrounding the Heisman Trophy: who is college football's outstanding player?

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: MANNHEIM STEAMROLLER: ''Christmas Extraordinaire'' (American Gramaphone). Taking fan requests from its Web site, Mannheim Steamroller selected a mix of carols and seasonal compositions for its long-awaited fourth official Christmas album. With precision, taste and compositional derring-do, Chip Davis (the man driving the Steamroller) refines the blend of early classical and modern instrumental music that has characterized his best work (along with the occasional and welcome touch of humor). Though some of the production and sounds are too generic for my ears, the arrangements, which mix historical mindfulness with a compulsion for innovation, make this almost as classic as the previous ones, especially when Mr. Davis is wafting choirs and glee clubs into the mix. The CD is also sold in a box set with the group's three other main Christmas albums as ''Christmas Collection.'' NEIL STRAUSS

The songs, most of them written by Ms. Braxton and collaborators, use the Christmas season as one more excuse to luxuriate in her husky endearments. The tempos are slow, the grooves are plush and she keeps her Christmas spirit secular and sensual; ''Christmas in Jamaica,'' a duet with the pop-reggae singer Shaggy, ends with Ms. Braxton whispering ''sex on the beach.'' Even when she eventually falls back on warhorses like ''The Christmas Song,'' she seems to be promising a very intimate party. JON PARELES

And somewhere along the way, someone had the bright idea of letting the art dictate the food, which, in its own way, fills another niche. In a small room to the right of the entrance, Kurt Gutenbrunner, the chef and owner of Walls, has created a Viennese cafe, named after the collector Serge Sabarsky, whose works help form the basis of the museum's collection. It is deliberately humble, with homey, robust Austro-Hungarian dishes, a few Austrian wines and lots of Viennese desserts.
