title: The Miracle of Coltrane: Dead at 40, Still Vital at 75
description: Performing artists like John Coltrane don't usually become famous. He was quiet, generous, even-tempered, honest, unjudgmental. There are no published reports of his flying off the handle, and he had no apparent gift for public relations. The stories of his desperate need to practice, above all else, start before he reaches 20; they continue through his first public successes and to the end. The end came with liver cancer at 40 in 1967. Coltrane would have turned 75 this year.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: PINK FLOYD: ''Echoes: The Best of Pink Floyd'' (Capitol); SYD BARRETT: ''The Best of Syd Barrett: Wouldn't You Miss Me?'' (Capitol). There are some classic rock groups whose songs seem inseparable from the context of the albums in which they appear, and one of them is most definitely Pink Floyd. Its best albums were conceptual and architectural explorations loaded with musical, visual and lyrical themes that continue to stump fans. Thus, in attempting an impossible task, ''Echoes'' does the best job imaginable. It mixes the hits (''Another Brick in the Wall, Part 2''), the instrumental favorites (''One of These Days'') and the madcap laughs of the band's original singer, Syd Barrett (''Bike''). Add to this the album's references to the synchronicity that occurs when one plays the song ''Echoes'' over the ''Jupiter and Beyond'' music in the movie ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' and you have a best-of that just may belong in the band's excellent oeuvre. Compiling a best-of for Mr. Barrett, on the other hand, is an appropriate approach to the songs that were coaxed out of him in his fragile post-Pink Floyd mental state. Where his solo albums have their many moments of beauty, introspection, imagination and simplicity, this compilation cuts out the chaff (and adds the previously unreleased ''Bob Dylan Blues''), making it a necessary first purchase for those wishing to explore the mind of the tortured genius who sang lines from the heart like ''Inside me I feel/ Alone and unreal.'' Toshiba said the decision was also partly based on concern about slumping earnings among electronics makers as the economy slows. A Toshiba spokeswoman declined to say whether Toshiba would continue efforts to develop faster phones on its own or seek partners. Jacobs. The county was just a few days and decimal points from a budget takeover by a state-appointed board, and instead of finding a solution to a $45 million deficit, from her vantage point, its legislators were behaving like kindergartners.

Like boys taunting each other in a schoolyard, they hurl mutual accusations until the Bosnian, Ciki (Branko Djuric), who is armed, forces the Serb, Nino (Rene Bitorajac), at gunpoint to say out loud that the Serbs were to blame. Ciki continues to give orders, and when Nino asks why, Ciki growls, ''Because I have a gun and you don't.''

description: Two months after it began, the war in Afghanistan seemed to be coming to a surprisingly rapid end, as Taliban forces agreed to surrender the southern city of Kandahar, their last stronghold. Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader who remained in the besieged city, negotiated a peace which calls for him to transfer power to a local tribal leader and for his Afghan soldiers to lay down their weapons: the fate of their Arab comrades in arms was not certain.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''ALLIGATOR RECORDS: 30TH-ANNIVERSARY COLLECTION'' (Alligator). Alligator Records started as a way for a fan named Bruce Iglauer to make an album of the Mississippi bluesman Hound Dog Taylor. Thirty years later, its roster extends from its home in Chicago all the way to Australia. This set concentrates on the label's last decade, with one CD each of studio and live recordings. With muscular, no-frills production, Alligator catches the blues as it melds with soul, rock, gospel, country and zydeco, trying to party away the pains of love. JON PARELES

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: THE MIGHTY HANNIBAL: ''Hannibalism'' (Norton). Born James Shaw, the beturbaned Mighty Hannibal, now in his early 60's, began his soul-shouting career in 1958 rather modestly, with ''Big Chief Hug-Um An' Kiss-Um.'' He was a second-tier star, with songs that sounded like Sam Cooke, James Brown and others; he had one incontrovertibly great dance tune, ''Jerkin' the Dog.'' His greatest moment of relevance may have come in the mid-60's with a message song, ''Hymn No. 5,'' a soldier's letter home from Vietnam. But the most valuable part of this labor-of-love reissue is Hannibal's lengthy liner notes, culled from recent interviews: he's a sly fox who has seen the best and worst of the show-business life, from television talk shows to pimping, and lays it out baldly, like a picaresque novella. title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: B. B. KING: ''A Christmas Celebration of Hope'' (MCA). B. B. King hadn't gotten around to making a full-length Christmas album until this year, and he pulls it off like the blues trouper he is. He skips the carols in favor of blues and soul songs, bouncing between blue-Christmas laments and the pleasures of home and family, along with the naughty ''Back-Door Santa.'' The band, with a horn section, is crisp and jovial, taking on touches of New Orleans, where the album was made, while Mr. King sings like a patriarch who still remembers past troubles. JON PARELES

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Homestore.com Finance Chief Quits
description: Shares of Homestore.com Inc. fell 63 cents, or more than 20 percent, to $2.47, yesterday after the online home-listing company said its chief financial officer, Joseph Shew, had resigned. Mr. Shew, who had been in the post since February, left for personal reasons, Home store.com said. Although it controls more than 90 percent of the home-sale listings on the Internet, Homestore.com lost $106 million in the third quarter as advertising revenue, which accounts for a third of its sales, plunged 44 percent.

title: A Steamy Christmas to All
description: When Jane Monheit tosses her head and slinks into a slow-burning performance of ''Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas,'' one of the most wistful of all holiday anthems takes on a sensual blush. That aura is not a conscious attempt by the pop-jazz singer to bring a Marilyn Monroe-like sexiness to the standard introduced by Judy Garland in ''Meet Me in St. Louis.'' Youthful sensuality just evaporates off her as naturally as perspiration in sultry phrasing that lingers behind the beat and a voice that dips and curves around lyrics and at times rises to the brink of a wail.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Arrest Outside White House
description: The Secret Service arrested a 26-year-old man with a foot-long knife near the White House, and agents later discovered loaded weapons and 1,000 rounds of ammunition in his pick-up truck. The Secret Service said the man, William T. Duncan, was ''acting suspiciously'' near the southwest gate around 7 a.m. A search of his pick-up truck, parked several blocks away, found an assault rifle, a rifle with a scope and a loaded handgun, along with a bullet-proof vest and a Kevlar helmet. Mr. Duncan, who has no fixed address, was charged with weapons offenses.

An additional $18 million will be paid after the transaction closes if certain performance goals are met, Omnicare said. American Pharmaceutical provides respiratory, pharmacy and consulting services to nursing homes and assisted-living residents through a network of 32 pharmacies in 15 states.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: ''A VERY SPECIAL CHRISTMAS 5'' (Interscope). Who let this one out? There are some great moments on this pop-and-rock compilation, and some of it just hurts, particularly the two contributions from Wyclef Jean, who would sound a lot better if he possessed one-tenth of the skills he thinks he's flaunting on these tracks. Macy Gray, however, makes a surprisingly fine showing with ''This Christmas''; Dido's ''Christmas Day'' is beautiful and eloquent; Powder's take on a Chipmunks' holiday classic (especially the squeaky way the word Hula-Hoop is sung) is precious; and B. B. King and John Popper make quick work of ''Back-Door Santa.'' Now, if Santa could only squeeze as many notes and extra things into a stocking as Mr. Popper squeezes into a few bars of harmonica playing, we'd all be very happy this Christmas. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: CANDI STATON: ''Christmas in My Heart'' (Beracah/WEA). The first Christmas song to mention elderly mall-walkers is the title tune on Candi Staton's Christmas album. Since the 1970's, Ms. Staton has moved from Southern soul to gospel. The two styles were never far apart, and Ms. Staton still sings with womanly conviction and exuberant leaps. Her piano-centered band unites church and club for her own Christmas songs, including ''Christmas in My Heart,'' as well as an up-tempo gospel take on ''Joy to the World'' and a slow-rolling ''Silent Night.'' The closing song, ''Change in My Life,'' moves the timeline forward to disco gospel. And look out, Martha Stewart: liner notes include Ms. Staton's recipe for turkey stuffing. JON PARELES

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''THAT'S ALL FOLKS!: CARTOON SONGS FROM MERRIE MELODIES AND LOONEY TUNES'' (Warner Brothers). High culture, erstwhile pop hits and linear narrative didn't stand a chance against the jokers behind Warner Brothers cartoons. This two-CD set, the follow-up to an instrumental collection, features vocal numbers from Bugs Bunny, Donald Duck and their cohorts. It includes the soundtracks for six full cartoons -- including ''What's Opera, Doc?,'' Richard Wagner distilled to seven frenetic minutes -- along with snippets from countless others. Behind wordplay as nutty as the voices that delivered it, Carl Stalling and the studio's other composer-arrangers left no genre unparodied, and only the most adventurous current disc jockeys can rival their quick-changing pastiches. JON PARELES

title: Voters in Sri Lanka Reject The Nation's Ruling Coalition
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 7  In election results announced today, Sri Lanka's voters rejected the coalition that has governed for the past seven years. They chose instead the main opposition party and its allies, who have promised to pursue peace talks with Tamil rebels and seek an end to the ethnic conflict that has claimed more than 62,000 lives in the past 18 years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VERISIGN INC., Mountain View, Calif., a provider of Internet trust services needed by Web sites to conduct e-commerce, said it had agreed to buy closely held 1GlobalPlace Inc. and NameEngineInc., two providers of international domain-registration services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 2 Big Chip Makers Raise Forecasts
description: Intel and Advanced Micro Devices raised their financial forecasts for the current quarter today, saying that their microprocessors that power personal computers were selling better than expected.

title: Bill Seeks to Change Arlington Rules
description: Representative Christopher H. Smith, a New Jersey Republican and the chairman of the Committee on Veterans' Affairs, today introduced legislation that would eliminate the age requirement for retired reservists who would otherwise be eligible for a burial plot at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: For a Body That Nobody Ever Had
description: ''EXTREME BEAUTY: The Body Transformed'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute may be the ultimate fashion survey. It is at once a celebration and an indictment of fashion. It reveals both the artistry and the perversity of fashion designers. It demonstrates the powerful pull and aesthetic coherence created by ideals of physical beauty. Yet, because these ideals tend to concern the fairer sex, the show also exposes their link to misogyny and self-loathing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ARTHUR L.
description: LEWIS-Arthur L. Passed away on November 28, 2001 after a brief illness. He was 76 years old. Arthur is survived by his wife of 53 years, Joan Lewis, two daughters, Cathy Lewis of Larchmont, NY and Jane Horsfall of Freeport, Maine, and four grandchildren. He was a husband, father and grandfather extraordinaire, as well as an astute businessman and proud Marine. A memorial service will be held at the Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main Street, Eastchester, New York (914-337-4585) on Saturday, December 8 at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the East Yonkers Rotary Club Scholarship Fund, and to the First Church of Christ Scientist, White Plains-Scarsdale.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Putin Signs Pacts
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, starting a four-day visit, signed six agreements intended to forge closer ties with Greece in areas ranging from counterterrorism to culture. A major topic of talks is expected to be the construction of lucrative energy pipelines linking the Black Sea to the Aegean.

title: Holiday Forecast: A Chance of CD Flurries
description: GLOBAL warming has no effect on the blizzard of Christmas albums, which starts with preliminary flurries as early as August and September and blankets the market in October and November. Sooner or later, it seems, every musician is tempted to remake the seasonal staples, while a few more adventurous ones come up with new songs to address holiday feelings from coziness to desolation. At the same time, greatest-hits albums, quickie live recordings, reissues and compilations turn up to tempt holiday shoppers. Here, pop and jazz critics of The New York Times comment on this year's most notable holiday albums, along with a selection of hits, compilation and reissue albums. (Prices for the CD's range from $7.97 to $18.99.) JON PARELES

title: An Old Violin Whose Music Is Peculiarly Haunting
description: Jonathan Levi, a writer who was a founder of the literary magazine Granta, and Gil Morgenstern, a violinist, formed the Nine Circles Chamber Theater two years ago, after they collaborated on a stage adaptation of Dante's ''Inferno'' at the 92nd Street Y. Their goal is to create new musical theater works, and for their first collaboration, they have used a short story by Mr. Levi, ''The Scrimshaw Violin,'' as the basis for a chamber opera. Mr. Levi wrote his own libretto, and Bruce Saylor was enlisted to write the music. On Monday evening they presented the work at the Y as their new company's inaugural production.

title: Giuliani to Appeal Decision On a Work-for-Shelter Policy
description: Nearly two years ago, a state judge ruled that the Giuliani administration could not bar adults from shelters if they failed to meet work requirements and other welfare eligibility rules.

title: Tracking of Anthrax Letter Yields Clues
description: At 5:27 p.m. on Oct. 9, amid tons of bills, birthday greetings, credit offers and other mail, an anthrax-laced letter to Senator Patrick J. Leahy zipped into the humming, high-speed machinery at a postal sorting center in Hamilton Township, N.J.

title: Iranian Boy, Afghan Girl And Love's Strange Magic
description: ''Baran'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 9; the full text is available at nytimes.com. The film, in Persian and Dari with English subtitles, opens today at Lincoln Square, 1998 Broadway, at 68th Street, and nationwide on Feb. 1.

title: U.S. Official Praises China for Its Cooperation in Rooting Out bin Laden's Terror Network
description: A top American antiterrorism official wound up two days of talks here today by praising the Chinese for their cooperation in fighting Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's terror network, and said he was hopeful that the F.B.I. would soon be allowed to open a liaison office in Beijing.

title: Synagogue From 1800's Is Damaged In a Fire
description: A fire yesterday ravaged a synagogue on the Lower East Side that houses the city's oldest Orthodox congregation. The fire destroyed the roof and ceiling of the 150-year-old building, which has been the subject of recent preservation efforts, but did not cause any injuries.

title: Joe Hin Tjio, 82; Research Biologist Counted Chromosomes
description: Dr. Joe Hin Tjio, the research biologist who produced the first correct count of the chromosomes in human cells, died Nov. 27 in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 82.

title: Mercedes Matter, 87, Artist And Studio School Founder
description: Mercedes Matter, a painter, teacher and the chief founder of the New York Studio School in Greenwich Village, died on Tuesday. She was 87 and lived in East Hampton on Long Island.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''A HISTORY OF GARAGE AND FRAT BANDS IN MEMPHIS, 1960-1975'' (Shangri-La Projects). Sometimes ''ahead of one's time'' translates roughly as ''made for under $10,'' as this disc amply demonstrates; sample the leadoff track by Flash and the Casuals, which sounds like a wood chipper with a good rhythm section. But it's from Memphis, an astonishing music town back in the 60's and early 70's, so there's a decently wide pop-music vocabulary even to this shaggy ephemera. The album is for anybody who thought the justly famous ''Nuggets'' compilations were the alpha and omega of 60's garage rock. BEN RATLIFF

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''GREEN DAY: INTERNATIONAL SUPERHITS!'' (Reprise). First of all, this CD is a testament to the completely unexpected pop longevity of these bratty West Coast punk revivalists. Second, it's amazing to hear how far these band members have come, from songs about playing with themselves to lyrics on politics, morality and patriotism in ''Maria,'' one of two new songs on the album. The only complaint is that the song selection sticks too closely to the title, neglecting to offer anything from the band's early independent releases that date back as far as 12 years. NEIL STRAUSS

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Grenade Hits Kashmir Market
description: A paramilitary spokesman said 17 people, including a 1-year-old child, were wounded when a suspected anti-India militant threw a grenade at a vehicle of the security forces in a crowded market in downtown Srinagar, the summer capital of the Indian state of Kashmir, and missed. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Oil Output To Fall
description: Norway's oil minister said the country would decide by Christmas how much oil to trim from its production, but indicated that the cut would be about 150,000 barrels a day, Reuters reported. Oil output cuts from Norway, the largest exporter after Russia outside OPEC, would probably satisfy the cartel, which had insisted on cuts of 500,000 barrels from all nonmembers before trimming 1.5 million barrels of its output early next year. The secretary-general of OPEC, Ali Rodriguez, said in London that the cartel is ready for a deal ''in principle,'' but is still waiting for other countries, like Norway, to decide on pledges. Russia said yesterday that it would trim exports by 150,000 barrels a day. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: John Ashcroft Misses the Point
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft's appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday was a much-needed chance for lawmakers to express their concerns about the secret detentions and military tribunals that the Bush administration has made part of its response to Sept. 11. But Mr. Ashcroft's politely unyielding testimony showed he is far from getting the message.

title: Officials Say Bomber of the Cole Was in Yemeni Custody Earlier
description: One of the suicide bombers who attacked the destroyer Cole in the Yemeni port of Aden last year had been arrested -- and released -- just 17 months earlier by Yemeni authorities on charges of conspiring to kidnap Americans working in Yemen.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Craig Braasch was named vice president for global advertising and promotions at the Burger King Corporation, Miami, part of Diageo. He succeeds Richard Taylor, who was named to the new post of vice president for alliances and partnerships. Mr. Braasch had been managing director for worldwide advertising and sponsorships at Northwest Airlines, St. Paul, Minn.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Legislature Approves Budget Cuts
description: State lawmakers ended a 10-day special session to balance the budget by approving $1.08 billion in cuts to spending on education, health care and law enforcement. Legislators also agreed to delay a tax cut for investors that was set to take effect in January. Estimates had shown the state faced a $1.3 billion deficit. A group of Cuban-American legislators walked out when former Attorney General Janet Reno was introduced in the gallery, saying they were upset with her role in returning Elin Gonzlez to his Cuban father last year. She is a Democratic candidate for governor. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Rejects PlanTo Allow Mullah Omar 'To Live in Dignity' : Taliban Fighters Agree to Surrender Kandahar
description: WASHINGTON  Afghanistan's Taliban militia said Thursday that it had agreed to surrender its last remaining stronghold, the southern city of Kandahar, to a prominent anti-Taliban commander and would begin giving up its weapons on Friday.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Foote, Cone Quits Last AT&T Account
description: Foote, Cone & Belding in New York said yesterday that it had resigned the last part of its AT&T account. The job involved creating campaigns for AT&T Business, and billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Rangers Desert Richter Once Again
description: The best defense might very well be a good offense. But as far as the Rangers are concerned, a little defense every now and then might not be such a bad thing, either.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: SMASHING PUMPKINS: Greatest Hits'' (Virgin). This is a well-done tribute to the legacy of one of the most important rock bands of the 90's, and at one point the biggest. At 18 tracks, the first disc in this two-CD set, titled ''Rotten Apples,'' initially seems to fall short, missing so many of the band's great songs, but that is not its purpose. It tracks a few standout songs (not always hits) from each CD by a band that always managed to be completely alternative- and mainstream-minded at the same time, never losing its artistic vision in the morass of success pressures and intra-band problems. The collection traces the evolution of Smashing Pumpkins from the intensely textural rock onslaught of its first albums to the pop grandiosity of its glory days to the more conceptual and stylistically far-reaching songs of its final years. For the second disc, I would have liked an official CD of the band's Internet-only album, ''Machina II.'' Instead, there is a disc called ''Judas O,'' which is an impressively high-quality collection of B-sides, tracks from ''Machina II'' and other rarities (a follow-up to a similar collection from 1994, ''Pisces Iscariot''). NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: THE ASYLUM STREET SPANKERS: ''A Christmas Spanking'' (Bloodshot). The Asylum Street Spankers, a jaunty unplugged neo-swing combo from Texas, recorded its Christmas album live, and it's full of convivial in-jokes. The band works its way through Christmas novelties from ''Mele Kalikimaka'' to its own ''Red Nose Reindeer Blues'' (in stop-time Chicago style), not to mention ''Silent Night'' played as a solo on musical saw. But nothing beats its whimsical opener, changing styles -- swing, reggae, bluegrass -- with every verse of ''You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch.'' JON PARELES

title: Senators Spar Carefully in Hearing on Security
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Beneath the stylized courtesies and careful political positioning, the nods to balance and bipartisanship, there was a rough struggle in the Senate Judiciary Committee today.

title: Debt Rating Raised On Trump Hotels
description: The debt rating of Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts was raised by Standard & Poor's yesterday after Trump, a casino company, made a $91 million payment to bondholders before a grace period expired.

title: Striking Back at Hamas
description: Give Yasir Arafat credit for some encouraging first steps against Hamas, the group that claimed responsibility for last weekend's deadly terrorist bombings in Jerusalem and Haifa. Placing Hamas's spiritual leader, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, under house arrest sent a clear message to Hamas supporters, who have responded with angry protests. The real test of the crackdown, however, will be whether Mr. Arafat's security forces break up Hamas's actual terrorist networks, starting with the arrests of approximately three dozen people for whom Israel has provided evidence of involvement in terrorist attacks against Israeli targets.

title: O Treasured Tannenbaum
description: As longtime friends, we have often shopped for Christmas trees together, scouring the street corner lots of Brooklyn for fine spruces and firs. We've enjoyed haggling over the final price almost as much as the fresh piney aroma. But last holiday season our transaction went sour. Our usual dealer, a guy named Vlad with a great selection of balsam firs, didn't show up on his customary corner. And we ended up with a more expensive and less desirable tree from a fast-talking salesman on Flatbush Avenue. This Christmas, we figured we had better go to the source. We decided to cut down our own.

title: Corrections

Scott Vanderhoef. He eliminated funds for 20 agencies and organizations, including a group promoting reading and a Haitian-American cultural group. He did not eliminate the groups; some get private funds.

title: 'Medium Cool' Retains the Heat
description: Year-end ''best'' lists are sprouting, but few shuffle the deck like the annual collection of bests put together by Facets Video, a Chicago chain and mail-order distributor (800-331-6197). Facets lists all-time bests, not just annual bests, and puts them into catchy categories: best director's cuts, best restored films, best British television shows, best films directed by women. This year Facets' 60-page bests catalog, drawn from its main catalog of around 40,000 titles, has 32 lists, among them the 17 best pacifist films. Roberto Benigni's ''Life Is Beautiful'' is there, along with Richard Attenborough's ''Gandhi'' and Sergei Bodrov's ''Prisoner of the Mountains.'' Also included are John Huston's banned documentary ''Let There Be Light,'' about the psychiatric treatment of traumatized World War II veterans, and Spike Lee's ''Four Little Girls,'' about the bombing of a black Baptist church in Alabama.

title: The Neediest Cases; After Some Events, Losing a Job Is the Least of Things
description: Glenn Zoll was scheduled to start his new job as a telecommunications engineer on Wednesday, Sept. 12. Unlike his previous job, it was going to be a permanent position, with benefits. Mr. Zoll, 54, was going to work for Deutsche Bank at 130 Liberty Street, across the street from the World Trade Center. But 130 Liberty Street was severely damaged by the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, and he was left without a job.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Emergency Food Aid Needed
description: Severe flooding in some regions and drought in others has left many Zambians in serious need of food, the World Food Program said. About 1.3 million people will need emergency assistance between December and March, the lean season when family food stocks shrink, particularly among subsistence farmers. Severely reduced harvests in most of southern Africa will probably force the price of corn, the country's staple food, to climb beyond the reach of many Zambian families, the United Nations agency said. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELWANI, SHASHI
description: MELWANI-Shashi. The School for Strings students, faculty, staff and Trustees are extending their heartfelt sympathy to the family of Shashi Melwani. Our thoughts are with you during this very difficult time.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: RADIOHEAD: ''I Might Be Wrong: Live Recordings'' (Capitol). It has been interesting to watch Radiohead's live concerts evolve from manic twitching affairs to symphonies of stillness. This eight-song album captures the latter, mostly with songs from the band's previous two recordings. Just as a concert can sometimes open up a band's album and make it more accessible, this live album strips away the production and studio effects to reveal the songs lurking behind some of the soundscapes on these albums. It also features a live acoustic version of an unreleased favorite, ''True Love Waits.'' Despite its relatively short length, this album actually works as an addition to the evolving oeuvre of this band, and is just as intense a listening experience as some of its previous albums, especially when paired with the bootleg of the band performing acoustic versions of their songs. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Tokyo Journal; Not Samurai Kicks, but Jabs at Today's Politicians
description: With his shock of permed gray hair, his eloquence and a lady-killing look that seems to marry inner strength and outright seduction, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has transformed the political zeitgeist in Japan. Now, the changes are spilling over into prime-time television.

title: Firefighters Oppose a Plan to Record Their Memories of Sept. 11
description: In the days after the Sept. 11 attack, the Fire Department tried to gather its surviving firefighters to record an oral history of the day when more of their colleagues perished than any other. It was to be a kind of spoken monument of scarred memories, captured in individual voices, to immortalize an awful but seminal event.

title: Political Memo; Clouds Loom for New York, But Bloomberg Stays Sunny
description: The ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria, where the Citizens Union was holding its holiday dinner the other night, was rustling with the concerns heard all around New York these days. The city's fiscal situation seemed as perilous as anyone could remember. Washington was resisting pleas for help. New York's government was in transition, and the region was on high terrorist alert again.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: RUDY RAY MOORE: ''This Ain't No White Christmas'' (Emperor Norton). Under the name Dolemite, Rudy Ray Moore made a career of bawdy music and comedy albums, and he couldn't resist taking on the Christmas season. This brief album, an expanded version of his 1971 Christmas album, transfers his lewd slapstick to a sex-crazed Santa, among other insatiable characters. Dolemite stays so busy with raunch that he barely has a moment for blasphemy. JON PARELES

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: PHIL KLINE: ''Unsilent Night'' (Cantaloupe). More than 50 cassette tapes played through boomboxes, carried through Greenwich Village on a December night, add up to Phil Kline's gorgeous ''Unsilent Night.'' The tapes hold layered sounds of bells, voices and electronics, and as the boomboxes inevitably fall out of sync, acoustic phenomena make the tones shimmer and ripple while the music evolves with minimalistic leisure between chiming and interludes of quasi-liturgical singing, including alleluias. The recorded version can't recreate the spatial dispersion of the event, or the randomness of a New York night. Instead, it immerses a listener in suspended wonderment, as if time itself had paused within a string of jingling sleigh bells. As for the live version, the 10th annual ''Unsilent Night'' takes place on Dec. 15, beginning at the Washington Arch at 7 p.m. JON PARELES

title: Fatah and Hamas in Truce After Clashes Kill Militant
description: Yasir Arafat's Fatah faction and the extremist group Hamas appeared to have achieved a fragile truce Thursday, after clashes extended into the morning and left a young Hamas activist dead.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: HARUNA ISHOLA AND HIS APALA GROUP: ''Apala Messenger'' (IndigeDisc/PDSE). It's Nigerian, though quite different from the most familiar aural marks of the area to Westerners, Sunny Ade's juju or Fela Kuti's Afro-beat. In fact, it's just vocals and percussion, with talking-drum and thumb piano figured prominently; its arrangements are so beautifully rendered that you may find yourself imagining instruments that aren't there in the weave. Ishola, who died in 1983, was one of the most popular practitioners of apala, a deeply religious music that is as much Islamic as Yoruban; these recordings were made from 1968 to 1971. BEN RATLIFF

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''SAMBA SOUL '70!'' (Ziriguiboom/ Six Degrees). The music Brazilians called samba soul in the 1970's was more like samba funk as Brazil's already far-reaching rock went on to annex the horns, electric keyboards and scrubbing guitars of 1970's funk. In the 16 songs on this album, the results are nothing short of euphoric, as Carnaval revs up the sex machine and Superfly does the samba. Instrumentals take action-movie soundtracks on location to Rio, where the wah-wah meets the tambourine; songs mesh smooth Brazilian melody with pinpoint riffs. The package offers neither translations of the Portuguese lyrics nor much information on the performers, but the music is pure delight. JON PARELES

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Opposition Claims Victory
description: The opposition United National Party claimed victory over the People's Alliance coalition that has governed the country for the last seven years, but the final vote tally in the parliamentary election will not be announced until today at the earliest. After an election day marred by violence, officials imposed a nationwide curfew on Wednesday night that is scheduled to end this morning.

title: For the New Rat Pack, It's a Ring-a-Ding Thing
description: IT would be hard to make a movie worse than the first ''Ocean's Eleven,'' the 1960 Lewis Milestone film. Who remembers that it was the man responsible for the powerful, dogmatic antiwar film ''All Quiet on the Western Front'' who was being led around by the ring-a-ding leader of the Rat Pack, Frank Sinatra?

title: Was There a Historic Presidential Epiphany That Day?
description: ''Who's minding the store?'' Ronald Reagan joked to his top aides as they watched the president being wheeled into surgery, a bullet from the gun of a would-be assassin, John W. Hinckley Jr., lodged in his chest. The three men, James A. Baker III, Edwin Meese III and Michael K. Deaver, recall this remarkable bon mot in ''Bulletproof: Reagan After Hinckley,'' a gripping documentary about the attack, which occurred a mere 70 days into his first term.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''THE WORDS AND MUSIC OF WORLD WAR II'' (Rhino). Want to see how much (and how little) the United States has changed in 60 years? Just listen to the country's responses to World War II, in the form of presidential addresses, news reports and pop songs on this two-CD set, which ranges from the chilling to the humorous. Beginning with the attack on Pearl Harbor and President Franklin D. Roosevelt's announcement of war, the CD jumps back to the Munich Conference in 1938 and then plows through the London air raids, various radio propagandists (from Lord Haw-Haw to Tokyo Rose), the Yalta Conference and Hiroshima. Scattered in between are what might be called pop-aganda, with songs like ''Stalin Wasn't Stallin','' ''Der Fhrer's Face,'' ''You're a Sap, Mr. Jap'' and lyrics from a song that is probably no longer appropriate to bolster troop morale: ''Girls, don't refuse to kiss a soldier/For you know that he is fighting for your peace.'' NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: ''BACK TO LOVE 3,'' ''SERVE CHILLED 3,'' ''BASE IBIZA'' (Hed Kandi). When it comes to original packaging, meticulous song selection, artful sequencing and overall good taste, Mark Doyle's fantastic Hed Kandi compilations have stood among the best of their kind in dance music, particularly house and its offshoots. The latest CD in the excellent ''Back to Love'' series looks at a stylistically wide swath of classic club music, with Frankie Knuckles, A Guy Called Gerald, Raze, Soul II Soul and Arrested Development. ''Serve Chilled 3'' offers two CD's of entrancing down-tempo beats, usually accompanied by whispered diva vocals, sparse piano melodies and atmospheric electronic effects, all better suited to getting romantic on a couch at a club than getting jiggy on the dance floor (with Zimpala, Salt Tank, Ski Oakenfull, and Bebel Gilberto). ''Base Bar Ibiza,'' part of a new line of compilations from the label, pays tribute to the Ibiza bar of the same name, collecting some of the party destination's most popular anthems, remixes and flashbacks of 2001, featuring Danny Tenaglia remixing Depeche Mode, David Morales taking on Photek, and Ian Pooley versus himself. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 4th Manslaughter Count Against Ex-Officer
description: The former police officer accused of killing three people while driving intoxicated must also stand trial for the death of a baby delivered to one of the victims, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday. The officer, Joseph Gray, right, has pleaded not guilty to manslaughter charges stemming from the Aug. 4 deaths of three family members. Mr. Gray's lawyer, Harold Levy, asked Justice Anne G. Feldman to drop the fourth manslaughter count, saying the medical examiner's office had ruled that the baby had been stillborn. But Justice Feldman denied the motion, saying there was evidence that the baby had a heartbeat for several hours after delivery. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Harvard data showing that nearly half of all undergraduate grades in recent years have been A or A-minus omitted a reference to the news report that brought the situation to public notice. (The Lessons column the same day, about the issue of grade inflation, also omitted such a reference.) The university's acknowledgment followed a two-part report in The Boston Globe in October disclosing that 91 percent of Harvard graduates received honors in June, far more than at other elite universities.

title: Recent Events Recast Debate on Fuel Economy
description: Domestic automakers argued against changes to federal fuel economy standards at a Senate Commerce Committee hearing today, but the events of Sept. 11 appear to have recast the usual debate about automotive fuel economy into one about national security as well as environmental concerns.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Compilations, Live Albums And Reissues
description: TIM BUCKLEY: ''Morning Glory: The Tim Buckley Anthology'' (Elektra/Rhino); ''The Dream Belongs to Me: Rare and Unreleased Recordings 1968-1973'' (Manifesto). Throughout his brief, lambent career, Tim Buckley sang about a longing to lose himself: in music, in sensuality, in love. His supple, androgynous, sweetly pained voice floated through his songs like a passionate apparition. Before he died in 1975 at 28, he made nine albums, starting in folk-rock and meandering through jazz, blues, funk, soul and anything else that drew his restless ear. The two CD's of ''Morning Glory'' carefully compress his passage from poetic righteousness to howls of lust and sorrow, downplaying his abrasive final albums. ''The Dream Belongs to Me'' presents Buckley at his most introspective and volatile: experimenting with jazz backup in 1968 and working on incantatory songs in 1973, most of which would be contorted into would-be commercial arrangements on his last albums. It brings to light two previously unknown, richly obsessional songs. JON PARELES

title: Mail at Federal Reserve Tests Positive for Anthrax, but Cause Is Still Unclear
description: A batch of mail delivered to the Federal Reserve on Wednesday tested positive for anthrax today, the central bank said, raising further concern about cross-contamination among letters in the postal system or the possibility of new anthrax letters.

description: Beneath the stylized courtesies and careful political positioning, the nods to balance and bipartisanship, there was a rough struggle in the Senate Judiciary Committee today.

title: Bridging a Collegiate Gulf; Hugs and Pledges of Unity for Columbia and N.Y.U.
description: When Lee C. Bollinger, who is to be the next president of Columbia University, walked through the door of a private Manhattan club last week, John Sexton, the next president of New York University, was there to greet him. Mr. Sexton bounded over, knelt down and grabbed Mr. Bollinger's hand as a sign of respect. Then he gave Mr. Bollinger one of his trademark hugs. Mr. Bollinger, a more measured man, eyed his hugger warily, and then grinned. He was willing to be friends.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries; Christmas Albums
description: BARBRA STREISAND: ''Christmas Memories'' (Columbia). The sequel to Barbra Streisand's 1966 Christmas album is filled with lush orchestral strings, tremulous vocal lines and not a glimmer of whimsy or lightheartedness. Any of the songs, touting fond remembrances or high-minded wishes, could swell behind the final credits of a blockbuster romance. But together as an album, they sink under their pretentious sentimentality. JON PARELES

title: Indiana Factory Shooting Leaves 2 Dead and 6 Hurt
description: Hours after arguing with a co-worker, an angry employee opened fire at a small factory here this afternoon, killing one worker and wounding six others, one seriously, before committing suicide, the police said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Status Restored
description: The Federal Aviation Administration restored Korea to Category 1 in terms of air safety. The United States ambassador to Korea, Thomas Hubbard, informed the Construction and Transport Ministry of the upgrade, which was based on compliance with regulations on safety and training. As a result, Korean Air and Asiana will be able to expand routes to the United States, acquire aircraft and enter into code-sharing arrangements with other airlines. The ministry scrambled to raise standards after the rating was lowered in August. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Report Says Ulster Force Failed to Heed Tip Before Fatal Bombing
description: An investigation by a new Northern Ireland police watchdog has reportedly uncovered evidence that Royal Ulster Constabulary intelligence officers failed to pass along a tip about the bombing of Omagh that was given to them 11 days before the blast, which left 29 people dead and more than 200 injured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTONE, SIDNEY M., M.D.
description: SILVERSTONE-Sidney M., M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our distinguished friend and colleague. Dr. Silverstone served Mount Sinai for over sixty years as a clinician and teacher and has served humanity as a world renowned radiation oncologist. In 1984, the Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacob Medallion, to Dr. Silverstone in acknowledgement of his extraordinary contributions to the specialty of radiation oncology and his life long devotion to Mount Sinai and the Alumni. A caring and beloved physician, he will be missed. Our sincere condolences are extented to his entire family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., President William G. Stein, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secretary George Raptis, M.D., Treasurer

title: Editorial Observer; In Sizing Up Anthrax, Don't Trust Your Gut
description: If the anthrax crisis has taught us anything, it is that neither we -- nor the nation's supposed experts in disease and bioterrorism -- should trust our instincts or our presumed knowledge. That first became obvious as public health experts struggled to unravel the medical side of this unfolding mystery, only to find that much of what they thought they knew about the disease was probably not true. Now it looks as if bioterrorism experts may have been equally off base in their assumptions about who might have the skills, materials and motivation to carry out an anthrax attack through the mails.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Demand For Oil Shares
description: Shares of the Thai oil and natural gas company PTT rose 2.2 percent in their first day of trading on the Stock Exchange of Thailand. Thailand's government sold one-third of the company last month for 32.2 billion baht ($733 million), making rare progress in its plan to privatize public companies and fill a government budget deficit. Overseas investors demonstrated a surprising interest in the shares, which appeared to signal a newfound taste for emerging-market assets. Analysts said foreign funds continued to pour into Southeast Asia this week, but that investors had shifted their purchasing to technology stocks that could benefit from indications of a rebound in the semiconductor industry. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: European Hotel Discounts
description: Through March 31, 2002, Radisson SAS Hotels are cutting prices at 100 hotels in 25 countries under the Europe Advantage Program. At the Alcron Hotel in Prague, for example, rates are $137 (normally $256). At the Radisson SAS in Brussels, it's $183, down from $265; the Radisson Palais in Vienna is $140, regularly $246. These prices, which include breakfast for two, are subject to currency fluctuations and availability; call (800) 333-3333 and ask for the program, or visit www.radissonsas.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, DAVID
description: ROTHSTEIN-David, 54. On December 6, 2001, of Gunnison and Denver, Colorado, San Francisco, California and Baldwin, New York. A third generation New Yorker. Father of Shay Michelle, son of the late George and surviving Elaine. Former husband of Denny and Suzan. Brother of Michael and Babs, uncle of Mark and Lisa George. He leaves behind a legacy of the music that he shared with all of us, and some very sick humor. We're still laughing at his unprintables. As per his wishes, there will be no formal memorial service. His memory lives in the hearts of his family and many friends.

title: Holiday Forecast: Cool to Sultry, and a Chance of CD Flurries
description: GLOBAL warming has no effect on the blizzard of Christmas albums, which starts with preliminary flurries as early as August and September and blankets the market in October and November. Sooner or later, it seems, every musician is tempted to remake the seasonal staples, while a few more adventurous ones come up with new songs to address holiday feelings from coziness to desolation. At the same time, greatest-hits albums, quickie live recordings, reissues and compilations turn up to tempt holiday shoppers. Here, pop and jazz critics of The New York Times comment on this year's most notable holiday albums, along with a selection of hits, compilation and reissue albums. (Prices for the CD's range from $7.97 to $18.99.) JON PARELES

title: The Big City; Warming Up To the Notion Of Warming
description: IF you've been enjoying 72-degree weather in December, you may appreciate Robert O. Mendelsohn's new analysis of global warming. He, too, concludes that it's not such a bad deal for New York.

description: JOHN COLTRANE: ''Coltrane for Lovers'' (Impulse/Universal). You know Coltrane the missionary, spitting fire, brimstone and religious conviction; Coltrane the uniquely sensuous saxophone-ballad player, influenced by his onetime boss Johnny Hodges, has perhaps been undervalued. This collection, including tracks from his albums with Johnny Hartman and Duke Ellington, and his benchmark recordings of Mal Waldron's ''Soul Eyes'' and his own ''After the Rain,'' presents all the argument you need. BEN RATLIFF

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Harvard data showing that nearly half of all undergraduate grades in recent years have been A or A-minus omitted a reference to the news report that brought the situation to public notice. (The Lessons column the same day, about the issue of grade inflation, also omitted such a reference.) The university's acknowledgment followed a two-part report in The Boston Globe in October disclosing that 91 percent of Harvard graduates received honors in June, far more than at other elite universities.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  In forceful and unyielding testimony, Attorney General John Ashcroft today defended the administration's array of antiterrorism proposals and accused some of the program's critics of aiding terrorists by providing "ammunition to America's enemies."

title: He May Be Institutionalized, But His Delusions Seem Real
description: Campbell Scott's ''Final,'' which opens today at the Screening Room, is not an easy movie to characterize, and it is difficult to discuss without giving away the surprise that pops up halfway through, just when you thought you had figured out what was going on. Until that point, the movie is a vaguely Pinteresque dialogue between a psychiatrist and her moody, delusional patient, interrupted by flashbacks of the patient's earlier life. But then, just as the splinters of his shattered personality begin to yield a coherent picture of who he was, the boundary between delusion and reality shifts, and the movie ventures from the familiar terrain of doctor-patient psychodrama into hazy sci-fi allegory and ethical problem play.

title: When a Wounded President Was Closer to Death Than People Knew
description: Running alongside the gurney that is taking her husband to surgery, Nancy Reagan leans over as she clutches a jar of his favorite candy. ''I brought your jelly beans, darling,'' she says. Every action in the simplistic film ''The Day Reagan Was Shot'' is so clumsily telegraphed that even the jelly beans eventually get their close-up. As the fictional Nancy waits for word from the operating room, she sits alone and watches the career-shattering news conference in which Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. announces in a voice so quavering it could only inspire fear, ''I am in control, here at the White House.'' She is so appalled she literally spills the beans, and the camera focuses on brightly colored candies scattering on the floor around her black pumps.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Economy Minister To Visit U.S.
description: As the government seized $3.5 billion in pension funds in another desperate attempt to avert bankruptcy, Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo pleaded for calm and said he would he would travel to the United States in an effort to work out an arrangement with the International Monetary Fund to free up $1.3 billion that was frozen this week after Argentina missed the fund's budget-deficit targets by a wide margin. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: The High Cost of Collusion
description: On Wednesday, the jury in a Manhattan federal district courtroom convicted A. Alfred Taubman, the former head of the international auction house Sotheby's, for his part in a price-fixing scheme with his counterpart, Sir Anthony Tennant, at Christie's. In a handwritten memo, Sir Anthony, who lives in England and cannot be extradited, found a graceful, self-forgiving, but ultimately arrogant phrase for price-fixing. He called it ''intervening from on high.'' There was incontrovertible evidence that Mr. Taubman and Sir Anthony had met repeatedly to plan such interventions.

title: U.S. Is Voicing Confidence In a Kabul Administration
description: The senior American diplomats for Afghanistan said today that despite grumbling from some members of the Northern Alliance, they were confident that the interim Afghan government patched together in Bonn would succeed.

title: Manhattan Prosecutor Criticizes Caymans Tax Pact
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, is critical of the agreement that Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill signed last week with the Cayman Islands to share information that would help the United States track down suspected income tax evaders, calling it ''a sham.''

title: 1950's Work, 1700's Style, 21st-Century Flourishes
description: Like its makers, ''The Rake's Progress'' has no permanent home. But in celebration of its 50th anniversary, this paean by Stravinsky to the Classical era has returned to the birthplace of its principal librettist, W. H. Auden, and to the source of its inspiration.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Limits On Crabbing
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening announced restrictions on crabbing in an effort to bolster the Chesapeake Bay blue crab population. The restrictions retain a shorter workday imposed last summer, reduce the number of smaller crabs that watermen can keep and outlaw possession of crabs with visible roe. The restrictions, which take effect April 1, come after one of the state's worst crab seasons in years. To help ease the burden on watermen, whose hours have been cut to 8 from 14 a day, next year's crab season will be lengthened by two weeks.

title: Republicans Break Off Talks On Measures to Spur Economy
description: House Republicans broke off bipartisan negotiations on an economic recovery package today, reducing the chances that Congress and the Bush administration will reach a deal this year, even as the latest statistics showed a surge in unemployment.

title: Devils Turning Around After Forgettable November
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 7 — Coach Larry Robinson was trying to find ways for Jason Arnott to produce more during a dreadful November. Arnott, the center on the Devils' premier line, scored just two goals in 14 games last month, which included a streak of just one victory in 10 games for the Devils. Robinson went as far as to split the line of Arnott, Patrik Elias and Petr Sykora.

description: It's no longer just politically incorrect to criticize George W. Bush or anyone in his administration these days -- now it's treason.

description: A few years ago, Bobby Valentine tried to be a broadcaster. The reviews were not kind. One critic said he spent the whole broadcast wondering which muppet Valentine sounded most like.

title: Isolated Figures and Frolicking Duos
description: Better dances have been done by Dwight Rhoden and Judith Jamison than the ones presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Thursday night at City Center. The audience cheered after Mr. Rhoden's ''Chocolate Sessions'' and Ms. Jamison's ''Double Exposure,'' but the chief pleasure of the two works was the chance they offered to savor the dynamic Ailey dancers.

title: European Critics of U.S. Find That the War Gives Them Little Ammunition
description: European criticism of the United States and the war in Afghanistan has quieted rather suddenly, in part because the Taliban have been overthrown so much more quickly than anyone expected.

title: Conference on Biological Weapons Breaks Down Over Divisions
description: The anthrax attacks in the United States focused international attention on germ weapons, but the countries meeting here to strengthen the global pact banning those weapons were so divided on how to proceed that today they suspended the gathering for a year rather than allow their effort to collapse.

title: Thelma Cuccinello: `Nuts at Christmas'
description: Christmas was Thelma Cuccinello's favorite holiday, a time when she could deck her house in Wilmot, N.H., with all the ornaments and decorations she had made over the years. And not just her house. Her eldest daughter, Cheryl O'Brien, who lives in Bedford, Mass., recently opened a box of Christmas wreaths, only to realize that every one had been made by her mother. "She made the skirt for our Christmas tree, the decoration for our mantlepiece," Mrs. O'Brien said. "She and Dad would go nuts at Christmas."

title: In Middletown, A Strike Ends Without a Deal For Teachers
description: A bitter, weeklong strike by the teachers' union in Middletown ended abruptly this morning as teachers agreed to honor a court back-to-work order and return to their classrooms on Monday morning without a new contract.

title: U.S. Trade Panel Backs Putting Hefty Duties on Imported Steel
description: A federal trade panel recommended hefty duties on steel imports today, clearing the way for President Bush to protect troubled domestic steel companies but almost certainly raising the price of cars, appliances and other steel products.

title: A Lackluster Practice Infuriates Van Gundy
description: The Knicks had been practicing in lackluster fashion for a little more than an hour when Coach Jeff Van Gundy decided that he had tortured himself enough.

title: Sentiment Could Sway Heisman
description: Numbers, leadership and highlight-reel moments. Those are the criteria that voters focus on to select a Heisman Trophy winner. Each of the more than 900 members of the news media and former Heisman Trophy winners who cast ballots weighs them differently. Many try to battle regional biases or sentiment. This year, unfortunately, it looks as if they won't be successful.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REMSON, AL D.
description: REMSON-Al D. Always remembered. Always loved.

title: Yanks Got the Better Of This Transaction
description: Brian Cashman started inquiring about Robin Ventura last summer, trying to cajole Steve Phillips into trading the vanishing third baseman. While the general managers of the Yankees and the Mets are cordial, they had never collaborated on a deal. The conversations were delicate. Why make a trade with your keenest competitor? The job is onerous enough without being judged on a decision directly involving the team that operates eight miles away.

title: Seydou Keta Dies; Photographed Common Man of Mali
description: Seydou Keta, whose sure grasp of photographic portraiture and sophisticated understanding of strong graphics in African textiles turned him from a little-known studio artist in Mali to a formidable figure in photography, died on Nov. 21 in Paris. He lived in Bamako, the capital of Mali, and did not know his birth date, but said in a 1997 interview that it was ''around 1921.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Broadcaster Reduces Forecast
description: The RTL Group, a large European television broadcaster that is controlled by Bertelsmann of Germany, reduced its full-year profit forecast, and said it did not expect to see a turnaround in advertising in the next six months. Earnings before interest, taxes and amortization could fall as much as 40 percent in 2001, or more than the 15 percent drop in profits initially projected, the company said. RTL shares traded in Frankfurt rose 1.25 percent, or 50 euro cents, to 40.50 euros. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFANE, LYDIA
description: SAFANE-Lydia. On December 6, 2001, of Cliffside Park, NJ. Formerly of Elmont, NY. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Clifford Safane. Loving grandmother of Aaron, Nina and Jake. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ, on Sunday 12:30 PM.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JOHNSON & JOHNSON, New Brunswick, N.J., the health care and consumer products maker, agreed to work with Caprion Pharmaceuticals Inc., Montreal, to develop the first test for variant Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease, the human form of mad-cow disease, with Johnson & Johnson getting exclusive global marketing and distribution rights if a test is developed. Terms were not disclosed.

description: CAN two Norman Minetas fetch a Colin Powell? Does a mint-condition Rumsfeld rate as high as a dog-eared Giuliani? And is Ashcroft-for-Pataki really an even trade? Schoolyard swapmeets will need to sort out such questions as they absorb Enduring Freedom picture cards, the latest offering from Topps, a trading card company more commonly associated with R.B.I.s and E.R.A.s than with MC-130H refueling aircraft  or so you might think.

title: Keith Glascoe: Big Man, Big Heart
description: Keith Glascoe was a big man  roughly 6-foot-4, 270 pounds  but maybe the biggest thing about him was his heart. "He was the sort who would stop and pick up a hurt animal in the street, take it to a doctor and pay for it," said his father, Benjamin Glascoe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTER, BOBBY
description: MINTER-Bobby. On December 6, Bobby Minter, loving spouse to Maggi Landau, and adoring father to Sarah and Casey, died from gastric cancer. He was 48. Caring son to Evelyn and Robert Minter and loving big brother to George, Bill and Sue Minter. Fantastic uncle to Thomas, Hannah, Ariel, Jake, Emma, Sophia and Jasper. He is forever cherished by his family and by the strong community of friends who shared his life. Services on Sunday, December 9, 4PM Greenville Community Reform Church, 270 Ardsley Road, Scarsdale, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Bobby Minter may be sent to: The Nature Conservancy of NY, 570 7th Avenue, Suite 601, New York, New York 10018.

title: Morgan Stanley Says Firing in Sex-Bias Case Was for Misconduct
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has fired back in court at a former bond saleswoman whose sex-discrimination complaint prompted the federal government to sue the firm three months ago.

title: Taliban Leader at Large, American Combat and 2 Dates Joined in Infamy
description: The Taliban's seven-year reign of killing and repression in the name of Islam appeared to be over in Afghanistan. After two months of American bombing and ground assaults by a coalition of opposition forces, the Afghan militia was reported to have abandoned its spiritual home and final stronghold at Kandahar. Some of the defenders fled with their guns, others surrendered. But the elusive Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, had somehow disappeared.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Rights Official Criticizes U.S. Tribunal Plan
description: The United Nations human rights commissioner, Mary Robinson, criticized the Bush administration plan to set up military tribunals for terrorist suspects, saying they skirt democratic guarantees. These safeguards, including right to a fair trial, must be upheld even in crises, she said, adding that it was ''not enough to say trust me as a government.'' She said that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were crimes against humanity meriting special measures but said that the plan for secret trials was so overly broad and vaguely worded that it threatened fundamental rights. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

It is in the Mediterranean, not the Aegean.

title: Veteran Cowboys Are Key
description: In many ways, the Dallas Cowboys, who will play host to the Giants on Sunday, are new, and their erratic play shows that. In two ways -- Emmitt Smith and Larry Allen -- they are the same old tough Cowboys, and that concerns the defense of the Giants (5-6).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, JOHN
description: ROBERTS-John. A memorial service will be held for John Roberts on Tuesday, December 11, 2:30 PM at Rodeph Sholom Congregation, 7 West 83rd Street, NYC.
