description: James Van de Velde, the only person the police here publicly identified as a suspect in the three-year-old unsolved murder of a Yale University student, filed a lawsuit against the police.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Funny New Yorker Map Is Again the Best Defense
description: A quarter century ago, on March 29, 1976, a simple, pastel map of New York City appeared on the cover of The New Yorker. Drawn from the perspective of a low-flying bird looking west from Ninth Avenue, you could see the world receding from the city: the Hudson River, New Jersey, Kansas City, then the Pacific Ocean and Japan. It was Saul Steinberg's famous ''View of the World from Ninth Avenue,'' a drawing reproduced and imitated countless times. Every city wanted a version of its own. Steinberg once said that if he had gotten the proper royalties, ''I could have retired on this painting.''

title: Liberty, Security and John Ashcroft's Message
description: To the Editor:

title: The Afghans Need America, and They Know It
description: For peace and a just government to take hold, Afghanistan needs a triumph of unflinching American reason. Stability and development in this nation, the crossroads of Asia, require recognition of two stark realities. First, power in Afghanistan now comes from control of the main border crossings and major roads. With little other infrastructure left -- forms of communication like telephones and the press are largely nonexistent -- roads are the primary conduits not only of goods and people, but of information as well. Second, peace in Afghanistan must be brought to Kabul's door. It will never spread into the countryside from an arbitrary apportionment of power from the capital.

title: Liberty, Security and John Ashcroft's Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Factory Feud Is Cited In Shooting In Indiana
description: The factory worker who killed a co-owner of the factory and wounded six others before fatally shooting himself was apparently angered over a dispute he had had with a male co-worker over a woman who also worked at the factory, the authorities said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHEN, ROBERT S.
description: KIRSCHEN-Robert S. December 7, 2001 at age 53. Musician, music director and writer. Beloved husband of Norma and loving father of David. Devoted son of Mary and the late Max Kirschen. Dear brother of Edna Lieberman and Yaakov Kirschen. Good friend to many. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, 3:30 PM.

title: Volunteers and Tigers Reach the Crossroads
description: The Southeastern Conference championship game on Saturday will be the 10th in conference history, which is not a long time for a recent innovation in the old sport of college football. When Louisiana State plays Tennessee here in the Georgia Dome, it will be the first appearance in the SEC playoff for the Tigers, who finished their regular season at 8-3 and their conference schedule at 5-3.

title: Cave Warfare Demands Patience
description: The fall of Kandahar heralds the end of the radical Islamist regime in Afghanistan. But the war on terrorism is far from over: Thousands of Qaeda militants are holed up in remote caves, and fighting these suicidal extremists remains a major challenge.

title: Megan's Law Requirement Struck Down By U.S. Judge
description: A federal judge has barred New Jersey from posting the addresses of sex offenders on its Internet registry, which was approved by the state's voters and is scheduled to begin Jan. 1.

title: Jurassic Lark: Creatures Great, Small and Extinct
description: If you are a paleogeek, tomorrow is your lucky day. You may, however, need to master the ''record one program while watching another'' feature of your VCR to take full advantage of it.

title: Yankees Got Better of Deal
description: Brian Cashman started inquiring about Robin Ventura last summer, trying to cajole Steve Phillips into trading the vanishing third baseman. While the general managers of the Yankees and the Mets are cordial, they had never collaborated on a deal. The conversations were delicate. Why make a trade with your keenest competitor? The job is onerous enough without being judged on a decision directly involving the team that operates eight miles away.

title: Currency-Trading Executive Pleads Guilty
description: An executive at a currency trading firm that had its headquarters in the World Trade Center and was accused of defrauding clients out of $110 million pleaded guilty yesterday to money laundering and agreed to forfeit $5.1 million.

title: Lay Teachers Continue Strike At High Schools
description: Lay teachers at nine Roman Catholic high schools run by the Archdiocese of New York struck for a seventh day yesterday, making their job action the longest staged by their union in 25 years.

title: Bloomberg Choices for Top Aides Set Inclusive Tone for Mayoralty
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg named three deputy mayors yesterday to his administration, a power triumvirate formed by a longtime close aide and two men hardly known to the mayor-elect.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL UP 2.9%. Crude oil prices rose on speculation that producers might reach an agreement this weekend to reduce output. In New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 52 cents, to $19.06 a barrel.

title: 7 in Brazil Are Charged With Murder Of Yachtsman
description: Seven men, described as small-time criminals, were arrested today and charged with the murder of Sir Peter Blake, the world champion yachtsman who was shot here Wednesday night while returning from an expedition to explore the remotest reaches of the Amazon.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Not Happy With U.S. Congress
description: The government assailed the United States Congress for passing the Zimbabwe Democracy and Economic Recovery Act, which urges President Bush to deny visas and freeze the assets of those ''responsible for violence and the breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe.'' Officials said that the bill, which has not yet been signed into law by President Bush, was intended to stop the government from redistributing land from the white minority to the black majority. White farmers own more than half of the fertile land in the country. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Jets Working to Erase Their December Demons
description: Because it is December, an understandable, though selective, memory overtakes many Jets fans as the team pursues playoff dreams.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY: THE YEAR IN IDEAS
description: Acquired Celebrity Narcissism? Personalized breakfast cereal? Hybrid cars? The return to segregation? In a special issue, The Times Magazine compiles an encyclopedia of notions, sometimes great, sometimes not, that shook the world in 2001. Or jiggled it.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Name For The Royal Baby
description: In an elaborate traditional ceremony with string music and ancient chants, the newest member of Japan's imperial family was given the name Aiko. The princess, born on Dec. 1, is the first child for Crown Princess Masako and Crown Prince Naruhito, who wed nearly nine years ago. The name, which stems from the teachings of the Chinese philosopher Mencius, is formed by the characters for ''love'' and ''child.'' In a break with past practice the name was chosen by the parents, not the emperor. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Mets and Yankees Find a Common Solution
description: Trades between the Yankees and the Mets are as rare as passing comets, but with both teams looking to shed high-salaried veterans, the Mets swapped third baseman Robin Ventura to the Yankees yesterday for outfielder David Justice. It was only the 11th player transaction between the teams in 40 years and by far the most significant.

title: Canceled Bout Sets Up Tyson-Lewis Title Fight
description: Mike Tyson said yesterday that he was canceling a Jan. 19 bout against Ray Mercer to fight Lennox Lewis in the spring for two heavyweight titles. The announcement came days after Lewis sued to try to prevent Tyson from fighting Mercer and possibly delaying a Lewis-Tyson bout.

title: Fed Building Is Untainted By Anthrax
description: Federal authorities said today that they had found no evidence of anthrax contamination at the Federal Reserve's headquarters, a day after Fed officials said that a batch of mail sent to the agency had tested positive for anthrax.

title: BANK OF AMERICA WILL SELL A SUBPRIME LOAN UNIT
description: Bank of America has agreed to sell its subprime real estate servicing operations to the Fairbanks Capital Corporation. Terms of the deal were not announced. Subprime loans are made at high interest rates to borrowers with bad or no credit history. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the year. The bank announced plans in mid-August to take a $1.25 billion third-quarter charge to get out of the businesses of auto leasing and lending to people who cannot qualify for standard loans. Bank of America has about $21 billion of its $26.3 billion subprime loan portfolio left to liquidate, a spokeswoman, Eloise Hale, said.

title: Liberty, Security and John Ashcroft's Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Networks Shared $80,000 Cost of Tape of C.I.A. Men Quizzing Captured Californian
description: Remarkably, an Afghan cameraman videotaped the C.I.A. officer Johnny Michael Spann as he tried to interrogate the young American Taliban fighter, John Walker, in a prison in Mazar-i-Sharif. Shortly afterward, Mr. Spann was killed in the prison uprising, and Mr. Walker, now being detained by American forces in Afghanistan, was shot in the leg.

title: Board Backs Nassau Plan For 9 Percent Tax Increase
description: The fighting continued right up to the end, but a protracted struggle to enact Nassau County's 2002 budget concluded today as a state oversight board approved the final changes made by County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUSTER, JOAN
description: SHUSTER-Joan. It is with profound sadness that we say goodbye to Joan. Loving wife, mother, nanny, daughter, sister, aunt and friend. Funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday, December 9 at 11:45 AM. All contributions should be made to Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care of Southwestern CT, 1029 East Main St., Stamford, CT 06902. In typical Joan style, she fought hard till the end. We will miss her dearly every day.

title: U.S. Rights Commission Blocks Seating of Bush Nominee
description: The White House was outmaneuvered today by Democratic-leaning members of the United States Civil Rights Commission, who barred President Bush's newest nominee to the commission from being seated and prevented him from voting.

title: Infant Girl Is Scalded
description: A 5-month-old girl was treated for second-degree burns last night after being scalded by a cup of boiling water that her mother threw at her boyfriend during an argument, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LILLIAN Y.
description: KAPLAN-Lillian Y., 94. Devoted wife of Abraham, mother of Rhoda and Hazel, grandmother of Michael, Marcy, Dana, Alexandra and Jonathan, and great-grandmother to Sara, Andrew and Jamie, passed away on December 2, 2001. She graduated from Barnard College with honors, received her Master's degree in Education at Teachers College and her Ph.D. in Guidance from Queens College. Lillian devoted her life to the education of minorities. Graveside service Monday, December 10th at 1pm at Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY.

title: Three Bad Calls In the Election? Not a Problem For Union Chief
description: Randi Weingarten, the hard-charging president of New York City's teachers' union, gambled mightily when she endorsed Alan G. Hevesi in the Democratic mayoral primary this summer, and sure enough, Mr. Hevesi placed dead last.

title: Keithroy Maynard: A Role Model by Choice
description: Keithroy Maynard was black. He was also a firefighter. Those two things meant everything to him, said his twin brother, Kevin.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Growth Forecast Of 3.9%
description: The Bank of Korea has forecast economic growth of 3.9 percent next year, citing consumer consumption and the recovery of the construction industry. The forecast followed a forecast of 2.8 percent growth this year and contributed to an optimistic mood among investors. The Korea Stock Exchange price index broke the 700 mark, rising 17.89 points to close the week at 704.50, its highest level since Aug. 30 of last year. The rise reflected improving export markets overseas as well as an increase in share prices of steel manufacturers, led by Pohang Iron and Steel, up 5.8 percent, in anticipation of a decline in American production. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD IS DEALT A BLOW ON COMPAQ DEAL
description: The family foundation that is Hewlett-Packard's largest shareholder dealt a severe blow today to the company's plan to buy Compaq Computer, declaring its intention to vote against the merger, the largest in computing history.

title: Patriotism and Academe
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 3,290 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Ridge's Terror Alert
description: To the Editor:

title: AOL's Future Chief to Bring Washington Connections
description: Richard D. Parsons, the newly designated AOL Time Warner chief executive, has forged a reputation for being a politically gifted and gracefully diplomatic corporate advocate with exceptional Republican contacts.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Collapse of the Taliban

title: David B. Brady: A Soccer Dad
description: At 41, David B. Brady had the trappings of success: an office on the 39th floor of the World Financial Center, where he was a first vice president at Merill Lynch , and a home in Summit, N.J.

title: Aaron Jacobs: Well-Traveled at 27
description: Aaron Jacobs wanted to retire at an early age and travel. He had already backpacked through Europe, taught English in Cozumel, Mexico, spent a semester in Madrid, climbed a volcano in Greece and vacationed with his family in Central America and the Caribbean.

title: In Letter, 300 Law Professors Oppose Tribunals Plan
description: More than 300 law professors from around the country are protesting President Bush's order to establish military tribunals for foreign terrorist suspects.

title: NASA Nominee Says He Has a Mandate to Reorder Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Sean O'Keefe, President Bush's nominee to head NASA, said today that the space agency should work more closely with the Defense Department and other agencies to reduce expenses and redundancy.

title: E*TRADE LIFTS ITS OUTLOOK FOR EARNINGS NEXT YEAR
description: The E*Trade Group, the Internet brokerage firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., has raised the bottom end of its 2002 profit forecast and said it would buy $146 million of stock from the Softbank Corporation, its biggest shareholder. E*Trade shares rose 66 cents, to $10.46, and have more than doubled since bottoming Sept. 21. E*Trade said it would earn 40 cents to 50 cents a share in 2002, up from its previous forecast of 35 cents to 49 cents. The revised forecast results from a lower number of outstanding shares, improved trading business and the effects of the company's efforts to cut expenses, analysts said. E*Trade said it would buy 20 million shares of its common stock from Softbank of Japan. The company will pay $7.28 a share.

title: The Taliban Exits
description: Wars in Afghanistan don't begin and end with clockwork precision, but the American-led campaign to overthrow the Taliban has succeeded. Though skirmishes may continue in the days ahead, Afghanistan's people can now look forward to a new and more hopeful era.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday was published in error. It showed Wendy White singing the role of Suzuki in ''Madama Butterfly'' at the Metropolitan Opera, not Catherine Malfitano in the role of Cio-Cio San, which she sang last night.

title: A Piece of Silverware Is Missing at Rowan
description: The office of K. C. Keeler, head coach of the Rowan University football team, is full of silverware. Three New Jersey Athletic Conference Coach of the Year awards, four conference title trophies and five plaques for participating in the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl, the national championship game for Division III.

title: Conference Panel Reaches Accord on Education Bill
description: After months of behind-the-scenes negotiations, a House and Senate conference committee has tentatively agreed on a bill that gives federal authorities an unprecedent role in requiring schools to ensure a minimum level of education for all students.

title: Bridget Jones Is Suddenly Spanish
description: From Spain, the romantic comedy-drama ''I Will Survive'' is a sort of Iberian ''Bridget Jones's Diary,'' complete with a self-mocking first person narration and a pixie-cute heroine, Marga (Emma Surez), whose blue eyes and bubbling personality irresistibly evoke Rene Zellweger as Bridget Jones.

title: Michael Clarke: Born for a Firetruck
description: Jack Clarke may have been a New York City police officer, but from the very beginning his youngest son, Michael, had this affinity for firefighting.

title: Charles Schwab Will Close Its Online Venture in Japan
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the American discount brokerage concern, said today that it would shut its online-trading joint venture in Tokyo in February.

title: Iran Intensifies Crackdown on Opposition
description: Muhammad Tavassoli would hardly seem a serious threat to Iran's Islamic government. He is a 63-year-old civil engineer who opposed the shah and served as mayor of Tehran after the 1979 Islamic revolution. He is religious, and supports the Constitution, which mandates a leadership role for the country's clerics.

title: U.S. Captain Reyna Joins Sunderland
description: The United States national team captain, Claudio Reyna, moved to the English Premier League yesterday, joining Sunderland in a $5.68 million transfer from the Scottish power Glasgow Rangers.

title: Covering a War, Rooting for the Yanks
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a shooting in a factory in Goshen, Ind., misstated the time SWAT teams entered the building. It was 4:30 p.m., not 3:30.

title: Eric B. Evans: A Gardener With Standards
description: He was gorgeous. That much everybody agreed on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASS, LOPEZ, EDITA
description: MASS-LOPEZ-Edita. On December 7, dear sister of Pilar, beloved aunt of Julio, Fernando, and Madeline. Former professor of Queens College. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke, 352 E. 87th St, NYC Sun. 2-5 PM, 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph RC Church, Monday 11 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Ascension, Monsey, New York.

title: A New Boom: Somewhere Over the Rainbow?; The Economic Evidence Is So Dismal, Yet the Forecasts Are So Hopeful
description: The economy sinks, but the nation's forecasters grow more optimistic. A vibrant upturn is just around the corner, they insist, certain to arrive by spring. In the world of forecasting, the upturn has been just around the corner for months.

title: Milbury Feels Need for Islanders to Take Charge
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 7 — General Manager Mike Milbury likes these Islanders so much that he thinks they are capable of much more. Milbury sometimes growls at them under his breath from the press box, like a dad at a Little League game.

title: Edward Keane: Too Restless to Retire
description: More than three years ago, Edward Keane retired. He had had a long and satisfying career as a mechanical engineer, and it made sense. He was 62.

title: Indian Point Faces Scrutiny After Some Crews Fail Tests
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it would immediately increase scrutiny of the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor because four control room crews had failed to pass their annual requalification tests, signaling ''substantial'' safety concerns.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Resignation At Weapons Lab
description: Dr. C. Bruce Tarter announced that he would step down as director of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, one of the nation's three major weapons laboratories. During a seven-year tenure, Dr. Tarter presided over a major expansion of civilian research at Livermore, but also numerous disputes, including delays and overruns in a $4 billion laser project and complaints of racial and sex discrimination by employees. Saying the laser project was ''aggressively back on track,'' Dr. Tarter added that he had moved to deal with employee concerns. James Glanz (NYT)

title: Peter G. Wallace: Opa's Second Chance
description: Peter G. Wallace believed that being a grandparent was a better deal than being a parent  all of the love and almost none of the work.

title: Abroad at Home; Hope Against Hope
description: The Hamas suicide bombings in Jerusalem last weekend were terrorism at its bloody worst, killing 25 innocent civilians. A military response by Israel was inevitable, and it came: air attacks on Palestinian police stations and on the headquarters of Yasir Arafat, pressuring him to arrest terrorists.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Reaches 7.5%
description: The unemployment rate in Canada rose to 7.5 percent in November, its highest level since mid-1999, with large losses in computer and electronics manufacturing and in the transportation sector offsetting gains in retailing, Statistics Canada said. Unemployment was 7.3 percent in October. For the second consecutive month, part-time jobs rose significantly even as full-time employment dropped. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: The B-52's Psychological Punch: The Enemy Knows You're Serious
description: At Davis-Mothan Air Force Base in the Arizona desert, a five-ton steel blade hangs high in the air, suspended from a crane. Suddenly the blade drops like a guillotine and slices through the fuselage of a B-52 bomber. The process is then repeated.

title: A Firefighter With Credits, A Man With Wanderlust And a Barbie Doll Collector
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Liberty, Security and John Ashcroft's Message
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Sale Raises $4.46 Billion
description: Shares in the indebted Dutch telephone company Royal KPN rose by more than 10 percent after the company raised 5 billion euros, about $4.46 billion, in an emergency sale of equity. Like other European phone operators, Royal ran up huge debts, almost $20 billion, by buying high-speed wireless licenses and rushing to expand. The share sale included 1.7 billion euros worth of stock to the Dutch government, which maintained a 34.7 percent stake, and 1.3 billion euros to existing investors. Shares rose by as much as 58 euro cents, to 5.69 euros. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Kwan's Ex-Coach Finds a New Skater
description: In the days after Michelle Kwan fired her longtime coach, Frank Carroll, in October, she left the door open for a reunion if her plan to prepare for the Olympics on her own fell apart.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen sank in response to a report that confirmed a recession in Japan and on concern that Japan will take steps to weaken its currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.62 yen, up from 124.75 on Thursday.

title: Shanghai Stunned: Mayor Quits for Academia
description: The popular mayor of this increasingly glittering city resigned suddenly today to take up an academic post in Beijing, a seeming demotion that stunned Shanghai residents and foreign business executives.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Budget Reserve In Danger
description: Unless oil prices rise sharply, the state's $2.4 billion in savings will run dry in July 2004, economists said. After two years of high prices, oil leveled off this year at $18 a barrel, widening a fiscal gap that will require the state to draw 40 percent, or about $1 billion, of the annual budget from its budget reserve fund. The state has no sales or income tax, so about 80 percent of its general fund comes from oil and gas revenue, and production has been declining at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska's largest source of oil. Since 1991, the state has had to dip into its reserves all but two years. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Israel Attacks Again in Gaza; Arafat Condemns U.S.
description: Israeli and Palestinian security officials met today for talks, but as the negotiating standoff continued, Israeli warplanes flattened two police buildings in Gaza City to press Yasir Arafat to act more firmly against Palestinian militants, and militants rallied here to warn him to do no such thing.

title: Housing Gains In Poor Areas, Study Shows
description: A new study shows that people in the 10 poorest neighborhoods in New York City gained economic ground even faster, by some measures, than those in the city's wealthiest neighborhoods in the second half of the 1990's.

title: Yes, It's Been Warm. And Why? Well . . .
description: The warm spell that kept New Yorkers in shirt sleeves (until today) and gave the United States its second-warmest November and the planet its warmest October on record was caused by -- well, climate scientists cannot quite agree.

title: Defendant's Tattoos Are Cited In Mexican Laborers' Case
description: A Suffolk County prosecutor flashing photographs of white-supremacist tattoos found on Ryan D. Wagner when he was arrested last year on charges of helping a friend try to murder two Mexican laborers -- today challenged Mr. Wagner's assertions that the attack was not racially motivated.

title: STORYBOOK SEASONS ON THE LINE
description: Another chapter in the storybook seasons of St. John's and Fairleigh Dickinson will unfold today in the quarterfinals of the Division I men's soccer tournament. St. John's will face undefeated Southern Methodist in Dallas tonight, after Fairleigh Dickinson plays at North Carolina this afternoon.

title: Experiments In Charity, In Groupings And in Music
description: After the highly publicized rock and classical music concerts to benefit Sept. 11 relief organizations, jazz was starting to seem deliquent. It finally came up with ''Made in America,'' a show at Town Hall on Wednesday night to benefit the Robin Hood Foundation, which helps poor New Yorkers.

title: Reclamation Effort by Isles Starts Too Late to Matter
description: Oleg Kvasha scored on a fierce wrist shot, then Brad Isbister banged in a rebound two and a half minutes later, and suddenly, what had been disintegrating into a rare lopsided loss for the Islanders somehow became salvageable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRADES, GUS.
description: CONRADES-Gus. The staff of Goodman Media International mourns the loss of our dear friend and former client, Gus Conrades. We will always remember his tremendous energy, enthusiasm and love for life. Tom Goodman President and CEO

title: Gayle Greene: Two Trips a Year
description: This year, for the first time, the Christmas lights outside Gayle Greene's town house in Montville, N.J., are red, white and blue.

title: Christopher R. Zarba: A Curious Mind
description: Christopher R. Zarba Jr. was just a baby when the Boston Pops performed a piece composed by his father, "Palm Sunday," in 1954. The younger Mr. Zarba inherited his family's musical genes, and grew up to be a talented pianist and French horn player who performed with local symphonies in his free time. He even married a fellow horn player, Sheila Kiernan.

title: CNN Will Cancel 3 Shows and Cut 30 Jobs
description: The Cable News Network said today that it was canceling three shows and cutting about 30 jobs.

title: In a Reversal, Army Permits Pilot's Burial
description: The secretary of the Army reversed course today, granting full burial rights at Arlington National Cemetery for Charles F. Burlingame, who served 25 years in the Navy and was the captain of American Airlines Flight 77 when it crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11.

title: Cave Warfare Demands Patience
description: WASHINGTON

title: TALIBAN ABANDON LAST STRONGHOLD; OMAR IS NOT FOUND
description: Two months after the American bombardment of Afghanistan began, Taliban forces today abandoned their last stronghold in Kandahar.

title: Alan D. Kleinberg: Planning a Park, and Legacy
description: On Sept. 10, Alan D. Kleinberg spent the evening at the East Brunswick Township Council, where he lobbied to move forward with a community skate park, a nod to his oldest son's affection for in-line skating. On the hot-button issue, known to provoke emotions, he was respected as a negotiator and mediator who helped gain acceptance for the idea.

title: Murder Arraignments for Two Accused in Brooklyn Shooting
description: Two men accused by the police of being the getaway driver and a gunman in a series of shootings in Brooklyn that killed two men and wounded two others, were arraigned yesterday on murder charges.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUFFER, JAMES CHADBOURNE
description: PUFFER-James Chadbourne, 65. Died Thursday, December 6, 2001 in Wellington, FL. He was the son of James C. Puffer and Margaret Davidson Puffer. Mr. Puffer was graduated from the University of Vermont and was a member of Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity. Mr. Puffer was formerly an executive with 20th Century Fox. He is survived by his wife, Karen Weygand Puffer, his sister Mary ''Pat'' Scott and her two sons, James and Charles, of Sudbury, MA. Burial will be held privately at the Puffer family plot at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in St. Johnsbury, VT. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Margaret Davidson Puffer Educational Fund, Braintree, MA or to The American Cancer Society, POB 79604, Baltimore, MD 21279-0604, or to Hospice of Palm Beach Co., 5300 East Ave., W. Palm Beach, FL 33407.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGEL, MURRAY
description: ANGEL-Murray. Of Brooklyn, NY, died on December 5, 2001. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father and father-in-law to Hal and Joanne and Lloyd and Joanie. Dear brother and brother-in-law to Sam and Madlen Ezratty. Adored grandfather to Kirsen, Morgan and Darryl. He was ''Prince Amongst Men'' and will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: Baoding Journal; In the Failed Mill's Shadow, the Workers Despair
description: For more than three decades after it was founded in 1958, the Baoding No. 1 Paper Mill seemed a model of Chinese socialism.

title: U.S. Hopes to Block Al Qaeda From Taking Hold in Somalia
description: A senior State Department official on a tour of Africa said today that the United States had begun surveying the waters and airspace around Somalia in hopes of preventing members of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network from establishing a foothold there.

title: In Spat on NATO and Russia, Powell Fends Off Rumsfeld
description: A proposal by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to fundamentally alter the structure of the Western alliance by expanding Russia's role in NATO decision-making ran afoul this week of a clash of views between Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, Western diplomats here say.

title: Yudh V. Jain: Finishing What He Started
description: Yudh V. Jain was his wife's dream. He encouraged her to buy clothes. He did the grocery shopping and showered her with flowers and greeting cards on not-so-special days. And every night, he remembered to make her a cup of tea.

title: Wheeling, Dealing and Making Side Deals; Vow to Scrap Latin Textile Deals Wins Vote on Bush Trade Powers
description: The Bush administration hailed Thursday's photo-finish vote on presidential trade powers as a sterling -- though slender -- victory for free trade. But in return for crucial support, House Republican leaders quietly agreed to weaken one of the Clinton administration's most-prized trade accords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, MORTIMER
description: TAYLOR-Mortimer. On December 6, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Pauline, loving father of Simeon and Jonathan, father-inlaw of Laura, devoted grandfather of Joanna, Josh, MeeYun and Joon. Services Sunday December 9, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, New York City. Donations may be made in Mortimer Taylor's name to UJA/Federation or The American Heart Association.

title: St. Raymond's Road Turns More Difficult
description: Gary Decesare, coach of the St. Raymond's High School basketball team, knew that defending his state championship would be difficult this season. What he did not realize was how much harder it might be to defend his city title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, DOLORITA
description: MOORE-Dolorita. The International Debutante Ball Foundation cherishes the memory of Dolorita Moore, a dear friend and a grand lady.

title: New York City Boom Helped Poorest, Too
description: The surging economy of the late 1990's helped New York City's poorest gain economic ground even faster, by some measures, than it helped the wealthy, a new study by two New York University professors shows.

title: After Taiwan Election, Chill Persists
description: When President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan won a landslide victory in legislative elections last weekend, his supporters said it would finally force China to pay heed to their leader. After all, Beijing has plenty of reasons to be alarmed.

title: Liberty, Security and John Ashcroft's Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Professional Women From Afghanistan Meet to Press for Full Rights in Their Country
description: Almost 40 prominent Afghan women, backed by American and European groups, gathered this week to stake their claim to a crucial role in rebuilding their country after years of being forced to live either in silence at home or in frustration abroad.

title: Gregory R. Sikorsky: Taking Little Brother Along
description: There was the time that Gregory R. Sikorsky decided to take his youngest brother, Perry, up in a four-seater Cessna. But after they got up at 6 a.m., after they had driven an hour to the airport, the plane's battery turned out to be dead. So he drove his truck onto the highway and jump-started the plane. Then they took off.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Tobacco Company Suit
description: A San Diego Superior Court judge, Ronald S. Prager, ruled that an advertising campaign by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company violated the 1998 settlement in a nationwide tobacco lawsuit, which bans many types of outdoor advertising for tobacco products, including billboards. The lawsuit challenged the outdoor promotion of Nascar Winston Cup and drag racing events. It is one of three cases that the state attorney general, Bill Lockyer, has brought accusing R. J. Reynolds of violating the settlement. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: A Vote for Free Trade
description: By a single vote margin, the House of Representatives on Thursday gave President Bush the negotiating power he will need to broker trade agreements vital to the health of the global economy. It is a shame that only 21 Democrats voted for the measure. Senate Democrats, less beholden to protectionist interests, should now hasten to support President Bush's request and reassemble a bipartisan consensus for freer trade.

title: Halliburton Battered As Asbestos Verdict Stirs Deep Anxieties
description: Call it the Enron aftershock.

title: Kathryn Anne Shatzoff: When Not Collecting, Giving
description: Kathryn Anne Shatzoff was not a collector, really, but her husband, Neil, the owner of a comic book shop, was. So a few years ago, he got her started collecting Barbie dolls.

title: George Hansen, 92, Designer Of Popular Swing-Arm Lamp
description: George Hansen, who designed a widely used wall-mounted swing-arm lamp, died on Tuesday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 92.

title: Europe's Muslims Seek a Path Amid Competing Cultures
description: Shazia Mirza is by most any standard a good Muslim. She is fasting this Ramadan, as always. She prays. She never drinks alcohol or eats pork. Yet three Muslim men jumped her, one actually wringing her neck, after she told this sly joke in a comedy club here about a pilgrimage she took to Mecca:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Satellite Project Stalls
description: European plans for the Galileo satellite navigation system stalled as transportation commissioners failed to release 450 million euros ($403 million) in financing. While the European Union has endorsed the idea of an alternative to the global positioning system operated by the United States, many member countries have expressed doubts about its cost, estimated to be at least $3 billion. Transportation ministers from Austria, Britain, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands and Sweden wanted more time to assess a cost-benefit report released two weeks ago. European leaders meet next week and may talk about reviving the project. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Christopher Quackenbush: `Christmas Carol' All Year
description: Most people think of "A Christmas Carol," the Charles Dickens classic, only during the holidays. But the tale of greed and redemption was on Christopher Quackenbush's mind his entire life.

title: Member's Racist Ties Split Confederate Legacy Group
description: For most of its 105-year history, the Sons of Confederate Veterans has worked quietly to honor its members' ancestors by cleaning cemeteries, marking graves and supporting genealogical research. If there were schisms, they were likely to be over the authenticity of the brass buttons on a Civil War re-enactor's uniform.

title: Urging Peace Talks, Sri Lankan Opposition Defeats President's Coalition
description: Sri Lanka's voters have rejected the coalition that has governed for seven years, according to election results announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOWLTON, PETER, M.D.
description: KNOWLTON-Peter, M.D. Of Marion, MA., died December 5, 2001. Memorial service will be Monday, December 10th, St. Gabriels Church, 124 Front St., Marion, MA. at 12 noon.

title: Wanda Prince: Coffee Healed All Wounds
description: Wanda Prince had a weakness for coffee. Whenever she was upset with her husband, Edward, about leaving his dirty clothes on the bathroom floor (again) or leaving his dirty dishes in the sink (again), Mr. Prince would woo her back with a strong cup of Joe. "She just loved coffee," said Mr. Prince.

title: Danaher Agrees To Buy Viridor
description: The Danaher Corporation, the maker of Sears Craftsman tools and testing equipment, agreed today to buy the Viridor Instrumentation unit of the Pennon Group for $135 million to bolster its water-quality business.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Lending Rate Is Cut
description: The Swiss National Bank has reduced its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, to the lowest in two years, as the country's economy continues to slide. The lending rate was lowered to 1.75 percent from 2.25 percent, the fourth cut this year, and perhaps not the last as indicators presage the country's first recession since 1996. The economy is dependent on exports, which have been shrinking. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: James R. Coyle: The Force Was With Him
description: James R. Coyle wanted to be Luke Skywalker. But because of certain difficulties in pursuing that career path, he decided to do what he thought was the next best thing, which was fighting fires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEYES, ROBERT W.
description: KEYES-Robert W. Of Holderness, NH, died December 2. Beloved husband of Susan S.; adored father of Austin, Travis and Justin; loving stepfather of Putney and Julia. Was a graduate of Princeton University and served in the USMC. Retired as Managing Director of Smith Barney, Inc. in NYC. Services will be private. Donations to: Dr. James Morgan, Rheumatology Clinic for Vasculitis Research, Dartmouth-Hitchock Medical Center, One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756 in memory of Bobby Keyes or to Princeton Blairstown Center, 330 Alexander St., Helm Bldg., 1 flr., Princeton, NJ 08544, in memory of Bobby Keyes.

title: Chester Journal; Raid and Investigation Unite City for Immigrant
description: People here worry about Dr. Irshad Shaikh, their Pakistani-born health commissioner. Not that he is a terrorist, even though federal agents raided his home last month, looking for anthrax.

description: To the Editor:

title: Brian P. Monaghan Jr.: The Archetypal Good Kid
description: His friends nicknamed Brian P. Monaghan Jr., "slick"  but not the deceptive, smooth-talking, street-smart kind of slick. Around Inwood, where he lived, Mr. Monaghan was known as the archetypal good kid, a 21- year-old who helped elderly women across streets and went to the store for neighbors who could not.

title: European Cell Of Al Qaeda Cited in Killing Of Massoud
description: Investigators piecing together the suicide-bomb assassination of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the Afghan rebel leader, say they believe the plot was carried out by members of a European-based cell of Al Qaeda that on remote-control command from Osama bin Laden reached back to Afghanistan to destroy its prey.

description: The Department of the Interior has shut down its Internet access and some computer connections after a federal judge here challenged the security of one of the department's computer systems.

description: MORRISSEY-M. Gertrude (nee Savage). December 5. 2001. Retired NYC teacher. Formerly of Quincy, Mass. Beloved wife of the late John Morrissey, FDNY, Ret. title: Steven H. Russin: A Childlike Wonder
description: There was something about Steven H. Russin that made his wife, Andrea, think of Tom Hanks's character in the movie "Big."

title: Turnabout at AOL Time Warner
description: This week's announcement that Gerald Levin would relinquish the helm of AOL Time Warner next May surprised Wall Street and left many observers wondering what his departure signifies for the media giant. For the moment, at least, it looks as if the traditional content providers from the old Time Warner -- the magazine, movie, television, book and music divisions -- have gained the ascendancy over the upstart Internet entrepreneurs from America Online. After a decade on the job, Mr. Levin will be succeeded as chief executive officer by his hand-picked successor, Richard Parsons, a Time Warner veteran. Wall Street had viewed Robert Pittman, the former president of AOL who will remain the chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, as the heir apparent.

title: A Firefighter With Credits, A Man With Wanderlust And a Barbie Doll Collector
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Mark L. Rosenberg: Saving Gas, and the World
description: Mark L. Rosenberg met his future wife, Jennifer, in 1995 on a seven-hour bus ride to Richmond, Va., for a Jewish youth program. He was trying to shine a flashlight on a book and turn the pages at the same time. She sat behind him, and finally offered to hold the flashlight. He gratefully accepted.

title: 9 States Ask Judge To Put Restrictions On Microsoft Systems
description: Prosecutors from nine states today criticized the Bush administration as settling too leniently with Microsoft in its antitrust case and asked a federal judge to impose a sharp set of business restrictions on the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHOURI, SYLVIA
description: KHOURI-Sylvia, 89. Of Lakewood, NJ, on December 7, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Elie. Dear mother of Eddie and late Patricia. Cherished grandmother to Scott and Christie. The funeral from D'Elia Funeral Home, State Hwy 70 and Vermont Ave., Lakewood, NJ. Funeral service offered in St. Mary's Church, Brooklyn, NY, Monday, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Macular Foundation, 210 E. 64 St., NY NY 10021 greatly appreciated by the family.

title: Los Angeles Lodging
description: More than 100 hotels in the Los Angeles area are offering two nights for the price of one through February. The program includes Los Angeles, Pasadena, Long Beach, Santa Monica, West Hollywood and Marina del Rey. And when guests check in, they will receive TheLAcard, good for 10 to 20 percent off at participating restaurants. Other benefits include a child's admission with each paid adult admission to Universal Studios Hollywood, shopping discounts from various stores in the Beverly Center and the Century City Shopping Center and two-for-one admission to the Norton Simon Museum, the Petersen Automotive Museum and others. Hotel rooms are subject to availability. For details, (800) 228-2452 or www.visitlanow.com .

title: Sidney Kelley, 92, Part of Used-Car Empire
description: Sidney H. Kelley, a member of the family of used-car dealers who developed the Kelley Blue Book on car prices, died Wednesday in Norco, Calif. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURTMAN, ALAN
description: GURTMAN-Alan. The Members, Board of Governors and Officers of the Preakness Hills Country Club mourn the loss of a good friend and fellow member of longstanding and extend their deepest sympathies to his wife, Jill, and the family. Morton Klein, President

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the New York philanthropist Louise Steinhart Loeb on Tuesday misstated the given name of her late husband. He was Henry A. Loeb, not John.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Savings At Credit Suisse
description: The Credit Suisse Group said its cost-reduction plan, which includes laying off more than 2,400 jobs in investment banking, should save $650 million next year. Most of the layoffs will be at Credit Suisse First Boston, the company said. The chief executive, Lukas Muehlemann, said yesterday that he did not expect an upturn in the fourth quarter. The bank lost some $180 million in the third quarter, and faces a pretax loss of about $100 million from its exposure to the energy trader Enron. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about Turkey's announcement of an agreement on the formation of a European Union security force misstated the location of Cyprus, whose partial occupation by Turkey since 1974 is a source of tension with Greece, a European Union member. It is in the Mediterranean, not the Aegean.

title: Gerard Jean Baptiste: Treats for Dogs, and Himself
description: There is a decent chance that Gerard Jean Baptiste had dog biscuits in his pockets when he died. A New York firefighter, he routinely carried treats to give to the pets that walked past Ladder 9 in SoHo. That helped start conversations with the children  or the women  that the dogs towed with them.

title: Unemployment Rate Jumped Last Month On Surge of Layoffs
description: A vast wave of job cuts in November sent the unemployment rate up sharply, to 5.7 percent from 5.4 percent the previous month, the government reported yesterday, suggesting that the current recession will be more painful than many forecasters had expected.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Queen's Daughter-In-Law Recovering
description: Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, who is married to Queen Elizabeth's youngest son, Edward, was recovering in a London hospital after an emergency operation that followed the discovery of an ectopic pregnancy, a life-threatening condition where a baby develops in a fallopian tube rather than the womb. Doctors said the countess, 36, would need a six-week convalescence and that the episode did not preclude another pregnancy. ''There will be other chances,'' she said.

description: The Argentine government scrambled yesterday to keep its economic crisis from spinning out of control as pressure mounted on its public finances, its securities markets, its banking system and its currency, now pegged to the American dollar.

title: Attacks Called Costly to City Tourism Industry
description: The president of the city's convention and visitors bureau told state legislators yesterday that tourism-related businesses would probably lose much more than $4 billion over the next two years because of the shrinking economy and the lingering impact of the terrorist attack on Sept. 11.

title: Historian's Prizewinning Book on Guns Is Embroiled in a Scandal
description: Only a year ago, Michael A. Bellesiles was well on his way to becoming an academic superstar. He had just published a book with a startling thesis: very few people owned working guns in colonial America. Stepping into the ferocious national debate over guns and the meaning of the Second Amendment, Mr. Bellesiles, a history professor at Emory University in Atlanta, caused a sensation. Legal scholars said his prize-winning book could influence federal court cases challenging gun laws; gun-control advocates championed the research as proof that America's gun culture is, as Mr. Bellesiles put it, ''an invented tradition''; angry gun owners saw it as an insidious attack, a calculated effort to prove that the Constitution's framers could not have intended the ''right to bear arms'' to apply to individuals if so few people owned them.

title: Seeing the Green Amid the Red, White and Blue; Wholesalers, in Rush to Market, Got Sept. 11 Souvenirs on Street
description: Capitalism triumphed again.

description: Gary Bright was still working flat out, usually seven days a week, sometimes at two jobs. Late last summer, he put together a combination that suited him fine: working evenings as a waiter at Spazzio's restaurant on Columbus Avenue and, during the days, as a temporary insurance analyst at Aon Insurance in the World Trade Center.

description: Backed by a veto threat from President Bush, Senate Republicans on Friday killed a Democratic plan to provide $17 billion of aid to New York, along with a similar amount of money for various domestic programs to combat terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTELSMANN, HEINZ O.
description: BERTELSMANN-Heinz O. The Bard College community deeply mourns the passing of Heinz O. Bertelsmann, professor emeritus and longtime friend of the college. For more than 30 years he shared his keen intellect and deep humanity with Bard's students and faculty as a professor of international relations. Over the past two decades the vitality, dedication, and generosity of Heinz and his wife Lilo continued to play an essential role in the life of the college. We extend our deepest condolences to Lilo and to his entire family. He will be sorely missed. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman

title: BIOPURE DELAYS SEEKING APPROVAL FOR BLOOD SUBSTITUTE
description: Shares in the Biopure Company fell as much as 19 percent after the company said it would not ask federal regulators to approve its blood substitute until next year. Shares in the company dropped $1.35, or 7.8 percent, to $15.95. Earlier, the shares touched $14.02. The company said earlier that it had hoped to submit an application to the Food and Drug Administration by the end of 2001 after a final-stage study of the product, known as Hemopure, showed the blood substitute was as safe as blood from human donors. Now, the company said that date might be pushed back as it tests a new plant built to make Hemopure.

title: Congress' Bomb-Screening Deadline Called Unrealistic
description: Congress was unrealistic when it set the end of 2002 as the deadline for screening all checked baggage for bombs, private and government experts testified today at a Congressional hearing.

description: One girl, from Massachusetts, broke the state-meet course record by more than 30 seconds. A girl from Illinois improved with coaching from an Olympic marathoner. description: BLEECKER-Rosalind P. Of Miami Beach and NYC. On Thursday, December 6, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Louis K. Bleecker, cherished mother of Barbara Appelbaum and Joan (Robert) Rosen, adored grandmother of Joseph Appelbaum, Adam J. Roberts and Meredith Rosen. Rosalind lived a long and glorious life immigrating to New York as a young girl, building a family, career and the loving adoration of nieces, nephews and friends. As the last of her generation she dispensed elegant wisdom to her family and friends with compassion and humility. Services were held at ''The Riverside''.

description: Grard Mortier, the departing artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, has been chosen to succeed Hugues Gall as director general of the Paris National Opera beginning in 2004, Culture Ministry officials said today. An official announcement is expected next week.

title: Thomas S. Strada: `Sky Was the Limit'
description: What made Terry Strada fall fast in love with her husband, Thomas, when they met 20 years ago? "Oh my God, he was the most fun person I ever knew," Mrs. Strada said. "He would take me out, and the sky was the limit. Limos, dinners. I said I liked the Boston Celtics; he flew me to Boston to see them."

title: Bill Reid, 79, Heroic Bomber Pilot for British in World War II
description: Bill Reid, a Royal Air Force pilot in World War II who received the Victoria Cross, Britain's highest award for valor, for completing a bombing mission over Germany in a crippled plane after he was severely wounded and his navigator killed, died on Nov. 28 at his home in Crieff, Scotland. He was 79.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Gendarmes Want More Money
description: Several hundred gendarmes drove their service vehicles to the force's national headquarters in a protest demanding better pay and shorter workdays. It was the fourth day of demonstrations by members of the 95,000-strong national police force, which, as a branch of the army, is forbidden to hold protests, and until Tuesday had never disobeyed that order. Other, larger gendarme protests, all nonviolent, have been held in other cities and as far away as Runion in the Indian Ocean.
