title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: Fouad Ajami (Nov. 18) provided a helpful sampling of the news programs and talk shows on Al Jazeera. For someone who enjoys the liberties of democracy, however, he comes to a perverse conclusion: that the station should be treated as a dangerous force. I, too, have been watching Al Jazeera and find it an important source of information on opinions and opinion-makers in the Arab world. Its reporters are on the ground, often filming bloody conflicts that Westerners would rather not see. Yes, the views are virulent. Yet no more so than those of commentators in the United States news media.

title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: I was not as upset about Al Jazeera as Fouad Ajami seemed to want me to be. While I don't agree with the views of fundamentalist Muslims, what's wrong with their being expressed? Even in the most outrageous terms? Isn't the Arab world entitled to its equivalent of Geraldo Rivera?

title: Maples Planted for an Old War Make Way for a New Shrine
description: Gardeners are intimate with the cycle of life, death and rebirth. But a different kind of renewal, both cultural and horticultural, is taking place at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Some 80 declining Norway maples, originally planted to commemorate the end of World War I and scheduled to be replaced, will soon make room for a grove of scarlet oaks dedicated to the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Some Books to Please Garden Lovers
description: BOOKSELLERS stock hundreds of books on cultivating tomatoes, growing rhododendrons and designing gardens. They also carry numerous volumes of garden essays, most often by writers who garden or gardeners who write.

title: No Volunteers for Game Against the Hurricanes
description: By upsetting Tennessee, 31-20, tonight in the Southeastern Conference title game despite injuries to two of its offensive stars, Louisiana State threw the national championship game to the whims of the voters in the polls and the computer programs of the Bowl Championship Series. So who will face top-ranked Miami in the national title game in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 3?

title: Two From Hewlett Win Science Contest
description: Two seniors from Hewlett Bay Park's Stella K. Abraham High School for Girls have won the top team prize in the nationwide Siemens Westinghouse Science and Technology Competition.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, which must decide whether to support the merger of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer, misstated the given name of a board member, as did a board membership list with the article. The director is Colburn S. Wilbur, not Colin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARFFENBERGER, GEORGE THOMAS
description: SCHARFFENBERGER - George Thomas. Born May 22, 1919 in Hollis, New York, died November 10, 2001 at his home in Rolling Hills, CA. He was a graduate of Columbia University and joined the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen. He later became chairman and CEO of City Investing Company in New York. He was a member of the Board of Trustees at both the University of Southern California and Georgetown University where he received Doctor of Humane Letters degrees. He was appointed a USC life trustee in 1994. He is survived by his wife, Marion, of 53 years and his children, Ann, George Jr., John, Tom, Jim and Joan, as well as 10 grandchildren. Funeral Services were private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the ''G.T. Scharffenberger Memorial Scholarship Fund'' at USC, (213) 740-2111.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 9, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Jail, Not Classes, Is Crowded In Middletown
description: WITH the holiday season already muted in this Monmouth County suburb, the last thing township residents needed or wanted was the mass arrest of its striking teachers like so many Taliban soldiers.

title: Ideas & Trends; Cornered Minds, False Confessions
description: CENTURIES apart, but under peculiarly similar circumstances, Margaret Jacobs and Marcellius Bradford got into big trouble by opening their mouths. ''They told me if I would not confess I should be put down into the dungeon and would be hanged, but if I would confess I should save my life,'' Miss Jacobs told a court in Salem in 1692.

title: On the Home Front, a Welcome Economic Kick
description: TO this rural town, population 400 and an hour east of Charlotte, Afghanistan may seem far away. But not the war effort.

title: Janus Chief Says He'll Stay
description: Tom Bailey, founder of Janus Capital, sold his last stake in the mutual fund company this fall, and Janus funds have had a dismal year, but he vowed last week, ''We will be back; I guarantee it.''

title: BANDITS KILL YACHTSMAN
description: A gang of masked robbers known as the Water Rats boarded a 130-foot research vessel anchored near the mouth of the Amazon River in Brazil and fatally shot its captain, Sir Peter Blake. At 53, Sir Peter was a larger-than-life sailing figure who had twice led New Zealand to victory in the America's Cup and then become immersed in environmental research. Two crew members were also wounded in the robbery. Seven men, aged 21 to 41, were arrested after a manhunt ordered by the Brazilian president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso.

title: When the Camera Goes Behind the Looking Glass
description: IN the live-action prologue to an animated 1951 version of ''Alice in Wonderland,'' the Rev. Charles Dodgson and his friends, the Liddells, are seen drifting lazily down an English river in a skiff. ''Tell me a story,'' says the Liddells' young daughter, Alice, to Dodgson, better known to history as Lewis Carroll. ''One filled with animals and nonsense.''

title: George Harrison, World-Music Catalyst And Great-Souled Man; Open to the Influence Of Unfamiliar Cultures
description: WE all naturally remember George Harrison as one of the cornerstones (but weren't they all?) of the late-20th-century phenomenon known as the Beatles. But for some, George, who died on Nov. 29 at the age of 58, was an icon of another phenomenon, equally influential in shaping the music of today. I'm referring to the world-music culture, which, starting in the 60's, has become an inescapable aspect of our music life. George was among the first Western musicians to recognize the importance of music traditions millenniums old, which themselves had roots in indigenous music, both popular and classical. Using his considerable influence and popularity, he was one of those few who pushed open the door that, until then, had separated the music of much of the world from the West.

title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: Fouad Ajami (Nov. 18) provided a helpful sampling of the news programs and talk shows on Al Jazeera. For someone who enjoys the liberties of democracy, however, he comes to a perverse conclusion: that the station ''should be treated as a dangerous force.'' I, too, have been watching Al Jazeera and find it an important source of information on opinions and opinion-makers in the Arab world. Its reporters are on the ground, often filming bloody conflicts that Westerners would rather not see. Yes, the views are virulent. Yet no more so than those of commentators in the United States news media.

title: N.F.L. Puts Mothers In Charge of the Playbook
description: FOR the health and welfare of my nose, I'd never have dared tell another kid his mother was a football coach. But now, thanks to a pilot program created and run by the National Football League, ''your mama's a football coach'' might soon be a simple statement of fact.

title: Commander's Mission Moving From Shore to Ship
description: With two small children to comfort and her husband suddenly gone forever, Laurie Laychak was not sure what to expect next as she gathered with the other 124 Pentagon families plunged into grief by the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CHARLES H.
description: WILLIAMS-Charles H. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles H. Williams, associated with The Times from 1969 until retiring in 1986.

title: The Game That Plays You
description: Last spring, an unusual game appeared on the Web -- though ''game'' isn't quite the right word. It was more like an original and expansive fictional world, mapped out on more than 1,000 interwoven Web pages. The untitled, unannounced creation was intended as a promotion for Steven Spielberg's film ''A.I.: Artificial Intelligence,'' and though its success as a promotional tool is debatable -- its very existence was a secret, even from many who were working on it -- as an interactive game, it broke new ground.

title: Van Gundy Stuns Knicks by Resigning as Coach
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Dec. 8 — Jeff Van Gundy, who rose from coaching a high school basketball team to leading one of the most prominent franchises in sports, resigned unexpectedly as coach of the Knicks today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MURDOCK, RANDY
description: MURDOCK-Randy. January 6, 1960 to December 5, 1991. Ten years have passed but it seems like yesterday. We so miss your laugh, your smile and all that was Randy. As long as someone says your name aloud, you live on. You are always with us. Lovingly, your family.

title: The Neediest Cases; Injury from 1937 Accident Confines Woman to Home
description: On a rain-soaked evening in 1937, a 9-year-old girl is hit by a car as she crosses the street, returning home from Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn. The impact knocks her unconscious.

title: ARGENTINE FISCAL WOES
description: The Argentine economy is nearing chaos, buffeted by nearly four years of recession created by low commodity prices, an overvalued currency and out-of-control deficits.

title: Artificial Chromosomes
description: In the last decade, the genetic revolution in American crops has brought us corn that grows its own pesticide thanks to a lab-inserted bacterial gene, and tobacco that makes its own antifreeze using DNA from a North Atlantic flounder. This year, however, a University of Chicago biologist, Daphne Preuss, appears to have succeeded in creating a technology that will make existing genetic modifications of plants seem quaint. She inserted not single genes, but entire artificial chromosomes, into a batch of mustard plants.

title: Transcending Equations
description: Ever since Newton, scientists have dreamed of capturing the universe in a neat set of equations. And who can blame them? From the law of gravity to e=mc2, equations have been stunningly successful in rendering the world around us comprehensible. But not all of the world. A lot of really complex phenomena -- the turbulence of a flowing liquid, the pattern on a mollusk shell, the gyrations of the stock market, the wiring of the human brain -- seem to resist being reduced to the simplicity of an equation. Does that mean they will forever elude our understanding?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the remaking of the television film ''Brian's Song,'' about the former Chicago Bears player Brian Piccolo, misstated the surname of his widow. She is Joy Piccolo O'Connell, not McConnell.

title: POSTINGS: Work Begins at Columbia Site at 110th and Broadway; Faculty Housing and a School
description: Construction has begun on a 12-story building at the southeast corner of Broadway and 110th Street where Columbia University plans to provide housing for faculty members and create a private school for 650 kindergarten through eighth-grade students -- the School at Columbia University.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: EAGER TO PLEASE

title: The Mission: Helping Women and Girls
description: WHEN the Delta Minerva Life Development Center in Roosevelt wanted to hold a conference on how to prevent teenage girls in Nassau County from joining gangs, it approached the Long Island Fund for Women and Girls. Soon the center, sponsored by Delta Sigma Theta, a black sorority, had a $2,500 grant from the fund, which is dedicated to improving the status of women and girls on the Island.

title: If You Take My Advice . . .
description: LETTERS TO A

title: Hunter Reno, Peter Rabbino
description: Hunter Reno, the daughter of Donna Reno of Seville, Spain, and Mark W. Reno of Miami, is to be married this afternoon to Peter Daniel Rabbino, the son of Tina and Bernard Rabbino of Livingston, N.J. Janet Reno, the former United States attorney general, a Florida notary and an aunt of the bride, is to officiate at the Fairchild Tropical Gardens in Coral Gables, Fla. Rabbi Robert Davis is to participate in the ceremony.

title: The Nation; Through a Prism of a Latin Past
description: THE novelist Isabel Allende was recently asked what came to mind when she heard the date Sept. 11. Without hesitation, Ms. Allende said she thought of Chile, her native land, and what happened there on Sept. 11, 1973. That was the day the military toppled the democratically elected government of Salvador Allende, causing his death. Ms. Allende, a second cousin of Mr. Allende, fled soon after.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE GIRL IN THE FALL-AWAY DRESS

title: Bronx Girl, 10, Is Shot in Domestic Dispute
description: A 10-year-old Bronx girl was accidentally shot in the leg yesterday morning during an argument between her mother and her mother's boyfriend, the police said.

title: Residents Wary of the Water, But the City Says Drink Up
description: There is water everywhere in the sand and gravel aquifer under southeastern Queens. But which of its drops are fit to drink?

title: False-Identification Prevention
description: Short of DNA evidence, an eyewitness who can view a police lineup and say, ''Yep, that's the guy; I'd never forget that face'' seems like the surest way to bring the right perp to justice. The problem is, eyewitnesses forget or misremember faces all the time. Gary Wells, a psychology professor at Iowa State who has studied why so many eyewitnesses point to innocent men and women, thinks that one big reason is the way standard police lineups are conducted, with six people displayed simultaneously. He advocates a radically different approach: showing eyewitnesses one person at a time and allowing them to say yes or no to each one.

title: Opening a Gateway, Closing In on bin Laden and Setting the Priorities
description: Supplies of food and medicine may soon be flowing into northern Afghanistan over a long-closed bridge from the former Soviet republic of Uzbekistan. Colin L. Powell, the secretary of state, who is visiting central Asian republics to say thanks for helping America in the war on terrorism, and the Uzbek president, Islam Karimov, announced in Tashkent that the so-called Friendship Bridge, a Soviet-built span closed since 1996, would be reopened today.

title: Populist Editing
description: Despite the popular conception of the Internet as our most interactive medium, on the great majority of Web pages the interaction all goes in one direction. But an intriguing new subgenre of sites, called WikiWikiWebs, really are interactive: users can both read and write. If you don't like the perspective of the article you are perusing, you can go in and rephrase the concluding paragraph. If you stumble across a spelling mistake, you can fix it with a few quick keystrokes. Wikis are like communal gardens of data: some participants do a lot of heavy planting, while others prefer to pull a weed here and there.

title: Airing the Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: PLAYING the Marquis de Sade has to be an emotional high for an actor, and Geoffrey Rush revels in the challenge in Philip Kaufman's harrowing drama QUILLS (2000). Joaquin Phoenix is the abb in charge of Sade at Charenton Asylum, and he does not approve of his prisoner's literary work (''It's nothing but an encyclopedia of perversions''). Michael Caine, the new doctor sent to advise the abb, is busy locking up his new under-age wife (Amelia Warner), fresh from the convent (''She is a rare bird; I intend to keep her cared''). Kate Winslet is the chambermaid who's sneaking the marquis's new work, page by page, to his publisher. This is a wrenchingly violent film, but not in the usual ways -- Tuesday at 7:45 p.m on Cinemax.

title: WEAK AS STEEL
description: In order to put the industry on more solid footing, the nation's biggest steelmakers are seeking government support to merge up to a half-dozen ailing steelmakers into one big company. The plan contains one key, and controversial, element: a government takeover of some $13 billion in health care costs for retired steelworkers. Criticism of the plan began immediately, even from some within the steel industry who called it a ''federal bailout.'' Leslie Wayne

title: Such, Such Are the Joys
description: ON a five-mile stretch of the old King's Highway that starts in Princeton and snakes southwest toward Trenton are several exceptional institutions. Princeton University, ivied and spired; Bristol-Myers Squibb's Pharmaceutical Research Institute, where in a park-like setting about 4,000 people build molecules to target human diseases; Drumthwacket, the governor's wedding cake of a mansion; and Jasna Polana, one of the most expensive houses every built.

title: Squirreling It Away With the State
description: PAUL THOMPSON of White Plains, like many parents, wanted to put away money for his child's college education. But unlike many other investors, he has chosen a rather untraditional place to put his money: with the state.

title: Actions Speak Only as Loud as Words
description: COLLECTED STORIES

title: Perennials of the Literary Variety
description: Booksellers stock hundreds of books on cultivating tomatoes, growing rhododendrons and designing gardens. They also carry numerous volumes of garden essays, most often by writers who garden or gardeners who write.

title: The Newest Tower: Working 24/7
description: ON the western rim of Columbus Circle, on the site of the old Coliseum, stands the skeleton of the city's newest skyscraper, the AOL Time Warner Center. At the moment, it is a mesh of steel and scaffolding 19 stories tall, but when completed in two years, the $1.7 billion center's twin towers will reach 53 stories, or 750 feet.

title: BOOX
Beginnings
description: Thank you for the rich and thought-provoking special issue of Nov. 11. I read it slowly, savoring a little every day.

title: Ideas & Trends; War's Hidden Cost
description: THIS much is all but certain: when bombs fall, some of them will fall on the wrong people. Sometimes innocents are killed, in what is coolly referred to as collateral damage. Sometimes comrades in arms die and the military call it fratricide or, more chillingly, friendly fire.

title: Undemocratic Example
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE LONG MARRIAGE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAMSKI, FREDERICK
description: DAMSKI-Frederick. 58, died December 6. Survived by wife Paula, sons Paul and Seth, mother Rachel, brothers Mel and Peter, sister Janice Kaminsky and grandchildren Yosef, Maya and Julia.

title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: Conspicuously absent from your polemic against Al Jazeera was any suggestion that Arab anti-Americanism may be an understandable response to a long history of post-World War II American policies offering largely uncritical support for Israel and for corrupt, unpopular regimes through the Islamic world.

title: Precautionary Principle
description: New technologies can bring mankind great benefits, but they can also cause accidental harm. How careful should society be about introducing innovations that have the potential to affect human health and the environment? For the last several decades, American society has been guided by the ''risk analysis'' model, which assesses new technologies by trying to calculate the mathematical likelihood that they will harm the public. There are other ways, however, to think about this problem. Indeed, a rival idea from Europe, the ''precautionary principle 2/3'' has just begun making inroads in America.

title: Ideas & Trends; That Scientific Breakthrough Thing
description: DISPATCH from the cloning wars: When Advanced Cell Technology announced that it had created human embryos by cloning, a political uproar ensued. Now comes the fight over vocabulary.

title: Letters: Boston Symphony
description: Airing the Issues

title: California Girl Romps to a Record
description: Running the fastest 5,000-meter cross-country race by an American schoolgirl, Amber Trotter of Redwood Valley, Calif., won the 23rd Foot Locker high school championship today by 41 seconds. Her time was 16 minutes 24 seconds.

title: Lower Air Fares Through E-Mail
description: BUYING an airline ticket on short notice used to mean paying top dollar. Although in many cases it still does, those who subscribe to weekly e-mail newsletters that most airlines now offer can find out about low fares for last-minute travel.

title: BattleSwarm
description: Recent events in Somalia, Kosovo, Chechnya and Afghanistan show that the new global threat is not conventionally massed national armies but what one study calls ''ethnonationalist paramilitary bands, organized in small, dispersed units.'' For the United States to succeed in combat against those forces, according to military theorists John Arquilla and David Ronfeldt of the RAND Corporation's National Defense Research Institute, we need a new form of combat: ''swarming.'' Arquilla and Ronfeldt intend it to transform the American military machine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RETTINGER, GINNY
description: RETTINGER-Ginny, 93. Died November 26, 2001. Interred on November 27 at the New Montefiore Cemetery next to her husband of 68 years, David (March 3, 1997). A graveside service for immediate family was held. Ginny leaves behind her children Martin and Jill, Phyllis and David, Diane and Harv; nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. She will always be loved and missed. Donations in her memory to any charity of your choice educating inner-city children.

title: Lakers Taking Flight Right From the Start
description: Nearly two years ago, Phil Jackson walked into the visitors' dressing room at Conseco Fieldhouse and held court with his new team. The Los Angeles Lakers' 16-game winning streak had just been snapped by the Indiana Pacers when Jackson surveyed the dejected players in front of him.

title: Political Briefing; Elizabeth Dole Sits On Big Lead in a Poll
description: There is also a gender gap -- the kind that Mrs. Carnahan would love to see -- in the race next year in North Carolina to replace Senator Jesse Helms, the veteran hard-right Republican who has decided to retire.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Nov. 25 about a new train station for Newark International Airport referred incorrectly to connections with it. PATH service ends at Penn Station in Newark, where passengers must transfer to New Jersey Transit or Amtrak trains to reach the airport. PATH trains do not go to the airport station.

title: A Health Maze: Which Way Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: Havana Moon
description: GUILTY OF DANCING THE CHACHACH

title: 'The Diaries of Kenneth Tynan'
description: 11 January

title: Down the Beaten Path
description: Memorable moments from Jeff Van Gundy's tenure as Knicks head coach. By CHRIS BROUSSARD

title: INTRODUCING . . .
description: After nine years of national expectation, Japan's Crown Princess Masako delivered a baby, named Aiko, which means, literally, love child. Because the baby was a girl, however, Japan's imperial family still lacks a successor to the baby's father, Crown Prince Naruhito. No males have been born into the imperial line for the last 37 years, and Aiko's birth has spurred debate about changing the male-only succession law, which was established in 1948 under the United States' occupation of Japan. Howard W. French

title: Cloning Endangered Species
description: Back in January, an ordinary milk cow from Iowa named Bessie gave birth to a rather unusual baby. It didn't resemble the mother, and with good reason: it was a gaur -- an endangered, humpbacked wild ox native to Southeast Asia. Its name was Noah.

title: U.S. Asks to Use Secret Evidence In Many Cases Of Deportation
description: The Justice Department has asked a federal appeals court for a broad ruling to authorize the use of secret evidence in cases in which it is trying to detain or deport immigrants it contends are in the country illegally. For national security reasons, the government argues that it should share secret evidence with only immigration judges and not with the immigrants and their lawyers.

title: Where Chinatown Reveals Itself
description: ON Waverly Place, a street adorned with the most beautiful painted balconies in San Francisco's Chinatown, I climb several flights of stairs inside the Sue Hing Benevolent Association building. I tiptoe past a second-floor ''traditional music and exercise'' club, where I spy no one warbling or working out, but plenty of elderly Chinese men watching Cantonese TV.

title: In the Greatest Evil, Finding What Is Most Human
description: ON Sept. 11, I was in Los Angeles. Being a New Yorker, I can't begin to tell you how disorienting that was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, EDWARD
description: KAPLAN-Edward, 44. of Old Westbury, formerly of Plainview, died of unexpected heart failure on December 7, 2001. Loving son of Robert Kaplan and the late Shirley Kaplan. He was a devoted husband to Penny and an extremely loving father to his children Heather and Lee. He is best known in business circles as one of the pioneers of creating adult home communities on Long Island as a founder of the Senior Care Group. He also built hotels, office buildings and other commercial properties. His most recent ventures included the opening of several storage quarters Self-Storage Facilities. He is survived by his sisters Linda and Deborah, and his brother Barton. His memory lives on in our hearts and souls of his many great friends and extended family. Charitable, generous and joyful to family and friends, Ed was a man who made everyone around him feel happy and special. We were fortunate to know him, love him, be loved by him and have him for these years. Services Sunday, December 9, 2001, 2 PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woobury, L.I.

title: The G.E. Racehorses, One Year Afterward
description: About this time last year, the horse race to succeed John F. Welch Jr. as the head of General Electric ( news/quote ) ended. Jeffrey R. Immelt got the job. In a nanosecond, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing ( news/quote ) snared W. James McNerney Jr., one of the two also- rans, and Home Depot ( news/quote ) grabbed Robert L. Nardelli, the other. Other companies in need of leadership could only watch with envy.

title: Sports of The Times; Ideal Combination: Coach and Teacher
description: WHILE participating in a conclave addressing thorny issues confronting major college basketball programs in Kansas City last summer, the longtime university educator and sports enthusiast Carol A. Cartwright found herself inspired by the passion of well-known coaches like Tubby Smith of Kentucky, Jim Boeheim of Syracuse and Roy Williams of Kansas.

title: Out of Harm's Way and Into the Unknown
description: DEBORAH OPPENHEIMER could never get her mother to open up about her wrenching childhood in Europe in the 1930's and 40's, to explain what it was like to have been torn from her parents at the age of 11, sent on a train out of Nazi Germany and into the care of a lord and lady who lived in a castle in England.

title: Troops Need Boots, So Closed Mill Will Reopen
description: In the blink-of-an-eye downtown that passes for the business district in this river town, the Prime Tanning leather factory is almost all there is. There is no doctor or supermarket to serve the 6,400 residents, and the town only just snared its first bank branch.

title: Defensive Play Helps Devils Perform Quick Turnaround
description: After a stretch of 10 games with one victory, the Devils have played the last four games with the patience and positional hockey that sent them to the Stanley Cup finals the last two seasons.

title: Where Touches of Green Match the Name
description: THE interior of Lime, a new dining spot here, glows in soothing, refreshing shades of lime -- on the walls, on the banquettes, and in the fruit stacked on the service bar at the entrance. Although limes make their appearance in several interesting dishes and drinks, Jonathan Dorf, the chef and owner of Lime, does not rely on that puckerish fruit as his one note. As much of his inspiration comes from fresh herbs, which he uses skillfully.

title: The Open-Source Celebrity
description: In the June 2001 issue of Esquire magazine, the writer Tom Junod published a profile of Michael Stipe, R.E.M.'s front man; about half of the profile was factual and half was made up. Junod portrayed Stipe as having said things he didn't actually say and having done things he didn't actually do.

title: Attaching Good Genes to Bad Viruses
description: Anxious about anthrax? Scared about smallpox? Then consider this: a special strain of virus, born in the laboratory, that's made up of equal parts Ebola and H.I.V. It may sound like the diabolical creation of terrorists, but in fact it's the product of research at the University of Pennsylvania's Institute for Human Gene Therapy. If scientists working there get their way, human patients will one day ingest these microbes as a way of curing genetic disorders.

title: Shifting Missions Come With Rising Risks
description: Inside Afghanistan

title: Attacks Aren't Keeping Students Close to Home
description: Contrary to predictions that high school seniors would choose colleges closer to home and avoid cities, especially New York, after Sept. 11, the attacks appear to have had relatively little effect on where they apply.

title: A Piece of a $50,000 Pie
description: WINNERS of the first Westchester Prize for New Works, established by the Westchester County Millennium Commission as its cultural legacy, have been named. The $50,000 prize will be shared equally among three Westchester arts organizations and their artistic partners: the Westchester Philharmonic and the clarinetist and composer Derek Bermel; Canticorum Virtuosi, parent organization of the New York Virtuoso Singers and the composer and cantor Gerald Cohen, and Project Ballet Theater and the dancer and choreographer Robert Hill.

title: HIRING FREEZE
description: Acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco imposed a state hiring freeze on all executive branch state employees except for state troopers, state hospitals and other institutions and family service specialists. Mr. DiFrancsco also cut $32 million in state spending from independent colleges, South Jersey Port Corporation subsidies and higher education grants and ordered all departments to search their individual budgets for another 5 percent trim, providing at least $200 million in savings. Jo Piazza

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATSURIS, KATHERINE
description: PATSURIS-Katherine, 66. Beloved wife and best friend of husband Theodore and loving mother of Penelope, succumbed to cancer on November 20. Kate was a passionate lifelong crusader for women's reproductive rights, working for Planned Parenthood for over three decades. She was a devoted wife and proud mother whose sharp wit and wonderful sense of the absurd will be sorely missed. The grace and courage with which she faced her illness continue to inspire us all. Mommy, wherever you are, you're always with us. Life is a banquet and you taught us to enjoy it on our own terms. Donations in her name can be made to the scholarship fund ''Young Voices for Choice,'' which was established in her honor. Planned Parenthood of Palm Beach and the Treasure Coast Area, 5312 Broadway, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: Lori Sherriton, Hugh Melnick
description: Lori Robin Sherriton and Dr. Hugh David Melnick were married last evening by Cantor Bruce Ruben at the Rihga Royal Hotel in Manhattan.

title: 'This Is the Beat Generation'
description: In 1979, living in Edinburgh, Scotland, I set out to write the story of the Beat Generation and its descendants. I had published only a little -- a few poems and articles in literary magazines -- but my projected book had a grand scheme. It would be divided into two parts: the first would describe the Westward trail blazed by Jack Kerouac and his mildly criminal gang in the late 1940s, while the other would trace the journey to the East made by the proliferating Beat children -- hippies, heads, freaks -- in the 1960s and 70s. I was among them, and therefore felt entitled to say "I am the man, I was" etc. The book would be called "Going West, Going East". I had thumbed my way across half the world, but had not yet set foot in the United States, so, in Edinburgh University Library, I studied maps to find the best way out of Queens, New York, where Kerouac waved goodbye to his mother on his first trip to Denver in July, 1947; filleted old newspapers for current events (was there any significance in the fact that both Henry Ford and Al Capone died that year?); and tried to see the bestseller list as Kerouac the would-be novelist might have seen it. The book people were talking about The Plague by Albert Camus, a carefully crafted political allegory, not his sort of thing at all. After a faltering start, Kerouac got on the road. I traveled with him all the way across a quire of foolscap before running out of steam.

title: Beauty Is Back
description: For at least the last hundred years, art has defined itself less by the pursuit of beauty than by suspicion of it. ''The impulse of modern art,'' Barnett Newman remarked in 1948, ''is the desire to destroy beauty.'' Modernism -- which began in Paris in the 1860's as a revolt against empty, academic prettiness -- unleashed the critical energies of art against its own aesthetic traditions. The art that came after modernism carried the criticism even further, placing the idea of beauty under permanent ideological suspicion. Artists from Francis Bacon to Damien Hirst, with their grisly subject matter; filmmakers from Godard to the Dogma 95 school, with their assaults on the audience's expectation of pleasure; musicians from Schnberg to Johnny Rotten, with their dissonant squalls: the recent art that has received the most attention has been that which challenges traditional canons of beauty -- and which, at times, challenges its audience's ability not to flinch.

title: Investing; Warming Up, a Bit, to Stock Offerings
description: INVESTORS have resumed dipping their toes into the market for initial public offerings. But with little prospect of making a fortune overnight, the buyers are more likely to be long-term shareholders than short-term opportunists.

title: Canada Relies On Discipline As Economy Slows Down
description: Finance Minister Paul Martin will present his budget to Parliament on Monday, and it is expected to demonstrate that the Canadian government is choosing a different way than the United States to deal with tough economic times.

title: Jokes Remain, but Many Say Bush Is Showing Signs of War's Burden
description: He may be a wartime president, but President Bush was hardly solemn during a meeting at the White House with a handful of lawmakers last month, days after he threw out the first pitch of a World Series game at Yankee Stadium.

title: The Oldest Tower: A Grand 7 Stories
description: BEFORE us is spread the most exciting, wonderful, and instructive view to be had on our continent . . . East and North Rivers and the bay appear as if at our feet, with their myriad flotillas of the navigable world. Suburban Brooklyn, Jersey City, Hoboken, Hudson City and Harlem are all plainly before us. Certainly not elsewhere in all New York can such another unobstructed bird's-eye view be had as from the open pavilions of the Equitable Life Assurance Society's building.''

title: A Troupe Endures, Always In Good Company
description: LIKE the indefatigable hero of Goldoni's ''Harlequin, Servant of Two Masters,'' the Piccolo Teatro of Milan is subject to two sets of seemingly irreconcilable responsibilities. As the artistic director of the theater, Luca Ronconi, enters his fourth year on the job, he is establishing a vision for the theater's future at the same time that he is upholding the distinguished tradition of his predecessor, Giorgio Strehler, who founded the theater in 1947 and directed its most memorable productions until his death in 1997.

title: Steganography Goes Digital
description: The microdot, a classic 20th-century spy tool, was once the ultimate in hidden writing, or steganography. Microdots are physically tiny, but can carry whole pages of data. They can be sneaked inside an innocent letter, disguised as part of a semicolon. But microdots are difficult to make and can't be copied easily. Plus, conspirators need microscopes to read them. The new, improved method of hidden writing is digital steganography. Each digital picture is made of thousands of tiny screen dots. Every such dot is identified by the computer with a long string of numbers, and a few of the characters in each string -- the ''least significant bits,'' as they are known -- don't matter much to humans. Their effects are invisible to the naked eye.

title: High-End Makeovers at Marked-Down Prices
description: It seems that retailers everywhere have lowered their prices to entice shoppers. So why shouldn't the beauty and health industry get in on it? In Manhattan, for example, a number of high-end spas, salons and studios are offering discounts to clients who want aesthetic or nutritional pick-me-ups.

title: At the Winter Meetings, Wheeling and Dealing Will Be High on the Agenda
description: Until Friday, baseball's off-season had moved at a rather tepid pace. Sure, the Yankees have been crawling toward a seven-year contract with Jason Giambi and will most likely sign him for close to $120 million in the next few days. Still, before Friday, the biggest free-agent signing had been John Smoltz's three-year, $30 million contract to return to the Atlanta Braves as their closer. Ho-hum.

title: Perfect Gentle Knights Return
description: LEOPOLD, the third Duke of Albany, the title character in the new movie ''Kate and Leopold,'' is a model of silken savoir faire. As played by Hugh Jackman, he is courtly but also refreshingly square, a man who can mount a steed or choose flowers for a lady with equal flair.

title: 'God Bless America': Born on Long Island
description: SINCE Sept. 11, Irving Berlin's ''God Bless America'' has been everywhere. But it began life on Long Island.

title: At Fresh Kills Landfill, Garbage Out, Grand Plans In
description: A methane-powered biosphere that creates winter year round. A pristine rookery for colonial wading birds. A World Trade Center memorial forest with distant views of the Manhattan skyline.

title: Megan Boyd, Who Made Tying Flies an Art, Dies at 86
description: Megan Boyd, whose fabled expertise at tying enchantingly delicate fishing flies put her work in museums and the hands of collectors around the world and prompted Queen Elizabeth II to award her the British Empire Medal, died Nov. 15 in Golspie, Scotland. She was 86.

title: Riverhead Stops Residential Subdivisions
description: Deluged by development, the Town of Riverhead has approved a six-month moratorium on residential subdivisions.

title: MY FIRST JOB; Radio Days, At a Tender Age
description: Ron Shaw, 63, is the president and chief executive of the Pilot Pen Corporation of America. Based in Trumbull, Conn., it is part of the Pilot Corporation of Japan. He joined the company as a national sales manager in 1975.

title: Nonromantic Dating
description: Since the code of courtly love swept through 12th-century France, romance has been understood to entail a certain amount of languishing, anguishing and wallowing. Perhaps it is that culturally ingrained expectation of pain that has allowed the current system of dating (and dumping) to persist without rival for this long. But this year, signs have begun to emerge that our idea of romance, with all its attendant anxiety, is finally facing competition from more practical models of courtship.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHEN, ROBERT S.
description: KIRSCHEN-Robert S. December 7, 2001 at age 53. Musician, music director and writer. Beloved husband of Norma and loving father of David. Devoted son of Mary and the late Max Kirschen. Dear brother of Edna Lieberman and Yaakov Kirschen. Good friend to many. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, 3:30 PM.

title: A United Cyprus?
description: To the Editor:

title: Iris Murdoch's Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: City Scraps Plan To Hire Big Firm
description: The Giuliani administration has abandoned plans to replace a city agency with a private construction company to run operations at the World Trade Center disaster site, a city official said yesterday.

title: Blame The Brokers
description: When the irrational exuberance has vanished, taking with it $4 trillion of capital from the nation's stock markets, who is to blame? A growing army of bellicose investors has come to believe that the culprit is not impersonal market forces or their own excess greed -- it's the brokers who are to blame. Aggrieved investors argue that the way reputable Wall Street firms like Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston pumped up Internet and technology stocks was no better than the notorious schemes of small-time ''boiler rooms,'' and they've filed an array of class-action lawsuits against major Wall Street firms and a record number of individual claims with the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Top of the List for Santa: Toys of Heroism and Rescue
description: JERRY BECKER and Judy Reda have been playing Santa and Mrs. Claus here for more than 10 years. In a decade on the job, Mr. Becker has heard wide-eyed children ask for everything from world peace to Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory. Wish lists, he said, are different this year.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Worth Noting column last week about Carl Lewis, the Olympian who was recently installed in the National Track and Field Hall of Fame, misstated the prospect for repairs at the Willingboro High School track, which is named for Mr. Lewis, a 1979 graduate. Work has indeed begun on the track; it started last month.

title: Front-Row Seats to the Streets Where They Live
description: THEY are the scene of countless first kisses. Their natural habitat covers Harlem, Greenwich Village, Brooklyn and beyond. They are tall, stately dames in limestone dresses, or brutish concrete slabs covered in grime. In any attire, they are immediately recognizable to anyone who grew up in New York.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, HAZEL
description: FREEMAN-Hazel. With profound sadness we mark the passing of Hazel Freeman, beloved wife of our former executive director, David Freeman. Our condolences to David and the Freeman children. Axel Rosin, Chair Emeritus Karen R. Sollins, Chair Sandra Silverman, President Scherman Foundation

title: In Florida, a New Emphasis on Design
description: BACK in 1981, a developer named Robert Davis set out from Miami on a sentimental journey through Florida. He had inherited 80 acres on the Gulf of Mexico in Florida's Panhandle, and he thought he would build a nostalgic beach town there. But nostalgia soon gave way to what came to be called ''New Urbanism,'' and the result was Seaside, a tiny resort town that has attracted wide praise for its planning and architecture. Today, Florida has become a showcase for smart -- in several senses of the word -- development, with new towns that feature buildings by an array of illustrious architects and gifted young designers.

title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: Ajami documents the anti-Americanism of Al Jazeera and states that this is one war that can't be won. He suggests that other Arabic news stations be given interviews by President Bush and other White House officials. But this would have little impact on anti-American attitudes. What is needed are interviews with Arab-Americans and other Americans of the Muslim faith who could show the freedom that exists in America to be a devout Muslim and to achieve professional success. This would be more effective than the solemn pronouncements of politicians.

title: Carrying Sticks and Hugging Trees
description: THEODORE REX

title: Corrections
description: Amap last Sunday with an article about suicide bombings in Jerusalem misidentified a main street shown. It was Jaffa Road, not Haifa Road.

title: Forget the Art -- It's All About the Building
description: It used to be that art museums were judged on the strength of their pictures. They made a point of acquiring classics like Rembrandt self-portraits, blurry waterlilies by Monet and Renoirs in curly gold frames. But nowadays, a new building is likely to create a bigger stir than a newly acquired Francis Bacon. So who needs good pictures, anyway? What today's museums really want is a signature building, preferably one that does not have a row of staid Doric columns out front.

title: Democrats Re-endorse Leader Of Nassau County Legislature
description: Just a day after a state oversight board approved a final budget for financially beleaguered Nassau County, the County Legislature's Democratic majority yesterday unanimously designated Judith A. Jacobs as its leader for a second term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, JUDITH SANDEN
description: ROGERS-Judith Sanden. Died on November 28, 2001, after a courageous battle with cancer. She was the headmistress of Saint Joseph's Episcopal School and president of the Schoolhouse Children's Museum, both in Boynton Beach, FL. She is survived by her daughter Jennifer N. Rogers, and brother Kenneth Sanden, both of New York City. Contributions in her memory may be made to Saint Joseph's School Endowment Fund, 3300B S. Seacrest Boulevard, Boynton Beach, FL. 33435.

title: 'Letters to a Young Lawyer'
description: Lawyers tend to be hero worshippers. Perhaps because we often work on an ethically ambiguous terrain, we need to create larger-than-life role models to look up to. We airbrush the warts of our heroes and turn them into saints who could do no wrong. Eventually, we learn the truth and we become disappointed, if not disillusioned. I know, since I have been through the process on several occasions.

title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: Your writer refers to the apparent incongruity of Al Jazeera's interposing a video of American bombs in Kabul with a view of life in Silicon Valley. This is not an example of incoherent programming, as Ajami suggests, but rather a deliberate attempt on the part of Al Jazeera to equate these events -- to show that, for Americans, there is no difference between sipping a cappuccino in Starbucks or dropping a bomb on Taliban ''martyrs'' in the heart of Afghanistan.

title: St. John's Reaches Final Four
description: St. John's soccer team advanced to the Division I men's final four by upsetting top-ranked and previously unbeaten Southern Methodist, 2-0, in Dallas last night.

title: Corporate Conformity
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: ERASED FACES

title: The World; Money Might Not Be Able To Buy Political Ties, Either
description: TAIWAN has led a separate existence since Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist forces fled there in 1949 after being routed by Mao Zedong's Communists. But in the last year, it began to tilt perceptibly toward its giant neighbor, China.

title: Perennials of the Literary Variety
description: BOOKSELLERS stock hundreds of books on cultivating tomatoes, growing rhododendrons and designing gardens. They also carry numerous volumes of garden essays, most often by writers who garden or gardeners who write.

title: An Avant-Garde Master Finds Art in the Everyday
description: ''IN Europe, they see me as a filmmaker; in Lithuania, I'm a poet; but here, in New York, I'm an archivist, a curator, a fund-raiser, that crank who runs the Anthology Film Archives,'' says Jonas Mekas, who is all those things and more. For nearly 50 years, he has energized, organized and sustained avant-garde film in America, while almost in secret making roughly two dozen films, some of which are among the great achievements of the genre.

title: Manifestoes for The Next New York
description: I enjoy new clothes, and I used to enjoy shopping for them. But for years I've had to keep my money in my pocket, the pocket I insist on having. I reject clothing that so clearly shows the fashion industry's desire for my money, with so obvious a lack of respect for me, the life I live and my desire for attractive garments that are as sturdy and useful as those sold to men.

title: Business; If a Name Is Tarnished, but Carved in Stone
description: VALETS were parking cars and assisting patients at the A. Alfred Taubman Health Care Center here last Wednesday when a federal jury in Manhattan convicted Mr. Taubman, principal owner of Sotheby's, in a price-fixing scheme.

title: Winning Isn't Everything
description: If Michael Jordan's career was supposed to exemplify anything, it was the bromide that championships -- winning -- equals greatness. What Jordan, coming out of retirement at age 38 to play for the Washington Wizards, seems to be promising this season is something new, even blasphemous, in the professional sports world of today: a beautiful loser.

title: PrivateSector; His Smoke Signals From Canada
description: When John Barnett, chief executive of the Canadian company Rothmans, made a friendly deal in late September to buy the Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Company, he started smoking Santa Fe's additive-free brand, Natural American Spirit, forsaking Rothmans's own Benson & Hedges. One of the few independent tobacco companies left in North America, Santa Fe was considered a prize because it was created after the health hazards of cigarettes became known, which immunized the company from lawsuits.

title: Dow Rises Above 10,000, and Stays There
description: Investors cleared some important psychological hurdles this week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average above 10,000 and the Nasdaq above 2,000 for the first time in months.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: 2 Former Officers And 4 Fateful Bullets

title: Recession Is Stretching the Limit on Welfare Benefits
description: Although the 1996 welfare law set a five-year limit for benefits, the economy is in recession at the very time the benefits are set to end, and many states are setting the deadlines aside for more and more recipients.

title: UZBEKS TO ALLOW OPENING OF BRIDGE ON AFGHAN BORDER
description: After weeks of diplomatic pressure from the United States, the president of Uzbekistan, Islam Karimov, agreed on Saturday to open a crucial bridge that could help speed urgently needed food and medical supplies from this Central Asian country to war-ravaged Afghanistan.

title: In Uncertain Times, Child Care Businesses Grow
description: EMPLOYERS are eliminating jobs around the country. The economy is officially declared to be in a recession. But child care businesses are expanding.

title: The View From/Woodbridge; A School Referendum Stirs Worry and Outrage
description: HE was only on the job a few weeks this summer when Andrew Potochney, Amity Regional School District's new finance director, was shocked to discover the district's $2.3 million budget shortfall.

title: Hempstead Trustees Rescind Wage Law
description: Trustees of the Village of Hempstead rescinded a law last week that set a $9 minimum hourly wage for its employees and those who work for companies subsidized by the village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRISCOLL, DAVID BURTON
description: DRISCOLL-David Burton. Died peacefully December 6, at age 59, after a heroic year-long battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Patricia Ellen Rowell, devoted father of Scott and Hannah, loving grandfather of Jack and Emma, and younger brother of Dr. Scott H. M. Driscoll. Graduate of Princeton University, class of 1964, and holder of an MBA from New York University. David was founder and president of Old New York Realty. He had a passion for nature, music and art and will be greatly missed for his intelligence, humor and grace. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, December 11, at 6 PM, at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Ave. and 29th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Harlem Valley Rail Trail Association, PO Box 356, Millerton, NY 12546.

title: Everybody's Child
description: CHEWED WATER

title: Mindy Krazmien, Daniel Miller
description: Mindy Melissa Krazmien, a museum curator, and Daniel A. Miller, a documentary film producer, were married last evening. Rabbi Gerald Zelizer performed the ceremony at Congregation Ahavas Sholom in Newark.

title: Jets Audio
description: Postgame audio from the Jets vs. the Pittsburgh Steelers provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Positive Asymmetry
description: The United States defense establishment has awakened to an unsettling paradox. America's military power vastly outstrips that of most potential adversaries, but unrivaled military superiority does not make the U.S. invulnerable to attack. Instead, Pentagon planners now realize, conventional military dominance only encourages potential adversaries to look for ''asymmetrical'' ways to neutralize our strengths by exploiting our vulnerabilities.

title: Washington Rewrites The Christmas Script
description: The security-related decision to cancel public tours of the White House during the holidays, along with the National Park Service restrictions on how close the public could stand to view of the lighting ceremony for the national Christmas tree last week, were disappointing to District of Columbia officials who were hoping for a revival of slumping tourism. But there are some new and slightly novel ways to make up for what's missing.

title: The Good Doctor Decoded
description: READING CHEKHOV

title: The White House Doesn't Need the Press
description: The Bush administration ushered in the era of the ''pressless presidency.'' It's a simple idea -- the press (more specifically, the national press) does not matter to the administration's success. When the Bush team first arrived in town, promising a White House free not only of leaks but also of administration in-fighting played out in the papers and of major-access features in magazines and on TV, political reporters laughed. A year later, no one in the press corps is laughing: the administration has clearly succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, A. SIDNEY
description: ROTH-A. Sidney. On Thursday, December 6, in Andover, MA; formerly of Palm Beach, FL and Massapequa, NY. Predeceased by his wife, Selma (Halpert). Survived by his children, Jonathan and Barbara of Westport, CT; Peter and Amy of Rochester, NY and Leslie and David Silverstein of Andover, MA and his grandchildren, David and Nancy; Michael and Deborah; Jamie; and Scott and Brett Silverstein. Loyal alumnus of Cornell University where he was an AllAmerican football player. Former president of the Long Island Association of Home Builders. Donations may be made in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611 or the American Diabetes Association, Memorial and Honor Program-NCC, P.O. Box 2680, North Canton, OH 44720.

title: In Plan to Help a Forest Heal, a Wider Rift Opens
description: When forest fires swept through the Bitterroot Valley and surrounding mountains south of here in the summer of 2000, they left hundreds of thousands of acres of burned timber, most of it on federal lands.

title: DROUGHT DECLARED
description: With reservoirs that feed the Delaware River holding just 24 percent of their water, the Delaware River Basin Commission last week declared the region is in a drought, marking the first winter drought conditions in 16 years. A commission spokesman, Chris Roberts, said that though winter was a time of lower water consumption, without above-average precipitation this winter, the situation could be severe in the spring. The Delaware River watershed serves seven million people in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware. The commission will hold a public hearing on Dec. 18 when the commissioners may declare a drought emergency that would allow tapping into backup water sources and could include conservation recommendations. Jill P.Capuzzo

title: By the Louvre, Bibelots, Brocade And Foie Gras
description: YOUR Paris stay is drawing to a close. You've resisted the siren charms of Shopping in favor of Architecture, Art and Gastronomy, but now the list of family and friends who expect to be remembered with gifts looms large. And, of course, there's that ''little something'' for yourself.

title: 'Molto Agitato'
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget Plastics. Go Find Subscribers.
description: A FEW months before he announced his retirement last week, Gerald R. Levin, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner, was asked about his grand vision for the company. He replied with just one word: ''Subscriptions.''

title: Ask Not What . . .
description: News anchor Tom Brokaw tells the story of meeting a young New York City fireman a week after Sept. 11. The fireman had just participated in a memorial service for some of his fallen colleagues and the two of them talked about the tragedy. ''As I said goodbye,'' Mr. Brokaw recalled, ''he grabbed my arm and his expression took on a tone of utter determination as he said, 'Mr. Brokaw, watch my generation now, just watch us.' '' As the author of the acclaimed ''The Greatest Generation,'' the story of the World War II cohort that saved America from Nazism, Mr. Brokaw told me he knew just what the man was saying: '' 'This is our turn to be a greatest generation.' ''

title: To Horse, or Not
description: Tallyho! The fashion world is off at full gallop, raiding the closets of equestrians for jodhpurs, boots, hacking jackets and even the saddle itself. But most people are not letting themselves be stampeded by the uncorralled fantasies of designers; they are taking pieces of riding outfits and integrating them into everyday casual sportswear.

title: Manifestoes for The Next New York
description: I have always felt that the women who most need to dress for functionality are flight attendants. They should wear clothing and shoes that enable them to help passengers in emergency situations -- and no synthetic material that might melt in high heat.

title: History Turns on the Tiniest Things
description: Foam, mauve, salt, nutmeg. The pencil, the compass, the martini. We're reading about the big picture through smaller and smaller units. This year, books like Amir D. Aczel's ''Riddle of the Compass'' -- which train their gaze on humble objects, but only in order to make grand, outsize claims -- became a genre in itself. The book jackets of these new histories typically boast that, as Aczel's subtitle proclaims, their subject is ''the Invention That Changed the World.''

title: Hybrid Cars
description: Most cars are at their gas-guzzling worst when they're crawling in bumper-to-bumper traffic. But in 2001, this logic was turned on its head. A new kind of car, the hybrid, is not only environmentally friendly -- it actually gets better gas mileage the longer you're stuck in stop-and-go hell.

title: A Time for Toys, and for Anxiety
description: WE never escape the tyranny of toys. We cherish toys when we are children and in a blink we are buying toys for our own children. When those children grow up, they are mysteriously replaced by grandchildren, then unbelievably by great-grandchildren. Siblings create nephews and nieces, who reproduce in their turn like fruit flies, and the sons and daughters of obscure cousins twice removed seem determined to overpopulate the earth single-handed. All of them together produce an insatiable demand for toys at this time of year.

title: Nebraska's Crouch Captures Heisman Trophy in Close Vote
description: Before his sophomore season, Eric Crouch briefly left the Nebraska football team. He had hoped to be the starting quarterback. His coach, Frank Solich, drove from Lincoln to Omaha and told him that he would start sooner rather than later.

title: Voucher Study Indicates No Steady Gains in Learning
description: A comprehensive study examining the research on the use of vouchers and charter schools for children attending substandard public schools has found no conclusive evidence that such programs consistently improve student achievement, though they do appear to raise satisfaction among parents.

title: Communal Bereavement
description: Anyone who has ever mourned the death of a loved one knows that grief can be a curiously somatic experience -- that the body can register sorrow as sensitively and as involuntarily as a seismograph, that sorrow can make you sick. Scientists have documented insomnia, depressed immune function, greater susceptibility to heart attacks and elevated levels of corticosteroids, the so-called stress hormones, in recently bereaved people. But a bereaved person is by definition someone who has lost an intimate. Is it even possible that vicarious grief -- grief for people you have never even known -- can afflict the body as well?

title: EXCITE NOT@HOME
description: Excite@Home, the pioneering developer of Internet services by cable TV lines, used to have nearly three million customers. But corporate wangling just cost 850,000 customers access. AT&T, the service's largest owner, balked at giving a bankrupt Excite $100 million-plus just to keep it in business. Excite will close for good Feb. 28; some of the AT&T customers who lost access waited as long as 10 days before being hooked to a replacement service. Saul Hansell

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 14 about a trans-Atlantic cruise from New York on the QE2 misstated terms of a $300 air fare offered by Cunard. The fare is for one-way flights between East Coast cities and New York, not between the East Coast and London. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Telesurgery
description: This September, two doctors in New York performed the world's first ''telesurgery'' operation -- on a patient 3,900 miles away in Strasbourg, France. From a room inside an office building in downtown Manhattan, Dr. Jacques Marescaux and Dr. Michel Gagner jointly performed a complete laparoscopic cholecystectomy (or gallbladder removal) on a 68-year-old woman in Hpital Civil in Strasbourg. By means of a wizardly mixture of high-speed fiber optics and surgical robots -- in this case, a setup known as the Zeus Telesurgical Robotic System -- the surgeons in New York were able to navigate around the patient's abdomen with precision. Although the Food and Drug Administration has not yet approved this procedure for widespread use, the operation was a striking success. Indeed, it may mark the beginning of a robotic revolution that will one day allow surgery to take place everywhere from remote battlefields to third-world countries that lack expert doctors.

title: High-End Makeovers At Marked-Down Prices
description: It seems that retailers everywhere have lowered their prices to entice shoppers. So why shouldn't the beauty and health industry get in on it? In Manhattan, for example, a number of high-end spas, salons and studios are offering discounts to clients who want aesthetic or nutritional pick-me-ups.

title: Justice Without Borders
description: Some crimes are so heinous, say legal experts, that they transcend jurisdictional boundaries. People accused of them should be prosecuted anywhere in the world, regardless of where the incident occurred -- and regardless of the nationality of anyone involved. But which crimes should fall under the umbrella of international justice? War crimes? Apartheid? Terrorism? Drug trafficking? There's no good answer; international justice can be a dismally ad hoc affair. So this year, 30 scholars and jurists had the bright idea of meeting to try and standardize this new realm of law.

title: Renowned From Trunk to Treetop
description: BY some estimates, there are more than 3,000 notable trees in Connecticut. What makes a tree notable?

title: Pick for NASA Says He Has Fiscal Mandate
description: Sean O'Keefe, President Bush's nominee to head NASA, the civilian space agency, said today that it should work more closely with the Defense Department and other agencies to reduce expenses and redundancy.

title: Global Antiretroviralism
description: With the establishment this year of the United Nations global fund for AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis, the world will nearly double its AIDS spending in 2002 -- and for the first time, much of the money in less-developed countries will go to antiretrovirals. At the beginning of 2001, AIDS drugs in Kenya or Ukraine cost the same as in the United States -- upward of $10,000 a year. But practically every week this year has brought a giddy new price drop for the third world. One Indian generic drugmaker, Cipla, now offers its triple-combination therapy for $350 a year. Multinational pharmaceutical companies, responding to competition from generics and widespread public criticism, have slashed prices for poor nations to a little over $1,000 -- although so far, the companies have attached so many obstacles to their offer that few places have been able to benefit.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday with an article about suicide bombings in Jerusalem misidentified a main street shown. It was Jaffa Road, not Haifa Road.

title: HomeGoods Opens Second County Store
description: With the recent opening of a HomeGoods store in Somers, the off-price home department store chain becomes the second one in the county, joining its Yonkers branch in offering trendy merchandise for the home to those in the northern reaches of the county. The store's opening adds 60 full- and part-time jobs to the local economy there.

title: An Old-Fashioned Man, A Pair of Loving Brothers, And a Jolly Snowboarder
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Your Very Own Breakfast Cereal
description: Advances in niche marketing have made it possible for Americans to buy a wide array of individually tailored products. At a Levi's store, you can be fitted for a pair of individual, custom-tailored jeans; online, you can order your own personally selected compilation CD. Now the power of niche marketing is being brought to your breakfast table. Next spring, General Mills is expected to introduce www.mycereal.com, a Web site that allows users to mix and match more than 100 different ingredients to create and name their own breakfast cereals, delivered to their homes in single-serving portions.

title: A Multilingual, Multispecies Effort To Clear the Minefields
description: THE SETTING -- Pamir, an Upper East Side Afghan restaurant. In a room hung with tribal rugs and photographs of village life, United Nations workers, Afghan-Americans and others feasted on kebab and scallion pastries. It was the first Night of a Thousand Dinners: at dinner parties around the world, guests donated money to ''adopt'' -- pay for clearance of -- a minefield in one of six countries littered with unexploded ordnance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, LILLIAN
description: ROSENBLUM - Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Louis Blitstein and David Rosenblum; cherished mother of Carol, Dovey (Martin), Robert (Harriet); adored and adoring grandmother of Joanne (Joel), Susan (Eric), Jon (Patty), Jim (Lone), Elizabeth, Melinda, Mark, Andrea; and great-grandmother of Adam, Alex, Emma, Liv, Harrison, Douglas. She lived 101 years giving and receiving love.

title: For Every Light, a Stargazer's Broken Heart

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWAN, PHILIP M.
description: COWAN-Philip M. The Officers, Trustees and Members of The Copyright Society of the U.S.A. mourn the passing of Philip M. Cowan, our Vice President/President-Elect on December 6, 2001, after a courageous battle with cancer. Phil was diagnosed with cancer just before our June 2000 Annual Meeting. He continued to attend Executive Committee Meetings and to participate in the life of the Society until recently. Phil was a dedicated, consistent and creative contributor to the Society over many years, serving as an officer, trustee, member of the Executive Committee and President-Elect. We are grateful not only for these contributions, but also for the warmth of his personality and his delightful sense of humor. Whether as a speaker, umpire of our annual softball game, a leading entertainment lawyer or a world-class bridge player, he brought insight, enthusiasm and energy to all his activities. Phil was a very special and beloved member of the Society. We will miss him sorely. We extend our deepest sympathies to Edna and the rest of Phil's family, his colleagues at the law firm he founded, and all those who have been touched by his life. The Copyright Society of the U.S.A. Robert J. Bernstein, President

(Weldon didn't try to hide anything; she called her book ''The Bulgari Connection.'') The literary world's moralists were, predictably, outraged. title: Tele-immersion
description: September's suicide jet attacks have given business travelers a new reason to stay on the ground. When it isn't absolutely necessary to fly, many are now trying teleconferencing instead. But teleconferencing, in its current form, has many drawbacks, including poor sound and image quality and unacceptable delays. Plus there is the eye-contact problem. Because the camera and the monitor are not in the same spot, it appears to the person with whom you're interacting that you're shifty or aren't paying attention. Worse, if the camera is mounted on top of the monitor, it looks as if you're trying to peek down the shirt of the person you're talking to. title: Old Masters Cheated
description: The exhibition ''Thomas Eakins: American Realist,'' on display this winter at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, celebrates the 19th-century artist as a painter of genius. But a close look at the exhibition's placards reveals a disconcerting truth: some of history's great painters relied on more than just inspiration. Commenting on ''Sailboats Racing on the Delaware,'' the curators note the ''remarkable precision'' of Eakins's 1874 canvas. Then they quietly drop a bomb: ''When conservators . . . recently examined his paintings, they discovered that Eakins actually projected photographs directly onto canvases. In this painting, the center boat and far right boat were painted using projections.'' The other boats in the picture, alas, look rather less seaworthy.

title: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; Software Is Free Speech
description: In the fall of 1999, a journalist named Eric Corley told the readers of his magazine how to acquire a short program called DeCSS that would let them view encrypted Digital Video Discs, or DVD's, on their computers. The Motion Picture Association of America, fearing loss of control of its content, sued him and persuaded a federal judge to order Corley to remove the program from his Web site -- and then later, to remove links to other sites where the code could be found. Corley has mounted an aggressive defense, and the case has been winding its way through the court system ever since. Written on a page, the DeCSS code looks innocuous enough: a dozen or so lines of letters, numbers and punctuation marks. But when it's run as a computer program, it performs a very specific action: it disables the encryption on a commercial DVD. And so the essence of the DeCSS case is a debate over the legal status -- and in fact the very nature -- of these few lines of code. Is the program a machine, subject to government regulation like a car or a gun? Or is it language, protected by the First Amendment?

Nate Fisher, the oldest sibling on Alan Ball's HBO drama ''Six Feet Under,'' is a 36-year-old whose entire life has been driven by rebellion against his funeral-director father. Instead of emulating his dad, he has worked halfheartedly at an organic grocery store; disdaining suits, he purposely dresses (and behaves) like a college boy on the prowl, his face covered in three-day stubble. Margot, the failed playwright in Wes Anderson's new film ''The Royal Tenenbaums,'' has been married for years to a famed cognitive scientist, but she sure doesn't act like it: she wears the same tattered coat she bought in high school, spends entire days sulking in the bathtub -- and sneakily hides her cigarette smoking from her mother. And Chip Lambert, the 39-year-old at the center of Jonathan Franzen's novel ''The Corrections,'' is a childishly impulsive slacker who shoplifts salmon at Manhattan grocery stores the way some kids pinch Twizzlers at the 7-Eleven: by stuffing it in his pants.

title: Dear Diary: I'm Locked in a Basement
description: Guy Burt's first novel, which became a cult favorite in England after it was published there in 1993, is about five teenagers who allow themselves to be locked in a school cellar for three days as a prank, or, as the charismatic mastermind behind this plan describes it, ''an experiment in real life.'' It goes without saying that things go horribly wrong. Burt was 18 when he wrote THE HOLE (Ballantine, $19), and the book is being published in America now to coincide with an upcoming film adaptation starring Thora Birch. Fans compare the book to ''Lord of the Flies,'' but it never reaches the heights -- or, better, the depths -- of William Golding's classic. Still, it's a chilling little book. More akin to ''The Blair Witch Project'' than ''Lord of the Flies,'' the story unfolds in the third person and in the journal entries of one of the teenagers, and the writing is remarkably assured for such a young author. The characters, who are vulnerable because nobody knows they're in the basement except Martyn, the boy who put them there, follow a predictable path of early camaraderie, then mild squabbling and finally utter breakdown as the awful realization hits that Martyn is not returning. A twist at the end will -- if you don't find it simply annoying -- intrigue you with the new levels of meaning it lends to a story about that most elemental of human fears, being buried alive. King Kaufman

title: Why Grade Inflation Is Serious

A recent report by the dean of the faculty of arts and sciences revealed that half the grades awarded to undergraduates in recent years have been either A or A-. The school is hardly the only institution of higher learning that has been troubled by nagging doubts about whether the line between mediocrity and real achievement is being blurred. The grading systems at American universities deserve to be re-evaluated, but it is important that the work be done on the basis of real data rather than guesswork.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, MOE
description: KESSLER-Moe. Lifelong NYC resident as well as the founder, president and CEO of Outwater Plastics Industries and Architectural Products by Outwater, died on December 4th in Manhattan. Kessler, who, with the love and support of his late wife, Sylvia and their two sons, Richard and Peter, went on to establish Outwater Plastics Industries in August of 1972. Outwater Plastics was founded on the premise of providing small furniture and cabinet manufacturers with a source from which they could purchase extruded plastic mouldings in quantities that actually reflected their requirements rather than the set substantial minimum quantities dictated by the plastic extrusion manufacturers at the time. Kessler, however, did not start his career in the Plastics Industry. Upon his discharge from the Navy, Kessler went to work for a large wholesale hardware company in New York City. It was quite by chance that Kessler began to experiment with Plastics. Having realized the potential advantages in manufacturing with and use of this then new material, Kessler decided to examine the suitability of manufacturing mouldings out of Plastic instead of the conventional materials from which they were then being produced. As Kessler had accurately envisioned, it was not long before his initial Plastic products became a huge success. Kessler began to manufacture other Plastic extruded mouldings that, up until that point, had only been available in metal. Each new success readily spawned another. The Plastics Industry began to prosper, thus giving way to more products. Not only did Kessler serve to open the manufacturers' eyes to numerous products that had not previously been available, because the Plastics manufacturers simply could not cater to the needs of the small furniture and cabinet manufacturers, through default, Outwater Plastics became the first Plastics distributor in the industry. From the vendor of a single product back in August of 1972, today Outwater Plastics and its corporate affiliate, Architectural Products by Outwater, with facilities in New Jersey and Arizona, are recognized as a major international supplier of nearly 40,000 standard and innovative component products to numerous industries. Best remembered for his generosity and contributions that he has made to the lives of everyone who knew him, Kessler attributed the success of Outwater Plastics and Architectural Products by Outwater to the dedication and hard work of its employees, whom he referred as his ''best investment in the whole world.'' Kessler further cited the generosity and support of his charter vendors, all who believed in Kessler and his dream to help keep his then young company operational in the early days. Kessler ultimately credited his success to Sylvia (nee Wallace), his wife of over forty years, who predeceased him in 1995. It was her wisdom and inspiration, in conjunction with his foresight and ability, not to mention ''Luck'' that helped Moe Kessler to realize his dreams. Kessler is survived by his second wife, Linda, his two sons, Richard and Peter, daughter-inlaw, Susan, and was the beloved grandfather of Stephen, Faye Lauren and William. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday, December 9th at 2:30 PM.
