title: 'Rainbow's End: The Crash of 1929'
description: If it is tree, as historian Jacques Barzun once observed, that "whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn about baseball," the 1920 season serves as a revealing emblem of both the country's past and its future. The game was in disarray and disrepute, wracked by internal bickering and reeling from the infamous Black Sox scandal in which eight members of the Chicago White Sox had been charged with accepting bribes to throw the 1919 World Series to the Cincinnati Reds. It had also been stunned by tragedy that summer when Cleveland Indians shortstop Ray Chapman died after being hit by a pitched bail—the first and only major leaguer killed by an injury on the field.

title: What Will the Card Say?
description: The United States Postal Service has seldom been called hiply retro, but a stamp it will issue honoring New Jersey has a design that fits that description. Last week it unveiled a Greetings From America series of 34-cent stamps. One emblazoned with ''Greetings From New Jersey'' depicts a beachcomber with an umbrella skewed to the side overlooking a stylized version of the Atlantic City skyline. The stamp is not as bucolic, as, say, the one from Maine, with a moose in a field before a lighthouse, or Montana's, which shows a cowboy amid snow-capped mountains. But neither is it as urban as that from Ohio, with its bridge going into downtown Cleveland, or the one from Illinois, which depicts, incongruously, a few ears of corn overlooking some tall Chicago buildings. The stamp will be available on a sheet with those from the other states in April. On the back of each will be its state bird, flower, tree, capital and the date it entered the union. For New Jersey that means American goldfinch, violet, red oak, Trenton and Dec. 18, 1787. Robert Strauss

description: Last winter Louis Rastelli, a struggling Montreal publisher, found himself suddenly in need of a brand-new distribution method. Rastelli's solution: buy some surplus cigarette machines -- the Canadian government had recently restricted them in restaurants, and so they were in plentiful supply -- and retrofit them into coin-operated delivery devices for art, literature and music. The ''Distroboto'' was born.

But nothing that has been tried in efforts to replace laces -- not Velcro, not zippers -- has been simpler. Until now.

But OPEC delayed cutting production anyway, saying it wanted to be sure about other nations' promised cuts. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Pharmacogenomics
description: Prescribing drugs is more of a specialized art than a precise science. Given identical drug dosages, patients suffering from the same disease will often experience radically different outcomes. Doctors have long chalked this up to ambiguous ''patient variation,'' relying on trial and error to figure out which drugs to prescribe for an individual, and in what quantity, to treat acute diseases while minimizing side effects. That's changing, however, thanks to pharmacogenomics, a brand-new field of research that promises to personalize medical treatment by examining how an individual's genetic makeup influences responsiveness to drugs.

title: Open Sperm Donation
description: In the early days of assisted reproduction, sperm donors were always anonymous and the need to keep them that way was supposed to trump any curiosity or confusion their future offspring might feel about them. Men would never donate sperm, the thinking went, if they knew that children might grow up and search them out -- and couples using donor insemination would want to keep it a secret, if only to protect a husband sensitive about his infertility. Over the last few years, though, donor offspring have begun arguing that they, like adoptees before them, have a compelling right to information about their biological parents. Fueled by renewed faith in the importance of genes and by the victories of open-adoption advocates, the so-called identity-release movement is now leading sperm banks across the country to change the way they do business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSHMORE, LEON
description: RUSHMORE-Leon. An active member of the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers), Westbury Meeting, died on December 5th at Stonybrook Hospital. He was 91. The cause was heart failure. A graduate of Friends Academy in Locust Valley, New York, and of Swarthmore College, in Swarthmore, Pennsylvania, he was a lifelong member of the Religious Society of Friends, Westbury Meeting. In addition, he was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Westbury Friends School. A true practitioner of the peaceful ways of the Religious Society of Friends, he possessed a great love of his fellow man and instinctively reached out to offer assistance to those less fortunate. His passion for people was evident in his optimistic manner and his talent for affirming the most positive characteristics of those with whom he interacted. His real gift was an ability to move groups with diverse interests to a common goal using a wonderful blend of verbal and written communication skills. Mr. Rushmore always gave generously of himself. At an early age, he became interested in the field of health care and became a well recognized figure at numerous Long Island medical associations and facilities. He served on the New York State Board of Medical Ethics and was Trustee Emeritus for Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, New York, where he had been associated for more than 50 years. A native Long Islander, Leon Rushmore was born in Roslyn Heights. His professional career was spent at the Long Island Lighting Company where he retired as Vice President of Employee Relations in 1975. Active in fund raising for numerous charitable organizations, he was also a Board Member of Planned Parenthood and a Founding Board Member of Friends of Long Island Heritage. In February 1932, he married Caroline Jackson of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and the young couple took up residence on the family farm in Roslyn Heights, where in addition to their professional careers, they operated several vegetable stands during the war years of the 1930s and '40s. They shared a love for the game of tennis and actively engaged in the sport until prohibited by health restrictions, at which point they became faithful observers of popular matches. Influential in developing legislation for life care facilities in New York State, he and Caroline were the initial residents at a model life care facility, Jefferson Ferry, in Port Jefferson, New York. In addition to his beloved wife, he is survived by his two daughters, Mary Lee Rushmore of New Harbor, Maine, and Carly Hellen of Chicago, Illinois, and his son, Stephen Rushmore of Roslyn Heights, New York as well as five grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 pm on Saturday, January 5th at the Westbury Meeting House (Religious Society of Friends), 550 Post Avenue, Westbury, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the Westbury Friends School, 550 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: Weather-Forecasting
description: Toast Never has the British phrase ''breakfast news'' been so literal in the execution. In June, an industrial-design student at England's Brunel University named Robin Southgate unveiled a toaster that actually sears the day's weather forecast onto the surface of a piece of bread. The $2,150 prototype doesn't offer much detail. Your slice pops up with a simple icon of the day's outlook: a shining sun, a cloud or raindrops, all of which inform a toast-friendly nation without the bother of newspapers or radio weather reports. The mechanism operates normally until the final 20 seconds of the heating cycle when, thanks to a microprocessor connected via telephone to a Web server, a heat-resistant stencil rolls out and brands the bread with the appropriate icon.

title: 'Theodore Rex'
description: On the morning after McKinley's interment, Friday, 20 September 1901, a stocky figure in a frock coat sprang up the front steps of the White House. A policeman, recognizing the new President of the United States, jerked to attention, but Roosevelt, trailed by Commander Cowles, was already on his way into the vestibule. Nodding at a pair of attaches, he hurried into the elevator and rose to the second floor. His rapid footsteps sought out the executive office over the East Room. Within seconds of arrival he was leaning back in McKinley's chair, dictating letters to William Loeb. He looked as if he had sat there for years. It was, a veteran observer marveled, "quite the strangest introduction of a Chief Magistrate . . . in our national history."

Steinerman of Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Mandelbaum is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Agudath Sholom.

description: My most indelible memory from high school is getting a Coke and peanut-butter cheese crackers from the vending machine at lunchtime and working on my translation of Julius Caesar's ''Commentaries.''

title: The Challenge: Criticizing Bush's Policies Without Attacking Bush
description: With President Bush's popularity rating in the stratosphere and the country solidly behind the war on terrorism, Democrats have adopted a delicate strategy for winning control of Congress in next year's elections and positioning themselves for challenging the president in 2004.

title: The Mission District: Affordable and Fun
description: I KNOW of no other North American neighborhood where you can have as much fun and eat in as many different, affordable restaurants as you can in the Mission District of San Francisco. The dot-com boom bought tons of new money here, and two years ago, when pioneering yuppies had gentrified the Mission -- or ruined it, depending on your perspective -- I began visiting regularly. There were a few restaurants I already knew: the venerable Taquera, the 10-year-old crperie called Ti Couz, and the newer Universal Cafe (actually in nearby Potrero Hill), Delfina, and the Slanted Door.

title: Bright Lights, Big Retail
description: THE young professionals nesting in this mushrooming city's Newport and Avalon Cove waterfront developments can cradle their Zest in a Tommy Hilfiger soap dish. The fashionable recent arrivals in the Porto Fino or Gotham high-rise buildings can wash their hands of second-tier department stores and dry them with Ralph Lauren bath towels.

description: AFTER reading Neil Baldwin's latest book, one might be forgiven for thinking that Henry Ford was nothing but a loon.

But there was plenty of debate over this question: How did HBO manage to get so good so fast?

title: Education Isn't Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Microart That Can Suggest Macrotruths
description: THE current vogue for large-scale artworks does not faze Paul Pfeiffer. He is mad for the miniature. ''Race Riot,'' for example, his startling new video, is only as large as the tiny pop-out screen on a digital camera. The peepholelike presentation of the piece, which is mounted on a pedestal in a tall glass vitrine, might seem more appropriate for a display of insect specimens than a work of contemporary art. But there is a reason behind it. ''It forces concentration,'' Mr. Pfeiffer explains, ''and a very intimate distance with the viewer.''

title: Black, White and Blue: The Layoffs at Steinway
description: Pianos, the workers at the Steinway factory in Astoria will tell you, are more like humans than you'd think. It takes nine months to build one. Its wood does not respond well to extreme cold or humidity.

title: Road to the Dome Began With a Dream
description: BACK in 1997, when Dobbs Ferry High School did not have a football team to call its own, Jamie Block was the first to dream about the Dome.

title: Alexandra Meckel, Troup Parkinson
description: Alexandra Carlyn Meckel, a daughter of Gail and Wilfred Meckel II of New York, was married yesterday to Anthony Troup Parkinson, the son of Joy Hirshon Ingham of New York and Anthony Parkinson of Miami. The Rev. Charles Papa performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: DECEMBER 2-8: ECONOMY; ENRON BOTTOMS OUT
description: Once the world's dominant energy trader, Enron capped its rapid collapse by filing the largest corporate bankruptcy in American history as well as a $10 billion lawsuit against its crosstown rival, Dynegy, for calling off their merger. Days before, it gave out $55 million in bonuses to 500 key workers. Richard A. Oppel Jr.

title: CRIME
description: ''When the phone rang, Parker was in the garage, killing a man.'' After dispensing with that little chore, Richard Stark's nihilistic hero spends the rest of FIREBREAK (Mysterious Press/Warner, $23.95) trying to get down to the real work of a criminal of his talents -- robbing an obnoxious billionaire of the old-master paintings he has stolen and stashed in his Montana hunting lodge. But Parker and his gang are beset by the vagaries of their trade, and some old scores have to be settled first. The contractor who put out a hit on Parker must be tracked down; the criminals staking the art heist need to be mollified; and something has to be done about Larry (''We all know Larry; he's O.K., but he gets too emotional''), the electronics whiz who is the weak link in their enterprise. By the time the gang arrives at the hunting lodge, the place is crawling with law.

title: A Tree Glows in the Bronx: An 18-Footer Near the Bruckner
description: Replace Mayor Giuliani with Marta Rivera, the chairwoman of Community Board 2. Substitute the Casita Maria Choir for the pop group Destiny's Child. Then shrink the tree 63 feet, exchange the ice rink for the Bruckner Expressway and there you have it: Hunts Point's answer to the Christmas tree lighting at Rockefeller Center.

title: Word for Word/Jihad Lit; Beware of Hidden Enemies And Their Wolves and Foxes
description: CONFLICTING reports last week suggested that Dr. Ayman al-Zawahiri, one of Osama bin Laden's top lieutenants, might have died or lost his wife and several children when American bombs struck Taliban bases in the Afghan mountains. Whatever his fate, Dr. Zawahiri, a 50-year-old Egyptian surgeon, is viewed as the man who convinced Mr. bin Laden to undertake a kind of death match against Western civilization by transforming his worldwide movement of Islamic militants into an instrument of mass murder.

title: 'From the Dust Returned'
description: At first, A Thousand Times Great Grandmère said, there was only a place on the long plain of grass and a hill on which was nothing at all but more grass and a tree that was as crooked as a fork of black lightning on which nothing grew until the town came and the House arrived.

title: Announced Assassinations
description: Last November, the Israeli government adopted a new strategy to combat suicide terrorism: precise, sometimes public military assassinations of leaders and operatives in the various Palestinian groups conducting armed attacks against them.

title: New Rochelle Is Eating Better Lately
description: Westchester residents in search of crusty breads baked in the European tradition and freshly picked fruits and vegetables at reasonable prices are traveling in increasing numbers to a corner of New Rochelle where they can be found in abundance. Mayor Timothy C. Idoni said that among his city's many attractions are the food markets springing up in the downtown area in recent months that reflect the ethnic diversity of the city.

title: How Do You Lose A Vice President?
description: WHITE House protestations that ''vice presidents have often disappeared for months without anyone noticing'' have failed to lower the eyebrows raised by Dick Cheney's continued absence from the public eye.

title: Simputer
description: The most significant innovation in computer technology in 2001 was not Apple's gleaming titanium PowerBook G4 or Microsoft's Windows XP. It was the Simputer, a Net-linked, radically simple portable computer, intended to bring the computer revolution to the third world. The Simputer, officially unveiled last April and intended for mass production in India next March, is a small hand-held device designed for the rough conditions of rural India. It operates -- without a keyboard -- through touch, sound and simple visual icons. It translates English-language Web sites into local Indian languages, reading the content aloud to illiterate users.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 30 about a pipe organ installed at Christ Church in New Brunswick misstated the rarity of the type. It is one of the few handmade mechanical-action pipe organs in the state custom built for a specific setting; there are several mechanical-action pipe organs -- more than two. A reader reported the error in November, and this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREDITOR, HILLY
description: CREDITOR-Hilly. Died on December 6, 2001, at the age of ninetythree and one half, survived by two loving sons, Paul and Richard; Richard's wife, Dayle; and Paul's special love, Ellen, as well as three grandchildren and their spouses who truly adored him, Jay and Karen; Jaime and Stuart and Jodi and Craig. He also leaves three great-grandchildren who will miss his kindness, humor and love, Amanda, Samuel and Anne and Ellen's son, Paul. Also surviving and sure to miss him are his lifelong pal and brother-in-law, Bernie; special friend, Bert Black, his aide whom he adored; Vera Rankine, and all the friends he met and kept on his travels around the world with his wife Lee and his sons. He sailed the world on more than 30 cruises and visited more than 70 countries worldwide. He was blessed with energy and spirit until the end and will be missed and always remembered by all the friends and relatives he leaves behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANCIGER, RUTH E.
description: DANCIGER-Ruth E. Of Lakewood, NJ. December 5. Age 94. Beloved sister of the late Herbert and Melvin Danciger. Survived by sisters-in-law Beulah and Lenore and four nieces and a nephew. Cherished aunt and devoted friend.

title: Researchers Differ Over Generating Neurons in Brain
description: Yale and Princeton are scrapping over an issue less simple than football but probably of greater consequence, how the human brain works.

title: He's No Bob Dole, but He's Still a Celebrity
description: THE manager of Golden Lady, the landmark gentlemen's club in the South Bronx with the 15-foot neon marquee of a woman swimming in a martini glass, did not immediately realize there was a celebrity in his midst.

title: Landmark Chicago Store to Be Restored
description: CHICAGO

title: Apes Have Culture, Too
description: In a recent article published in the scientific journal Nature, the British evolutionary psychologist Andrew Whiten presented the results of seven behavioral studies of African chimps by nine prominent authors -- including Jane Goodall, celebrated for her work at the Gombe reserve in Tanzania, and Toshisada Nishida, the famed primatologist who works in the Mahale Mountains nearby. Collating this research, Whiten concluded that there were 39 major behavioral differences between African chimp groups that could only be attributed to learning, not instinct. What this means is profound: humans are not the only animals that create -- and pass on -- cultural traditions.

title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: Although poverty, injustice and servitude may similarly compel the disenfranchised to an interest in Osama bin Laden or Che Guevara, the comparison of bin Laden to Guevara more usefully shows the difference between a freedom fighter and a terrorist. Guevara never targeted civilians, and he did not divide the world between good and evil, infidels and the chosen. Osama is feared. Che was, and still is, loved by millions.

title: Perspective; After a Year at Speed, These Books Offer a Chance for Some Reflection
description: Many of the pages I turned in 2001 are marked by oil, beer or barbecue sauce, reminders of my Year at Speed. An unusually high percentage of those stained auto racing books will remain on my shelf, and some I will even recommend for the gift-giving season.

title: The Right Not to Be Born
description: Leave it to France, home of the ''Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen,'' to take the lead in pioneering a hitherto undreamed-of human right: the right not to be born. This year France's highest appeals court ruled that a baby born with a severe handicap is entitled to compensation if the mother was not given the opportunity to have an abortion -- even though that would have meant the nonexistence of the plaintiff. The landmark case concerned an 18-year-old boy whose mother came down with German measles while she was pregnant with him. Since doctors failed to diagnose this illness, the mother went ahead and had the child, who is now deaf, mentally retarded and nearly blind.

title: Dropper Popper
description: This is the toy for the ex-dot-com millionaire reduced to living in his mother's basement. This is the toy you can keep on your desk to remind you of the quality of resilience in hard times. This is the Austerity Toy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLASSMAN, HARRY (BOB)
description: GLASSMAN-Harry (Bob). It's been a long time since you left. Think of you every day. Love you. Say hello to Mom and Ellie. Morty

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTELSMANN, HEINZ O.
description: BERTELSMANN-Heinz O. The Bard College community deeply mourns the passing of Heinz O. Bertelsmann, professor emeritus and longtime friend of the college. For more than 30 years he shared his keen intellect and deep humanity with Bard's students and faculty as a professor of international relations. Over the past two decades the vitality, dedication, and generosity of Heinz and his wife Lilo continued to play an essential role in the life of the college. We extend our deepest condolences to Lilo and to his entire family. He will be sorely missed. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman

title: In a London Park
description: To the Editor: ''Sitting With Memories in a London Park,'' by Marylin Bender (Nov. 11), rekindled my memories of buying a bench in another London park as a gift for my husband, Seymour.

title: For Britain, Euro Is Invasion It May Have to Invite
description: Deep in southeast England, this ancient village of turreted towers and beamed cottages was named for the Battle of Hastings, when William, the Norman conqueror from across the channel, overwhelmed the forces of King Harold in 1066 to begin the conquest of olde Englande. These days, some suspect another intrusion from roughly the same direction could be in the offing.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday comparing the nation's reaction to Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor with the reaction after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 misstated a word in a famous comment from President Roosevelt. In a speech the day after the Japanese attack, he said Dec. 7, 1941, was ''a date which will live in infamy,'' not ''a day which will live in infamy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTER, GARNET H. (GARY)
description: CASTER-Garnet H. (Gary). On Saturday, August 11, 2001, passed away peacefully at St. Michael's Hospital, Toronto, Canada after a long and courageous battle with Alzheimer's disease. He was age 86. Garnet dedicated his life to the pursuit of learning & the education of children and youth. He later expanded that role to include psychiatric social work in the Edmonton Public School System, Alberta, Ca. He tirelessly dedicated his free hours to community service and volunteer efforts to improve the lives of those around him. Lovingly remembered by all the family. Family may be reached at 416481-5846/780-466-8228.

title: Virtual Cities, From the Suburbs
description: Earlier this year, when the Port Authority leased the World Trade Center complex, Graphic Chart and Map of Hastings-on-Hudson was hired to create graphics for the offering memorandum. The company prepared a suite of images, including everything from transit maps of the surrounding area to elevator charts for the Towers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALEM, JACK
description: HALEM-Jack. Happy 100th Birthday in heaven. With love, your children, grandchildren, and 10 beautiful great-grandchildren.

title: Campo Makes, and Wins, Points
description: Late last month, Cowboys Coach Dave Campo did something that endeared him to several of his veterans, who believed some players were not taking the season seriously.

title: Unicef Says Afghan Children Need Immediate Aid to Survive
description: The executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund says that the organization is striving to provide the basics of food and water to ensure the survival of an estimated 1.5 million children in Afghanistan who are at the greatest risk.

title: Laptop Composing
description: A few years ago, people were talking about the virtual office, which allowed workers to stay home and connect to the workplace via computers. The trend was short-lived (it turns out that most people like having a nonvirtual office). But these days, musicians are embracing the idea of a virtual recording studio. No episode of the MTV program ''Cribs,'' which takes viewers inside the mansions of pop-music stars, is complete until we've seen the artist's home studio, where he can lay down tracks whenever inspiration hits. And now, using laptop computers and simple keyboards, people can create music wherever they roam.

title: The Video-Game Workout
description: A defining characteristic of video games has long been their high couch-potato quotient. The only exercise a person could expect to get punching buttons and moving a joystick was the kind of wrist workout that put them at risk for repetitive stress injury. Playing the video game called Dance Dance Revolution, however, is nothing less than a full-body aerobic activity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACK, J. PHILIP
description: STACK-J. Philip. The Vision Fund of America (VFA) is deeply saddened by the passing of Phil Stack, a founding member and first Chairman. Through the VFA, Phil, a retiree of the Sony Corp., worked tirelessly to encourage professionals within visual media industries, to ''give something back.'' For nearly twenty years, VFA's support of Lighthouse International has assisted in promoting independence for individuals who are blind or partially sighted. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Gayle. Donations may be made in his honor to the VFA Memorial Funds, 111 East 59th Street, New York, New York 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFAND, NAOMI
description: HELFAND-Naomi. 96, West Palm Beach, FL. Loving wife of the late State Supreme Judge Julius Helfand. Devoted mother of Joan and Robert and grandmother, and great-grandmother.

title: Final Word On Housing In Yonkers
description: THE decision last week by the U.S. Supreme Court to stay out of Yonkers's 20-year desegregation battle turned out to be a victory for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a disappointment for the city's mayor and another confusing twist for parents of the city's 26,000 students.

title: G.O.P. Enlists Women in Missouri Effort
description: As Republicans gear up to try to reclaim control of the Senate next year, they view Senator Jean Carnahan of Missouri as one of the most vulnerable Democrats. They note that she did not win the seat in her own right, but was instead appointed to fill it after the death of her husband, Mel. The Republicans contend that she is a political novice who will not be able to fend off their more experienced candidate, former Representative Jim Talent.

title: His Status Uncertain, Chaney Takes Control
description: On the Knicks' bench last night, the difference between the team's former coach and its new one was measured in what was missing: a can of diet soda and any trace of emotion.

title: Sitting Down With Frank Lloyd Wright
description: IN the early 1940's the Iowa businessman Lowell Walter wrote to Frank Lloyd Wright asking that he design a home for him. Wright's reply -- in its entirety -- read: ''My dear Mr. Walter: We will design a dwelling for you. Send further details. There will be no basement nor any attic.''

title: After 500 Years, Leonardo Gets His Bridge
description: A sweepingly modern footbridge, based on plans drawn up by Leonardo da Vinci in 1502, has just been completed by the Norwegian artist Vebjorn Sand in collaboration with the Norwegian transportation ministry. The 330-foot-long laminated timber bridge links Norway and Sweden over a highway at the town of Aas, 16 miles south of Oslo.

description: IF there were any investors out there who still thought AOL Time Warner was first and foremost an Internet company, the ascension last week of Richard D. Parsons to chief executive-to-be brought them out of their new-economy reverie.

description: A new study in a British medical journal has stirred a passionate debate among doctors in Europe and the United States by asserting that mammograms do not prevent women from dying of breast cancer or help them avoid mastectomies.

description: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE said that there are seven ages of man: infant, schoolboy, lover, soldier, justice, pantaloon and second childishness.

title: A Common Element in a Condo
description: Q I am a unit owner and member of the board of a condominium in lower Manhattan. The condominium association consists of several brownstone-type buildings. Next to one of the buildings is a paved area that has been used by the unit owners of that building since the condominium was created. A couple of unit owners from another building want to make use of the area, but the unit owners who have been using it have objected. The problem is that neither the declaration nor the bylaws of the condominium describe the intended use of the area. Can the board treat the area as a limited common element for the exclusive use of the unit owners who are now using it, or should the board treat the area as a common element for use by all unit owners? . . . William Ramos, Manhattan.

title: Charity Begins With Sept. 11, and Ends There
description: EXECUTIVES at some of Long Island's largest nonprofit and philanthropic institutions say that dozens of social-service or cultural programs are endangered because of the impact of Sept. 11 on local fund-raising activities.

title: The Cram-Down
description: So your dot-com has fallen on hard times. It turns out that the market for online quilt sales wasn't quite as robust as your projections made it out to be, and now you're laying off old friends, selling off excess office equipment and hemorrhaging money. Is all hope lost?

title: Air Taxis
description: Even before the threat of terrorism made commercial flight in the United States a particularly anxious affair, frustration among business travelers over curbside congestion and flight delays was simmering. A growing number of affluent travelers -- mostly high-level executives -- were enjoying travel by private jet, and fractional ownership schemes were making the trend more affordable. In May, United Airlines surprised the aviation world by ordering 200 small jets and announcing plans to enter the fractional business itself. As one United executive put it at the time, ''We had to do something -- our first-class cabins are emptying out.''

title: War on Terror Casts Chechen Conflict in a New Light
description: The only road from Georgia into Chechnya worms northward from the Russian border, across the Caucasus Mountains and through Russia's wild Argun River gorge. On a drizzly October day two years ago, Abdul Itslayev was standing beside it, hitchhiking.

Devoted brother of Bunny, Doris, Alvin, Marty and the late Bernie. Dear uncle and friend. Respected attorney who loved boating, fishing, family and friends. Graduate of Catawba College and NYU Law School. Generous, witty and kind-hearted, a very special person who is one in a million. He will be truly missed by many. Services were held December 3.

title: Every Happy Country Is Happy in Its Own Way
description: Happiness is one of those things that seem impossible to quantify. But Ruut Veenhoven, a Dutch social scientist, is trying to do it anyway. He has spent years asking people in 82 countries questions like ''All things considered, how satisfied are you with your life as a whole now?'' and ''During the past few weeks, did you ever feel on top of the world?'' After various statistical machinations (and accounting for factors like income and life expectancy), Veenhoven arrives at a number between 1 and 10 indicating how happy people in a specific country are. As the chart on the next page indicates, the Swiss are a pleased bunch (their happiness score is 8.15), whereas Ukrainians are grim (theirs is 3.95).

title: POSTINGS: East 57th Street Again Tops Retail List; Highest Rents In the World
description: East 57th Street from Fifth Avenue to Park Avenue is the most expensive retail location in the world, with asking rents averaging $700 a square foot annually, as of last June, according to a global survey conducted by Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate brokerage and services company.

title: U.N. Doubtful That Refugees Will Rush Back
description: About 10,000 Afghan refugees have trickled back to the capital of Kabul, but United Nations officials said today that they did not expect large numbers of people to return to Afghanistan until next spring.

title: REPORT ON CHARITY
description: New Jersey residents gave $5.8 billion to charity and foundations contributed another $913 million in 1999, according to the first report of its kind to calculate who gave money and where it went. The report, compiled for the Council of New Jersey Grantmakers, made up of 96 philanthropic organizations, showed that individuals donated an average of $1,467 in 1999, the latest year for which figures could be compiled, compared with a national average of $1,295. However that amount represented only 2.4 percent of state residents' per capita income, while the individuals nationally gave 2.8 percent. The state's 200 largest foundations gave only 38 percent of their grants to New Jersey causes, while 20 percent went to New York and the rest went to other states. Karen DeMasters

title: Designer Truth Commissions
description: When Argentina set up the world's first major truth commission in 1983, the participants never imagined their invention would someday become a required part of any transition to democracy. But truth commissions have proliferated, and now every nation emerging from dictatorship or war wants one. This year Nigeria, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Peru, Panama, East Timor, Yugoslavia, Bosnia and South Korea all began commissions or have them under way.

description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Hotel Developers Seek to Cash In on Casino Boom
description: THE phenomenal success of the Mohegan Sun casino has spawned a hotel boom in the once-rural town of Montville, Conn., where along a one-mile stretch of Route 32 two hotels have opened this year and two others are on the drawing boards, even as Mohegan Sun develops its own 1,200-room hotel tower a couple of miles away.

title: The Dangers Behind a Leap of Faith
description: TRUST me.

title: The Crawl
description: Television has become a print medium. Since 1980, when the Financial News Network, now defunct, added a stock ticker to the bottom of its screen, graphics have progressively crowded cable-news broadcasts to the point where anchors must struggle to be seen through a wilderness of numbers, logos and text. Now they have one more element to contend with. The major cable outlets -- CNN, Fox News and MSNBC -- have found a way to double up their coverage, showing a continuous stream of yellow or white news copy at the bottom of their screens. People in the news business call it the Crawl.

title: Firefighters Gladly Accept A Songwriter's Sincere Gift
description: Some New York firefighters are listening to the song at supper. Some are even singing it. ''Bravest of the Brave,'' written by a Bronx songwriter, has also been heard on WBAI (99.5 FM). Apparently, not all underground music is born in a gloomy loft in the Village.

title: New Steel Curtain Is Rising To Challenge the Jets' Offense
description: The pressure came in waves for Vinny Testaverde last week, the questions about his moribund offense and the Jets' play-calling and his own inability to make a critical fourth-down pass last Sunday buffeting him like so many sacks. He bobbed and weaved and escaped, a game smile on his face, a 7-4 record his greatest defense, explaining that in his 15-year career he has learned how to deal with adversity and that sometimes it takes a few weeks to recover.

title: The Moratorium Gambit
description: No one ever expected the pace of legal executions in America to slow down. The public overwhelmingly favors them. Political leaders long ago realized that the easiest shorthand for being ''tough on crime'' was to support capital punishment.

title: Felicia Santana, Anthony Johnson
description: Felicia Ann Santana, a daughter of Damian Santana of Far Rockaway, Queens, and the late Shirley Ann Santana, was married yesterday to Dr. Anthony Gerard Johnson, a son of Arthur F. Johnson of Sylmar, Calif., and the late Catherine Newman Johnson. The Rev. Paul E. C. Hamilton performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in College Point, Queens.

title: Quarterbacks as Middle Managers
description: There are millions of little boys who sit alone in their bedrooms and dream of becoming N.F.L. quarterbacks. There are considerably fewer who aspire to a life in which they claw their way into middle management. Yet somehow those two paths have merged into the same career.

title: Under Autumn Snow, Footnotes to Village's Sorrowful Decade
description: The graves are barely visible to the newcomer, a weathered row of bumps and stones that on an autumn day are shrouded in snow.

title: Afghan Women Are Not A Fit Subject for Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Torpedo
description: The best hockey teams on the planet these days come from Europe, whence all the innovation and creativity in the world's fastest sport now flow. In the 1990's, the Czech Republic brought to the game the so-called neutral-zone trap, in which the team without the puck clogs the middle of the ice and smothers its foe in a morass of defense. In the hands of gifted Czech players like Jaromir Jagr and Dominik Hasek, the trap produced stunning international success -- an Olympic gold medal in '98 and five world championships at the professional and junior levels in the years since. In the more quotidian hands of N.H.L. clubs, the trap was used to win Stanley Cups -- and bore the bejesus out of fans across North America.

title: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.
description: When looking back at the end of a year, we usually regard the 12 months that have just passed as a series of momentous events, a parade of notable individuals or a gallery of compelling images. But these are not the only ways to capture the arc and rhythm of a year. For this special issue, The Times Magazine has chosen a different lens: ideas. Presenting 2001 as the latest volume in the encyclopedia of human innovation, ''The Year in Ideas'' offers not a summary of the year's major news stories but a catalog of 80 notions, inventions, conceptual swerves and philosophical leaps that mattered this year and may well continue to matter in years to come.

title: Focus on the Negative
description: For years, the popular psychology and self-help movement has tried to help anxious or pessimistic people achieve a positive attitude. Among the enemies of emotional well-being, we have been told, are negative outlooks and ''catastrophizing,'' both of which could be battled through the visualization of a successful outcome: avoid the bad and focus on the good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANTWERK, BELLE
description: GANTWERK-Belle. On December 8, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Lewis and Barbara, Carol and Robert Davidson, Roslyn Gantwerk and Ronni Basis and Ellen and Paul Gantwerk-Mitchell. Devoted sister of Irving Ratner, Arthur and Laura Ratner and Marvin and Bernice Ratner. Cherished grandmother of Heidi (Andy), Rebecca (David), Adam (Lara), Jason (Kelli), Eric, Amy and Jonathan. Great-grandmother of Isaac, Samantha, Gabriel and Sebastian. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: PrivateSector; In Re Enron, a Judge of Caution
description: ANYONE expecting fireworks last week at the first bankruptcy hearing of the Enron Corporation, the biggest corporate failure in American history, was quickly disabused of that notion by the judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez.

description: After a sound beating in recent legislative races, Republican officials decided to shake things up at the State Committee.

title: Irma Eagleton, David Hill
description: Irma Jeanne Eagleton, the daughter of Paulette Eagleton Church of Avoca, N.Y., is to be married today to David Berry Hill, a son of Nancy Rogers Hill and James Berry Hill of New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor will officiate at the New York Palace Hotel in New York. The Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Political Briefing; G.O.P. Enlists Women In Missouri Effort
description: As Republicans gear up to try to reclaim control of the Senate next year, they view Senator Jean Carnahan of Missouri as one of the most vulnerable Democrats. They note that she did not win the seat in her own right, but was instead appointed to fill it after the death of her husband, Mel. The Republicans contend that she is a political novice who will not be able to fend off their more experienced candidate, former Representative Jim Talent.

title: The G.E. Racehorses, One Year Afterward
description: About this time last year, the horse race to succeed John F. Welch Jr. as the head of General Electric ended. Jeffrey R. Immelt got the job. In an instant, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing snared W. James McNerney Jr., one of the two also-rans, and Home Depot grabbed Robert L. Nardelli, the other. Other companies in need of leadership could only watch with envy.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Seeking the Spotlight
description: IT seems that Diane Allen is looking to make her next political move.

title: Using Forms Ingrained in Ballet To Help the Body Move Beyond It
description: THE word ''ballet'' doesn't instantly come to mind when looking at the work of William Forsythe. The dancers of the Frankfurt Ballet, the company he has directed since 1984, move in undefinable ways, their bodies arcing and convulsing around invisible forms, their limbs swerving in contrary directions and their movements apparently refracted from one part of the body to another with no implicit reference to any predetermined dance vocabulary. Nonetheless, for many dance lovers, the American-born Mr. Forsythe is the choreographer who is most important to the present and future of ballet, because he has immeasurably enlarged our notions of what the art form can do both physically and theatrically.

title: Robust and Russian in Suffolk County
description: RUSSIAN restaurants are as rare on Long Island as traffic-free trips on the Long Island Expressway. There is one in Oceanside, but Michael's Russian Restaurant, which opened in October at 880 West Jericho Turnpike in Smithtown (631-543-4678), is probably the only one in Suffolk County.

title: Turning a Bad Drug Good
description: Gamma hydroxybutyrate (GHB) is a central nervous system depressant that, like Rohypnol, became notorious in recent years as a ''date rape drug'' that could easily be slipped into the beers of unsuspecting coeds. As a result, last year GHB was classified by Congress as a Schedule 1 drug, like LSD or heroin. It is also known by the all-night rave crowd as Goop or G-Riffick, and taking it at a low dosage with alcohol multiplies its potency by 10 and provides a short, sexually stimulating high.

description: Afghanistan

title: Rangers' Late Rally Falls Short Against Leafs
description: With his team trailing by two goals and barely five minutes left in the game, Rangers center Petr Nedved saw a precious scoring chance unfolding and skated furiously toward the Toronto Maple Leafs' net.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDIN, CHRISTOPHER LAURISTON
description: HARDIN-Christopher Lauriston. Age 20, suddenly on December 5. Beloved son of Edward Hull Hardin and Sara Truslow Hardin, and brother of Haley Hardin. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, December 11, at 11 AM, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St and Fifth Ave. In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund has been established at Pomfret School, Box 128, Pomfret, CT. 06258.

title: LEAD PAINT LAWSUIT
description: The city of Newark filed a lawsuit last week against lead paint manufacturers, accusing them of knowingly poisoning Newark children for five decades. Mayor Sharpe James is seeking billions in damages for the cost of removing lead paint, evaluating Newark properties for it and medically monitoring children with problems related to lead paint, said Michael Gordon, a lawyer representing the city. The defendants in the case are the industry trade group Lead Industries Association and eight manufacturers, including American Cyanamid, DuPont and Sherwin-Williams. Newark filed the suit in Essex County Superior Court. Sarah Rubenstein

description: FOR some years now, a certain generation of New Yorkers has pined for a ghost of Christmas past. They long not for sugarplums, nor Currier & Ives, nor an era when batteries were included.

description: THE date: July 28, 1965.

description: War's Toll on Bush

title: Genetic Pollution
description: The way we think about and deal with pollution has always been governed by the straightforward rules of chemistry. You clean the stuff up or let it fade with time. But what do you do about a form of pollution that behaves instead according to the rules of biology? Such a pollutant would have the ability to copy itself over and over again, so that its impact on the environment would increase with time rather than diminish. Now you're talking about a problem with, quite literally, a life of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOAG, DR. JOHN MARSHALL
description: HOAG-Dr. John Marshall. Age 89. Of Pawling, New York. Died Tuesday, November 20, 2001. He was a former resident of Chappaqua and New York City. Dr. Hoag was an Osteopathic physician at Leroy Hospital in New York City, retiring in 1990. A life member of the Academy of Sciences, Medical Director, Osteopathic Hospital and Clinic of New York; Chairman of the Section on Research, the Postgraduate Institute of Osteopathic Medicine and Surgery. He was a member of Christ Church on Quaker Hill in Pawling. In addition to his wife, survivors include two sons and their wives, two granddaughters and a great granddaughter. The memory of Dr. John Marshall Hoag remains with those who knew him, and were touched by his gentle, caring and compassionate ways. He will be missed always.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMITH, LYNN PAYTON
description: SMITH-Lynn Payton. On your birthday, we miss you and love you. Your mom Elaine and your son William. 12/9/56 to 6/15/9

title: Music Boxes: Pleasing the Eye and Ear
description: RECORDED music has become so pervasive that it may be hard to imagine a quieter age when musical sounds were heard primarily at live performances and just beginning to be heard through mechanical means. ''Timeless Melodies: Musical Boxes and Automatic Musical Instruments of the 19th and 20th Centuries,'' at the Stedman Gallery of the Rutgers-Camden Center for the Arts, offers a fascinating look at those early days of recorded sound.

description: When administrators at Rodeph Sholom Day School at 168-70 West 79th Street look at the doughnut of space in the school's backyard, they see room for a two-story addition for a new seventh and eighth grade.

title: Music With Messages for Young Ears
description: SHE wrote her first song at age 12, gave her first live performance at 14, and signed her first recording contract at 15. Now, in her mid-40's, Patricia Shih is delighting youngsters with her songs about diversity, self-esteem, tolerance and other important lessons.

title: A Brighter Holiday (If the Goods Hold Out)
description: IF you visit garnethill.com, the online arm of the catalog retailer Garnet Hill, don't expect to buy those cute suede slippers from Italy. Every size but 7 is sold out. The same goes for those handsome suede shirts, one of the company's recommended holiday gifts.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Putnam Valley; A Quaint Town Facing Strong Demand
description: FIFTY-SIX years ago, Henry Wirtz, an accountant who is now 100, and his wife moved from their New York City apartment to Putnam Valley to escape the city's everyday hustle and bustle and the pressures of his job.

title: Zeroing In on a Killer
description: Geoprofiling -- the science of predicting where criminals live based on where they commit crimes -- was transformed this year from an academic novelty into a mainstream crime-fighting technique. It is now used by Scotland Yard, the F.B.I., the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the A.T.F. and others to solve apparent serial crimes. Kim Rossmo, the former police detective from Vancouver, British Columbia, who invented it, flew more than 100,000 miles in 2001 to consult on various high-profile investigations. He has advised on everything from serial murders in New York to serial rapes in Louisiana.

title: QUICK BITE/Monroe; Putting Delicious Surprises in a Shmear
description: In October, John Ingram had an idea. Why not make pumpkin-walnut cream cheese for the season? That's what he did -- nothing new for him. It just added to his noted repertory of creative cream cheeses: from olive-pimento to walnut-raisin to strawberry. Mr. Ingram, a former trucker, makes them at Dee's Bagel Cafe/Deli & Grill in Apple Plaza in Monroe. Outside the four-year-old establishment, diners are greeted by a smiling 6-foot-plus-tall wooden caricature of the 5-foot-3-inch former nail technician Denice (Dee) Ingram, John's wife. The wooden Dee is holding a hamburger, surrounded by a muffin, coffee and other goodies. Inside are sculptures of bagels that transmute into, for example, a tossed salad, a Danish, a bowl of soup. The Ingrams, who commute from Burlington Township, about a half-hour away, draw most of their patrons from the handful of adult communities in the township. At lunchtime, the cafe can serve up to 26 diners, many from surrounding businesses like a Sony warehouse, Aetna and Home Depot. There also is delivery for orders of at least $15. Lunch can be anything from salads and club, combo or deli sandwiches and wraps to baskets, burgers and grill -- all $4 to $6. Available any time, is a dish ($4.59) made from eggs, three cheeses, bacon and onions: the ''Deelux'' Cheese Omelette. Norm Oshrin

title: Marketing Ties That Might Have Been
description: HE Levi's Gremlin, dressed in denim. The plus-size American Motors Matador wearing, somewhat uncomfortably, Oleg Cassini couture. The Frank Sinatra Edition Chrysler Imperial, which came with tapes of the Chairman's hits -- you could drive it your way.

title: To Serve and Flirt Near Ground Zero
description: I HAVE been a volunteer near ground zero for a month now, ladling out meals to the firemen and policemen and F.B.I. guys at Nino's Restaurant on Canal Street, and what I'm thinking is, it all comes down to the butcher's apron.

title: Thai King Uses Influence To Undercut Prime Minister
description: For a man who hates criticism, this was about as unpleasant as it gets. People at the scene said his face grew red as he sat at humble attention.

title: As Catholic Teachers Strike, Egan Takes Reserved Approach
description: In 1986, Edward M. Egan, an auxiliary bishop in charge of education in the Archdiocese of New York, was negotiating with a teachers' union. To his sharp displeasure, his superior, Cardinal John O'Connor, went around him and talked with the union leader in hopes of reaching a settlement, current and former archdiocese officials said.

title: All Politics Is Local? In Glen Ridge, That's a Stretch
description: ABOUT a week ago, during a meeting filled with typical issues like drainage, the Glen Ridge Town Council got a request that would have seemed more likely on ''The West Wing'': to speak out against the Chinese government's torture of practitioners of Falun Gong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, HAROLD JAMES
description: BLUM-Harold James died on December 4, 2001 at the age of 90. Beloved son of the late Matilda Pearlstein and Louis Blum. Loving and loved husband of Anita, brother of the late Julius (Esther) and the late Theresa Stone (Dr. Frederick E.). Adored uncle of Judy Blum, Babara Coppe and Louise Spring (Lionel), great uncle of Michael and Tony Spring, greatgreat uncle of Tyler and Nathan Spring. Graduated Fieldston and University of Pennsylvania and served honorably as a Captain in World War II in the invasion of Anzio. Friends to many and respected by all.

title: PrivateSector; Writing a Big Check, With Style
description: With the auctioneer's closing gavel, 500 guests at a Swatch charity auction last Tuesday at Sotheby's burst into applause. They had just raised $400,000 for God's Love We Deliver, which feeds homebound people with AIDS. The bidders included Donald Trump, the philanthropist Henry Buhl and the fashion celebrities Heidi Klum and Isaac Mizrahi.

title: High-Tech Shortcut to Breathing Rarefied Air Gets I.O.C.'s Eye
description: Ah, the sacrifices required to be a great endurance athlete. The training that leaves you feeling like your lungs are several sizes too small. The strict diet. The constant travel and utterly uncertain long-term career prospects. The noise from the generator as you try to get some sleep inside the tent in your bedroom.

title: The Future of Up
description: I LOVE the skyscrapers of Manhattan. After all these years it's still a thrill to see them from far away, across the Hudson River, piled up like exclamation points at the center of the metropolis, or sticking out of the treetops, forming a great manmade escarpment at the edge of Central Park. They are both impressive and, for some reason, poignant.

title: Love and Piety: O My Brother, Where Art Thou?
description: THE call from Israel was jarring at 6 a.m. Because I'm lazy, I let my wife crawl out of bed to get it, but the phone was for me.

title: Rap Impresario Badly Hurt in Bronx Crash
description: A founder of a popular rap music record label remained in critical condition last night after his all-terrain vehicle hit a parked truck in the Bronx on Thursday, the police said.

title: Slow Food
description: What do the Vesuvian apricot, the Delaware Bay oyster and the Loire salmon have in common? According to the Italian journalist Carlo Petrini, founder of the Slow Food movement, they're all ''endangered'' foods. And like rare zebras, butterflies and rhinos, these exotic, traditional foodstuffs require an organized effort to defend them. Slow Food is that movement. Slow Food activism is curious but simple: the idea is to protest the spreading evils of fast food and the bland, unhealthy cuisine of the globalized economy by going back to the locally grown, ''authentic'' food that our grandparents cherished. Why eat mass-produced and plastic-tasting Monterey Jack, Slow Food activists cry, when you can eat a hand-made and zesty chevre from a tiny village in Corsica -- and support a Corsican farmer too?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLARD, RUTH
description: COLLARD-Ruth. Daughter of Reginald Auchincloss and Ruth Cutting, of New York City. Beloved wife of Lt. Cmmdr. Edward (Pinkie) Collard, RN (ret'd). Mother of Louise, David and Peter. Grandmother of Alex, Annalisa, Francesca, George, Harry and Alice. Passed away peacefully on November 27, 2001.

description: George Young, who in 19 seasons as the Giants' general manager lifted a storied but moribund football franchise to two Super Bowl championships and became perhaps the most respected professional football executive of his day, died yesterday in Baltimore after a short illness.

description: HOTEL, gambling and cruise-line companies have been hit hard as thousands of would-be vacationers decided to stay home after Sept. 11.

description: In any overview of the ideas of 2001, the massacre of Sept. 11 is unavoidable. However monstrous a crime, it was also a conceptual innovation. However evil, it was an idea.

description: SCHNEIDER-Helen. Died peacefully at age 79 on December 8, 2001, at Long Island Jewish Medical Center after a courageous battle with cancer. Loving wife for 51 years of Irving. Beloved mother of Bunny Mayersohn, Lynn Schneider Joseph and Mindy Schneider Lesser. Devoted mother-in-law of Ronald Mayersohn, Nathan Joseph and Dr. Michael Lesser. Adoring grandmother of Leah Mayersohn, Jeremiah Schneider Joseph, Max Schneider Joseph, Katie Schneider Lesser and Jake Schneider Lesser. Survived by sister Anne Jacobs, predeceased by brothers Samuel and David and sisters Celia and Estelle. Adored aunt to many nieces and nephews. A great lady, elegant and fine, whose passion and compassion touched people of all ages and all places. Funeral services will be held Monday, December 10, 12 noon, at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at 55th St. Donations may be made to Medical Development for Israel, 130 East 59th St, Suite 1203, NY, NY 10022, or Schneider Children's Hospital, Room CH102, Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY 11040.

description: WHEN he goes into the ring Friday night, George Jones will be wearing yellow trunks with a black B over his right thigh and a black R.I.P. over his left.

title: 4 and 20 Blackbirds, and Still Counting
description: IT is time to count the birds again in Connecticut, throughout North America, and here and there all over the world.

title: DECEMBER 2-8: NEXT WEEK
description: To mark three months since Sept. 11, President Bush will speak at The Citadel military academy. Congress, nearing recess, is expected to focus on education, trade, military spending and farm assistance legislation. The Federal Reserve meets, possibly for its 11th rate cut this year; figures -- probably grim -- on industrial production are expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTER, BOBBY
description: MINTER-Bobby. On December 6, Bobby Minter, loving spouse to Maggi Landau, and adoring father to Sarah and Casey, died from gastric cancer. He was 48. Caring son to Evelyn and Robert Minter and loving big brother to George, Bill and Sue Minter. Fantastic uncle to Thomas, Hannah, Ariel, Jake, Emma, Sophia and Jasper. He is forever cherished by his family and by the strong community of friends who shared his life. Services on Sunday, December 9, 4PM Greenville Community Reform Church, 270 Ardsley Road, Scarsdale, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Bobby Minter may be sent to: The Nature Conservancy of NY, 570 7th Avenue, Suite 601, New York, New York 10018.

title: Hygiene Is a Hazard
description: The use of soaps, sprays and other cleaners made with antibacterial agents has exploded in wealthy countries, a response to microbe horror tales -- if ebola doesn't get you (or now anthrax), raw chicken will. In the last three years, about a thousand new antibacterial cleaning products have made their debut worldwide. But this year, objections to antibacterials have grown, and public-health institutions, including the World Health Organization, have raised concerns that these products, intended in part as a defense against the new superbugs, may in fact be helping to create them.

title: A Mayor-Elect With Money Tells Friends to Ante Up
description: The Robin Hood Foundation, a charity to help New York City's poor, has a star-studded list of supporters mixing Wall Street and Hollywood. Founded by the hedge fund manager Paul Tudor Jones, its board includes Stanley Druckenmiller, former right-hand man to George Soros; Theodore Forstmann, the leveraged-buyout investor; the actress Gwyneth Paltrow; and Lachlan Murdoch, deputy chief operating officer of the News Corporation ( news/quote ) (and son of Rupert).

title: SuperSlow Exercise
description: Working out has come to this: twice a week for 20 minutes, lift weights as slowly as humanly possible, then sit back and revel in newfound muscles and weight loss. That is the idea behind SuperSlow exercise, a weight-machine routine for legs, arms and chest. The participant lifts at a creepingly slow rate for 10 seconds, then lowers for 10 seconds, repeating four to six times. Without the boost from momentum, muscles experience prolonged, concentrated contractions. Such intensity can thoroughly exhaust muscles; SuperSlow enthusiasts require three days rest in between sessions. In June, the Journal of Sports Medicine and Physical Fitness published a study that found the method resulted in 50 percent greater increase in strength compared with regular, faster and momentum-aided weight training.

title: Dickensian Wizardry
description: Before he became Harry Potter, Daniel Radcliffe (left, with Bob Hoskins as Mr. Micawber) experienced the kindness and cruelty of others as young David Copperfield in the 2000 ''Exxon Mobile Masterpiece Theater'' production of the Dickens classic, which will be shown tomorrow night at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Personal Business; In Search of Forever, Shoppers Return to 47th St.
description: DENNIS MARLOW leaned across his jewelry counter on 47th Street in Midtown Manhattan and told what is becoming a familiar story. Last month, he said, ''a guy just walked in and bought an engagement ring he's been promising his wife for 10 years.'' When they were planning their wedding, the customer explained, he didn't have enough money.

title: A Poet's View: Finding Solace in Books for an Escape Into the City
description: Ilive near Washington Square and would probably walk there daily, even if it weren't on my way to just about anywhere. The stately brownstones on the north end of the square retain the look they had when Henry James walked past them. Closing my eyes, I can will myself for an instant into James's 1881 novella "Washington Square." Returning home, where the book awaits me in a choice of editions, I can complete my act of literary escapism.

title: Refighting Old Religious Wars in a Miniature Arena
description: FOR more than a century, Sicilian puppeteers have re-enacted epic battles between Christians and Muslims, staging miniature massacres with special effects that include decapitation, fake blood and wooden torsos slashed in half by tiny metal swords.

Our sympathy is extended to the families of Robert Mapplethorpe's siblings, Nancy Rooney, Susan Schneider, James Mapplethorpe, and Edward Mapplethorpe. Michael Ward Stout, President

Gibson, which eneded with a hung jury, said last week that a new trial would be set for early October. Federal prosecutors had said that they planned to retry Mr. Gibson and two co-defendants on fraud and bribery charges over charges of improperly diverting $1 million from a $50 million school construction project handled by the Irvington consulting engineering firm led by Mr. Gibson. John Holl

title: A Better Golf Ball
description: A golf ball presents a complex fluid dynamics challenge. A blunt sphere pulls air along with it as it flies, creating a wake, and the energy needed to pull this air -- the drag -- slows it down. The challenge is to reduce the drag, allowing the ball to fly farther.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORT, FREDA. ''FRITZIE''
description: KORT-Freda. ''Fritzie''-87. Loving wife of the late Otto. Devoted mother of Jonathan. Dear sister of Shirley and the late Sylvia. Beloved aunt and great-aunt. title: English Cottage Look, but a French Accent

But the accent at this 28-year-old Amityville veteran is decidedly French, especially since September, when Jay Holt became its new owner and chef.

description: MATLIN-Bernard. December 1, 2001. Devoted and loving husband of 54 years to Lillian. Cherished father of Denise (Arnold) and Larry. Adored grandfather of Jason (Elisabeth) and Adam. A man for whom family was everything.

title: Katya Fels, Paul Smyth

The Rev. Donald Mulrenan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Valley Roman Catholic Church in Sheffield, Mass.

description: The economy may be weak, but some consumers are buying again. Online sales and sales of personal computers are up sharply. Sales at restaurants and movie theaters, however, are off.

description: In ''Forget Fashion, Think Product Design,'' Amy M. Spindler may be missing the first point of fashion: a garment that overtly serves function over style is not fashion; it is merely clothing.

title: Final Scratch
description: Electronic music has always been a paradox of sorts. Though the D.J.'s who produce it love digital technology, they continue to rely for their source material on what many consider an archaic item: the analog vinyl record. Digital files have obvious advantages -- they don't scratch or skip, they're virtually weightless and they're easy to distribute and share -- and over the past decade, many machines have appeared on the market that allow D.J.'s to manipulate sound digitally. But digital interfaces ignore the physical facts of D.J.'ing -- the comfortable feel of a record moving back and forth under a D.J.'s hand, the responsiveness of vinyl and the spatial and visual clues D.J.'s use to remember and find tracks and beats.

title: Hours Into a New Era, Knicks Pull Out a Victory
description: As the Knicks' 17-point lead slipped away and then disappeared in a rash of turnovers and defensive lapses, Mark Jackson heard a familiar voice pounding in his head. The voice belonged to a man who was watching last night's game from his home in Westchester County. But to Jackson, the man might as well have been running along the sideline, pointing and shouting instructions.

description: FROM Casablanca to Kabul, the statistics are stunning.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Two New Facilities for People With Alzheimer's
description: AN increase in the number of people afflicted with Alzheimer's disease has developers who specialize in housing for older people working to provide special facilities for those suffering from the disorder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, BARBARA L.M.
description: IRWIN-Barbara L.M. Age 85, died December 7, at home in Larchmont, NY. Loving and beloved of Wallace Irwin Jr., her husband; William W. Irwin, her son; Victoria Woolley of Minneapolis, her daughter; Benjamin Woolley, her grandson; Philip Sprott of Thame, Oxfordshire, England, her brother. Gifted in arts and crafts, avid tennis player, able and devoted supporter of Planned Parenthood. Twelve years a stroke survivor, she bore her disability with courage and grace. Her kindness, charm and humor earned her countless friends who will keep her in their hearts.

title: The Battery Is Up, for Once, With a Remade Park
description: The plan was to make Battery Park an elegant period just below the exclamation point of the nascent Hudson River park, with a new upper promenade lined with granite benches in shades of soft pink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, ROBERT
description: O'DONNELL-Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert O'Donnell, associated with The Times from 1931 until retiring in 1978.

title: Golfing as a Way of Enjoying Nature?
description: TINY Byram Lake is pretty much the same today as it was when I first came here 35 years ago. The same dirt road runs along its edge, with the same heights all around, the flies touching the surface of the water, the same perfect quiet. Except for a glimpse of Interstate 684 in the distance, it could be Montana instead of Westchester County, not an hour from Times Square.

description: JUST because Lanford Wilson seems to have given up on his projected cycle of plays about the Talley family of Lebanon, Mo., does not mean the American theater should give up on Mr. Wilson.

description: Four meet records were set and Fordham Prep of the Bronx took four first places in varsity boys' events yesterday in the 52nd Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor relay carnival.

description: Martin Dennehy and Virginia Ruggiero began Dec. 7 with a memorial service for those who died at Pearl Harbor and ended it by marrying.

The Rev. Ervin Adam Brown performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md.

title: Hollywood On the Hackensack
description: MORE feature films had scenes shot on location in New Jersey last year than in any prior year, with film production up 16 percent over 1999, according to an annual report issued by the New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission in November for 2000.

title: Reality Checks For the Wayward
description: In her television courtroom, Judge Glenda Hatchett, a petite 50-year-old who looks younger, lets her emotions come through. ''If you curse again, I promise you I'm going to come off this bench,'' the judge told a 16-year-old girl who admitted having fought with her mother.

Dr. Sarah Fogg, an American Baptist minister, officiated, and the Rev. Dr. Walter J. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

description: There's no ersatz Eiffel Tower or Doge's Palace, but at a new Las Vegas resort you can swim in two and a half acres of pools, play any of 2,400 slot machines, or see a movie at one of 14 theaters.

description: I REALIZE now that I've been a bit of a rube when it comes to understanding the concept of time. And I'd like to thank AT&T for helping me to better grasp the idea, by enlightening me to the space, time, customer-service continuum.

title: Self-Cooling Buildings
description: Air-conditioning allows designers of large buildings to happily ignore external factors like humidity, temperature changes, wind, noise and air pollution. The problem, felt acutely in the U.S. this past year, is that air-conditioning is no longer cheap (and is also environmentally destructive).

description: HARGRAVE-Marjorie Bywater Adams. Of NYC, died on December 4. Wife of the late James B. Adams, Jr. and the late John T. Hargrave. Mother of James B. Adams III, Audrey Bywater Adams Massa, John L. Adams, Louise Parlin Hargrave Meyer and Janet T. Hargrave. Grandmother to James L. Massa, John Charles Meyer and Louise Parlin (''PJ'') Meyer. She took great joy in life & had a loving and gracious spirit. Beloved by family and friends, she will always be in our hearts. Memorial service at St. Thomas More's Church, 65 E. 89th Street, on January 5, at 10:30 AM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Brearley School.

description: MOZART can finally reverberate properly in Hartford.

title: MEDIA GIANT'S NEW HEAD
description: Congratulations, Mr. Tortoise. When Time Warner agreed to be taken over by America Online to create the world's biggest media company last year, it looked like the world of films, magazines and television had capitulated to the high-flying Internet sector. Guess not: AOL Time Warner has announced that the company's next chief executive will be Richard D. Parsons, an executive who comes from some of Time Warner's mustiest old-media precincts. He will replace Gerald M. Levin, another corporate survivor with roots at Time Warner. Seth Schiesel

title: 'Reading Chekhov'
description: After they have slept together for the first time, Dmitri Dmitrich Gurov and Anna Sergeyevna von Diderits, the hero and heroine of Anton Chekhov's story "The Lady with the Dog" (1899), drive out at dawn to a village near Yalta called Oreanda, where they sit on a bench near a church and look down on the sea. "Yalta was hardly visible through the morning mist; white clouds stood motionless on the mountain-tops," Chekhov writes at the start of the famous passage that continues:
