He leaves his wife Esther Moellenhoff English, son Andrew, daughter Ellen & 3 grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife Constance Kent English. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Americans United for Separation of Church and State, 518 C Street N.E., Washington, D.C. 20002.

title: A Stimulus Not Worth Passing
description: If President Bush truly wants an ''economic stimulus'' package on his desk this year, he needs to do more than exhort Congress to get moving. He and the Republican leaders in the House and Senate should drop the pretense that tax-break giveaways to corporations and the wealthiest Americans are the key to reviving the economy.

title: Inheriting Caramoor In a Changed World
description: FALLEN leaves lent melancholy one recent morning to the spacious grounds of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, deserted in contrast with the crowds that had packed this summer's 56th annual international music festival.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Changes at the Top

title: Cheating Is Part of the Game
description: This summer, a skinny Little League pitcher named Danny Almonte dominated opposing hitters as if he were a man playing a child's game. But the sense of wonder at his brilliance hardened to suspicion and then exploded into outrage when a Sports Illustrated reporter located his birth certificate: Danny was, in fact, a 14-year-old playing a 12-year-old's game. Little League parents charged the perpetrator of this fraud, Danny's father, Felipe, with desecrating one of the last sacred grounds of American sports.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; A Slower Pace to Retailing's Growth in the State
description: AT many a store and shopping center this holiday season, cash registers are ringing -- but maybe not as constantly as last year -- and merchants are discounting their prices and working harder to consummate sales. Outside, parking spaces can still be found.

title: The New York Times's Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: With Lobsters Scarce, Questions Abound
description: TODD ROSS, the mate, loaded a blue plastic crate of flounder heads and skeletons onto the Christine-Jennifer while the captain, George Dahl, 56, siphoned fuel from a black plastic drum into a tank below deck. Perfumed in diesel and old fish, the Christine-Jennifer, a 40-foot, single-engine workboat, steamed out of Northport harbor.

title: A Pocketful Of Wine Sense
description: The 2002 Pocket Wine Guide (Harcourt) by the influential British critic Oz Clarke is indispensable for economizing buyers. Pages listing ''World-class wines that don't cost the earth,'' ''Best look-alikes to the classics,'' ''Regions to watch,'' ''10 best-kept secrets'' and ''Top value wines'' are worth the $13 charged at 67 Wine, 179 Columbus Avenue (68th Street), and at bookstores. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Group Plans Asian College For Women In Poverty
description: With the women of Afghanistan, Cambodia, Vietnam and other poor nations in mind, an international group of leaders in education and development have begun raising money to establish a new private university for women in Asia that would be accessible to the poor.

title: Saul Bellow
description: REVIEWS

title: December 2-8; FRONT LINES
description: AFGHANISTAN -- By week's end, some of the United States' military campaign's goals were either met or tantalizingly close. After a chaotic push, opposition forces strongly backed by American and allied troops took Kandahar, the Taliban's last stronghold, and were -- at least according to some reports -- close to control of Tora Bora, the northeastern mountain cave complex believed to be the last Afghan redoubt of Osama bin Laden. In Bonn, Afghan factions agreed on a provisional post-Taliban government led by Hamid Karzai, a Pashtun leader, that would be installed Dec. 22 and operate for at least six months.

title: Tuition Savings Plan Is About to Get Juicier
description: LIKE many grandparents, Evelyn and William Heath of Oyster Bay want to put away money for their grandchildren's college education. But unlike many other investors, they have chosen a rather untraditional place to put their money: with the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, LEONARD
description: GREENBERG-Leonard. In San Jose, CA. on November 28, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Arlene Greenberg. Father of Andrea Chesnov (Jahn) and Laurie Himelstein (Mark). Leaves behind four granddaughters and brothers Walter and Robert. He was formerly from the Bronx and Flushing. Condolences to Himelstein, 12256 Candy Court, Saratoga, CA. 95070.

title: ENDPAPER
description: A sampler of this year's crop of patents.

title: The 'X-Files' Conspiracy Trope Is Dead
description: According to ''The X-Files,'' the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. are involved in a vast and exquisitely executed scheme to hide the presence of extraterrestrials on earth. According to Don DeLillo's novel ''Libra,'' they plotted the assassination of John F. Kennedy. And in James Ellroy's ''American Tabloid'' and ''Cold Six Thousand,'' they engineered every political killing and scandal of the past 40 years. According to the newspapers, however, America's elite intelligence and law-enforcement agencies are a bunch of bumblers. They have botched investigations, lost files, harbored double agents in their ranks and, despite the clamorous wake-up call of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center, failed to both anticipate and prevent the worst terrorist attack in American history.

title: There's More to Medicine Than the Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford King Ranch F-150 SuperCrew; Sizzle From a Branding Iron
description: COWBOYS and pickups go together like blue jeans and boots. It doesn't take an advertising genius to dream up a marketing tie-in that uses the rough-and-ready image of a cowpoke to sell a durable, utilitarian truck.

title: Argentines Turn Shrine Into an Oasis of Miracles
description: Argentina's best jockeys come to this distant oasis of spirituality for good luck. So do boxers, soccer players, truck drivers, almost anyone with a special regard for motherly love, all asking for favors or giving thanks.

title: The All-Species Inventory
description: Experts estimate that there are around 100 million species in the world. What percentage of these flora and fauna have we named in the 250 years since Carl Linnaeus devised a classification system to complete Adam's task? Remarkably, only 2 or 3 percent. So two blue-sky thinkers in San Francisco -- Kevin Kelly and Stewart Brand -- recently came up with a solution to this problem: the All-Species Inventory. The goal is to identify and name every living thing, all in a single human generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, SYLVIA
description: MOSKOWITZ-Sylvia. 87, December 7, 2001. Beloved wife of Ben for 65 years. Loving mother of Deanna Glassmann, Joseph Moskowitz and Phyllis Figluizzi. Cherished grandmother of Leonard, Dina, Steven, David, Minda, Robert, Adam and Michael. Greatgrandmother of Jennifer, Erica, Gabrielle and Abigail, and loving sister of Frances Wiesenfeld, Sidney Weinberg and the late Milton Weinberg. A woman of valor, dedicated to her Jewish heritage through her involvement in the Sisterhood of the Brooklyn Jewish Center, Hadassah and State of Israel Bonds. Services Sunday, 1 PM, Gutterman's Parkside, 98-60 Queens Blvd; 718-284-1500. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hadassah.

title: Footlights
description: Online Music Making for Tots

title: A Generation Holds Its Course
description: Most baby boomers plan no changes in investing or savings as a result of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a new survey has found.

title: Works With a New Ring In the Wake of Sept. 11
description: ''I'D kind of rather not go there,'' Doug Varone said when asked about the reported impact of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on dances that he will present at the Joyce Theater this week. Living on Canal Street in Lower Manhattan, Mr. Varone finds the sky's new emptiness to the south to be ''very present.'' Choreographers tend to be reluctant to interpret dances for their audiences. But Sept. 11 loomed as a spectral presence in the conversation.

title: Shifting Fronts, Rising Danger: The Afghanistan War Evolves
description: When Afghanistan's new transitional government takes power two weeks from today, it will inherit a capital full of blaring horns, busy markets and a nearly universal yearning for peace.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE BIOGRAPHER'S TALE , by A. S. Byatt. (Vintage International, $14.) In a literary fable populated by bickering scholars, writers and critical theorists, a graduate student named Phineas G. Nanson abandons his postmodern wanderings to write a biography of a noted biographer, and soon becomes lost in his subject's dizzying manuscripts (and sidetracked by his alluring niece). "The novelist's power amid the talk to configure love and that which is uncannily alive . . . exhilarates this book and its readers," Richard Eder wrote here in January.

title: Who Needs Snow If All Else Is White?
description: Put away those tortured blacks and optic-popping brights. This Christmas, peaceful white is the color to dream in, as clothes, accessories and objects for the home take a deliciously pristine turn. Far from boring, the new blank canvases come in an array of textures, finishes and subtleties of shade. Plus, there is no need to worry about wear and tear: for spring, designers like Ralph Lauren are showing weathered-white pieces, pre-smudged and begrimed, in the style of dirty denim. But until then, let the alabaster city gleam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATT, AARON D.
description: BLATT-Aaron D. December 5, age 86, of Tamarac, FL. Retired Superintendent of US Postal Service. Beloved husband for 65 years of Mollie Blatt, retired Secretary, Canarsie HS. Loving father of Marilyn Young, Carole Gonshak, Leah Glasser and husband Gerald. Devoted grandfather of Lauren and Michael Young, Jeff and Greg Gonshak, Rachel and Ben Glasser; and great-grandson Jeffrey P. Gonshak. Loving brother of Elsie Doroff and Claire Meltz.

title: NORTH BERGEN SEARCHES
description: Federal agents searched the municipal building, local sewer authority and several residences in North Bergen on Tuesday, prompting widespread speculation about why. No arrests were made, and the F.B.I. and United States attorney's offices in Newark refused to say what or whom the agents were after. The township's lawyer, Herbert Klitzner, said officials were cooperating but knew little about the searches. Mayor Nicholas Sacco, who is also a state senator and an assistant superintendent of local schools, would not comment, his spokesman said. Critics and political opponents of Mr. Sacco said the search supported their claims that the administration is rife with corruption. Steve Strunsky

title: Pan-Mediterranean
description: PAST the tender and fresh seafood, the inventive menu and the joyful presentation of food that's within a sliver of very good, there's one thing I really like about La Terraza: You can get a table.

title: Evidence-Based Medicine
description: When visiting our family doctor, most of us feel secure in the belief that modern science has purged medicine of such practices as cupping and bloodletting. But according to a recent article in the journal Patient Care, ''Some experts estimate that only 20 percent of medical practices are based on rigorous research evidence.'' The rest are based on what has been published in books repeatedly without independent testing -- or what doctors have always said should work. In other words, it's a kind of folklore.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Reissues
description: The designers responsible for some of the most iconic pieces of clothing in fashion history have later seen them copied or sold at auction and in vintage stores for thousands of dollars -- and received none of the profits. In response, innovators have begun to reissue, under their own labels, some of their most important works. This year, Diane Von Furstenberg even went so far as to reproduce the first wrap dress she ever made, in a black-and-white link print, and then run the very same ad she used to sell it the first time around. Pucci and Missoni are working with original signature patterns and prints. Taking a cue from art galleries, Valentino has begun numbering reissued pieces from its archive. And Yves Saint Laurent has made his couture more specialized than ever. While clients are usually offered only the season's designs to order, the Mondrian dress and the safari top, his most copied works, are now regularly available. But no company has perfected the limited-edition concept more deftly than Herms. Waiting lists are kept for all its historic handbag shapes, and it can take years to get one; Herms has made limited editions business as usual. AMY M. SPINDLER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERER, OLGA
description: SCHERER-Olga. Born in Krakow, Poland in 1924, died on November 26, 2001 in Paris. She earned MA and PhD degrees in Comparative Literature at Columbia. She taught at Bard College, Yale and Indiana University. A Guggenheim Fellowship led to a professorship at the University of Paris. She published many works in her field as well as fiction. She took an active part in the Polish expatriate community in Paris. She will be deeply missed by family, colleagues and friends worldwide.

title: Acquired Situational Narcissism
description: We all know that movie stars, professional athletes, rich people and politicians often act like complete jackasses, but Robert B. Millman, professor of psychiatry at Cornell Medical School and the medical adviser to Major League Baseball, thinks he knows why. The cause, he says, is acquired situational narcissism, a psychological dysfunction that Millman was the first to identify and that he treats in his celebrity patients.

title: Too Soon to Clone
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Was That the Future We Just Passed By?
description: FOR those who can remember it, the future was a time of unrivaled wonder. Oh, you remember the future, don't you? Not the hokey old future of flying cars and teleportation, but the future of just a couple years ago -- before Sept. 11, before the crash of the Nasdaq. It was in all the papers. With the stock market following a 1999 best seller called ''Dow 36,000'' and an e-book in every lap -- there was never a future like it.

title: Brazil's Effort to Overhaul Its Labor Code Stirs Heated Debate
description: The government talks of flexibility, the labor unions of betrayal. With elections looming, an effort to overhaul a national labor code that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso calls antiquated is causing both protests and a long-overdue national debate.

title: A Rescuer of Sinking Treasures From China's Past
description: IN 1992, after 30 years of trying, Robert H. Ellsworth finally arrived for the first time in this city in central China, 750 miles south of Beijing and 250 miles southwest of Shanghai. Situated near the majestic Mount Huangshan (the name means yellow mountain), a site made famous by the ink wash drawings of Song, Yuan and Ming painters from the 10th to the 17th centuries, the city was long a prominent trade center.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FILLER, JUAN, M.D.
description: FILLER-Juan, M.D., December 9, 1997, beloved husband. ''To live in hearts we leave behind is not to die.'' Maria

description: 'Molto Agitato'

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 100 of The Times Magazine today about the legal dispute over the publication of computer code to disable the encryption of DVD's includes an outdated reference to the status of the case. On Nov. 28, after the magazine had gone to press, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found in favor of the Motion Picture Association of America, which had brought the suit against Eric Corley, a magazine publisher.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the screenplay by Frances Goodrich, Albert Hackett and Frank Capra for ''It's a Wonderful Life'' misspelled the surname of a writer credited with ''additional scenes.'' He was Jo Swerling, not Swirling. The article also misstated the number of feature films directed by Capra after that one. It was five, not three.

title: Screenwriters Adjust to Being Bit Players Again
description: LAST month, a company called New Regency beat out five other Hollywood studios for the rights to a psychological thriller written by a novice screenwriter. It was a fierce bidding war that recalled the heady days of the mid-1990's when Joe Eszterhas got a reported $2 million for the disastrous ''Showgirls'' on the basis of a story scribbled on a napkin and Shane Black was paid a record-breaking $4 million for another flop, ''The Long Kiss Goodnight.''

title: Whose Game Is It, Anyway?
description: AS some parents cheered and others screamed, Lakers and Celtics played a game that had shades of the 1980's-era rivalry between those professional teams. With a buzzer-beating shot, the game was sent into overtime, to the accompaniment of more cheers and lung-searing screams.

title: Music's Dangers And The Case For Control
description: AND on top of everything else, the Taliban hate music, too. In an interview in October with Nicholas Wroe, a columnist for the British newspaper The Guardian, John Baily, an ethnomusicologist on the faculty of Goldsmiths College, London, gave the details. After taking power in 1996, the Islamic fundamentalists who ruled most of Afghanistan undertook search-and-destroy missions in which musical instruments and cassette players were seized and burned in public pyres. Wooden poles were festooned with great ribbons of confiscated audio and video tape as a reminder of the ban, imposed in keeping with a maxim attributed to the prophet Muhammad warning ''those who listen to music and songs in this world'' that ''on the Day of Judgment molten lead will be poured into their ears.''

title: Return to Segregation
description: The release earlier this year of residential data from the 2000 census led to the conclusion that assimilation isn't working the way it used to. Though blacks, Hispanics, Asians and other nonwhite groups now constitute 31 percent of the population, up from 24 percent in 1990, the new housing data demonstrated a startling degree of isolation: Hispanics and Asians are living in more heavily Hispanic and Asian neighborhoods than they were 10 years ago, while whites and blacks are only slightly more exposed to one another than they were in 1990.

title: For the Elite, Easing the Way To Prison
description: IN February of last year, A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's, had a chat with Diana D. Brooks, the company's former chief executive. During their talk, he pointed to a newspaper photograph of her and said, ''You'll look good in stripes.''

title: Mirrors, Steel and Smoke for a Fairy Tale of Shadows
description: A NEW production of ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten,'' which opens at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening, directed by Herbert Wernicke in his Met debut, will be the company's second. Its predecessor was unveiled 35 years ago in celebration of the new theater in Lincoln Center. Indeed, that production was as much about the Met stage as it was about this fairy-tale opera by Richard Strauss and Hugo von Hofmannsthal.

title: Newark's Plan for an Arena May Rise Again
description: A deal that would allow the construction of an arena here for the New Jersey Nets and New Jersey Devils has been considered dead since it failed twice in recent months to advance in a State Assembly committee. But some of its backers said Friday that it might yet emerge from a lame-duck legislative session.

title: Security Is Tightened On Ships and at Ports
description: JOHN D. MACKEY, a San Francisco stockbroker, says that he has taken many cruises but had never experienced security measures as tight as those he encountered on a Crystal Harmony foliage cruise two months ago. The original itinerary called for leaving Montreal on Sept. 29 and arriving in New York 11 days later. But because the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center closed the Port of New York, the Harmony docked in Baltimore, from which New York-bound passengers were taken on chartered buses.

Nobody, it seemed, had the gumption to face the top-ranked and undefeated Hurricanes on Jan. 3 at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., this season's venue for the national championship game. Florida, Texas and Tennessee all had legitimate late-season shots at the No. 2 spot, which would have assured them a trip to Pasadena. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JANE
description: LEVY-Jane. 84 years, died at home early Sunday morning, December 9, 2001, after a long, brave battle with pancreatic cancer. For 61 wonderful years, she was the devoted and adoring wife of Jules, 88. She was the loving and proud mother of Fred, 54, of New York City, and Doug, 52, of Needham, MA, mother-in-law of Kathy and Margo, and grandmother of Andres, 21, and Nathaniel, 16, Jennifer, 21, and Jonathan, 16. Her parents were Rita and Morton Frederick of Margate, NJ. She also leaves her wonderful companion and caregiver of 25 years, Grace White. Jane had a long, full life, taking care of her family, traveling this country and the world with Jules, and working for 46 years with the Women's City Club to make New York a better city for everyone, serving as its Secretary and Treasurer. Her family mourns her passing, but celebrates her life. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be sent to the Women's City Club, 33 West 60th St., New York City 10023-7905.

title: A Recital Filled With Lively Connections
description: It was a beautifully planned and played recital that Aleck Karis gave at Merkin Hall on Tuesday. Connections were everywhere. Debussy at the start -- the second book of ''Images'' -- prepared the way for the musical fluidity of Elliott Carter's ''Night Fantasies,'' which followed. Harrison Birtwistle's ''Harrison's Clocks,'' musical mechanisms that had been prompted by a reading of Dava Sobel's ''Longitude,'' her book on the clocks of John Harrison, came after one of Harrison's contemporaries had just been heard from: J. S. Bach. The more chordal sections of the Bach piece -- his early Toccata in E minor -- had as much poetry as the Debussy.

Reserved, cool, calm. While others seethed, he simmered. Neat suit, lean 6-foot-5 frame, beard, watchful, seemingly gentle eyes. This is what was apparent when the Knicks held off a game Indiana Pacers team to win, 101-99, Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Lower Heating Bills Expected
description: Heating bills this winter are likely to be lower because of slowing demand, warm weather and the resulting increased energy inventories, industry officials say. Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest public utility company, said customers who heated their homes with oil and propane gas would see the largest and most immediate reductions in heating bills because those fuel prices more closely reflect current conditions in the commodities markets. But natural gas prices are set further in advance, so customers will not see a decrease in those bills until next month, the company said.

title: The Tao of Living

He was named one of the world's two main influences on hapkido by the Korean Hapkido Association and owns the New York Martial Arts Center of Downtown Manhattan. Given his background, I expected that Master Herbert (who asked that his first name not be used) would be purely focused on the physical. title: TALIBAN GIVE WAY IN FINAL PROVINCE WHERE THEY RULED
description: The five-year rule of the Taliban, exceptionally harsh even in a land governed for decades by bloodletting, came to an official end today as the last Afghan province slipped from their control. Their fractious opponents, due to start governing in two weeks, agreed to bury some of the many feuds that could jeopardize peace, but the two men most wanted by the United States continued to elude capture.

description: A resource crucial to the economic recovery of the United States is buried underground. Hundreds of thousands of miles of fiber-optic cable, which enables the fast, robust communication that was so important to the economic success of the last decade, currently lies unused, the digital equivalent of fallow farmland.

title: Wavering on Campaign Reform
description: In the closing weeks of this year's Congressional session, lawmakers who say they are for campaign finance reform have a chance to prove that they mean it. Only seven more signatures are required to force the Shays-Meehan soft-money ban to the floor of the House, where it has passed twice. The House speaker, Dennis Hastert, has said he will not bring the bill out of committee until 218 signatures, or a majority of House members, are on the list. Two groups, one of Democrats and one of Republicans, are conspicuously not going along. Their refusal cannot be excused any more.

Funeral services will be held Monday, December 10, 12 noon, at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at 55th St. Donations may be made to Medical Development for Israel, 130 East 59th St, Suite 1203, NY, NY 10022, or Schneider Children's Hospital, Room CH102, Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY 11040.

title: Laurie Johnston, 87, Former Times Reporter
description: Laurie Johnston, a World War II correspondent, an author and a reporter for The New York Times who was cited for the humanity and wit of her writing, died at her home in Honolulu on Friday. She was 87.

title: Patents; Some inventions for the season of gift giving, including how to pass along virtual fruitcake.
description: MARK TWAIN once observed that the gift-giving pressures of the December holidays bring ''harassment and dread to many excellent people.'' Twain (who was an inventor as well as a writer -- his hottest idea being the scrapbook, which he patented in 1873) might have embraced a patent that was issued last month to RichFX, a company that make 3-D video graphics. It has headquarters in Manhattan and Israel.

title: The Week's Economic Events
description: MONDAYNone

title: White House Letter; Bush the Commander Is Political Leader, Too
description: George W. Bush had to perform a wide straddle between the war and home fronts last week, first at a cheery boost-the-economy town hall meeting in Orlando, Fla., then at a somber boost-the-troops speech on the gargantuan deck of the U.S.S. Enterprise.

title: Another Tape Ties bin Laden To Hijackings

He was 71.

description: What is the sound of one hand chatting?

description: The landlord wasted no time in slapping a ''For Lease'' sign on the offices of the Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development after the federal government froze its assets on Monday, calling it a terrorist front. Several major corporate donors announced they would block all contributions to the foundation.

title: Mentally, They're Fine. Dentally, Not Always.
description: When Charles Lewellen reported for his weekend rotation at the Naval Reserve Center in the Bronx last month, he checked to see if he had made adequate preparations in case he was called up for active duty. His finances? Check. His physical and mental health? Check, check. His life insurance, will and paperwork? Check, check and check.

Devoted mother of John Avrutis, Amy Avrutis and Hilary Avrutis Samter. Loving mother-in-law of Stephen Samter and Marci Avrutis. Cherished grandmother of Alexis Samter, Zachary and Paige Avrutis. description: It has been a long decline for the Giants this season, with each stunning collapse only the prelude to deeper disappointment. Today at Texas Stadium, the failure was so stark, so plain and repugnant, the Giants finally trampled the last vestige of good will remaining from their Super Bowl season of a year ago.

description: As the ritual of end-of-the-year forecasts begins, Wall Street's legions of economists are lining up to predict the recession's imminent end. With signs emerging that manufacturing orders and business investment are starting to perk up, all that is needed, the optimists say, is for consumer spending, which has held up better than in past downturns, to improve just a little. All will then be well.

title: In 5th Season, 'Ally' Seems To Be Stalling
description: ''Ally McBeal,'' the Fox comedy series that in its first four seasons generated big ratings, numerous male-female sociological discussions and, most memorably, a Time magazine cover story, is now generating mostly shrugs. That is bad news for Fox, which considers the show one of its premiere attractions for the younger-adult audience advertisers covet.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Greystone Land Sale
description: The State Senate approved legislation last week to sell part of the land surrounding Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital to Morris County for $1, to preserve the land as open space. The Assembly approved the bill on Nov. 29, and it now goes to the governor for his signature or veto. Critics call the bill a giveaway of land that could have generated revenue for mental health services. But the bill's sponsors say the sale prevents the state from selling the land to developers. The state has announced plans to close the hospital, which has had a troubled history, but there are proposals to build a mental health center on another part of the property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, DOROTHY (SLOTNICK)
description: RUBIN-Dorothy (Slotnick). December 7, 2001, three weeks before her 82nd birthday. Predeceased by her beloved husband Jack and sister Lee. Avid reader, film buff, grammarian and the true spirit and historian of the family. She lived in Delray, FL, but her heart was in New York. She was the most wonderful, generous, beautiful, loving and proudest mother of Sandi and Steven Spivak, and Ellen and Neil Stepman, and grandmother of Lisa, Jessica and Amy. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice by the Sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRISCOLL, DAVID BURTON
description: DRISCOLL-David Burton. Died peacefully December 6, at age 59, after a heroic year-long battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Patricia Ellen Rowell, devoted father of Scott and Hannah, loving grandfather of Jack and Emma, and younger brother of Dr. Scott H. M. Driscoll. Graduate of Princeton University, class of 1964, and holder of an MBA from New York University. David was founder and president of Old New York Realty. He had a passion for nature, music and art and will be greatly missed for his intelligence, humor and grace. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, December 11, at 6 PM, at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Ave. and 29th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Harlem Valley Rail Trail Association, PO Box 356, Millerton, NY 12546.

The revenue from coated papers, inks and all the other paraphernalia needed to make those prints would be a soothing balm to film companies wounded by digital photography, and to printer manufacturers suffering from plummeting prices.

title: The Latest Mammography Debate
description: Breast cancer screening by mammography has become such an accepted part of medical care for American women that it is a shock to find analysts still questioning whether it has any value. Two researchers writing in a recent issue of The Lancet, a respected British medical journal, have analyzed all the main clinical trials used to justify the value of mammography and found most of them faulty. Their own conclusion is that mammography, which uses X-rays to detect tiny lumps in the breast before they can be felt by physical examination, has not been shown to reduce mortality from breast cancer or prolong women's lives.

Investigators arrested Mr. Rios first and caught Mr. Mundo after he tried to hijack a car in Connecticut, the police said. They said the accused knew the victims. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

As might be expected of this wildly imaginative theater company, what it attempts is preposterous: an exciting journey into the ideas of Galileo, who pushed the Earth aside; Tycho Brahe, whose precise astronomical observations helped establish a vital scientific standard of evidence; and Johannes Kepler, whose laws of elliptical planetary orbits foreshadowed Newton's theory of celestial mechanics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVERSTROM, GUNNAR S, JR.
description: OVERSTROM-Gunnar S, Jr. Of West Hartford, CT, a prominent banker and distinguished community leader, died unexpectedly on December 6, while traveling in Chicago, IL. He was 59. Mr. Overstrom, a former Vice Chairman of FleetBoston Financial, and the former President and Chief Operating Officer of the Shawmut National Corporation, was a Managing Director of Shawmut Capital Partners, a venture capital firm headquarted in Boston, MA, as well as the Founder and Managing Member of Larus Brothers, LLC, an investment and consulting company in Farmington, CT. Mr. Overstrom joined Shawmut Capital from Fleet where he served as a Vice Chairman from 1995 through 1999, following the merger of that company with the Shawmut National Corporation. He was instrumental in building Fleet's asset management portfolio and its brokerage and securities business. Prior to the merger with Fleet, Mr. Overstrom served as President, Chief Operating Officer and a Director of Shawmut National from 1988 to 1995, as well as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of all its major banking subsidiaries. While at Shawmut National he helped lead the corporation in making over 50 acquisitions and building the company from a $2 billion regional bank to a $35 billion super-regional institution with offices in five states. Mr. Overstrom became an officer of Shawmut National as a result of the 1988 merger between the Shawmut Corporation and the Hartford National Corporation, where he served as a Director, its Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Overstrom began his banking career at Hartford National in 1975 as Vice President of Planning. He was elected Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer in 1978. Prior to Hartford National he worked at the Travelers Insurance Company and at White Weld & Co. Mr. Overstrom was born in Buffalo, NY, on August 18, 1942. He was the son of Gunnar S Overstrom and Selma Mansour Overstrom. He received a bachelor's degree from Babson College, Wellesley, MA, in 1965; an L.L.B. from Suffolk University Law School, Boston, MA, in 1968; and an M.A. in Economics from Trinity College, Hartford, CT, in 1972. He served on the Board of Directors of HPSC, Inc., Boston, MA; NexClaim Technologies, Inc., Rocky Hill, CT; Poorman Douglas, Beaverton, OR; and was a Trustee of T.O. Richardson Co., Farmington, CT. Mr. Overstrom was a member of the Board of Overseers and a former Trustee of Babson College. He also was a past President of The Old State House Association in Hartford and a member of the Emerging Issues Committee of The Bankers Roundtable. He was a former Trustee of the Kingswood Oxford School in West Hartford, CT, The Science Center of Connecticut, also in West Hartford, and the Museum of Science in Boston, MA. He previously served as a corporator of Hartford Hospital, Saint Francis Hospital, Mount Sinai Hospital, the Institute of Living, and the Old State House, all in Hartford, and as a Director of Connecticut Health Systems, Inc. He also was a member of Boston's Private Industry Council and served on its Corporate Diversity Committee. Of all the things he treasured, his family was his greatest joy in life. Mr. Overstrom is survived by his wife of 36 years, Margery Larus Overstrom of West Hartford, CT, and his two sons and daughter-in-law, Gunnar S Overstrom III and his wife Claudia Taylor Overstrom of New York City, and Alexander Edward Cadwell Overstrom, also of West Hartford; Mr. Overstrom's aunt and uncle, Esther Hall of Buffalo, NY, and John Mansour of Olean, NY, also survive him. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, December 12, at 10 AM, at St. Patrick's Church, 110 Main St., Farmington. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Mr. Overstrom's memory can be made to the Gunnar S Overstrom, Jr., Family Foundation for WALKS Scholars, a foundation created to support the education and enrichment of young minority students from the Greater Hartford area, c/o The Loomis Chaffee School, Windsor, CT 06095.

description: The Great Conciliator has gone to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, RUTH ANN
description: MARTIN-Ruth Ann. Of Naples, Florida, formerly of Lloyd Harbor, New York, died peacefully December 8, 2001. Beloved wife of Milward W. Martin II, loving mother of Katherine B. Martin, Tucson, AZ; Milward W. Martin III of Naples, FL; Alison S. Martin of Beverly Hills, CA; Susan G. Martin of N.Y., N.Y. and a grandson Andrew Allman of New Smyrna Beach, FL. She is also survived by her sisters Camilla Ridley and Gail Wynns both of Naples, FL. Her parents were the former Mr. and Mrs. Jules R. Gimbernat of Naples, Florida and Locust Valley, NY. She was a graduate of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York and Manhattanville College. A memorial service will be held at St. Anns Church, 745 3rd Street, Naples, FL 34112 on Friday, December 14, 2001 at 11:30 AM.

title: Bush's Speech at The Citadel
description: Following is the full text of President Bush's remarks yesterday at the Citadel, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Shot Dead
description: A 21-year-old man was found shot in the head last night at 93-12 212th Street in Queens Village, just before 10 p.m. The man, who was not identified, was taken to North Shore University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. No arrests have been made, and police are investigating the death as a homicide. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Bush Leads Sept. 11 Ceremony and Vows to Right the Wrong
description: In a short and somber ceremony, President Bush led the nation and the world today in remembering the events of Sept. 11, when the first of two hijacked airliners smashed into the World Trade Center at 8:46 a.m. Eastern time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERER, CLARA LEGG
description: SCHERER-Clara Legg. Age 92 died on Monday, December 10, 2001 in Manchester, VT. Beloved wife of the late Albert G. Scherer, Jr., mother of A. George Scherer III of Bondville, VT and Elaine S. Romaine of New York, NY. She also leaves 4 grandchildren and 5 great-grandchildren. She was a member of the Colony Club of New York and the Colonial Dames of New York City. She was a 1927 graduate of Miss Porter's School. The funeral service will be private in the family plot in Middletown NJ. Donations may be made to The Berkshire Humane Society, 108 Cadwell Road, Pittsfield, MA 01201, or Miss Porter's School, 560 Main St, Farmington, CT, 06032 would be greatly appreciated. For further information please contact the Brewster Funeral Service, Manchester, VT.

title: One For His Country, and One Against It
description: Shortly before he left for Afghanistan, Johnny Micheal Spann sent an e-mail message to his parents back in Winfield, Ala.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Engineers Ask Nature For Design Advice
description: What does a flower known as the sacred white lotus have to do with house paint?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, BEN
description: STEIN-Ben Zion. Congregation Orach Chaim extends its heartfelt condolences to our devoted member, Dr. Barry Stein, on the passing of his beloved father in South Africa, where the shiva will be observed. May he and the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi James A. Lassner, President

title: Dynegy Asks Court to Let It Buy Pipeline From Enron
description: Dynegy opened a new front yesterday in its legal battle to gain possession of Enron's valuable Northern Natural Gas pipeline, arguing that loan defaults by Enron give Dynegy the right to buy the pipeline.

title: Big Steel: An Invalid That Can Roar In Washington
description: Trying to keep their long downward slide from becoming a death spiral, the nation's old-line steel makers are pressing the federal government for special treatment granted to almost no other industry.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Deadline For Redistricting
description: Commissioners on the state's redistricting panel began five days of special meetings that they hope will bring an end to the often contentious process of drawing up a plan for the state's new political boundaries. The citizens' panel of two Republicans and two Democrats has until Saturday to submit borders for Washington's 49 legislative districts to the Legislature, which can make only minor changes. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture by The Associated Press yesterday with an article about state and local governments' concerns over the costs of security to prevent terrorism misspelled the name of a company whose nuclear power plant in Minnesota was being guarded by the local police. It is Xcel Energy, not Excel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, MAXINE
description: CHARNEY-Maxine. Of Yonkers, NY on December 10, 2001. Devoted daughter of the late Frances and Edward Gurvitch and sister of the late Morton Gurvitch. Loving wife of Dr. Sol Charney and devoted mother of Dr. Richard Charney of Briarcliff Manor and Dr. Robert Charney of Springfield NJ. Loving mother-in-law of Stacy Charney. Adoring grandmother of Molly and Laura. Beloved sister-in-law, aunt and cousin. Graveside services at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey on Wednesday, December 12.

title: Delphi Automotive Will Cut 1,400 More Jobs
description: The Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, the maker of auto parts, said today that it would eliminate 1,400 more jobs, on top of 11,500 cuts announced in March, as it reduces costs and as vehicle production slows.

title: CHAIN OF USED CAR DEALERS IS BOUGHT BY ITS CHAIRMAN
description: The Ugly Duckling Corporation, a chain of used car dealerships for people with bad credit, has agreed to be sold to its chairman and largest stockholder, Ernest C. Garcia, for about $15.5 million. Under the terms of the deal announced yesterday, companies controlled by Mr. Garcia and Gregory Sullivan, Ugly Duckling's president and chief executive, will pay $3.53 a share for the remaining common stock in the company, which is based in Phoenix. The price is 40 percent higher than Mr. Garcia's Nov. 26 tender offer price of $2.51 a share, his third in 13 months. Mr. Garcia owns about 65 percent of the 12.4 million shares outstanding, the company said.

title: Rangers Overlook Their 4-Game Slide to Praise a Comeback
description: Mark Messier called it a gutty point after the Rangers rallied from a 3-1 deficit in the third period at Madison Square Garden last night, only to lose to the Carolina Hurricanes, 4-3, on Ron Francis' power-play goal in overtime.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE TO USE SMALL JETS AND ADD RUNS IN WEST
description: The AMR Corporation's commuter airline will use regional jets from Los Angeles for the first time, introducing them on some flights dropped by the company's American Airlines unit after the terrorist attacks. The regional airline, American Eagle, will start flying the 44-seat jets in February between Los Angeles International Airport and Phoenix; Albuquerque; and Oakland, Calif. Flights to Sacramento will be added in March. American Eagle is adding 19 regional jet flights to its 60 daily departures from Los Angeles. The regional jets permit American Eagle to fly longer distances than with turboprops and at a lower cost than with a jetliner.

title: Erstad Is Next On Yankees' Wish List
description: With Jason Giambi's signing all but complete, the Yankees are considering trading Orlando Hernndez and minor league pitchers to the Anaheim Angels for the All-Star outfielder Darin Erstad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCLAFANI, FRANK
description: SCLAFANI-Frank. The Firm of Diamond, Wohl, Fried, Roth & Co. wishes to extend our deepest sympathy to our longtime staff member, Anna, on the untimely loss of her husband and send condolences to the rest of their family.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Insurance After Sept. 11
description: The New York State Legislature has scheduled a public hearing on insurance issues after the Sept. 11 terror attack, including how quickly consumer claims are processed and the financial health of the industry. Assembly Hearing Room, 19th floor, Room 1923, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 10:30 a.m. Information: (518) 455-3888.

title: Gauges Are Down as Many Energy Issues Are Hammered
description: Stocks fell yesterday as investors cashed in on the recent run-up and cast a cautious eye toward the Federal Reserve's meeting today.

title: Spending on Ads Is Down Sharply
description: Advertising spending in major media fell 7.8 percent in the first nine months of 2001 as cutbacks by marketers accelerated, according to a report yesterday from CMR in New York, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MURRAY
description: GOLDMAN-Murray. Consulting Engineer, age 81, died December 1, 2001. Devoted husband of Anne, loving father of David, Susan Luca and Ellen, and brother of Rosalind Black. Murray spent his first years on the Lower East Side in New York City; the family later moved to Ozone Park. In the early 1940s he worked for the government as a pipefitter at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He was a veteran of a railway shop battalion in India in W.W. II and was a graduate of the NYU School of Engineering. He went on to become a contractor and a mechanical engineer for over 50 years. A man with a wonderful sense of humor, a generous heart and the highest professional standards, Murray worked on hundreds of projects throughout New York City. Services were held on December 4, at the I.J. Morris Funeral Home in Hempstead, NY; burial was at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations may be made in his name to your local chapter of the American Heart Association.

title: Snow at Last
description: Until late last Saturday night, there had been nothing seasonal about this season. People stood in lines in front of the holiday windows on Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue, wishing, in their shirt sleeves, that it was possible to feel cozy, which the holiday demands, when the thermometer reads 68 degrees. Even in the country north of the city, the grass stayed green later than it ever had. Three weeks ago it was still possible to mow the lawn meaningfully or play a round of golf without having to pretend that it somehow didn't count.

title: Coaching Change Will Affect Layden, Too
description: The Knicks officially began a new coaching era yesterday when their president and general manager, Scott Layden, announced that the longtime assistant Don Chaney had been promoted to coach. Chaney, who inherited the position when Jeff Van Gundy resigned unexpectedly on Saturday, was endorsed heartily by Knicks players. It is their performance over the next 62 games and the playoffs, if they make it far, that will determine the length of Chaney's tenure.

title: The Wrong Foot, And Other Tales Of Surgical Error
description: Most people can easily tell right from left, but for some surgeons it seems to be a problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, BERNARD
description: ROSENBERG-Bernard. Passed away Friday, November 30, 2001 at the age of 81. Beloved husband of Rita, devoted father of Richard and Andrea and father-in-law of Louis Kerner. Cherished grandfather of Dana and Melissa. Everyday you will be missed. We all love you dearly.

title: Sports of The Times; Van Gundy Can Finally Hit the Sack
description: MARK JACKSON, who for 15 pro seasons has played point guard with a purpose, aspires to be a head coach. When he gets the deserved opportunity, here is how he will prepare for a December meeting with the Boston Celtics, tonight's opposition for the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Green Aide Calls Finances In Race Unfair
description: The chairman of Mark Green's unsuccessful mayoral campaign testified yesterday that the city's respected campaign finance program ''failed completely'' to level the playing field between Mr. Green and Michael R. Bloomberg, who was elected mayor after spending $69 million on the race.

title: Carrier Adjusts Fuel Fee
description: Airborne Inc., the air-freight carrier, is lowering the portion of its express rates linked to fuel costs to 2.9 percent from 4 percent, after similar moves were made by larger rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUNTEE, ROGER W., M.D.
description: COUNTEE-Roger W., M.D. We mourn the death of Roger Countee. Dr. Countee completed his neurosurgical training at the Neurological Institute of New York, Columbia University in 1975. He was a dedicated and caring physician, outstanding surgeon, respected colleague and a dear friend. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife, Jane, and his wonderful children and family. Dept. of Neurological Surgery New York Presbyterian Hospital Columbia University

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Hospital Chief Concedes Problems
description: Inmates sent to the Arkansas state psychiatric hospital by the courts are not receiving the necessary treatment or evaluation and are a threat to themselves and others, the medical director of the hospital, Dr. Larry Miller, testified. Dr. Miller conceded that the hospital's equipment and resources were not adequate to its mission and said the situation was deteriorating. He testified on the first day of a suit in Federal District Court by the American Civil Liberties Union to force improvements.

title: Ready to Sacrifice for Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Pressplay To Allow Home CD'S
description: Pressplay, an online music venture backed by Sony Music Entertainment and the Universal Music Group, said yesterday that subscribers would be allowed to create compact discs from music downloaded from the service. Executives of Pressplay reiterated that the service was scheduled to start this month, adding that it would make available about 100,000 songs. Pressplay has yet to disclose how much the service will cost or how many songs subscribers will be able to download each month. However, the company said that in the some cases, subscribers would be allowed to burn songs onto compact discs, effectively creating their own CD's. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: As Acid Reflux Cases Rise, Doctors Are Asking Why
description: In 1993, right out of college, Maura Donovan began to feel sick to her stomach periodically throughout the day. She had a burning sensation in her chest and cramps that were at their worst every morning after breakfast. Occasionally, when she went out for pizza and beer or Chinese food with friends, the pain got even worse.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Protest Turns Violent
description: More than 100 demonstrators attacked two British Army watchtowers and a police barracks on Sunday night, leaving 21 police officers and 3 British soldiers injured, some with serious head injuries and burns. The attacks, in the Armagh area near the border with the Irish Republic, began as protests demanding faster British demilitarization in Northern Ireland that were organized by the youth branch of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Out of Many, New York
description: The eggs Benedict and the Bloody Mary are still delights at P. J. Clarke's on Third Avenue, and when I try to get tickets for ''The Producers,'' they tell me all the seats are booked until May. In the cinemas, restaurants and museums of New York I see nothing unusual. However, what occurred on Sept. 11 is an ominous backdrop to all conversations with New York friends and intrudes on a visitor in unexpected ways.

title: Testaverde Braces for Critics of Offense
description: Vinny Testaverde knows that after two terrible losses, and after a six-game stretch in which the Jets' offense has scored seven touchdowns, he is on trial during the final month of the season.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, LUCILLE G.
description: MARSHALL-Lucille G. December 6, 2001. Services December 12, 12N. Pope Funeral Homes, 11315 Lockwood Dr, Silver Spring, MD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREVILLIAN, MARY LOU
description: TREVILLIAN-Mary Lou. Of Greenville, S.C., wife of Dr. Wallace D. Trevillian, a Dean Emeritus of Clemson University, died Sunday. She was a graduate of Spence School, New York and Sarah Lawrence College. Other survivors include two sons, three grandchildren and a sister. She was predeceassed by her parents Bonnie E. and W.W. McEachern.

title: Giving Birth in England
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Mideast Peace Envoy Makes His Impatience Clear
description: Concerned that the Bush administration's Middle East envoy was about to walk out on them, Israelis and Palestinians urged him today to stick with his peace-seeking mission, which has yet to produce a glimmer of progress.

title: In Nobel Talk, Annan Sees Each Human Life as the Prize
description: Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations, used the occasion of the 2001 Nobel Peace Prize lecture today to make an impassioned case for the continued importance of the organization as a promoter of peace and a champion of individual rights in an unstable and unequal world.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Weigh Criminal Sentencing
description: The Supreme Court took a long-awaited next step today in its continuing re-examination of the respective roles of judges and juries in criminal sentencing, accepting a case that could call into question several important federal sentencing provisions and perhaps the federal sentencing guidelines themselves.

title: America West Revises Request To Offer U.S. 10% of Airline
description: America West Airlines, seeking to win a federal loan guarantee, said yesterday that it had amended its application to give the government an option to buy 10 percent of the airline.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Group Raises Funds
description: Colt Telecom Group, which provides voice and data services to customers like the London Stock Exchange and Buckingham Palace, raised 494 million ($708 million) by selling 649.4 million new shares, or 97.5 percent of the offering, to existing investors. Fidelity Investments, a unit of FMR and Colt's largest shareholder, agreed to buy 309.5 million shares, and subscribed for an additional 168 million shares, including 16 million shares that other investors did not want. The transaction will raise Fidelity's holding in Colt to 54 percent from about 48 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Flesh-and-Blood Intimacy From Wagnerian Granite
description: Walking along the festive Saturday afternoon streets of Covent Garden -- rock bands, African dancers and roistering pub crawlers -- and into the pious, ecstatic world of Wagner's ''Parsifal'' was the shock of human behavior at its two extremes: Bruegel and Drer separated by the walls of the Royal Opera House.

title: Republican Leader to Announce Plans for His Future, Aide Says
description: Following reports that he is considering retirement, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, plans to make an announcement this week about his political future, an associate said.

title: Argentina Scrambles for I.M.F. Loans
description: The economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, has announced that he will annul more than $4 billion in tax cuts for businesses in an effort to cut the budget deficit next year and persuade the International Monetary Fund to release $1.3 billion in loans before the end of the month.

title: Transcript of Gov. Gary Johnson's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Wednesday, Dec. 5, the NYTimes.com Drug Policy forum hosted New Mexico Governor Gary Johnson. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: H.I.V. Patients Get Fresh Hopes for Donor Organs
description: It would not be like him to lie down and die quietly.

title: Hyatt Hotel Family Will Pay $460 Million in S.& L. Case
description: The Pritzkers, one of the nation's wealthiest families and heirs to the fortune created by the Hyatt hotels, agreed today to pay a record $460 million to the federal government to avoid being punished for the failure of Superior Bank F.S.B., the big savings and loan institution that regulators seized last summer.

title: Pearl Harbor's Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: A Season Makes All the Difference in Calgary
description: Last March, on the day after he was traded from the St. Louis Blues, a Stanley Cup contender, to the struggling Calgary Flames, center Craig Conroy had to adjust to another big change. Coach Don Hay was gone.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Former U.S. Official To Run For Senate
description: Gloria Tristani, a former member of the Federal Communications Commission, said she would seek the Democratic nomination for Senate and challenge Senator Pete V. Domenici, a Republican, in the 2002 election. Mr. Domenici, 69, has served five six-year terms since he was first elected in 1972. Ms. Tristani, 47, appointed to the commission in 1997 by President Bill Clinton, resigned in September. A granddaughter of a former senator from New Mexico, Dennis Chavez, Ms. Tristani hopes to be the first woman to be a senator from the state. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Melting Glaciers in Antarctica Are Raising Oceans, Experts Say
description: Antarctica appears to be melting and contributing to the slow rise in the oceans, scientists reported to their colleagues here today.

title: North Africans in Europe Said to Preach War, Enlisting Young Immigrants
description: The young man left his home here with the same dreams that have propelled thousands of Tunisians across the Mediterranean to Italy: a job, adventure, a taste of freedom.

title: Phone Giants In Europe Shift Focus
description: In an effort to put the free spending and rapid debt run-ups of the last few years behind them, European telecommunications companies are turning to a search for ways to squeeze revenue growth from their existing assets, company executives said today. Signs of the new thrift are visible in two deals, one announced today and another to be unveiled later this week.

title: A Young Strauss Ventures Into the Scary Bluebeard World
description: Philadelphia Orchestra

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Nov. 24 about an archaeological boom in the Southwest that is overwhelming the region's museums and anthropological institutions misstated the reason the National Park Service removed a collection from the Museum of Anthropology at the University of Denver last summer. The action resulted from a raise in the museum's fee for curatorial services, not from substandard conditions.

title: Giants' Long Shot Becomes Virtually No Shot
description: In the time it took to fly to Dallas, play miserably and fly back, the Giants were transformed from a team playing defiantly against long playoff odds to a team playing out the string. The Giants did not say today that they were giving up on what was left of their season; they just appeared and sounded defeated, which comes with not having won a game for a month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Kennedy Terminal Evacuated
description: A terminal at Kennedy Airport was evacuated after a passenger found a knife past a security checkpoint at 5:45 p.m. yesterday. Flights out of the terminal were grounded, and passengers who had boarded planes had to return to the terminal. Police dogs checked the entire building, Terminal 3, which houses Delta Airlines, and passengers waiting for 11 planes had to be screened again. The rescreening was completed by 10 p.m., said Jim Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The knife, found between the cushions of a seat in one of the boarding areas, had a four-inch serrated blade, an F.A.A. official said. It was not known how long the knife had been there. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Separatist Leader Re-Elected
description: The tiny self-proclaimed republic of Transdniestr re-elected its president, Igor Smirnov, to a third five-year term, apparently ensuring the continuation of a long feud with Moldova over the region's claim to independence. Russia quietly backed Transdniestrian independence until Moldova elected a pro-Russian Communist government this year; this time, it called the election illegal, as did other international observers. Transdniestr residents speak Russian and broke from Moldova in part because Moldovans speak Romanian. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Bus Company Is Accused Of Traffic in Illegal Aliens
description: In one of the government's largest actions ever against smugglers, the Justice Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service today announced the indictment of 32 officers and employees of a bus company that they said moved thousands of illegal aliens from the Mexican border to cities in the Western United States.

title: Lawyers Say That Rabbi Should Not Face Death
description: Lawyers for a South Jersey rabbi are hoping that an appeal in a little-noticed murder case may spare their client from facing the death penalty when he is retried following a jury deadlock last month in his first trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTCHTAR, HAROLD
description: POTCHTAR-Harold. Age 77, passed away Friday, December 7, in Boca Raton, FL. Mr. Potchtar was the former president, CEO and co-founder of Toscany Imports Ltd., NYC. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in W.W. II earning two DFC's. Mr. Potchtar was the former president of the Italy America Chamber of Commerce and an appointee to President Carter's Special Commission for US-China Trade, and was decorated by the Italian government as ''Commendatore'' (Knight Commander). A longtime resident of New York, he is survived by his wife, Marsha, his daughter, Jan (Scott) Kokjer, and sisters, Sheila Sell and Leona Kovner. The family requests that any contributions be directed to American Diabetes Association. Information: Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapels, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Pierre de Benouville, 87, Hero Of Resistance in World War II
description: Pierre de Bnouville, a hero of the French Resistance in World War II, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 87 and lived in Paris.

title: The bin Laden Tapes
description: Having discouraged American television news organizations from broadcasting videotapes made by Osama bin Laden, the White House now finds itself in the awkward position of weighing what to do with a new recording that it obviously wants the world to see. It should make the tape public, as it seems inclined to do. The White House never should have gotten into the news management business in the first place.

title: Intimate 'Parsifal'
description: Something special was happening as the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden in London unveiled a new production by Klaus Michael Grber of Wagner's ''Parsifal,'' conducted by Simon Rattle. Bernard Holland's review, Page 5.

title: Digging Up A Disorder From a Mess
description: Behaviors that we do not understand often become nearly invisible -- even when, in retrospect, we see how truly strange they are.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Offer For Psinet's Japanese Unit
description: Cable and Wireless said yesterday that it had submitted a bid to acquire the Japanese operations of PSINet, the bankrupt Internet services company. Cable and Wireless, which is based in London, agreed to pay about $10.2 million in cash for PSINet Japan and assume about $25 million of the unit's liabilities. The move is an extension of the Cable and Wireless strategy of using cash resources to acquire the Web site operating and Internet storage assets of ailing concerns. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Later Video Of bin Laden May Be Public This Week
description: President Bush said today that a videotape showing Osama bin Laden reveling in the Sept. 11 attacks proved that the Al Qaeda leader was ''guilty of incredible murder'' and that he ''has no conscience and no soul.''

title: Tom Daschle Isn't the Problem
description: The closing days of this year's Congressional session have brought forth a wild Republican campaign to demonize Senator Tom Daschle. It almost seems as if the G.O.P. is holding a contest to see who can most often use the word ''obstructionist'' to describe him. The attacks -- including ads in Mr. Daschle's home state of South Dakota featuring side-by-side photographs of him and Saddam Hussein -- are a sure sign of the Senate majority leader's effectiveness in blocking President Bush's hard-right agenda. Today Mr. Bush meets with Mr. Daschle at the White House, where they can move beyond vilification to legislation.

title: $460 Million Payout Set in S.& L. Failure
description: The Pritzkers, heirs to the fortune created by the Hyatt hotels, agreed to pay a record $460 million to the federal government to avoid being punished for the failure of Superior Bank, the big savings and loan institution in Illinois that regulators seized last summer.

description: To the Editor:

title: Chaney May Be Easygoing, But His Practices Won't Be
description: Leave the shuffleboard sticks in the closet. Do not bother bringing the swimsuit. Do not even think of packing the golf clubs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZIFF, CHARLIE
description: ZIFF-Charlie. 12/11/49 to 7/4/92. You're always in my heart. Happy Birthday. Love, Stephe

title: Nomination For New Post As Safety Chief
description: The White House intends to nominate a former head of the Secret Service and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to take charge of the new Transportation Security Administration, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, CHARLES
description: RUSSO-Charles. On December 9, 2001. Beloved husband of Roberta, devoted father of JR, Gabriel, Elana and Michael, adored grandfather of Matthew, Craig and Ryan. Services today 1:15 PM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Blvd, Flushing, New York.

title: TALIBAN DEFEATED, PENTAGON ASSERTS, BUT WAR GOES ON
description: Three months after the attacks on America and nine weeks after bombs began falling on Afghanistan, a senior-level Pentagon official said for the first time today that the Taliban government had been defeated.

title: Accomplice in Massacre Says He Heard Police Beat Partner
description: A confessed accomplice in the brutal killing of five people at a Wendy's restaurant in Queens last year testified yesterday that he had heard his partner in the crime being roughed up and shouting, ''They're beating me up,'' while the two were being questioned at a police station house.

title: Daylong Venezuelan Strike Protests Economic Program
description: Businesses across Venezuela closed today, and millions of workers stayed home in a stunning display of opposition to President Hugo Chvez's economic program.

title: 2001 Bonuses On Wall Street Decline 30%, To $10 Billion
description: It's official: this year's bonuses for Wall Street workers will plunge by about 30 percent, to $10 billion, according to State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, whose office annually estimates bonus payments.

title: Holding the Victims' Purse Strings, Uneasily
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Washington mediator in charge of the multibillion-dollar federal fund set up to compensate the families of those killed and injured in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, had just taken his first close look at ground zero in New York, the smoking pit where the twin towers once stood.

title: You Get Just One Night Out, You Want Your Own Look
description: In the ''don we now our gay apparel'' department, some folks have a definitive edge. Take Santa Claus, for example. With his white-trimmed red velvet sack suit, jaunty hat and black patent leather belt, Santa is generally conceded to be, if not the best-dressed man at Christmas, then the one who is absolutely sure that what he's wearing is correct.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Meeting XBOX Goals
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had shipped 1.1 million Xbox video-game consoles since their Nov. 15 release and planned to ship another 300,000 this month. The figures fall at the high end of Microsoft's forecast that it would ship 1 million to 1.5 million by the end of the year. While Microsoft did not release sales figures, Credit Suisse First Boston said Microsoft sold 182,000 Xboxes the week after Thanksgiving, with a retail price of $300, for a total of 738,000 systems since the console's introduction. Nintendo -- which began selling its GameCube, priced at $200, on Nov. 18 -- sold 65,000 systems in the same week, for a total of 534,000. Credit Suisse said sales across the game industry this quarter were exceeding forecasts. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Television Concern Cuts Jobs
description: NTL, a British cable television provider, said it would eliminate 2,000 jobs, bringing the total jobs cut this year to 8,800, nearly one-third of its work force. The company is also freezing pay for managers to cut costs and is selling assets to reduce about $17.5 billion in debt. The sale of a unit that provides satellite links and broadcasts television programs has recently run into trouble. France Tlcom, which owns 25 percent of NTL, said last month that it would bid for the unit only as part of a consortium. Analysts had expected France Tlcom to buy the unit on its own. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Star Clipper
description: The Star Clipper, a four-masted 170-passenger ship that sails the Caribbean, is offering two-for-one pricing on four one-week departures this winter. Rates start at $1,475 a cabin, based on double occupancy, and all trips leave from St. Maarten. On Jan. 20, the stops include St. Barts, Nevis, Guadeloupe and Antigua. On Feb. 10 and 24 and March 10, the ports of call include Anguilla, Virgin Gorda, St. Kitts and St. Barts. Trips must be booked by Jan. 31, and the rates do not include air fare, tips, port charges and miscellaneous expenses. title: Mets Acquire 11-Time All-Star From Cleveland
description: BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- The Mets acquired Roberto Alomar from the Cleveland Indians in a blockbuster eight-player trade today, immediately upgrading themselves with an 11-time All-Star who is considered the best second baseman in the major leagues. The Mets dealt outfielder Matt Lawton, elite prospect Alex Escobar, reliever Jerrod Riggan and two players to be named while also getting two minor leaguers in the deal, according to a baseball official involved in the talks. General Manager Steve Phillips predicted on Monday night that the Mets would probably make a trade before the winter meetings ended and, several hours later, he followed with a major transaction. Alomar is a .306 career hitter and has won 10 Gold Glove Awards so he will give the Mets a boost at the top of their lineup while also stabilizing their middle infield. Now that the Mets have acquired Alomar, it is obvious they will move second baseman Edgardo Alfonzo to third base. Alfonzo, who shifted from third to second once before and is in the last year of his contract, had expressed doubts about switching back. Although Phillips said he had tremendous respect for Alfonzo's opinion, he planned to explore any options that would better the team. Even before getting Alomar, the Mets were convinced that Alfonzo would switch if they asked him. Now Alfonzo has no choice. Alomar, who turns 34 in February, is a future Hall of Fame player who is only expendable because Cleveland is trying to shed payroll. He has two years and $16 million left on his contract. While Lawton is arbitration eligible and could earn more than $5 million this season, Escobar and Riggan will barely make above the minimum salary. The Mets began discussions with the Indians two weeks ago and the talks intensified at the meetings. There is an 11 a.m. press conference today to announce the trade.

description: About a month after anthrax spores were released from a letter in the office of Senator Tom Daschle, researchers were able to stir up spores that remained there and disperse them into the air just by simulating normal activity in the office, federal scientists reported here today.

description: This border town, where the only bridge linking Afghanistan to its northern neighbor, Uzbekistan, was opened with fanfare on Saturday, lay desolate and inactive today, a junkyard of discarded Soviet military armor and decaying concrete buildings.

description: No question about it, the seven philanthropists who received the inaugural Andrew Carnegie Medals of Philanthropy yesterday were an august bunch: Leonore Annenberg, Brooke Astor, Irene Diamond, William H. Gates Sr., David Rockefeller, George Soros and Ted Turner.

title: The Veiled Resource
description: I was in a burka shop the other day, chatting with the male proprietor, when two women walked in to browse the latest fashions (powder blue, gold embroidery). They observed silently as the two of us men discussed whether women want to wear burkas. It seemed a bit ridiculous, so I asked the women: ''What do you think?''

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Three months after 19 men commandeered four planes to kill thousands of Americans, the government today filed its first criminal charge directly related to the attacks, indicting a man who officials believe was meant to be the 20th hijacker.
