title: Latin Stars Unite In Benefit Concert With Radio Roots
description: From across the hemisphere Latin pop singers gathered at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night for a benefit concert, Hispanos Unidos por New York. It paid a triple tribute: to the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, to the victims of the crash of Flight 587 to Santo Domingo, and to the dominion of the Spanish Broadcasting System, which operates 25 radio stations, including two in the New York region, WSKQ (97.9 FM) and WPAT (93.1 FM).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINTEN, LILLIAN (NEE KLEIN)
description: LINTEN-Lillian (nee Klein). On December 7, 2001, beloved wife of Leonard, cherished mother of Sharon Duckett, loving grandmother of Vernon Lewis. Services today, 9:45AM at Parkside Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Viacom Unites UPN and CBS; Executive Quits
description: Viacom consolidated its two network television operations yesterday, expanding the power of Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS, while prompting the resignation of the executive in charge of UPN.

title: The B.C.S. Formula Is Working Just Fine
description: The Bowl Championship Series ranking formula was designed to give something to everybody. The human polls are counted along with computer rankings, the strength of schedule is factored in, and teams are penalized for losses and credited for victories over better teams. As it has the past three years, the system worked. Can anyone honestly say undefeated Miami versus Nebraska (11-1) is not the best matchup for the national title game?

title: More Hurdles for EchoStar-DirecTV Plan
description: EchoStar Communications knew it was going to have a tough task getting government approval for its planned $32 billion takeover of DirecTV, a deal that would combine the nation's two largest satellite television systems. Just how hard is now clear.

title: Transcript of Laurie Goodstein's Visit to the Religion in America Forum
description: On Tuesday, Dec. 11, Laurie Goodstein visited the Religion in America forum. Here is a transcript.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JANE
description: LEVY-Jane. 84 years, died at home early Sunday morning, December 9, 2001, after a long, brave battle with pancreatic cancer. For 61 wonderful years, she was the devoted and adoring wife of Jules, 88. She was the loving and proud mother of Fred, 54, of New York City, and Doug, 52, of Needham, MA, mother-in-law of Kathy and Margo, and grandmother of Andres, 21, and Nathaniel, 16, Jennifer, 21, and Jonathan, 16. Her parents were Rita and Morton Frederick of Margate, NJ. She also leaves her wonderful companion and caregiver of 25 years, Grace White. Jane had a long, full life, taking care of her family, traveling this country and the world with Jules, and working for 46 years with the Women's City Club to make New York a better city for everyone, serving as its Secretary and Treasurer. Her family mourns her passing, but celebrates her life. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be sent to the Women's City Club, 33 West 60th St., New York City 10023-7905.

title: Did Hubby Really Have to Go? He's Such a Nice Guy
description: In the lobby of the Music Hall at Fair Park here, where on Saturday night the Dallas Opera presented the fourth and final performance of Tobias Picker's much-anticipated ''Thrse Raquin,'' its premiere production, there was a display with photos and information about the composer; the librettist, Gene Scheer; and the 1867 novel by mile Zola upon which the opera is based. One quotation from Mr. Picker stood out, for it read like a disclaimer.

title: Ford to Close Office Focused on Women
description: Ford Motor will eliminate a three-person office that helped look for ways to market vehicles to women, as the company restructures its North American business to reduce costs.

title: Fewer Heisman Voters
description: The Sept. 11 attacks, an extended college football season and no clear front-runner caused an unusually low turnout of Heisman Trophy voters. Nearly a third of the 924 voters failed to turn in a ballot, the highest percentage in 20 years.

title: Witnesses Say Many Taliban Died in Custody
description: Dozens of Taliban prisoners died after surrendering to Northern Alliance forces, asphyxiated in the shipping containers used to transport them to prison, witnesses say.

title: The Big City; G.I. Stands Tall Again (12 Inches)
description: AT New York's hottest toy store, the new Toys ''R'' Us at Times Square, you can find some of the hottest toys at a display in between the five-ton roaring dinosaur and the six-story Ferris wheel. There, under a tyrannosaurus-size American flag, you see women like Diane Stauss trying to decide whether to buy the G.I. Joe Army Ranger, the G.I. Joe Army Grenadier or the G.I. Joe Vickers Machine Gun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLEWELLYN, MRS. NESSA F.
description: LLEWELLYN-Mrs. Nessa F. Widow of Charles Llewellyn, died on Saturday, December 8, 2001 at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in NYC. She was 103. Born Nessa Lopez on October 31, 1898 in Christiana, Jamaica, British West Indies, she immigrated to the United States in 1917 and became a citizen in 1923. She was the last survivor of twelve brothers and sisters. Her husband, a fellow immigrant from Jamaica, became one of the first minority linotype operators at the New York Herald Tribune. Mrs. Llewellyn, a mother, wife, businesswoman, family matriarch and loyal friend, lived for over 73 years in White Plains, NY before becoming a resident, at age 101, of the nursing home. She is survived by a son, J. Bruce Llewellyn, Chairman and CEO of the Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Co., a daughter, Dorothy Cropper, Judge of the NY State Court of Claims, three grandchildren, a daughter-in-law, a son-in-law and numerous nieces and nephews including Secretary of State, Colin Powell. Viewing hours 9-10 AM. Service to follow at 10. Viewing and service will be held on Wednesday December 12, 2001 at The Cathedral of St. John The Divine.

title: Players Ask Why, But System Rules Day
description: It was supposed to be a nostalgic luncheon for his departing senior football players, and Dick Tharp did not really want to talk about computers and statistics and decimals.

title: Sofia Journal; Posters of Hitler Rouse Talk, and Fears, in Bulgaria
description: The posters went up here overnight, about 500 copies of a painting of Hitler. They were plastered at the outdoor book market across from the Sheraton, near the Jewish center downtown, where Emil Kalo viewed them not only with alarm but also with puzzlement: Bulgaria simply has not been a place with much anti-Semitism.

title: Spending on Ads Is Down Sharply
description: Advertising spending in major media fell 7.8 percent in the first nine months of 2001 as cutbacks by marketers accelerated, according to a report yesterday from CMR in New York, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONSVERIZON SELLS WIRELESS UNIT Verizon Communications ( news/quote ), the largest local-telephone company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its TSI wireless services unit for about $800 million to the investment firm GTCR Golder Rauner of Chicago. Verizon said the deal for TSI Telecommunication Services, which provides wireless call processing services, is expected to close in the first quarter of 2002. TSI has 800 employees, about 750 of whom are in Tampa, Fla., where the company is based. Edward Evans, president of the wireless- service company Dobson Communications Corporation ( news/quote ), will become chief executive of TSI.   (Reuters)

title: Firm of Reagan Adviser Raises $1.4 Billion Fund
description: Heartland Industrial Partners, a private equity firm started by a former Reagan administration official, David Stockman, finished raising a $1.4 billion fund with an investment from a Canadian pension plan.

title: Fight Against Money Laundering Widens
description: The securities industry has been called the weak link in efforts to combat money laundering. But Wall Street firms are facing the same anti-money-laundering regulations that banks have faced for years -- and a raft of new ones adopted after the terrorist attacks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Top Police Official To Retire
description: New York's second-highest-ranking police official, Joseph P. Dunne, the first deputy police commissioner, said yesterday that he was retiring. Mr. Dunne, left, narrowly missed being named police commissioner last year. He will become director of security for the American operations of the Swiss bank UBS, including its brokerage firm, UBS PaineWebber. Mr. Dunne began his 32-year career as a police officer in his native Brooklyn and made his mark as the commander for northern Brooklyn when crime declined sharply there in the mid-1990's. Some thought Mr. Dunne, who also served as the first deputy to Commissioner Howard Safir, had the inside track to succeed Mr. Safir in August 2000. Mr. Dunne had worked hard to repair relations with minority groups after incidents like the shooting of Amadou Diallo. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani chose Bernard B. Kerik, the correction commissioner. At a ceremony at City Hall, where Mr. Dunne had said he would stay on as Mr. Kerik's top aide, Mr. Dunne said, ''Whenever I see a Miss U.S.A. contest and they announce the runner-up, I will know just how she feels.'' Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lattice Is Buying Agere Business
description: The Lattice Semiconductor Corporation of Hillsboro, Ore., has agreed to buy the programmable-integrated-circuit business of Agere Systems Inc., which makes communications equipment components, for $250 million. The deal includes Agere's field-programmable system chip, which can be changed through software rather than by replacing the chips or the equipment. Agere, the chipmaking unit that Lucent Technologies plans to spin off, had a loss of $3.35 billion on revenue of $600 million in its fiscal fourth quarter ended Sept. 30. The purchase is expected to increase Lattice sales by about $70 million a year. Shares of Lattice rose 15 cents, to $20.84.

title: Eastern Alliance Sets Ultimatum for Possible Al Qaeda Surrender
description: TORA BORA, Afghanistan, Dec. 11  Besieged Al Qaeda fighters were trying to work out a surrender agreement tonight after Afghan tribal forces, backed by American bombs and Special Operations commandos, forced their way up the slopes of their mountain redoubt.

title: Agent Praised as Patriot In Graveside Ceremony
description: Praised by his boss as ''an American hero'' and by his widow as one who ''didn't separate serving his country from serving his family,'' Johnny Micheal Spann, an intelligence agent who was the first American killed by the enemy in Afghanistan, was laid to rest with full military honors today under a bleak sky at Arlington National Cemetery.

description: Young goalkeepers who play soccer with adult-size balls instead of smaller ones increase their risk of breaking their hands or wrists, a new study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, WALTER
description: GREEN-Walter, 62. On December 9, after a 10-year battle with ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease). A respected executive in the fashion industry since the early 1970's, he headed up several companies and served as president of Joseph Abboud and Burberry. He was a tireless ALS advocate and in 1999 was the second recipient of the Helen Hayes Commissioner's Cup, given for his inspiration to others and his outstanding courage and determination. He is survived by his wife Susan; his brothers and sisters Michael and Marylou, Marsha, Stephan and Beth, Richard and Evelyn, Patricia, Stephanie and Richard; his children Nanci and Michael, Amy and Elliot, Matthew and Judith, Chelsea and Carolyn and Alixandra; grandchildren Carly, Jamie, Grant, Genny, Caroline and Chloe; nephews Max and Sasha and nieces Allegra and Xiao-Mei, and caregiver Shirley Barboza. Service 9:30 AM today at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St., NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Eleanor and Lou Gehrig Center at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Fall At JDS
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation, which makes fiber optic components, said yesterday that sales in the three months ending in March would fall 10 percent to 15 percent from this quarter, dampening optimism for an earlier recovery. The fiscal third-quarter drop will be the fifth consecutive sales decline. JDS, which has cut more than half of its work force and closed several plants, said it expected demand to pick up after March. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., reiterated that sales in its second quarter, which ends Dec. 29, will be down as much as 15 percent from the first quarter's $329 million.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: 4 More Elk with Brain Disease
description: Four of 158 elk killed to test for chronic wasting disease have tested positive for the illness, state officials said. This year in Colorado, 11 elk tested positive for the brain disease, which affects deer and elk and is always fatal. The 158 elk were known to have had contact with an infected herd. Most cases were traced to one Colorado ranch, and elk that had been sold and shipped to other states were also killed for testing. Those elk tested in New Mexico, Idaho and Pennsylvania did not have the disease. But a herd in Kansas tested positive. Officials plan to destroy 1,500 more elk that were on ranches where the disease occurred. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Association of Promotion Marketing Agencies Worldwide, Stamford, Conn., presented its 2001 Globes Awards for excellence in promotion marketing. The winner of the Grand Prix was Roche-Azevedo, Sao Paulo, Brazil, part of Marketing Store Worldwide, for a campaign for Fiat Automoveis S.A. The campaign also won two other awards. Saatchi & Saatchi, London, part of the Publicis Groupe, won three awards for a campaign for the British Army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTER, BOBBY
description: MINTER-Bobby. The Board and staff of Citymeals-on-Wheels mourn the untimely passing of Bobby Minter, beloved husband of our past president, Maggi Landau. Our hearts go out to Maggi and her family on this tragic loss. Gael Greene, Chairman Preston Robert Tisch, President Marcia Stein, Executive Director Citymeals-on-Wheels

title: Silver Bells, Silver Angels
description: There has been a Christmas tree lighting ceremony at the northern end of Bowling Green Park in the financial district every year since 1986. Last night's ceremony was unlike any other, though. Members of the Bowling Green Association decorated the 75-foot evergreen with 427 angels made from silver retrieved from a vault in the World Trade Center. The silver, worth $17,000, belonged to Scotiabank, which donated it for the angels, said David Scott, a spokesman for the bank. The National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations Foundation made up half the bank's expense.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Monday, 3,278 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: British Are Set To Lead Force That Will Keep Peace in Kabul
description: Britain is poised to take the lead in a security force of thousands of foreign soldiers to be deployed in and around Kabul, Western diplomats and officials said today.

title: For Many Generation X'ers, Grass Is Greener at Home
description: Generation X'ers, the workers known for job-hopping, aren't as footloose in the employment market as they are reputed to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVLIN, HARRY
description: DEVLIN-Harry. Died on November 25 of lymphoma at his home in Mountainside, NJ. An artist and writer of great renown, Harry was the loving husband of Wende for 60 years; together they created 26 children's books, including the ''Cranberry'' series and ''Old Black Witch,'' later a movie. A Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II, his drawings were used by the Office of Naval Intelligence. His many award-winning paintings of old houses grace museums and corporations around America. Cartoonist, illustrator, painter, and writer, he wrote ''Portraits of American Architecture,'' and was commissioned to do paintings for U.S. postage stamps. Honorary Chairman of the National Cartoonists Society, recipient of the Chairman's Gold Medal from the Society of Illustrators, Arents Award winner from his alma mater Syracuse University, he left a legacy of art to the nation and to his children: Harry, Wende Gates, Jeffrey, Alexandra Eldridge, Brion, Nicholas, and David. For information call 908-233-1280.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Expects Down Quarters
description: Anadigics Inc., a maker of telecommunication chips based in Warren, N.J., said that sales in the fourth quarter would fall 33 percent and that first-quarter revenue was also expected to drop. Fourth-quarter sales will fall to $20.3 million from $30.7 million a year earlier, Anadigics said. It expects first-quarter sales of $16 million to $19 million, as much as 44 percent less than a year earlier. The company said that it expected to reduce expenses by 30 percent and that it might sell its fiber optic business. Its shares closed down $2.09 at $16.25.

title: New Chief Executive At Investment Bank
description: Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin, an independent investment bank based in Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had hired Franklin Hobbs, a former chairman of Warburg Dillon Read, to succeed O. Kit Lokey as chief executive.

title: Germ Warfare of Sorts Shows Promise Against Cancer
description: Chemotherapy and radiation are efficient killers of tumor cells. But they are not always effective because many tumors contain central zones devoid of blood and oxygen. Drugs cannot reach places where blood does not circulate, and radiation fails in these zones because it needs oxygen to kill cells. The two therapies often let enough cancer cells survive to defeat the treatment.

title: UNITED BANKSHARES BUYS CENTURY FOR $70 MILLION
description: United Bankshares, the holding company for United Bank, said yesterday that it had bought Century Bancshares for about $70.3 million in cash and stock to add branches in Maryland, Virginia and Washington. Century Bankshares shareholders will receive 0.45 share of United Bankshares common stock and $3.43 for each share. That values the shares at $15.76 based on yesterday's closing price. No premium was offered to Century stockholders. Century Bancshares was the holding company for Century National Bank. United Bankshares is based in Parkersburg, W.Va.

title: Feuding With Legal Aid
description: The holiday season is no time for old grudges. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has been angry with the Legal Aid Society since 1994, when the society's union of lawyers went on strike for higher wages early in his first term. Now Mr. Giuliani may be thinking about delivering a final blow to the society, the spine of New York's fragile system of providing legal protections to the indigent.

title: Miller Realizing Some Long-Held Dreams
description: A half-day after his first World Cup victory, Bode Miller unfolded his boxy 6-foot-2 frame from a stiff car seat after a seven-hour drive across northern Italy late Sunday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Gendarmes' Protests Pay Off
description: Is the French government giving in too easily to protesters? Critics of Lionel Jospin's government are accusing the prime minister of buying social peace before the presidential election next year, in which he is expected to run, and of ignoring the long-term consequences. On Saturday, the government gave in to the demands of protesting gendarmes, agreeing to spend $400 million on pay increases, 4,500 new officers and bulletproof vests. Deals in recent weeks with other groups of striking workers -- the police, hospital workers, private doctors and midwives -- are expected to cost about $6 billion.

title: Madison Ave. Grapples With Post-Sept. 11 Era
description: Three months after Sept. 11, Madison Avenue continues struggling to determine the right tone, approach and content for post-attack campaigns. The result has been advertising that is often strained or off-putting, even inappropriate.

In fact, many are redoubling their efforts to suppress any discussion of the problem.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Justice Dept. Sues On Civil Rights Post
description: The Bush administration has sued to clarify the membership of the Civil Rights Commission. The administration says the term of one commissioner, Victoria Wilson, has expired. President Bush wants to seat Peter N. Kirsanow, a lawyer from Cleveland, in her place. Ms. Wilson was named in January 2000 by President Bill Clinton to fill the term of the late Judge A. Leon Higginbotham, whose term was to have ended Nov. 29. Her lawyer and commission lawyers say Ms. Wilson is entitled to a six-year term. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Trade: Opposition To Steel Plan
description: The European Commission condemned a recommendation from the United States International Trade Commission to raise import tariffs on steel by up to 40 percent. It said that if the proposal was adopted it would close off the United States market from imports. ''This is a worryingly negative signal to send to the rest of the world,'' the commissioner for trade, Pascal Lamy, above, said, urging the Bush administration to ignore the call for protectionism. He warned that if the United States does adopt the recommendations the European Union would complain to the World Trade Organization. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: False Alarm On Uranium Deal
description: Seven Russians arrested outside Moscow last week who were reported to be offering to sell about 2 pounds of weapons-grade uranium were in fact peddling low-grade uranium pellets that would be useless to a terrorist, the Interior Ministry said. Nuclear experts said the pellets, used in heat-releasing elements of nuclear reactors, were safe enough to be held in one's hand. The men were asking $30,000 for the pellets in a deal the Interior Ministry called a transaction between organized crime groups.

title: Santa Clara Supplants N. Carolina
description: Santa Clara dethroned North Carolina from its perennial spot on the women's collegiate soccer pedestal. The Broncos edged the Tar Heels, 1-0, on Sunday in Dallas to capture their first national title. Aly Wagner, Santa Clara's premier player, scored a goal four minutes before intermission to end the Tar Heels' 34-game winning streak.

title: Zurich Financial Reshuffles As Heir Apparent Resigns
description: Zurich Financial Services, Europe's third-largest insurer, announced today an executive shake-up that left the company's chairman and chief executive, Rolf Hppi, firmly in charge.

title: Stocks End Session Lower Despite Rate Cut
description: Stocks erased much of their gains today, after a modest afternoon rally that followed the Federal Reserve's latest interest-rate reduction faded when Merck ( news/quote ) warned that it would not meet its earnings forecast.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Stake In Drug Maker
description: The Chugai Pharmaceutical Company and F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd. will form an alliance that will allow Roche of Switzerland to buy a majority stake in the Tokyo-based pharmaceutical company. Chugai will merge with Roche's Japanese subsidiary by the end of 2002. The merger and the purchase of new share allotments will allow Roche to obtain a 50.1 percent stake in Chugai. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: EQUITY FIRM BUYS CONTROLLING STAKE IN CARVEL
description: The Roark Capital Group has bought a majority stake in the closely held Carvel Corporation, an ice cream distributor and franchiser, for $30 million. Roark, a closely held equity firm, bought $30 million in preferred stock that is convertible into a majority stake in Carvel from Investcorp, Scott Pressly, a Roark vice president, said yesterday. Investcorp, based in New York, made additional investments and retains a minority stake in Carvel that is valued at $18 million, he said. Neal Aronson, founder and president of Roark, based in Atlanta, becomes the chairman of Carvel, based in Farmington, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, HELEN
description: LIVINGSTON-Helen. Died December 9, 2001. Cherished mother of Julie. Devoted wife of the late Raymond. Beloved sister of Joseph and his wife Rose. Adored aunt of Stephen. Loving, kind, brave, generous, beautiful, brilliant, humorous, vibrant and unique. Had enormous will to live despite her illnesses. She is alive in our hearts.

description: For the first time since American planes began bombing Afghanistan more than two months ago, a shipment of food was distributed today inside the sprawling and squalid refugee camp here, marking the resumption of a relief effort for thousands of families set adrift by war and drought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTON, JAMES WILSON
description: BUTTON-James Wilson. Age 84, retired Sears marketing executive and Navy veteran. Beloved husband of Lurena Stubbs Button. Loving father of James W. Button, Jr. of St. Louis, MO, Douglas S. Button of Louisville, TN, and Katherine Button Bell of St. Louis, MO. Dear grandfather of eight; great grandfather of five. Brother of the late Bland Ballard Button, Jr. During his career he ran Sears' New York office and was president of Simpson Sears in Canada before returning to serve as Vice President of Merchandising and finally as Senior Vice President of Sears in Chicago. Mr. Button served as director on the boards of Sears, Simpson Sears, Allstate Insurance, Chemical Bank, Grainger, Harris Bank, GTE Telephone, as well as the Council of Economic Education. Visitation will be held from 5:30 to 9 PM Wednesday, December 12, at Wm. H. Scott Funeral Home, 1100 Greenleaf Ave., Wilmette, IL. Services and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to The Palliative Care Center and Hospice of the North Shore, 2821 Central St., Evanston, IL 60201 and to the University of Chicago, C/O Gwen Jessen, 1116 East 59th St., Chicago, IL 60637. For information 847-251-8200.

description: It could be a sign of widespread corruption or simply the consequence of increasing political tensions between reformists and conservatives. The only certainty is that Iran's oil minister has been called to court.

description: SILVER-Elaine (nee Bienenfeld). On December 8, 2001, in the evening at the age of 67. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Billboard Law Upheld
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn has upheld a city law enacted in March that bans large billboards in certain neighborhoods and along highways. On Oct. 11, a judge in United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York ruled that the law did not ''censor ideas or target certain messages'' in violation of the First Amendment. Floyd Abrams, the lawyer representing Infinity Outdoor, a large billboard company, said his client planned to appeal. Supporters of the law only recently heard of the ruling. ''It was put on the back burner after Sept. 11,'' said Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, a sponsor of the law. Denny Lee (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With thoughts of Enron still fresh in their minds, investors send Calpine shares tumbling.
description: SECURITIES of the Calpine Corporation, the nation's largest independent power producer, plummeted yesterday as investors grew uneasy about the company's ability to finance its aggressive construction plan in markets still reeling from Enron's collapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIERER, IDA
description: SPIERER-Ida. Died peacefully on Dec. 7, 2001, at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Cynthia (Noah) Fleschner, Sandra (Nat) Geller and Rosalind (Jacob) Weinstein. Adored grandmother of nine and great grandmother of 21. She was the matriarch of our family and will be sorely missed.

description: WEINSTEIN-Claire. Of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, passed away on Sunday, December 9. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Weinstein, affectionate mother of Kenneth (Merle) and the late Jill Ascher. Adoring grandmother of Brian (Dana) and Kevin Ascher. In days gone by she enjoyed the company of her many friends. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Funeral will be graveside at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, on Tuesday, Dec. 11, at 11 AM.

description: Mentor Graphics, which designs software for computer chip makers, has sued a rival, Ikos Systems, which Mentor hopes to acquire for $99 million.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  House and Senate conferees agreed this afternoon on final details of President Bush's education bill, giving him his first domestic legislative victory since Democrats took over the Senate and giving poor children, especially in big cities, a major increase in federal aid.

title: GENZYME SETTLES ACTION AGAINST TROUBLED PHARMING
description: The Genzyme Corporation has agreed to buy assets related to the treatment of Pompe's disease from the Pharming Group, a Dutch biotechnology company, and terminate legal action against Pharming. Genzyme, based in Cambridge, Mass., will take on production of a protein to treat nine patients suffering from Pompe's disease, a hereditary muscle-wasting disease that can be fatal. Genzyme will obtain all of Pharming's licenses to patents. Terms were not disclosed. But it means that Pharming, which was granted protection from creditors last week, will have a chance to stay in business, said Rein Strijker, management board member responsible for corporate development. Pharming's legal dispute with Genzyme was over rights to patents on Pharming's Pompe's disease drug and production at a Belgium plant, he said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: Orders for machinery, a crucial gauge of corporate capital spending, fell to a 14-year low in October, a sign that Japan's recession is intensifying. Orders fell a worse-than-anticipated 10.1 percent in October from the previous month to 791 billion yen ($6.3 billion), the lowest since November 1987. Economists had expected a small gain after similar cutbacks in September. Orders are unlikely to rebound before the second half of 2002, a government official said. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: South African Leader Looks For Business
description: President Thabo Mbeki arrived on his first trip to China hoping to expand trade ties between the countries, which established full diplomatic relations only in 1998. Accompanied by business leaders and a host of cabinet members, Mr. Mbeki said he was looking for expanded cooperation in mining, telecommunications and manufacturing. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Agriculture Secretary vs. Sacred Cow
description: As secretary of agriculture, Ann M. Veneman, a lawyer who spent her childhood on a California peach farm and watched her father rise in state and national Republican politics, seemed well placed to help President Bush wean big farmers from decades of multibillion-dollar subsidies.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Nauru: Taking More Asylum Seekers, And Money
description: The remote Pacific island agreed to take in more asylum seekers turned away at sea by Australia, raising the number held in a detention camp to 1,200 from 800. In exchange, Australia is to increase its payment to Nauru to $15 million from $10 million -- a total amounting to more than half the tiny island's gross domestic product. In August, Australia closed its doors to asylum seekers smuggled from the Middle East and began diverting them to Pacific islands. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Across Afghanistan, Taliban Soldiers Keep Up the Fight
description: The face that peered through the driver's side window might have appeared on a recruiting poster for the Taliban movement, which has been declared dead.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Zurich Unit Goes Public
description: Zurich Financial Services began trading its reinsurance unit, Converium Holding, in a $1.7 billion public offering, the biggest in Switzerland in several years. The parent company, Europe's third-biggest insurer, opened Converium, a smaller competitor to Munich Re, to add some $200 million to Zurich Financial's bottom line, which has been hit by lower investment returns and demands from terrorist attack claims and from exposure to the ailing energy trader Enron. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

description: WASHINGTON  A federal grand jury has indicted a Moroccan-born French national, suspected of having terrorist links even before the Sept. 11 attacks, of conspiring with the Qaida group to join in the plot, Attorney General John Ashcroft said Tuesday.

description: Little League officials said yesterday that they were establishing rules intended to prevent players, coaches and administrators from lying about a player's age, residency or other eligibility criteria.

title: Only the Latest Blow for a Staggered Commercial Printing Industry
description: Several inches of dust on the floor made it look as if a snowstorm had blown through the offices of Admiral Communications, a printing company four blocks south of the World Trade Center. That was bad for the hundreds of reams of paper that had recently been delivered, much of it for a big job for one of the Wall Street firms that made up the bulk of Admiral's customer base before Sept. 11.

description: THE biggest victims of the initial public offering craze of the late 1990's were the investors who wound up with shares that went from being worth billions to having a value -- if they have any at all -- as collectibles.

Giuliani's use of a jet owned by Donald Trump for a trip to Israel misspelled the given name of a mayoral spokeswoman who discussed the arrangement. She is Sunny Mindel, not Sonny. The article also misstated her title. She is the mayor's communications director, not his press secretary.

title: Four Are Charged in Scheme That Preyed on Anthrax Fears
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday charged a Colombo crime family associate and three other men with trying to profit from anthrax fears by selling shares of a company claiming to be the sole distributor of a device that kills the disease in seconds.

And a correction in this space yesterday misidentified her hometown. The recipient is Grace Yu; Kanagawa, in Japan, has been her temporary residence as a volunteer teacher. She is from Montrose, Calif.

title: For Some Professions, Thinking Small Can Pay Big Dividends
description: Engineers, architects and surveyors are well paid almost anywhere. But if they really want to make their paychecks go farther, they should consider moving to Corpus Christi, Tex.; Mobile, Ala., or Hickory, N.C.

title: Beijing Asks For the Return Of Any Chinese Among Taliban
description: Responding to reports that there are some Chinese among the captured Taliban fighters, the Chinese government said today that it wanted such prisoners to be returned to China to face charges of terrorism.

title: Judge Censured for Unauthorized Court Absences
description: A Supreme Court justice has been censured by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for ethical misconduct and ''reprehensible'' behavior, including trying to undermine the boss of a woman he was dating and leaving the bench without permission to attend classes in broadcasting.

title: Assembly Panel Will Meet
description: Five months have passed since SHELDON SILVER, the State Assembly speaker, created a panel to study mayoral control of the city school system. But the group has not exactly been productive; it will hold its first meeting on Friday. Assemblyman STEVEN SANDERS, a panel member, said the group was supposed to convene in September but postponed its work after the terrorist attack. He said the panel hoped to work quickly and issue recommendations early next year. One question is whether DENNIS WALCOTT, a panel member who was named last week to be a deputy mayor in the Bloomberg administration, will still partici pate. Abby Goodnough

title: Knoblauch May Play At Second for Royals
description: Chuck Knoblauch may sign with Kansas City, and if he does, Royals Manager Tony Muser would like to ask him about the possibility of occasionally playing second base, a position Knoblauch never played last season after his throwing problem forced his move to the outfield.

title: Queens College Helps Teachers
description: The Board of Education has awarded the Queens College Division of Education a five-year, $1.25 million contract that will enable teachers in Queens middle schools who are not certified in mathematics to enroll in a tuition-free one-year program. The participants will observe the work of experienced middle school teachers and take courses in middle school teaching methods at the Louis Armstrong Middle School in East Elmhurst, as well as math courses at Queens College. The contract also provides for an internship program and courses in methodology for minority candidates interested in middle school teaching.

title: The Man Behind the Curtain In the Hewlett-Compaq Merger
description: With its merger with Compaq in serious danger, Hewlett-Packard will increasingly turn to a leading member of its board to sell the plan to large shareholders, whose votes will make or break the deal.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Tuesday, 3,273 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: China Joins W.T.O. Ranks
description: China became the 143rd member of the World Trade Organization today, starting what is expected to be an uneasy era of change for one of the world's largest and fastest-growing economies.

title: A Fond Adieu to the French Franc
description: Sometimes in Paris one has the feeling of having wandered into a magical city in a parallel universe. One drinks wine without getting drunk and eats fatty foods without gaining weight. Tell a man in Paris you're a writer, and it's like telling a man in the States you're a model. The little lamplit cobblestone streets sound like lanes in a fairy tale: Rue Git-le-Coeur (Here Lies the Heart Street), Rue du Chat Qui Pche (Street of the Cat Who Fishes), Rue des Mauvais Garons (Bad Boys' Street). And the money seems like fairyland money.

title: Business Travel; A UAL unit will use Airbus Corporate Jetliners for trans-Atlantic and domestic shuttle service.
description: IN this big party town, it's a little like a coming-out soiree for United Airlines' mysterious new business-jet subsidiary, which had been keeping a somewhat low profile as it gears up to start operations early next spring.

title: Police Say a Getaway Car Didn't Get Far
description: In another addition to the ''Gang That Couldn't'' reel of bloopers, the police said a Queens man -- accompanied by his 89-year-old father -- couldn't quite get the getaway right. The police said the son and his father were arrested moments after a robbery at a Queens bank yesterday when they almost collided with another car -- a police cruiser.

description: Faced with a daunting deficit and falling government aid, New Jersey Transit today proposed its first fare increases in more than a decade.

description: At a two-day meeting here about anthrax and other bioterrorism threats, officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said they had learned much about anthrax in the last two months, but there was still a great deal they did not know.

title: Former Player Recalls Rough Side of Chaney
description: Cedric Maxwell, who stopped Don Chaney from choking Benoit Benjamin when Chaney coached the Los Angeles Clippers in 1986, says Knicks fans do not have to worry about Chaney's being tough enough to get the most out of his players.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Clears Excite@Home Plan
description: The At Home Corporation may continue to provide cable companies with high-speed Internet service under a $355 million agreement, a judge ruled after the companies waived some claims against each other. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Thomas Carlson approved the settlement, saying At Home has gained something very valuable.'' The contracts with Cox Communications Inc., the Comcast Corporation and other cable companies will give At Home financing to continue operating through the end of February, when it plans to cease operations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Cipro Requests Soar
description: The number of New Yorkers with long-term prescriptions for ciprofloxacin, the preferred antibiotic for anthrax, more than quadrupled in October, and far exceeded federal government estimates of the number of people receiving the drug, an alliance of health insurers reported yesterday. The report, by the Health Plan Association, said much of the trend was a needless response to the widespread fear of anthrax. Surveying its member insurers, who cover less than one-quarter of New York State's total population, the association found that more than 32,000 people had been given prescriptions in October alone.

title: Boeing's War Footing; Lobbyists Are Its Army, Washington Its Battlefield
description: Staggered by the loss of the largest military contract in history and the collapse of the commercial airline market, Boeing has sharply intensified its efforts in Congress and the Pentagon to win an array of other big-ticket military contracts.

title: Fusion Across Politically Charged Lines
description: Simon Shaheen's Town Hall concert with his 10-piece ensemble, Qantara, was originally meant to be a normal world-music affair on Oct. 5. It was postponed, along with much else. On Saturday it became a benefit concert for a fledgling project that will mount educational forums on Arab, Middle Eastern and North African culture.

title: Isles Discover Group Hugs Are Not Enough
description: The Islanders charged ahead tonight with two second-period goals, celebrating each with hearty group hugs. Then they stopped, as if the two goals and two group hugs would be plenty.

title: Princeton Helps Victims
description: Princeton University is committing $1 million to four programs to support New York City and help people affected by the attack on the World Trade Center. Princeton will spend about $500,000 to pay for up to 10,000 New York City-area schoolchildren to attend plays and concerts and visit art galleries and museums in the spring. The university will also provide $250,000 in scholarships for students at New York's John Jay College of Criminal Justice, which lost more than 100 students and alumni -- most of them firefighters and police officers -- in the attack. A third program will pay for children who lost parents in the attack to attend one-week programs next summer on Princeton's campus or nearby. Finally, Princeton said it will support student research related to the attack and also pay for faculty and staff members with special expertise to contribute to New York's rebuilding efforts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Dies In Collision
description: A woman was killed and her 10-month-old infant critically injured yesterday when a van collided with a car, sending the van spinning out of control into the mother and child walking in the crosswalk, the police said. No summonses were immediately issued or charges filed, the police said. The woman, Christine Hunnicutt, 39, of Brooklyn, was pushing a stroller with her daughter, Mya Chapman, at the intersection of Williams and Flatlands Avenues in Canarsie shortly before noon when the collision occurred. Ms. Hunnicutt was pronounced dead at the scene and the infant was listed in critical condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Try to Imagine It: A Foie-Gras-Sicle
description: The amuse-bouches that David Burke came up with for Park Avenue Cafe and One C.P.S., the restaurants where he is chef, were so popular that he is now selling them at retail. Called Gourmet Pops, they include smoked salmon wrapped around a cream cheese filling, creamy herbed goat cheese with a nubbly almond and pistachio coating, and foie gras that's glazed with port and cranberry jelly and looks like a little candy apple. The frozen pops, 12 to a box and a bite or two each, thaw in less than 30 minutes but should be served chilled. The goat cheese is $18, the smoked salmon $20 and the foie gras $22 at Dean & DeLuca and at Kings Super Markets in New Jersey. At Caviarteria, a box of 12 in assorted flavors is $25.

title: Suit Seeks $2.1 Billion in Enron's Assets
description: In the latest tangle in the Enron Corporation's bankruptcy reorganization, J. P. Morgan Chase, one of Enron's biggest lenders, filed a lawsuit yesterday demanding the company turn over $2.1 billion in assets that backed loans extended by J. P. Morgan and a group of other lenders.

title: Fishermen Fear Yachts Signal End of Old Ways
description: At Fishermen's Terminal here today, the familiar smells were in place, that endangered blend of diesel, fresh-gutted fish and sweat. But the people who work and live out of what may be the largest active commercial fishing port left in the contiguous United States could detect something else in the air -- the smell of death.

title: Swiss Judge Convicts Six in Deaths of Adventurers Lost in Flood
description: A Swiss judge today convicted six employees of a Swiss adventure company of negligent manslaughter in the deaths of 18 tourists and 3 guides in a flash flood that raged through a narrow Alpine gorge during a canyoning expedition two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, LEONARD K.
description: ROSEN-Leonard K. Age 87, passed away on Tuesday, December 11, 2001. He is survived by his wife of almost 63 years, Thelma J. Rosen. He is also survived by his daughter, Gail F. Berman and a daughter in California, five grandchildren, Alan, Matthew, Marion and Kevin, and a granddaughter. Mr. Rosen was an active member of the Bronx community for over 40 years from real estate to construction to civic volunteering. He will be missed by everyone who knew him as ''Lenny-Mr. Boston Road''. Services at 1 PM on Thursday, December 13th at GarlickRiverside Memorial Chapel, 1439 Unionport Rd, Bronx, NY. Interment Beth David Cemetery. In lieu of flowers or fruit baskets, contributions to your charity of choice.

title: MY JOB; My Creativity Comes in Packages
description: I've worked in the gift-wrapping department for over 20 years. I can wrap gifts in one minute flat, in any of 12 styles. When someone brings me a fur coat or a wedding gown, I stuff it with paper so it looks as if there's a person inside. If I'm wrapping a dress and a toy for a baby, I'll put the toy inside the dress and arrange it just so.

title: Germany Bans an Islamic Group After 200 Police Raids in 7 Cities
description: BERLIN, Dec. 12  Germany, using new antiterrorist legislation, moved sharply today against a radical Islamic group, banning it and 19 associated groups and carrying out more than 200 raids in seven cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DR. LAWRENCE
description: KAPLAN-Dr. Lawrence. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Larry Kaplan. Jacqueline Bellsey, President Leonard Golub, Secretary

title: Compaq Chief Says He Is Committed to Merger
description: Though he said he was ''surprised and disappointed'' that Hewlett-Packard's largest shareholder opposed the merger, the chairman of Compaq Computer declared yesterday that he remained firmly committed to the plan and confident the deal could be rescued.

title: Gambling on a Film Fantasy; 'Lord of the Rings' Shows New Line Cinema's Value to AOL
description: The recent management shuffle at the top of AOL Time Warner -- in which Richard D. Parsons, a veteran Time Warner executive, emerged as the surprise successor to the retiring chief executive, Gerald M. Levin -- only revived a question that has nagged New Line Cinema, a mere cog in the company's vast global empire, for years: What does AOL Time Warner, which already has Warner Brothers studios, , need with a second, separate film studio?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HELEN
description: SCHNEIDER-Helen. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Helen Schneider, a beloved leader and cherished friend who was greatly admired for her extraordinary generosity and compassionate concern. Mrs. Schneider and her husband, Irving, earned enormous respect throughout the world as philanthropic giants, deeply devoted to Jewish and humanitarian causes. Through their inspiring leadership and insightful vision, they fostered new standards of excellence in pediatric care as the primary benefactors of the Schneider Children's Hospital of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center and the Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel. Mrs. Schneider's significant contributions to health care, education, and the cultural arts in New York and overseas will be felt for generations to come. At UJA-Federation, she was cherished for her wisdom, guidance, and unwavering commitment. As a former trustee of UJA-Federation's Thrift Shop, she enhanced the facility's work on behalf of the Jewish community. Mrs. Schneider's extraordinary legacy lives on in the continuing efforts of her husband and her three daughters. We mourn the loss of a dear friend, and extend our deepest sympathies to Irving, a great leader in the Jewish community, who is a lifetime trustee of UJA-Federation and an inspiring force in our Real Estate Division; to Mrs. Schneider's daughters, Bunny, Lynn, and Mindy; her five grandchildren; and the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg, Chair of the Women's Campaign

title: You and Your Best Friend, a Little Closer to Heaven
