There is a whole-wheat version, as well as Rye Treats, Baked Doggie Treats with meat broth and Not Really Chocolate, made with carob, all without additives or preservatives. A one-pound sack is $5, four are $18, from (800) 618-6622. Proceeds from the bakery support the National Theater Workshop of the Handicapped.

title: Software Piracy Raid
description: Federal law enforcement agents seized computers and raided computer networks at M.I.T., U.C.L.A. and other large universities in shutting down what they described as one of the Internet's largest and most sophisticated networks for pirating software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, IRENE
description: KRAMER-Irene. Beloved wife of Aaron. Loving mother of Margia Kramer and Barbara Arlen. Cherished grandmother Naomi and Nathaniel Hupert, great grandmother of Ian & Natasha Kinmont. Services at Crestwood Memorial Chapel 33 Spring Street, NYC Thursday 12:30 PM. Donations in lieu of gifts should be made to The Alzheimers Association, NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10017.

title: Talks on Contraction Go On
description: A Major League Baseball official said today that the contraction settlement talks between the owners and the players' union would continue on Wednesday, the third straight day negotiators will meet. The talks center on delaying elimination of two teams until at least the 2003 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LAWRENCE I., M.D.
description: KAPLAN-Lawrence I., M.D. Passed away Dec. 11th at home in Longboat Key, FL. Loving and singularly devoted husband of 58 years to Janet, cherished father to Richard and Laurie, and beloved grandfather to Wesley. Adored by family and friends for his limitless generosity and his gift for finding and nurturing the best in each of us. He is respected and admired by patients, colleagues and students for his unfailing devotion to medicine. In addition to his private practice, he maintained a lifelong affiliation with Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan where he trained, taught and practiced neuropsychiatry, served as Chairman of the Medical Board at Gracie Square Hospital and shared his medical expertise with the Practicing Law Institute. His extraordinary kindness will be missed and long remembered by all who knew him. Funeral services to be held on Friday, December 14, 9:30 AM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: ARTS IN AMERICA -- Michael Pollak; Glass, Wet Fingers and a Mysterious Disappearance
description: The glass harmonica is a beautiful, rare instrument with a haunting past. Hand-blown, finely tuned crystal bowls are mounted on a spindle like an angel's version of an industrial lathe. The musician touches the turning edges with wet fingers. The music is crystalline, too, and can fill a room, seeming to come from everywhere and nowhere.

title: Court Voids Law Covering School Prayer In Louisiana
description: A federal appeals court today struck down a Louisiana law allowing vocal classroom prayer, believed to be the only such law remaining in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, JAMES FRANCIS
description: QUINN-James Francis. Innocently, tragically and heroically on September 11, 2001 at the office of Cantor Fitzgerald. Beloved and adored son of Michael (ret. NYPD) and Noreen (nee Daly). Loving and treasured brother of Michael and Joseph. Also survived by many heartbroken aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. Was graduated from Manhattan College (1999) and Xaverian H.S. (1995). A Memorial Mass celebrating Jimmy's life will be held at Good Shepherd RC Church in Brooklyn on Saturday, December 15, 2001 at 12 PM. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in Jimmy's memory to Good Shepherd School, 1943 Brown St., Brooklyn, NY 11229 or to Xaverian H.S., 7100 Shore Road, Brooklyn, NY 11209, Attn: Dr. Sal Ferrera.

title: Documents Are Found In Tora Bora Caves as Hideouts Are Overrun : Ultimatum To Qaida:Surrender Or Be Killed
description: Tribal fighters overran the eastern mountain hideouts of Qaida militants in Afghanistan on Tuesday, boxed large numbers of them into a rocky canyon and set a deadline for the surrender of the harried members of the network headed by Osama bin Laden, reports from the area said.

title: THE BOSS; 'That Girl' Goes Tailgating
description: In 1949, when I was 8, my mother, my two sisters and I sailed here from Taiwan to join my father. When I started school two months later, I didn't know a word of English. I sat in my third-grade class and copied everything from the blackboard into my notebook. My father would come home at night after working two or three jobs and translate for me.

title: A Temple Where Wine and Food Are the Deities
description: THE good life is a religion in Northern California. Now, it finally has a temple.

title: 'Grandchildren and Ladies' Become Casualties
description: Each ward of the Ghazni Hospital features a new calamity. In the first, two 14-year-old boys had lost parts of their hands when they picked up land mines. ''I was playing with a toy and it exploded,'' said one of them, Muhammad Allah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, SEYMOUR
description: BROWN-Seymour. The City College Fund mourns the passing of its longtime eminent Director and Board member. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Ruth, and family. Stanley H. Kaplan, Chairman Herbert Robinson, President James L. Schatz, Executive Director

title: Helen Schneider, 79, Hospitals Benefactor
description: Helen Schneider, who with her husband gave major philanthropic support to charities, especially children's hospitals, died on Saturday in New Hyde Park, N.Y. She was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Closing In on the Caves, Indictment in the U.S., Debate Over Trials
description: The pressures on Al Qaeda escalated yesterday on two continents. In the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, where Osama bin Laden and his followers are believed to be hiding, Afghan tribal forces, supported by American bombs and commandos, were advancing on the group's cave complexes. Some tribal commanders said the group had agreed to lay down arms today, but the deal unraveled early this morning and American B-52's resumed bombing.

title: The Battle Over Special Education
description: The leaders of the House and Senate reached formal agreement yesterday on a groundbreaking education bill. But Republican leaders, with the support of the White House, defeated an attempt by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa to dramatically increase financing for special education. The Bush administration argues that the issue should be put off until next year, when the whole special education program comes up for review. Both sides in this debate have a point. The special education system needs both more money and more reform.

title: Aide Says Bush Will Do More to Marshal Religious Base
description: Karl Rove, President Bush's top political adviser, said today that Republicans did not rally enough religious conservatives to the polls in last year's presidential race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFUNKEL, B. JULIAN
description: GARFUNKEL-B. Julian. December 10, 2001 at age 89. Spirited and loving husband of Edith for 65 years; proud father of George and Sandy, Ronald and Sande; loving and involved grandfather of Jon and Betsy, Jill, Stacy and Rob; adoring great-grandfather of Emily and Maddie. Survived by his sister Professor Florence G. Roswell. Beloved uncle to three generations of nieces and nephews. Community activist and founder of Service Directions, Inc. Services at 11:30am Thursday, December 12 at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pine Brook Blvd, New Rochelle, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Global Source Education Network, Inc., P.O. Box 11316, Bainbridge Island, WA 98110 and to The Garfunkel Child and Family Training Institute of North Shore Child and Family Guidance Association, 480 Old Westbury Road, Roslyn Heights, New York 11577.

title: And on That Farm He Had a Tomato, a Lemon, A Beet, a Cucumber . . .
description: The Neighbor Corporation of Wakefield, Mass., claims that EIEIO Tomato Smash may help prevent Type 2 diabetes and lower the risk of cancer, and that it provides 130 percent of the recommended daily allowance of vitamin A. What the earnest company doesn't claim is that the juice can save a last-minute dinner party. With a garnish of cilantro or chopped cucumber, it becomes instant gazpacho. There are tomatoes, of course, and celery. But then there is spice and acid and a pervasive sweetness, from ingredients like apple juice and beets, and a garden full of other produce -- cucumber, watercress, pepper, garlic, lemon and spinach. All are blended in thoughtful proportion, so you can pop open a bottle and taste a dash of summer. A 10-ounce bottle is $1.99 at the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street; 24 ounces is $2.99 at Whole Foods, 250 Seventh Avenue. AMANDA HESSER

title: Investors Wary of Fiat Plan to Issue Bonds
description: Investors reacted negatively and with some puzzlement yesterday to one component of the restructuring plan announced Monday by Fiat S.p.A., the struggling Italian automaker -- a $2.2 billion convertible bond issue backed by the 32 million shares of General Motors Corporation stock that Fiat holds.

title: F.B.I. Studies Terrorists' Engineering Expertise
description: The F.B.I. is making inquiries to determine whether terrorists used specialized engineering software to help plan the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon in a way to do the most damage and kill the most people, engineers who have been contacted by investigators said.

title: Lawyers Say Public Trial Would Make Convicting bin Laden More Difficult
description: Gerry Spence, the defense lawyer known for his Stetson and Western swagger, imagines that at a civilian trial, a lawyer for Osama bin Laden would try to force American secret agents to blow their cover in order to explain how they came up with damning videotapes of the master terrorist.

title: My Creativity Comes in Packages
description: I've worked in the gift-wrapping department for over 20 years. I can wrap gifts in one minute flat, in any of 12 styles. When someone brings me a fur coat or a wedding gown, I stuff it with paper so it looks as if there's a person inside. If I'm wrapping a dress and a toy for a baby, I'll put the toy inside the dress and arrange it just so.

title: Rights for Hungarians
description: To the Editor:

title: Modest Rally Fizzles After Merck's Warning on Earnings
description: Stocks erased much of their gains yesterday, after a modest afternoon rally that followed the Federal Reserve's latest interest rate reduction faded when Merck & Company warned that it would not meet its earnings forecast.

title: Forrest Gives Up Belt for Shot at Greatness
description: Vernon Forrest does not need a title, at least not for now. He is relinquishing the only world championship belt that he has ever had. He waited years for the chance to get it, he won it last May and now he is giving it up.

title: Blurs and Blots Joined in Sound and Motion
description: Things kept moving in ''Analog vs. Digital, for a free mind,'' the program that a mixed-media organization called Radical Low presented on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio. But the most interesting movements were not those of dancers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, MYRON J.
description: GREENFIELD-Myron J. Of Teaneck, NJ, died peacefully in his sleep on Sunday, December 9, after a long illness. His memory will be cherished by his wife, Sophie Greenfield, his children, Peter Greenfield and Phyllis G. Ross, his grandchildren, Lillian and Sarah Ross, his great grandson, Jacob Ross, his brothers, Jonas and Martin Greenfield, his sisters, Rita Charney and Muriel Shookhoff, along with their families and the many friends whose lives he brightened.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Tightening Noose

title: Betraying the Helpless
description: A much-awaited report issued last week by New York's chief judge, Judith Kaye, documents the degree to which unchecked patronage practices have corrupted the state's system for safeguarding the finances of the elderly and infirm. Rather than a program to protect the helpless, the report depicts a jobs program for politically connected lawyers who drain the estates of the vulnerable clients they are supposed to defend.

title: Nassau Workers Protest Building Conditions
description: They said they had already endured asbestos contamination, major electrical fires in 1998 and 1999, repeatedly flooding toilets, 88-degree heat on one floor, 60-degree chills on another, roaches and mice.

title: As Innocents Die in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: USA Networks' TV Business May Be Bought by Vivendi
description: Vivendi Universal and USA Networks are close to a deal that would give Vivendi control of most of USA's television operations, while potentially granting USA Networks' chairman, Barry Diller, the corporate independence that he has craved for years.

title: Italian Leader Drops Opposition To Europe-Wide Arrest Warrants
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi gave in to pressure from his critics today and said Italy would not, after all, try to block the establishment of a European arrest warrant, which prosecutors consider a crucial tool in fighting terrorism.

title: A Children's Surgeon Feels Better Than He Looks
description: DR. SHARADKUMAR DICKSHEET is said to do 35 to 40 operations a day on the disfigured children of India, a number so astonishing it seems it must have been reported in error. When one meets the doctor, at his apartment in Brooklyn, it's even more difficult to believe.

title: Testimony Describes Order to Kill Sheriff-Elect
description: Two or three weeks after losing an election to Derwin Brown, Sheriff Sidney Dorsey of DeKalb County summoned a deputy to the back porch of his house and handed him a note that said, ''Kill Derwin Brown.''

title: Cognac's Country Cousin
description: FOR an elegant holiday gift, a bottle of Cognac, the world's best-known and most prestigious brandy, is an almost reflexive choice. For that reason alone, Armagnac, Cognac's country cousin, might impress simply because it is a more personal selection.

title: How Low Will They Go?
description: LAST year when the Hudson Cafeteria opened, no one blinked an eye at the $28.50 macaroni and cheese with seared foie gras. No, New Yorkers waited in line for it like horses at a trough. Diners, by then, had grown used to $32 roast chicken and $15 shrimp cocktail. It was the price of admission to the newest restaurants, even when the chef was just out of cooking school.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The indictment issued today is a chronicle of evil, a carefully documented year-by-year, month-by-month, day-by-day account of a terrorist conspiracy that gathered both force and intensity in the weeks before September the 11th.''

title: Broad Reform in the Military, And Fast, Is Bush's Priority
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks yesterday at the Citadel, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. The full text is available at The New York Times on the Web at nytimes.com/ world.

title: Search for a Web Site Creator
description: The New York City Board of Education has named two companies, Accenture and KPMG, as finalists in the bid to develop a special Web site through which teachers, administrators, students and parents can get access to the Internet. The new portal would generate revenue by selling advertisements and sponsorships, and would provide e-mail accounts for the school system's 80,000 teachers and 1.1 million students. The board will choose between the finalists early next year.

title: The Short Haul
description: Ninety-eight percent of Americans live within a 30-minute drive of a small airport.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL To Test Music Service
description: America Online said it would begin offering a test version of its digital music subscription service, MusicNet 1.0. The service is based on MusicNet, a partnership of Real Networks and the record labels owned by AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann and the EMI Group. Last week, Real Networks released RealOne, the first pay-for-play service to come out of MusicNet. AOL said it planned to make the service broadly available in January for $9.95 a month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a biographical sketch on Saturday about a World Trade Center victim, a firefighter at Ladder Company 9 in SoHo, misstated his name. He was Gerard Baptiste, not Gerard Jean Baptiste. He had no middle name.

title: Mets Turn Alomar Into Crown Jewel Of Their Infield
description: The Mets' executives dream, too. They dream big. General Manager Steve Phillips said that the Mets spend hours hoping, wishing and praying that certain trade proposals will work out, and a significant one worked out today when they acquired the 12-time All-Star second baseman Roberto Alomar in a blockbuster eight-player trade with the Cleveland Indians.

title: Recipe: Thai Caramelized Pork Salad
description: Adapted from "Off the Shelf"

title: Senators Express Skepticism About Microsoft Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Democrats and Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee today voiced deep skepticism of the Bush administration's proposed settlement of the antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation ( news/quote ).

title: Long, Long Legal Battle for Tall, Tall Building
description: Three powerful real estate figures are battling once again for control of the Empire State Building, the 102-story tower on Fifth Avenue that recently regained its status as New York's tallest skyscraper.

title: Pakistan Sends Troops to Border to Prevent bin Laden Escape
description: Thousands of Pakistani soldiers have been deployed on mountain peaks and in hidden valleys along the Afghan border in recent days in a bid to cut off escape routes for Osama bin Laden and his fighters from the remote enclave of Tora Bora in eastern Afghanistan, Pakistan military officials said today.

title: An Improbable Incubator For a Militant Muslim
description: Whatever an incubator for radical fundamentalist Islam is supposed to look like, it is safe to say Marin County is not it.

title: Compromise Settles Debate Over Tribunal
description: The decision to try Zacarias Moussaoui in civilian court followed an often contentious debate among senior government officials about whether to bring him before a military tribunal, which was ultimately settled on Monday at the White House.

title: Should I Get a Mammogram?
description: To the Editor:

title: St. John's Rises Early To Avoid Another Upset
description: First there was a practice, a morning scrimmage that no longer surprises St. John's players. Tonight came another lethargic first half and again the Red Storm appeared primed to be upset.

title: Rating Firm Turns Negative About New Jersey's Economy
description: In the clearest sign yet of New Jersey's weakening fiscal condition, Moody's Investors Service warned today that the state is likely to face a significant downturn during the next 18 months, and assigned a negative outlook to the state's newly issued municipal bonds.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Motorola To Offer Instant Messenger
description: AOL Time Warner and Motorola have entered into a multiyear marketing and technology alliance that will, among other things, allow Motorola to build AOL's Instant Messenger feature into its wireless devices. Instant Messenger is available on one other wireless device, the Nokia 3390, which is sold in conjunction with VoiceStream's cellular service. The AOL Time Warner alliance with Motorola will not affect the VoiceStream agreement. The terms of the alliance were not disclosed. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Reno Names Aide
description: Janet Reno, the former United States attorney general, has appointed an aide to Gov.-elect Mark R. Warner of Virginia to manage her campaign for governor. Ms. Reno, who is widely expected to win the Sept. 10 Democratic primary and face Gov. Jeb Bush, the Republican incumbent, chose Mo Elleithee to oversee campaign strategy, field operations, scheduling, fund-raising and communications. Mr. Elleithee was Mr. Warner's communications director and the Warner campaign's press secretary. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: U.S. to Pull Out of ABM Treaty, Clearing Path for Antimissile Tests
description: President Bush will announce this week that Washington will withdraw from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty in six months, the first time in modern history that the United States has renounced a major international accord, according to administration officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARTIN G.
description: STEIN-Martin G. Formerly of Cambria Heights, died Saturday, December 8, 2001, at the age of 79. Devoted husband of the late Gloria. Loving father and father-in-law of Anetta, Steffi and Laurie; Ray, David & Jon. Adoring grandfather of Jamie, Dana, Emma and Ben. Cherished brother of Sam. Kind friend of Anette. Martin's generosity and warmth will be greatly missed. His dedication as an attorney, friend, community member and family man will be remembered forever.

title: Sports of The Times; December Baseball Madness
description: ALOMAR in the 3-hole?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about recovery workers on the night shift at the World Trade Center site referred imprecisely to the presence of streetwalkers on Greenwich Street. They operate near the Pink Pussycat club, not in it.

title: Confession in Wendy's Deaths Wasn't Forced, Detective Says
description: A detective who investigated the killings of five workers at a Wendy's restaurant in Queens last year testified yesterday that the man accused of staging the massacre was not coerced by the police into confessing and was given a chance to speak with a lawyer.

title: That Old Blue Magic Has No More Tricks
description: It was halftime of the Giants' game with the Philadelphia Eagles Oct. 22 and at that moment nearly everyone in Giants Stadium -- television commentators, newspaper reporters, scouts from other league teams and team executives -- believed that the Giants were among the elite teams in the National Football Conference. That was not conjecture; it was the overriding subject of conversation during intermission that evening.

title: Food for Afghanistan
description: Combat is subsiding in Afghanistan, which should make it easier to get food to those who need it. The world can also begin to focus on other urgent problems, most importantly basic health care, and the humanitarian needs of other desperate nations.

title: From a Taliban Jail Into the Arms of a Drought
description: Had the Taliban returned? one man asked nervously today as trucks, minibuses and cars full of men pulled into town.

title: Congress Reaches Compromise on Education Bill
description: House and Senate conferees agreed today on final details of President Bush's education bill, giving Mr. Bush his first domestic legislative victory since Democrats took over the Senate and giving poor children, especially in big cities, a major increase in federal aid.

title: Armey, House Majority Leader, May Retire
description: A political drama with two Texas Republicans in the lead roles unfolded today on Capitol Hill as word spread that Representative Dick Armey, the majority leader, would probably announce plans to retire at the end of his current term and that Tom DeLay, the party whip, would seek Mr. Armey's job, the No. 2 position in the House Republican hierarchy.

title: Drastic Shifts In Climate Are Likely, Experts Warn
description: The vast reshaping of the environment by modern civilization raises the chances of sudden and drastic upheavals in the climate, a panel of experts warns.

title: Groups Seek to Lift Ban on Foreign Screeners
description: Jeimy Gebin, a proud veteran of the United States Army, is angry that a new federal law may cost her her job as a baggage screener at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about a decline in the stocks and bonds of the Calpine Corporation, reversed the identities of buyer and seller in a series of power purchases in the quarter ended Sept. 30. It was the Enron Corporation that bought power from Calpine, at significant premiums to market prices.

title: A Bread That's as Stout As the Brew It Comes From
description: A hefty, crusty bread demands a hearty soup, a slab of Cheddar cheese or some good salami and mustard. Tom Cat Bakery's new dark rye made with Brooklyn Brewery's Black Chocolate stout is a fine example. The loaf, 11 inches across and weighing nearly four pounds, is $1.99 a pound for the whole loaf or a portion at Fresco Market, 218 East 14th Street, and at Garden of Eden and Gourmet Garage stores.

title: Chauvinism on Wheels
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Meet the Press' Moderator Agrees to Long Extension
description: NBC announced yesterday that it had signed Tim Russert, the moderator of ''Meet the Press,'' the top-rated Sunday morning political discussion program, to a contract that would keep him in the job for the next 12 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Conducts a Review
description: Concerned about an internal review of the company's operations and finances, investors pushed British Airways shares down 5.6 percent. The airline is evaluating operations to find the best way to reduce costs and refocus its strategy in the wake of Sept. 11. The airline has said it is losing about 2 million ($2.9 million) a day as concerns over security have kept travelers home. A spokesman said that five managers would review its operations but that any discussion of job cuts or route changes was premature. He also said British Airways had ''no immediate plans'' to shore up its finances by selling equity to existing shareholders. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The New York Times's Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: British Life Is Fractured Along Racial Lines, a Study Finds
description: A government report said today that whites and ethnic minorities in Britain had become deeply divided and that they were leading separate lives with no social or cultural contact and no sense of belonging to the same nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, CHARLES
description: RUSSO-Charles. With deep sorrow, we mourn the passing of Charles Russo, dedicated member of the Board of Directors of the Sephardic Nursing Home. Son of Jacob Russo, one of our great founders. We offer condolences to his wife, Roberta Russo, his children and the entire family. Officers and Board of Directors of the Sephardic Home & LASHA Ira Rousso, President Robert A. Cohen Chairman of the Board Michael New Executive Director Marion Crespi, President, LASHA Reggie Goldberg Chairman of the Board, LASHA

title: Man Held Since August Is Charged With a Role in Sept. 11 Terror Plot
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Three months after 19 men commandeered four planes to kill thousands of Americans, the government today filed its first criminal charge directly related to the attacks, indicting a man who officials believe was meant to be the 20th hijacker.

title: Indictment Chronicles 'Overt Acts' That It Says Led to Sept. 11 Attacks
description: Following are excerpts from the federal indictment of Zacarias Moussaoui that outlines a numbered chronology of ''overt acts'' that led to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The full indictment is available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Crew Rescued After B-1 Bomber Crashes Into Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  An Air Force B-1 bomber involved in the Afghanistan campaign crashed into the Indian Ocean today, the Pentagon said. A short time later, the four crew members were rescued, military officials said.

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Force Executive of Enron to Testify in Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a federal judge today to force Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ), to testify in an S.E.C. investigation into the accounting at the giant energy company, which has collapsed into bankruptcy.

title: Westchester Village Decides to Buy G.M. Site on Hudson
description: In a sign of growing impatience here, village officials have decided to buy the site of a former automotive assembly plant along the Hudson River from its owner, the General Motors Corporation, after waiting more than five years for the property to be redeveloped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, EDWARD F.
description: KELLY-Edward F. Died peacefully at home December 9th, at age 78, after a courageous three year battle with cancer. For 50 years he was the loving husband of Jeanne Bradley. Devoted father of Marie Frances Burns, Kate Kelly Smith, Edward F. Jr., and T. Bradley. Adoring grandfather of Talley, Peter, Eddie, Isabel, Grace, Sam, Davis and Jack. He graduated from Cornell University, class of '44. During W.W. II, he was Aide-deCamp to General James F. Collins in the Pacific Theater. He worked in the advertising industry for over 30 years. An avid golfer he was a member of the U.S. Seniors' Golf Association and the Father/Son Golfing Organization. His courage, spirit and good humor will live on in the hearts of his children and grandchildren. He will always be remembered for his love of family and friends. Funeral mass will be celebrated on Wednesday, December 19, at 10AM, at St. Michael the Archangel, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. The memorial mass will be Friday, January 4, at 10AM, at Holy Cross Church, Vero Beach, FL. Contributions in his name may be made to the VNA Hospice of Indian River County, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, Florida 32960.

title: THE ALOMAR IMPACT
description: Roberto Alomar is a year-in, year-out All-Star who instantly provides the Mets with offense, defense and speed. He will also have to navigate the challenges of playing in New York. Here are three factors to consider.

title: District Protests Multiple Tests
description: The rumbles of protest against the state's expanded testing program have gotten a little louder. The Byram Hills school board in Armonk recently adopted a resolution asking that the state reduce the number of exams that eighth graders are required to take. They now take state tests in math, English language arts, social studies, science and technology, with those students who have studied a foreign language expected to pass a language proficiency exam as well. The resolution also calls on the state education commissioner, RICHARD P. MILLS, to offer greater flexibility in testing for school districts that annually exceed the state's standards. ''We're trying to instruct eighth graders, not just test them,'' said JOHN CHAMBERS, the superintendent of the Byram Hills school district.

title: Dave Graue, 75, Cartoonist of Stone Age Tales of Alley Oop
description: Dave Graue, one of only three cartoonists to work on the syndicated strip ''Alley Oop'' since its beginnings in 1933, died on Monday after a truck hit his car near his home in Flat Rock, N.C. He was 75.

title: As Innocents Die In the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Report On Teacher Shortage
description: To close a growing statewide teacher shortage, New Jersey should offer scholarships and bonuses where there are teacher shortages, including urban districts, and it should more aggressively recruit minority teachers, according to a study released yesterday. The Fund for New Jersey, a nonprofit group, also urged that the starting salary for teachers be raised to $40,000 a year from less than $34,000 now. Higher pay, based on knowledge and skills, should also be offered as incentives for teachers and administrators, according to the report.

title: A Finale in Three-Part Harmony
description: The most important and least surprising conclusion to the work of President Bush's Social Security commission was nowhere and everywhere in the final report the panel approved today: overhauling the retirement system is so complicated, painful and politically sensitive that it is almost impossible to get a consensus.

title: 69 Are Accused of Lying to Get Airport Jobs
description: The federal government announced indictments yesterday of 69 workers, most of them immigrants, at Salt Lake International Airport, accusing them of providing false information or documents to obtain security passes for their jobs.

title: Pope, Not Mentioning U.S., Urges Military Restraint
description: Three months after the terrorist attacks in the United States, Pope John Paul II issued a strong statement today on the importance of carefully limiting military action, even when that action is justified.

title: Still Cozy After All These Years
description: WHEN I was just starting out in the kitchen -- a young woman with expensive pots, no experience and an ambition to cook in the grand manner -- a friend of mine, an older, wiser man who had notched decades behind a stove, gave me this advice: ''Before you attempt souffls and flambs,'' he said, ''master one no-matter-what recipe.''

title: Public Is Wary But Supportive On Rights Curbs
description: Americans are willing to grant the government wide latitude in pursuing suspected terrorists but are wary of some of the Bush administration's recent counterterrorism proposals and worried about the potential impact on civil liberties, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Compromise Settles Debate Over Tribunal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The decision to try Zacarias Moussaoui in civilian court followed an often contentious debate among senior government officials about whether to bring him before a military tribunal, which was ultimately settled on Monday at the White House.

title: Employment Data Archive
description: December 26, 2001

title: KRAFT TO CUT 1,000 JOBS AND CLOSE 3 PLANTS IN ASIA
description: Kraft Foods Inc., the maker of Miracle Whip, said yesterday that it would cut about 1,000 jobs, or less than 1 percent of its work force, as it closes three plants in Taiwan and China. The company, based in Northfield, Ill., will close a plant in Hangzhou, China, near Shanghai, that has been inactive for two years, and shut another in Shekou, China, on Dec. 16, a spokeswoman said. Kraft will also consolidate some operations of its plant in Tainan, Taiwan, at a plant in Cikarang, near Jakarta, Indonesia, she said. The closings are part of a plan to make operations in Asia more efficient, the spokeswoman said.

title: A Painkiller's Double Life As an Illegal Street Drug
description: In a scene of creepy voyeurism and joltingly effective reporting, a 22-year-old named Troy Swett, who looks like any middle-class college student in a red sweatshirt and baseball cap, sits in his messy apartment in Maine and prepares to stick a needle in his arm as the cameras watch. ''I'm ashamed of it,'' he tells Harold Dow, the CBS reporter sitting next to him as he crushes a pill, cooks it up in a spoon and ties off his arm.

title: The Turn of the Season
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Jets Are Low on Points and Now Time
description: During training camp, quarterback Chad Pennington was frustrated with his inability to master the West Coast offense. Paul Hackett, the Jets' offensive coordinator, had to soothe him.

title: Bin Laden's Laughter
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Tax Rise Trimmed
description: The Westchester County Legislature yesterday pared down its proposed 2002 budget, shaving spending and raising revenue projections in order to lower a projected tax increase. County Executive Andrew J. Spano had proposed a $1.3 billion budget that included a 9.5 percent increase in property taxes, but the Legislature reduced it to 2.8 percent. The revised proposal also saves, for at least another year, the 70-year-old Playland Ice Casino, which was scheduled to close under the original proposal. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, CHARLES
description: BARNETT-Charles. The Woodcrest Club of Syosset, N.Y. mourns the recent passing of fellow member Charles Barnett and extends its sincere sympathy to his family. He was loved and will be missed by all the members and staff of The Woodcrest Club.

title: Corrections
description: The recipe with the Chef column last Wednesday, for tropical fruit trifle, omitted an instruction. The two layers of spongecake should each be sliced in half horizontally before being layered with the other ingredients.

title: Israeli Planes and Tanks Attack as Cabinet Vows to Arrest Militants
description: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Dec. 13 -- The Israeli government decided early Thursday morning to break off contact with Yasir Arafat after Palestinian militants killed 10 people Wednesday evening. The Israelis died when members of Hamas detonated bombs underneath a bus in the West Bank and gunned down passengers as they fled.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: 11 Antiterrorism Laws Are Signed
description: Gov. Jeb Bush signed into law 11 antiterrorism bills passed during a special 10-day session of the Legislature. The measures create regional domestic security task forces, a new chief of domestic security for Florida and allow for the creation of an antiterrorism database. Another allows law enforcement officials to obtain a statewide wiretapping permit. The measures include several public records exemptions, including one that makes confidential the location of drug stockpiles maintained by the state. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Look Out, Martha Stewart: A Rival From Down Under
description: CALL it the Foodies' Paradox: With every passing year, we care more and more about food, and we have less and less time to cook.

title: A Sales Tax Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Cloud Making A Name
description: On the map, St. Cloud, Minn., is about 70 miles northwest of Minneapolis-St. Paul. On the college hockey map, St. Cloud State University is a looming presence. Sitting atop the two major national Division I polls for the second straight week, the Huskies (13-2-1) combine balanced scoring with a strong goaltending tandem. Forwards Mark Hartigan (13 goals and 17 assists for 30 points) and Nate DiCasmirro (11-17-28) have the nation's top two points-per-game averages. Matt Hendricks has 14 goals and a freshman, Mike Doyle, has a precocious 12 goals. In goal, Dean Weasler and Jake Moreland are ranked 6th and 10th in winning percentage.

title: Try to Imagine It: A Foie-Gras-Sicle
description: The amuse-bouches that David Burke came up with for Park Avenue Cafe and One C.P.S., the restaurants where he is chef, were so popular that he is now selling them at retail. Called Gourmet Pops, they include smoked salmon wrapped around a cream cheese filling, creamy herbed goat cheese with a nubbly almond and pistachio coating, and foie gras that's glazed with port and cranberry jelly and looks like a little candy apple. The frozen pops, 12 to a box and a bite or two each, thaw in less than 30 minutes but should be served chilled. The goat cheese is $18, the smoked salmon $20 and the foie gras $22 at Dean & DeLuca and at Kings Super Markets in New Jersey. At Caviarteria, a box of 12 in assorted flavors is $25.

title: Taliban Gone, but Fear Lingers in Kandahar
description: At least 30 American Special Forces soldiers have occupied the inner courtyard of the sprawling house belonging to Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader who disappeared once his Islamic militia crumbled, leaving the streets of his stronghold in disarray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUZAKITIS, SPYROS
description: MOUZAKITIS-Spyros. Died on Monday, December 10, 2001. Will be buried on Friday, December 14, 2001 in Byron's Cemetery, Athens, Greece. Viewing will take place at Antonopoulos Funeral Home, Inc. 38-08 Ditmars Blvd., Astoria, NY on Wednesday, December 12, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Adored husband of Jane. Beloved father of Natasha Devlin, Christos and Christina Mouzakitis. Cherished grandfather of Isabel and Patrick Devlin, Spyros and Emmanuela Mouzakitis. Brother of Maria and Evangelos Marneris. Uncle of Matilde and Dimitri Marneris. Godfather of George Tzabellas. Dear friend to many. Spyros was a special man loved by all who knew him. He lived life to its fullest and touched the hearts of many. He will be sorely missed. Rest in peace dear husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, godfather and friend. We all loved you so much!

title: Coconuts To the Rescue
description: IN Italian cookbooks, the rules for risotto are quite flexible. The simple ingredients -- short-grain rice, seasonings and liquid -- can be combined in a thousand different ways. This risotto, however, is so far from the canon that Italian risotto purists will probably scoff; it is a distinctively American dish. But the difference is just one ingredient: coconut milk in place of stock.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Start-Up Buys Magazine
description: Tom.com, an In ternet start-up owned by the Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing, is continuing to evolve into a traditional media company, buying Taiwan's largest business magazine publisher for $47.5 million. Tom.com, which caused a tumult when it issued shares in 1999, bought the Business Weekly Media Group, owner of Taiwan's leading weekly business magazine. Tom.com, which reported a $10 million loss in the third quarter, gets 70 percent of its sales from non-Internet businesses. It financed the deal with loans from Mr. Li's other companies. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Yankees Talk Up White As Alou Pursuit Wanes
description: The Yankees are deep into negotiations with the free-agent outfielder Rondell White, who must decide from competing offers from other teams, including the Chicago Cubs and the Seattle Mariners.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Follonico's Successor

title: Wisdom, Women and a Touch of Wit
description: THERE is a macho side to wine. It turns up in opaque, alcoholic pinot noirs that mock the variety's potential for delicacy and finesse. It's in musclebound zinfandels with even more alcohol that might better be served in a shot glass, in viscous, one-dimensional syrahs and in heavy chardonnays that would be more appealing served frozen on a stick.

title: Should I Get a Mammogram?
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Industry Threat: CD's Made From Webcasts
description: For two years, Andrew Rasiej, the founder of the New York club Irving Plaza, has slowly been obtaining the rights to live performances by young bands. As the debate over the unauthorized trading of songs on online file-sharing services like Napster raged, he secured authorized deals that might upset record labels even more, because there's little they can do about them.

title: One Man's Parenthood, in Minute Detail
description: ''It's the ultimate Dogma movie, before the birth of Dogma,'' the experimental filmmaker Jonas Mekas says of his minutiae-ridden sprawl of a movie, ''As I Was Moving Ahead Occasionally I Saw Brief Glimpses of Beauty.'' An old-school independent filmmaker, Mr. Mekas reclaims minimalism with ''As I Was Moving Ahead,'' which begins a five-day run today at the Anthology Film Archives. The genre had been turned into the oxymoron renegade institutionalism by adherents of the Dogma 95 movement, as exemplified by Lars von Trier's ''Breaking the Waves'' and by the films of other practitioners.

title: 11 School Custodians Held in Kickback and Bid-Rigging Scheme
description: Eleven school custodians were arrested yesterday on charges of taking kickbacks from companies that were given contracts to wash school windows without going through an authentic bidding process, law enforcement authorities said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Colonial Soldiers Win Bigger Pensions
description: The government has agreed to raise the pensions of foreigners who fought in the French colonial forces to the same levels as those of their French counterparts. The decision followed a suit by a former Senegalese soldier. The change is estimated to affect 85,000 former fighters and will cost France about $1.3 billion, the Defense Ministry said. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Protestant Guerrilla Shot Dead by Ulster Unionists
description: LONDON, Dec. 12  A former British soldier, Protestant paramilitary guerrilla and police informer who was acquitted two weeks ago of charges of plotting the fatal shooting of Northern Ireland's best-known Catholic human rights lawyer was shot dead himself today in Belfast.

title: Harris's Hot Hand Gives Bulls Heave-Ho
description: The seconds were ticking down in the first quarter when the Nets reserve guard Lucious Harris dribbled the ball across the top of the arc, bobbled it, stumbled and collected the ball again. He thought about passing it, but when Harris saw there were two seconds remaining, he heaved a shot while falling backward.

title: Man Held Since August Is Charged With a Role In Sept. 11 Terror Plot
description: Three months after 19 men commandeered four planes to kill thousands of Americans, the government today filed its first criminal charge directly related to the attacks, indicting a man who officials believe was meant to be the 20th hijacker.

title: Tracing a 16-Month Infusion of Men and Money, Culminating in the Horror of Sept. 11
description: The first clue came in May 2000, when Ramzi bin al-Shibh applied for a visa to travel to the United States and was denied. American investigators would later say that Mr. Shibh, a Yemeni living in Germany as part of a Qaeda terrorist cell, was intended to be the 20th hijacker in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.

title: CALENDAR
description: A Rancher's New Hat

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Patent Spat Over TV Recording
description: TiVo Inc., the leading maker of digital video recorders that allow viewers to pause and replay television broadcasts, dismissed reports yesterday that the company was seeking to license patented technology from its chief rival, SonicBlue. The statement came after SonicBlue said that it had planned ''to initiate discussions with TiVo'' because SonicBlue had won a new patent for digital video recorders. SonicBlue said that it had received a patent last week for technology covering the basic digital video recorder channel selection functions. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: U.S. Warns Zimbabwe That Next Year's Election Must Be Fair
description: A senior Bush administration official met today with Zimbabwe's ministers of finance and foreign affairs and warned them that time was running out to create an environment for fair national elections next year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about CD's for the holiday season misidentified the label that issued ''This Ain't No White Christmas'' by Rudy Ray Moore. It is Norton Rec ords; Emperor Norton is an unrelated company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORUCI, HAMDI H., M.D.
description: ORUCI-Hamdi H., M.D. Of North Massapequa, on December 10, 2001. Beloved husband of Lee. Devoted father and father-in-law of Diana and Steven Adams, Shpresa Oruci and Edward and Olga Oruci, M.D. Loving brother of Hajro Oruci. Cherished grandfather of James, Andrew and Alexander. The family will receive friends Wednesday 2-5PM and 7-9:30PM at The McCourt & Trudden Funeral Home Inc., 385 Main Street, Farmingdale. Religious Service Thursday 11AM at the funeral home. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: A Fond Adieu to the French Franc
description: PARIS -- Sometimes in Paris one has the feeling of having wandered into a magical city in a parallel universe. One drinks wine without getting drunk and eats fatty foods without gaining weight. Tell a man in Paris you're a writer, and it's like telling a man in the States you're a model. The little lamplit cobblestone streets sound like lanes in a fairy tale: Rue Git-le-Coeur (Here Lies the Heart Street), Rue du Chat Qui Peche (Street of the Cat Who Fishes), Rue des Mauvais Garcons (Bad Boys' Street). And the money seems like fairyland money.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Steel Makers Propose Ties
description: The Japanese steel company Sumitomo Metal Industries said yesterday that it had proposed deeper ties with a rival, the Nippon Steel Corporation, as steel makers worldwide link to combat a glut that has dragged down prices. Sumitomo Metal offered to supply Nippon Steel with slab, a semiprocessed steel, from its mill in central Japan, reducing Nippon Steel's need to get the material from its own, more distant mills. Nippon Steel said it was considering Sumitomo's proposal.

title: Nokia Offers Note of Optimism on Earnings
description: Offering a rare piece of encouragement to investors who have watched telephone stocks take a beating this year, Nokia, the world's largest maker of cellular phone handsets, said today that fourth-quarter earnings might turn out better than the company's previously published targets.

title: Changing a Bulb Atop a Changed World; Stray Thoughts at 1,454 Feet, Once Again the City's Highest Perch
description: Tom Silliman, the man responsible for the care of the antenna that crowns the Empire State Building, climbed 1,454 feet 6 9/16 inches to its pinnacle early Monday morning to change the light bulb.

title: A Weekend in Philadelphia
description: W. C. Fields once said he spent a week in Philadelphia one night  sort of a seven-for-one deal. Through March 31, you can spend a weekend in Philadelphia for the price of one night. Check in on a Friday or Saturday at any of 40 hotels (ranging from $89 to $350) and parking is included, along with a Philly Overnight Card good for two-fers at 80 restaurants, attractions and shops. Hotels include the Adams Mark, Chestnut Hill, Comfort Inn Historic Center, Sofitel, Hyatt Regency Penns Landing and Ritz-Carlton. For a listing of hotels and to reserve, visit www.gophila.com . Rates do not include tax and tips; restrictions apply, and availability is limited. You can also reserve through the hotels; ask for the Philly Overnight package.

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Force Enron Executive to Testify in Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a federal judge today to force Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ), to testify in an S.E.C. investigation into the accounting at the giant energy company, which has collapsed into bankruptcy.

description: Adapted from "Off the Shelf"

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Russian novelist Viktor Astafyev on Dec. 3 misstated the date of his short novel ''I Want to Survive.'' It was published in 1995; he was not working on it at his death. The article also misstated the timing of ''The Damned and the Dead'' and of the State Prize of Russia he was awarded for it. The book's two volumes were published in the 1990's, not in the mid-70's, and the prize for that work was awarded in 1996. He also received the honor in 1975, for ''The Crossing'' and other stories.

title: Army Coffins, $2,500 Each, Anger Indians
description: India's military and political establishment was shaken today by the release of an official audit that found the army had paid ''highly inflated'' prices for coffins to bring home soldiers killed by Pakistani Army infiltrators on the frigid, treacherous heights of Kashmir two years ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer entry error, a brief front-page summary article on Saturday about the economic gains of the poorest New Yorkers during the 1990's misstated the number of poor and wealthy neighborhoods compared in a study by two professors. The 10 poorest were compared with the 10 wealthiest, not 90 and 90.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Members of Militant Anti-Arab Group
description: Two members of the Jewish Defense League have been arrested on charges of conspiring to blow up a Los Angeles area mosque and the office of an Arab-American congressman, law enforcement officials said today.

title: U.S. Considers Restricting Cellphone Use in Disasters
description: Federal officials are working on a plan to close cellphone networks to almost everyone but government officials in the event of another major emergency like the Sept. 11 attacks, officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Civil Liberties Union Chief
description: Donna Lieberman, the interim director of the New York Civil Liberties Union since January, has been named executive director, the organization announced yesterday. She succeeds Norman Siegel, who left in January and run unsuccessfully for public advocate. Ms. Lieberman, 53, joined the New York State affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union as associate director in 1988 and was the founder of the group's Reproductive Rights Project. Ms. Lieberman graduated from Rutgers law school.

title: With Iran, Against Americans
description: I was one of the Americans held hostage by the government of Iran for 444 days beginning in 1979. I was kidnapped at gunpoint from the American Embassy in Tehran, blindfolded, interrogated, beaten and locked in a government prison cell where I was not allowed to speak to anyone. For months I was kept next to a torture chamber; to this day, I cannot forget the screams of the dying. Some of the embassy people kidnapped with me were subjected to mock executions and threatened with the kidnapping and dismemberment of their children.

title: Dear Saudi Arabia
description: Memo from: President Bush

title: Daneyko Is Placed On Injured Reserve
description: The Devils apparently lost a great deal more than a 3-1 game in Columbus, Ohio, snapping a four game unbeaten streak. In the game Monday night Ken Daneyko, their veteran defenseman, also sustained a shoulder injury that appeared to be serious, because the Devils not only refused to disclose the severity of the injury but also placed him on injured reserve yesterday. That means he will be out at least seven days.

title: First Boston Seen Settling Kickback Case
description: Credit Suisse First Boston may pay $100 million to securities regulators to end an investigation into whether it received kickbacks from buyers of hot stock offerings in the late 1990's, several people close to the matter said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Antiterrorist Plan
description: Aberdeen Proving Ground plans to build igloo-shaped, reinforced steel structures to protect mustard agent from possible terrorism. The earthen-covered structures, expected to cost a total of $9 million, will take eight months to build, said a spokesman at the 72,500-acre Army installation north of Baltimore in Harford County. About 1,800 canisters containing 1,621 tons of the carcinogenic chemical warfare agent will be moved to the structures from an open yard, where they have been stored since World War II. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIMLEY, STANLEY (STAN) PETER
description: KLIMLEY-Stanley (Stan) Peter. Died December 2, in Boca Raton, FL of cancer at the age of 86. Beloved husband of Ann; adored father of April and Abbott Peter; beloved stepfather of John Sarafoglu and Stephanie Tassos; esteemed father-in-law of Patricia and Anna Soo Hoo; admired uncle of Susan. Predeceased by his first wife Dorothy Abbott Klimley. A talented artist and prominent illustrator. A kind man with a sharp wit, zest for life, intellectual depth and perpetual curiosity. A man for all seasons. We miss you terribly. A memorial service will be held in late January in Boca Raton, FL.

title: Chick Corea, Celebrating With Friends
description: Chick Corea's continuing 60th-birthday celebration at the Blue Note -- he will have played 18 nights by Dec. 23, in 9 different bands -- is distinguished by a productive, happy informality.

title: The Computer World, Inside and Out
description: THE FUTURE OF IDEAS

title: Kerik Asks That the F.B.I. Share Terror Information
description: New York Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik today called on lawmakers to pass legislation that would encourage the F.B.I. to share information on terrorism with local law enforcement officials, saying the walls between the agencies were ''the worst kind of dysfunctional thinking in government.''

title: U.S. Detainee Sends Letter to Parents
description: John Walker Lindh, the 20-year-old American captured with Taliban fighters in Afghanistan, sent a letter to his family saying he was safe and apologizing for not being in touch and causing them ''a lot of grief.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Uzbek Dissident Released
description: The leader of Uzbekistan's democratic opposition, Muhammad Salikh, was released from a Prague jail where he was being held on a warrant from Uzbekistan's authoritarian ruler, Islam Karimov. A Czech court will decide if he will be extradited to his homeland to serve a 15 1/2-year prison sentence on terrorism charges. Human rights groups say he was convicted in a show trial and faces certain death if sent home. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, MAXINE
description: CHARNEY-Maxine. Of Yonkers, NY on December 10, 2001. Devoted daughter of the late Frances and Edward Gurvitch and sister of the late Morton Gurvitch. Loving wife of Dr. Sol Charney and devoted mother of Dr. Richard Charney of Briarcliff Manor and Dr. Robert Charney of Springfield NJ. Loving mother-in-law of Stacy Charney. Adoring grandmother of Molly and Laura. Beloved sister-in-law, aunt and cousin. Graveside services at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey on Wednesday, December 12.

title: Bye, Rudy, Yurts And All
description: It was getting dark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINTEN, LILLIAN (LEE KLEIN)
description: LINTEN-Lillian (Lee Klein). On December 7, 2001, beloved wife of Leonard, cherished mother of Sharon Duckett, loving grandmother of Vernon Lewis. Services today, 9:45AM at Parkside Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Bond Issue Passes In Middletown
description: Voters in Middletown, N.J., approved a $10.5 million bond issue yesterday to complete $75 million in renovations and additions at the town's secondary schools. The renovations began in the late 1990's.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Suppliers Cut Off Daewoo
description: Daewoo Motor closed its three major plants after suppliers suspended shipments while waiting for the financially troubled company to pay its bills. Suppliers say Daewoo Motor owes them $1.2 billion and have suggested that General Motors, which has agreed to take over the company, make the payments. A Daewoo spokesman said the company would run out of cars in a week unless parts arrived. Union members of Daewoo Motor Sales, the subsidiary responsible for selling Daewoo cars in Korea, staged a brief walkout and threatened a strike to protest layoffs and restructuring. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: David Astor, 89, Liberal Voice As Editor of Britain's Observer
description: David Astor, who as editor for 27 years of Britain's oldest Sunday newspaper, The Observer, built it up into a respected and successful advocate for liberal causes but later presided over its financial decline, died on Dec. 7 in London. He was 89.

title: A Bite of Tea or Maybe Lemon
description: MEYER LEMON TRUFFLES: In a small pot, combine the zest and strained juice of 4 Meyer lemons with 3 tablespoons sugar. Simmer, stirring, until sugar dissolves. Cool completely; stir into chocolate filling mixture in place of raspberry-rose mixture (see attached recipe).

title: MIDWAY TO RESUME FLYING IN 6 MARKETS ON THE EAST COAST
description: The Midway Airlines Corporation, which received $10.1 million in federal aid last month, said yesterday that it would resume flying in six East Coast markets next week. Midway filed for bankruptcy protection in August. It ended all flights and laid off 1,700 workers on Sept. 12, predicting that demand for air travel would fall after the Sept. 11 attacks. The additional financing was provided in the second round of a plan meant to help airlines recover. Midway will schedule one morning round-trip flight and one in the evening from Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina to Boston, New York and Newark starting Dec. 19, the company said. It also will offer round-trip service from Raleigh-Durham to three Florida stops: Orlando, Tampa and Fort Lauderdale. Passengers can begin making reservations tomorrow.

description: In percent

title: So Much Like a Crepe, So Perfect for Hanukkah
description: YEARS ago when I was in the Ardche region of France, north of Midi and south of Grenoble, I stopped at a tiny restaurant on the side of a winding mountain road. The waiter ushered me to a table where three other people were already seated. After we tasted the local charcuterie and a daube de boeuf, a crisp, paper-thin potato pancake the size of the entire plate was placed on the table. Almost as thin as a crepe, this ''crique'' was absolutely delicious. I said to myself, ''I have found the ultimate latke.''

title: Milosevic Will Face Two Trials Instead of One
description: Slobodan Milosevic appeared today before the international war crimes tribunal here and was told that he would face two separate trials, not just one, for the grave crimes of which he is accused.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Footlights
description: Masters' Touch

title: With the Economy Still Fragile, the Fed Again Cuts Rates
description: With unemployment rising and the outlook for recovery muddled, the Federal Reserve continued its campaign of interest rate cuts today as President Bush and the two parties in Congress made progress in reviving negotiations on an economic stimulus package.

title: A Traveler With Strong Views on the Right Kind of Islam and No Fear of Sharing Them
description: Evening prayers had just ended at the mosque in Oklahoma City one Friday last summer when the imam was confronted by a burly man with dark eyes. The man was Zacarias Moussaoui, a French-Moroccan student at a nearby flight school, and he wanted to talk about the sermon.

title: Cuts May Delay Reopening Of Smithsonian Museums
description: The Old Patent Office Building in downtown Washington, home of the Smithsonian American Art Museum and the National Portrait Gallery, was shut down last year for a major five-year renovation that befits the third-oldest public building in the nation's capital. President Andrew Jackson laid the cornerstone for it in 1835, and Abraham Lincoln danced there at his inaugural ball.

title: Mr. Science, Mother Hen, Intrepid Traveler and a Singing Cockatiel
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHBAUM, SAUL
description: ROTHBAUM-Saul, 82. Died December 11. Beloved husband of Rose, adored father of Brad and Linda Rothbaum. Cherished Poppa of Andrew and Hayley Rothbaum. Funeral today, 2:30PM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: HARTMARX SAYS ITS PRESIDENT WILL SUCCEED CHAIRMAN
description: The Hartmarx Corporation, the men's apparel maker, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Homi Patel, would become chief executive effective April 11. Mr. Patel will succeed Elbert Hand, who will remain chairman until June 2004. Hartmarx did not say who would become president and chief operating officer. In 2000, the Hartmarx board approved a restructuring and management succession plan, with several executives reaching retirement dates over the next two to three years.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Usenet Archive Is Posted On Web
description: The big search engine Google restored decades of the Internet's own history to the World Wide Web by putting an archive of 700 million Usenet newsgroup messages dating back to 1981 online. The archive can be found at www.groups.google.com. Usenet predates Internet domain naming, and emerged alongside e-mail as a method to share messages among a wide community of computer users. Google acquired Usenet archives stretching back to 1995 from Deja.com in February 2001. But earlier postings were not warehoused in any central location. ''There's absolutely no central point of authority,'' said Sergey Brin, co-founder of Google and president for technology. Longtime Internet users helped Google's search for older messages by retrieving long-held CD-ROM's, which Google pieced together.

title: Overtime Becomes Class-Action Fodder
description: Chris Lyle was excited about her promotion from waitress to store manager at Pizza Hut in Northern California a few years ago, but soon wondered what her new title really meant. She said her duties were mostly making dough, mopping floors and taking orders, pretty much what an hourly worker would do -- except she was not paid overtime. ''There were times my employees were making more money than me, when I looked at the hours I worked,'' said Mrs. Lyle, 30, who lives in Fairfield, Calif.

title: A Tone Rooted in Compassion And Peace
description: In Israel, Chava Alberstein is Joan Baez and Sarah McLachlan rolled into one: a thoughtful songwriter with folky roots, peaceable instincts, a voice filled with compassion and an earnest desire to improve things. Ms. Alberstein, who performed on Saturday night at the 92nd Street Y, is one of Israel's most acclaimed singers. She identifies herself closely with her country's yearnings and its history.

title: 200 Muslims Are Sought In Michigan
description: Federal and local investigators began searching today for more than 200 young foreign men believed to be living in the Detroit area who failed to respond to letters sent last month inviting them to schedule interviews with law enforcement officials in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Adviser Hired In Hynix Talks
description: Creditors of Hynix Semiconductor Inc. have hired a lawyer from New York, Mark Walker, who helped South Korea overcome its financial crisis in 1997 and 1998, to advise them in talks with Micron Technology Inc. Mr. Walker, a partner at Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, will advise Hynix creditors in talks with Micron that could lead to a merger of the two chip makers, said Lee Young Jin, chief credit officer of the Korea Development Bank, a major Hynix creditor. Hynix is struggling to repay 8.6 trillion won ($6.7 billion) of debt. It had losses of 3.9 trillion won ($3 billion) in the first three quarters of the year.

title: Official Faults Drug Company For Marketing of Its Painkiller
description: The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration testified today that he believed that the aggressive promotion of the painkiller OxyContin by its maker had played a role in its widespread abuse.

But the test, conducted by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, did not examine the chief complaint against Explorers and other S.U.V.'s -- their tendency to roll over more than cars do.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- An Air Force B-1 bomber involved in the Afghanistan campaign crashed into the Indian Ocean today, but its four crew members were rescued in good condition after two hours in a warm, calm sea.

Funeral services Friday 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Interment to follow at Westhampton Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Trial Denied For Conspirator
description: A federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to grant a new trial to Mokhtar Haouari, convicted of conspiring to bomb the Los Angeles International Airport during millennium celebrations in 1999. Mr. Haouari's lawyer argued that a crucial witness was not believable and that had the jury known, the verdict would have been different. The witness, Ahmed Ressam, failed to tell the authorities about his attempt to rob a Montreal currency exchange in 1999. The prosecution disclosed the information in October after learning about it. But the judge ruled that the prosecution had met its ethical obligations and that the information would not have changed the outcome. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

Contributions in her memory may be made to Mothers' Voices, 165 West 46th Street, Suite 701, New York, New York 10036.

With Anaconda from 1935, General Counsel in 1949, President Anaconda American Brass in 1958, serving also as Chairman and CEO. Affiliations: NY Bar; Downtown Athletic Club; Sigma Nu. Also was Commissioner of Commerce, State of Connecticut. Survived by wife of 67 years, Noel Russell Stewart of Florida; sons Barry of Winslow, ME; Donald of Weston, MA; Robert of Montpelier, VT; their spouses; eight grandchildren; four great grandchildren. Spring memorial services planned Middlebury, CT.

title: Man Held Since Sept. 12 Faces Fraud Charge
description: A man from India who has been held since he and his roommate were arrested on a train in Texas as possible accomplices in the Sept. 11 attacks has been charged with credit card fraud, according to a person familiar with the proceeding.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Avesco Reports a Loss
description: Shares of Avesco slid 29 percent after the company, which organizes conferences and owns half the merchandising rights to the television program ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' said it had lost 1.2 million ($1.7 million) in the six months to Sept. 30. That compared with profit of 2.4 million ($3.4 million) in the period a year ago. Sales slipped 3 percent, to 32.6 million pounds ($46.8 million). Avesco said it had been hurt by an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Britain and the terrorist attacks in the United States, both of which caused clients to cancel conferences. Also, fewer people bought merchandise linked to ''Millionaire,'' the company said. The program has lost about half its audience in the last year, and may not return next year, ABC executives said last month. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: What's Eroding South Africa's Currency?
description: South Africa has slipped into a currency crisis that is confounding economists and threatening to undo much of the county's considerable progress in curbing inflation and lowering interest rates.

title: Dawning of a New Age for the Biltmore
description: It seems like ages since the Age of Aquarius dawned at the Biltmore Theater and recent years have not been kind. Fire swept through it. Water penetrated its walls. Scavengers made off with its fixtures. And all along, the abandoned playhouse seemed to resist every attempt to resuscitate it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JANE
description: LEVY-Jane. 84 years, died at home early Sunday morning, December 9, 2001, after a long, brave battle with pancreatic cancer. For 61 wonderful years, she was the devoted and adoring wife of Jules, 88. She was the loving and proud mother of Fred, 54, of New York City, and Doug, 52, of Needham, MA, mother-in-law of Kathy and Margo, and grandmother of Andres, 21, and Nathaniel, 16, Jennifer, 21, and Jonathan, 16. Her parents were Rita and Morton Frederick of Margate, NJ. She also leaves her wonderful companion and caregiver of 25 years, Grace White. Jane had a long, full life, taking care of her family, traveling this country and the world with Jules, and working for 46 years with the Women's City Club to make New York a better city for everyone, serving as its Secretary and Treasurer. Her family mourns her passing, but celebrates her life. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be sent to the Women's City Club, 33 West 60th St., New York City 10023-7905.

title: Skakel Loses Last Appeal; Faces Trial In '75 Death
description: Michael C. Skakel lost his last chance to avoid a trial in the 1975 slaying of his neighbor Martha Moxley when a judge ruled today that the statute of limitations in effect at the time did not apply to the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, AUBREY
description: LEWIS-Aubrey. The Board of Commissioners and the employees of The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey mourn the passing of Aubrey C. Lewis, who served as a distinguished member of the Board from 1997 to 1999. Commissioner Lewis gave freely of his time and talent in service to the Port Authority and the people of the New York-New Jersey region, and we wish to express our heartfelt appreciation for the time he spent on the Board. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Annie, his five children and eleven grandchildren.

title: Britain Ready To Lead Force For the U.N. After the War
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that Britain was willing to lead an international military force to provide security and stability in Afghanistan, but a final decision on its makeup and mandate was still under intense discussion among allied military forces and the United Nations.

title: Calpine Moves to Reassure Its Investors
description: With their company's stocks and bonds sinking again, executives at the Calpine Corporation conducted a marathon conference call with investors yesterday, hoping to reassure them about the company's financial strength and future profits. But even as management answered questions from 55 analysts and investors during the three-and-a-quarter-hour call, Calpine securities continued to decline, closing near their lows for the day.

description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the City University of New York, including how its 2002 budget has been affected by the Sept. 11 terror attack. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (718) 507-0813.

description: IKEDA-Mary. 89. Pianist for local ballet and modern dance companies, and political activist passed away December 9. title: Yukon Gold Guy Does It Again: The Ratte Potato
description: La ratte, an heirloom potato that French chefs adore, is now widely available in the United States. James Huston, right, a farmer who brought the Yukon Gold potato to the American market in the 1980's, decided to develop the ratte after tasting it in 1990 in Paris, where Jol Robuchon was using it to make his buttery potato pure. After searching for a place where the potato would thrive, Mr. Huston finally found success on a farm north of Seattle. This is a shiny, pale-yellow oval or fingerling-shaped potato with a firm texture and a flavor suggesting chestnuts and hazelnuts. Its smooth skin slips off easily when cooked. La ratte potatoes are $2.99 a pound at Agata & Valentina and at Citarella stores. Cooking demonstrations by Mr. Huston will be held at Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street), today and tomorrow from 5 to 8 p.m.

title: Killer-Cannibal Withdraws Plea to Leave Mental Hospital
description: Albert Fentress, the former Hudson Valley schoolteacher charged with torturing, killing and cannibalizing an 18-year-old man more than 20 years ago, withdrew his petition today to be released from a mental hospital.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chemical Weapons Delay
description: The Kremlin's security council said Russia would need 10 years to destroy its 40,000-ton stock of chemical weapons, not 5 years as promised, because it lacked the money and organizational resources for the task. The 1997 International Chemical Weapons Convention requires Russia to eliminate a fifth of its stocks by the end of this year and the rest by 2007. So far, said the deputy secretary of the security council, Oleg Chernov, Russia has been able to destroy only a tiny fraction of its chemical arsenal, the world's largest. He said the government needed $3 billion for the task and hoped Western nations would contribute a third of that. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: ARCH CAPITAL GROUP NAMES PRESIDENT OF INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Arch Capital Group, an insurance holding company based in Bermuda, has named Constantine Iordanou president of Arch Worldwide Insurance and Reinsurance Group. Mr. Iordanou, 51, had been chief executive of Zurich North America. Mr. Iordanou previously worked at the Berkshire Hathaway Group.

title: Radiance And Joy To Welcome The Season
description: Seventeenth-century Paris came alive in a corner of New York on Friday night. The Christmas music of Marc-Antoine Charpentier was written for spectacular and popular performances in the Church of St.-Louis (now St.-Paul-St.-Louis) in the 1690's. And spectacular and popular was exactly how it seemed more than three centuries later, at the church of St. Ignatius Loyola on the Upper East Side, in the masterly interpretation of William Christie and Les Arts Florissants.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Killed By Truck
description: A newspaper deliverer was struck and killed by a passing truck as he was unloading newspapers yesterday morning, the police said. The man, John Medica, 51, of Manhattan, was pronounced dead at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. An employee of The New York Times, Mr. Medica was pulling stacks of newspapers from a Times truck parked along Seventh Avenue near 51st Street around 6 a.m., the police said. Mr. Medica was hit by a southbound bread truck as he bent down. The Times delivery truck was cited for double parking, the police said. No charges were expected to be filed against the driver of the bread truck. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Dressed Up to Go
description: HOW many ways are there to wrap a chocolate truffle? Gifts of homemade food seem even more thoughtful when their packaging reflects the care that went into making them. You can choose the container to match the style (or perhaps the age) of the recipient. Some are made to cradle their delicate contents, while others may need to be lined with paper or plastic.

title: All-American Spot Tackles the Moment
description: EVERY once in a while, a restaurant comes along that matches, in style and cuisine, the mood of the moment. The Harrison is one of those. Jimmy Bradley, the executive chef and one of the Harrison's partners, built a loyal following at his first restaurant, the Red Cat, with imaginative, modestly priced new American food. Diners love the place, and they flock to it. The temptation must have been strong to simply create Red Cat, the sequel, but Mr. Bradley resisted the urge. Instead, while sticking with a clean, all-American look for the interior, he developed a modestly priced menu poised carefully between new American and fusion cooking.

Seven men were convicted of killing nine people, including a Roman Catholic priest, two nuns and an Indonesian journalist. Three others were found guilty of torture and forced deportations.
