description: PARIS, Dec. 12  A French Army officer was convicted of treason today for handing NATO secrets over to the Serb authorities in the buildup to the Kosovo war, in a case that embarrassed the French military and strained its ties with the 19-member alliance.

title: Interview With bin Laden Makes the Rounds
description: Al Jazeera, the Persian Gulf television network, obtained an exclusive interview with Osama bin Laden in October, the only television interview the terrorist leader has given since the war in Afghanistan began. But the network never broadcast the interview, partly because it revealed how much Mr. bin Laden had intimidated the network's correspondent, according to American and Middle Eastern government officials.

title: Another Rate Cut From the Fed
description: An economic recovery may be on the horizon, but don't expect things to get frothy any time soon. That was the Federal Reserve Board's message to financial markets yesterday, as it cut overnight interest rates yet again, this time by a quarter of a percentage point. It was the 11th cut this year, bringing the rate down to 1.75 percent, below the rate of inflation and its lowest level in more than four decades. While noting that the economy remains soft, the central bank also indicated, for the first time, that it sees signs that the slump may be ending.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: New Power To Dismiss Leaders
description: The increasingly influential national assembly approved a constitutional amendment that gives it the power to hold no-confidence votes and to dismiss government leaders, including the president and prime minsiter. Its power does not extend to the Communist Party hierarchy and the ruling politburo. Other new amendments include the right of the assembly to approve or reject international agreements and the elevation of the private sector of the economy to equal legal status with state-owned enterprises. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the first criminal charge directly related to the Sept. 11 attacks omitted a name in some copies for a man listed as one of 23 unindicted co-conspirators, and erroneously included one man twice, under differing spellings of his surname. Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a Yemeni citizen who the authorities say was an intended hijacker, should have been listed among the 23. A man accused of opening bank accounts used in the plot is Mustafa Ahmed al Hawsawi, not al-Hisawi.

title: Counting Birds at the Grass Roots
description: AS long as there have been amateur naturalists, the field notebook has been an indispensable tool. Where else to note the abundance of salamanders in a particular summer, or the paucity of bluebirds?

title: Scale In a Glass
description: Sometimes a product is so simple that you wonder why it hasn't been done before. A new kitchen scale from the Eva Solo company in Denmark has just three pieces: a stainless steel container (calibrated both inside and out so it doubles as a measuring cup), a giant-size tumbler and a stainless steel spring. You put what you're weighing in the metal cup, which rests on the spring, and read the weight markings on the glass. The scale, designed by Claus Jensen and Henrik Holbaek, can weigh as much as two pounds of, say, flour, and the cup and glass are dishwasher safe.

title: Seoul Journal; A Cultural Clash Forces Korea to Beware of Dog
description: Some say that dogs are man's best friend, but Lee Mi Kyoung, a restaurateur in one of this city's upper-middle-class neighborhoods, thinks dogs are something more.

title: Black Ice, Wise Bridge: Repelling the Foe Before It Forms
description: THE eight-lane bridge that spans the Mississippi River on Interstate 35 near downtown Minneapolis was a notorious spot for car accidents in the winter. Moisture from the river and the bridge's high elevation quickly combined to form black ice, and more than 100 accidents in the late 1990's were attributed to the roadway's treacherous surface.

title: Bush's Move On ABM Pact Gives Pause To Europeans
description: The Bush administration's decision to abrogate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty with Russia will increase European concerns about American unilateralism re-emerging as the war in Afghanistan appears to wind down, senior European officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the dedication of the Gardens of Remembrance in Lower Manhattan honoring victims of the World Trade Center attack misstated its location. It is on the Upper Promenade of Battery Park, not Battery Park City.

title: In a Land Where Old Youths Meet as Distant Neighbors
description: A Palestinian boy named Faraj tells a documentary filmmaker about his desire to avenge a friend who threw stones at an Israeli soldier and was killed. But when the filmmaker arranges to have Faraj meet two Israeli twins -- who are as sports obsessed as he is -- he prepares for the rendezvous as if it's a date. On the telephone he asks them what kind of food they like. Before they arrive, he spritzes himself with cologne.

title: Flashback to Deadly Clash of '68 Shakes Mexico
description: On Oct. 2, 1968, soldiers and university students clashed at a rally in the working-class neighborhood of Tlatelolco, a violent night that remains a watershed in Mexico's modern history and has haunted its politics for 33 years.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Trade Negotiating Bill Moves On
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved a bill that would grant President Bush the power to negotiate trade agreements that Congress could approve or reject but not amend. The House approved a similar bill last week by one vote. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader, were among the 18 committee members in support. Only three senators voted against the bill. But it is not expected to come before the full Senate until early next year, and it would then have to be reconciled with the slightly different House version. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Armey Says He'll Retire, And DeLay Looks to Lead
description: House Republicans began maneuvering for top leadership jobs today as Dick Armey, the majority leader, announced that he would retire from Congress after serving one more year.

A true woman of valor, Elaine Silver was very caring, compassionate and devoted to the well-being of our AMIT children in Israel. She will always be remembered for her vision and her professionalism. title: NATIONAL AUSTRALIA SELLS ASSETS TO WASHINGTON MUTUAL
description: The National Australia Bank, Australia's largest bank, has sold the assets of its American mortgage unit, HomeSide Lending, to Washington Mutual Inc., a large savings and loan based in Seattle, for $1.9 billion. The bank sold HomeSide's operating platform and associated assets, but will retain the mortgage servicing rights and related financial hedges for the business, based in Jacksonville, Fla. In September, Australian National was forced to write off $1.75 billion, largely from bungled interest rate hedging at HomeSide. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Recorder Writes and Rewrites Memories on a Digital Disc

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,263 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: MCGRAW-HILL TO CUT 925 JOBS IN 3 DIVISIONS
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies, the publisher of Business Week magazine and the owner of the Standard & Poor's bond-rating service, said yesterday that it would cut about 925 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, to reduce costs after ad sales slowed. McGraw-Hill said about 575 jobs would be cut in its education business and another 300 would come from the information and media operation. The financial services segment, which includes Standard & Poor's, will eliminate 50 jobs.

description: Is Osama bin Laden still in Afghanistan? Is a wholesale surrender by Al Qaeda in the offing? Have large numbers of Mr. bin Laden's recruits slipped over the border into Pakistan? The answers to these and other crucial questions are as elusive as who holds sway over large pockets of a struggling and threadbare Afghanistan.

description: SEVERAL restaurant and retail food marketers are planning changes that affect assignments with billings estimated at $75 million to $90 million.

title: Nonstop From Rue Jacob to Duane Park
description: Les Migrateurs, a modern furniture store, has joined the antiques dealers around Duane Park in TriBeCa. The shop offers New Yorkers an alternative to Crate & Barrel and Pottery Barn. ''Our furniture is contemporary, but it can be integrated into all styles of architecture and dcor,'' said Henry Personnaz, above, the owner of the company, which is based on Rue Jacob in Paris. (Duane Park is its first American outpost.) Most of the wood is European oak, which has a different grain from American or Canadian oak. A dining table, above, is 82 by 43 inches ($4,800) but can be ordered in other sizes. Upholstered chairs are $930 each, in a choice of fabrics. Table and floor lamps are $250 to $1,000. Mr. Personnaz also offers a decorating service in the store. At 188 Duane Street (near Greenwich Street), (212) 966-8208. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Aubrey Lewis, 66, Athlete Who Was an F.B.I. Pioneer
description: Aubrey Lewis, who was one of New Jersey's greatest high school athletes and a track and football star at Notre Dame, then forged careers in law enforcement, business and public administration, died Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: Back to School
description: A year ago, when I was chairman of the Senate Education Committee, I joined several senators and representatives from both parties and traveled to Austin, Tex., to meet with George W. Bush, the president-elect, to discuss education reform. At that time, we all pledged to work together to pass an education reform bill that would raise school accountability and improve student achievement. With budget surpluses projected as far as the eye could see, it seemed that this nation was on the verge of making a significant investment in education. For me, it was a time of optimism and hope.

title: Jai Alai Retires From Connecticut; Sport's Fans, Most Elderly, Lament
description: When the big red Budweiser clock above the bettors' lounge struck 5 today, it not only ended the state's 25-year experiment with jai alai -- the speedy, balletic court game that means ''merry festival'' in the Basque language -- it also closed a small but colorful chapter in this state's political, cultural and sporting past.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Satellites' Life Expectancy Lengthened
description: Iridium Satellite, the partnership in Arlington, Va., that acquired the Iridium group of satellites out of bankruptcy last year, said yesterday that the fleet would be able to operate well into 2010, three years longer than previously estimated. Iridium said the new estimate was based on analysis of the performance of the current 66 satellites, plus spares, and planned modifications. Iridium provides phone and data communications to remote locations for the Defense Department and commercial customers. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Weekend on Friday with a review of the film ''Tuvalu,'' by the German director Veit Helmer, was published in error. It showed a scene from the Spanish film ''I Will Survive,'' which opened in Manhattan on Friday.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Jury Indicts Mayor's Ex-Aides
description: Two top former aides to Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta were indicted as part of a long-running federal investigation of corruption. Larry Wallace, the former chief operating officer, was charged with accepting cash from the Spectronics Corporation, a software company seeking city business. Herbert McCall, the former commissioner of administrative services, was charged with making false declarations to a grand jury and with obstructing justice. The deputy chief operating officer, Joseph Reid, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to accepting an illegal payment from Spectronics and is cooperating with investigators. The mayor, who leaves office in January, has not been charged. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: A Fed-Up Israel Turns Its Back on Arafat
description: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Dec. 13  In announcing that it would break off contact with Yasir Arafat and conduct military operations in Palestinian cities, the Israeli government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon came close this morning to proclaiming the end of the peace process that flowered eight years ago in Oslo.

The Digital Studio suite has five applications, including a video-editing program with professional-looking effects, software for enhancing and organizing digital photos and a component for recording and creating playlists for audio files. Two other programs allow users to easily record videos, pictures and songs to compact disc, and then to design and print labels and jewel-case inserts for the resulting creations.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: More Fallout From One.Tel
description: Repercussions continue from the failure earlier this year of the start-up telecommunications company, One.Tel, backed by Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer. Australia's securities regulator accused several former directors of breaching their duties and withholding information. The Securities and Investments Commission started civil proceedings against the former managing directors, Jodee Rich and Bradley Keeling, and the former chairman, John Greaves. Evidence shows, however, that other directors, including Mr. Murdoch's son Lachlan, above left; James Packer, above right; and Rodney Adler, did not know the ''true financial position of One.Tel'' until shortly before it failed, the regulator said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

It also advances Mr. Violy's reputation as one American architect capable of fully satisfying a contemporary taste for classical design.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Ocean City: School Projects Approved
description: Residents of two New Jersey school districts have approved the money for construction of two new high schools. Voters approved nearly $50 million for Washington Township, which has never had a high school, and just over $40 million to demolish Ocean City's current high school and replace it with a new school across the street, school board officials said. The bond referendums for Washington Township and Ocean City were two of 21 statewide construction projects approved Tuesday during the New Jersey School Boards Association's ''Super Tuesday'' election. title: Cancer Study Finds Support Groups Do Not Extend Life
description: Contrary to popular opinion, support groups do not extend the lives of women with advanced breast cancer, according to a large study being published today. The study disputes a belief that has been stated so often it is almost considered a truism -- that the mind influences the course of advanced cancer so powerfully that patients can hold off death by getting emotional support in a group.

Bechtel said it would have completed the work using the existing contractors and union labor.

title: S.E.C. Wants to Question Former Officer
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday identified Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, as a possible target of its investigation into the company's collapse. The commission asked a federal judge to order him to appear before commission investigators.

title: ALBERTSON'S PLANS NORTHERN CALIFORNIA EXPANSION
description: Albertson's Inc., the nation's second-largest food and drug retailer, plans to spend $185 million in Northern California next fiscal year, building stores and remodeling others to try to recover market share in the region. That is more than three times the $60 million that it is spending on new stores and renovations for the year ending Jan. 31. Albertson's will renovate 23 stores and open several supermarkets and gas stations, the company said.

title: Alliance Captures Australian Man Fighting for the Taliban
description: A 26-year-old Australian drifter who had been fighting alongside the Taliban was captured over the weekend by Northern Alliance troops, Australian authorities said today.

One of her close friends, Jean DePalma, worked on the 100th floor of the north tower, and the more Ms. Kostenko heard about the crash, the more her body filled with dread.

title: Bush Pulls Out of ABM Treaty; Putin Calls Move a Mistake
description: In a move that reflected what he said was "a vastly different world," President Bush formally announced today that the United States was withdrawing from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty that it signed with the Soviet Union in 1972.

title: Justice Department Decision to Forgo Tribunal Bypasses Pentagon
description: Top Pentagon officials said today that they were not consulted by Attorney General John Ashcroft in his decision to go to federal court rather than seek a military tribunal to try Zacarias Moussaoui in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Stores Fined For Price Discrepancies
description: Holiday shoppers are being shortchanged at stores that fail to post correct prices or whose checkout scanners charge the wrong amount, especially during sales events, the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said yesterday. The county's consumer affairs staff found overcharges of 50 cents to $10 per item in an investigation of supermarkets, pharmacies and department stores. The agency issued 177 violations and collected $80,000 in fines, many from branches of well-known retail chains. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

Survived by his sister Professor Florence G. Roswell. Beloved uncle to three generations of nieces and nephews. Community activist and founder of Service Directions, Inc. description: Some South Jersey leaders said today that their fellow Democrat, Governor-elect James E. McGreevey, had angered them by trying to kill a $180 million spending plan to improve Camden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CHRISTOPHER J.
description: MURPHY-Christopher J. A 34 year resident of Scarsdale, NY. Chris, 41 years old, died suddenly on December 11, 2001 of the complications of juvenile diabetes. He was born in Old Bridge, NJ on September 18, 1960. Chris was a graduate of Seely Place School and Edgemont High School in Scarsdale and went on to earn his Bachelor of Arts Degree in Business Management from Syracuse University in 1982. He pursued an active career in investment and commercial banking and at the time he left us he was a shareholder, Director and Executive of Country Bank, New York, NY, in which the Murphy family has a majority interest. Chris was a warrior in the battle to find a cure for juvenile diabetes which he contacted at the age of six. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Chapter of Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International. In that regard he was a member of the real estate committee at the annual ''Walk For a Cure'' and was an active participant with his family in the development of the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, ll50 St. Nicholas Avenue at 168th Street, Manhattan. Chris is survived by his parents Catherine Jo Ann and Joseph Michael Murphy, in addition to his brother Joseph M. Jr., his sisters, Carolyn and Mary Murphy and Patricia MacGillivray. He was adored by his nephews, Ryan and Sean MacGillivray, Brent Murphy, Joseph Michael III and Brian Murphy and his nieces, Kelly MacGillivray and Cailin Murphy. His brothers-in-law, Glen MacGillivray and Robert Murphy and sister-in-law Michele Murphy will sadly miss him. Visitation at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY, Thursday and Friday, December 13th and 14th from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of a Christian Burial will be celebrated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Post Road (Route 22) at Carman Road, Scarsdale at 10:45 AM Saturday, December 15th. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Secor Road, Hartsdale, New York. In lieu of flowers, friends are asked to make a donation to either Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International or the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center.

title: Program Makes Linux System A Friendlier Place to Work

Help may come in the form of Ximian Evolution, a new information-management program for Linux and Unix devotees that integrates e-mail, task and contact lists, scheduling and calendars.

title: In Embarrassing Episode, French Officer Is Guilty of Aiding Serbs
description: A French Army officer was convicted of treason today by a military court for handing over NATO secrets to Yugoslavia in the days leading up to the Kosovo war.

title: Rangers Lose Lindros And Fall to Predators
description: The Rangers' prospects for the season will be at stake today when Eric Lindros undergoes a magnetic resonance imaging test to determine how severely his knee was injured last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pledging Allegiance to the Season
description: THERE are two kinds of people this time of year: those who deck the halls and those who don't. The deckers normally hold to the belief that red and green and boughs of holly, mangers and eight tiny reindeer are the fitting seasonal images. But this Christmas, large numbers of deckers, departing from the standard repertory, are emulating the red, white and blue Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center and adding patriotism to their displays.

title: Palestinian Assault on Bus Kills 10; Israeli Response Is Swift
description: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Dec. 13  The Israeli government decided early this morning to break off contact with Yasir Arafat after Palestinian militants killed 10 people Wednesday evening. The Israelis died when members of Hamas detonated bombs underneath a bus in the West Bank and gunned down passengers as they fled.

title: Film Directors' Union Reaches Tentative Contract Agreement
description: The union representing Hollywood's film and television directors reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract today with negotiators for the leading studios, networks and production companies, with many of the provisions mirroring agreements reached earlier in the year with actors and writers.

title: Paris Fights Death Penalty
description: The French government said today that it would oppose the death penalty in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, a French citizen indicted on Tuesday by the United States on charges of conspiracy in the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Using Sliding Strings to Suggest the Tangled Canopy of a Forest
description: As part of the exploration of contemporary composers that has become the central mission of the Miller Theater in recent years, Ensemble 21 devoted its Saturday evening concert to the kaleidoscopic music of James Dillon. Mr. Dillon, a Scottish composer born in 1950, has said that his influences range from Scottish traditional music and rock to the more abstruse end of the contemporary music spectrum.

title: Nets Coach Says Riley Will Be Able to Turn the Heat Around
description: There are some things, Nets Coach Byron Scott knows, you simply do not say to Pat Riley. For instance, ''Hang in there.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IGLER, KIRK A.
description: IGLER-Kirk A. Age 57. Of Starksboro, VT. Died unexpectedly Tuesday, December 11, 2001. He was born in Scranton, PA., on May 4, 1944, the son of the late Frederick and Viola (Kirkendall) Igler. Kirk was a graduate of Drew University in Madison, N.J. He was an antique dealer and appraiser working for many years with Sotheby's. Kirk's passion in life was foremost his granddaughter, Anna, his dogs and golf. He is survived by his wife Roberta Igler of Starksboro, his two sons and their wives, Keith and Susan Igler of New Providence, N.J., Matthew Igler and Missy Kelsen of Bristol, VT., his granddaughter Anna Igler, a brother Glenn Igler and his wife Suzanne of Georgia, his uncle William Kirkendall of PA. and his many friends. A memorial service will be held Friday, December 14, 2001 12 Noon in the Trinity Episcopal Church, 5171 Shelburne Rd., Shelburne, VT. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LAWRENCE I., M.D.
description: KAPLAN-Lawrence I., M.D. Passed away Dec. 11th at home in Longboat Key, FL. Loving and singularly devoted husband of 58 years to Janet, cherished father to Richard and Laurie, and beloved grandfather to Wesley. Adored by family and friends for his limitless generosity and his gift for finding and nurturing the best in each of us. He is respected and admired by patients, colleagues and students for his unfailing devotion to medicine. In addition to his private practice, he maintained a lifelong affiliation with Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan where he trained, taught and practiced neuropsychiatry, served as Chairman of the Medical Board at Gracie Square Hospital and shared his medical expertise with the Practicing Law Institute. His extraordinary kindness will be missed and long remembered by all who knew him. Funeral services to be held on Friday, December 14, 9:30 AM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Playing Piero as Just Enough of a Mess
description: Observing the world through hooded snake eyes in a fog of cigarette smoke, jabbing the air as he raps out poetry in a sly staccato drawl, Benjamin Bratt resurrects the spirit of the playwright, poet and actor Miguel Piero with the kind of thrilling brio that Dustin Hoffman brought to his screen portrayal of Lenny Bruce 27 years ago. In ''Piero,'' Leon Ichaso's moody agitated portrait of the playwright, who died in 1988 of cirrhosis of the liver, Mr. Bratt looks no more like Piero than Mr. Hoffman looked like Bruce, but it hardly matters. Both performances spark with inner truth.

title: Fireman's Body Is Found, But Serenity Is Elusive
description: The remains of Lt. Dave Fontana were found last Thursday in the wreckage of the south tower of the World Trade Center, his widow, Marian Fontana, said yesterday.

title: Is Government the Good Guy?
description: The market defines America. Labor markets organize our work; consumer markets structure our spending; securities markets shape our future. The idea of the market dominates our mythology: Americans are open to ''market solutions'' to public problems, from providing housing to improving education -- especially with a fumbling, inefficient government program cast as the alternative.

description: The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the main shareholder in Airbus Industrie, said deliveries of Airbus SAS planes in 2003 would fall and that job losses might follow. The company attributed the decline in aircraft production to the slowdown in air travel after Sept. 11. A spokesman told Bloomberg News that Airbus was sticking to its target of 300 deliveries in 2002 but warned that if deliveries fell below 270 or 280, job cuts could follow. European Aerospace has said it will deliver a record 320 planes this year. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Terrorism and Justice
description: The United States will rightly try the first person accused of conspiracy in the Sept. 11 attacks in an American courtroom, before a civilian jury, and not in some hastily assembled military tribunal of dubious legitimacy. True justice calls for no less. We hope Tuesday's indictment by a federal grand jury of Zacarias Moussaoui, a 33-year-old French national of Moroccan descent, reflects a new determination on the part of the Bush administration to try all those implicated in the terror attacks in the civilian criminal justice system.

The deal is expected to close in February. Francis Mer, chairman of Usinor, and Joseph Kinch, chairman of Arbed, will be co-chairmen of Arcelor until 2004, when a single chairman will be named. The new company will have an eight-member management board made up of four representatives from Usinor, three from Arbed and one from Aceralia. It is expected to be the world's largest steel maker. And this time it was No. 4 Kansas, a team that, for a moment, looked beatable.

title: In Los Angeles, a Museum Under a Plastic Bubble
description: The decision is in, and it's in favor of Rem Koolhaas's radical proposal to tear down most of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and start over. The museum named Mr. Koolhaas, the Dutch architect, above, the winner of a design competition to make over its hodgepodge of buildings on Wilshire Boulevard. His scheme, top, would replace almost all the buildings with an exhibition plaza under a translucent plastic roof. (Art would be hung on freestanding displays, above right.) ''We found that it was the most radical short-term solution and most fiscally conservative long-term,'' said Andrea Rich, the museum's president and director. Mr. Koolhaas was one of five leading architects to submit plans. The others were Steven Holl Architects of New York; Daniel Libeskind, the Berlin-based architect; Thom Mayne of Morphosis in Los Angeles; and the French architect Jean Nouvel. If the new museum is built -- it is estimated to cost $200 million, and the money still has to be raised -- it will join other modern landmarks in Los Angeles, including Frank Gehry's Disney Concert Hall, Raphael Moneo's Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels and the already open Getty Center by Richard Meier. By hiring Mr. Koolhaas, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art may be making up for a past oversight. It ignored the Modernist giant Mies van der Rohe and hired a local architect, William Pereira, for its first building, finished in 1964. Perhaps to make amends, Mr. Koolhaas has nicknamed his proposed plaza, between Wilshire Boulevard and the museum's spacious garden, the Miesian Court. FRANCES ANDERTON

title: Government's Focus in the First Sept. 11 Trial: Al Qaeda
description: The trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, accused of conspiracy in the Sept. 11 hijackings, is certain to be an international courtroom spectacle. But the defendant may be just a secondary figure. The government seems intent on putting Al Qaeda on trial.

title: Pilot of Hijacked Plane Buried With Honors in Arlington
description: Charles F. Burlingame, who served 25 years in the Navy and was the captain of the hijacked American Airlines plane that crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11, was buried today with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Sentiment on Japan's Economy Worsens
description: Japanese business leaders are rapidly losing confidence in the country's weakening economy, and they see no end to the current recession in the first quarter of 2002, according to a closely watched Bank of Japan survey released today.

title: A Second Life for Ornaments
description: Re ''Memories Swaddled in Packing Peanuts'' (Online Shopper, Dec. 6): About 20 years ago I started collecting ornaments for each of my three daughters (who at that time ranged in age from 1 to 10). Every year, when I bought a new ornament for our tree, I'd get three extras and put them away in a box in the attic.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Scansoft Gets Lernout Assets
description: ScanSoft, a maker of digital imaging software, completed its purchase of the speech technology assets of Lernout & Hauspie, a Belgian company that filed for bankruptcy in November 2000 after accounting irregularities came to light. The sale of Lernout's assets, including the Dragon speech recognition software, was approved on Tuesday evening by a federal bankruptcy court, which affirmed the results of a Nov. 26 bankruptcy auction despite a protest from SpeechWorks International. The value of the transaction was $51 million. The acquisition is ScanSoft's first foray into speech technology. Paul Ricci, its chief executive, said. ScanSoft, based in Peabody, Mass., had already offered jobs to 200 of the 500 former Lernout employees. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Don Tennant, Creator of Characters for Ads, Is Dead at 79
description: Don Tennant, the advertising agency executive who specialized in creating characters like Tony the Tiger during the heyday of such marketing ploys, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Arrested In Death Of Mother
description: A man with a history of mental illness stabbed and strangled his mother to death yesterday morning after a fight in their Harlem apartment, the police said. The man, identified as Frederick Robinson, 45, who was charged with second-degree murder, argued with his mother, Rozella McGee, 75, about 10 a.m. yesterday and then stabbed her 19 times and strangled her, the police said. Ms. McGee was found dead at the apartment by officers responding to a call of an assault in progress. The police said that Mr. Robinson and his mother had been arguing over his refusal to end his drug habit.

title: HEALTHSOUTH SAYS FIRST QUARTER WILL EXCEED FORECASTS
description: The HealthSouth Corporation, which runs rehabilitation hospitals, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings would exceed forecasts because the federal government had approved a change in payment collection. Profit will be about 27 cents a share, the company, based in Birmingham, Ala., said. The company is expected to earn 22 cents, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. HealthSouth expects to gain from the government's system of compensating rehabilitation hospitals, which provides a set fee from Medicare for services provided. The company said it could make a profit on the new payments because it had lowered costs.

description: Afghan fighters set a new deadline of Thursday for Al Qaeda fighters bottled up in mountain canyons and caves to give up, after an agreement for a surrender this morning collapsed in confusion amid continued American bombing.

description: WHEN it comes to Christmas, many families have special food traditions. I won't bore you with the details of my childhood favorite (two words: shrimp tree) because I'd rather talk about the sort of universally revered item that might actually do you some good this month: the tamale.

title: Corrections

She was Mary Jo Kimelman, not Kimmelman. The sketch also misstated her relationship to Pat Kimelman. She was her stepdaughter, not her daughter.

title: Sharp's Tiny New Laptop

The teapot has been in production since 1967; the hot water pot and tea strainer are being reissued for the occasion.

description: Airborne Express, the package-delivery company, said yesterday that it would place drop boxes and service centers in OfficeMax stores in the United States. Under the three-year agreement with OfficeMax, Airborne Express drop boxes and kiosks will be installed at 32 stores in the Seattle and Cleveland markets, and eventually in about 960 stores nationwide, the companies said. The agreement calls for each company to market the other's services on its Web site.

description: The Los Angeles group headed by Irving David Rubin is one of two United States offshoots of the Jewish Defense League, which was founded in 1968 by Meir David Kahane, the militant rabbi who was assassinated in New York City in 1990.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless To Offer Auto Services
description: Verizon Wireless is expected to announce today that it has reached an agreement to be the exclusive service provider for Wingcast, a company formed by Ford Motor and Qualcomm to provide a wireless service in automobiles. The agreement will permit Wingcast to offer consumers voice-activated services, including emergency phone calls, instant messaging, e-mail access and streaming video. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Agreement On Placement Of Bridge
description: Battery Park City officials and residents and members of Community Board 1 reached an agreement last night on where to place a temporary pedestrian bridge crossing West Street in Lower Manhattan. The new site for the $2 million crossing, an emergency replacement for bridges that were destroyed in the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, is between Rector and Carlisle Streets, just north of a small community park in the southern part of Battery Park City. The original plan, which caused an outcry in the neighborhood, cut across the middle of the park. The community board unanimously approved the new design for the bridge, which could be constructed within the next three months. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Curling Up With a Wealth of Designs for the Holidays
description: FOR design mavens, here are some of the most lavish books published this year, on topics rarely covered elsewhere, and never so comprehensively. These books will suit those on your gift list -- whether they are the sort who like to pore through albums of rarefied silver clocks, to churn up clouds of sawdust while woodworking or to imagine themselves aloft over 1950's megalopolises -- and some of them might even be a necessary addition to your own library.

title: Alomar Wants the Mets to Want Him for the Long Haul
description: Roberto Alomar has been a Met for two days, and he already wants to stay for the rest of his career. Alomar, the star second baseman the Mets acquired Tuesday from the Cleveland Indians, said today that he wanted to negotiate a long-term contract with the Mets.

title: Calpine's Accounting Ways Have Been Issue With S.E.C.
description: Securities regulators earlier this year instructed the Calpine Corporation, the nation's largest independent power producer, to alter its financial documents to make them more easily understood by investors. And though the company promised to make the requested changes, subsequent filings show that it did not always do so.

title: Giuliani Plans Own Business With Top Aides in Consulting
description: Compstat for private firms? A former mayor's management reports? State of the Company speeches? Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cast some light yesterday on his plans for life after City Hall, saying that he was working to establish his own consulting business with some of his top lieutenants.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Arrest In Migrants' Death
description: An investigation into the deaths of eight migrants in a sealed freight container in Ireland last week has led to the arrest of a Belgian truck driver on charges of trying to smuggle people, a Belgian prosecutor said. The driver is believed to have driven the migrants, mainly Turks, to the Belgian port of Zeebrugge, from where they were apparently expecting to take a short ferry ride to Britain. But the container was instead put onto a ferry heading for Ireland, a journey of more than two days. Five survivors are in critical condition. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Bin Laden, on Videotape, Gloats About Sept. 11's Destruction
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Exulting in the success of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Osama bin Laden told two devoted followers that the operation was even more destructive than he had hoped it would be and that it would surely bring more converts to Islam.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid To Stop Mining Sale Is Rejected
description: One hurdle has been removed to a proposed takeover bid by Newmont Mining aimed at Australia's largest gold producer, Normandy Mining. The Australian Takeovers Panel has rejected a challenge that a rival suitor, AngloGold, had filed over aspects of Newmont's three-way merger proposal, which includes Franco-Nevada Mining. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Is Censured
description: Judge Donna G. Recant of Manhattan Criminal Court was censured yesterday by a state panel for behavior toward prosecutors, defense lawyers and defendants that the panel said was ''coercive, discourteous and contrary to law.'' In 1998 and 1999, Judge Recant attempted to coerce defendants into pleading guilty, had improper communications with prosecutors, and was abusive toward defense lawyers, according to a ruling by the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct. In some cases, she threatened to set bail and have defendants taken into custody if they refused to plead guilty, the commission said. Judge Recant's term ends in 2005. The judge and her lawyer agreed to a statement of facts drawn up by the commission. Jane Fritsch (NYT)

title: Sri Lanka's President Installs Her Rival's Choice of Cabinet
description: Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, today swore in a cabinet picked by the new prime minister, her bitter rival, Ranil Wickremesinghe, whose coalition vanquished her governing alliance in elections last week.

title: ALBERTO-CULVER TO ACQUIRE ARMSTRONG-MCCALL
description: The Alberto-Culver Company, which sells beauty salon products, has agreed to acquire the closely held Armstrong-McCall to expand its distribution area. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The acquisition of Armstrong-McCall, which distributes Matrix hair care products, will extend the geographic reach of Alberto-Culver's Beauty Systems Group to salons in more than half the United States and into Mexico, according to Alberto, which is based in Melrose Park, Ill.. The purchase is expected to add about $75 million in sales in the last three quarters of the year ending next September.

title: Telephone Regulation Is Approved
description: A package of European Union laws meant to knit together and regulate a single 15-nation telecommunications market cleared its final hurdle today when the European Parliament approved a compromise with member governments.

title: When Last Deserves To Be First
description: Some song recitals should begin at the end. In the encores, virtually de rigueur, the singer can let loose, vocally and emotionally, and it's not uncommon for someone to produce his best singing after the program is over.

title: Mets Bringing Back Cedeo
description: BOSTON, Dec. 13  The facelift of the worst lineup in the major leagues got another nip and tuck this morning. The Mets signed outfielder Roger Cedeno to a four-year, $18 million contract, inserting him at the top of a lineup that is rapidly going from limp to lively.

title: ISRAEL BREAKS WITH ARAFAT AFTER PALESTINIAN ASSAULT ON BUS IN WEST BANK KILLS 10
description: The Israeli government decided early this morning to break off contact with Yasir Arafat after Palestinian militants killed 10 people Wednesday evening. The Israelis died when members of Hamas detonated bombs underneath a bus in the West Bank and gunned down passengers as they fled.

title: Protestant, An Informer, Is Shot Dead In Belfast
description: A former British soldier, Protestant guerrilla and police informer who was acquitted two weeks ago of plotting the fatal shooting of Northern Ireland's best known Catholic human rights lawyer was shot dead himself today in Belfast.

title: Late 3's Becoming Bad Habit
description: While much has been made of the low-key demeanor of the Knicks' new head coach, Don Chaney, his ascension does not mean the walls of the locker room will no longer reverberate from an occasional tirade.

title: Let the Pros Do That Photo Album
description: Now there's a way to convert those boxes of photographs (baby's first year or last summer's vacation) into a real book. And send copies to relatives besides. Recollections, in Valhalla, N.Y., will scan 50 photographs, print them on 10 pages of archival-quality paper, then bind them into a hardcover book (9 inches by 11 1/4 inches), right, in seven business days after receiving them by mail. Digital pictures can be done online. The company ships back the finished book, your pictures and a CD of them. A 10-page book is $29.95; copies are $19.95 each; 1 to 40 pages more are $3 each; (800) 432-8290 or www .my

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Tuesday with a biographical sketch of two World Trade Center victims -- Firefighter Peter Langone and Police Officer Thomas Langone, brothers who were leaders at the Roslyn, N.Y., volunteer fire company -- was published in error. It showed Robert Lane, a firefighter who died in the attack. Officer Thomas Langone is pictured here.

title: Back to School
description: WASHINGTON -- A year ago, when I was chairman of the Senate Education Committee, I joined several senators and representatives from both parties and traveled to Austin, Tex., to meet with George W. Bush, the president-elect, to discuss education reform. At that time, we all pledged to work together to pass an education reform bill that would raise school accountability and improve student achievement. With budget surpluses projected as far as the eye could see, it seemed that this nation was on the verge of making a significant investment in education. For me, it was a time of optimism and hope.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Express to Cut Up to 6,500 More Jobs

title: Postholiday Sales Arrive Early
description: BEFORE Christmas, December is not normally associated with deep discounts or sales. But this year good buys already abound. The merchandise can help refresh your home for the holidays, or it can make good gifts.

title: Greece Drops Spying Charges Against Visitors Who 'Spot' Planes
description: Fourteen British and Dutch ''plane spotters,'' accused of spying after they took snapshots of fighter jets in Greece, were cleared of espionage charges today and ordered free on bail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUGARMAN, GOLDIE G.
description: SUGARMAN-Goldie G. Wife of the late nuclear chemist Nathan Sugarman who was part of the University of Chicago Manhattan Project and the team that went to Los Alamos, died December 10th at 85. ''Goldie was a deeply thoughtful and caring human being who endeavored to understand the world and her place in it'' said her daughter Tanya. She was born Goldie Gertrude Greenberg; daughter of Alex Louis Greenberg, a first generation Russian immigrant. Goldie loved art, dance, books, yoga, her family and friends and referred to her year in Los Alamos as one of the most exciting years in her life. She was a life long learner at the University of Chicago Basic Program as well as a gun control advocate. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband Dr. Nathan Sugarman and son Dr. Barrett Sugarman. She is survived by her daughter Tanya Sugarman of Evanston, three beautiful grandchildren John, Nadya and Chris MacAloon, sisters Marci Keeshin and Ida Schultz, daughter-in-law Linda Angell and many devoted relatives and friends. Interment is private. The family will be receiving visitors on Thursday, December 13th, 3 to 8 PM, at 947 Elmwood, Evanston, IL, 847-866-6234. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: 2 Suspects Found on Train Probably Are Not Linked to Attack, Officials Say
description: Two men from Jersey City who aroused some of the most tantalizing suspicions in the terrorism investigations have faded as suspects and are unlikely to be charged with any crimes directly related to the Sept. 11 attacks, federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROTTER, PARSONS
description: TROTTER-Parsons. Age 84, died after a brief illness on December 10, 2001. Born on March 5, 1917 in Rochester, N.Y., Mr. Trotter was associated with Crown Publishing before his retirement. Funeral services will be held at 2:30pm on Saturday, December 15th at St. Thomas Church, 5th Ave & 53rd Street.

title: City to Consider 2 Sites for Plant To Filter Water
description: New York City has identified two possible sites for a water filtration plant, after its previous proposal to place it under a golf course in the Bronx drew vigorous local opposition and was effectively rejected by the State Court of Appeals. The announcement yesterday is the most recent move in a continuing battle over the quality of water coming from the Croton watershed.

title: California Stops Selling Personal Data
description: OVER the last six years California has sold its database of birth and death records, in whole or in part, nearly two dozen times -- to local governments, law offices, medical groups and genealogy research firms.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: New Review Of Corruption Case
description: The Court of Appeals agreed to review a court ruling that overturned prison sentences for a senior police officer, an intelligence official and 12 others convicted of taking part in organized crime. The case came to light in 1996 when a car carrying a senior policeman, a mafia boss, a member of Parliament and a former beauty queen crashed. An investigation linked government officials and nationalist groups to drugs and weapons trafficking. Prison sentences imposed on security and intelligence officials were overturned in October on grounds of insufficient evidence. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Smells Like Mean Spirits
description: Ten years after the release of Nirvana's seminal ''Nevermind'' album, the legacy of the band is being threatened by infighting between Dave Grohl and Krist Novoselic, the surviving members of Nirvana, and Courtney Love, the widow of Kurt Cobain, over control of the music.

title: Report Calls Ulster Police Force Inept in Fatal-Bombing Inquiry
description: The police officers investigating the 1998 terrorist bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland -- from the chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, to the detectives -- hampered the inquiry by ineptitude, poor judgment, lack of communication and constant delays, according to a report published today.

title: Arafat's Group Suspends Effort To Crack Down on Extremists
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 13  Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority today suspended any effort to crack down on extremist groups conducting attacks against Israeli civilians, saying that the continued Israeli military assault made such police work impossible.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Friday and Sunday about a plan that New York City had considered to hire the Bechtel Group to run operations at the World Trade Center disaster site omitted the company's response to the suspicions of union leaders that it would bring in nonunion labor and outside contractors. Bechtel said it would have completed the work using the existing contractors and union labor.

description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GANS, JEROME
description: GANS-Jerome. Ten years-never forgotten, still loved. Mona, Andrew, Jamie, Larry, Helene, Pam, Casey, Kyle

title: Devils' Overtime Victory Leaves Islanders Seething
description: Scott Niedermayer, the Devils defenseman, who will admit that he is sometimes reluctant to shoot, was in the middle of a jubilant mob of teammates, the hero of a rough night at the rink.

title: Accounts
description: * Symbol Technologies, Holtsville, N.Y., a wireless technology company, to the New York offices of Draft Worldwide and Golin/Harris International, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, as lead agencies for the company's first integrated marketing and communications account. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. The decision came after a review that MatchWorks, New York, helped manage.

title: The Tree That Grew In a Metal Shop
description: Need Christmas decorations in a hurry? The Julien tree is shiny and metallic and comes trimmed and packed flat in a pizza-style box. It's from Ikea and is the opposite of the store's traditional Scandinavian holiday ornaments, which are made of natural materials like wood and straw. The metallic tree is anchored by a stand and center pole, included in the box. In silver with purple balls or green with red ones; 48 inches ($16.95) or 72 inches (29.95). At Ikea, (800) 434-4532.

title: Corrections
description: The College Hockey Notebook column yesterday, about the strength of St. Cloud State, in Minnesota, misstated the national ranking of two of its players, Mark Hartigan and Nate DiCasmirro, in points per game. They rank third and fourth nationally, not first and second. Darren Haydar of the University of New Hampshire is first, and Ben Eaves of Boston College is second.

title: 2002: A Pinstripe Sneak Preview
description: For the first time since 1996, the Yankees are remaking their team. Their starting lineup in 2002 will look a lot different from the one the club used in losing Game 7 of the World Series in early November. And it will look especially different if Manager Joe Torre follows through on his early thoughts of stacking the top of the lineup with the Yankees' best hitters. In this potential lineup, Jason Giambi would bat third; Rondell White, not a classic power hitter, would bat fourth; and John Vander Wal, who may soon be acquired by the Yankees, would platoon with Shane Spencer and probably bat sixth. By BUSTER OLNEY

title: Economic Scene; To avoid terrorism, end poverty and ignorance. Right? Guess again. Debunking conventional wisdom about the roots of hate crime.
description: HARDLY a day goes by without an expert proposing more foreign aid or support for education as a cure for terrorism. There are compelling reasons for improving the living standards and education of people in developing countries, but is reducing terrorism one of them?

title: Skepticism In Senate Panel Over Accord With Microsoft
description: Democrats and Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee voiced deep skepticism today about the Bush administration's proposed settlement of the antitrust case against Microsoft, as the company denounced the list of tougher penalties being sought by nine states as ''radical and punitive.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We were dragging our feet on getting it finished. The 11th made me realize that you're more vulnerable than you thought. And you can't control the circumstances.''

title: Levy Offers Pared-Down School Construction Plan
description: Faced with a huge gap in the construction budget, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy proposed yesterday that the building of new schools or annexes be limited to 21 in the city's most crowded districts. He also requested that repairs be made only to schools so dilapidated that they posed safety hazards.

title: Berlin Cameron Agency Won't Seek G.M. Work
description: Berlin Cameron & Partners in New York has decided not to participate in a review now getting under way for the Saturn division of General Motors ( news/quote ) to select an agency to create campaigns for the new Ion coupe and sedan. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $100 million.

title: House Vote Puts Overhaul Of Elections Step Closer
description: With a strong bipartisan vote, the House of Representatives today approved legislation intended to prevent ballot disputes like the ones in Florida after last year's presidential election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNEY, RAYMOND
description: DOWNEY-Raymond. Of Deer Park, LI, FDNY-Deputy Chief of Special Operations Command, heroically in the line of duty at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001, a week before his 64th birthday. Beloved husband of Rosalie (nee Princiotta). Loving and adored father of Joseph and Lynn, Marie and Girolamo Tortorici, Chuck and Melissa, Ray and Christine, Kathy and Brian Ugalde. Cherishd poppy of Gina Marie, Nicolette Rose, Peter Raymond, Joseph James, Connor Joseph, Olivia Faith and Kayla Rae. A dear brother to Eugene, Thomas and the late Joseph and Alice Routledge. Dear brother-in-law of Eileen Downey, Jean Downey and Sal Princiotta. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews and cherished family and friends. Memorial viewing at the Claude R. Boyd-Caratozzolo Funeral Home, 1785 Deer Park Ave, Deer Park, NY, on Thursday and Friday from 2-5 PM and 7-9:30 PM. A memorial mass will be held at St. Cyril and Methodius, RC Church at 11:00 AM on Saturday, December 15th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his loving memory to the Deputy Chief, Raymond Downey Scholarship - Charity Fund (D.C.R.D.S.C Fund) 7 Bardish Lane, Babylon, NY 11702.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HELEN
description: SCHNEIDER-Helen. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Helen Schneider, who with her husband Irving, generously supported ADL. Through their philanthropy, she and Irving demonstrated their commitment to the Jewish people, the State of Israel and the well being of children everywhere. We extend our deepest condolences to Irving, her daughters and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director Arnold Forster, General Counsel

title: Faulty Fireproofing Is Reviewed as Factor in Trade Center Collapse
description: An expert in fire protection who is helping lead a federally financed inquiry into the collapse of the World Trade Center towers said yesterday that inadequate or faulty fireproofing that had gone unrepaired for years may have played a role in the failure of the two 110-story buildings.

title: 2 Boys Charged as Adults in Father's Killing
description: Two Pensacola boys accused of bludgeoning their father to death last month have been indicted as adults on charges of first-degree murder.

title: ROYAL DUTCH AND SAUDI REFINING BUY INTO 2 VENTURES
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Saudi Refining Inc. have agreed to buy the stakes of the ChevronTexaco Corporation in two refining ventures for $3.86 billion. The companies will pay $2.26 billion in cash to the Texaco Alliance Trust and assume about $1.6 billion in debt, the trust said. ChevronTexaco put its stakes into the trust in October as part of a settlement with regulators that allowed Chevron to buy Texaco. Under the deals, the Shell Oil Company, the American unit of the British-Dutch company, will own all of the Equilon Enterprises venture it had owned with Texaco. Shell and Saudi Refining will each own 50 percent of Motiva Enterprises, which had been 35 percent owned by Texaco. The sale, which requires approval from federal regulators, is expected to close in mid-January.

title: Struggling Jets Peek in Mirror To See the Struggling Bengals
description: See if this sounds familiar: good defense, great running back, not enough points, too many losses.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Tearing Up the ABM Treaty
description: With his decision to junk the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, President Bush is rolling the diplomatic dice. If he is lucky, the Russians will live with the decision and relations with Moscow will continue to improve while Washington freely experiments with new missile defense systems. If he is not, Mr. Bush may alienate the Kremlin and give rise to a dangerous new arms race with Russia and possibly China as well. Why he would choose to take that risk at a moment when he badly needs Russian cooperation in the war against terrorism is baffling. It is not as if the lesson of Sept. 11 was that the United States is vulnerable to a missile attack.

title: Pooh-Poohing the Purists, a Scholar Revels in Netspeak
description: THE future of the Internet isn't just commercial or technical. It's linguistic, too -- at least in the eyes of Dr. David Crystal, an eminent Welsh authority on language and the producer of many scholarly volumes, including the Cambridge Encyclopedia of the English Language. His new book on Internet communication was just released by Cambridge University Press.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: SonicBlue Sues TiVo
description: SonicBlue filed a patent infringement lawsuit yesterday against TiVo, saying TiVo's digital video recorder violates a patent granted to SonicBlue. The lawsuit, filed in federal court in California, adds to the escalating legal battles in the nascent digital video recording market. Production studios and television networks have sued SonicBlue, saying it violated the copyright on television programs. TiVo has been sued for patent infringement by Pause Technology. ''We're disappointed that SonicBlue is opting to use litigation to build visibility for its company,'' TiVo said in a statement. SonicBlue executives said they had licensing discussions with TiVo before the lawsuit was filed. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about the first criminal charge directly related to the Sept. 11 attacks omitted a name in some copies for a man listed as one of 23 unindicted co- conspirators, and erroneously included one man twice, under differing spellings of his surname. Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a Yemeni citizen who the authorities say was an intended hijacker, should have been listed among the 23. A man accused of opening bank accounts used in the plot is Mustafa Ahmed al Hawsawi, not al-Hisawi.

title: Floats Like a Butterfly, Eats Gas Like a Buick
description: When Dean Kamen unveiled his long-awaited personal scooter, the Segway Human Transporter, this month, even his more fervent followers were a little let down. Sure, it has its merits, but it fell short of the science-fiction holy grail. (It doesn't fly.)

title: Magazine Ad Pages Fell in November
description: Magazine advertising pages continued their steep decline last month, according to data released by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York, an affiliate of the Magazine Publishers of America.

description: It will be a most unusual advertising campaign for the State Department.

title: A Former Boss Tries to Put Honeywell on a New Path
description: In July, when Lawrence A. Bossidy came out of retirement to once again take the reins at Honeywell International, he was simply floored by the contrast between the company he had left in April 2000 and the one that welcomed him back.

title: House and Senate Negotiators Agree to More Base Closings
description: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on legislation that would close more military bases, starting in 2005.

description: Stocks fell sharply today on renewed fears about the health of the economy after two technology bellwethers, Lucent Technologies ( news/quote ) and Ciena ( news/quote ), both forecast unexpected weakness in their financial results and the government reported a steep drop in retail sales in November.

description: BERNHEIM-S. Lewis. Of Short Hills, NJ, on December 11, 2001; beloved husband of Claire (nee Stern). Funeral service Friday, December 14, at 11 AM, in BernheimApter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Treaty's End Would Ruffle Russia's Politics
description: The Russian government was silent tonight about the White House's apparent decision, over its objections, to quit the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. But in academic and legislative circles outside the Kremlin, experts split over whether the snub was a bump on the road to a true Russian-Western alliance or a more serious roadblock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENNBERG, BENKT ROBERTSSON WENNBERG, PH.D.
description: WENNBERG-Benkt Robertsson Wennberg, Ph.D., born in Nykoeping Sweden, November 21, 1920. Died in Wyncote, PA December 11, 2001. Survived by wife Dorothy Henderson Guenther Wennberg; daughters Louise Wennberg and Signe Merritt (Charles) and son John Wennberg and grandchildren Margaret and Robert Merritt. Family members in Sweden and Massachusetts.

title: The Real Carmen Miranda Under the Crown of Fruit
description: She may be the most famous person their country has ever produced, but Brazilians have always had mixed feelings about Carmen Miranda. Yes, she made Brazil better known all around the world, but did so by playing scatterbrains and reinforcing every condescending stereotype the Anglo-Saxon world has ever had about Latin Americans.

title: Prudential Insurance Raises $3.03 Billion in Initial Public Offering
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, one of the best-known names in life insurance, has raised $3.03 billion in the largest initial public stock offering since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, BEATRICE ''BABBIE'' S.
description: SMITH-Beatrice ''Babbie'' S. Formerly of NYC in Concord, MA, December 10, 2001. Wife of the late Morgan K. Smith. Memorial services in Concord will be announced at a later date. Gifts in her memory may be sent to Trinity Church, 81 Elm St., Concord, MA. 01742, the Adirondack Trail Improvement Society, Keene Valley, NY 12943 or the Museum of Fine Arts, Attn: Development Office, 465 Huntington Ave., Boston, MA 02115. For information MacRae - Tunnicliffe, Concord.

title: Sports of The Times; The Manner Of the Yanks' New Man
description: NOW that Jason Giambi is cashing his seven-year, $118 million to $120 million lottery ticket, he will be talking today about what it's like to be a Yankee, what it's like to be the biggest bat in Joe Torre's lineup, what it's like to join the New York franchise that, with him here, will be expected to win the World Series for the fifth time in seven seasons.

title: Is Government the Good Guy?
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- The market defines America. Labor markets organize our work; consumer markets structure our spending; securities markets shape our future. The idea of the market dominates our mythology: Americans are open to "market solutions" to public problems, from providing housing to improving education  especially with a fumbling, inefficient government program cast as the alternative.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Military's Radar Is Half-Blind
description: The armed forces have only spotty radar coverage of the country's airspace east of the Ural Mountains and are unable to reliably track even top government officials for as long as 90 minutes on some flights to the Pacific coast, the commander of radio-technical troops told the Interfax military news service. Lt. Gen. Aleksandr Shramchenko said Russia had only a thin line of radar coverage of its southern border from Kazakhstan to the Pacific and only a limited ability to spot low-flying planes. He said a decade of military reforms had cut the number of radar troops by 60 percent. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Equipment Isn't Built With Women in Mind
description: The poster in the window proclaimed: ''Ski Like a Girl!''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Palm Buys Wireless Applications Maker
description: The hand-held computer maker Palm said yesterday that it had acquired ThinAirApps, a privately held company, based in New York, that makes software linking wireless devices to corporate e-mail systems. Palm, which has long licensed ThinAirApps' technology, said the acquisition would permit it to play a more influential role in the development of wireless e-mail applications. Together with the Actual Software Corporation, which Palm acquired in June 2002, ThinAirApps will permit Palm to offer a broader range of corporate messaging products. The acquisition is valued at $19 million, to be paid in Palm common stock. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Yanks Will Introduce Giambi and Are Not Done
description: The Yankees will finally unveil Jason Giambi as their newest player at a news conference Thursday, and the new Yankee already feels like an old Yankee. It has been obvious for several days and speculated for more than a year that Giambi would be the first baseman for the Yankees next season, and it became a reality after the sides agreed to a seven-year contract that will pay him either $118 million or $120 million. The difference depends on the possibility of deferred money.

title: Political Memo; Bloomberg Appointments Trouble Some G.O.P. Leaders
description: Shunning the political party that he adopted to successfully usher him into office, Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg has put together an inner circle that is nearly Republican-free. His selection of four deputy mayors, the corporation counsel and the leader of his transition team, registered Democrats all, has set off some grumbling among the state's and city's Republican leaders, some of whom believe that Mr. Bloomberg owes them at least a nod as he puts together his administration and who worry about what his choices may mean for city policies.

title: 'Lost' Meissen Collection Brings Millions to Heirs
description: The Rudolf Just collection of porcelain, glass, paintings and gold coins, which inspired Bruce Chatwin's last novel, ''Utz,'' and that for almost 30 years was presumed destroyed, fetched $2,235,927 on Tuesday at an auction at Sotheby's in London.

title: Assaulting the Senses And Doing the Opposite
description: Yesterday's scandal is not necessarily today's classic. The American composer George Antheil raised a ruckus with the cacophony of his famed machine-age score, ''Ballet Mcanique,'' in 1926 in Paris.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Sept. 11 Victim Dies Of Wounds
description: Three months to the day after the attack on the World Trade Center, the disaster claimed another victim. David Bernard, 57, of Chelmsford, Mass., died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital of injuries from being hit by the rain of debris from the north tower of the trade center. Mr. Bernard worked as an industry specialist for the Internal Revenue Service and was based in Boston. But he had traveled to Lower Manhattan for a meeting at the I.R.S. offices at 7 World Trade Center.

title: Pacifica, Owner of WBAI-FM, Settles Lawsuits
description: The owners of WBAI-FM settled four lawsuits brought by listeners and dissident board members yesterday, ending a bitter two-year struggle that led to street protests and a national boycott against the parent of the left-leaning radio station and its four affiliates.

title: Idea of an Electricity Cable Under the Sound Is Revived
description: A plan for an underwater electricity cable between Long Island and Connecticut that Connecticut regulators rejected in March was revived this week, as the same regulators gave preliminary approval to a new proposal that would reroute the cable around shellfish beds.

title: 10 Arrested In Visa Cases In San Diego
description: Beginning what they characterized as a major crackdown on foreigners who violated the terms of student visas, immigration officials arrested 10 young people from the Middle East in San Diego today and said more arrests would be made.

title: Enron Auditor Raises Specter of Crime
description: Enron's accounting firm told Congress today that the company had engaged in ''possibly illegal acts'' before its collapse and misled its auditors by withholding crucial information.

title: Greeks Drop Spy Count on Plane-Spotters
description: BRUSSELS  Greek judges dropped espionage charges Wednesday against 14 British and Dutch plane-spotters, defusing a bitter diplomatic dispute between London and Athens on the eve of a European summit meeting.

title: Young Performers Tackle Stravinsky's Brutal Rhythms
description: The New York Youth Symphony has been training musicians ages 12 to 22 since 1963, and in its annual series at Carnegie Hall, it presents its young charges in daunting programs, usually with admirable results. Since 1984 it has also undertaken a commissioning program that ensures that each of its concerts includes the world premiere of a short symphonic work.

title: The Fabric of Sweet Dreams
description: URBANE babies and stylish children can now bunk down and snuggle up in sheets and blankets that have more pizazz than the usual pastel pink and blue bunnies. This season's designs are bolder than last winter's. Some sheets come in dazzling colors from designers like Tricia Guild of England, known for fine cotton bedding. Bonnie Berkowitz, a designer in Toronto, offers cashmere-soft fleece baby blankets in many colors with matching dog blankets, in two sizes, which can be used as dog beds.

title: Black Americans Are Still Buying
description: Two seemingly disparate occurrences. A publisher told me recently that generally first novels by African-Americans have larger first printings than those by white authors, because they sell better. And I became aware of a new, remarkable book of photographs and text about the black experience in America since World War II that has 37,500 copies in print, a substantial amount for such a book other than those depicting Sept. 11.

title: E-Mail Finds the Rare Ear in Congress
description: IN theory, e-mail should be a useful tool for democracy, an easy and prompt way for citizens to reach their representatives. And with the fear and disruption resulting from the discovery of anthrax in Congressional mail, e-mail might seem an ideal alternative.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALLAY, ELIZABETH ANN (BETTY)
description: MALLAY-Elizabeth Ann (Betty). December 13, 2000, Philadelphia, formerly NYC. Graduate 1939 Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart. Retired Vice President Johnson and Higgins, NYC. Remembered affectionately by Mary Katherine and the Hawryluk family, many friends and cousins in the Carroll family

title: Officials Recount Road to Deadlock Over Missile Talks
description: Six months of negotiations between the United States and Russia over the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty failed because the Bush administration was unwilling to discuss each missile test with Moscow in advance, senior administration officials said today, and because Russia refused any change that would allow unrestricted testing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, MICHAEL WYLIE
description: SLATER-Michael Wylie, 58 years old, died suddenly from injuries suffered in an accident, on December 8, 2001. He is survived by his beloved wife of 34 years, Teri, his two adored sons, Eric and Edward, as well as his brother Jonathan Slater, numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. He attended the Lawrenceville School and Stanford University, and was the former President of Friends of the Earth Foundation. As an investor, as well as an environmentalist, he used his keen mind, his wit and his charm to remind us all of our humanity, and our obligation to ensure that what we have today, will be there for the next generation to enjoy tommorrow. We all deeply mourn his untimely loss. There will be visiting hours from 2-5 and 7-9PM Thursday, December 12, 2001 at the Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, corner of East 81 St. On Friday, December 14, 2001 a Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Avenue and 84th Street, with a reception to follow at The Explorers Club located at 46 East 70th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Friends of the Earth, 1025 Vermont Avenue, Washington, D.C. 20005.

title: 12 Michigan Residents Are Convicted of Plotting Against Judges
description: A dozen Michigan residents who tried to instigate audits of 18 judges by filing bogus reports with the Internal Revenue Service were convicted yesterday on 67 counts of fraud, conspiracy and tax evasion.

title: Slide Show: Attack on India's Parliament
description: Armed attackers stormed India's Parliament House complex on Thursday.

title: Emotional First Aid in a Firehouse Culture
description: At some point, the funerals will end. The memorial candles will be removed, the sympathy notes from schoolchildren will be taken down and the fog of unreality will lift from the city's firehouses. Then what?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Office Space For Sinn Fein
description: The government has decided that Sinn Fein's four members of the British Parliament will be allowed to have office space and use research facilities in the House of Commons even if they do not formally take their seats. The party, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, refuses to pledge allegiance to the British Crown, a requirement for occupying seats in the Commons. A spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair said the four had been elected in the same way as other members of the house and should have the same access to parliamentary services. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Disputes Layoffs
description: District Council 37, the city's largest municipal employee union, has filed charges with city regulators against the city because the Health and Hospitals Corporation plans to dismiss more than 100 temporary employees at its Manhattan North network at the end of this month. Chris Policano, a union spokesman, said that the two weeks' notice given to the employees and union violated the city's labor agreement requiring 30 days' notice for layoffs and to meet with the union on ways to avoid the dismissals. The union also charged the city with disregarding decades of past practice by failing to give enough notice. But Jos R. Snchez, a senior vice president of the corporation, said that because the workers were temporary the corporation was within its rights. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEINBERG, RICHARD
description: STEINBERG-Richard. 12/14/181/22/01. No light verse & strawberry shortcake today, just wonderful, now terribly sad, memories. Miss you so much, Dad. Love, Vick

description: A Prize For Lights

title: Fireside Intimacy for Folk Art Museum
description: WE can stop waiting for state officials to produce plans for redeveloping the city's Financial District. The Rebuilding of New York has already begun. The new American Folk Art Museum in Midtown, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, is a bighearted building. And its heart is in the right time as well as the right place. The design delves deeply into the meaning of continuity: the regeneration of streets and cities; the persistence and mingling of multiple memories in the changing polyglot metropolis; and the capacity of art to transcend cultural categories even as it helps define them.

title: Security Lapse at Airport
description: The Federal Aviation Administration shut down two concourses at Logan Airport here this morning after discovering that some guards at two security checkpoints had not been trained.

description: BRIAN GRAZER sat behind the sleek executive conference table in the headquarters of Imagine Entertainment, enthusiastically working his way through a Cobb salad.
