description: Turnover of 38 City Council seats at the end of this month will involve not only new members, but also, literally, the chairs they occupy in the Council's ornate chambers.

title: New Leader Meets Players In First-Day Capital Tour
description: Officials from the Northern Alliance paraded Hamid Karzai, the ethnic Pashtun who will lead the interim government in Afghanistan, around the capital today, and potential allies and potential foes dutifully paid homage to him.

title: NBC, With Conditions, to Accept Ads for Liquor
description: Five years after some liquor companies began producing television commercials for alcoholic beverages like vodka, cordials, rum, liqueurs and Scotch whiskey, a large national broadcast network has agreed to begin accepting those spots.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Costs For Homeless Rise
description: When the city's shelters are full, the city pays hotels to house homeless families with children. Such emergency spending rose sharply, to $40.9 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30, up nearly 43 percent from the year before, the city's Independent Budget Office reported yesterday. The office also warned that as the economy weakened, the city's costs for homeless services were likely to grow even more steeply than the increasing number of homeless people. Over all, city costs are anticipated to rise nearly 12 percent, to $531 million next year. The state pays only half of the costs of adult shelters, up to $72 million. The limit was exceeded last year, and is likely to happen again. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Rochelle Park: Metro Lounge To Reopen
description: A nightclub that closed last month after a makeshift dance floor above a swimming pool collapsed and injured 30 people, will be allowed to reopen and not incur additional fines. The owners of the club, the Metro Lounge, must agree to limit occupancy to 100 people and use the space as a restaurant or a lounge, not as a dance club, Gary L. Montroy, a township construction official, said yesterday. The club and its landlord, the Ramada Inn, were fined $3,000 for the Nov. 25 incident.

title: A Calm Presence in a Tense, Tight-Deadline World
description: IF Adrienne Brodeur is having a crummy day, she certainly isn't letting on. She is the editor in chief of Zoetrope: All-Story, a literary magazine started by the filmmaker Francis Ford Coppola.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, JULIA (NEE CAHILLANE)
description: MITCHELL-Julia (nee Cahillane). Beloved wife of the late Francis X. Loving mother of Julia Keane, Margaret Strickland and John. Adored grandmother of Sean, Niall, Kiera and Joseph. Dear sister to Thomas and James Cahillane. Proud aunt to many and great friend to all who knew her. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 7-9 pm at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10am, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: DANAHER SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 1,100 JOBS NEXT YEAR
description: Danaher, maker of Sears Craftsman tools and testing equipment, will close 16 plants and eliminate about 1,100 jobs next year to reduce expenses. The closings and job reductions, along with other cost-cutting measures, will reduce fourth-quarter profit by about $45 million, or 30 cents a share, the company said. The job cuts represent about 4.2 percent of the 24,000-employee work force at the end of last year. Danaher said sales in the fourth quarter were expected to decline as much as 13 percent because of the recession. It has cut 4,000 positions this year.

title: An Illinois Tire Plant Closes and a Way of Life Fades
description: Steve Collins is a skilled tire builder. For 17 of his 22 years at the Firestone plant here, he worked nights. His wife has not worked for 13 years, since the second of three children was born. On his wages, now $23 an hour or about $46,000 a year, he said, ''I built the house, got the toys -- the boat, the cars.''

description: Feature Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about independent magazines' performance in the economic slump misidentified the winner of this year's Magazine of the Year award from the Society of Publication Designers. It was Esquire; Nylon was a nominee. The article also misstated the title of Barry Rosenbloom, the owner of Bridal Guide. He is publisher; Diane Forden is editor in chief.

title: With 'Ring,' Studio May Try Prequel Teasers to Sequels
description: Even before the release on Wednesday of ''The Fellowship of the Ring,'' the first installment in a trilogy of films based on J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Lord of the Rings,'' New Line Cinema is contemplating a novel distribution plan to lure those who enjoy the film back to see it at least one more time.

description: The United States released a videotape today showing Osama bin Laden laughing and boasting about the Sept. 11 attacks that killed more than 3,000 people.

title: Experts Say Decision Could Undermine Online Journalists
description: Free speech advocates are worried that a recent federal appeals decision could have a chilling effect on online journalists who use hyperlinks to direct readers to relevant, newsworthy sites that contain illegal material.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, CHARLES K.
description: McSHERRY-Charles K., MD, F.A.C.S. Emeritus clinical professor of surgery, Cornell University Medical College. Director of surgery, Beth Israel Medical Center 1976-1990. Attending surgeon at the New York Presbyterian Hospital. Past-President of the New York Surgical Society, NY, Gastroenterological Association, Knight of Malta. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Ryan. Loving father of Maureen and cherished grandfather of Casey. Admired uncle of several nieces and nephews. Devoted friend of Miriam K. Moran. Predeceased by his parents and siblings. In repose at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St., NYC, Saturday and Sunday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. title: Mourners Speak of Piety, Not Revenge
description: Gathering here today for the funeral of a local boy, one of 10 people killed in a Palestinian attack on Wednesday near this Orthodox Jewish settlement, the men of the town spoke little about revenge or military reprisals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Punishment Sought For Journalist
description: In a closed military tribunal, prosecutors asked for a sentence of nine years of labor for Grigory Pasko, a journalist who disclosed that the Russian Navy dumped nuclear wastes at sea. A defense lawyer for Mr. Pasko, Ivan Pavlov, said the charges were fabricated by the military. Mr. Pasko's defense is to present its closing arguments on Monday. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jordanian Freed On Bail
description: A Jordanian charged with lying before a federal grand jury investigating the Sept. 11 attacks posted bail yesterday in Manhattan, his lawyer, Jesse Berman, said. Osama Awadallah, 21, is scheduled to fly home to San Diego today. He was attending Grossmont College in El Cajon, Calif., when he was arrested as a material witness. He was held for three months and later accused of lying when he denied knowing the name of a suspected hijacker, Khalid al-Midhar. Prosecutors wanted Mr. Awadallah held without bond. But a judge, questioning the evidence against Mr. Awadallah, ordered a $500,000 bond, which required a posting of $50,000 in cash. His lawyer said the money came from Mr. Awadallah's ''family and people in the Arab-Muslim community of San Diego.'' Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Oracle Hits Profit Goal, but Sales Are Far Off Estimates
description: The Oracle Corporation reported quarterly earnings today that matched Wall Street's expectations despite a sharp decline in its sales, especially in its software that runs enormous computer databases.

title: Port Authority Approves New PATH Station for Lower Manhattan
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday authorized spending $544 million to build a temporary PATH station in Lower Manhattan beneath the rubble of the World Trade Center.

title: Turkish Company and Iraqi Kurds Plan Project
description: The Turkish state-owned petroleum company plans to join the Kurds of northern Iraq in an ambitious oil exploration project in Kurdish-held territory beyond Baghdad's control, officials with the company said today.

title: A Wife, a Boyfriend and a Very Busy Life
description: ''Second Skin'' is the story of Alberto (Jordi Moll), a young aeronautical engineer who leads an increasingly stressful double life, dividing his time between his wife and son and a handsome orthopedic surgeon with whom he is having an affair. While Pedro Almodvar might, a few years back, have played Alberto's dilemma as farce, and any half-dozen French filmmakers might have made a wistful romantic comedy, Gerard Vera, the director of ''Second Skin,'' steers right down the middle of the melodramatic road. The movie is quiet, modest and sympathetic almost to a fault; its scenes of emotional discord, accompanied by a swooning, sniffling score, seem best suited to cable television. It's like a Lifetime movie about men.

title: Kwan Grows Up, Awkwardly, in the Public Eye
description: The aging process for Michelle Kwan has unfolded like time-lapse photography, in a frame-by-frame account that has whisked her from childhood into adulthood before everyone's eyes.

title: 300 at Hearing In Westchester Urge Closing Of Indian Point
description: More than 300 people crowded into a county hearing on emergency procedures at the Indian Point nuclear plant tonight, most of them saying the plant was vulnerable to terrorist attack and should be shut down. The protest came just a few hours after federal and state security officials appeared at the plant to assure the public of its safety.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Response Light For Medical Marijuana
description: A new statewide medical marijuana program has not attracted as many people as expected since it took effect on June 1. At the six-month mark of the voter-approved measure, 101 people had applied to use the drug for medical purposes, with 98 people approved. Officials had predicted that 600 to 800 people would sign up in the first year, as was the case with a similar program in Oregon. Applicants must register with the state to possess six marijuana plants or maximum of two ounces. But unlike California, Colorado does not have any clubs for patients to acquire marijuana. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hotjobs.Com Shares Surge On Offer
description: Shares in the job-listing Web site HotJobs.com rose 59 percent yesterday after Yahoo made an offer to buy the site for $436 million. Shares rose $3.83, to $10.30. The offer topped a $382 million bid by TMP Worldwide, owner of the Monster.com job-posting site. TMP and Monster.com did not return phone calls yesterday. But in a statement released late Wednesday, HotJobs said that its deal with TMP remained in effect. HotJobs.com also said that there was ''no assurance as to whether a transaction would result from any discussions with Yahoo.''

title: Seniors Take Charge for St. John's
description: The St. John's men's soccer team arrived Wednesday for its semifinal match in the N.C.A.A. tournament, bolstered by a week of encouragement back home in Queens. Banners had been put up outside the athletic department and other buildings on the St. John's campus, saying ''Go Storm'' and ''Beat Indiana.'' But they had nothing to do with basketball. The posters referred to the soccer team, which will be seeking another national title this weekend after winning its first championship in 1996.

title: Abstract on the Surface, With Layers of Meaning
description: Paintings are complicated things. Physically they're all chemistry and physics: oil, water, pigment, layering, tension. Optically they change with distance, ambient lighting, angle of vision. Psychologically they are a meeting -- sometimes amorous, sometimes combative -- between an artist and a viewer within the shaping context of a moment in history.

title: Experts Assess Officials On Anthrax Outbreak
description: The government investigation of the deliberate spread of anthrax received praise and criticism from officials in directly affected states and in the postal system at a meeting here today.

title: ExxonMobil to Pay $11.2 Million for Lying About Poison Waste
description: The ExxonMobil Corporation has agreed to pay $11.2 million, one of the largest fines in the history of environmental law, for illegally discharging hazardous waste in Staten Island and lying about it, the state attorney general's office said yesterday.

title: America's Tires: Worn Down, Overlooked and Underinflated
description: THIRTEEN months after Congress required new tire safety measures, out of concern over Ford Explorer rollovers caused by the failure of Firestone tires, studies by the Transportation Department show that there is still much to be done to improve the safety of the small but crucial patch where rubber meets the road. And the department has already missed a deadline established under the new law.

title: Congress Takes Small Steps on Economic Aid
description: Democrats and Republicans in Congress pressed ahead today with negotiations on an economic recovery package, seeking to overcome substantive differences even as they positioned themselves to avoid blame if their efforts failed.

description: Flatotel, in Midtown Manhattan, is so named because it has flats. Moda, the new restaurant at the back of its lobby, is called Moda for no reason in particular, other than that the word means ''fashion'' in Italian, and fashion is always in fashion.

title: Breast Cancer Is a Complicated Enemy
description: Doubts about mammography are not new. Though many women and their doctors think of annual mammograms after age 40 as normal and necessary, there have long been vocal skeptics. Their dissident view about the usefulness of mammograms may seem to have been fully validated by the study published this fall in The Lancet, concluding that women who have mammography die of breast cancer at the same rate as those who don't. But the issue of breast cancer screening isn't so easily settled.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Miami's Bond Status Rises
description: Five years after a $68 million budget deficit caused Standard and Poor's to drop Miami's bond rating to junk bond status, the Wall Street firm re-evaluated the city's bond status to investment grade. Standard and Poor's cited the election last month of a new mayor, Manny Diaz, and the recent renewal of a parking tax.

title: ALLIED FORCES SAY THEY'VE CORNERED OSAMA BIN LADEN
description: American-backed forces believe that they have surrounded Osama bin Laden and the last of his hard-core fighters in a complex of caves between two valleys just south of here, a senior American military official said tonight.

description: TO understand the strange world of Enron accounting, think of a carnival fun house. Small amounts seem huge, and big ones appear to be unimportant.

title: Contemporary Brazil In Fabric and Thread
description: ''The Thread Unraveled,'' an exhibition at El Museo del Barrio, is a contemporary sideshow to ''Body and Soul,'' the sprawling four-century survey of Brazilian art now on view at the Guggenheim Museum. The two shows are strikingly dissimilar. While the Guggenheim takes viewers on a wild ride through four centuries of artistic extremism, the Barrio's exhibition is subdued, focused, elegant and colorless.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Monitoring At Oil Fields
description: Gov. Tony Knowles proposed a plan to significantly increase monitoring of the environment and worker safety at oil fields on the North Slope and Cook Inlet, while speeding the leasing and permit process for private oil exploration. Under the plan, full-time, on-site regulators would review air and water quality and aging equipment.

title: Bin Laden, on Tape, Boasts of Trade Center Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The United States released a videotape today showing Osama bin Laden laughing and boasting about the Sept. 11 attacks that killed more than 3,000 people.

title: Aetna Will Cut 6,000 Jobs, About a Sixth of the Work Force
description: Aetna Inc., the troubled health insurance giant, said yesterday that it would eliminate 6,000 jobs, or about one-sixth of its work force, and take a $125 million charge in the fourth quarter as it struggled to regain profitability.

title: Nuclear Realism for a Changed World
description: The 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty is dead, and unsurprisingly so. It has been aging for a long time, patched up with reinterpretations over the years. It was almost killed in the 1980's when Ronald Reagan tried to pursue his dream of a space shield. Even the Clinton administration's development of defenses to protect troops against short-range missiles like the Scud threatened the viability of the ABM treaty because the treaty contains no clear demarcation between defenses against shorter-range missiles, which are permitted, and ''national'' defenses against longer-range missiles, which are prohibited. Near the end of his term, President Clinton proposed a national missile defense system, based in Alaska and focused on North Korean missiles, that would have violated the treaty.

title: Committee Seeks to Lower Limits of New Jersey's Booster Seat Law
description: New Jersey became a leader in child passenger safety on Dec. 1 when it began requiring car booster seats for children under age 8 or 80 pounds. But now, some people think it went too far.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Workshops Hunt Backers

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kohl Still Won't Name Names
description: Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl refused again to tell a parliamentary inquiry the names of people who gave him about $1 million in illegal campaign donations. Mr. Kohl has acknowledged accepting undeclared party contributions between 1993 and 1998 but has denied he ever exchanged favors for the money and insisted in several hearings that he could not name the donors because he had promised he would not. In June, Mr. Kohl paid a $140,000 fine to end a criminal investigation of the payments.

title: Coloring a Playful Portrait Of a Theatrical Grande Dame
description: ''An ancient stringed instrument that fell into disuse and was replaced by a viola'' is the way a contemporary of Gertrude Lawrence described the voice of that musical-comedy star, whose brilliant last hurrah was her lead performance in the original Broadway production of ''The King and I.''

Devoted father of Dennis and Jennifer. Cherished Pop-Pop to Katerina. Funeral Saturday, 9:45AM, from the D.J. Schaefer Funeral Home, 4123 4th Ave., Brooklyn. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Utility To Pay Bondholders
description: Elektrim S.A. agreed to use assets to secure an $11.45 million loan as the company, a Polish phone and power provider, tries to raise money to pay bondholders who have demanded repayment of 488 million euros ($438 million) by Monday. Bank Handlowy S.A., a unit of Citigroup Inc., agreed to a loan backed by 97 percent of Elektrim Megadex, an energy equipment supplier, Elektrim said. Elektrim has asked investors for additional time to pay off the bonds. Elektrim sold the five-year bonds, which are convertible into the company's stock, to help finance its transformation into Poland's No. 2 phone company from an electrical equipment maker.

title: Urban Lives Are Entangled, With Suspense in the Air
description: Ray Lawrence's ''Lantana'' takes its name from an Australian plant whose delicate exterior leaves and flowers conceal a dense thicket of sharp branches. That the bush is a symbol of the tangled relationships the movie explores -- marriage, chance acquaintanceship, the prickly bond between therapist and patient -- is clear enough, and the movie, accordingly, finds traps and snares beneath the most benign and ordinary interactions.

title: Corrections
description: A crossword clue yesterday for 59 Across -- seeking the answer ''TOA'' -- misstated the main word in the title of a poem by William Cullen Bryant. It is ''To a Waterfowl,'' not ''Waterfall.''

title: Tearful Giambi Is Proud To Put On the Pinstripes
description: Jason Giambi burst out of his seat like an aggressive linebacker when he was introduced as a Yankee yesterday. He quickly bent the brim of a Yankee cap and put it on his head; he tore off his black pinstripe jacket and wrapped himself in a Yankee uniform jersey; he hugged Manager Joe Torre as if he were the best man at his wedding; then he cried.

title: For Jets' Chrebet, A Quiet Season
description: Vinny Testaverde and Wayne Chrebet look at the statistics sheets and needle each other, sharing gallows humor about their shared plummet into the numerical abyss.

description: ROSE-Saul Charles. Beloved husband of Marion, devoted father of Gary and Elissa, Ron and Cynthia, cherished grandfather of David, Julie and Jake. Always in our hearts, NMW. Services Friday 11:45AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St, New York City

title: Rebuilding a Day at a Time; Law Firm Pushes 2 Steps Forward for Every Step Back
description: In the world before Sept. 11, John A. MacKinnon rated a spacious corner office -- not quite big enough for basketball, but enough to consider playing handball. That kind of luxury was not unusual for the partners at Sidley Austin Brown & Wood, a worldwide law firm that occupied most of floors 54 through 59 at 1 World Trade Center.

title: Facing Pact's End, Putin Decides to Grimace and Bear It
description: President Vladimir V. Putin tonight voiced his acceptance, albeit through gritted teeth, of the White House's decision to quit the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, saying that the move did not threaten Russia but that a new arms control regime must quickly replace the discarded treaty.

title: Man Named in Terror Conspiracy Ordered to Virginia for Trial
description: A man charged with conspiring with Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda to kill thousands of people in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Zacarias Moussaoui, yesterday was ordered transferred from New York to Virginia for a trial that could bring the death penalty.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Commission Chooses To Admonish Judge
description: A Westchester County judge should be admonished for saying publicly that he had changed his view of the law in death-threat cases, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct has decided. In an interview in February with The New York Times, Thomas A. Dickerson, an acting Family Court judge, said he had changed his mind and would broaden his view of the law to protect alleged victims of death threats, even if the victims initiated the phone call in which the death threat was made. These comments ''convey the impression of a biased judge whose views shifted in response to public criticism,'' the commission wrote, adding that such an impression is inaccurate. Judge Dickerson said he would not appeal the decision. ''In my enthusiasm to protect the victims of domestic violence, I mistakenly gave the impression in a New York Times interview that I would be unfair to alleged abusers,'' he said. ''I have never been unfair, but I regret giving that impression.''

title: U.S. Jewish Leaders Say Bush Was Blunt In Assailing Arafat
description: Using exceptionally blunt language, President Bush has told American Jewish leaders that Yasir Arafat bears responsibility for ending the violence against Israel, and he has dismissed Mr. Arafat's demand that the United States pressure Israel to stop retaliatory strikes, according to some of the leaders.

title: Portrait of a Terrorist
description: The images may be grainy and the audio a bit garbled, but the essence of the man comes through with chilling clarity. The videotape released yesterday by the Department of Defense captures the evil of Osama bin Laden in a candid, unguarded moment. This was not a piece of propaganda produced for wide distribution, but rather the recording of an intimate, informal gathering in early November between a relaxed bin Laden and a few gleeful followers who seem almost giddy that the Sept. 11 attacks were far deadlier than expected.

title: Iris Murdoch Conquering All but the Alzheimer's
description: The power of Judi Dench's accusatory stare -- Ms. Dench could bring Anne Robinson of ''Weakest Link'' to her knees and still have enough energy to take on John Ashcroft -- makes her the heir to Glenda Jackson's icy glare. Understanding the drama inherent in portraying the loss of that power, the director Sir Richard Eyre captures Ms. Dench's chilblain gaze slowly diminishing in the moldy, minor-key melodrama ''Iris.'' She stars as the literary force Iris Murdoch, as her appetite for language and pleasure collapses under Alzheimer's disease.

title: A Radical's Tale: Compassion Then Led to Prison Now
description: Sitting in her lawyer's office here and describing for the first time her murky journey from footloose actress to associate of the radical Symbionese Liberation Army 26 years ago, Sara Jane Olson insisted it was just a matter of trying to protect some troubled friends from the authority figures that young people had grown to distrust.

title: Hong Kong Leader Expects a Sequel, Based on China's Script
description: Hong Kong's chief executive announced today that he would run for a second term -- opening an election campaign that has been engineered by the Chinese government to produce little suspense and only one outcome.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Oct. 11 about a World Trade center victim, Stephen Tompsett, who was reared in Australia and worked for the Instinet Corporation, misstated his job title and the date of his arrival in New York. He was a senior vice president, not a vice president. He moved 15 years ago, not 13.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Teen Suicides Double
description: The number of teenage suicides in Connecticut has nearly doubled in the last year, a new state report shows. The state's Office of the Child Advocate said its report was prompted by the jailhouse suicide of a 16-year-old girl in July 2000. The agency reported that 15 teenagers committed suicide between Oct. 1, 2000 and Sept. 30, 2001, compared with 8 in the same period the year before. Fourteen of those who committed suicide last year were boys, and 11 were white, Jeanne Milstein, the Child Advocate, said yesterday. There are no immediate explanations for the rise, she said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Cocaine Ring Smashed
description: A ring believed to have smuggled 75 tons of cocaine to the United States in the last two years has been dismantled with the arrests of seven suspected smugglers, the National Police said. The men, who were arrested in a nationwide sting involving Colombian and American authorities, had been indicted by a Florida grand jury and are being sought by the United States for extradition, said Javier Pea of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: New Video Releases
description: Jurassic Park 3

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Spirits Purchase
description: Davide Campari-Milano S.p.A. agreed to buy control of Skyy Spirits L.L.C. for 233.4 million euros ($209.7 million) to increase the American business of the company, the Italian liquor maker best known for Campari, its bitter red aperitif. The transaction will give Campari an additional 50 percent of Skyy, the San Francisco-based owner of the SKYY vodka brand, raising its holding to 59 percent. Campari said it would finance the deal with cash and bank loans. Campari, which is based in Milan, has been looking for acquisitions since its July share sale to increase its presence in markets like the United States, Germany and Japan.

title: Sports of The Times; For the Yankees, the Familiar Theme Is Buy, Buy, Buy
description: Nothing against Jason Giambi, who seems like a terrific fellow, but there is a reek of obscenity in the cable television money the Yankees and Mets are spending on players.

title: Bush Claims Executive Privilege in Response to House Inquiry
description: President Bush invoked executive privilege today for the first time in his administration to block a Congressional committee trying to review documents about a decades-long scandal involving F.B.I. misuse of mob informants in Boston. His order also denied the committee access to internal Justice Department deliberations about President Bill Clinton's fund-raising tactics.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Dec. 1 and last Saturday about a strike by a teachers union, the Lay Faculty Association, at nine schools run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misidentified the administrator of a proposed pension plan. It is the union's parent, the Laborers International Union of North America, not the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Who's Looking Out for the Shareholders?
description: WASHINGTON -- Using populist arguments straight out of a Frank Capra movie, the scions of the Hewlett and Packard families are urging other shareholders of the Hewlett-Packard Company to join them in opposing the company's purchase of Compaq Computer . But this is no struggle between money-loving Mr. Potter and man-of-the-people George Bailey for the soul of the Building and Loan. There are no George Baileys here.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Wednesday about ''As I Was Moving Ahead I Occasionally Saw Brief Glimpses of Beauty,'' by Jonas Mekas, misstated the length of its run at Anthology Film Archives. It continues through Dec. 23, not this Sunday. The article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Mekas's children, who are seen in the film. They are a son and a daughter, not both daughters. The review referred incorrectly to the person whose first communion is shown in the film. It is a family friend, Sky Sitney, not the Mekas children, who were not reared as Roman Catholics.

description: The applause had not yet stopped when Dr. John briefly closed his eyes for his own personal moment of silence for George Harrison, who died Nov. 29, as he recalled memories of the Beatle backstage between his performances at the B.B. King Blues Club.

description: The Federal Reserve Board has expanded the scope of a 1994 law aimed at preventing the growth of what is known as predatory mortgage lending without making all the changes consumer groups sought.

title: Boeing's Cuts Hit Goodrich
description: Goodrich, a leading maker of aircraft landing gear, will incur up to $230 million in costs to close 16 plants, in part because of Boeing's decision to cut production of its 717 aircraft. Profit this year, excluding some items, will exceed $3.10 a share, the company said. Goodrich had reduced its profit forecast in October to $3.10 a share. It expects profit in 2002, excluding some items, to be $2.45 to $2.55 a share. In October, Goodrich said it would lay off 2,400 employees, or 10 percent of its work force.

title: In Digital Copyright Case, Programmer Can Go Home
description: The federal government yesterday agreed to defer the prosecution of a Russian computer programmer who was the first person to be charged under a controversial digital-copyright law.

title: A Bare Budget Provokes Another Strike In Argentina
description: Several major unions staged a 24-hour nationwide strike today, crippling businesses and government functions. They were protesting austerity measures intended to avert a default on the $132 billion public sector debt and economic collapse.

description: Walter Hewlett, the most outspoken opponent of Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq, stepped up the pressure yesterday with a letter urging the boards of both companies to abandon the merger plan.

title: Pizza Hut Seeks Agency for 'Projects'
description: Pizza Hut, part of Tricon Global Restaurants, said yesterday that it had begun searching for an agency to handle projects, separate from its main agency, the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, which has handled the Pizza Hut account since 1987.

title: AT&T IS SAID TO BE REQUESTING NEW BIDS FOR CABLE UNIT
description: AT&T has asked the three companies that are vying to acquire its cable television business to submit new proposals by Sunday morning, people close to the talks said yesterday. AT&T's board is set to weigh the offers on Wednesday and could make a final decision on the cable unit's fate at that meeting, the people said. AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications have each submitted bids to acquire the unit. At a meeting last weekend, AT&T's board deemed each of those offers inadequate. Financial details have not been disclosed, but any sale would be worth at least $40 billion. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: 2 Weak Forecasts in Technology Push Equities Lower
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday on renewed fears about the health of the economy after two technology bellwethers, Lucent Technologies and Ciena, forecast unexpected weakness in their financial results, and the government reported a steep drop in retail sales in November.

title: A Chilling Video, a Siege of bin Laden, an Airport Occupied
description: The images were shadowy and the voices at times muffled, but in the videotape made public by the United States government, Osama bin Laden and his guests, gathered together for dinner somewhere in Afghanistan in November, were certainly gleeful as they told and retold the terrible events of Sept. 11.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The tape that was released today by the White House offers an unparalleled glimpse into the world of Osama bin Laden and like-minded Islamic extremists.

title: Victims' Families Lack Voice In Effort to Coordinate Relief
description: For weeks officials from leading charities have been meeting privately to create a single unified database of the victims of Sept. 11 and their families, a long-sought goal promoted as an antidote to the red tape and disarray that have bogged down relief efforts. They have grappled, sometimes heatedly, with delicate questions of privacy and procedure that will ultimately influence how hundreds of millions of dollars are distributed to thousands of families.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Nicaragua: Ortega To Face Sex Accusations
description: Former President Daniel Ortega has agreed to give up his immunity as as a member of the legislature and answer sexual-abuse accusations his stepdaughter first made against him in 1998. Mr. Ortega, who governed Nicarauga from 1979 to 1990 as head of the Sandinista party, lost the presidential election last month after a campaign in which the accusations were used against him. Mr. Ortega, who had long invoked his immunity to avoid legal proceedings, went to a criminal court in Managua on Wednesday to declare his innocence and his intention to face the charges. ''The elections are over,'' he told The Associated Press, ''and I belive this is an opportune moment to close this case.'' David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Contest For Lieutenant Governor
description: James Rappaport, a Republican businessman, announced that he would run for lieutenant governor, against the wishes of acting Gov. Jane M. Swift. That could create a Republican face-off for lieutenant governor because Ms. Swift, the Republican candidate for governor, has said she wants to choose her own running mate. Mr. Rappaport, a principal in a real estate investment and management company and a former state Republican Party chairman, could present a serious challenge. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Homewood Suite Hotels
description: More than 100 Homewood Suites hotels, a Hilton brand, are offering rates of $69 a night for a one-bedroom suite that can accommodate a family of four. The rate is available any day Dec. 20 to 30, and Thursday to Sunday nights through Jan. 13. Rates include breakfast for all guests and Zany Brainy Fun Sacks with toys and arts and crafts materials. Not all Homewood Suites are participating in the offer, and availability is limited; other restrictions apply, too. Call (800) 225-5466 and ask for the Homewood for the Holidays rate or visit www.homewood-suites.com .

description: Despite deepening financial woes at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Gov. George E. Pataki pledged yesterday that there would be no fare increase next year, and that the state would help the agency balance its budget.

description: The New York Film Critics Circle yesterday gave its award for best picture of 2001 to David Lynch's ''Mulholland Drive,'' a mystery with a twist that he retooled from a television pilot.

title: Giants' Collins Feels He's Improving
description: Kerry Collins has gained nothing over the last few years if not an abundance of perspective, from his partying days as a young quarterback in the National Football League to his standing as a stable, mature leader on the Giants. His off-field difficulties have granted him unusual insight, enabling him to almost seamlessly mix self-deprecation with a sunny outlook.

title: Eleven And Counting
description: Embarrassing but true: Just one month ago the James A. Baker III Institute presented Alan Greenspan with its Enron Prize. I'm not suggesting any impropriety; it was just another indication of how deeply the failed energy company was enmeshed with our ruling elite.

title: Comet May Be the Darkest Object Yet Seen
description: A comet visited by the spacecraft Deep Space 1 in September may be the darkest object yet seen in the solar system, scientists reported today.

description: They filed out of the lobby of the Boston Sheraton all afternoon, tipping bellhops and hailing cabs. Executives from the Braves, the Phillies, the Athletics and other teams left the winter meetings today, some work completed, some still to do. Even the player agent Jeff Moorad is gone, unable to find a home for the slugging free agent Juan Gonzalez.

(Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CHRISTOPHER J.
description: MURPHY-Christopher J. A 34 year resident of Scarsdale, NY. Chris, 41 years old, died suddenly on December 11, 2001 of the complications of juvenile diabetes. He was born in Old Bridge, NJ on September 18, 1960. Chris was a graduate of Seely Place School and Edgemont High School in Scarsdale and went on to earn his Bachelor of Arts Degree in Business Management from Syracuse University in 1982. He pursued an active career in investment and commercial banking and at the time he left us he was a shareholder, Director and Executive of Country Bank, New York, NY, in which the Murphy family has a majority interest. Chris was a warrior in the battle to find a cure for juvenile diabetes which he contacted at the age of six. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Chapter of Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International. In that regard he was a member of the real estate committee at the annual ''Walk For a Cure'' and was an active participant with his family in the development of the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, ll50 St. Nicholas Avenue at 168th Street, Manhattan. Chris is survived by his parents Catherine Jo Ann and Joseph Michael Murphy, in addition to his brother Joseph M. Jr., his sisters, Carolyn and Mary Murphy and Patricia MacGillivray. He was adored by his nephews, Ryan and Sean MacGillivray, Brent Murphy, Joseph Michael III and Brian Murphy and his nieces, Kelly MacGillivray and Cailin Murphy. His brothers-in-law, Glen MacGillivray and Robert Murphy and sister-in-law Michele Murphy will sadly miss him. Visitation at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY, Thursday and Friday, December 13th and 14th from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of a Christian Burial will be celebrated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Post Road (Route 22) at Carman Road, Scarsdale at 10:45 AM Saturday, December 15th. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Secor Road, Hartsdale, New York. In lieu of flowers, friends are asked to make a donation to either Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International or the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZO, PETER CYRUS, M.D.
description: RIZZO-Peter Cyrus, M.D. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff, and Admistration of the Hospital for Special Surgery mourn with profound sorrow the death of their Honorary Staff member Peter Cyrus Rizzo, M.D., whose lifelong dedication to the field of orthopedics began when he entered the Hospitals's residency program and went on to join its staff. His two sons, the late Dr. Peter C. Rizzo, and Attending Staff member Dr. Thomas D. Rizzo, followed their father into the Hospital's residency program and went on to become highly respected orthopedic surgeons as did his grandson Dr. Peter F. Rizzo. The eldest Dr. Rizzo's work in orthopedics contributed greatly to the progress made in that field and earned him the respect and admiration of his colleagues. During his long career he treated many thousands of patients not only with skill and expertise but also with limitless kindness and compassion toward them and their families. Dr. Rizzo's devotion to his profession has inspired generations of doctors who strive to follow his example of selfless service and has engendered the love and gratitude of those patients who benefited from his knowledge. He will be greatly missed and long remembered by all fortunate enough to have known him. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Rizzo family. Richard L. Menschel Chairman Aldo Papone Co-Chairman Board of Trustees John R. Reynolds President, CEO Russell Warren M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Stephen Paget M.D. Physician-in-Chief Philip D. Wilson Jr. M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief, Emeritus

title: Since the Beginning, Questions Dogged the Trade Center's Fireproofing
description: Engineering experts involved in studying the World Trade Center disaster are now closely examining the spray-on fireproofing used on much of the steel framework of the twin towers to determine whether it contributed to their collapse.

description: India's leading media company, Zee Telefilms, announced today the first of what it said might soon be a wide-ranging series of partnerships with AOL Time Warner.

title: National Briefing | Washington: House Passes Education Bill
description: By a vote of 381 to 41, the House passed and sent to the Senate a compromise version of President Bush's education bill that would sharply increase federal aid to schools with large numbers of poor children and require annual testing in reading and math to assure that schools make progress. The Senate is expected to pass it on Tuesday. Representative John A. Boehner, the Ohio Republican who leads the Committee on Labor and the Work Force, said the measure would repair flaws in a 1965 act, under which money often went to wealthier school districts. Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Money Staying Home
description: The surplus in Japan's current account, the broadest measure of money flowing in and out of the country, rose for the second consecutive month as fewer Japanese traveled overseas, keeping their money at home instead. The surplus rose 14 percent in October from a year earlier. Japan runs a large deficit in services, which reflects the country's penchant for international travel. After the September 11th terrorist attacks, however, the deficit in services fell 10.8 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: China Voices Muted Distress At U.S. Blow To ABM Pact
description: Using muted language, China today registered its displeasure with the Bush administration's announcement that it planned to withdraw from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Still Heavily Armed, Ready to Die And Recovering Nicely in Ward D
description: They had treated many wounded fighters before at the Mirvais Hospital, Kandahar's finest. So it seemed almost routine in the waning days of Taliban rule, when soldiers delivered 11 seriously wounded men, foreign-born zealots who had come to wage holy war.

title: F.B.I. Queries Expert Who Sees Federal Lab Tie in Anthrax Cases
description: F.B.I. agents yesterday questioned a leading proponent of the theory that the anthrax attacks were the work of someone linked to a federal laboratory or contractor, asking her about possible clues to the culprit's identity.

title: A Teddy Bear Celebrating A Real Teddy
description: One new stuffed animal on the market this Christmas may resonate, particularly with adults, after the events of Sept. 11. Steiff, the 121-year-old German toy company, has produced a police commissioner teddy bear to honor President Theodore Roosevelt, the man who gave his name to the teddy bear and who served in 1895 as the first police commissioner of New York City.

title: A Setback for Missile Shield As Booster Rocket Fails Test
description: A test of a prototype booster rocket for missile defense failed today when the rocket veered off course seconds after liftoff and had to be destroyed over the Pacific Ocean, the Pentagon said.

title: Cuba Leads Latin America in Primary Education, Study Finds
description: Cuba, a Marxist nation with profound economic difficulties, leads Latin America in primary education, a regional task force has found.

title: Number of Shootings by Police Expected to Drop for 4th Year
description: For the fourth straight year, the number of shootings by the police in 2001 is expected to fall, following several high-profile cases involving civilians who were shot by officers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Energy Concern Pulls Out
description: The Mirant Corporation said it would abandon its two Indian power projects and pull out of the country because of poor progress on changes in the power sector. Mirant said it would exit the $5 billion joint venture, Hirma Power, in the eastern Indian state of Orissa. The 3,960-megawatt Hirma plant would have been India's largest. Mirant, which is based in Atlanta, was a partner in the venture with Reliance Power, a subsidiary of India's largest private company, Reliance. Mirant is also getting out of its 26 percent stake in the 500-megawatt Balagarh power project in the state of West Bengal. Mirant's departure bodes ill for energy-starved India, closely following a virtual exodus of four other foreign power producers, including Enron, which is trying to sell its 65 percent stake in Dabhol Power. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Marines Move To Kandahar And Secure An Airport
description: A vanguard of marines in armored vehicles rolled into the airport outside of Kandahar early today, consolidating control over a scene of intense fighting against the Taliban and clearing the way for deliveries of supplies and aid.

title: Big Networks Clear the Decks For Coverage And Comment
description: All three major television networks as well as the three all-news cable channels gave blanket coverage to the release of the Osama bin Laden tape yesterday, the first time in two months that all of them agreed that a development in the terrorism story merited such across-the-board, live coverage.

title: Falwell Is Raising Money to Press Conservative Family Agenda
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell has told supporters in a new fund-raising letter that he is organizing a campaign to take advantage of President Bush's popularity from the war to press aggressively for a conservative family-oriented social agenda.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS LOWERS PROFIT OUTLOOK FOR 2002
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that profit would decline next year after it loses exclusive rights to the diabetes medicine Glucophage, which had sales of about $1.7 billion last year. Bristol-Myers, based in New York, said profit next year would fall to $2.25 to $2.35 a share, from the $2.41 the company expects to earn this year. Analysts had expected Bristol-Myers to earn $2.57 a share in 2002. Bristol-Myers had lobbied lawmakers to delay generic versions of Glucophage, giving the company time to switch patients to newer forms of the drug and to bring on other new products. The Senate passed legislation that does not include an amendment Bristol-Myers sought to extend its monopoly on Glucophage. The House is expected to follow suit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTLEN, DAVID
description: KOTLEN-David, 91. On December 12, 2001 of Teaneck, NJ. Longtime resident of Fall River, MA. Beloved husband of the late Ida. Adoring father of Jill and Steve Meisels, Jason and Susan Kotlen. Loving grandfather of Jessica and Lauren Meisels, Robyn Kotlen, Melissa Nagin. Great grandfather to Zachary and Sarah. Friend to all who he touched. Services private.

title: Hailing a Past And a Future
description: WITH the unveiling of its long-awaited new building on West 53rd Street, the American Folk Art Museum has assumed a new identity. Known until this year as the Museum of American Folk Art, it has rearranged its name to reflect its growing interest in 20th-century folk art from abroad.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Isuzu To Shift Manufacturing
description: Facing mounting losses and an impatient parent company, the Japanese automaker Isuzu Motors Ltd. will stop making sport utility vehicles in Japan and move their production to the United States. Isuzu, which is 49 percent owned by the General Motors Corporation, will build its Trooper, Rodeo and Axiom S.U.V.'s entirely in the United States, starting with next year's models. Isuzu sold 83,000 S.U.V.'s in North America in 2000, down 36 percent from 1995, its best year. The automaker said it expected to sell 3,500 sport utility trucks in Japan this year as competition with other makers increased. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Razorfish Selling European Units
description: Razorfish, a Web site designer and consultant, plans to sell its European units to the managers of those operations as it tries to return to profitability. The company said it had agreed to sell the stock, assets and liabilities of its units in Amsterdam, Hamburg, Frankfurt, Munich, Oslo and Stockholm. Razorfish wants to focus on its profitable American operations, the chief executive, Jean-Philippe Maheu, said. It lost $14.9 million in the third quarter.

title: Unraveling Mysteries Cast in Stone by Easter Island Sculptors
description: Who really made the colossal stone figures that put Easter Island on the map? Despite centuries of speculation and misattribution on the part of the Western world, the answer is really quite simple. The French ethnographer Alfred Mtraux who visited the island in 1934, said the stone giants were erected not by a lost race but by the ancestors of the islanders who live there today.

title: Pratt Workers Approve Pact And End Strike At Four Plants
description: A strike by the 5,100 members of the machinists' union at Pratt & Whitney ended today as workers approved a three-year contract granting increased job security but not all of their pension demands -- two issues that prompted the walkout almost two weeks ago.

title: Farm Bill Stalls as Senators Criticize Subsidies
description: A new Web site listing all the subsidy payments made to American farmers over the past five years is playing havoc with the politics of the farm bill and helped to stall it today in the Senate.

title: Voices Rise in Disgust and Anger at Views of a Gloating bin Laden
description: It was damp and dreary in New York yesterday for the broadcasting of what seemed to many viewers like an admission of guilt by the world's most wanted outlaw. The sun was nowhere, certainly nothing like that morning three months ago when it happened. It was magnificent then.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, MICHAEL WYLIE
description: SLATER-Michael Wylie, 58 years old, died suddenly from injuries suffered in an accident, on December 8, 2001. He is survived by his beloved wife of 34 years, Teri, his two adored sons, Eric and Edward, as well as his brother Jonathan Slater, numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. He attended the Lawrenceville School and Stanford University, and was the former President of Friends of the Earth Foundation. As an investor, as well as an environmentalist, he used his keen mind, his wit and his charm to remind us all of our humanity, and our obligation to ensure that what we have today, will be there for the next generation to enjoy tommorrow. We all deeply mourn his untimely loss. On Friday, December 14, 2001 a Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Avenue and 84th Street, with a reception to follow at the Explorers Club, located at 46 East 70th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Friends of the Earth, 10025 Vermont Avenue, Washington, D.C. 20005.

title: Ending Impasse, Senate Leaders Agree to Overhaul Nation's Voting Systems
description: A day after House passage of legislation to improve election procedures, senators from both parties announced today that they had broken a long partisan deadlock and reached agreement on a companion bill meant to prevent ballot disputes like the one in Florida after last year's presidential election.

title: Once Again, Sprewell Misses a Big One
description: A basket would send the game into overtime and go a long way in easing the pain Latrell Sprewell felt on Tuesday when a missed free throw in the final seconds of a loss to Boston spoiled the finest game of his career. A miss tonight would add another wrenching loss to the Knicks' record heading into Friday's game against Michael Jordan and the Washington Wizards.

title: Please Do Not Feed or Annoy the Woebegone Prodigies
description: ''The Royal Tenenbaums'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 5; the full text is available at nytimes.com. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Poetry As Urgent As Rhythms Of Life
description: Poets don't always search for immortality; sometimes they just want to be heard, right now.

title: Buga Journal; A Dying Boy's Wish Only the Rebels Can Grant
description: His energy sapped by cancer, Andrs Felipe Prez, 12, managed to sit up in his bed, propping himself atop legs now bone-thin and useless. Bald from chemotherapy, his skin pallid after a long fight with the tumors that invaded his body, he rubbed his thick Homer Simpson socks and managed a smile.

title: '02 Forecast For Europe Is Darker
description: The European Central Bank cut its forecast today for the European economy, predicting that growth in the 12-nation euro zone would be about 1 percent next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMADO, ELLIS
description: AMADO-Ellis. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Patricia Lampl, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: A Boost for the Economy
description: President Bush and Congressional leaders are finally getting serious about negotiating an agreement to stimulate the economy and provide help for those hit hardest by the recession. With only a few days left to reach an accord, Republicans have, little by little, acceded to Democratic demands to extend jobless payments and provide health benefits to those thrown out of work. The Democrats in turn have agreed to expand tax breaks for business. But the talks remain snagged on a few areas, the biggest of which is the Republicans' misguided insistence on income tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. Dropping that demand could help produce a quick and welcome agreement.

title: Debut Shares Of Prudential Rise Modestly On First Day
description: Shares of the Prudential Insurance Company of America rose 6.5 percent yesterday in their first day of trading as the broad stock market declined.

title: Nuclear Realism for a Changed World
description: MC LEAN, Va. -- The 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty is dead, and unsurprisingly so. It has been aging for a long time, patched up with reinterpretations over the years. It was almost killed in the 1980's when Ronald Reagan tried to pursue his dream of a space shield. Even the Clinton administration's development of defenses to protect troops against short-range missiles like the Scud threatened the viability of the ABM treaty because the treaty contains no clear demarcation between defenses against shorter-range missiles, which are permitted, and "national" defenses against longer-range missiles, which are prohibited. Near the end of his term, President Clinton proposed a national missile defense system based in Alaska and focused on North Korean missiles that would have violated the treaty.

title: GEMSTAR SAYS IT WILL LICENSE TECHNOLOGY TO MATSUSHITA
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International, a leading maker of software for television program guides, has announced plans to license its technology to Matsushita Electric for products sold in Japan. Gemstar said a high-definition television with a built-in digital recorder and Gemstar technology would be available beginning next week in Japan. Other televisions, digital recorders and digital cable boxes will be introduced over the next year, the company said. The agreement is one of several Gemstar has with Japanese companies. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Look at bin Laden Is Unlikely to Change the Minds of Arabs Hostile to U.S.
description: The videotape of Osama bin Laden that was released today is unlikely to change the minds of those Arabs who already suspect the worst of the United States.

title: Sprained Knee Sidelines Lindros
description: A magnetic resonance imaging test performed yesterday on Eric Lindros's right knee revealed a sprain of his medial collateral ligament.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Panel Criticizes U.S. On Salmon
description: A committee of scientists convened by the National Marine Fisheries service to analyze salmon recovery efforts has criticized federal policy on Northwest salmon harvests, calling the fishing limits too high. Washington Trout, an environmental group, is using the report from the Salmon Recovery Science Review Panel to bolster its lawsuit against the fisheries service. The report said the service's focus on the size of the catch had contributed to the decline in salmon. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUSNER, LAWRENCE

His warmth, kindness and zest for life will forever be in our hearts. Services Friday, 10AM, at Temple Judea of Manhasset.

title: Good Looks, Bad Karma
description: In ''Vanilla Sky,'' a timely Hollywood fable about male vanity, Tom Cruise (right) plays a man who has everything. He toys with a woman (Cameron Diaz) until he meets the right one (Penlope Cruz), and then pays a fateful price. The movie shifts from a yuppie frolic to a morality tale, framed in a Hitchcockian riddle that ventures into the realm of science fiction.

description: The Giuliani administration is trying to block a plan by three borough presidents, one currently in office and two who were elected this year, to appoint themselves to the Board of Education, warning that it would be ''inappropriate'' and pose serious conflicts of interest.

title: Pauline Campanelli, 58, Artist Who Evoked Rustic Simplicity
description: Pauline Campanelli, a painter whose super-realist still lifes were so popular that their sales were rivaled only by those of Andrew Wyeth among living artists, died on Nov. 29 at her home in Pohatcong Township, N.J., a few miles south of Phillipsburg. She was 58.

title: Small Wonders in the Winter Woods
description: It's a tossup which was more interesting, the holly or the beetle. I went looking for holly trees, and found them, 40 feet tall and full, with glossy green leaves and bright red berries that seemed to demand snow as a backdrop.

title: Deal to Close Bases Leaves Rumsfeld Disappointed
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he was extremely disappointed with a decision by Congress to delay until 2005 the closing of unneeded military bases, and he said the decision would force the Pentagon to waste money that could be better spent fighting terrorism.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Government To Investigate Killings
description: President Vicente Fox ordered federal investigators to take over the inquiry into the murders of 67 women in the northern border city of Ciudad Jurez in the last eight years. In November, the discoveries of the bodies of eight partly-clad women stirred fears that a serial killer had started a new rampage of violence. State police have arrested more than a dozen bus drivers for the murders, but victims continue to be found.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vivendi Selling BSKYB Shares
description: Vivendi Universal is selling $1.5 billion worth of shares in the British Sky Broadcasting Group, or about one-third of its holding in the pay television company. The sale is intended to give the French media company ''breathing room for various opportunities of strategic partnership in U.S. television,'' the company said. Vivendi is in talks to acquire the entertainment assets of USA Networks. It will receive only a fraction of the proceeds from the sale, because the stake has already been used as collateral on a 4.2 billion euro ($3.77 billion) loan from Deutsche Bank. The European Commission had required Vivendi to dispose of its stake in BSkyB in return for clearance of Vivendi's acquisition of Seagram, which would combine the Universal Studios entertainment assets with Vivendi's Canal Plus. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: New Claims for Unemployment Hit Lowest Level Since Sept. 11
description: The number of workers filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the government reported today, suggesting that the job market may be improving.

description: ''Kandahar'' is bound to attract potential audiences, if only because it may be the only film whose name gets more mentions than Harry Potter on CNN. Though the Iranian director Mohsen Makhmalbaf's picture was filmed long before today's breaking news from Afghanistan, it is worthy of some attention because it happens to portray the culture -- specifically the treatment of women in that Taliban stronghold -- in forceful and dramatic terms.

description: For two years, Stefano Dambruoso, a young prosecutor, and his team in Milan have been after a group they are calling Europe's main logistical support center for Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terror network.

description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg is close to naming his fifth and final deputy mayor, and Daniel L. Doctoroff, the founder and president of an organization dedicated to bringing the Olympics to New York City, is the leading candidate for the post, said people close to Mr. Bloomberg's transition team.

title: Hotels Expect Tough Times Next Year

title: GILLETTE TO TAKE $130 MILLION WRITE-OFF FOR BATTERY UNIT
description: Gillette, maker of the top-selling Duracell battery line, said yesterday that it would write down the value of its battery businesses outside the United States by $130 million before taxes in the fourth quarter. The write-off, of battery brands that do not carry the Duracell name, will reduce earnings by 12 cents a share but will not require any cash, Gillette said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expect Gillette to earn 32 cents a share in the fourth quarter.

title: Palestinians Petition the Security Council
description: The United Nations Security Council met this evening after an urgent request from the Palestinians to address the growing crisis in the Middle East, setting the stage for a raucous debate and a probable American veto.

title: Looking Beyond Yasir Arafat
description: As violence threatens to engulf the Middle East, it is all too easy to lose sight of realities that Israelis and Palestinians cannot escape, no matter how much each side would like to determine its own destiny. History has dealt an awkward hand to both camps, throwing together on a tiny, arid plot of land two peoples that have suffered mightily through the ages and that have reason today to be wary of one another. But neither group is going anywhere, so they must learn to coexist. That, in essence, was the idea at the heart of the Oslo peace agreements and should remain the guiding principle in the difficult days that are now convulsing the region.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Job Cuts At Chemical Maker
description: Showa Denko K.K., a Japanese manufacturer of chemicals and aluminum products, said it would cut 1,000 jobs in January and reduce salaries as much as 15 percent to counter a drop in profit. Showa Denko, Asia's biggest maker of ethyl acetate, which is used to make solvents, predicted that the moves, including eliminating 7.5 percent of its global work force, would cut annual costs by 10 billion yen ($79.4 million), said a Showa Denko spokesman, Sadamasa Takamizu.

Meanwhile, three clumsy, sex-crazed freshmen are perched in an air duct above the girls' bathroom, where they witness a young woman's intestinal distress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACK, VIVIAN B.
description: PACK-Vivian B. Died at home December 12, 2001, three days before her 84th birthday. Mother of Leonard, Frederick and Jennifer Pack and mother-in-law of Adele Weisman and Sandra Pack. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, ROBERT (BOB)
description: SACKS-Robert (Bob). Passed away on December 12, 2001 with dignity as he lived. He is survived by his wife Irene, children Stuart and Donna, daughter-in-law Renee and son-in-law John, grandchildren Aaron and Rebecca, brothers Jack and Lester. He will be dearly missed.

title: WELLS FARGO IS BUYING TEJAS BANCSHARES FOR $82 MILLION
description: Wells Fargo & Company, one of the nation's largest banks, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Tejas Bancshares for $82.5 million in stock. Wells Fargo is buying the six branches and trust business of Tejas for $6.22 a share, according to the companies' joint filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Tejas operates the First National Bank of Amarillo, Tex., and has 124 employees. Tejas Bancshares, with four offices in Amarillo and one each in Dalhart and Fritch, Tex., has $364 million in assets, $323 million in loans and $270 million in deposits, according to the filing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSPAN, HEDY

The Officers, Directors, Staff and Students of The Hebrew Academy of Long Beach note with profound sorrow the passing of Mrs. Hedy Forspan A''H, beloved wife of Harold and beloved father of current SKA student, Chaya. title: Gunfight and Birth, All in the Same Shift
description: A day's work brought two police officers through the highs and lows of the human experience yesterday, as they were shot at and then delivered a healthy baby, all within the space of 10 hours, the police said.

title: Firms Settle With Parents Of Ill Children
description: A group of parents in Toms River, N.J., whose children were stricken with cancer have reached a monetary settlement with two chemical companies and a water utility that they accused of causing the disease through pollution, lawyers for the two sides announced yesterday.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Washington Letter; Reticence on a Failure Of Intelligence May End
description: Three months after the deadly surprises of Sept. 11, in a society where finger-pointing is a way of life, the nation's intelligence agencies have largely escaped condemnation for not having seen what was coming.

title: Banks Brace for High Demand As Euro Coins Are Put on Sale
description: European banks will start selling euro coins for the first time on Friday, but many fear they will not be able to keep up with demand.

title: U.S. and Spain Swap Notes
description: The Spanish interior minister, Mariano Rajoy, and Attorney General John Ashcroft met here today to discuss their cooperative efforts to combat terrorism. But they avoided the thorny issue of whether suspects arrested in Spain could be extradited to the United States where they may face the death penalty.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Restaurants Face Racial Bias Suit
description: A federal lawsuit accuses the Cracker Barrel restaurant chain of widespread discrimination against black customers, charging that blacks are often refused service, or are forced to wait while white customers are served. The suit was filed in Rome, Ga., by 21 plaintiffs who accused the restaurant chain of more than 175 acts of racial discrimination, in the manner of a successful lawsuit against Denny's that was settled in 1994. A spokeswoman for Cracker Barrel, which operates 450 restaurants, denied the charges and said the company did not tolerate discrimination. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Where Holly Reaches 40 Feet And There's Beauty in Bugs
description: A sprig of holly (left) may make you think of the cheerful shrubs with which we deck the seasonal halls, but for the real thing a trip to sites like Parvin State Park in New Jersey's Pittsgrove Township offers the delight of full-size holly trees. The enthusiast who ventures into these woods can enjoy an arboreal spectacle: clustered in groves or standing solitary with a near-Druidic force in the midst of winter brown, these trees -- 40 feet tall and full, with glossy green leaves and bright red berries that seem to demand a snowy backdrop -- shimmer with an irrepressible brightness. While you're there you may also notice what else is going on in the woods, like the bark on pine trees and the beds of club moss a few inches high. You may even find the time to connect with a wayward beetle.

title: Officials Irked as Merchants Cash In on City's Heroic Logos
description: Of the myriad symbols that emerged from the disaster of Sept. 11, none were embraced more fully across the country than the insignias of the New York City Fire and Police Departments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, STEPHEN R.
description: HALL-Stephen R. Died peacefully at age 62 on December 12 after a courageous battle with cancer. For 36 years, he was the loving husband and best friend of Jena Hall. Proud father and father-inlaw, confidant, counselor and best friend to Jocelyn and Ronald Burton, and Marni and Edward Hallissey. Adoring amd playful grandfather, ''Zaydee,'' to Benjamin and Madeline Burton. Devoted brother to Judith Hymowitz and brotherin-law to Michael and Rachael Goldman. Dedicated partner of Norman Hirsh and Glen Ehrenman in a unique and pioneering practice in pediatric dentistry in Westbury, NY. He brightened up the lives of all those he encountered as friend, advisor and mentor. His zest for life included a long daily walk in the woods and, with great enthusiasm, he climbed Mount Kilimanjaro at age 60. Stephen Hall loved life and lived fully. Memorial contributions can be made to The Stephen Hall Pediatric Oncology Memorial Fund at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, LI. Services Friday, 11AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Just See the Way They Play Games
description: A COLLEGE basketball game is scheduled for tomorrow night in Uncasville, Conn., at the Mohegan Sun, not a campus but a gambling casino. The University of Massachusetts will be ''visiting'' Central Connecticut State in an arena adjoined by the clanging of slot machines, raising the obvious question of what's wrong with this picture?

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Names Compliance Officers
description: Microsoft has appointed two lawyers who will work to ensure that it meets its legal obligations, including the proposed antitrust consent decree with the Department of Justice and nine states. The company said that Odell Guyton, 46, a former federal prosecutor and compliance officer at the University of Pennsylvania, would be director of compliance, overseeing legal issues that include antidiscrimination, privacy and competition law. David Dadoun, 37, a former antitrust enforcement lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission and currently a lawyer in Microsoft's antitrust practice group, will be antitrust compliance officer. Susan Stellin (NYT)

description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,263 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

description: Major League Baseball will move ahead with its plan to eliminate two teams next season after negotiations with the players' union about delaying contraction until 2003 broke down Wednesday night.

title: Judges Pushing for Restoration of Courthouse
description: With its Corinthian columns and gleaming phalanx of stairs, the historic federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan may inspire awe. But behind its marble walls, ancient water pipes often burst, decrepit heaters frequently leak and old electrical circuits periodically fail.

description: Two weeks in a jail cell may have been a step up for the leader of Uzbekistan's opposition.

description: A 37-year-old man from Lincolnshire was found guilty of causing the deaths of 10 people when he fell asleep at the wheel of his Land Rover, which swerved off a highway onto rail tracks in North Yorkshire as two high-speed trains were converging from different directions. Six passengers and four crew members died in the crash on Feb. 28. Gary Hart will be sentenced next month to what the trial judge said would be ''a substantial jail term.''

title: Where Smugglers Once Roamed, Toothpaste Hardly Squeezes Through
description: For years, Rahmat Ullah has navigated his bruised old truck along the treacherous Grand Trunk Road from the Pakistani frontier city of Peshawar to the historic Afghan capital of Kabul, dodging maniacal drivers, bandits and donkey carts to deliver wheat, cauliflower and whatever else he could load.

title: European Union's Top Court Rejects French Ban of British Beef
description: France's continued ban of British beef because of fears that it is not safe from mad cow disease is illegal, the European Union's highest court ruled today.

title: Pirates Freshman Jump-Starts Victory
description: Despite his accomplishments at Coatesville High School in Pennsylvania -- where he broke the career scoring record set by Richard Hamilton -- and the expectations for his freshman year at Seton Hall, John Allen had yet to prove worthy of the hype. All he needed, it seems, was a chance.

May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President

description: President Bush was host to the World Series champion Arizona Diamondbacks at the White House yesterday and paid tribute to a team he said had provided Americans with a brief escape from thoughts of war and terrorism.

title: Number of Executions Falls For Second Straight Year
description: For the second year in a row, the number of executions declined across the country, a pattern partly attributable to the ebb and flow of the appeals process yet one that punctuates a year in which many states re-examined the fairness of capital punishment.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Allows Area Codes For Cellphones
description: The Federal Communications Commission says that it will allow states to establish area codes for cellphones and pagers. Since 1996, more than 100 area codes have been added nationwide. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Jennifer McLean was named vice president and director for public relations at the T&O Group, Irvine, Calif. She had been vice president for technology at the Huntington Beach, Calif., office of Stanton Crenshaw Communications.

title: Memorial for Herbert Ross
description: A memorial service for Herbert Ross, the director and choreographer, is planned for Monday at noon at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street. Mr. Ross, whose credits include ''Funny Girl,'' ''The Sunshine Boys'' and ''The Turning Point,'' died in October at 74.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Profit Drops At Adobe
description: Adobe Systems, which makes Photoshop photo-editing software, said profit for its fourth quarter declined 57 percent. Net income was $34.3 million, or 14 cents a share, in the period ended Nov. 30, compared with $79.2 million, or 31 cents. Sales fell to $264.5 million, from $355.2 million.

title: Who's Looking Out for the Shareholders?
description: Using populist arguments straight out of a Frank Capra movie, the scions of the Hewlett and Packard families are urging other shareholders of the Hewlett-Packard Company to join them in opposing the company's purchase of Compaq Computer. But this is no struggle between money-loving Mr. Potter and man-of-the-people George Bailey for the soul of the Building and Loan. There are no George Baileys here.

title: Bowl Formula Was Born With the Best of Intentions
description: The future of college football emerged during a hushed meeting one Saturday evening in the bowels of the Georgia Dome in Atlanta.

title: A Willkommen Mat For Charisma
description: Anyone who has ever wondered how a Broadway star is born can watch it happening to Ral E. Esparza. In Hollywood some handsome young thing seems to catapult overnight from a bit part to the cover of Vanity Fair. On Broadway the process is more gradual, almost imperceptible: an actor creeps from the margins of regional theater or a touring company toward the center of New York's casting consciousness.

title: Pope Rebukes Israelis and Palestinians and Pleads for Christians
description: ROME, Dec. 13  Pope John Paul II sternly rebuked Israelis and Palestinians today, saying each side in the Middle East conflict was "disfiguring the Holy Land" and crushing the tiny minority of Christians living there "between two extremisms."

title: Scenes of Rejoicing and Words of Strategy From bin Laden and His Allies
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of the videotape released yesterday by the Pentagon showing Osama bin Laden discussing the Sept. 11 attacks during a visit to a Sheik al-Ghamdi, possibly in mid-November in Kandahar, Afghanistan. The full text and two video excerpts are available at The New York Times on the Web at nytimes.com/world.

title: STANLEY FURNITURE SAYS IT IS ELIMINATING 400 JOBS
description: The Stanley Furniture Company said yesterday that it would lay off 13 percent of its workers as it moved more manufacturing to China to cut costs. The company also reduced its profit forecast for the fourth quarter. The company, a maker of mid- to high-priced wood furniture, is eliminating 400 jobs as it closes its plant in West End, N.C. The company employs 3,100 people. The action should save $4 million to $5 million a year, Stanley said. Stanley expects to earn 26 cents to 31 cents a share in the fourth quarter, down from an earlier forecast of 59 cents to 64 cents, excluding some exceptional items. Sales for the quarter are expected to drop 15 percent to 19 percent.

title: Slideshow: Delivering Hope by Another Route
