What a Wonder-Full World
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Ruling On Photographs
description: A judge in South Lake Tahoe, Calif., has ordered that any photographs that a newspaper prints of two defendants be in black and white. The judge, Jerald Lasarow of Superior Court, made the ruling after lawyers asked that the defendants, a couple charged with murdering the woman's 9-year-old daughter, be allowed to wear street clothes to court rather than orange jail jumpsuits to avoid prejudicing potential jurors. The judge refused but ordered that only black and white photographs of the couple be printed. The Tahoe Daily Tribune is fighting the order on First Amendment grounds. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Jewish Militant's Road to Jail Was Filled With Arrests
description: There are many reasons that Irving David Rubin, who has been arrested some 40 times and has faced charges as serious as soliciting murder, has always emerged relatively unscathed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: I.M.F. Pact Paves Way For Loan
description: Turkey and the International Monetary Fund agreed on a three-year economic program, clearing the way for new aid from the lender to close a $10 billion financing gap through the end of next year. The agreement with Turkey, a United States ally in the war against terrorism, follows by a month an I.M.F. promise to provide $10 billion in financing, in what would be the fund's third infusion of aid in the last year. The economy minister, Kemal Dervis, has argued that the Sept. 11 attacks undercut Turkey's ability to emerge from its worse recession since World War II. ''The first priority under the new program will be to make Turkey's economy more robust to shocks and prevent future crises,'' the fund said in a statement.

title: Looking for bin Laden: Reading the Signs
description: In reaching their assessment that Osama bin Laden is probably still in the mountains of Afghanistan near Tora Bora, American commanders are relying on high-tech surveillance equipment, but also on surmise and on reports from local Afghan fighters who are helping in the fight against his forces there.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Aide Quits In Bribery Scandal
description: President Kim Dae Jung accepted the resignation of his deputy justice minister, Shin Kwang Ok, in a scandal that has embarrassed his government. Mr. Shin resigned while prosecutors investigated reports that he had accepted a bribe from Jin Seung Hyun, a businessman said to have bribed others in the ruling and opposition parties as well. Mr. Jin says he offered bribes in hopes of escaping prosecution on charges of misuing the funds of his securities firm. He was sentenced last month to seven years in jail on fraud charges. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENET, SAM
description: BENET-Sam. Beloved husband of the late Muriel. Loving father of Andrea and Frank, Jay and Jeanne. Dear brother of Robert. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan and Nicholes, Joshua, Christopher and Jon-Paul. Devoted great grandfather of Marissa and uncle of Helene, Todd, Rochelle, Roy, Traci, Adam and Erica. Visiting 79PM today a service Sunday 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY.

description: A subsidiary of the Turkish state-owned petroleum company announced today that it had signed a deal with the Iraqi government of Saddam Hussein to drill for oil.

title: Igor Zukelman: Ugly Car, Beautiful Dream
description: Nobody but a scrap yard scout would give it a second look, but to Igor Zukelman, the rather tired eight-year-old Toyota Cressida was a steel chariot, a three-dimensional symbol of his cherished dream of becoming an American.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Court Upholds Death Penalty
description: The Court of Appeals narrowly upheld the state's death penalty, rejecting arguments that the United States Supreme Court had invalidated Maryland's law last year when it struck down a New Jersey hate crimes law that allowed judges to increase prison sentences beyond the statutory maximum. The Maryland court's 4-3 ruling came in an appeal by Lawrence M. Borchardt, who was sentenced to death in the 1998 killing of a Baltimore County couple. The court concluded that death sentences did not exceed the sentencing range. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Dave Brubeck, Cowboy's Son, Found Rhythm on the Range
description: Is it already time to be ''rediscovering'' Dave Brubeck? That's the word Hedrick Smith has chosen for the title of his pleasant one-hour look at this jazz pianist, which PBS is broadcasting tomorrow night. But when a song has the impact of ''Take Five,'' the international hit Mr. Brubeck's quartet recorded in 1959, no rediscovery is needed, even for people who weren't born yet.

title: Connecticut Strains to Handle Anthrax Fears
description: In a guest room of a Hartford television station, a priest waiting to go on the air spilled coffee creamer on the floor. On the front doorknob of a home on a quiet New Haven street, a bird left its telltale signature, while across town a discarded box of baking soda fell into the street during a trash pickup.

title: Preparation For Anthrax Is Called For
description: The public health system worked well in containing the deliberate spread of anthrax but is inadequately prepared for a larger outbreak, state and local health department officials said at the close of a meeting here today.

title: Demand Rises For Widening Investigation Into Collapse
description: Several fire safety experts around the country and some families of victims in the World Trade Center attacks asked yesterday for an intensive federal investigation of exactly why the twin towers collapsed and whether the peculiarities of their structural design, inadequate fireproofing or other factors could have contributed to the disaster.

title: Kittles Meets Challenge Of Facing Heat's Jones
description: Kerry Kittles passed his challenge tonight. So did the rest of the Nets as they continued along their giddy way atop the Atlantic Division.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Spending Plan
description: Gov. Tony Knowles announced his spending plan for 2003, which includes a bond package to address maintenance of schools, harbors and highways. The $7.3 billion budget proposal comes a week after news that the state's $2.8 billion savings account would run dry in 2004 because of falling oil revenues. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: E.P.A. Reconsiders Human Tests of Pesticides
description: The Bush administration is backing off its earlier inclination to consider the results of experimental tests on people in regulatory decisions on toxic pesticides.

title: An Oddball Work, Uncut, a Director's Debut, Liftoff
description: According to the Metropolitan Opera's press office, the house was only 52 percent full for the premier of the new production of Richard Strauss's ''Frau Ohne Schatten'' on Thursday night. Some of this was due, no doubt, to the opera's reputation as an oddball work, a fairy tale bogged down with symbolism. And reputation is the right word, since this formidably challenging opera is more heard about than heard.

title: Edward J. Papa: The Center of Five Families
description: Edward J. Papa, 47, was lost Sept. 11. Not one, but five families were devastated.

title: U.N. Resolution on Palestinians Vetoed by U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Saturday, Dec. 15 -- The United States used its veto power on the Security Council early this morning to block an Arab-sponsored resolution reaffirming the "essential role'' of the Palestinian Authority in any Mideast peace negotiations.

title: Brodeur Takes Night Off, And So Do the Devils
description: Martin Brodeur was given a rare game off tonight. It made perfect strategic sense. Another big day in his career looms Saturday, and all the Devils had to do tonight was whip the Florida Panthers.

title: W. G. Sebald, Elegiac German Novelist, Is Dead at 57
description: W. G. Sebald, the profoundly elegiac and distinctive author of ''Austerlitz'' and other novels and one of the most acclaimed of contemporary writers, was killed yesterday in an automobile accident in Norfolk, England, near his home in Norwich in East Anglia. He was 57.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: New Stock Rallies
description: Shares in France's biggest consumer bank, Crdit Agricole, rose 5.6 percent above their offer price in their market debut. Only 18 percent of the bank's shares were available for trading, and fund managers demanded 17 times the amount available. Crdit Agricole is expected to join one of Europe's top equity indices, the CAC 40. The bank, based in Paris, sold $2.6 billion in shares at 16.6 euros in Europe's third-largest initial public offering this year. Proceeds of the offering will probably be used to buy rivals, including Crdit Lyonnais; Credit Agricole already owns a 10 percent stake in Lyonnais. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Bar That Gave Up Its Store to Weary Is Now Stripped Bare
description: Whoever designed the St. Charlie's logo, an angel offering succor in the form of a beer, could not have known how appropriate it would seem in the days after Sept. 11. Just as people gave blood, so, in a way, did St. Charlie's, its deserted larder yielding up keg after keg and case after case.

title: Mayor Backs Borough Chiefs Seeking School Board Posts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani clashed with his own law department yesterday, saying that borough presidents should be able to appoint themselves to the Board of Education.

description: The annual fashion show sponsored by the Pakistan Student Association at the University of Houston is a showcase of modesty. This year, to the sound of Pakistani music, female students wore traditional neck-high gowns and took care not to touch hands with the male escorts beside them.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Unemployment Rate Rises
description: Labor economists said Oregon's unemployment rate had become the highest in the nation, soaring nearly a percentage point in November to 7.4 percent from 6.5 percent. More than 125,000 Oregonians were unemployed, up 52,000 from last November. Before the new figures were released, Washington State had the nation's highest unemployment rate, 6.6 percent. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

description: Talks in Congress over an economic recovery package stalled today after the chief Republican negotiator asked for more sweeping income tax cuts than the Bush administration is seeking.

title: Corrections

It was the United States Justice Department, not the New York State attorney general's office.

title: U.S. Help Sought to Monitor Aid Groups
description: At least 39 countries, including several in the Middle East, have asked the United States to examine their systems for regulating charitable organizations to help ensure they are not used to finance terrorist groups, senior administration officials said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Sentence Reduced In Killings
description: A man who was condemned to death for killing his girlfriend and her grandson became the first inmate to have his sentence reduced under a state law barring execution of the retarded. A Superior Court judge ruled that the sentence of the man, Sherman E. Skipper, should be reduced to two life terms. The law, approved this year, prohibits the execution of anyone with an I.Q. below 70. Mr. Skipper's I.Q. was tested at 69, and he was said to have the mind of a first-grader. Kevin Sack (NYT)

description: He had an eye for special objects  a street grate in Paris, a license plate in the Virgin Islands, a gondola in Venice.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: U.S. Seeks To Reopen Talks
description: The United States has sought to reopen a dialogue with North Korea stalled since the final months of the Clinton administration, according to a South Korean Foreign Ministry official. The official said Jack Pritchard, the special envoy dealing with North Korea, hoped to arrange a meeting through the North's United Nations mission in New York. North Korean newspaper commentaries have recently accused President Bush of worsening tensions by remarks that appeared critical of North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il. The North also rejects American efforts to include the issue of conventional forces on the agenda. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Giants Are Down but Not Quite Out
description: The Giants are down, desperate and dispirited. They have lost their last three games, become an afterthought to the playoff chase and are on a pace to have one of the worst records of any team coming off a Super Bowl appearance. They have not had a single game that was a laugher, instead clawing their way to each of their five meager victories. They have discouraged their fans -- providing fodder for the legion of doubters who considered them overrated a year ago -- with routine second-half collapses, three times losing a lead in the final minutes.

description: Moody's Investors Service cut the credit rating of Calpine today to junk, causing its shares to fall to a two-year low and its bonds to drop to 78 cents on the dollar.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Governor Proposes Budget Cuts
description: Gov. Bill Graves proposed budget cuts of nearly 10 percent, or $426 million, reducing financing for schools, canceling highway construction projects and cutting Medicaid benefits. Mr. Graves, whose proposed $100 million tax increase was recently defeated in the Legislature, said the cuts would be needed because of declining revenues and rising Medicaid case loads. Some lawmakers have suggested expanding legalized gambling to avoid budget cuts and new taxes. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Grounded by an Income Gap
description: For 30 years the gap between the richest Americans and everyone else has been growing so much that the level of inequality is higher than in any other industrialized nation.

title: Refugees Reclaim a Blocked Tunnel as Their Road Home
description: The mouth of the Salang Tunnel gapes black and scarred, and inside a mountain of rubble prevents motor vehicles from passing through. Yet today hundreds of people, travelers and porters, scrambled over rubble and under great slabs of concrete hanging on rusty girders from the destroyed roof, making a journey that has been off limits for four years of Taliban rule.

title: Settlement Reached in Insider-Trading Deal
description: A temporary worker placed through an agency at Goldman, Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston settled federal charges that he passed confidential information about 23 mergers and other transactions to friends and investors he met in an Internet chat room.

title: Euripides' Philosophy Survives, but a Princess Doesn't
description: Like most Greek tragedy, Euripides' ''Iphigenia at Aulis'' puts the television soaps to shame in terms of intrafamily craziness. And the Greeks have it all over contemporary theater with the grand gesture. Both elements are clear in the Pearl Theater Company's current production of this 2,400-year-old play.

title: Domingo's Voice Fails; Return Brings Cheers
description: There was more in the air than just another ''second night'' of a new season at La Scala. Plcido Domingo was making his farewell appearances in the title role of ''Otello,'' a role in which he made his Scala debut 25 years ago and that he has since made his own.

title: Clerics Named By bin Laden Seen as Posing Little Threat
description: The Muslim clerics mentioned on the latest Osama bin Laden videotape, along with his Saudi dinner guest, are seemingly low-level religious figures known more for their anti-Western fervor than for having any widespread following in the kingdom or elsewhere, Saudi sources and Western diplomats said today.

title: If Diller Did Comment on This, He Might Say, 'Rosebud'
description: Barry Diller's favorite movie is ''Citizen Kane,'' in which Orson Welles plays a brilliant, restless and enigmatic media mogul.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Vincent Edward Cooks, the last prisoner to be executed in the United States this year, misidentified the state in which he was put to death on Wednesday. It was Texas, not Virginia.

title: Jets Must Now Beat Beatable Opponents
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards recalled the balloon gambit today, perhaps ruefully, as the Jets prepared to plunge into the final four weeks of the regular season and the race for the playoffs.

title: Steve Pollicino: Living in the Moment
description: Any evening, Steve Pollicino, 48, might call his home in Long Island to say: "Get ready! I've got tickets to the Knicks!"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMADO, ELLIS W.
description: AMADO-Ellis W. On December 13th, 2001. Husband of Evelyn. Father of Richard and Ann, Ellen and Peter Gordon. Grandfather of Samantha and Michael. Funeral service on Sunday, 10 A.M. at Temple Israel, New Rochelle. ''Always in our hearts.''

title: John Skala: Always Time for His Friends
description: John Skala enjoyed himself, but it was important that he made sure everyone else was having fun before he could get comfortable. "He loved making people laugh," said his sister, Irene Lesiw. "If he didn't see you smiling, he would try to make you smile before he would smile."

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: SHOW US THE MONEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, EDWARD
description: KAPLAN-Edward. The Woodcrest Club of Syosset, NY mourns the recent passing of fellow member Edward Kaplan and extends its sincerest sympathy to his family. He will be missed by all the members and staff of the Woodcrest Club.

title: G.I.'s Had Crucial Role In Battle for Kandahar
description: On the morning of Dec. 5, Hamid Karzai, who would be named Afghanistan's new interim leader hours later, was meeting with seven of his closest advisers in a house in Shawalit Kowt, at the foot of a hill 18 miles north of here. The men sat on the carpeted floor around Mr. Karzai, who kept thrusting his hands in the air as he mapped out plans to advance on Kandahar, the Taliban's last stronghold.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Nuclear Phase-Out Approved
description: The German Parliament approved a plan to phase out nuclear power over the next two decades. All of the country's 19 nuclear plants, which supply one-third of Germany's electricity, will be switched off gradually by 2021. The legislation also phases out the highly disputed shipment of nuclear waste to reprocessing centers in France and Britain. Members of the opposition Christian Democrats, which had opposed the nuclear phase-out arguing that it would force the use of less desirable energy sources, pledged that they would abolish the law if they win national elections next fall. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; How Humble Are the Boastful
description: THE Rev. Edward A. Malloy, the president of Notre Dame, wakes up this morning to a head-splitting problem: his university is without a head football coach, and the coach Notre Dame wanted played Russian roulette with his career and lost.

title: The Division III Title Is Mount Union's Goal
description: Larry Kehres, the coach with the highest winning percentage in college football history, becomes noticeably uncomfortable when asked to discuss his accomplishments at Mount Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, NORMAN
description: ROBBINS-Norman. Beloved and devoted husband of Lynn. Adored son of Mollie. Loving father of Dr. Steven and Judi, and Lawrence and Eve. Cherished grandfather of Jake and Halley. Dear brother of Elaine and Charlie Schmelkin and Gloria and Phil Darvin. Services at 10AM, Sunday December 16 at Gutterman's, Woodbury.

title: State's Leaders Are Together In Fight for $9.5 Billion Deal
description: New York lawmakers are mounting a bipartisan effort to ensure that New York gets at least the $9.5 billion that the Senate approved last week to help the city recover from the Sept. 11 attack, an amount that is by no means assured.

title: Rape Inquiry Involves Players From Colorado
description: The police are investigating an accusation that a female student was raped repeatedly last weekend at an off-campus party attended by some members of the University of Colorado football team and some high school recruits.

title: Gregory Saucedo: Speaking His Mind
description: Gregory Saucedo was marching in the St. Patrick's Day Parade last year when he came across some men he knew. "He said, 'This guy's a great guy, this guy's a great guy, this guy I just don't like,'" said Dave Simoes, a childhood friend and fellow firefighter.

title: Lynn Catherine Goodchild and Shawn M. Nassaney: Inseparable Travelers
description: It was supposed have been a quick getaway for Lynn Catherine Goodchild and Shawn M. Nassaney, a four-day trip to Maui, Hawaii, before they hunkered down to study for their M.B.A. degrees at Providence College.

title: GE CAPITAL IS IN $4 BILLION DEAL FOR REAL ESTATE ASSETS
description: GE Capital agreed yesterday to buy the Security Capital Group for $4 billion in cash and stock to gain real estate assets. GE Capital, a unit of General Electric will pay $2.9 billion in cash to Security Capital Class B shareholders and $1.1 billion of ProLogis Trust shares held by Security Capital, G.E. said. The transaction values Security Capital at $26 a share, a 26 percent premium over its closing price yesterday. The deal will give G.E. ownership of Storage USA, a self-storage property owner that this month agreed to be acquired by Security Capital, and interests in the Regency Centers and InterPark. G.E. will also acquire BelmontCorp, an owner of assisted living centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARECOR, LORRAINE BREITBARD
description: ZARECOR-Lorraine Breitbard. On December 11, 2001. Beloved mother of Heather. Thirty-three year spouse of Kenneth. Great friend, wonderful poet and artist.

title: In Push for European Unity, Leader Finds Fissures
description: Romano Prodi had been squirming and struggling for more than an hour to articulate his ideas about the European Union, when he suddenly reached back to the history of his native Italy.

title: America's New Role In the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Igor Zukelma: Ugly Car, Beautiful Dream
description: Nobody but a scrap yard scout would give it a second look, but to Igor Zukelman, the rather tired eight-year-old Toyota Cressida was a steel chariot, a three-dimensional symbol of his cherished dream of becoming an American.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Electrolux Cuts More Jobs
description: Electrolux, the Swedish appliance maker, said it would eliminate a further 2,800 jobs, making the total number of staff reductions this year 6,900, or 8 percent of its work force. Electrolux, the maker of Frigidaire refrigerators and Eureka vacuum cleaners, said it might cut more jobs next year if the economy did not improve. Electrolux shares fell 96 cents and closed at $28.89. The company said it would take a 1.5 billion kronor ($142 million) charge to account for the job reductions. The company said it expected to save 1.4 billion kronor by the end of 2003, after which it would save 940 million kronor a year by operating with less staff. Other appliance makers have struggled as consumers delay large purchases in the face of rising unemployment and an economic slowdown. Moulinex S.A. of France was liquidated in October, and Maytag of the United States said last week that it would eliminate 200 jobs.

title: Crossair Expects More Jet Seizures
description: Crossair A.G., the airline that is taking over part of the Swissair Group, expects Thursday's seizure of a plane in France to be the first of many by former Swissair partners trying to recover debts.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Dissident Web Site Blocked
description: Dissidents and human rights advocates who just last week mounted the country's first opposition-run Web site said the government had blocked its citizens from seeing the site. The site -- which lists dissident organizations, alternative reports on the island's economy, editorials and photos of the harsher side of daily Cuban life -- was started last week by the Cuban Institute of Independent Economists. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about criticism of Yasir Arafat delivered by President Bush at a meeting on Monday with American Jewish leaders misstated the given name and title of one leader who attended. He was Mortimer Zuckerman, not Morton; he is chairman and co-publisher of The Daily News in New York, not publisher.

title: U.S. SPREADS WORD OF BIN LADEN TAPE
description: The Bush administration moved today to make the newest Osama bin Laden tape the centerpiece of an effort to convince the Arab world, and the larger Muslim one, that the Saudi terrorist does not deserve their allegiance.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Bans Spying On Church
description: A Berlin court banned intelligence services working in the German capital from infiltrating the Church of Scientology to obtain information on the actions of its members. The ruling followed the group's complaint against surveillance by the Office for the Protection of the Constitution. The Church of Scientology is under official surveillance in all of Germany's states, with the exception of Schleswig-Holstein. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Raids 2 of the Biggest Muslim Charities; Assets of One Are Seized
description: F.B.I. agents raided the offices of two of the nation's largest Muslim charities today in what Bush administration officials described as a broadening of its campaign to shut a financial pipeline to terrorist groups overseas.

title: Corrections
description: The Watching Movies column in Weekend yesterday, about observations on Mel Brooks's ''Blazing Saddles'' from the producer Brian Grazer, misidentified the actor who portrayed a medieval hangman in two short scenes. He was Robert Ridgely; he merely resembles Zero Mostel.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about economic prospects for New York hotels in the coming year misstated the name of one on Park Avenue that has many guests for the holidays. It is the Regency, not the Regent.

title: Verizon Seeks Advantage Over Smaller Competitors
description: Verizon Communications, New York's local phone carrier, has begun a lobbying effort in the wake of the terrorist attack on Sept. 11 that would give the company a competitive advantage, and its rivals are criticizing it for trying to profit from the disaster.

title: Bin Laden's Glee, Our Disgust
description: To the Editor:

title: '01 Media Model: Content and Distribution Go Together
description: Ever since Jean-Marie Messier began aspiring to turn Vivendi Universal from a French water company into a global media conglomerate, critics have said its weakness was a lack of control over the distribution of its entertainment products.

title: Before the Euro, Money Talked of Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Web Postings Bring 4-Year Sentence
description: A 29-year-old pro-democracy activist, Wang Jinbo, was sentenced to four years in prison for posting articles on overseas Internet sites that demanded a reassessment of the government's 1989 decision to send in troops to break up student demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. The Linyi Intermediate Court in Shandong Province found Mr. Wang, who had been associated with the now-illegal China Democracy Party, guilty of subversion. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Mad Cow Case Confirmed
description: The government said final tests on a slaughtered cow confirmed that the country had found its first case of mad cow disease. The nearly six-year-old contaminated cow came from a farm in the eastern province of Lower Austria. Both the farm and slaughterhouse have been closed to allow for further testing on other animals and their feed. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: A Choreographer Who at 82 Does Warm-Ups to Hip-Hop
description: Merce Cunningham and his art have seldom been explained as simply as they are in ''Merce Cunningham: A Lifetime in Dance,'' which will be broadcast tomorrow night on PBS as part of the American Masters series. That simplicity is something of a shock, given Mr. Cunningham's reputation for obscurity and the reputation of Charles Atlas, the director, as a blithe hipster. But Mr. Atlas has created an hourlong primer on one of the most influential avant-gardists of the 20th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EROS, CLARA
description: EROS-Clara. A retired textile importer. Died on December 8th at age 85. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, December 19th at 2 PM. She is mourned by family and friends.

title: Erica Van Acker, 62, Subject of TV Documentary on Rape
description: Erica Van Acker, whose experience was the basis of a pioneering public television documentary on rape in 1971 and who became an early public spokeswoman for those who had been raped, died on Sept. 11 in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. She was 62 and lived in Manhattan and Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Bin Laden's Glee, Our Disgust
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallflower Blooms in a Loving Crowd
description: ''As Natural As Breathing,'' Doug Varone's bouncy, stylish new work, is set to pop songs and jazz recordings. Had it come at the end rather than the middle of Wednesday's program by Doug Varone and Dancers at the Joyce Theater, it would have been dessert after a full meal.

title: U.S.-BRITISH FORCE ON THE FRONT LINE IN AFGHAN ATTACK
description: American and British commandos, operating behind a screen of local Afghan fighters, had the last remnants of Osama bin Laden's followers -- and perhaps the terrorist mastermind himself -- cornered here this morning in a narrow stretch of a ridge line, canyons and caves high in the White Mountains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAS, ALFRED EGON
description: MAAS-Alfred Egon. On December 13, 2001. Beloved husband of Lane and loving father of the late Clifford W. Maas. He is also survived by nephews Mark and Jeffrey, and his very close-knit family. He was cherished by all who knew him.

title: Christopher M. Duffy: Nice Suits, Hawaiian Shirts
description: Christopher M. Duffy was determined. At 160 pounds, he was the fullback on his high school football team. He was captain of his lacrosse team and spent a good part of his time on the field knocking other players down.

title: Westchester Executive Vetoes Revenue Projections
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, today vetoed what he said were overly optimistic revenue projections in the proposed budget that county lawmakers had used to hold the line on property taxes.

title: Delivering Hope By Another Route; H.I.V. Activists Collect Drugs For the Needy Outside the U.S.
description: It started when a stranger asked for help.

title: Holiday Car Rental Rates
description: Pick up a car by Jan. 2, and Hertz will charge $20 a day for a compact at over 40 airport locations nationwide. These include Atlanta, Dallas, Washington-Dulles Airport, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Seattle. Airport fees can add up to $3 a day and 15 percent. Taxes are extra. There is a two-day minimum rental and a 10-day maximum, and availability is limited. Reservations are required, and the minimum age for the renter is 25; (800) 654-3131 or visit www.hertz.com .

title: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Senator Slain
description: The government ordered increased security for legislators after a senator from the ruling party died from wounds sustained earlier this week. Senator Dario Gomez was shot on Tuesday night by unknown gunmen as he arrived at a friend's house. News reports said he had suffered major neurological damage, possibly from a delay in getting proper medical attention for him. Mr. Gomez, of the Revolutionary Democratic Party, was an author of legislation that called for harsher penalties against money laundering. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, REV. JAMES F.
description: FOX-Rev. James F., S.J. on December 14, 2001. Dear brother of Margot Lowth of Ireland, loving uncle of Louise. Friends may call at the Loyola School Chapel (enter at 63-69 E 83 St) on Sunday 3-5 & 79PM, as well as Monday 2-4PM. Mass of Christian burial at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Ave at 84th St, Monday 6PM. Burial will take place at the Jesuit Cemetery in Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Loyola School, Father James Fox Faculty Endowment Fund. For further information or directions, call: Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: America's Best Friend
description: This week Tony Blair, the British prime minister, said British soldiers were ready to lead an international peacekeeping force in Afghanistan. He also pushed to get peacekeepers into place quickly to create secure conditions for food deliveries, a plea for speed that Washington does not fully share. The dual message was classic Tony Blair, who is at once a steadfast ally of the United States and the bearer of necessary truths to the Bush administration.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Serb's Indictment Disclosed
description: The prosecutor of the war crimes tribunal in The Hague has published an indictment of a Bosnian Serb army commander, Vinko Pandurevic, charging him with genocide and other war crimes. He led the Zvornik Brigade that took part in the attacks on the Muslim enclave of Screbrenica in 1995, the charges said. After the fall of the enclave, Bosnian Serb forces executed more than 7,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys and hid their bodies in mass graves. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Gandalf and the Sorcerer's Stone of Evil: On Fighting the Good Fight
description: The great triumph at the end of J. R. R. Tolkien's trilogy ''The Lord of the Rings'' has a tragic tinge. The film of the first volume opens next week, and any viewer -- and any reader beginning the books -- naturally assumes that by the epic's end absolute evil will be vanquished.

title: Michael Lynch: Lightening the Mood
description: In a family of 10 children like the Lynches -- this one Democrat, that one Republican, some of them independents -- disagreements happen. And at family dinners, Michael, the seventh oldest, was peacemaker. He would don a silly hat, utter a one-liner, and "they would just realize we shouldn't take ourselves too seriously," said his father, Jack.

title: James E. Hayden: The Love Stayed Young
description: Looking back on their nearly 25 years of marriage, Elizabeth Gail Hayden credits James E. Hayden with bringing her much joy, to say nothing of chicken and fish.

title: U.N. Resolution on Palestinians Faces U.S. Veto
description: UNITED NATIONS, Saturday, Dec. 15  The United States used its veto power on the Security Council early this morning to block an Arab- sponsored resolution reaffirming the "essential role" of the Palestinian Authority in any Mideast peace negotiations.

title: Disney Pays Back Wages For Contractor
description: The Walt Disney Company paid $903,000 to the State of California this week to cover back wages for a contractor who violated child labor, minimum wage and overtime laws while producing toy tiaras and wands.

title: P.S. 234's Reopening Is Shifted to February
description: The Board of Education has pushed back its early January deadline for opening Public School 234, one of the schools near the World Trade Center disaster site, to Feb. 1, parents of children at the school said. The board reached an agreement yesterday with representatives of the parents, who felt that their children needed more time to prepare psychologically for the return to their school.

title: Alliance Resists Returning Aid Agencies' Cars
description: The Northern Alliance army has been cast in many roles since the United States joined in its fight against the Taliban more than two months ago. It has been a resistance movement, a liberator, an interim police force and the military arm of a government that is just taking shape.

title: College Officials Are Wary on Visa Enforcement
description: Although college officials have publicly promised to cooperate with a crackdown on foreign students who overstay their visas, the officials are privately concerned that the effort may discourage foreigners from applying to American colleges, where they represent an important source of revenue and research assistance.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Doctor Needs Care After Years of Helping Others
description: Charles H. Bauer got his first inkling that he had multiple sclerosis while attending a neurology lecture as a student at Harvard Medical School in 1952. He thought the pins and needles he felt in his right leg were an early symptom of a mysterious and incurable disease.

title: After ABM Treaty: New Freedom for U.S. in Different Kind of Arms Control
description: When President Bush stepped into the Rose Garden on Thursday morning, he did far more than announce America's exit from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. He buried an entire era of arms control.

title: America's New Role in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Babies Used In Drug Ring, Officials Say
description: Federal officials today charged 35 people with running an international cocaine and heroin smuggling ring that used women traveling with infants -- some of them ''rented'' from poor families -- to transport drugs in cans of baby formula.

title: Jim Cleere: 'Good Man.' Good Voice.
description: That October night in 1977, Jean Rieger, a divorced mother with a 10-year-old daughter, got down on her knees and prayed to God to send her "a good man" to marry.

title: Building Plan For Schools Passes, Barely
description: Just three days ago, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy put forward a plan for building and repairing schools that seemed assured of being easily approved by the Board of Education. But in the sometimes inscrutable world of school politics, nothing is ever sure.

title: Beliefs; Tithing in a time of extra need. For a Manhattan couple, a 10th is a good round number.
description: Among some devout religious believers, tithing -- giving 10 percent of one's income to charity -- is a duty commanded by God and strictly observed. But meet a Manhattan couple who do not tithe primarily out of religious obligation. They do it out of efficiency.

title: America's New Role In the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernard Mascarenhas: An Anonymous Benefactor
description: Bernard Mascarenhas was a zealous bridge player, an executive who had risen steadily up the corporate ladder, and a man who liked to take it easy on weekends with his wife and two kids. But it was what he was not known for that is worth remembering as well.

title: Retro Toys Can Get Nostalgic Parents to Spend
description: Maybe it's that the new millennium is off to a rough start. Maybe it's one more sign of technology fatigue. In any case, toy retailers and others say that as people shop for the children on their holiday lists this year, old-fashioned playthings -- call them retro toys -- are getting a fresh burst of attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, DAVID B.
description: LYNCH-David B. Died at his home in Gladwyne, PA December 14, 2001 of Lou Gehrigs disease (ALS). Beloved husband of Josephine, devoted father of David, Tina L. Fiertz and Linda, and three grandchildren. Survived by his sister, Helen L. Dickey of Devon, PA and brother, William R. Lynch of Greenwich, CT. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University and New York University Law School. He retired as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Multibank Financial Corporation of Massachusetts in 1992 following the bank's merger with the then Bank of Boston. A memorial service will be held at St. Christopher's Church, Righters Mill Road in Gladwyne, PA. on December 18th at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH.

title: BellSouth Will Cut 1,200 Jobs
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,200 more technical and clerical jobs, the latest announcement of sweeping cutbacks by a telecommunications company.

title: Tape Suggests U.S. Spying Missed Signals
description: The Osama bin Laden videotape is raising new questions among intelligence officials about why American authorities failed to uncover the plot of the Sept. 11 attacks before they occurred.

title: New York's Legal Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: ELIMINATION OF JOBS AND CLOSING OF PLANTS SET
description: ITT Industries is eliminating 3,400 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, and closing five plants as demand for electronics from the telecommunications and aerospace industries declines. The company, which makes switches and connectors, said its fourth-quarter profit would be reduced by $65 million, or 72 cents a share, because of the firings and closings. ITT Industries has 38,000 employees and is based in White Plains. ''We don't see a sharp recovery in 2002, or even a modest recovery,'' its chief executive, Louis Giuliano, said on a conference call. ''We don't see any real recovery until 2003.'' ITT expects sales to be little changed or down next year.

title: 93rd Birthday Gift for Elliott Carter
description: Concerts of Elliott Carter's music just seem to keep happening around town, and this venerable composer somehow manages to attend most of them. It's a wonder he has time to write music. But he does. On Monday night at Merkin Concert Hall the essential New York contemporary-music ensemble Speculum Musicae performed four works by Mr. Carter, including two quite recent ones. And sure enough there he was, on the eve of his 93rd birthday.

title: David T. Wooley: A Decorating Officer
description: Anyone could see that it was a strange combination of jobs, fighting fires and interior decorating. But not David T. Wooley. Captain of Ladder Company 4 in Midtown Manhattan, he also put up wallpaper on the side, turning it into a family affair that included his son, brother and cousin. "He did that because my mother was always asking him to decorate around the house," said his son, David Jr. "He changed the wallpaper so often, and he was so good at it, that he decided to make it his second career. He did it since 1985 or 1986."

title: Washington Talk; Congress Starts Looking for Plan to End Session
description: The senators' cars were marshaled outside the Capitol on Thursday evening, looking like an officers' motor pool or perhaps the start of the Beltway 500. Senators had just finished saying how urgent it was to pass a farm bill or an insurance guarantee measure. Now it was time to take the last four-day weekend of the legislative year.

title: Iran Could Be a Valuable Ally
description: In the long-term war on terrorism, forging friendships will be critical, and one of the countries most important as a potential American ally is Iran. To many Americans, rapprochement with Iran seems repellent. Iran took 52 Americans hostage in 1979 and kept them for 444 days. Its leaders referred to the United States as the Great Satan, and only last month, our confiscated embassy in Tehran was turned into a kind of anti-American theme park. But Iran is important to us.

title: N.R.C. Is Watching Operators At Indian Point Nuclear Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it had begun round-the-clock observation of the operators at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant and that it would continue to do so until it had seen each of five operating teams complete three 12-hour shifts.

title: Cable Is Said to Muscle Out NBC for N.B.A. Rights
description: The National Basketball Association's new television contracts, which are to be announced soon, will usher out NBC Sports as the league's broadcast partner and give cable television its largest role ever in a major league sport, two industry executives said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Joblessness Is Fraying Istanbul's Social Fabric
description: Hands stuffed into empty pockets, Ali Adiguzel stood in the cold dusk, waiting for the muezzin's call and a free meal.

title: John G. Coughlin: Civil Servant, Times Two
description: John G. Coughlin was a giving man, and that kept him very busy.

title: Training Pvt. Evans: 4 Months From a Slacker to a Soldier
description: Basic training for Kirk Evans started in the infirmary. He landed there for three nights with an infected arm after the Army did a routine drawing of blood. A couple of weeks later he was about a mile into a three-mile march when he broke his left foot. Next was a bout of bronchitis.

title: No Penalties For Towson's New Coach
description: Officials at Towson said yesterday that the university had investigated accusations that its men's basketball coach had engaged in abusive behavior and concluded that the coach should not be suspended and that the player who made the accusations should be allowed to finish the year on scholarship.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about criticism of Yasir Arafat delivered by President Bush at a meeting on Monday with American Jewish leaders misstated the given name and title of one leader who attended. He was Mortimer Zuckerman, not Morton; he is chairman and co-publisher of The Daily News in New York, not publisher.

title: An Afghan Village Where Errant Bombs Fell and Killed, and Still Lurk in Wait
description: The errant bombs landed on this northern village more than three weeks ago, in a terrifying and rolling barrage that the villagers believe was the payload of an American B-52. Some bombs landed in the rice paddies, sending up enormous showers of dirt. Others leveled houses. The villagers say 30 people died.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen tumbled to a three-year low against the dollar after a report said Japanese companies were failing at the fastest pace since 1984. In New York, the dollar settled at 127.38 yen, up from 126.21 on Thursday.

title: Israelis Raid Four Towns In Counterterror Action; Eight Palestinians Die
description: In a new form of Israeli counterterrorism, stealthy troops swept though Salfit before dawn today in a lightning raid, overwhelmed astonished Palestinian security forces, killing six, and then went door to door arresting several suspected militants.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Firmly Tilting, Tower Of Pisa Reopens
description: The Leaning Tower of Pisa will reopen to the public today for the first time since 1990 after major efforts to prop it up. The $25 million in repairs were designed to straighten the building enough to keep it from toppling over but without taking away its trademark tilt. Pisa officials said they planned a low-key ceremony in deference to those killed in the Twin Towers attacks on Sept. 11. Melinda Henneberger (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: New Public Advocate Faces Looming Fiscal Crisis
description: Betsy Gotbaum, the incoming public advocate, is on the verge of inheriting a financial crisis as she takes over from Mark Green, with a fraction of the office's budget left for the last half of the current fiscal year.

title: Robinson and Cassell Lead Bucks Past Sixers
description: Glenn Robinson matched his season-high with 34 points and Sam Cassell scored a season-high 29, including 25 in the second half, as the visiting Milwaukee Bucks dealt the Philadelphia 76ers their seventh straight loss, 96-80, last night.

title: As the War Shifts Alliances, Oil Deals Follow
description: There is no oil in Afghanistan, but there are oil politics, and Washington is subtly tending to them, using the promise of energy investments in Central Asia to nurture a budding set of political alliances in the region with Russia, Kazakhstan and, to some extent, Uzbekistan.

title: Subway Booth Is Set On Fire in Brooklyn
description: A man set a subway token booth on fire early yesterday morning in what appeared to be a robbery attempt, but was thwarted when a fire-extinguishing system put out the blaze, the police said.

title: Overtime Pay for Police and Fire Chiefs Stirs Fears
description: New York City has agreed to pay hundreds of hours of overtime to high-ranking police and fire supervisors to reward them for the long hours they worked after the terrorist attacks, even though commanders at their level are normally not entitled to such pay, city and union officials said yesterday.

title: Toy Store Is Leading Retail Shuffle In Times Sq.
description: Mickey Mouse and other Disney characters will not be coming back to the giant retail store at Seventh Avenue and 42nd Street that was a fixture in the resurgence of Times Square. Cosmetics Plus quietly closed its doors on 42nd Street and Planet Hollywood, with its flagship theme restaurant now in Times Square, slipped back into bankruptcy court in October.

title: Oleh Wengerchuk: Soul Mates From Age 2
description: Oleh Wengerchuk and his wife, Oksana, met as children, when their families were interred at a German displacement camp when they were toddlers. Their families were Ukrainian. "I don't remember him from that time," Mrs. Wengerchuk said. "My mother used to tell me that we would play together all the time, he and his brother and I. We were like the three musketeers. We were only 2 or 3 years old."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 3 about the reconstruction of the Manhattan Bridge misstated the weight of its steel girders and misidentified the fasteners being used to repair them. The girders weigh 60,000 tons, not millions of tons. The fasteners are bolts, not rivets.

title: Giggling Falls Silent, And Fountains Are Dry: 'My Everything' Is Gone
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Sandra Campbell: Helpful Was Her Only Gear
description: Early on the morning of Sept. 11, Corey Wilson took the phone when he heard that Sandra Campbell was calling from work. The 5-year-old wanted his godmother to know how much he liked the book bag she bought him for school. The response so pleased her, she told the boy's mother, "I'm going to buy him two more."

title: Peredelkino Journal; Novelist Chronices the Intrigues of the New Moguls
description: In the quiet snow of this old writers' community, Yuliya Latynina is at home working on her next novel. The window of her small second-story room opens out onto a birch grove and the house of Boris Pasternak, now a museum.

title: Misusing Executive Privilege
description: President Bush's broad assertion of executive privilege to block a Congressional review of internal Justice Department documents pertaining to F.B.I. misuse of mob informants has inflamed lawmakers on both sides of the aisle -- and properly so.

title: An Early Finish Follows a Late Night for the Knicks
description: Don Chaney saw a weary bunch being dominated in the lane, on the perimeter and on the fast break. With the Knicks trailing by 15 points after three quarters tonight, he sat four of his starters for the entire fourth. The coach saw the situation as a no-brainer. The players saw it as surrender.

title: Screening for Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Fannie Mae Sets Mortgage Record
description: Fannie Mae, the nation's leading buyer of home loans, said it had committed itself to buying a record $49 billion in mortgage loans in November as homeowners flocked to refinance and take out new loans.

title: Vital Help for New York
description: The initial surge of national sympathy for New York City and the victims of the terrorist attack may have subsided, but we believe most Americans, including members of Congress, still want to help heal the wounds of Sept. 11. Right now, a vital package of federal aid for the city and the victims is stalled in Washington. It will take only some flexibility for lawmakers to get it moving again. Congress should not adjourn for the year without fulfilling the spirit of President Bush's pledge to do what it takes to make New York whole again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, CHARLES K., MD
description: McSHERRY-Charles K., MD, F.A.C.S. Emeritus Clinical Professor of Surgery, Cornell University Medical College. Director of Surgery, Beth Israel Medical Center 1976-1990. Attending surgeon at the New York Presbyterian Hospital. Past-President of the New York Surgical Society, NY Gastroenterological Association, Knight of Malta. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Ryan. Loving father of Maureen and cherished grandfather of Casey. Admired uncle of several nieces and nephews. Devoted friend of Miriam K. Moran. Predeceased by his parents and siblings. In repose at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St., NYC, Saturday and Sunday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday 10:00 AM at St. Joseph's Church, 404 E. 87th Street. In lieu of flowers kindly direct contributions to the St. Agnes High School Foundation, 555 West End Avenue, New York, New York 10024.

title: Neither Ruiz Nor Holyfield Expecting to Go 12 Rounds
description: During his long career, Evander Holyfield has been a skillful boxer and a willing brawler. So if the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship fight between Holyfield and John Ruiz on Saturday turns into a rugged scuffle, Ruiz will not be surprised.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan's Wizards Get a Sniff of Success
description: A NEW odor wafted recently from the MCI Center, the home arena of the Wizards. Two weeks ago, after a lame loss to Cleveland and the team with a 3-10 record, Michael Jordan held the proverbial nose and declared: ''We stink.''

title: An Assault on India's Democracy
description: A spike in tensions between India and Pakistan is just what the world does not need right now, but it will be hard to avoid after Thursday's bloody assault by a suicide squad on India's Parliament House that left 12 people dead. Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan condemned the attack. Nevertheless, Indian leaders charge that two groups operating within Pakistan were responsible for this assault and another in October on the legislative hall in Kashmir, though they did not disclose any supporting evidence. Pressure on India to retaliate is bound to rise. Because of the unsettled situation in Afghanistan this is a particularly dangerous time for India to act precipitately. The United States must do all it can to persuade India to respond with restraint.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALKER, MARK HOPKINS
description: WALKER-Mark Hopkins. December 15, 1991. Remembered with love. Your family & friends

title: Top Official, But No Others, To Get Raise At Port Agency
description: At a time when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is projecting a 23 percent drop in operating revenue, the governors of the two states have approved a 22 percent salary increase for the executive director's post.

title: Catharina Robinson: She Was Aunt Patsy
description: When teacher conferences were scheduled for her brother's children, you could count on Catharina Robinson to be there. She kept in touch with some of her older nieces and nephews by e-mail and rewarded them for good grades.

title: Kwan and Hughes Trail After an Uneven Day on Ice
description: Sarah Hughes usually seems suspended above the ice as if puppet strings were tethered to her costume, keeping her upright no matter what trouble she might encounter.

title: Blazes in the Bronx and New Jersey Kill Two Children and Three Adults
description: Two fires claimed the lives of five people yesterday, including two baby boys in the Bronx and a mother and her parents in Brick, N.J.

title: Notre Dame Coach Resigns After 5 Days and a Few Lies
description: Five days after naming George O'Leary its new head football coach, the University of Notre Dame announced today that O'Leary had resigned suddenly after admitting to falsifying parts of his academic and athletic background.

title: Bin Laden's Glee, Our Disgust
description: To the Editor:

title: South African Court Orders Medicine for H.I.V.-Infected Mothers
description: In a rebuke of South Africa's AIDS policy, a judge ruled today that pregnant women under state care who are H.I.V. infected are entitled to a low-cost drug that has been found to reduce a newborn's risk of contracting the virus.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Business Day on Thursday about House committee testimony by the chief executive of the Arthur Andersen accounting firm, on the finances of the Enron Corporation, misstated his middle initial. He is Joseph F. Berardino, not Joseph P.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS PROFIT SHARING STUDY IS URGED
description: British Airways should provide United States regulators with more information as part of its application for permission to share sales and profit on some flights with the AMR Corporation's American Airlines, three airlines said. Continental Airlines, Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines filed a motion with the Department of Transportation requesting that British Airways produce a study that may provide insight into how the planned alliance would affect airline competition. American Airlines and British Airways asked in August for antitrust immunity in the United States to share sales and profit on some flights. Delta and other airlines want American Airlines to give up slots at Heathrow Airport in London to prevent an allied American Air and British Air from dominating the route.

title: Before the Euro, Money Talked of Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Charities Pledge to Include Families' Input
description: Responding to complaints from victims' families, leaders of a group formed to coordinate the charities responding to Sept. 11 pledged yesterday to include victim representatives on its board of directors.

title: Open Space Institute Buys Scenic Site of an Old Friary
description: The Open Space Institute has bought a 93-acre parcel along the Hudson River in Garrison, N.Y., from an order of Capuchin-Franciscan friars who ignited fierce protests a few years ago when they proposed selling the land to a developer.

title: Brian McDonnell: 'A Cop's Cop'
description: Maggie McDonnell is trying to keep Christmas normal for her two children. Their Long Island lawn is decorated in lights and they will have a tree. The tree will be decorated in red, white and blue, and Daddy's police cap will stand atop it.

title: Corrections
description: An opera review on Dec. 4 about singers who had taken over roles in ''Die Meistersinger'' at the Metropolitan omitted one cast change. Matthew Polenzani replaced Mathias Zachariassen in the role of David.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consolidating To Build Ships
description: The Hitachi Zosen Corporation, a Japanese shipbuilder, and the NKK Corporation, the steel maker, said yesterday that they would close one of their six shipyards and cut 200 jobs as they merge shipbuilding operations in October 2002. ''China will emerge as the main competitor, replacing South Korea at the top of the shipbuilding industry,'' NKK's president, Yoichi Shimogaichi, said. ''We must take action while our profit is stable, because China's lower labor costs, at about one-twentieth of our own, are a threat.'' The equally owned venture, Universal Shipbuilding, will have annual sales of 150 billion yen ($1.2 billion) and 3,200 employees, down from 3,400 workers in the operations now. The new company is expected to save 3.5 billion yen ($27.77 million) by 2004 by pooling purchasing and improving efficiency.

title: In Chechnya, Truth Is a Dangerous Goal
description: Anna Politkovskaya doesn't think of herself as a war reporter. When colleagues all over the world rushed this fall to cover the war in Afghanistan, she wasn't even tempted. ''I looked inside myself, and I understood I had no desire to go,'' she said during a recent visit to New York.

title: Brian Bilcher: Always to the Rescue
description: Captain America. That's what Tina Bilcher called her husband, Brian, a firefighter at Squad Company 1 in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, PAUL
description: PALMER-Paul. The Officers, Members, and Staff of the Pawling Mountain Club mourn the passing of our fellow sportsman and dear friend. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Philip Bonanno, Chairman Peter Cholnoky, President

title: Canadian Securities Firm Fires Its Leader
description: Yorkton Securities Inc. today fired its chief executive, Scott Paterson, who ran the Canadian securities firm while stocks it promoted in the dot-com boom fell to pennies a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASSERT, THOMAS H.
description: GASSERT-Thomas H. Of Little Silver, New Jersey, on December 12, 2001, at age 73. He was a NJ lawyer for almost 40 years. In 1945, he graduated from Xavier High School in Manhattan; and was a 1949 graduate of Fordham College, as well as a 1954 graduate of Fordham Law School, both at the Bronx campus. He was honored by the Pope in 1964, being made a Knight of St. Gregory the Great. From 1970 to 1971, he was a member of the New York Stock Exchange with the specialist firm, Henderson Bros., Inc. He is survived by his wife, the former M. Anita Henderson; eight children; a sister, Joan G. Henderson; sixteen grandchildren; and two great grandchildren. For further information call John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, New Jersey at 1888-747-0332.

title: Ann Taylor To Open A Store Near Wall St.
description: Ann Taylor, the clothing store chain, has become the first national retailer since the attack on the World Trade Center to lease space below Canal Street in Lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, IRVING
description: SCHWARTZ-Irving, 81. Of Sarasota, FL and Norwalk, CT. Husband of Rita Mischel Schwartz, died on Friday in Sarasota. Born in New York City on December 28, 1919, he was the son of the late David and Regina Drucker Schwartz. Mr. Schwartz, a retired CPA, was the founding partner of Schwartz & Hofflich, CPAs. He started the firm in 1948 in New York City and moved it to Norwalk in 1955. He was a member of numerous professional organizations and a visiting guest lecturer at Yale University, speaking on the business aspects on the profession of architecture. An ardent supporter of the state of Israel, he had made over 25 trips there. In addition to his wife, he is survived by two daughters, Susan Mischel of Norwalk and Jane Deer-Hileman of Seattle, three grandchildren, two great grandchildren and a brother, Murray Schwartz of New York City. Services Sunday 11AM Collins Funeral Home, Norwalk, CT.

title: Trials and Tribulations
description: John Ashcroft may talk like an ayatollah, but this week he acted like an attorney general. He dispatched the first indicted suspect in the 9/11 attacks not to a secret military tribunal but to one of those civilian courts he seems to regard as criminal-coddling, secret-spilling, procedure-clogged terrorist pulpits.

title: South Korea Sees Prospects Of Its Leader Steadily Ebb
description: One by one in recent weeks presidential candidates have been emerging like hibernating bugs from Korea's political woodwork, first in the opposition parties, and then in the ruling party of President Kim Dae Jung himself.

title: Claude Richards: Bombs Were His Business
description: If ever a man was to the bomb squad born, it was Detective Claude Richards of the New York Police Department. Fearless, meticulous and disciplined nearly to a fault, Detective Richards, 46, the bomb squad's intelligence coordinator, spent his off-duty hours working, working out and planning his next workday. When he took some time off, it was to defuse land mines in Bosnia with a United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: Frederick J. Hoffmann and Michele L. Hoffmann: All Too Much in the Family
description: There was a piece of favorite banter between 5-year-old Derek Leohner and his grandpa, Frederick J. Hoffmann. The grandfather would ask, "Who loves you?" Derek would reply, "Pop Pop." "How much?" Mr. Hoffman would ask, and the answer would come back, "Too much."

description: BRUSSELS  COUNTDOWN TO THE EURO 2002 series
