description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Electricity Deregulation Is Still Sound Policy
description: Some members of Congress say the collapse of Enron shows the need for a return to a regulated energy market. On the contrary, what the Enron debacle shows is that deregulation, carefully monitored, remains sound public policy -- and is the best way to prevent future Enrons.

title: Heels and Hoosiers To Meet for Title
description: A long soccer season came to an abrupt end in the second overtime for St. John's tonight, when the Red Storm suffered a 2-1 defeat to perennial power Indiana in the N.C.A.A. semifinals.

title: After Two-Decade Halt, Marijuana Research Is Set
description: Research on the medical uses of marijuana is scheduled to begin early next year, for the first time in nearly two decades, now that the government has approved new experiments to test whether smoking it can help patients who have multiple sclerosis or who suffer from pain in their limbs as a result of AIDS.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Joanne Cregan: Everyone's Best Friend
description: Joanne and Grace Cregan were sisters. The kind who moved here from Ireland and bought identical apartments, just two floors apart in the same Brooklyn Heights building; the kind who sent each other e-mail messages throughout the day and watched television together every night; the kind who were best friends.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE GAINS. Angola, an independent oil producer, said it would cut output, joining other non-OPEC members that agreed to do so. In New York, crude oil for January delivery settled up $1.11, or 6 percent, at $19.23 a barrel.

title: 4 Years Later, Asking Who Got the Best Of Whom
description: If Vivendi Universal completes a deal to reclaim USA Networks, Barry Diller stands to more than double his original investment. And Edgar Bronfman Jr., the man who made the deal, stands to face questions about whether his strategy paid off.

title: Mets Say Gonzalez Is Still Too Costly
description: Three and a half years ago, Nelson Doubleday told Mets General Manager Steve Phillips to pursue Mike Piazza. Phillips did, and the Mets were transformed into a contender.

title: GROUP IN PAKISTAN IS BLAMED BY INDIA FOR SUICIDE RAID
description: India today blamed a militant Islamic group that operates openly in Pakistan and Kashmir for a suicide attack on the Indian Parliament that killed seven people, and it demanded that Pakistan halt the group's activities, arrest its leaders and cut off its financial assets.

title: Iran Shiites Celebrate And Mourn A Martyr
description: On the 19th day of Ramadan in 661, Imam Ali was struck on the head with a sword as he bent to pray at the Great Mosque in Kufa, Iraq. Two days later, he died.

title: Cashman Says Yanks Will Keep Hernndez
description: General Manager Brian Cashman conceded that he had grown weary of answering questions about pitcher Orlando Hernndez's uncertain future with the Yankees, so he emphasized yesterday that he had no intentions of trading the 36-year-old Hernndez and considered him a vital part of next year's revamped team.

title: Seeking New Market, Kirin Buys Into Philippine Brewer
description: Kirin Brewery of Japan said yesterday that it would pay 27.9 billion Philippine pesos ($536 million) for a 15 percent stake in the beer and beverage conglomerate San Miguel, tapping into Asia's fast-growing thirst for beer and providing what may be crucial boardroom support for San Miguel's embattled chairman, Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr.

title: Scott Sees MacCulloch Contributing Even More
description: MIAMI, Dec. 14 — When center Todd MacCulloch joined the Nets this season, Coach Byron Scott expected him to give the team inside scoring and more rebounding. Scott now says he underestimated the 7- foot MacCulloch.

title: French Concern Aims to Expand In U.S. Media
description: Vivendi Universal of France, one of the world's leading media companies, has lined up a set of deals intended to challenge the American entertainment giants in their struggle to dominate the production and distribution of movies and television programs.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Rwandan Singer Headed To Tribunal
description: The Dutch government will hand over a well known Rwandan singer and composer, Simon Bikindi, to the tribunal dealing with Rwandan war crimes. Mr. Bikindi was arrested in July in the Netherlands in a center for asylum seekers. Prosecutors for the Rwanda tribunal, which meets in Arusha, Tanzania, have charged him with inciting genocide with his songs calling for the elimination of ethnic Tutsi. It says he also took part himself in the orchestrated campaign of 1994 in which Hutu extremists killed some 800,000 people, most of them Tutsi civilians. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGENBACH, EDWARD
description: HAGENBACH-Edward. Of Stamford, CT on December 13, 2001. He is survived by his wife, Ann, and their four children. Calling hours Sunday 4-7 at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. Mass at the Church of the Holy Spirit, on Monday, at 11 AM.

title: Bryan C. Bennett: He Filled the Time Available
description: Bryan C. Bennett could turn an opportunity into an adventure, and in his 25 years, he had too many of both to recount in detail. The highlights included working on a farm in Spain, teaching English to schoolchildren in Chile, visiting a remote village in Cuba, white-water rafting in Costa Rica, and backpacking in the Andes.

title: Giambi Tags All the Bases
description: Day 2 as a Yankee for Jason Giambi started at 7 a.m. yesterday with the talk shows and continued with a visit to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at City Hall. Giambi told the mayor that he planned to live in Manhattan in his first year with the Yankees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CHRISTOPHER J.
description: MURPHY-Christopher J. A 34 year resident of Scarsdale, NY. Chris, 41 years old, died suddenly on December 11, 2001 of the complications of juvenile diabetes. He was born in Old Bridge, NJ on September 18, 1960. Chris was a graduate of Seely Place School and Edgemont High School in Scarsdale and went on to earn his Bachelor of Arts Degree in Business Management from Syracuse University in 1982. He pursued an active career in investment and commercial banking and at the time he left us he was a shareholder, Director and Executive of Country Bank, New York, NY, in which the Murphy family has a majority interest. Chris was a warrior in the battle to find a cure for juvenile diabetes which he contacted at the age of six. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Chapter of Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International. In that regard he was a member of the real estate committee at the annual ''Walk For a Cure'' and was an active participant with his family in the development of the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, ll50 St. Nicholas Avenue at 168th Street, Manhattan. Chris is survived by his parents Catherine Jo Ann and Joseph Michael Murphy, in addition to his brother Joseph M. Jr., his sisters, Carolyn and Mary Murphy and Patricia MacGillivray. He was adored by his nephews, Ryan and Sean MacGillivray, Brent Murphy, Joseph Michael III and Brian Murphy and his nieces, Kelly MacGillivray and Cailin Murphy. His brothers-in-law, Glen MacGillivray and Robert Murphy and sister-in-law Michele Murphy will sadly miss him. Visitation at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY, Thursday and Friday, December 13th and 14th from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of a Christian Burial will be celebrated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Post Road (Route 22) at Carman Road, Scarsdale at 10:45 AM Saturday, December 15th. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Secor Road, Hartsdale, New York. In lieu of flowers, friends are asked to make a donation to either Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International or the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center.

title: America's New Role In the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Containing Al Qaeda, Reviewing Bin Laden, Seeking Aid at Home
description: Two months ago, the war in Afghanistan seemed dauntingly open-ended. Taliban and Al Qaeda forces controlled 90 percent of the land. The local opposition was in disarray. Mullah Muhammad Omar reigned in Kabul and blustered in Kandahar. Finding Osama bin Laden seemed hopeless.

title: When Modern Methods Put Bidders in the Wrong Game
description: Modern bidding fashions occasionally tie their users into knots, and they reach inferior contracts that a traditionalist would never have had to suffer. The diagramed deal from the Senior Knockout Teams in the Fall Nationals in Las Vegas last month is an example.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSHER, ALBERT
description: MUSHER-Albert. On December 14, 2001, age 97. Beloved husband of the late Willma. Loving father of Betsy M. Boruchoff, Jonathan E. Musher and Leo Boruchoff. Dear grandfather of Nancy Orgel, Barbara Winer, Louis, Caroline, Noah, Lucas and Jeremy Musher. Great-grandfather of Jeffrey, Hilary and Alison Winer and Evan and Zoey Orgel. Cherished friend of Lorraine Albert. Service Sunday 1:00 PM at ''the Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: NRG ENERGY, POWER PRODUCER, MOVES TO SUPPORT DEBT
description: NRG Energy Inc., a power producer, plans to postpone spending $900 million on electricity generators next year to try to support its debt rating. The company also may sell some assets, Leonard Bluhm, its chief financial officer, said on a conference call with analysts and investors. He did not provide details. Last week, Moody's Investors Service put NRG's senior unsecured debt on review for a possible downgrade, citing concern about new debt to complete the $1.5 billion purchase of four power plants from the FirstEnergy Corporation. Power company debt is coming under more scrutiny after this month's bankruptcy of Enron, once the biggest energy trader.

title: A. Keith Smiley, 91, Executive Of Resort and Preservationist
description: A. Keith Smiley, a resort executive and environmentalist who helped protect thousands of acres of scenic landscape in Ulster County, N.Y. as a nature preserve, died on Dec. 6 in Goshen, N.Y.

title: Anderson Loses Time as Chaney Takes Over
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Much has been made of Don Chaney's laid- back demeanor and up-tempo aspirations, but the biggest change under him as the Knicks' coach has been in the area of minutes. The playing time of Latrell Sprewell, Allan Houston and Marcus Camby has increased significantly, while Shandon Anderson's minutes have almost vanished.

title: Defense Lawyers See Ways To Attack Tape, if Not Win
description: While it may seem like the ultimate smoking gun, defense lawyers said there would be ways to try to undercut the videotape of Osama bin Laden if he were to go on trial for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Bus Station To Be Museum
description: The Dothan Historic Commission approved an $850,000 plan to turn a former bus station into a black history museum. The building, vacant for several years, once housed racially separate restrooms, drinking fountains and entrances. The new museum will be named for George Washington Carver, the African-American educator and agricultural researcher. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Dominick Pezzulo: The Unusual Was Typical
description: Two kids from the Bronx just out of high school on their first date: Let's take the train to Manhattan and walk around, they say. Approaching a fountain, he's afraid she's not paying attention. He steps in front to block her, and falls right in. "We had to ride home with his brand-new sneakers squeaking," recalls Jeanette Pezzulo, with a laugh. And after that, she says, there was no way she could avoid marrying Dominick Pezzulo.

title: Tyrone May: The Music, and Party, Man
description: Tyrone May's music collection was vast: hundreds and hundreds of records and CD's, running the gamut from reggae and disco to rhythm and blues. And his apartment in Rahway, N.J., was littered with the announcements for record fairs he received in the mail each month. Naturally, people leapt to conclusions.

title: State Attorneys General Taking Steps to Block Satellite TV Acquisition
description: Even as Vivendi announced its plans to take a stake in EchoStar, some state attorneys general said yesterday that they were preparing efforts to block EchoStar's purchase of a rival and take control of 90 percent of the satellite TV industry.

title: Students Gear Up, Again, for SAT After Anthrax Scare
description: On the eve of taking the SAT's for the first time, Maggie Parks drilled like a quarterback preparing for the Super Bowl.

title: Slideshow: Nation Building, Brick by Brick
description: The process of rebuilding Afghanistan is beginning in places like Factory  No. 35 in the village of Betani, near Jalalabad, where bricks are made. The factory operates seven days a week, and the workers tend the fires in the kiln all night.

title: Slide Show: Scenes Around Afghanistan
Learning to Trust the Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart on Dec. 5 tracing the history of Afghanistan's leaders referred incorrectly to Hamid Karzai, the country's new interim leader. He is not a cousin of the deposed king, Mohammad Zahir Shah. The king's cousin was Sardar Mohammad Daoud, who deposed him.

title: RABBI'S DEATH PENALTY HEARING
description: Judge Linda G. Baxter of Superior Court last week set Jan. 11 for a hearing on whether Rabbi Fred J. Neulander can be retried for capital murder. Mr. Neulander's defense lawyers argue that because his first trial for the 1994 murder of his wife ended in a hung jury last month, he should be exempt from the possibility of the death penalty in his second trial.

title: Prelude to Kiss
description: In any other week, Gene Simmons's praise of the market as a sufficient arbiter of artistic merit might seem credible (The Way We Live Now, Dec. 2). In mistakenly attributing the popular acclaim of the Beatles to their antics alone, Simmons seems deaf to their abundant musicality, innovation and empathy. Could the popular outpouring attending George Harrison's death make this distinction any more clear?

title: By Land and By Sea: All in a Day's Lesson
description: ''HI class. It's Peter. Welcome to the Research Vessel Connecticut. This morning we're going to begin taking water samples.''

title: U.S. Officials Say Al Qaeda Routed From Afghanistan
description: TORA BORA, Afghanistan, Dec. 16 -- American officials said today that Al Qaeda had been effectively destroyed in Afghanistan, and Afghan commanders here declared victory in the fierce battle for the mountain stronghold of Osama bin Laden's organization. But neither Americans nor Afghans said they knew where Mr. bin Laden is.

title: SOAPBOX; Questions en Pointe
description: I APPROACHED the head of my daughters' school recently to ask if she would consider sending students to see the Westchester Ballet Company's ''Nutcracker.'' It wasn't an entirely objective request for I am the mother of two members of the company. I, myself, perform a couple of character roles in the production, and I serve on the company's board of directors. I thought it would be nice for their fellow students to see the results of what my daughters -- and many other children -- spend every evening and weekend working so hard on, to the exclusion of parties, sports events, concerts and television shows.

title: Salvador
description: Foreigners may flock to Rio de Janeiro, but savvy Brazilians like to argue that the best place in their country to spend the Southern Hemisphere summer is Salvador da Bahia. Brazil's third largest city slides easily into a hedonistic groove as the weather grows hotter, with irresistible rhythms pulsing from every street corner and parties and dancing propelling revelers toward an exuberant Carnival that just may be the best in Brazil.

title: Expecting the Worst
description: EVER since Americans began fighting wars, they have mostly done so in the name of ideals -- freedom, democracy, human rights. The war in Afghanistan is no exception. Once the press conferences are over, however, relatively few of the people who decide when and where to wage war actually think of themselves as idealists. The term preferred by members of the American foreign policy establishment is ''realism,'' which in this context has a very precise meaning.

title: Private Sector; Happy to Watch While Others Feed
description: The crash of the Enron Corporation, which landed the company in bankruptcy court two weeks ago, has lured lawyers like moths to a candle, sharks to a swimmer, hyenas to a carcass. In other words, a lot of lawyers. But Joseph D. Jamail Jr., one of the nation's most successful lawyers -- who just happens to live and work in Houston, Enron's hometown -- wants nothing to do with it.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALAY, IRVING ''PENNY.''
description: PALAY-Irving ''Penny.'' Daddy, we have so many wonderful memories to cherish forever. Your loving daughters, Elizabeth Palay Lowrance and Daryn Deodato

title: Adelaide Shafer, John Barrett III
description: Ellen Adelaide Shafer and John Joseph Barrett III were married yesterday by the Rev. Boniface Ramsey at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan.

title: In Unfamiliar Spot, a Familiar Choice: Indian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, PHILIP

title: The Year in Boxes, From Folk to the Four Tops
description: The compilers of this year's crop of compact disc boxed sets must have been humming ''All of Me.'' Instead of sifting through the recordings of musicians both revered and half-remembered, a number of boxed sets simply reprocess an entire label's catalog, plus outtakes, for performers as disparate as Billie Holiday, Joy Division, Simon and Garfunkel and the Grateful Dead. While collectors and completists revel in the profusion, casual listeners may hold back, waiting for the more selective and affordable best-ofs and greatest-hits collections that are bound to follow in a year or two. At the same time, other archivists are still trying to survey entire genres and repertories. One unexpected side effect of increasing consolidation among recording conglomerates is that boxed-set compilers can choose from more labels' rosters.

title: Eat the Rich Stuff
description: Of all the Christmas images of my childhood, by far the most vivid is of the vast trunk of my grandparents' gray Cadillac filled with the bounty they brought to the Mississippi Delta from Nashville. Every other year they drove down to visit us for the holidays, and every other year I couldn't wait to see the car come up the driveway. (On off years, the same loot came on the bus.) There were always dozens of presents wrapped in silver-and-gold paper, an enormous country ham, a caramel cake, a chess pie and a chocolate chess pie. But the thing I remember most was the plum pudding, bought from some mail-order place and tied up in yards of red cellophane with a huge silver ribbon. We never even ate it. The puddings piled up, still in their wrappings, on the top shelf of the entrance hall, until one year I insisted we actually cook one. We all discovered that it was delicious. (Actually, we discovered that pretty much everything served with hard sauce is delicious.)

Smiley is correct. But when exactly, before or after Sept. 11, did American feminists call for the United States to bomb Afghanistan to liberate its women? Did feminists advocate a war of any kind to save Afghan women?

title: RIDGEWOOD STUDENT SURVEY

In reinstating the case, the court reversed Judge Nicholas H. Politan of Federal District Court in Newark, who had ruled that the 1999 survey of student sexual behavior, drug and alcohol use and family relationships was not unconstitutionally intrusive or a violation of federal education law. The judges did affirm Judge Politan's contention that the survey was not a form of compelled self-incrimination. George James

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, RICHARD ELLIOT
description: MORRISON-Richard Elliot. 72. Passed away December 11, 2001, in Summit, NJ, his home of 43 years. Beloved husband of Nina. Cherished father of Shira and father-in-law of Jonathan. Loving grandfather of Samantha. Devoted brother, brother-in-law and deeply missed uncle. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Richard will be remembered as a man of warm humor and intelligence who was granted a Doctor of Literature degree from Drew University at age 70. Always giving of his knowledge, time and experience he mentored numerous young people, as well as serving as adjunct professor at Monmouth College, Rutgers University and NYU Graduate School. An Army veteran, he volunteered for the Airborne during the Korean Conflict and was later issued a professional appointment at Quarter Master School in Fort Lee, Virginia. As a sought after expert in the field of packaging engineering, he was awarded eight patents and in 1980 formed the Summit Group Packaging Consultancy of which he was Chairman. A graveside service was held at Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, NJ on December 13.

title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-16-01: SALIENT FACTS; Chilling Effect
description: WHY IS THE WIND CHILL FACTOR ALWAYS SO COLD?Remember all those times the weatherman warned of a wind chill factor of minus 40 degrees, yet you survived? Well, the National Weather Service has just rolled out a new wind chill index that promises to be more in line with people's own experience of cold. The first index, devised in 1945 by a pair of Antarctic explorers, tended to produce extreme results -- in part because it used wind speed as measured 33 feet up and in part because it assumed that people walk straight into the wind at a very brisk four miles an hour.

description: The compilers of this year's crop of compact disc boxed sets must have been humming ''All of Me.'' description: WHAT'S COOKING, JAMELA?

Niall Ferguson defines terrorism as ''the use of violence by nonstate organizations in the pursuit of extreme political goals'' (Dec. 2). But countless state organizations have used violence against innocent civilian populations, killing millions of people for ''extreme political goals.'' Human rights organizations continually report systemic state terrorism around the world, including that by several allies of the United States. To define ''terrorism'' as something states don't do is dangerous and reactionary. ''State terrorism'' and ''nonstate terrorism'' must be acknowledged and combated equally, without any presumed moral distinction between them, if we are to establish a just international order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLETTA, HAROLD R.
description: COLETTA-Harold R. Violist extraordinaire and bon vivant was born in the Bronx on January 25, 1917, and died in NYC on November 29, 2001. His parents emigrated from Italy with their families; his from Fondi, hers from Sorano in the early 1900's. Harold became interested in the violin at an early age. In his late teens he switched to the viola, which suited him perfectly because of his impressive stature of 6'1'' with broad shoulders and large hands. He soon began what was to be a long and illustrious career, which spanned over 60 years. This began with the Bridgeport W.P.A. Symphony where he spent his free time working on the classical repetoire. This diligence paid off, and he was accepted into the National Youth Orchestra conducted by Leopold Strakowski, which toured South America twice. He studied at Juilliard for a short time, but his study with Raphael Bronstein was, he felt, more valuable. Harold played in The New York Philharmonic and then The NBC Orchestra for nin years under the baton of Arturo Toscanini. He performed in Carnegie Hall with Heifetz and Piatigorsky as part of a sextet. He played in the Casals Festival in Puerto Rico a number of times. His tours consisted of the American String Quartet, solo tour of Europe in the 1960's, and the final tour in 1987 with Frank Sinatra. His studio career in radio/TV days was with Sinatra, Como and Crosby to mention a few. He was part of many soundtracks for recordings, movies and commercials, which continued up until his death. Harold's passion for music, Italy and life, was evident to all who knew and loved him. A biography in progress, being written by a student/colleague should be released in the very near future. Harold is survived by his wife, Mary (Lewis), his brother Paolo, his son Michael Bradley Albert (Diane), two daughters, Suzanne Hallie (Seth) Glasser, and Hallie Adrienne Coletta, five grandchildren, Jennifer and Adam Colletta, and Alex, Anna, and Nick Glasser. There was no services or visitation. A special musical memorial tribute is planned for Spring. For information contact Joseph W. Sorce F.H., Inc.; 845358-4433.

title: This Separate Season
description: The patterns that shape the December holiday season are so familiar to most Americans that even the slightest variation makes one year's version of Noel or Hanukkah seem strikingly different from another's. Much snow or little snow, more prosperity or less, ''It's a Wonderful Life'' or ''The Bishop's Wife'' -- these things make an enormous difference in what matters most of all, which is how the season feels. If it seems odd, some years, that so much should depend on the emotions these few weeks arouse, in other years it seems entirely natural, a fitting indulgence of what is often the very best we know about ourselves.

title: Love the Service Around Here

I know whereof I speak; the Peace Corps (Senegal 1967-69) shaped my life.

title: LIVES

I could take the piece of paper I'm writing on, crush it into a ball and hit pilot No. 1 on the back of his blond head. Pilot No. 2 flips a few switches. Previously, I would have been delighted to catch a glimpse of pilots at the helm. Now I'd like to tell them, Shut that door! But I am loath to interrupt as they steer what I know is a potential weapon. Pilot No. 1 says Blah blah blah to No. 2, and they laugh, tipping back their heads.

title: Gene Hackman, Hollywood's Every Angry Man
description: SEEN back to back to back, Gene Hackman's three leading roles in three current movies offer a clue to his nervy greatness: he seems energized by messing with his directors' expectations. In the comedy ''The Royal Tenenbaums,'' he plays the self-absorbed patriarch of a family of despondent geniuses, and his airy cunning is in dry counterpoint to Wes Anderson's arch, storybook compositions. In John Moore's ''Behind Enemy Lines,'' he's an admiral who mostly squints into monitors and assures a trapped young soldier that he won't be abandoned. But instead of John Wayne-like breast-beating, Mr. Hackman seems eaten up by the character's impotence, quietly riven by opposing inner forces of military discipline and rage. In ''Heist,'' he transcends the stifling universe of the writer and director David Mamet, in which spontaneous feeling tends to be trampled under a procession of double-, triple- and quadruple-crosses. Mr. Hackman supplies a strain of uncertainty: in a sea of duplicitous masks, his is the only human face.

title: The Year in Boxes, From Folk to the Four Tops
description: The compilers of this year's crop of compact disc boxed sets must have been humming ''All of Me.'' Instead of sifting through the recordings of musicians both revered and half-remembered, a number of boxed sets simply reprocess an entire label's catalog, plus outtakes, for performers as disparate as Billie Holiday, Joy Division, Simon and Garfunkel and the Grateful Dead. While collectors and completists revel in the profusion, casual listeners may hold back, waiting for the more selective and affordable best-ofs and greatest-hits collections that are bound to follow in a year or two. At the same time, other archivists are still trying to survey entire genres and repertories. One unexpected side effect of increasing consolidation among recording conglomerates is that boxed-set compilers can choose from more labels' rosters.

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; A Bakery Delivers 20,000 Season's Greetings
description: Every time I go to Carlo's Bake Shop, I feel like a walking Lay's commercial. Try as I may to order a single pecan Danish ($1.95), I always fail; the pastries are simply too good to eat just one. They're enough to test even Fergie's willpower. Then again, everything in this family-run Italian bakery puts self-control to the test. At breakfast, it might be the crumb cake ($5.95 a sheet), topped with crumbs -- if that's the right word -- about two inches long and an inch and a half deep. In the afternoon, it might be cheesecake ($8.25) or chocolate rugelach ($10.95 a pound), made with an achingly tender butter-and-cream-cheese dough. At the moment, real temptation lies in the traditional Italian Christmas cookies, which the head baker, Buddy Valastro Jr., turns out by the thousands -- roughly 20,000 during the season, in fact. The bakery even stays open late on Christmas Eve with 20 people behind the counter (instead of the usual 3) to handle the rush. Hoboken's large Italian community orders by name: mostaccioli, struffoli, torrone, biscotti natalizi. Everyone else just points, selecting their favorites among the rows of almond-paste cookies, nut bars, honey balls and so-called love knots, iced-cake-like creations made with a lemon sour cream dough. Two-pound trays loaded with 15 varieties are sold for $19.95. Mr. Valastro Jr., who learned the trade at his father's side and began baking at age 12, said the 91-year-old bakery goes through 300 pounds of butter a week. No wonder willpower has no chance. Gretchen Kurtz

A stink of burning vehicles, gunfire, and stale sweat hung heavily on Tiananmen Square; thousands of tired bodies huddled in fear around the Monument to the People's Heroes, with its carved images of earlier rebels: the Taiping, the Boxers, the Communists of course, and also the student demonstrators of May 4, 1919, who saw "Mr. Science" and "Mr. Democracy" as the twin solutions to China's political problems. The huge, rosy face of Chairman Mao stared from the wall of the Forbidden City across three or four dead bodies lying where his outsize shoes would have been had his portrait stretched that far. Tracer bullets and flaming cars lit up the sky in bursts of pale orange. Loudspeakers barked orders to leave the square immediately, or else. Spotlights were switched off and then on again. And over the din of machine-gun fire, breaking glass, stamping army boots, screaming people, wailing sirens, and rumbling APCs, young voices, hoarse from exhaustion, sang the "Internationale," followed by the patriotic hit song of the year, "Descendants of the Dragon":

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CHRISTOPHER J.
description: MURPHY-Christopher J. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of Chris Murphy, son of Joseph and JoAnn Murphy of Scarsdale, N.Y. Just 41 when he died of complications of juvenile diabetes, Chris was a wonderfully dedicated supporter of efforts to find a cure for diabetes. He and his family were visionary supporters of the establishment of the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center at Columbia Presbyterian, and active members of the Medical Center family. The Medical Center and others in the campaign against juvenile diabetes will always remember Chris's warmth and commitment. We extend our condolences to his many friends and family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

title: Some Book Buyers Read the Price And Decide Not to Read the Rest
description: Taking a break from Christmas shopping last week, Bernadine Fagan stopped by the Borders near her home in Bohemia, on Long Island, to buy some books for herself -- Merriam-Webster's Encyclopedia of Literature and a paperback by Susan Johnson, the romance novel ''Tempting.''

title: Naomi Schor, Literary Critic and Theorist, Is Dead at 58
description: Naomi Schor, a literary critic and theorist who combined psychoanalytic theory, avant-garde philosophy and feminism to come up with quirky, often startling insights into 19th-century French authors including Flaubert and Zola, died on Dec. 2 at a New Haven hospital. She was 58 and lived in Hamden, Conn.

description: Boys will have their toys, and Thomas Warren Hohlweck Jr. had his. Starting with a used Fiat in high school, Mr. Hohlweck loved to tool around in racy vehicles, although he could not be described as a racy driver. "He liked to rev the engine but he was no speedster," said his wife, Pamela. "In fact, he was the best driver I ever met."

title: THE LAST SCHOOL PRAYER
description: Organized prayers in public classrooms have been illegal since a 1962 United States Supreme Court ruling, but that decision never sat well in Louisiana. State legislators there passed a law in 1999 requiring every school to permit a brief morning prayer or meditation, and this week a federal appeals court unanimously struck down the law, the only one of its kind. The court rather scornfully rejected the law as wholly religious in nature and thus unconstitutional, but the state, enjoying the challenge, plans to appeal. David Firestone

title: Finding Fleeting Moments of Intimacy In the Sale of Lowly Objets
description: Kerry Johnson had three thumbtacks to hang a poster in her new Fort Greene apartment. She needed one more and could easily have bought it at a hardware store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, ROBERT J.
description: FARRELL-Robert J. 64 years old, of Delmar, NY, and Manchester, VT. Formerly of Queens, NY. Died December 14, 2001, of cancer. Beloved husband of Dorothy Van Buren Farrell of Delmar NY. Devoted father of Peter T. Farrell and Christopher A. Farrell of Manhattan. Son of the late New York State Supreme Court Justice Peter T. Farrell and Agnes M. Loving brother of Ann Marie FitzPatrick of Manhasset, NY, Lois Phillips of Baiting Hollow, NY, Stephen P. Farrell of Manhattan, and the late Peter M. Farrell. Graduate of Xavier High School in Manhattan; Holy Cross College, Worcester, MA; NYU Law School and NYU Graduate Law School. Formerly Chief of the Law Department of the Queens County Surrogate's Court. Appointed by Governor Hugh Carey as General Counsel of the NY State Thruway Authority. Former President of the International Bridge, Tunnel and Turnpike Association; former member of the Board of Directors of the Queens County Bar Association; and former President of the St. Patrick's Society of Queens County. Viewing Monday, 4-8 PM, at Keenan Funeral Home, 490 Delaware Ave., Albany, NY 12209. Mass of Christian Burial 9:30 AM, Tuesday, December 18, at Historic St. Mary's in Albany. Memorial contributions may be made to Community Hospice, 445 New Karner Rd., Albany, NY 11205 or to the James Patrick Memorial Fund, c/o Charter One Bank, Latham, NY 12110.

title: 'By Any Means Necessary'
description: THE SCENE ON the other side of the Plexiglas, far beyond the steady, rhythmic drone of the engines and the reach of the machine guns, was sublime. It could have been a classic Chinese scroll, a Song dynasty painting, come to life. Capt. John E. Roche, belted securely in the copilot's seat, took in a vast landmass shrouded in early morning fog. He couldn't make out the coastline, but he could clearly see several mountain peaks towering above the thick mist. Roche guessed that they were seventy to a hundred miles away. The mountains and the mist had an ethereal quality. But they were not Chinese. They were Siberian.

title: WALL STREET'S PAIN
description: Stockbrokers are crying in their (imported) beer, and New Yorkers of all stripes are sharing their pain. That's because 2001 bonuses will total just $10 billion, far less than last year's record $14.3 billion, according to the New York State comptroller, thanks to recession, sagging stocks and, of course, the events of Sept. 11. The missing $4.3 billion translates into fewer taxi rides, apartment buys, restaurant meals, golf lessons and Chinese food deliveries. Tax revenues and charitable donations will also take big hits. Leslie Eaton

description: Powerful creatures that once roamed the Asian landscape can be seen in Toronto this winter in ''Great Asian Dinosaurs! Unique Creatures From Russia's Vaults'' at the Royal Ontario Museum from Wednesday to March 31.

title: ARMEY TO RETIRE
description: Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, announced that he would retire from Congress at the end of his current term. Republicans immediately began jockeying for position on the party's leadership ladder. Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip and as staunch a conservative as Mr. Armey, emerged as the frontrunner; the choice will be made late next year. Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, the chief deputy whip, said he would run for whip. Representative Ray LaHood of Illinois, a conciliator with a more moderate voting record, also jumped into the race. Robert Pear

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, LAWRENCE DR.
description: AMES-Lawrence Dr., 94, formerly of Brooklyn, died December 12, 2001 at the Jewish Home of Central New York in Syracuse. A 1931 graduate of New York Medical College. He was a physician in private general practice in Brooklyn since 1932. A past President of the Kings County Medical Society, past President of the NY State chapter of the American Academy of Family Practice, the New York State Board of Professional Medical Conduct and the Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst. He was a Captain in the Medical Corps, World War II. Predeceased by his wife Blanche in 1989. Survived by a son, Dr. Ira of Fayetteville, NY, a sister Edna Braverman of NYC, two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, CLARICE

title: Visions of a Brand-Name Office Empire
description: SAM ZELL is not a man plagued by self-doubt. He never has been. Nearby stands a green board Mr. Blieden surfed on last year, now used mostly to adorn his largely bare walls. The pice de rsistance: stereo speakers that belonged to his father, their woofers and tweeters on full display, minus any decorative covering.

description: The white exiles jolt through the smoky mountains in their battered pickup trucks, swerving along dirt roads to stake their claims to this wild and secluded land. There are no paved roads in these lonely hills, no running water, no telephone lines snaking through the tangle of trees.

description: One by one, the defendants file into the large steel cage. There are 10 of them, young men in their mid-20's. Some wear jeans and sweatshirts -- and defiant expressions. Others appear bruised and frightened.

title: Habitats/Springfield, N.J.; In an Artist's House, Angels Symbolize Hope
description: ELEVEN years ago, Lin Evola, a painter, had a vision. She would melt down guns and the casings of nuclear weapons, and use the metal for sculpturing angels -- peace angels. In the course of asking people to put down their weapons, she imagined that she would contribute to the process of creating peace in the world.

title: TORT REFORM ROLLING ALONG
description: Considered politically moribund before Sept. 11, the move to revise the tort law system, which governs civil liability, has gained significant momentum. In legislation signed by President Bush, airlines, landlords and real estate owners in New York City have won important protections against lawsuits arising out of the attacks, and the House adopted a measure that would impose sharp restrictions on lawsuits from future terrorist incidents. Business interests maintain that the rethinking is a necessary consequence of the terrorist attacks, while consumer groups and trial lawyers say that it is little more than a product of political opportunism. Stephen Labaton

title: A Grassroots Fight
description: IT began quietly after Sept. 11, with a few neighbors meeting to talk about their fear of living in the shadow of the Indian Point nuclear power plant. But those conversations spread rapidly and now thousands of people in more than a dozen area towns, villages and school districts have signed petitions and passed resolutions urging the plant's shutdown.

description: Yale's president, Richard Levin, took on a daunting but worthy project last week when he suggested in an interview with The Times's Karen Arenson that it would be a ''good thing'' to abandon early-decision admissions to the nation's select colleges. Mr. Levin seems to have been reacting to the anguish of students and parents who find that the frenzied process of trying to lock in a position at elite schools is casting a pall over the high school years. The question now is whether he will be able to persuade enough colleagues at other colleges to abandon a system that is causing more harm than good with each passing year.

title: Making Art From the Splintered Memories of War
description: LATE in September 1991, Serbian forces of the Yugoslav Army began bombing the Croatian city of Dubrovnik, a glorious 1,400-year-old walled tourist destination at the foot of the Dinaric Alps and the edge of the Adriatic Sea. Dubrovnik is a designated Unesco World Heritage Site, but in 1991, at least 100 of its inhabitants were killed and more than half of its historic monuments were damaged by rockets and mortars.

But set one to find the shortest route, and to avoid freeways and toll roads, and you can drive confidently on interesting back roads you never tried before. I recently tried a Blaupunkt system on several trips, around New Jersey and to the far end of Virginia, and learned a bit about what the systems can and cannot do.

title: THE END OF ABM TREATY

But Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, merely called the move ''mistaken'' and noted that Russia would retain enough nuclear weapons, 1,500 to 2,200, to overwhelm whatever Mr. Bush builds. He moved on to talking about building a new ''strategic relationship.'' China, not a party to the treaty, was harsher in its criticism, but accepted Mr. Bush's offer to hold strategic talks as well. ''You must all forgive me if I seem somewhat egotistical,'' she once proclaimed, presumably with a straight face, ''but my Life is so tightly bound up with my Art, it is so much one and the same, that I must always refer to it.''

title: Brown-Bagging It
description: From the first page, John Speirs's book THE LITTLE BOY'S CHRISTMAS GIFT (Abrams, $16.95; ages 4 and up) transports the reader to a distant time, yet to a place that seems comfortingly familiar. Drawing on his study of the Bruegels and Hans Memling, Speirs sets the biblical Christmas story in Renaissance Europe, following the journey of a boy and three wise men to a distant stable. Along the way, they are joined by scores of everyday people with gifts for a new king: farmers with loaves of bread, nomads with bright rugs, beekeepers with combs of honey. Not the least of them is the boy, who carries a brown sack with his gift, even though he is told by the wise men that he has nothing worth offering. He does, of course, and the mystery of the brown sack, along with the implicit challenge of finding the boy in each illustration, makes for captivating reading. In his text, Speirs uses a soothing, poetic repetition that builds, layer upon layer, as new groups join the journey. The tale is simple yet evocative, faltering slightly at the end, which has a feel-good quality and lacks the freshness that Speirs brings to the rest of the book. That is a minor flaw, especially because the accompanying art and its presentation are stunning. The illustrations, on right-hand pages, are framed in gold. The text, on left-hand pages, is framed with illuminations and embellished with small illustrations, like a 15th-century manuscript. The spiritual images -- Christ child, Madonna, angels, star -- radiate with a subtle gold overlay. Speirs's pictures -- of a caravan traveling through spired cities, mountain passes, seaside villages, wheat fields at harvest time -- do far more than illustrate the story. They enhance it, giving it depth and movement as they celebrate both God and humanity. In an author's note, Speirs writes that ''The Little Boy's Christmas Gift'' is the result of a lifetime's research. It shows. Doug Ward

This ceremonial costume was worn by the Nahuatl-speaking indigenous peoples of the state of Guerrero, Mexico. Buried in the earth most of the year, the suit was unearthed only during harvest time, for a ritual dance. It is decorated with intertwined suns and moons, which in pre-Columbian mythology represent the cosmic forces of heaven overcoming the lords of the underworld and ensuring the earth remains fertile.

At Flicka, the children's store in Los Angeles (where a girl's first fur is taken very seriously), Cachcach's black ''Persian lamb'' ($155) is selling out. In New York, Space Kiddets on 21st Street at Park Avenue offers a shaggy tomato-red ''Mongolian lamb'' jacket by Wild Child (left; $164) and an aqua-and-black number by Zazi ($159). For the funkier girl, Contrevents makes a magenta topper with blue tips ($132 at Fred Segal in West Hollywood, Calif.), and an unrabbity black-tipped white fur ($90 at Bombalulu on West 10th Street). title: The Year in Boxes, From Folk to the Four Tops
description: The compilers of this year's crop of compact disc boxed sets must have been humming ''All of Me.'' Instead of sifting through the recordings of musicians both revered and half-remembered, a number of boxed sets simply reprocess an entire label's catalog, plus outtakes, for performers as disparate as Billie Holiday, Joy Division, Simon and Garfunkel and the Grateful Dead. While collectors and completists revel in the profusion, casual listeners may hold back, waiting for the more selective and affordable best-ofs and greatest-hits collections that are bound to follow in a year or two. At the same time, other archivists are still trying to survey entire genres and repertories. One unexpected side effect of increasing consolidation among recording conglomerates is that boxed-set compilers can choose from more labels' rosters.

title: 'The Pickup'
description: Clustered predators round a kill. It's a small car with a young woman inside it. The battery has failed and taxis, cars, minibuses, vans, motorcycles butt and challenge one another, reproach and curse her, a traffic mob mounting its own confusion. Get going. Stupid bloody woman. Idikazana lomlungu, le! She throws up hands, palms open, in surrender. They continue to jostle and blare their impatience. She gets out of her car and faces them. One of the unemployed black men who beg by waving vehicles into parking bays sidles his way deftly through fenders, signals with his head -- Oka-ay, Oka-ay go inside, go! -- and mimes control of the steering wheel. Another like him appears, and they push her and her car into a loading bay. The street hustles on. They stand, looking musingly beyond her while she fumbles for her purse. An expert's quick glance at what she has put in his hand assures the street boss that it is more than adequate. She doesn't know how to thank them enough, etc. He hitches his body to get the money stowed in trousers cut to fit somebody else and smiles with his attention on the lookout for the next vehicle seeking a place to park. A woman wearing a towel as a shawl, enthroned on a fruit-box before her stock of hair combs, razor blades, pumice stones, woollen caps and headache powders, yells out to him what must be a teasing remark in a language the young woman doesn't understand.

title: 'Limbo'
description: Ihave moved eleven times in the sixteen years since leaving home, a word that to me will always mean southeastern Wisconsin, and the little town where I was raised, and my grandmother's one-hundred-acre farm seven miles to the north. At thirty-six, wading through the shallows of middle age, I have been permanently shaped -- and am still held fast -- by landscapes that exist in memory alone, though this makes them no less real when they come to me in dreams, when fragments are triggered by a random fact or phrase. Here is my body's lost exuberance. Here is my Catholic faith, that Gothic cathedral, that haunted house. Here are the straight highways, the crops and their seasons, the blue haze of Lake Michigan: wide open space beneath a close sky.

title: Meredith Lynn Whalen: Cruising Between Dreams
description: Meredith Lynn Whalen wanted to be a successful portfolio manager and then the owner of a horse farm in Kentucky. And between those goals, she planned to cram in a lot of travel, including many cruises.

title: Certainly a Recession, but an Odd One
description: RESTAURANTS from Southport to Vernon to West Hartford are crowded; some manufacturers are reporting growing profits and are considering hiring more workers; housing permits are up, and defense contractors are saying they expect to have a good year in 2002.

title: Steep Rise in Gun Sales Reflects Post-Attack Fears
description: Gun and ammunition sales across the country have risen sharply since Sept. 11 as more Americans take what many consider to be the most personal step toward feeling safer: arming themselves.

title: James P. O'Brien Jr.: He Was 'Totally Normal'
description: or the seven years I've known him, we've basically done nothing but be at home together," Lisanne MacKenzie said of James P. O'Brien Jr. "There were two children in the house, babies when he moved in, and we live really modestly in a three-room apartment. We don't have a country house, he doesn't golf, he was totally normal: come home from work, hang out in the house, do nothing, watch TV, hang out with the kids on the weekend."

title: DataBank; Breaking the Benchmarks, in Reverse
description: Stocks slipped back below some benchmark numbers this week, leaving investors to ponder whether the market in general, and the technology sector in particular, had come too far too fast.

title: An Evolving Idea
description: WHAT EVOLUTION IS

title: T-Shirt Philosophizing
description: Elaborating on the famous ''I NY'' logo from the 70's, SWAK & Company's ''I am NY'' T-shirt provides the next emotional step.

description: WILDMAN-Dorothy K. Passed away December 14. Wife of the late Dr. C.J. Wildman. Beloved mother of Judith and Kenneth, Joseph and Margot. Cherished grandmother of Sarah, Rebecca, Elana, Shira and Aviva. Adored sister of Helen Weiss. Devoted to philanthropy and pursuit of higher knowledge. A pillar of her community. Contributions in her name to the Pittsfield Chapter of Hadassah. 235 East St, Pittsfield, MA 01201.

description: HALL-Stephen, D.D.S. Rest in peace, dear friend. You are at the top of the mountain. Sara, Howard, Jon and Peter

title: Arafat Aide Says Israel Is Preventing A Crackdown
description: The chief of Palestinian security forces in the West Bank said today that Israeli military strikes had made it impossible for him to crack down on militants, even as another Israeli raid resulted in more arrests and the deaths of four Palestinians, one of them age 11.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WILSON, MARVIN (BUDDY)
description: WILSON-Marvin (Buddy). December 16, 1996. My dear and gentle heart. Not a day goes by.

title: War, Without Any Answers
description: A WAR movie may or may not succeed as an entertainment vehicle, but it almost always serves the purpose of telling us how we're feeling -- or ought to feel -- about war itself: proud, sorrowful, ashamed, angry, resolute. The films usually are part of the times that produce them.

title: Name That Tuning
description: TEMPERAMENT

title: Show Us the Money
description: It must gall her a little -- to come begging at the door of a colleague who once articulated the possibility, or maybe really the wish, that lightning would strike her before she took her seat in the United States Senate, sparing Republicans her dread company. But right now, Hillary Clinton needs Trent Lott. She needs him and any other senator who can be made to rain dollars upon New York, which is thirsty for them like almost never before. So she walks with a hopeful, beseeching smile into Lott's private conference room and takes a seat next to his, although not too close.

title: JoAnn Tabeek: Tough Cookie, Soft Heart
description: JoAnn Tabeek worked in the World Trade Center for more than 20 years, always for Cantor Fitzgerald. "She was dedicated to her job," said Vincent Milotta, Ms. Tabeek's fiance. "But she wanted to get out and retire in three years. We had already gone to Florida to look around for a place."

title: A Mediterranean Diamond in the Rough
description: THERE'S a pro in the kitchen and amateurs in the dining room at the Delphini Restaurant in Deer Park. There also might well be confusion among diners about this new Mediterranean storefront at 1844 Deer Park Avenue (631-586-7750). It is the fourth Turkish-owned eating place to open on this site within a relatively short period (the others were Ephesus, Kebabi Musiki and the Turkish Palace).

title: Luxury in Hard Times
description: Having read Hirschberg's article on Tom Ford and the fashion industry, I understand now, more than ever, just how insignificant and ridiculous $2,500 puffy shirts are.

title: Cheer Makes a Comeback
description: FOR obvious reasons, this has not been a great season for eccentrics, socially or sartorially.

title: EDUCATION BILL COMPROMISE
description: A House-Senate conference agreed on a major education bill that sharply increases aid to schools with large numbers of students in poverty. The House then passed the bill, a major priority for President Bush, and sent it to the Senate where passage Tuesday seems assured. The measure also provides for annual reading and math tests for grades three through eight, so that failing schools can be identified and their students allowed to transfer to other public schools or get free tutoring. Adam Clymer

title: Well Planned
description: To the Editor:

title: Scout Teams, Burger Runs and Even an Occasional Game
description: The opportunities for a seventh-round draft pick to prove himself in the National Football League are as rare as precious gems. Cincinnati wide receiver Touraj Houshmandzadeh, who Bengals coaches think has potential nearly as vast as his name, understands this well.

title: Stefanie Krasnow, Daniel Kaufman
description: Stefanie Gail Krasnow, a daughter of Jamie Krasnow of Charlestown, Mass., and William Krasnow of Newport, R.I., was married last evening to Daniel Andrew Kaufman, a son of Linda and Andrew Kaufman of Cambridge, Mass. Judge Rudolph Kass, who is retired from the Massachusetts Appeals Court in Boston, officiated at the Harvard University Faculty Club in Cambridge.

title: New Weapon in Discount Warehouse Wars
description: A SANDWICH sign heralding what may be the area's cheapest gasoline lured a steady stream of bargain-hunting drivers the other day to a recently opened gas station at the far end of Daniel Street, a dead-end road off Route 110.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, MILTON
description: CHASIN-Milton. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the brother of our devoted member, Aaron Chasin. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein President Chaim Edelstein

title: The World According to Powell
description: It is always difficult to critique a man you respect, but having served in combat as a marine, both in Vietnam and the gulf war, I have sadly reached this conclusion with regard to Secretary Powell: good man, timid general; linear-thinking company man, always with a company plan. And, the crazy paradox of it all: if Paul Wolfowitz had worn the general's stars and Powell the statesmen's suit during the gulf war and beyond, we just may have precluded the Sept. 11 debacle. Great wartime leadership takes more than being the world's most popular man. When we need George Patton, we get Ike.

title: OPINION; Nassau G.O.P.: Wait Till Next Year
description: THE New York Yankees and the Nassau County Republican Committee have learned some tough lessons this autumn. We both learned that a history of hard work and unparalleled success doesn't necessarily get you a World Series ring. We learned that if you drift from the fundamentals you are vulnerable to the opposing team. And we learned that when you've been the major league leader for so long there are those who will seek to tear your reputation down simply because -- for once -- you didn't win.

title: Kathryn Sillman, Ray Lewis
description: Kathryn Sillman, the daughter of Dr. Jane Seligson Sillman and Dr. Frederick Holden Sillman of Cambridge, Mass., was married last evening to Raphael Lewis, the son of Vivian and Paul Lewis of Manhattan. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor: I am responding to ''New Year's in Madrid'' (Q & A, Dec. 2). My son and I often took overseas trips during our New Year breaks. In 1997, at the Puerta del Sol in Madrid, we had our only bad New Year's Eve experience.

title: For Victims' Kin, Grief in the Holiday Glitter
description: Thanksgiving was hard enough. And now there are the dozens of little rituals that make up a Christmas, each one a sugared plum with a bitter center.

title: Christopher Slattery: The Man Behind the Fun
description: Fog cloaked the treacherous Colorado slope; a half-dozen skiers couldn't see past their ski tips. Then, through the soup, came a rhythmic clattering: Christopher Slattery, an expert skier, was banging his poles, leading them to safety.

title: Death and Checkbooks
description: THE mind has a hard time dealing with its own nonexistence. Yet each day, Suzanne S. Klein must weave nonexistence into a sales pitch. Mrs. Klein is in charge of securing planned gifts for Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. It is her job to persuade people to earmark money that the school can use after they die. Mrs. Klein, who is 32, said that even friends and family flinch at her work.

title: Love the Service Around Here
description: Like Robert Berschinski an Ivy League member of the R.O.T.C., I am surprised how little the average person knows about the United States military.

title: 2 TRIALS FOR MILOSEVIC
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, will face two trials, not one, at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Three tribunal judges decided that the first, to start Feb. 12, would focus on Kosovo. The second will deal with earlier wars in Bosnia and Croatia. A third indictment, which relates to Bosnia and includes charges of genocide, was read into a loudspeaker trained directly on Mr. Milosevic, who defies the tribunal's authority. Marlise Simons

title: Those Online Bargains Aren't Always Bargains
description: To tempt shoppers to buy, many online merchants have been offering free delivery and other shipping promotions. But the deals, it seems, won't necessarily save you money.

title: Questions For Sellers Of Homes
description: LEGISLATION that will require sellers to provide potential buyers with detailed information about residential properties was signed into law last month by Gov. George E. Pataki. The Property Condition Disclosure Act, an amendment to the state's real property law, applies to one- to four-family residences but not to co-ops, condominiums, raw land and new construction. It will take effect on March 1, 2002.

title: Health Care: The Sound and the Fury
description: DURING the year and a half that I have been writing a column about the economics of health care, I have received e-mail messages from readers calling me shortsighted, hopelessly antimanaged care, maddeningly pro-managed care and just plain dumb.

title: JERSEY CITY POWERHOUSE
description: The Powerhouse, the 1906 structure along the Jersey City waterfront, was named to the National Register of Historic Places last week. The designation, which was sought by the Jersey City Landmarks Conservancy, provides protection to the building, which was a coal-burning plant that generated electricity for the trans-Hudson railway now known as PATH. Its joint owners, the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, had contemplated demolishing the building. But its very might -- 28-inch-thick walls and a implacable steel framework -- helped preserve the brick structure by making its demolition a daunting project in itself. Steve Strunsky

title: Filling a Stage With Hype (and Soap)
description: MOST of us have probably never heard of the 1914 play, ''It Pays to Advertise,'' by Roi Cooper Megrue and Walter Hackett, in performance at Yale Repertory Theater. This is a revival so rare, it may well be the only professional one of our lives. Consistent with the play's theme, say that if there has been a production of it in the last six decades, it was not well promoted.

title: The World: Sharon vs. Arafat; Lebanon Revisited
description: BY default or design, Israelis and Palestinians are on the verge of recreating on Jerusalem's doorstep the chaos of their conflict in Lebanon.

title: Managing Danger Responsibly: How Much Do You Tell?
description: DURING times of uncertainty, company management has the responsibility, from a business and ethical standpoint, to manage that uncertainty.

title: A Lifetime of Paintings On an Imposing Scale
description: THE main gallery at the Neuberger Museum of Art here is a huge box, and it can easily swallow up a show. But it's an ideal space when the exhibition consists of work that is of commanding scale itself. Such is the case with the 14 paintings by Grace Hartigan now on view. They go around the room in chronological order, and the major stages of Ms. Hartigan's long career are seen very clearly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDER, ALYCE SCHERZER
description: FELDER-Alyce Scherzer. On December 12, 2001 in San Diego. Wife of the late Karl Felder and the late Michael Scherzer. Mother of Larry, Don and Judie Stuart. Motherin-law of Carole, Toni and David Stuart. Grandmother of Mike, Ian, Erica & Mark Land, and Gabrielle. Beloved teacher and counselor to many. She was active in the Jewish communities of Long Island and San Diego. She enriched all of our lives and for this we are grateful. We will miss her. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the charity of your choice.

title: Duty-Free Shopping
description: I have bought three pairs of jeans since Sept. 11 in Lower Manhattan. I don't mean to sound unpatriotic, but I bought them because they make my bottom look good. Not because they're all-American or utilitarian or because ''boot cut'' and ''rivet'' sound kind of butch-military appropriate. Certain acts -- for starters, shopping, sex, leaving work early to see a dumb movie, ordering mashed potatoes -- are most enjoyable when not premeditated or endorsed by anyone else, when you can believe that the only economy you're affecting is yours and when neither the mayor nor the president is involved.

title: When the Combat Ends, Another Struggle Looms
description: In a matter of days, Afghan Kalashnikovs and American jets could largely fall silent here, giving way to an extraordinarily intricate political dance involving scores of tribes, parties, warlords, neighboring nations and more distant powers. The process of winning the peace in Afghanistan will begin.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about companies whose complex financial reports force investors to rely heavily on their managements' word misstated the name of one such business, which has moved rapidly into energy trading. It is the El Paso Corporation; El Paso Electric is an unrelated utility.

title: Artists of Church Installation Welcome the Controversy
description: RACISM. Gun violence. Police brutality. The work of the artists Bradley McCallum and Jacqueline Tarry charges headlong into provocative territory. That their public art projects in Connecticut and elsewhere ignite response is perhaps typical of contemporary artists.

title: Jets Audio
description: Postgame audio from the Jets vs. the Cincinnati Bengals provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: And on the 2,555th Day, There Were Bass
description: In the Bible, good and bad fortune frequently occur in seven-year cycles. On Long Island, apparently, so do the blueback herring and the enormous striped bass that feed on them.

title: Some Call Them Heroes, Others Italian Shlubs
description: Two legislators are trying to come up with an offer you can't refuse. In political parlance, they want to pass a law. The measure, introduced by two Republican senators, Anthony Bucco of Morris County and Lou Kosco from Bergen County, would earmark $350,000 in state funds to establish a Commission on Italians and Americans of Italian Heritage Culture and Education.

Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Thursday, January 17, 2002 at 4 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the City Bar Fund of the Association of The Bar of the City of New York, 42 W. 44 St, NY, NY 10036.

description: The Big Menorah

title: Navy Missile Defense Plan Is Canceled by the Pentagon
description: The Pentagon has canceled a Navy program intended to shoot down short-range ballistic missiles, a decision that military officials said today was the first in a series of changes that the Bush administration is likely to make in its missile defense programs.

title: The One Who Stayed
description: Before Afghanistan arrived in the American consciousness and before Special Forces or nation-building experts arrived in Afghanistan, the representatives of several dozen nongovernmental aid groups from around the world were on the ground working with people in need. But after Sept. 11, when the political situation became too dangerous, the aid groups pulled their international staff out of the country.

title: Standing Still
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Makes Point; Crosses Picket Line
description: A BASKETBALL coach's toughest decisions usually revolve around which players to start, whether to leave the star in when he is in foul trouble and how to defend against the opposition's big scorer.

title: Little Neck, Queens, Still Misses Its Supermarket . . .
description: Mary Jane Himes needed some onions for the chicken franaise she was whipping up the other night. For a split second, she figured she could pop down to the Grand Union supermarket at Northern Boulevard and Marathon Parkway, a block from her home.

title: A Fat, Bearded Man in a Red Suit? No, Not That One
description: IT arrived one day in the fall of the Verdi year like an early Christmas, down to the fat red-clad, white-whiskered gentleman twinkling on the cover. Of all the new Verdi releases of 2001 -- the Requiem recordings and aria compilations, the Nikolaus Harnoncourt ''Aida'' on Teldec and the praiseworthy ''Aroldo'' and ''Alzira'' on Philips -- this was the one that elicited a yelp of excitement: Claudio Abbado's ''Falstaff'' on Deutsche Grammophon.

title: Suozzi Assembles His Advisory Panels
description: PREPARING to take over Nassau County government on Jan. 1, the county executive-elect, Thomas R. Suozzi, has assembled advisory panels that include two former New York City police commissioners, the deans of two law schools, the co-owners of the New York Mets and other prominent business and civic leaders.

title: At the Met: A Wolf, a Lamb and an Old Song
description: OUR drama takes place in the Metropolitan Opera House. The dcor is golden and plush red. The show is Verdi's ''Traviata.'' Above, in the balcony, young people kiss. Below, near the orchestra, old people complain.

title: Months Pass; We Still Search, and Ache
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, DAVID MALCOLM
description: BRUSH-David Malcolm, December 10, 2001. Memorial service at First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, CT, 178 Oenoke Ridge Rd, December 20, 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either the David Brush Memorial Fund, Steppingstones Museum for Children, Mathew's Park, 303 West Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06850, or the Waveny Care Center, 3 Farm Road, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: A Single-Minded Sailor Conquers the Sea Solo
description: When the Russian freighter came alongside to pluck him from his sinking boat last February in a severe gale off South Africa, the biggest concern of the single-handed sailor David Clark, 77, was getting his West Highland terrier, Mickey, to safety.

title: 'Heidegger's Children'
description: The protagonists of Heidegger's Children -- Hannah Arendt, Hans Jonas, Karl Löwith, and Herbert Marc -- use -- were non-Jewish Jews who thought of themselves as proverbial "Germans of Jewish origin." As philosophically trained intellectuals, they expected to find salvation and meaning not in the traditions of Jewish cultural belonging but in the hallowed Germanic ideals of Geist and Bildung . All four were trained by Germany's greatest philosopher, Martin Heidegger. Although Heidegger was virtually unpublished until the landmark appearance of Being and Time in 1927, his talents as a lecturer and teacher had already gained him considerable renown.

title: Nobuhiro Hayatsu: Each City an Adventure
description: In a world of the reserved and the circumspect -- Japanese banking -- Nobuhiro Hayatsu stood out: he was outgoing, sunny, loquacious. He embraced foreign assignments as a vice president of Chuo Mitsui Trust and Banking Company with alacrity, for each tour of duty was a chance to make even more friends, party in a new town. At 36, Mr. Hayatsu had already lived and worked in Taiwan, Tokyo, London, Hong Kong and, as of this spring, New York City.

title: BENEFITS
description: 'Here's Love' for Playwrights

title: Ideas & Trends: The Banality of Terror; Dreams of Holy War Over a Quiet Evening
description: IT looks so ordinary. Men are sitting in a small white room on the floor near some gray, flowered throw pillows. They are laughing, drinking, eating with their hands, adjusting their turbans. A visitor identified in the transcript as a sheik sits next to Osama bin Laden. He exclaims what a nice pad Mr. bin Laden has, how clean and comfortable the guest quarters are.

title: A Soothing Jaunt in Rugged Arizona
description: TWO things I truly appreciate about the southeastern corner of Arizona: It's not crowded and it's not cute. I can get out of town -- any town -- with ease, and when I do, the Great Outdoors is open, unpredictable, dispassionate. I feel free.

title: A Neighborhood Takes to Heart A Watchtower Built for War
description: As architecture, the 50-foot concrete watchtower near Beach 216th Street and Palmer Drive is unremarkable. But as an image, the tower has what advertisers would call total market penetration. You see it on local T-shirts, restaurant menus, lightpole banners and even Christmas tree ornaments.

title: Afghan Drought Inflicts Its Own Misery
description: The monumental task of rebuilding Afghanistan after the war has been made far more difficult, experts say, by a problem that would have existed even without the Taliban and Osama bin Laden: the drought that has gripped the country and much of southwestern Asia for three years.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: City Revival May Imperil Stone Pony
description: LESS than two years after the Stone Pony, the New Jersey shore's most famous rock and roll club, survived a temporary closure, it may again be in jeopardy.

title: Donna Marie Giordano: Family Friends
description: Donna Marie Giordano liked to go to Bon Jovi concerts with her son, Michael. "Bon Jovi was her second love," he said. But the Giordanos' common interests went beyond music. "We would drive to the mountains and go hiking. Or go out to dinner," Mr. Giordano said. "We did everything together. We were more like brother and sister."

Such luxurious fur is more appealing in smaller doses -- around a collar, down a seam, dangling as a pompom. At Goldin Feldman Furs on West 30th Street, denim jeans by Cassin have rabbit, sable or mink detailing around the hem and up the calf (bottom right; $350 to $2,000).

description: The Internet has become an important tool for many job seekers -- with a few clicks on their PC's they can fire off rsums to dozens of potential employers. But these days, they may not always receive a timely reply.

title: For Reality Stars, the Reality of a One-Time Payment
description: THE very notion of the famously dysfunctional casts of ''The Real World'' working together will surprise anyone who has watched the MTV show. In the last decade, each season's cast members have fought over everything from leaving the toilet seat up to the meaning of rape. But now many of the show's alumni have laid their differences aside to take up a common cause: more money and better contracts.

title: Overcoming the Handicap Of Starting at the Top
description: IF a movie is ever made about the karmic consequences of blowing your big chance in Hollywood, James Mangold would be an ideal person to write and direct. But the ending, at least if he wrote it today, would be oddly triumphant.

title: Where Churchill Waged War, Underground
description: THE Cabinet War Rooms on St. James's Park and Horse Guards Road in London were ready for use on Aug. 27, 1939, exactly a week before the German invasion of Poland and Britain's declaration of war. There, 10 feet underground in the basement of the Office of Works building, the prime minister and his staff, his military strategists, were to work in relative safety for the next six years. Here the leadership -- Winston Churchill, Clement Atlee, Gen. Sir Hastings Ismay and Sir Edward Bridges, Anthony Eden, Lord Beaverbrook and others -- were to plan both attack and retreat, talk to President Franklin Roosevelt on the phone, and put tacks into maps that covered the walls to chart the movements of troops and supply convoys across ocean and land.

title: Rangers Unsound
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Afghans Looking Homeward From Exile With Wary Eyes
description: The streets of Islamabad's Afghan quarter bustle with the sights and smells of Kabul. Freshly slaughtered sheep hang on hooks outside butcher shops and sidewalk chefs prepare fried cauliflower and lamb to break the Ramadan fast. Most people pausing over the gold bangles and bolts of cloth are Afghans, and most of them have one eye turned toward home now that the promise of peace has arrived there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORZIO, LINDA
description: PORZIO-Linda. Age 51. Passed away on December 14, 2001 after a long and courageous battle with Multiple Sclerosis. Linda touched and loved everyone with whom she came in contact and she bore her illness without complaint. She is survived by her husband Richard. Service Friday, December 21, 11AM at St. John the Martyr RC Church, 250 East 72nd Street, NYC.

title: Anthrax Shot Considered For Civilians
description: The government is considering making the anthrax vaccine that is now used by the military available to postal workers and others at high risk of exposure to the deadly bacteria, federal health officials said today.

title: Thomas P. DeAngelis: In the Thick of Things
description: Five years ago, when Thomas P. DeAngelis was promoted to battalion chief in the New York City Fire Department, his wife, Patty, told him: "You've been running into burning buildings for 22 years. But you're a battalion chief now, so you won't have to do that anymore."

title: Al Qaeda's Last Legs, Preparing for Peace, Holiday Shadows
description: The war in Afghanistan moved inexorably toward a climax. American warplanes bombed the ridge positions and cave and tunnel hideouts of Al Qaeda's remnant forces in the eastern mountains around Tora Bora, and on the ground the Afghan militia was closing in on what may be Osama bin Laden's last redoubt.

title: Prelude to Kiss
description: The only thing overvalued is Gene Simmons's opinions of everything, including himself. Of course, music was never the point with Kiss. One has to be able to play music for it to be the point. This guy is pure show business in the worst sense of the term.

title: Let It Spray, Let It Spray
description: New Yorkers who want Christmas trees that make a statement are opting for flocked trees -- pines or firs coated with artificial snow. Retro, kitschy and peculiarly American, flocked trees have infiltrated such bastions of traditionalism as the St. Regis Hotel; tony floral designers like Castle & Pierpont and Avi Adler are spraying trees, wreaths and greens for both corporate and private customers.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION; Does That Come With Whitewalls?
description: How close did postwar America's auto industry come to building a fallout shelter on wheels? Or a family car with a retractable patio? According to THE LAST DREAM-O-RAMA: The Cars Detroit Forgot to Build, 1950-1960 (Crown, $25), not close enough. The dream-car caricatures in Bruce McCall's wry, satirical glimpse at 50's style symbolize the ''fatuousness, bad taste and shameless excess'' that marked the era. McCall, the author of ''Zany Afternoons'' and a frequent contributor to The New Yorker, writes, ''You can read a culture in its cars, and judging by the cars of that time, American culture was in a state.'' His imaginary cars -- elongated, brightly colored assemblages of chrome, vinyl and whitewalls -- lampoon everything from popular culture to geopolitics. The Vegastar StripStreak Headliner Deluxe boasts a slot-machine gearshift and a speedometer that shows three cherries when the car hits 100 miles per hour; the Bossmobile Gal Friday Execustreak comes complete with an office, a secretary at the wheel and Scotch bottles stashed in a desk drawer; the Nixoneer Squelchoramic RN, one of McCall's finest contraptions, demonstrates to Khrushchev and the Soviets the superiority of American engineering (the car sports an assortment of ''electric domestic labor-saving devices''). McCall provides each car with a rationale behind its design and its ultimate demise. The book closes with a Naming Guide (name your own dream car in seconds!) and a brief survey of dream cars from around the world. The 1950's have weathered as many criticisms as rosy retrospectives, but McCall's entertaining surrealism finds a novel point of entry. ''The Last Dream-O-Rama'' parodies the very ''haze of fond nostalgia'' it is sure to evoke. Ihsan Taylor
