title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-16-01; Closet-Case Studies
description: Since Sept. 11, many Americans have been trying to make sense of what led Mohamed Atta and his accomplices to launch their deadly strikes against the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Readers and writers have been digging into everything from the history of Islam to the stalled pace of globalization in the Middle East. But amid the competing theories, one has proved particularly alluring. It begins, sotto voce, with the spicy details of Atta's upbringing: how he sat on his mother's lap until college, how his father advised him, ''Toughen up, boy!'' and accused his wife of raising their son ''as a girl.'' It is reinforced by Atta family photos: one of young Mohamed, slender arms snaking around his sister, or in another, languid cheek obliging his mother, delicate frame at anxious remove from his father.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Bald Eagles Thriving
description: Bald eagles, which almost disappeared in New Jersey in the 1980's, are now thriving. A record 31 pairs of bald eagles have nested in New Jersey this year, according to a report released last week by the state's Endangered and Nongame Species Program. State biologists increased the population by hand-raising 60 chicks from Manitoba, Canada, in a project that ended in 1990. Many of the New Jersey nests are clustered around the Delaware Bay shore in Cumberland and Salem Counties. Eagles almost disappeared because the pesticide DDT thinned their eggs.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Dec. 5 about helicopters at a Marine base in Afganistan misidentified several of them, and a correction in this space last Monday also misstated a type. The twin-rotor helicopter on the ground at the left was a Marine Corps CH-46E Sea Knight; it was neither a CH-53 nor a Chinook, which is designated CH-47 and is the Army version of the Sea Knight. Only the craft at the right was a CH-53. While two of the craft in the air were correctly identified as Super Cobra attack helicopters, the third was a Huey UH-1.

The manager, Mark Yagalla, was a Philadelphia investment adviser who ran two hedge funds, Ashbury Capital Partners L.P. and Apex Investments. Prosecutors said Mr. Yagalla, who is charged with securities fraud, sent phony monthly accounts to clients representing false profits. He faces a fine of up to $1 million and 10 years in prison when he is sentenced on Feb. 14. An attorney for Mr. Yagalla declined to comment. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

A member of the New York and Washington, D.C., Bar Associations, Lou worked as a litigator in the areas of aviation law and international trade law. Information: (800) 845-5279 or www.vacationclub.com .

description: Forget the theories and watch the movement, especially when the dancers are dancing in the dark. That is often the best advice for looking at William Forsythe's brainy, off-center choreography, and it seemed at the heart of the lusty ovation Mr. Forsythe's Ballett Frankfurt received on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Three New York premieres were presented as part of the Next Wave festival.

title: Deal Bolsters Satellites as Cable TV Competitors

title: The Neediest Cases; After Sept. 11, Donors Feel a Greater Need to Give
description: Envelopes of all shapes and sizes are flooding Post Office Box 5193 as the 90th appeal by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund enters its seventh week and the holiday season reaches its height.

title: Week 14: Twists, Turns and a Holiday Gift for Lions Fans
description: CLEVELAND A near-riot broke out after an overturned call in the final minute helped give Jacksonville a 15-10 victory over the Browns. The game was halted by an official with 48 seconds remaining when fans, left, pelted the field with thousands of plastic bottles and debris. But while both teams were in the locker room, the N.F.L. commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, called the game supervisor and ordered him to have the final 48 seconds played. The Jaguars then ran out the clock.

title: This Time, North Carolina Men Win Title
description: The North Carolina men's soccer team has long lived in the shadow of the Tar Heels women's team, which has captured 16 of the 20 N.C.A.A. tournaments. But the men's program may gain some recognition after capturing its first national title with a 2-0 victory over Indiana today -- a week after the women's team lost in its championship game.

And so Edwards, with his team trailing the Bengals by 4 points, pulled quarterback Vinny Testaverde aside as the second half of today's game was about to begin and said something he has never said before: This game, Edwards told Testaverde, is on your shoulders.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Dec. 5 about helicopters at a Marine base in Afganistan misidentified several of them, and a correction in this space last Monday also misstated a type. The twin-rotor helicopter on the ground at the left was a Marine Corps CH-46E Sea Knight; it was neither a CH-53 nor a Chinook, which is designated CH-47 and is the Army version of the Sea Knight. Only the craft at the right was a CH-53. While two of the craft in the air were correctly identified as Super Cobra attack helicopters, the third was a Huey UH-1.

title: Butler and La Salle Surprise Seton Hall

La Salle was supposed to be another in a string of outclassed opponents for Seton Hall that would be handled with appropriate disdain, just like Rider, St. Peter's and Fairleigh Dickinson. It would be another unchallenging victory, a warm-up for the testing schedule ahead. But there was one problem, namely Rasual Butler.

title: Technology & Media; A Surge in Demand To Use Biometrics

title: International Business; Small-Scale Financing Takes Hold in Africa
description: N. Justin Chinyanta saw the outlines of an opportunity almost a decade ago. Africa's markets were opening up in a big way, and capitalists were looking to cash in. The big ones, especially from overseas, would find their own way, but the little, local ones could not go it alone. They would need financing and advice.

title: Hamm Named World's Top Female Player

title: Reforming Elections, a Year Later
description: Washington indirectly took notice of a painful anniversary last week. A year after the Supreme Court intervened to bring the 2000 presidential election to its messy conclusion, the House of Representatives passed a bill to overhaul the nation's flawed voting process. A key group of senators from both parties agreed the next day to embrace a stronger measure that is expected to be voted on in January. The President should ultimately sign a bill that more closely resembles the Senate's approach to ensure that the federal government adequately protects the integrity of national elections.

World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Successful Stock Issue
description: Shares in the Nomura Research Institute, a unit of the country's largest brokerage house, Nomura Holdings, jumped 28 percent on the first day of trading in Japan's largest public offering this year. Shares in Nomura Research, Japan's largest integrator of computer systems, hit 14,050 yen ($110) a share. The company raised 150 billion yen ($1.2 billion) in the share offering, topping an initial stock offering in July by McDonald's Japan. The surge came even though Nomura Research expects net income to decline 15.3 percent in the year to March 31, 2002. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Sees More Involvement for Russia in NATO
description: The Russian defense minister declared today that his nation's security was not threatened by President Bush's decision to withdraw from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, but he warned of a dangerous new arms race -- not of countries building more weapons, but of more countries scrapping arms-control treaties.

title: City Report Says the Economy Will Shrink 3.1% Next Year
description: New York City's economy will shrink next year for the first time since 1991, according to a report that was issued yesterday by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. The report predicts that the aftershocks of the attack on the World Trade Center will contribute to a net loss in jobs, a slowing of growth in wages and a sharp decline in the amount of money that the city will be able to collect in taxes in the next year.

title: Arts in America: It's Museum Time Down South; From Virginia to Louisiana, a Building Boom for Culture
description: On the shore of a shaded pond a few miles from the Gulf of Mexico construction machinery roars and screeches in a din that is now familiar across the southeastern United States.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Arrests In Killing
description: The police arrested five men who mortally wounded a senator from the governing party last week in what now appears to have been a botched robbery attempt. Sen. Dario Gmez of the Revolutionary Democratic Party was shot after he arrived at a friend's home, and there was speculation that he had been the target of drug dealers because he was co-author of a bill that mandated stiffer penalties for money laundering. But the men who were arrested said they had shot Mr. Gmez only to disable him during a robbery, the police said.

title: A Little Electric Car That Might; Gasless Vehicles Are Tested For Short Trips to Rail Stations
description: One morning next month, John Steward will get into his car, leave his house in White Plains and stop off at the Y.M.C.A. for a swim. Then he will drive to the Metro-North station and do a very strange thing.

title: Mullah Omar's Martyrdom Operation
description: LONDON -- Even as Osama bin Laden crowed over the success of the Sept. 11 attacks in the home video taped Nov. 9 and released last week, the Taliban's control of Afghanistan had begun to buckle, first in Mazar-i-Sharif on Nov. 7, then down through Kabul to the very foundation of Mullah Muhammad Omar's power in Kandahar.

title: The Big City; Myth or Not, This Bud's For America
description: NO matter what you may have heard, a truck driver delivering Budweiser beer on Sept. 11 did not walk into a convenience store and find two Arab clerks celebrating. Furthermore, the nonexistent truck driver did not wreak vengeance on the nonexistent Arabs.

title: Priest Will Not Face Charges In Handling of Church Funds
description: A Queens priest who was suspected of stealing almost $2 million from his parish will not face criminal charges, although a yearlong investigation uncovered a ''disturbing pattern of questionable financial transactions,'' prosecutors said yesterday.

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES RAISES PROFIT ESTIMATE
description: Mylan Laboratories increased its fiscal third-quarter profit projection on stronger-than-expected sales of generic versions of drugs like the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's anti-anxiety treatment BuSpar. Mylan, a leading maker of generic drugs, raised its forecast for the period, which ends Dec. 31, to 54 to 56 cents a share, up from an earlier forecast of 38 to 40 cents. Mylan, which is based in Pittsburgh, won regulatory clearance in March to begin marketing its version of BuSpar, which had $709 million in sales last year.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Expanded Rail Service
description: Rail commuters on the Shore Line East no longer have to change trains in New Haven to get to Bridgeport and Stamford, under a two-year experiment to expand rail service as a way of easing highway congestion. Yesterday was the first day of the service, made up of one morning westbound train and one evening train that heads back east, said Harry Harris, chief of rail operations in the State Department of Transportation. Eighty-nine people used the service yesterday morning, but officials expect that more will soon. The service will cost the state $1 million for the two years, Mr. Harris said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Theft At Saks Fifth Avenue
description: An estimated $250,000 worth of jewelry was stolen from Saks Fifth Avenue after the department store closed Sunday night, the police said yesterday. Investigators would not disclose the type of jewelry or how many pieces were taken. Employees discovered jewelry missing from a shattered display case when they returned to work yesterday morning, the police said. There was no sign of forced entry into the store, at 50th Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and investigators say they believe the thief may have hidden in the store after it closed. A surveillance tape showed a man breaking the glass display case, and investigators were trying to identify him. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: U.S. Holds Suspect With Ties To Group Linked to Terror Aid
description: A Muslim leader in Ann Arbor, Mich., who has connections to an international relief agency whose assets were recently frozen by the government on accusations of contributing to terrorist activity is being held on immigration charges, his family said today.

title: Producing a TV Spot Cost 3% Less in 2000

title: Republic New York Pleads Guilty to Securities Fraud

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Prices Increased
description: Samsung Electronics and Hynix Semiconductor, two of the world's leading producers of memory chips, raised prices of the 128-megabit dynamic random access chip 10 percent to 20 percent for the second time this month. The increase, another sign of gradual recovery of the semiconductor industry after a long period of falling prices, spurred an increase in share prices of European chip makers on European markets. Hynix, more than $8 billion in debt, is completing the first round of talks this week with Micron Technology, the second-ranking memory chip producer, for what Hynix executives have said will be a strategic alliance. description: After bearing the multibillion-dollar cost of the war in Afghanistan, the Bush administration is now questioning how much it will contribute to the United Nations reconstruction effort in that country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, DUNCAN J.
description: STEWART-Duncan J. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and colleague, Duncan. One of our first Board members, Duncan brought a rare combination of intelligence, humor, compassion, and generosity to this young organization at a time when we most needed these strengths. We are proud that he joined us in our work. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Duncan's family. Catherine J. Douglass Executive Director, and the Board of Directors Past and Present of inMotion (formerly Network for Women's Services)

title: New Wave of the Homeless Floods Cities' Shelters
description: With unemployment rising and housing costs still high, cities around the country are experiencing a new and sudden wave of homelessness. Shelters are overflowing, and more people this year are sleeping on floors in dingy social service centers, living in cars or spending nights on the streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JAMES G.
description: KELLY-James G. On December 15, 2001. Native of County Offaly, Ireland. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of James Jr and Stephen Kelly and Margaret Lojpersberger. Dear brother of Elizabeth Edmondson. Beloved grandfather of Katie Lovinger. Friends may call at the Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx on Tuesday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, December 19 in St. Margaret of Cortona Church, 6000 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Incarnation School are requested.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Labor Deal At Hyundai
description: Hyundai Motor has reached an agreement with its workers after three weeks of daily walkouts ranging from two to four hours. A spokesman for the workers, affiliated with the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, said the company had agreed on hefty bonuses as well as wage increases. The union settled on a compromise after demanding that workers receive 30 percent of this year's profits, expected to reach nearly $1 billion. The company said it lost $577 million in sales during the strike. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: American Aide Meets Chinese on U.S. Pullout From ABM Pact
description: A senior United States State Department official met with Chinese counterparts here over the last two days in what was described by the Americans as an effort to explain President Bush's recent decision to pull out of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas fell as new forecasts showed milder-than-expected weather in the Midwest. In New York, natural gas for January delivery fell 16 cents, or 5.6 percent, to $2.686 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about security drills at nuclear power plants omitted part of a Web address in some copies for The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, which published an article about plant security. Its site is www.thebulletin.org.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Citizens Ends Purchase Plans
description: Citizens Communications, which sells telephone service in 24 states, has ended talks with Verizon Communications to buy about 63,000 phone lines in Arizona and California for $223 million. Citizens, which agreed to buy the lines in 1999, ended the deal because it could not obtain approval to operate the lines in California and had not set a closing date for the acquisition, the company's treasurer, Don Armour, said.

title: One War, Differing Aims
description: TORA BORA, Afghanistan, Dec. 17  The United States' heavy dependence on proxy forces in the Afghan war has been a calculated decision that has generally worked well. But as the war enters its final phase, the limitations of this policy also seem clear.

title: Chaney's Gripe Session Turns Into a Meeting
description: It has been a tumultuous 10 days for Don Chaney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIMAN, BETTY ANN
description: LEIMAN-Betty Ann. The Committee on Entertainment of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York extends its sincere sympathy to Eugene A. Leiman, a founding member, on the death of his wife Betty Ann. Martha Stine, Secretary Robert D. Lippmann, Chair

title: Climate Change: The Signs Are There
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suharto In Hospital
description: Former President Suharto, 80, collapsed during a celebration marking the end of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan. A doctor said he was suffering from pneumonia and breathing problems. Mr. Suharto has a history of stroke and heart problems. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Senate Passes Education Bill, in Major Shift for Public Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Senate today completed the biggest shift in decades in federal education policy, overwhelmingly approving legislation to shift the focus of aid to public schools with large numbers of poor children. The measure also mandates annual tests to measure student performance.

title: Slutskaya Focuses on Skating, Not a Medal
description: Giuseppe Arena rarely cracks a smile when he is working with a skater. An Italian ballet dancer who has performed with Mikhail Baryshnikov and is now a figure skating choreographer, Arena is impressed with nothing less than perfection. Away from the ice rinks, he is a charming man, but he doesn't want his skaters to see that side of him.

title: Footlights
description: Otherness

title: Converting Stereotypes Into Virtue
description: ''Neil's Garden,'' a new two-hander at the Rattlestick Theater, takes on the subject of late-in-life reckoning in the hanky-wringing tradition of ''The Gin Game'' and ''Driving Miss Daisy.'' It achieves some of the same sentimental appeal, and it claims its own niche in the genre because the two characters are gay men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSON, GERT
description: ELSON-Gert. Of East Meadow, N.Y. on December 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Bern for 62 years. Loving mother of Roger and Sheryl, Robert and Robin, and Richard. Devoted sister of Vivian and Abe, Gloria and David. Cherished Grandma of Brooke and Duane, Wendy and Russell, Sarab, Zach, Avtar and Oliver. Adored aunt of Barry and Ronnie, Danny, Janet, Glenn and Debbie, and all their children. She was loved by all who knew her.

title: Britain to Send Up to 1,500 for Security Force
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that Britain would contribute up to 1,500 troops to an international peacekeeping force it has agreed to head up in Afghanistan.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Offers Music Service
description: Yahoo started a music service yesterday, offering Internet users free access to thousands of music videos and to online radio content. The company hopes to support the service through advertising, sponsorships and retail partnerships. The offering is based on a service created by Launch.com, a music company in Santa Monica, Calif., acquired earlier this year by Yahoo for $12 million. In calling the service ''Launch, Your Yahoo Music Experience,'' Yahoo departed from its usual strategy. Typically, a Yahoo acquisition is given a Yahoo brand name. The company said it made an exception because Launch already had strong name recognition. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: In Production of Stem Cells, Many Featured Actors but Few Stars
description: Stem cell biology is a growing field with many players. To the public, the best known is probably Dr. James A. Thomson of the University of Wisconsin who, as the first person to isolate human embryonic stem cells, has cut a prominent profile in the news media and seems to bestride the field like a colossus.

title: President Has Lesions Taken Off His Face
description: President Bush had four benign skin lesions removed from his face on Friday, the White House announced today. Two of the lesions, actinic keratoses, can become cancerous if left untreated.

title: Unsure About Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining the Undefinable: Being Alive
description: Much as people may wish these days for the comforts of a few black and white distinctions -- between good and evil, democracy and tyranny, friends and fiends -- our restless color wheel of a world refuses to comply. And that law of equivocation and qualification, scientists say, extends down to the most basic distinction of all: whether something is alive or not.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: 2 Rival Legal Teams for '20th Hijacker' Case
description: As he watched the smoke curl above the Pentagon on Sept. 11 from the window of an office building a few miles away, Frank W. Dunham Jr., the federal public defender for the eastern half of Virginia, figured the attack might change his life.

title: WITH SEATS EMPTY, AIRLINES CUT FARES TO BARGAIN LEVELS
description: Airlines desperate to fill seats in the economic downturn that deepened after Sept. 11 are cutting some fares to levels not seen in years.

title: 400 Demolition Experts Will Try to Harvest Afghanistan's Field of Mines
description: Operations to clear hidden explosives from the soil and roads of northern Afghanistan, one of the world's most heavily mined areas, are scheduled to resume on Wednesday with the arrival of more than 400 demolition specialists in several provinces.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Producing a TV Spot Cost 3% Less in 2000
description: The average cost of producing a 30-second national television spot decreased 3 percent from 1999 to 2000, according to an annual survey by the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York.

title: GLOSSARY
description: The debate over whether the government should finance research on embryonic stem cells has forced politicians and the public to grapple with the arcane language of cell biology. Here are some terms, as gleaned from reports by the National Institutes of Health and other sources.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, PETER S.
description: KAHN-Peter S. Longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY, died December 14, 2001 in New Milford, CT at the home of his daughter, Alexandra McBrian. At his side, was his loving wife of 61 years, Lida Huelsman Kahn. He is survived by his wife Lida, his sister, Yereth Knowles of Alexandria, VA, and his 3 children, Alexandra McBrien of New Milford, CT, Patrina Ulmer of Eugene, OR, and Gretchen Espe of DeMoines, IA, as well as his six wonderful grandchildren.

title: Church Lawsuit Tries to Stop Police From Ejecting Homeless
description: The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church went to federal court yesterday to stop the police from enforcing a new policy of ejecting homeless people from its property amid some of the most expensive stores and hotels in the city.

title: Bonanza or Bust? Czech Sale Of Privatized Assets Fizzles
description: The Czech government's plans for a multibillion-dollar privatization bonanza ended in confusion and recrimination today. The country's electricity monopoly was left unsold, questions were raised about a winning bid for a petrochemical conglomerate, and analysts worried that a sudden inflow of capital to buy privatized assets would push the Czech currency up sharply and punish struggling exporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ANGELO, PETER
description: D'ANGELO-Peter. The Board of Governors and members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our retired General Manager. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his dear wife, Loretta and to all his family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors, Paul Seidenberg, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUTTERMAN, PAULINE
description: GUTTERMAN - Pauline. Thirty years have passed and you remain in our memories with love. Gutterman and Liebman Families

title: Keenan Back in His Element
description: t's great to be back," Mike Keenan said at Madison Square Garden last night. "In both senses."

title: Mets Are Still Trying To Make Some Deals
description: The Mets will unveil the core of their new acquisitions today, presenting Roberto Alomar, Roger Cedeo and several of the other players acquired during General Manager Steve Phillips's frenzy over the past week. But the Mets are not done, and they may need more introductions within days.

title: Taliban Leader Is Hiding in Mountain Province Near Kandahar, Afghan Official Says
description: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban's paramount leader, is hiding in a mountainous region not far from his former headquarters here, the region's intelligence director said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Case Closed On Japanese
description: The search for 10 Japanese who Japan says were kidnapped by North Korean agents in the 1960's and 1970's is over as far as North Korea is concerned. The Korea Central News Agency said Japan's ''fuss about 'kidnapping' '' had provoked the Korean people and ''made it impossible for us to go ahead with this work any longer.'' North Korea has always maintained that it knew nothing about the missing people but agreed to investigate after Japan insisted on some measure of progress as a condition for relations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Amgen Deal May Signal Biotech Consolidation

title: Accounts
description: Pentair, Minneapolis, to Fitzgerald & Co., Atlanta, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle advertising for its Delta Machinery and Porter-Cable power tool maker brands. Spending was estimated at more than $10 million. Delta Machinery had been at Gray Baumgarten Layport, Pittsburgh. Porter-Cable had been at Sossaman & Associates, Memphis.

title: The Hidden Enemies
description: Abdul Taher is a slight 14-year-old farm boy facing a choice that would baffle any grown-up: Should he risk starvation or risk having his leg blown off by a land mine?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Plotter Against King Extradited
description: The man believed to be the former military leader of the Basque separatist group E.T.A., who is accused by Spain of plotting to kill King Juan Carlos, arrived in Madrid yesterday under a new fast-track extradition procedure agreed on by Spain and France. Jos Javier Arizkurn Ruz, who was arrested in 1999, is charged with 12 murders, as well as organizing an assassination attempt against the king in 1995. Under the pact signed on Oct. 11, Mr. Arizkuren will be tried in Spain and then returned to France, to finish a 10-year sentence. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Agencies, many owned by Interpublic, make changes in senior management.
description: AGENCIES are moving ahead with top-level personnel changes, seeking to have new senior executives in place for the new year.

title: Bloomberg Is Changing Strategies On U.S. Aid
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg has been quietly lobbying Republican lawmakers and the White House to sign off on financial aid packages to help New York recover from the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, even though the current mayor has said that New York does not need any more money this fiscal year.

title: FLUOR NAMES ITS PRESIDENT AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Fluor Corporation, a leading engineering and construction company, named Alan Boeckmann as its chairman and chief executive yesterday, succeeding Philip Carroll Jr. Mr. Boeckmann, 53, had served as the president and chief operating officer since February, Fluor said. He will take the new positions Feb. 6. Mr. Carroll, 64, had been chief executive since 1998, the company said. Fluor, which is based in Aliso Viejo, Calif., is trying to increase earnings by concentrating on its engineering, procurement, construction and maintenance-services businesses. The company reduced its fourth-quarter and 2001 forecasts in October as its mining and telecommunications businesses slowed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom To Repurchase Stake
description: The board of Russia's giant gas monopoly, Gazprom, voted to buy back control of a subsidiary called Purgaz, which had slipped out of Gazprom's control in 1999 in a transaction that investors called dubious. Shareholders applauded the decision and said it indicated that the company's new management, installed this year by President Vladimir V. Putin, was prepared to fight to reclaim assets lost to shadowy offshore companies under the previous management. Gazprom must pay $190 million by the end of December to regain a controlling stake in the gas producer, said Boris Fyodorov, a member of Gazprom's board. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: To Little Avail, U.S. Presses For Steel Output Cut Abroad
description: Using a mixture of gentle persuasion and thinly veiled threats, United States trade officials pressed steel-making countries from around the world today to reduce production and lift prices.

title: Liberty Island Will Reopen, But With Statue Cordoned Off
description: Starting Thursday, huddled masses will once again be allowed to visit Ellis Island and Liberty Island, though Lady Liberty herself will remain off limits, a lingering victim of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: Al Qaeda Fleeing Toward Pakistan, U.S. Officials Say
description: TORA BORA, Afghanistan, Dec. 17  Hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters have fled from the caves of Tora Bora into the snow-capped mountains that mark the Pakistan border, and Osama bin Laden may be among them, according to United States intelligence officials, who acknowledged today that they had lost track of him.

title: Reviving Predigital Keyboards With the Styles of the 1970's
description: Zero 7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREW, JOAN M.
description: DREW-Joan M. On December 15, 2001 after a long illness. Daughter of the late Stephen and Josephine O'Connor Drew. Beloved sister of Michael Drew & his wife Barbara. Friends may call Wednesday 1-3 & 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10 AM at Saint Thomas More RC Church. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Diamond Agreement
description: De Beers, the world's biggest diamond trader, reached an agreement to buy $800 million worth of stones a year from Russia's diamond producer, Alrosa, putting an end to months of negotiations. The agreement, reached today in the Siberian city of Yakutsk, allows Russia to more than double the volume of rough-cut diamonds it sells outside the cartel, Bloomberg News reported. Under the new, five-year agreement, Alrosa, the world's second-largest diamond producer with an annual production of $1.6 billion, is allowed to export $200 million a year outside of De Beers, a unit of Anglo American. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALL, I. MAXWELL
description: SMALL-I. Maxwell. Uncle Mac, your smiling face and kindness will not be forgotten. Love, Renee and Marty

title: Wines of the Week
description: No holiday celebration is complete without sparklers. Whether you're pouring Champagne from France, sparkling wine from California and Washington, cava from Spain, or prosecco from Italy, if there are bubbles in the glass, it's a party.

title: A Defender of Faith in Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: A Competition in Squalor From Adjoining Kitchens
description: Chris Messina is an actor who seems to specialize in the misguided, out-of-it young men spawned by fecklessness and drugs. He has the jittery physicality down: the rocking stance of uncertainty; the slovenly posture; the nervous, nearly spastic hands; the alert, darting eyes. And in forgettable Off Broadway plays like ''Blur'' and ''The Hologram Theory'' he has stood out by plumbing his characters' pathetic qualities for a sorry comic charm.

title: Mathis's Goals Are Far-Reaching
description: Clint Mathis has scored goals on the soccer field with shocking proficiency. Some of his other goals and aspirations might seem shockingly simple for their brashness and unequivocal confidence.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Sunday with a biographical sketch of Paul Curioli, a World Trade Center victim who was an insurance company vice president who enjoyed woodworking, was published in error. The subject was unidentified. Mr. Curioli is pictured here.

title: Aspects of Jewish Life, Thoughtful or Rollicking
description: Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company

title: For Some Students, Early Decision Is Best
description: Last week thousands of high school seniors received acceptance letters from the colleges of their choice. But the early-decision process that they used has received much unfair criticism. Richard Levin, president of Yale, for example, has said he wants to end early-decision admissions, the process by which a student applies to one college and promises to attend that college if he or she is admitted in December, before the regular admissions cycle begins.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Asset Manager Resigns
description: Kazuyoshi Kimura, president of the Nikko Asset Management Company, resigned to take responsibility for the collapse of his company's money market fund that invested in corporate bonds issued by the Enron Corporation, the failed energy trader. The prices of five Japanese money funds, including one of Nikko's, fell below their par prices of 10,000 yen ($78) in late November after investors learned that the funds held Enron bonds. Like their counterparts in the United States, Japanese money funds carry an implied guarantee that the principal will not be touched. Financial authorities in Tokyo have called on fund managers to disclose more information to investors about their holdings. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airbus Cuts Jobs
description: The European aviation giant Airbus Industrie said that it would eliminate 500 jobs in Britain, and announced cost-cutting measures that would save the equivalent of 9,400 jobs in France, Germany and Spain. The chief executive of Airbus, Noel Forgeard, insisted that these measures did not include layoffs, but instead reduced the number of work hours per year. ''When we get rid of overtime, or move to part-time unemployment we reduce the number of men employed,'' Mr. Forgeard told Bloomberg News. The year has been a difficult one for the industry; eight days after the Sept. 11 attacks, its American rival, Boeing, announced that it was laying off 30,000 workers. As recently as October, the parent company of Airbus, EADS, insisted that it would not need to lay off anyone. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Up a Texas Channel Without a Dock
description: Residents of Galveston cling to the century-old glory days when their port city was the largest and most prosperous in Texas. But their port has long since been upstaged by Houston's, 50 miles up a ship channel to the northwest.

title: Saudi Prisoner Called a Chief For Al Qaeda
description: American officials identified a Saudi man today as the highest ranking Al Qaeda official captured in Afghanistan and taken into American custody.

title: Firefighters Contain Blaze at Cathedral of St. John the Divine
description: Awing of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine erupted in flames yesterday morning, a week before thousands were to gather there for its late Christmas Eve service. The intense heat shattered several stained-glass windows, and orange towers of fire leapt 40 feet in the air, as the cavernous sanctuary was filled from floor to vaulted ceiling with a haze of inky smoke.

title: Judge Overturns Death Sentence for Former Radio Journalist
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18  A federal judge here upheld the murder conviction today of Mumia Abu-Jamal, a former journalist and Black Panther whose case has attracted enormous international attention, but threw out the death sentence against him.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about a performance by Ballett Frankfurt at the Next Wave Festival misstated the closing date of the troupe's engagement at the Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It is Thursday; it was not Sunday.

title: Houston Arena Manager Sends Apology to Knight
description: The Houston arena manager who accused Texas Tech Coach Bobby Knight of abusive behavior Saturday apologized yesterday for confronting Knight, saying in a letter that ''I overstepped myself.''

title: Gathering for Cookies Prompts Jerusalem Terror Detention
description: It was only a morning reception for foreign diplomats and important local figures, a way to celebrate the Muslim post-Ramadan feast, Id al-Fitr. But in Jerusalem there is no such thing as ''only.''

title: Haitian Commandos Attack Palace Before Being Routed
description: Commandos apparently intent on ousting the government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti stormed the presidential palace early this morning and battled the police for several hours before being routed, Haitian officials said.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Nurses Strike
description: Nurses at the Oregon Health and Sciences University in Portland walked off the job after voting overwhelmingly to reject the hospital's latest contract offer on Saturday. Negotiators from the Oregon Nurses Association sought a 19 percent raise over the next two-year contract, as well as full health coverage, while the hospital offered a 14 percent increase over 27 months. The nurses' strike is the first in Oregon in a decade. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Putin Sees Continued Alliance Despite the End of ABM Pact
description: In a lengthy interview published today, President Vladimir V. Putin cast the Bush administration's withdrawal from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty as a difference between friends that should not, if handled properly, crush ''the spirit of partnership and even alliance'' between the two nations.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: The Hunt for Osama bin Laden
description: On April 30, 1945, as Soviet troops closed in on central Berlin, Adolf Hitler bid farewell to the aides gathered in his bunker beneath the Reich Chancellery and killed himself with a bullet to the head. Many Americans grew up with a vision of war as something that ends with that kind of finality. Since then we have become acquainted with more inconclusive finales. As America searches for Osama bin Laden in the mountainous wilderness of eastern Afghanistan, we are learning that even in victory, finding the end point can be frustratingly elusive.

title: Scientists Seek Ways to Rebuild the Body, Bypassing the Embryos
description: Human embryonic stem cells may not be the only source of tissue needed to repair damaged organs. Alternative approaches from the mundane to the exotic are being explored to avoid the ethical controversy surrounding embryonic stem cells. Those cells are obtained by destroying human embryos, which some people view as human life.

title: Legal Residency Sought for Undocumented Victims' Families
description: A coalition of immigrant groups, labor unions and religious organizations is urging Congress to grant legal immigration status to the widows and children of several dozen illegal immigrants who died in the World Trade Center disaster.

title: One War, Differing Aims
description: The United States' heavy dependence on proxy forces in the Afghan war has been a calculated decision that has generally worked well. But as the war enters its final phase, the limitations of this policy also seem clear.

title: One Nation, Loosely United
description: The agreement by Afghan factions meeting in Bonn, Germany, to form an interim government has been hailed as a breakthrough. Already, its chances of success are in question because of disparities in the power-sharing formula and the exclusion of several major warlords. Even if these disparities are corrected in an inclusive loya jirga -- a grand assembly of tribal leaders and ethnic factions -- the new government's mission to create a powerful centralized administration based in Kabul is unlikely to succeed in a historically fractious and ethnically diverse land.

title: A Defender of Faith in Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMAN, MARCUS
description: WEISMAN-Marcus, at age 91. Beloved husband of the late Nina. Devoted father of Jael (with Vicki) and Peter (with Marie-Claude). Adored grandfather of Jacob and Emmanuelle. Graveside services under the direction of RiversideNassau North Chapels (516487-9600) Tuesday, December 18th at 11 AM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The Lives column in The Times Magazine on Sunday, about airline security, misstated the cause of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 in 1996, an event that prompted a momentary tightening of security in countries with less consistent systems than Israel's. It was an explosion in a fuel tank, not a bombing.

title: When Mistakes Happen
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Have Shaky Start but a Strong Finish
description: The Rangers' night began inauspiciously at Madison Square Garden.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Norway Will Cut Oil Output; Last Holdout on OPEC Effort
description: Norway, the third-biggest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia and Russia, pledged today to cut its output by 150,000 barrels a day. The announcement moves the OPEC and non-OPEC nations closer to an agreement, but one that still seems to fall short of the cartel's demands.

title: White Joins Yankees, And Wells May Be Next
description: Base runners used to lure the worst habits from within Rondell White. He would stand in the batter's box and twist the bat handle in his palms, knowing he had a chance to drive in some runs, and then White would hack at the first pitch, or maybe the second pitch, never waiting for something good to hit.

title: Al Qaeda Fleeing Toward Pakistan, U.S. Officials Say
description: TORA BORA, Afghanistan, Dec. 17  Hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters have fled from the caves of Tora Bora into the snow-capped mountains that mark the Pakistan border, and Osama bin Laden may be among them, according to United States intelligence officials, who acknowledged today that they had lost track of him.

title: A Port Authority Tenure Shadowed by Crisis
description: It galls Lewis M. Eisenberg, who stepped down last week as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, that through some caprice of history, his time at the agency will be bracketed by two painful bookends: the rebuilding of the agency's trophy property, the World Trade Center, after the 1993 bombing, and the toppling of the towers Sept. 11.

title: Cellphones in Crises
description: To the Editor:

title: Bids Get Higher To Buy Red Sox
description: Another day, another dollar; another day of bidding, another few hundred million dollars. That is the direction the sale of the Boston Red Sox has taken.

title: Singleton Buys Stake In Thompson Business
description: The Singleton Group in Sydney, Australia, has agreed to take a 49 percent stake in the Australian and New Zealand operations of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. As part of the deal, Singleton will issue 16.2 million shares of its stock to WPP. Singleton and Thompson will continue to operate as separate agencies in Australia and New Zealand, with separate managements.

title: Now Boarding, the Overdue Train to the Plane
description: New Yorkers like to think of their city, for all its chaotic energy, as a product of enlightened urban planning, a great metropolis that overcame the failure of most American cities to be shaped by any force other than the automobile. But the lack of convenient rail service to any of the metropolitan area's major airports has long undermined these pretensions, making New York seem more akin to Omaha than Paris or Tokyo.

title: The Neediest Cases; Widow Receives an Answer to Her Call for Help
description: Another long day ended with a busy signal, and Robert Sorsaia said he was feeling a lot like the phone cord dangling from his mother's coffee table -- twisted in knots and hanging in midair.

title: City Council Seat, and Life's Vocation, Gone at 45
description: There are victims and there are victims: this one bills himself as the youngest victim of the city's term-limits law. He had his political wings snipped after two four-year terms on a City Council turned topsy-turvy by the 1993 whim of a failed but rich candidate that was seconded by a voting public suspicious of having elected a bunch of deadbeats. If Councilman John D. Sabini, 45 but already gone gray, owned a dartboard, Ronald S. Lauder's well-groomed face would be its bull's-eye.

title: Push Resumes For Notifying Parents Of Abortions
description: In the waning hours of Republican control of the State Legislature, New Jersey lawmakers today revived a proposed constitutional amendment requiring parental notification for minors seeking abortions and voted to require sex-education classes to emphasize abstinence.

title: CENDANT IS ACQUIRING MARKETER OF TIME SHARES
description: The Cendant Corporation, which franchises Howard Johnson and Days Inn Hotels, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Equivest Finance for about $98 million to expand its time share business. Cendant, based in New York, said it would pay about $85 million, or $3 a share, more than double Equivest's closing price of $1.25 on Friday. Equivest, which markets time share resort interests to consumers and helps to finance those purchases, will be merged with Cendant's time share unit, Fairfield Resorts, said Elliot Bloom, a Cendant spokesman. Equivest, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., operates at 29 resort facilities in more than 17 locations, mainly on the East Coast and in the Virgin Islands.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Uzbek Avoids Extradition
description: A Czech court has dropped extradition proceedings against the Uzbek opposition leader Muhammad Salikh, saying he could be tortured or killed if he were sent to Uzbekistan. Mr. Salikh spent two weeks in jail after he was arrested last month by the Prague police on an Uzbek warrant. Uzbekistan's authoritarian ruler, Islam Karimov, says Mr. Salikh is a terrorist; rights groups call the charges fabricated. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Playing From the Elbows Down, And Making It Look Effortless
description: Dubravka Tomsic, pianist

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANE, BETTY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESNICK, ANNE
description: BRESNICK-Anne. Died in Boca Raton, FL, December 17th. Devoted widow of Stanley; beloved mother of Philip and Margaret, Arthur and Carin; grandmother of Lynn and Rob, Jill, Danielle and Jamie; great-grandmother of Jeffrey and Jonathan.

title: CATERPILLAR IS SELLING TRACTOR LINE TO AGCO
description: Caterpillar Inc. said yesterday that the Agco Corporation, a leading maker of farm equipment, had agreed to take over assembly and marketing of its Challenger line of tractors, as Caterpillar stops producing the farm equipment. Agco, which is based in Duluth, Ga., will acquire a plant in Dekalb, Ill., as part of the agreement. Caterpillar, which is based in Peoria, Ill., said its earnings would be reduced by $80 million before taxes because of write-downs. Caterpillar's distribution system is aimed at construction customers, rather than farmers, making it difficult to sell agricultural products, analysts said.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Redistricting Effort Falters
description: The state's redistricting commission missed its deadline for redrawing the 49 state legislative districts, completing the boundaries on Sunday, a day late. The commissioners, two Republicans and two Democrats, were unable to reach an agreement on Washington's nine Congressional districts, leaving the fate of the redistricting project uncertain. The State Supreme Court could order the commission back to work, or the Legislature could extend the deadline retroactively when it convenes next month. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Setback for Overhaul Campaign in Japan
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi agreed with ruling-party lawmakers today to put off a decision on merging eight state-run financial institutions. The news was taken here as an ominous sign that Mr. Koizumi's campaign to revamp the country's elephantine public finances had run out of steam.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: A Fix For Internet Explorer
description: Microsoft has released a patch that fixes security flaws in its Internet Explorer browser software. The problem allowed hackers to design Web sites and e-mail messages that caused users to unknowingly download dangerous programs and ''run code of the attacker's choice,'' as the company's security bulletin put it. The patch also fixes two other problems, including one that allowed the creators of specially designed Web sites to read files on the victim's computer. ''Customers using I.E. should install the patch immediately,'' the company said. An announcement on the patch can be found at www-.microsoft.com/technet/security/ bulletin/ms01-058.asp. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Final Cuts for Women's Team
description: The United States women's hockey team announced its 20-player roster for the Salt Lake City Olympics yesterday, with 14 women returning from the team that won the inaugural gold medal at the 1998 Nagano Games.

description: ''We feel like we're seeing a lot more first-time scared-to-death homeless. And we're looking at working homeless, not just welfare homeless.''

title: Turkish Hunger Strikers Risk Body and Mind
description: Ismail Hakkisalic's memory is shot to pieces. He can read only a few paragraphs at a time. He has great difficulty concentrating, closing his eyes for several minutes as he struggles to form a sentence.

title: Fewer Murders In New York City
description: The number of murders and shootings in New York City fell last week after several weeks of increases, statistics released yesterday show.

title: Ulysses S. Grant Sharp Jr., Vietnam War Admiral, 95
description: Adm. Ulysses S. Grant Sharp Jr., the commander in chief of the United States Pacific Command in the Vietnam War and an outspoken critic of how the war was fought, died on Wednesday at home in San Diego. He was 95.

title: Miscellany
description: Roth Associates, New York, and Acadia Consulting Group, Armonk, N.Y., are forming a joint venture brokerage specializing in mergers and acquisitions of smaller agencies. Principals at the venture, Roth Acadia, are Dick Roth, president at Roth Associates, and Matt Ryan, principal at Acadia Consulting.

description: BORDEN-Albin. On December 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Annarae (Robbins), dearest brother of the late Florence and Alex, fond uncle of Barbara Woods. Services private.

title: U.S. Criticizes Trans-Atlantic Air Alliance
description: The Justice Department urged transportation officials today to reject a proposed alliance between American Airlines and British Airways unless the two carriers sell some landing and takeoff rights to increase competition on routes between the United States and London.

title: A School Finds Strength in a Network of Grief
description: The catalog of loss at Xavier High School is both familiar and harrowing: 60 dead in the World Trade Center terror attack, including alumni, as well as close relatives of teachers, staff members, and students past and present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWELL, GEORGE G.
description: POWELL-George G. On December 17, 2001 of Sands Point, NY. Founder of Lourdes Industries Inc. Beloved husband of Isabelle. Loving father of Scott, Pamela, Patrice, Glen, Vicki, Joanne. Cherished grandfather of Hannah, Stephanie, Laura, Elizabeth, Wesley. Also survived by his sisters, Catherine and Frances. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, Thursday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30AM St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Parkinson Disease Association.

title: Cruise Line Deal Hinges on More Than Price
description: When shareholders of P&O Princess Cruises meet next month to vote on a proposed merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises, they will also consider an unsolicited rival bid from the Carnival Corporation.

title: Finally, a Fuss For Prokofiev, Both Uptown And Down
description: Prokofiev appears to have become the poor relation among the great 20th-century Russian composers. The music world spends plenty of time examining and agonizing over the life and music of Shostakovich, and Stravinsky looms over the lot despite the relatively small percentage of his music -- virtually all of it early -- that has become part of the standard repertory. This year Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall are paying lavish attention to Rachmaninoff. But Prokofiev seems to be lingering at the corner of the table, present but not making a fuss.

title: Hospital Layoffs Loom in Nassau After a Budget Vote
description: About 400 of Nassau County's public hospital and nursing home workers -- nearly a tenth of the employees -- would be laid off under the budget adopted here today at a turbulent board meeting of the Nassau Health Care Corporation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Weapons For Ulster
description: The Irish Army prepared to send weapons and ammunition to Northern Ireland republicans after riots in Belfast and Londonderry in 1970 drove thousands of Roman Catholics from their homes, according to newly released documents. They show that the prime minister at the time, Jack Lynch, and the defense minister, Jim Gibbons, ordered the preparation of the shipments, which were never delivered. Both men had denied doing so.

title: LONE STAR SAYS IT CANNOT COMPLETE DEAL WITH CARGILL
description: Lone Star Technologies Inc., a maker of pipe used in oil and gas drilling, said it had not been able to arrange financing for a $430 million purchase of the steel-tube-making unit of Cargill Inc. Investors are reluctant to buy the bonds and new stock that Lone Star planned to issue to finance the purchase because of falling demand for the company's seamless pipes among drillers, analysts said. Interest rates on some types of high-yield debt have soared 40 percent since the deal was announced four months ago, driving up financing costs. Cargill has filed a lawsuit charging Lone Star with breaching their agreement and seeking unspecified damages, said Greg Lauser, a spokesman for Cargill, which is based in Wayzata, Minn. Lone Star officials did not return calls seeking comment.

title: Dimming Prospects for Farm Reform
description: Next September the 1996 farm bill, the Freedom to Farm Act, expires. It was a failure in almost every respect. It promised to reform a system of federal farm subsidies that had grown larger, more complicated and less equitable with every passing farm bill. But the good intentions behind that bill were trumped every year by emergency appropriations that essentially continued the old way of doing business and in many cases made that old way actually worse. As it stands, the structure of farm subsidies in this country ensures that Washington will continue giving billions of dollars to large, wealthy farming corporations whether or not that is good for consumers, the soil, the water or the health of rural communities.

title: Qaeda Survivors by the Hundreds Hide in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 18 -- Hundreds of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters have slipped across the Afghan border and evaded the Pakistani Army to disappear into remote tribal areas, Western and Pakistani officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, IRVING
description: LEWIS-Irving. 93, known to family and friends as ''Mr. Danskin,'' passed away peacefully at his home in Woodland Hills, California, on December 14, 2001. Former Vice President and co-creator of the Danskin name, Mr. Lewis was the youngest member of the Tenek Icelanders Winter Bathing Polar Bear Club during his youth in Coney Island, New York. He was also a former Chancellor Commander of the Knights of Pythias Kombine Lodge in New York. A longtime resident of Bal Harbour, Florida, he was the husband of the late Minnie Weisman Lewis. He is survived by his daughters Barbara MacDonald and Judi Lovell, his son-in-law Ryan MacDonald, his grandchildren Michael, David, Jay and Jarret, and his great-granddaughter Shalea. A father figure to nephews, nieces and extended family, he earned the love and respect of all who knew him.

title: Fleet Fingers of Pianist and Conductor
description: After each of their first two concerts at Carnegie Hall last week, on Thursday and Friday, the Kirov Orchestra and Valery Gergiev had their audience leaving exhilarated and entranced. But the listeners left only after demanding, and getting, two or three encores to add to what had already been long programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISPONZIO, ANN
description: DISPONZIO-Ann. On Sunday, December 16, 2001 at age 77. She was a woman of warmth, generosity and love. Born to Italian immigrants, she rode the tide of her generation to a successful career without every compromising her devotion to family and friends. Founder of Disponzio Queens Lawyer Service, she was honored by Borough President Claire Shulman last March for her five decades of service to the New York legal community. But, her real joy was shopping and cooking. Holidays were gift-filled, joyous and delicious. Beloved by hundreds, none more so than her family who include her husband of 57 years, John, daughter Louise, son Joseph, granddaughters Eleni and Anna, great granddaughter Leena and her brother Dan and sister Rose.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Parts Maker Lays Off 1,600
description: The Kemet Corporation, a maker of electronic parts for cellphones and hand-held computers, will lay off 1,600 workers in the United States and Mexico, its second wave of job cuts this year. The cuts represent as much as 15 percent of the company's work force, and along with other charges, will cost about $25 million in the current quarter, Kemet said. The company announced in June that it was laying off 1,805 workers. It said customers were buying about one-third the number of capacitors, small parts that regulate electricity, that they did last year.

title: New Suit Filed Against U.S. About Nuclear Waste Dump
description: The State of Nevada filed suit today in its continuing effort to prevent the federal government from establishing a nuclear waste burial site at Yucca Mountain, about 90 miles from Las Vegas.

description: There were times yesterday morning when it seemed as if the cheerful orange V emblazoned on the front of the new V train stood for ''Very Nice Train That No One Wants to Ride.''

title: Death By Guru
description: ''Lies. Arrogance. Betrayal.'' So reads Fortune's current cover, under the headline ''The Enron Disaster.'' Sounds good to me. But Fortune may have overlooked one force for evil: trendy management theories. In part, this was a case of death by guru.

description: A London-based Saudi businessman and two Egyptians lost a three-year battle today to avoid extradition to New York to stand trial on charges of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in bombing the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in August 1998.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Plans Stock Split
description: The Symantec Corporation, which makes Norton antivirus software and whose shares have doubled since September, said yesterday that it was planning a 2-for-1 stock split. The split will increase the number of shares outstanding to 140.4 million, the company said. Shares rose 9 cents, to $67.25. They closed as low as $34.67 on Sept. 28.

title: Tora Bora Perp Walk, Fugitives on the Fly, Conflicting War Aims
description: It is the supporters of terrorism in the mountains of Tora Bora who are looking terrified these days. Exhausted and whimpering, vanquished fighters for Osama bin Laden were paraded for the cameras yesterday by their new Afghan jailers as visual aids for the continuing story of Al Qaeda on the run.

title: Hamm Is Selected The World's Top Player
description: MIA HAMM, the marquee player in women's soccer in the United States for the past several years, was honored yesterday as the first FIFA women's player of the year. FIFA, the sport's world governing body, also named LUIS FIGO of Portugal as the men's player of the year.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Fast Laptop Chip From Advanced Micro
description: Advanced Micro Devices has introduced a 1-gigahertz Duron chip for notebook PC's. Until recently, such fast chips could not be found in inexpensive laptop computers. In October, Intel, Advanced Micro's competitor, released a similarly priced mobile chip, the 933-megahertz mobile Celeron. Advanced Micro, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said that Compaq Computer would sell its 700 series notebooks with the Duron chip. The notebook, when configured with the 1-gigahertz chip and a 13.3-inch display, sells for $899, which is less than a similarly equipped model with an Intel budget chip. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: A federal jury awarded a rap group, the Sugar Hill Gang, nearly $3 million from the Snapple Beverage Corporation and Turner Broadcasting System for unauthorized use of the group's work in an advertising campaign.

title: Elephant Trainer on Trial in an Abuse Case
description: Trading the red tuxedo tails that characterize his public appearances for a conservative black suit, Mark Oliver Gebel, one of the biggest stars of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus, went on trial today on charges that he abused an Asian elephant when the ''greatest show on earth'' marched through here this summer.

title: A Defining Maverick Shows Up
description: The San Francisco Symphony's Mavericks series could never be fully certified without the appearance of Henry Brant, so he showed up in Davies Hall here on Saturday night ready to cause more trouble. Eighty-eight years old, exceedingly small but very much on his feet, his white tie and tails accessorized by a poker dealer's visor, Mr. Brant banged away at the organ as Michael Tilson Thomas and the orchestra brought a stunned and happy audience ''Ice Field,'' written for San Francisco and scored for just about everything you could think of.

title: Amgen-Immunex Deal Spurs Forecasts About Others
description: Amgen's $16 billion acquisition of Immunex is the largest of a spate of acquisitions sweeping the biotechnology industry and portending a change in the structure of the industry and in its relationship with shareholders.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Messaging System For Agency
description: The WiredRed Software Corporation, which develops instant messaging and communications software, said it would provide the Department of Labor with an emergency notification system. The company, based in San Diego, said the system, called the e/ pop Alert, would allow officials to notify employees throughout its headquarters in Washington about emergencies, meetings and important information through their desktop computers. The one-way customized messages can include embedded WAV files like siren alarms that play instantly when the alert pops up on a user's screen.

title: Enron's Fall Reverberates In Houston's Arts World
description: The spectacular collapse of Enron, the energy and trading giant that until a few weeks ago was considered one of the country's most powerful businesses, has derailed an ambitious effort to create a major corporate art collection.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Seeks Response Alternative
description: Verizon Wireless plans to increase its network capacity and take other measures to serve the emergency communication needs of the government, rather than carry out a limited form of priority access, according to a filing last week with the Federal Communications Commission. Federal officials have been working on a plan to restrict the use of cellular networks to government and emergency personnel in the event of a major disaster, but providers are concerned about the cost and public reaction. Federal officials hoped to have a priority system operating in Washington, New York and Salt Lake City by the end of January, in time for the Winter Olympics. Verizon said it could respond by deploying portable cell sites, rerouting traffic and distributing free handsets rather than limiting access. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: In Tiny Cells, Glimpses Of Body's Master Plan
description: The human body looks and works like a seamless whole, but it is constructed of individual units too small to be seen, some 100 trillion living cells. The designer of the body is evolution, but its builders are the cells themselves. They proliferate from a single egg, morph into at least 260 different types and spontaneously organize into a perfectly integrated system of organs and tissues.

description: Linda A. Fairstein, who became the nation's best-known prosecutor of sex crimes in a 30-year career of major cases, legislative reforms and best-selling books that explored the legal and emotional realities of rape, will retire next year as chief of the Manhattan district attorney's sex crimes unit.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Seeking Aid After Floods
description: Ten widely scattered counties appealed for disaster assistance after more than 48 hours of rain flooded homes and businesses. Scores of residents were evacuated by boats and fire engines after as much as six inches of rain fell in west and northeast Arkansas. One traffic death was linked to the storm. The authorities cautioned that at least 10 major rivers were likely to crest above flood stage within 48 hours.

description: NationsRent Inc., which rents heavy construction equipment to contractors, sought bankruptcy protection from creditors after an industry slowdown.

title: Nothing Up The Rams' Sleeves This Time
description: The coaches who do not like St. Louis's Mike Martz, the ones who call him arrogant, the ones who say Martz believes he has never met anyone smarter than he is, point to his almost pathological use of trick plays as their primary evidence. There are times when Martz, the head coach of the Rams, uses those plays, his critics say, the way a bully uses his muscle to shove someone's face in the sand.

title: U.S.-Based Muslim Charity Raided by NATO in Kosovo
description: NATO troops have raided the offices of an American charity in Kosovo as part of an investigation that, according to the Bush administration, links at least two large Muslim charities based in Illinois to fund-raising for Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network.

title: KINDER MORGAN ENERGY TO PURCHASE TEJAS GAS
description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners L.P., which owns a 2,600-mile natural gas pipeline in Texas, agreed to buy Tejas Gas L.L.C. for $750 million to expand its network in the state. The company will buy Tejas Gas from InterGen, the Bechtel Group's power venture with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. Tejas Gas's 3,400-mile Texas pipeline carries 3.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day, Kinder Morgan Energy said. Kinder Morgan Energy, based in Houston, said the purchase would give it access to natural-gas-fired power stations being built along the Tejas Gas pipeline in southern and eastern Texas and the Texas Gulf Coast region.

title: Another Reform Politician in Iran Is Sentenced to a Prison Term

Also survived by sister Phyllis (Jack), sister-in-law Sylvia (Moe) and many loving grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Emanu-El, Yonkers, NY, or the JCC on the Hudson, Tarrytown, NY. Graveside service Wednesday 2 PM at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, CATHERINE, SU
description: KEATING-Catherine, SU. The Board of Trustees of Notre Dame School records with sorrow the death of Sister Catherine Keating, SU. Sister Catherine served at the school from 1945-1974. An outstanding principal Sister Catherine was loved by students and parents alike as a nurturing educational leader. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 46 West 16th Street, NY, NY on Tuesday, January 15, 2002 at 6:15PM. Barbara Rowbo Seymour ''77 Chairperson Board of Trustees Sister Mary Dolan, SU President

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yeltsin In Good Shape
description: Former President Boris N. Yeltsin, 70, was said to be in ''very good'' health after a checkup at the German Heart Center in Berlin. Mr. Yeltsin had bypass surgery five years ago and the heart center said that ''the result of the operation can be considered as excellent as ever and the president's state of health as very good.'' Victor Homola (NYT)

description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the new V subway line between Queens and Manhattan referred incorrectly to a line serving the 23rd Street-Ely Avenue stop in Queens. The F no longer stops there; the V has replaced it.

title: Britain Urges U.S. to Expand Worldwide Antipoverty Programs
description: As the war in Afghanistan nears a possible conclusion, Britain is putting increasing pressure on the United States to follow the fighting with a worldwide antipoverty program unmatched in scale since the rebuilding of Europe after World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONAY, THOMAS
description: RONAY-Thomas. The officers and staff of Joseph R. Loring & Associates wish to express our profound sadness at the sudden passing of Thomas Ronay, our friend, mentor, Chief Financial Officer and Director. His advice and counsel, which guided us for 15 years, will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends.

title: Duke Set to Meet Kentucky
description: His guards are still learning to complement each other, and his team does not shoot as well as last season's squad.

title: One Nation, Loosely United
description: LOS ANGELES -- The agreement by Afghan factions meeting in Bonn, Germany, to form an interim government has been hailed as a breakthrough. Already, its chances of success are in question because of disparities in the power-sharing formula and the exclusion of several major warlords. Even if these disparities are corrected in an inclusive loya jirga  a grand assembly of tribal leaders and ethnic factions  the new government's mission to create a powerful centralized administration based in Kabul is unlikely to succeed in a historically fractious and ethnically diverse land.

title: U.S. Approves Timber Sale, Prompting Court Challenge
description: The Bush administration cleared the way today for a gigantic sale of trees charred last year by fires in a national forest in Montana and Idaho, prompting two environmental groups to go to court to challenge the move.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Sunday with a biographical sketch of Paul Curioli, a World Trade Center victim -- an insurance company vice president who enjoyed woodworking -- was published in error. The subject was unidentified. A correct picture appears today, on Page B8.

title: Shell to Extend Its Cost-Cutting
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group stepped up a three-year cost-cutting drive today and singled out $7 billion of underperforming assets, equal to 10 percent of its holdings, to be fixed or sold. In his first strategy outlook since taking the job in July, the chairman, Phil Watts, said he planned to deliver savings of $500 million a year, on top of $5 billion made since 1998 by his predecessor. Mr. Watts, a 32-year Shell veteran, also raised the company's assumption for average oil prices to $16 a barrel from $14, giving greater freedom for acquisitions and exploration.

title: Hot-Cha, Tchaikovsky: 'Nutcracker' Swings
description: In Duke Ellington and Billy Strayhorn's reworking of Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker Suite'' from 1960, the jazz composers didn't lean on Tchaikovsky for anything beyond the strength of a melody. Not that it was easy. Strayhorn called the process agonizing; they didn't want to cast japes at European music or stain their own body of work. But the piece sounds anything but agonized.

title: Stefan Heym, Marxist-Leninist Novelist, Dies at 88 on Lecture Tour in Israel
description: Stefan Heym, the widely published author of more than a dozen historical and political novels, died yesterday while on a lecture tour in Israel. He was 88 and lived in Berlin.

title: Lawyer Demands to Meet Client Held by Military for Two Weeks
description: Frustrated that military officials have interrogated John Walker Lindh, the Californian found with Taliban fighters, without allowing him access to his lawyer, the lawyer said today that the government was violating Mr. Walker's rights and demanded to meet with his client.

title: Study Ties Childhood Cancer In Toms River to Pollution
description: A long-awaited state and federal study of the high incidence of childhood cancers in Toms River, N.J., says that air and water contamination from chemical plant pollution appears to be responsible for at least some of the cancers, people familiar with the report said yesterday.

title: Kandahar Hospital Was Unhappy Host To 18, Not 11, Armed Unholy Warriors
description: In the latest twist in a bizarre standoff at Kandahar's main hospital, officials said today that 18 wounded but armed foreign holy warriors were brought in together at the end of November, several more than previously described.

title: MORGAN LEWIS IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE PATENT LAW FIRM
description: Morgan Lewis, a national law firm with its largest offices in Philadelphia, New York and Washington, announced yesterday that it would acquire Hopgood Calimafde Judlow & Mondolino, a 35-lawyer patent litigation firm based in New York. After the completion of the deal, the terms of which were undisclosed, Morgan Lewis's New York office will have more than 300 lawyers and the firm will have more than 1,100 lawyers worldwide, according to a Morgan Lewis spokeswoman. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Many Arabs Nervous About Attack on Iraq
description: Most Arab governments share the American sentiment that removing Saddam Hussein could much improve the neighborhood. But there is little stomach for watching the United States take war to yet another Islamic nation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Palermo: 3 Arrested In Arson At Sikh Temple
description: Three teenagers have been arrested in connection with an arson fire that severely damaged a Sikh temple upstate. Federal officials are investigating whether the fire is a hate crime; Sikhs, who wear turbans for religious reasons, are sometimes mistaken for Muslims. William Joseph Reeves, 18, of Parish, N.Y., and Joshua Centrone, 18, of Mexico, N.Y., were charged with arson. Cassie Joan Hudson, 19, of Parish, was charged with conspiracy. Officials said a fire was set Nov. 18 at the temple, Gobind Sadan USA. Mr. Reeves and Mr. Centrone were held in $10,000 bail or $20,000 bond; Ms. Hudson was released Friday on $5,000 bail. Palermo is 30 miles north of Syracuse. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Nets' Rise Exposes the Knicks' Decay
description: THERE he stood, in the fast-emptying lower stands of Madison Square Garden, watching the corporate ticket holders scramble from their seats as if free cellphone service were suddenly available outside. ''Terrible, just terrible, for us to come in here and win like this,'' Lewis Katz, the principal owner of the New Jersey Nets, said mischievously.

description: GLADSTONE-Richard Bennett. Of Wellesley, MA, on December 16, 2001. Richard Bennett, husband of Kathleen (Dandy) Gladstone. Father of Sarah Gladstone of Managua, Nicaragua. Margaret Calkins, of Hamilton, MA. Emily Coombs, of Jackson, WY, and La Grave, France, and William Gladstone, of Mount Vernon, NY. Brother of Margaret Hargrave Wayland, New York, Ann Hallett, of Scio, NY, and William Gladstone, of Avoca, NY. Richard Gladstone is survived by seven grandchildren, ages three to fourteen, and fifteen nieces and nephews. Richard Gladstone devoted his forty-one year professional career to the advancement of education and reading with Houghton Mifflin, Boston, where he served as Vice Chairman of The Board of Directors, from 1986 to his retirment in 1988. A rural children library will be built in Richafd Gladstone's name in La Concepcion, Nicaragua, a farming community he frequently visited, Contribution are gratefull accepted at The Gladstone Fund for Progress in Rural Central America. Service Friday, December 21, 11AM at St. John the Martyr RC Church, 250 East 72nd Street, NYC.

title: THE STEM CELL DEBATE
Weighing the Rights of the Embryo Against Those of the Sick
description: In theory, millions of people suffering devastating diseases may one day be helped or even cured with treatments derived from human embryonic stem cells. But human embryos must be destroyed to obtain these stem cells. So research involving them is mired in controversy, with each side arguing passionately for the rights of the sick or the rights of the unborn.

But the company faces another difficult challenge: its goal, the use of such therapeutic cloning to produce useful treatments, may simply be impractical.
