description: A contractor for the Gristede's supermarket chain has been ordered to rehire employees who claimed that the contractor had paid them less than the minimum wage and threatened them with deportation. The contractor, the Great American Delivery Company, has not yet rehired the five deliverymen, said Catherine Ruckelshaus, the lawyer for the deliverymen. In ordering the reinstatement on Nov. 28, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of Federal District Court said that the dismissals sought to ''chill the willingness of others to testify'' about possibly illegal employment practices. Charles Baur, owner of the Great American Delivery Company, did not return calls seeking comment. Denny Lee (NYT)

But the lack of convenient rail service to any of the metropolitan area's major airports has long undermined these pretensions, making New York seem more akin to Omaha than Paris or Tokyo.

He pursued his educational career and became principal of P.S. 97 in Woodhaven, Queens and eventually principal of P.S. 101 in 1962. He remained Principal of P.S. 101 until his retirement in 1971. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANELLA, DANIEL J.
description: MANELLA-Daniel J. Former Chairman and CEO, Faberge Elizabeth Arden. Former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of Faberge Elizabeth Arden, Inc. died peacefully Monday evening at the home of his daughter after an extended illness. He was 76. Born in Chicago, IL. on June 23, 1925, Mr. Manella was a graduate of Saint George High School in Evanston, IL. and later received both his B.S. degree in Industrial Engineering and his M.B.A. from Northwestern University, also in Evanston. Mr. Manella's business career spanned over five decades and the highlights of his distinguished career include Vice President, American Colortype Co., Chicago; Vice President, Rapid American Corp., N.Y.C., Executive Vice President, American Paper Specialty Co., N.Y.C., Chairman of the Board, American Paper Specialty Co., Chicago, President, SCM/Allied Paper Converting Co., Chicago, President, Chief Executive Officer, KGA Industries, N.Y.C., Director, BVD Co., Inc; President, BVD Co., Inc., N.Y.C., President, Anvil Brand, Inc., N.Y.C., President, Botany Shirt Co., Inc., N.Y.C., Chairman of the Board, CEO, Kenton Corp., N.Y.C., Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer, McGregor Corp., N.Y.C., Executive Vice President, Rapid American Corp., N.Y.C., Vice President, McCory Corp., N.Y.C., President, Charles Town Race Track, Charles Town, W.Va.,President, Riviera Hotel, Las Vegas, NV., Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer, Faberge Co., Inc., N.Y.C., Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer, Faberge Elizabeth Arden, Inc., N.Y.C., Chief Executive Officer, Jelsert Co., Inc., Chicago. Known as a billiant manager and financier, Mr. Manella's professional achievement and personal philanthropy have been recognized by many business and charitable organizations including The Advertising, Broadcasting and Communications Industries Division of the Anti-Defamation League of the B'nai B'rith, The Boys Club of Little Italy and the Cabrini Medical Center of N.Y.C. where he also served as a director. Mr. Manella is survived by his daughters Susan Charkey and DeDe Manella and his son Daniel, Jr. Mr. Manella's wife Pat passed away in 1991. He is also survived by four grandsons, Steven and Jason Sharkey, Patrick and Christopher Harmes and by his two sisters, Rosemary Halleck and Margaret Mary Manella. The funeral mass will be held 10:30AM Friday, December 21st at Saint Edward Catholic Church, Palm Beach, FL. with entombment to follow at Riverside Memorial Park in Jupiter, FL. Inquires to Quattlebaum-HollemanBurse Funeral Home, 561-832-5171.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suspect Sought In 8 Rapes
description: Investigators are looking for a man who they say has sexually assaulted eight Brooklyn women since June 7, often at knifepoint. The most recent attack occurred at 1:30 a.m. yesterday morning, when a 20-year-old woman was taken to a building rooftop in Brownsville and raped, the police said. Detectives said they were looking for a black man in his 20's, 5 feet 10 inches tall and weighing 180 pounds. He was last seen wearing a blue sweater with a dark green collar, blue boots and a chain with a scorpion charm. He is known to follow women from bus stops in Brownsville and Bedford-Stuyvesant to housing developments, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: At Last, a Natural Path to the Deli
description: FOR years, a few small producers of deli meats have been trying to prove that sodium nitrite, a hazardous chemical used to color and flavor almost all processed meats, is not necessary to produce tasty hot dogs and bacon, salami and bologna. It has been a long, slow journey.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Industrial Production Falls
description: Industrial production in the 12-nation euro zone fell by an estimated 1.4 percent in October compared with the previous month, the European Union statistics office, Eurostat, said. That followed a fall of 0.7 percent in September and a rise of 1.4 percent in August. The sharpest declines, estimated at more than 7 percent from September, were recorded in Ireland and the Netherlands. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: School District Faces Deadline
description: The state education commissioner has set a Jan. 3 deadline for a troubled Nassau County school district to cut spending or risk having the state take over the district. Without the cuts in funds and staff, the Roosevelt School District will run out of money in April, two months before the end of the school year. Richard P. Mills, the commissioner, said last month that he would ask the State Board of Regents to remove the board if they could not agree on budget cuts and did not address maintenance and safety problems at the district's buildings. Mr. Mills has also threatened to dissolve the school district if the Legislature and the governor do not set long-term financing for the district. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

Bank Street will use the gift to teach natural and environmental sciences in its School for Children as well as in public schools in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut where the college runs programs and places teachers. description: Reacting to the fast pace of events in the Middle East, European leaders are struggling to forge a unified position that puts more pressure on the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, without undermining him.

title: At Ducasse, A Ticket to the Stratosphere
description: IN the annals of New York dining, few events compare with the tempestuous arrival of Alain Ducasse in New York. A year and a half ago, he swept into town, trailing his Michelin stars like a diamond-studded cape, and offering himself to the city as a gift it might or might not deserve.

title: Despite Suit Filed by Church, Police Rouse Homeless Twice
description: Early yesterday morning and again last night, police officers roused a group of homeless people sleeping on the sidewalk outside the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, the day after the church filed suit to stop the city from ejecting people sleeping on its property.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Australia: Detained Asylum Seekers Riot
description: Asylum seekers, mostly from the Middle East, rioted and set fires inside the country's largest and most isolated detention camp, Woomera, an Immigration Department spokesman said. The detention camps, which house thousands of people detained as they tried to enter Australia illegally, have come under criticism for their harsh conditions. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Like Old Times: U.S.O. Is Back, Playing to G.I.'s in New York
description: O.K., so Bob Hope wasn't there to deliver jokes about Kaopectate. And unfortunately, neither Jennifer Lopez nor Mariah Carey was available.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Expects Profit To Fall
description: The French insurance giant AXA warned that profits for 2001 would fall 53 percent, to 1.2 billion euros, and announced 525 layoffs in the United States. The job cuts, which total 625 for the year, are part of a plan to reduce costs by 700 million euros in 2002. The Paris-based company, which had not given a 2001 forecast since the Sept. 11 attacks, said the decline was a result of the effects of the attacks.

title: Workers Are Added at Trade Center Site
description: With smaller and smaller pieces of debris being excavated from the World Trade Center site, it is getting harder for salvage crews to sort through them for recognizable objects.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Access At Battery Park City
description: Gateway Plaza, one of the hardest-hit apartment complexes near ground zero, plans to reopen access to more than 400 apartments on Saturday. The building, 600 Gateway Plaza, is the final part of the 1,700-unit complex to reopen after Sept. 11. This week, the tenants and landlord, the Lefrak Organization, also agreed to a rent adjustment for next year. Rents will reflect the drop in market rates in Battery Park City. A typical two-bedroom apartment renting for $3,150 before the attack will rent for $2,441, said Jack Lester, the tenants' lawyer. Lefrak will cover some tenants' moving expenses and continue to monitor Gateway's air quality. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALCALY, LILLIAN MELTZER
description: ALCALY-Lillian Meltzer. Died on December 6, 2001. Age 89. The widow of Leon Alcaly and sister of Emma Courlander. She is survived by her sons, Roger and Peter, her grandchildren, David and Mara and her daughters-in-law Helen Bodian and Judith Alcaly.

title: Peter Elias, 78, Noted Theorist Of Information and Computers
description: Peter Elias, a theorist in the field of information and computer science, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 78.

title: India Raises The Pitch In Criticism Of Pakistan
description: On the first full day of business since a suicide squad attacked India's Parliament last week, the country's home minister, L. K. Advani, today accused Pakistan's intelligence agency and two Islamic militant groups operating there of having ''the temerity to try to wipe out the entire political leadership of India.''

title: Three-Pepper Chutney
description: Chutney (from the Indian word chatni ) is basically any condiment containing a sweet component (usually fruit) and a sour, acidic component (usually vinegar and spices). This three-pepper chutney is an excellent alternative to the traditional cranberry sauce (really a chutney itself) served at most holiday dinner tables.

title: Fire Damages St. John the Divine
description: Awing of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine erupted in flames yesterday morning, a week before thousands were to gather there for its late Christmas Eve service. The intense heat shattered several stained-glass windows, and orange towers of fire leapt 40 feet in the air, as the cavernous sanctuary was filled from floor to vaulted ceiling with a haze of inky smoke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLODNY, SAUL
description: KOLODNY-Saul on December 11, 2001 at age 83 in Danville, California. Devoted husband of Myra. Beloved father of Nancy, Carol, and her husband Richard Lees. Loving grandfather of Laura. Born in Yonkers, New York, graduated from Columbia College with honors in 1940. He began his career at the U.S. Cane Sugar Refiners Association as a chartist while in college and joined the U.S. Department of Agriculture to oversee the wartime sugar program. In 1944, he received a direct commission to the U.S. Naval Supply Corps and served as a supply officer in two Advanced Bases in the South Pacific Theatre. After the war, he returned to the Department of Agriculture. In 1947 he was employed by the American Sugar Refining Company, the world's largest sugar firm. He served as Economist, Manager of Planning and Analysis, and Director of Economic Research and Distribution. In 1975 he was named Corporate Vice President of Economic Research for Amstar Corporation. Twice he was designated Official Industry Advisor to the United Nations International Sugar Conferences. He was greatly honored when his collected personal papers from 45 years as a leading sugar industry expert were taken to reside in the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C. He retired from the company in 1983 and enjoyed an active retirement with family and friends in Florida. His love of life was a great gift to all who knew him and he will be remembered and loved forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, ROYAL M., M.D.
description: MONTGOMERY-Royal M., M.D. of Silver Springs, MD on Friday, December 14, 2001. He was preceded in death by his wife of sixtythree years Maxine Cooley Montgomery and daughter Diane Greene. An eminent dermatologist with a practice in Manhattan for more than fifty years, he moved from Forest Hills to Leisure World in Silver Springs in 1984. Dr. Montgomery was nintyfive years old. He is survived by sons Andrew E. Montgomery of Eden Prairie, MN, R. Bruce Montgomery of Block Island, RI, his daughter Clare M. Davis of Virginia Beach, VA, their spouses, twelve grandchildren and thirteen great grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made in Dr. Montgomery's name to Church-inthe-Gardens, 50 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY 11375.

title: Irish Echo, a Weekly Newspaper, Is Sold
description: The Irish Echo, a family-owned, 73-year-old weekly newspaper published in Manhattan, is to be sold to an Irish telecommunications executive in a transaction to be completed in January, the newspaper said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Needs More Funds
description: Korea First Bank, taken over by Newbridge Capital in 1999, will need another $1.4 billion in public funds next year, according to the ministry of finance and economy. The ministry said the agreement under which Newbridge acquired a 51 percent stake in the bank called for fresh infusions of funds against any nonperforming loans discovered within two years from the final date of sale. The government has already pumped $2.8 billion into the bank since rescuing it from imminent collapse during South Korea's economic crisis four years ago. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Outlook issue of Business Day on Monday about the biometrics industry, which centers on equipment that identifies people by characteristics like fingerprints and voice patterns, gave an outdated name for a consulting firm that has promoted programs with that technology. It is Accenture, no longer Andersen Consulting.

title: Footlights
description: Drawing Dickens

title: All Alone, Again
description: Anyone in Washington planning to take the war on terrorism to Iraq after Osama bin Laden is eliminated should not count on Russia's help -- at least for now. The word here when you ask about marching on Baghdad is very simple: ''Nyet.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about political and economic conditions in Algeria misspelled the name of a daily newspaper there whose managing editor commented on the country's problems. It is El Watan, not El Wata.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, VALERIE
description: ELLIS-Valerie. Passed away on December 16, 2001 at her Miami Beach home at the age of 86. Born January 4, 1915 in Newark, NJ and married to the late Abraham Ellis. She is survived by four children, Carol Shapiro (Dr. Stanley), Lynn Clurman (David), Dr. Eugene Ellis (Madeline) and Dr. Stephen Ellis (Ursulla), nine grandchildren, Lara Shapiro, Jessica Shapiro, Brian Shapiro, Benjamin Metzger, Matthieu Clurman, Lauren Ellis, Ryan Ellis, Heidi Ellis and Antonio Ellis and two sisters, Terri Tortorello and Agnes Silbernagel. Funeral services will take place Friday, December 21, at 8 AM at the Keri Memorial Home, 125 Main St, Lincoln Park, NJ. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Alzheimer's Association, 1175 North East 125th St, N. Miami, FL.

title: Broadcasts On Terrorists Win Awards
description: Several televised reports that looked forward to the events of Sept. 11 with unusual prescience are among the winners of the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards in broadcast journalism, which were announced yesterday.

title: To Jolt the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, a biographical sketch on Saturday about two family members who worked together at Cantor Fitzgerald and died at the World Trade Center misspelled their surname in some copies and at one point misstated their relationship. They were Frederick J. and Michele L. Hoffmann, not Hoffman -- father and daughter, not uncle and niece.

title: A Tale of the Mullah and Muhammad's Amazing Cloak
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Dec. 18  The first time Mullah Muhammad Omar was allowed to enter the Shrine of the Cloak of the Prophet Muhammad here in Kandahar, and cast his gaze on the sacred ancient robe, he trembled.

title: Promises to Keep, in New Times
description: LAST year at this time I tried something new. I e-mailed a random group of readers and asked them to share their New Year's resolutions. Now that a most sobering year has passed, I contacted the group once again. Together they give a glimpse not just of good intentions kept or abandoned, but also of how transforming these last 12 months have been.

title: New Glory for the Goose
description: THERE is no food more celebratory than goose. But as spectacular as a whole roasted goose looks on the platter, it is often a disappointment on the plate. Unless it is perfectly cooked, the meat will be fatty and tough. And it's not easy to carve either.

title: For the Interim, Coaches Suspend Fraternizing
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 18  Any other time, they would have had dinner and a bunch of laughs. But now that Don Chaney and Paul Silas are competing, stuff like that will have to wait for the off-season.

title: Winning Is Helping Kittles Heal His Aches and Pains
description: He had just led the Nets to an exhilarating 18-point victory over the Knicks, but as Kerry Kittles left Madison Square Garden on Sunday night, his left ankle was sprained, wrapped and sore.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Terri Bunofsky was named to the new post of vice president for marketing at Green Light Worldwide Media, New York. She had been vice president for marketing for Playboy Enterprises International, New York. Also at Green Light, Sean Portley was named account executive for the Southwest region, based in Dallas. He had most recently been senior regional account manager at Go.com, based in Dallas.

title: Amid Riots, Argentine President Declares State of Siege
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19 -- President Fernando de la Rua declared a state of siege today after food riots and looting broke out across Argentina and police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at rock-throwing protesters here and in several provincial cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, HEATHER
description: EDELSTEIN-Heather, 52, passed away peacefully on December 18, 2001 after a long and courageous fight against breast cancer. She had the heart of a lion and served as a beacon of strength to all who had the honor of knowing her. Her family and many dear friends will forever miss her dignity, passion, loyalty, love and devotion. Her infectious smile is emblazoned on our hearts for eternity. Most beloved and devoted wife of Lee, mother of Seth and Lauren, aunt of Sam, Gabe and Noah, sister of Raphael and Phyllis, daughter of Lillian. You will remain always in our hearts and minds. Services Thursday, 2:15pm at Star of David, 7701 Bailey Rd, Tamarac, FL.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Helping Hand May Be in Your Pocket; Pickpockets Thriving on Good Will
description: It happens at Rockefeller Center. A man leaning over the railing to get a better look at an 80-foot spruce suddenly notices some mustard running down his shoulder. Then, without notice, a woman he has never met is there, wiping his shirt clean and wishing him well with holiday cheer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cultural Center Loses Argument
description: The Charas/El Bohio Cultural Center, which has spent much of the year fighting eviction in a complex dispute with its landlord, faces eviction soon, perhaps Dec. 24. A 72-hour eviction notice was served on Charas Friday. Chino Garcia, the center's executive director, urged a trial judge to allow more time for artists and programs using the former schoolhouse to find alternative space. But yesterday the trial judge, Saralee Evans, rejected a move by Charas lawyers for another delay, and an appeals court ruled that eviction should proceed.

title: New Leader Is Assured Of Support
description: Hamid Karzai, who is to become Afghanistan's new leader on Saturday, received the blessing of his country's deposed king today and a pledge of assistance from Italy's prime minister.

title: Death-Row Celebrity Wins New Sentence
description: After a two-decade court battle, a judge in Philadelphia threw out the death sentence of Mumia Abu-Jamal, the former journalist and Black Panther who is perhaps the world's best known death-row inmate.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Power Plant Flooded
description: The basement of a Public Service Electric and Gas power plant near the Pulaski Skyway flooded yesterday, forcing firefighters to pump out the basement to prevent an explosion and power failure, officials said. Pumper trucks from Engine Companies 7 and 15 of the Jersey City Fire Department drew four feet of water out of the basement after being called to the plant at 8:19 a.m., said Jose Cruz, the city's deputy fire director. Mr. Cruz said the cause of the flooding was unknown. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Christmas Verses Begin In Early, Dark Rebellion
description: NATIVITY POEMS

title: Deep Space 1 Ends Mission, But Triumphs Are Clear
description: Deep Space 1, a small spacecraft that overcame seemingly impossible odds to complete its primary mission and then capture the best pictures ever taken of a comet, ceased its operations today.

title: Braised Red Cabbage
description: Amainstay in Germanic kitchens, braised red cabbage is a great side dish to accompany meat plates. After this preparation, you will have a colorful, tangy heap of cabbage without that unpleasant cabbage smell, thanks to the caraway seeds. Use gloves while cutting and handling the cabbage to avoid staining your hands purple.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Tora Bora: Deep Ravines Hide Many Enemies
description: The sun so pulsed off the great gorges here that the walls of rock seemed adorned with spangles. Below, at the floor of the canyon, a shallow river, barely inches deep, rushed across a bed of stones. The water was glassy clear.

title: Introduction
description: There's certainly nothing wrong with the traditional side dishes usually offered at the holiday table -- cranberry relish, roasted veggies, chestnuts and the like. In fact, leave out too many of the usual suspects and you may have a dinner-time insurrection on your hands. But you might also find that sprucing up your holiday offerings with a few of these dishes, some drawn from traditional recipes in other parts of the world, will make you some new fans comes holiday time.

title: Verdict Near on Mother of Dead Children
description: Marilyn Lemak sat inside Courtroom 4000, her legs shaking and her body rocking as it has throughout the three weeks of her trial on charges that she murdered her three children.

title: Defending, and Recasting, an Unloved Client
description: When the lawyer for John Walker Lindh, the American captured with the Taliban, talks about his client, he sidesteps the hyperventilated debate that has led people to call Mr. Walker a Benedict Arnold and a rat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, DONALD CHARLES, REV.
description: MATTHEWS - Donald Charles, Rev., S.J. Beloved brother of John Jr., Elmer, Dr. Sanford, and Peter. Survived by eight nieces and fourteen nephews and many grand nieces and nephews. Reposing on Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Spellman Hall, Fordham University. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday at 11 AM, at the Fordham University Church. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to The Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau. For information, contact Farenga Brothers Inc Directors, 718-654-0500.

title: Filled With Pepper and Provenance
description: Some pepper mills do yeoman work in the kitchen, and some are designed for the table. In the meant-to-be-seen category, there are dozens of giftworthy vintage examples at Deco Deluxe, 993 Lexington Avenue (72nd Street). Some are handsome, in silver or pewter. Others are amusing, resembling a Champagne cork or a monk. One, from Christofle, was made of ebony and ivory. All are in good working order. They range from $100 to $500 each. Some mills have matching salt shakers. The shop also specializes in vintage cocktail gadgets, another gift idea.

title: Brazil's Unlikely Rising Star in Politics: a Woman
description: As a presidential hopeful, Roseana Sarney would seem to have almost everything going against her. Not only is she a woman practicing what remains largely a man's trade here, but she comes from one of Brazil's poorest states and is the daughter of a former president whose term in office is remembered as a perpetual crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEBALD, W.G.
description: SEBALD-W.G. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of novelist W.G. Sebald. On October 15, 2001, Sebald graced the stage of the Unterberg Poetry Center, reading from his novel, ''Austerlitz''. The Y honors Sebald's stylistic bravery and depictions of life in the aftermath of World War II and the Holocaust. His death is a blow to literature, but his work is a gift. We send our thoughts and prayers to his family. Matthew Bronfman, President Philip L. Milstein, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director, 92nd Street Y Hanna Arie-Gaifman, Director, 92nd Street Y, Tisch Center for the Arts David Yezzi, Director, 92nd Street Y, Unterberg Poetry Center

description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Looks At the Past And Future
description: Looking back on 2001, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that the horrific events of Sept. 11 had marked him and the entire state forever. Looking forward, the two-term Republican predicted the coming year would be one of the hardest periods in the state's history.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Sunday, 3,251 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Thinking Super Ideas: Rams Versus Steelers
description: St. Louis Rams Coach Mike Martz was on the phone the other day with his friend Russ Grimm, the offensive line coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers. Grimm had called to give Martz a little good-natured ribbing.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Argentina's Blue Christmas: No Jingling Registers
description: Any serious Argentine shopper seeking furs, leather or jewelry knows that a trip down Florida Street is indispensable -- and even more joyful at Christmastime, when the tango dancers sensuously gliding down the street-turned-pedestrian-mall every afternoon are joined by youthful choruses offering holiday songs.

description: To the Editor:

description: AUTO RACING

title: Cathedral Is Bruised, But Remains Sacred Haven
description: Priests and bishops already tending to a wounded flock rushed to their spiritual home as it burned. Residents of Morningside Heights looked on in anguish as flames shot out of a beloved neighbor, a symbol of civic, even national, togetherness.

title: Bacalao
description: Bacalao is another traditional Italian classic that fits in perfectly in the all-fish meal. A mixture of salt cod, herbs and vegetables, this dish is best made the day before serving, to allow the flavors to really come together.

title: And for Dessert On Christmas Day, The Box, Please
description: The English carol counts the 12 days of Christmas. In Provence, the Christmas number is 13, counted in desserts, symbolic nibbles to spread on the Christmas table. The number refers to Jesus and the 12 Apostles. The colors of dates and nuts represent the robes of monks. These and other sweets, including nougat, olive oil cakes, marzipan candies and candied fruit, all come in a gift box from France. In a season of overindulgence, this is about as restrained a dessert as there is. The cost is $22, plus shipping, from French Feast, www.frenchfeast.com or (212) 860-7716. At Payard Ptisserie, 1032 Lexington Avenue (73rd Street), Franois Payard will assemble gift baskets of the 13 desserts, $80, to serve up to 12. To order: (212) 717-5252. Provence en Bote, 8303 Third Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, sells a similar assortment, including a bottle of muscat wine, for $65; (718) 759-1515.

title: In Tight Market, Toned-Down Rsums
description: To underplay or not to underplay their qualifications to prospective employers -- that is the question facing many white-collar job hunters these days.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Paraguayan General Freed
description: The Supreme Court rejected Paraguay's request to extradite the former military strongman Gen. Lino Oviedo, who fled to Brazil after being accused of organizing the assassination of Vice President Luis Mara Argaa in 1999. General Oviedo, who was released from jail after being held for nearly 18 months while his case was being heard, said he was the victim of political persecution. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Path Cleared For Sainthood
description: Among those Pope John Paul II will soon consecrate as saints are the founder of the ultra-conservative Catholic group Opus Dei, Josemaria Escriva, and the mystic Italian priest Padre Pio, who is said to have borne the stigmata, the wounds of Jesus. Both choices are controversial, but cardinals of the Congregation for the Causes of Saints decided to recognize miracles attributed to them, clearing the way for canonization. Melinda Henneberger (NYT)

title: Miss America Group Has Offers to Move
description: Miss America without the Boardwalk?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Crestwood: Seminary Chooses Dean
description: Prof. John H. Erickson, a longtime faculty member and church historian, has been elected dean of St. Vladimir's Orthodox Theological Seminary. Professor Erickson, 58, has been a faculty member since 1973 and is also an expert in canon law. He is one of the few laymen to run the seminary, the nation's leading school for Orthodox clergy. Professor Erickson will become dean on June 30 and will succeed the Very Rev. Thomas Hopko, who is retiring. The seminary, founded in 1938, is run by the Orthodox Church in America, but trains priests from most of the world's Orthodox branches. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Tracy Locke Named To Frito-Lay Account
description: PepsiCo in Purchase, N.Y., has expanded its relationship with the Tracy Locke Partnership in Dallas, part of the Omnicom Group, by naming the agency to handle promotion marketing and merchandising for its Frito-Lay North America division, which had been for three years at Frankel in Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Road to College, Paved With Angst
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush May Use Senate Recess To Fill 2 Jobs Without Vote
description: President Bush pressed Senator Tom Daschle today for Senate confirmation of two presidential nominees who have drawn strong criticism from Democrats. Republicans said the White House might install them anyway if the Democrat-controlled Senate did not act.

title: PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS NAMES GLOBAL EXECUTIVE
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm, named Samuel A. DiPiazza Jr. as its global chief executive yesterday, effective Jan. 2. Mr. DiPiazza, 51, will replace Jim Schiro, 56, who said in June that he would retire as soon as a successor was found. Mr. DiPiazza has been chairman and senior partner of the company's United States firm since August 2000. Before that he was in charge of the North American tax-services business, the company said. Global partners of the closely held firm, which is based in New York, approved the choice of Mr. DiPiazza. PricewaterhouseCoopers will hold an election to choose a successor to Mr. DiPiazza as the United States chairman and a senior partner.

title: Norwegian Vacations
description: Book by Feb. 28 and save $150 on 11- to 15-day vacations from Norwegian Coastal Voyages. These trips include round-trip air fare from New York to Oslo, cruises of six to 12 days along the coastal fjords from Bergen to Kirkenes, hotel accommodations in Oslo or Bergen, a scenic train ride between those two cities and airport transfers. Rates are $2,515 to $5,845 a person, double occupancy, for the 11-day trips, and $2,590 to $7,070 for the 15-day trips. Travel may be any time until Dec. 31, 2002. Call (800) 323-7436 and mention booking code IDN. Information: www.visitnorway.com/us .

title: Ex-Lawmaker From Jordan Is Held in Chicago
description: A retired Jordanian lawmaker who was here to lead local Muslims in a celebration to mark the end of Ramadan is being held on immigration charges.

title: Little Reassurance for Toms River Residents About Causes of Cancers
description: The residents came to the high school this evening hoping to hear reassuring certainties from state and federal scientists who have examined local fears that the community's high rates of childhood cancers were caused by pollution from industrial sites here.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HONEYWELL, Morristown, N.J., the diversified technology and manufacturing company, said a subsidiary, Honeywell Technology Solutions Inc., had been awarded a satellite control network contract by the Air Force. The contract is estimated at $1.22 billion.

title: BULLETIN BOARD; Information Head at Rutgers Law School
description: KAREN FROMKES has been named the director of information technology at the Newark campus of Rutgers School of Law. Ms. Fromkes, 50, a graduate of Cornell University, will oversee educational applications of computer technology, including a project to digitize documents in the law library. Peter Valdina

title: United Nations to Get A U.S. Antiterror Guide
description: The United States will present a detailed report to the United Nations on Wednesday of steps it has taken to combat international terrorism, hoping that it will give teeth to a Security Council resolution requiring all nations to join the struggle, administration officials here said today.

title: UBS Ousts President After 7 Months in Job
description: UBS A.G., the Swiss banking giant with an expanding presence on Wall Street, surprised financial executives on both sides of the Atlantic today by firing its British president just seven months after he took the top job.

title: Fire Damages St. John the Divine, Gutting Gift Shop and Scorching Art
description: A wing of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine erupted in flames yesterday morning, a week before thousands were to gather there for its late Christmas Eve service. The intense heat shattered several stained-glass windows, and orange towers of fire leapt 40 feet in the air, as the cavernous sanctuary was filled from floor to vaulted ceiling with a haze of inky smoke.

title: Rufus Thomas Dies at 84; Patriarch of Memphis Soul
description: Rufus Thomas, the jovial patriarch of Memphis soul, who billed himself as the ''world's oldest teenager,'' died on Saturday at 84.

title: Meetings and a Miss End Knicks' Skid
description: Baron Davis was alone behind the 3-point arc with 15 seconds remaining tonight, and for a split second, it looked as if the Knicks were about to relive last week's nightmare against the Boston Celtics.

title: Grant for CUNY Minority Students
description: The City University of New York has announced that it has received a $500,000 grant from the New York Life Foundation to support 25 minority students in its new Honors College for four years. SY STERNBERG, chairman, president and chief executive of New York Life Insurance Company, is also a member of the CUNY Business Leadership Council. In its first year, the honors program has 214 freshmen at five CUNY senior colleges: Baruch, Brooklyn, City, Hunter and Queens. Karen W. Arenson

title: Budget Talks Going Down To the Wire At City Hall
description: As night fell over City Hall yesterday, officials were still negotiating over the city's budget, unsure whether they would reach an agreement before the final voting session of the City Council, scheduled for today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: AT&T's Board To Meet Today On Cable Sale Or a Spinoff
description: Amid a late push by AOL Time Warner, AT&T's board is to meet in Manhattan today to decide whether to sell the company's cable television operation or instead spin it off as an independent company.

title: Demand-Feeding Becomes Another Extreme Sport
description: A combination of real actors and stop-action animation, Jan Svankmajer's ''Little Otik'' is a handmade dream, cobbled together from dirt, wood and more imagination than most of us can muster in our most fevered states. Because this Czech master refuses to work in the scrubbed, antiseptic manner of most animators, this fable comes to life as hilarious and creepy. Finally, though, because of its obvious, reductive condescension, the picture is a half-hour too long.

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Adds Mail Order Catalogs
description: Printed holiday mail-order catalogs from 600 stores, including L. L. Bean and even Amazon.com, have been digitized and indexed by the search engine company Google at catalogs.google.com. The company developed its own optical character recognition software to turn the type in headlines and product descriptions into searchable computer text, a Google spokesman said. Searches bring up thumbnail images of matching catalog pages, along with full-size excerpts of the pages with the search terms highlighted. The catalogs may also be browsed. Web site links and phone numbers for the stores are displayed along with the results. Google introduced the site without seeking permission from catalog retailers, but the spokesman, David Krane, said it would comply with all requests for removal. None have been received so far, he said. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: California's French Sparkle
description: NOT many years ago, California's sparkling wines were predictably heavy and overly fruity, almost clumsy tasted against comparably priced Champagnes. But in the last decade, the improvement has been remarkable, and today carefully selected American sparklers not only hold their own against their exalted French role models but sometimes offer good values.

title: British in Accord With Afghans On Force to Keep Order in Kabul
description: After a week of intense negotiations, Afghan and British officials agreed that fewer than 100 British marines would be deployed in Kabul before a new interim government took power on Saturday, Western diplomats said tonight.

title: THE CHEF
description: GELE is a trendy thing for pastry chefs to serve right now. Usually, it gets an elegant touch, shaped into neat little cylinders or served in a precious spoonful as a jelled sauce. These are fine, even beautiful things.

title: Equity for All Victims
description: NEW HAVEN -- America's response to the catastrophe of Sept. 11 is in many ways reassuring. Through both public policy and individual action, we are striving, in Lincoln's memorable phrase, to bind up the nation's wounds.

title: Radio Used On Sept. 11 Is Questioned
description: Fire Department officials are investigating whether some firefighters engaged in rescue efforts at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 did not hear an order to evacuate the buildings because the handheld radios they were using did not function properly, officials said yesterday.

title: Bradlees Liquidation
description: The liquidation of Bradlees Inc. was completed yesterday when a United States bankruptcy judge approved a plan to repay creditors of the discount retailer. Approved unsecured creditors will be paid 22 cents for every dollar in claims. An initial distribution of 17 cents per dollar will be sent to creditors with approved claims beginning on Dec. 28, said Adam Rogoff, a lawyerfor Bradlees. Bradlees filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, LOUISE R.
description: COHEN-Louise R. Died peacefully at age 91. Loving mother of Judy (and Milton) Birnkrant and Philip (and Carol) Horowitz. Devoted grandmother of Elizabeth and David Birnkrant, Jason, Benjamin and Michael Horowitz. Cherished aunt of Richie (and Barbara) Males, and grandnephew Nathaniel Males. Memorial service to be held at a future date.

title: Bringing a Chef's Experience to Neighborhood Cooking
description: IN the best sense of the phrase, Deborah Stanton has been around the block a few times. She has cooked with Wayne Nish at March, James Chew at Vong and Don Pintabona at Tribeca Grill. She was the chef at Mika, a Japanese fusion restaurant in SoHo, and in the mid-1990's she was the head chef at the Galaxy on Irving Place, where she experimented successfully with dishes like clams in hemp broth.

title: A Tale of the Mullah and Muhammad's Amazing Cloak
description: The first time Mullah Muhammad Omar was allowed to enter the Shrine of the Cloak of the Prophet Muhammad here in Kandahar, and cast his gaze on the sacred ancient robe, he trembled.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola To Cut 9,400 Jobs
description: Motorola is cutting another 9,400 jobs, or more than 8 percent of its work force. The company has now shrunk its work force by 32 percent from 150,000 worldwide in August 2000. Motorola, the world's No. 2 cellphone manufacturer and a leading maker of computer chips, disclosed the cuts while confirming that it was headed for a quarterly loss of 11 to 14 cents a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILINSKY, ELIZABETH BROWN
description: WILINSKY-Elizabeth Brown. December 17, 2001, at home, after a long illness. Survived by husband, Michael Rafferty; parents, Mary and Gene Wilinsky; older brother, John Wilinsky and his wife, Cindy, and daughters, Charlotte and Anna; younger brother, Thomas Wilinsky and his partner, Daniel Lebson; extended family and many friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Joslin Diabetes Center, Attention: Memorial Gifts, 1 Joslin Place, Boston, MA 02215.

title: With Promise Of Rate Rise, Insurer Halts Plan to Leave
description: New Jersey insurance regulators said yesterday that they were permitting the American International Group, the state's sixth-largest auto insurer, to increase its rates, and the insurance company said it was suspending its plans to shut down operations in the state.

title: To Blend or Chop, the Mean Machine
description: FOR preparing some foods, like mayonnaise and pesto, a blender is as good as a food processor. But the two machines are not interchangeable. In its corner, a blender produces a finer pure for sauces and soups and does a much better job of making drinks. But it cannot chop an onion.

title: Gilbert Bcaud, 74, French Pop Songwriter
description: Gilbert Bcaud, a popular French crooner and prolific songwriter whose song ''Et Maintenant'' became a worldwide hit in English as ''What Now My Love,'' died in Paris today on his houseboat on the Seine. He was 74.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Budget Cuts
description: Gov. Gary Locke proposed further spending cuts that would eliminate 30 programs and hundreds of jobs to cover the $1.25 billion shortfall in the state's two-year budget. The plan would eliminate 835 full-time jobs, and state employees would be asked to pay a greater percentage of their health insurance costs. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: KRAFT FOODS PLANNING TO SELL SOME BUSINESSES
description: Kraft Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Farley & Sathers confectionery businesses and its Mexican pasta business as it sheds brands that no longer fit with its other product lines. Terms were not disclosed. Kraft will sell Farley & Sathers to the FS Acquisition Corporation by the end of January. The pasta business, which includes the Yemina brand, will be sold to Barilla Alimentare of Italy by next month, Kraft said. Farley & Sathers, which makes brand-name and generic candy like gummy fish, employs about 1,100 people and is expected to have about $220 million in combined sales this year.

title: Duke-Kentucky Classic With Familiar Ending
description: Nearly a decade later, and 90 minutes away from where perhaps the greatest college basketball game was played, Kentucky and Duke again went into overtime.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Injunction Against Adobe
description: A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction yesterday against Adobe Systems Inc., ruling the company must stop distribution of some versions of its InDesign software, a program used for layout and design. Judge William J. Rea of the United States District Court in Los Angeles issued the ruling in a copyright infringement lawsuit brought by the software maker Trio Systems. Trio, based in Los Angeles, has accused Adobe of using its C-index database as part of the InDesign software without its permission. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Panel Asks Raise for Low-Pay Harvard Workers
description: A study commission forced on Harvard University by protesting students recommended yesterday that the university sharply increase the pay of its janitors, guards and other low-wage workers. But the proposed raises would mean pay that still falls short of the ''living wage'' the students continue to demand.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: After Fighting, Fleeing

title: Preflight Check Showed Problems on Ill-Fated Jet
description: The American Airlines plane that crashed in Queens on Nov. 12 showed two problems with the tail during a preflight check the morning of the crash, but both were resolved by resetting a computer, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Settlements' Growth Slows
description: With the Israeli-Palestinian conflict showing no sign of a letup, the number of Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza Strip is growing at its lowest rate in a decade, Israeli government figures show. The settler population continues to rise, to 204,900 through September, the Central Bureau of Statistics said. But the 4.4 percent increase for the first nine months of 2001, compared with the same period last year, was well below the average annual growth of about 8 percent in recent years. The numbers strongly suggest that frequent Palestinian attacks on settlers have made life in the West Bank and Gaza less attractive to many Israelis. Clyde Haberman (NYT)

title: LIPA Staff Urges Buying Plants From KeySpan
description: Citing the potential to lower electricity rates by more than 1 percent, a Long Island Power Authority staff team recommended today that the authority buy power plants that can produce 4,000 megawatts from KeySpan Energy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is what Afghanistan is. We kill each other.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Outlook For Educational Publisher
description: Pearson said full-year profit at its educational publishing unit would rise less than analysts had been expecting. The unit, the world's largest, has suffered from an economic slump that has crimped demand for its training materials, especially in Latin America, the company said. Full-year operating profit for the division, which accounted for about half the company's total profit last year, will rise 10 percent, to about 352 million ($513 million), Pearson said. Pearson, which publishes The Financial Times, had been counting on its educational division to cushion a slump in advertising. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Business Travel; Despite some improvements, post-Sept. 11 flying is still a chore, especially at security checks.
description: IRONY is supposedly pass after Sept. 11, so I had no reason to doubt the earnestness of the admonitions being displayed on a video screen at the security gate at Newark International Airport when I checked in for a flight to New Orleans early last week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Mother Charged In Child's Death
description: The mother of a 7-year-old Bronx girl who died in November of what authorities called child abuse syndrome was arrested yesterday and charged with criminally negligent homicide and endangering the welfare of a child. The woman, Natasha Anderson, 24, told the police in November that she had witnessed the abuse of her daughter, Inez Bennett, by the girl's stepfather, Jason Lewis, 24, who was charged with second-degree murder shortly after her death. The girl was found with broken arms, burns and a fractured jaw, and with splints made of notebooks wrapped around her arms. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; A Family Finds a Haven and After-School Help
description: When she was growing up in East Harlem, Zuny Melendez attended an after-school program in a community center half a block away from her tenement apartment and hoped that it would help her pursue a career one day.

title: BULLETIN BOARD; Intrepid Doesn't Travel, but Teachers Do
description: In the nervous aftermath of Sept. 11, field trips by schools to museums declined steeply. To make up for this falloff, the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum on the Hudson River is sending its instructors to classrooms around New York. LT. GEN. MARTIN R. STEELE, a retired marine and the president and chief executive of the museum, said that since Sept. 11, ''attendance is coming back in the public sector, but for school groups we haven't seen the volumes that we would historically see.'' The lessons cover science-related topics like buoyancy and ship design, and historical topics like the Tuskeegee airmen of World War II. Peter Valdina

title: Martinez and Knoblauch Land on Their Cleats
description: Chuck Knoblauch waited for several weeks after the World Series before finally cleaning out his locker at Yankee Stadium, and others who work there wondered if he fostered some small hope he would somehow return.

title: Rumsfeld Asks NATO to Shift To Wide Fight Against Terror
description: Declaring that the war on terrorism will not end in Afghanistan, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld today urged America's NATO allies to shift their focus and resources to fighting terror around the world.

title: Living Large, Hanging Tough, Breaking Ground and Loving the Flag
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Now at Your Bookstore: Sticker Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: MAGNUM HUNTER RESOURCES WILL BUY PRIZE ENERGY
description: Magnum Hunter Resources Inc., which has more than 3,000 oil and natural gas wells in the South and Southwest, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, the Prize Energy Corporation, for $300 million in stock and cash. After the acquisition, Magnum Hunter shareholders would own 51 percent of the combined company and Prize Energy shareholders would own the remainder, the companies said. Prize Energy's shareholders will get $24 for each of their shares, which rose $4.41, or 24 percent, to $22.51. Magnum Hunter shares fell 51 cents, or 6.1 percent, to $7.79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARECOR, LORRAINE BREITBARD
description: ZARECOR-Lorraine Breitbard. On December 11, 2001. Beloved mother of Heather. Thirty-three year spouse of Kenneth. Great friend, wonderful poet and artist.

title: The Danger in a One-Basket Nest Egg Prompts a Call to Limit Stock
description: Plunges in retirement accounts that were heavily invested in company stock are prompting some calls for change by employee rights groups and lawmakers.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: New Bid To End War
description: The government has agreed to allow the United Nations and church groups to act as intermediaries between the government and the rebels led by Jonas Savimbi, the state news agency reported. Officials said the intermediaries should urge Mr. Savimbi to give up his weapons and work toward ending the civil war that has continued with few interruptions since Angola won independence from Portugal in 1975. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Hundreds of Qaeda Fighters Slip Into Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 18  Hundreds of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters have slipped across the Afghan border and evaded the Pakistani Army to disappear into remote tribal areas, Western and Pakistani officials said today.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Giuliani's Fateful Minute

title: Sports of The Times; Alomar Has Shed Baggage
description: ''ROBERTO ALOMAR comes to the Mets with some baggage,'' it was mentioned to Steve Phillips at a news conference yesterday at Shea Stadium. ''Did you have any concerns about it before making the trade?''

title: Appointed Guardians
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Says Loss Narrowed
description: 3Com, which cut half its work force this year, said its fiscal second-quarter loss narrowed to $103.7 million as sales fell 50 percent. The loss, 3Com's seventh in a row, was 30 cents a share, compared with $142.4 million, or 41 cents, a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended Nov. 30, fell to $393.9 million from $789.5 million.

title: Taking Tea With Hatters And Queens
description: There's no mock turtle soup on the menu, but verses from ''Alice in Wonderland'' are written on the walls of Alice's Tea Cup, a whimsical new tea salon and emporium at 102 West 73rd Street. It is a lovely addition to the neighborhood. The owners, Haley and Lauren Fox, center and right, with Julie Taras, the chef, are serious about tea and sell more than 100 varieties. They also offer Alice-theme gifts like ''Drink Me'' salt and pepper shakers ($15), miniature tea sets ($25 to $55) and English teapots covered with illustrations of Mad Hatters and Red Queens ($55). Elephant-size and -shape tea cozies from Pakistan ($45) have more to do with Kipling than Lewis Carroll. Brewed tea is served, along with soups, salads, sandwiches and sweets, some tea-flavored, at tables in the back, several of which display Alice memorabilia under glass. Complete afternoon teas are $20 to $30. A separate room seats up to 24 for private tea parties, mad or not.

title: WILLAMETTE AGREES TO TALK WITH WEYERHAEUSER
description: Willamette Industries Inc., which has been trying to thwart a hostile takeover bid from the Weyerhaeuser Company for more than a year, said yesterday that it was willing to start negotiations about the sweetened offer it has received from its rival in the lumber and paper business. No decision on the proposal is expected before its board reconvenes in the first week of January, Willamette said. Weyerhaeuser raised its offer 10 percent, to $55 a share, on Thursday. The proposal was increased to $7.76 billion after Willamette began talks to buy or to create a venture with the Georgia-Pacific Group's building-products business. Willamette will also continue to hold negotiations with Georgia-Pacific.

title: Senate Approves a Bill to Expand the Federal Role in Public Education
description: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill today that would dramatically extend the federal role in public education, mandating annual testing of children in Grades 3 to 8, providing tutoring for children in persistently failing schools and setting a 12-year timetable for closing chronic gaps in student achievement.

title: Washington said to Fear Use of galileo by Enemy in a War : U.S. Out of Line on Global Positioning, EU Says
description: PARIS  The European Commission said Tuesday that the United States had sought to block the deployment of a European system of navigation known as Galileo, with the Americans arguing that an enemy could turn it against the West in the event of a war.

title: Flipping And Spearing With Chuckles And Giggles
description: New stainless-steel implements from Germany can help keep even the most frazzled cook from losing it. The turning fork with the devilish smile ($24.95) and the happy spatula ($26.95) are just two in a line that also includes cake servers, cheese slicers and cocktail picks. They are available at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street).

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: The Giants' Blue Streak Remains a Mystery Man
description: Quarterback Kerry Collins pulled aside Ron Dixon, the enigmatic wide receiver, before a play during the first quarter of the Giants' game Saturday against Arizona.

title: A Little Something For the Dish Washers
description: FOR the dish-washing marathons that follow holiday meals, nothing beats microfiber towels. Conventional cotton towels seem to push around more water than they absorb. But a dishcloth made of superfine polyester fibers, similar to the material in fleece pullovers and vests, wicks away water and holds onto it. Ten wineglasses later, it's slightly damp to the touch but still grabbing moisture without streaking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, ELEANOR E.
description: O'BRIEN-Eleanor E. December 18, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Jack O'Brien (former Senior Editor of Newsweek Magazine). Loving mother of John and his wife Bea Jae, James and his wife Trang, David and his wife Carol, Peter and his wife Carol, Eleanor Carsey and her husband Kevin, Kerry and his wife Fran and Kevin and his wife Michelle. Cherished grandmother of 24 and greatgrandmother of 11. Beloved sister of Joseph Walsh. An incredible lady whose love touched both her family and friends. A courageous lady whose light continues to shine. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday and Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, December 21, 10AM at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W. 121 Street. In her memory the family requests that all say a special prayer for the children of the world.

title: Anchovy-Stuffed Peppers
description: This traditional side dish is a wonderful segment of the all-fish dinner found in many Italian homes at Christmas.

title: The Wine Press: A Gusher
description: THE proper study of man, we are told, is man himself. It's the same with wine: the proper study of wine is wine itself. It should follow then that the best wine gifts at this time of year should be ones from which we must extract corks.

title: Turnover at Board of Education
description: GREG BROOKS, the Brooklyn member of the Board of Education for the last nine months, is leaving the board to be the deputy to the incoming New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr. The Brooklyn borough president, Howard Golden, announced on Monday that Mr. Brooks would be replaced by EDISON O. JACKSON, the president of Medgar Evers College. Yilu Zhao

title: Anthony Gigliotti, 79, Philadelphia Clarinetist and Teacher
description: Anthony Gigliotti, a mainstay of the Philadelphia Orchestra sound as principal clarinetist for 47 years and a polymath of the instrument who trained generations of colleagues, died on Dec. 3 at a hospital in Camden, N.J. He was 79 and lived in Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Print the Recipes
description: Fresh Apple Sauce

title: Britain to Lead 5,000 Troops in Kabul Peacekeeping Role
description: LONDON, Dec. 19  Britain said today that the international peacekeeping force it will lead in Kabul could number up to 5,000 troops, but that it still had to work out rules of operation with local authorities and that the force would not be fully in place for a month.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Groton: Fugitive In Custody
description: A Connecticut man wanted in a fatal shooting outside a Groton bar last month was taken into custody in Rhode Island, after the police there recognized him from a wanted poster, the police said. The man, Michael G. Smith, 28, of Uncasville was arrested at 3:36 a.m. Sunday, in Westerly, R.I., for possession of a knife, said Chief J. David Smith of the Westerly police. The suspect may have been in Rhode Island to visit a girlfriend, Chief Smith said. Lt. Mark Karasevicz of the Groton Police said Mr. Smith fatally shot Eric R. Dames, 28, of Brooklyn on Nov. 8. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Verizon Wireless Is Revising Deal for a Regional Carrier
description: Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest wireless carrier, plans to announce a $1.7 billion deal today to acquire the wireless operations of Price Communications ( news/quote ), a regional carrier in the Southeast, executives close to the deal said last night.

title: Contraction Hearings Postponed Till 2002
description: The hearing on the union's grievance against the commissioner's contraction plan was adjourned yesterday until next month, meaning that both paths of the double-barreled legal challenge to the plan will take the controversial issue into the new year.

title: The Ravages of Puberty Painted in Pretty Pastels
description: Painted with pastels, awash in remembrance and melancholy and humming with palliating jingles, the new musical ''Summer of '42'' arrived at the Variety Arts Theater yesterday, timely in its way, the title notwithstanding. It is the season, after all, of greeting cards.

title: Road to College, Paved With Angst
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Westchester Hospital Cases Are Investigated by the State
description: The State Health Department is investigating two incidents at Westchester Medical Center in which one patient was paralyzed and another left with brain damage during treatment.

title: Blame in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, JONATHAN S., ESQ.
description: LIEBOWITZ-Jonathan S., Esq. On December 17, 2001. Age 69. Son of the late Sidney and Florence Liebowitz. Cornell University ILR, BS 1954; JD Columbia University 1959. Member N.Y. Bar Association, U.S. Supreme Court, U.S. Court of Appeals and District Court. Served in the U.S. Army. Was an Arbitrator, Special Master, Mediator and Fact Finder. Taught at Rutgers, Pace and Cornell Universities. Member National Academy of Arbitrators and the American Arbitration Association. Authored published articles. His wife, Helen K., daughter Robin K. and son Daniel S. survive. Funeral service Thursday, 2PM, Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, N.Y. Memorial contributions to White Plains Hospital Center, Oncology Unit, 5F Davis Ave, White Plains, N.Y. or WNET Channel 13, 450 W. 33 St, N.Y., N.Y. 10001-2605.

title: Agencies add their creativity to the campaign to urge shoppers to return to Lower Manhattan.
description: WHILE most television advertisements try to persuade consumers that a product or service is superior to others and thus worth their hard-earned dollars, TV spots that began last week in the New York area seem to neglect the customer entirely.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Unhappy With North Korea
description: Placing a chill on Japan's relations with North Korea, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi described as ''an extremely insincere action'' a decision by North Korea to suspend efforts to locate at least 10 Japanese who Japan says were kidnapped from coastal towns by North Korean agents in the 1970's and 1980's. Mr. Koizumi called the suspension ''regrettable'' and pledged to seek ''earnest actions'' from the North to resolve the issue. The government said it would delay until next year a decision on whether to provide additional rice to North Korea in response to an appeal by the World Food Program. James Brooke (NYT)

title: For Tiny Tims Who Dream Of Being Chefs
description: From extremely small cookbooks come instructions for making extremely small foods. Cookies like the ever-so-tiny petits fours served on silver trays with coffee at fancy restaurants are easy to make with the cutters that come with a mini ''Joy of Cooking'' booklet of recipes in a stocking-stuffer-size box. The series includes a doll-size sushi kit, with a scrap of a rolling mat, baby chopsticks and directions for making sushi, and an itty-bitty fondue kit with a fondue pot suitable for dipping one strawberry in chocolate. The fondue pot could also warm butter for lobster. The kits, all by Running Press, are $5.95 each in bookstores.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: At the Ritz Carlton

title: A Bright Spot in a Bleak Holiday Retailing Season
description: In the worst year in recent memory for most retailers, there appears to be one small bright spot: the Internet. Many of the biggest store chains, other than the discounters like Wal-Mart, are bracing for sales to be lower than last year. But Internet sales, while growing more slowly than in past years, are expected to increase by about 30 percent, according to recent surveys.

title: Now at Your Bookstore: Sticker Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: Pact to Cut Steel Production Doesn't End Risk of Trade War
description: After two days of talks here intended to ease the world's glut of steel, representatives from 39 nations announced an agreement in principle today to cut production by about 10 percent over the next decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUBAUER, ARCHIE
description: NEUBAUER-Archie. On December 18, 2001. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted and loving father of Lonnie. Former Dean of Boys and history teacher at DeWitt Clinton High School. WWII U.S. 8th Air Force veteran. We will always love you and you will always be with us.

title: Did Russian Gas Giant Just Glimpse The Future?
description: Alexei Miller, the 39-year-old executive handpicked by President Vladimir V. Putin to run Gazprom, Russia's giant gas monopoly, has cleared the first major hurdle in his struggle to bring the sprawling gas company under his control.

title: Giants Stadium Imposes a Ban On Bottled Drinks
description: Officials at Giants Stadium decided yesterday to ban bottled drinks for the rest of the football season, while stadium officials around the country and the National Football League were reviewing security measures and policies on bottled drinks in the wake of violent fan behavior at games Sunday and Monday.

title: McCall Sees $4.7 Billion City Budget Gap
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall issued a report yesterday warning that the budget gap that New York City would face next year would be even worse than other officials had predicted: $4.7 billion, which is more than $1 billion larger than the gap forecast by the Giuliani administration.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Prison For Convicted Official
description: A Honolulu city councilman has been sentenced to four years and three months in federal prison for a bribery and kickback scheme, making him the highest ranking elected official in Hawaii to be convicted of a federal felony while in office. The councilman, Andy Mirikitani, 45, was convicted in July of theft, bribery, extortion, wire fraud and witness tampering for offering bonuses to aides if they shared the money with him.

title: Housing Fraud May End Up As a Revival
description: Federal and city officials have forged an unusual partnership that is intended to repair the damage from a recent mortgage scandal that left hundreds of dilapidated properties in Harlem and other low-income neighborhoods in default, the United States housing secretary, Mel Martinez, said yesterday.

title: An Operatic Duet About Passions Pursued
description: ''Amato: A Love Affair With Opera,'' a sweet documentary, pays tender homage to marital and musical passion, and to a kind of New York artistic life that is vanishing.

title: Officers and GIs Shun Duty There : Seoul Resists U.S. On New Barracks
description: SEOUL  Midlevel U.S. military officers find the prospect of life in South Korea so repugnant that a third of them turn down the chance to come here in command positions, even though they know they will probably have to retire with no more promotions.

title: There's Barbie on the Left, Death-Metal on the Right
description: For a mule kick of cultural disjunction, try tourist-drunk Times Square, radiant with both an enormous new Toys ''R'' Us store and the new World Theater (which doubles as the World Wrestling Federation's theme restaurant), scene of a death-metal concert last Wednesday by Deicide and Morbid Angel.

title: Arab Soldiers in the Israeli Army Find They Are Always on Guard
description: His friends were wishing the Israeli lieutenant happy birthday over the telephone just after midnight this morning when, with a flash and a room-shaking boom, an antitank grenade burst outside this lonely, scarred Israeli outpost, which separates a Palestinian refugee camp from the border with Egypt.

title: The Cathedral Fire
description: The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan has always been defined by two things -- it is, by some estimates, the largest cathedral in the world, and it is unfinished. Its very incompleteness became a metaphor, for good or ill, for the church's place in modern society. The sight of the permanently truncated towers was frustrating. Yet it sometimes seemed that only a work-in-progress cathedral could be an appropriate site for much-loved services like its annual blessing of the animals, a ritual that managed to be solemn and silly at the same time.

title: A Helping Hand May Be in Your Pocket
description: It happens at Rockefeller Center. A man leaning over the railing to get a better look at an 80-foot spruce suddenly notices some mustard running down his shoulder. Then, without notice, a woman he has never met is there, wiping his shirt clean and wishing him well with holiday cheer.

title: NEGOTIATORS BACK $8.2 BILLION IN AID FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: Negotiators for the House and the Senate agreed tonight to provide New York with an additional $8.2 billion in emergency aid to help recover from the World Trade Center terrorist attack and also approved billions more dollars for tighter domestic security nationwide as part of a broader defense appropriations bill.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Pressplay To Start Today
description: Pressplay, an online music venture backed by Sony Music Entertainment and the Universal Music Group, plans to start its service today, although it will be available only to several thousand consumers. The service, accessible through three Web sites -- MSN Music, Roxio and Yahoo -- will offer users who pay monthly fees of $9.95 to $24.95 the ability to download songs and listen to music streamed live via their computers. Pressplay was to have started last summer. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: And for Dessert on Christmas Day, the Box, Please
description: The English carol counts the 12 days of Christmas. In Provence, the Christmas number is 13, counted in desserts, symbolic nibbles to spread on the Christmas table. The number refers to Jesus and the 12 Apostles. The colors of dates and nuts represent the robes of monks. These and other sweets, including nougat, olive oil cakes, marzipan candies and candied fruit, all come in a gift box from France. In a season of overindulgence, this is about as restrained a dessert as there is. The cost is $22, plus shipping, from French Feast, www.frenchfeast.com or (212) 860-7716. At Payard Patisserie, 1032 Lexington Avenue (73rd Street), Francois Payard will assemble gift baskets of the 13 desserts, $80, to serve up to 12. To order: (212) 717-5252. Provence en Boite, 8303 Third Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, sells a similar assortment, including a bottle of muscat wine, for $65; (718) 759-1515.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: U.S. Expands Investigation Into Piracy Of Software
description: In a scene repeated at some of the nation's most prestigious universities over the last week, students and employees have found themselves face-to-face with federal law enforcement agents offering them a choice: Talk to us about thrill-seeking software piracy gangs or face a prison cell.

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Mets Look to Mo Vaughn As Power-Hitting Solution
description: Steve Phillips stood at a lectern at Shea Stadium yesterday and declared that he had not been to such a well-attended news conference in years. But Phillips, the Mets' general manager, must have felt like the father whose children unwrap their presents and then ask for more. All the talk was about a move he had not made.

title: From a Factory to a Bank
description: When I was in college, I did not want to go into traditional banking; I wanted to be a stockbroker. I just thought that was the highest calling -- maybe because an older friend of mine talked it up.

title: Paying Tribute, in Sound, For the Naumburg Prizes
description: In 1926 when Walter W. Naumburg established the foundation that bears his name, his idea was to underwrite New York debuts for talented young musicians in the hope that their recitals would be reviewed, managers would sign them up and they would tour the world making music happily ever after.

title: A Calm Hand to Handle the Schools' Hot-Button Issues
description: To mark his 50th birthday this year, Dennis Walcott, the incoming deputy mayor for policy under Michael R. Bloomberg and the person who will be the mayor's education maven, leapt out of a plane and parachuted back to earth. In keeping with his temperament, he maintained a Zen-like state throughout.

title: INSIDE
description: Bigger U.S. Role in Schools

title: Homages Blanketed With Dreamy Fog
description: Mercury Rev loves the pomp of yesteryear's rock without irony or doubts. At Irving Plaza last Wednesday night, it had smoke machines puffing continually and strobe lights flickering at peak moments, just like its idols from the era when the regal psychedelia of a band like Pink Floyd could fill an arena.

title: To Stay or Go? City Opera Is Deciding on Its Home
description: In many ways, the New York City Opera finds itself in an enviable position these days. Perennially overshadowed by the Metropolitan Opera, its own future is now the center of attention in the debate about Lincoln Center's proposed $1.2 billion redevelopment plan.

title: Road to College, Paved With Angst
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Plan To Track Terror Funds
description: Interpol has reached an agreement with the United States to create a database that would provide law enforcement agencies around the world with quick access to information for the crackdown on terrorist financial networks, Treasury Department officials said today.

title: LTV Seems on the Verge of a Shutdown
description: After more than half a century in business, the LTV Corporation will soon shut its doors, barring a government-supplied miracle.

title: Recipe for Rebuilding: Afghan Muscle, Marine Planning, Lots of Dollars
description: Marine C-130 cargo aircraft lumbering into the airport here in total darkness each night have carried in troops, equipment, water and, now, large amounts of American dollars.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sale Of Expedia Stake Delayed
description: Microsoft said yesterday that the sale of its stake in the Expedia travel agency would be delayed because of the sale of the entertainment units of USA Networks to Vivendi Universal. In July, Microsoft agreed to sell its 75 percent stake in Expedia to USA Networks, which hoped to create a vacation shopping channel. Earlier this week, Vivendi Universal announced that it would acquire the television and film units of USA Networks in a deal worth more than $10 billion. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Flying Home for the Holidays
description: The holiday season and bargain fares will draw many reluctant travelers back into the air. The anticipation of vacation trips or family reunions is bound to be at least slightly diluted by concerns over safety. Happily, since Sept. 11 the federal government and the airlines have taken some important steps toward protecting against terrorism.

title: Hit the Road, Middle-Earth Gang
description: There are two groups probably sharing the same dread about the film adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien's ornate and busy ''Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' -- its most loving adherents and those who have spent their lives avoiding the books. But neither side is likely to be disappointed by the director Peter Jackson's altogether heroic job in tackling perhaps the most intimidating nerd/academic fantasy classic ever.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Khmer Rouge Tourist Sites
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen has ordered that the homes of Pol Pot and other former leaders of the Khmer Rouge be preserved as tourist attractions. The homes are in the dusty town of Anlong Veng, a three-hour drive from the ancient temples of Angkor, which draw hundreds of thousands of visitors each year. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Surgery Will End The Season For Hill
description: Having spoken with his coaches and players, Doc Rivers would walk into his office after Orlando Magic games last season and often find a visitor. A rehabilitating Grant Hill would sit up in his chair, waiting to pick his coach's mind.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Trade: Music Royalties
description: The European Union and the United States agreed on a temporary solution of their dispute over music copyright. At present, European musicians do not receive the royalties owed to them when their songs are played in bars in the United States. The United States trade representative, Robert Zoellick, said the agreement would result in a financial contribution from the United States to support projects and activities to benefit European music creators. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: The Last Gift Of the Morning
description: CHRISTMAS dinner is a meal deeply rooted in family traditions. It may be a roasted goose with chestnut stuffing or a spiced souffl that is made only once a year. There may be a special toast before the meal or a postdinner walk. But there is another meal at Christmastime that is just as important and receives only a fraction of the attention. It is breakfast on Christmas Day.

title: NBC Signs Couric, Making Her Top-Paid in TV News
description: NBC and Katie Couric, the anchor of its morning "Today" show, agreed today to what is believed to be the largest financial deal ever signed in television news, reaching well beyond $60 million for the next four and a half years.

title: SABRE, TRAVEL CONCERN, RAISES PROFIT FORECAST
description: The Sabre Holdings Corporation, the largest travel-reservation company and owner of Travelocity.com, raised its fourth-quarter profit forecast yesterday because of an increase in bookings. Sabre expects to break even or earn as much as 5 cents a share in the quarter. The company earlier forecast a loss of as much as 15 cents to a profit of as much as 5 cents. Sabre, which is based in Fort Worth, expects Travelocity.com's revenue to rise 20 percent to 30 percent in 2002 from 2001, Sabre's chief executive said.
