title: QAEDA SURVIVORS BY THE HUNDREDS SAID TO DISAPPEAR
description: Hundreds of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters have slipped across the Afghan border and evaded the Pakistani Army to disappear into remote tribal areas, Western and Pakistani officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. 9 years without you, Malvin dear. Your inner beauty and compassionate nature live with us always. Love you, Audrey, Irik and Jaar-mel

title: Dean of Yale-Affiliated Divinity School Leaves Amid Spending Dispute
description: The dean of the Berkeley Divinity School, an Episcopal seminary affiliated with the Yale Divinity School, announced yesterday that he was resigning, following a widening rift between Berkeley and Yale that began over the propriety of the dean's use of the school's money.

title: In the Sensitive Office, Laying Off Is Hard to Do
description: Anna Marie Teague thought somebody would start crying when the vice president of a media relations firm in Dallas summoned her and three co-workers to a meeting last April and dismissed them.

title: 2 of Cathedral's Baroque Tapestries Lie in a Soggy, Charred Pile
description: Two rare 17th-century tapestries, designed by a master of the Italian Baroque and hand-woven in a workshop in Rome, were severely damaged by the fire at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, dealing a setback to the cathedral's 20-year effort to restore its most famous tapestries.

title: Study Says a Slumping Economy Doesn't Mean Crime Will Rise
description: Higher unemployment and a faltering economy will not necessarily lead to higher crime in New York City if the police continue their effective enforcement efforts, according to a study released yesterday by the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research.

title: SUNY Opens Manhattan Recruiting Office
description: The State University of New York, eager to lure more New York City students, unveiled its new New York City recruiting center in Manhattan last week. It is in the Graybar Building at 420 Lexington Avenue at 43rd Street. SUNY draws about a quarter of its applicants from New York City, and the new center is aimed at helping high school students and their counselors and parents with college applications and financial aid. The new center replaces a smaller recruiting office in Brooklyn. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIDDINGS, PAUL G.
description: GIDDINGS-Paul G. Age 67. On October 18, 2001 after a long battle with cancer. Mr. Giddings was the first full time employee of Donaldson Lufkin and Jenrette in 1959 and retired as Executive Vice President in 1975. He was formerly Vice Chair of the Studio Museum in Harlem and a consultant to the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York. He was also a jazz aficionado and, for many years, co-owner of the popular Village restaurant Zinno's, which regularly featured jazz performers. He is survived by his brother Arthur Giddings, nephews James and Robert and a devoted circle of friends. Interment took place in Oak Brook, Illinois.

title: Albany Backs Acting Superintendent
description: The state commissioner of education, RICHARD P. MILLS, left, has dismissed an appeal by two members of the community school board of District 24 challenging the assignment of JOSEPH QUINN as the acting superintendent of their district, which includes Ridgewood, Elmhurst and other blue-collar and middle-class areas of Queens. Members of this school board first tried to oust Mr. Quinn, then the superintendent, in the fall of 1999, but their request was repeatedly rebuffed by the Board of Education. Yilu Zhao

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWELL, GEORGE G.
description: POWELL-George G. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

title: Bush May End Offices Dealing With Women's Issues, Groups Say
description: The Bush administration is considering shrinking or eliminating some federal offices charged with protecting women's interests and has stalled activity in other offices, say women's advocacy groups and some of the women who work for the offices involved.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Judge Blocks Aid Cut
description: A federal judge blocked the state on Monday from reducing aid to developmentally disabled children. Faced with a $150 million deficit in its $3.5 billion budget, the state had proposed cutting $5.7 million from the Child Health Management Services agency, saying it was not legally obligated to care for the children. The judge, William R. Wilson of Federal District Court, disagreed, ruling that the services were mandated by federal law and could not be eliminated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESNICK, ANNE
description: BRESNICK-Anne. Died in Boca Raton, FL, December 17th. Devoted widow of Stanley; beloved mother of Philip and Margaret, Arthur and Carin; grandmother of Lynn and Rob, Jill, Danielle and Jamie; great-grandmother of Jeffrey and Jonathan.

title: Court Tells City to Improve Services for AIDS Victims
description: A year after finding that New York City was not doing enough to assist thousands of people living with AIDS, a federal judge in Brooklyn ordered the city to issue them rent subsidies, Medicaid, emergency housing and other benefits in a timely manner.

title: U.S. Force May Search Tora Bora for bin Laden
description: TORA BORA, Dec. 19 -- Frustrated by the failure to capture Osama bin Laden, the commander of American forces in Afghanistan has proposed that United States marines or Army troops be deployed to comb the wild terrain of Tora Bora to try to determine the fate of Al Qaeda leaders, American officials said today.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Two American executives gain control over a big share of the operations of UBS.
description: THE promotions yesterday of the top two American executives at UBS A.G., John Costas and Joseph Grano, were obscured by the sudden ouster of the bank's chief executive, Luqman Arnold.

title: G.E. TO BUY INTERLOGIX FOR $777 MILLION
description: General Electric said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Interlogix Inc. for about $777 million in cash and stock, adding commercial and residential security equipment to its line of products. Interlogix shareholders will get $38.86 a share, a 35 percent premium, General Electric said. Interlogix, based in Austin, Tex., has about $600 million in sales a year. The company's video and integrated systems link security devices to a central control. General Electric, which is based in Fairfield, Conn., said the products would complement many of the components already made by its GE Industrial Systems unit, which makes power and factory controls. Separately, General Electric said it would cut 3,000 jobs at its GE Capital unit and will exit some financing businesses to reduce expenses.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tories End Cooperation On Ulster
description: The Conservative party said it was ending more than three decades of official bipartisan cooperation on Northern Ireland policy to protest the Labor government's decision to give the four members of Sinn Fein, the party of the Irish Republican Army, elected to Britain's Parliament access to office space, resources and cash allowances. The four cannot take their seats because they refuse to pledge allegiance to the Crown, but the government said their constituents were entitled to parliamentary services. ''This is an horrific announcement that breaks longstanding rules of the House in favor of a particular group of people who are ex-terrorists,'' said Quentin Davies, their Northern Ireland spokesman. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: The Terrorism War's Next Phase, Old Feuds in Kabul, Aid on the Way
description: With hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters fleeing Afghanistan and thousands of peacekeeping troops preparing to move in, American officials are making an ever more urgent case for expanding the war on terrorism beyond the borders of that nation.

title: Roasted Onion Gratin
description: When roasted, the intensity of onions mellows and sweetens. Though the best onions are usually available in the spring, a good selection can now be found year-round. This recipe is best with small, flat cippolini onions, but Vidalia or the bigger Spanish variety will work almost as well. Don't substitute the little pearl onions, as they are too small and will likely burn. (This recipe is also wonderful with fennel -- just slice the fennel thin and proceed with step 3.)

title: IDT Is Said to Offer $40 Million for Winstar
description: IDT has made an offer for the bankrupt Winstar Communications of about $40 million, a senior official at Winstar said yesterday.

title: About-Face on Campaign Reform
description: For months Republican leaders in the House have pleaded that the legislative calendar is just too crowded to include campaign finance reform. Now in this season of miracles, the calendar appears ready to open up -- not to pass campaign reform, but to repeal a campaign disclosure law enacted last year. Bill Thomas of California, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is promoting a measure to water down a law requiring secret campaign slush funds to disclose their donors. It should be stopped cold.

title: 401(k) Changes Go Unheeded
description: Few workers seem to be aware that as of Jan. 1, Congress is letting them save more in their 401(k) plans, perhaps because most companies have not told their workers about the changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUIR, CATHERINE EDNA (NEE SWIFT)
description: MUIR - Catherine Edna (nee Swift). Of Port Washington, NY, Pocono Pines, PA and Delray Beach FL, December 17, 2001 in NYC. Born November 29, 1930 in Brooklyn, Cassie was the beloved wife of Robert for 46 years, devoted mother of Bob, Cathy Dwyer, Eileen Lawson and Sean, tender grandmother of Maura, Catherine, Michael, Emily and Jackie, fond sister of Margaret Hakim, Ann Rafferty, the late Thomas Swift, and their spouses, Jamshid Hakim, Edward Rafferty and Sheila Swift. Cherished mother-in-law to Dayna Muir, Jim Dwyer and Mike Lawson. Loving aunt, faithful friend, Cassie could turn a park bench into a cathedral, a small child into royalty. Her family will receive callers at Knowles Funeral Home, 123 Main Street, Port Washington, tonight 7-9, Thursday 2-4, 7-9. Service 10AM Friday at the United Methodist Church of Port Washington, 1515 Middle Neck Road. The family suggests gifts to the church.

title: Last-Minute Gifts
Slide Show: A Scarred Land
description: Scenes from a shattered nation.

title: Keeping the Faith
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Early Signals From the Mayor-Elect
description: Almost anyone who has been paying attention to Michael Bloomberg's rather low-key efforts to put together a management team and lay the groundwork for his New York City mayoralty should be encouraged by the decisions he has made so far.

title: Crown Prince Of Papering And Painting
description: SOMEWHERE between the first adult prophylaxis, in front of the gold baroque mirror, and the fitting for the occlusal orthotic device, next to the silver Art Deco floor lamp, I realized that my dentist, Dr. Michael C. Iott, loves to decorate.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: No Exceptions On Sacred Cows
description: The government of India's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, completely banned the slaughter of cows, even those that are sickly or produce no milk. With elections just months away, the state cabinet in a government led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party recommended the step. In Hindu custom, cows are considered sacred.

title: Economic Scene; For too many people, including some of the rich, Social Security is the main retirement plan.
description: THE basic problem facing Social Security is that as the baby boomers age, there will be fewer workers to support more retirees. Either benefits have to be reduced or more money has to be found.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Listen, Officeholders
description: To the Editor:

title: One Letter's Odyssey Helps Mend a Wound
description: On Sept. 10, Donna Snyder dropped a letter into the mail. The plain white envelope was addressed to the Allegro Vacation Club in Irvine, Calif., and it contained a check for $170, the monthly payment for Mrs. Snyder's coming winter trip to Aruba. Having mailed it, she forgot about it.

title: Fish to FedEx: Bowl Name Game
description: Match the sponsors with the correct bowl game: AXA, Capital One Florida, Chick-fil-A, Culligan, FedEx, Mainstay, SBC, Sega Sports, Tostitos and Visit Florida. Actually, you don't have to. My guess is that it would take too long, requiring a lifeline or two, and only annoy the marketing types from each corporation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: TV Rights Granted
description: The Star TV unit of the News Corporation has been granted rights for a new Chinese-language entertainment channel in a small area of Guangdong Province. Similar rights were granted to the company's 38-percent-owned Phoenix Satellite Television affiliate in October. AOL Time Warner was also granted the rights in October. The rights, which allow cable systems in the Pearl River delta north of Hong Kong to distribute Star TV's new channel, are considered commercially insignificant because of the limited size of the Pearl River delta market. As part of the agreement, the Fox Cable Networks unit of the News Corporation will carry China Central Television's English-language channel CCTV 9 in the United States. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Deficits and Rate Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: Organized, Schmorganized. Let's Frag Some Spaceships.
description: Playing video games on a hand-held computer has always been a bit of a trial. With the exception of Nintendo's Game Boy, using anything small like a Palm device for gaming is a sure route to finger strain.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 8 about the recent imprisonment and trial of nationalists in Iran misstated the date of Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh's overthrow with the C.I.A.'s help. It was August 1953, not in 1954. The article also characterized his beliefs incorrectly. He was most commonly identified as a secular nationalist, not a religious one.

title: Battling for Bullion
description: In the high stakes struggle between Newmont Mining of Denver and South Africa's AngloGold for control of Australia's largest gold producer, Normandy Mining, Barrick Gold of Canada has so far been a silent spectator.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Tuesday about Matthew Yarnell, a World Trade Center victim known for his prank phone calls to his mother, misidentified his employer. It was Fiduciary Trust Company, not Cantor Fitzgerald.

title: Spring Barging
description: French Waterways is taking over 30 percent off on five spring departures of its eight-passenger barge Bon Vivant. The seven-day cruises on the Loire through Sancerre depart from Nevers and cost $2,750 a person, double occupancy (regularly $4,000). That includes transfers between Paris and the cruise, all meals, wine with lunch and dinner, open bar, admissions to museums and chateaus, use of bicycles and land tours with a guide. Departures are March 31 and April 7, 14, 21 and 28; (866) 498-3920 or www.frenchwaterways.net .

title: Management Shift at Cline, Davis & Mann
description: Top management at Cline, Davis & Mann in New York, a health care agency owned by the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ), is being realigned as the two top executives relinquish their posts.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Policy on Detaining Immigrants
description: In a case that could affect thousands of immigrants detained while they fight deportation, a federal appeals court in Philadelphia ruled yesterday that the government's mandatory detention policy was unconstitutional and that each detainee was entitled to an individualized bond hearing.

title: Financier's Gift Helps Double the Size of Bard College's Endowment
description: Bard College announced yesterday that its trustees had banded together to present a $120 million donation, a gift that will roughly double the school's $115 million endowment overnight. The sum is believed to be one of the largest contributions to a small liberal arts college.

title: At Least 35 Injured in Mazar-i-Sharif Blast
description: MAZAR-i-SHARIF, Afghanistan, Dec. 20  An explosion ripped through the packed money-changers bazaar here this afternoon, injuring at least 35 people and causing panic. No one was killed in the blast, but authorities said several people were seriously injured.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Delay In Democracy Case
description: Saad Eddin Ibrahim, an imprisoned democracy advocate whose conviction this year drew widespread criticism of the Egyptian government, will remain in jail for at least another month. The Court of Cassation, the country's highest appeals court, postponed until Jan. 16 a decision on whether to overturn his conviction on charges of defaming Egypt by suggesting parliamentary elections had been marred by vote fraud. He was sentenced to seven years in prison.

title: Accounts
description: * CNT, Minneapolis, a technology services company, to Gabriel deGrood Bendt, Minneapolis, to handle its account, which had been at Whitney Morse, Minneapolis. Spending was estimated at less than $5 million.

title: Senators Call for Inquiry on the Terrorist Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Two prominent senators, one a Democrat and the other a Republican, called today for a special commission to investigate the circumstances surrounding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the country's response to them.

title: Researching the Rabbi
description: To the Editor:

title: MARINES AND ARMY MAY SCOUR CAVES, U.S. GENERAL SAYS
description: Frustrated by the failure to capture Osama bin Laden, the commander of American forces in Afghanistan has proposed that United States marines or Army troops be deployed to comb the wild terrain of Tora Bora to try to determine the fate of Al Qaeda leaders, American officials said today.

title: Victims' Families Get Break on Earlier Charity
description: Under pressure from New York's political representatives and leading charity executives, the overseer of a federal compensation fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has decided that the charity the families have received will not count against them in the calculation of awards from the fund, according to people who have been briefed on the fund's new rules.

title: The Pressure Rises in Pakistan
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan has been performing a political high-wire act since Sept. 11 by supporting the war against terrorism while trying to prevent a rebellion at home among Islamic fundamentalists angered by his rejection of the Taliban. He has succeeded thus far, but now faces new dangers created in part by his own tolerance for terrorists before Sept. 11. If he does not deal with these threats quickly and effectively, he may undermine his own rule as well as the American campaign against terrorism.

title: Unable to Control Protesters, Argentina's President Resigns
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20 - Halfway through his four-year term, President Fernando de la Rua resigned today, swamped by violent protests and looting that erupted after his government failed to reverse a deepening economic crisis.

title: Baseball Labor Talks Are Set
description: Six weeks after the labor agreement between baseball players and owners expired, full-fledged negotiations for a new one are on the horizon.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,225 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Study Finds Teenagers Smoking Less; Campaign Is Cited
description: Janel Horton, 17, has been smoking since she was 11, but she admits to being the odd bird among her friends, many of whom have kicked the habit or never even started.

title: Tyson Foods Indicted in Plan To Smuggle Illegal Workers
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest meat producer and processor, was indicted yesterday with six employees on charges that it conspired to smuggle illegal immigrants across the Mexican border to work in its processing plants.

title: Kidd's Numbers Big Except at Ballot Box
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 19  Jason Kidd is settling into his comfort zone with the Nets, finding his teammates seemingly without looking and finding the basket with more consistency. But outside of New Jersey, he feels a bit displaced.

title: Management Shift At Cline, Davis & Mann
description: Top management at Cline, Davis & Mann in New York, a health care agency owned by the Omnicom Group, is being realigned as the two top executives relinquish their posts.

title: CONGRESS GIVES UP ON DEAL THIS YEAR TO HELP ECONOMY
description: Congress gave up hope today of reaching a deal this year to help the growing ranks of the unemployed and hasten a recovery from the recession and along with the Bush administration turned instead to partisan finger-pointing over who was to blame for the impasse.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 8 about the recent imprisonment and trial of nationalists in Iran misstated the date of Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh's overthrow with the C.I.A.'s help. It was August 1953, not in 1954. The article also characterized his beliefs incorrectly. He was most commonly identified as a secular nationalist, not a religious one.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 13 about Don Tennant, who created the advertising character Tony the Tiger, misstated the word that Tony roars in cereal commercials in German. It is ''grossartig'' -- ''great'' -- not ''bartig.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, DAVID
description: BRUSH-David. The Board of Directors and staff at Waveny Care Center note with profound sorrow the loss of founder and first Board President David Brush. David's vision, leadership, and dedication to the Care Center throughout its 26year history will always be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Board of Directors, Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, CT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RILEY, RICHARD L., M.D.
description: RILEY-Richard L., M.D. On December 17, 2001 in Petersham, MA, age 90. Beloved husband of Barbara Ellis. Devoted father of Molly, Susan and Dick. Loving grandfather of Lissa and Hannah. Dr. Riley's first wife, Polly, predeceased him in 1999. Dr. Riley graduated from Philips Exeter Academy, Harvard College and Harvard Medical School. He was a Professor of Medicine at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore from 1950 to 1977, and from 1960 to 1977 served as Chair of the Department of Environmental Medicine. Dr. Riley published over 100 scientific papers on cardiovascular and respiratory physiology, and on airborne infection and control. He received in 1970 the Trudeau Medal for his work in determining that infectious tuberculosis is transmitted principally through the air. A man endowed with both physical and intellectual grace, Dr. Riley was a good amateur pianist, a fine tennis player, and enjoyed writing poetry for family occasions.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Nassau Appointments
description: Thomas R. Suozzi, below, the Nassau County executive-elect, appointed Lorna Bade Goodman, an official of New York City's Law Department, to become the new county attorney. She is the founder and chief of the city's affirmative litigation division and senior assistant to the corporation counsel, the city's top legal officer. Mr. Suozzi also appointed as a deputy county executive Hezekiah Brown, a Hempstead Village trustee and former commissioner of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service who is chairman of the State Mediation and Employment Relations Board. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Trumping Charity
description: The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church is on the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, just north of Rockefeller Center. It's in the heart of a neighborhood that is saturated with money.

title: VALERO ENERGY GETS CLEARANCE FOR ULTRAMAR PURCHASE
description: The Valero Energy Corporation has had its $5.3 billion acquisition of the Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation cleared by antitrust enforcers. The Federal Trade Commission said it approved the takeover after Valero agreed to sell a San Francisco-area Ultramar refinery and divest itself of 70 Beacon and Ultramar gasoline stations in Northern California. The F.T.C. vote to accept the divestitures clears the way for Valero to complete the takeover that will create the second-largest U.S. oil refinery, behind the Exxon Mobil Corporation. The combined company will have 12 refineries in the United States and Canada. Valero, which owns no gasoline stations, will acquire 5,000 Ultramar retail outlets.

title: Fan's Tribute to the Mets Out of the World, Sort Of
description: The year of your seventh birthday can be a formative one. Just ask Mike Massimino.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEMPLE, JOHN
description: WEMPLE-John, 79. Of Bridgewater, NJ, died at his home on December 16 after a long illness. He was the son of the late William Lester Wemple and Dorothy Gunnells Wemple. He is survived by brothers William Wemple of Charlottesville, VA and Francis Holland Wemple of Plandome, NY and eleven nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister Mary Margaret Wemple. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 5, 2002 at noon at the St. John's Episcopal Church, 158 W. High St., Somerville, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMPHREYS, GEORGE H., M.D.
description: HUMPHREYS-George H., M.D. The Columbia University Department of Surgery mourns the loss of our beloved and esteemed former Director and Chairman, and Valentine Mott Professor, Dr. George H. Humphreys, who died December 18, 2001. He was appointed Chairman in 1946, at age 43, and over a span of 23 years he guided the Department's growth and renown. He pioneered the discipline of cardiac surgery in New York City, and earned world-wide recognition for innovations in esophageal surgery. He is perhaps most respected for establishing this department as one of nation's top training centers for surgeons in his day. He trained scores of surgeons, may of whom have gone on to distinguished careers of their own in academic surgery and clinical practice. Our sincere condolences to his wonderful family. Department of Surgery Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons Surgical Service, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Eric A. Rose, M.D., Chairman, and Surgeon-In-Chief

title: A New Trio Gives an Artful Mauling to Old Pop Radio Hits
description: The Bad Plus, a new jazz trio that wrapped up a weekend of performances at Roulette on Sunday, goes down easily. But it takes a while, on reflection, to sift through the volume of good ideas they throw around.

title: Technology Tips for the Holidays
description: It's holiday time, and I've got gift-giving on my mind. I wracked my brain: What could I send to all of this newsletter's 170,000 subscribers as a token of thanks for their readership? DVD players? Digital cameras? Peanut-size camcorders?

title: City Had Been Warned of Fuel Tank at 7 World Trade Center
description: Fire Department officials warned the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 1998 and 1999 that a giant diesel fuel tank for the mayor's $13 million command bunker in 7 World Trade Center, a 47-story high-rise that burned and collapsed on Sept. 11, posed a hazard and was not consistent with city fire codes.

title: NEW JERSEY HOME BUILDER EXPANDS TO CALIFORNIA
description: Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., the largest home builder in New Jersey and North Carolina, said it planned to buy the California operations of the Forecast Group for about $225 million to expand in that state. Hovnanian will pay about $130.5 million in cash and issue $45.5 million of Class A common shares. Hovnanian also will pay off about $15 million of Forecast debt, Hovnanian's chief financial officer, J. Larry Sorsby, said. The purchase would create the eighth-largest home builder in the nation and add 50 cents a share to earnings for the year ending in October, Hovnanian said. The company, based in Red Bank, N.J., expects fiscal 2002 earnings of $3 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENFELD, GLADYS (NEE WINTER)
description: RUBENFELD-Gladys (nee Winter). Beloved wife of Paul. Devoted mother of Elliot, Helene Scott, Neil, Steven and Mark. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Dear sister of Harold Winter and Rose Savitsky. Services at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills today at 12:00 noon.

title: Chapter 11 Filings Point Fingers at Sept. 11
description: The fallout from the World Trade Center terror attack has started landing in a new place: the Federal Bankruptcy Court at Bowling Green.

title: A Bad Week May Get Worse: Boras Wants N.F.L. Certification
description: If it wasn't a crazy enough week already for the N.F.L., what with lingering images of referees being pelted by beer bottles in two of its games, here comes another potential nightmare for its clubs: the super agent Scott Boras, the tough-as-nails negotiator who has extracted some of baseball's benchmark salaries, is now seeking to represent professional football players.

title: Adcritic.com's creators say it is a victim of its own success.
description: ADCRITIC.COM, a Web site that gained a broad following among devotees of television commercials new and old, collapsed on Tuesday. The site, which offered streaming video versions of the ads, was a victim of its own success, its creators said.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Lions And Tigers And Bears, Oh No!
description: Following the lead of more than a dozen other counties in the state, Travis County, which includes Austin, voted on Tuesday to ban the ownership of wild and dangerous animals. But the county excluded two animal sanctuaries, the Austin Zoo and the Crow's Nest. Earlier this year, the Legislature required counties to ban or regulate about a dozen species, including lions and tigers. ''When I look at the possibilities of regulating dangerous wild animals, I don't have many good thoughts,'' Judge Sam Bisco told The Austin American-Statesman.

title: Enron Allowed to Auction Off Some Assets
description: A federal bankruptcy court paved the way yesterday for the Enron Corporation to auction off ownership interests in a joint venture that would operate the company's flagship energy commodities trading operation. The move came after Enron's lawyers said contracts for supplying power would probably not be included in the sale.

title: Philadelphians Take a Giant Step Toward Leading the U.S. Cable Industry
description: For years, the Roberts family of Philadelphia has been determined to expand Comcast, its midranked cable company, into an industry giant. In 1999, that strategy suffered a big setback at the hands of AT&T, which beat out Comcast in a bidding war for another major cable operator, MediaOne.

title: The Anti-Times Square, With Bar and Rooms
description: Inside the entrance of the new W Times Square is a glass ceiling that shields guests from a sheet of flowing water. ''The idea was to create a sensual, cocoonlike, pared-down antidote to the frenetic pace of Times Square,'' said Glenn Pushelberg, creative director of Yabu Pushelberg, the Toronto firm that designed the 509-room hotel, the fifth W to open in New York, with Brennan Beer Gorman/Architects. Up seven floors is the lobby, above, with wood-veneer light boxes hanging from the ceiling and geometric ottomans. It may well be a gathering place for the media crowd (Cond Nast, Random House, Reuters) that has relocated to Times Square. Rande Gerber's Whiskey bar is also relocating, from the Paramount to the basement of the W Hotel, which opens Dec. 27. Steve Hanson's Blue Fin restaurant will be on the ground floor. The neutral-toned rooms will be $209 to $2,500 a night; 1567 Broadway at 47th Street; (212) 930-7400. PILAR GUZMAN

title: '81 Gunshots Still Reverberate in Philadelphia
description: The door to the mayor's office remained firmly shut. But Pam Africa, a partisan in a death row cause that has flared divisively in this city for 20 years and counting, blocked the executive threshold in the glare of television lights today and boomed forth her message: ''We have built a worldwide movement out of Mumia!''

title: Holidays of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: A Hewlett Director Is Criticized
description: In a letter to shareholders, the top executives of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer criticized a Hewlett board member, Walter Hewlett, whose opposition to the two computer makers' planned merger has cast the deal in doubt, and challenged him to offer a better plan. ''His recent opposition to the merger is based on a static and narrow view of H.P. and the industry,'' wrote Carleton S. Fiorina, Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, and Michael D. Capellas, her counterpart at Compaq Computer. The letter was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Walter Hewlett, the son of a Hewlett-Packard co-founder, William Hewlett, and the only director to oppose the purchase, is soliciting proxies against the acquisition. He says buying Compaq would make Hewlett-Packard too reliant on low-profit personal computers. The company said today that Walter Hewlett had misjudged changes in the market that make the combination attractive.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Katie Couric Signs NBC Contract Said to Be Largest in TV News
description: NBC and Katie Couric, the anchor of its ''Today'' show, agreed yesterday to what is believed to be the largest financial deal ever signed in television news, reaching beyond $60 million for the next four and a half years.

title: Galveston Rejects Houston Port Merger
description: Residents of Galveston voted Tuesday to reject merging their port with the Port of Houston, 50 miles to the northwest.

title: PRODUCTION FLAWS DELAY TWO NEW DRUGS FROM LILLY
description: Eli Lilly & Company said Food and Drug Administration regulators were not satisfied with the company's efforts to correct quality control problems and were continuing to delay introduction of two new drugs. An F.D.A. inspection of plants in Indianapolis, completed in November, found 50 problems involving computer systems, reviews of manufacturing practices and handling of information, the company said. The quality control flaws are holding up approval of the injectable form of Zyprexa, the best-selling schizophrenia drug, and Forteo, a bone-building drug. Lilly said it could not predict when the deficiencies would be corrected.

title: Manning and Colts Get Taste of Adversity
description: When last we left the Indianapolis Colts, they were storming toward the Super Bowl, their high-powered offense embarrassing the Jets, 45-24, on opening day, the promise of the last two seasons when they have lost in the first round of the playoffs about to be fulfilled.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Ford pilot program to lease all-electric cars to 100 suburbanites in the New York region misstated the location of Brewster North, a Metro-North station that has free parking for them. It is in Putnam County, not Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARSON, CHARLES A.
description: LARSON-Charles A. On December 18, 2001. Devoted and loving husband of Dolores (nee Martin). Beloved father of Christopher Larson. Loving brother of Ruth Larson. Retired Vice-President of Exxon Chemicals. Graduate of Rensselaer Poly-Tech Institute, Chemical Engineer. Also belonged to the Sigma Xi and Taubetati, and a Harvard Business School graduate, Class of '49. Family will receive friends Thursday 2-4PM and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial Friday 11AM at St. Jean Baptiste R.C. Church. Interment to follow at Lutheran Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Panel Rejects Mine And Plant
description: Washoe County planners voted 5 to 2 against a proposed mine and cat-litter processing plant about 10 miles north of Reno because of pollution concerns. The Oil-Dri Corporation of Chicago, the world's largest producer of cat litter, said it would appeal. Local residents, primarily members of the Reno-Sparks Indian Colony, opposed the plant, citing concerns about air, noise and water pollution. Oil-Dri wants to mine clay from more than 200 acres of public land over 20 years. The Bureau of Land Management has concluded that the company's claim to the land is valid under federal mining law. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Province Leader To Cut His Drinking
description: The premier of Alberta pledged to ''curb and control'' his drinking after a late-night incident at a homeless shelter last week. Ralph Klein, 59, made an unscheduled visit to the Edmonton shelter where, witnesses say, he shouted, told the men to get jobs and threw money on the floor. Mr. Klein denied being drunk or throwing money but apologized for causing ''a commotion.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business on Tuesday about auctions of state-controlled companies in the Czech Republic referred incorrectly to some losing bidders for Transgas, the country's natural gas pipeline network. E.on, Gaz de France and Ruhrgas submitted one joint offer; E.on did not bid separately.

title: Trade Center Count Of Missing and Dead Falls Below 3,000
description: The official count of the dead and missing from the World Trade Center attack dropped below 3,000 yesterday for the first time, as city officials said that they were nearing a final tally.

title: The Bank of Japan Moves to Halt Economic Slide
description: The Bank of Japan said today that it would greatly step up its purchases of government bonds and pump even more cash than before into the nation's money markets.

title: Iraqi Tells of Renovations at Sites For Chemical and Nuclear Arms
description: An Iraqi defector who described himself as a civil engineer said he personally worked on renovations of secret facilities for biological, chemical and nuclear weapons in underground wells, private villas and under the Saddam Hussein Hospital in Baghdad as recently as a year ago.

title: Women in Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELENSKY, SAMUEL
description: ZELENSKY-Samuel, 92. Of New York, NY, passed away on Dec. 19, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Jewel Zelensky, son of Max and Eva Zelensky. He is survived by loving brother, Arnold Allen (Phyllis) & many nieces, nephews, great-nieces, great-nephews, god children and friends. Dear brother to the late Beatrice Nelson and Lillian Fractenberg. A very special man to all who knew him. Esteemed attorney and graduate of New York University Law School, he also served our country in the World War II War Crimes Unit. Services will be held at Riverside, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue on Thursday, December 20, 2001 at 11:15AM. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be sent to New York University Law School for the Sam and Jewel Zelensky Scholarship Fund.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Fears Of Terror Attack
description: The government said it would like Radio Free Europe to move its headquarters away from downtown Prague. Prime Minister Milos Zeman said the government feared that the network, which broadcasts to Iran, Iraq and Central Asia, as well as to the former Soviet bloc, could be the target of a terrorist attack. Since Sept. 11, Czech paratroopers and armored vehicles have patrolled the headquarters. Some analysts noted that the government did not like the independence of the radio's Czech-language broadcasts and believed that the broadcasts to the Middle East had hurt its commercial contacts there. Officials of Radio Free Europe, which is financed by the United States Congress, say they will consider a move if it will not affect their broadcasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAMOTA, MANUEL J.
description: DAMOTA-Manuel J. Of Valley Stream. Tragically on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Cherished son of Maria Ferreira. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Christopher, David and Justin. Loving brother of Joao, Samy, Manuela, Carmelita, Celina, Carolina and Cecilia. I'll always be grateful for the day you walked into my life and for all the days after that when loving you made all the difference. Memorial mass to be held on December 22, 2001, 11:00 am at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament. In memory of Manuel, his family would appreciate donations to be made to the Church of the Blessed Sacrament Family Services, 201 North Central Avenue Valley Stream, NY 11580.

title: Bush Gives Secrecy Power To Public Health Secretary
description: President Bush has granted the secretary of health and human services the power to classify information as secret, a step that shows how the battle against terrorism is drawing domestic agencies into the national security apparatus.

title: Global Crossing Looks Overseas For Financing
description: Seeking to prevent a messy financial collapse, Global Crossing is trying to reach a restructuring plan that would include large investments from Asian and European companies, people close to the companies involved said yesterday.

title: A Digital Compass for Those Who Can't Tell Right From Left
description: If women ask for directions while driving and men prefer the company of maps, who uses a dashboard compass? The PNI Corporation, which makes digital compasses for automobiles, says that, given a choice, everyone would. ''A few years ago when I got my first minivan, I had a compass built in,'' said Ingrid Canelo, a brand manager at the company. ''After a while, I was constantly looking at it. It almost becomes like a clock in the car. You get to need it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, HELEN (NEE LEWIS)
description: BARNETT-Helen (nee Lewis). On December 16, 2001, at age 92, after a brief illness. Loving wife of the late Ben. Sister of the late Julian Lewis, sister-in-law to Annette. Devoted mother to Jim Barnett and Alice Schachter, mother-in-law of Sue Barnett and Sherman Schachter. Adoring grandmother to Larry, Liz, David, Carrie and Amy; and their respective spouses Laura, Robert, Beth, Larry and Frank. Beloved ''GG'' to nine great-grandchildren. She was cherished by all who knew her. Services were held.

title: No More Waves From the Tower, Trips to Church, Tattooing Ambitions
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the reopening of the United States Botanic Garden in Washington referred incorrectly to a plant there, Vanilla odorata, which is a source of vanilla beans. It is an orchid that grows as a vine, with narrow leaves about six inches long. It does not have enormous paddle-like leaves or otherwise resemble a banana tree; that impression resulted from its adjacency to such a tree.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Judges Rule In Cement Case
description: A three-judge panel, reversing a trial judge, has ruled that neighborhood residents do not have the legal right to challenge the opening of a nearby cement plant. The residents in the largely black section of Camden had challenged the plant as ''environmental racism.'' By a vote of 2 to 1 on Monday, the panel ruled that the residents cannot cite civil rights law to sue the State Department of Environmental Protection. The residents' lawyer said they would appeal the decision to all 12 judges of the Third Circuit. The $50 million plant opened in June. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: A Design Student Gets Up On the Right Side of the Bed
description: What happens when an established furniture maker sponsors a sofa-bed design competition for students at Pratt Institute? In September, Avery Boardman, a company based in New York, did just that, and the result was a boxy, low-slung model that will go into production next year. With a hollow back and arms, where the cushions can be stored when in bed mode, the convertible was designed by Margo Porras, 28 (seated, with the runners-up, Monica Link-Jackson, left, and Jina Jung). It opens like a regular sofa bed. ''The challenge was to make something that was not big and heavy,'' Ms. Porras said. ''I didn't want to design an elephant.''

title: A Hand-Held Mouse for Those With an Itchy Web Finger
description: At first glance, it may look like a futuristic video-game controller crossed with a giant plastic novelty ring, but once you put the Micro Trac mouse in motion, you'll never need a flat surface to point and click again. The Micro Trac, made by Fellowes, sits in the palm of your hand as you use it to control your computer.

title: Christmas Lesson In the Cathedral
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Six Charged In Securities Fraud
description: Six men have been arrested and charged with conspiracy to commit securities fraud in connection with a boiler-room operation that investigators say bilked investors of $1 million, Mary Jo White, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said yesterday. A seventh defendant, Jeffrey Chaimowitz, a bank manager who is charged but remains at large, is accused of making employees view the movie ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' a film of a David Mamet play, for instruction on how to make false representations and use high-pressure tactics to close deals. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A Third Generation Of Olympians Near
description: Nearly eight years after he took up a sport that few people in this country know anything about, Jim Shea is on the verge of a historic berth on the United States Olympic skeleton team.

title: Sports of The Times; The Nets Audition Every Night
description: EVERY day is a day of reckoning, if you're a member of the Nets.

title: Best-Dressed and on a Budget
description: FOR anyone who has ever spent sleepless nights and fruitless days trying to put together a winning living room, listen up. There are decorating superhumans among us who can redo a room in a weekend. They can furnish an apartment for $1,000. They can turn a car filter, a couple of dowels or a bag of plastic foam cups into a lamp chic enough to land on a magazine cover. Not only can they do this, they do do it, and they do it nonstop.

title: Cloths Large and Small, Signaling Shifts in Tone
description: One of the great dance success stories in recent years has been the development of the ABT Studio Company as a producer of fine young dancers. Under the direction of John Meehan, this junior, or second, company at American Ballet Theater has become known for dancers who are both technically adept and dramatically resonant. And the troupe offered a typically high-level performance on Tuesday night at Kaye Playhouse. If only the three choreographers had achieved as much.

title: Metro Matters; Like Avatars Of Crime, They're Back
description: THE statistics say New York just went through a spike in crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DEBORAH (NEE GITTLEMAN)
description: KAPLAN-Deborah (nee Gittleman). On September 11, 2001, of Paramus, NJ. Beloved wife of Harold, cherished daughter of Ralph and Tillie Gittleman, devoted mother of Jeffrey, Eric, Matthew, and Shaina. Dear sister of Bruce Gittleman. Services Thursday 12:30 P.M. at The Jewish Community Center of Paramus, East 304 Midland Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Contributions may be made to The Jewish Community Center of Paramus. For more information, contact Gutterman-Musicant, 800522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, DONALD CHARLES, REV., S.J.
description: MATTHEWS - Donald Charles, Rev., S.J. Beloved brother of John Jr., Elmer, Dr. Sanford, and Peter. Survived by eight nieces and fourteen nephews and many grand nieces and nephews. Reposing on Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Spellman Hall, Fordham University. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday at 11 AM, at the Fordham University Church. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to The Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau. For information, contact Farenga Brothers Inc Directors, 718-654-0500.

title: In Changed World, Qadaffi Is Changing, Too
description: Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi has notified diplomats in the Netherlands that after two decades of building one of the largest stockpiles of chemical weapons in the Middle East he is ready to sign an international treaty banning them.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: History Unearthed

title: Groups Oppose Proposed Rise In Transit Fares For New Jersey
description: A coalition of mass transit, consumer and environmental advocates joined here today to denounce proposed fare increases for New Jersey Transit buses and trains, urging state lawmakers to raise the consumer gasoline tax instead.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: A Place to Work, and a Place to Mourn
description: To the Editor:

title: Wiring Is Suspected Cause of Cathedral Fire
description: A five-alarm fire that tore through a wing of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Tuesday appears to have been caused by electrical wiring serving computers in the gift shop, fire officials said last night.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Talks End
description: Standard Chartered said it ended talks to buy 75 percent of Egyptian American Bank. Standard Chartered began discussions to buy the bank soon after its two main shareholders, the state-owned Bank of Alexandria and American Express, said in May that they would sell their combined 75 percent stake. James Vaughn, Egyptian's managing director, died of a heart attack Tuesday, soon after he notified investors of the talks' demise. Mr. Vaughn previously worked at Seattle First National Bank and studied at the University of Washington in Seattle. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Yes, Publishers Read for Fun
description: If book publishers and editors actually had to go into a store and buy all the books they say they are going to read over the holidays the slump in book sales might be over. Ask what they're going to do over Christmas and New Year's and the answer is read, read, read. And many of them will. Even for those going skiing or some such. It's as if they hadn't opened a book all year. So it's like asking a chef his day-off plans and being told he's going to a four-star restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALTMAN, BOB
description: ALTMAN-Bob. Gone seven years today. I recall with great pleasure the many good years we had together. Eddie

title: CALENDAR
description: Study of an Artist

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNNEWELL, JAMES F.
description: HUNNEWELL-James F. Of Westwood, MA., and Prouts Neck, ME. on December 19, 2001 at age of 87. James F. Hunnewell, husband of the late Eleanor (McClurg) Hunnewell. Father of James F. Hunnewell, Jr. and Ogden McC. Hunnewell, both of Brookline, and Robert C. Hunnewell of Dedham. Brother of Thomas B. Hunnewell of Boston, Richard F. Hunnewell of Newport, RI and the late William P. Hunnewell of Boston. Also survived by 6 grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Redeemer, Chestnut Hill, MA on January 16 at 11AM. Relatives and friends are invited. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Rogerson Communities of Boston or Dexter School of Brookline. For further information please contact J.S. Waterman & SonsEastman-Waring Funeral Service, Kenmore Square, Boston.

title: Turning to bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Distance Partnerships Now Flourish
description: In days of yore it was a disadvantage to have a regular partner who lived far away, opportunities for practice were limited to national championships and an occasional regional tournament. Nowadays cross-country partnerships flourish because the players can practice online.

title: Star-Spangled or Reflective, Pop Captures the Mood
description: On Dec. 11 at 8:46 a.m., three months after the first airliner hit the World Trade Center, the FM band was dotted with stations playing ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' fulfilling a request from President Bush. Jimi Hendrix's screeching 1969 version, Whitney Houston's sultry 1991 performance and Faith Hill's glossy new 2001 recording were all broadcast at the appointed time. Not every station fell in line and played the anthem, but most did. After all, it was available in every format.

title: Group to Give 150,000 Tickets To Victims' Families
description: As part of a continued push to provide emotional solace to victims of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 as well as economic stimulus to New York cultural institutions, two new plans to give away thousands of free and discounted tickets to cultural and other events are beginning this week.

title: Lacking Suitors, Bonds Remains With the Giants
description: In the nearly 30-year history of baseball's salary arbitration procedure, no arbitrator has been asked to decide the salary of a player who hit 73 home runs the previous season.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Fresh Kills Design Contest
description: Three finalists have been named in a design competition to plan the future of the Fresh Kills landfill. The design teams, announced on Tuesday, were picked by a jury convened by the Department of City Planning. The finalists will now have the chance to negotiate a contract with the city. By order of preference, they are: Field Operations of Philadelphia; JMP Landscape and John McAslan & Partners of London; and RIOS Associates of Los Angeles. The winning proposals call for a 2,200-acre park, including several structures, on top of 50 years of city garbage. The finalists' designs can be viewed on the Web at nyc.gov/freshkills. Denny Lee (NYT)

title: Carnival's Bid for P&O Princess Suffers Setback
description: The Carnival Corporation's unsolicited offer for P&O Princess Cruises appeared to receive a lift this morning only to suffer a setback later in the day.

title: Don't Want to Clean The Linens? Rent Them
description: Despair not. You can still plan an extravagant table for Christmas or New Year, even without a deep linen closet. Tablecloths (for tables up to eight feet long), including velvets and tapestries, can be rented from Linda Lieberman's Just Linens, 770 Lexington Avenue at 60th Street. The cotton and rayon overlay, below, rents for $55; a gold damask bottom cloth, 120 inches in diameter, is also $55. Napkins start at $3 each. Linens are delivered and picked up. For Christmas, orders must be placed by 5 p.m. today at (212) 688-8808, for New Year's Eve, by Dec. 26. A minimum order is $150 (delivery is $35 in Manhattan, or the FedEx fee elsewhere). ELAINE LOUIE

title: U.S. Troops In the Gulf Go Aboard Iranian Ship
description: American naval forces intercepted and boarded an Iranian oil tanker in the Persian Gulf early this morning, drawing a ''strong protest'' from the Iranian government, state television reported.

title: Re: Season's Greetings (Smiley Face Optional)
description: EVERY Christmas card that Montgomery Taylor is sending this year shows him standing in front of the tree in Rockefeller Center -- a friend with a digital camera snapped the picture. Every card carries a handwritten note -- ''Hope your holidays are wonderful,'' he told a couple he had seen at a party the night before.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Unilever Expects A Profit
description: The food and soap maker Unilever said fourth-quarter earnings would rise about 35 percent before costs related to takeovers. As it combines new businesses, the company said it was benefiting from higher prices and savings. Uniliver, the Dutch-British maker of Lipton teas and Dove Soap, said it expected to meet its target for annual earnings growth of at least 10 percent this year and next.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Goldman May Be Fined
description: Japan's top financial market watchdog, the Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission, asked the government to punish the Japanese subsidiary of Goldman, Sachs, accusing it of violating rules on selling stocks short. The commission accused the brokerage firm of failing to declare more than 2,300 of those trades from late 1998 to July of this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Christmas Lesson In the Cathedral
description: To the Editor:

title: New Law Bars Rabin's Killer From Pardon or Commutation
description: The Israeli Parliament overwhelmingly passed a bill today that bars a presidential pardon or commutation of the life sentence of Yigal Amir, the right-wing militant who assassinated Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin six years ago. The bill does not name Mr. Amir, but was drafted with him in mind.

title: Pokmon Get Their Own Player: Gotta Market Them All
description: While the cultural zenith of fame for Pikachu, Misty, Blastoise and the 248 other Pokmon characters has probably passed, Nintendo has just released their very own game player. About the size of a pager, the Pokmon Mini is a cross between a Nintendo Game Boy and another Japanese fad from the past, the Tamagotchi.

title: British Officially Offer to Lead Peacekeepers in Kabul; First 200 Are Due by Saturday
description: Britain formally advised the United Nations yesterday that it would lead a security force in Kabul, Afghanistan, and that an advance contingent of 200 soldiers was expected to arrive by Saturday for the swearing in of the interim government.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT QUESTIONS ECHOSTAR DEAL
description: As part of its inquiry into a plan by EchoStar Communications to buy Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV operation from General Motors, the Justice Department has issued a second request for information about the deal, executives close to the companies said yesterday. The second request, which was widely expected, signals a new, more aggressive phase of the inquiry into the proposed transaction's effects on competition. Opponents of the deal contend that it would create a monopoly on satellite television in the United States, while the companies say the merger is necessary to create a true competitor to the cable industry. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Changing School Admittance
description: The school committee in Cambridge, finding that some of its schools have higher percentages of impoverished students than others, voted to change the way it assigns students to elementary schools. Starting in September, kindergartners will be sent to schools based in part on whether they qualify for subsidized lunches. The committee said it relied on research showing that poor students are influenced by affluent classmates. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwalk: Skakel Trial Date Set
description: A Superior Court judge has set May 7 for the start of the murder trial of Michael C. Skakel, who is charged with bludgeoning Martha Moxley to death in Greenwich in 1975. At a meeting yesterday with prosecution and defense lawyers, Judge John F. Kavenewsky Jr. scheduled jury selection to begin on April 2. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: A Murder Mystery Filmed In Rooms Fit to Kill
description: PERHAPS the rest of the 100 top international designers and architects listed in the January issue of Architectural Digest spent their recent Sunday afternoon in more diligent pursuits, but two of them, Mario Buatta and Thomas Britt, convened in Mr. Britt's Upper East Side maisonette to screen a review copy of a film over lunch.

title: Less Holiday Cheer In the Mail This Year
description: SOME blame the weather, and some blame free-floating anxiety. But whatever the cause, New Yorkers are beginning to talk about the dearth of greeting cards this holiday season.

title: Council Adjourns Itself Into History
description: On its final, bittersweet day of conducting legislative business yesterday, the City Council, with many of its members leaving office because of term limits, approved a slew of zoning changes, made several appointments and generally acted as if it was the end of the school year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sale of Burned Timber Is Delayed to Hear Appeals
description: Responding to a lawsuit filed by environmentalists, a federal judge today prohibited the United States Forest Service from moving ahead with the sale of more than 44,000 acres of burned timber until a hearing can be held on Jan. 3.

title: COMCAST WINS BID FOR AT&T'S CABLE
description: AT&T agreed yesterday to sell its cable television business, the nation's largest, to the Comcast Corporation for about $47 billion in stock.

title: JDS UNIPHASE TO BUY I.B.M. TRANSCEIVER UNIT
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation agreed to buy the optical-transceiver unit of I.B.M. for as much as $425 million. I.B.M. will receive $240 million in JDS stock and $100 million in cash for the business. JDS, which is based in San Jose, Calif., might pay another $85 million in cash or stock in 2003 if the business reaches undisclosed goals. The unit has 115 employees and plants in Rochester, Minn., a JDS spokesman, Jeff Wild, said. The sale is I.B.M.'s latest step to shed less-profitable units within its technology group. Transceivers convert electronic signals carrying phone calls and data into wavelengths of light and beam them through optical fiber.

title: Digital Cameras for Less: How Much Will $300 Buy?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Hung Jury In Murder Case
description: The murder trial of a teenager accused of fatally stabbing a 12-year-old has ended in a hung jury, the Brooklyn district attorney's office said. The defendant, Rickley Gregoire, will be tried again in January, along with Eduardo Hall, another youth accused in the stabbing. Mr. Hall and Mr. Gregoire were both 16 in October 2000 when they were arrested in the stabbing of Anthony Haynes, a 12-year-old immigrant from Guyana who was killed several hours after a fight in the cafeteria at Canarsie High School. The jury in Mr. Gregoire's case voted 11 to 1 on Tuesday in favor of convicting him but after four days of deliberation was unable to reach unanimity, a law enforcement official said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: School Official Is Arrested
description: An acting assistant principal at an intermediate school was charged with criminal possession of a weapon on Tuesday after officers pulled him over for driving through a stop sign, the police said. They said that a loaded .22-caliber pistol was found in the car. The driver, Arthur Alex, 60, works at Intermediate School 349 in Brooklyn. A spokesman for the Board of Education said that Mr. Alex had no disciplinary marks on his record, but that as a result of the incident, he had become ineligible for a permanent assistant principal's or principal's position at a city school. Mr. Alex did not return calls seeking comment.

title: Clash of the Convergers
description: Comcast won the auction for AT&T's cable television business yesterday, but the other big winner was Microsoft. Using its deep pockets, Microsoft gave financial support to the Comcast bid and thus played the spoiler in denying the prize to its archrival, AOL Time Warner.

description: Diageo of Britain and Pernod Ricard of France received approval today from United States antitrust regulators for their joint acquisition of the Seagram wine and spirits business.

The arranger he chose, Nina Gilbert, directs choral activities at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa. Both write and edit music by computer, so it seemed a simple matter to swap files by e-mail.

It is still easy to find personal stories of tragedy and survival on television, but rare to find a report as moving and eye-opening as Tom Brokaw's on ''Dateline'' (tomorrow night at 9 on NBC).

title: Reeling From Riots, Argentina Declares a State of Siege
description: President Fernando de la Ra declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across Argentina today, and the police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at rock-throwing protesters in Buenos Aires and several provincial cities. Five people were killed in the rioting.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Law Puts Reward In Doubt
description: A 27-year-old woman and four companions who helped the police find a mass murder suspect in Sacramento may not receive a $50,000 reward promised by the state because the suspect killed himself. State law limits rewards to cases that lead to arrest and conviction, the governor's office said. The suspect, Joseph Ferguson, 20, a security guard, shot himself after shooting at the police, who had been tipped to his location by the unidentified woman and her companions. Mr. Ferguson, apparently angered over his breakup with his girlfriend, shot five people dead on Sept. 9, the authorities said. Rob Gunnison (NYT)

title: Reading the Meter (and the Customer) From Afar
description: FOR decades, neither rain nor sleet has kept the familiar utility company meter readers from their appointed rounds. But soon technology and terror may alter that tradition. The one stranger that Americans still widely permit to enter backyards and basements could eventually be replaced by automated systems that collect and transmit highly accurate, regularly updated information from electric, gas and other meters to a main office, untouched by human hands.

title: Out to Do Good, Some First-Time Blood Donors Get Bad News
description: After three days of watching endless loops of the World Trade Center towers collapsing on television, Kristina Lakey of Davison, Mich., decided she could not stand by any longer. She had to do something. So on Sept. 14, she recruited her sister, and they went to their church and donated blood.

description: About 1,200 people died in public hospitals in Britain last year because of mistakes in prescribing and administering medicine, according to a report published today by a government watchdog group.

description: Nine months ago, Mike Richter was on crutches, recovering from his second reconstructive knee surgery in less than a year. Last night, Richter, the Rangers' 35-year-old goaltender, was named to the United States Olympic team for the Salt Lake City Games.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Estonia: Premier To Step Down
description: Prime Minister Mart Laar said he would resign on Jan. 8 after a disclosure that one party of his three-party governing coalition had deserted to the opposition. The defection of the Reform Party leaves Mr. Laar with the support of his own Pro Patria Union and the coalition's third member, the Moderate Party. Mr. Laar's decision means Estonia's cabinet also must resign. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: THE program that Jane Paley, newly appointed member of the city's Board of Correction, has been running for the women of Rikers Island is a very little program, averaging an ounce, or perhaps three by four inches, depending on packaging.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Handspring Raises Cash
description: Handspring Inc., the money-losing maker of the Visor hand-held computer, said it had raised $48.5 million from investors including Qualcomm Inc. Qualcomm, which licenses patents for a technical standard used in 96 million mobile phones, bought 1.84 million shares from Handspring for $10 million, or about $5.44 each. Handspring also sold seven million shares to the public at $5.50 each, raising $38.5 million. Handspring's shares rose 89 cents, or 14.5 percent, to $7.01. The money could help ease concern that Handspring will run out of cash before turning a profit, analysts said. Handspring, which makes hand-held devices based on the Palm Inc. operating system, is preparing to introduce a product called Treo that combines the functions of a cellphone and an electronic organizer.

Almaden Research Center, in San Jose, Calif., are announcing today that they have performed the most complex such calculation yet: factoring the number 15.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Automakers Expect Small Sales Gain
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and Honda Motor, Japan's two largest automakers, expect small gains in global sales in 2002. Toyota, which holds more than 40 percent of the Japanese market, expects sales to rise 2 percent when including the subsidiaries Daihatsu and Hino. Exports are expected to fall 10 percent, but Toyota will offset the decline by increasing output at its plants overseas by 16 percent. Honda, meanwhile, expects global sales to rise 6 percent in 2002. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Forecaster Sees 33% Drop In Chip Sales
description: Gartner Dataquest said yesterday that semiconductor companies would end 2001 with revenue of $152 billion, down 33 percent from last year. Gartner estimates that sales will grow 3 percent in 2002, just half the rate predicted recently by the Semiconductor Industry Association. The weak recovery is likely to force some companies to exit the business, Gartner said. It said that NEC of Japan, the sixth-largest chip maker, was hardest hit this year, with sales dropping 49.4 percent. I.B.M., ranked 11th over all but the world leader in partly customized chips, fared best, with chip revenue down 8 percent. Intel, the industry leader, ended up increasing its market share to 15.5 percent from 13.3 percent, despite a sharp drop in revenue. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

Survivors include his wife, Jeanne; his stepmother, Dulcie, of Evanston, Illinois; his brother, Peter of Baltimore; his son, Robert Jr., of San Francisco, and daughters, Sally of Stanford, California and Kathy Crawford of San Carlos, California; and his grandsons, Peter and Matthew Crawford. title: ENERGY COMPANY TAKES STEPS TO INSURE ITS CREDIT RATING
description: Williams Companies, an energy trader and owner of a leading natural gas pipeline network, plans to cut capital spending by $1 billion and sell assets to reassure investors it will not collapse like the Enron Corporation. Proceeds from asset sales next year are expected to total $250 million to $750 million, Williams said. The company, based in Tulsa, Okla., also plans to issue $1 billion in convertible preferred stock next year and to reduce 2002 capital spending by 25 percent, to $3 billion. Williams said the moves would help it retain an investment-grade credit rating. Williams' plan includes selling assets like gasoline stations and ethanol production plants, a spokesman, Jim Gipson, said.

Dirk Kempthorne said the state is projecting an additional $20 million shortfall for the remaining six months of the fiscal year, even after two rounds of budget cuts in August and November. Mr. Kempthorne said he would ask the Legislature to dip into the state's savings account to balance its $2 billion 2002 budget. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Milosevic Prosecutor Wants One Trial
description: The prosecutor of Slobodan Milosevic filed an appeal of a ruling by the United Nations war crimes tribunal that the former president should face two trials rather than one. Carla Del Ponte had argued that the conflicts and charges of war crimes in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo all belonged in one trial because they were part of the same strategy by Mr. Milosevic to create what he saw as an ethnically pure Greater Serbia. The court ruled last week that the links among Mr. Milosevic's indictments were ''too nebulous'' to deal with in one trial, and that two trials would be fairer for Mr. Milosevic and more manageable. Marlise Simons (NYT)

description: Radio advertising sales declined 8 percent in October compared with figures for October 2000, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported. National sales were down 15 percent in October, compared with the same month a year ago, while local sales were down 6 percent.

title: Using E-Mail to Count Connections
description: THE ''six degrees of separation'' theory has been used to explain everything from why it is likely that your neighbor went to school with your doctor to why every film actor in Hollywood is closely linked to Kevin Bacon. The theory was developed in the 1960's by Stanley Milgram, a social psychologist who suggested that every person in the United States is connected through a chain of, at most, six people.

title: Two Added To Ski Team

title: Hawaii's 2 Airlines to Merge via Stock Swap
description: Hawaii's two airlines, battered by the steep drop in tourism after Sept. 11, agreed to merge yesterday in a deal that would place the former president of Continental Airlines in charge of the new combination.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Earthlink Founder Plans New Venture
description: Sky Dayton, the founder of Earthlink, will unveil a nationwide wireless Internet service today. The venture, Boingo Wireless, will offer users flat-rate access to high-speed wireless networks at more than 750 locations. Special Boingo software will enable customers with a single log-on to connect to the high-speed networks, which use a technical standard known as Wi-Fi and are operated by dozens of unrelated companies, through ''hot spots'' in hotels, airports and restaurants. The software provides corporate-level encryption and automatically locates available networks in a user's vicinity. Boingo plans to charge $7.95 for a 24-hour connection at a single venue and as much as $74.95 a month for unlimited access. ''The goal is presenting that connect button to the customer,'' Mr. Dayton said. ''They just click 'connect' and then they're on.'' Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: Thousands on Welfare Face Face a Temporary Gap in Aid
description: Several thousand of New York City's poorest families have been cut off all government assistance and are facing at least 45 days without benefits, falling into a gap between the end of their federal welfare benefits and the start of the state-financed alternative, known as Safety Net, city and state welfare officials confirmed yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

title: Handmade Ornaments, For the Bohemian Tree
description: New York has been blessed lately with new and expanded museum shops. Think of the Neue Galerie New York, with its reproductions of German and Austrian decorative arts; the AsiaStore shop at the Asia Society; the enlarged gift shop at the Lincoln Center satellite of the American Folk Art Museum; and the new MoMA Design Store in SoHo. Now add to that the ground floor gift shop sandwiched into the new building for the American Folk Art Museum, which was designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. The shop offers a wide selection of furniture and hooked rugs and, right now, unusual handmade and signed Christmas tree ornaments. ''The new pieces we sell are in the folk tradition and draw on its iconography,'' said Gerard C. Wertkin, the museum director. The globe covered with a New York City subway map ($10) is by Damen Blumberg, a New York artist. The small papier-mch flying pig ($12) is by Le Hunt of Wisconsin. The twig rooster ($18) is made by Lonnie and Twyla Money, a couple who live in Kentucky. Inset top left, candlesticks with fruit motifs by Sue Parker and Don Gidley of Toronto are $54 each. The redware plate ($36) by Lester Breininger, a Pennsylvania potter, is similar in style to some antique redware in the Ralph Esmerian collection on view at the museum. The ornaments are available at the American Folk Art Museum shop, 45 West 53rd Street in Manhattan. The shop is open daily, 10 to 6. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: The Neediest Cases; Young Woman's New Joy Is Finding Her Relatives
description: Bernice Beyan does not have a photograph of her mother. No keepsakes, not even a memory. At 17, all Ms. Beyan knows is her mother's name, Maybe Beyan, and the stories and memories that her grandmother, Rebecca Weah, has shared with her. Her mother died at the age of 13 while giving birth to her in Monrovia, Liberia. Ms. Beyan has no recollections of her life in Liberia, other than her grandmother's boarding a ship bound for New York and waving goodbye, leaving her in the custody of a man and woman from her hometown who had adopted her.
