description: The FedEx Corporation said today that its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 26 percent as the company received government aid after Sept. 11. FedEx said it might earn less than forecast this quarter.

title: Bloomberg Fills Nine Posts With Government Veterans
description: With less than two weeks before he takes over as mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced the selection of nine more people to serve in his administration, saying that he expected to have most of the senior jobs filled by the time he takes his oath of office on Jan. 1.

title: Fund Raises $285 Million For Start-Ups
description: The Ignition Corporation, a venture capital firm headed by former executives of Microsoft and McCaw, will announce today that it has raised $285 million to back technology start-ups. The fund reflects not only a sign of life in the battered venture-capital market, but also how much that market has changed in the last year or so.

title: Today's Army?
description: To the Editor:

title: Samuel Meyers, 83, President Of a New York U.A.W. Local
description: Samuel Meyers, a labor activist and longtime president of a union local representing automobile workers in the New York area, died at 83 last Saturday in Deerfield Beach, Fla., where he had a winter home. He was a resident of Marine Park, Brooklyn.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T to Sell Cable Unit To Comcast for $47 Billion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALPETER, BURTON F. M.D.
description: SALPETER-Burton F. M.D. died Tuesday, December 18, after 58 years of family practice. Graduate of Far Rockaway High School, University of Virginia and Georgetown Medical School; he served as Director of Family Practice at Peninsula Hospital Center. Accomplishments ranged from tennis junior finalist at Forest Hills, World War II Battalion Surgeon under General Patton, and President of Rockaway Rotary. Beloved husband of Lucy for 53 years, father of Ann Schockett and Steven Salpeter, grandfather of Debra, Erica, Paul and Jeffrey. Services are scheduled for Friday, December 21, at ''Riverside-Boulevard'' Chapel, Hewlett, L.I. Interment at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: Tributes to the Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Puts Pain Aside And Stays Above Rim
description: Marcus Camby could have taken the day off today and no one would have questioned his decision. His aching left foot, which had him contemplating sitting out Tuesday's game in Charlotte, was more painful than usual this morning after he leaped and scrambled his way through a 43-minute effort in the Knicks' victory.

title: People
description: * Cheryl Idell, chief strategic and research officer at the Intermedia Advertising Group, New York, was named to the new post of president.

title: Warm Body, Cold Feet: Stuff for the Slopes
description: People are always saying that skiing is becoming easier and easier. Faster lifts, heated gondolas, man-made snow, shaped skis, softer boots and lighter poles, not to mention microwave popcorn in a slopeside condo and five kinds of nachos in the lodge.

title: Only 5 Days Remain In a Game of Chicken
description: WHEN it comes to exchanging gifts each holiday season, my father and my husband play a harrowing game of chicken.

title: Resting Nuclear Plant Is Finally Put to Sleep
description: The Energy Department announced today that it was closing a nuclear reactor that was built for a program canceled almost 20 years ago. The department has spent about $1 billion on the reactor, with almost half of the money used to keep it in standby condition since 1992 in case anyone could find a use for it.

title: Bluetooth Defies Obituaries
description: BLUETOOTH took a beating in 2001.

title: Arrests in Belgium Highlight Its Role as a Militants' Base
description: Belgian police have arrested a Tunisian-born man they say had intense contacts with Muslim militants across Europe and recruited men for training in the camps of Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, JONATHAN S.
description: LIEBOWITZ-Jonathan S. National Academy of Arbitrators, NY Region, mourns the passing of our longtime colleague and friend and expresses heartfelt sympathy to his wife Helen and family. Mattye Gandel, Chair

title: His Term Ending, Giuliani Celebrates His Record
description: In the first of several farewell appearances yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani listed many of the benchmarks of his administration, like crime reduction, in what seemed an attempt to cement his legacy beyond his much-heralded leadership since Sept. 11.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Ex-Officer Pleads Guilty
description: Michael Quinn, who recently resigned from the New York City Police Department, pleaded guilty yesterday to drunken driving and vehicular manslaughter. The charges stemmed from a car accident in March that killed his passenger, Glen Gerrato of Berkeley Heights, N.J. Investigators said that Mr. Quinn was driving 75 miles an hour in a 30-mile-an-hour zone in his hometown, Rockville Centre, when he lost control of the car. Under a plea agreement, Mr. Quinn will receive a one-year prison sentence. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, MARTIN
description: ANDREWS-Martin. 62, filmmaker, lighting designer and gaffer, died at home in Hoboken, NJ, last Friday of cancer. Location technical director on ''Woodstock,'' Marty most recently lit the Christmas scenes in ''Riding in Cars With Boys.'' Born in NYC, he crewed for Pomfret School and the Univ. of Penn. A passionate sailor, Marty divided his time between homes in Hoboken and Wiscasset, ME. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth and sons Hilary, Alexander and Frederick. Friends and family will gather at the Elks Club, 1003 Washington St, Hoboken, on Sunday, December 23, 2-5 PM. Donations may be made in his name to the Wilderness Society.

title: An Advantage for Seasoned Students
description: The results of the latest state Regents high school exams in English and mathematics show a starkly Darwinian pattern: virtually anyone who can survive to the senior year within the traditional four-year span is able to pass both tests. But for the rest, the road to a high-school diploma can be elusive, as students find courses too hard and are left back, drop out or repeatedly cannot pass the tests.

title: Taliban Chiefs Prove Elusive, Americans Say
description: Virtually the entire top leadership of the Taliban has survived the American bombing and eluded capture by American-backed Afghan forces, according to United States officials and people close to the Taliban.

title: A Muddled Message on Anthrax Vaccine
description: If you had any doubt about how little the nation's top experts really know about anthrax, all you need do is look at the latest step by the federal government to help thousands of people who were potentially exposed to the deadly spores through contaminated mail at postal facilities, government offices or media offices. They were initially told to take antibiotics for 60 days to ward off the disease. Now federal officials have offered to provide anthrax vaccine and another 40 days' worth of antibiotics to anyone who wants added protection against the slight remaining risk of illness.

title: Sharon and Arafat in a Deadly Dance
description: President Bush should be reminded that when Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is given an inch he takes a mile, that when he gets a green light he will not stop at a red one. Washington should inspect Mr. Sharon's moves carefully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, BORIS
description: RIFKIN-Boris, December 18, 2001. Cherished husband of Ruth and the late Lillian. Beloved father of Steven and Valerie Rifkin and Janie and Robert Fisher. Adored grandfather of Cari and Andrew Schwartz, Julie and Wayne Feder and Todd Fisher. Proud greatgrandfather of Joseph, Reuben and Leah Schwartz and Leah Feder. Loving brother of William, Robert and the late Sidney Rifkin. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity. Services Thursday, December 20, 11:30AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 4 about White House Christmas decorations referred incorrectly to Sagamore Hill, one of the presidential homes modeled in miniature. The house, at Oyster Bay, N.Y., was built by Theodore Roosevelt for his family and served as a summer residence while he was president. It was not his boyhood home.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Talks With U.S. On Iraq
description: American and Russian officials opened talks at the Foreign Ministry on the situation in Iraq, including sanctions against Saddam Hussein's government and aid to the country's citizens. A Foreign Ministry statement said that the Kremlin was ready for serious work with Washington on problems in Iraq but that Russia's support for suspending economic sanctions had not changed. John S. Wolf, an assistant secretary of state, is representing the United States in the talks. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Citigroup Goes to the Well Again on Travelers Unit
description: Sandy Weill knows value when he sees it. And now he seems to think that the big run in property and casualty insurance stocks is nearing an end.

title: Afghan Labor, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Shot To Death
description: Two men were found shot to death last night in the stairwell of an apartment building on West 149th Street, the police said. The police were called at 9:30 p.m. by someone who reported hearing a shot fired. When they arrived at the building, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, they found two men, ages 21 and 34, in between the first and second floors, with multiple gunshot wounds. The men, who were not identified, were pronounced dead at the scene.

title: Clearing the Way for Santa's Descent
description: ON an unseasonably warm morning in late November, Jim Glider walked down Park Avenue looking like the anti-Santa. He fit the requirements of jolliness and stoutness, but the giant sack slung over one shoulder was inky black, as were his clothes, hands and a long quiver full of tools. He carried an industrial vacuum that had been yellow but was so smudged that it would soon be black.

title: The Kidd and Martin Show Takes Over in Overtime
description: Kenyon Martin raced to find Jason Kidd at midcourt and slammed him for a heartfelt hug shortly after they had decided the Nets' most dramatic victory of the season with a stunning steal and layup and and then a slam-dunk play against the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Gang Members Plead Guilty
description: After a 14-month spree of robbery, assault and murder in a rivalry between two gangs of immigrants, 10 members of Salvadorans With Pride have pleaded guilty to federal charges. Two men from the rival MS-13 gang were killed. Seven people pleaded guilty on Tuesday in federal court here; three pleaded earlier. After prison, the 10 will be deported. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Bribe Scandal Draws Near To President In Korea
description: Prosecutors said today that they planned to arrest a former top aide to President Kim Dae Jung in a growing bribery scandal that has also raised questions about the roles of two of the president's sons.

title: Becoming Mr. 'Of Thee I Sing'; Lee Greenwood Voices Today's Patriotic Fervor
description: At halftime on Sunday at the Tennessee Titans football game in Adelphia Coliseum, the voice of the announcer boomed over the public address system. ''The men and women of the armed services are proudly defending America's way of life in Operation Enduring Freedom around the world,'' he said. ''The heroism, unity, and American spirit that emerged in the midst of this tragedy will prevail.''

title: As U.S. Offers Anthrax Shots, Safety Debate Begins Again
description: As dozens of Congressional staff members prepared to be vaccinated against anthrax, critics questioned the safety of the vaccine today and complained about the failure of federal health officials to take a stand on whether postal workers who may have been exposed should get the shots.

title: Council Cuts $766 Million From Budget
description: The City Council approved $766 million in spending reductions yesterday to help the city close an estimated $1.3 billion shortfall in the current year's budget. The reductions were approved after the Council negotiated an agreement with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to restore some cuts to cultural institutions, libraries and social services.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Rights Ordinance Faces Challenge
description: Miami-Dade County voters could go to the polls in September to decide whether to repeal a county amendment banning discrimination against gays and lesbians. The Miami-Dade elections supervisor, David Leahy, on Tuesday certified enough signatures on a petition by a coalition of religious and civic groups to require the vote on the 1998 amendment to the county's human rights ordinance. County commissioners must repeal the ordinance or approve a referendum.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 3 about Mary Whitehouse, a British crusader against pornography, misidentified her native county. Her birthplace, Nuneaton, is in Warwickshire, not Cheshire.

title: Harrison Mosher Hayford, 85, Professor and Melville Expert
description: Harrison Mosher Hayford, a leading expert on Herman Melville, died on Dec. 10 in Evanston, Ill. He was 85.

title: Terrifying a Mass Killer With Pure Brain Power
description: PURSUIT

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Cable Agreement
description: Reach Ltd., equally owned by Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd. and the Telstra Corporation, will purchase undersea cable and transmission capacity in Asia from Level 3 Communications Inc. to expand in Japan, Taiwan and Korea. Reach will receive $90 million of working capital from Level 3 and agreed to spend $170 million in the next year on cable systems, Telstra said. The company, whose owners are the biggest phone companies in Hong Kong and Australia, is effectively paying about $80 million for cables, data stations, landing stations, licenses and transmission capacity that cost Level 3 about $436 million to build, the Reach director of corporate development, Robert Kenny, said.

title: Procrastinator's Paradise
description: IF there were no Internet, last-minute Christmas shoppers would be facing an intense weekend of running (or driving) around town looking for the elusive perfect gifts. But now, Web sites enable procrastinators to stay home and relax (or sit in the office and pretend to be working). Most sites will accept late orders until tomorrow and most offer next-day or second-day delivery -- for an extra fee. And if you find the perfect gift on Christmas Eve, you can always print out a picture and wrap it with an IOU.

title: Porcelain Bowls Pretty Enough To Decorate With Soup
description: Andy Shaw, a British ceramist, has fused the delicacy of porcelain with the singular look of hand-thrown pottery. His porcelain bowls, below, are handmade on a potter's wheel but are only one-sixteenth of an inch thick. They are decorative yet functional enough to hold soup. ''Just don't put it in the dishwasher,'' said Mr. Shaw, who lives in Derbyshire. The bowls (in blue, a combination of black and white, or a combination of brown and white) come in four sizes. Below are bowls 7 1/2 inches ($130 to $150) and 3 inches ($45 to $50) in diameter. They are also available at 11 1/2 inches ($200 to $250) and 5 inches ($70 to $75). At the American Craft Museum, 40 West 53rd Street; DKNY, 655 Madison Avenue (60th Street); and Shi, 233 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street). ELAINE LOUIE

title: U.S. Tells Colombia to Improve Rights Record Before It Gets Aid
description: The House attached a series of conditions to American aid to Colombia today, demanding that the government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence there. The Senate, which initiated the restrictions, is expected to concur.

title: Whither the Weather?
description: We are told that because we drive gas-guzzling utility vehicles and insist on repeatedly exhaling, greenhouse gases are entrapping the warm air, raising the earth's temperature, which will inexorably melt the polar icecaps and drown us all.

title: One Woman's Quest, Fraught With Cultural Land Mines
description: The woman nattering on about Afghanistan has none of the shiny urgency of a Tim Russert or a Cokie Roberts. She endlessly circles her subject and never seems to land on it. Her words are often ridiculously quaint, and so polysyllabic that they would never squeeze naturally into a sound bite.

title: NTT DoCoMo Breaks Off Talks With South Korean Company
description: In a sharp setback for SK Telecom, one of South Korea's largest companies, plans for the Japanese wireless phone giant NTT DoCoMo to infuse it with cash and take a 14.5 percent equity stake fell apart today when NTT DoCoMo broke off talks, both companies said.

title: As Economy Slumps, Even Manhattan Rents Fall
description: Rents on thousands of apartments in Manhattan have tumbled in the last few months as the economy has worsened and fallout from the terrorist attack has spread beyond Lower Manhattan.

title: Jos Fajardo, 82, Flutist And Bandleader, Is Dead
description: Jos Fajardo, a Cuban flutist who was one of the most influential bandleaders in Latin music, died on Dec. 11 in Jersey City. He was 82 and lived in West New York, N.J.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: IDT Acquires Winstar Assets
description: The IDT Corporation has acquired substantially all of the assets of the bankrupt Winstar Communications for about $42.5 million, Winstar lawyers said. IDT will pay $30 million in cash plus $12.5 million in its own shares, said Mark J. Shapiro, a Winstar lawyer. IDT will also assume some Winstar debts and put up $60 million in cash reserves to cover operating costs. The deal brought in substantially less than company executives had hoped for, but the cash infusion will allow Winstar to maintain services to its 29,000 customers, which include the Defense and Justice Departments and the Securities and Exchange Commission. The IDT bid was approved over an 11th-hour attempt Tuesday by Winstar's former chairman and chief executive, William Rouhana, who resigned from Winstar on Nov. 21. Mr. Rouhana offered $30 million in cash, $25 million in subordinated notes and a minority equity stake in the company, but Mr. Shapiro said that transaction would have taken 8 to 10 days to close. The New York-based Winstar, which uses a fixed-wireless technology to transmit voice and data over radio signals, filed for bankruptcy protection in April. Ann Wozencraft (NYT)

title: India Seeks International Support to Force Pakistan to Crack Down on Militants
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said today that India was vigorously pursuing diplomatic efforts to get Pakistan to crack down on two militant groups that India blamed for an attack on its Parliament last week. But he also said that if peaceful means failed, India would consider other options.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEYK, HUCKLEBERRY PAUL
description: FEYK-Huckleberry Paul. 12/20/612/8/94. A cherished son and loving brother. We love you and miss you. Mom, Charlie & Crai

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, SAUL
description: WEBER-Saul. Born October 10, 1915 in Hartford, CT. Died on December 16, 2001 in Hartford, CT. Husband of the late Caroline Fox Weber for 50 years, he is survived by his wife Ziona Kaplan Weber of West Hartford, CT, his daughter Nancy Weber and son-in-law Robert Cahn of New York City, his son Nicholas Fox Weber and daughter-in-law Katharine Weber of Bethany, CT., and the four grandchildren he adored-Rose, Lucy, Charlotte and Albert. President of Fox Press in Hartford, an avid angler and golfer, Saul was one of life's true enjoyers. Memorial contributions to benefit the Saul and Caroline Weber Scholarship Fund at the Hartford Art School may be sent to the Hartford Art School, University of Hartford, 200 Bloomfield Ave, West Hartford, CT. 06117.

title: Technology Tips for the Holidays
description: It's holiday time, and I've got gift-giving on my mind. I wracked my brain: What could I send to all of this newsletter's 170,000 subscribers as a token of thanks for their readership? DVD players? Digital cameras? Peanut-size camcorders?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, VALERIE
description: ELLIS-Valerie. Passed away on December 16, 2001 at her Miami Beach home at the age of 86. Born January 4, 1915 in Newark, NJ and married to the late Abraham Ellis. She is survived by four children, Carol Shapiro (Dr. Stanley), Lynn Clurman (David), Dr. Eugene Ellis (Madeline) and Dr. Stephen Ellis (Ursulla), nine grandchildren, Lara Shapiro, Jessica Shapiro, Brian Shapiro, Benjamin Metzger, Matthieu Clurman, Lauren Ellis, Ryan Ellis, Heidi Ellis and Antonio Ellis and two sisters, Terri Tortorello and Agnes Silbernagel. Funeral services will take place Friday, December 21, at 8 AM at the Keri Memorial Home, 125 Main St, Lincoln Park, NJ. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Alzheimer's Association, 1175 North East 125th St, N. Miami, FL.

title: Everybody's a Champ
description: o the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Leads Game Makers
description: The Sony Corporation has sold 1.5 million PlayStation 2 video game consoles since Thanksgiving, giving it a lead over Nintendo, which markets the GameCube, and Microsoft, with its Xbox. Since introducing the game console in March 2000, Sony has sold more than 20 million units, about one-third of those in the United States. In November, however, Nintendo and Microsoft started selling their own game machines, which have sold more than one million units each. In response, Sony has lowered the price of its consoles in some markets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Widens Rule Covering Stock Options
description: To the surprise of shareholder advocates, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously yesterday for far greater disclosure of corporate stock option plans.

title: Goalies Make Big Plays; Rangers and Devils Tie
description: The Rangers were without their best player, Eric Lindros, and their captain, Mark Messier, last night, but they played the Devils to a tie at Madison Square Garden and almost came away with a dramatic victory.

title: Israelis Discuss Security Matters With Arafat's Military
description: Although it declared Yasir Arafat irrelevant a week ago, the Israeli government signaled today that perhaps there was a little relevance left in him after all.

title: Leonard T. Kurland, 79, Neurologist-Researcher
description: Dr. Leonard T. Kurland, a neurologist who mined the science of epidemiology for techniques that led to new thinking about diseases in his field and others, died on Dec. 4 at his home in Rochester, Minn. He was 79.

title: INSIDE
description: A New Realm of Secrecy

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: For the Glass House Crowd at Christmas, No Tinsel Please
description: IF you are a minimalist, the Christmas season poses certain problems. Your midcentury modern rooms do not appreciate the clutter of trees, ornaments and boughs of holly. At your house, it's light and space and uninterrupted planes. You are not about to subject the simple elegance of your Barcelona chairs to the party scene from ''The Nutcracker.''

title: Downtown Renewal Head Vows Independent Effort
description: John C. Whitehead, the newly appointed chairman of the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Commission, has been making the rounds of business and civic groups for a week assuring them that he will lead a politically independent effort to rejuvenate the area and build a monument to rival the Lincoln, Jefferson or Vietnam Memorials.

title: 3 Minutes of Patriotism on Film
description: Chuck Workman buzzed from room to room in his second floor office suite in the flats south of Beverly Hills, putting the finishing touches on his latest film, ''The Spirit of America,'' a short montage of moments from classic Hollywood films that will be on one-fourth of the nation's movie screens by Christmas Day, some as early as Friday.

title: Screen Play
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slide Show: Argentina in Crisis
description: Protestors surged into the streets in early hours of Thursday to protest their government's policies.

title: Violent Crime Reported Declining in Workplace
description: Reflecting the drop in violent crime over the last seven years, violence in the workplace declined 44 percent since 1993, a Justice Department report said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Limelight Gets Liquor License
description: The state has approved a liquor license for the Limelight nightclub once it is under new management. The club's manager, Peter Gatien, filed for bankruptcy after being convicted of tax fraud. The club will be operated by a partnership led by John Blair, left, who agreed to pay off Mr. Gatien's $3.6 million debt. In exchange, the government will issue Mr. Blair a long-term lease for the property at 20th Street and Avenue of the Americas. In 1998, city prosecutors tried unsuccessfully to convict Mr. Gatien, who was accused of running a drug supermarket at Limelight. Mr. Blair promised neighbors a strict no-drugs policy.

title: Sports of The Times; Hamilton Following Jordan's Lead
description: THE chase is on, around the screens and after the quick-triggered guards and in the vague direction of the Michael Jordan standard. So this is what stardom is all about? Pushing and pursuing until your spindly legs are begging for another line of work? Playing every night as if your reputation, not just a game, is on the line?

title: United Airlines Mechanics' Strike Is Blocked by Bush
description: President Bush blocked a strike yesterday at United Airlines, the second time this year that the White House has intervened to prevent a walkout at a large carrier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ELIZABETH (NEE PRIDDAY)
description: WILSON-Elizabeth (nee Pridday), 73. Loving mother of Edward Wilson, grandmother of Cameron and Caitlin Wilson, beloved sister of Jeanne P. Jolliffe. Memorial mass is at St. Paul the Apostle, at 10 A.M. Friday. Contributions to Deserving Poor Boys Priesthood Association.

title: Police and Firefighters Win Court Victory in Seeking Raises
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the city's police and firefighter unions may ask a state panel to help resolve contract disputes. Union leaders had long sought that change in the hope that they would win significant raises that would make their pay comparable to that in suburban departments.

title: Trains, Planes, Pains
description: To the Editor:

title: Daily Goodbyes, a Simple Life and a Devotion to Things Portuguese
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: South Korea Reports a Widening Income Advantage Over North
description: The people of South Korea are more than 12 times richer on average than those of North Korea and are steadily widening the gap, according to statistics released today by the South Korean government.

title: Amnesiac Recalls His Best Lines
description: A man out of place arrives in a small town and finds himself, while David Ogden Stiers, as Doc, puts one of his caring paws on the confused young fella's shoulder.

title: St. John's Struggles to Edge St. Francis
description: The holidays are coming, the ranked teams and the Big East schedule are looming and St. John's is still trying to find itself.

title: Life of Clocks, Measured In Passion
description: Collectors can be wonderfully eccentric. Winthrop Kellogg Edey, a renowned clock collector who lived in Manhattan and died in 1999 at 61, stayed up all night and slept all day.

description: Marian Goodman

description: To the Editor:

description: Tibor de Nagy

description: A gift list with the Personal Health column in Science Times on Dec. 4, offering ideas for people with hearing loss, misstated the telephone numbers for the League for the Hard of Hearing. The numbers are (917) 305-7700; TTY (917) 305-7999; fax (917) 305-7888.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Pentagon's decision to cancel a Navy missile defense program misstated the name of a military policy Web site directed by John Pike, a critic of such programs. It is GlobalSecurity.org (not .com).

title: A Leaping Lepidopterist Stalks His Prey
description: Sugarplums, go home! Let the bugs take over.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Terror Fears Vs. Free Speech
description: The lower house of parliament overwhelmingly endorsed amendments to media laws that would bar the news media and computer networks from ''popularizing or justifying terrorism and extremism'' and from publishing or broadcasting statements that support or justify extremism and terrorism ''if they complicate antiterrorist operations or advocate or justify resistance of counterterrorist operations.'' The Kremlin says it opposes the two measures. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: INSIDE
description: Hamas Leader Defies Arafat

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ruling Deferred In Overcharge Suit
description: A federal judge postponed for at least three weeks his ruling on Microsoft's $1 billion plan to equip needy schools with computers to settle claims it overcharged consumers. Judge J. Frederick Motz of the United States District Court delayed his decision on the settlement to give Microsoft and the plaintiffs who are settling more time to negotiate an agreement with lawyers opposed to the settlement. The lawsuits accuse Microsoft of abusing its Windows monopoly by overcharging customers for the personal computer operating system and other programs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHER, LILLIAN
description: FISHER-Lillian. Dear Mom, missing you more with every year. Wish you were here. With all our love. Amy, Lily and Mai Mai

title: Cadillac, Too, Shifting Focus To Trucks
description: Cadillac has built a pickup truck the Cadillac of pickups, nearly three tons worth, available in sable black, white diamond or silver sand, with the familiar Cadillac coat of arms stretched across its hulking grill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, CLAIRE
description: WINKLER-Claire. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Claire Winkler. May the Almighty console her family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Knicks Fail to Answer Their Late Wake-Up Call
description: Marcus Camby, the Knicks' tallest starter and their best finisher, was right in front of the rim. Only a straight-up dunk would have been more convenient. But in a sequence that brought to mind Charles Smith's missed opportunities in the 1993 Eastern Conference finals, Camby could not convert.

title: India Recalls Envoy to Pakistan Over Attack on Parliament
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 21  India recalled its high commissioner to Pakistan today and terminated bus and train service to Pakistan to show its deep displeasure with what it called Pakistan's failure to crack down on two Pakistan-based groups that India has accused of carrying out a suicide attack on parliament.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Tuesday about the effect of the collapse of the Enron Corporation on its corporate art collection misstated the surname of a curator at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, who was commented on the program's ambition. He is Barry Walker, not Martin.

title: U.N. Picks Britain to Run A Security Force for Kabul
description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously today to authorize a British-led international force to provide security in and around Kabul, the Afghan capital.

title: Cendant Is Said to Be in Talks For U.S. Operations of Budget
description: The Cendant Corporation is in discussions to acquire the American operations of Budget Group, the troubled car rental company, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Diagnosis of World's Health Focuses on Economic Benefit
description: For $101 billion a year in medical research and treatments, eight million lives could be saved annually in the developing world, and $186 billion a year in world income now lost to illness could be recovered. So concludes a report on economics and health released yesterday by the World Health Organization.

title: Autos On Friday/Design; G.M. Turns the Corner And Rediscovers Style
description: LAST January, when Robert A. Lutz described future-car designs at the Detroit auto show as ''angry kitchen appliances,'' his put-down no doubt included vehicles from General Motors, which was widely derided for its bizarre Pontiac Aztek. Next month, Mr. Lutz, former president of Chrysler, will hold court at the show as vice chairman of G.M.'s North American operations, and the company's concept cars will have come from his kitchen.

title: The Big City; Christmas And the Spirit Of Commerce
description: OUR text for this, the fourth shopping day before Christmas, is from a scene in Macy's locker room in ''Miracle on 34th Street.'' The head of the store's toy department has just given Kris Kringle, the newest Santa Claus, a list of overstocked toys to be foisted on the children in his lap.

title: KILLINGS INCREASE IN MANY BIG CITIES
description: Homicides have increased sharply this year in many large cities, a development that troubles law enforcement officials and experts who fear it may signal a return to rising crime rates after a large decline in the 1990's.

title: The Lure of a Maryland Marsh

title: Album of the Week
description: NORTH MISSISSIPPI ALLSTARS: ''51 Phantom'' (Tone-Cool). If you ever doubted that blues has within it a very happy music, here's your proof. The young trio from the Mississippi's hill country -- Luther Dickinson on guitar, Cody Dickinson on drums and Chris Chew on bass -- do put some dire monochord drones into their second album. It's a sound legacy they've inherited from their local heroes R. L. Burnside and Junior Kimbrough. But even at their most traditional, a fuzz-guitar cover of Kimbrough's dark ''Lord Have Mercy,'' the North Mississippi Allstars take hill-country music and make it highly amiable.

title: Meatpackers' Profits Hinge On Pool of Immigrant Labor
description: The indictment of Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest meat processor, on charges that it conspired to smuggle illegal immigrants to work at its plants, is a sign of how dependent the American food and agriculture system has become on foreign-born workers, many of them here illegally.

title: How Being Punched Out Ends Up Fine

Here the bully, instead of kicking sand in the weakling's face and calling him skinny, punches him out in front of his 12-year-old daughter when he complains that the bully has broken the rules and taken his company parking space. Instead of following a Charles Atlas regimen, the weakling takes a crash course in martial arts with a former star of grade-C kung fu movies.

title: UNIVISION ACQUIRES RIGHTS FROM TWO PROGRAMMERS

The transaction will give Univision, based in Los Angeles, broadcast rights in the United States to Televisa and Venevision programming through 2017 and expand its programming. In exchange, Venevision, based in Venezuela, will receive warrants to buy about $112 million in Univision stock, increasing its stake to 19 percent from 18 percent. Televisa, based in Mexico, will get warrants to buy about $363 million in Univision stock and agreed separately to buy $375 million in Univision preferred shares. Its stake will increase to 15 percent from 6 percent.

Shareholders of record on Dec. 31 will receive one additional common share for each share they own, payable on Jan. 16, the company said. Shares of Liz Claiborne had risen 21 percent this year as the company increased sales and profit, helped by demand for accessories, Monet jewelry and clothing brands like Crazy Horse and Villager. Shares fell 78 cents yesterday, to $49.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDRICKSON, EDWIN F.
description: HENDRICKSON-Edwin F. Died on December 18, 2001 at his home in Glen Head, NY with his family at his bedside. Cause of death was pancreatic cancer. Born on December 29, 1910 in the then farming community of Bridgehampton, NY, to Howard and Edith (nee Rogers) Hendrickson. He attended public school there and went on to receive both his undergraduate and law degrees from Cornell University. He was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1941. His first employment was with the firm of Root, Clark, Buckner and Ballentine in New York City. In 1941 he was called to active duty in the U.S. Army. He served as an Artillery Officer with the First Infantry Division in campaigns in North Africa and Sicily and landed on Omaha Beach during the Normandy Invasion. At the end of World War II, Mr. Hendrickson stayed in the U.S. Army Reserves eventually retiring with the rank of Colonel. His military service having begun in the horse-drawn artillery was completed in the age of the computer. Returning to civilian pursuits in 1946, he rejoined his former firm. Two years later he joined the firm of Payne, Wood and Littlejohn in Glen Cove, NY for a career that spanned over 50 years and led to a senior partnership. Greatly respected in the legal profession, Mr. Hendrickson was honored this past April by the Nassau County Bar Association in celebration of the sixtieth anniversary of his admission to the Bar. Mr. Hendrickson was an avid golfer all his life. As a youth in the 1920s, he caddied at the National Golf Links and the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club at Southampton, NY, thus helping finance his college education. Later he was a member of the Cherry Valley Club at Garden City, NY and the Piping Rock Club at Locust Valley, NY. Aged 88, he sank his last hole-in-one at the Miles Grant Country Club in Stuart, FL, where he and his wife of 63 years, Margaret Weeks Hendrickson, had wintered for several years. Both had previously wintered in Homestead, FL for over 25 years. Besides belonging to a number of professional organizations, Mr. Hendrickson was a member of the Hempstead Harbour Yacht Club, the First Division Society, the Holland Society and the Townsend Society of America. In addition to his wife, Mr. Hendrickson is survived by his children, Edwin, Jr. of Sag Harbor, NY, Howard of Tarrytown, NY, and Margaret H. Kessler of Atlanta, GA. His survivors also include three grandchildren, two great grandsons, a brother Richard of Bridgehampton, NY, and a sister Edith Williams of Raleigh, NC. There will be a memorial service held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Sea Cliff, NY. The family prefers, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network, PO Box 1010, Torrance, CA 90505 or the Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590. Committal will be private. For information, contact Whitting Funeral Home 516671-0807.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Shift At Eurotunnel
description: Eurotunnel, which operates the Channel Tunnel rail link between Britain and France, said Philippe Lazare, the chief executive, would resign over a difference of views regarding management. Mr. Lazare, 44, held the post for less than a year. Richard Shirrefs, the chief financial officer, will succeed him as of Jan. 1. Mr. Shirrefs, 46, a former securities analyst, has been Eurotunnel's chief financial offer since 1996. Eurotunnel also said that it expected second-half earnings to be lower than analysts had expected as a result of the economic slowdown and the foot-and-mouth disease that affected livestock in Britain. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The American Prisoner
description: As much as his family would like the nation to see John Walker Lindh as a confused young man who somehow stumbled into trouble in Afghanistan, adolescent innocence is not the first thought that comes to mind in considering this curious case. Evidence so far disclosed suggests that treason would be too strong a charge to stamp on Mr. Walker's association with the Taliban. But he made some serious mistakes and will have to face the legal consequences. The kind of indictment considered by the Justice Department -- aiding a terrorist organization -- sounds about right. It carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. Someone convicted of treason can be sentenced to death.

title: Argentina Unraveling
description: With severe economic troubles, weak leadership and a restive population, Argentina has been courting trouble for months. It arrived with the collapse of the elected government and a second day of deadly rioting yesterday in the streets of Buenos Aires and other cities. Whether Argentina comes out of this crisis as a stable democracy will depend on the restraint of its army, the patience of its people and steady leadership by the successor to President Fernando de la Ra, who resigned yesterday.

title: FRIENDLY ICE CREAM COMPLETES A REFINANCING TO CUT DEBT
description: Friendly Ice Cream, an ice cream maker and restaurant operator, said yesterday that it had completed a refinancing to reduce debt by about $30 million. The financing includes a $34.5 million sale and lease-back of 45 restaurants, $55 million in mortgages and a $30 million loan. Friendly expects the refinancing to add $700,000, or 9 cents a share, to fourth-quarter earnings. The company said on Monday that holders of $53.7 million in debt had agreed to sell their notes at no more than 80 cents on the dollar. The refinancing plan was intended to replace about $80 million in bank credit lines and loans.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Sales To Fall
description: Japanese automobile sales will probably decline for the second consecutive year in 2002 as fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States continues to hurt the global economy, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said. The industry group expects sales to fall 0.7 percent next year, to 5.9 million cars. Sales of passenger cars are expected to fall 4.6 percent while sales of minicars, which have engines of less than 660 cubic centimeters, are expected to rise 1.6 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Car Plant Planned
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan and PSA Peugeot Citron of France said yesterday that they would build a 1.5 billion euro ($1.4 billion) plant for a new range of subcompact cars in the Czech city of Kolin, about 40 miles east of Prague. In a 50-50 venture, Peugeot will oversee purchasing and logistics, while Toyota will handle development and production of the new 1.0-liter, low-emission car. The car will be aimed at Europeans who usually buy used cars. The plant will employ 2,000 people and produce up to 300,000 cars a year, Peugeot said. All three of the companies' brands, Peugeot, Citron and Toyota, will offer different body styles on the same mechanical platform. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 2 Sentenced In Stock Case
description: Two executives of a now-defunct stock brokerage firm in Millburn, N.J., that a jury said swindled customers out of more than $100 million have been sentenced to federal prison terms. The executives of the First Interregional Equity Corporation were found to have used the money for personal gain, including vacations, home furnishing and clothing. Judge William Bassler of Federal District Court sentenced Peter Goettlich, 47, of Livingston on Dec. 10 to 63 months in prison and ordered $10 million to be paid in restitution. His brother David Goettlich, 43, of Florham Park, was ordered to serve 46 months and pay $800,000 in restitution.

title: From Math To Madness, And Back

They live in a crystalline world of perfect platonic forms. An ice palace. But they also live in the common world where things are transient, ambiguous, subject to vicissitudes.'' Mr. Nash, whose life is a case study in the difficulty -- and also the wonder -- of living in both, now inhabits a third: the treacle palace of middlebrow Hollywood moviemaking, in which ambiguity is dissolved in reassuring platitudes and freshly harvested tears.

description: The overseer of the federal fund set up for the families of those killed or injured in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks estimated today that the fund could cost taxpayers as much as $6 billion and would provide tax-free awards, on average, of approximately $1.65 million for the families of those who died in the attacks.

description: SULLIVAN - John J. Retired NYPD, Dean and Professor John Jay College and Professor at Mercy College. Survived by his wife Theresa (nee Chambers), five beautiful children, John L., Marybeth, Tim, Matt and Eileen. Daughters-in-law (nee Marybeth Robertson and Karen Comerford. Dear grandchildren Kerry, Allie, Daniel and Connor. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30AM, Transfiguration Church, Tarrytown. Visiting 2-4 & 7 - 9 Friday Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry.

title: Senators Press for an Inquiry On U.S. Intelligence Lapses
description: With the Taliban vanquished in Afghanistan, prominent senators put the Bush administration on notice today that the time was nearing for a broad investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks and the government's failure to forecast or prevent them.

title: Cost Controls Help Raise Nike's Profit
description: Nike Inc. said today that its profit rose 8.3 percent in its most recent quarter as the company controlled costs, increased sales overseas and sold more clothing in the United States.

title: The Avis Ski Saver Package
description: The Avis Ski Saver package includes a 20 percent discount or more on rental rates and a ski-rack rental, unlimited mileage and a one-year subscription to Ski or Skiing magazine. It's available at participating airport sites in western states and Canada through April 30. Weekly rates require a five-night minimum and a Saturday-night stay. There are blackout dates during the holidays, and availability is limited. Taxes and fees are extra. A reservation is required, and the ski rack will not fit subcompacts; (800) 230-4898 or www.avis.com .

title: Past Economic Cures Are Now Fuel for a Crisis
description: In the end, the Argentine miracle worker could not work his magic again.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Covad Exits Bankruptcy
description: Covad Communications, a provider of high-speed Internet services, emerged from bankruptcy yesterday after reaching a deal to eliminate $1.4 billion of debt by offering a combination of cash and equity to its debt holders. Covad, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., also received $150 million of loans and service payments from SBC Communications, providing it with a cash cushion. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Whimsy Fights Violence in a Vendetta
description: Repertory programmers, take note: ''Behind the Sun,'' the new film from the Brazilian director Walter Salles, would make a good double feature with Todd Field's ''In the Bedroom,'' released last month to general critical approval. Mr. Field's movie, based on a short story by Andre Dubus, uses understated sympathy to explore a father's act of vengeance for the murder of his son. Its power comes from the spectacle of a civilized, middle-class Maine doctor succumbing to the atavistic impulse to answer violence with violence.

title: A Real Home for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: DNA Matches Surge, Aiding in the Identification of Victims
description: The number of victims of the World Trade Center attack whose remains have been identified and released to families has increased sharply in the past few days, largely because of a surge in DNA matches confirmed by the New York City medical examiner's office.

title: Tourists Line Up for Ferry as Liberty Island Is Reopened
description: Liberty and Ellis Islands, which had been closed since Sept. 11, reopened to the public yesterday, with hundreds of people undergoing a strict new security screening to see the newly resonant icons close up.

title: You Don't Want to Levitate? Hold On
description: Even in the new Times Square, the bizarre is not unusual. Still, the sight of a levitating woman must be counted remarkable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, MASHA GREENHOUSE
description: SOLOMON-Masha Greenhouse, died peacefully in her sleep on December 18, 2001. Widow of the late Ed Solomon. She is mourned by her sons, Mark and Roy, and their wives, Peggy Eliot and Yvonne Van Cort, her grandchildren, Ben, Laina, Ellie and Jonah, and his wife Elkie, and the great-grandchildren, Sorah Esther, Eli Moshe, and Shira, and her sister, Sophie Greenhouse Lehman. Services were held Thursday. No flowers, please.

title: Saluting, Not Repeating, the Standards
description: The pianist Kenny Barron has versatility; tracing the high points of his 40-year career proves it. They include solo piano albums, imaginative stretchings of the post-bebop language in the 1980's, phenomenally empathetic duets with Stan Getz at the end of that saxophonist's life, a sideman job with Ornette Coleman at Lincoln Center in 1997 that still glows in retrospect, and conceptual albums with a revolving cast of jazz and para-jazz players.

title: Both Parties Deflect Blame For Stalemate On Economy
description: Acknowledging the risks of their failure to settle on a recession-fighting package, leaders of the two parties in Congress said today that they would take up the issue again next month when they return from their holiday recess.

title: DOLLAR THRIFTY TO CUT SALARIES OF 40 TOP EXECUTIVES
description: Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group plans to reduce salaries for executives and suspend 401(k) contributions and pay raises in 2002 after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks reduced demand for rental cars. Wages for the top 40 executives at Dollar Thrifty, the owner of Dollar Rent a Car Systems and Thrifty Inc., will be pared as much as 22 percent, a spokeswoman said. Dollar Thrifty said in October that it would eliminate 1,200 jobs and reduce its rental-car fleet about 20 percent. Dollar Thrifty, based in Tulsa, Okla., had an 83 percent decline in third-quarter profit, and said the attacks deepened a slide in travel and rental-car demand caused by the recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASBURGER, ALBERT F.
description: STRASBURGER-Albert F., 90. An attorney, died December 19, 2001. Funeral services will be held Saturday at Simpson-Gaus Funeral Home, Kingston, New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Aid For Russia To Destroy Weapons
description: Britain will help Russia get rid of its 40,000-ton stockpile of chemical weapons under a treaty signed on the eve of a meeting in London between Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Vladimir V. Putin. Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon told his Russian counterpart, Sergei B. Ivanov, that Britain understood the ''daunting task'' Moscow faced and the need for international assistance. Britain will contribute $17 million over the next three years. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Despite Sneezes, No Cold Yet in Brazil
description: As a rising tide of popular frustration with the precarious state of the Argentine economy swept away the government of President Fernando de la Ra today, the financial markets of Brazil and neighboring nations took the turmoil in stride, suggesting that the damage may not spread much beyond Argentina.

title: The 'Portraits' and Me
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprewell Isn't Banking on All-Star Spot
description: Latrell Sprewell had just had another spectacular game, a 30-point outing in Tuesday's victory at Charlotte. As the news media converged on Sprewell for a postgame interview, Marcus Camby, sitting in nearby locker, began chanting, "All-star, baby. All-star."

title: Saudis Assail 'Media Blitz' Against Them In the West
description: Venting new frustration at how Saudi Arabia is being portrayed in the West, two of the kingdom's top officials have publicly assailed what they called unfair and biased news coverage, with the defense minister citing a ''slanderous campaign.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMPHREYS, GEORGE H., II, M.D.
description: HUMPHREYS-George H., II, M.D. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons are deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. George H. Humphreys II. From 1946 to 1969, Dr. Humphreys was Attending Surgeon and Director of the Surgical Service at The Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York, and Valentine Mott Professor of Surgery and Chairman of the Department of Surgery at the College of Physicians & Surgeons. He led the Department of Surgery through a period of growth and achievement, and was among the first to perform several procedures of pediatric and thoracic surgery, a field in which he had a special interest. Born in New York City in 1903, he was educated at Harvard College, Harvard Medical School, and the College of Physicians & Surgeons, and began his career at the Hospital as an intern in 1930. He was a beloved surgeon, who trained generations of the nation's leading surgeons and professors of surgery. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and C.E.O. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University

title: Divinity School Dean
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Moves Toward Talks
description: The Unification Ministry issued a new appeal to North Korea to resume talks. The call came after North Korea's Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of the Fatherland said the North would stick by timetables agreed on between the Koreas for cooperation on a range of issues, including visits between members of families divided by the Korean War. North Korea's statement was a change from its angry comments after talks broke up last month. One factor may have been the decision of the United States to donate 105,000 tons of food to the North as it faces depletion of supplies in the winter. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Morgan Owed More by Enron Than Previously Disclosed
description: J. P. Morgan Chase is owed $2.6 billion -- $1.7 billion greater than previously thought -- linked to Enron, the bankrupt energy trading company, worrying some analysts and investors that the bank could yet reveal further exposure. The latest disclosure, made late Wednesday, includes nearly $1 billion the bank said it was owed by a group of insurers who backed commodity contracts that J. P. Morgan had with Enron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALBONI, EDWARD
description: BALBONI-Edward. On December 11, 2001, in New York City. Beloved husband of Patricia Henry Balboni and son-in-law, brother-in-law, uncle, friend of numerous family members. Long-time member of Hunter College faculty and NY Academy of Sciences.

title: Calling Birds. French Hens. Turtledoves. Flamingoes?
description: You know Dasher and Dancer and Prancer and Vixen. But do you know about Blitzen's short-lived career as a stand-up comic in Las Vegas? (''How do Eskimos keep their houses stuck together? With i-glue.'')

title: Wireless Deal Falls Apart In Congress
description: The $16 billion deal to transfer more than 200 highly coveted airwave licenses to the nation's largest wireless telephone carriers collapsed today after Congress failed to adopt legislation that was necessary to make it happen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREVILLE, GLORIA
description: PREVILLE-Gloria. The Officers, Trustees, Members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, Gloria Preville. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family. Paul M. Weltz, President Burton J. Esrig, Secretary

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Hollinger Canceling A Plan to Go Private
description: Hollinger Inc., the international newspaper group, has decided not to proceed with an offer to minority shareholders to take the company private. Hollinger said it was ''not feasible'' to go ahead with the offer to holders of 7.1 million retractable common shares in light of ''current market conditions and business developments since Sept 11.''

title: U.S. to Send More Troops to Search Caves of Tora Bora
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he had approved the deployment of a substantial number of American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora for die-hard terrorists.

title: At Least a Quarter of Ground Zero Firefighters Ill
description: A quarter of the 6,500 firefighters who have worked at ground zero after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center have respiratory ailments, and 100 to 200 are exhibiting serious symptoms that may allow them to retire on a disability pension, Fire Department officials said yesterday.

title: Thwarted Hopes in Congress
description: In a disappointing conclusion to its 2001 session, Congress has adjourned in a blaze of partisan recrimination over the failure to pass a measure to stimulate the economy. Though President Bush and Republican leaders made some last-minute concessions on the bill, their final offer was too costly, too unlikely to help the economy and too unfairly weighted toward corporations and rich taxpayers to be acceptable. On a separate issue, Congress passed a spending bill to provide significant help for Lower Manhattan. But in a last-minute setback that was discouraging, a bipartisan agreement to provide tax incentives to help rebuild the area was blocked by two Republican senators.

title: Love and Sex From France
description: Smaller blips on the release radar screen this week reveal a couple of interesting films by the French director Catherine Breillat: ''Perfect Love'' of 1996 and ''A Real Young Girl,'' made in 1976 but released this year in the United States. Both were issued on Tuesday by Wellspring Media, a New York distributor.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Flaws Found In Windows XP
description: Microsoft said its new Windows operating system had a ''major'' flaw that could let hackers steal or destroy files or damage computer hard drives. Microsoft shares fell $2.73, or 3.93 percent, to $66.76. The company posted software patches on its Web site for the business and home versions of Windows XP, which went on sale on Oct. 25, and encouraged users to download the fixes immediately. Microsoft, which has touted Windows XP as the most secure version of Windows, has been criticized by security and consumer-advocacy groups for the poor security record of its products. Major flaws have surfaced this year in the company's server software for Internet sites and in its e-mail program.

title: One Life in the Light, Another in the Shadows
description: In most ways that would matter to a modern-art lover, John Koch (1909-78) was not a great artist. A self-taught imitator of the old masters, he painted with facile but cautious finesse, aiming for realist transparency. What he achieved was at best a moody illustration and at worst old-fashioned academic kitsch. And yet there is something fascinating about the Koch retrospective at the New-York Historical Society, for his painting evokes like no one else's a particular social milieu: a mid-20th-century world of monied, artistic New York gentility.

title: The Silence of the Alert System; Experts Urge Overhaul of Plan Unused Even on Sept. 11
description: As Carol L. Friedland listened to the hissing sound that issued from her radio on Sept. 11, she waited patiently for an urgent message from the nation's Emergency Alert System.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTIER, WILLIAM B
description: CARTIER-William B, of Manhattan, NY, formerly of Dover, Mass. Died December 16 at the age of 32 while skiing in Alta, Utah. Former Vice President of Prudential Securities. Beloved son of William Lambert Cartier, of Newport, RI, and Marie ''Pooh'' Bannard Lockwood of Dover, Mass. Step-son to Charles C. Lockwood of Dover, Mass. Devoted brother to Thomas Gallup Cartier of Santa Monica, Calif., and Charles Markle Cartier of Boulder, CO. Step-brother to John Lockwood, Laura Lockwood, Dorothy Wagner and Gwen Lockwood. Cherished nephew to David and Gussie Bannard, Barbara and Christopher Haller, John and Suzie Cartier, Fred and Rosalee Cartier and Barbara and Elliot Frederic, and 13 first cousins. Bill will be remembered for his vitality of spirit, strength of character and extraordinary capacity for friendship. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at 2pm, Thursday, December 27th, at The Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue (74 St), NY. There will be a reception immediately following the service. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in memory of William to Big Brothers, Big Sisters, 223 E. 30th St, NY, NY 10016.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: DoubleClick Appoints Executives
description: DoubleClick, the New York online advertising company, said yesterday that it had named three executives to senior posts, effective immediately. David Rosenblatt, left, 33, president for technology, data and research, was named to the vacant post of president. Bruce Dalziel, 43, acting chief financial officer, was named chief financial officer. And Mok Choe, 43, was named to the new post of chief information officer. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Delay On Deregulation
description: The Public Service Commission urged the legislature to delay until at least 2010 full deregulation of retail electric competition. The commission said its studies showed that consumer electricity rates would almost certainly increase and that the price of power from the Entergy Corporation, the largest electricity provider in the state, would increase more than 13 percent. The legislature had already delayed by one year its previous mandate for full deregulation by Jan. 1, 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, SOL
description: BIRNBAUM-Sol. In his 98th year. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Philip and Marilyn, and Irwin and Arlene. Services at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels,'' 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, Friday, December 21st, 12:15PM.

title: AMERICAN HOME AND ELAN TO WORK JOINTLY ON SLEEP DRUGS
description: The American Home Products Corporation and the Elan Corporation, Ireland's largest drug maker, said yesterday that they would work together to sell treatments for sleep problems, including American Home's Sonata. Terms were not disclosed, but Elan's chairman, Donal Geaney, said Elan has an option to buy all rights to Sonata. American Home is based in Madison, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGENHEIM, JOSEPH

Services Sunday 10 AM at the Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Soccer Team's Shares Fall
description: Shares of Juventus, Italy's most successful soccer team, fell 6 percent on their first day of trading. Though the offering -- only the third I.P.O. on the Milan exchange since July -- was twice oversubscribed by retail investors, there was little demand from institutional investors. ''The share price will depend on the fans,'' Steve Roberts of Winterflood Securities in London told the BBC News. The shares closed at 3.49 euros ($3.14). Juventus of Turin and its owners, the Agnelli family, sold 35 percent of the team, raising $129 million. Juventus is the third Italian soccer team to go public, following the two big Roman clubs, Lazio and Roma. Juventus, which has won 25 Italian championships, is currently in fourth place.

title: U.S. Says It Favors Deferring Argentine Aid
description: Despite Argentina's severe economic and political crisis, Bush administration officials said today that they were unlikely to support any new aid until the country adopted an economic course that had a chance of lifting it out of a four-year recession.

description: A group led by John Henry, owner of the Florida Marlins, won the Boston Red Sox yesterday in a unanimous vote of the team's majority owner and limited partners.

description: John W. Magaw, President Bush's choice to head the new Transportation Security Administration, promised at a confirmation hearing today that his agency would not miss any deadlines for baggage screening and other aviation security measures.

description: Fifty-five British Royal Marines landed near the Afghan capital tonight as the vanguard of an international force intended to enhance security for the country's new leader, Hamid Karzai, and his interim government when it takes power on Saturday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Orders Extend Slump
description: The chip-equipment industry continued to report slumping orders and sales in November, a trade association said. Semiconductor Equipment Materials International, based in San Jose, Calif., said equipment makers in North America took in $612.3 million of orders last month. The industry posted a book-to-bill ratio of 0.73, meaning $73 in new orders were received for every $100 in products shipped. A ratio of less than 1 signals a declining market. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Colorado: Killing Wild Horses
description: Five wild horses have been shot to death at close range on public lands this month, the federal Bureau of Land Management said. Last December, 37 wild horses were shot to death on public land in southern Wyoming. In March, six were killed in Nevada. All the cases are unsolved. In Colorado and Wyoming, ranchers have been involved in disputes over the wild horses. Killing a wild horse or burro is punishable by up to $2,000 in fines and a year in prison. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Pamela Chu: Taking It in Stride
description: As a 31-year-old vice president and United States equities trader at Cantor Fitzgerald, Pamela Chu was under constant pressure. "I never saw her stressed out," said her close friend Christiana Yu, "but she told me about customers barking, `This is what I want. Don't sell too low. Don't buy too high.' And there was a lot of trading going at one time. And she was the only female trader and only Asian in her department, and that was difficult, but she seemed so relaxed."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the falling stock price of A.C.L.N. Ltd., an automobile transport company, reversed the middle names of a Lebanese car trader whom public records have linked with A.C.L.N. He is Merhi Ali Abou Merhi, not Merhi Abou Ali Merhi.

title: Children Removal Curbed for Battered Women
description: A federal judge ordered New York City yesterday to stop removing children from their mothers and placing them in foster care simply because the mothers were victims of domestic violence.

title: Evening of Russian Songs, From Ardent to Sentimental
description: Maybe it was not planned this way, but Sunday night's recital at Carnegie Hall by the bass-baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, with Mikhail Arkadiev at the piano, provided a kind of sunset postscript to the festival of Russian music that had been brought to the hall in four preceding concerts by the Kirov Orchestra. Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff were on the program (as they had been for the orchestra): nine songs by each. The sound was superb, the mood glowing.

title: H. Peter Kriendler, 96, Operator of '21' Club
description: H. Peter Kriendler, who helped transform ''21'' from a speakeasy into one of Manhattan's most beloved and enduring restaurants, and for decades was its face, voice and ambassador, died yesterday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 96 years old. .

title: Turner's Games, Losing Money, Are Dropped
description: The Goodwill Games, conceived by Ted Turner in the 1980's as a galvanizing alternative to the boycott-plagued Olympics, were discontinued yesterday, having lost millions of dollars as well as political relevancy after the fall of communism.

title: Dick Schaap Dies at 67; Ubiquitous Sports Journalist
description: Dick Schaap, the affable and ubiquitous journalist who introduced an 18-year-old Cassius Clay to Harlem, coined the term Fun City for New York and embodied the role of the ''as told to'' writer of autobiographies, including his own, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.

description: Enron Ex-Chief Speaks Out

title: Andrew I. Rosenblum: Love Was All Around
description: As a lawyer, Andrew I. Rosenblum grew frustrated with defending the guilty and, sometimes, seeing the innocent convicted. So he left the law and entered the world of finance, eventually becoming a vice president at Cantor Fitzgerald. When entertaining clients, he had a knack for listening and making people feel comfortable, said his wife, Jill. "Andrew was always able to make people feel at ease."

description: The Nets' signature fast break was slow and broken tonight, a telling indicator for the rest of their game.

description: It is lonely at the top, but it also seems secure. The view is intoxicating. Every potential challenge is visible. The perch seems to guarantee invulnerability.

title: Sweep of Foreign Men Half-Finished as Deadline Passes
description: As the Justice Department's deadline for interviewing 5,146 young, foreign men in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks passed yesterday, officials said that Washington had so far received information on about half of those wanted for questioning and that the canvass had turned up at least two leads.

description: RED CROSS IN WARTIME

title: Margaret Mattic: Dimples Right and Left
description: Margaret Mattic was the only one of the five Mattic girls of Detroit to have dimples. Right and left, the dimples set off the shy smile and the lilting, gentle voice that everyone remarked on. As a young girl, in elementary school productions, she played Snow White as well as Gretel in "Hansel and Gretel."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIMKIN, HAROLD
description: SHIMKIN-Harold. Age 94, on December 20, 2001, in Sunrise, FL. Beloved husband of Theresa. Devoted father of Barry and Jane, Susan and Steven Goodman. Cherished grandfather of Peter and Jodie, Elizabeth and David Lean, Andrew and Paula. Loving great-grandfather of Nicholas. Graveside services Sunday, December 23, 10:30 AM at Beth David cemetery, Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Association for Children with Down Syndrome, 4 Fern Place, Plainview, NY 11803.

title: Islanders Beat Rangers to Punch
description: First place in the Atlantic Division was at stake last night and retribution was in the air at Madison Square Garden.

title: Kevin P. York: Man With Snowblower
description: After a big snow last winter, the serene streets of Kevin P. York's neighborhood in Princeton were tucked under a thick blanket of snow. His new snowblower made easy work of his driveway. Then he wheeled it to a neighbor's driveway and cleared that one, too. And then he did another, and another, all day until the light gave out.

title: India Recalling Pakistan Envoy Over Delhi Raid
description: India today recalled its ambassador to Pakistan and ended bus and train service between the two countries to protest what it called Pakistan's failure to shut down two Pakistan-based groups India has accused of carrying out a suicide attack on Parliament last week.

title: Life Partners, Teaming Up, Nearly Upset A Top Group
description: It is often said that husbands and wives cannot play together effectively, but there are some notable exceptions to this generalization.

title: Joseph McGovern, 92, Lawyer And Head of New York Regents
description: Joseph Washington McGovern, whose long record of public service included six years as chancellor of the state Board of Regents, died Wednesday at Mount Vernon Hospital in Westchester. He was 92 and lived in Irvington, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Steel Acquisition
description: The Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Japan agreed to buy a rival, the NKK Corporation, for 314 billion yen ($2.5 billion) in stock, challenging the Nippon Steel Corporation's dominance of the market. Kawasaki Steel's shareholders will receive one share in a new holding company, JFE Holdings Inc., to be formed in October 2002, for every share they have. NKK shareholders will get 0.75 share for each share they hold, the companies said. Fumio Sudo, the president of Kawasaki Steel, will head the holding company's steel business, the JFE Steel Corporation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Funds To Sell Chip Maker's Stock
description: Two Taiwan government funds and other investors plan to sell as much as 350 million shares in the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, worth $800 million at today's price, the company said. The Economic Daily newspaper reported the National Stabilization Fund and the cabinet's development fund would sell 330 million shares in the company, a leading maker of computer chips that are built to order. The report set off a decline of 6.4 percent in the company's share price.

title: Michael Edward Roberts: Firehouse Psychologist
description: When Michael Edward Roberts was just 4, his father took him to a firehouse and sat him on a rig parked there. That's all it took. From that moment on, life was a countdown to the Fire Academy. He took time to get a degree in psychology from the State University of New York at Buffalo, but "he knew without a doubt what he was going to do," said his father, Thomas Roberts, a retired New York City fire captain. "He'd say the only decision he needed to make was whether to grow up, or become a firefighter."

title: Before Adjournment, Congress Acts on Bioterrorism and Security
description: In the final hours before adjourning for the year, Congress took action on measures to combat bioterrorism; to protect the food supply; and to increase security at seaports, nuclear power plants and the nation's borders.
