title: Red Sox Ownership Is a Tangled Web
description: When John Henry was a limited partner of George Steinbrenner with the Yankees, he looked seriously into the possibility of buying the Kansas City Royals. Then the Florida Marlins became available and he bought them.

title: With Viewing Platforms, a Dignified Approach to Ground Zero
description: Transparency -- unobstructed vision -- is the solid virtue that will hold aloft a set of public viewing platforms on the perimeter of ground zero. Construction has begun on the first of four nearly identical platforms now proposed. The temporary structure is on Fulton Street, between Church Street and Broadway, just south of St. Paul Chapel, and it is to be completed by Friday.

title: Spending Rate Is Pointing To a Rebound
description: Consumer optimism rose to a four-month high this month, and Americans have been spending at a pace that suggests they will help the economy rebound during the next three months, reports released today showed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LEONARD
description: LEVINE-Leonard. After a very long and courageous battle our dear friend and associate Lenny was taken from us on Wednesday, December 19. His gentle nature and loving kindness will always be cherished as his gift to all of us. Our condolences to his wife Mimi, his children Andrea, Debra (Robert Berks), and Lisa (Steve Karczmer). His grandchildren Pamela, Jennifer, Lauren, Melissa, Rachel, Stefanie, Nicole, and Emily. And his sisters Ruth Mogul and Judy Altman. Al & Mickey & Steve, Richard Shankman Peerless Electronics Inc. Staff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEITERMAN, JEAN
description: MEITERMAN-Jean, 90. Of Miami Beach, FL, formerly of Manalapan, NJ, died at her home on Thursday, December 20, 2001. Born in Poland in 1911, she ran a restaurant with her family until WWII. She was a Holocaust survivor with her husband and two sons. After the war, she moved to Forest Hills where she dedicated her life to her children and grandchildren. In 1989, she moved to Covered Bridge in Manalapan to be closer to her family prior to relocating to Miami Beach. Her husband, Michael Meiterman, predeceased her in 1990. Surviving are two sons, Morris of Marlboro, NJ and David of Ft. Lee, NJ, four grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Services will be held Sunday, December 23rd, at noon at the Hebrew Institute of Lakewood, 124th Street, 4th and Monmouth, Lakewood, NJ, 732364-2230. Shiva will be observed beginning Sunday at 22 Evan Drive, Morganville, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Ski Report column on Thursday, about holiday gifts, misidentified the publisher of the book ''Breakthrough on the New Skis.'' It is Mountain Sports Press, not Velo Press.

title: Agenda: To Bipartisanship and Back Again
description: Alook at what the first session of the 107th Congress passed and what awaits further action.

title: Harvard Builds for a Return To Its Former Prominence
description: Harvard University's 1989 N.C.A.A. Division I championship should have put to rest the notion that the Crimson's most notable hockey player was Oliver Barrett IV, the fictional character played by Ryan O'Neal in the 1970 film ''Love Story.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Milosevic Challenges His Arrest
description: Slobodan Milosevic has filed a complaint against the Netherlands at the European Court of Human Rights, according to the court, which is based in Strasbourg, France. The former Yugoslav president claimed he had been illegally arrested, transported and held since June at the detention center in The Hague. Therefore the Netherlands was violating the European Convention on Human Rights, the complaint said. He awaits trial at the war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia; it is scheduled to begin in February. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Green to Miss Inauguration Of Bloomberg
description: At noon on Jan. 1, a procession of prominent leaders -- including a former United States president, two United States senators and two former New York mayors -- will assemble on the steps of City Hall to mark the inauguration of Michael R. Bloomberg as the city's 108th mayor.

title: Sports of The Times; Shaking Off That Losing Mentality
description: EARLIER this week, Jets Coach Herman Edwards challenged the franchise to shake itself out of being content with just getting by. Edwards made his remarks in New York, but his message resonated throughout the country, to every manager to every coach from Pee Wees to Division I-A who is confronted with changing a culture of low expectations.

title: Goodman Plans to Quit State Senate For a City Job
description: After 33 years in office, State Senator Roy M. Goodman has agreed to step down and take a position in the Bloomberg administration, clearing the way for what should be a hotly contested race to secure his seat and represent the Upper East Side.

title: Black Leaders Are Pleased To Be Courted By Bloomberg
description: Assemblyman Carl E. Heastie, a Democrat from the Bronx, tells the story about having called Michael R. Bloomberg within a week of the election that made the billionaire businessman the successor to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Heastie said he had called only to leave a message with a secretary congratulating Mr. Bloomberg on his victory.

title: Camby Lashes Out At Knicks' Guards
description: Perhaps it was the fact that his three late misses from point-blank range were shown repeatedly across the nation Thursday night. Or maybe he did not like being categorized as the Charles Smith of the new millennium, the goat in the Knicks' infuriating 90-88 loss to the Memphis Grizzlies. Or it could just be his way of dealing with the frustration of the Knicks' current slide.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trading Firm To Cut Its Debt
description: A leading Japanese trading firm, the Nissho Iwai Corporation, said it will sell one-fifth of its assets and eliminate more than one-quarter of its staff to reduce debt. The company hopes to pay back 80 percent of its 3.3 trillion yen ($25.6 billion) in debts by 2005. Last week, Moody's Investors Service downgraded Nissho Iwai's senior debt ratings to B2 from B1 with a negative outlook, citing concerns that Japanese banks may cut off funds to highly indebted firms. Nissho Iwai's stock closed at 69 yen (54 cents) yesterday, well below the 100 yen threshold normally seen by investors as a danger sign. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Once Reviled, Ex-Communists Join Coalition To Rule Berlin
description: If it had happened anywhere else but Berlin, the political deal reached on Thursday would barely have been noticed outside that city's limits.

title: Bruce Eagleson: Attention to Detail
description: When Bruce Eagleson would say he would make dinner, his sons  they're 15, 19 and 22 now  would groan and say, "Now we'll never eat  it'll take hours!" It was probably worth the wait, though, because Mr. Eagleson was a perfectionist  whether at home or at work, he had to get every detail just right.

title: Litigation Settled On Gene Patents
description: Affymetrix Inc. and Incyte Genomics, two pioneering Silicon Valley genomics companies, said yesterday that they had settled all patent infringement litigation between them and had agreed to cross-license various patents. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: York to Join Malakhov and Dvorak in Olympics
description: Two team executives confirmed yesterday that Rangers forward Mike York would be named to the United States Olympic team today.

title: The Marines' 21st-Century Beachhead Is Far Inland
description: Just past 2 a.m. on Dec. 7, a company of marines -- scouts, snipers and troops in armored vehicles -- stretched a roadblock across the main road out of Kandahar, Route 1, and ambushed a sport utility vehicle of the kind favored by the Taliban.

description: In 1998, just two days after AT&T announced its great leap into the cable television business, C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman, was already exasperated.

title: Simon V. Weiser: Medieval History Buff
description: Simon V. Weiser was born in Kiev, Ukraine, in 1936. For most of the next 36 years, his family says, he tried to leave. Finally, his opportunity came, in a brief warming of the cold war in 1972, when some Jews were allowed to emigrate to Israel. His wife and son followed in 1974; the family moved to the United States in 1978  to Canarsie, Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Thursday about Gary Shamay, a Cantor Fitzgerald computer specialist who became a World Trade Center victim, misspelled the given name of his father. It is Beniamim Shamay, not Benjamin.

title: David Arce: Stray Cats, Dogs, Kids
description: When Margaret Arce opened up her son's apartment in Stuyvesant Town, she found remnants of his generosity, letters to Santa Claus from poor children. David Arce, a firefighter, would answer them by delivering wished-for toys, year after year.

title: Robert D. Mattson: A Hero in 1993
description: Robert D. Mattson did not seek out danger. But danger seemed to have a way of finding him. A lot of his friends managed to avoid Vietnam. He ended up over there in the Army, smack in the middle of harm's way, came home with a Bronze Star for valor and some memories he would never share, not even with his wife, Elizabeth. "He would just slough it off as not worth talking about whenever I asked," she said.

title: No Indictment for Officer In Death of Unarmed Driver
description: An Essex County grand jury refused to indict a white police officer today in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black driver last spring in Irvington, N.J.

title: Key Tronic Verdict May Put It in Default
description: The Key Tronic Corporation said it would not be able to make some loan payments after a jury concluded it must pay $16.5 million for giving stolen trade secrets to the Microsoft Corporation.

title: $800,000 in Painkilling Pills Disappear on a Zigzag Route
description: Law enforcement officials and company investigators are tying to track down a missing shipment of the prescription painkiller OxyContin, which has become increasingly popular as an illegal recreational drug, after the shipment disappeared during a circuitous journey from Philadelphia to New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Weekend yesterday about a grant by the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts for an exhibition by the performance artist William Pope.L misidentified the museum in Maine that is organizing the exhibition. It is the Institute of Contemporary Art at the Maine College of Art in Portland. (The Portland Institute for Contemporary Art, in Oregon, is also an organizer of the exhibition.)

title: David L. W. Fodor: Rescuer of Animals
description: The accountant was also a mountain man. David Lawrence William Fodor had moved from his native Staten Island to the hills of Putnam County, but the plan was to keep on heading north. He and his wife, Claudia Petrone, had started scouting possibilities in the Adirondacks last summer. For the time being they had their rocky two and a half acres in Garrison with the vegetable garden in front  tomatoes, corn, lettuces, scallions and the beginnings of an herb garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIENDLER, H. PETER
description: KRIENDLER-H. Peter. In sorrow, Congegration Emanu-El of the City of New York records the passing of our distinguished member, H. Peter Kriendler. With his family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: New Clashes in Gaza; Hamas to Limit Suicide Attacks
description: Six Palestinians were killed and dozens injured today in clashes with Yasir Arafat's police in the Gaza Strip, even as the militant group Hamas said that to preserve Palestinian unity, it was halting suicide attacks within the borders of pre-1967 Israel.

description: Manhattan Coach Bobby Gonzalez stole the question posed to one of his players as if it were an errant pass thrown into a zone trap: is Manhattan the best team in the New York area?

description: Two summers ago Kimberly Elster was an eligible nursing student, fresh from a broken engagement and clicking on bachelors' personals ads on a singles Web site.

description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he was ordering more American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora, and described the effort as crucially important for capturing die-hard members of Al Qaeda, seizing their weapons and uncovering intelligence on terror attacks now being planned.

title: NORTEL, PHONE EQUIPMENT MAKER, EXPECTS LOWER LOSS
description: Nortel Networks said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss would be smaller than analysts' estimates. Shares of the company, North America's second-biggest maker of phone equipment, rose 12 percent. Nortel forecast a loss of 16 cents a share, excluding $1.53 billion in costs from job cuts and acquisitions. Analysts had expected an 18-cent loss, according to a Thomson Financial/First Call survey. The company also said it extended a line of credit and would eliminate 3,000 fewer jobs than planned.

title: Charges in Death Of Homeless Man
description: A homeless man who was beaten with a baseball bat in Queens on Monday died on Thursday, and another homeless man has been charged in his death.

description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Journal; You Pretend to Drive, We Pretend to Get You There
description: This city's widest, busiest, most expensive and most fabled highway was first built under Nikita Khrushchev's rule, but it was not until late 1998, after an ambitious reconstruction project, that it reached its current exalted status. Ten lanes wide, 67.73 miles long, costing more than $1 billion (nobody seems quite sure how much more), it draws a colossal limited-access concrete circle around Russia's capital.

description: EUROPE

title: Siege Mentality in Buenos Aires
description: BUENOS AIRES -- On Wednesday night, no one in Buenos Aires slept. Midweek during a stretch of brutally hot, steamy weather, the city's streets were taken over by thousands of irate citizens marching on the Plaza de Mayo, the elegant square that faces the presidential palace, to protest the government's lack of response to the rioting and ransacking that had spread across the nation.

title: Circus Trainer Is Acquitted Of Abusing a Rare Elephant
description: After a weeklong trial pitting animal rights groups against the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, a jury in San Jose acquitted Mark Oliver Gebel today of abusing an endangered Asian elephant before the grand finale of a performance last summer.

title: Sandra Conaty Brace: 25 Cats, 55 Words
description: Sandra Conaty Brace might have appreciated a short biographical sketch about her. After all, she herself had mastered the 55-word short story  a challenge to the most diligent amateur writer. Mrs. Brace had published much of her work on Web sites dedicated to the genre.

title: Arkady Zaltsman: A Man of Many Views
description: If you were Arkady Zaltsman's guest in New York, you could be sure he would take you to the esplanade at Brooklyn Heights. And you could be sure he would be beaming as he showed off that vista. It was his favorite view.

title: Boston Journal; New Owners of Red Sox Are Welcomed, Warily
description: Greg O'Brien had a few traits on his wish list for the new owners of the Boston Red Sox. He wanted a group with baseball experience. He wanted a group with lots of money to spend on good players. And sure, he would have liked them to be hometown fellows, born with B-shaped marks over their hearts.

title: Here's a Big Surprise for Boss Tweed, Wherever He May Be
description: The newly renovated former New York County Courthouse -- generally referred to as the Tweed Courthouse -- opened its doors yesterday for a celebratory ceremony, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani welcomed the building's new tenant, the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FLORENCE
description: COHEN-Florence. The Cohen family deeply mourns the loss of their heart and soul, Florence Cohen, of Larchmont, NY on December 21 at age 75. Cherished wife of Martin, affectionate sister of Leah, loving mother of Jason and Jo Ann, Larry and Susan, and Liz and Steven, and adored grandmother of Julia, Danny, Jessie, Cassie, Alex, Matt, and Ethan. A true ''city girl'', Florence was born and raised in New York City surrounded by scores of Sugarman relatives. While attending Hunter College, she formed friendships for life with Barbara, Seena, Sydell, and her sorority sisters. As an educator and psychologist, Florence profoundly touched thousands of lives. With Martin, she traveled the world many times, from the Arctic to Antartica. Florence tirelessly supported the Brandeis University National Women's Committee, for which she served with distinction as chapter and then regional president. If you measure your life by the depth and breadth of your relationships with others, then Florence enjoyed unrivaled success her entire life. Her memory lives on through her many wonderful friends and extended family. Her warm, generous, charitable, and fun-loving ways will be missed always. Memorial contributions may be made to NARAL or Brandeis University National Women's Committee. Services Sunday, December 23, 11:30am at Schwartz Brothers, 11403 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Christopher Larrabee: Putting Life in Focus
description: Christopher Larrabee was a Californian, raised with the sun and the sea, who had just come to New York in March to start on the bottom rungs at Cantor Fitzgerald. He was 26 and decided to trade his breezy California lifestyle for a career in finance, just like his father and older sister, Nicole.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about an increase in homicides in several United States cities referred incorrectly to the comparison between Chicago's number and New York's. If Chicago, as expected, finishes the year as the city with the most homicides, this will be the second time it has surpassed New York City's total. The first occurred in 1998.

title: Alan D. Feinberg: Mr. Mom's Fire Truck
description: When Wendy Feinberg recalls meeting Alan D. Feinberg 21 years ago, she remembers not only the man, but also his car  a sharp Datsun 240-Z. From that encounter in the parking lot of a Sheepshead Bay diner came marriage, children and a life for Mr. Feinberg as both a firefighter and a Mr. Mom.

title: Mets Take a Step Closer To a Decision on Vaughn
description: Two years ago, the Mets had something more to celebrate on the day of their office Christmas party: Steve Phillips traded for a top starting pitcher, Mike Hampton. There were no eggnog toasts to a new player at yesterday's party, but the Mets could still trade for the slugging first baseman Mo Vaughn.

title: Head of Fund Says Families Should State Their Cases
description: Faced with widespread protests that he has been stingy, Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master of the federal fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, urged disappointed families yesterday to seek a hearing to argue for larger compensation awards.

title: Newark Council's New Star Sees Campaign Reform Fail
description: Councilman Cory Booker failed to advance a campaign reform measure in the Newark City Council this week that would have sharply limited contributions by those doing business with the city.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Merger Opposed
description: The Japanese airline, All Nippon Airways, has filed an antitrust complaint with the Fair Trade Commission protesting the proposed merger of Japan Airlines and the Japan Air System. All Nippon, which controls just less than one-half of Japan's domestic market, says the merger of its two rivals, announced on Nov. 12, would give them an unfair advantage on local routes. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Fassel and Holmgren Remember the Good Ol' Days
description: Asked to recall his days as a teammate of Jim Fassel's at Southern California in 1969, Seattle Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren laughed on Wednesday and said: ''We had a lot of fun. Maybe too much fun.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELUCIA, MICHAEL
description: DeLUCIA-Michael. The Calhoun School mourns the passing of Michael DeLucia, husband of Carole and father of Lily '03. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family.

title: Suspect in Vast Drug Ring Held in Mexico; May Be Sent to U.S.
description: A man suspected of being one of Mexico's biggest drug traffickers is under arrest and facing extradition to the United States after a decade of thumbing his nose at law enforcement authorities, Mexican officials said today.

title: A Clash of Online Titans
description: AT&T's sale of its cable television business, the nation's largest, to Comcast, the third-largest, is more than another episode in the continuing consolidation of the nation's cable industry. The bidding war for AT&T Broadband must also be seen as another skirmish in the conflict between Microsoft and AOL Time Warner to control the information pipes that bring news, entertainment and communications services into American households. If federal regulators approve this cable merger, as seems likely, they must impose conditions aimed at preserving and fostering competition in the online world.

title: The Neediest Cases; Fire Survivor Continues His Climb Back
description: On a warm July evening last year, James Tucker's bedroom window was wide open, an invitation to a cool breeze. He slept with his two cats, Sketch and Larry, by his side. Suddenly, smoke filled the quiet room.

title: Officials Say School Choice Often Just Isn't an Option
description: The education bill passed by Congress this week carried a striking promise: children in nearly 7,000 chronically failing public schools would be given escape hatches, in the form of an option to transfer to other schools in their district with better academic track records.

description: As a partner at Sandler O'Neill, Mark H. Rosen knew investment banking. As a father, he knew baton twirling.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Voiding Abortion Rules
description: Although a state law that requires minors who are seeking abortions to obtain parental or court permission is constitutional, a federal judge in Boise ruled, two elements are not. The judge, Magistrate Mikel Williams, dismissed a challenge to the law from Planned Parenthood of Idaho. But he said the law could not limit the court permission to a judge in the district where the pregnant girl lives or in the county where the abortion is to be performed. He also overturned a requirement that a parent be notified in 24 hours if an abortion is performed for a medical emergency. Jim Robbins (NYT)

title: Michael A. Tamuccio: A Bud in Any Season
description: Michael A. Tamuccio was a true guy's guy, which is why his friends knew that Kathleen Horner was "the one" when the couple showed up at a Halloween party in Raggedy Ann and Andy costumes.

title: Tennessee Town Loses Allure for Immigrants
description: In the 1990's, they came here by the thousands from Mexico and Central America, making their way across the border and traveling by van to this rural town in horse country.

description: First place in the Atlantic Division was at stake last night and retribution was in the air at Madison Square Garden.

title: Exploring Sounds of Poetry As Background for the Piano
description: On her own and in her work with Da Camera of Houston, Sarah Rothenberg has been interested in expanding the conventional concert format by including examples from the visual arts and literature. Her concepts are often persuasive and make lively, illuminating programs.

title: Parrish Hopes He Can Join Kvasha
description: The Islanders' enigmatic left wing, Oleg Kvasha, who entered last night's game against the Rangers with four goals and the worst plus- minus rating (minus-11) on his team, was named yesterday to the Russian Olympic team.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Dec. 11, about the prevalence of smoking referred incorrectly to arrangements between tobacco companies and movie producers. Tobacco companies say they do not pay to have their products placed in movies, and they are forbidden to do so under the terms of a settlement with 46 state attorneys general.

title: Method Used To Kill Deer Is 'Barbaric,' Critics Say
description: A New Jersey township's plan to reduce its deer population by capturing them in nets and firing a bolt into their skulls has provoked an outcry from animal rights advocates and some of the community's well-known artists and thinkers.

description: Sweden's Volvo A.B., a leading maker of heavy-duty trucks, broke off talks to supply large engines for the Navistar International Corporation's International brand trucks, saying the terms of the agreement were not met.

title: ARGENTINA'S CHAOS RAISES NEW DOUBTS ON MONETARY FUND
description: The deadly riots in Argentina, the collapse of its government and another multibillion dollar bailout gone awry have raised fresh questions about the effectiveness of the International Monetary Fund and the financial policies of the United States, the fund's leading shareholder.

title: After Twists Of a Novel, Congress Goes Home
description: Congress snarled its way out of town today, after a session as remarkable for its mood swings as the laws it passed but ending with dramatic inaction on the economy.

description: ZACHARY-Murray. Died peacefully at home on December 21st, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Rose (nee Wilder). Devoted father of Ed, Carol and Seth and fatherin-law of Lois and Nancy. description: LEHMAN-Kate (nee Hoffman). description: ''Operation Babylift,'' the 1975 transport of 2,700 orphaned or abandoned Vietnamese children to the United States, was regarded by many as a noble rescue, by others as paternalistic intervention. Either way, it proved to be a tragically emblematic coda to the Vietnam War. The first plane out, carrying 330 adults and children, crashed 15 minutes after takeoff, killing 154 of its passengers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Hardier, Ha'penny Bridge Reopens
description: The Ha'penny Bridge, so named because pedestrians were charged a half-penny to cross in early 19th century Dublin, reopened after nine months of repairs costing $2.3 million. At peak hours, more than 30,000 people walk the footbridge spanning the River Liffey every day. The 185-year-old wrought-iron railings and structural supports were originally designed to handle just 450 people daily. The reopening coincides with efforts to spruce up the riverside, adding boardwalks with cafes and stalls for booksellers. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

description: OBENZINGER-Romana. Age 87, on December 20, 2001. Beloved wife of Nathan, deceased just 8 weeks ago. Dear sister of Zosha, loving mother of the late Ronald, Mark and Hilton, and cherished grandmother to Rachel, Isaac and Eric. Her love for her husband took her to him yet her loving spirit stays with us.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections

title: Cairns Doesn't Back Down and Neither Do Isles
description: Two hours later, shreds of skin hung from the parts of his knuckles not covered with scabs. Islanders defenseman Eric Cairns won a long-awaited and much-anticipated fight against the Rangers' Sandy McCarthy last night, and the Islanders beat the Rangers, 2-1, in a tough, exciting game at Madison Square Garden. Don't think the two events are unrelated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, JOSEPH W.
description: McGOVERN-Joseph W., 92. On December 19, 2001. The only son of Philip and Jane Fahy McGovern. Predeceased by his dear wife Marie, sons Philip and Joseph Raymond. Survived by one daughter Marie Therese Melillo, three sons Raymond, Joseph and Lawrence, twenty two grandchildren and twelve great grandchildren. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday 9AM, Fordham University Chapel, Bronx, NY. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM, EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to Calvary Hospital or Fordham University appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE GAINS. Crude oil rose on expectations of an OPEC cut, which offset concern that mild weather is curbing heating oil demand. In New York, crude oil for February delivery rose 34 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $19.62 a barrel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 11 about a military study of Persian Gulf war veterans and Lou Gehrig's disease referred incompletely to the veterans' risk of developing the disease, also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The study found that among the nearly 700,000 soldiers deployed to the gulf between August 1990 and July 1991, the risk of contracting A.L.S. was an average of 6.7 cases per million people per year over the 10 years after the war, not over their lifetimes. Among the 1.8 million who were not deployed, the risk was 3.5 cases per million people over those same years, not over their lifetimes.

title: A Knack for Inventing, a Love of Animals, and a Flair for the Dramatic
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Delay Sought By Microsoft In States' Case
description: Microsoft asked a federal judge today to delay by at least four months the hearings on the proposed remedies of its antitrust case, a move that would push the proceeding to August at the earliest. The company also announced that one of its witnesses in the hearing might be its chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Stake
description: Microsoft plans to acquire as much as 3 percent of the equity in Korea Telecom, a leading South Korean telephone company and Internet service provider, under a deal that South Korean officials said was ready for signing. Microsoft planned to buy bonds with warrants under which it could purchase shares in the government-controlled company, according to the ministry of information and communications. The signing was postponed, however, because of an unrelated crisis in Argentina that changed the price of the bonds. The stake, when converted into cash at the current value of Korea Telecom stock, would be worth about $360 million. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: James G. Geyer: The Team Is the Goal
description: James G. Geyer worked as a bond broker at Cantor Fitzgerald and for a catering company on weekends. But his true calling was as a friend, a father and a coach in Rockville Centre, on Long Island, where he and his wife, Cathy, grew up and settled.

title: Median Income Drops Are Tied to Immigrants
description: Median household income dropped between 1989 and 1998 in Queens, Brooklyn, Suffolk, Fairfield and many other counties across the nation that experienced a large influx of immigrants, according to new census data.

title: In Largest Schools Takeover, State Will Run Philadelphia's
description: With the hard-won blessing of the mayor of Philadelphia, the governor of Pennsylvania assumed responsibility early this morning for the city's long-troubled public school system, an arrangement that is expected to lead to the hiring of Edison Schools, a private company, as a systemwide consultant and manager of several dozen schools.

title: York to Be Next Olympian
description: Two members of the Rangers were named to their country's Olympic teams yesterday, but the United States will wait until this afternoon to name forward Mike York to its squad.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I wanted the guys who are more like George Steinbrenner -- deep pockets and would do anything to see the Red Sox win.''

title: Frank Koestner: Every Other Weekend
description: For the last eight years, Frank Koestner was a stock trader for Cantor Fitzgerald, leaving home at 6 a.m. and trying to leave his office by 7 p.m. At 48, there was never enough time for jogging or skiing or hiking or biking or whitewater rafting.

title: Thomas Gulotta's Irresponsible Exit
description: In his last major act before leaving office, Nassau County's departing Republican county executive, Thomas Gulotta, extended his record of fiscal mismanagement and made the job facing his Democratic successor, Thomas Suozzi, a lot harder. Making last-minute changes to the budget approved by the County Legislature's narrow Democratic majority, Mr. Gulotta rejected its core idea of accelerating three planned 5 percent tax increases into a single 15 percent increase next year. Instead Mr. Gulotta lowered next year's tax increase to 9 percent, relying for superficial balance on the same sort of phony assumptions and gimmicks that led the populous suburban county -- one of the nation's wealthiest -- to pile up huge public deficits in the midst of an economic boom.

title: Japan and China in Pact On 8-Month Trade Dispute
description: Japan and China said today that they had settled an eight-month dispute that threatened to seriously disrupt trade between them, an $85 billion relationship fraught with an unusual degree of political testiness.

title: Failure in Congress On Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: The Road to Equal Education
description: George W. Bush's promise to wipe out the achievement gap between rich and poor students was perhaps the most important theme of his presidential campaign. The fact that he followed through with an important new education bill despite the distractions of Sept. 11 is a tribute to both the president and his legislative allies. But the effort to rescue millions of disadvantaged children from failing schools can succeed only if Mr. Bush places the full weight of his office behind this new law.

title: A New Chief Steps In at a Changed National Endowment for the Arts
description: The Senate confirmed a new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts late Thursday and hardly anyone noticed.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 3,187 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Cease-Fire, On Both Sides
description: The new government, elected on a pledge to revive a stalled peace effort with ethnic Tamil rebels, has matched a monthlong cease-fire declared by the rebels to begin Dec. 24. Last month the rebels said for the first time that they would settle for less than a separate nation for the minority Tamils. The government and rebels have been fighting for 18 years in a civil war that has killed more than 62,000 people in the island nation of 19 million people. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: NEW LEADERS SET TO ASSUME POWER IN TRANQUIL KABUL
description: Some 100 days after a terrorist attack on America turned the world's attention to Afghanistan and its Taliban regime, Afghans prepared today to install an interim government they hope will prove historic by ending 22 years of war.

title: Nina Bell: Air Force Child
description: Nina Bell was every inch a fighter pilot's daughter  slender, athletic and looking even taller than her 5 feet, 8 inches. Born in the Netherlands, the first stop in a nomadic Air Force childhood, she grew up confident, smart, "the It girl," as a friend once put it. A bachelor's degree in business administration from the University of Colorado at Boulder led her to become a manager of information systems and, most recently, into project management.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bill Would Force Amtrak To Act
description: A Florida Republican has introduced legislation in the House to force the restructuring or liquidation of Amtrak, which is projected to lose $1 billion in the current year. The bill by Representative John L. Mica, a member of the Transportation Committee, would transfer ownership of two profit-making corridors, Washington-Boston and the Virginia-Florida Auto Train, to the Transportation Department and, ultimately, to the private sector and the states. Christopher Marquis (NYT)

title: Posada's Surgery Went Well. Surgery?
description: Joe Torre was talking with reporters during an informal luncheon yesterday and he casually mentioned how catcher Jorge Posada was doing well after undergoing surgery on his right shoulder Dec. 6. Surgery? The word halted every fork at the table. The Yankees had never disclosed that Posada had an arthroscopic procedure to repair a small tear in his labrum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATHWOOD, SARAH G. (SADIE)
description: LATHWOOD-Sarah G. (Sadie). Age 94. Born in New York City 1907. Died 21st of December, 2001 near her long time home in the Bronx. Sadie was a teacher in the NYC Public School System for over 40 years at PS 53 in the Bronx. She leaves her son Peter.

title: Cairns Doesn't Back Down, and Neither Do Isles
description: Two hours later, shreds of skin hung from the parts of his knuckles not covered with scabs. Islanders defenseman Eric Cairns won a long-awaited and much-anticipated fight against the Rangers' Sandy McCarthy last night, and the Islanders beat the Rangers, 2-1, in a tough, exciting game at Madison Square Garden. Don't think the two events are unrelated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSNOW, KATE
description: SOSNOW-Kate. On December 21, 2001 at the age of 91 of Kings Point, N.Y. and Miami Beach, Fla. Loving wife of the late Morris Sosnow. Devoted mother of Bernice and the late Jerrold Lieberman, Lorraine and Irving Aaron, Sheila and Richard Nagler. Beloved sister of Betty Benstock. Adored Nana to Zabrina, Seth, Kristina, Daryl, Mindy, Ron, Robert, Tracie, Ethan and Julia. Proud great-grandmother of Dari, Eric, Perri, Cari, Madison, Jennifer and Max. Services to be held Sunday, December 23, 2001 at 12:30, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in her memory to the North Shore University Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITTAY, ELIAS
description: KITTAY-Elias. Of New York and Los Angeles on December 11, 2001. Husband of the late Irma. Father of Seth and Burton. Grandfather of Eric, Jennifer, Rachel and Adena. Great grandfather of Megan, Domenique, Emma and Elisabeth.

title: Alysia Basmajian: In 2 Years, a Full Life
description: Alysia Basmajian and her husband, Anthony, used to marvel to each other that theirs were lives lived in fast forward. They became parents at 21, just before the start of their senior year at the College of William and Mary, when their daughter, Kaela Grayce, was born. They graduated in May 2000, were married in June that year, and found jobs in Manhattan  he on the floor of the stock exchange, she as a staff accountant at Cantor Fitzgerald.

title: OXFORD HEALTH TO BUY MEDSPAN FOR $19 MILLION
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., one of the biggest health insurers in the New York area, agreed yesterday to buy MedSpan Inc. for about $19 million in cash to more than double its commercial memberships in Connecticut. The acquisition increases Oxford's commercial membership to 130,525 from 56,000, a spokeswoman, Maria Gordon Shydlo, said. The transaction is expected to be completed in about three months. MedSpan's network has 74,525 commercial members and more than 7,400 providers affiliated with 33 hospitals in Connecticut. Oxford, based in Trumbull, Conn., provides health plans in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: Michael Edward Roberts: Holder of Heirloom
description: 6611. That was the number of Firefighter Robert Roberts's badge. When he left the job, the badge was assigned to his brother, John. When Firefighter John Roberts left the job, No. 6611 was passed on again, this time to John Roberts's son, Michael Edward.

title: Political Map In Connecticut Is Redrawn
description: Ninety minutes before a deadline that would have forced a court to decide the outcome, state lawmakers today approved a new Congressional map that redraws Connecticut's six House districts into five and sets up a showdown between two seasoned incumbents: Representatives James H. Maloney, a Democrat, and Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Governor Acts, As Expected
description: To the surprise of no one, Gov. Rick Perry formally entered the 2002 race for governor this week. Mr. Perry, 51, a Republican elected lieutenant governor in 1998, rose to the top job last December, when Gov. George W. Bush became president. He is not expected to have serious competition in the Republican primary. His most likely Democratic opponent is a Laredo executive, Tony Sanchez. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: And Now, a New York Version of Star Wars
description: Seldom in this capital of compromises can a fight over a bill be called a battle between darkness and light, but that describes the struggle over a bill passed this year that was intended to let more New Yorkers see the stars.

title: Interim Presidency Decided in Argentina but Doubts Linger
description: Argentine political leaders today proposed an unusual three-step process to install a new president to complete the term of Fernando de la Ra, who resigned on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An op-ed article yesterday inaccurately stated that Florida voters went twice for Bill Clinton in presidential elections. Mr. Clinton carried Florida in 1996 but not in 1992.

title: As the Travel Rush Begins, Patience Is a Must-Have
description: On a stage, Mariachi Allende, a Mexican-style band in colorful charro outfits, set the crowd dancing and clapping with its rendition of ''Feliz Navidad.''

title: Paul Zois: Games as Sacred Rites
description: For Paul Zois, his children's ball games were sacred rites  events that took precedence over practically everything. He emmigrated from Greece at the age of 9, and was poor: he had never had time to play. As soon as his children  Stefania and Theo  were able to toddle, he began to make up for it. He coached their soccer and basketball teams year-round. Nearly every night, after work, he went to a practice or game. Frequently, he did not get home for dinner until 10 or 11, said his wife, Dorota.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Comcast Corporation's acquisition of AT&T Broadband misspelled part of the name of AT&T's law firm. It is Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz; not Wachtel.

title: In New Leader's Village, Taliban Rules Are Just Tradition
description: In this brown village of high-walled mud compounds, freed from the rule of the Taliban, not a single woman has shed her head-to-toe burka.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: The Economy May Be Facing More Hurdles
description: At first glance, the economy seems primed for a speedy revival from recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, JEAN
description: STILLMAN-Jean. The Board and Staff of The Project Return Foundation extends its deepest sympathies to Marshall Goldberg, our Chairman Emeritus, and his family on the loss of his beloved sister, Jean. Our thoughts are with them at this most difficult time. Dr. Judith D. Wallach Chairperson, Board of Directors Jane Velez, President

title: Matthew O'Mahony: No Waster of Sleep
description: Matthew O'Mahony, 39, refused to let sleep usurp time that could be put to better use. The hours he could allot to pleasure were limited enough, without sleep cutting into them. On his annual Paris vacation, for instance, he was ready to start the day at 4 in the morning. "Let's go for a walk in the Tuileries," he would say, nudging Lauren, his wife, awake. "Let's go see it when no one else is there, so we can appreciate it."

title: Mozambique Pays for Capitalism in Dollars and in Blood
description: The morning rain drenches the sidewalk shrine on the Avenue of Martyrs, soaking the red and purple ribbons and the sagging banners that still plead for justice. Blood no longer stains the street here, but when the clouds burst, it seems even the heavens grieve.

title: Holiday on Tuesday
description: Christmas

title: U.S. Expatriate Is Seen Facing Capital Charge
description: Administration officials said today that John Walker, the American who was captured in Afghanistan, would probably face at least one charge that would carry the death penalty, and President Bush linked Mr. Walker directly with the terrorist group Al Qaeda.

title: Chris Orgielewicz: Straight Arrow
description: Chris Orgielewicz's 18th birthday was one to remember. When he returned to Fairfield University, he told his roommate, Martin Sullivan, all about it. He went bowling with his father, Mr. Sullivan recalled. He had cake with his family. Then he visited his grandfather and had cake all over again.

title: Heir Divorced His Missing Wife 11 Years Ago
description: Robert A. Durst, heir to a real estate fortune, quietly divorced his long-missing wife in 1990 without the knowledge of her grieving family or friends.

title: Embassy Row Scandal Consumes Fleet Street
description: London's chattering classes are chewing over a drawing room scandal called, in a rare instance of English gentry venturing a phrase in a foreign tongue, ''l'affaire Bernard.''

title: Totally Extreme Taliban
description: At first it looked as though the outbreak of a shooting war meant a cease-fire in our long-running culture war. Conservative pundits realized that berating the American public for its ungodly values was less than wise in a time of such overwhelming common feeling. But if there has ever been a national crisis in which liberals escaped being tagged with negativism, weakness or treason, I haven't heard of it. And with the capture in Afghanistan of John Walker, a Taliban soldier from the cushy liberal lair of Marin County, Calif., the present crisis is quickly returning to familiar form.

title: New Yorkers Carry Aid, and Relics, to Kabul
description: ''Follow the lady in the blue burka.''

title: Simon V. Weiser: Medieval History Buff
description: Simon V. Weiser was born in Kiev, Ukraine, in 1936. For most of the next 36 years, his family says, he tried to leave. Finally, his opportunity came, in a brief warming of the cold war in 1972, when some Jews were allowed to emigrate to Israel. His wife and son followed in 1974; the family moved to the United States in 1978  to Canarsie, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRITZER, DAVID JOSEPH, RABBI
description: SPRITZER-David Joseph, Rabbi. Age 61. Died in Hemlock Farms, Lords Valley, PA, December 21, 2001, of cancer. Rabbi Spritzer was a beloved husband, father and grandfather. He leaves behind six children, seven grandchildren, and his devoted wife Cynthia Winograd Spritzer. Rabbi Spritzer was born in Mt. Vernon, New York. A graduate of Stanford University and the Jewish Theological Seminary, he had a Master's degree in Education and Counseling from California State University. Rabbi Spritzer served in congregations Peru, California, and Israel. His last congregation was at Temple Israel in Stroudsburg, PA. He served in the Israeli army and was the founder of two Conservative congregations in Israel. He also served as the president of the Rabbinical Assembly in Israel. Rabbi Spritzer, to all those who knew him well, was an inspiring teacher and was described as a '' sweet man'' who was known for his kind and caring relationships with people. Rabbi Spritzer will be buried in Jerusalem. Donations in his memory can be made to Temple Israel in Stroudsburg PA.

title: Durrell V. Pearsall Jr.: Imposing Yet Inviting
description: His name was Durrell V. Pearsall Jr., but everyone called him Bronko. At 6 feet 2, 285 pounds, Firefighter Pearsall could bench press 455 pounds as easily, said someone who witnessed the feat, as if "it was nothing."

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Transfer of Power

title: Pakistan Freeze on Assets
description: Pakistan intends to follow Washington's lead and freeze the assets of an Islamic charity, Ummah Tameer-e-Nau, a spokesman for President Pervez Musharraf said today.

title: The American With the Taliban
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Chemicals Acquisition
description: Solvay S.A. agreed to buy Montedison S.p.A.'s Ausimont N.V. fluorinated-products unit for 600 million euros ($540 million) as the company, Belgium's biggest chemical maker seeks more profitable businesses. Solvay, which is based in Belgium, will double its sales of fluorine enhanced materials and become the No. 2 manufacturer of products like nonstick coatings for frying pans. It would rank behind the DuPont Company. Solvay will also assume 660 million euros ($594 million) in long-term debt.

title: An Inauguration, an Attack on a Convoy, Questions for the Captured
description: Afghanistan, whose 26 million people have suffered war, poverty, religious intolerance and ethnic brutality, stood on the threshold of its first peaceful transfer of power in decades. New leaders, with peacekeepers to back them up, arrived in Kabul on the eve of the inauguration of a power-sharing interim government intended to lead the nation into a post-Taliban era of recovery and stability.

title: The Penis as Text for Serious Thinkers: Be Careful What You Wish For
description: Lyndon B. Johnson once answered reporters badgering him about why the United States was in Vietnam with a simple, unmistakable off-the-record gesture: he unzipped, pulled out his penis and said, ''This is why!''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GOLDMAN SACHS INC., New York, the global investment banking firm, said it had agreed to buy the specialist assets of the closely held investment firm, TFM Investment Group L.L.C., Philadelphia. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, JOAN JOHNSON
description: HART-Joan Johnson. Daughter of Richard O. Johnson and Jean F. Holt. Born February 28, 1918 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. Wife of the late Thornley W. Hart. Beloved mother of Richard M. (Susan), Thornley A. Hart (Barbara), Angela H. Morris and her grandchildren, Nina, Edward Morris, Richard A., Nicholas, Kelsey and Gaelen Hart, and Thornley F. Hart. Died peacefully at home December 21. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: Boy Pleads Guilty in Killing of Homeless Man
description: The youngest of 13 teenagers charged in the fatal beating last June of a homeless man in Paterson, N.J., has pleaded guilty to juvenile manslaughter charges and agreed to testify against the others in exchange for leniency, officials said yesterday.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: A Warning to the F.B.I.

title: A 'Messiah' At Home And Human
description: Hearing the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys at their church on Fifth Avenue is a bit like hearing the New York Philharmonic in Avery Fisher Hall: these are musicians at home. The choir's performance of ''Messiah'' on Tuesday had that ease of people performing in familiar surroundings, in a place whose aura and acoustic space they inhabit as their own.

title: Margaret Mattic: Dimples Right and Left
description: Margaret Mattic was the only one of the five Mattic girls of Detroit to have dimples. Right and left, the dimples set off the shy smile and the lilting, gentle voice that everyone remarked on. As a young girl, in elementary school productions, she played Snow White as well as Gretel in "Hansel and Gretel."

title: Postal Workers Hesitant on Anthrax Vaccinations
description: The Postal Service doled out little teddy bears today to the scores of letter carriers and other workers at a makeshift mail-processing center on Route 130 here, but the gesture did little to lift holiday spirits.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Poet's Palestine as a Metaphor
description: In the Arab imagination, Palestine is not simply a plot of land, any more than Israel is a plot of land in the Jewish imagination. As the Palestinian poet Mahmoud Darwish has observed, Palestine is also a metaphor -- for the loss of Eden, for the sorrows of dispossession and exile, for the declining power of the Arab world in its dealings with the West.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOONT, SONIA
description: FOONT-Sonia. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Lenore and Jerry Helfman and Alan and Fran Foont. Cherished grandmother of Dennis, Donald, Keri and Todd and greatgrandmother of Lauren, Lindsey, Brian and Dani. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: St. John's Set For a Challenge
description: St. John's had just survived an encounter with St. Francis of Brooklyn on Thursday when Coach Mike Jarvis was asked if the Red Storm could possibly be ready to face a ranked team after such an inelegant performance.

title: One Week in Britain
description: From Jan. 5 to March 23, Country Cottages, in Boca Raton, Fla., has one-week fly-drive plans to Britain that include round-trip air fare to London from New York, Newark or Boston; seven nights in a country cottage with modern bath and kitchen, all linens and utensils and at least two bedrooms, and a rental car with unlimited mileage. The price is $598 a person for couples and $498 a person for groups of four to eight (six or more get two cars); children under 2 are $99. For information on the house-party packages and reservations: (800) 674-8883, Web site www.villacentral.com .

title: Flight School Warned F.B.I. Of Suspicions
description: An instructor at a Minnesota flight school warned the F.B.I. in August of his suspicion that a student who was later identified as a part of Osama bin Laden's terror network might be planning to use a commercial plane loaded with fuel as a weapon, a member of Congress and other officials said today.

title: Chrebet Sees New Comfort in Old Connection
description: The Vinny Testaverde-to-Wayne Chrebet connection, once the envy of professional football, had stopped working so well this season. That is why, Chrebet said today, he and Testaverde went to the Jets' new offensive coordinator, Paul Hackett, three games ago to try to revive the passing game they knew so well.

title: After Yearlong Grounding, Osprey Is Set for New Tests
description: The problem-plagued V-22 Osprey, which has been grounded for the last year, will return to flight testing early in 2002, but under a strict new regime that is likely to delay full production by two years or more, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Siege Mentality in Buenos Aires
description: On Wednesday night, no one in Buenos Aires slept. Midweek during a stretch of brutally hot, steamy weather, the city's streets were taken over by thousands of irate citizens marching on the Plaza de Mayo, the elegant square that faces the presidential palace, to protest the government's lack of response to the rioting and ransacking that had spread across the nation.

title: A Fairer Sort of Harvard
description: Last spring protesting students at Harvard demanded that the university pay all of its workers at least a living wage and that it stop contracting with outside companies for low-wage work. Faced with unflattering national publicity, Harvard set up a committee of faculty members, administrators, students and employees to look at the situation of its low-wage workers and make recommendations. The protests had raised a fundamental question: Does a major employer like Harvard have a responsibility to be a good employer to workers, or should it seek to get by with the least it can in the labor market?

title: The American With the Taliban
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks With North Could Follow as South Korea Lifts Troop Alert
description: The South Korean government said today that it had canceled the alert placed on South Korean troops at the outset of the war in Afghanistan, removing a prime obstacle to dialogue with North Korea.

title: Ted Turner Signs a 2-Year Agreement With AOL Time Warner
description: Ted Turner, the vice chairman of AOL Time Warner, signed a two-year contract at the media and Internet company yesterday, a couple of weeks after the chief executive-designate, Richard D. Parsons, asked him to stay.

title: The American With the Taliban
description: To the Editor:

title: Vanessa Kolpak: Letters for a Mother
description: hat has been so beautiful in the last three months are the letters I've gotten," said Vivian Kolpak, about her daughter, Vanessa, 21, a financial researcher at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. "Those are the things that say more about her than even I could say." Some excerpts:

title: Sign Gonzalez, Keep Appier, Avoid Vaughn
description: The promise of failure hung over Mets rallies last season like a stationary weather front. They would load the bases with one out or have two on and nobody out and inevitably some dejected hitter -- Robin Ventura, Todd Zeile, insert your name of choice -- would yank disgustedly at the straps of his batting gloves as opponents jogged off the field.

title: 3 Hijack Commuter Bus on Way To New York City, Police Say
description: Three passengers hijacked a jitney bus yesterday morning, as it made its way into New York City from New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARITY, NATALIE, (LYONS)
description: GARITY-Natalie, (Lyons), December 22, 1989. You are still the first person I want to call. Remembered with love everyday by your children & your grandson. Miss you mom. Love Susie

title: Argentina's New Chapter In an Epic of Frustration
description: Argentina has some of the world's richest agricultural and cattle lands and a good deal of oil, an educated and cultured population, and a mere 36 million people sprinkled over a land mass nearly the size of India. At the turn of the last century, its economy was comparable to that of the United States.

title: York Research Forced Into Bankruptcy Court by Unit's Creditors
description: The York Research Corporation ( news/quote ), a power-plant builder and operator, was forced into bankruptcy court by seven creditors of its North American Energy Conservation Inc. unit that say York is not paying its debts.

title: Amtrak Deserves Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: An Actress From Spain as at Ease in Lightheartedness as in the Dark Side
description: In films directed by Pedro Almodvar, Marisa Paredes has played sexy, open-hearted women with strong creative instincts: a cabaret singer in ''High Heels,'' a famous actress in ''All About My Mother'' and a best-selling writer of romance fiction in ''The Flower of My Secret.''

title: A Soft Sell for Troubled Times; Retailing's Elite Keep the Armani Moving Off the Racks
description: Ruth Lazar, a Bergdorf Goodman saleswoman dressed in Chanel, is moving briskly through the store. She is searching for clothes to show to a longtime customer later in the day but is also reaching for several garments that are not on the woman's wish list, including a sleeveless red silk Guerriero dress adorned with three large velvet and chiffon flowers.

title: One Women Portrays the Many Faces of Apartheid
description: No other show in New York asks the audience to earn its rewards in the manner of ''The Syringa Tree,'' Pamela Gien's play about a girlhood spent in apartheid-riven South Africa. It's worth it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKEMAN, BERNICE D.
description: BLAKEMAN-Bernice D. We mourn the loss of our beloved past-president. Sincere condolences to her family and friends. The Sisterhood of Forest Hills Jewish Center

title: Former Head of Enron Denies Wrongdoing
description: As government investigators look for the roots of Enron's demise, the Enron chief executive who quit just months before the company collapsed broke his silence today to deny any responsibility or wrongdoing.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Hint Of Motive In Stabbings
description: A first-degree murder indictment in the stabbings of two Dartmouth professors says they occurred during a robbery, the first hint of a motive in the case. The charge is one of two theories the prosecution may offer in the trial of Robert Tulloch, 18, of Chelsea, Vt., in the deaths of Half Zantop, 63, and Susanne Zantop, 55, in January. The other is that Mr. Tulloch ''purposefully'' planned to kill the couple with James Parker, 17, also of Chelsea, who has pleaded guilty as an accomplice to second-degree murder.

title: William E. Krukowski: Pedal to the Metal
description: When William E. Krukowski gave up his motorcycle  and, by the way, skydiving  he took up with a bicycle. He got his exercise: he rode the bike to work most days at Ladder Company 21 in Manhattan from his home in Bayside, Queens.

title: James Andrew O'Grady: A Place for Everything...
description: James Andrew O'Grady kept his shirts arranged by color. He lined up his cuff links just so. And he liked his towels in a certain place. His love of order and ritual might have seemed out of place in the tumultuous world of the bond market, where Mr. O'Grady, 32, was a managing director of fixed-income sales for Sandler O'Neill & Partners.

title: Ice Crush: Tykes Skate at 4 A.M.
description: AT Iceland in New Hyde Park, the ice is in use 18 to 20 hours a day, seven days a week, and figure skaters are given ice time at weekday morning freestyle sessions beginning at 5:30 a.m. Rich Roulston, Iceland's general manager, said children as young as 6 are being brought in by their parents before school to work on their moves.

title: Meet the New Boss
description: Q: Why do you think you were picked as minister for women's affairs?

title: December 16-22; Really, I Promise. But Next Year.
description: I RESOLVE to: lose weight; exercise more; quit smoking; stop drinking; keep in touch with friends; be nicer to all the jerks in my life.

title: How Americans Came to Deck the Halls
description: ''DECK the halls with boughs of holly,'' the old Yuletide song goes. Down through the ages cultures as diverse as the Roman, Druid and American -- from colonists to today -- have done just that to color festivities during dark December days.

title: Into That Darkness, Again
description: THE HEALING WOUND

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOORSTEIN, LUCILLE

title: Back to the Old Bathhouse: Free to Laugh Once Again
description: Steam billows out from the doorway, but it is the peals of women's laughter and children's shrieks that swell powerfully under the arched vaults of the old hamam. The public bathhouses, or hamam as they are known here, are once again open for the women of this city after three and a half years under the Taliban, and the women are flooding back to enjoy them.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In this critical time when our mother country is looking at our actions let us come together and be brothers and sisters.''

title: A. Todd Rancke: A Community Fixture
description: When A. Todd Rancke knocked you down, you did not want to get back up, because you were too busy laughing. Mr. Rancke, a managing director at Sandler O'Neill, had a teasing sense of humor that played on people's flaws but did not generate any ill will, said his sister, Cindy Bienemann. "He could crack on you in a way without making you feel bad," she said.

title: Acquired Situational Narcissism
description: Superpower America suffers from ''acquired situational narcissism.'' It is unable to understand why it is unloved for its arrogance. It will continue to offend until it learns that ''other apes have cultures, too.''

title: A Painter's Canvases Are Store Windows
description: Holding a paper-plate palette in her hand, Jane Rubinstein swept her paintbrush across a window at R. S. Jones, a restaurant in Merrick, adding yet another layer of light blue snow to the drift she was creating. She stepped back off a ledge onto the sidewalk and surveyed the winter scene with a toothy, exuberant grin.

title: Jordan Deflates Knicks As Wizards Inflate Streak
description: He can no longer float in the air and mesmerize fans and opponents the way he did for so many years, but Michael Jordan proved last night that he could still demoralize a Madison Square Garden crowd.

title: The Year in Ideas
description: Your concept for ''the year in ideas'' was brilliant. Ideas make our culture, and the news media usually give them short shrift in comparison with ''human interest'' stories. Although there could be endless debate about what was included, your basic idea is so good that it ought to be included in the list.

title: Meanwhile, in Crazed Pet News . . .
description: A FEW big stories have been taking up most of the news space since Sept. 11. Here are some goings-on that may have escaped your attention: Santa's booming ''Ho! Ho! Ho!'' can frighten children, according to a New Zealand recruiting agency that hires mall Santas. An agency executive said this year's Santas were urged to adopt new tot-friendly greetings, like ''Lovely of you to visit.'' . . .

title: INVESTING WITH/Gene W. Henssler; Henssler Equity Fund
description: WHEN Gene W. Henssler was a finance professor at the University of Toledo in the 1970's, he managed his own investments and started choosing stocks and bonds for a handful of friends.

title: Pushing to Speed Up East Side Rail Link
description: THE Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center has prompted the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to speed up work on the East Side Access Project, which would provide Long Island Rail Road riders another route into Manhattan.

title: Deborah Kobus: Open to Adventure
description: Getting downsized is no fun at all, unless you have the Deborah Kobus perspective on things. Ever since her days at New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, she was the sort who knew how to cheer herself up, lately by sailing to Tahiti or going skiing in Argentina.

title: Imagine; The Penalty of Death
description: In August, the highest appeals court in Texas unexpectedly stayed the execution of a death row inmate whose case had attracted international attention because he was 17 when he murdered the father of a federal judge. For death penalty opponents, the case was another victory in a year in which polls suggested that the public was growing increasingly concerned about the fairness of capital punishment.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: 'The Birds of Heaven'
description: On a rare clear morningthe first day of summer 1992flying across the Bering Strait from the Yukon delta toward the Diomede islands and the Chukotskiy Peninsula of Siberia, I imagine the gray sun-silvered strait as seen from on high by a migrating crane, more particularly, by the golden eye of the Crane from the East, as the lesser sandhill crane of North America is known to traditional peoples on its westernmost breeding territory in Siberia. The sandhill commonly travels a mile above the earth and can soar higher, to at least twenty thousand feetnot astonishing when one considers that the Eurasian and demoiselle cranes ascend to three miles above sea level traversing the Himalaya in their north and south migrations between Siberia and the Indian subcontinent.

title: Crowd Flees as Man Is Shot in Times Sq.
description: A Brooklyn man was shot in Times Square early yesterday, sending dozens of other people on the street running for safety, the police said.

title: Letters
description: Our special issue on ideas was roundly cheered by readers, igniting calls for "more, more" and suggestions that we make it a permanent feature. And our article on paying and playing in big-league basketball prompted some to cut the game down to size, literally and figuratively.

title: Season's Biddings
description: Last week I got a package from a very nice lady who lives on the West Coast. Inside, I found a lovingly wrapped wool plaid shirt, just my size, in my favorite colors, with a handwritten note on a small card. The shirt fit perfectly, and when I raised the sleeve to my face I could smell not the newness of the new -- so formerly intoxicating -- but something else entirely. It was a perfume of untraceable subtleties, the kind of scent that made me wish I were a hound dog, able to discern in just what proportions the aromas of laundry soap and laundry room, of closet, kitchen and the humans who lived there, intermingled in the cloth. From that odor, I almost knew the house the shirt had come from. If it had been mailed 40 years ago, it could have come from my aunt's house in Des Moines, a hand-me-down from a cousin. But this package came from a total stranger. I had won the shirt on eBay.

title: Giuliani, With Eye Toward 2012 Games, to Carry Olympic Flame
description: As if Rockefeller Center were not already awash in lights, representatives of the 2002 Winter Olympics said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would light the Olympic flame today over the center's skating rink.

title: Going Global? Forget Borders
description: IN the early 1990's, Motorola was king of the wireless telephone game. Few Americans had even heard of a Finnish company called Nokia, based in a suburb of Helsinki. Motorola was fat and content; Nokia was the ambitious challenger. It dispatched executives to California, Japan and London to see the latest ways in which people were using their cellphones. Nokia combined that knowledge with what was happening in the Finnish market, one of the most advanced in percentage of cellphone users.

title: A Mittenless Autumn, for Better and Worse
description: Across the Northeast, people opened their doors yesterday to discover something unfamiliar: a chill in the air.

title: If Bloomberg Says Goodnight to Gracie, Readers Have a Few Suggestions

Bloomberg has said he prefers to live inhis East 79th Street town house. Since New York,like nature, abhors a vacuum, the City sectioninvited readers to submit their own ideas. Here is a sampling:

title: EARLY ADMISSIONS DEBATE
description: Yale's president, Richard C. Levin, unleashed a major debate by calling for an end to early admissions. Many students apply early and agree to enroll if admitted because they're likelier to get in. Most are upper-class whites; other students may not know about the option or want to compare financial aid offers. Some colleges fill nearly half their freshman class this way. Critics say it pushes students into rushed decisions. Karen W. Arenson

title: Christopher Sullivan: True Partner at Home
description: Christopher and Dolores Sullivan were high school sweethearts, and he gave her a happy ending with a modern twist. She got a prince who was never too tired to play with their sons, Sean, 6, and Brian, 4 or to prepare her lunch for work. Mr. Sullivan, 39, was a firefighter at Ladder 11 and Engine 214 in Brooklyn.

description: MELINDA WHICHER was a high school student in Oklahoma City when her father was killed in the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building on April 19, 1995. A few months later, she wrote a poem that ended:

description: ON oceanfront land in Brooklyn once occupied by the Brighton Beach Baths, the Muss Organization of Queens is moving into the third year of construction on a condominium project that is reversing the symbolism of the site -- from one linked with the past to one reflecting the possibilities the city holds for its recent immigrants and their children.

The publications were meant to supplement the 68-page Westchester Country Travel Guide, updated annually and also published by the Office of Tourism.

description: e was no saint!" said Eugene Whelan's mother, Joan, her laughter bubbling up. "Yeah, he could be a giant pain!" her husband, Alfred, added, chuckling about the ninth of their 10 children.

description: The likelihood of North American corporations defaulting on their debt over the next year has increased to 4.1 percent from 3.3 percent, according to Moody's Investors Service.

description: WITH garlands and tinsel, twinkling lights dangling from houses, illuminated reindeer on lawns, electric menorahs glowing in windows and candles burning to mark the winter solstice, the season of light is a most visual feast. But Becky Barnes cannot see it. She must experience Christmas, her favorite holiday, in other ways. Mrs. Barnes, 50, is blind and has been since birth.

description: Like many fine food stores, Cheese Traders and Wine Sellers has the soft lighting, nice music and free samples that enable customers to spend $80 on a bag of groceries without bursting into tears over the prices.

title: The Sadness of the Temporary Santa
description: MAURICE DE WITT, 62, sat in his small room packed full with hand-me-downs and secondhand stuff, dreading the prospects of Christmas Eve. He smoked cigarettes and drank stout from the bottle, philosophizing on his role as the second-most-famous Santa Claus in town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARPER, ETHEL
description: HARPER-Ethel. 92, December 13, 2001, in New York City after a long, gallant fight with Alzheimer's. Daughter of David and Rose Harper of Lavenham and London, England. A prominent philatelist, auctioneer, and lecturer on postage stamps and postal history, in ten years she gave over 200 presentations. In addition, Ms. Harper broadcast regularly to a national audience on BBC Canada and created the very popular course on postal history for young collectors. In 1952 she was appointed Assistant to the Chairman, Louise Boyd Dale, at the Philatelic Foundation in New York City and served with distinction for 25 years. A world traveler and firm friend to so many, she has no known survivors. Her remains are interred in the Kirby family plot near Boston, Mass. A memorial service Monday, January 14th, 2002 at 11:30 am, Campbell Funeral Home, 81st St. and Madison Avenue, New York City. Her favorite charity is Recording for the Blind, 20 Roszel Road, Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: Private Sector; Crown Jewel for a Fashion Heir?
description: CLAUDIO DEL VECCHIO fondly remembers the scent of oil at his father's eyeglasses factory in Agordo, in the Italian Alps. As a teenager, Mr. Del Vecchio worked there during summers, cutting metal frames for sunglasses and earning one lira for every cardboard box he folded. ''I loved it -- I loved to be able to say, 'I created something,' '' he said.

title: Satisfying a Yen for Seafood Year Round
description: AS the car crossed the Ponquoque Bridge and headed east on Dune Road in Hampton Bays, someone in the back seat said, ''Are you sure there's something open down there?'' It was late November and the road ahead was dark and desolate, not a person, car or light in sight. Then, near land's end, just 45 seconds from the Shinnecock Inlet, there were lights, people, action and that rarest of Long Island restaurant birds, a good, low-priced seafood spot. For despite nearly a thousand miles of coastline, Long Island has very few good fish houses, especially modestly priced ones.

title: 'Pragmatic Palestinian' Draws Road Map to Peace
description: For centuries, the Nusseibeh family of Jerusalem has held the keys to the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, built on the sites where tradition says Jesus was crucified and entombed.

And so he spent 14 years at Ladder Company 3 in the East Village, where he was decorated for bravery last spring after rescuing a woman from a burning apartment.

title: A Stylish Fir Grown in Nova Scotia Finds a Good Home in the Bronx
description: Seven years ago last spring, in a forest in Antigonish, Nova Scotia, about 10 miles from St. George's Bay, the seed of a balsam fir took root. As the seedling became a sapling and then a tree, it withstood the whip of wet salt air; the weight of snow and freezing rain; and the onslaught of twig aphids and woolly aphids and tussock moths and gall midges.

title: Susan Spivak, Edward Rucker

description: Elizabeth Christine Gandy, the daughter of Meredith and Theodore Gandy of Manhattan, was married yesterday to John Lee, a son of Pan Li-chu Lee and Ming Lee of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Mel Cure performed the ceremony at Trinity Baptist Church in Manhattan.

title: Palmina Delli Gatti: Keeper of Helpful Secrets
description: Palmina Delli Gatti knew things. The secret of homemade pie crusts, for instance, and of a good thick pasta sauce. She knew. She knew the powerful people in the World Trade Center by their first names. When she traveled, she often went alone. They knew her in Paris, London, Rome.

title: Corrections
description: The last line was omitted last Sunday from an article about relations between Russia and the United States since Sept. 11. The full sentence quoted Ivo Daalder, a Brookings Institution specialist, saying that Russia's disappointment over the ABM treaty could end ''the presumption of future cooperation that has been so central to our relations with allies and friends around the world.''

title: He Made New York's Mayor Matter Again
description: In New York, every mayor since Fiorello La Guardia has left office either defeated or demoralized. Vincent Impellitteri, Abe Beame, Ed Koch and David Dinkins all lost bids for re-election, while William O'Dwyer resigned in disgrace and Robert Wagner and John Lindsay lost the will even to run again.

description: How people search the Internet offers insight into what they are thinking about and interested in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUER, HERBERT J., JR.
description: BRAUER-Herbert J., Jr. Of Setauket, (formerly of Kings Park) suddenly of Diabetes-related complications at the age of 37. A man of his convictions, a highly intelligent, very professional and extremely competent attorney; a graduate of Colgate University, Phi Beta Kappa, and New York University's Law School. Cherished son of Herbert J. Brauer, Sr. and Jean Brauer. Son of the late Ruth C. Brauer. Devoted father of Katrina Brauer. Beloved brother of Laura Brauer Campbell, Robert Campbell, James Brauer, Tabitha Ryan Brauer, Christopher Brauer, Kimberly Holmberg, William Holmberg, and Dana Love Holmberg. Dear uncle of Heather Caltabiano and Elizabeth Campbell. Grand-uncle of Katelyn. Beloved nephew of Eleanor Mueller, Charles F. Brauer and Arthur G. Brauer. Services and interment are private. In Herbert's honor donations may be made to The Diabetes Research Institute Foundation, 45 Glen Cove Road, Greenvale, New York 11548; (516) 621-8804.
