title: A Scientific Search for Cougars
description: Wildlife officials have maintained that cougars have been extinct in Michigan for almost a century, but Dr. Patrick Rusz, without benefit of traps, a tranquilizer gun or a pack of yowling hounds, recently brought back evidence to the contrary.

title: Volunteering On Vacation
description: JUDY GABEY, an English teacher from New York City, spent two weeks in Africa in October helping scientists collect data on a diminishing cheetah population. As a volunteer with the organization Earthwatch, she worked with Namibians radio-tracking the wild cats on foot, from four-seater planes and from all-terrain vehicles. She slept in a thatched hut on a bed shrouded in mosquito netting, helped with the cooking and ate in a straw-roofed pavilion overlooking a plateau where eland, oryxes, kudus and red hartebeests came to drink. From her point of view, it was a perfect vacation.

title: Dropper Popper
description: Dropper Poppers ran rampant in the hallways of my elementary school some 10 years ago, albeit lacking the clever moniker (Jamie Wolf). I wouldn't call them one of 2001's crucial ideas, but try sticking one on your forehead for a cheap 3 p.m. energy jolt.

title: How Americans Came to Deck the Halls
description: DECK the halls with boughs of holly," the old Yuletide song goes. Down through the ages cultures as diverse as the Roman, Druid and American  from colonists to today  have done just that to color festivities during dark December days.

title: Stereotyping Rankles Silent, Secular Majority of American Muslims
description: Khalid Pervaiz is an American Muslim, an investment banker in Los Angeles with two young daughters. On the door of his home is a Christmas wreath made by his 7-year-old, and in the living room is a Christmas tree with an angel on top. His daughters go to the mosque, or masjid, on Sundays for classes in the Koran, but Mr. Pervaiz himself goes once a year on the major Muslim holiday of Id al-Fitr.

title: Occupancy and Rates Sag at New York Hotels
description: New York's hotel industry, along with the national economy, showed signs of weakness even before the terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. But those attacks plunged New York and large parts of the tristate area into an economic tailspin almost overnight and had a drastic impact on tourism.

title: Winter the Swiss Way
description: CERTAINLY the easiest way to take a skiing vacation in the Swiss Alps is to have a niece marry a very congenial Swiss engineer (as one of mine did last summer) and let him plan all the hotels, ski instructors, rentals and New Year's Eve festivities. But it is not the only way, and after six days in Lenzerheide-Valbella, a low-key ski resort an hour's drive north of glamorous St. Moritz, I know that planning such a trip is possible. And it is well worth it, especially if one has a sense of adventure about foreign countries and speaks even a smidgen of German -- especially now, when air fares are nearly half what they were a year ago.

title: This Line Will Not Be Crossed
description: After every home game, the seven offensive linemen of the University of Miami's football team celebrate another victory with a communal dinner at Chili's or Ruby Tuesday's or, as tonight, at Monty's in the Grove. (This happens often: the Hurricanes are 11-0 and favored to win the national championship against Nebraska in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 3.) As the players walk through the dining room, dressed in their baggy sweatshirts and drooping shorts, the other patrons, sharply dressed, look up from their plates, their forks poised at their lips, disbelieving, gawking.

title: CONGRESSIONAL ROUNDUP
description: Congress went home playing the blame game over who killed the economic stimulus package, but first it passed a rewrite of aid to education to put more money into schools in poor areas and test annually to see results. It also agreed to more base-closings, raised military pay by at least 5 percent, and added $8.3 billion to homeland defense and $8.2 billion for New York reconstruction aid -- more than President Bush sought. It agreed that Sept. 11 victims should not pay income taxes for 2001 or 2000. But partisan wrangling blocked action on a farm bill and help for insurers. House Republicans killed an effort to get health-plan coverage for mental illness on a par with physical ailments. Adam Clymer

title: The Man Who Romanced the Stones
description: LAST week, Ambaji Shinde was doing what he has done six days a week for the last 40 years: he sat before an easel in his studio overlooking West 56th Street and painted meticulous, lavish pictures of diamond jewelry. Were they real, these jewels would be worth millions, and soon in fact they would be: Mr. Shinde, the chief designer at Harry Winston, was drawing a pair of enormous earrings for a client. She had specifically requested that he do the work.

title: Private Sector; Celebrating a 50-Year-Old Flier
description: On Dec. 19, 1951, the Northrop Grumman Corporation, then an aircraft company, was listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Last Wednesday, Northrop's chief executive, Kent Kresa, celebrated the anniversary by ringing the closing bell of the Big Board. Since the listing, Northrop has grown into an $18 billion military contractor whose products are used in the war in Afghanistan and whose stock has risen 20 percent since Sept. 11. In fact, Mr. Kresa noted that a dollar invested in the Dow Jones industrial average on the day Northrop was listed would be worth $37 today. That same money invested in Northrop stock would be worth $231. In Mr. Kresa's view: ''So, we've done O.K.'' Leslie Wayne

title: Editorial Observer; When Smallpox Struck During the Revolutionary War
description: The year 2001 is not the first time in history that war and fear of disease and bioterror have gripped Americans at home. The country was born amid all three. Smallpox killed at least 130,000 North Americans during the Revolutionary War, writes the historian Elizabeth Anne Fenn in her new book on the epidemic, ''Pox Americana.''

title: 'The War Against Clich'
description: In 1919, after prolonged study, the Harvard ethologist William Morton Wheeler pronounced the male wasp an ethological non-entity. An animal behaviourist had scrutinized the male wasp and found  no behaviour. We can well imagine the male wasp's response to such a verdict: his initial shock and hurt; his descent into a period of depressed introspection; his eventual decision to behave more intriguingly. For nowadays, according to a recent Scientific American , interest in the long-neglected male is flourishing, a tribute to the animal's broad array of activities. Male humans will surely feel for their brothers in the wasp kingdom. After a phase of relative obscurity, we too have rallied. In fact, we seem to have bounced back pretty well immediately, with all kinds of fresh claims on everyone's attention. Male wounds. Male fights. Male grandeur. Male whimpers of neglect.

title: More Is Still Not Better
description: The poems in Jeffrey Harrison's new collection, FEEDING THE FIRE (Sarabande, cloth, $20.95; paper, $12.95), chronicle our growth from the cluelessness of childhood to that slightly greater state of awareness called adult life. In ''Lure,'' for example, the speaker remembers both the sexy adult neighbor who flirted with him when he was a boy and his own obliviousness of her appeal; ''I didn't even have to pretend / I didn't catch on,'' he says. But when, years later, the speaker meets again the husband she has since cast off, the man's sad-dog eyes suggest that while we experience more as we go along, we don't necessarily learn all that much about love or anything else. Actually, the poems here about sex (''Sex and Poetry,'' ''The Pond of Desires'') are better than the ones about love, a topic so daunting it requires an indirect approach. For the same reason, among Harrison's best are the poems on cars, rock music, skin diving: after all, these subjects open doors to the place in the heart where we come closest to knowing who we really are. A poem central to this collection is ''Horseshoe Contest,'' in which men spend hours at a game that will confirm ''something / unchanging at their core, / small but of a certain heft.'' Another is ''Three Wishes,'' where a father tells his grown children each of them can take a souvenir from the family summer home before it's sold, though in this contemporary fairy tale, as in the old ones, what one wants and what one gets are not always the same. We don't become smarter as we get older, Harrison seems to be saying; we just have more to be aware of. David Kirby

title: CAMDEN CEMENT PLANT

A ruling last May allowed residents of the predominantly black neighborhood to sue the state Department of Environmental Protection on the ground that the agency violated the federal Civil Rights Act by issuing a permit to the plant, which residents say amounts to discrimination. But by a 2-1 vote last week, a panel from the Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the statute does not grant private citizens that right. Steve Strunsky

It gave no hint of the passionate, even viperous intrigue that was playing out behind closed doors. At a moment when the Red Cross was supposed to be absorbed with ministering to a nation in crisis, it was confronting an internal crisis of its own making.

title: Evidence-Based Medicine
description: The news that 80 percent of doctors' practices are not based on any scientific evidence certainly comes as no surprise to midwives and consumers of midwifery care (Jack Hitt). Such obstetrical protocols as forcing women to labor and deliver on their backs, performing mandatory episiotomies, hurrying labor along with pitocin and separating mother and newborn for ''observation'' have been shown, in the obstetricians' own research, to be harmful to mother and child. In the name of following procedure, hospital personnel enforce these pseudoscientific practices that interrupt the natural, and usually flawless, progression of pregnancy, labor, delivery, breast-feeding and bonding. And women who question any of it are tartly reminded who went to medical school and who didn't.

title: Dietrich at 100: The Camera's Truest Lover
description: SHE would have been 100 on Thursday -- or is it 1,000? Hers was a face that might have been found on an ancient temple wall -- timeless, mysterious, equivocal. It was a mask that epitomized the glamour, or even the spirituality, in modern photography. But it concealed a will that had made sure there were no awkward or plain photographs of Marlene Dietrich. She had been cast once in a film called ''The Devil Is a Woman,'' without any complaint of injustice in the attribution. If ever any bad pictures had existed some deviltry burned them, or had them wither in her gaze. At the same time, this icon was a woman eager to bake you a cake, to be warm, ordinary, so much more or less than a photograph.

title: MORE HOMELESS
description: A United States Conference of Mayors survey of 27 cities showed homelessness had increased an average of 13 percent from last year. The likeliest causes: recession, still-high housing prices and Sept. 11, which increased layoffs and diverted charitable donations that usually support shelters and other homeless organizations.

title: Who Owns a Dance? It Depends on the Maker

Her lamentation was caused by the dire financial straits of her dance company, which forced her to consider licensing some of her 180 ballets to other troupes to raise cash. ''I am horrified at the thought of all this,'' she said, ''but the company must continue now and in the future.''

title: The Next Campaign
description: As the holiday season commences, it may seem premature to start thinking about the 2002 elections -- unless you are a member of Congress running for re-election next November. As Congress adjourned last week, it was clear that the jockeying for 2002 had already begun. Lawmakers left Washington dazed and exhausted, preparing to wage the campaign next year on many of the same issues they contested in recent weeks, including taxes, health care, the budget and the economy.

title: DROUGHT DECLARATION
description: The Delaware River Basin Commission, which regulates water use from the river, declared an official drought emergency last week after several reservoir levels fell to record lows. The declaration does not impose water restrictions on the region that draws water from the river, which includes New Jersey. The state had already reduced the amount it was taking from the river in late last month when a drought warning was issued. Further reductions are not imminent unless the drought continues into the warmer months, according to the state Water Supply Administration. Jo Piazza

title: Kenneth Swenson: Man of Inner Peace

It was late May or early June, and the couple and their two sons, 10-year- old Kyle and 13-year-old Eric, were at a local field in Chatham, N.J. kicking a ball around. Suddenly, balloons of all colors floated from the sky and landed on the field. "He brought them over to me and said, `I ordered these for you,' " Mrs. Swenson said.

They lay them elegantly across the chaise longue, tuck them in neatly all around lest a wayward breeze dislodge them and, just when you're stretching out, opening your book and thinking that this is the life, they roll up a third towel and place it under your feet. They bring ice water, too, and as soon as it looks as if you might have a bead of perspiration on your forehead, they offer tiny cold towels scented with eucalyptus or a spritz of Evian. Oh, and they take bar orders.

title: A Fair Shake for Victims

The problem of course has never been the money itself. The lucky ones had life insurance or, like the police and firefighters, generous lifetime pensions. The less fortunate could count on the extraordinary generosity of the American people, who at last count had provided over $1.5 billion in private charity. And at the end of the road, courtesy of the United States Congress, there was an open-ended, multibillion-dollar victims' compensation fund.

''The director, Marc Forster, did not want to see me,'' Berry recalls, sipping coffee at Oona, a restaurant near her apartment in Manhattan. ''My character in the movie has a husband on death row, she's losing her house, her car is breaking down and she's beating up on her son. I couldn't stop reading. I called my manager and said, say yes, say yes, say yes. He said, 'I'm glad you love it, but they don't want you.' The director thought I was too beautiful or something.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, JOSEPH W.
description: McGOVERN-Joseph W. of Irvington. Dies at 92: Former Chancellor of the Board of Regents. Mr. McGovern made a peaceful crossing into new life on December 19 in Mount Vernon Hospital. He was elected to the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York in 1961 and served on Board for 14 years -the last six as Chancellor. This caps a long litany of public service contributions rendered while Mr. McGovern was practicing and teaching law. Until 1999, he served on the Board of Calvary Hospital for 18 years, the last several as Chair. Mr. McGovern was widely known as the consummate lawyer. A partner for many years in the firm of Sullivan, Donovan, Hanrahan, McGovern and Lane, in 1996, Mr. McGovern moved his office from Pine Street in Manhattan to Main Street in White Plains, where he practiced with son Lawrence in the firm of McGovern and Dawson. At Fordham University School of Law he taught a generation of law students, who still refer to him with respect and affection as Professor McGovern. Mr. McGovern's study at home is dotted with the dozen honorary doctorates he was awarded and the numerous awards he received for his teaching. Few were surprised when Fordham Law School in 1996 selected Mr. McGovern for its first ''Second Harvest'' award for one who ''has made exceptional contributions to society in the humanities, the legal profession, business world, community, civic or charitable affairs.'' He did it all. Those who know ''Joe'' McGovern best, though, point out that his proudest moments were spent as devoted teammate with his deceased wife Marie and the six children, 22 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. The only child of Jane Fahy and Philip McGovern, immigrants from Ireland, Mr. McGovern was born in the Bronx on February 22, 1909. The first of his generation to attend college, he graduated with honors from both Fordham College and Fordham Law School. Mr. McGovern is predeceased by his sons Joe-Ray, and Philip; he is survived by his daughter Teesie Melillo, sons Lawrence, Joseph, and Ray, and his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held on Monday, December 24, at 9:00 AM in Fordham University Chapel in the Bronx. Friends may pay their respects at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, from 2:00 to 4:00 and from 7:00 to 9:00 PM on Sunday, December 23. The family asks that any memorials be sent to Calvary Hospital, 1740-70 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461, or to Fordham University, Bronx, NY 10458.

She could play hell-bent, the vaudevillian that she was, or she could play slow, and over her face would visit a stray look of sadness, something blowing past. She would begin to sing.

A snowman on in-line skates, below, and an angelic group of visitors from Virginia brought smiles to grown-ups last week. But the real joy of the holiday showed on the faces of children, like the girl at a ''Nutcracker'' party at the New York City Ballet, top left, or the many groups making Hanukkah toy-store visits.

title: Kasparov Defeats Kramnik And Wins Money and Glory
description: The Botvinnik Memorial Match in Moscow, Dec. 1-9, was won by Garry Kasparov over Vladimir Kramnik in an unconventional format. It was not a return series for the world title. It was for money, a $1 million purse, and bragging rights.

title: From Switzerland With Lots of Buzz
description: WITH its hilltop Topanga Canyon location, outdoor hot tub and floor-to-ceiling glass windows framing an un obstructed view of a glittering Pacific Ocean, Marc Forster's home has all the trappings of a hot feature film director's. That is, for a few more days, until the wealthy owners of this remote hideaway return from the Caribbean, and Mr. Forster moves back to the tiny apartment he rents in nearby Santa Monica. ''If I could afford it, I would live like this,'' said Mr. Forster, who was only house-sitting for some friends this fall. ''But the choices I have made have led me down another path.''

description: THE tight-knit community of Rye is a hockey town. The New York Rangers practice at Rye Playland, and children -- boys and girls -- grow up playing youth hockey there and at the Rye Country Day School. Many of the men lace up their skates on weekends and some weeknights to play recreational hockey. Rye's mayor, Steve Otis, plays goalie for the Rye Rangers, a 25-year-old hockey club, whose entire membership of 300 players ranges in age from 5 to 60.

He is survived by his wife, Namhi Kim Wagner, a brother John Wagner, two sons from his first marriage, Robert Camner and J. title: MUSIC: The Year in Classical Music: The Critics' Choices; Music's Raw Power, Both Old and Young
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'AMERICA: A TRIBUTE TO HEROES' -- (Universal). Like everyone else, musicians were shaken by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, and at this telethon just 10 days later, their reactions were raw and complicated. Choosing one song each as if there might be no tomorrow, they sang elegies, prayers, warnings, wishes for peace and affirmations of patriotism and love. Without layers of celebrity and promotion, the music reclaimed the power of songs to confide and share listeners' innermost thoughts.

description: Al Gore keeps saying he has not decided whether to run for president again in 2004.

title: MUSIC: The Year in Classical Music: The Critics' Choices; Ligeti's Mysteries; Lachenmann's Year
description: GYORGY LIGETI: INSTRUMENTAL WORKS -- Pierre-Laurent Aimard, pianist; Asko and Schnberg Ensembles, conducted by Reinbert de Leeuw (Teldec New Line). ''Melodien,'' the Chamber Concerto, the Piano Concerto and ''Mysteries of the Macabre'': music that has always glistened glistens again, but now with a completely unexpected expressive power. Around every strange and colorful corner is a lurking poignancy.

title: Investing; Fuel Cell Companies Offer Choice and Risk
description: SHARES of fuel cell companies soared last year, posting triple-digit gains during the California energy crisis. This year, as energy supplies have rebounded, their prices have sunk as much as 95 percent from the highs.

title: Imagine; And the Winner Is . . .
description: For the first nine months of this year, the political world argued over who really won the Florida presidential election and eagerly awaited a comprehensive review of the uncounted ballots by eight news organizations.

title: Drop Someone a Card
description: What do Wild West City and Washington's Headquarters have in common? Both are New Jersey icons. And now, thanks to a Jerseyana journalist named Helen-Chantal Pike, postcards depicting Netcong's American West theme park and the Morristown mansion that Theodosia Ford donated to the Revolution, as well as hundreds of other images, are bound within the 250 pages of ''Greetings from New Jersey: A Postcard Tour of the Garden State'' (Rutgers University Press). At $26, it could make a fine last-minute gift for anyone who might enjoy postcards of Thoroughbreds straining at Monmouth Park Race Track or Lobster King Harry Hackney with his Lobster Waitresses, on the Boardwalk in Atlantic City. Ms. Pike's brief text and extended captions accompany an exquisite collection of postcards chronicling the state's 19th and 20th centuries, many of them -- the Edison Tower, topped by a giant light bulb; the Victorian-style Hereford Light in Anglesea -- reproduced in the dreamy pastels of hand-painted photographs.

title: Roll's Roles
description: Todd Beamer was a passenger on the doomed Flight 93, taken over on Sept. 11 by terrorists who intended to use the aircraft as a missile to destroy the White House or the Capitol. He had a telephone line open to an operator in Chicago, who reported hearing him recite the Lord's Prayer before leading a group of heroic passengers to rush the suicidal hijackers. Then Beamer said: ''Are you guys ready? Let's roll.''

title: Three Tests Find Fault With Liberty
description: AFTER a round of generally positive reviews, the Liberty has run into problems. First, one rolled in testing by AutoWeek magazine. Then a loaded Liberty ''tipped dangerously'' in testing by Auto Bild, a German magazine. Finally, low-speed crash tests by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety inflicted costly damage to the bumpers.

title: Our Towns; Ideas for an Ailing Hospital: Layoffs, and Advertising on Imus
description: THE social workers are the people who need consoling these days at Nassau County's public hospital. All but 12 of the 28 on the staff will be laid off by the end of the year, officials say. Irene Burk, the only one assigned to the cancer ward, has just 11 months on the job and knows she is gone. ''How do you tell dying patients, 'We'll talk about it next week,' '' she says through reddening eyes, ''when you're not even sure you're going to be here next week?''

title: The World; Money Talks, Sovereignty Walks
description: A DECADE ago, Argentina took a drastic step to stamp out the hyperinflation that was crippling its economy: it effectively gave up control of its national currency. Under a program developed by its economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, it shackled the peso's value to that of the dollar on a one-to-one basis, and pledged to do whatever necessary to maintain that link.

title: For Christmas, 47 Trees And One Man's Toys
description: Christmas trees representing Egypt, Latvia, Colombia and 44 other countries are part of the annual Christmas Around the World and Holidays of Light festival running through Jan. 6 at the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAUGHN, CHARLOTTE
description: VAUGHN-Charlotte. Born in Boston, MA, she grew up in Jaffrey, NH, and Long Island, NY. After graduating from Chatham Hall, she received a BA from Smith College. She began her teaching career in New York City and later moved to San Francisco, where she taught at the Hamlin School, where she was honored as Teacher of the Year. In 1954 she married James Vaughn, her beloved husband of 47 years. She raised her four children in Woodside, CA, and would later live in New York City, London, Sun Valley and Pebble Beach. Charlotte passed away December 17, in Monterey, CA, with her family at her side. She is survived by her husband James and her three children, Peter Vaughn, a teacher in Pasadena, Ca, Patsy Pinney, a mother in La Canada, CA, and Diana Ryan, a mother in Mill Valley, CA. She is the proud grandmother of eight grandchildren, Ben, Emma, Harry, Annie, Will, Timothy, Julia and Katharine.

title: Krause Defends Dismantling Bulls
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (Bloomberg News)  Jerry Krause of the the Chicago Bulls says he does not regret breaking up the Michael Jordan-led dynasty or rebuilding with a pair of teenagers even though the team now has the worst record in the N.B.A.

title: Business; An Economic Speedometer Gets an Overhaul
description: WHEN the Consumer Price Index is announced each month, it gets a lot of attention. People might assume that its creators know exactly what consumers are doing: how much they spend on an average trip to Costco, for example, or on a delivery from the local Thai takeout; how many DVD's they rent or buy; or how much they pay each month for their high-speed Internet service.

description: Those around the 87-year-old former king of Afghanistan, Mohammad Zahir Shah, who has spent nearly three decades in isolated exile here, want to see him take on more than a symbolic role in rebuilding their country. Some even speak of restoring the monarchy.

title: The Drug-Price Express Runs Into a Wall
description: WITH a clatter of stadium-style seats, several hundred drug stock analysts rushed from the crowded amphitheater in Merck's gleaming $250 million headquarters in Whitehouse Station, N.J., on Dec. 12. Racing into the nearby atrium, they began feverishly contacting their trading desks on their cellphones and Blackberries to report a bombshell for investors.

title: How a Fat Apple Pancake Saved Christmas
description: A great pal of mine at the somewhat curious high school I attended was Ronnie Reuben, one of six grandchildren of Arnold, the feisty German immigrant who founded and maintained Reuben's, which from the late teens till the 60's was the show-biz-journalist-politico-occasional-mobster restaurant of choice. It was open 24 hours a day and was sort of a cross between Katz's Deli, Liquids and Nobu. Among other things, Ronnie introduced me to the most self-indulgent meal I had until I was 33 and ate at a German beer hall in Munich, after which I thought I was literally going to explode. Reuben's also taught me that when the holidays roll around and you're solo, exuberance and self-indulgence can keep the worst of the demons at bay.

title: U.S. Providing $8.2 Million To Rebuild TV Antennas
description: The federal government is providing millions of dollars to help restore television service to hundreds of thousands of viewers in the New York City region who lost it as a result of the collapse of the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSNOW, KATE
description: SOSNOW-Kate. On December 21, 2001 at the age of 91 of Kings Point, N.Y. and Miami Beach, Fla. Loving wife of the late Morris Sosnow. Devoted mother of Bernice and the late Jerrold Lieberman, Lorraine and Irving Aaron, Sheila and Richard Nagler. Beloved sister of Betty Benstock. Adored Nana to Zabrina, Seth, Kristina, Daryl, Mindy, Ron, Robert, Tracie, Ethan and Julia. Proud great-grandmother of Dari, Eric, Perri, Cari, Madison, Jennifer and Max. Services to be held Sunday, December 23, 2001 at 12:30, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in her memory to the North Shore University Hospital.

description: Jayesh Shah and his brother were always close, whether the family lived in India or Wisconsin or Tulsa or Houston.

description: A senior official said today that India was seriously considering military action if diplomatic pressure fails to persuade Pakistan to crack down on Pakistan-based groups that India has accused of attacking Parliament on Dec. 13.

description: DARK wood, sepia walls and old photographs lend a decades-old ambience to this steakhouse in business for only six years. Far from dainty, Ye Olde Tollgate is fashioned after the old New York steakhouses like the Palm or Smith & Wollensky, no-frills dining spots once thought of as bastions of masculinity, in the days when, rumor had it, real men conducted serious business over two martinis and a thick steak.

description: As the state recalls the 225th anniversary of the American Revolution, and the winter of 1776-77 when Washington's troops fought the British and Hessians, one local museum is remembering the Hessians.

title: KILLINGS RISING
description: In what may be a leading indicator that crime is starting to increase again, after a nearly decade-long decline, homicides in many big cities have increased sharply. The rise was led by Boston and Phoenix, which both have had a greater than 60 percent jump in homicides so far this year. Not all cities are up -- in New York, homicides have fallen 5.2 percent. But police chiefs worry that several factors may be pushing violent crime up: rising unemployment, a growing number of inmates being released from the nation's expanded prison system, and a new surge in domestic killings. Fox Butterfield

description: JENNIFER McLAUGHLIN of Brewster, N.Y., is not an athlete.

description: The ''precautionary principle'' is just a clever way of banning scientifically improved foods of the sort that the European Union recently called ''probably even safer than conventional plants and foods'' (Michael Pollan).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, CHARLES K., M.D.
description: McSHERRY-Charles K., M.D. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical College deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Charles K. McSherry, Clinical Professor of Surgery Emeritus and Attending Surgeon. A graduate of Cornell University Medical College, who completed his training in surgery at The New York Hospital, he was nationally renowned for his research into cancer of the colon and gallstone formation. He worked with Dr. Frank Glenn in creating a biliary disease registry and led the way in introducing laparoscopic surgery for gallstones. We extend our condolences to his family. John M. Daly, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Surgery, New York Weill Cornell Medical Center

title: Malakhov Finally Reaches Potential
description: There was a time when Vladimir Malakhov was considered an enigma. No more.

title: DEATH SENTENCE RULING
description: A federal ruling appeased neither side in Philadelphia's anguished, 20-year dispute over the fate of America's best-known death-row inmate, Mumia Abu-Jamal, 47. A militant journalist and former Black Panther, he was convicted of killing a white policeman in a 1981 street shootout. He has been a charismatic campaigner for his innocence, and his cause has sparked worldwide criticism of American justice. His conviction was affirmed, but his death sentence struck down, making further airings of the case likely. Francis X. Clines

description: Late last month, the commandant of the United States Coast Guard met with leaders of the International Maritime Organization on the banks of the Thames in London to propose sweeping changes in the way the world conducts international shipping.

description: THE Jeep Cherokee is, no doubt, an American icon. A modern classic. But these words are bandied about too freely these days to really capture the place of this vehicle.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about towns' projects to buy up open space misstated the year Greenburgh established a sales tax surcharge for the purpose. It was 1997, not 1996. The chart also misattributed a vote to issue a bond anticipation note to buy 41 acres. It occurred in New Castle, not Bedford.
