title: In Cable, The Race Approaches A Far Turn
description: COMCAST'S planned $47 billion acquisition of AT&T Broadband is the latest, biggest step toward consolidation in the cable industry. But it is probably not the last.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/High Bridge, N.J.; Steel Town Reborn as Family Community
description: OLD-TIMERS in High Bridge like to call their tiny Hunterdon County borough Mayberry. Dating back to the 1700's, this old steel town has managed to retain much of its old-fashioned character. There are bandstand concerts under a gazebo on September weekends, an annual Halloween parade and sports fields that are constantly in use for football, soccer and softball games.

title: 'The Price of Terror'
description: It happened on the darkest day of the year, December 21, 1988: a moonless, dank winter night in the town of Lockerbie, in southern Scotland. Overhead, a little more than a half hour into its flight from London to New York, a Boeing 747 had just leveled off at 31,000 feet, making a steady 500 miles an hour against a quartering wind from the west. The airplane carried 243 passengers, most of them Americans flying home for the holidays, and a crew of 16.

title: Political Briefing; Michigan to Curb Gifts From Outside PAC's
description: Emily's List, a national organization that supports candidates who are women and favor abortion rights, played a major role in last year's Senate race in Michigan. It raised more than $1 million for Debbie Stabenow, the Democrat who unseated the Republican incumbent, Spencer Abraham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, EVAN S.
description: GILBERT-Evan S. December 21, 2001, age 40. Beloved son of Thomas and the late Rosann Gilbert. Loving brother of Clifford Gilbert. Devoted stepson of Marjorie Gilbert and stepbrother of Wendy Tayer, William Gorlin and Douglas Gorlin. He was President of the golf division of Gilbert Hosiery. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Evan was considered to be one of the greatest salesmen in the industry. For funeral information call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500.

title: EXPLOSIVE FEARED
description: An American Airlines flight from Paris to Miami made an emergency landing in Boston today after a man on board tried to ignite what were believed to be explosives hidden in his shoes, airport officials said.

title: BackTalk; Life in the Santa Claus Zone: Who Has Been Naughty or Nice?
description: For your seasonal picks -- especially of the naughty -- there have been some sports standouts this year. Even people who boast about cheating the I.R.S. have expressed outrage at a respected college football coach pumping his rsum and a Little League pitching ace lying about his age. I would include a noted filmmaker who shaved points on an icon's life. Is nothing sacred anymore?

title: FILM: The Year in Film: The Critics' Choices; Spielberg's Pathos
description: 'A.I.' -- Steven Spielberg's science fiction fairy tale is not only the best movie of the year but also the most misunderstood. Critics who scoffed at its supposed sentimentality ignored its dark pathos and unsettling ambiguities. No film in recent memory has put the technological resources of the medium to such ravishing and humane use. ''A.I.'' peers 2,000 years into the future; it should not have to wait nearly so long to be recognized as the masterpiece it is.

title: Camby Gives Back As He Gets Away
description: Marcus Camby stepped from a cold and windy curb in Harlem on Friday afternoon and into a climate-controlled motor coach. No one asked him about the state of the Knicks, his health or why in the world he could not tip in a gimme follow shot in the final seconds against Memphis on Thursday night.

title: A Crisis Unlikely to Be Contagious
description: Argentina's fiscal and financial crisis has resulted in a run on its banks, political turmoil, hunger and even death. A default on the public debt or a devaluation of the peso would cause still more pain for Argentines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANNING, THOMAS EDWARDS
description: WANNING - Thomas Edwards. Died December 20, 2001, at Lenox Hill Hospital. Born February 18, 1918, in Shelton, CT. Reader and denizen of the old Cedar Bar. Mourned by his five nieces and nephews, his faithful friend Milton Trexler and his longtime caregiver Gloria Nelson. Services Sunday, Dec. 23, 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: The Wright House
description: To the Editor: So Wayne Curtis thinks that by shooting pool for a couple of hours in a Frank Lloyd Wright house (''Sitting Down With Frank Lloyd Wright,'' Dec. 9), he's learned the secret of Wright's genius, that his homes were brilliantly ''designed for living.''

title: Word for Word/A Fire Captain's Eulogy; First In, Last Out: The Unbreakable Links in the Chain of Command
description: THE building housing Engine Company 40 and Ladder Company 35 is on the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 66th Street, and because it is on the West Side, its men managed to get to the World Trade Center disaster sooner than many other units. Of the 13 firefighters who jumped aboard the two rigs that morning, only one survived, Kevin Shea, who was apparently knocked unconscious during the collapse of one of the towers and literally blown out of the building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAAP, DICK
description: SCHAAP-Dick. Journalist and sportscaster died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He is survived by his wife Trish, his six children Renee, Michelle, Jeremy, Joanna, Kari and David and five grandchildren. Although remembered by the public for his journalism and broadcast career, his family will remember and cherish his love for his wonderful wife Trish, his family, endless friends and love of life and all it offered him. He flashed before our eyes and he will be missed. A private family service is planned for Sunday morning, December 23, at Riverside Chapel in Manhattan. A memorial service will be held in January at a time to be announced. In lieu of flowers and in honor of Dick's dedication to the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation, Gilda's Club, ALS and the Hank Greenberg Foundation, the family asks that donations be sent to any one of these organizations.

title: Illegal and, Sometimes, Unpaid
description: AS an illegal immigrant living in Ossining, Jose Loja, an Ecuadorean, stood every day at a street corner, trying to catch the eye of passing contractors. Like fellow day laborers, he found that seven days of waiting usually yielded two days of work.

title: Greetings Without Fear
description: Fears about anthrax in the mail apparently have not hurt holiday card sales at Hallmark Cards, the nation's largest greeting card company. Hallmark, based in Kansas City, Mo., said last week that sales were up 2 to 4 percent since Thanksgiving, compared with the corresponding period last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAINE, MARILYN
description: CAINE-Marilyn, on December 17, 2001. Widow of Max. Survived by her daughter Cathy and many loved ones.

title: The Corporate Concerns of Fund Managers
description: Mutual fund managers and other big investors are worried that corporate boards may not be acting in the best interests of shareholders, according to a survey conducted last week.

title: The Cult
description: In Northern California this September, wine lovers and merchants were speaking secretively and longingly about a new wine -- said to be sublime but impossible to find in stores -- called Merus Cabernet Sauvignon. Some described Merus as ''the next cult wine.'' Cult wines, I knew, were serious things, highly sought after beverages of unquestionable quality and rarity. So, hoping to see a state-of-the-art wine production facility, I drove out to Napa to find this Merus vineyards.

title: CHARTER SCHOOL CLOSING
description: The state Department of Education last week ordered the closing of one the 17 charter schools founded in the state in 1998, the second year in which charter schools were approved, and putting three others on probation. The contract for the Greater Trenton Area Academic and Technology Charter School will not be renewed after this school year. The state cited ''weak'' student achievement. The Granville Charter School in Trenton, the state's largest charter school with 1,400 students operated by Edison Schools Project, the nation's largest for-profit school management firm, was placed on probation as were the International Charter School of Trenton and the Englewood on the Palisades Charter School. The action came as part of a regular review of charter schools conducted during their fourth year. Karen DeMasters

title: Philadelphia's Wilson Goode Casts an Eye to the Shore
description: While Miss America may be on the next bus out of Atlantic City, W. Wilson Goode -- Philadelphia's former Democratic mayor -- is apparently thinking about moving in.

title: A Shy Ramirez Tries to Find His Comfort Zone
description: The first priority of the new Boston Red Sox owners should be a campaign. Call it ''Make Manny Mine.''

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DURING a week when you can watch four versions of ''A Christmas Carol,'' three different films with the title ''I'll Be Home for Christmas,'' ''Miracle on 34th Street'' (original and remake), a total of at least 18 movies with the word Christmas or Santa in the title, not to mention ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' it would be easy to miss THE BELLS OF ST MARY'S (1945). Bing Crosby stars as the new priest in charge of a financially struggling Roman Catholic school, and Ingrid Bergman is the sister superior, who believes that if she prays hard enough the corporate mogul next door (Henry Travers, better known as Clarence the angel) will donate his brand-new building. Bergman's boxing-lessons scene is as winning as ever. So is the children's Nativity pageant, which ends with a rendition of ''Happy Birthday'' to Baby Jesus. Leo McCarey directed - Tuesday at 10:15 p.m. on TCM.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Celebration in Stamford

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGER, LEONORE Y.
description: NAGER-Leonore Y. December 21. Devoted daughter, loving sister, adored aunt, dedicated volunteer, vivacious dancer. Loved by all who met her.

title: Imagine; For Immigrants, a Colder World
description: On Sept. 6, President Vicente Fox of Mexico urged a rare joint meeting of Congress to grant legal status to millions of his countrymen, saying they brought cultural and economic benefits to the United States. President Bush expressed support for Mr. Fox's proposals.

title: Precautionary Principle
description: The precautionary principle is hardly a novel concept in this country. Activists have been working for years toward better-safe-than-sorry policies despite significant opposition from industry. Anti-tobacco activists undertook the cause long before we had proof of the biochemical process that turns smoke into lung cancer. The same precaution needs to be taken in every area of public health, because waiting for absolute scientific proof is killing us.

title: Investing; It's Not What They Know, but Whom
description: DAVID BEARD, a hedge fund manager, contemplated an investment in coal earlier this year, thinking that its price was about to spike.

title: A Vote for Golfing And Enjoying Nature
description: Yes, Mr. Geller, golfing is a way of enjoying nature; and more important, awakening an appreciation of nature's pleasure and precariousness (Soapbox, Dec. 9.).

title: Imagine; Privacy Gives Way to Security
description: Last week the Center for Democracy and Technology unveiled an ambitious Web site (www.consumerprivacyguide.org) to help people protect their privacy online. The site probably would have gotten much more attention if it had appeared, say, last June. That was when a polling firm, Public Opinion Strategies, found that 67 percent of those surveyed claimed that privacy was their most important issue, ahead of fighting crime (55 percent) and preventing nuclear attack by building a missile shield (22 percent).

title: MUSIC: The Year in Classical Music: The Critics' Choices; A New 'Falstaff'; Earl Kim's Genius
description: VERDI: 'FALSTAFF' -- Bryn Terfel, Thomas Hampson; Berlin Philharmonic, conducted by Claudio Abbado (Deutsche Grammophon; two CD's). Though there are several classic recordings of Verdi's miraculous final opera, this new one takes its place among the best. Mr. Abbado elicits a bustling and transparent performance, and Mr. Terfel owns the title role. The entire cast is superb, especially Dorothea Rschmann as Nanetta and Mr. Hampson as Ford.

title: In Kandahar, a Top School Reopens, and Girls Are Welcome
description: Two weeks after the Taliban's defeat, this city reached a milestone today as its top school reopened -- this time for girls as well as boys, and with no stern mullahs to dictate what is taught.

title: CRIME
description: The game's afoot in Thomas Perry's dazzling new thriller, PURSUIT (Random House, $24.95) -- and the contest isn't checkers. The key players in Perry's deadly sport are James Varney, a sociopathic hit man whose handiwork has left 13 people dead in a Louisville, Ky., restaurant, and Roy Prescott, the professional manhunter hired to track him down by the father of one of the victims. The odds seem to favor Varney, who is young, strong, disciplined and fearless. Lacking a conscience to slow him down, he is a finely tooled killing machine, ''a superior being'' who isn't quite human. But the odds even out when Prescott makes his moves. Like one of those scary action figures beloved of 12-year-old boys, he's ''a man who would not give up, could not call for reinforcements and would not stop coming.'' It's a perfect match.

title: A Fiery Chief Takes a Leap Into the Blaze At Lazard
description: BRUCE WASSERSTEIN, the big, brash Wall Street deal maker, is used to being in charge. So he has wasted little time moving to imprint his style on Lazard, the famously private investment bank beset by chronic infighting and defections, which he will officially start running on Jan. 1.

title: PEOPLE-SMUGGLING CASE
description: Federal officials in Chattanooga, Tenn., charged Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest beef and poultry processor, and six employees, with conspiring to smuggle hundreds of people from Mexico and Central America to work at more than a dozen plants. Tyson, the Arkansas-based company that dominates the supermarket meatcase and supplies fast food restaurants like McDonald's and Burger King, denied the accusations, blaming a handful of Tyson managers for violating company policy. David Barboza

title: It Will Be Difficult, but the League Must Now Replace George Young
description: George Young, the cherished former vice president for football operations, had one of the toughest jobs in the league. He dealt with two areas in the National Football League that often cause the most consternation: on-field rules and officiating. There are few subjects in the sport that elicit more emotional responses. But Young, who died on Dec. 8, always handled the toughest issues with great professionalism and skill.

title: How TV Tells Us What Went Before
description: UNLIKE other art forms, television has a vast number of viewers who don't start at the beginning. Theatergoers are expected to be in their seats when the curtain rises, and movie audiences rarely miss even the previews, much less the opening credits. But we television watchers are a more feckless bunch. We hear repeatedly about a new show from our friends (or our newspapers) before deciding that it would be a good idea to start watching it. Or we have a job that keeps us busy on Wednesday nights for a few months, so we only belatedly discover that evening's programs. Or we go on vacation to a television-less spot. . . . There could be any number of reasons we might miss the scene-setting episodes of a show.

title: The World; As the Battlefield Changes, So Does the War Itself
description: NO one knew last week whether Osama bin Laden had moved to Pakistan; he hadn't sent out change-of-address cards. But the war certainly began to shift there -- to a country where the terrain is more hospitable than Tora Bora, but the politics are a lot less forgiving for Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARMEL, LEE, MRS.
description: CARMEL-Lee, Mrs. 97. Of Summit, New Jersey. Formerly of Miami Beach, FL. Passed away Dec. 11, 2001. Beloved mother of Gilda Carmel Spielberg of Summit, NJ and the late Milton. Cherished grandmother of four, adored great grandmother of three.

title: FLOUNDER QUOTAS
description: Recreational anglers face increased restrictions on flounder fishing next year because they greatly exceeded this year's quota. Coastal quotas set by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission and the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council allowed about 1.6 million pounds of summer flounder caught recreationally, but regulators estimate that more than two million pounds were caught in 2001. State regulators now must adopt a plan -- limiting numbers or size of fish, for instance -- that cuts the 2002 summer catch by nearly 16 percent. John Holl

title: Henry Miller Jr.: Gentle Procrastinator
description: With one exception, Henry Miller Jr., 51, made his way through life slowly, meticulously. He took maddeningly long to finish anything  woodworking, roofs, stories. His Massapequa, N.Y., garage was a testament to the potential of broken objects, the dream of a thousand somedays when he would get around to fixing them. (Enduring mystery: just how old was that slice of pie found under the scuba gear and fishing tackle?)

title: Style Beside Sorrow
description: I went downtown to the New York Epicenter on Friday evening.

title: Counsel for Lawyers
description: Alexander Star replies:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
Top-Flight Preparations in Historic Spot
description: SOUTHERN Suffolk's newest culinary star is also one of its oldest. The Bayport House, then called the Fiat Inn Hotel, opened in 1869. During its 132-year history, the landmark building has been a stagecoach stop, waiting room for the train, speakeasy and restaurant. The food has roamed from American to German to Italian. Today, everything is new at this historic spot: owners, chef, staff, food and ambience.

title: Sports of The Times; The Mets Adopt a Firehouse Near Them
description: OUTSIDE the redbrick firehouse of Squad 288 and Hazmat 1 in Maspeth, Queens, you can look across the Long Island Expressway to the Manhattan skyline. And as firefighters assembled there for roll call that warm September morning, Kevin Smith saw a burst of flame high in the north tower of the World Trade Center.

title: A Last Chance to Beat Eurailpass Price Rise
description: Travelers planning a train trip in Europe next year can save money by buying a Eurailpass before Dec. 31. Rail Europe, the largest distributor of European rail products in North America, has announced that prices will increase between 3 and 5.5 percent next year, but a pass bought at current prices will be usable for six months.

title: CATHEDRAL BURNS
description: A fire, apparently caused by faulty wiring connected to computers, ripped through the gift shop at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, the world's largest Gothic cathedral, in Upper Manhattan. Two rare 17th century Italian tapestries, part of a set of 12 given to the cathedral more than a century ago, were also severely damaged. The cathedral's core was not badly damaged, and a round-the-clock cleanup effort by clergy and staff was clearing the way for Christmas Eve services.

title: Imagine; The Former Root of All Evil
description: The case didn't change, but the politics surrounding it did.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about an East Farmingdale filling station operated by BJ's, a discount warehouse outlet, reversed two prices. On Dec. 12, customers with BJ's membership cards were paying $1.259 a gallon for premium gasoline, and nonmembers were paying $1.199 for regular.

title: Life in line: four snapshots; Denver International Airport
description: Several correspondents for The New York Times were asked about their experiences with airport security in the United States this fall. Here are their responses:

title: The World; Hussein and bin Laden: How Opposites Attract
description: AS the United States ponders whether to expand the war on terrorism to Iraq, various officials and ex-officials have tried to connect the dots between Osama bin Laden and Saddam Hussein. Administration officials debate the credibility of claims by Czech officials of a meeting in Prague between an Iraqi intelligence officer and Mr. bin Laden's leading suicide operative in the Sept. 11 attacks. R. James Woolsey, the former director of central intelligence, has tried to link Mr. Hussein to the anthrax attacks in America.

title: FILM: The Year in Film: The Critics' Choices; Dizzying 'Love'
description: 'IN THE MOOD FOR LOVE' -- Wong Kar-wai's bewitching melodrama on the nature of romance as seen through the eyes of a man and woman being cheated on by their respective spouses; it's as dizzyingly romantic, and as unsettling, as the aftermath of a first kiss. A meditation on the intensity of heartbreak, woven by a director whose maturity has evolved at an astonishing rate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCO, MURIEL
description: FRANCO-Muriel. Passed on December 20, 2001, at age 89. Adored and loving mother of Elaine Krieger. She was a devoted relative, friend and media colleague. Mother, you will be greatly missed, but your humor, integrity, generosity, guidance and your indomitable spirit will always remain in the hearts of all those whose lives you touched. The family will receive visitors at home December 27-29; 3-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research Foundation, 1 Intrepid Square, West 46th St. and 12th Ave., NY, NY 10036.

title: McCloy Exhibition in Norwich
description: William Ashby McCloy, an artist and educator, left a prodigious legacy of more than 2,500 prints, drawings, pastels, paintings, collages and sculptures.

title: A Governor In Search Of a Policy For Old Cities
description: IN his successful run for governor, James G. McGreevey piled up impressive majorities in most of the state's urban areas. He was such a regular fixture it seemed -- even when not campaigning at black churches in poor urban communities -- that aides joked he was his own advance man. They marveled how at times he even recalled birthdays and anniversaries.

title: Imagine; Headlines From the Cutting Room Floor
description: THE world did not stop on Sept. 11; it only seemed that way. Many people, riveted by the extraordinary, paid little attention to anything else.

title: Gene Experiment Comes Close to Crossing Ethicists' Line
description: In the experimental field of gene therapy, scientists have worked carefully to avoid the momentous step of making a genetic alteration that could be passed along to future generations. But now it appears that one experiment may inadvertently have come close to breaking that barrier.

title: Sex Web Spun Worldwide Traps Children
description: British detectives play cat-and-mouse with pedophiles who prey online, while, more out in the open, gangs lure young girls from Burmese villages to Bangkok bordellos.

title: Mister & Mistletoe
description: Matthew Broderick & Sarah Jessica Parker actors: On marriage: 'I believe in being married only once.' -- Sarah Jessica

title: Imagine; Continental Drift
description: Quietly, the European Union is moving toward an enlargement that will alter the nature of the continent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGOWAN, STEPHEN CHARLES
description: MAGOWAN-Stephen Charles. On December 20, 2001, from complications of kidney cancer. Born in New York City on May 7, 1944, the fourth son of Robert Anderson Magowan and Doris Merrill Magowan. Educated at St. Bernard's School, St. Mark's School and Yale. Playwright, actor, pianist, Stephen Magowan was gifted with a unique sense of humor, personal fortitude, and an abundant capacity for enduring friendship. He is survived by his brothers Robin, Merrill, Peter and Mark, and his friend Antonio Jorge da Silva. Memorial contributions may be made to the Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th St, NY, NY 10021, attn: Dr. John Wang.

title: Habitats/Manhattan; New Hampshire Teacher Decides to Seize the Day
description: WHEN Gene Boccialetti talks about his life in New Hampshire, it sounds idyllic. He was a professor at the University of New Hampshire, teaching management development and leadership. He lived in a big house on the coast, and in his free time worked as a ski instructor.

title: 3 Cheers For The Arts
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: January 6, 2002, Sunday A picture caption in the Evening Hours column on Dec. 23 about the opening of the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia misstated the surname of the woman shown with Joan Spain. She is Gerry Sills, not Seiller.

title: Brandywine Valley
description: If ever there was a Christmas season that called for tradition, even nostalgia, this is it. The Nativity has been celebrated for nearly four centuries in the gentle countryside of the Brandywine Valley, extending from Chester County, Pa., to Wilmington, Del. Quakers settled in the valley well before the American Revolution; Moravians set down a record of the first known American Christmas tree nearby in Bethlehem, Pa. The Dupont family, arrivals from France, left remarkable houses and gardens as their public legacy.

title: Distinctively American
description: 'THE ROYAL TENENBAUMS' -- At a time when Hollywood movies seem to be nothing but self-conscious recyclings of ancient comic-book clichs, Wes Anderson walks in with a bursting bagful of ideas, presented as the story of an eccentric New York family of geniuses. With reference points from Thurber to Faulkner, it represents the American idiom at its finest and most distinctive.

title: Amy Chang, Peter Cureton
description: Amy Park Chang, a daughter of Yusoon Park Chang and Dr. Myung Yong Chang of Dunwoody, Ga., was married yesterday to Peter Stewart Cureton, a son of Lana and Stewart Cureton Jr. of Houston. The Rev. Anthony Hinchliff, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

title: A Go-It-Alone Democrat Who's Seeking Company
description: Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, cast the only vote in the Senate against the Bush administration's antiterrorism legislation this fall, deploring its effects on civil liberties and chiding his Democratic colleagues for pushing it through.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Jeep Liberty; A Chip Off the Old Rock Crawler
description: IT was one of those one-shack crossing points on the Quebec-New York border, and the lonely agent took a long time inspecting the Jeep Liberty I was driving, walking around and peering here and there until I became nervous. Finally, he ambled up to the window. ''I've had two Cherokees,'' he said. ''And I'm wondering whether to get one of these next.''

title: Thriving on a World in Crisis; Life at the Woodrow Wilson School, a Training Ground for Policy Wonks, After Sept. 11
description: LIKE a ghost, a stark, white reminder of the fallen World Trade Center stands over a corner of Princeton University.

title: F.B.I. Tests Find Explosive in Shoes of Jet Passenger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Justice Department announced today that laboratory tests confirmed that explosives packed with wires had been hidden in the sneakers of a 28-year-old man who was violently subdued by passengers and flight attendants aboard an American Airlines jet over the Atlantic.

title: Sports of The Times; Time for Baseball to Get Its Story Straight
description: IT has just become even harder for baseball to whimper its sad tales of poverty, what with the Boston Red Sox valued at $700 million during the current sale of the franchise.

title: OPINION; Bearing the Weight of History
description: AT a time when Long Islanders are about to observe the holidays by consuming several billion calories, one is compelled to wonder how the course of local history could have been changed by certain foods and to consider alternative scenarios that allow us to ask, ''What if?''

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: On Desk, But Not On Books
description: SINCE his election victory last month, Governor-elect James E. McGreevey has implored lawmakers to avoid deepening the state's deficit, asking them to stall any legislation carrying an appropriation. But that hasn't stopped them from trying to spend the state's money.

title: TELEVISION/RADIO: The Year in Television: The Critics' Choices; History, From Jazz to Britain to Chickens
description: ATTACK AND AFTERMATH -- Sept. 11 brought new vigor and purpose to a medium that is too often mired in trivia. Once again, television became a unifying force in a tragic time, bringing audiences information and helping them grieve. Over time, the nonstop news inevitably veered toward hysteria and jingoism, but much of the instantaneous coverage was remarkable in its intelligence and sensitivity.

title: Philadelphia Chief's Path Runs From Bronx Beat to Corporate Suite
description: For a man who just nailed down a new job, as chief executive of a private New York security firm, with a financial package beyond a police officer's wildest dreams -- double his $140,000-a-year salary, plus a reported six-figure bonus and a stake in the company -- Commissioner John F. Timoney does not sound very excited.

title: Special Delivery
description: HE is tall, dark and handsome and his eyes are locked with mine. His back is to the room so other distractions -- a woman walking by, the clink of a wine bottle touching the rim of a glass -- fade away. He leans toward me ever so slightly, his dark eyes only glancing at my companions' before returning to mine, and begins to talk. He speaks passionately, commandingly, with pauses for drama, his voice rising and falling.

title: Botswana Weighs Bill to Place Tighter Control on Journalists
description: Broadening its efforts to clamp down on the news media, Botswana's government has proposed legislation that would allow the authorities to determine which journalists and newspapers can operate in the country and permit the police to seize any publications deemed offensive.

title: Brooklyn, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Stretching Out in Waikiki
description: ON cold, gray days, I sometimes daydream about the Super Pool. As I stare out my window, I see myself sliding peacefully through clear water, tinted blue from its painted floor and surrounding brilliantly colored tiles, as the white-hot sun glints through palm trees, scarlet and coral hibiscus, and flowering birds of paradise. Few others ever seem to swim in this free-form 10,000-square-foot pool at the Hilton Hawaiian Village on Waikiki Beach. The giant pool is edged with what seems like an acre of empty recliners, covered mainly by large green towels staking obscure absentee claims. By midafternoon, perhaps 30 people in tropical-print shorts or bikinis are lounging poolside. They read paperbacks with gaudy covers and sip drinks of dark, fruity liquids crowned by little paper umbrellas, but they seldom go into the water. Savoring the pool all to myself, I just swim.

title: Suffolk's Open Spaces Still Worthy of Attention
description: Long Islanders were scandalized by the revelation that the Suffolk County real estate director, Allan Grecco, had helped a business associate, Robert Toussie, to get from the county nearly twice what earlier appraisals suggested the environmentally sensitive Chandler Property in Mount Sinai was worth. Mr. Grecco resigned under fire and taxpayers were outraged [''What Next for Suffolk Land Purchases?'' Dec. 16].

title: Psst! You Can Still Get Your Presents Here
description: In the final Christmas stretch, chronic procrastinators can still buy a reprieve: the secret is in store shipping policies. Here are 10 quick and easy presents, tailor-made for the 11th hour. New for the holiday season, all are guaranteed to be in stock and at the ready for overnight or messenger delivery until the close of business on Dec. 24 (as an inducement, the Scholastic Store is offering free messenger service anywhere in Manhattan for purchases of $100 or more). Last-minute shopping doesn't always have to yield second-rate purchases. Didn't the three wise men pick up their gold, frankincense and myrrh on the way to a Christmas celebration?

title: Mister & Mistletoe
description: First they tell. Then they kiss. A holiday album.

title: Always Grounded
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Monastery Reopens as Housing Complex for Elderly
description: FROM some angles, the four-story red-brick monastery, part of its nine-acre grounds enclosed by a wall, looks much the same as it did when the building was constructed in 1885.

title: Middle-Aged and Not Too Far Off Broadway
description: IN September, the newspaper announcement appeared: ''The Fantasticks,'' at the Sullivan Street Playhouse in Greenwich Village, would close in January, after a run of over 42 years. Lore Noto, the show's producer, said of the production's fans, ''Next time, they may have to go to Kansas.''

title: FRONT LINES
description: MILITARY CAMPAIGN -- There was a price for the reliance on Afghan opposition forces on the ground, and the United States has begun paying it. Afghan commanders considered the war over when they captured the mountainous territory of Tora Bora, while American and allied forces prepared to send a large force to search its caves themselves for Al Qaeda leaders, especially Osama bin Laden. Many fighters have already escaped into Pakistan. Phase 2 in the war on terror, Page 3.

title: Gazeteer
description: 3-bedroom, 1-bath Victorian at 54 East Main Street, $165,000.

title: Barry Simowitz: Of Cats and Cashmere
description: Not every cat is presented with its own futon. But then, not every cat owner is as devoted as Barry Simowitz was to Wanda June, the brown- and-white beauty with whom he shared the last five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIES, KITTY C.
description: MARGULIES-Kitty C., 93, in NYC on November 4. Beloved mother of Susan Sheehan, mother-in-law of Neil, grandmother of Maria and Catherine. Also survived by other cherished relatives. Please raise a glass to a lady of character and style who knew how to have a good time. We'll miss you, Mums.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: F.Y.I.
description: Spreading Santa Around

title: Past and Present Help a Police Commissioner Establish a New Brain Trust
description: As he settles on a new team to lead the Police Department, the incoming commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, is cobbling together a cadre of supervisors that includes trusted aides from his former tenure as commissioner and current chiefs who have performed well in executive roles.

title: As Democracies Spread, Islamic World Hesitates
description: While more than three-quarters of 145 non-Muslim nations around the world are now democracies, most countries with an Islamic majority continue to defy the trend, according to a survey published last week by Freedom House in New York.

title: A. Todd Rancke: A Community Fixture
description: When A. Todd Rancke knocked you down, you did not want to get back up, because you were too busy laughing. Mr. Rancke, a managing director at Sandler O'Neill, had a teasing sense of humor that played on people's flaws but did not generate any ill will, said his sister, Cindy Bienemann. "He could crack on you in a way without making you feel bad," she said.

title: ACTIVISTS CHARGED
description: Two San Francisco AIDS activists were charged with harassing, stalking and threatening nearly a dozen city health officials, researchers and reporters. David R. Pasquerelli and Michael A. Petrelis denounced their targets by phone for disseminating data showing a rapid rise in sexually transmitted diseases among gay men. Their lawyers defend the calls as simply offensive, not dangerous. Greg Winter

title: The League's No. 4 Pass Defense to Challenge Manning
description: Jets cornerback Aaron Glenn threw an arm around the defensive coordinator, Ted Cottrell, as free safety Damien Robinson leaned in with a smile at Thursday's practice, but this was no heartwarming scene for Cottrell.

title: 'Bloodied But Unbowed'
description: THESE days, Joe Clark walks with a slight limp. Still, at age 62, Mr. Clark slows his brisk pace only when he has to linger at every doorway of the Essex County Juvenile Detention Center while the guards trigger the locks that allow him to walk between hallways and cells.

title: Optimists Aside, He Still Sees a 98-Pound Rebound
description: WITH the broad stock market averages up almost 20 percent from their September lows, it is clear that investors not only believe the recession is ending almost as soon as it began, they also think the recovery will wow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, SAMUEL
description: MEYERS-Samuel. Died peacefully on December 15, 2001, at the age of 83. A fearless trade union organizer, a skillful union president, committed to the struggle for economic and racial justice. For 37 years, as president of UAW Local 259, he championed progressive social unionism, not only gaining decent wages, working conditions and benefits for members, but also supporting progressive causes in the communities where members live. He accomplished at his death what he practiced in life-preserving dignity, promoting unity and loving-kindness. Sam is survived by Carolyn Meyers, the love of his life and wife of 60 years; sons, Matthew and Daniel; daughter-in-law, Joan Max Reinmuth, five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A spring memorial is planned. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be sent to the Sam Meyers Scholarship Fund, C/O Local 259 UAW, 113 University Place, NYC 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMOSE, CELIA
description: SAMOSE-Celia. December 23, 1946. In loving and cherished memory. Grandchildren

title: A Mr. Fix-It in Brooklyn, A Dedicated Traveler, A Model of Self-Discipline
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Private Sector; An Offering, With Road Show
description: Michael Flatley, the Lord of the Dance, the man with Feet of Flames, clicking heels and oily bare chest, may take his Irish dance spectaculars to the stock market in London next year. Mr. Flatley's company, Unicorn Entertainment, wants to raise 100 million, or about $145 million, through a public offering, The Independent of London reported. Mr. Flatley, 43, could not be reached for comment. But analysts expressed skepticism about what kind of expansion he might have in mind. About 300 million people have seen Mr. Flatley's troupes since he split from the Riverdance group in 1995. Brian Lavery

title: A Bigger Ice Hotel Takes Shape in Quebec
description: Quebec's Ice Hotel is getting ready to open for a second year -- in a new location and much bigger, with a spa, a wedding chapel, a driving range and a skating rink.

title: December 16-22
description: CONGRESSIONAL ROUNDUP

title: Private Sector; A Bond Man's Eye View, From Behind the Camera
description: James A. Lebenthal spent 38 years in the family business, Lebenthal & Company, selling tax-free municipal bonds. Now that he has passed the boss's seat to his daughter, Alexandra, Mr. Lebenthal, 73, is doing what he did as a young man: making films. ''For most of my career I was in a state of denial,'' he said in an interview last week. ''My ambition has been on ice.''

title: 'Christ'
description: The Messiah, Ironically

title: A Surge in Controversy for Power Proposal
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY may be the engine of Connecticut's economic growth, but a few cities and towns in this critical corridor are challenging Connecticut Light and Power Company's current proposal to provide it with more power.

title: A Jolt of Energy for the Royal Ballet
description: ROSS STRETTON had been in his new post as director of the Royal Ballet for little more than a month this fall when his first production, Rudolf Nureyev's ''Don Quixote,'' brought forth dark warnings from British dance critics that retro was the shape of things to come. Then, lo, his next production, an even older work, John Cranko's ''Onegin,'' turned up trumps, applauded by public and critics alike, and Mr. Stretton's bruised image was miraculously repaired. But for how long?

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 23, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Catherine Simon, Craig Giventer
description: Catherine Anne Simon and Craig Mitchell Giventer were married last evening by Rabbi Max A. Lipschitz at the Four Seasons Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Rise of the Holly in North America
description: ''DECK the halls with boughs of holly,'' the old yuletide song goes. Down through the ages civilizations as diverse as the Roman, Druid and American -- from colonists to today -- have done just that to color festivities during dark December days.

title: Ideas & Trends; Armageddon Again: Fear in the 50's and Now
description: ALTHOUGH some nervous sorts may be whiling away the Yule hours in a bunker, most Americans are still exhibiting ambivalence over how much daily life should be subsumed by threat. Nonetheless, just as in the cold war, when Americans flirted with fallout shelters as a modern and patriotic alternative to nuclear obliteration, so the threat of terrorism has unleashed contradictory -- and in some cases wacky -- cultural reflexes.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: A Bavarian in Texas: Tales of the South
description: To the Editor:

title: The Show Must Go On, Just Not This Year
description: For those waiting for the lights to go up at the Crossroads Theater, the wait just got longer.

title: Setting the Tone (Pink) For Antiques Business
description: JOHN BRUNO opened his front door with a plastic pink flamingo tucked under each arm. He had already planted a dozen of the birds around his Northport garden and he could not wait for the new ones to join his flock.

title: Holiday on Tuesday -- Christmas
description: NEW YORK

title: Putting His Nightclub Experience to Good Use
description: NED DOUGHERTY'S account of his fast-track life as a Hamptons nightclub owner, punctuated by his near-death experiences and subsequent apocalyptic visions, was published in March, initially to limited interest. ''Fast Lane to Heaven: Celestial Encounters That Changed My Life'' (Hampton Roads Publishing Company, $21.95) was merely another title in a crowded category of books about faith and spirituality.

title: Dan DeCarlo, Archie Artist and Creator Of Josie and the Pussycats, Is Dead at 82
description: Dan DeCarlo, a top cartoonist for Archie Comics for more than 40 years and a creator of the characters Josie and the Pussycats and Sabrina the teenage witch, died on Tuesday in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 82, and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: The Haunting Mystery Of the Softly Ticking Clock
description: In an 1843 story by Poe, a man was haunted by ''a low, dull, quick sound'' emanating from his floorboards. He finally found the source of it. The story did not have a happy ending.

title: Counting Mines to Save Lives in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cornucopia of Toys May Be Too Much of a Good Thing
description: To the glut of heartfelt gifts that have landed on the city's doorsteps, from blood donations to giant greeting cards, add another example of generosity: toys. At bake sales and in classrooms and fire stations across the country, a trove of stuffed animals and other playthings has been gathered for the children of firefighters, police officers and other emergency workers who died on Sept. 11.

title: MUSIC: The Year in Classical Music: The Critics' Choices; Blues and 60's Rock; Classy, Slick Soul
description: WHITE STRIPES: 'WHITE BLOOD CELLS' -- (Sympathy for the Record Industry). The album of the year is the one I've bought 25 copies of to give away, the one that has received so much wear and tear that it's covered with scratches. Full of loud, raw guitar, passionately caterwauling vocals and heaps of blues, punk and 60's rock, this third album from the Detroit duo the White Stripes earns that honor with the most unschooled-sounding schooled music around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERFNER, JOHN AMDUR
description: DERFNER-John Amdur. Dear son of the late Morton Derfner and Selma Heringman. Stepson of Craig Heringman. Brother of Elizabeth Bass and stepsisters Kay Chernush, Anne Pehrisch, Sue Heringman. Father of Tessa Derfner. Cousin of Robert Golub. Died at home in Lancaster, CA. in December 2001. Services private.

title: Imagine; Stem Cell Redux
description: All summer, the debate over human embryonic stem cell research dominated the news. And on the morning of Sept. 11, the National Academy of Sciences had scheduled a news conference to release a report that, in effect, criticized the strict limits President Bush placed on federal financing for the research. Mr. Bush had restricted he financing to studies of existing colonies, or lines, of stem cells, estimated at about 60. The report said a bigger supply would be needed.

title: Private Sector; Carrying Her Thankful Client's Torch
description: Mario Lemieux survived cancer and won consecutive N.H.L. scoring titles. He carried the Olympic torch in Pittsburgh.

title: Imagine; Raiding the Lockbox
description: Remember the Social Security lockbox?

title: Livingston Sets A National Mark
description: Stacey Livingston, who seems to have no limitations from 400 meters to a mile, proved once again yesterday that she is one of the nation's elite high school runners.

title: CEMETERY SCANDAL
description: A class-action suit in Fort Lauderdale charged the nation's largest funeral company, Service Corporation International, with a pattern of desecrating remains at its five Florida cemeteries -- crushing burial vaults, layering remains, interring people in plots owned by others, digging up bodies to make room for new ones and dumping remains in the nearby woods. The accusations are already leading to calls for federal regulation of the funeral industry. Tamar Lewin

title: A Sparkler From Australia
description: Fans of robust California sparkling wines can find similar pleasures more cheaply in 1999 Seaview brut, a white from Australia that's popular there. This wine, made from pinot noir, muscadelle, chenin blanc and smillon grapes, is nifty for buffets and big parties. It offers a toasty aroma with rich fruit, nut and raisin flavors. Mr. Wright, 1593 Third Avenue (89th Street), Manhattan, asks $8. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: The Capital of Oom-Pah-Pah
description: WHETHER the tuba is in a marching band on the football field or in a brass quintet playing Christmas carols at the mall, chances are it came from the Tuba Exchange in Durham, N.C.

title: Doormen: Gatekeepers, Psychiatrists, Confidants
description: TO a visitor to New York from the unguarded suburbs, they are curiosities: the white gloves, the double-breasted coats trimmed with gold braid, the almost fatherly manner as they open a door and enfold a stroller into a marble lobby. To outsiders, they are gatekeepers, filtering out the unknown or unwelcome. To tenants, they are allies, protectors, keepers of the intimate secrets of habitation.

title: Streetscapes/West 95th Street Between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues; The Block Where Virginia, 8, Asked About Santa
description: IN 1897, the residents of West 95th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues included a police surgeon, Dr. Philip O'Hanlon, his wife, Laura, and their 8-year-old daughter, Virginia. In the summer of that year, Virginia asked a question, and she received a reply printed in The New York Sun. ''Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus,'' the newspaper said.

title: Sending a Smile To the Troops
description: LOOKING to send a message of thanks to American troops overseas? Until Dec. 31, shoppers at all 603 Circuit City stores nationwide can videotape 30-second greetings to be shipped to United States military bases. Those with a family member in the military can tape a personal five-minute message, which will be transferred to a DVD and given to the family to send.

title: Confronting the Zeitgeist When Life Overtakes Art
description: ART imitates life. That's been the working theory, anyway. The artist is supposed to find a way into the realm of the imagination and, there, transmute messy quotidian reality into coherent sublime beauty. From ancients to moderns, the timeline of art was straightforward: Life -- Art.

title: Loss of Jonsson to Concussion Proves a Big Blow to Islanders
description: Islanders Coach Peter Laviolette can find no adjectives grand enough for Kenny Jonsson. Laviolette considers Jonsson the best defenseman on the team, if not in the National Hockey League.

title: Remembering, or Forgetting, A Donor's Name on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a Wonderful Night
description: I was 17 when I moved to New York from Puerto Rico in 1990. I never really knew much about Rockefeller Center. I knew about the tree lighting because we had cable, so you could see it when it was shown on NBC. But I thought Rockefeller Center was a private place where people had to pay lots of money to skate. One night, I decided to take a walk. I didn't know anyone in New York. I was just following people, friendly faces, and I got to Rockefeller Center. I was mesmerized, just watching people skating around. At home, there weren't indoor or outdoor rinks. The next thing you know, I was there for two hours. Then I started going every night, skating sometimes.

title: Counsel for Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sue Afghanistan!
description: THE PRICE OF TERROR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, GOLDY
description: ROSENBERG-Goldy. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our revered former Associate Rabbi, Rabbi Moshe Rosenberg and his entire family upon the loss of their mother and grandmother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: December 16-22; NEXT WEEK
description: Congress is in recess; the president goes to his Texas ranch after Christmas. OPEC decides in Cairo on Friday whether to cut oil production. ''Gosford Park'' opens on Wednesday, ''Ali'' on Tuesday and ''Black Hawk Down'' on Friday.

title: Imagine; Trouble, Still, in the Balkans
description: The Balkans -- the last place the United States went to war -- remain an area of simmering tension, despite slow-moving efforts to get beyond the hatreds and suspicions that helped to tear Yugoslavia apart.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the film ''Black Hawk Down'' included an outdated screenplay credit. The screenplay is credited to Ken Nolan, no longer with Steven Zaillian.

title: India Weighs Force In Pakistan Dispute
description: A senior official said India was seriously considering military action if diplomatic pressure fails to persuade Pakistan to crack down on Pakistan-based groups that India has accused of attacking Parliament on Dec. 13. India has already recalled its envoy in an effort to push its longtime adversary to act.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in this section last Sunday, about winter light in New York, misstated the year in which the city's zoning code began requiring stepped setbacks in buildings, to provide more light. It was 1916, not 1961.

title: Wired, Jobless and Free (for Now)
description: THERE wasn't an empty seat at 71 Irving Coffee & Tea Bar, a cozy below-street-level coffee shop near Gramercy Park. A stream of customers lined up for lattes and bagels. Men with rumpled hair flipped through magazines, and young women in yoga pants and sneakers caught up over coffee, some sitting at tables by the fireplace, others on the benches outside. Half a dozen laptop screens glowed in the dimly lighted room, and cellphones trilled over a Sunday morning soundtrack of twinkly jazz piano.

title: LEAD POISONING
description: More New Jersey children were tested for lead poisoning during fiscal year 2001 and fewer were found with elevated levels of lead in the blood than in the previous year, according to a statewide survey taken for the second year by the state Department of Health and Senior Services. The survey, released last week and covering the year ending June 30, found that 149,233 children under 17 were tested for lead poisoning, an 8.5 percent increase over fiscal 2000. The number of children with lead levels considered to be elevated declined 18 percent to 5,616. However, only about a third of 1- and 2-year-olds were tested, despite a state law requiring all children of those ages to be tested.

title: Helping Hand in Houston
description: File this in the thought-that-counts category.

title: Life on Freedom Street
description: AT 5:15 a.m. on a Monday in early December, 30 men bounded off a bus in Queens Plaza, many of them whooping and cheering. Some cursed the bus or made gestures at it. Clutching translucent plastic bags bulging with their possessions, they looked around, drawing in the surroundings: the vacant, shadowy streets, the Citibank Tower looming on the murky horizon, the aluminum coffee cart glinting under the jaundiced glow of street lamps.

title: Paul R. Hughes: The Ultimate Technophile
description: Paul R. Hughes was a computer guy. "And our house looked like it," said his wife, Donna Hughes. "He put together most of the electronics in our house. He built all our computers from scratch and was in the middle of building another one. He would go to computer shows or visit online auctions to get parts. U.P.S. visited my house quite frequently."

title: Joseph Sisolak: Helping Others to Think
description: When there was a problem in the e-mail system at Marsh & McClennan in the World Trade Center, someone would call Joseph Sisolak at home in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, no matter what the hour. Mr. Sisolak, a 35-year-old senior vice president in charge of the e-mail system, would listen but would not hand out an answer. He would tell the caller to think the problem through, a technique that colleagues said made them better at their jobs.

title: A Fresh Legacy for Bill Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Heal Thyself
description: I'm a physician in New York City. On Sept. 12, an elderly patient, who probably has some degree of organic mental disorder, announced, ''The Americans deserve this; they bombed Hiroshima and Nagasaki.'' I replied, ''Nobody deserves this,'' feeling angry. Still angry a week later, I told him I would no longer be his physician, referring him to another doctor. Was I wrong to give up on him because of his political beliefs? Anonymous, New York

title: Walking Onto a Bare Stage (And Into Scrooge's Skin)
description: WHAT compels actors whose work is customarily an ensemble or collective activity to venture out onto an empty stage and face an audience quite alone, and often with material personal and personally devised? Wouldn't it seem that our profession is insecure and exposed enough?

title: Battle for Majority Leader Heats Up in the Senate
description: The war of the words has already started in the Senate, which for the first time remains evenly split among Democrats and Republicans.

title: Edward Saiya: Minor Fame, Major Fun
description: The Saiya brothers have a place among the countless lesser-known Brooklyn legends. Frank, Art, Mike and Eddie were known as the Fame Brothers of Dayhill Road, based on the first letters of their names.

description: Having glimpsed civil war on Friday, Palestinian factions maintained a truce today that left their fundamental differences unresolved and their supporters' anger still simmering.

title: James Straine: Pleasure From Fishing
description: Last August, the Straine family moved to Oceanport, N.J., so that James Straine, 36, could be near the ocean and the Shrewsbury River. Everywhere you go in Oceanport you can see water, and it was just perfect for his great passion, fishing. He would arrive home from his job as a bond salesman at Cantor Fitzgerald in the World Trade Center, scoop up his son Finn, 3, and off they would go, to fish. "He and Finn were best friends," said Mr. Straine's wife, Trish. Last summer, Finn caught his first one, a little snapper, and naturally, Mr. Straine took a picture.

description: ARGENTINA'S long-running financial crisis has finally become unbearable. Stores are being sacked in eruptions of anger and frustration. People are hungry. Unemployment approaches 20 percent. Recession is turning into depression. And day after day, the endless debate over how to restart the economy comes to dead ends.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 22  Karl Malone came into tonight's game against the Nets terribly frustrated, and Byron Scott on the Nets' sideline was the least of his worries.

Wars may change everything, but how is a mystery that can be unraveled only well after the truce.

description: Few employees can escape the annual performance review. It is a ritual of appraisal of performance and achievement of goals that is approached with dread -- sometimes by the reviewer, too. Now come these reviews of the review process.

title: The Departing Parks Chief Leaves a Legacy of Nicknames
description: Ten thousand is a significant number for Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern. It is approximately when the clicker broke as he was trying to pet his dog, Boomer, enough times to set a world record. And it is the number he has almost reached in the ''Noms de Parc'' -- nicknames -- he doles out to New Yorkers.

A true woman of valor and cherished by all those who knew her, Claire Winkler lead a life devoted to Torah values, Israel and the Jewish community. Heartfelt condolences to the family. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTIER, WILLIAM B
description: CARTIER-William B, of Manhattan, NY, formerly of Dover, Mass. Died December 16 at the age of 32 while skiing in Alta, Utah. Former First Vice President of Prudential Securities. Beloved son of William Lambert Cartier, of Newport, RI, and Marie ''Pooh'' Bannard Lockwood of Dover, Mass. Step-son to Charles C. Lockwood of Dover, Mass. Devoted brother to Thomas Gallup Cartier of Santa Monica, Calif., and Charles Markle Cartier of Boulder, CO. Step-brother to John Lockwood, Laura Lockwood, Dorothy Wagner and Gwen Lockwood. Cherished nephew to David and Gussie Bannard, Barbara and Christopher Haller, John and Suzie Cartier, Fred and Rosalee Cartier and Barbara and Elliot Frederic, and 13 first cousins. Bill will be remembered for his vitality of spirit, strength of character and extraordinary capacity for friendship. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at 2pm, Thursday, December 27th, at The Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue ( E. 74 St), NY. There will be a reception immediately following the service. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in memory of William to Big Brothers, Big Sisters, 223 E. 30th St, NY, NY 10016.

title: Showing an African Nation to Itself
description: WHEN photography came along in the 19th century, it provided a novel means of defining the self. Mathew Brady's ''Gallery of Illustrious Americans,'' published in 1850, was a partial attempt to explore and uncover the character of a still-young country.

Their baubles did more than change the flavor of Brewster's annual tree-lighting festival; they symbolized a growing friendship between this struggling village and New York City's conceptual art community.

title: THE DEAL OF THE YEAR
description: Ending almost a year of wrangling, brinksmanship and high-stakes negotiations, Comcast struck a deal to acquire AT&T's cable television unit. The final price: $47 billion in stock. Comcast was already the nation's No. 3 cable operator. After ingesting AT&T's cable operation, AT&T Comcast will be a behemoth with more than 22 million customers, or roughly one of every five homes in the United States.

title: QUICK BITE/Haddonfield; Popping Corks Without Busting Banks
description: The Moore Brothers Wine Company sits in a low-slung office park just one traffic light from Camden, the state's poorest city. Despite the setting, the brothers make no apologies for their wine elitism. ''If I had to sell Korbel or even Perrier-Jouet in volume every day, I couldn't get up in the morning,'' said Dave Moore, who sold just those types of labels to restaurants before starting Moore Brothers in 1996 with his brother, Greg, a former sommelier at the elite Bec Fin restaurant in Philadelphia. ''I look at us like the farm stand in Glassboro where you get that lumpy tomato that tastes like a tomato should. The other guys sell the three shrink-wrapped things you get in the supermarket.'' Yet not everything on the wooden racks at Moore Brothers will burn a hole in your wallet. Yes, for your New Year's party, you could go for the $90-a-bottle 1990 Ployez-Jacquemart Liesse D'Harbonville. But if you want to spend less, Dave will happily steer you toward one of his favorite sparkling wines, the Clos Baudoin Vouvray Aigle D'or for only $15. ''I have a friend whose New Year's party I go to every year,'' Mr. Moore said. ''He serves this through the evening, then at midnight, he brings out the Perrier-Jouet,'' a Champagne that costs four times what the Vouvray does. Mr. Moore shakes his head at the thought. ''Everyone wants him to go back to this. It tastes better. It is better.'' The store is at a constant 55 degrees, the better for wine storage, though it means sweaters even in summer. Moore Brothers keeps computer files of wines bought for customers, so they can easily order another of that obscure bottle they liked or avoid the one they didn't. And there is a children's play area, to entertain the offspring of the take-your-time-please customers. Robert Strauss

The bill passed in the House hit heavy opposition in the Senate over whether it would allow religious groups to discriminate in their hiring practices. But some Senators are working on salvaging the incentives for charitable giving and block grants to social service programs.

As a performer, I can think of no more opprobrious behavior. History, however, affords us a retrospective view which, on occasion, can transform the fatuous into the farcical. When the perpetrator of act-stealing is animal rather than human, our willingness to smile instead of chide is increased, particularly when the performing repertoire can be antedated by many dog years, indeed.

title: Among the Poor, Sympathy for the Families of Sept. 11
description: A man known as Brother Sanchez approached the men who sat, still in their coats and warm knit hats, at a long cafeteria table at the Help House Love Kitchen, inside the Manhattan Bible Church in Inwood. Very politely, Brother Sanchez, who works as a cook at the soup kitchen, asked for a moment of silence so that he could bless their supper. Part of what he said, in a rapid, almost guttural chant, went like this: ''We pray for the tragedy of the trade center, Lord God, all those families who lost people, Lord God, and the plane crash that hurt so many families, Lord God.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Folk Singer Wins Eviction Case
description: Jack Hardy, the folk singer and songwriter who was threatened with eviction last year when the owners of his rent-stabilized apartment at 178 West Houston Street accused him of using it as a second home, won the civil court battle last week to keep his apartment. Mr. Hardy, 53, was paying $325 a month for the apartment he first rented in 1975. Mr. Hardy is widely considered a leader in the modern folk tradition that emerged in Greenwich Village in the 1960's, and his apartment became popular as a place for music exchange and criticism. Mr. Hardy called the decision ''the best news I've heard all year.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

He immediately declared a default on the country's $132 billion debt, promising to use the money saved to create jobs and fortify social programs.

title: A Season to Help the Neediest
description: Every year the Christmas season is inherently associated with acts of charity. One way or another, nearly every cultural representation of this holiday affirms that the spirit of Christmas lies in the giving we do, whether it's wise men bringing frankincense and myrrh to Bethlehem or the Whos of Whoville in a Christmas Eve frenzy. We give to one another willingly, comfortably, whether or not we expect any return. And each year it occurs to many of us that perhaps the giving we do among ourselves doesn't come close enough to the real character of the day that will dawn tomorrow morning. The search for Christmas has become one of the great modern themes of this holiday, a version of the story of the prodigal son. But the search should always be a short one. Need lies all around us in every imaginable form, and the act of relieving that need is the very doing of Christmas itself.

title: Betrayed by the White House
description: Last month, Congress overwhelmingly approved a provision, added to a spending bill, that would have prevented federal agencies from opposing civil lawsuits by former prisoners of war against Japanese individuals or corporations. The White House succeeded in having the provision struck in a conference committee; the Bush administration feared it might interfere with gathering international support for the war on terrorism. A week later, on the 60th anniversary of the bombing of Pearl Harbor, President Bush and his father paid glowing tribute to the memory of World War II veterans. The president compared the Sept. 11 tragedy to Japan's surprise attack on Dec. 7, 1941, while his father announced that ''duty, honor, country'' still prevail.

title: The Neediest Cases; Support for Foster Mother In a Round-the-Clock Role
description: It is a typical afternoon in the Lewis family's town house in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. Six-year-old Elizabeth sits in her wheelchair, eyes darting back and forth as if she could see. Her arms and legs jerk spastically, clearly not under her control. Her brain is able to hear what people say but not comprehend it.

title: Seahawks Deflate At Wrong Time

He chose not to watch as the Seahawks' defense dug in at the Giants' 4-yard line, needing only to stop an unlikely drive to keep Seattle's playoff hopes alive.

title: Narcotics Officers Kill Man in Harlem
description: Undercover narcotics detectives, trying to arrest a man who had just sold them crack cocaine in Harlem late Saturday night, shot and killed him after he pulled out a gun and fired at them, the police said yesterday.

title: Japan Talks Tough After a Naval Battle
description: Japan's prime minister, a nationalist who has raised the profile of the country's military, called for increased territorial vigilance after the Japanese Coast Guard traded heavy fire with a vessel suspected of being a North Korean spy ship. The ship sank just inside an economic zone claimed by China, and its crew of 15 is believed to have drowned.

description: The soup kitchen at the Church of the Holy Apostles on Ninth Avenue in Chelsea is the largest in New York. And the operators of the kitchen will try to make today, Christmas Eve, a little special for the people in tough circumstances who show up for a meal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, DAVID A.
description: GARDNER-David A. Real estate developer, venture capitalist and philanthropist, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 54. Born in Cleveland, OH, David Gardner received his bachelor's degree from Princeton University in 1969 and an MBA from Harvard University in 1971. He began his career at Celanese Corp. and later moved to Oppenheimer and Co., where he became a Partner in 1978. In 1980, he formed Gardner Capital Corp., which developed commercial and residential properties principally in New York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Maryland. He served as a Board member of a number of public and private companies. Active in community and nonprofit sectors, Mr. Gardner served as Chairman of the Board and Executive Committee of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York City, a nonprofit policy and advisory group on housing issues for 22 years. He was a national Board Member of the Muscular Dystrophy Association for 12 years. He also served for 25 years on the Board of Young Audiences, Inc., bringing the performing arts to three million public school children annually and served from 1973 to 1989 as Treasurer of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies in New York and as a Board Member and Founder of Literacy Volunteers of New York City. He was active in Princeton alumni affairs, serving as Co-Chair of the New York Region for Princeton's 250th Capital Campaign. In 2001 he endowed the David A. Gardner Professorship of Medicine at Columbia University. He is survived by his wife Lynn, his mother Matilda, his sister Cynthia and his brother Daniel. Services Wednesday, December 26, 4 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Gory Details Cheerfully Supplied; Trading Police Forensics For Writer's Life on 'C.S.I.'
description: The writers of the highly successful CBS drama ''C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation'' sat slumped around a table one afternoon this month at a studio in this quiet, mountainous region about an hour's drive north of Los Angeles. Armed with notepads and coffee cups, they threw out ideas as Andrew Lipsitz, a producer, stood at a blackboard and outlined an episode involving the murder of several Buddhist monks in a monastery near Las Vegas, a story that, like most of the show's episodes, came from actual events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAPPEL, JOHN

Dr. Happel held 46 patents. An avid hiker, he was a summer resident of Lake Placid, NY, for over 50 years. Survived by his wife Dorothy Merriam Happel; children Jill, George Syms and Ruth Emilie; sister Ruth Smiley; granddaughter Robin Jane. Memorial service 11 AM, January 12, 2002, Zion Episcopal Church, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Put Cameras in the Cockpit
description: WASHINGTON -- Airline accidents today, like the recent American Airlines crash in Queens, can puzzle safety experts. They struggle for months, even years, often unable to explain fully a flight's problems or how the pilots reacted. Video cameras in the cockpit could help answer such critical questions.

title: Caribbean Hiltons
description: Through Jan. 15 (excluding some blackout dates), all eight Hilton hotels in the Caribbean are cutting rates 42 to 74 percent and including daily breakfast for two, early check-in and late check-out. Also, children under 17 stay free in their parents' room and eat for half price. Rates start at $99 a night in the Hilton Tobago, and go to $207 at the Jalousie Hilton Resort and Spa on St. Lucia. In Kingston, Jamaica, it's $109; in Nassau, the Bahamas, $119. The Hilton Trinidad is $130, and on Margarita Island, $140. There are two choices on Puerto Rico: The Caribe in San Juan for $160 and the Ponce for $145. Information and reservations: (800) 445-8667 or www.hilton.com .

He was overpowered by crew and fellow passengers and was taken into custody. But questions swirled: Who was he? Had he acted alone? Was he part of a terrorist network? And how did he board a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives and no baggage?

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Little Fear Of Anthrax Or The Economy
description: A new Quinnipiac University poll shows that most state residents do not fear being exposed to anthrax, despite the death last month of an Oxford woman from inhalation anthrax, and that they believe the state's economy is outperforming the nation's. More than 70 percent of registered voters polled said they were ''not too worried'' or ''not worried at all'' about being exposed to anthrax in the mail, and 91 percent said they believed the mail was safe, the survey found. More than half said that the economy was good or excellent, and that they expected it to remain so through next year. A total of 1,194 registered voters were polled by telephone between Dec. 10 and Dec. 17. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percentage points. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Coleman Doesn't Start

title: Science at the Smithsonian
description: The fate of three outstanding research centers that are part of the Smithsonian Institution remains uncertain as the Bush administration completes its fiscal year 2003 budget. Under a proposal floated initially by the Office of Management and Budget, the three centers would be removed from the Smithsonian's jurisdiction and transferred to the National Science Foundation, a federal agency that awards grants for scientific research. That possibility has Smithsonian scientists in a tizzy, as well it might. Although Bush administration officials were justifying the move on management grounds, it is not clear that they have thoroughly explored the likely consequences to the research programs or to the Smithsonian itself.

title: Betrayed by the White House
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. -- Last month, Congress overwhelmingly approved a provision, added to a spending bill, that would have prevented federal agencies from opposing civil lawsuits by former prisoners of war against Japanese individuals or corporations. The White House succeeded in having the provision struck in a conference committee; the Bush administration feared it might interfere with gathering international support for the war on terrorism. A week later, on the 60th anniversary of the bombing of Pearl Harbor, President Bush and his father paid glowing tribute to the memory of World War II veterans. The president compared the Sept. 11 tragedy to Japan's surprise attack on Dec. 7, 1941, while his father announced that "duty, honor, country" still prevail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, HERBERT J.
description: McCOOEY-Herbert J. Of Jupiter, FL, Westhampton Beach, NY, and formerly of Manhasset, NY, on December 21, 2001. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on July 6, 1926, he was the son of Herbert and Elizabeth (Larney) McCooey. Grandson of the late John H. McCooey, political leader of Brooklyn for twenty-five years. Graduate of Brooklyn Prep High School and the College of the Holy Cross, Class of 1949. Mr. McCooey served as a signalman in the United States Navy during World War II. He had a long and distinguished career on Wall Street where he was a member and former Governor of the New York Stock Exchange. He was the Executive Vice President of Robb, Peck & McCooey Specialist firm until his retirement in 1984. Mr. McCooey served as a trustee of St. Mary's Parish in Manhasset where he was a driving force and ardent supporter of the CYO program. Knight of Malta as well as a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. Mr. McCooey sat on various Boards including the Long Island Savings Bank, Plandome Country Club, Westhampton Country Club and La Ronde Beach Club. Mr. McCooey is survived by his wife Dolores (nee) McCarthy, brothers John of New York City and Richard of Washington, DC, and predeceased by Robert of Rye, NY. Loving father of Bert Jr. (Lori), Sean (Jane), Bess (Tom), Patrick, Maureen (Carter), Dan (Suzanne) and Dee. Proud grandfather of Bert III, Sara, Matt, Bryan, Kellen, Brendan, Shareen, Cassie, Regan, Julie, Luke, Dolores, Mae, Danny, and Jack and many nieces and nephews. Bert will be remembered for his vitality of spirit, strength of character and extraordinary capacity for family and friends. Family will receive friends at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, on Wednesday from 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM. On Thursday, family will receive friends from 3-6 PM, in St. Mary's Church, 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, immediately followed by a Mass of Christian Burial. Interment private on Friday. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

description: An 18-year-old man returning from a late night in New York City died yesterday when he fell between two cars of a westbound PATH train, officials said. Investigators said the man, identified as Tiago W. A PATH official said Mr. Pinheiro was traveling with three companions. title: Three Signatures Short of Reform
description: In a surprise boost for campaign finance reform, the final hours of Congress's session last week brought the Shays-Meehan soft-money ban a significant step closer to a vote in the House. An overwhelming majority of House members are for the bill. But as a vote on it was about to occur last summer, Speaker Dennis Hastert broke his promise for a fair process and sent the bill into committee, where the signatures of 218 House members are required to get it out. Late last week, four more lawmakers signed the petition. Now only three more are needed to break the bill loose. Wavering lawmakers need to act before Congress returns in late January.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Arrested At Airport
description: A man authorities described as emotionally disturbed was arrested yesterday at La Guardia Airport after shouting at and harassing passengers at a gate, officials said. A spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said there was no indication that the man, Thomas Duffiel, 32, of St. Paul, Minn., was threatening or discussing a terrorist attack. He was waiting to board a Continental Airlines flight, officials said. It took five Port Authority police officers to subdue him, three of whom sustained minor injuries, said the spokesman, Allen Morrison. Mr. Duffiel was charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest, Mr. Morrison said. He said that Mr. Duffiel was intoxicated from a combination of alcohol and antidepressants and was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center for a psychiatric evaluation. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Taiwan: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Taiwan's jobless rate climbed to an 11th straight record in November as companies shed workers and moved production to China to cut costs amid falling sales. Unemployment rose to 5.3 percent from 5.2 percent in October, seasonally adjusted, the government said. That was the highest since the government began compiling figures in 1978. Taiwan's economy contracted 4.2 percent in the third quarter from a year earlier as exports tumbled, falling into its worst slump since the 1970's. Jobs are also dwindling as companies like Chunghwa Picture Tubes, a unit of Tatung, and Ritek move production lines to China to cut costs.

Rhona's fervent love of life, love of people-and we mustn't forget to mention her love of shoppingcombined with her incredible energy for living each day to the fullest to inspire so many. Leslie Popoff of Great Neck, NY said ''Rhona was unique in her ability to see the joy in almost everything life has to offer.''
