After years as a practicing dental hygienist, she joined the insurance industry and organized dentists into provider networks. Prior to Ridgefield, she resided in Great Neck, NY. Rhona died peacefully at home on December 22, 2001, of breast cancer. She is survived by her husband, Dean Meyer; her daughter, Bonnie Stein of Great Neck, NY; her son, Brad Stein of Honolulu, HI; and her sister, Robyn Schwartz of Morganville, NJ. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, HERBERT J.
description: McCOOEY-Herbert J. Of Jupiter, FL, Westhampton Beach, NY, and formerly of Manhasset, NY, on December 21, 2001. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on July 6, 1926, he was the son of Herbert and Elizabeth (Larney) McCooey. Grandson of the late John H. McCooey, political leader of Brooklyn for twenty-five years. Graduate of Brooklyn Prep High School and the College of the Holy Cross, Class of 1949. Mr. McCooey served as a signalman in the United States Navy during World War II. He had a long and distinguished career on Wall Street where he was a member and former Governor of the New York Stock Exchange. He was the Executive Vice President of Robb, Peck & McCooey Specialist firm until his retirement in 1984. Mr. McCooey served as a trustee of St. Mary's Parish in Manhasset where he was a driving force and ardent supporter of the CYO program. Knight of Malta as well as a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. Mr. McCooey sat on various Boards including the Long Island Savings Bank, Plandome Country Club, Westhampton Country Club and La Ronde Beach Club. Mr. McCooey is survived by his wife Dolores (nee) McCarthy, brothers John of New York City and Richard of Washington, DC, and predeceased by Robert of Rye, NY. Loving father of Bert Jr. (Lori), Sean (Jane), Bess (Tom), Patrick, Maureen (Carter), Dan (Suzanne) and Dee. Proud grandfather of Bert III, Sara, Matt, Bryan, Kellen, Brendan, Shareen, Cassie, Regan, Julie, Luke, Dolores, Mae, Danny, and Jack and many nieces and nephews. Bert will be remembered for his vitality of spirit, strength of character and extraordinary capacity for family and friends. Family will receive friends at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, on Wednesday from 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM. On Thursday, family will receive friends from 3-6 PM, in St. Mary's Church, 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, immediately followed by a Mass of Christian Burial. Interment private on Friday. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMER, SIDNEY
description: GOMER-Sidney. Died peacefully in his home in Santa Monica, California at age 85. Predeceased by his beloved wife Rosalyn in 1993. He is survived by sons Gary, and Steven, his grandchildren Sarah and Jesse, as well as sister Dorothy Saks and his brothers Bob and Ed. Funeral services at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY at 10AM Wednesday, December 26.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Zoo Animals Die
description: Several animals at the Staten Island Zoo -- two wallabies, four deer and a peacock -- were found dead yesterday and investigators believe they may have been killed by a dog, the police said. The dead animals were discovered at 8:15 a.m. by the zookeeper, who notified the police, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Next, Pavel From Irkutsk Gives Putin A Mouthful
description: President Vladimir V. Putin did something today that might be deemed remarkable even in a robust democracy like the United States: he spent two and a half hours on national television, taking questions from ordinary Russians.

title: Blacks Who Voted Against Bush Offer Support to Him in Wartime
description: Steven Price, the proprietor of the Wise Choice Barber Shop on Jacksonville's north side, was none too happy with George W. Bush this time last year. In this city's heavily black and Democratic neighborhoods, like the one where Mr. Price wields his trimmer, one of every five votes was thrown out because of confusion over the ballot, and folks here were street-marching mad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, RUTH
description: ALPERT-Ruth. On December 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of Stuart and the late Elliot. Loving motherin-law of Rosalind and Audrey. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Nancy and David. Dear sister of Lillian Borgenicht, Sylvia Luckom and Rosalie Steier.

title: Union Head Objects to Anthrax Vaccine Program
description: The president of the New York region's postal workers union said he objected to the anthrax vaccinations that the federal government would be offering to post office employees in a few days.

title: Engine Maker Cuts 145 Jobs in Milwaukee
description: The Briggs & Stratton Corporation, a leading maker of lawn mower engines, said it had cut 145 jobs in Milwaukee by laying off workers and offering others early retirement, a move intended to save the company $6 million a year.

title: Desperation Sales Fail to Lure Shoppers
description: The holiday shopping season opened the day after Thanksgiving with nervous merchants cutting prices 40 percent. It ended over the final weekend before Christmas with a frenzy of desperation sales with as much as 70 percent off that failed to save the season for most retailers.

title: So Who Is Buried in Midas' Tomb?
description: Refinements of radiocarbon dates appear to rob the monumental tomb at Gordion of its claim to having been the final resting place of the illustrious King Midas, researchers reported last week in the journal Science.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Plan to Let Nations Declare Bankruptcy Gains
description: Argentina's chaotic political and financial collapse has given a strong push to a plan by the International Monetary Fund to allow nations to declare bankruptcy and seek legal protection from their creditors, much as people and companies can do, fund officials and private experts said.

title: Season's Greetings From Houston, the Bipolar City
description: HOUSTON -- I saw Continental's chief executive, Gordon Bethune, give a speech the other day, and I was happy to see he had his game face on. His slicked-back silver hair shimmered; the charcoal suit that squared his shoulders was a thing of beauty. Mr. Bethune's Houston-based airline may be fighting for its life, but he was confidently witty and profane, with a bounce to his step that was nearly convincing.

title: From the Rubble, Icons of Disaster and Faith
description: All that remains of St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church can be contained in two suitcases.

title: Ardito Desio, Leader of K2 Ascent, Dies at 104
description: Ardito Desio, an inveterate explorer who in 1954 meticulously organized the first ascent of K2, the world's second highest mountain, died on Dec. 12 in Rome. He was 104.

title: Layden Expresses Confidence in Chaney, at Least for Now
description: Even though the Knicks have plummeted under the direction of Don Chaney, Scott Layden said today that he had faith in him. Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, refused to say Chaney would be the Knicks' coach for the rest of the season, but he made it clear that Chaney would be given plenty of time to turn the team around.

title: A Knight Astride A White Charger
description: A long-running fantasy drilled into the minds of generations of American women by Hollywood movies and romance novels is that a refined, dapper Englishman with a cultivated accent and a title is the ultimate catch. That fantasy is made all the sweeter if the Englishman is a blast from the past. How about a courteous Victorian gentleman who stands when a lady rises from the table, refers to dating as courting and understands the language of flowers? (Orange lilies imply hatred, and begonias and lavender signal danger and suspicion.)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Trial Aimed At Islamic Group
description: A military tribunal outside Cairo began hearing charges against 22 men, including university professors, who are accused of membership in the Muslim Brotherhood. The trial is the latest effort to muzzle the 80-year-old group, which Egypt says seeks to overthrow the government. The Brotherhood, which at one time controlled the major professional unions and provided social and health services, has disavowed violence and is represented in Parliament. Susan Sachs (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; Horse Sense Vs. 6th Sense
description: TO what sartorial influence did Manhattan women most easily capitulate this year? As it happens, the answer comes in two parts. Anthropologists of street fashion surely noticed that while Upper East Siders strolled Madison Avenue looking as if they had been trapped in their television rooms with ''National Velvet'' in continual rerun, young women below 23rd Street disported themselves like so many students of Gurumayi.

title: Odessa Journal; By the Black Sea: Humor Graces the Citizen Taxis
description: In these times, in this cold, in the coal-stink grayness that still fills the nose in the former Soviet empire, it seemed a good idea to turn for a moment toward life's sweeter side.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar rose on expectations the economy will recover in coming months. In New York, the euro settled at 87.68 cents, down from 88.72 cents on Friday. The dollar traded at 129.78 yen, up from 129.39 yen.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION UNIT WILL BUY STOCK-OPTIONS FIRMS
description: Toronto-Dominion Bank's securities unit will pay as much as $430 million in cash and stock to acquire the Lee E. Tenzer Trading Company and most of Stafford Trading Inc., two firms based in Chicago that trade equity options. The bank will pay $280 million now and another $150 million over four years if the firms meet undisclosed performance targets, said Donald Wright, the vice chairman of Toronto-Dominion, a leading Canadian bank. Tenzer, known as Letco, is one of the largest independent options-trading firms. The acquisitions will add 600 employees and give Toronto-Dominion a foothold in a business that is potentially more lucrative than is trading stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLURMAN, GLORIA
description: CLURMAN-Gloria. Beloved wife of the late Herman; devoted mother of Ann Clurman and Judith Clurman Ruben; dear mother-inlaw of Cantor Bruce Ruben; loving sister of Frances Buchsbaum, Marcia Feinman and the late Ethel Zanger; cherished grandmother of Ari Ruben. Services today 10:30 AM at Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, NY.

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; Seeing Past the Cloud From Downtown
description: FASHION'S built-in unreality was violently cast into high relief on the morning of Sept. 11. Security guards rushed to padlock the Seventh on Sixth tents moments after the Liz Lange maternity show as a grotesque plume of smoke filled the sky above the lower Avenue of the Americas. If life as one knew it had not come to an end, it certainly seemed as if fashion had.

title: Major Critic of Interim Government Is Appointed to Afghan Defense Post
description: Afghanistan's new interim government appointed as deputy defense minister today a prominent northern warlord who had been critical of the distribution of power in the new administration.

description: I saw Continental's chief executive, Gordon Bethune, give a speech the other day, and I was happy to see he had his game face on. title: EXECUTIVES AT INTERFOODS TO TAKE THE COMPANY PRIVATE
description: Interfoods of America said its chief executive, Robert Berg, and its president, Steve Wemple, had agreed to buy the shares of Interfoods they do not already own to take the company, a franchisee of Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits restaurants, private. Interfoods shareholders will receive notes valued at $1.45 a share, the company said. The notes will bear interest at the rate of 10 percent a year. In October, Mr. Berg and Mr. Wemple offered to buy the outstanding shares for notes valued at $1.20 a share and bearing interest at 5 percent a year. The company is based in Miami.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, CHARLOTTE
description: WEIN-Charlotte. Beloved wife of Herbert for over 50 years. Predeceased by her loving brother Rudy; sister-in-law of Dr. Mark Imberman, and of Ron, Robert, Deborah, and Ingrid; cousin of Michaela and Ruti; most valued friend of Greta Loebl, Herta Klinger, Harriet Rader, Giselle Neely and Rosa Chinchilla and countless others. A bright, engergetic, outspoken, cultured woman who enjoyed life to its fullest. She had a love and deep understanding of opera, classical music, and art. A person dedicated to keeping the memory of the Holocaust alive, she was charitable and full of goodliness. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the UJA in her memory. Funeral services, Wednesday, December 26th at 11:15 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: AT&T SELLS OFF WIRELESS STAKE FOR $1.4 BILLION
description: AT&T, which is selling assets to reduce debt, sold its remaining stake in its former wireless unit for $1.4 billion. AT&T had retained a $3 billion stake in AT&T Wireless Services, the third-largest mobile-phone company in the nation, which was spun off in July. AT&T had already reduced the stake by $1.6 billion. Last week, AT&T agreed to sell its cable business to Comcast for $72 billion. AT&T's debt rose to $65 billion last year after it spent over $100 billion to form the biggest cable operator in the nation. The company has said it planned to have debt of $35 billion, after subtracting cash, at the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILFER, NATHAN, M.D.
description: HILFER-Nathan, M.D. On December 22, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Frieda. Devoted father of Dr. William, Dr. Carol and Dr. Jane. Cherished grandfather of Ann. Services were held on December 24th.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Airlines Discuss Agreement
description: Virgin Express Holdings said it expected to resume a code-sharing agreement with Delta Air Transport, the would-be successor to bankrupt airline Sabena, by January, and that a merger might follow. Talks between Virgin Express, a no-frills airline based in Brussels, and SN Airholding, a group of investors who conditionally bought D.A.T. for a symbolic 1 euro on Friday, are also touching on the subject of a merger, Yves Panneels, a Virgin Express spokesman, said.

title: The Visa Loophole In Airline Security
description: To the Editor:

title: An Outsider Finds His Future by Facing His Past
description: At its most memorable, Lasse Hallstrom's pictorially sumptuous screen adaptation of E. Annie Proulx's novel ''The Shipping News'' offers stirring panoramas of the severe, rugged seacoast of northeastern Canada. With its churning seascapes, worthy of Winslow Homer, in 20 shades of gray, and fading purple sunsets pressed against the sky like cosmic handprints, the movie at moments evokes the same awed sense of human insignificance as the desert island sequences in ''Cast Away.'' Two indelible images are of an austere saltbox house being towed by a human chain across the ice, and the stark silhouette of the same house, a symbol of desolation, etched against the luminous evening sky.

title: Finding Harmony Behind Closed Doors
description: It was one of the low points of the season for the Jets. They had just come off two tough losses, one in the last minute to the division rival New England, and another in which Pittsburgh physically pounded them. A sense of concern, if not dread, began to fill the team. The Jets players knew they were losing their grip in the playoff hunt, just as they did last season, when they dropped their final three games.

title: Coors Acquires A Big Brand In Britain
description: Seeking to expand abroad as it faces greater pressure from rivals at home, the Adolph Coors Company said today that it would buy the Carling operations of Bass Brewers from Interbrew for $1.7 billion.

title: Kidney Patients Maintain Their Muscle
description: Low-protein diets can help slow the progression of kidney disease, but they can make the muscle wasting that the disease causes even worse. Now a study has found that weight training can help these patients maintain or increase their muscle mass.

title: Birth of Rare Rhino Is a Bright Spot For Species' Future
description: When an 11-year-old Sumatran rhinoceros named Emi gave birth to a pudgy, sloe-eyed calf at the Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden on Sept. 13, biological scientists worldwide cheered.

title: Archaeologists Find Celts In Unlikely Spot: Turkey
description: In storybook histories, the ancient city of Gordion is remembered only as the seat of King Midas, he of the golden touch, and the place where Alexander the Great struck a famous blow in legend and metaphor. Challenged to separate the strands of an impossible knot, the Gordion knot, the conqueror cut through the problem, in the manner of conquerors, with one authoritative swing of his sword.

description: Pork barrel spending used to mean roads and bridges and dams. Now it also means hospitals, medical schools and local health care projects singled out by Congress to receive tens of millions of federal dollars.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Welch To Advise Fiat
description: Fiat hired John F. Welch Jr., General Electric's former chief executive, to consult on strategy as the car and truck maker gears up to cut production more than previously planned. Mr. Welch, who has been a Fiat board member for more than a year, retired from General Electric in September. The details of his contract with the Italian carmaker have not yet been worked out, said Gualberto Ranieri, a spokesman for Fiat. Fiat will cut production by 8,300 units in the next two months, rather than by 1,800 as it said two weeks ago, Mr. Ranieri said. The company will lay off 3,400 people at its Mirafiori factory in Turin from Jan. 21 to Feb. 10, Mr. Ranieri added.

title: SAD? Maybe It's Hormones on Overtime
description: Scientists have long wondered why some people become depressed in the winter, suffering from a condition called seasonal affective disorder or SAD.

title: AMC, a Movie Chain, Will Sell Bonds
description: AMC Entertainment Inc., the biggest publicly traded movie chain in the nation, is preparing to sell the first bonds to be issued by a theater chain since investors lost $1.7 billion in a three-year wave of bankruptcies by other cinema companies.

title: With Genome, A Radical Shift For Biology
description: With the Human Genome Project -- the effort to work out the sequence of the three billion chemical letters that embody human heredity -- nearly complete, biologists are facing a daunting transition.

title: In Raid on Hospital, a Fighter Is Captured
description: American soldiers, evidently Special Operations troops, arrested an Arab fighter at the hospital here Sunday night after a chaotic raid by local Afghan security forces that included a brief firefight.

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; So Sept. 10: Epitome of the Former Age
description: EVEN before a New Yorker cartoon designated some trifling act as ''so September 10th'' that expression had entered New York City's vernacular as the ultimate description for all the silly, self-obsessive tendencies that seemed to suggest the world that came before.

title: A New Day at the City Council
description: As the year turns, New York City will have an almost entirely fresh government. A new mayor, a new public advocate and a new comptroller will serve at the citywide level, while the City Council begins its term with a majority of new members. For this freshman Council class, now so full of ideas and promise, the first hurdle comes on Jan. 9. That is the day the Council is scheduled to pick a speaker and outline its legislative rules. It will be a long time before this untested 51-member body faces any more important decision.

title: Officials Race to Finish Stadium Plans For Mets and Yankees Before Year's End
description: Despite the city's growing fiscal problems and the approaching departure of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, city officials are laboring furiously to complete plans for new stadiums for the Mets and the Yankees by New Year's Eve.

title: In Offering Anthrax Vaccine, Officials Admit to Unknowns
description: Thousands of postal employees and workers on Capitol Hill who took antibiotics because they were exposed to anthrax two months ago now face a difficult new medical decision: whether to take an anthrax vaccine to forestall the slim and theoretical possibility that they may still develop the disease. And the advice they are getting from federal health officials -- consult your doctor and decide for yourself -- is less helpful than many workers would like.

title: AN ACCOUNTING CHANGE WILL INCREASE PROFITS AT KROGER
description: Kroger, a leading grocery-store chain, said that an accounting change would increase its fiscal 2002 profit by $90 million to $100 million. The change will eliminate the quarterly write-off of goodwill, the excess purchase price for an acquisition above the net value of its assets, Kroger said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Friday. Two weeks ago, Kroger said it would lay off 1,500 workers in the next 12 months, and it reduced profit forecasts through fiscal 2004. In the next two years, Kroger said its earnings would rise 10 percent to 12 percent. The company, based in Cincinnati, had $3.62 billion of goodwill as of Nov. 10, and had been writing that off over 40 years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Seek Robber
description: Investigators are searching for a man who they say follows elderly women to their apartments and robs them, often assaulting them or threatening violence, the police said yesterday. Detectives have connected the man to nine robberies in Central and East Harlem from Oct. 13 to Dec. 3, the police said. He is a black man in his early 20's, around 6 feet tall and 170 to 180 pounds, and was last seen wearing a black jacket, green pants and white sweater, the police said. The victims' ages have ranged from 63 to 92. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Officials Remain Uncertain On Identity of Suspect on Jet
description: Federal officials said today that the man who tried to ignite explosives in his shoes on a flight from Paris to Miami on Saturday had no known address, and investigators in the United States and Europe struggled to determine his identity, nationality and motive.

title: As Jets Open Offense, Even Laterals Are an Option
description: The Jets ripped the wrappings off a more daring offense on Sunday night and discovered that Vinny Testaverde would not lose the game for them if they let him pass, that they could even survive if he tried an improvisational lateral in the final minutes of the game.

title: Pfizer Is Not Liable in Suicide Risk Lawsuit
description: Pfizer Inc. is not liable to the family of a man who committed suicide because it did not warn physicians and patients that the depression drug Zoloft might have dangerous side effects, a federal judge ruled today.

title: Truce Helps Revive Hope For Peace In Sri Lanka
description: The guns, bombs and mortar fire that have killed more than 63,000 Sri Lankans over the past 18 years are falling quiet for the first time in 6 years, as a truce agreed to by Sri Lanka's newly elected government and ethnic Tamil rebels takes effect.

title: A Better Network for Emergency Communications
description: WASHINGTON -- With the consent of Congress, the Bush administration has now committed to spending tens of billions of dollars to build a missile defense shield. In time this technology may prove useful. Yet we are reluctant to spend far less money on far more feasible technology that is just as crucial to our national defense and safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, DAVID A.
description: GARDNER-David A. The Board, Officers and Staff of the Muscular Dystrophy Association mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague who served on MDA's board since 1994. His tireless support of the Association played a significant role in the rapid advancement of research seeking cures for neuromuscular diseases. He will be greatly missed by all those who were privileged to know him. Jerry Lewis, National Chairman Robert M. Bennett, Chairman of the Board Lois R. West, Chairwoman of the Executive Committee Victor R. Wright, Treasurer Robert Ross, President

title: Bloomberg Vows to Work at Center of Things
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would create a large, open office in the heart of City Hall -- modeled after the one that he used to manage his private company, Bloomberg L.P. -- from where and he and his top deputies would run the city. Mr. Bloomberg said he would relegate the mayor's formal corner office to mainly ceremonial purposes.

title: Japan Says a Mystery Boat Fired Rockets at Its Ships
description: Crewmen on a vessel suspected of being a North Korean spy boat used shoulder-held launchers to fire rockets at two Japan Coast Guard ships in a high seas battle that involved the firing of about 1,000 rounds from machine guns and other automatic weapons, Japan Coast Guard officials said today.

title: The Third Verse of Christmas
description: In one of the traditional Christmas carols, the angels who appear by night ask the shepherds, ''Why are you so dismayed?'' This year we have learned something about dismay ourselves, and not the kind the shepherds felt. It's what most of us mean when we talk about Christmas somehow being different this time around, without being able to put our finger on the difference. This year almost everyone feels as though Christmas came sooner than expected. Many people have found themselves saying they just don't feel very festive, as if they were reluctant, even afraid of being hopeful, wondering whether the glad-heartedness of Christmas weren't somehow inappropriate. It's almost as though we believed that this holiday means most when times are best.

description: Dr. Thomas T. Perls leaned in close and spoke gently, locking his eyes into Mary Lavigne's. He had pulled his chair to within two feet of the petite, white-haired woman in her sunny living room in Lancaster, Mass.

title: New Jitters in the Air, Critics at Ground Zero and Christmas in Kabul
description: Airport security, or lack of it, once again preyed on the minds of travelers, as well as political leaders, airline officials and law enforcement agencies, both here and abroad. This new wave of jitters, at holiday season, followed the bizarre case of the ''shoe bomber,'' who might have blown up an American Airlines flight from Paris to Miami on Saturday were it not for an attentive flight attendant who found that he had lit a match and fellow passengers who helped subdue him.

title: Prison Switch For Terrorists In Bombings
description: The four terrorists convicted of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa have been moved to the most secure federal prison in the United States, the so-called Super Max in Florence, Colo., officials said.

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; Role Models Bulk Up
description: ON the subject of manhood, fashion could not have predicted just how drastically the collective mind-set would shift this year. Even after stocks faltered and nerdy Internet entrepreneurs lost their cachet, men's fashion set as its muse the kind of guy who looked as if he had spent the last decade playing Dungeons and Dragons on his desktop. At the 2002 men's shows in Milan last June, and in the advertising campaigns that followed, muscles were nowhere in evidence. Sunken-cheeked models looked like boys who did not have the energy it would take to wield a nutcracker.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Worse Rates In Bypass Surgery
description: After a four-year decrease, New Jersey's mortality rate for patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery rose in 1999, a study shows. The fourth annual Cardiac Surgery Report Card shows a 1999 death rate of 2.89 percent, compared with 2.6 percent in 1998. Health officials say it is too early to tell if mortality rates have reached a plateau. The report surveyed 14 hospitals that performed 8,108 cardiac surgeries in 1999. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: In the 1970's and 1980's, when she was developing her fictional voice, Xu Xi felt alone in her homeland. Unlike most Asian writers here, she wrote in English. Twice, for long periods, her antidote for isolation was to live in the United States.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Tuning Out the Clutter

title: A Memorable Christmas Eve, a Girls' Night Out, and an Ideal Daughter
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Alain Levy, the new chief executive at EMI Recorded Music, misstated the given name of the founder of Virgin Music, which EMI acquired in 1992. He is Richard Branson, not Kenneth.

title: Looking Downtown, With Feeling
description: To the Editor:

title: In Holiday Rite, Pataki Grants Clemency to 2 Drug Offenders
description: Concluding a year of failed attempts to ease the state's severe drug laws, Gov. George E. Pataki granted clemency today to two longtime inmates convicted under those laws.

title: St. Patrick's Ceremony All in a Morning's Work
description: ''CRACKING the whip'' sounds more like a job for the Spanish Inquisition. But that is what Msgr. John T. Ferry says he does, though in a much gentler but equally authoritative way, at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Angelic Deviled Eggs
description: Ingredients

title: Few Shoes Shed In Airports' Lines
description: Grace Stamey came to Hartsfield International Airport today fully prepared to help keep the skies safe by removing her shoes for inspection. She had heard all about the man with the explosive shoes in Boston and assumed that the airlines would begin peering beneath laces and into soles to prevent copycats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURVIN, SAUL
description: PURVIN-Saul. Attorney on December 18, 2001. You will always be part of our lives. Loving wife Sylvia Devoted sons Alfred and Jack Dear friends and relatives

title: HotJobs.com Tells Suitor to Surpass a Rival Bid From Yahoo
description: Call it the war for help-wanted dot-coms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMBERG, NATHAN
description: GOMBERG-Nathan. On December 23, 2001. Beloved husband and best friend of Ruth for sixty years. Cherished father of Ira (Judy), Gail (Gerry), Lloyd (Doriet), Adored grandfather of Josh, Eric, David, Andrew, Halli and Ariel. Brother of Bertha Kirsh. Devoted brother-in-law and friend to so many who knew a kinder and gentler soul there never was. Truly a prince of a man. The family requests donations to be made to The American Cancer Society or Hopice by the Sea, Boca Raton, Fl.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think he's handled the situation properly and he's showing that he's a strong president. I don't even look at him now as having bought the presidency. I just look at him as president.''

title: Master of the Boast, King of the Ring, Vision of the Future
description: ''Ali'' is a breakthrough for its director, Michael Mann. The film, based on the life of Muhammad Ali, is Mr. Mann's first movie with feeling; his overwhelming love of its subject will turn audiences into exuberant, thrilled fight crowds.

title: Franco Dino Rasetti, 100, a Nuclear Pioneer
description: Dr. Franco Dino Rasetti, who worked with the Nobel laureate Enrico Fermi and the select team of Italian scientists that discovered one of the key processes in nuclear reactions, died on Dec. 5 at a retirement home in Belgium. He was 100.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: A Partial Peace Deal
description: Somalia's transitional government signed a peace agreement in Nakuru, Kenya, with some of the warlords who control chunks of the country. The signers are seeking to end the anarchy that has raged since 1991, but three prominent faction leaders backed by Ethiopia refused to sign the power-sharing agreement. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Air Passengers Are Watchful, But Still Flying
description: In the unnerving new world of air travel, where the gentleman across the aisle may be a mad bomber and every passenger is a potential hero, Eddy Donis was steeling herself for action. Slipping into a beige pair of leather mules (easier to remove for security), Ms. Donis, 39, scanned her fellow travelers at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon, trying to suss out the shifty-eyed and excessively anxious from those simply afraid to fly.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEIBLER, JOYCE
description: LEIBLER-Joyce. Happy Birthday Christmas Angel. We love you and we miss you. Mom-Joel and I bought a house, you'd love it! Love Mara and Steffi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNHARDT, RUTH SCHONZEIT
description: BERNHARDT - Ruth Schonzeit, 101. Beloved mother of Helen Carr (deceased), Marcia Model, Lisa Leblang and Joyce Siegel, wife of the late New York State Supreme Court Justice Maurice Bernhardt, grandmother of ten loving grandchildren and sixteen great-grandchildren, on December 23. She moved to Maryland in 1989 after an active life in New York, where, among other achievements, she headed the Brooklyn Jewish Center Sisterhood and organized their WWII Red Cross Chapter. She was known for her skills at the piano, bringing joy to many people; for her role as a helpmate to Justice Bernhardt, representing him at public events, supporting his career and philanthropic activities; as an energetic summer camp head counselor; and as a devoted sister of eight Schonzeit siblings. She had a full, rich life and we, who love her, mourn our loss. The family will receive friends at the home of Marcia Model, 17-85 216th St., Apt. 10M, Bayside, NY, through Dec. 31. There will be a memorial service in Bethesda. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be sent to: Ruth and Maurice Bernhardt Scholarship Fund, American ORT, 817 Broadway, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10003.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Friday about a meeting of former President Bill Clinton and some supporters to devise ways to defend his legacy misstated the title of one participant, Al From, at the Democratic Leadership Council. He is chief executive, not executive director.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Pop and Jazz Guide in Weekend on Friday about Darlene Love's concerts on Friday and Saturday included a song erroneously among her credits. The vocalist on the Crystals' 1963 recording of ''Da Doo Ron Ron'' was La La Brooks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINDERBAUM, HARRIET (NEE BENDER)
description: WINDERBAUM-Harriet (nee Bender), 85. On December 24, 2001 of cancer. Beloved wife of Harold for 62 years and loving mother to Michael (Rae) and Larry (Helene). Adoring grandmother of Anna (Gary), Nomi (Jim), Elise and Eli. Devoted daughter to Nathan and Celia and sister of Shirley Leonard and the late Blanche. She was uniquely compassionate, honest and protective to all of her family and friends. She empowered us all with guidance, support, encouragement and unconditional love. Funeral services to to held today, December 25, at Plaza Funeral Home, (91st Street and Amsterdam) at 9:30AM.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bank Seeks Stake In Broker
description: Banca di Roma, a leading Italian lender, said it was close to acquiring a 10.3 percent stake in Bipop-Carire, owner of Italy's biggest online brokerage firm, as part of a bid to expand its fund management business. The bank, based in Rome, reached agreement to acquire the stake held by Mauro Ardesi, a Bipop investor.

title: After a War, Deadly Reminders of It
description: Land mines recently wounded three American soldiers in Afghanistan; one lost a leg. And the task of clearing hundreds of thousands of mines there has just begun.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Human Rights Extraditions
description: The new government intends to lift a ban on the extradition of officials who committed human rights violations during the 1976-1983 military dictatorship. As one of his last acts as president before resigning last week, Fernando de la Ru signed a decree making such actions virtually impossible, thereby blunting existing extradition petitions from France, Germany, Italy and Spain, who say their citizens were the victims of human rights abuses. But the new justice minister, Alberto Zuppi, said yesterday that Mr. de la Ru's action ''is something that must be corrected.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economic Output Increases
description: Canada's real gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 0.3 percent in October, helped by retail sales and home construction, Statistics Canada said. The increase, the first monthly advance since May, exceeded economists' expectations and compared with a 0.8 percent decline in September. But Statistics Canada cautioned that the underlying weakness in the economy persisted in October. Output of computers and electronics slid 2.7 percent, the 14th monthly decline in a row. Communications equipment output was down 9.3 percent. Retail sales climbed 2.3 percent in October, due mostly to a 3.6 percent jump in motor vehicle sales. In manufacturing, 10 of 21 sectors advanced, accounting for 62 percent of production. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about a meeting of former President Bill Clinton and some supporters to devise ways to defend his legacy misstated the title of one participant, Al From, at the Democratic Leadership Council. He is chief executive, not executive director.

title: SHARES OF INTERNET SECURITY SOFTWARE MAKER PLUMMET
description: Shares of WatchGuard Technologies fell 32 percent after the maker of Internet-security software and hardware said that it would have a wider-than-expected loss this quarter as sales miss forecasts. Shares of the company, based in Seattle, fell $3.24 to $6.95. They have declined 78 percent this year. The company said it expected a loss of 23 cents to 29 cents a share this quarter. It was projected to have a loss of 4 cents, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. The company attributed the drop in sales to the weak economy and less demand for its more expensive products.

title: From Pierced Tongue to Infected Brain
description: Doctors at Yale believe that a brain abscess in a woman in her 20's was caused by an infection she suffered after having her tongue pierced.

title: Challenge the Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Wines of the Week
description: Laurent-Perrier, one of Champagne's top wine producers, has a winning lineup of wines from the widely-available Brut L.P. to the coveted Grand Siecle. What's appealing about Laurent-Perrier's bubblies are their consistent elegance and refreshing crispness. These Champagnes serve up pure drinking pleasure.

title: A Better Network for Emergency Communications
description: With the consent of Congress, the Bush administration has now committed to spending tens of billions of dollars to build a missile defense shield. In time this technology may prove useful. Yet we are reluctant to spend far less money on far more feasible technology that is just as crucial to our national defense and safety.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Party Says 3 Members Have Been Killed
description: Zimbabwe's leading opposition party said today that three of its members had been killed in recent days by supporters of President Robert Mugabe, in what it charged were politically motivated attacks.

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; The Adrover Fame Lesson
description: FOR a moment, at the turn of this century, his was the most compelling narrative in fashion. In spring 2000, myth-making reached a peak with the invention of Miguel Adrover, the son of a Spanish farmer, who, as the story went, toiled away geniuslike in a squalid two-room apartment on East Third Street, for which he was months behind on the rent.

title: American Investors in Argentina Mostly Taking Losses in Stride
description: As Argentina struggled to avert complete fiscal collapse with the anticipated issue of a new currency, the fallout in the United States is slowly coming to light.

title: Colors Are Truly Brilliant In Trek Up Mount Metaphor
description: Hovering above the ghoulish terrain, a visitor might feel transported to a distant planet. Rendered in black and white, the lay of the land would seem comfortably familiar: clusters of low, rounded foothills give way to higher, rougher ones, finally converging on majestic snowcapped peaks.

title: Waste in the Womb
description: Q. If the fetus is nourished through the placenta while in the womb, what happens to the waste?

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN MOBILIZING TROOPS ALONG THE BORDER
description: A warlike momentum is building between India and Pakistan as both countries mount large-scale troop buildups along the full length of their border in response to rising antagonism since a suicide attack this month on India's Parliament.

title: U.S. Decision On New Drug Lifts Schering
description: Shares of Schering-Plough rose 76 cents yesterday, to $37.11, in shortened pre-Christmas trading after the company said the Food and Drug Administration had approved a successor to Claritin, the company's heavily advertised allergy drug. Claritin is scheduled to lose patent protection at the end of next year.

title: Make These Bacteria Go to Work for You
description: One of the most nutritious and healthful foods on supermarket shelves is yogurt. I'm not talking about frozen yogurt; though a fine dessert, it has too little of the beneficial ingredients to qualify as a health-promoting food. Nor do I mean the heavily sweetened varieties, in which calories overwhelm nutrients, or heat-treated yogurts, in which beneficial micro-organisms are killed for the sake of a longer shelf-life.

title: Louise Bourgeois At 90, Weaving Complexities
description: The artist Louise Bourgeois turns 90 today. Imagine 90 years of celebrating your birthday on Christmas.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL WIRELESS HOLDINGS, New York, the communications company, said it had repurchased 90,000 of its own shares, and plans to buy back as much as 20 percent. The company's shares rose 43 cents, or 4 percent, to $11.32. They had fallen 19 percent this year.

title: Edwin F. Russell, 87, Newspaper Publisher
description: Edwin F. Russell, a former newspaper publisher who joined the Royal Navy to fight Germany before the United States entered World War II, died Saturday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Middle East: Pipeline Plan
description: TotalFinaElf of France said its Dolphin Energy Ltd. natural gas venture completed an agreement with Qatar to develop the first cross-border gas pipeline in the Middle East, costing an estimated $3.5 billion. Dolphin will build a 236-mile pipeline to carry as much as 2.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day from Qatar's offshore reserves to the United Arab Emirates for 25 years, the company said. Total owns 24.5 percent of Dolphin, state-owned United Arab Emirates Offset Group the rest.

title: A Fiscal Crisis, Paid in Credibility
description: Argentina's declaration of a moratorium on repayment of its foreign debt marks the end of a failed economic experiment that has cost this country dearly. But it is also a blow to the United States and the International Monetary Fund, which had invested much of their credibility and prestige here, yet proved unwilling to help when things began falling apart.

title: Ridge Is Opening a Center To Analyze and Share Data
description: Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, is opening a national coordination center in a former naval complex here that will analyze and share intelligence about threats and vulnerabilities with federal agencies. It will also coordinate the response of agencies to a terrorist attack.

title: RECKSON SELLS ITS STAKE IN A NEW YORK CITY PROPERTY
description: Reckson Associates Realty, a New York-area developer, sold a stake in a New York City office building for $221 million as part of plan to raise cash for further developments and acquisitions. The company sold a 49 percent part in a 1.4 million square foot building at 919 Third Avenue to the New York State Teachers' Retirement System, a pension fund, Reckson said. Reckson's sale values the building at $450 million, 60 percent more than it paid in 1999. Including the $98 million gained from this sale, Reckson said it raised $342 million this year from property sales. The company, based in Melville, N.Y., buys distressed or under-performing buildings and refurbishes them to sell at a higher price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATLIN, ROSE B.
description: PATLIN-Rose B. NYC August 31, 1914. Beloved wife of Sonny. Mother of Wendy & Michael. G'mother to Sean, Scott, Courtenay, Daniel, & Will. ''She could walk into a desert & come out with a friend''. We will miss her. November 1, 2001.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''The Majestic'' in Weekend on Friday misstated the title of a television movie in which the new film's star, Jim Carrey, appeared. It was ''Doing Time on Maple Drive''; ''Doin' Time on Planet Earth'' was released in theaters in 1988.

title: Op-Art
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Hasek Named The Player Of the Week
description: Detroit goaltender Dominik Hasek was named the N.H.L.'s player of the week after posting a 3-0 record with two shutouts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, HELEN KRASS
description: POPPER-Helen Krass on December 24, 2001, at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Edward Popper. Loving mother of Jane & Warren Zorek and John and Abby Popper. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer and Mark Pressman, Michael Zorek and Shelly Friedland, Robert Arthur Popper and Marta Melvin & Juliette Popper. Adoring great-grandmother of Noah Duncan Popper, Ella Popper and Jessica Pressman. Loving daughter of the late Rabbi Nathan Krass, Senior Rabbi at Temple EmanuEl, and the late Eda Krass. Dear sister of Alice Loewenheim. Service and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the 92nd Street Y or Temple Emanu-El.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cabinet Approves Frugal Budget
description: The cabinet approved the country's smallest proposed budget in four years, $635 billion. It reflects government estimates that tax revenues next year will drop by almost 8 percent, as the nation limps though its fourth recession in a decade. The budget, to be debated in Parliament next month, cuts foreign aid and public works spending by about 10 percent but expands spending for the elderly and job-training. James Brooke (NYT)

title: A Diet That's Beneficial at Any Age
description: Switching to a healthy diet and eating less salt can lower the blood pressure of healthy young people as well as those with hypertension, according to a new report in The Annals of Internal Medicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHIAS, SOPHIE
description: MATHIAS-Sophie. Beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Mathias family on the loss of this truly special woman. Marion and Steve Leber Nuny Grey and Harvey Stuart

title: Letters: The Stem Cell Frontiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: Christmas Eve In Bethlehem: Santas, Songs But No Arafat
description: The bagpipes played ''Auld Lange Syne'' today in Manger Square as balloons of Santa Claus and the cartoon character Pikachu floated with the smell of falafel over a festive Christmas Eve procession of priests in white gowns and scouts in brown uniforms.

title: American Snowboarder Uses Podium as Platform
description: The soothing voices of National Public Radio were filling Chris Klug's car as he traveled past Utah's Desolation Canyon on a lonely stretch of Highway 6.

title: Lester Persky, 76, Producer Of 'Taxi Driver' and 'Shampoo'
description: Lester Persky, a film and television producer whose hits included ''Taxi Driver'' and ''Shampoo,'' died on Dec. 16 in Los Angeles. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABATCHNIK, CLEMENTINE G. (NEE REIMANN)
description: TABATCHNIK - Clementine G. (nee Reimann). Beloved wife of the late Marc. Revered mother of Martina & mother-in-law of Daniel Jackson. Cherished grandmother of Catherine Jackson-Walley. Proud grandmother of Rebecca Jackson-Walley. Services Wednesday, 1:30PM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Passengers Are on the Alert
description: As passengers moved through the nation's airports, just about everybody seemed prepared to take a part in the war on terrorism. Page B1.

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; Nudity Was Out of Step
description: ''KIDS aren't so bashful or so shy anymore,'' Sam Shahid, the art director for the Abercrombie & Fitch catalogs, said in July, explaining the clothier's back-to-school catalog, which portrayed the college experience as a protracted romp in the buff. These days, Mr. Shahid added, everybody ''wants to see skin.'' Abercrombie provided so much of it in its vastly popular catalogs, which sell for $6, that the lieutenant governor of Illinois undertook a boycott campaign. The catalogs, photographed by Bruce Weber, were chockablock with coy nudity. They even came in wrappers that contained mature-content warnings.

title: Security Steps Are Tightened At Airports In Europe
description: Security measures were reinforced today at airports all around Europe after the incident Saturday on a Paris-Miami flight in which a passenger tried to ignite bombs hidden in his shoes.

title: Pearson Set To Leave TV Industry
description: Pearson said today that it would sell its 22 percent stake in RTL, Europe's largest broadcasting company, to Bertelsmann for 1.5 billion euros, or $1.33 billion.

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; The Glitter and the Glory
description: GEM hounds had a banner year in 2001, what with the Jean Schlumberger jewelry retrospective at Tiffany & Company, the American Museum of Natural History's scholarly survey show ''Pearls'' and the Metropolitan Museum of Art's sumptuous ''Jeweled Arts of India in the Age of the Mughals,'' drawn almost entirely from the collection of Prince Nasser el Sabah of Kuwait.

title: Campaign by Pilot's Family Secures Benefits for Gulf War Veterans
description: Michael Donnelly was at the top of his game flying combat missions in the Persian Gulf war. His plane, the F-16, was handsome and sophisticated. Tall and strapping in his olive drab flight suit, his blue eyes hidden behind aviator glasses, Major Donnelly seemed the perfect match for that machine.

title: As Glaucoma Treatment Advances, Vision Is Saved
description: Roger Martin of Milford, Conn., watched his grandmother go blind from glaucoma. His mother lost most of her sight in her 40's from the same condition and had to give up the successful catering business that she loved. Four years ago, when Mr. Martin, then 51, found out that he too had open-angle glaucoma, the most common form of the disease in the United States, he was determined to have a better outcome.

title: For Street Vendors With a Dream, a New Indoor Market in Flatbush
description: For years, the corner of Flatbush and Caton Avenues, in the heart of Caribbean Brooklyn, has been an economic battleground, a place where enterprising street vendors went head to head with local store owners. The vendors dreamed of one day having a market all their own, while Flatbush merchants wished they would just go away.

title: Covanta Shares Fall Because of Cash Woes
description: Shares of the Covanta Energy Corporation fell 60 percent today after the power producer said it had limited cash available and was negotiating with its banks for covenant waivers.

title: And a Star for Every Christmas Tree
description: It's red and green, and not just for Christmas. This Hubble Space Telescope image of the ''Ghost Head Nebula'' was, however, just released by NASA with the holidays in mind.

title: Deep Roots of Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: The Year in Fashion, Before and After; What Not to Wear
description: THEY'RE called press dresses, clothes made more for shock effect than to be worn. That doesn't mean one should slough them off, though, since designers often exhibit their best ideas in the form of these runway stunts. Among the standouts in a bumper year were Viktor & Rolf's frothy communion-dress-after-exposure-to-gamma-rays; Hedi Slimane's gunshot-wound shirt ''quoting'' directly from Richard Hell, the proto-punk musician; Marjan Pejoski's big-bird confection for Bjork's appearance at the Oscars; John Galliano's Around the World in 80 Dresses couture collection for Dior; and Alexander McQueen's matador frocks, which came complete with lances for the cross-dressing picador. GUY TREBAY

title: Slide Show: A Year to Remember
Christmas in Afghanistan and New York
Holidays Seasoned with Meaning
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On Display, Once Again, Artifacts of Police Past
description: Not many museums have a display of the drugs available on the streets of New York City, complete with syringes, pipes and other paraphernalia.

title: Agha Shahid Ali, 52, a Poet Who Had Roots in Kashmir
description: Agha Shahid Ali, a Kashmiri-American poet who was a finalist for the 2001 National Book Award in Poetry, died on Dec. 8 at his brother's home in Amherst, Mass., where he was staying. He was 52 and had lived in Brooklyn.

title: Critics' Attack On Tribunals Turns to Law Among Nations
description: Going beyond claims that the military tribunals authorized by President Bush would violate civil liberties guaranteed by American law, some experts are beginning to argue that they would breach international law guaranteeing fair treatment of prisoners of war.

title: Job Fairs Give Ex-Convicts Hope in Down Market
description: In September, 600 men and a sprinkling of women nervously clutched their rsums and waited for a chance to land an interview with one of several dozen recruiters at the civic center's main library in downtown San Francisco.

title: Suspect in Bomb Plot Linked to Muslim Extremists
description: LONDON, Dec. 26 - The man who threatened to blow up a passenger plane with explosives hidden in his shoes is a British small-time criminal who converted to Islam in prison and then was lured to radical action by Muslim extremists, the head of a London mosque he attended confirmed today.

title: An Inventive Menu That Travels the Map
description: MI does not tip its hand quickly. In fact, it may be the most inscrutable restaurant I've walked into all year. The small sushi bar in the main dining room says Japan. Korean vases, lovingly displayed like museum artifacts high on the opposite wall, say something else. The daring Modernist curves of the ceiling panels and the exposed industrial ducts suggest downtown. A life-size mannequin imprisoned in a glass case and outfitted in a traditional Korean robe suggests Coney Island. The instinctive reaction is to put in a coin and wait for the head and arms to start moving.

title: Our Privacy in a Time of Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Thank-Yous, but Fewer of Them, Await Rescuers at a Corner
description: It was cold and drizzling along West Street in Greenwich Village the other morning, but John Bennie was there: bundled up in a yellow slicker, standing alone on the center island amid the American flags and the small Christmas tree, and hoisting a tattered ''Thank You'' sign to the cars and trucks heading to and from the patch of Manhattan where the World Trade Center once stood.

title: Our Privacy in a Time of Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethereal Layers and a Gentle Crunch
description: HALVAH, the Middle Eastern confection made from ground sesame seeds and sugar, is one of the most interesting sweets there is. It has a terrific earthy flavor, but what I really adore is its texture. At first it seems perfectly smooth, but as you chew, a slight crunch emerges. It's as if it were made up of millions of sugary, wafer-thin caramel layers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, DAVID A.
description: GARDNER-David A. The Board, Officers and Staff of the Muscular Dystrophy Association mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague who served on MDA's board since 1994. His tireless support of the Association played a significant role in the rapid advancement of research seeking cures for neuromuscular diseases. He will be greatly missed by all those who were privileged to know him. Jerry Lewis, National Chairman Robert M. Bennett, Chairman of the Board Lois R. West, Chairwoman of the Executive Committee Victor R. Wright, Treasurer Robert Ross, President

title: Passenger Searches
description: To the Editor:

title: Worshipers Hail the Miraculous at Cathedral
description: Hundreds of families gathered yesterday for the Christmas Eucharistic service at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, a week after a five-alarm fire almost forced the cancellation of all holiday services. Over and over, the visitors used the same words: It was a miracle.

title: Close the Borders
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Sits Out Game Because of Pain in Big Toe
description: About two hours before last night's game, Knicks center Marcus Camby told Coach Don Chaney that he could not play against the Toronto Raptors because of pain in his left big toe.

title: Sports of The Times; For Kidd, Passing Dreams
description: MOST young boys, when they dreamed heroic daydreams, imagined themselves as the Red Baron gunning down flying foes, or Sherlock Holmes cracking a case, or, at this time of year, perhaps Santa all a-bundle spreading cheer and largess as he wriggles down chimneys. Or, if basketball was the springboard to wonderland, then it was scoring the winning basket in a big game. Not so, though, for Jason Kidd.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Year to Make Mascara Run

title: Courtesy and Decency Play Sneaky With a Tough Guy
description: Hank Grotowski (Billy Bob Thornton) is, like his father and his son, a Georgia corrections officer. Leticia Musgrove (Halle Berry) is a waitress struggling to make ends meet and to raise her 12-year-old son. She is also the widow of a man whose execution Hank helped to conduct. The relationship between Hank and Leticia, a relationship born of chance, moral reflex and desperate need, is at the center of ''Monster's Ball,'' a tough, heartfelt new film from the young Swiss-born director Marc Forster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, SYLVIA SCHWARTZ
description: FEINBERG-Sylvia Schwartz. On December 25th, 2001, at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Boris Feinberg. Loving mother of Cynthia and Paul Jacobson, Renee Feinberg and Henry and Janet Feinberg. Cherished grandmother of Adam and Steven Jacobson, Sheelah Feinberg and Andrew Dinkelaker, and Hannah, Rachel and Samuel Feinberg. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, December 27, 2001, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (91st Street & Amsterdam) at 12 noon. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Japan Wants to Salvage Boat It Says Fired on Its Coast Guard
description: Japanese officials on Tuesday advocated salvaging a sunken boat believed to be from North Korea, a move that could give new insight into the electronic eavesdropping ability of that secretive nation.

title: PAKISTAN LEADER IN SHARP REBUKE TO INDIAN THREAT
description: The leaders of Pakistan and India traded stiff warnings today about the risks of a wider conflict between them as their armies traded sporadic artillery fire in the mountains of Kashmir and continued an intensive military buildup elsewhere along their 1,800-mile border.

title: Celebrating The Colorful Iris Murdoch
description: In photographs of the young novelist Iris Murdoch, she is sensual and androgynous, staring out at the camera as if daring the viewer to resist her.

title: A Preference for the Limelight
description: Clinton Portis describes himself as a ''sweet'' defensive back, but he converted to offense because that was where he could receive the recognition he craves. Now Portis, a junior, is the Miami Hurricanes' top rusher.

title: Wheels on the Office Go Round and Round; Next Stop for a Legal Team? A Personal Injury Case in Queens
description: The law office of John C. Dearie gets about 11 miles to the gallon. It runs on diesel fuel and can go from zero to 60 miles per hour in 20 seconds flat.

title: Our Towns; Trying for Joy At a Home Of Last Resort
description: SANTA showed yesterday morning, but Darnell's grandmother didn't. Donors and staff members could be counted upon to make sure there were plenty of gifts under the tree -- giant bags full of Game Boys and portable CD players, teen magazines and sets of colored pens, sweaters and mittens, and makeup sets for all the girls. But parents and grandparents are not always the most reliable strands in the safety net for troubled teenagers.

title: Small Cable Operators Worry About Life After Big Mergers
description: The stakes in the battle for the nation's televisions are gargantuan -- subscription TV generates revenue of $60 billion a year. So the players need to be gargantuan as well, some industry executives argue.

title: An Enlightened Moment at 9

We flew him in by helicopter, with live radio coverage of his arrival, and made a landing pad of thousands of small stones on the roof of the local bus terminal. The welcome party had to run for cover as the helicopter hovered and sent the stones like buckshot in all directions.

title: A Muted Christmas, Corporate Obligations, the Anthrax Mystery
description: Fifteen weeks have passed since terrorists took down the twin towers. Holidays have come and gone, none more poignant than this first Christmas in a changed world, a changed city, where no amount of tinsel can replace the sparkle of nearly 3,000 lost lives. But hesitantly, reluctantly, inevitably people are inching toward more normal lives, groping for wisdom and perspective.

title: Immediate Needs at Ground Zero
description: Last week, workers in New York City finally extinguished the fires that have been smoldering for almost 100 days at Ground Zero. This should ignite a new resolve among political, business and civic leaders to take the first small but critical steps on the road to restoring Lower Manhattan. Most New Yorkers imagine restoration in grand terms -- as a big, architecturally innovative complex of commercial, residential, cultural and commemorative structures created by some of the world's most talented people. In reality, these permanent structures are years away, and while a larger vision must always be kept in mind and indeed animate the entire project, the task now is to focus on downtown's urgent short-term needs.

title: North Korea Denounces Japan Over Sinking of Boat in Battle

title: Funds for Fellows
description: The New York City Teaching Fellows program, an alternative route for aspiring teachers, most of them career changers, to obtain certification, is going to receive $500,000 in federal funding. The program recruits and trains people in other professions to become teachers in schools in need of academic improvement. Representative NITA M. LOWEY, whose district includes portions of Westchester, Queens and the Bronx and who is a member of the House Appropriations Committee, helped secure the funds which will help the school system in its effort to hire 46,000 teachers over the next four years. title: The Genius Behind the Tree
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  As children, we invent the world by telling ourselves stories: the debonair man who lives down the street is really a desperate criminal; the lady next door is a world-famous dancer, or a spy, or both; the Wilkersons may or may not have countless millions buried in their backyard. In my extended childhood  as a freshman at Princeton in 1970  I encountered one of the more remarkable of these ready-made myths. It concerned a campus character we called Purple Sneakers, a harmless middle-aged crazy man who hung around the main undergraduate library.

title: To Bless, to Listen, to Comfort
description: With Cardinal John J. O'Connor, there were wild moments. One time he led a meeting on housing for the poor with the mayor, the deputy mayor, the housing commissioner, the chancellor of the archdiocese and me. I had to give a presentation. The cardinal sat directly in front of me and my flip chart, with everybody else sitting in back of him. Well, he fell asleep. So to rouse him, I kept saying in a loud voice, ''As the cardinal well knows.'' But it didn't work. He was a workaholic, but he was also an insomniac, and sometimes he dozed off during the day.

title: No Budget Increase at SUNY
description: In his annual report last week, ROBERT L. KING, chancellor of the State University of New York, said that he did not plan to seek any budget increase for the coming academic year. He also said that SUNY's 64 campuses were making good progress in their outside fund-raising. Twenty-four campuses are engaged in capital campaigns totaling $1.1 billion, nearly half of which has already been collected or pledged. Another 14 campuses are about to begin campaigns totaling more than $110 million. And 19 others are just beginning to plan campaigns that will be announced late next year or in early 2003, or otherwise expanding their fund-raising programs.

title: Magnet School in Westchester
description: A magnet high school open to students from three Westchester County school districts will begin classes at the State University of New York's Purchase campus at the end of January. The high school, known as the Westchester Magnet Academy, hopes to bring together students from different ethnic and economic backgrounds who live in Irvington, Harrison and the Greenburgh Central Seven School District, based in Hartsdale. A major lure is Purchase College's intense arts courses and its professional faculty and studios. The magnet school, financed by a $2 million, three-year federal grant, is starting with 60 ninth graders and will add a grade successively until the current freshmen graduate. So far about three dozen students have applied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, HERBERT J.
description: McCOOEY-Herbert J. Of Jupiter, FL, Westhampton Beach, NY, and formerly of Manhasset, NY, on December 21, 2001. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on July 6, 1926, he was the son of Herbert and Elizabeth (Larney) McCooey. Grandson of the late John H. McCooey, political leader of Brooklyn for twenty-five years. Graduate of Brooklyn Prep High School and the College of the Holy Cross, Class of 1949. Mr. McCooey served as a signalman in the United States Navy during World War II. He had a long and distinguished career on Wall Street where he was a member and former Governor of the New York Stock Exchange. He was the Executive Vice President of Robb, Peck & McCooey Specialist firm until his retirement in 1984. Mr. McCooey served as a trustee of St. Mary's Parish in Manhasset where he was a driving force and ardent supporter of the CYO program. Knight of Malta as well as a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. Mr. McCooey sat on various Boards including the Long Island Savings Bank, Plandome Country Club, Westhampton Country Club and La Ronde Beach Club. Mr. McCooey is survived by his wife Dolores (nee) McCarthy, brothers John of New York City and Richard of Washington, DC, and predeceased by Robert of Rye, NY. Loving father of Bert Jr. (Lori), Sean (Jane), Bess (Tom), Patrick, Maureen (Carter), Dan (Suzanne) and Dee. Proud grandfather of Bert III, Sara, Matt, Bryan, Kellen, Brendan, Shareen, Cassie, Regan, Julie, Luke, Dolores, Mae, Danny, and Jack and many nieces and nephews. Bert will be remembered for his vitality of spirit, strength of character and extraordinary capacity for family and friends. Family will receive friends at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, on Wednesday from 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM. On Thursday, family will receive friends from 3-6 PM, in St. Mary's Church, 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, immediately followed by a Mass of Christian Burial. Interment private on Friday. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: From Coppola, A New Sparkler To Greet the New Year
description: The New Year countdown has started, and you are about to pop the cork on something sparkling. But it is also late enough to be hungry for dessert, and a dry brut Champagne may not be the best choice to pair with a baked alaska or chocolate mousse cake. Here's another option for toasting 2002: Sofia, a blanc de blancs that isn't sweet yet has a touch of mellow charm, thanks to muscat in the blend. It's frothy, but not aggressively so, and is lower in alcohol -- 11.5 percent -- than most Champagnes. The wine, made by Niebaum-Coppola in California, was first produced for the 1999 wedding of Sofia Coppola, the daughter of Francis Ford Coppola, the winery's owner. A bottle of the 2000 vintage is about $20 at Morrell & Company in Rockefeller Center and at Zachys in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Using a Little Honey as a Lure
description: Honey can be as pale as straw or as dark as molasses, delicately floral or earthy. It all depends on the bee's taste in nectar. The honey sampler by Beehive Products of Brooklyn has nine honeys in glass vials set in a wooden stand. The corks identify the varieties, which include the fairly pungent saw palmetto, as well as more familiar orange blossom, blueberry and buckwheat. Easing the corks back into the vials takes a little effort because they are fitted very tightly. But once the honey has been consumed, the vials in the stand make great flower holders. These are all-natural raw honeys, and many are organic. The set is $49 at Nice House, 117 Perry Street (Hudson Street). Beehive Products also sells eight-ounce jars of its honeys, which are $10 at French General, 35 Crosby Street (Grand Street). Individual one-ounce vials are $3.

title: Dolan Re-enters Picture As Possible Red Sox Owner
description: Charles Dolan, a losing entrant in the bidding for the Boston Red Sox, could still wind up as a part-owner of the team. John Henry, head of the winning group, acknowledged yesterday that he had spoken with Dolan about joining the ownership group.

title: South Asian Brinkmanship
description: President Bush is heading to his Texas ranch today, but his administration will get no break from rising tensions in South Asia. Just as a new government in Kabul has begun moving to rebuild a ravaged Afghanistan, a new crisis is brewing next door. It is one that the United States must try to temper. In recent days India and Pakistan have been building up forces along their border, and yesterday the leaders of both countries gave belligerent speeches raising the possibility of war. India has threatened military action against Pakistan if it does not do more to shut down militant groups that New Delhi believes have carried out terrorist attacks, most recently at the Indian Parliament building. Pakistan has taken action against some groups, but the situation remains highly combustible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, HOWARD R.
description: SLOAN-Howard R., age 64, Dec. 24, 2001. Physician, biochemical geneticist, researcher, teacher. Survived by Elaine, wife of 41 years; sons Michael, Stephen, Eric, and their wives Maria, Tracey, and Dominique; grandchildren, Sarah, Soledad, and Sacha; sisters, Lois Fenton and Nancy Sorkin. Born in Pittsburgh, PA; A.B., Harvard College; M.D., Univ. of Pitts.; Ph.D., Johns Hopkins Univ. Former Chair of Pediatrics at Staten Island Univ. Hosp. and Lincoln Hosp. Prof. at the NY Medical College; Prof. in College of Medicine and Dept. of Biochemistry at Ohio State Univ. Began career with N.I.H. Author of over 60 research papers. Most recently at L.I. College Hosp., where he led rounds just days before finally falling ill from lymphoma, the week before Thanksgiving. A natural leader, he was active in civic groups everywhere he lived. Never seen sitting still, Howard followed his curiosity wherever it led, and, because his curiosity was insatiable, he went everywhere, tried everything, and knew everyone. He will be sorely missed. Funeral Thurs. Dec. 27 11:30 AM, Riverside Mem. Chapel on 76th St. Family will receive friends on Thurs. Dec. 27 from 4:30-7:00 PM and Fri., Dec. 28 from 12-4:00 PM at 445 Riverside Dr. Contributions may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice, NY, NY.

title: Board of Education Changes
description: Schools Chancellor HAROLD O. LEVY has made a round of year- end staff changes, shifting around several longtime managers at the Board of Education. Among the more significant changes is the addition of MICHELLE GOLDSTEIN, a lobbyist in the Giuliani administration. She will become director of local government relations, reporting to STEPHEN ALLINGER, the board's Albany lobbyist. An aide to Mr. Levy said that Ms. Goldstein brought a lot of experience to a job that the chancellor felt would be important as a new City Council takes office. BURTON SACKS, pictured, a longtime liaison to community school districts, will also oversee charter schools. HOWARD TAMES, the veteran head of human resources, will become chief executive for labor policy at a time when contracts for teachers, principals, custodians and others are being negotiated or are about to be negotiated. KEVIN GILL, the chief of food and transportation, will expand his territory to include instructional technology, an area that, Mr. Levy's aide said, the chancellor thought was weakly managed. Mr. Gill has one of the most sophisticated internal and customer Web sites at the board. Mr. Levy also named KATHY NADURAK, a longtime budget aide, as his chief of staff. LYNNE SAVAGE, who had served many previous chancellors, though not Mr. Levy, as chief of staff, will work with ANTHONY SHORRIS, a deputy chancellor, on reorganizing the central staff.

title: Wines in This Shop Must Display Their Report Cards
description: As the world of wine expands, wine shops are getting more focused. The new buyer-friendly Bacchus on the Upper West Side carries only wines rated B-plus or higher by the Wine Advocate, the Wine Spectator or other guides. Among those are intriguing alternatives to Champagne, including Oregon's Argyle and a sparkling Grner-Veltliner (Schlumberger) from Austria. With the slogan ''Wine Made Simple,'' Bacchus looks like Best Cellars without the best buys, but it is actually the first New York franchise of a chain. It displays wines in vertical racks by category (Fruity, Bold). Prices are not held to the $15 limit that Best Cellars imposes on its discoveries, but a Bodegas del Cep cava from Spain is $9.99. Wine tastings are nightly from Monday through Saturday; 2056 Broadway near 71st Street; (212) 875-1200.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airlines Set Share Ratio
description: The Japan Airlines Company and the Japan Air System Company agreed on a 1-to-9 ratio of stock allocation in the merged holding company that they plan to form next year. The ratio means that for each Japan Air System share, nine times as many shares in the new company will be allocated as for each Japan Airlines share. The allocation is based on the average ratio of the two carriers' stock prices over the year to Nov. 9, the last trading day before the merger was announced on Nov. 12, officials from the airlines said.

Together with her husband, who is Secretary of the American Board of Trustees and member of the Global Board of Trustees, Mrs. Strochlitz was a presidential founder of the University and with him, established The Sigmund and Rose Strochlitz Judaic Teaching Fellowship Center for the training of Judaic Studies and Bible teachers. Mrs. Strochlitz was a full partner in all of her husband's philanthropic endeavors, especially those concerning Israel, Holocaust remembrance and higher education. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mr. Strochlitz and the entire family. May they derive solace from inspiring memories and be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Melvin Stein, Esq., President, American Board of Trustees Brig. Gen. (ret) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Compensation For Leprosy Law
description: The government has decided to settle a long-running case with the families of 72 former leprosy patients who had been segregated from society, and with 16 other former patients for mistreatment. The out-of-court settlement is expected to cost the government about $7.7 million. The families being compensated are those of former patients, some of whom are now dead, who were forcibly segregated under the 1953 Leprosy Prevention Law, which was repealed in 1996. The 16 former patients the government settled with were not allowed into the leprosy treatment centers and were subsequently denied adequate treatment. In a separate case, the government passed a law last summer awarding $116,000 to each of about 2,100 leprosy patients for human rights abuses, including forcible internment and sterilization.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Man Charged With Strangling Friend
description: A Pleasantville man was charged with murder in the death of a friend after the two men argued while driving through Atlantic City, the authorities said yesterday. The suspect, Francisco Sanchez Marenco, 40, of Pleasantville, is accused of strangling Silvio J. Carcache, 41, of Egg Harbor Township, on Tuesday. Mr. Carcache was driving with Mr. Marenco when they began arguing. According to the Atlantic County prosecutor's office, Mr. Carcache stopped the car at the side of the road, and Mr. Marenco, who was sitting behind Mr. Carcache, began strangling him. Another passenger, who was not identified, ran off and flagged down a police officer. They returned to the car 20 minutes later and found Mr. Carcache in the front seat and Mr. Marenco standing outside the vehicle, the authorities said. Bail was set at $350,000, and he is being held at the Atlantic County Jail.

title: WISCONSIN COMPANY BUYS 3 POWER PLANTS IN NEW YORK
description: The WPS Resources Corporation, the owner of a Wisconsin utility, has agreed to buy three power plants in New York from the CH Energy Group for $61 million to increase its wholesale electricity sales in the Northeast. The plants, in Beaver Falls, Niagara Falls and Syracuse, can produce a total of 257 megawatts of power, enough to light 257,000 average homes. WPS, based in Green Bay, said the acquisition would increase its wholesale power-generating capacity to 930 megawatts. WPS owns the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation, and its power development subsidiary owns plants in Wisconsin, Maine, Arkansas, Oregon, Kentucky, Pennsylvania and Canada.
