title: ENRON BROADBAND FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: Following in the footsteps of 28 of its affiliates, Enron Broadband Services, a telecommunications products trader, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The filing, which the company, a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation, made on Monday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, listed assets of $64.5 million and debt of $63.7 million, not counting off-balance-sheet and contingent obligations. The Enron Freight Markets Corporation sought bankruptcy protection on Friday. Enron Freight listed $6.3 million in assets and $4.7 million in debts, not counting off-balance-sheet and contingent obligations. Enron Broadband Services estimated that it had 16 to 49 creditors.

Mr. Buffett holds almost 1.7 million shares in Burnham Pacific, a real estate investment trust based in San Diego, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Buffett is the chairman of his own investment company, Berkshire Hathaway. Burnham Pacific said last week that it would make a liquidating distribution of $1.25 a share to its common stockholders. The company raised money by selling eight properties.

Aracruz Celulose's fourth-quarter net income will drop to 26 million reais ($11.3 million), from 122.4 million reais in the comparable period a year ago, the company said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Passaic: Man Charged In Wife's Death
description: A man has been charged with killing his wife on Christmas Eve after an argument. The man, Slawomir Weilgat, 50, killed his wife of 12 years, Bronislawa, and then spoke on the phone with his stepdaughter in California, saying, ''I just killed your mother,'' the police said yesterday. Sgt. James Rhoades, a police spokesman, said that officers forced their way into the Weilgats' apartment and found Mrs. Weilgat's naked, beaten body in the bedroom. The initial investigation cites blunt force trauma to the head as the cause of death, the police said. They said Mr. Weilgat was drunk and was found a short time later lying in the street a few doors from his apartment. He was arrested and charged with murder, and is being held in $500,000 bail.

title: Pavarotti's Debut in Shanghai, With a Little Help

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Traffic Off
description: Passenger traffic at Japan's main gateway, Narita Airport, fell to a 10-year low after the terrorist attacks in the United States and the war in Central Asia. Arrivals and departures at the airport, which handles just over half of Japan's international traffic, fell to 1.5 million in November, 32 percent less than the same month a year earlier. It was the first time since April 1991, just after the war in the Persian Gulf, that traffic slipped below 1.6 million passengers. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Nestl said yesterday that it had paid $641 million to General Mills for the 50 percent it did not own in a venture that sells Hagen-Dazs ice cream in the United States. The venture, called Ice Cream Partners USA, was formed in August 1999. It combined the Pillsbury frozen desserts business of Diageo with Nestl's ice cream division. General Mills acquired Pillsbury this year. The venture had sales of about $700 million in 2000, said Desa Davis, a spokeswoman for Nestl's United States unit.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Output Down
description: Four of Japan's five largest automakers reduced production in November as sales at home and in many export markets dried up. Toyota Motor, the world's third-largest carmaker, cut global production 4.6 percent, while Nissan Motor, Japan's No. 3 automaker, trimmed output 3.1 percent. Mitsubishi Motors and Mazda cut production more than 10 percent each. Only Honda Motor, helped by demand for its subcompacts and minivans in Japan, increased output. Ken Belson (NYT)

I find myself listening for the mockingbird early in the morning or knocking on the window glass when the blue jay bullies the nuthatches or shushing all conversation for the royal procession of the scarlet cardinal and his demure little wife.

description: Afghanistan's foreign minister said today that negotiations over the shape and duration of an international security force were nearing an end, although various political factions in and out of the government continued to express resistance to a large contingent.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Big Spending Cuts Seen
description: Cutbacks in spending on information technology in the United States were even sharper than expected this year and will continue to drag on the economy in 2002, the Giga Information Group, a market researcher, said. It said strong declines in equipment purchases contributed to an estimated 5 percent drop in spending in 2001, to $750 billion, compared with growth of 22 percent in 1999 and 24 percent in 2000. Before Sept. 11, Giga had predicted a 3 percent decline. It predicted that spending would improve by 4 percent in 2002, lowering its earlier forecast of 7 percent. Chris Gaither (NYT)

description: COMPUTER passwords are supposed to be personal, disposable and discreet. But people become sentimentally attached to them or leave them taped underneath their keyboards or on their monitors, to the dismay of computer-security professionals worldwide.

description: There is free food in New York City, but for the hungry to get some, they must often set aside their dignity. They must also set aside a part of their day to stand in a food pantry line.

Sabena collapsed last month as the economic fallout from Sept. 11 amplified the financial strains on Europe's ailing second-tier airlines.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ads Cut From Web Traffic Count
description: Those pop-up Internet advertisements will be popping up in at least one less place -- the Jupiter Media Metrix rankings of the most popular Web sites. Since this sort of ad opens a separate browser window, Jupiter had counted the ad as it did any other Web site. As a result, x10.com, which has blanketed the Web with pop-up ads promoting wireless cameras, ranked as the fifth-most frequently visited site in Jupiter's October rankings, with 39 million users. Big Web sites, like Yahoo, said this policy sullied ratings used by both advertisers and investors. In the November rankings, released yesterday, x10 was nowhere to be found. Jupiter attributed the change to ''the evolving Internet landscape.'' Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOORSANGER, CATHERINE HOOVER
description: VOORSANGER-Catherine Hoover, 51. Died from complications of melanoma, December 24, 2001. Born in San Francisco, December 18, 1950, she was the daughter of Beatrice B. Slater and Robert C. Hoover. She attended the Katherine Delmar Burke School, Smith College and received her doctorate in the Art History Program from the Graduate Center, City University of New York in the Fall of 2001. Catherine was Curator at the San Francisco Historical Society from 1972 to 1979 and most recently Associate Curator at the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum. She joined the Metropolitan Museum in 1983 and in 1991 had the responsibility for furniture after 1825 in the American Wing, including the Frank Lloyd Wright Collection. She participated in and made major contributions to the scholarship of her field in the three exceptional exhibitions and publications at the Museum: ''The Aesthetic Movement,'' ''Herter Brothers'' and ''Art and the Empire City.'' The publication ''Art and the Empire City'' received The Henry Allen Moe Prize from the NY State Historical Society and a distinguished award from the NY Public Library. Mrs. Voorsanger is survived by her husband Bartholomew Voorsanger, her mother and father, her sisters Holly de Montmarin and Whitney Hoover, and brothers Robert C. Hoover II, Samuel S. Slater and John S. Hoover. A memorial service will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, NYC, January 11, 2002 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a new Fellowship Fund established in the Art History Program at the Graduate Center, City University of New York with an emphasis on the Decorative Arts in the name of Dr. Catherine Hoover Voorsanger. Information may be obtained from Mr. Larry Cowen at CUNY, 212-817-7132.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Golden Gate Operators Plan To Raise Toll
description: Faced with a $16 million budget shortfall over the next two years, the operators of the Golden Gate Bridge, which connects San Francisco and Marin County, are considering a toll increase of as much as $1 next year. With layoffs in Silicon Valley and a dwindling stream of tourists since Sept. 11, traffic on the bridge dropped 4 percent in the second half of the year, while security costs increased. The last toll increase was in the state's last recession, in 1991, when the fee rose to $3 from $2. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Belarus Wants Quick Wedding
description: Talks on a long-proposed union of Russia and Belarus, never trouble free, struck new sour notes at a meeting in Moscow of a council charged with consummating the merger. President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus accused the Kremlin of foot-dragging on plans to meld its economy with its far poorer neighbor in 2005, warning that ''either we implement what we agreed or we make serious changes to our plans and say it openly.'' Meanwhile, Belarus's prime minister said that $2.3 million of the council's budget, marked as missing after an audit, was not stolen. Russia's prime minister declined to characterize the discovery. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Dead Infant Found In Bathroom
description: The body of a newborn boy was found Tuesday night in the toilet of a home in Staten Island where a 14-year-old girl had just given birth, the police said yesterday. The girl has not been charged, and the medical examiner's office said it would take at least another day to determine whether the infant was alive when he was born. Medics were called to the girl's home at 11:35 p.m. after she complained of stomach pains and they found the girl seated on the toilet, the police said. When she stood up, medics saw the boy in the water and tried to resuscitate him. The girl's mother told investigators that she did not know that her daughter was pregnant, the police said. Jacob H. title: No Help on Social Security
description: President Bush hand-picked a commission last spring and asked it to recommend ways to carry out his campaign promise to privatize Social Security. The commission has dutifully turned in its report, recommending three options. If anything, they reinforce the reasons that Mr. Bush's approach on Social Security is dubious. All three options would require drastic benefit cutbacks and large infusions of money from outside the system to keep it solvent. Instead of building a consensus for reform, the commission's recommendations make it even less likely that Congress will act on Social Security any time soon.

It looks like an old-fashioned candlestick with a base of blue, yellow or silver. The bulb, 40 watts, sits in a stainless-steel stem; $109 at Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street). He is a New York City decorator who plays his role to the hilt, flaunting a taste for exuberant color and showiness in his fake fur chubby, his orange-lined suits and his velvet paisley newsboy cap. As seen on the cover of the November issue of Elle Decor, Mr. Drake unleashed his most riotous impulses in his own home, a Manhattan loft done in throbbing pink, Tyrian purple and chrome yellow, the last thrown into high relief by a zebra-and-leopard-pattern rug. ''People don't come to me for beige or for Laura Ashley sweet,'' he told Elle Decor last fall. ''I have very bold taste.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Hint Of Economic Upturn
description: Singapore's economy may already be recovering from its worst recession since independence in 1965. The government said that manufacturing output in November fell 13.6 percent compared with the month a year ago, a much gentler decline than in September and October, when output dropped 21.9 percent and 20.6 percent, respectively. Electronics continued to lead the slump, dipping 29.8 percent in November year on year. But the country's fledgling biomedical sector offered a bright spot, with output more than doubling.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brewer Acquires Spice Line

Kirin, based in Tokyo, will buy the seasoning business of Takeda, Japan's biggest drug maker, for a little less than 20 billion yen ($153 million), said Takeshi Ishida, a spokesman for Takeda. With domestic beer sales falling for a 20th consecutive month, Kirin is seeking sources of growth in nonbeer and foreign operations. Kirin in the last month announced an agreement to buy the Four Roses whiskey brand from Diageo and Pernod-Ricard.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Prison Disturbance
description: Twenty-one correction officers and three prisoners were treated for minor injuries after a disturbance at Rikers Island late Tuesday, when about 20 prisoners in a common area refused to go back to their cells, the City Department of Correction said yesterday. The officers, including three captains, were treated for exposure to a chemical spray used around 11 p.m. to subdue the prisoners, said Sandra Lewis Smith, a deputy correction commissioner. She said that the prisoners' injuries were unrelated to the spray and that the incident lasted only a few minutes. Robert Gangi, executive director of the Corrections Association of New York, a prisoners' rights group, said the spray, known as C4, should be used only as a last resort. Inmates have died from it, he said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

Until Jan. 15, it is offering 15 percent off on all flatware. A five-piece place setting of Acorn, Jensen's most famous pattern (new at $1,040 on Madison Avenue), costs $563. title: ENTERCOM TO BUY RADIO STATIONS FROM TRIBUNE CO.
description: The Entercom Communications Corporation will acquire three radio stations in Denver from the Tribune Company for $180 million The stations that are being bought are KOSI-FM, KKHK-FM and KEZW-FM, said Entercom, which will now own stations in 19 cities. The Denver acquisitions are the latest Entercom has made to enter new markets. They include two stations in Greensboro, N.C., last month and five in Wichita, Kan., last year. Entercom, based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., will manage the stations for as long as three years before it takes ownership, the Tribune Company said. The Tribune Company, based in Chicago, publishes The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Reversal On Reward
description: Overruling his staff, Gov. Gray Davis said a woman and four companions whose tip on Sept. 9 led the police to a mass-murder suspect in Sacramento would receive a $50,000 reward. Mr. Davis's press office had said the woman, whose name was not released, would not be given the money because the suspect, Joseph Ferguson, had killed himself and state law allowed rewards only in cases that lead to arrests and prosecutions. Mr. Davis said he would honor the reward promise, made a few hours after Mr. Ferguson, apparently angry over his breakup with his girlfriend, had killed five people. Rob Gunnison (NYT)

title: What You Get When You Cross Chintz With Andy Warhol
description: Here's a surprise. Chintz upholstery fabric is appearing in a downtown shop this season. But it's a far cry from the familiar old floral patterns made famous by the Prince of Chintz, the New York decorator Mario Buatta. Tulip (on the chair) is a 65-inch-wide polished cotton, printed with digital photographs tinted in yellow or pink. P. J. Casey, a New York architect and president of C.I.T.E. Design, created the pattern with photographs she took of tulips from her corner grocery store. Another Casey pattern digitally produced (not as chintz) is Blue Highway (on wall), a cotton canvas with photo images of bridges and roads in the Catskill Mountains. Both are made in Italy and cost $35 a yard (the slipper chair is $995) at C.I.T.E Design, 100 Wooster Street (Spring Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Homelessness in New York
description: Mayor-Elect Michael Bloomberg faces all sorts of daunting challenges when he takes office in New York City next week. High on the list are the twin problems of hunger and homelessness that have taxed soup kitchens to the limit and jammed the city's homeless shelters with record numbers of men, women and children. In a city where so many people are needy, the problem of what to do for the very neediest has bedeviled mayors for the last two decades. We hope Mr. Bloomberg can bring a new energy and determination to the issue.

title: OIL AND GAS SERVICE COMPANY BUYS 17 MORE DRILLING RIGS
description: Patterson-UTI Energy, which provides drilling services to oil and natural gas exploration companies, has acquired 17 land-drilling rigs from the Cleere Drilling Company for at least $23.4 million in cash and stock. The price includes $13.5 million in cash, 450,000 shares of Patterson-UTI common stock and 325,000 warrants convertible into common shares at a price of $26.75, Patterson-UTI said. The common stock portion is valued at $9.9 million based on Monday's closing price. The acquisition is the first since Patterson Energy completed its $1.1 billion buyout of the UTI Energy Corporation in May. The purchase from the closely held Cleere gives Patterson-UTI, based in Snyder, Tex., 319 rigs. Cleere Drilling is based in San Angelo, Tex.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Telephone Plan Withdrawn
description: Taiwan's third-largest cellular operator, KG Telecommunications, said it had withdrawn an application to provide so-called third-generation mobile-phone services because it does not think it can make money from the venture. ''In view of the current economic condition of the Taiwan economy and the high number of available 3G licenses,'' a KG unit, the Ho Hsiang Broadband Telecommunications Corporation, withdrew its application submitted earlier this month, a KG spokeswoman, Nancy Yin, said. KG's withdrawal leaves six bidders for five licenses.

Motorists may continue to use the estimated 30 million tokens they already have after Jan. 1, but the authority will destroy the tokens that it collects. The end of token sales is part of Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's plan, which also includes discounts for E-ZPass users, to help reduce congestion on the highway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUADRON, HOWARD M.
description: SQUADRON-Howard M. The Board of Trustees and staff of City Center express great sadness at the passing of our Chairman of 23 years-the ''father'' of City Center. His love for this theater, its many and diverse artists and the staff and the audiences who support them was unsurpassed and continuous. Howard saved City Center in the 1970's and worked tirelessly to assure both the survival and success of this landmark cultural institution. Thanks to Howard Squadron, City Center thrives today. His relationship with City Center began in his teens when he joined others in the top balcony to view and appreciate performances, and it never wavered as he ascended to the Chairmanship later in life. His devoted stewardship guaranteed a home for the New York City based dance companies such as, The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Paul Taylor Dance Company, Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theatre of Harlem, American Ballet Theatre and others. City Center Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert was born during his leadership. Though Howard was involved in many other worthy and prestigious causes and organizations, he was always and unfailingly ''there'' for City Center. Our sympathy and love to Anne and all of the family. Howard will be greatly missed by all of us connected with the theater and will never be forgotten. Raymond A. Lamontagne, Chair, Board of Trustees, City Center Elaine Malsin, Co-Chair, Board of Trustees, City Center Judith E. Daykin, President and Executive Director, City Center

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Block On A Judicial Appointment
description: A state judge temporarily blocked a last-minute judicial appointment of the wife of a state senator and longtime political supporter by the departing Atlanta mayor, Bill Campbell. The judge, John Goger of Fulton County Superior Court, said the appointment seemed improper because Mr. Campbell had named Cheryl Cofield-Fort to a four-year term as a municipal judge even though she was not on a short list submitted by the city's judicial commission. Members of the commission and the four candidates it approved went to court to stop Ms. Cofield-Fort's swearing in, which had been scheduled for Thursday. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: MB FINANCIAL IS BUYING FIRST LINCOLNWOOD OF CHICAGO
description: MB Financial, the holding company for MB Financial Bank, said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held First Lincolnwood Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Under the deal, MB Financial will acquire the three offices of the First National Bank of Lincolnwood, on Chicago's north side. The purchase would expand MB Financial's locations in Illinois to 34. MB Financial, which has more than $3.3 billion in assets, focuses on lending to small and midsize businesses like real estate developers and health-care companies. Its shares rose 13 cents, to $28.23. They have more than doubled this year.

title: When a Year Becomes An Old Acquaintance
description: Soon it will be over. That may be the best thing left about 2001. No one needs to be reminded of the devastation of Sept. 11, of the recession that was already under way, of a war with no immediate end in sight. And it would hardly be surprising if New Year's Eve events were more muted than they have been in recent years, and filled with mixed emotions: relief, sadness, determination, uncertainty, hope.

title: Bloomberg Appoints Five To Be City Commissioners
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg appointed five city commissioners yesterday, reappointing one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's commissioners, promoting two city deputies and an assistant, and tapping a doctor serving with the World Health Organization as the city's next health commissioner.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Says Accord Is Near
description: The chairman of Hynix, Park Chong Sup, has told the company's lenders that Hynix and Micron Technology have narrowed their differences over formation of a strategic alliance. Micron reportedly wants managerial control over Hynix, more than $8 billion in debt, but may settle for certain Hynix facilities, notably its semiconductor plant in Eugene, Ore., if Hynix balks at selling more than a minority stake. Hynix shares were steady on the Korean Stock Exchange after having risen by the daily limit of 15 percent on Wednesday, when the company said it expected to reach an agreement with Micron by next month. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Bush Says bin Laden Will Not Escape
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  Virtually ignoring the possibility that Osama bin Laden may never be found, President Bush pledged again today that the United States will bring him to justice, "dead or alive." And though he expressed total confidence in how the war in Afghanistan is being waged, he emphasized that American troops will not be coming home soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUCHMANN, WILLIAM F.
description: SUCHMANN-William F. On December 23, 2001 in auto accident. Retiring in 1984 after 25 years at Kenyon and Eckhardt Inc, moved to VT and became involved in local politics and was elected to two terms in the state legislature, ending in 2000. He was serving on several community boards involving early childhood education and social issues. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Katharine W. and three adult children, William, Kate, and Christopher, also five grandchildren.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Globix In Debt-Reduction Talks
description: Globix, an Internet service provider, said it was negotiating with bondholders and preferred shareholders to reduce its debt through a prepackaged bankruptcy filing. Current shareholders would receive nothing under the plan, which would give equity in the reorganized company to preferred stockholders and holders of Globix's $600 million in 12.5 percent senior notes. Globix, which is based in New York, has been hurt by the dot-com collapse and the recession as demand for World Wide Web services and space on computer servers has slowed. At its peak, Globix's market value was almost $1 billion. Its shares closed yesterday at 17 cents, down 30 cents.

title: Just Who Would Want to Defend Suspects Before a Tribunal? Probably Plenty
description: As Pentagon officials finish assembling a draft of the rules that will govern military tribunals, there is no shortage of defense lawyers willing, if not eager, to step in on behalf of anyone accused of terrorism who might be tried before them.

title: Studying Ancient Ruins With the Eye of a Poet
description: At the beginning of the 20th century, when few women pursued advanced university studies, Esther Boise Van Deman did not merely become the first woman with a doctorate in Latin from the University of Chicago. Or the first female American archaeologist in Italy to focus on ancient Roman building materials and techniques. Or the first American woman to acquire an international reputation in Roman archaeology.

title: The Antiterror Bandwagon
description: Since the Bush administration announced plans to proceed with military tribunals and other limitations on liberties in the war against terror, foreign leaders have used the American example to justify all manner of repressive acts at home. It is a lamentable -- and predictable -- response to misguided American leadership in this area.

title: Corrections

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Campaign Finance Veto
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vetoed a bill yesterday that would have changed the city's campaign finance law, saying it would make candidates for public office ''more beholden'' to large campaign donors. The bill called for allowing candidates in the program to continue raising money long after elections to help them pay off campaign debts. It would have allowed candidates to solicit more money from donors who had already contributed the maximum amount allowed under the current law. It will be up to the new City Council, which has yet to be sworn in, to decide whether to try to override the veto. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Corrections

That law, the 1991 Telephone Consumer Protection Act, has been challenged on constitutional grounds but has been upheld. It has not gone unchallenged.

Her eyes narrow and flicker with a gleam of reflected firelight, and her cherry lips spread into a Cheshire cat smile that's impish, imperious and impassioned all at once.

description: What happened in cyberlaw during the past year that was significant and enduring -- or at least interesting? That's the question Cyber Law Journal put to several well-regarded law professors and legal practitioners.

title: Landeta Still Hitting 'Em High and Far
description: The punter usually trots onto the field only six or seven times in a game. Lining up 15 yards behind the line of scrimmage, he catches the snap, drops the ball precisely in midair and swings his right leg. The impact sounds like that of a rifle shot. When done properly, the ball spirals high into the sky and hangs there for several seconds before spinning down more than 55 yards away, or 40 yards from scrimmage.

title: Steinbrenner Meets With Wells
description: David Wells has met with George Steinbrenner a second time. title: Argentina Pins Its Hopes On 3rd 'Floating' Currency
description: Before this week, the word argentino simply meant a man from Argentina, or perhaps a member of a mediocre soccer team from the Avellaneda neighborhood of Buenos Aires. Now it is the name of Argentina's third currency and, depending on whom you believe, either the country's salvation or its ruin.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Coral Reef Site For U.S. Base
description: The government has approved a plan to build a United States military airport on an Okinawa coral reef, a decision that is expected to draw anger from conservationists who want to protect the southern subtropical island for tourism. The new airport, off Nago City, is also expected to enrage many local residents who want the military airport, a helicopter base, to be moved off the island. James Brooke (NYT)

title: P&O PRINCESS EXPECTS EARNINGS ON HIGH END OF FORECAST
description: P&O Princess Cruises, which is planning to buy Royal Caribbean Cruises and is fending off a hostile bid from Carnival, said yesterday that its 2001 profit would be on the high end of earlier forecasts. P&O Princess, the third-largest cruise operator, after Carnival and Royal Caribbean, said earnings would be at least 40 cents a share, because cruise bookings were better than expected. Last week, P&O Princess pushed back a planned shareholder meeting on the purchase of Royal Caribbean by a month to give Carnival a chance to improve on its $6 billion bid. The company may be releasing the positive earnings news to induce Carnival to bid more, an analyst said.

title: Could've Been Worse
description: It has not been a good year for economic policy, at home or abroad. The best you can say is that things could have been worse.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Renault To Cut Dealers
description: Renault, the big French automaker, said it planned to cut the number of car dealers in Europe more than half by 2004 in a bid to increase profit. The carmaker will reduce the number of dealers to 800 from the current 1,900. It will not cut the number of dealerships, said a spokeswoman, who did not give details on how many outlets the dealers now operate. Renault's sales in Europe rose 0.5 percent from a year ago to 1.48 million units.

title: Mission Of Mercy Goes Bad In Africa
description: ''BLACK HAWK DOWN'' has such distinctive visual aplomb that its jingoism starts to feel like part of its atmosphere. Establishing mood through pictorial means is the director Ridley Scott's most notable talent. There may be no working director more accomplished at wringing texture out of the color blue than the prodigious and now prolific Mr. Scott; you'd swear that with his dazzling washes of blues and sand tones, he was inventing additional hues on the spot. Because Mr. Scott's eye delivers so much information, he then is at a loss to give the material a proper emotional grounding. ''Black Hawk Down'' is like Mr. Scott's ''G.I. Jane'' but this time with an all-boy cast.

title: A Retarded Man Tries to Keep His Child
description: Anyone who has tried to raise a young child will be helpless before ''I Am Sam,'' a shamelessly uplifting melodrama about a mentally challenged man fighting for custody of his young daughter. In a climactic courtroom moment, Sam Dawson (Sean Penn), recites a courtroom speech from ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' one that reduced parents to helpless tears 22 years ago.

Squadron, who made himself one of the city's powerful lawyers by mixing an active law practice with liberal politics, support for the arts, a keen sense of public relations and ties to influential clients like Rupert Murdoch, died Wednesday night at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Monday about Lashkar-e-Taiba, a militant Islamic group that is challenging India's rule in Kashmir, misstated the age of the Grand Trunk Road, which runs across Pakistan and India and through the Pakistani town of Muridke, where the group has its spiritual headquarters. It was built during the reign of Sher Shah Suri in the mid- 1500's, not when Pakistan and India were part of British-ruled India.

title: Corrections

title: Profit Report Lifts United Auto Shares
description: Shares in the United Auto Group rose 13 percent today after the company, a leading auto retailer, said late Wednesday that its fourth-quarter profit would beat estimates.

title: OPEC Cuts Oil Output in Pact With Rivals
description: CAIRO, Dec. 29  Alarmed that the global economic slowdown could result in further sharp drops in world oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today agreed to cut its oil production by 6.5 percent, or 1.5 million barrels a day, for at least six months starting Jan. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOW, SYLVAN
description: LEBOW-Sylvan, December 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth for 69 years, loving father of Mark and his wife Patricia E. Harris and Joy and her husband Dr. William Cohen. title: Court Order Tells 10 Executives To Pay $75 Million to Samsung
description: Small shareholders won a landmark legal victory yesterday against what they call abusive and highhanded practices by the executives and families who control South Korea's major corporate groups, known as chaebols.

title: KODAK SCHEDULES SHAREHOLDER VOTE ON OPTION PLAN
description: Eastman Kodak has scheduled a shareholder vote on its plan to revalue stock options after a 22 percent drop in the share price this year. Although it is not legally required to obtain the approval, Kodak said ''sound corporate governance'' dictated the vote. The company, based in Rochester, N.Y., scheduled the vote for Jan. 25. Options representing about 31.4 million shares are affected. Employees with options to buy the stock at $37 a share can receive new options at a 1-for-1 ratio. They can swap two grants for one if their options are priced at $58 to $69.99. Options priced at $79 and higher can be exchanged at a ratio of 3 to 1. Kodak stock closed yesterday at $30.54, down 4 cents.

title: Keeping Up With the van Hoogstratens in the 17th-Century Netherlands
description: Bourgeois home life in the Netherlands during the bountiful 17th century was not a modest affair. International trade had brought prosperity to the country, and a rising merchant class was into mansions, manners, modes, art, furniture, finery, pets and banqueting -- just like burghers of today.

In the film, which tips its cap to ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' he is aided by Michelle Pfeiffer as a tough lawyer and abetted by a network of eccentric friends led by Dianne Wiest.

Hill stopped in front of Gonzalez and said, ''Hey, Bobby, I know who the coach of Manhattan is.''

title: RULES ON TRIBUNAL REQUIRE UNANIMITY ON DEATH PENALTY
description: The military tribunals that may be used to try Al Qaeda members and others accused of terrorism will require a unanimous verdict to impose a death penalty, although a two-thirds vote of the panel of military officers will be enough to find someone guilty, according to rules drafted by senior Bush administration officials.

title: Crouch Has Matured Beyond His 23 Years
description: Think of life as a big, dark cave, Susan Crouch would tell her sons when they challenged her wisdom. ''You can't even see in there,'' she said, recalling their conversations. ''I'm here first. So I go ahead in there, in that dark cave. And, when I come out of my cave of life, I tell you what's in there. And what's scary. And where to step. That's where my wisdom comes from. Whether you take it or leave it, I'm still going to give it to you.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Hard Line On Chechnya
description: The secretary of the Kremlin's security council underscored Russia's hard line toward guerrilla fighters in Chechnya, saying the government has nothing to negotiate with the separatist rebels except their unconditional surrender. The secretary, Vladimir Rushailo, echoed President Vladimir V. Putin, who said in a September speech that Russia was willing to discuss procedures for disarming the rebels but would not negotiate their demands for independence. A Kremlin aide later met with a rebel negotiator, but apparently made little headway toward ending the two-year-old war, which appears to be at a standoff. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Mishandled Treason Case To Proceed
description: A regional court said prosecutors had mishandled a treason case against Igor Sutyagin, a Russian military analyst, but sent the case back to investigators for further work instead of dismissing the charges, as many had believed likely. The court said investigators had committed ''significant violations'' of criminal procedure and Mr. Sutyagin's rights. Mr. Sutyagin, an analyst for the Institute of U.S. and Canada Studies, is accused of espionage for selling freelance analyses of unclassified Russian military data to a London firm that prosecutors call a front for Western intelligence. Mr. Sutyagin's colleagues and many human-rights groups say the charges are baseless. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: An Afghan defense official said tonight that Osama bin Laden had escaped the country and was hiding in the mountainous border region of Pakistan. The Pentagon dismissed the report but said it had no idea of his whereabouts.

Frances Degen Horowitz President, CUNY Graduate Center

description: Prosperity floats past this shabbily elegant island city every day, and Harris L. Kempner Jr. has a great view of the procession. Out the window of his 12th-floor conference room, Mr. Kempner can see the line of tankers and cargo ships that chug past Galveston to carry their goods to Houston.

description: After Tara Lipinski pulled off her stunning upset of Michelle Kwan for the Olympic gold medal four years ago in Nagano, Japan, there were many in and out of the skating community who wondered why she did not want to continue training to defend her medal in Salt Lake City.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp Response To North Korea
description: The chief cabinet secretary, Yasuo Fukuda, brushed off North Korea's complaints about Japan's sinking of an unidentified boat on Saturday, which had fired on Japanese Coast Guard boats and may have been from North Korea. Responding to North Korea's description of the sinking as ''unpardonable terrorism of a modern brand,'' Mr. Fukuda said that ''such criticism expressed in a poor and vulgar manner is totally inappropriate.'' North Korea yesterday threatened unspecified ''countermeasures.'' James Brooke (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Promises Bonuses
description: One of France's largest banks, Socit Gnrale, said it was prepared to pay bonuses and raise salaries to try to avert a strike that would disrupt France's switch next week to euro notes and coins. The bank is offering a bonus worth 12 percent of monthly salaries, plus 400 euros ($352), said Jerome Fourre, a spokesman for the Paris-based company. It also is ready to increase salaries 0.5 percent to 0.7 percent, he said. Unions are demanding a 1,000 euro salary increase for all banking employees and are calling for members to strike on Jan. 2. They are also asking other workers, including savings bank employees and cash transporters, to join the strike.

title: A Turbulent First Year
description: George W. Bush is spending the days before New Year's at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., enjoying the kind of informal, secluded weekend he has probably envisioned having many times during his presidency. And the public, much of which was once prepared to resent Mr. Bush's desire to get away from Washington as much as possible, now simply hopes he gets to catch up on his sleep. It has been a far different first year than the one the president, or the country, anticipated.

title: Maldini to Coach Paraguay in Cup
description: Cesare Maldini agreed to coach the Paraguayan national team through next year's World Cup in Japan and South Korea, where he may oppose his son Paolo, Italy's captain.

title: Elephants Float (As Does Music)
description: In the 1950's Dr. Seuss won a bet by writing a book with a vocabulary of only 225 words: ''The Cat in the Hat.'' In the 1990's Raphael Mostel undertook a similar challenge but with music. He decided to compose a work whose themes were the most basic musical units: scales.

description: Escalating the fight over the future of Hewlett-Packard, the oldest son of the company's co-founder made a preliminary proxy filing today calling the proposed $24 billion acquisition of Compaq Computer overpriced and unnecessarily risky. He urged shareholders to vote against it.

description: ''I began in the theater,'' Emily Watson said, ''and I was heading toward being a British theater actor when I was sort of derailed by Lars von Trier.''

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Historians will have to decide on the precise date, but sometime in the last couple of years, the Upper West Side decided that it wanted to eat well. With alarming regularity, one serious restaurant after another has opened its doors, and although it's doubtful that Alain Ducasse is scouting Amsterdam Avenue for his next venture, there's no question that the physical distance between acceptable restaurants is shrinking.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,163 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Theatrical Environments, Punctuated by Surprises
description: The Spanish sculptor Juan Muoz, who died of an aneurysm in August at 48, had one of those European careers that Americans tend to see as pumped up by excessive intellectualization and repeated exposure at big international exhibitions. Of course Europeans tend to see this appraisal as an indication of American chauvinism and provinciality. So be it. It seems unlikely that the survey of Muoz's work at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden here will do much to end the schism.

title: WCBS Wins the Rights To Yanks on the Radio
description: After 21 seasons with WABC-AM, the Yankees' broadcasts will be heard on WCBS-AM for the next five years, the YES Network said yesterday.

title: Barrick Gold Joins Battle For a Rival
description: Citing the need for a long-overdue rationalization in the gold mining industry, Barrick Gold of Toronto has waded into the takeover battle over Normandy Mining of Australia, with plans for closer cooperation with AngloGold of South Africa if AngloGold's bid for Normandy succeeds.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: PDI To Market Ortec Treatment
description: Ortec International, a start-up company based in New York that has developed a wound treatment product containing live human skin cells, said yesterday that it had hired a sales force from PDI, a health products marketing specialist, to market the new product to the 150 or so hospitals with major centers for the treatment of burn victims. Ortec's engineered living tissue stimulates regrowth of the victim's own skin. The product is not currently aimed at treating burns directly but rather for use in repairing the areas of the patient's body where skin has been removed to use as a graft on the burned area. Ortec, which will get all revenue from sales made by PDI, will pay PDI an undisclosed fee for a two-year contract.

title: Thomas Blames Referees For Fouls
description: It has become as familiar to Knicks fans as Latrell Sprewell's cornrows. You see it every week, if not every game. It is the sight of Kurt Thomas, the Knicks' growling power forward complaining to a referee about a foul call before stomping angrily toward the bench, usually midway through the first quarter.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Court Blocks Sharon Appointment
description: The Supreme Court barred Prime Minister Ariel Sharon from appointing as his antiterrorism adviser a former senior agent of the Shin Bet security service who battered to death two Palestinian prisoners in 1984. The former agent, Ehud Yatom, said in a newspaper interview in 1996 that he had used a rock to crush the skulls of the Palestinians, who were taken alive after they hijacked an Israeli bus. The court, ruling on a petition filed by political opponents of Mr. Sharon, said Mr. Yatom was unfit for the antiterrorism post because he had followed an illegal order to kill the prisoners and then played a major role in covering up the incident. After the killings were disclosed Mr. Yatom and other people involved, including four top Shin Bet officials who resigned, were given presidential pardons. Joel Greenberg (NYT)

title: KEYSTONE BUYS WAREHOUSE COMPLEX FROM MORGAN UNIT
description: Keystone Property Trust said yesterday that it had bought a warehouse and distribution complex in Allentown, Pa., for $56 million from a unit of J. P. Morgan Chase, to add to its investment in industrial properties. Keystone, a real estate investment trust, bought the complex, Westpark Business Center, a property with 11 buildings and 1.4 million square feet. Keystone developed several of the buildings and had leased and managed them for J. P. Morgan Investment Management, the company said.

title: In Marketing, Much Wheat and More Chaff
description: For Madison Avenue, the September terrorist attacks provided a devastating blow  and also a chance to shine. A few advertising campaigns in recent months have more than risen to the occasion.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Interest Rate Cut
description: Taiwan's central bank unexpectedly cut its key lending rate by an eighth of a point to a record low at its quarterly policy meeting as it sought to help the ailing economy, which is suffering its worst slump since the 1970's. The Central Bank of China cut the key rediscount rate, charged to commercial lenders for 10-day loans, to 2.125 percent, according to a statement released after the meeting. Taiwan's economy contracted 4.2 percent in the third quarter from a year earlier as exports tumbled, falling into its deepest recession since the 1970's. A Central Bank governor, Perng Fai-nan, said after the meeting that the government would ''continue to maintain a loose monetary policy next year,'' an indication that the bank was more concerned about economic growth than about Taiwan's weakening currency.

title: Official Vows All Families Of Victims Will Get Aid
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master of the multibillion-dollar federal fund set up to compensate victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said yesterday that he would ensure that the fund left no eligible family empty-handed, even if a strict application of the fund's rules might have produced that result.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Turnout Is Heavy
description: There were long lines at polling stations for the most competitive election in the country's history, with 11 candidates vying to succeed President Frederick Chiluba. Earlier this year, Mr. Chiluba tried to change the constitution in order to run for a third term, but the move prompted widespread protests and when he abandoned the effort a host of hopefuls jumped at the opening. Because of the long lines, voting continued into the night beyond the scheduled poll closing times. Some delays in delivering ballots were reported but heavy rain, common at this time of year, held off in most places, prompting a higher turnout than expected. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Another New York Example of the Kindness of Strangers
description: As one ambulance after another wailed past, Melody Belkin switched on the car radio. Plane crashes into tower. At that moment, she was under New York Harbor in the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, driving directly toward the World Trade Center. In the back of the car, her two small children read the spinning lights with different eyes. Ava, 22 months, laughed giddily. Noah, age 4, panicked and vomited.

description: With concern growing about ree trade and continental security, the economy of Canada has become so rigidly synchronized with that of the United States that if America stumbles, they both fall, and cannot regain their feet alone.

title: Well-Earned Obscurity Eludes Bach Scion
description: Peter Schickele has founded a career on the observation that as seriously as the classical music world takes its music (and itself), its audiences have a sense of humor and are happy to laugh at their own musical pieties. The P. D. Q. Bach concerts that Mr. Schickele has been presenting since 1965 are built of musical parodies wrapped in a skewed vision of a particular kind of musicology. The musicology in Mr. Schickele's cross hairs is the monomaniacal devotion to unknown composers of past centuries, many of them unworthy of the time, effort and research grants lavished on them.

title: Longer Holiday Season Helped Sales at Malls
description: An extra day of spending and sharp increases in home furnishings and home entertainment system sales helped rescue sales at malls this season, according to a report released yesterday by the International Council of Shopping Centers.

title: Shaw Fixes the Balkans in a Gimlet Eye
description: It's war in the Balkans again, but this time the only casualties are the pretensions of the participants and the illusions of their adoring admirers. It is of course ''Arms and the Man,'' George Bernard Shaw's 1894 comedy based on a brief war nine years earlier between Serbia and Bulgaria. Shaw did not give a hoot about that war or the combatants, but the Balkans were still remote enough then to let him use the tiff to lampoon patriotism and mock the folly of warfare altogether.

title: Relentless Ferguson Will Start For Jets
description: They call him Angry Man. And while Jets safety Nick Ferguson is only mildly irritated when his nickname is revealed, he embraces the sort of fearless tackling that has earned him the name from teammates and, earlier in the season, a rare public rebuke from Coach Herman Edwards. After all, it is Ronnie Lott's philosophy that Ferguson has absorbed: ''When in doubt, just hit everybody,'' Ferguson repeats. ''If you hit everybody, everybody is on the ground.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Air Traffic Congestion Plan
description: In a move to reduce congestion in the sky, flights heading into Newark and La Guardia Airports from the south will now avoid crossing paths over Raritan Bay, under new, more direct approaches, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday. The new approaches, which were put into use yesterday, were devised after a study of seven bottlenecks identified by the F.A.A. in October 2000 within the New York-Chicago-Washington region, said James Peters, an agency spokesman. There were no complaints of additional aircraft noise eight hours after the new routes went into effect, Mr. Peters said.

title: The U.S. Must Strike at Saddam Hussein
description: Within hours of the Sept. 11 attacks, President Bush said, ''We will make no distinction between the terrorists who committed these acts and those who harbor them.'' From that first statement, Mr. Bush shaped a grand strategy for the war on terrorism that is as transforming of American policy as was Ronald Reagan's pledge to consign an ''evil empire'' to the ''ash heap of history.'' It breaks with the past by taking aim at states harboring terrorists as well as at terrorists themselves. It is why we have destroyed the Taliban regime in Afghanistan even as we hunt down Osama bin Laden himself. It is why the war against terrorism cannot be won if Saddam Hussein continues to rule Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEN, MARJORIE FETERSON
description: WIEN-Marjorie Feterson. Sisterin-law of the late Lawrence A. Wien, 87, passed away on December 25. Miami Beach was her home for 66 years. She was born in New York City, May 8, 1914. She met her future husband Leonard A. Wien at a Pi Lambda Phi Fraternity party at New York University in 1930, and they were married June 5, 1932. In 1935 the young couple moved to Miami Beach. Marjorie and Leonard quickly became involved in projects that founded many charitable institutions in South Florida. They helped raise funds for the creation of Mt. Sinai Hospital. Serving in many capacities at the hospital, she became President of the Women's Auxiliary. In 1987 Marjorie and Leonard gave the initial gift for the founding of the Wien Center for Alzheimer's Disease and Memory Disorders. Marjorie became a charter member and proud wearer of the Lion of Judah in 1972 at the Greater Miami Jewish Federation. She was a longtime member of Westview Country Club, the Jewish Museum of Florida, the Cancer Lifeline at Mt. Sinai, and the United Way of Dade County. She & Leonard are Founders of the University of Miami, and the Sylvester Cancer Institute, the Miami Jewish Home for the Aged, Golden Angels of the Jackson Memorial Foundation, and supporter of the Miami City Ballet, the New World Symphony, and Brandeis University. Marjorie is survived by her loving husband and dearest friend of 69 years, Leonard A. Wien, by her children Carole Langer (Marshall), Josephine Kenin (David), and Leonard A. Wien, Jr. (Barbara), by eight grandchildren, and 13 great grand children. She is also survived by her sisters-in-law Irma (Bernard) Hein, Ruth (Lawrence) Wien, and Deborah (Bernard) Feterson, nieces Claire (Richard) Morse, Enid (Lester) Morse, Isabel (Peter) Malkin, Barbara (Sidney) Wien, Lois Wien Pick, Mickey (Jerry) Balash and many cousins. Services will be held at Temple Beth Sholom, Miami Beach at 11 A.M. on Friday, December 28, 2001.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Crowding In Homeless Shelters
description: Milwaukee's homeless shelters its only operating overflow shelter have exceeded their capacity, the chairman of the Milwaukee Emergency Shelter Task Force, Joseph Volk, said. It is the first time the 30-bed overflow shelter, created in 1998, has run out of room. The city's other overflow shelter, run by the American Red Cross, is closed for renovation until March. The task force said the city has about 900 beds. The Interfaith Conference of Greater Milwaukee is planning to provide temporary beds at a church. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

The film begins with shots of big-city building exteriors, a taxi roof light, a cigarette in close-up. Mr. Goldberg's voice-over sets the mood, to say the least: ''There wasn't particularly anything to do that week, but then there never was in the city that's always sleeping. A familiar voice was telling me a story, one I had heard too many times before.''

title: How to Try a Terrorist
description: The Bush administration is about to release procedural rules for its proposed military tribunals that are much fairer than originally feared. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld is considering dropping some of the disturbing provisions contemplated in the White House's November order, such as the ability of the tribunals to operate largely in secret, and to have a two-thirds majority of presiding officers sentence defendants to death. The Pentagon deserves credit for responding to some of the serious concerns of civil libertarians, legal scholars and the military's own jurists. But a better response would be to try suspected terrorists under the normal American criminal justice system.

title: 'Reaching for Glory': The Workings of Lyndon Johnson's Mind
description: Oct. 14, 1964, is a very bad day for Lyndon Johnson . With only three weeks left in his race against Barry Goldwater , his personal lawyer, Abe Fortas , calls to report that the president's longest-serving aide, Walter Jenkins, has been arrested for performing oral sex on another man in the basement pay toilet of a Washington Y.M.C.A. An incredulous Johnson immediately takes charge of damage control. He directs Fortas to force Jenkins's resignation and to spirit damaging files from Jenkins's White House safe; orders the F.B.I. to produce an official report declaring that Jenkins is not a national security threat; asks the Pentagon to scour Jenkins's military reserve file for positive comments from his commanding officer, Barry Goldwater; urges the attorney general to intensify a bribery investigation of Goldwater's running mate, William Miller ; coaches the first lady on how to secretly assure the Jenkins family that its financial future will be secure; and commissions a poll on the scandal's impact from his private pollster. Johnson suspects a Republican frame-up and fears the Jenkins arrest will cost him the presidency. ''Every farmer in the country is upset about it,'' he tells Fortas. ''It could mean . . . the ballgame.''

title: Reporters in Afghanistan: Fear, Numbness and Being a Spectacle
description: On the day that I entered Afghanistan from Iran, driving for three hours over 60 miles on a broken road, I saw camel herds roaming the desert. I saw many men sitting beside villages raised from dust, and boys lining the road like a welcoming committee. But I saw only a few women, and hardly any girls, an absence that set the pattern for what was to come. In the villages, they were mostly behind walls. In the city of Herat, they were behind burkas, reduced to faceless ciphers. Two decades of war had cemented the marginalization of women. They had been excluded even from the destruction that had become this society's central narrative.

title: SNAP-ON, A TOOLS CONCERN, TO PAY SPX $44 MILLION

Snap-On, which makes tools for the automotive maintenance industry, said it would set aside $27.9 million, or 48 cents a share, against fourth-quarter earnings to pay the after-tax cost of the arbitration award. The dispute started in 1996, when Snap-On, which is based in Pleasant Prairie, Wis., accused SPX of infringing its patents and improperly hiring away an executive from the Sun Electric Corporation, a company that Snap-On bought in 1992. SPX, of Muskegon, Mich., countersued, accusing Snap-On of infringing on its patents.

title: Selling the Forests
description: Trees are an important natural resource for many poor countries. A well-managed forest can provide permanent income and environmental protection. But unlike resources like oil and gas, timber is easy to steal. In too many nations, illegal loggers protected by corrupt officials are selling off forests for personal gain. Their logging has been so voracious that forests in Liberia, Cambodia, Indonesia and some other nations may be effectively bald in 10 years. In Cambodia, the international community has begun to impose controls on illegal logging. Despite mixed results, the program has shown enough promise to suggest that stronger measures might be able to preserve endangered forests.

description: A Beijing court sentenced to death a former manager for China's national airline, Air China, who was convicted of embezzling $3 million. It was not clear whether Yang Ning, formerly deputy head of the airline's finance department, had appealed, but appeals are rarely granted in capital cases. Death sentences are usually carried out immediately after final judgment. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: CLOTHING RETAILER SEEKS TO CLOSE 48 STORES
description: The Casual Male Corporation, the biggest specialty retailer of large-sized men's clothing, asked a bankruptcy judge yesterday for permission to close 48 unprofitable stores and hold sales at the locations. The company, based in Canton, Mass., sought Chapter 11 protection in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan on May 18, listing $299.3 million in assets and $244.1 million in debts. The retailer, formerly called J. Baker Inc., sells apparel and accessories at 606 stores in 47 states under several names including Repp Big & Tall and Casual Male Big & Tall. If approved, the 48 closings would begin on Jan. 20.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: President Speaks Out On Rape
description: In his New Year's address, President Thabo Mbeki urged people to end the silence and indifference that have helped to allow rape, particularly of children, to plague the country. Mr. Mbeki praised the country's progress in many areas but said more had to be done on crime. A number of child rapes over the last couple of months have focused attention on what Mr. Mbeki called ''a matter on which both government and the people have to act together.'' Henri E. title: The Chicken Light
description: I wake up sometimes at night, 2 or 3 o'clock, and walk to a window that looks out over the pasture. Some nights the moon is high in its December arc, so different from the angle it cuts through the sky in summer. Its light falls like a pale shadow among the white birches on the hillside. But on nights when the sky is hidden by clouds, when I can almost feel my pupils dilating in the search for a reference point outdoors, I find myself turning to a flat panel of light that shines out along the fenceline. It comes from a bulb in the chicken house that clicks on automatically at 1:30 in the morning. Dawn comes abruptly to the chickens. I imagine them blinking at reveille on their roosts.

title: In Raphael Exhibition, Women Do the Talking
description: An exhibition by Raphael is a rarity. This High Renaissance master's most grandiose works, his large religious frescoes in the Vatican, cannot travel, while museums lucky enough to own some of his 80 or so extant oils are famously reluctant to lend them. Even for the 500th anniversary of his birth in 1983, Italian museums chose to highlight their own Raphaels rather than join forces in a megashow.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the appointment of Michael Hammond as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts misstated a change in the size of the National Council on the Arts, a presidentially appointed group that evaluates grant applications, and misstated its timing. The number of council members went from 26 to 20, not 20 to 26; the change was enacted in 1997, not in 1996.

title: Inrange Chief Executive Resigns Posts
description: The Inrange Technologies Corporation, the networking- and switching-equipment maker spun off by the SPX Corporation, said today that its chief executive and president, Greg Grodhaus, had resigned.

title: Solich Makes His Stand Before the Title Game
description: Frank Solich did not actually say Colorado or Gary Barnett, but the words were implied. Solich, the Nebraska coach, had to defend once again the presence of his Cornhuskers in Thursday's Rose Bowl against Miami for the national championship. He remained polite and diplomatic, but the debate seemed to be wearing on him.

title: Dominican Lawmakers' Move Denounced as Power Grab
description: Ignoring warnings of a constitutional crisis and the possibility of creating an illegitimate legislature, lawmakers in the Dominican Republic are planning to meet soon for a vote that could extend their terms in office by two years.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Federal Budget Approved
description: Hoping to distance itself from the economic chaos in neighboring Argentina, the Brazilian government has won approval of its $118 billion budget for 2002 in near-record time. President Fernando Henrique Cardoso had expressed concern that any delay in passing the budget would make foreign investors and lenders wary, but persuaded Congress not to consider dozens of amendments offered by the left-wing Workers Party, including one that would have raised the minimum wage 11 percent. As approved, the budget calls for a surplus equivalent to 3.5 percent of gross domestic product, which is in line with commitments made to the International Monetary Fund in August in return for a $15 billion loan.

title: Corrections

title: Land of Alluring Beauty, Contradictions and Death
description: After a two-hour flight from Tajikistan, the helicopter touches down in the Panjshir Valley, the spiritual and military stronghold of the Northern Alliance, the rebel group fighting the Taliban. It carries the alliance's foreign minister and a group of journalists. It is Sept. 25, two weeks after the attacks on the United States.

title: Funeral Company Manager, Upset by Suit, Is Found Dead
description: The manager of four funeral homes in southern Florida whose owner is being sued over accusations of desecrating remains at its cemeteries has been found dead in his parents' garage, apparently a suicide, the police say.

title: Beliefs; How should time be lived? A professor sees a billable-hours culture, and religious antidotes.
description: As visions of sugarplums give way to images of Father Time bearing his scythe or of bouncing babies clad in sashes labeled ''New Year,'' no one is surprised to encounter religious reflections on the meaning of time.

title: U.S. FORCES FACING LONG AFGHAN STAY, PRESIDENT ASSERTS
description: President Bush said today that he expected American troops to remain in Afghanistan for ''quite a long period of time'' to flush out remaining Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters and to interrogate, fingerprint and process more than 6,000 prisoners of war.

description: As wary New Yorkers prepared for New Year's Eve festivities, police officials yesterday promised an elaborate security effort for Times Square that is to be broader and more vigilant than their millennial celebration plan.

description: NOONEY-Edward, J. Passed away December 26, 2001. He is survived by his wife Edna, his sister Gladys, brother-in-law Kennith. Brother of the late George. description: Trying to seal an 11th-hour deal on one of his most cherished projects, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had entered into tentative deals with the New York Yankees and the New York Mets to build stadiums for a combined $1.6 billion in the backyards of the teams' current ballparks.

title: SUNRISE ASSISTED LIVING PLANS TO SELL 14 PROPERTIES
description: Sunrise Assisted Living Inc., which provides homes for people with Alzheimer's disease and memory impairment, will sell 14 properties for $223 million to pay off debt and invest in building new properties. Twelve properties, worth $198 million, are being sold to Macquarie Capital Partners, a real estate investment firm, Sunrise said. Sunrise, which is based in McLean, Va., will manage all 14 properties under long-term management contracts. Sunrise said the other two properties were being sold to Christopher Place Inc. for $25 million. Separately, the company said it had obtained $167 million in financing from Glaser Financial and GMACC. The loans were sold to Fannie Mae.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inquiry Into Nuclear Tests
description: Scotland Yard is investigating a claim by the widow of a Royal Air Force pilot that her husband and other fliers were used as ''guinea pigs'' during nuclear tests in the late 1950's by being exposed to deadly levels of radiation. Shirley Denson told specialist crime squad officers that her husband, Squadron Leader Eric Denson, was ordered to fly through mushroom clouds from bombs detonated on Christmas Island in the Pacific in 1958. Mrs. Denson said many of the fliers fell ill, including her husband, who committed suicide in 1976. Warren Hoge (NYT)

They prepared their largest player, Felton Spencer, for major minutes in tonight's game. They thought a battle was going to take place in the paint, and they entered Gund Arena ready to bang.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: More Political Violence
description: The authorities have accused members of the leading opposition party in the killing of a 41-year-old supporter of President Robert Mugabe whose beaten body was discovered on Tuesday, the state-controlled newspaper reported. Tensions between Mr. Mugabe's party and the opposition are growing with the approach of the presidential election, which is scheduled for March. The opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, has accused government supporters in the killings of four of its members in recent days. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

Brother of Arthur. Proud grandfather of Laurel, Jake, Elizabeth, Alex, Neill, Justin, Sam and Catherine. A life-long New Yorker devoted to family and community. His commitment to the law, the Jewish community, the arts and human rights was extraordinary. His strength, wisdom and humor will live with us always. Contributions in his memory may be made, in lieu of flowers or other expressions of sympathy, to the American Jewish Congress, City Center 55th Street Theater Foundation, International Center of Photography or the Squadron Program in Law, Media & Society at Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Fund Eases Restrictions
description: Unit Trust of India, the country's biggest mutual fund manager, will increase the number of units that investors in its flagship fund may sell when it lifts its six-month freeze on redemptions on Jan. 1. Unit Trust will allow investors to redeem as many as 5,000 units, up from 3,000, at a price set earlier. The government will compensate it for any difference between the declared net asset value and the repurchase price, the finance ministry said. Redemptions were suspended on July 2 after an investigation of possible fraud by the fund's managers set off massive withdrawals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kremlin Foe To Quit
description: The president of the republic of Ingushetia in southern Russia, home to perhaps 150,000 refugees from the war in neighboring Chechnya, said he would resign by year's end because his two terms in the job were ''more than enough.'' Ruslan Aushev has been sharply at odds with the Kremlin over the lack of federal support for refugees and over Russia's conduct of the war against separatist rebels in Chechnya, which has ravaged much of the civilian population. Should the government's current policies continue, he told the Interfax news service, ''there will be no stability here for the next 10 years.'' Michael Wines (NYT)

title: How to Define a Muslim American Agenda
description: The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 must foster a fundamental rethinking about the American Muslim agenda. And many believe that this connection, and consequent religious profiling of Muslims, is the result primarily of the lack of knowledge among non-Muslim Americans of Islam.

Toniah Durham, a high school senior and single mother from the Bronx, was shopping with friends, taking advantage of the post-Christmas sales to buy socks with silly patterns.

title: ASTRAZENECA SEEKS APPROVAL OF CANCER DRUG
description: The drug maker AstraZeneca has asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve Iressa, a cancer treatment that the company predicts will have sales of more than $1 billion. The filing asks the regulator to approve the drug to treat advanced non-small-cell lung cancer. AstraZeneca is looking for a way to make up for lower revenue from Prilosec, an ulcer treatment that accounts for about 40 percent of its sales. Prilosec may soon face cheaper generic rivals. Iressa is being studied for the treatment of breast, colo-rectal and gastric cancers, the company said. The F.D.A. has given Iressa a fast-track designation, which may allow the agency to expedite its review.

title: LENNOX PLANS TO LAY OFF 340 OF ITS WORKERS
description: Lennox International, which makes heating and air-conditioning products, said yesterday it would lay off 340 employees to reduce expenses and would report a fourth-quarter loss because of lower sales and costs related to the job reductions. Lennox will have $32 million in costs before taxes in the fourth quarter and $8 million in the first quarter related to the job cuts. The company expects to save $7 million before taxes starting in the second quarter and $11 million a year beginning in 2003 from the layoffs. The company, based in Richardson, Tex., said there was lower demand for air-conditioners and heat pumps in October.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: President Fires Banker
description: In a dispute that centers on how much of a new parallel emergency currency the government should emit, the interim president, Adolfo Rodrguez Sa, yesterday ordered David Expsito, the president of the country's most important state-run bank, Banco de la Nacin, to step down. When he took office on Sunday, Mr. Rodrguez Sa announced that the new currency, the argentino, will circulate alongside the American dollar and the Argentine peso, which have the same nominal value. But he faces widespread fears that the new currency will cause inflation, concerns that grew after Mr. Expsito earlier this week proposed that the government put the equivalent of $15 billion of the new currency into circulation.

title: Pilgrimage to New York City: Paying Respects and Spending Little

The city is desperate to attract visitors to spend money, especially downtown, where businesses have been suffering since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. But the biggest tourist attraction downtown, and probably in the city, is the site of that attack. And the thousands of people who visit it every day are proving to be tourists of a sort that the city has never seen before.

title: The Story of Islam's Gift of Paper to the West
description: The paper on which these words are printed comes to you courtesy of Islamic civilization. Not directly, of course. Paper was invented in China around the first century. But it was Muslim merchants traveling the Silk Road in the eighth century who first brought the light, thin, pliable stuff west. And it was through Islamic culture in North Africa that paper arrived in medieval Europe, where it took on an explosive life.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Fishing Dispute Ended
description: South Korea and Japan have patched up a dispute over fishing rights in time for the World Cup soccer finals that the two countries are sponsoring in June. South Korea agreed not to fish next summer in waters off the southern Kuril Islands, an area in dispute. Japan, claiming sovereignty over the islands, threatened to deny Koreans the right to fish in an exclusive economic zone off Japan. In return for Korean compliance, Japan said Koreans could fish in the zone off Japan. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: ORACLE, SOFTWARE MAKER, PLANNING LAYOFFS OF 800
description: The Oracle Corporation, the database-software maker, plans to lay off as many as 800 employees, or 2 percent of its work force, to cut costs by reducing duplicate positions in consulting and sales. Oracle, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., has been trying to pare costs by cutting jobs and automating business with its own software. The company is reorganizing its North American consulting unit after Jay Nussbaum, executive vice president, left last month to join KPMG Consulting Inc. The company's services business, which includes technical support and consulting, made up 65 percent of Oracle's $2.36 billion in sales in the November quarter.

That means a sizzling skirt steak at El Gauchito restaurant, a cup of steaming mat with flaky vigilantes at the Ro de la Plata Bakery and a haircut from Carlos Liberti's barbershop. Dry cleaning employees have complained of fumes in their workplace, while customers have noticed residual odors in their clothes and worried about the impact of the chemical not only on their wardrobe, but also on their skin.

title: Puttin' On The Blitz
description: It may be that when war comes to fashion magazine editors, as it has now and as it did in 1938 to Audrey Withers at British Vogue, the best way for those ladies to stay au courant would be to volunteer as fire-service drivers, transporting soldiers. That's exactly what Withers, who died in October, did evenings. And she wore a gas mask doing it, while producing by day a magazine unflinchingly of its time and place. Her ascension to editor in chief was a bit like a game of 10 little Indians; one editor became sick, another returned to America, and there she was with her skeletal staff trying to make fashion make sense in insensible times. Paper shortages meant a subscriber literally had to die before someone else could sign on, and Vogue was only available by subscription.

description: Elaine Dannheisser proved that art collectors can be as vivid as the artists they collect. A blunt, unsubtle woman, she often recalled her days as a housewife who had so little social standing that dealers like Mary Boone refused to sell her a painting. But who could doubt her persistence? In 1996, she donated some 75 works to the Museum of Modern Art; it was the largest cache of contemporary art ever given to the museum.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WESTERNS took a turn for the psychological when Henry King made THE GUNFIGHTER (1950). Gregory Peck is at his finest as the laconic Jimmy Ringo in this grim, gripping, poignant story that reworks and deepens the familiar tale of an aging top gun who yearns to hang up his pistol. But young punks can't resist literally taking a shot at a man weary of gunplay, haunted by his past, all too aware that time is running out and seeking only to be reunited with his little boy. The screenplay by Andre de Toth and William Bowers earned an Academy Award nomination - Friday at noon on AMC.

title: Many Give, But All Receive
William Harry Thompson: The Stair Climber
description: Capt. William Harry Thompson never took the elevator. He taught at the court officers' academy on the 12th floor at 123 Williams Street. Every morning, Captain Thompson, 51, would walk up the stairs to the academy. If he went out to lunch, he would climb the stairs to go back to work. When he would take the recruits, most of them less than half his age, out for runs three times a week, they would climb the stairs after the runs were over. He would be the only one not out of breath.

title: Slowing the Search, Reading the Tea Leaves, Securing the Skies
description: Osama bin Laden's trail in Afghanistan has gone cold. His fighters of Al Qaeda have faded from Tora Bora. There are no signs that they left behind important clues to future terrorist attacks, and the American-backed effort to search the caves that had been their last stronghold has lost its once urgent priority.

title: Hunt for bin Laden Loses Steam As Winter Grips Afghan Caves
description: The American-backed effort to comb the caves of Tora Bora for signs of Osama bin Laden, his fighters and intelligence on terrorist attacks that might be in the works has made little progress and seems to be fading as a top priority, American and Afghan officials said today.

This prompted designers at the Van Alen Institute to ask what could be done to make this bottleneck more friendly, even pleasant, to humans.
