title: An American Minimalist Who Can Stir the Soul
description: ONE of the most intractable myths of the classical tradition is that Western art music is ''autonomous,'' heroically transcending the context that nurtures it and lacking any genuine social function. It's hard to see how anyone could take this notion seriously after Sept. 11. Within days of the attacks, memorial events were held in concert halls throughout the country, vividly confirming an often forgotten attribute of classical music: its ritual power. I recently spoke to a friend about what we'd been listening to, post-apocalypse. At the top of his list was Arvo Prt, the Estonian composer known for his haunting settings of Christian texts. At the top of mine was Ingram Marshall. To which my friend replied, ''Ingram who?''

title: NUMBERING HIS DAYS; The Rudy Years
description: The Giuliani years were hard for jaywalkers, conceptual artists, squeegee men and school chancellors, among others. But, for the most part, the city flourished: Wall Street ran with the bulls, e-business (temporarily) helped fuel the city's economic growth, tourists seemed to outnumber residents, and the only thing Times Square seemed to need was the venerable Cyclone roller coaster from Coney Island. In December 1994, a year into his reign as a brawling Republican champion for a Democratic city, Mr. Giuliani promised: ''I'll tell the people of the city what I believe is in the best interests of the city, what I think is the truth, rather than what I think people would like to hear.'' In that spirit, we offer some eclectic truths from the past eight years, statistical snapshots that bookend Mr. Giuliani's reign.

She was born in New York City and lived there until moving to Sunrise, FL and then to Watsonville, CA. She was the mother of Phyllis Levine of Scott's Valley, California, Dr. David Satlof of West Hartford, CT & Ronald Satlof of St. Petersburg, FL. title: The Dark Excitements of 1971
description: TEN-BEST lists are for appointed film critics. The rest of us do what we can to like as many films as possible, and I find I can muster nine for 2001, without too much cheating. In no particular order, it goes: ''Hannibal,'' ''Faithless,'' ''Ghost World,'' ''Moulin Rouge,'' ''Conspiracy,'' ''The Deep End,'' ''Mulholland Drive,'' ''Last Orders,''''In the Mood for Love'' and ''Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring.'' Yes, ''Conspiracy'' was shown on HBO, so you could say it was television. But it looked and felt like a big movie, and ''Wit'' was HBO, too, and that nearly made my list. And yes, I excluded ''Apocalypse Now Redux'' (one of the great experiences), because I guessed that sticklers would say that was cheating.

title: Minimal Forces, Maximal Bach
description: JOSHUA RIFKIN is best known to early-music enthusiasts for having declared, some two decades ago, that the traditional Bach choir is a modern invention. Mr. Rifkin's radical conclusion was that Bach had designed the chorus parts in his cantatas and Passions to be performed by just the four or five solo singers who also take the arias and duets.

title: Bitten
description: When Joe Slowinski first visited Myanmar, he fell in love. The size of Texas, with snake-filled forests and mountains, Myanmar is a crossroads of Asiatic species, a biodiversity hot spot that was last thoroughly explored by the British in the 1940's. On his very first expedition, he found a new venomous snake. ''Finding a new cobra species is the ultimate discovery,'' he wrote a short time later.

As a teacher of English literature for over forty years at Barnard and Harvard, she touched and challenged thousands of students. A memorial celebration will be held later this winter. description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has very few regrets about his eight years in office -- in fact, the only thing he wishes he did is win his fight to abolish the Board of Education.

title: Private Sector; Thanks for the Hard Work: Layoffs Ahead
description: Much has been said about the insensitive ways that many dot-com companies dismissed employees last Christmas season, with no notice. Justin L. Jaschke, the chief executive of Verio Inc., which operates Web sites for businesses and provides Internet service, has tried to be more compassionate. In a two-page memo to employees signed by Mr. Jaschke and Verio's president, Alain Andreoli, and distributed just before Christmas, they thanked employees for improving the company's financial stability but warned them to expect job cuts in the new year. ''We understand the angst and uncertainty this news will cause,'' reads the memo, which was posted on a corporate-bashing Web site. ''We have chosen to be open with you about the additional restructuring to dispel rumors and speculation.''

title: The Catch
description: World Series, 1969, Game 3, Mets and Orioles tied at a game apiece. In the fourth inning, Orioles catcher Elrod Hendricks steps to the plate. He's a lefty swinger, so Tommie Agee, the Mets center fielder, shades him to right. Hendricks smacks one the opposite way, and Agee, with an impossible distance to cover, is off at the crack of the bat. Lunging back, he just gets the tip of his glove on the ball, and it's enough. Three outs. In the seventh, Agee would make another sensational grab. There were four future Hall of Famers playing that day, but the game belonged to a journeyman outfielder on a miracle team.

title: Philippine Troops Hunt Elusive Foes
description: It was dawn, and a lone guerrilla picked his way through the forest to draw water. A government soldier, waiting in ambush, rose quietly to his feet, took aim and threw a coconut.

Pagoda rooftops, the wings of mythological birds or carvings of flowers or animals are woven into the ornamentation, revealing more than a hint of Asian Buddhist or Hindu inspiration.

title: Brian P. Williams: Honest Abe From Kentucky
description: Brian P. Williams found stardom at Covington Catholic High School, in Kentucky. He won the "That's My Boy" award, given by northern Kentucky football coaches to the best scholar-player- leader (a prize now named after him). Columbia University recruited him for football. In New York, he acted as unofficial tourist bureau for visiting Kentuckians.

title: Filling Handel's House, Once Again, With Music
description: THE holiday lights burn extra-bright in Mayfair, dazzling from the windows of the chic, expensively turned-out couturiers that line the streets of this most fashionable area of London. They seduce the eye so effectively that it takes some effort to look above the street level of the shops and notice what remains of the red brick 18th- and 19th-century terraces these buildings used to be.

title: The Catch Of the Day
description: Piaget's new collection, Upstream, offers a claspless design that manages to avoid pinching your wrist. The watch pops open from the top, at 11 and 1, while unhinging from the bottom, at 5 and 7. Reminiscent of the door of a DeLorean sports car, the watch has been flying off shelves in Europe since July, when it was introduced there. One European head of state (the company reveals that much and no more) bought 50. The watch, which sells for $5,900 to $18,000, is available beginning this month at the Piaget store at 730 Fifth Avenue. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: A Bit of a Hurry For a New Year
description: It is not something most people do very often, wishing away time. But that is what is happening in the waning days of 2001.

title: Going Out of Business? They Can Help
description: ON Nov. 30, 125 conservatively dressed men and women gathered to bid on some of the choicest real estate in the metropolitan area. Because Lechters Inc., the housewares giant, had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, DJM Asset Management of Melville was conducting a ''going out of business'' auction of all 315 of its stores. The sale, held in Manhattan at the crowded offices of Lechters's lawyers, was a controlled and orderly event, evoking the low-key sophistication of Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: Rumbling Hooves In a Furious Game
description: Buzkashi is a frenzied contest dating back to the days of Genghis Khan in which teams of horsemen fight for control of a goat or calf carcass. It was Afghanistan's national game before the Taliban banned it. Now it has returned to Babrak's Field in Kabul. In a recent contest, the riders battled for honor, and money collected from the spectators.

Beloved husband of Rebecca (nee Shafran), father of Ethan Coven and Judy Green, brother of Grace Siegmeister and Bernice Grant, grandfather of Joanna DePorter, Seth Green, Martha Coven, and Emily Coven, great-grandfather of Hannah DePorter, Margo DePorter, and Daniel Green.

title: Closing the Trunk Lid On a Topsy-Turvy 2001
description: THINK back to 1998. Chrysler was the hottest company around, with fresh products, a can-do attitude and an $8 billion hoard of cash.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: This is the eighth incarnation of ''The Lives They Lived,'' our annual tribute issue, and it was probably the most difficult one to put together, for the all-too-obvious reason. In a year in which so many died together and horribly and right before our eyes, did it make sense to celebrate the lives of a chosen few?

title: Anthrax Resurfaces at a Manhattan Post Office
description: More than a month after the Morgan mail-processing center on the west side of Manhattan was thought to have been cleared of anthrax, additional traces of the lethal spores were discovered on one of its high-speed mail-sorting machines, postal officials said yesterday.

title: When Bad Things Happen to Good Children
description: When I was little, I was a Grimms girl. Not a Hans Christian Andersen girl.

title: Warily Adapting A Scary Book
description: TO adapt a novel for the screen, filmmakers almost always need to be ruthless. They must kill characters, lop scenes, eliminate one plot line and ratchet up another. So it's understandable, then, that Robert Nelson Jacobs, while writing a screenplay based on the highly acclaimed novel ''The Shipping News,'' had little desire to meet E. Annie Proulx, the novel's author.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, ALFRED STEELE
description: HUGHES-Alfred Steele. On December 9, 2001. Retired Greater New York YMCA employee whose career with the organization spanned 65 years. Steele served for five decades as the Administrative Secretary of the Flatbush YMCA Church League andfor over 40 years as the Brooklyn Board Secretary of the International Association of Approved Basketball Officials. He was a Trustee and Elder at the Flatbush Christian Church, Bethlehem United Church of Christ and All Souls Bethlehem Church. Service of Death and Resurrection to be held 11AM Saturday, January 5, 2002 at the Flatbush-Tompkins Congregational Church, Dorchester Road at East 18 Street, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowerse, contributions may be made to the Alfred Steele Hughes Foundation, C/O Flatbush YMCA, 1401 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11210.

title: Our Towns; Forget Peace on Earth. Just Stop the Back-Seat Bickering.
description: BY the time the Bermans and the Ehrlichs made it down from outside Monticello, N.Y., to New Roc City -- the closest thing to Mecca for mothers and fathers with youngsters to entertain for 11 straight days -- Robert Berman was ready to launch his daughter, Carly, 13, all the way back to the Catskills. Too bad the Space Shot ride was shut down for the winter.

description: ON a hipness scale of 1 to 10, the actor Scott Cohen ranks himself a zero. ''I didn't hang out with the hip,'' he said. ''I never went to clubs. I'd rather talk than dance.''

description: DESPITE a rebound in stock prices since Sept. 11, J. Dennis Delafield and Vincent Sellecchia, co-managers of the $190 million Delafield Fund, are being cautious.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Quick and the Dead , by Joy Williams. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.) Filled with wounded characters and hectoring spirits running loose in the desert Southwest, this novel revolves around a motherless 15-year-old girl who is an animal lover of the prickliest, most judgmental sort. The result is an "odd, intelligent, unsettling and sometimes spectacularly uningratiating" tale, Jennifer Schuessler said here last year. "Williams's language runs with virtuosity across a wide range, from dead-on vernacular to gorgeously, unabashed oracular."

title: Plan for a Bryant Park Carousel Comes Around Yet Again
description: Bryant Park is meant to exude a French charm. Its landscaping is formal, its promenades symmetrical. Even the small metal lawn chairs mimic those in Parisian parks and lend a refinement to the lunch-hour scene. Come spring, the park, at 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas, may also have a carousel. The Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, the private group that oversees the park, plans to set a modest carousel with a fabric tent top and a menagerie of seats on a graveled area on the south side of the park, near a bust of Goethe.

description: HARRISBURG, Pa.

title: Ariadne Tsairis, Gregory Cousoulas
description: Ariadne P. Tsairis, a daughter of Aphrodite Tsairis and Dr. Peter Tsairis of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Michael Cousoulas, the son of Maria and Michael Cousoulas of Newfoundland, N.J. The Rev. James C. Moulketis officiated at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Wyckoff, N.J.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; New London Is Bustling After Pfizer Complex Opens
description: THREE years ago when Pfizer announced it was going to build a $300 million, 790,000-square-foot research center in New London, it planned to occupy the complex in phases over several years. Instead, the three buildings, which opened last summer, are already filled, and the rest of the city is quickly changing as well.

title: Theodore Labrecque Jr., 70, Judge in High-Profile Trials, Dies
description: Judge Theodore J. Labrecque Jr., who presided over many highly publicized criminal trials in New Jersey, died Sunday at a hospital in Long Branch, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER-Richard. Today is your 55th birthday-37 away. Ever loved and missed, my precious Richie. Mom

title: Hank Soar, 87, Former Umpire and Football Back, Is Dead
description: Hank Soar, an outstanding two-way back for the football Giants, a coach in pro basketball and a longtime American League umpire, died Monday in Pawtucket, R.I. He was 87.

title: The Nation; Taking on Republicans, But Not Their Leader
description: AT long last, many Democrats say they can shed the conciliatory straitjacket that has constrained them since Sept. 11 and engage in genuine partisan politics. After all, 2002 is an important midterm election year. And now that the intense crisis environment has abated a bit, the Democrats may have an opening to criticize Republicans and not come off as unpatriotic.

title: Mississippi Gothic
description: In the landscape of the national imagination, Mississippi was once the heart of darkness, a faraway jungle where exploitation and evil coexisted under a ground cover of flowers as well as poisonous bramble. It was amid the fragrance of some honeysuckle vines around midnight on June 11, 1963, that Byron De La Beckwith, the descendant of an old slaveholding family, hid in a black neighborhood of Jackson and fired a bullet into the back of Medgar Evers, the state's outstanding civil rights advocate. And a tangled wood outside Philadelphia, Miss., was the killing field where, one year later, a beefy sheriff's deputy named Cecil Ray Price delivered three young civil rights workers -- Mickey Schwerner and Andy Goodman, two white Yankee boys; and a black Mississippian, James Chaney -- to be gunned down in the dark by a squad of Ku Klux Klansmen.

title: OPEC CUTS
description: Meeting for a record seventh time this year, OPEC agreed to trim production by 1.5 million barrels a day to bolster prices. The decision, which goes into effect on Tuesday, followed promises by rivals Russia, Norway and Mexico to also trim production. Since Sept. 11, the price of a barrel of crude has averaged $19.34; it recently fell below $19.

title: Man Arrested in String of Rapes in Brooklyn
description: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday on six counts of rape and one count of assault in a string of attacks on seven women, the police said last night.

title: Safety a Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: Drama That Moved From Stage to Page
description: The illustrator James McMullan is the master of the dramatic image that captures the emotional tone of a stage work. Starting Jan. 8, three dozen theatrical posters for Lincoln Center (many by Mr. McMullan) dating to the 1970's and representing productions like ''Contact,'' ''Carousel'' and ''Six Degrees of Separation,'' will go on view at the Gallery at Lincoln Center (underneath the Metropolitan Opera House), through Jan. 26.

title: Father Charged in Abuse
description: A Queens man was charged yesterday with assaulting his 4-month-old daughter, who was hospitalized in critical condition.

title: Lincoln, Inspiration For a Church Crawl
description: NO less a critic than John Ruskin called Lincoln Cathedral ''out and out the most precious piece of architecture in the British Islands.'' Yet this Gothic masterpiece is only a starting point for visitors to Lincolnshire who are inspired by churches. Southwell Minster, the most charming and perhaps least-known cathedral in England, is 25 miles away, just across the boundary in Nottinghamshire. And Lincolnshire possesses what Simon Jenkins, in his guidebook ''England's Thousand Best Churches (2000),'' calls ''the finest collection of medieval churches overall of any county in England.''

title: S.E.C. Inspection Finds Amex Rules Lack Teeth
description: The American Stock Exchange has listed many companies that do not meet its requirements, and it has not adequately informed investors about these companies' problems, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Private Sector; A Return to Extravagance by Chrysler
description: Amid all the invitations descending on the automotive media for the Detroit Auto Show next weekend, one is particularly intriguing. Chrysler has rented a 1929 red-brick firehouse near the show site, the Cobo Exhibition Center, and is turning it into a big party space where Dieter Zetsche, Chrysler's chief executive, and other senior managers will be tending bar. This is not the first time Chrysler has put on an extravagant party at the show. Two years ago, Chrysler turned an old warehouse into a swing-dance nightclub at a reported cost of $2 million. Given the rate at which Chrysler's fortunes are evaporating, the bartending practice might be useful in case any of the company's executives are looking for work soon. Micheline Maynard

title: Southern Comforts
description: Had Elvis been from Detroit, he would have still had a brilliant career. The difference between Northern Elvis and Southern Elvis would have come after the time of his death. In the North, his house would have been cleaned, sold and bought by other people who would have actually lived there. Perhaps they would occasionally say to guests at dinner parties, ''Did you know that Elvis Presley once lived in this house?'' But Elvis was from the South, which means that for the price of a ticket you can stand behind velvet ropes at Graceland and look at the sad shag carpet in the Jungle Room or drive down to Tupelo, Miss., and tour the little house where he was born. He was, after all, a poor country boy who drove a delivery truck, loved his mother and ate bad food, which means he had all the fundamental elements of Southern heroism. It takes a certain amount of storytelling to make a person into a myth, and that's something we've specialized in down here since Davy Crockett first cut his name into a tree. But as any good storyteller knows, the heroes we are most likely to root for are the ones who look like us.

title: Ideas & Trends; For These Artists, Characters Were Fate
description: WHO hasn't woken up early on a Saturday and screamed ''Yaaba Daaba Doo!'' along with Fred Flintstone as he slides down the tale of a dinosaur at the end of his workday? Or leafed through the Sunday paper to find the comics page featuring Hank Ketcham's Dennis the Menance, or George Gately's cool cat, Heathcliff?

description: THE economy may have slowed during 2001, but news in the business world didn't skip a beat. Among its highs and lows were many moments that were memorable for their importance, their humor or their sheer brazenness.

title: Personal Business; The New Year Is Bringing New Breaks for Taxpayers
description: THE passage of tax legislation this year has brought a reduction in most people's tax rates, along with rebate checks, and further breaks will kick in at 12:01 a.m. Tuesday.

title: Why the Best Action Is Often No Action at All
description: IN 2002, resolve to stick to your investment discipline, resisting any temptation to react to day-to-day events by making impulsive changes.

title: Portugal Is Losing a History Told in Bank Notes
description: For anyone who imagines that bank notes are just money, take a last look at the Portuguese escudo before it and 11 other European currencies are subsumed into the common coin of the euro.

title: Prague Rock
description: Milan Hlavsa was a young man in Prague who played the electric bass, and in the fall of 1968 he organized a rock band. It was called the Plastic People of the Universe, with the name in English instead of in Czech. The Czech Republic was in those days part of the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic, which was part of the Warsaw Pact, which was under the thumb of the Soviet Union, which was ruled by the Communist Party. Rock bands with English-language names faced an uncertain future in that environment. Hlavsa's Plastic People of the Universe began by playing covers of the more adventurous rockers from America, the Velvet Underground, the Fugs, the Doors, the Mothers of Invention and others. Then the Plastic People took up their own compositions. Their popularity grew. And the government, by now worried, stripped the band of its license to perform. The Plastic People were obliged to build their own equipment and to perform mostly in private. Sometimes they played at a farm owned by a dissident playwright, Vaclav Havel, when he wasn't in jail. In 1976, a particularly bad year, the band was arrested. The indictment cited lyrics of ''extreme vulgarity with an anti-Socialist and antisocial impact, most of them extolling nihilism, decadence and clericalism.'' Clericalism was a terrible accusation in those days. The Communist press railed against ''moral filth.'' But the authorities had gone too far. Havel and the dissident intellectuals in Czechoslovakia organized a petition in the band's defense, and this petition marked a turning point in the history of the Soviet bloc. The petitioners did not express a right-wing ideology, or a left-wing ideology, or any ideology at all. They merely called for the right to be oneself and to think one's own thoughts -- the right to be honest. Their argument was extremely moderate and reasonable, and it proved to be extremely difficult to oppose. The petition was called Charter 77. Some 1,300 people eventually signed, which was a lot. And in 1989, when the East bloc revolution broke out, the signatories of Charter 77 put together a political organization, and their organization overthrew the Communist Party. Did Milan Hlavsa and the Plastic People contribute to the revolution merely by being martyrs, or was their music itself a revolutionary force? ''The ironic thing about the Plastic People is that our music had absolutely no political message,'' Hlavsa once said in looking back. The music consisted of sardonic vocals on top of jeering, bass-driven rhythms, often as not on a single chord, with a guitar, saxophone and viola screaming hysteria overhead. But this sound matched the human rights argument perfectly. It was the sound of personal honesty, stripped of every adornment, without sentimentality, without posturing, without falsity. Milan Hlavsa had his days of glory. He and the band once performed at the White House for Presidents Havel and Clinton, two rock fans. But when he died of cancer, on Jan. 5, he was only 49. Whatever the specific cause of Hlavsa's cancer may have been, it is worth recalling that during the years of Communism, industries freely polluted the atmosphere without any of the inhibitions that come from public protest and that life expectancy sank accordingly. And so Hlavsa suffered, not just from police persecution. But the man did play the electric bass, and he refused not to play the electric bass, and those jeering rhythms of his told a truth, which turned out be unstoppably powerful.

title: Nibbling on Virtual Seeds as Winter Deepens
description: I DO a lot of catalog dreaming online these days, which isn't as cozy as curling up with the real thing, but surfing from black kale to rare fruit trees to miracle fertilizers has a definite stream-of- consciousness effect.

title: The Stadium-Stock Parallel
description: It is no secret that stadium naming rights have become a corporate kiss of death in the last couple of years. Enron Field in Houston, the Trans World Dome in St. Louis and PSINet Stadium in Baltimore are just three of the modern-day coliseums named for companies that have found new homes in bankruptcy court. (Conspiracy buffs will be saddened to know that the Trans World Dome, which was named after the now-defunct Trans World Airlines and sounded like something out of a bad science fiction movie, is now the Dome at America's Center.)

title: Birders, and Birds, Turn Out in Numbers
description: FOR serious birders all over the Hudson Valley, the weekend before Christmas meant hard work, and not just the kind that involves pushing through the shopping mall. But that work was rewarded by sightings of a record number of species of their quarry.

title: HIGH-RISK COVERAGE
description: One of the four companies that insure high-risk drivers in the state, Eagle Insurance Company, based in Edison, will withdraw from writing high-risk insurance next year. Eagle, which said it could not raise rates enough to make a profit, now provides car insurance for about 12,000 of the 100,000 drivers in the state categorized as high risk. The policies for those drivers will not be renewed when they expire.

title: A Contender In a City Of Spas
description: THE sprawling Century Plaza Hotel in the Culver City section of Los Angeles has long been a popular site for trade conventions and Hollywood award banquets like the recent Emmy party. In fact, as an Angeleno for the past 10 years, I have spent many hours in semiformal wear in its vast subterranean ballrooms. So when I learned that the hotel had completed a $70-million face lift this year that included an ambitious new Asian-themed spa and fitness center, I was intrigued.

title: Streetscapes/326 Spring Street; Fixture on the Block May Face an Upstart Neighbor
description: EVER since he moved in as a student in the 1970's, Richard Hayman has been restoring and researching his landmark early-19th-century house at 326 Spring Street. Now, as a developer plans an unusual apartment building next door using his air rights, Mr. Hayman, an editor, seaman and musician, is worried he may lose it all.

title: Just One Man Juggling the Two-Party System
description: THERE is a certain look a professional matre d'htel puts on when faced with a crisis in customer service. The corners of his eyes crease like a cheap linen suit, and his smile tightens much like the head of a snare drum. His jaw muscles turn knotty, and if the problem is truly severe, he will lean heavily on the word ''sir'' as though it were his one good leg.

title: Quiet! Dad Is Dusting His G.I. Joes
description: AT 33, Evan Bernard can't walk past a toy store without stopping in to assess its selection of action figures. Last month, Mr. Bernard, a New York-based director of music videos and commercials, was in Minneapolis shooting a video for Slayer, the heavy metal group, when he found his way over to the Mall of America.

title: Proving the Singular Value of a Voice in the Dark
description: IN explaining why he felt that an analyst should sit unobtrusively behind his patients' couch, Sigmund Freud explained that he did not want analysands to be influenced by his physical reactions and facial expressions. What is more, he added, ''I cannot stand being stared at eight hours a day (or longer) by others.''

title: Cynthia Motus-Wilson: Instiller of Love
description: Cynthia Motus-Wilson was a people person, according to her husband, William Wilson, and their daughter, Cynthia Motus-Chan. "She was very caring," Mr. Wilson said. "A small woman, five- foot nothing. But a heart bigger than Alaska."

title: 2001: LOOKING BACK; A Year of Champions: The Fastest, the Strongest, the Best
description: ARCHERY

title: Suffering Silently
description: Arthur Worsley had a simple, perfect ventriloquist's gimmick. His wooden figure, Charlie Brown, did all the talking. There was no give-and-take with the ventriloquist, no repartee. Throughout the act, Worsley stood silently by, mute as a dummy.

title: Boxes Are Only One Way To Distribute a Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Downhill? Cross-Country? Another Cup of Coffee?
description: THE sun was bright, bringing a pink glow to the very tip of Mont Blanc, the steep peaks around it ranging toward the horizon in snowy splendor, their points outlining the blue sky. The air through the half-open window in the old farmhouse was cool, but there wouldn't be snow till evening. What a day to ski. Thank God, I didn't have to.

title: In Mexico, Bitterness Is Sugar's Legacy
description: EVERY morning at dawn, through the winter and spring, the cutters of Crdoba come to the sugar cane fields.

title: Bit Player
description: Halfway through the last century, information became a thing. It became a commodity, a force -- a quantity to be measured and analyzed. It's what our world runs on. Information is the gold and the fuel. We measure it in bits. That's largely because of Claude Shannon.

title: Survivor's Gilt
description: You should have seen her in her prime. In the late 1960's, Priscilla Wilborn was all flash and trash, the saucy princess of Texas vamp. She had a mane of platinum hair and a closetful of tiny miniskirts and specially designed low-cut halter tops. Each spring at the Colonial National Invitational golf tournament in Fort Worth, hordes of men would gather around her just to get a peek at what they fondly described as her ''balcony.''

title: Life as a Blockhead
description: I met Melvin Burkhart two years ago, when he was 92 and I was 29. He was the last survivor of America's great sideshow era, having spent his life performing in circuses and freak shows of every size and reputation. He was generally billed as the Human Blockhead (a title he earned by hammering a massive steel spike up his nose, 14 performances a day). But he was also known as Melvin the Two-Faced Man, on account of his ability to smile on one side of his face while frowning on the other. He was also known as Melvin the Anatomical Wonder -- a great contortionist. I went to visit him on a road trip I gave myself as a special gift for my 30th birthday. I drove to Florida from New York to hear the story of his brilliant career.

title: STORMING THE CHUNNEL
description: About 500 asylum-seekers who live at a refugee camp near the French end of the Channel Tunnel made a break for England. In two waves, the men -- mostly Afghans, Iranians and Kurds -- broke the electric fence guarding the entrance. Some poured into the tunnel to be chased down by the French police. Others were captured in the barrage of tear gas laid down in the rail yards. Some ran for miles, but none reached the middle of the 30-mile tunnel -- where they would have met British officers with dogs. The incident prompted increased calls for the camp's closure. Donald G. McNeil Jr.

title: N.J. Transit Sees Future In the Past
description: In 1865, the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad carried anthracite from Scranton, Pa., to Hoboken. The freight of coal moved easily through Pennsylvania, but once it crossed the Delaware River, the trains had to slow down for the next 40 miles as the track undulated through the mountains and lakes of northern New Jersey.

title: Black Is the New Black
description: THE Thursday before Christmas was mild and sunny, yet if you squinted through the late afternoon sunlight, you might have discerned a somber pattern: At the Museum of Modern Art gift shop on Spring Street, three 50-ish women in black leather motorcycle jackets drifted past the felt coasters and bowls on the sale table. On Broadway and 44th Street, a rather conventionally dressed woman sported a black leather skullcap; a young man on West Ninth Street rushed by in black jeans, black T-shirt and black motorcycle jacket. This was not ''fashion'' black, but old-style urban black, the sort made by American companies like Schott and Walker.

title: Nicole Herb, Bradley Mann
description: Dr. Nicole Suzanne Herb, a daughter of Mary Herb and Dr. Robert Herb of Pittsburgh, is to be married tonight to Bradley William Mann, a son of Charlene and William Mann of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Colin L. Leitch, a pastor of the United Church of Christ, is to perform the ceremony at Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: A Phone Card You Don't Carry
description: Travelers can buy ''electronic phone cards'' with global access through a new Web site, www.card4anywhere.com.

title: BOAT MYSTERY
description: North Korea denied any connection to a boat with a crew of 15 sunk by Japan after it fired on Japanese Coast Guard ships in the East China Sea. But the touchy, secretive government in Pyongyang certainly got worked up, accusing Japan of ''brutal piracy and unpardonable terrorism of a modern brand that could be committed only by samurais of Japan.'' Its bellicosity may erode Japan's already weakening commitment to food aid and could result in more aggressive Japanese marine patrols. James Brooke

title: GIULIANI'S FAREWELL
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's official farewell address, given in a chapel near ground zero, was weighted with references to the Sept. 11 attacks, but he also managed to work in some jabs at critics and to defend his approaches to crime-fighting and homelessness. His calm, strong and compassionate response to the attacks drew national appreciation and overwhelmed the other aspects of his eight-year tenure, a mixed bag of reduced crime, budgetary responsibility and racial divisiveness.

title: Sheldon R. Kanter: Borough Switch Hitter
description: Alittle boy is born in Brooklyn on a late-July day in 1948, and though there are still plenty of innings left to play at Ebbets Field, and even a World Series to win, in his heart time has run out for the Dodgers. By the time he is old enough to count base hits, the boy, Sheldon R. Kanter, has turned to the Bronx, where Mickey Mantle is playing center field, and attached his affection to Mantle for keeps.

title: 'Wittgenstein's Poker'
description: On the evening of Friday, 25 October 1946 the Cambridge Moral Science Club -- a weekly discussion group for the university's philosophers and philosophy students -- held one of its regular meetings. As usual, the members assembled in King's College at 8:30, in a set of rooms in the Gibbs Building -- number 3 on staircase H.

title: Ideas & Trends; Minds Over Money
description: TO many, the idea that neuroses or depression could be diagnosed as precisely or treated as effectively as a broken leg or a burst appendix seems counterintuitive, even preposterous.

title: Fast Track Is a Drag On Chilean Trade Pact
description: BOTH sides deny it, but the record suggests that even before he has it, the very first effect of President Bush's coveted fast-track authority -- which is supposed to speed up trade negotiations -- has been to slow down a trade deal with Chile.

title: Syracuse Defense Too Much For Kansas State to Handle
description: With two losses before Labor Day, Syracuse did not have a promising start to the season, especially with road games against national powers like Virginia Tech and Miami still ahead. But with a 26-3 triumph today over Kansas State in the Insight.com Bowl before a crowd of 40,028 at Bank One Ballpark, the Orangemen (10-3) capped an impressive turnaround, winning for the 10th time in 11 games. Their only loss in that span was to undefeated Miami, 59-0.

title: NIGERIAN UNREST
description: The Dec. 23 murder of Nigeria's justice minister, Bola Ige -- considered one of the fathers of Nigeria's two-year-old democracy and a critic of aspects of the introduction of Islamic law, in northern Nigeria -- raised fears among the ruling circles. President Olusegun Obasango sent troops to the volatile southwest states of Oyo and Osun, where Mr. Ige was killed. A man confessed, but no motive was immediately announced. Marc Lacey

title: Maclovio Lopez: Falsely Gruff Exterior
description: People sometimes wondered why Maclovio Lopez, known as Joe, always wore sunglasses when his picture was taken. The answer: they weren't sunglasses at all. Hiding his eyes were photogray lenses, the same way his demeanor covered his heart.

title: The World; A Business Plan For Islam Inc.
description: TWO weeks after Osama bin Laden's operatives staged the Sept. 11 attacks, the Senate passed a bill approving a free trade agreement with Jordan, the first of its kind with an Arab nation.

title: Sheelagh Flanagan Peter Walsh
description: Sheelagh Moira Flanagan, the daughter of Mrs. Edward Leo Farrell Jr. of New York and the late Luis Flanagan, was married yesterday to Peter Duhagon Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Walsh of San Francisco. Msgr. Robert F. McCormick officiated, and Archbishop Edwin F. O'Brien, who oversees the archdiocese for the military services, took part in the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: A YEAR OF LAYOFFS
description: The number is round, but the pain is sharp: corporate America announced roughly a million layoffs in 2001. Since Sept. 11, more jobs were cut than in any full year from 1993 to 1997. ''There's never been downsizing on this scale,'' said John Challenger, of the recruiting firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. The pain is worst at Motorola, which is cutting more than 40,000 jobs, followed by Boeing, with 30,000, and two airlines, American and United, with 20,000 each. Hubert B. Herring

title: Social Security: Why Not Fix It?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Springtime Dreaming, Online
description: I DO a lot of catalog dreaming online these days, which isn't as cozy as curling up with the real thing, but surfing from black kale to rare fruit trees to miracle fertilizers has a definite stream-of-consciousness effect.

title: Jennifer Kelly, Roger Cortesi
description: Jennifer Ann Kelly, a daughter of Deborah Chisholm Kelly and James E. Kelly of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lt. j.g. Roger Shapley Cortesi, the son of Deborah Shapley Cortesi and Roger S. Cortesi of Washington. Msgr. John Mescall performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Family in New Rochelle.

title: James Murphy: Faithful to Family
description: James Murphy, a Cantor Fitzgerald trader, kept his eye on the basics. His family were his friends, and together they were a big crowd. He and his wife, Mary, had two children and were expecting a third. He had 10 brothers and sisters, between the ages of 44 and 30, and 13 nieces and nephews. Most of them lived within a 20-mile radius of the Jersey Shore.

title: Now in America, the Films of the Soviet Walt Disney
description: IF Russians of a certain age pooled their experiences of childhood in the Soviet Union, their collective memory would include the first time they saw a film by Alexandr Ptushko. American children had the animated antics of Walt Disney's cartoon characters; Russian children had the characters of Ptushko: richly textured animated puppets who inhabit a miniature land, beautiful fairy-tale queens and handsome, brave heroes who defend the motherland from outside invaders.

title: 'Wide Blue Yonder'
description: Beige Woman was saying Strong Storms. She brushed her hand over the map and drew bands of color in her wake. All of Illinois was angry red. A cold front currently draped across Oklahoma, a raggedy spiderweb thing, was going to scuttle eastward and slam up against your basic Warm Moist Air From the Gulf. The whole witch's brew had been bubbling up for the last few days and now it was right on the doorstep. Beige Woman dropped her voice half an octave to indicate the serious nature of the situation, and Local Forecast nodded to show he understood.

title: A Roster Of Awards Better Off Unawarded
description: MEASURED by its stock market action alone, 2001 was clearly a disappointment. But judge the year instead by the audacity of its corporate schemers, Washington scalawags and Wall Street rogues, and 2001 becomes tough to top.

title: William R. Johnston: Soccer and Football Whiz
description: For a while there, a large firefighter was walking around with one eyebrow. That was thanks to William R. Johnston of Engine Company 6 in Manhattan.

title: Foreign Troops Keep Burundi's Peace
description: Bullets have ended so many governments in this central African country that foreign troops have been invited in with the sole purpose of keeping its political leaders alive.

title: Roosevelt School District As Child of Neglect
description: It is disheartening to read [''Saving Roosevelt, or Killing It,'' Dec. 16] that in one of the wealthiest counties in the country, Nassau County, there is talk of dissolving the Roosevelt school district because of inadequate financing to maintain the school district. Can we allow this discrimination when there are so many good schools in Nassau County?

title: Political Memo; Opening Jan. 1: Mayor Bloomberg, Unedited
description: After eight weeks in which Michael R. Bloomberg immersed himself in what is almost certainly the fastest crash course in government in the history of the city, New Yorkers are about to see their new mayor unfiltered -- presented not through the television advertisements with which he defined himself for six months, but standing alone, starting with his inauguration speech on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, MELVIN
description: SLOAN-Melvin. Of Old Tappan, NJ; December 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father to Ronni and Peter Zlotnick, Ruby and Jeffrey Bodner, Rory and David Folender, and Rachel Sloan. Extraordinary stepfather to Jill and Evan Seigerman and Kelly Alpert. Loving brother to Cheri Dworkin. Devoted grandfather to Allison, Emily, Evan, Justin, Jamie, Jessica, Satchel, Lucien and Alexandra. Mel was a loving, giving and kind man who lived life to the fullest, and showed us all how to embrace each day. We are broken hearted and will miss the man with a heart of gold.

title: Unity Eludes Argentina's Governing Party
description: The Peronists are now back in power in Argentina after two tumultuous years in opposition. But with an emergency presidential election scheduled for early March, the party has no obvious leader and is split by factional disputes and unable to decide on a candidate.

title: Little Buzz In a Season Of Quiet Surprises
description: Every television season, one or two series sneak in under the radar screen and come out of nowhere to become hits. (''C.S.I.,'' last year's unhyped CBS crime drama, is now one of the country's favorite shows.) But never before has an entire season sneaked in the way it did this fall.

title: The Beauty Queen and the Beast
description: SEARCHING

title: Anchors Mattered Again, and 'Survivor' Didn't
description: A YEAR ago at this time, Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings and Dan Rather were roaming the Jurassic Park of television news, dinosaurs in a changed world of cable and the Internet. As with so many things, the terror attacks changed that, at least for the moment. On Sept. 11 and in the days after, the network news anchors assumed a central importance in the national consciousness, a position they hadn't filled for years. Each calmly held his network's round-the-clock coverage together, expressing the grief and shock the country shared while playing down the fear and panic that many people felt as well.

title: I.N.S. DETAINEES IN COUNTY PRISON
description: The Middlesex County Detention Center will hold up to 200 people charged with federal noncriminal immigration offenses beginning Tuesday in an agreement with the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The prison, which can hold 1,100 inmates, will receive $72 a day for each federal inmate. John Holl

description: To the Editor:

title: New Mayor's First Speech To Call for Belt-Tightening
description: When he stands before New York City as its newly elected mayor on Tuesday, Michael R. Bloomberg will call for sweeping sacrifices from all quarters of government, particularly the City Council, which will begin the new year with a gaping hole in the budget and a fairly novice body of members to deal with it.

title: Camera Captures Crisis on Flight 63
description: Jean-Claude Joly was sitting a few rows behind Richard C. Reid on American Airlines flight 63 from Paris to Miami on Dec. 22 when the plane erupted in confusion after Mr. Reid tried to light a fuse coming out of his sneaker. Mr. Joly, 62, the owner of a technology company in Toulouse, grabbed his digital camera and captured the scene in these photos, which he made available to The New York Times on Friday.

title: Habitats/149th Street Near Broadway; A Web Consultant Moves Close to Her Roots
description: LAST year at this time, Sandra Oei was living in a small apartment on the Upper East Side and commuting every morning to her office on Morton Street in Greenwich Village, where she was running an Internet consulting business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEYSER, HOWARD
description: PEYSER-Howard. We extend our sympathy to his beloved wife Joanne and his adored children Alison and Ross. And to all of his friends and family who will miss him so dearly. His warmth and friendship will be greatly missed. Steven, Wanda, Rachel and Tracy Lockwood

title: NO STATE SPENDING HALT
description: A judge denied a request last week by a New Brunswick activist to immediately halt state spending. Simeon Larson had filed a lawsuit seeking an immediate order to bar Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco from signing bills that spend money until the state Treasury Department completed an official accounting of state revenues. Superior Court Judge Neil Shuster denied the request for immediate action, but allowed the lawsuit to proceed. No hearing date has been scheduled. The state attorney general's office is seeking to have the lawsuit dismissed, saying it infringes on the separation of powers.

title: Friends Through the Lens
description: Louis Faurer and Robert Frank met in 1947 at Harper's Bazaar, where both were employed as fashion photographers. A Philadelphian in the process of moving to New York (and abandoning his wife and son), Faurer was eight years older than the 22-year old Swiss migr. But they quickly discovered a shared alienation from postwar America, along with a disdain for the cutthroat monde de mode.

title: Or Else; Caution: This Weapon May Backfire
description: ISRAEL and India have long suffered horrific terror attacks. But when they were struck again in recent weeks, they had a new precedent to follow, set by no less than the world's most powerful nation, as they considered how to respond. Following America's lead, and anticipating American support, each issued an ultimatum to the leaders of the land from which the Islamic militants came: crush the terrorists, or else.

title: To Be Young, Eager and Unwanted
description: IN May, I graduated from college with four years' worth of information, a half-dozen awards and a lot of self-confidence to go with a decent-sized ego. After taking a few weeks off, I started contacting employers from part-time jobs that I had during school. I thought they'd be thrilled that I was back in town and ready to roll up my sleeves full time. Instead, many said they just weren't hiring.

title: Ideas & Trends; In Death's Shadow, Valuing Each Life
description: WHAT is a life worth? What is each of the lives that were lost in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks worth?

title: Apulian Muscat Is Seductive
description: Dry and near-dry muscats are one of the wine world's undervalued splendors. The intricate 1997 Rivera Piani di Tufara Moscato di Trani, with the color of old gold and the smoothness of cashmere, is a great example of the genre. This seductive Apulian wine, which can double as an aperitif or a dessert, is tangy, honeyed and raisiny. Vino, 121 East 27th Street (Park Avenue), Manhattan, charges $18.

title: New Year Resolutions in a More Serious Vein
description: NEWTON, Iowa, Dec. 28  This year, like last year, and the year before that  and, well, every year he can remember  Ryan Shipley has a New Year's resolution: to stop biting his fingernails.

title: The Gulotta Legacy: His Version
description: IT has been a privilege and an honor to serve the residents of Nassau County for the past 14 years. Working with our residents since 1987, we have built upon our strengths and addressed our weaknesses. County property taxes have been controlled, the crime rate has been dramatically cut, unemployment is at an all-time low, commercial vacancy rates are at record lows and residential property values have soared. Today, Nassau County is a far better place to live, work and raise a family than it was in 1987.

title: Countdown to 2002
description: The meaning of the word ''rockin' '' may have changed over the last 30 years, but Dick Clark is still doing it -- to the sounds of the new century -- on ''Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve 2002.'' The three-part live event from Times Square begins at 10 p.m. on ABC with clips of the year's top music groups. From 11:35 to 1:05 performances by Blink 182, Bush, Pink and Busta Rhymes precede and follow the midnight countdown. The show wraps up with encore performances and scenes of Times Square until 2:05 a.m.

title: The Deadly Importance of Making Distinctions
description: ARCHITECTURE is a protagonist in the public realm. Often, it is called upon to enact the primal drama of loss and compensation. When the loss is great, compensation is often visualized in terms of civic grandeur. The losses this year were incalculable.

title: For Women, Slap Shots and Olympic Goals
description: THE first time Sue Merz met Julie Chu was about four years ago. At the time, Merz was presenting national championship medals to members of the Connecticut Polar Bears, a team she had also won a title with as a youngster playing in the USA Hockey girls' league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SECKLER, BEATRICE
description: SECKLER-Beatrice. Of Englewood, N.J. on December 28, 2001. Survived by David, Goldie, Amy, Andrew and Rachel Berkley. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, on Sunday, December 30th, at 3 PM.

title: An Industry Motivated, More Than Ever, By Fear
description: IT'S hard to look at film this year without regard to the impact of the most important event, the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. If the movies are where our hopes and dreams are expressed, we want to believe more than ever that somehow, these embodiments of our collective subconscious can heal the wound from a blow we never expected. And, in the backs of our minds, we find ourselves wondering if the movies we export -- the rousing, violent genre pictures that travel as well as Ford Focuses and Microsoft Word -- played a part in the attacks.

title: For Some, Lives in the Shadows Ended in Attack, Indiscernibly
description: Some illegal immigrants drown in boats on their way to America. Others die in the desert. Still others disappear in a different way -- swallowed by the thrill of America, never again to call their families back home. Very little of all this is ever officially recorded.

title: Questions Grow Over Usefulness Of Some Routine Cancer Tests
description: Medical researchers are increasingly questioning one of the most widely held beliefs in preventive medicine: that screening healthy people for cancer and catching it early saves lives.

Money & Business invited Martin Lipton, a founding partner of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, a law firm that specializes in representing corporate clients in takeovers, and Steven Koch, chairman of the mergers and acquisitions group at Credit Suisse First Boston, to talk about the current mood in the business and what it means for the future. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

description: George Smith did a lot of things that would make a mother proud. He worked his way through college. He landed a good job as a senior business analyst at SunGard Asset Management. He even became the deacon of his local church.

description: LIEBLER-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Liebler, associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1989.

title: ZAMBIAN ELECTIONS
description: The party that ushered in multiparty politics a decade ago faced a reckoning of sorts as the most competitive presidential election in the country's history was held. Whether the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, led by the departing incumbent, Frederick Chiluba, manages to hold on to the presidency, or ends up ceding it to one of the 10 other parties that fielded presidential candidates, the election is notable in a region where stepping aside still does not come easily. Henri E. Cauvin

description: BOOT-Claude. On December 28. Former model. Dear friend of John, Gene, David, Phyllis, Anthony, Doreen and Allison. She was also well loved by many others from the Art Students League. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St, NYC, Sunday, 12-4PM. Funeral mass Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Vincent de Paul Church.

title: Lost in Hoboken?
description: ELEVEN minutes after the first plane hit the north tower, Krishna Moorthy called his wife at work and left a message on her answering machine. He said he was evacuating the south tower -- and would call again when he made it out. Four minutes later, the second plane hit his building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUMB, PETER CARY
description: PLUMB-Peter Cary. Of South Burlington, VT died peacefully on Sunday, December 23, 2001. Peter was raised in Buffalo NY, the son of Ralph H. Plumb and Sally Getman Plumb. He is survived by his three children and their spouses, Peter Jr. and Susan Plumb of South Burlington, VT, William and Virginia Plumb of Bedford, NY, and Wendy and Douglas Corper of Wilton, CT; along with his five grandchildren. Peter was a longtime resident of Bedford, NY where he leaves many dear friends. He was an incredibly dedicated and loving father and friend. His children and grandchildren were the center of his life. His unconditional love and support was felt by all he came in contact with. A private service will be held in Burlington, VT. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY on Jan. 26, 2002 at 4PM. Interment will follow in the Plumb family plot in Gowanda, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of Chittenden and Grand Isle counties, Colchester, VT.

title: Memories And More
description: Every day the memorials continue, as they should, for the dead of Sept. 11.

title: Ba-Da Bang
description: Was Sir Fred Hoyle one of the most distinguished astrophysicists of all time, or was he a diehard speculator, a lover of hullabaloo and an embarrassment to consensual science -- almost a crank? Certainly, his groundbreaking research influenced every aspect of astronomy. At the same time, he admitted to ''aesthetic bias'' and to letting favorite theories become a ''sort of religion.'' For a man who claimed that the famed Archaeopteryx fossil in the British Museum of Natural History was a fake and that microbes rained down on earth as part of a possible seeding experiment by extraterrestrials, Hoyle won a great number of the most prestigious awards science offers.

title: When Bills For Water Are Murky
description: RECENT legislative changes that increase the time period during which New York City property owners can seek reimbursement for water overcharges have highlighted a mundane yet potentially costly aspect of property ownership.

description: IT has been a tough year for the corporate takeover business.

title: A Tricky Stick
description: The Slim Jim was created by Adolph Levis in Philadelphia in the 1940's. After an unsuccessful early career as a violinist and a failed effort to operate a string of tobacco shops, Levis and a partner had turned to the pickled-food trade, hawking pig's feet, cabbage and cucumbers to bars and taverns in and around Philadelphia. Pepperoni, he noticed, was becoming popular among his clientele, and he made an end run around the fad by creating a preserved meat product that, rather than curing for weeks, could be manufactured in a matter of days by a process of fermentation and hot smoking.

title: GUILTY OF TREASON
description: Vladimir V. Putin lamented the shortcomings of Russia's judicial system during a nationwide call-in program, a first for a Russian president -- and then the system handed up what many consider a prime example. A military tribunal convicted Grigory Pasko, a navy captain and military journalist, of high treason. The betrayal consisted of helping Japanese journalists prepare a report on the navy's dumping of nuclear waste at sea. Human-rights groups protested, as did some Russian politicians. Captain Pasko, sentenced to four years, appealed. Michael Wines

He was strikingly handsome, a former high school football star who had recently run a marathon in under three- and-a-half hours, and who made a very nice living as a foreign exchange trader at Carr Futures.

description: Dr. Charles Kenneth McSherry, a New York surgeon who pioneered a simpler way to remove gallstones and was a leading researcher into gallstone formation and cancer of the colon, died on Dec. 13 at New York Hospital. He was 70 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, DAVID CRESAP
description: MOORE-David Cresap. Of Cambridge and Truro, MA, died on December 27, 2001 after a long brave struggle. Deeply loved husband of Sally Falk; adored father of Nicola of Rochester, NY and Penelope of Belmont, MA; wonderful grandfather to Benjamin and Samuel of Belmont, MA; dear brother of Albert Preston of NYC and John Clark of Cashiers, NC. Historian of 19th C. British politics, gardener, floutist, baker, philanthropist. Retired Professor of History, UCLA; Fellow, Royal Historical Society; Associate, Center for European Studies, Harvard University; CoMaster, Dunster House, Harvard University, 1984-89; Lieutenant JG, US Naval Reserve, Active Service 1943-46. Memorial to be arranged.

title: Not on the Bed
description: ''A Stitch in Time,'' an exhibition of 30 quilts from the Victorian era, can be seen at the Carriage House Gallery at the Emlen Physick Estate, 1048 Washington Street in Cape May, though Jan. 6. With patterns like ''Goose in the Pond,'' ''Monkey Wrench'' and ''Log Cabins,'' these quilts offer a glimpse into the lives of the bourgeoisie at the end of the 19th century.

title: The Latter-Day Viking
description: There are some people for whom the Far North is eternally fascinating, and one of these was Helge Ingstad. Ingstad was a living link to the great tradition of Nordic exploration -- like Roald Amundson and Thor Heyerdahl, he liked to set out on long and difficult journeys. Before the age of satellite positioning systems and cellphones, before even the age of airplanes in the Arctic, Ingstad made his way across the ocean and over the tundra in the traditional, arduous way, and then came home to write about it.

title: Coaching Assistants Get Chance
description: In May 1997, they competed for the Eastern Conference championship, two proud teams with future Hall of Famers patrolling the court and the sideline. If Pat Riley's Miami Heat was rugged and strong up front, the Phil Jackson-coached and Michael Jordan-led Chicago Bulls were too balanced and too good for anyone to topple.

title: A Luxury Resort In Pristine Galpagos
description: For much of the last half-century, environmentalists have worried that the isolated Galpagos Islands and their fragile ecosystem would be overrun by alien species of plants and animals. Now the islands' once sheltered fauna and flora have a new competitor on their shores: the upscale tourist.

title: The Plot Thins
description: He invented the perfect pedagogical product for the 1950's, for that moment when postwar America caught a tantalizing glimpse of the silvery, streamlined tail fins of the future. Daily chores would demand less of us. In the kitchen of tomorrow, a turkey would roast itself in 20 minutes. Smart cars would intuit our destination and get us there in a flash. Dad and Mom would reap the glorious benefits of space-age science and labor-saving efficiency. So why couldn't -- why shouldn't -- Junior be able to read ''War and Peace'' in an hour?

title: The Life Serene
description: IT was the day that Sister Mary of the Incarnation would take her final vows of chastity, poverty and obedience as a cloistered Dominican nun and bride of Christ. The small chapel of the Corpus Christi Monastery was full of female heads shrouded by veils and those whose uncovered hairdos had frizzed in the light December rain.

title: Cabinets, Ancient and New, Full of Wonder for the Eyes
description: IN a room full of wonders, little epiphanies strike in strange and unexpected ways. An 18-foot crocodile sculpture that the architect Frank O. Gehry made for a trendy restaurant in Venice, Calif., suddenly finds new meaning alongside a Gregorian telescope, which in turn makes sense of a delicate 1830's handbill about astronomical lectures found under the bed of Ricky Jay, the Hollywood actor and sleight-of-hand wizard.

title: The Christmas Parade
description: A United Nations of languages rang in the cold Christmas Day air, as tourists, immigrants (some in native dress) and a few churchgoing New Yorkers mingled on Fifth Avenue. The Rockefeller Center tree was the destination of them all. Mylar balloons, knitted caps and scarves paraded the Stars and Stripes, filling the streets with this year's post-September spirit. For the day, the police had cleared the avenue's sidewalks of vendors and its streets of horse-drawn carriages. Bicycle rickshaws became an enjoyable form of transport. An embracing couple, above, paused to admire a new diamond engagement ring. Big dogs and small sported their Christmas finery. Italian and French visitors in mink and sable made their traditional Christmas stop on the way to Caribbean vacations. A group of Japanese wearing silver aluminum shell coats, designed by Yoichiro Sakamoto, an architect, posed for pictures by the 81-foot Norway spruce lighted by 30,000 red, white and blue bulbs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRALOW, NETTIE
description: ISRALOW-Nettie. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Loving mother of Eta Chalfin and Jill Schaefer. Loving sister of Rae Smith. Loving grandmother of Hali, Julie, David and Michael. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. 12:30 PM Sunday.

title: NO SECRETS IN FARM AID
description: A Web site has made public every federal subsidy payment made to every farmer in the last five years, setting off waves of anger and surprise in rural America. The site -- www.ewg.org -- was put together by the Environmental Working Group with data retrieved under the Freedom of Information Act. In one month, it has received more than 11 million hits. Farmers are discovering which of their neighbors are among the 20 percent of the country's biggest farmers who receive 84 percent of payments. Lawmakers home for the holidays are gauging how the site will affect their efforts to redirect farm policy. Elizabeth Becker

The United States pulled back from a plan to send its marines, instead coming up with a deal for Afghans willing to do the job: arms, money -- and winter clothing.

title: New York Changes Command; Mayor Giuliani Bows Out
description: Each of New York's legendary mayors is captured in the city's collective memory by a singular, powerful moment -- Fiorello La Guardia reading the comics over the radio, John Lindsay walking through Harlem. Edward Koch may be remembered standing on the Brooklyn Bridge, urging on the pedestrian commuters during a transit strike. When this year began, most New Yorkers could have suggested any number of nominations for Rudolph Giuliani's defining portrait. For those who watched him carefully, this mayor was perhaps most himself during his budget and state-of-the-city speeches -- didactic but entertaining lectures of up to two hours that he delivered without notes, controlling the stage like the prosecuting attorney he used to be. When it comes to sheer memorability, it would be impossible to top the public performances in drag, when he appeared as a blond bombshell, an Italian grandma or, most recently, a leggy Rockette.

title: The Radical Do-Gooder
description: In 1972, David McTaggart, a Canadian badminton champion, sailed his yacht to the Mururoa atoll in the South Pacific, where France had been conducting nuclear tests for six years. The French rammed his boat and detained him and later claimed to have rescued him after an accident. The following year McTaggart repeated the stunt, and French commandos boarded his boat and assaulted him, injuring his right eye. The French claimed that McTaggart fell, but photos smuggled from this incident proved that he had been attacked. From then on, McTaggart transformed Greenpeace from an obscure organization into one with international recognition, one that was often associated with the ''environmental commando'' tactics McTaggart favored. Below, Ted Turner talks about the fiery environmentalist.

title: Hippos on the Delaware
description: An Ohio-based management company hopes that by the spring of 2003, visitors will have a chance to eat with the sharks and commune with the hippos on the Camden waterfront. Steiner + Associates has proposed an expansion of the Thomas Kean State Aquarium along the Delaware River, doubling its size and adding a hippo tank, perhaps the biggest such tank in the country, and as many as seven restaurants, one with a glass wall looking into the aquarium's shark tank. All this is contingent on financing, either through direct grants or government loans of up to $25 million. Steiner, which runs other entertainment centers around the country, would take over management of the aquarium from the state and add 72,000 feet to the north and later develop 20 additional acres as a shopping and entertainment complex. The cost of the entire project is estimated at $200 million. If approved at a meeting of the Delaware River Port Authority on Jan. 16, the project could break ground that month and the aquarium expansion could be finished in about a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, HERMAN
description: SINGER-Herman. Editor and political analyst, died at his home in Manhattan on November 8, 2001, at the age of 86. He worked with Norman Thomas on behalf of the Socialist Party, serving as Editor of The Socialist Call from 1945 to 1958. He then joined the staff of East Europe magazine, published by Radio Free Europe (RFE), becoming Editor in the mid-1960's. He was also active in the New York Newspaper Guild, and was for several years elected the National Delegate for the RFE Unit. He was a contributing editor to Dissent magazine and a freelance contributor to other national journals. In later years, he became Editor of the MDA News, published by the Muscular Dystrophy Association. He was a writer and person of depth, charm, compassion and courage, and is greatly missed by his family and friends. He is survived by his sisters, Sylvia Singer and Frieda Singer-Shapiro, of New York; his daughter, Judith Singer Sam, of Arcadia, California; and his grandchildren, Michael and Carolyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUADRON, HOWARD M.
description: SQUADRON-Howard M. Howard was a man of commanding intellect and sweeping vision. He was a brilliant lawyer and negotiator, patron and lover of the arts, and a passionate, articulate and persusive spokesman for Israel and the Jewish people, civil rights and civil liberties, and the City he loved so much. He was equally conversant with international, domestic and Jewish affairs, art and literature, law and politics, and the latest sports results. The son of Jewish immigrant parents, he knew and advised Presidents, world leaders, members of Congress, governors, mayors, artists and art organizations, and countless others. Affiliated with the American Jewish Congress for over 40 years in capacities from staff attorney to President, he succeeded in all of those roles with a dazzling mix of ability, charisma, hard work and abiding loyalty. His commitment to AJCongress, and the Jewish community here, in Israel and world wide, was unshakable. It was to him we confidently turned first for principled and practical advice on matters as diverse as Israel, separation of church and state and religious liberty, freedom of speech, inter-group relations, and organizational concerns. He left an insightful and enduring imprint on those and countless other issues. AJCongress, and all with whom he shared his bold vision and considerable talents, are immeasurably the better for having benefited from his counsel. We, and they, are diminished by his passing. Our condolences to his wife Anne and his children Bill, Richard, Diane, Seth and Daniel. Jack Rosen, President Phil Baum, Executive Director Belle B. Faber, Assoc. Exec. Dir.

title: Order of Magnitude
description: It took awhile to unlearn the number 6,000. Though the estimated death toll at the World Trade Center has been falling steadily since early October -- and has by now shrunk by half -- the smaller number proved hard to absorb. As late as Thanksgiving, the larger figure was still being cited by disc jockeys and pundits, by Northern Alliance fighters and admirers of Osama bin Laden. Maybe even now it remains embedded in the minds of Americans who have been paying less avid attention to the news than they did in September. And of those fully aware of the revised number, many seemed reluctant to adopt it. When lower death estimates were first reported, few Americans were in the mood for revisionism, even of the most benign and understandable sort. Nobody wanted to insert the word ''only'' in front of a new tally of the dead. Body counts often become a proxy measure of a tragic event's significance; as the historian Karel Bartosek has written, they are ''a mathematical truth'' that ''transforms mass deaths into a kind of sacrament.'' Viewed in this light, insisting on precise new estimates can seem morally obtuse, beside the point. Lowering the body count can -- perversely, irrationally -- feel like a sad thing, as if it were an exercise in diminishing the weight of Sept. 11.
