title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROCHLITZ, ROSE
description: STROCHLITZ-Rose. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum and its governing Council mourn the passing of Rose Strochlitz, mother of Council member Romana Primus and wife of Sigmund Strochlitz, former Council member and a leader in Holocaust remembrance in the United States. A Holocaust survivor, her dedication and commitment to both the creation and on-going mission of the Museum, as well as to the Jewish people, will be deeply missed. The Museum extends its sincere condolences to her husband, children, family, and friends. Rabbi Irving Greenberg Chairman Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chairman Miles Lerman, Chair Emeritus Sara J. Bloomfield, Director

title: Health Care Precipice
description: To the Editor:

title: RACE TRACK FOR MILVILLE
description: In the latest proposal for big-time car racing in the state, a New York real estate developer said last week it was prepared to build a Nascar-style auto racing track near the Millville airport in Cumberland County. New Jersey Motorsports, Inc. proposed a $50 million facility that would include a 3.2-mile track, two hotels, restaurants, golf and tennis facilities and a driving school. New Jersey Motorsports would put up about half of the money, with the rest coming from state or local agencies.

title: Turnaround Prospects After Two Bad Years
description: FOR many investors, the end of 2001 won't come a minute too soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ELENA SUE (NEE SADOCK)
description: HECHT-Elena Sue (nee Sadock). Loving mother of Joshua. Beloved sister of M. William and Benjamin. Grateful friend to her devoted caregiver, Anita. Died peacefully on Saturday, December 29, 2001. Elena endured all with grace, humility and love. She will be deeply mourned by all those who knew her. Services Monday, December 31, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: From the Counter To the Computer
description: THE year was 1981 and I was 15. The economy was awful and I was willing to do anything for work. I found a job at Sunrise Deli, a mom-and-pop Italian delicatessen in Westerly, my hometown. I turned beef into hamburger, cleaned the store, made sandwiches and put together take-out orders. The only thing I didn't do was run the cash register.

title: Film Series Listings
description: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE  Alice's Adventures on Film. Today, 2: Bower's "Alice in Wonderland" (1951); at 4: Svankmajer's "Alice" (1988). Ends Mon., 2: Geronimi, Luske and Jackson's "Alice in Wonderland" (1951). W. C. Fields. Sat., 2: La Cava's "So's Your Old Man" (1926) with piano by Donald Sosin; at 4: Kenton's "You're Telling Me" (1934). Repertory Nights. Today, 6:30: Reisner's "Steamboat Bill Jr." (1928) with piano by Mr. Sosin. Sat., 6:30-next Sun., 6:30: Powell and Pressburger's "Red Shoes" (1948). 35th Ave. at 36th St., Astoria, Queens. (718-784-0077)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROZ, PAUL JOSEPH
description: MOROZ-Paul Joseph. Age 73. Of South Kent, CT. Died Christmas morning, December 25, 2001 at New Milford Hospital, CT. He leaves his wife Norma, five children and eight grandchildren.

title: The Master Builder
description: HIS INVENTION

title: Severance Packages Growing, Survey Finds
description: Alayoff can be a financial nightmare for anyone, but a new study of severance packages shows that many employers have been trying to ease the blow.

title: CHINA TURNS TO NEEDLES
description: Courts in China's largest cities have begun using lethal injection as a means of executing some of the thousands of people being put to death in the country's current anti-crime campaign. Beijing, which wants the new method implemented in all provincial capitals and major cities by the end of this year, says it is switching because lethal injection is more humane and cheaper than execution by gunshot. Some people worry, though, that lethal injections will make it easier for organs to be harvested from executed prisoners, which are currently the country's main source of transplantable organs. Craig S. Smith

title: The bin Laden Video Club Presents
description: The Complete Collectors' Edition

title: DataBank; Small Gains in a Quiet Holiday Week
description: Trading was subdued last week as many investors stepped back from the market to celebrate the holidays.

title: Death and Scandal Left Their Scars
description: In a year when death scarred the nation, death too often saddened sports -- at an auto-racing track, in a plane crash, on a sun-scorched football field, in a boxing ring on an aircraft carrier, on a ski slope in Tyrol, even on a world-class sailor's anchored yacht.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, ELIHU DALE
description: ALBERT-Elihu Dale, 87. Of White Plains. Devoted father and grandfather; 1934 graduate of Wesleyan University, admitted to College of Physicians and Surgeons, but of necessity took a position as research chemist, completed a MA at Columbia, wrote textbooks. During WWII, he had a maritime commission, developing coatings for lighter, faster ships. In 1951, he married the love of his life, Rose Perlstein, who predeceased him in 1981. For many years he was Executive V.P. at Merkin Paint Company. Until he was 84, he was in charge of new accounts at CSS. A man of high intelligence and rare integrity, he had a rich sense of humor. Compassionate and generous, he took great care of his family and made friends where ever he went.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, two portraits with the New & Noteworthy Paperbacks column on Page 16 of the Book Review today carry erroneous credits. The picture of Joy Williams, at the top, is by Rollie McKenna; the picture of Arthur Miller is by Susan Johann/Corbis Outline.

title: Kidd Goes All Out in Lifting Nets
description: Jason Kidd had quarter-size scabs on his left and right knees, and both of his forearms were emblazoned with pink burn marks. They were tattoos of sacrifice, souvenirs mostly from one spectacular play tonight that left his Nets teammates grateful and awestruck again.

title: Telecommuting for Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Comes With Batteries. Not a Shrink.
description: WHO says American kids won't learn foreign languages? Truth is, they will even learn a nonexistent foreign language in order to chat with their toys. C.I.A. strategists need only create a few playthings that speak Kurdish or Pashto and they could solve the Middle East staffing problem in a generation.

title: MISS AMERICA PAGEANT
description: After a very public threat to move the Miss America Pageant out of Atlantic City after 80 years, the pageant's board of directors decided last week to stay at least another year. The chief executive of the pageant, Robert Renneisen Jr., said earlier this month that it had become too expensive to put on the event at Boardwalk Hall and announced that he was considering offers to move it next year to Nevada, Florida, California or Connecticut. But the pageant's board of directors met Wednesday and decided to turn down the offers. Pageant officials have asked state or local agencies for $1 million to make up for deficits. A panel of officials and citizens will be formed to make recommendations for the pageant's future.

title: Close Call: An Eviction Proceeds, But the Pickle Endures
description: History keeps getting pushed out of the Lower East Side. The 25,000 pushcart vendors and six Yiddish newspapers are long gone. This month, the pickles almost disappeared, too.

title: Pants on Fire
description: It's not often that a pathological liar gets his own talk show. But in the late 1980's, one did. At a time when most talk-show hosts strained for sensitivity -- think Donahue in a dress or Ted Koppel's earnestly furrowed brow -- Morton Downey Jr. made his name screaming at supporters of abortion rights, gun control, affirmative action or any other cause that smacked of liberalism. The spectacle of Washington wonks cowering in front of the blue-collar bully proved strangely watchable, and his syndicated show became a national phenomenon.

title: At Ease on the Eastern Shore
description: THE fog was so thick as I crossed the Chesapeake Bay Bridge that I couldn't even see the opposing stream of traffic, much less the water. It was a few days past Thanksgiving, but this morning the weather felt more like September than late November. I was comfortable in a cotton shirt, and as I hit the eastern shore of the bay, I felt out of time and season as well as out of town.

title: The Actors Who Make History Live
description: IT'S always 1916 in the Confino family's crowded apartment on Orchard Street, where 13-year-old Victoria, broom in hand and kerchief over her black braids, regularly welcomes guests. The Confinos, Sephardic Jews from Turkey, arrived at Ellis Island three years ago, and though she still has an accent, Victoria knows her way around.

title: Private Crises of Conscience
description: When the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were struck by hijacked planes on Sept. 11, reaction in the county ranged from initial raw emotions of sorrow, grief and shock to -- in many cases -- anger and thoughts of revenge.

title: Uncertainty Seems the Only Sure Thing
description: Maybe it is the baseball version of whistling past the graveyard, circa 2001.

title: Bloomberg Picks New Leader for Fire Department
description: NEW YORK -- Mayor-elect Michael Bloomberg named Nicholas Scoppetta to replace Thomas Von Essen as commissioner of the fire department, which was devastated by the loss of 343 firefighters on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPANELLA, VINCENT R.
description: CAMPANELLA - Vincent R. 1915-2001. Abstract painter Vincent Campanella died December 23. Born and educated in New York City, he worked at Easel Division of the WPA and went on assignment to Wyoming. As a member of the Artists Union, He lobbied for continuation of the WPA and its mission to spread knowledge of American culture throughout the country. Campanella's paintings were exibited at the Rehn Gallery, in museums nationally, and held in collections of the Toledo, Newark, Memphis and San Francisco museums. He talked at the Kansas City Art Institute and taught college 28 years, and Professor Emeritus another 21 years. He is survived by his wife Leah Campanella of New York City, daughter Tura Campanella Cook, son-inlaw Gene Cook, and grandchildren Roy, David, Winn and Margaret of Austin, TX, son David Campanella, daughter-in-law Joanne Campanella and grandchildren Alexander and Sara of Sudbury, MA. The family suggests contributions to the Library at Park University, Parkville, MO. A memorial is planned for April 20, 2002 at Park University.

title: John Bocchi: Prankster With a Heart
description: With a top broker's panache, John Bocchi presented himself as if to say, Either you love me or you don't.

title: Partners Who Run a Different Sort of Steakhouse
description: BEFORE they decided to build the Boulder Creek Steakhouse chain together, its founders considered whether their nearly lifelong friendship could survive the challenges that a business partnership inevitably brings. They decided it could.

title: Robert Wallace: Humor Against Adversity
description: Nancy Wallace remembers Robert, her husband of 21 years, for his wacky sense of humor and the way he took every little car breakdown in stride. And there were many. "We put three engines in it, and two trannies," she said of the family's Jeep Wagoneer. "Half the time we didn't make it to where we were going."

title: Leathery Body Language
description: For those seeking a painless, removable tattoo without those tacky decals, Orga, a Tokyo-based artists collective, has a solution: a snug-fitting line of hand-tattooed leather clothing. ''There are a lot of people who don't have tattoos for social or domestic reasons,'' said Orga's founder, Takeichiro Morinaga, a former textile and graphic designer for Yohji Yamamoto. ''We're giving them the feeling of a tattoo without the permanence.''

title: Stone-Age Visionary
description: William Hanna, who with his partner, Joseph Barbera, created a host of cartoon characters from the Flintstones to Scooby-Doo, either saved animation or ruined it. Hanna's signature contribution to cartoon history was what he called ''limited animation'' -- a process that reduced the number of drawings in a cartoon by as much as 90 percent.

title: In Montclair, a Controversial View of American History
description: THE remodeled and enlarged Montclair Art Museum has opened its special exhibitions galley with an ambitious show, ''Primal Visions: Albert Bierstadt 'Discovers' America,'' whose theme incorporates the idea of new beginnings.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Democracies don't prepare well for things that have never happened before.''

title: Pitching Horseshoes For Luck And Style
description: New Year's Day is traditionally a time for good-luck rituals, with pots of black-eyed peas for prosperity, cabbage leaves symbolizing green-lined coffers and long noodles for long life simmering on the stove. This year, retailers are peddling a little extra good fortune. Blue Angel's ribbed tank tops in black, white or turquoise, above, are emblazoned with a horseshoe or a shamrock ($35 at Olive & Bette's), and a Barneys New York pink cashmere top ($350), second from left, follows suit. Cynthia Rowley's studded coin belt ($165) promotes prosperity for men and women, and to carry that prosperity around, there's a Marc by Marc Jacobs shamrock change purse ($48), center, in red felt. And there is jewelry, too. Tracey Zabar makes a 14-karat gold Milagros (Miracles) charm bracelet, with miniature votive amulets for good luck ($2,400), as well as a bracelet, above, featuring a four-leaf clover with a diamond in the center ($600); both are available at Bergdorf Goodman. Mia & Lizzie have graduated from last year's popular horseshoe theme to a diamond four-leaf clover pendant in white, yellow or rose gold ($260). It is available at Patricia Field -- so watch for it next month in ''Sex and the City'' on Sarah Jessica Parker's Carrie, whom Ms. Field dresses. Chanel adorns the luckiest toes with shamrock-appliqud ankle boots ($770), as well as leather slides ($415) and ballet flats, above far left, studded with gold clovers ($370; all at Saks Fifth Avenue). Apparently, if you're going to walk down fortune's path, you might as well do it in nice shoes.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 30, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Missed Signals
description: This is the last of three articles. The first report examined Saudi Arabia's policies toward militants who left home to wage holy war. The second looked at how Muslim militancy took root in Europe and how European governments failed to understand its danger and depth.

title: Salvatore P. Lopes: Worked in Two Worlds
description: Salvatore P. Lopes retired from the New York Police Department after he fell off a roof while trying to help someone down, and hurt his back.

title: Ewing, the Edge Gone, Is Back in Town
description: It is easy to picture Patrick Ewing as a bitter, aging ex-star who still wants the most shots, still wants to be the franchise player and still wants the glory. But Doc Rivers, his former Knicks teammate and current Orlando Magic coach, sees a different Ewing this season, one who is comfortable playing a lesser role and is relieved about not carrying the championship hopes of an entire team, and town, on his back.

title: At Home and in Israel, Expressing Passions
description: THE art of Alexander Rutsch (1916-1997) is soaked with Modernist tendencies. Using everything he found or happened upon -- drift material from the Long Island Sound, pine needles that found their way to the wet surfaces of his canvas -- Rutsch strived to create works that revealed his subjects' inner and outer beauty.

title: The Contrarian
description: Roger Starr, a restless bear of a man, brimmed with expertise. He knew where to find the best jewelry on 47th Street, the best fly fishing on the Beaver Kill and the most memorable conch stew in Islamorada, Fla. He loved tennis, bridge and pool. He knew classic architecture in Sicily and unusual words like ''trunnion'' and ''gudgeon'' (both referring to bus parts and the latter also to fish).

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Silvermine, Conn.; Enclave Steeped in History and the Arts
description: DEVOTEES of the comic strip ''Hi and Lois'' may have noticed the occasional reference to the Silvermine Golf Club or the Silvermine Market.

title: Fiesta Bowl Could Make A National Co-Champion
description: If college football used the New York Times's computer ranking to plan its national championship game, Miami would play Colorado in the Rose Bowl on Thursday. If the sport used the opinion polls of the news media or the coaches, the Hurricanes would play Oregon in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Ingenuity's Blueprints, Into History's Dustbin
description: On these frigid winter nights, Randy Rabin can be found combing through trash bins outside the United States Patent and Trademark Office, trying to rescue from destruction yellowed copies of patents from America's golden age of invention.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Dec. 16 about the political and aesthetic ideas that influenced the architecture of the new Prada store in SoHo misstated the name of the Italian Communist Party's former newspaper, which Prada was once rumored to be interested in acquiring. It is L'Unit, not Humanit. (L'Humanit is the French Communist paper.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELVER, RENE
description: SELVER-Rene. Passed away at the age of 84 years on December 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Jill. Father of Paul Selver and Elsbeth Haladay and grandfather of Jesse and Eden Haladay and Adam, Max and Katelyn Selver. He served his country as a soldier in the United States Army in World War II, rising to the rank of Captain. He led Dutchess Lingerie, Inc. and Sylvester Textile Corp. for over two generations. He gave generously to his community as a participant and leader of the United Jewish Appeals Mission to Israel, as a fundraising chair for the March of Dimes, as a patient advocate at Englewood Hospital and as Chairman of The Dispute Resolutions Committee in the building where he lived. He was a gentle and honorable man. His love of his wife, his children and grandchildren knew no bounds. He lived his life to the fullest. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St., 10 AM on Sunday December 30, 2001. Contributions in his memory may be made to either The Anti-Defamation League or the Federation of Jewish Philanthropy.

title: Planning for Terror but Failing to Act
description: Inside the White House situation room on the morning terrorism transformed America, Franklin C. Miller, the director for defense policy, was suddenly gripped by a staggering fear: ''The White House could be hit. We could be going down.''

title: Drives That Made the Year Worthwhile
description: EVERYTHING was to have changed on Sept. 11, yet much in the automotive world is the same. Gas is cheap and plentiful. S.U.V.'s are selling briskly. Thanks to financing deals, carmakers will have another near-record year.

title: Sarra Pyun, David Cho
description: Sarra Misook Pyun, a daughter of Chung Ja Pyun and Choong Moo Pyun of Waynesville, Mo., is to be married today to David Dae-Hyun Cho, the son of the Rev. Sarah S. Cho and Yosung Cho of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Gary Parrett is to perform a nondenominational ceremony at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Contributors
description: Thomas A. Bass is the author of ''Vietnamerica'' and, most recently, ''The Predictors.''

title: New Guys' Teacher, Anticipatory Father and a Family Ringleader
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: BEGINNINGS

title: NEXT WEEK
description: President Bush may make short trips from his Texas ranch to Austin and to the West Coast before returning to Washington on Jan. 7. The euro goes into circulation in 12 European nations on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGAN, MARY EILEEN
description: REGAN-Mary Eileen. On Dec. 28, 2001. Beloved daughter of Catherine and the late Maurice. Loving sister of Kathleen McCabe, Patricia, Mele, Maurice and Thomas. Devoted aunt to nine nephews and nieces. Family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Rd, Rye, NY, Saturday 79PM, Sunday 2-4 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45AM at the Church of the Resurrection. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Sports of The Times; The Postcards From 2001: Sport Helped People Cope
description: THIS past year will always be divided -- Before and After. How simple life was, back then. But we kept on because . . . because . . . because Mayor Giuliani told us to. In its own shallow way, sport helped the bad hours to pass.

title: Free Spirit
description: ISADORA

title: On the Lookout For High Anxiety
description: THE image is frozen in her mind. A 12-year-old girl who witnessed one of the planes hitting the World Trade Center still sees it as a vivid picture. She can remember the expressions on people's faces, the color of the sky and the sounds of people crying and screaming. The memory replays constantly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BEN
description: GOLDBERG-Ben. 83, retired President of SEIU Local 3036 (The Taxi Drivers Union), died December 28, 2001, following a brief illness. He was the beloved husband of the late Leah Duhl Goldberg. Father of Lawrence Goldberg and Cindy Wapnitsky. Father-in-law to Bryn Johnson and Ken Wapnitsky. Grandfather of Leah, Jack and Pheobe. He dedicated his life to his family, friends and to the labor movement. The family pledges to carry on his good work. Funeral 10 AM, Thursday, January 3, 2002, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, or to The Jewish Labor Committee, NYC.

title: In Europe, a Possible Surfeit of Airlines
description: More than two decades after deregulation reshaped the American airline industry -- and quickly spelled the end for Pan Am and Eastern -- Europe appears to be in the early stages of the same process, which is likely to reduce the number of carriers there. This era of change for both airlines and passengers is being sped up by a severe drop in air travel following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States.

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: 2001's Lessons: We Must Go On; We Can Go On
description: EVERY year-end, the critics of The New York Times sum up their fields over the last 12 months. So it is now. But 2001 has not been an ordinary year. Reading the eight critical essays in this issue constitutes a survey of what happened to the arts in New York and the United States after Sept. 11.

title: Waterspouts Batter Sydney-to-Hobart Crews
description: In hindsight, it might have been an omen. When the 75-boat fleet in the Sydney-to-Hobart race set out from here last Wednesday, it did so before a smudged cityscape blanketed in a smoky haze from the dozens and dozens of bushfires blazing throughout the state of New South Wales.

title: Kasparov's Nimble Pieces Frustrate Kramnik's Queen
description: In the seventh game of the Garry Kasparov-Vladimir Kramnik blitz segment of their Botvinnik Memorial Match in Moscow Dec. 1 to 9, an exciting confrontation of the white queen against the black rook, bishop and pawn arose. This opposition is about equal on paper, but it is the concrete features that determine who has the upper hand.

title: Truth in Advertising
description: THE dish is called, simply, Shanghai casserole. On a menu that otherwise bristles with useful information, its entry is unadorned. You choose medium ($13.95) or large ($19.95). We chose large.

title: Social Security: Why Not Fix It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tall Order for a Small Player
description: THE Art Deco sign for the Suitcase Motel two bathing-suited vacationers waving from inside a suitcase -- is, of course, dark for the winter. The crowds that jam Five Mile Island on much balmier days are somewhere else.

title: Katie Weinberg and Patrick Schumacher
description: SIX months ago, and only weeks before Katie Weinberg and Patrick Schumacher were to take off for a two-year London adventure, they hit a snag. Mr. Schumacher, an investment banker at Lehman Brothers, had accepted an offer to work in his company's London office, but only after Ms. Weinberg agreed to go with him. She had left her apartment and given notice at Dolce & Gabbana, where she worked with fashion editors. Then she discovered that she could not get a work permit in England unless she and Mr. Schumacher were married.

title: Public Can Speak Its Mind (In 120 Seconds or Less)
description: Few would accuse Aubrey Lees of being a stickler for process. When she became chairwoman of Community Board 2 in Greenwich Village last summer, she set her sights on keeping the meetings brief.

title: Bringing to Light The Stresses of War
description: WHEN the New York choreographer Tamar Rogoff started working on a piece about post-traumatic stress disorder three years ago, she had no idea that it would become such a personal subject for many Americans. She simply wanted to understand her father, a World War II veteran who experienced insomnia, claustrophobia and other typical symptoms of the disorder, though in his case, it was never diagnosed.

title: Westchester Jobs Remained Steady in 2001
description: Westchester County's unemployment rate remained steady in 2001, according to the New York State Department of Labor.

title: Wraps and Rambles In the Desert
description: I HAD been warned, in the brochure describing the Turquoise Wrap, that at some point the therapist would perform a ''smudging ceremony,'' described as ''a traditional Native American practice to purify the spirit, space and self.''

title: Jessica Taylor, Michael O'Mary
description: Jessica Rogers Taylor, a daughter of Deborah and Robert Taylor of Boston, was married there last evening to Michael Allen O'Mary, the son of Rosemary and John Michael O'Mary of Katy, Tex. The Rev. Susan Richmond, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Old North Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUTHWORTH, KATHARINE JONES
description: SOUTHWORTH-Katharine Jones. December 25, 2001. Widow of Dr. Hamilton Southworth. Born in New York City March 16, 1910. Survived by four children, Hamilton Southworth, Jr., Jean Southworth Leness, Thomas Shepard Southworth and Katharine Southworth Smith, eight grandchildren and sixteen great grandchildren. Memorial service to be at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Ave, February 23rd, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Chapin School, 100 East End Ave., NY, NY. 10028 or to Columbia University, Department of Medicine, Southworth Lectureship Fund, PH8, 630 W. 168 St, N.Y., N.Y. 10032 would be appreciated.

title: Suddenly, Uncle Sam Wants to Bankroll You
description: IT may be quiet these days in Silicon Valley, but don't tell that to Gilman Louie, the chief executive of In-Q-Tel, a private nonprofit venture capital company set up and financed by the Central Intelligence Agency in late 1999 to get a better bead on innovative technology the intelligence crowd might put to use.

title: U.S. Subpoenas Records Of Suffolk Land Deals
description: Federal investigators have subpoenaed records from Suffolk County officials involving county purchases of the Chandler Estate in Mount Sinai and three other properties.

title: For Many Burmese, China Is an Unwanted Ally
description: Each morning here, in the Buddhist heartland of the country once known as Burma, dozens of monks clamber onto ramshackle buses and leave this stately, sprawling city.

title: The Neediest Cases; For New Head of a Family, Help With a Daunting Job
description: For some reason, 5-year-old Demetrius Porter could not sleep on a frigid evening in East Harlem in February. As his mother, Victoria Lopez, scrubbed his school clothes in her kitchen sink, Demetrius continued to try to get her attention.

title: Ideas & Trends; At the End Of a Decade
description: TEN years ago -- at 7:32 p.m. on Dec. 25, 1991, to be precise -- the Soviet Union died a lonely death. There was no violence, no ceremony, no pathos, only the televised resignation of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the lowering of the red Soviet flag over the Kremlin. A handful of surprised foreigners let out a victorious yelp while an old war veteran issued an angry tirade.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pulse column last Sunday about Clifford the Big Red Dog gift baskets, a last-minute item from the Scholastic Store, misstated the telephone number. It is (212) 343-6166.

title: The Euro Unites 12 Countries
description: FOR anyone who has traveled across Europe, the arrival of euro notes and coins on Tuesday will be a breathtaking change.

title: Webb: An Elite College Trying to Stay Afloat
description: MOVIE buffs and superhero aficionados might recognize the Webb Institute as the Wayne mansion from ''Batman Forever'' and ''Batman and Robin.'' But the true identity of the walled, 26-acre former Pratt estate at the tip of Glen Cove has long been a mystery, even to many of its neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, EVA
description: SILVERMAN-Eva. Of West Palm Beach, Florida, on December 21, 2001, at age 88. Cherished wife of Louis Silverman for 60 years. Loving mother of Leslie and Douglas Rothkopf and Paula and Charles Head and grandmother of Joshua and David Rothkopf.

title: Giants Audio
description: Postgame audio from the Giants vs. the Philadelphia Eagles provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Ballroom Dancing With a Russian Flair
description: ELENA GRINENKO, a Russian ballroom dance champion, left her home in Moscow in 1998 to go to America. In September, she and her boyfriend opened the Dance Zone studio in Old Bridge.

title: The Most Italian State in the Nation? Guess.
description: Connecticut hardly conjures up images of ravioli or cannoli. But according to the 2000 Census, Connecticut has more residents claiming to be of Italian origin per capita than any other state in the nation.

title: The Great Red, Green and Blue Way
description: THEY say the light-emitting diodes are bright on Broadway. Just when it seemed Times Square could not get much more dazzling, several new supersigns were switched on recently, transforming a half dozen office towers and stores into colossal, kinetic video monitors and digital displays.

title: Consortium to Preserve Threatened Landmark
description: Two preservationist groups and a private foundation have joined to save and restore the A. Conger Goodyear House in Old Westbury, a modernist house of international importance that was nearly demolished less than two months ago.

title: In the Region/Long Island; A Bomber Hangar Is Reborn as a Children's Museum
description: THE newly painted bright yellow windows and doors of a renovated 1930's hangar at Mitchel Field in Garden City almost disguise the fact that it once housed dun-colored Army airplanes. Inside the building -- which is being resurrected as a two-story children's museum -- huge walls glowing with brilliant colors line a 3,035-square-foot open lobby. The ceiling has been removed and the original trusses exposed and painted white to match the interior of the vast 42-foot-high peaked roof.

title: Warming Trend
description: As winter finally reaches seasonally appropriate temperatures, beauty counters are experiencing a warming trend, with salves, lotions and gels designed to ward off frost and raise body heat. Next month, Kiehl's will introduce its All-Sport Non-Freeze Face Protector, an oil-free balm to ward off the elements during winter sports ($15 at Kiehl's). There is also Becoming's warming Hand and Foot Blanket, for chilly extremities ($10 at the Avon Spa), while Dr. Hauschka's Rose Body Moisturizer ($28.95 at Sephora) is

title: Questions Line the Road as Nascar Steers Into a New Year
description: A well-born Southern lady of a certain age, rich and accomplished, leaned across the dinner table last week and said: ''My country is Virginia. I'm also a citizen of the United States, but it's a distant second. I am still furious that the South was not allowed to recover until after the Second World War. There was no good reason to scorch our earth. It was just vengeance.''

title: QUICK BITE/Pennsauken; Who Needs Nostalgia Where the 50's Never Left?
description: You enter the Pub in on otherwise tawdry Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Pennsauken and you go back in time. All right, so maybe it's not the 15th century, as the faux medieval decorations in the cavernous dining room would affect. It's more like the 1950's, when comfort food, humongous dining rooms and homespun gaudiness ruled the dining scene. The Pub's main dining room holds 500, and even on a Monday night it can be filled. And so can the diners, with the huge portions, none of them a bit culinarily cute. The specialty of the house is red meat. The front of the main dining room is a set of six open brick ovens under a massive copper canopy. Large men in toques shove large steaks and chops in those ovens continuously through lunch and dinner. The manager's special is a slow-roasted boneless 14-ounce prime rib, with a baked Yorkshire-puff potato on the side. With it comes unlimited trips to the 20-foot-long salad/bread/cheese bar that sits under what must be the biggest moose head in South Jersey currently adorned with a floppy Santa cap. A large round mound of bread, with a knife for you to slice yourself, is plopped on every table. All this will set you back only $17.95. The names on the menu evoke the pre-jumpsuit Elvis. There's a filet mignon steak-a-bob ($14.95, with all the above extras), a half char-broiled chicken ($11.55) and twin all-jumbo lump crabmeat cakes ($17.95). The carafes of house wine are called flagons, and the Pub still advertises 1 1/2 drinks, an extra half-finger of hard stuff going into every cocktail. Desserts are similarly one-and-a-halfish, the high-rising chocolate turtle cheesecake($4.35) billowing with caramel, pecans, whipped cream and chocolate chips topping the 20-item list. Even the most gourmandesque succumb to doggie-bagdom, taking home the honest-and-true retro experience for another day. Robert Strauss

title: They Brought Enough Film
description: A by now familiar story is told again in SOUTH WITH ENDURANCE. Shackleton's Antarctic Expedition 1914-1917: The Photographs of Frank Hurley (Simon & Schuster, $50). In 1914, Sir Ernest Shackleton and 27 men set out in the ship Endurance with the harebrained idea of crossing Antarctica on foot. At the Weddell Sea, the ship is beset in the ice pack and eventually sinks. The men camp on the ice for months. When the floes break up, they take to three small boats, and six days later land on stark Elephant Island. Shackleton and five others then undertake, arguably, the greatest open-boat voyage ever -- 800 miles to South Georgia over the wildest seas on earth. Remarkably, they make it, but they land on the uninhabited side of the island. With almost no equipment, Shackleton and two men cross the uncharted mountains in 36 hours (recently three world-class climbers with modern gear re-enacted the feat; it took three days). Then Shackleton rescues everybody back at Elephant Island. The shelf of books this epic has inspired includes one consisting of leadership tips inspired by Shackleton. He wouldn't have minded. Among many other things, he was an opportunist out for the main chance, and a pictorial record of his expedition was crucial to its financial success. That's why he and his photographer, Frank Hurley, went back to the sinking Endurance and lugged many photographic plates across the ice and sea. These photographs appeared in the surprisingly popular 1999 show at the American Museum of Natural History, and most were reproduced in Caroline Alexander's best seller, ''The Endurance.'' Now all of Hurley's photographs from the expedition (and some from others) are reproduced in a handsome coffee-table book. They are as stunning as ever, and surely Shackleton and Hurley would be delighted that the images they fought so tenaciously to save have endured. Robert R. Harris

title: Private Sector; A Los Angeles Laker in King Arthur's Dome

He continues to snap up soccer teams, recently taking control of New York's MetroStars, defying those who say the league is a dud. He bought the bankrupt Regal Cinema chain at a time when American movie theaters were struggling. And he has won approval for a $1 billion plan to create a 27-acre entertainment district in downtown Los Angeles, a gamble even in the best economic times. Now Mr. Anschutz has gone further: his latest project is to turn London's blighted Millennium Dome into a sports and entertainment complex. The dome, which resembles an upside-down wok, is a national joke, mocked for its dearth of visitors and attacked for its expensive upkeep. title: The Moviegoer
description: Robert Warshow, a film critic for Commentary and Partisan Review, died young, at 37, in 1955. As sometimes happens, the abbreviation of the life contributed to the survival of the reputation. When this tall, slender, chain-smoking New York intellectual had his fatal heart attack, he had published exactly 11 essays on film, of which only half transcended the category of review. He was mourned with the depth of sorrow that often accompanies the unfulfillment of promise. ''I have never known a death so intensely and openly grieved over,'' Lionel Trilling wrote in a 1962 introduction to Warshow's work. ''No one was inclined, in the modern way, to 'accept' it.'' Nearly 50 years later, Warshow retains his presence. He is widely quoted, if not widely read, and ranked by other film critics among the masters of the genre. Last month, Harvard University Press reissued a posthumous compilation of his writing, ''The Immediate Experience: Movies, Comics, Theater & Other Aspects of Popular Culture.'' The book comes with Trilling's introduction, a new introduction by the film critic David Denby and an epilogue by the philosopher-turned-film-critic Stanley Cavell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPIDES, ROBERT E.
description: LAPIDES-Robert E. Chairman of United Aluminum Corporation, one of Connecticut's oldest private corporations, passed away on December 21, after a brief illness. A devoted New Havener, Yale Man and WWII Naval commander, he was 83. Mr. Lapides was born and raised in New Haven and graduated from Yale University, Class of '39S with an engineering degree and an Ensign's commission in the U.S. Naval Reserve. Shortly thereafter, he was called to active duty. At 25, he became one of the youngest ever commanding officers of a fleet destroyer (the U.S.S. Dahlgren DD187, in 1943, followed by command of the U.S.S. Niblack DD424, in 1945). The Niblack was part of the American armada preparing to invade Japan, and he was one of the first ashore to witness the destruction of Hiroshima. Upon release from active duty in 1946, Mr. Lapides returned to United Smelting & Aluminum Company, the New Haven firm founded by his grandfather in 1891. Remaining in the Naval Reserves, he became Commanding Officer of Surface Division 3-8 and later Surface Battalion 3-27. He also served as Mobilization Director for the State of Connecticut until recalled to active duty as a Commander when the Korean War began. He was then called to the Pentagon, where he served on the staff of the Chief of Naval Operations on the Anti-Submarine Warfare Desk. After the war he returned to New Haven and rejoined his family's firm, where he was elected President in 1957. The Company became a leader in precision cold rolling of aluminum coil, serving markets worldwide. In 1968, Mr. Lapides relocated the Company to North Haven, CT, and in 1989 assumed the role of Chairman. It continues as United Aluminum Corporation, the second oldest aluminum roller in America. Mr. Lapides was active in community affairs. He served as the President of the Board of Trustees of the Hopkins School and Chairman of the North Haven Police Commission, and on the Boards of Yale New Haven Hospital, the St. Raphael's Foundation, First Bank of New Haven, the New Haven Savings Bank, Congregation Mishkan Israel and the New Haven Boy's Club. In 1996 Mr. Lapides was honored with a Hall of Fame Award from Junior Achievement; in 1998, both a Founders Award from Business New Haven and a Lifetime Achievement award from the Aluminum Association. Recently he was an Associate Fellow at Yale's Branford College and Treasurer of his Yale Class. Mr. Lapides is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Ruth R. Lapides, and three children, John S. Lapides, of New Haven, James A. Lapides, of Brookline, MA, and Susan J. Lapides of Cambridge, MA, a sister, Joan L. Wingate, of Branford, CT, and four grandchildren. description: This issue of ''A Nation Challenged'' is the last one scheduled as a separate section of The Times. The events of Sept. 11 and their aftermath -- terrorism, war, trauma and recovery, the search for causes and solutions -- have become woven into all aspects of national and international life. The New Year provides an occasion to reflect that evolution by incorporating the coverage into the newspaper's main sections.

''Words fail us'' was the predominant clich in the days immediately after the attacks, but for some, even intellectuals in other secular democracies, words have been too easily and cheaply produced; they matter-of-factly declared, ''The United States had it coming.''

title: The Year in Pictures: TERROR STRIKES

By the time the twin towers collapsed, more than 2,900 people were dead, lower Manhattan was covered in ash-laden debris and the lot where two of the world's tallest buildings had stood for more than a generation had a new name, ground zero. Then another hijacked airplane plowed deep into the side of the Pentagon, killing 189. The fourth plane crashed in western Pennsylvania, killing 44 people, after some of the passengers apparently fought with the four hijackers.

Community leaders were worried that the problem might fester for years. description: An estimated half-billion Chinese tuned in to watch their national squad beat Oman in October to qualify for its first World Cup ever. The tournament will be held next June in South Korea and Japan. In Ireland, which qualified after beating the formidable Dutch, pub owners are seeking to change liquor licensing laws to allow them to open at 6:30 a.m. during the tournament. Meanwhile Argentina, Nigeria and England are atwitter that they must play each other in the first round.

title: The Year in Pictures: POLITICAL ACTS
description: Settling into the job, one new leader sized up his counterparts while another, a septuagenarian hawk who led Israel's newly reinvigorated right wing, was elected against a backdrop of the worst Israeli-Palestinian violence in years. Soon the Bush administration abandoned the Middle East peace proposals that President Bill Clinton had left on the table, saying they did not apply once Ariel Sharon had replaced Ehud Barak. AIDS was back in the headlines; under pressure, pharmaceutical companies cut prices of potentially lifesaving drugs for countries like South Africa, where millions are infected with H.I.V. And then there were the celebrities, preening at the Academy Awards and mugging onstage in ''The Producers.'' Its $100-a-seat ticket prices were a new high for Broadway.

title: Season Is Over for Martinek
description: Radek Martinek, the rookie defenseman who had become one of the Islanders' steadiest players, is scheduled for knee surgery Wednesday and will be out for the rest of the season, the Islanders said yesterday.

title: A Watch List for 2002
description: Trying to look over the horizon to plot the coming year in business has always been a tricky enterprise. Add a slumping economy, a government and a populace concerned about terrorism and a recent flurry of unsettled mergers and acquisitions, and the prospect can be treacherous.

title: Patents; Resolved once again: To shorten the time that inventions spend in the land of patent pending.
description: NEXT year is supposed to be the culmination of a five-year plan to reduce the average time it takes the Patent and Trademark Office to process a patent application to 18 months from the current 24. The agency is not likely to make it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Central Bank President Predicts Upturn in Europe

title: A Tough Year For Disney's Chief
description: Michael D. Eisner can breathe a sigh of relief to see 2001 end. The Walt Disney Company, with its ABC network suffering and attendance down at its theme parks, can expect to report that its operating income dropped about 24 percent in 2001, Richard A. Bilotti, media analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said.

title: Canadian Imperial Bank Buys Merrill Unit
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Canada's third-biggest bank, completed its acquisition of Merrill Lynch's Canadian retail brokerage and fund-management unit on Friday, the bank said.

title: Thrash's Long Route Takes Many Twists
description: The moon was full over Veterans Stadium and the old joint was stacked full of fans, and pretty soon Thunder and Lightning appeared in the form of Giants running backs Ron Dayne and Tiki Barber.

title: A Viewing Stand Brings Pilgrims to Ground Zero
description: The days of craning necks and peeking through gaps in plywood fences ended yesterday when the city opened its first official viewing stand for the World Trade Center site, and thousands of New Yorkers and tourists braved frigid winds and six-block-long lines to get their first unobstructed looks at the devastation.

title: Op-Art
Using the Voice To Tour the Internet
description: The Web's next trick? Talk to me.

title: Countdown To The Euro: Euro:It's More Than Just a Pretty Penny
description: PARIS  In the biggest currency swap in history, more than 300 million Europeans in 12 countries will start using the euro as their day-to-day money Tuesday, irrevocably casting their old marks, francs, lire, pesetas and other national currencies into the trash can of history.

title: The Chaplain's Embrace, the Sergeant's Songs, and More Than One Parent's Devotion
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Palm, Long a Leader, Has Big Plans for 2002
description: Though still dominant in the hand-held computing market it helped create, Palm faces major challenges in 2002.

title: Devils' Brodeur Rebounds to Defeat Oilers
description: Martin Brodeur will carry a Canadian flag into Salt Lake City in February, although it has not been a banner year for the Devils' goalie.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Killed By Subway Train
description: A 72-year-old man was killed Saturday night when he was struck by a No. 6 train after he fell onto the tracks as it pulled into the 86th Street station, the police said. The man, whom the police identified as Waldemar Norwig, of East 67th Street near Fifth Avenue, was struck by the southbound train just before 8:30 p.m. Mr. Norwig was pronounced dead at the scene at 8:37 p.m.

title: Naturalization Requests by Arab and Muslim Immigrants Reportedly Surge
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  The government's clampdown on the civil liberties of non-citizens since the attacks on New York and Washington has led to a surge in naturalization requests filed by Arab and Muslim immigrants, immigration lawyers report.

title: Internet Leash Can Monitor Sex Offenders
description: Jim McIntire says he likes the computer program that monitors his every move online. ''The software is great,'' he said, because ''it keeps a real tight rope'' on him.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages lastMonday about the CBS drama ''C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation'' misidentified its competition on NBC from 9 to 10 on Thursday nights. NBC broadcasts ''Will and Grace'' and ''Just Shoot Me''; ''E.R.'' is seen on Thursdays at 10.

title: Holiday Tomorrow: New Year's Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Walter John Moore, Chemist And Honored Biographer, 83
description: Dr. Walter John Moore, a physical chemist, textbook author and biographer, died on Dec. 20 in Bloomington, Ind. He was 83.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Eric Beckson, executive vice president at Turnstile Publishing Company, Orlando, Fla., was named president and chief executive. He succeeds Ken Hanson, who resigned, the company said, to pursue other interests. Turnstile publishes Goldweek magazine.

title: Bin Laden Sought Iran as an Ally, U.S. Intelligence Documents Say
description: Representatives of Osama bin Laden contacted Iranian intelligence agents in the mid-1990's in an attempt to forge an anti-American alliance of terror between Iran and Mr. bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda, according to United States intelligence reports.

title: The Year in Pictures: IN THE TOWERS' SHADOW
description: So overpowering are the images of jetliners heading into the World Trade Center, of people watching in disbelief and fleeing in horror, that the other news of 2001, significant and not so significant, already fades from memory. And some of it was significant. There was the swearing in of a president after the Supreme Court decided the presidential election. There was the death of the legendary driver Dale Earnhardt in a stock car crash. There was Cal Ripken's retirement after 3,001 games, including a record 2,632 in a row (and 3,184 hits, 1,695 runs batted in and 431 homers). There was Robert Tools's quiet thumbs-up after becoming the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart.

title: Uncertain Deal Is Key To Fate of Executive
description: Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, occupies the highest wire in corporate America. If her plan to buy Compaq Computer is defeated, she is likely to fall.

title: Off-Duty Officer Among 4 Killed in 2 S.I. Crashes
description: Four people, including an off-duty police officer, were killed early yesterday in two separate traffic accidents in Staten Island, the police said.

title: When a Son Falls in Love With Dad's Intended
description: Valery Gergiev's reputation as a Verdi conductor took a temporary hit from critics last summer when he brought his adventurous company, the Kirov Opera, to Covent Garden in London for a Verdi festival. The performances were pretty ragged. The problem was that Mr. Gergiev had crowded six difficult operas and the Requiem into two weeks of nightly performances, which would have been too much for any company to pull off.

title: To Make New York A More Livable City
description: To the Editor:

title: Viewers Gravitate To Tried and True
description: In the post-Sept. 11 television world, Lucy is up and the Rock is down.

title: Jets Get Signals Crossed
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  ONE way or another, yesterday was going to be a significant day in Jets history.

title: Government Delays Korean Cellular Merger
description: South Korea delayed approval over the weekend for the combination of SK Telecom, the nation's top cellular service provider, with Shinsegi Telecom.

description: A team of international observers said today that they had ''serious concerns'' about how votes were being counted in Zambia's most fiercely contested presidential election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUFER, BERTHA
description: LAUFER-Bertha. Adored wife of the late Philip, beloved sister of Saul (and Helen) Goodman, cherished mother of Joseph (and Joan), loving grandmother of Jonathan (and Amy Arpadi), Jeffrey and Jason, loving great-grandmother of Benjamin, and treasured friend of many. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Hebrew Tabernacle, 551 Ft. Washington Ave, NYC 10033. For information, Zion Memorial Chapel of Westchester, 914-381-1809.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHATZBERG, RUTH
description: SCHATZBERG - Ruth. Beloved wife of Arthur. Devoted mother of Francine and Robert Leichtung. Cherished grandmother of Stacy, Dana and Alison. Loving sister of Jack and Jessie Friedberg. Graveside services Monday, 11 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Every Year, an Old Story Helps Open a New Season
description: It's the same every year. Shortly after dusk, on the evening before the opening of deer season in Pennsylvania -- the season usually opens the Monday after Thanksgiving -- three or four of us stuffed into a vehicle driven by Chris von Strasser can be found doodling around the hills of this quaint old railroad town on the upper Delaware River looking for the house of Stan Petlan.

title: Winterfest Hotel Rates
description: More than 30 boutique hotels in the Kimpton Group have Winterfest Rates through March 31 that are 30 percent lower than last year's. Most of them are in San Francisco, including the Juliana ($119), the Hotel Triton ($129) and the Clarion Bedford ($99). Farther up the West Coast are the Alexis in Seattle ($160) and the Fifth Avenue Suites and Vintage Plaza (each $99) in Portland. Salt Lake City has the Hotel Monaco ($92), and Aspen, Colo., the Aspen Club Lodge ($275). Another choice for skiers: the Summit Lodge in Whistler, British Columbia ($127, at 65 cents to the Canadian dollar). For sightseeing in the nation's capital, the Topaz Hotel and Hotel Rouge, both in Washington, are $109 each. Information and reservations: (800) 546-7866 or www.kimptongroup.com .

title: A Man Who Became More Than a Mayor
description: He bounded through City Hall as if it were his living room, singing ''what a wonderful tow-w-n,'' while trailed by silent bodyguards. They stopped shadowing him only when he reached his corner office, a sanctuary where the most telling additions to the dcor were the most recent: cardboard moving boxes stacked in the corner.

title: Chaney and Knicks Struggle to Find Consistency
description: Don Chaney, calm and cool on the sideline, is beginning to get perturbed with his Knicks. Ten games into his tenure as head coach, and 29 games into the season, the 13-16 Knicks have still not shown any consistency or developed any identity.

title: Rangers Shake Off Concerns On Lindros
description: Mark Messier, the Rangers' captain, is well aware that Eric Lindros is the team's most important player this season. But he said he was not worried about Lindros's latest injury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDAUER, JOANN
description: LINDAUER-Joann. Of West Harrison, died on December 27, 2001. She was 62. She is survived by her husband Howard Lindauer, daughter Lisa, and son Jason. Also survived by two brothers, Norton and Howard Huttner. She was a loving aunt and great aunt to many nephews and nieces. For information contact Zion Memorial Chapel 914381-1809.

title: The Fifth 'Potter' Raises Questions
description: The hottest new book of the new year is not in doubt: ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,'' the fifth book in the best-selling series by J. K. Rowling. But there are some questions about the details of the next installment, including how Ms. Rowling will address Harry's growing interest in girls and whether she will stick with her previous American publisher, Scholastic.

title: Bloomberg Chooses Head Of Fire Dept.
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday chose Nicholas Scoppetta, who won praise for overhauling New York City's child welfare system the last six years, to be the city's next fire commissioner and rebuild a department that lost 343 firefighters in the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROCHLITZ, ROSE
description: STROCHLITZ-Rose. The World Federation of Bergen Belsen Associations mourn the passing of our beloved Rose, Belsen survivor, wife of our lifelong dear friend Sigmund, a distinguished leader and guiding force in Holocaust Remembrance. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Strochlitz family, whose grief we all share over our great loss. Sam Bloch, Pres. Menachem Rosensaft, V.P. Mannes Schwarz Israel Krakowski Jack Rozmaryn Isidore Eisenberg Max Silbernick Moshe Kraus Dov Zelmanowitz, Israe

title: Accessible Cockpit Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Persuading Audiences To Pay to Listen
description: For the nation's two producers of satellite radio, XM Satellite Radio Holdings and Sirius Satellite Radio, the coming year will probably answer the question that will make or break them: are listeners frustrated enough with mainstream radio programming to pay monthly for a bigger selection, much as they now pay for cable television?

title: La Guardia's Legacy Is Formidable, but It May Be Surpassed
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani leaves office tonight assured of one pedestal in the pantheon of New York mayors: no other modern mayor, not even Fiorello H. La Guardia, departed at the crest of his popularity. But precedent suggests that history -- not the euphoria of the moment -- will determine whether Mr. Giuliani, after two terms, edges aside La Guardia, who served three, as New York City's greatest mayor.

title: 2 Christians Ordered to Die As China Acts Against a Sect
description: Two leaders of a Chinese Christian sect were sentenced to death today, the first time executions have been ordered under the country's 1999 anti-cult law.

title: To Make New York A More Livable City
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALISON, LILA
description: KALISON-Lila. On December 29, 2001, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Mack Kalison. Loving mother of Charles and Peter. Beloved mother-in-law of Sandy and Marsha. Adored grandmother of Glenn, Rachel, Tamara and Kristina and cherished great-grandmother of Rebekah and Benjamin. Service and interment private. Contributions in Lili's memory may be made to the Women's Auxiliary, Alzheimers Association, NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10017.

title: Box Office Was Busy, And Potter Was King
description: Despite the widespread perception that it has been a lackluster year for Hollywood movies and fears that the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 would keep people rooted at home and away from multiplexes, 2001 has turned out to be yet another record-breaking year at the box office.

title: The Year in Pictures; SOLIDARITY AND SACRIFICE
description: The weeks after Sept. 11 were a time of grief, anger and anxiety. The city mourned those lost in the World Trade Center in private rituals and public ceremonies. Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, led a Mass that mixed poignancy and newly stirred patriotism. The soprano Leontyne Price, 74, came out of retirement to sing ''America the Beautiful'' at Carnegie Hall. For a while, a familiar September hope took on a new kind of urgency: baseball fans dreamed of another Subway Series. But the Mets' last-ditch drive to get into the playoffs fizzled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, JACK
description: FINK-Jack. We record with deep sorrow the passing of one of our dearest friends and major benefactors. A Holocaust survivor, Mr. Fink's devotion to Am Yisrael, Torat Yisrael and Eretz Yisrael was exemplified by his most generous sponsorship of several significant projects at YBA Or Etzion, Meron and Ner Tamid. May his deeds live on as a shining example for all who knew him. May the family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Friends of Yeshivot Bnei Akiva

title: Dolphins' Late Stand Clinches Playoff Bid
description: The Miami Dolphins were in their defensive huddle before the Atlanta Falcons came to the line of the scrimmage today in the game's waning seconds, needing 1 yard to possibly force overtime.

title: Players Left Standing Now Seek Viability
description: A milestone of sorts was reached last week when Yahoo succeeded with a hostile offer to buy HotJobs.com, an online recruiting site.

title: VerticalNet Buys A Software Maker
description: VerticalNet, a manager of Web sites where companies buy and sell goods, said today that it had bought Atlas Commerce, a closely held maker of Internet software, for $24.2 million in stock and cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LEONORA
description: LEVINE-Leonora. Of Bayside, NY, on December 29, 2001. Beloved sister of Sheila Kaldor, Jerome and Frederick Steigmann. Cherished aunt to many nieces and nephews. Retired school teacher and devoted animal lover. Funeral held on December 30, at Wellwood Cemetery, Lindenhurst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZBERG, ARNO
description: HERZBERG-Arno. On Saturday December 29, 2001. Of Union, formerly of Newark. Beloved husband of Annelie (nee Baruch). Devoted father of Dr. Steven Herzberg and Peter Herzberg. Loving grandfather of five grandchildren. Funeral services were held on Sunday, December 30, 2001, at Congregation B'nai Ahavath Shalom, Union, NJ. Interment King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton. For information, contact Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd., Union, NJ.

title: Teachers to Return to Work at Catholic Schools as Talks Continue
description: Striking teachers at nine Catholic schools in the New York region said yesterday that they would go back to work this week, but warned that they would walk out again if a settlement was not reached by the end of next month.

title: With Door to Playoffs Open, Jets Hit a Wall
description: The wind was gusting, the ghosts were dancing and the Jets were buffeted by both today.

title: Bush's Budget Director Girds for a Tough Year
description: To President Bush, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr. is Blade, the guy who takes a knife to spending proposals in a quest to slow the inexorable growth of government, as Republicans see it -- or to cut into vital programs, in the Democratic view.

title: Reginald Pollack, 77, Painter Known on Both Coasts, Dies
description: Reginald Pollack, a painter and printmaker, died on Dec. 6 at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 77.

title: AIRBORNE TROOPS RELIEVING MARINES AT KANDAHAR BASE
description: The Pentagon has ordered soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division to relieve the Marine Corps in southern Afghanistan, paving the way for a long-term American military presence in the country, military officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIMPERT, HAROLD J. III, ''BOB''
description: LIMPERT-Harold J. III, ''Bob''. President, Limpert Bros., Inc., Vineland, NJ, on December 29 at age 79 after a brief illness. During WWII he proudly served as a naval aviator, test pilot, instructor, and was in the naval reserves. An outstanding businessman, author, inventor and speaker for his industry, he was a member of The Young Presidents Organization, The Westchester Country Club for over 50 years, Navy League, Board of Directors of 60 Sutton Place South for almost 40 years, Vineland Library Foundation Board of Directors, National Fruit and Flavor Association, NICYRA, and founding member of the South Jersey Business Association. He is survived by his beloved companion Ruth Robinson of NYC, cherished colleague of Pearl Giordano of Vineland, NJ, brother John Jr. of Plainfield, NJ, as well as his loving nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St., on Wednesday, January 2, 2002, from 10:30 AM until funeral services at 12:30 PM. For further information contact Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Hillside Journal; The Bulls? Perhaps The Calves
description: The wooden stands inside the high school gym here are filled all the way to the nosebleed seats. The cheering runs thick, as does the smell of hot dogs, pizza and popcorn.

title: New Year Resolutions In a More Serious Vein
description: This year, like last year, and the year before that and, well, every year he can remember -- Ryan Shipley has a New Year's resolution: to stop biting his fingernails.

description: Losses Cost Giants and Jets

title: At Year's End
description: Sept. 11 was the 254th day of the year, which is just a way of saying that most of 2001 passed in the way that most years pass. The high points and the low points of those first 253 days look much like the high and low points of most years, only seen from a very great distance.

title: Bills Take Advantage Of More Defensive Holes
description: Two weeks ago, the Jets gave up 85 yards rushing to Corey Dillon of the Cincinnati Bengals; no big deal because Dillon is one of pro football's premier running backs. The Jets won by a point.

title: Tribal Area of Pakistan Gives Refuge to Qaeda Fighters Fleeing Caves
description: Chased from the caves of Tora Bora, hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters have made their way east across the ice-slicked rocks of the White Mountains and into the untamed tribal areas of Pakistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINCLAIR, BERT
description: SINCLAIR-Bert. Peacefully, December 29, at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, NY, where he had resided for several years. Born in Brooklyn, May 5, 1913. Served honorably US Army, South Pacific, 1943-1945. Owner and operator of Oscar's Restaurant, Brooklyn, NY. Predeceased by his wife Pearl Suben Sinclair. Survived by his sister Martha Sinclair Zimmerman of Fort Lee, NJ. Graveside service Wednesday, January 2, 2002, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, NY, at 1:30 PM. For details: Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschenbaum Chapels, 718-377-4848.

title: London Revels In Art, Cheeky Or Grandiose
description: Tate Britain has expanded. The British galleries at the Victoria and Albert have just opened. And at the Courtauld ''Art on the Line,'' an excellent show, celebrates the coming of age of British art in the annual exhibitions that took place in the Great Room at Somerset House starting in the late 18th century.

title: Giants Lose In Race To End Zone, And Playoffs
description: As Ron Dixon galloped toward the Philadelphia end zone, with the yard markers swiftly passing beneath his feet 5 and 10 at a time, the Veterans Stadium game clock completed its countdown to zero. On their sideline, dozens of Giants surged toward the field, riveted by the ever-widening strides of their fastest teammate while players jumped in place as if they could will Dixon over the last few pursuing Eagles and into the end zone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLOWAY, EDWARD JR.
description: HOLLOWAY-Edward Jr. 83, of Buck Hill Falls and formerly of New York City died December 29. Born in Brooklyn, son of the late Edward and Lenora (Walker) Holloway. A graduate of Princeton and Yale Law School, he was an attorney, he served with the National Society of Colonial Warriors. Surviving are his wife, Gail (nee Fiske), daughter, Hope; and brother, Ernest W. Services Saturday, January 5, 11 AM, United Methodist Church, Canadensis, PA. Donations to the Church or the Browning School, NYC. Clark Funeral Home, Stroudsburg, PA.

Services Monday, December 31, 12:45 PM, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: More than an era of changed government, Rudolph W. Giuliani presided at a moment of utterly changed minds -- about the city, the nature of urban life, and nearly every few weeks, about himself.

description: It began as an imperfect answer to a journalistic problem, the absence of a definitive list of the dead in the days after the World Trade Center was attacked. But it evolved improbably in the weeks and months after Sept. 11 into a sort of national shrine.

title: Neglected Cotton Bowl Confronts Its Future
description: It is a New Year's Day staple that, in its 65 years, has featured players like Davey O'Brien, Doak Walker, Ernie Davis, Jim Brown and Joe Montana. It is still played in the same stadium, a cozy relic on the Texas State Fairgrounds near downtown Dallas. Its sidelines are haunted by coaching legends like Bear Bryant, Darrell Royal and Frank Broyles.

title: Under Tightest Security Ever, Times Square Awaits New Year
description: Under the tightest security procedures ever, New York City prepared today to mark the arrival of the New Year with the traditional Times Square gathering, using the occasion to again pay homage to the victims and heroes of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

description: Consider this small New Year's Eve paradox: The best-played deal of the year was played in November 2000. title: Pakistan Is Reported to Have Arrested Militant Leader
description: In what appeared to be a last-ditch effort to forestall war with India, Pakistan was reported this morning to have arrested Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of one of two Islamic militant groups accused by India of mounting an attack on the Indian Parliament 18 days ago.

description: FISHER-Elsa (nee Landesberg). On December 29, 2001. Born in Vienna, Austria. Devoted wife of the late Otto Fisher. Lichenography
description: Coming out of the shade in a book all their own.
